title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUNRISE ASSISTED LIVING, McLean, Va., said it would sell an 80 percent stake in 13 nursing home properties to a private investor group for $196 million. Sunrise will retain a 20 percent stake and manage the properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAND, STANLEY J.
description: RAND-Stanley J. On September 30. Beloved husband to Lenore. Devoted father to Andrea and Andrew Levenbaum, and Lee and Mary Rand. Loving grandfather to Benjamin, Jason and Sarah Levenbaum, and to Rachel and Molly Rand. Dedicated mason and past master of Guiding Light - Olympia Lodge and longtime member of Central Synagogue of Nassau County. Services will be at ''Guttermans'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre on Wednesday, October 2nd, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Mexican Oil Contract Is Victory for President
description: President Vicente Fox has won a major political battle with old Mexico, forcing the powerful union at the state-run oil giant, Pemex, to call off a strike that would have sent the nation reeling.

title: McCall Cites Poor Test Scores
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee for governor, began broadcasting this 30-second ad Thursday. It is running on New York City stations.

title: Liz Claiborne Makes Deal to Buy Ellen Tracy for $170 Million
description: Liz Claiborne Inc., one of the largest fashion apparel companies in the United States, bought the clothing manufacturer Ellen Tracy yesterday for $170 million, plus the assumption of $10 million in debt.

title: Democrats Seek Compromise With White House on Iraq
description: Congressional Democrats scrambled today to win White House support for a resolution to narrow the conditions for an invasion of Iraq, hoping Republican concessions might allow skeptical Democrats to support the use of force and thus limit floor debate on an issue that seems to grow more contentious by the day.

title: With Three Options, the A's Go With Hudson
description: Some baseball teams arrange their starting rotations so that their best pitcher opens the postseason. The Yankees, for instance, will begin Tuesday with Roger Clemens against Anaheim; the Arizona Diamondbacks will pitch Randy Johnson against St. Louis.

title: Meddlers in Provinces Rattle Russia's Fragile Election System
description: Russian democracy appeared today to be stumbling after local authorities in two areas meddled with election results, causing a national scandal.

title: Pledges of Eternal Love, Balm for Broken Hearts
description: For a guy without much of a voice, Enrique Iglesias is doing pretty well as a pop star. He headlined Madison Square Garden on Friday night to the squeals of female admirers, who thrilled to the vows of passion and devotion that have sold millions of albums for him.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Sand Held DDT In Check
description: A federal study has concluded that a sand cap can be used to cover DDT and PCB deposits on the ocean floor off Southern California. The report, by the Environmental Protection Agency and the Army Corps of Engineers, examined a test conducted in the summer of 2000 in which thousands of tons of clean sandy sediment was used to cover DDT deposits off the Palos Verde Peninsula and found the cap largely free of contaminants. Years of discharge by a manufacturer had let an estimated 1,800 tons of DDT settle over 17 square miles. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: Giambi Still Adjusting To His Part in the Play
description: The tall man with the granite body strides through the players' parking lot at Yankee Stadium, wearing sunglasses, a black T-shirt and baggy blue jeans. He stares forward as he talks on his cellphone, his personal trainer at his side, his hair brown and short except for the spiky blond flecks just above his forehead. Jason Giambi is coming into focus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, FRIEDA
description: DEUTSCH-Frieda. On September 28, 2002. Wife of the late Irving. Loving mother of Alex (Edith). Devoted grandmother of Adam (Francine), cherished great grandmother of Eliana. Services were held yesterday. She will be missed greatly by all who knew her.

title: Qaeda Suspect Talking, U.S. Says
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz said today that Ramzi bin al-Shibh, the suspected member of Al Qaeda captured in Pakistan earlier this month, was providing American authorities with ''valuable information.''

title: 3 Big Advertisers Seeking New Agencies
description: Three large advertisers said yesterday that they were beginning account reviews, after unexpectedly parting ways with their agencies.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of winning lottery numbers yesterday misstated one number for Sunday's New York Take Five in some copies. The numbers were 8, 22, 29, 33 and 34 (not 39).

title: ALLIED BUILDING FACES 244 ASBESTOS SUITS
description: CRH, a building materials conglomerate, said yesterday that a subsidiary in the United States, Allied Building Products, faces 244 personal injury lawsuits related to asbestos in roofing materials made by others that Allied distributed before CRH acquired it. CRH, which is based in Dublin, said that its subsidiaries had settled 33 similar cases for ''minimal'' amounts of a few thousand dollars apiece and that the pending cases were without merit. Still, CRH's stock fell 15 percent in Dublin, in part because investors recalled the troubles other European companies like ABB have had with asbestos liability at American subsidiaries. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LOTTIE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lottie. Oct. 1, 1996. Love Eternal. Beyond Space. Beyond Time. Georg

title: Despite Fraud At Bell Labs, Chip Research Barrels Ahead
description: Two papers by Harvard and Cornell researchers in the June 13 issue of the journal Nature described a spectacular breakthrough in miniaturization: researchers have now created transistors whose switching components are literally single atoms.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Wholesale Business Declines
description: German wholesale sales dropped sharply in August, the Federal Statistics Office said. Compared with August last year, the sales fell 6.3 percent, based on figures adjusted for inflation. On a monthly comparison, sales dropped 1.8 percent. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Plan Moves Ahead
description: A plan by the Daewoo Motor Company's creditors to split the company into five entities as part of the sale of assets to the General Motors Corporation was approved by a South Korean court. The approval is a step closer to sealing 32 months of efforts to sell the insolvent Daewoo.

title: Japanese Executives Think Recovery Is Losing Momentum
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1  Japanese executives now think the country's fragile nine-month old recovery is losing what little momentum it had, according to an influential quarterly survey published by the Bank of Japan.

title: Europeans to Exempt U.S. From War Court
description: The 15 nations of the European Union agreed today to exempt American soldiers and government officials from prosecution for war crimes at the International Criminal Court, an issue that had troubled trans-Atlantic relations for several months.

title: Ravens Surprise Broncos
description: Somebody remind the Baltimore Ravens that this is their rebuilding year.

title: Our Towns; New Day but Same Sorry Script
description: THE New Jersey Democrats knew precisely how to choreograph this debacle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, ALFRED J.
description: WEISS-Alfred J. Of Tenafly, N.J. Beloved husband of Ava (nee Morgan). Devoted father of John and Andrew. Dear father-in-law of Amy. Loving grandfather of Sarah and Samuel. Graveside service Tuesday at Beth El Cemetery, Washington Township, NJ. For info call ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' 1-800-522-0588.

title: When Heroes Faced Down Injustice And Terror
description: ''I'm not ashamed of the segregated and Jim Crow experience because we were able to devise techniques for survival,'' W. W. Law says. ''That permitted us to bide our time and to wait until change come.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about fighting between rebel and government troops in Ivory Coast misstated the connection of a missionary group to a school under siege in Bouak, the country's second-largest city. The Free Will Baptist Foreign Missions had a family based at the school but does not own it.

title: Dow Gains 4.6% as Stocks Start New Quarter With a Comeback
description: After finishing its worst quarter since the 1987 crash, the stock market shot sharply higher today, despite a negative report on manufacturing and the closing of 29 West Coast ports.

title: Sir John Rennie Is Dead at 85; Led Aid Effort for Palestinians
description: Sir John Rennie, a British administrator who struggled to keep the United Nations aid program for Palestinian refugees afloat in the 1960's and 70's, when the Middle East was scarred by war and civil conflict, died on Aug. 12 in London, the United Nations recently announced.

title: Following Gaugin
description: Islands in the Sun, a tour company based in El Segundo, Calif., has two packages to the South Pacific with round-trip air fare from Los Angeles that amount to a saving of up to $1,600 a couple versus putting it together yourself. The Bora Bora Bonanza includes five nights at the 84-room Le Maitai Polynesia in Bora Bora and one night at the 265-room Tahiti Beachcomber Inter-Continental. Rates start at $1,389 a person, based on double occupancy, with departure Nov. 4 (slightly higher before then). The Tahiti Treat includes five nights in the Tahiti Beachcomber Inter-Continental, a day trip to Moorea with lunch and a day of bird-watching on Tetiaroa Island, which Marlon Brando operates as a resort. Departures are on Saturdays in November and December; rates start at $1,379 a person, double. These prices reflect a 3 percent discount for paying in cash or by check. Information: (800) 828-6877, www.islandsinthesun.com .

title: A Prince Charming More Than Charming
description: When you go to see a performance of Cinderella, you don't expect Prince Charming to be the center of attention. But in ''La Cenerentola,'' Rossini's version of the fairy tale, which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, Juan Diego Flrez, the 29-year-old Peruvian tenor, walked off with the show.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AARON, GREGG RICHARD
description: AARON-Gregg Richard. October 1, 2001. Remembered with love. Love, Mom

title: Young Band, Derailed Dream
description: Plates piled high with cheeseburgers and crispy French fries bedecked a private table at Ed Debevic's in Beverly Hills one evening in late June. A farewell dinner was taking place for the tattooed and pierced members of the nascent rock 'n' roll band Dry Cell and their parents. Two days later would come the start of the group's first tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINHART, STEPHANIE
description: REINHART-Stephanie. Tango Kinesis Dance Company of Argentina, Ana Maria Stekelman, Artistic Director, is deeply saddened upon learning of the death of Stephanie. She shared her love of dance around the world. Our sympathy to Charles & the family.

title: Some Members Balk at Union Support for Pataki
description: In Albany yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki was basking in the benevolent gaze of union leaders who usually have eyes only for Democrats.

title: New Era of Consumer Genetics Raises Hope and Concerns
description: Some people can eat slabs of steak and butter without gaining weight or raising their cholesterol levels. Others assiduously shun fats and still have a high risk of heart disease. The different response to diet is determined in part by one's genes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Prosecutors Charge Skinhead Band
description: Three members of a skinhead rock band have been charged with inciting hatred and violence with songs against Jews and foreigners, and an associate was charged with attacking a witness ready to testify against them. The four were also charged with membership in or support of a criminal organization that distributes compact discs to a right-wing extremist network. The band, Landser, stopped touring in 1993 but has continued to release discs. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Braves vs. Giants
description: Here they are, for the 11th time in the last 12 years, missing only in 1994 when there was nothing to miss because there were no playoffs.

title: Caroline Kennedy Appointed to Schools Post
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein appointed Caroline Kennedy today to serve as fund-raiser-in-chief for the New York City schools, a new post that he hopes will increase donations from the private sector and strengthen partnerships between the business community and the vast, cash-strapped school system.

title: UMass Extends Lappas's Contract
description: Massachusetts Coach Steve Lappas received a one-year contract extension through the 2006-7 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAND, JAMES H.
description: BOLAND-James H. Died on Sept. 28, 2002 in Bridgeport, Connecticut. A retired lawyer for Railroad Express Co., funeral services will be held Thursday 9:30 A.M. at Lesko Funeral Home, 1209 Post Rd, Fairfield, CT. Calling hours, Wednesday from 4-8 P.M. www.leskofuneralhome.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, HOWIE
description: HARRIS-Howie. Of Boca Raton died September 30, 2002. He is survived by his loving wife Lucille, daughter Susan, son Bruce and grandchildren Brian, Ricky, Zachary, David and great-grandson Jackson. Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 1-800-992-9262.

title: Rivera Seems Healthy, So the Yankees Exhale
description: He is still the most indispensable Yankee in a season of Soriano soaring and Giambi jelling. Late in the game, he is still the player who will have more of an influence on anything the Yankees accomplish in the next week or, perhaps, the next month. He is still the best closer ever to pitch in the postseason and the primary reason the Yankees have habitually been showered with confetti along lower Broadway.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Antismoking Advertisements
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken his campaign for smoke-free-workplace legislation to the airwaves, with three radio spots produced by the city's health department to promote his opposition to smoking. Mr. Bloomberg has introduced legislation to ban smoking in all public places, including bars and restaurants, which currently operate under more lenient laws. The department's spokeswoman, Sandra Mullin, said, ''Public education efforts have to undo decades of misinformation about the effects of smoking.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Drug Industry Is Told to Stop Gifts to Doctors
description: The government warned pharmaceutical companies today that they must not offer any financial incentives to doctors, pharmacists or other health care professionals to prescribe or recommend particular drugs, or to switch patients from one medicine to another.

title: Turns From Midtown Streets Will Be Banned on Weekdays
description: In an ambitious attempt to liberate Manhattan from traffic congestion, the Bloomberg administration will try to turn 10 Midtown streets into express routes by banning turns from them during weekdays when traffic is heaviest.

title: Cordiant Gives 3 Executives New Jobs
description: The Cordiant Communications Group in London has named three executives to senior management posts at the Bates Group, a division being formed as part of a reorganization of its traditional and nontraditional advertising operations.

title: Don't Resume the Elephant Harvest
description: Of all creatures on Earth, elephants surely rate the sympathy of Republicans, and in many ways we have stood by our party's symbol through their many troubles. After a decade in which ivory poachers had taken their AK-47's to 700,000 elephants -- compared to the 500,000 or so still with us -- a Republican president signed the African Elephant Conservation Act of 1988. A Republican president boldly applied that law in 1989, barring ivory imports and initiating a worldwide ban, and in January of this year a Republican president reauthorized the law.

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNGLASS COMPANY NAMES TOP EXECUTIVES TO NEW GROUP
description: Oakley, which makes sunglasses, named four top executives to a new office of the chairman. The group consists of the chairman and chief executive, Jim Jannard; the chief operating officer, Link Newcomb; the president, Colin Baden; and the executive vice president, Tommy Rios, the company said. The executives must guide Oakley through a ''difficult retail environment,'' Mr. Jannard said. Sales of designer sunglasses in most of Oakley's big markets have missed forecasts because consumers are cutting back on purchases. On Sept. 4, Oakley predicted a third-quarter sales increase of 10 percent to 12 percent, about 15 percent less than previously forecast. The company, based in Foothill Ranch, Calif., also cut its fourth-quarter profit estimate to 10 cents a share from 16 cents.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Connecting Green Dots

title: As Trees Die, Biologists Battle Back
description: Ascending the forested slopes of Mount Tamalpais, 15 miles north of San Francisco, Dr. Matteo Garbelotto and Dr. David Rizzo point out victim after victim of the fast-spreading new disease known as sudden oak death syndrome. But despite seeing dead, wilting and yellowing plants throughout these woods, it is hard for an observer to fathom the real power of this plague until the trail abruptly ends in a heap of ghostly white branches and trunks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAL, PATRICIA
description: LEAL-Patricia. Died peacefully at home on September 29th, 2002 at the age of 73. Preceded in death by her husband Jack. Devoted mother of Andrea, Brian and Diane. Adored grandmother of Jason, Kevin and Alison. Cherished sister of Clyde and Kenneth. Loving daughter of Gladys Broderick. Pat was loved and appreciated by all who knew her. We will miss her greatly. Family will receive friends today, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Conway Funeral Home, Northern Boulevard and 83 Street, Jackson Heights.

title: Fassel Says It's Time To Simplify
description: The Giants' long flight from Phoenix landed after 1 a.m. yesterday, but by some accounts there was more seething than sleeping along the way. A 21-7 loss to the Cardinals, packed with penalties and blunders, was the kind of regrettable game that remains vivid on the backs of eyelids.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett To Cut 1,206 Jobs In France
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, the world's biggest personal computer maker, will eliminate 1,206 jobs in France as a result of its $18.9 billion purchase in May of Compaq Computer. About half of the cuts will be made in Grenoble, in eastern France, and most of the rest will be in the Paris region, the company said yesterday. Workers' committees and unions at Hewlett-Packard have been informed, as French law requires, the company said. Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has said it will drop 16,800 employees. Hewlett-Packard shares fell 36 cents, or 3 percent, to $11.67. The shares have dropped 32 percent since the acquisition closed on May 3.

title: Full Text of Powell's News Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Following is Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's remarks on Iraq at the State Department today, as provided by the Federal News Service.

title: Iraq's Little Secret
description: The White House is right that Iraq is by far the most repressive country in the entire Middle East -- but that's true only if you're a man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELFMAN, ISIDORE
description: ELFMAN-Isidore, 89. A wonderful partner & lover to wife, Carole. A caring & dedicated parent to Abba, Joel & Nina. Poet laureate of 12 W. 96 St. Services Tuesday, 1pm, Plaza Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam.

title: ELECTRONICS COMPANY TO CUT ADDITIONAL JOBS IN U.S.
description: The CTS Corporation, a maker of electronic components and assemblies, plans to cut an additional 140 jobs and move more work to China to cut costs, it said yesterday. The transfer will take place by the fourth quarter of next year. Last month, CTS cut 160 jobs. It employed 6,000 to 6,200 workers before the new job reductions, a company spokesman said. CTS, based in Elkhart, Ind., now expects related costs to cut third-quarter results by $18.5 million, compared with a previous forecast of $15 million to $17 million. The revamping is expected to increase pretax savings to $15 million to $17 million in 2003 from an earlier estimate of $11 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Toms River: No Death Penalty In Spree Killing
description: A retired police officer who went on a shooting spree in February, killing four people, including his granddaughter, will not face execution, the Ocean County prosecutor, Thomas F. Kelaher, announced yesterday. The decision not to seek the death penalty was heavily influenced by the victims' families, who opposed execution, said James A. Churchill, the executive assistant to the prosecutor. The retired officer, John W. Mabie, is charged with four counts of murder. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWSUM, FLETCHER A.
description: NEWSUM-Fletcher A., 49. Of New York City on Monday, September 9, 2002, at his home. Survivors include his mother Barbara, brothers C.T. and Matt, sister Sherree, nephews Patrick, Daniel, Thomas and Nathan and nieces, Kaity and Lauren. His father, Thomas Newsum, preceded him in death. He was born August 17, 1953. He received his BA from Swarthmore College, a Master's Degree in Philosophy from Oxford University, and an MBA from Harvard. At the time of his death he was employed with Muzinich & Company as a portfolio manager. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 3, at 4:00 PM at The Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Nurses Bridge Cultures to Give Better Care
description: ''I started doing drugs when I was 13,'' says Suzanne Ferraro, a middle-aged caseworker with a mane of curly hair.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Settlement In Box Cutter Sales
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs announced a $125,000 settlement with Home Depot yesterday after the department cited the chain store for selling box cutters and aerosol paint cans to minors, which is banned under municipal law. As a result of the settlement, Home Depot has agreed to train its staff not to sell those items to minors and to limit their display within the stores. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: People
description: Tom O'Keefe, executive creative director at the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, was named executive creative director at the Chicago office, a vacant post since late last year, when Bob Dreveny. A successor to Mr. O'Keefe in San Francisco is expected to be named soon. Foote, Cone is part of the FCB Group of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Mortgage Monopoly Ends
description: South Korea's largest commercial bank, Kookmin, will soon face competition in administering low-interest loans that are subsidized by the government for people buying homes for the first time. The Construction and Transportation Ministry said it would name two more banks in October to deal with such loans. The government decided to give others a chance after Woori Finance Holding, whose Woori Bank ranks second to Kookmin, objected to the monopoly. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Winners Using Same Formula
description: Most coaches view the 16-game season in four quarters. It has become part of their playbook, the idea of separating the season into four-game stretches and yearning for at least three victories in each. That translates into a 12-4 season, maybe a divisional title and most likely a playoff spot.

title: Bloomberg Is Considering Tax Increases
description: Facing yet another steep budget deficit, the Bloomberg administration has signaled that it is no longer opposed to tax increases, and the debate at City Hall has shifted to which taxes should be raised and by how much.

title: Emotions Worry Washburn
description: When Jarrod Washburn becomes nervous, he really leans into his fastball, reaching for those extra miles an hour instead of doing what he did so often this year during his breakout season: pitching to spots. Washburn became nervous on opening day and it cost him a four-run first inning against the Cleveland Indians, a loss that sent the Angels on a 6-14 course before a turnaround that culminated in a 99-63 season.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Down At Travel Agent
description: MyTravel, Europe's third-largest tour operator, said changes in accounting procedures would leave its 2002 profit far short of previous expectations. The company's shares fell by more than one third, to 81.5 pence, their lowest in more than 10 years. The company, which is based in Manchester, said pretax profit this year could be as low as 90 million ($141 million), a decline of 38 percent from last year and 14 percent lower than earlier forecasts. Under its new accounting procedures MyTravel will book earnings when clients depart on vacation rather than when they make reservations. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Suit Settled Over Pricing Of Music CD's At 3 Chains
description: Music lovers who have complained that compact discs are too costly were officially vindicated yesterday, as five big music labels and three national retailers settled a lawsuit charging them with price fixing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANGER, DAVID
description: GRANGER - David. The American Society and US Priory of the Order of Saint John offers deep condolences to Mrs. Granger and sons in the loss of our dear friend and esteemed colleague David Granger, OBE, K. St. J., longtime Treasurer of the American Society, a Life Governor and by Her Majesty's Pleasure, a Knight in the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem. John R. Drexel, IV, Prior Joseph B. Walsh, MD, Chancellor Don W. Lundquist, Secretary Peter S. Goltra, Treasurer

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Archdiocese Bars Group
description: An auxiliary bishop at the Boston Archdiocese has barred the Voice of the Faithful, a group of lay Roman Catholics formed in response to the sexual-abuse scandal, from meeting in a church in North Andover. The auxiliary bishop, Emilio Allue, wrote to the priest at St. Michael Parish in North Andover that until Cardinal Bernard F. Law concluded a ''dialogue'' with Voice of the Faithful about its ''hidden and open issues,'' the group's activities ''must be curtailed in order to avoid further 'scandal' and polarity among our parishioners.'' James E. Post, president of the group, said archdiocesan officials had cut off dialogue months ago. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: In a Film Festival's Winners, a Focus on Artists at Work
description: Among the glittery clatter of film festivals here each year, for many one stands out as a model of intellectual curiosity: Le Festival International du Film sur l'Art (known as FIFA). The festival celebrated its 20th anniversary in March, and now a selection of its films are being shown in New York City.

title: White House Predicts Economic Pace Will Pick Up Next Year
description: The Bush administration set out an optimistic view of the economy today, saying the drop in the stock market was probably not enough to derail the recovery and that the most critical component of the outlook, capital investment by businesses, would begin turning around by the end of the year.

title: AOL Chairman's No. 1 Ally Turns Into His Biggest Foe
description: Soon after America Online agreed to acquire Time Warner in January 2000, Stephen M. Case called Ted Turner one of his heroes, pledging that they would be ''joined at the hip'' in planning for the merged company. Mr. Turner, a cable pioneer, saw in Mr. Case another entrepreneur who had persevered through ridicule to forge a new kind of media giant.

title: Finding Magic at Lincoln Center, and Moving On
description: GET out of the way or submit, buddy, because Linda LeRoy Janklow, the Lincoln Center Theater's brand new chairman emeritus -- ''God, I hate that name, makes me sound like a jowly old man'' -- is coming straight at you. Remember that as she hits you with the charm, the dry humor, the heady stories of life as a Hollywood princess, and the bittersweet ones about her brother, Warner LeRoy, the late restaurateur.

title: From Doctor, An Overdose Of Kindness
description: I once worked with the nicest doctor in the world. She was a true marvel of kindness and dedication. Day or night, her patients could reach her for anything, and they adored her. She was their friend, their advocate and their savior, grieving at every mishap from divorce to pneumonia, and rushing to heal their pain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Dix Hills: Three Killed In Drunken Driving Accident
description: A Woodhaven man was charged with driving when intoxicated early yesterday after his mother, sister and grandfather were killed in a car accident on the Long Island Expressway, the Suffolk County police said. The driver, Luis Ramirez, 20, was driving a 1991 Toyota in the center lane of the expressway near Dix Hills when he got a flat tire and slowed or stopped, the police said. His car was hit from behind by a 1998 pickup truck. Mr. Ramirez's sister, Fiorella Ramirez, 12, and his grandfather, Ernesto Villavincio, 83, were pronounced dead at the scene, and his mother, Cecilia Ramirez, 40, was taken to Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, where she was pronounced dead. His girlfriend, Laurie Luna, 19, was taken to the same hospital, where she was in critical condition last night. Mr. Ramirez was treated at University Hospital at Stony Brook for minor injuries Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Taj Mahals and Tempers Rise in Beach Bohemia
description: For decades, no one paid much attention to the Venice canals, a development carved out of a swamp near the beach in 1905 in an homage to its Italian namesake, but that never achieved anything close to its grand promise.

title: Finding the Humor in Haydn, Ravel and Shostakovich
description: The fashion in concert programming for the last decade or more has been to offer works with either stylistic or philosophical ties, either subtle or apparent, perhaps as a way of helping listeners find a sense of order in an experience that doesn't absolutely need it. Maybe the need to find these connections has become a bit too much of an obsession.

title: N.J. Transit Links Midtown And Montclair
description: New Jersey Transit inaugurated its Montclair Connection service today, opening a $63 million station and a stretch of track that transit officials said would add more than 4,000 new riders and cut travel times to New York City by linking two existing lines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JUDITH H.
description: COHEN-Judith H. The Musicians, Trustees and Staff of the Marlboro Music School and Festival mourn the loss of a treasured member of the Marlboro Family. To her husband Isidore, our dear friend and Senior Participant since 1966; to her daughter Erica and granddaughter Ana-Luz and to her son Allen and daughter-in-law Ana Torrent; and to her sister Sally and brother-in-law Al Burton, we send our heartfelt condolences. As a dynamic and generous member of the Recreation Committee and our whole community, her wonderful contributions, her spirit and courage will continue to inspire us for years to come. Marlboro Music 135 South 18th Street Philadelphia, Pa. 19103

title: Book by Clinton Aides Says Saudi Diplomat Misled F.B.I. Chief on '96 Barracks Attack
description: Two of President Bill Clinton's counterterrorism aides contend in a new book that Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States repeatedly misled Louis J. Freeh, the former director of the F.B.I., about the 1996 Khobar Towers bombing case, reinforcing Mr. Freeh's suspicions that the White House had little interest in the case, in which Mr. Freeh had a strong personal commitment.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: ARCHDIOCESE BARS GROUP An auxiliary bishop at the Boston Archdiocese has barred the Voice of the Faithful, a group of lay Roman Catholics formed in response to the sexual-abuse scandal, from meeting in a church in North Andover. The auxiliary bishop, Emilio Allue, wrote to the priest at St. Michael Parish in North Andover that until Cardinal Bernard F. Law concluded a "dialogue" with Voice of the Faithful about its "hidden and open issues," the group's activities "must be curtailed in order to avoid further `scandal' and polarity among our parishioners." James E. Post, president of the group, said archdiocesan officials had cut off dialogue months ago.    Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Court for Mentally Ill Defendants Will Start Today
description: An experimental court intended to give certain mentally ill criminal defendants treatment instead of jail time will open officially in Brooklyn today.

title: 'Rooms' Whose Walls Seem About to Explode
description: A program note for ''The Silicon Dance Project'' defined silicon as ''a nonmetallic element occurring in a combined state in minerals and rock.'' That note served as an unnecessarily contrived introduction to the fascinating performance offered on Thursday night as part of the Dance: Access series at St. Mark's Church in the East Village.

title: Senator Torricelli Bows Out
description: Senator Robert Torricelli's announcement yesterday that he was withdrawing from the New Jersey Senate race was the correct step to take. His ethical lapses had irreparably damaged his personal reputation, his stature as a legislator and, judging by recent polls, his chances for re-election. He really had no other choice. That said, he should have reached this decision a long time ago. His failure to do so earlier has left his party scrambling to find a replacement and the election itself in a state of legal chaos. The task now is to find a way to give New Jersey's voters the choice they deserve.

title: Nets Are Bigger; So Are Their Goals
description: Dikembe Mutombo's monumental shadow and the sparkling white conference and division championship banners were not the only discernable differences inside the Nets' Champion Center today on the eve of training camp.

title: Why the Risky Behavior?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Fire Valentine to Close Out a Dismal Season
description: The Mets' owner, Fred Wilpon, frustrated by his team's basement performance despite its penthouse payroll, fired Bobby Valentine as manager today, informing Valentine of his decision in a morning meeting at Shea Stadium.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Adams Linked To I.R.A. Killers
description: A new book accuses Gerry Adams, president of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, of having led the paramilitary organization's Belfast division in the early 1970's and of setting up a unit to kill informers. Mr. Adams, left, denied the accusations. The book, ''A Secret History of the I.R.A.,'' by an Irish journalist, Ed Moloney, also says Mr. Adams knew of the killing of Jean McConville, who disappeared in 1972 after she had comforted a wounded British soldier. The I.R.A. has admitted that it killed Mrs. McConville, a widowed mother of 10, but her body has not been found. ''There was an injustice and it was inflicted by republicans on their family,'' Mr. Adams said on RTE Radio, ''but I clearly had no knowledge of this at the time.'' Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Market Place; A Bad Quarter for U.S. Markets Was Worse in Other Countries
description: The American stock market has been a horrible place to be. But it was better than most markets overseas in the quarter that ended yesterday.

title: Easing Students' Strain
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Invites 5 To Design Its Open Areas
description: Five architects have been invited to submit designs to renew or reconfigure Lincoln Center's 6.3 acres of public space as part of its $1.2 billion redevelopment.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Fire Valentine to Close Out a Dismal Season
description: Mets Close the Door on Valentine Bobby Valentine met last week with Fred Wilpon, the owner of the Mets, and mentioned the possibility of his having a more expansive role in the team's personnel decisions for 2003, the final year of his contract. He said he received no response. Valentine also asked about renewing the contracts of his coaches. Again, Valentine said, Wilpon was silent.

title: Europe dives as 'disastrous quarter' ends : Grim data unnerve markets worldwide
description: LONDON:  Investors recoiling from the prospect of war in Iraq were hit with a barrage of bad economic news Monday, battering stock prices around the world.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, Not Quite Everyone Is Sold on Sex
description: Finally, the collections here produced a designer who is alive and connected to the real ground, someone not caught up in the old games about sex and class, but firmly part of his times. Christopher Bailey sent out a superb collection tonight for Burberry.

title: Paul Williams, 87, Rock Pioneer With 1948's 'The Hucklebuck'
description: Paul Williams, a saxophonist and bandleader whose 1948 recording of ''The Hucklebuck'' was an important precursor of rock 'n' roll, died on Sept. 14 in New York City. He was 87.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The German finance minister, Hans Eichel, cut one percentage point off his forecast for economic growth next year and said he opposed raising taxes to meet European Union budget requirements. The economy will expand 1.5 percent next year, the Finance Ministry said, compared with an earlier estimate of 2.5 percent. Mr. Eichel said he planned spending cuts of 10 billion euros ($9.8 billion) to avoid hurting the economy by pushing up taxes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Economic Growth
description: India's gross domestic product grew at a better-than-expected 6 percent in the quarter ended in June, backed by robust growth in the financial sector. The farm sector expanded 4.4 percent in the quarter and the financial, insurance and business services industry grew 9.7 percent, according to data provided by the government's Central Statistical Organization. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Testaverde Sits and Pennington Will Start
description: In the emotional raw moments after the Jets' loss to Jacksonville, Coach Herman Edwards refused to commit to starting Vinny Testaverde on Sunday against Kansas City. This morning, after spending all night thinking about it, Edwards benched Testaverde and made Chad Pennington the starter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MILTON
description: COHEN - Milton. Age 88, passed away September 27th, 2002. Beloved husband of Lillian Cohen. Devoted father of Mitchell Cohen and Robin Harvey. Dear grandfather of Seth, Noah and Raphael Cohen. Brother of the late Myron and Philip Cohen. Memorial contributions to Hebrew Union College, 3101 Clifton Ave., Cincinnati, OH 45220.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Leisure on Sunday about the concert series ''Americans in Rome: Music by Fellows of the American Academy in Rome,'' which begins tomorrow, misstated the location. It is Weill Recital Hall, not Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Silverstein Sending Tower Data to U.S. Agency
description: A day after disclosing that their engineering experts had produced an important body of analysis on why the twin towers collapsed on Sept. 11, lawyers for Larry A. Silverstein, whose companies own the lease on the World Trade Center, said yesterday that they had abruptly begun shipping the material to a federal investigative agency.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I will not be responsible for the loss of the Democratic majority in the United States Senate.''

title: One Visa Problem Costs a Festival Two Filmmakers
description: The internationally acclaimed Iranian film director Abbas Kiarostami, who won the Palme d'Or at Cannes in 1997 for ''A Taste of Cherry,'' was unable to get a United States visa in time to attend the premiere of his new film, ''Ten,'' at the New York Film Festival last Saturday, prompting his friend and fellow director Aki Kaurismaki of Finland to boycott the festival in protest.

title: With Arafat Siege Lifted, Sharon Faces a New Storm
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, away on a three-day visit to Russia, faced withering criticism at home today for his handling of a 10-day siege of Yasir Arafat's compound in the West Bank, which was lifted on Sunday.

title: Sports of The Times; The Jets Had To Change Quarterbacks
description: THIS past week, during a meeting of the offense, Jets quarterback Vinny Testaverde got medieval on his teammates. Testaverde is normally as excitable as a bowl of bran cereal. But last Wednesday, there he was, standing before the players, cursing, raising his voice, putting some of the team's woes squarely on his shoulders, but dishing just as much criticism, sometimes going player by player, calling them out by name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, CHRISTOPHER
description: ELIAS-Christopher. On September 30, 2002. Survived by his wife Alyne, his son Christopher, and his daughter Caroline. Service Wednesday 79 PM, Keri Memorial Funeral Home, Lincoln Park, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORING, KATE
description: HORING-Kate. On September 29th, 2002. Beloved aunt and friend. Services are on Wednesday, 11:30 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Milwaukee; More Than Just Made Famous by Beer
description: For Milwaukee, a city long identified with beer, bratwurst and cheese, the Milwaukee Art Museum's new addition by the Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava, a soaring pavilion with a sun screen that opens and closes like a bird's wings, is quite an image enhancer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULLMANN, HANNI
description: ULLMANN-Hanni. We are deeply saddened by the passing at the age of 94 of Hanni Ullmann, the Founding President of Neve Hanna in Kiryat Gat, Israel. Hanni was a gracious, dynamic and selfless lady. In 1933 Hanni was one of the leaders of the Ahava Home for Children and Youth at Kiryat Bialik that saved countless youngsters from the Holocaust. In 1974 she established a home for troubled children from dysfunctional families at Kiryat Gat that in time became an exemplary institution for all of Israel. Hanni was honored by the Prime Minister of Israel in 1991 for her outstanding leadership in the protection of children. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family in Israel and in the States. She has left us a glorious heritage that we hope to perpetuate. The Steering Committee American Friends of Neve Hanna Rabbi Benjamin Z. Kreitman Rabbi Henry Glazer Rabbi Barry Dov Katz Sylvia Lubliner Jack Topal Lee Rosenberg

title: Global Crossing Memo Indicates Early Warning Of Downfall
description: The chief executive of Global Crossing warned the company's chairman, Gary Winnick, as early as mid-2000 that the company was doomed to collapse, according to documents released yesterday by Congressional investigators.

title: Powell Says U.N. Ought to Hold Up Iraq Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 - Hours after Iraq agreed with United Nations officials that weapons inspectors could return in two weeks, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said tonight that any search of Saddam Hussein's arsenals should be delayed until the Security Council approves a ``new, strong, tough resolution'' setting terms.

title: Judge Upholds Privacy For Jeb Bush's Daughter
description: A judge ruled today that staff members at a drug rehabilitation center in Orlando, where Gov. Jeb Bush's daughter, Noelle, is receiving treatment, cannot be forced to cooperate with an investigation into an accusation that she had possessed crack cocaine.

title: Athletics vs. Twins
description: They are in the playoffs for the third consecutive year, but for the first time they don't have to play the Yankees in the division series. That change puts them ahead of the past two years right off the bat.

title: Problems Cited In Soldiers' Gear
description: The federal program to protect soldiers from chemical and biological attacks is flawed, a Congressional audit has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESHEN, ESTELLE P.
description: LESHEN-Estelle P. On September 29, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Melvin. Devoted mother of Debra Tillis and Joseph Leshen. Cherished grandmother of Julie, David and Michael.

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: For Sale: A DNA Test To Measure Racial Mix
description: A company in Sarasota, Fla., is offering a DNA test that it says will measure customers' racial ancestry and their ancestral proportions if they are of mixed race.

title: Hotels Are Doing Business on a Last-Name Basis
description: It has long been common for corporate travelers at luxury hotels to be addressed by name when they call the front desk, the concierge or valet parking. Switchboards equipped with digital displays make this easy. But now many elite hotels are doing such ''guest recognition'' programs one better, by instructing employees to greet guests by name in hallways, in elevators, even in the gyms.

title: Quick Approval for Drug
description: Pharmacia won United States approval sooner than some analysts expected for Inspra, a hypertension medication that it estimates may have peak sales of $1 billion a year.

title: Accounts
description: Rmy Amrique, New York, part of Rmy Cointreau, to KraftWorks, New York, as the agency of record for Cointreau liqueur. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. The account had been handled by Adair-Greene, Atlanta, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Woman Gets 12 Years In Kidnapping
description: A federal judge sentenced a West Virginia woman to 12 years in prison, the maximum, for kidnapping a 16-month-old girl at a bus station in Chicago on Christmas Eve. The woman, Sheila Matthews, left, tearfully told the judge, Matthew F. Kennelly of Federal District Court, that she needed help. Ms. Matthews, 33, was entrusted with the toddler for a few minutes while her mother went to buy her bus ticket, but fled with the child to her West Virginia home. The child was not harmed. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: European Charm, Yankee Reliability
description: YEAH, I know travel writers are supposed to get all dewy-eyed about that precious inn with the charming rose gardens in the Cotswold countryside, or that delightful three-star with the antique quilts on the beds just a stone's throw from the Champs-lyses.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Notes Create Smallpox Scare
description: The Hart Senate Office Building, where an anthrax-laced letter was discovered last year, was closed for 40 minutes after an employee found a slip of paper with the word ''smallpox'' written on it. The paper, which also contained some writing about the need for vaccinations, appeared to be someone's notes rather than a threat, said Terry Gainer, chief of the Capitol Police. No harmful substances were found. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Bonuses for Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Expects Loan Losses
description: Commerzbank said it might set aside an additional 200 million euros ($197 million) to cover potential loan losses, mainly because of flood damages in eastern Germany. The bank, which is based in Frankfurt, expects total loan-loss provisions this year to rise to 1.3 billion euros, up from an earlier forecast of more than 1.1 billion euros.

title: Japanese Executives Think Recovery Is Losing Momentum
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1  Japanese executives now think the country's fragile nine-month old recovery is losing what little momentum it had, according to an influential quarterly survey published by the Bank of Japan.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Guide column on the arts page of the Long Island section on Sunday for a tribute to the artist Larry Rivers, who died on Aug. 14, misstated the day of the event, which includes a screening of ''Larry Rivers: Public and Private.'' It is at the Duke Lecture Hall of Southampton College at 7 p.m. on Saturday, not Thursday. Information: (631) 287-8143.

title: 3 Big Advertisers Seeking New Agencies
description: Three large advertisers said yesterday that they were beginning account reviews, after unexpectedly parting ways with their agencies.

title: Excerpts From Senator Torricelli's Announcement
description: Following are excerpts from Senator Robert G. Torricelli's speech yesterday at the New Jersey State House, as recorded by The New York Times. The complete text is online at nytimes.com/metro.

title: When Patients Have Their Say
description: Are patients blabbermouths? Many doctors apparently think so.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: PRODUCTION GROWS Industrial production grew a slower-than-expected 1.6 percent in August from July, suggesting Japan's export-led recovery may be losing steam. Government forecasters expect output to increase 0.4 percent in September and just 0.2 percent in October. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Necessary Cautions
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Called Terror For a Reason
description: THIS one deals with life in our new world, which may or may not be brave.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Paving Way To European Union
description: Edicts issued at the end of World War II expelling ethnic Germans from their homes in Czechoslovakia should not bar the Czech Republic from entering the European Union, according to a report by European Union lawyers. Rightists in Austria and Germany have called for the decrees to be officially rescinded and for expelled Germans and their descendants to be allowed to reclaim lost property. The Czechs say the sometimes violent expulsions were a justified response to Nazi Germany's occupation of Czechoslovakia.

title: U.S.  IS  DISMISSING RUSSIA'S CRITICISM OF STRIKES IN IRAQ
description: The Bush administration today brushed aside criticism from Russia that intensifying airstrikes by American and British warplanes on radar and antiaircraft installations in Iraq were interfering with the diplomacy aimed at averting war.

title: Wendy Hilton, 71, Specialist In Recreating Baroque Dance
description: Wendy Hilton, a specialist in Baroque dance, died on Sept. 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 71.

title: DNA Will Let a Montana Man Put Prison Behind Him, but Questions Linger
description: A couple of weeks after Jimmy Ray Bromgard was sent to prison in 1987, another inmate broke his jaw in a fight. Mr. Bromgard, then 18, was starting a 40-year sentence for the rape of an 8-year-old girl here.

title: Lean, Hungry Dialogue Between Pianist and Soprano
description: Torn between the reductive art of Anton Webern and a Central European bent toward theatricality, Gyorgy Kurtag has managed to employ the first in the service of the second. Mr. Kurtag, whose music was celebrated by the Ensemble Sospeso at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night, spent his early years in the thrall of Webern, the Austrian Serialist who set tiny, ingenious line-drawings in sound against empty spaces of silence. The centerpiece of Wednesday's concert -- a long, elaborate and spectacularly dramatic dialogue between soprano and pianist -- rejects Webern's skeletal purity while retaining much of its lean and hungry look. Quite a trick.

title: A Curtain Is Lifted On Faded Glory
description: The inner worlds of the once mighty, once secretive Russian space program are laid bare in ''Kosmos,'' a book of beautiful photographs taken by Adam Bartos and published last year by the Princeton Architectural Press, based in New York City.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Former Ally Is Seeking Chairman's Ouster at AOL

title: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,695 JOBS
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, said yesterday that it would cut 1,695 jobs, or 5.4 percent of its work force, as two and a half years of falling stock prices had thinned the assets it has under management. The job cuts at the company, based in Boston, came after last October's announcement that it would trim 760 jobs, or 2.3 percent of the work force. That time, the brokerage unit accounted for about half the cuts. A Fidelity spokeswoman said the cuts would be felt in almost every unit of the closely held company, which employs more than 31,000. No fund managers or analysts will lose their jobs, she said.

title: Putin Cheers Sharon Over Lifting of Siege
description: President Vladimir V. Putin applauded Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today for ending Israel's much criticized siege of Yasir Arafat's compound.

title: Cellphone: A Convenience, a Hazard or Both?
description: When a new technology takes off, it seems to fly with the speed of light. So it is with cellphones, now owned by well over half the population and soon to be found in more than 90 percent of American households.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESKIN, CLAIRE
description: DESKIN-Claire. The Board of Directors and staff of the 92nd Street Y mourn the loss of Claire Deskin, mother of longtime Board member, Michael Steinhardt. Our hearts and prayers are with Mr. Steinhardt and his wife, Judy; their sons, David and Daniel; their daughter, Sara Berman, chair of the Y's Makor/Steinhardt Center committee, and the entire Steinhardt family. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Matthew Bronfman President Philip Milstein, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director Deborah Nadel Magee Acting Director Makor/Steinhardt Center David Gedzelman Creative & Rabbinic Director Makor Program

title: Justices Asked To Rule Early On University Admissions
description: White students who sued the University of Michigan to block its affirmative action policies for undergraduate admissions plan to file a petition this morning asking the United States Supreme Court to review the case, even though the lower appellate court, which heard arguments last year, has not yet ruled on it.

title: Torricelli Quits Campaign, Citing Risks to His Party
description: TRENTON, Sept. 30  Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat whose aggressive fund-raising helped his party gain its single-seat majority in the United States Senate, announced today that he was ending his bid for re-election, acknowledging that his campaign had become overwhelmed by questions about improper gifts he accepted from a contributor.

title: Lawmakers Pushing for a Deal on Terrorism Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  President Bush urged Congressional leaders today to resolve their differences by the end of the week and adopt legislation to protect the insurance industry from losses from future terror attacks.

title: Why the Risky Behavior?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Boy Modigliani, Playing With Murder
description: It's a wonder that dozens of films and plays haven't been written about Amedeo Modigliani. His life story has all the sexy material a mini-series fan could want. He was a handsome young Italian who moved to Paris and struggled for years to sell his paintings. He abused drugs and alcohol and had a turbulent affair with a British poet, Beatrice Hastings. He found love again but died young (35), of tubercular meningitis. The day after his death Jeanne Hbuterne, the mother of his 14-month-old daughter, flung herself out a window. Two years later Modigliani was famous.

title: Pentagon Shows Videos Of Iraq Firing At Allied Jets
description: Senior Pentagon officials today showed previously classified video footage of Iraq's efforts to shoot down American and British warplanes patrolling Iraqi no-flight zones, apparently in an American effort to build support for a tough new Security Council resolution on Iraqi weapons.

title: Strange Ended Up as a Pawn in Torrance's Game
description: A few questions in the aftermath of a fascinating and thrilling Ryder Cup.

title: A Best Friend in Times of Stress
description: People cope better with stressful tasks in the company of a pet than when alone or supported by a friend or spouse, a new study has found.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA: NEW INDICTMENT The United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague announced a new indictment for the Srebrenica massacre, saying a former Bosnian Serb commander had reneged on promises to surrender. Ljubomir Borovcanin was secretly indicted on Sept. 6 for complicity in genocide in the killing of up to 8,000 Muslim males in 1995 after Bosnian Serb forces overran the enclave. (Reuters)

title: Democrats See Slipping by G.O.P. on Environment
description: Congressional Democrats, trying to revive the issue of the environment in a political atmosphere increasingly devoted to war, said today that the Bush administration had fallen down on enforcing the nation's environmental laws.

title: Market's Worst Quarter Since '87 Crash Limps to a Close
description: The stock market finished its worst quarter since the 1987 crash yesterday with a sell-off that sent the Dow Jones industrial average to a four-year low and the Nasdaq composite index to a six-year low.

title: Israeli Forces Take Positions Near Arafat's Compound
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 1  Israeli forces took up positions in buildings near Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah today, two days after they complied with American demands and lifted a 10-day siege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, HELEN POND
description: McINTYRE-Helen Pond. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of Barnard College are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved trustee emerita, alumna, and friend of the College, Helen Pond McIntyre, Barnard class of 1948. A former president of the Associate Alumnae of Barnard College (1975-78) and a trustee of Barnard since 1975, Mrs. McIntyre had a long, productive and supportive relationship with the College. She chaired the College's first Capital Campaign and the National Centennial Committee; and served as national co-chair for The Campaign for Barnard. Her wise counsel, caring leadership and warmth will be deeply missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Ranny and the entire McIntyre family. Judith Shapiro, President Gayle F. Robinson, Chair, Board of Trustees

title: Japan Names New Economy Czar to Tackle Banking Crisis
description: Declaring Japan's banks in an ''emergency,'' Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi fired his chief financial regulator today and unexpectedly concentrated economic policy making in the hands of a 51-year-old cabinet member known for advocating aggressive action to tackle Japan's long-running banking crisis.

title: Secret Deal Part of Tangle In Enron Case
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, will be charged in a criminal complaint as soon as tomorrow with defrauding shareholders through a secret agreement guaranteeing that Enron would shield his LJM partnership from losses, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Pataki Criticizes McCall on Education
description: Gov. George E. Pataki released this 30-second ad on Friday, a response to what his campaign characterized as a negative ad by his Democratic opponent, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. It is running on New York City stations.

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: Come on In, the Hudson's Fine; The Slime Is Gone, and the Swimmers Have Returned
description: As summer was winding to a close 10 days ago, 96 competitors crowded around the Hudson riverbank in Washington Heights, slid down a boulder into the water and began stroking to Chelsea, 7.8 miles downstream.

title: Argentina Permits Withdrawals From Savings
description: Banks started to ease a nine-month-old freeze on the savings accounts of Argentines today, in a move the government hopes will help breathe life into the moribund economy and help the recession-weary country move closer to a rescue deal with the International Monetary Fund.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose against the dollar as traders said the resignation of Japan's financial regulator would pave the way for aid to banks. In New York, the yen settled at 121.78 to the dollar, from 122.84 on Friday.

title: Dealing With W
description: I got obsessed with the Japanese economy after it was fashionable.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PROFIT DOWN AT TRAVEL AGENT MyTravel, Eu- rope's third-largest tour operator, said changes in accounting procedures would leave its 2002 profit far short of previous expectations. The company's shares fell by more than one third, to 81.5 pence, their lowest in more than 10 years. The company, which is based in Manchester, said pretax profit this year could be as low as 90 million ($141 million), a decline of 38 percent from last year and 14 percent lower than earlier forecasts. Under its new accounting procedures MyTravel will book earnings when clients depart on vacation rather than when they make reservations. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: De Varona Ends Suit Against ABC
description: ABC Sports yesterday rehired Donna de Varona, the two-time Olympic gold medalist in swimming, more than two years after she sued the network in Manhattan federal court for unlawfully firing her because of her age and sex. The lawsuit sought $50 million in damages.

title: AIDS in 5 Nations Called Security Threat
description: Rates of infection from the AIDS virus in five of the world's most populous countries are rising so fast that they pose potential security threats to their regions and to the United States, a group that advises the Central Intelligence Agency said here today.

title: Judge Agrees to New Delay In Trial in Conspiracy Case
description: A federal judge today ordered a nearly six-month delay in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, the sole person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks. The judge determined that an earlier trial date could result in a ''miscarriage of justice.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, ROSE
description: BLAU-Rose. Yeshiva University and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law are saddened by the passing of the loving wife of the late David Blau and beloved mother of Harvey Blau, longtime member of the Board of Directors of Cardozo. Harvey, along with his wife, Arlene, are YU Guardians and CSL Fellows. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to brother Dr. Jeffrey (and Lynn) Blau, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and to all members of the bereaved family. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Earle I. Mack, Chairman CSL Board of Directors David Rudenstine, Dean, CSL

title: Telemedicine, the Easy Way
description: Telemedicine can be successful without being complicated, Australian doctors said in a case report being published today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about a writers' panel discussion, part of the New Yorker Festival, reversed the identities of two participants. Dave Eggers was at the far left and Martin Amis at the far right.

title: Excerpt From Senators' Iraq Resolution
description: Following is an excerpt from a resolution on removing weapons of mass destruction, presented by Senators Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, that is being offered as an alternative to the Bush administration proposal on the issue. The text, as well as the text of the administration proposal, is online at nytimes.com/politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMANN, ANNE
description: WEISMANN-Anne. On September 28, 2002 at age 72. Originally from North Carolina Mrs. Weismann was former head registered nurse at Doctor's Hospital, NY, NY. She did extensive volunteer work at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church. Beloved wife of the late Henri Andre Weismann. Loving sister of Mildred Roberts, Evelyn Deal, Lee Ballard, Joy Sloop and the late Lester Smith Jr. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Wednesday, October 2, 11:00 AM till noon, with service at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Trinity Mausoleum.

title: Letters
description: Why the Risky Behavior?

title: Chief of Big Pension Plan Is Choice for Accounting Board
description: The chief executive of one of the nation's largest pension programs, John H. Biggs, has agreed to be the first head of a new regulatory oversight board for the accounting profession, people involved in the selection said today.

title: A TV campaign is intended to gain support for Israel, but not everyone likes it.
description: THE first television advertising campaign intended to drum up support for Israel in the United States begins its nationwide run this week, nearly three weeks after CNN refused to broadcast one of the ads. But the commercials, created and paid for by two Jewish groups, have already ignited criticism from Arab-Americans.

title: Ford Reaches Agreement With Union In Canada
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Canadian Auto Workers union said today that they had agreed on a tentative three-year contract covering 13,300 workers at Ford plants in Canada.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article on Sept. 20 about the Big Dig in Boston misstated the size of Central Park. It is 843 acres.

title: UAL Payments Suspended
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, will defer $5 million in dividend and interest payments due on preferred securities as the airline seeks to preserve cash and avoid a bankruptcy filing.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about renewed competition among Web browsers misstated the given name of an editor who commented on the strategies of high-speed Internet access providers, and misidentified his publication. He is Dave Burstein, not Dan; he is the editor of DSL Prime, not DSL Reports.

title: Sweden Frees Man Detained in Hijacking Case
description: Swedish authorities today released a man arrested last month when he tried to board a flight with a loaded gun in his carry-on luggage, saying they did not yet have enough evidence to indict him on hijacking charges.

title: Avoiding Ginkgo Fruit
description: Q. The female ginkgo tree on my street is dropping its smelly fruit on the pavement. Is there no way that the sex of a tree can be determined before it is planted?

title: Dow Gains 4.6% as Stocks Start New Quarter With a Comeback
description: After finishing its worst quarter since the 1987 crash, the stock market shot sharply higher today, despite a negative report on manufacturing and the closing of 29 West Coast ports.

title: Front Row
description: Casual Is for Friday Only

title: St. John's, the New No. 1, Will Be a Marked Team
description: Coach DAVE MASUR said it was early and a bit of a distraction, but the St. John's University men's team yesterday moved up to the No. 1 ranking in a poll of coaches nationwide.

title: Parents on the Sidelines
description: To the Editor:

title: News Corp. Seen Buying Italian Unit Of Vivendi
description: The News Corporation and Telecom Italia are expected to announce a deal today to acquire the Italian satellite television operation of Vivendi Universal for 470 million euros ($464 million) in cash, people close to the deal said yesterday.

title: Learning the Etiquette of Patting Down Passengers
description: In a cafeteria recently converted to offer quick training in place of quick meals, Laura Tyler of Tulsa, Okla., waited patiently next to a metal detector, cuddling a plastic baby doll a bit smaller than her own youngest child. John Stewart, until recently a construction worker from Claremore, Okla., asked the standard questions: ''Any metal? Keys? Cell phone, beeper?''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about fighting between rebel and government troops in Ivory Coast misstated the connection of a missionary group to a school under siege in Bouake, the country's second-largest city. The Free Will Baptist Foreign Missions had a family based at the school but does not own it.

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Boston Janitors Strike
description: Boston-area janitors went on strike, and thousands of workers picketed at buildings. Union officials said the strike would be gradual, with 1,200 janitors not reporting for work at 16 office buildings. More will walk off at other buildings each day until demands for fulltime work, higher pay and health benefits are met, the officials said. Local teamsters have pledged not to deliver packages or pick up trash at the buildings. The strike is against Unnico, the city's largest janitorial company.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: HEWLETT TO CUT 1,206 JOBS IN FRANCE The Hewlett-Packard Company , the world's biggest personal computer maker, will eliminate 1,206 jobs in France as a result of its $18.9 billion purchase in May of Compaq Computer . About half of the cuts will be made in Grenoble, in eastern France, and most of the rest will be in the Paris region, the company said yesterday. Workers' committees and unions at Hewlett-Packard have been informed, as French law requires, the company said. Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., has said it will drop 16,800 employees. Hewlett-Packard shares fell 36 cents, or 3 percent, to $11.67. The shares have dropped 32 percent since the acquisition closed on May 3.

title: Deflating Self-Esteem's Role in Society's Ills
description: Low self-esteem is to blame for a host of social ills, from poor academic performance and marital discord to violent crime and drug abuse.

title: AirTrain Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSMITH, HARRY
description: SILVERSMITH-Harry. Beloved husband of the late Florence. Loving father of Shoshona Pascoe and Mark Silversmith. Cherished grandfather of Jenessa, Lorrin and Brendan. Dear brother of Ben. Services today 10:15 AM in ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAWLEY, THOMAS PATRICK
description: CAWLEY-Thomas Patrick. A former captain with the New York City Police Department, law student and respected leader among the Irish community and organizations of Rockland County, was found dead Saturday at his home in Pearl River of an apparent heart attack. He was 63. He retired from the NYPD in 1996 after 33 years. At the time of his death he was a third-year student at Fordham University School of Law and hoped to specialize in geriatric law. Mr. Cawley was a former president of Division III, Rockland County Ancient Order of Hibernians. His wife, Ellen Anderson Cawley, predeceased him in 1992. Survivors include four sons, Charles Anderson, with the US Air Force in Idaho; James Anderson of Bloomingburg, NY; Frank Anderson of Utah and William Anderson of Wisconsin; five grandchildren; four brothers, Michael of Tampa, Fla., Roger of Long Valley, NJ, Raymond of Seattle, WA, and Leonard of Pomona, NY; and numerous nieces and nephews. Wyman - Fisher Funeral Home, Pearl River, NY for funeral info. 845-735-2161.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: SPRINT NAMES NEW PRESIDENT OF PCS Sprint has named Len J. Lauer, left, president of the Sprint PCS operation. The appointment, announced yesterday, is effective immediately. Mr. Lauer replaces Charles E. Levine, who is retiring. Mr. Lauer, 45, was head of the company's global markets group. He joined Sprint in 1998 from Bell Atlantic-New Jersey, where he was president and chief executive officer. "During his career, Len Lauer has demonstrated the ability to successfully lead large, diverse organizations," Sprint's president and chief executive officer, William T. Esrey, said. "His background in sales and marketing, combined with his operational experience, make him well suited to lead our wireless operation." The Sprint president and chief operating officer, Ronald T. LeMay, will lead the global markets group until a permanent successor for Mr. Lauer is named, Sprint said. Sprint's global markets group includes its business and consumer long-distance operations. Sprint PCS is one of the nation's largest mobile-service providers. Sprint PCS shares rose 7 cents, to close at $1.96. (AP)

title: Biggest Drop for Attendance in Major Leagues Since the 1995 Season
description: Major League Baseball attendance fell by 6 percent this season, the largest drop since 1995, when 20 percent fewer fans came to stadiums after the settlement of the players strike that eliminated the previous year's playoffs and World Series.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: New Threat From Basque Group
description: The armed Basque separatist group ETA threatened to attack the offices of the governing Popular Party and the opposition Socialists, saying they are ''military objectives.'' The group has killed 11 politicians from the parties since ending a truce in 1999. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Iraq, the U.N. and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLICKSTEIN, FLORENCE
description: BLICKSTEIN-Florence. Died September 29, 2002. She was of Spring Glen, NY and the retired co-owner and operator of the Homowack Lodge. She is survived by her two daughters, Karen and Ellen, and her three loving grandchildren: Michael, Ann and Maia. Funeral services will be held today at Congregation Ezrath Israel Synagogue, Ellenville, N.Y. at 2 P.M. Burial at Ezrath Israel Cemetery, Wawarsing.

title: Corrections
description: The explanatory footnote yesterday with the chart of the New York Times computer ranking for college football included a factor erroneously among those used for rating teams. Margin of victory -- the difference in scores between a game's winner and loser -- is no longer considered; it has been removed for this season.

title: Sky's the Limit for Canada's Air Taxes
description: WestJet Airlines of Calgary set out to prove a point in the summer by offering what it described as a ''ridiculous'' fare of 3 Canadian dollars ($1.90) one way, or twice that for a round trip, on two of its busiest short-haul routes.

title: Louis Wiesner, 86, Former Diplomat And Refugee Aide
description: Louis A. Wiesner, a retired American diplomat who played a prominent role in the International Rescue Committee, one of the largest nonreligious groups that helps refugees around the world, died on Sept. 20 in Meredith, N.H., the group has announced. He was 86.

title: The Valentine Chronicles: Six Years Near the No. 7 Train
description: Bobby Valentines six full seasons as Mets manager were rarely quiet, more than occasionally controversial and, at times, very successful.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gray In Britain Isn't Just Weather
description: For the first time, the number of people in Britain age 60 and above outnumbers those 16 and younger. According to a one-day snapshot of life in Britain conducted on April 29, 2001, 21 percent of the population of 58,789,194 people is 60 and older; 20 percent is 16 and younger. The census -- which has been criticized after census takers disclosed that they had invented details for thousands of people who did not fill out their forms -- also found there are 1.62 million more women than men in Britain, with women outnumbering men in all age groups after the age of 22. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Democrats Seek Torricelli Replacement After Pallone Declines
description: Democratic leaders scrambling to replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the Nov. 5 ballot asked Representative Frank E. Pallone today to be that stand-in, but Mr. Pallone declined, according to a party official involved in the negotiations.

title: Options in the Final Days
description: ''What Dying People Want,'' by Dr. David Kuhl, Public Affairs/Perseus Books, $25.

title: U.S. Charges Student Who Carried Box Cutters
description: The federal government filed new charges yesterday against a Bulgarian exchange student arrested early Sunday for trying to take a small pair of scissors and two box cutters aboard a jetliner at the Atlantic City International Airport.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Elections May Be Delayed
description: A cabinet minister said the government may consider delaying parliamentary elections scheduled for Nov. 13 because of potential violence by Maoist rebels. On Sunday, the main political parties appealed to Prime Minister Sher Bahadur Deuba to delay the elections for up to six months, and the senior planning minister, Chiranjibi Wagle, said the government had to take their views seriously. The six-year insurgency aimed at toppling the constitutional monarchy has claimed 5,000 lives. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTERMAN, SIDNEY
description: GITTERMAN - Sidney, 84 passed away September 30, 2002. Born in Brooklyn, NY, on March 16, 1918. He was a WWII Veteran, a watchmaker and 25 year teacher, Assistant Principal at PS4, Bronx. He was married to the late Esther Jacobowitz Gitterman in 1950. He loved art, writing, music and hiking. Final years in Huron Woods Alzheimer Home, Ypsilanti, MI. Beloved father of Dena and David. Grandfather of Bill, Adam and Elizabeth. Brother of Yetta, Irene, Molly, Jack and the late Murray and Irving.

title: No Indictment of Senator in Ethics Inquiry, but Enough Questions to Wreck Campaign
description: It started as a run-of-the-mill fraud case, and if it led quickly into the murky waters of New Jersey politics, the biggest fish that federal agents could initially see on the surface was an obscure suburban lawyer who was the Republican chairman in Bergen County, N.J.

title: Let a Thousand Writers Bloom
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Perfume Companies At Odds Over Territory
description: In a case of ''Truth'' and possible consequences, a small cosmetics company that makes a perfume called Truth is suing Calvin Klein Cosmetics, the maker of Truth Calvin Klein perfume, for breach of contract. At issue is whether Calvin Klein's fragrance is trespassing on the smaller company's territory.

title: Teachers Agree to New Plan for 100 Extra Classroom Minutes a Week
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced a new agreement with the New York City teachers' union yesterday to use most of the extra 100 minutes a week that teachers are working this year for instruction. Under a previous plan, half of the time was to be used for teacher training, and the extra instruction was being delayed until November.

title: Yankees vs. Angels
description: Pitching

title: GOODY'S FAMILY CLOTHING IN NEGOTIATIONS TO BE BOUGHT
