description: Goody's Family Clothing, a discount retailer with stores in the Southeast and Midwest, said yesterday that it had signed a nonbinding agreement to be bought by a private equity group for as much as $244.2 million. The price will be $6.50 to $7.50 a share, a premium of as much as a 59 percent over today's closing price of $4.72, the company said. The acquisition could close in the first quarter of next year, Goody's said. The identity of the purchaser is not being disclosed. Goody's is based in Knoxville, Tenn.

title: DYNEGY TO SELL A NATURAL GAS STORAGE SITE IN BRITAIN
description: Dynegy said yesterday that it had agreed to sell part of its British natural gas storage business to Scottish and Southern Energy for $202 million. Scottish & Southern, an owner of power plants in Britain, will buy the Hornsea storage site, which has 325 million cubic meters of storage space in nine caves, the companies said. Scottish and Southern, based in Perth, Scotland, said it hoped to tap rising demand for gas storage services in Britain. Dynegy, whose shares have fallen 96 percent this year, has been selling assets to raise cash after energy trading collapsed in the wake of the Enron Corporation's demise. Dynegy is based in Houston.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: BRAZIL: GANG ORDER SHUTS RIO In a show of strength said to be aimed at securing better living conditions for its imprisoned leader, Rio de Janeiro's most powerful criminal gang has forced schools, businesses and public transport throughout the city to shut down. Followers of Fernandinho Beira-Mar, a drug lord with ties to Colombian guerrillas who has been indicted in the United States, have issued such orders before in slum areas they control, but this action, which was successful despite police efforts to encourage shops to stay open, also affected exclusive neighborhoods, including Ipanema and Copacabana. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Seeking Deeper Meaning in the Babbling of Babies
description: An 11-month-old baby, her face spattered with food and her lips wet with drool, pushes her chin toward the camera and says, ''Da da da da da'' in a soft singsong voice.

title: Thinking Caps Required For a Tale of Betrayal
description: A filmmaker as cerebral as Manoel de Oliveira risks becoming so enamored of his own metaphysical speculations that he abandons his audience to frolic in his own private garden of intellectual delights. And in ''The Uncertainty Principle,'' his eighth movie to be shown in the New York Film Festival, this 93-year-old Portuguese director goes where only a few cult admirers are likely to follow.

title: New Day but Same Sorry Script
description: TRENTON

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Delay In Ex-Judge's Sentencing
description: A State Supreme Court justice postponed the sentencing of a former Brooklyn justice, Victor I. Barron, yesterday after expressing irritation at Mr. Barron's claim that recovery from surgery was keeping him from court. Justice Nicholas Colabella said he would not permit Mr. Barron to use his convalescence to delay prison. ''I'm just not going to put up with that,'' he said as he rescheduled the sentencing for Oct. 28. In August, Mr. Barron pleaded guilty to receiving a bribe under an agreement that will send him to prison for at least three years. Mr. Barron's lawyer, Barry Kamins, said that complications from Mr. Barron's hernia surgery had made prostate surgery necessary, and that the operation took place on Sept. 25. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVAS, LIBBY
description: NEVAS-Libby. The American Jewish Committee is profoundly saddened by the death of Libby Nevas, beloved wife of our longtime leader and Honorary Chair of our Board of Governors, Leo Nevas. Leo and Libby were treasured members of our National Leadership Council. Their devotion to each other, and their loyalty and friendship to AJC and the Jewish community, enlightened and enriched us all. We send heartfelt condolences to their son-in-law Michael Price, an AJC Board member, their children and grandchildren. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Exec Dir

title: A Building's Flaws, Out in the Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Fictions Embraced by an Israel at War
description: A dangerous and deceptive plot line has become superimposed on the story that Israeli society tells itself about its conflict with the Palestinians. Since the outbreak of the current intifada two years ago, it is as if the Israeli mind has turned to a new page in the chronicle of the conflict and, at the same time, erased many of the pages that preceded it.

title: Poultry Farm Settles Suit
description: MILWAUKEE, Sept. 30 (Bloomberg News)  DeCoster Farms, a poultry and egg processor in Iowa, has agreed to pay $1.53 million to settle government allegations that migrant employees were raped or harassed by supervisors. Some of the money will go to women who said they were sexually assaulted or harassed by supervisors at the company's poultry and egg farm in Clarion, Iowa, about 80 miles north of Des Moines. DeCoster Farms did not admit liability, and the supervisors have been fired for unrelated reasons, said the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which filed the suit.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Agency Council of Long Island named Ed Brennan, vice president, as president, succeeding Lyn Nielsen, who left the agency business to start a marketing consulting practice. Mr. Brennan is chief executive at Erin/Edwards Communications, Glen Head, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATER, HYMAN
description: SLATER-Hyman. The HiTech Talmud Torah mourns the sudden passing of our dear friend and founding member, Mr. Hyman Slater, a man of faith, courage & compassion who invested tremendously in the future of the Jewish People. May the Almighty comfort his family amongst all the mourners of Zion & Jerusalem. Rabbi Naftali Rotenstreich Executive Director

title: Blair Presses Call for Action on Iraq With Laborite Delegates
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 1 — Prime Minister Tony Blair today confronted doubters in his Labor party with his case for threatening the use of force against Saddam Hussein and his belief in steadfast alliance with America.

title: Tunnel Vision; After a Century of Dreams, Still Envying the Sardine
description: ''Whatever is said about this project in the years to come, certainly no one can say that the city acted rashly or without due deliberation.''

title: Washington Talk; Whistle-Stops and War Whoops Bury Budget Woes
description: Congress is in a fiscal mess of major proportions, yet hardly anyone is paying attention.

title: A Tribute to Frank Zappa, Including His Own Inventions
description: Frank Zappa's fascination with contemporary classical music is evident even in some of his early Mothers of Invention albums, and by the mid-1980's he was overseeing recordings of his own classical works as a sideline to his rock endeavors. The Meridian Arts Ensemble -- a brass quintet, augmented on this occasion by piano and percussion -- was taken with Zappa's music, and not long before his death in 1993 the group won his approval for its arrangements of several of his pieces.

title: Ivolginsk Journal; A Russian Lama's Body, and His Faith, Defy Time
description: A miracle has occurred here in Siberia. Or it may be a hoax. Others believe science can explain it. It is a question, it seems, of faith.

title: Pregnant Women, Fear Not the Cat
description: Pregnant women have less to fear from cats and litter boxes than they do from undercooked meat, according to a newly published article discussing toxoplasmosis, an infection that can cause miscarriages or damage to fetuses.

title: Sophomoric at Halftime
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares of Retailers Fall on Reports of Slow Sales From Chains
description: Shares in retail stores fell yesterday after some of the companies said that September sales were less than expected. Wal-Mart Stores, J. C. Penney, Federated Department Stores and Sears, Roebuck & Company were among the retailers warning of disappointing results.

title: Capt. Kathleen McGrath, 50, Pioneering Warship Commander
description: Capt. Kathleen McGrath, the first woman to command a United States Navy warship, died on Thursday at the National Naval Medical Center in Bethesda, Md. She was 50 and lived in McLean, Va.

title: Injury and an Arrest Dim the Knicks' Optimism
description: The Knicks have yet to practice this season, but their off-season optimism has been swept away by an injury to Latrell Sprewell and today's arrest of Kurt Thomas.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SOYBEANS FALL. Soybeans fell sharply after a quarterly government report said supply levels on Sept. 1 were higher than first thought. In Chicago, soybeans for November delivery fell 14.5 cents, to $5.45 a bushel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLITZ, ZVI
description: KOLITZ-Zvi. Beloved husband of Mathilde; father of Daliah, Elinoar, Sylvia, Irene and Jonathan; brother of HaRav Yitzhak Kolitz and Rachel Margalioth; grandfather of Oren, Limor, Nuphar, Alon, Daniel, Ezra and Hannah; and great-grandfather of Royee, Omer, Tamir, Gal and Neve. Went to his reward on September 29th. Author, teacher, film and theatrical producer, his intellect, EMUNAH and works influence believers and searchers throughout the world. Services Tuesday, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A New Intrusion, of Soldiers, Threatens an Amazon Tribe
description: The Yanomami Indians have lived precariously in the most remote reaches of the jungle here for thousands of years, hunting with bows and arrows, and warring among themselves and with the few white intruders who have appeared in recent years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, LILLIAN
description: GREENBERG - Lillian. On September 30, 2002, beloved wife of Marvin, loving mother of Barbara and Michael Goldstein, Janet and Norman Baker, Frank and Karel Greenberg. Cherished grandmother to Julie, Emily and Diana Lichter, Alix and Danielle Greenberg and Jenny Rose Baker. Dear sister of Etta Shapiro, Ruth Scheine and Michael Peck. Services Tuesday, 11:45 A.M., ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

title: Caring for the Shrubs and Something More
description: BLESSINGS

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Production Grows
description: Industrial production grew a slower-than-expected 1.6 percent in August from July, suggesting Japan's export-led recovery may be losing steam. Government forecasters expect output to increase 0.4 percent in September and just 0.2 percent in October. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: U.N. Inspectors Report Some Progress in Talks With Iraqis
description: United Nations weapons inspectors used their first meeting with Iraqi officials in almost four years to press today for unfettered access to sensitive sites like the Defense Ministry and the headquarters of Saddam Hussein's Republican Guard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, RONNIE H. (NEE HABER)
description: COOPER-Ronnie H. (nee Haber). Beloved wife of the late Milton Cooper, loving mother and mother-in-law of Andrew and Marjorie Cooper, Glenn & Jackie Cooper and Candice & Gary Baxley, dear sister of the late Sylvia Sachs, cherished grandmother of Hayley, Margo, Rachel, Zachary, Jordan, Bethany, Danielle and Brannon, and dear companion of Mike Fischbein. Services will be held Tuesday October 1 in Baltimore, MD. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hospice of Howard County, 5537 Twin Knolls Road, Suite 433, Columbia, MD 21045. For information, Sol Levinson & Bros, Inc, 800-338-1701.

title: Ethics Is Again Focus of Governor's Race
description: Questions about patronage and influence peddling overshadowed the governor's race today, as the Democratic challenger, H. Carl McCall, and the Republican incumbent, George E. Pataki, sparred over the use of political offices to help friends and relatives.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Lotus Software to tie its products more closely to those of I.B.M., its corporate parent, misstated the year that Ray Ozzie, chief architect of Lotus Notes software, left the company. It was in 1997, not 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINBINDER, SAM
description: EINBINDER - Sam. Loving father of Gloria Nathan, Carol and Harriet Tritch. Cherished grandfather of Fran and Ross, adoring zadie of Jamie and Blake, devoted brother of Rose Schneider and Meyer Einbinder. Services today at noon, Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue, (Corner Avenue M).

title: A CONVERSATION WITH -- Steven Wise; A Courtroom Champion For 4-Legged Creatures
description: Among the high-flying lawyers who roam the halls of Harvard Law School, Steven M. Wise, 51, is an oddity. Instead of devoting himself to the fine points of torts or contracts, he teaches the school's first ever course in animal rights law.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: A Step Toward Compensation
description: A volunteer lawyer, Paul Scrudato, hugged Leonor Santoro yesterday after the federal Victim Compensation Fund offered awards averaging $1.75 million in 14 test cases.

title: Testing Iraq on Arms Inspectors
description: Efforts to resolve the dispute over Iraq are proceeding on parallel tracks that appear contradictory but could be complementary. United Nations officials are meeting with Iraqis in Vienna this week to plan for the return of weapons investigators under existing United Nations resolutions. Meanwhile, Washington is calling for a tough new resolution with deadlines and enforcement provisions.

title: MEMO PAD
description: America West Takes New Swipe at Fares

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Privatization Deal Fails
description: One of the Czech Republic's largest privatization deals collapsed when the Czech businessman Andrej Babis announced that he was withdrawing from the $361 million purchase of a 63 percent stake in the country's largest chemical producer and refiner, Unipetrol. The cancellation sent Unipetrol's share price up 4.4 percent. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: A Chance For White To Fulfill His Wish
description: When the Yankees won three games at home in last fall's World Series, one of the fans caught up in the atmosphere was Rondell White. Sitting in the stands at Yankee Stadium with his friend Cliff Floyd, also a major league outfielder, White listened to Frank Sinatra's ''New York, New York,'' watched the fans waving their arms and knew where he wanted to play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALOWSKY, ALEC
description: KALOWSKY-Alec. On September 29, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Marguerite (nee McHale). Loving father of Carol and Marguerite Benoit. Proud grandfather of Danielle, Robert, Megan and Alec. Also survived by his sister, Helen Olsen and many nieces and nephews. Visiting today 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Av, Bklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, 9AM at Saint Anselm's R.C. Church. Donations in his memory may be made to Visiting Nurse and Hospice Care of Stamford, CT., (Restrict funds to Hospice Program only.) 1029 E. Main St., Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: A Cash Cow For U.S.
description: Officials said they expected to buy $112 million of United States agricultural products as a result of a four-day trade fair that ended yesterday. American executives have signed contracts for everything from corn and soy meal to cattle and poultry, much of which will be shipped to Cuba by this year. Organizers said they were planning a combined agricultural and health-care exhibit in 2004. They added that makers of farm equipment,currently prohibited by American law from selling to Cuba, had expressed interest in taking part. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Laborites Meet and Blair Takes a Beating
description: This working-class resort on the Irish Sea is the busiest vacation spot in Britain, but delegates to the Labor Party annual conference here were in no holiday mood today as they greeted their leader, Prime Minister Tony Blair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANAS, STUART, HAZZAN
description: KANAS-Stuart, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of the revered colleague of over three decades. A wonderful Cantor, he quietly and gently served the spiritual needs of his congregations in New York and Florida. He served with dignity, warmth and care and his kindness, humanity and his davening inspired us all. We extend our sympathy to his wife Roz and his children. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Sheldon Levin, Pres. Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: Spitzer Sues Executives Of Telecom Companies Over 'Ill Gotten' Gains
description: Eliot Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, sued former top officials of five telecommunications companies yesterday, contending that they had steered investment banking business to Citigroup in exchange for inflated ratings on their companies' stocks and new shares of other companies.

title: Ethnic Clenching: Misrule in Ivory Coast
description: The conflict that has gripped this country for almost two weeks has its source in xenophobic policies unleashed nine years ago by the death of Flix Houphout-Boigny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, VICTOR LEWIS
description: STONE-Victor Lewis, died on Saturday, September 28, age 62. Beloved father of Sarah and Eric Stone and husband of 28 years to Pamela Stone. He was a graduate of the University of Florida, where he was captain of the tennis team, and went on to receive his Master's in Counseling. He had a thirty year career at Central Connecticut State University where he was the tennis coach and had the winningest record to date in Central Connecticut history. He was voted Coach of the Century by the Hartford Courant. Himself a nationally ranked world class tennis player, he traveled the world playing tournaments. He won the 1989 Maccabiah Games in Israel. He will be remembered for his tenacity, determination and competitiveness. A true individual, he touched the lives of all who knew him. He was a contender! The Memorial service will be held Thursday, October 3 at 11:30AM at Hirsch and Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, WILBUR E. (BILL)
description: PETERSON-Wilbur E. (Bill). Loving companion and friend of Alan Brockman for 37 years. Devoted eldest brother of Pidge Collier, Irma Grenier, Ronnie Peterson and the late Eddie Peterson and their spouses. Caring uncle and granduncle of all their offspring, friend of all at Fire Island Pines, kind, gentle and generous, Bill was truly a prince among men.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, NORMAN A.
description: ROBERTS-Norman A. On September 27, 2002, died peacefully at home at age 85. Beloved husband of the late Bettina. He is survived by his sister Eleanor Rosenblatt. He was predeceased by a sister, Pearl Markowitz and two brothers; Dr. Sidney Rosenfeld and Irving Rosenfeld. Contributions may be made to the Norman & Bettina Roberts Foundation, Inc., C/O Gruntal & Company, Attn: Joseph Canciglia, 2125 Center Avenue, Fort Lee, NJ 07024.

title: Diamondbacks Are Seeking A Little Lift to the Spirit
description: To soothe their crumpled psyches, to make them feel like the defending World Series champions again, the Arizona Diamondbacks were able to park themselves next to a jalopy for a few days this past week.

description: Rootless

title: Labor Lockout At West's Ports Roils Business
description: Cargo ships waited offshore today and factory owners worried about parts shortages as port operators from Seattle to San Diego shut down 29 West Coast ports in a dispute with the longshoremen's union.

title: Cardinals vs. Diamondbacks
description: They are the sentimental favorites because of what they went through during the season, overcoming the emotional distress triggered by the death of pitcher Darryl Kile. No one, however, scores on sentiment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULDER, BERTIE
description: SCHULDER-Bertie. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Bertie Schulder. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: TORRICELLI QUITS CAMPAIGN, CITING RISK TO HIS PARTY
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat whose aggressive fund-raising helped his party gain its single-seat majority in the United States Senate, announced today that he was ending his bid for re-election, acknowledging that his campaign had become overwhelmed by questions about improper gifts he accepted from a contributor.

title: Hard-Hit Monarch Butterflies Demonstrate Their Resilience
description: In January, hundreds of millions of monarch butterflies were killed by a storm on their winter roosting grounds in Mexico, leaving scientists and countless monarch lovers wondering how the surviving insects would fare when they migrated back to the United States and Canada.

title: Testing the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: West
description: BILL ON RADIOACTIVE WASTE DIES Gov. Gray Davis vetoed a bill to strictly limit the disposal of low-level radioactive waste but ordered a ban on debris from decommissioned nuclear sites at municipal landfills. The bill was "overly broad, unworkable and would do little to significantly enhance protection of the public health," Governor Davis said. Its sponsor, State Senator Gloria Romero, said "giant corporate interests" fought the bill. Mr. Davis ordered the California Water Resources Control Board to adopt a model regulation barring any waste with residual radioactivity from landfills for household garbage. A Superior Court judge in Sacramento County had ordered a moratorium, Ms. Romero said.    (AP)

title: Walter Annenberg, Philanthropist and Media Baron, Dies at 94
description: Walter H. Annenberg, the philanthropist, art collector and former ambassador to Britain who at one time presided over a vast communications empire that included TV Guide and The Philadelphia Inquirer, died today in Wynnewood, Pa. He was 94 and had homes there and in California.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: DIX HILLS: THREE KILLED IN DRUNKEN DRIVING ACCIDENT A Woodhaven man was charged with driving when intoxicated early yesterday after his mother, sister and grandfather were killed in a car accident on the Long Island Expressway, the Suffolk County police said. The driver, Luis Ramirez, 20, was driving a 1991 Toyota in the center lane of the expressway near Dix Hills when he got a flat tire and slowed or stopped, the police said. His car was hit from behind by a 1998 pickup truck. Mr. Ramirez's sister, Fiorella Ramirez, 12, and his grandfather, Ernesto Villavincio, 83, were pronounced dead at the scene, and his mother, Cecilia Ramirez, 40, was taken to Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, where she was pronounced dead. His girlfriend, Laurie Luna, 19, was taken to the same hospital, where she was in critical condition last night. Mr. Ramirez was treated at University Hospital at Stony Brook for minor injuries Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: An Appraisal; Ground Zero: 6 New Drawing Boards
description: The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has taken a giant step toward securing public trust. Last Thursday, the corporation, a state agency, announced the selection of six design teams to study the future of the World Trade Center site and the financial district. The teams include some of the most fertile minds at work in architecture today. If the public keeps its eye on the ball, the development corporation's latest effort could change the course of cultural life in New York.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Gang Order Shuts Rio
description: In a show of strength said to be aimed at securing better living conditions for its imprisoned leader, Rio de Janeiro's most powerful criminal gang has forced schools, businesses and public transport throughout the city to shut down. Followers of Fernandinho Beira-Mar, a drug lord with ties to Colombian guerrillas who has been indicted in the United States, have issued such orders before in slum areas they control, but this action, which was successful despite police efforts to encourage shops to stay open, also affected exclusive neighborhoods, including Ipanema and Copacabana. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENKUS, FLORENCE
description: HENKUS-Florence. Congregation Talmud Torah Adereth El wishes to express heartfelt condolences to our dear member and former president, Mr. Irving Henkus, on the loss of his beloved wife, Florence Henkus. May he be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Chicago-Area Factory Index Falls for Month
description: Manufacturing in the Chicago area unexpectedly contracted in September for the first time in eight months, according to a report released today, suggesting that the economic rebound might be in danger of stalling.

title: The Dress Code Demands Pinstripes
description: David Eckstein -- all 5 feet 8 inches of him -- stood alone in the sunshine in the dugout of an empty Yankee Stadium yesterday. Eckstein will lead off for the Anaheim Angels tonight, with flashbulbs popping, fans roaring and Roger Clemens rocking into his Hall of Fame delivery.

title: How Am I Doing -- Really?
description: Ever the savvy businessman, Michael Bloomberg has again demonstrated that he knows his customer. His first Mayor's Management Report -- covering his first six months in office and the last six months under Rudolph Giuliani -- surprised good-government advocates and a public that has come to view New York City's report card as an obligatory exercise in eyestrain and endurance.

title: Low-Payroll Clubs Show They Can Be Successful
description: That oft-quoted statistic is about to change.

title: Iraq, the U.N. and Us
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices in Korea were 3.1 percent higher in September than they were in September of last year, according to the National Statistical Office. The consumer price index rose 0.6 percent from August and 2.4 percent from September 2001. The biggest increase was in vegetable prices, which surged 19.8 percent from September 2001 because of a typhoon that damaged crops. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Scioscia's Moment
description: Before Kirk Gibson hit a hanging slider against Dennis Eckersley in Game 1 of the 1988 World Series, Mike Scioscia had the most important home run of that postseason for Los Angeles. Scioscia, then a Dodgers catcher and now the manager of the Anaheim Angels, turned on a Dwight Gooden fastball over the inner half of the plate in the top of the ninth inning of Game 4 of the National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium against the Mets, and the ball sailed over the right-field fence for a two-run home run that tied the game, 3-3.

title: Fakery at a Top Research Lab
description: It was a bleak day for science last week when research that seemed destined to win a Nobel Prize was determined to have been faked. A whole series of dazzling advances that had promised to revolutionize electronic devices and superconducting materials was cast under a cloud when an investigative panel concluded that the key scientist, a 32-year-old physicist, had fabricated data and graphs in papers published over four years. Even worse, the deception occurred at Bell Labs, the most renowned of the nation's industrial laboratories, and many of the fraudulent papers were published in two of the world's most prestigious journals, Science and Nature, suggesting that the nation's premier scientific institutions need better procedures to spot fraud.

title: Election Statute Offers No Clear Answers
description: Title 19 of the New Jersey election law clearly states that if a ballot vacancy occurs 51 days or more before an election, the party may nominate a new candidate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Expansion Of Clergy Law Is Urged
description: District Attorney Denis E. Dillon of Nassau County called yesterday for expansion of the county law that requires clergy members to report suspected child sex abuse. In particular, he wants more detail on the alleged abuse, including the name of the victim and who is making the allegation. A county law passed this year does not specify what information must be reported. Rick Hinshaw, a spokesman for the district attorney, said that the Diocese of Rockville Centre had recently told the office of an allegation against a priest, but refused to name the victim or the informant. The diocese said the informant insisted on anonymity. Mr. Dillon said that other professionals who work with children, like schoolteachers, should be included in the law. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Increase in Uninsured
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Real Yankees? Newcomers' Turn to Prove It
description: THEY may be wearing pinstriped uniforms, but five of the nine Yankees in tonight's batting order still have to prove they're Yankees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, FREDA BARAF
description: GELLER-Freda Baraf. On September 30, 2002. Beloved wife of David, devoted mother of Stephen, Andrew, and Lydia. Dear sister of Lila and Jean. Loving grandmother of Meredith, Michael, Richard, Joshua, Jonathan, Jeffrey, and Jason. Memorial service Thursday 2:30 P.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Republican 'Moderates'
description: To the Editor:

title: Grounded No Longer, Shuttle Atlantis Is Readied for Space
description: After a three-month grounding to repair cracks in the fuel systems of the space shuttle fleet, the shuttle Atlantis is to resume flying this week with a mission to continue construction of the International Space Station.

title: Democrats Scramble for a New Contender, But G.O.P. Vows Fight to Keep the Old One
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli's abrupt decision to abandon his re-election campaign caught national Democratic leaders by surprise today and added new uncertainty to the ferocious battle for control of the Senate.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Angiotech To Buy Cohesion For $42 Million
description: Angiotech Pharmaceuticals agreed yesterday to buy Cohesion Technologies, a maker of surgical sealants and products, for about $42 million in stock. Shares of Cohesion surged as much as 66 percent. Angiotech said it would pay $4.05 a share for Cohesion, which is 80 percent more than Cohesion's closing stock price on Friday of $2.25. As part of the acquisition, Angiotech, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia, will gain a 40 percent stake in Neucoll, a provider of biomaterial products, based in Campbell, Calif. Cohesion is a developer of products used in biosurgery, including CoStasis, used in controlling surgical bleeding. Shares of Cohesion, based in Palo Alto, Calif., rose $1.43, to $3.68. Angiotech shares fell 25 cents, to $39.58. They had dropped 29 percent this year.

title: The U.S. Case Against Iraq: Counting Up the Reasons
description: In seeking support from Congress and the United Nations to wage war with Iraq if he deems it necessary, President Bush has cited one overriding concern: Saddam Hussein's possession of weapons of mass destruction, his efforts to acquire more and the risk that he or others might use them against the United States.

title: A Parrots Day in Court
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: STEEP RISE IN LAYOFFS

title: Braves Make the Best of Mets' Plight
description: It was hard escaping the Mets, even in Atlanta. I had just landed Tuesday morning, stopped to grab lunch to go and planned on consuming my sandwich quickly in my hotel room before I raced to Turner Field for the workout-interview day of the division series between the Braves and Giants when my phone rang. Bobby Valentine, the Mets manager, was fired and the team was having a news conference to announce it that afternoon at 3 p.m.

title: Archdiocese Taps Worker to Hear Stories of Abuse
description: Some come with poetry they have written or pictures they have drawn to capture the pain and stabbing sense of betrayal they felt when a priest they respected raped them.

title: Don't Change the New Jersey Ballot
description: Over the next few days and weeks, we are likely to encounter a lot of arguments, and a lawsuit or two, claiming that democracy and the Constitution demand that the Democratic Party in New Jersey be allowed to put on the ballot a new candidate in place of Robert G. Torricelli, who dropped out of the race for the United States Senate on Monday. Such arguments should be rejected.

title: Thomas Turner, 100, Hopkins Medical Dean
description: Dr. Thomas B. Turner, an authority on infectious diseases and microbiology who led a vast expansion at the Johns Hopkins University medical school, died on Sept. 22 in Baltimore. He was 100.

title: Stable World Oil Prices Are Likely to Become a War Casualty, Experts Say
description: Amid all the unknowns about the American campaign against Saddam Hussein, the one certainty is its potential to shake up oil markets.

title: Executive to Leave AT&T
description: AT&T said that Richard J. Martin, the executive vice president for public relations and brand management, had announced plans to retire and would leave the company early next year.

title: UAL EXECUTIVES ARE REVIEWING UNION CONCESSIONS
description: Glenn F. Tilton, the chief executive of UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, said that executives were meeting with union leaders this week to review the concessions offered by the company's five unions last Wednesday. The unions have offered $1 billion in annual concessions over five years, less than United's earlier demand of $1.5 billion a year over six years. But Mr. Tilton, in a voice mail message to employees this week, said that executives were working quickly to try to present a revised business plan to the federal government to bolster an application for a $1.8 billion loan guarantee.

title: From Soy Soup to Soy Nuts, A Cafe and Store Under One Roof
description: What inspired John Pi and Vivian Cheng to open the Soy Luck Club, a soy cafe and market at 115 Greenwich Avenue (Jane Street)? ''Look at the soy section in the supermarket,'' Mr. Pi said. ''It's become almost as big as the dairy department.'' The name suggests the book ''The Joy Luck Club'' and Chinese food, but this is an almost Scandinavian-modern spot with a more mainstream menu: flavored soy milk lattes, frosted soy smoothies and frappes (drinks, $2.75 to $5.25), sandwiches spread with soy mayonnaise on soy bread and salads with tofu and edamame and soy dressing ($4.95 to $7.50) and even a blackout cake made with soy milk. Everything is organic. Soy-based baby formula, crackers and pasta are sold in a grocery section.

title: Big Bequest to Brooklyn College
description: Brooklyn College has received the largest bequest in its history, $6.5 million, from the estate of Walter Cerf, a professor of philosophy at the college from 1948 to 1972. The money is to be divided equally among the Departments of Theater and of Art and the Conservatory of Music. The estate is making similar bequests to Princeton University and the Weizmann Institute for Science in Israel.

title: Home for a Swedish Clothing Retailer
description: Some rapidly expanding retailers like to cite stacks of market research before deciding where to open stores, but not Hennes & Mauritz, the huge Swedish clothing retailer whose fashionable but value-conscious customers usually refer to it as H&M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with profound sadness the passing of Walter H. Annenberg, who for more than four decades demonstrated on a breathtaking scale his passion for art and his support of this institution. With his wife, Leonore, he based his philanthropy at the Metropolitan on the understanding that great museum collections remain great by continuing to evolve and to grow. Through a series of landmark gestures-gifts of works of art from masterpieces by Van Gogh to masterpieces of Asian sculpture, along with major grants for acquisitions-they have enhanced the very heart of the Metropolitan Museum, its collections, for generations to come. Walter Annenberg was involved in countless other ways as well: as a Trustee and benefactor; as a committed supporter of education in the arts; and as the donor of a major challenge grant that has enabled the Museum to build a new Center For Imaging and Photography. But his most spectacular gesture was the decision in 1991 to bequeath his collection of fifty-three Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, watercolors, and drawings to the Museum, the largest single gift of art to the Metropolitan in more than a quarter century. Since 1993, this outstanding collection has been in residence at the Museum for six months of each year for all to enjoy. Walter's motto was ''strength to strength,'' and his legacy of sweeping generosity will be held dear by us and by the museum-going public in perpetuity. We extend our deepest condolences to Mrs. Annenberg and to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director David E. McKinney, President

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer To Bolster U.S. Unit
description: The German reinsurance company Munich Re said it would inject $1.4 billion into its United States unit, American Re, to strengthen its capital position. The move, which still needs regulatory approval, would be financed out of Munich Re's own funds. By focusing clearly on the American market and reorganizing management and structure, American Re will be able to increase profitability, the company said. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Netiq Buys Security Software Concern
description: The NetIQ Corporation, a software maker based in San Jose, Calif., announced yesterday that it would buy PentaSafe Security Technologies, a security management software company, for $192.2 million in cash and 4.3 million shares and options. The total deal is valued at about $255 million, the companies said. A privately held company in Houston, PentaSafe makes software that helps clients make their computer systems secure from hackers and viruses; that market has grown considerably since September 2001. The acquisition plan announced yesterday, which still awaits approval by PentaSafe's shareholders, is another example of a consolidation in the security software industry. In a conference call, Charles M. Boesenberg, chief executive of NetIQ, said that PentaSafe's security business would add $125 million in revenue next year. He also said there would be layoffs in all areas of the company because of staff redundancies. NetIQ also reiterated yesterday the earnings guidelines it issued in September. Shares in NetIQ, which traded at more than $100 at the height of the technology boom, fell 80 cents, to $13.70. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Signs 10-Year Pact With Boots
description: International Business Machines said yesterday that it had signed a 10-year computer-management and technology-services agreement with Britain's largest pharmacy chain, Boots. The $1.1 billion agreement with Boots requires I.B.M. to set up a research center in Nottingham, England, to help Boots develop wireless and mobile systems to improve customer relations and cut costs. I.B.M. will deploy and manage point-of-sale terminals and operate telecommunications for Boots in addition to running Boots' computers. It will hire 400 Boots employees. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: 2 Sides Sign Off On Labor Pact
description: Completing the most unlikely year in baseball labor history, the union chief and Major League Baseball's chief labor lawyer signed a memorandum of understanding yesterday, signing off on a collective bargaining agreement that will provide labor peace for four more years.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Man With Box Cutters Is Freed
description: The man charged with trying to carry box cutters aboard an airliner at the Atlantic City International Airport was freed yesterday, the United States attorney's office said. The man, a Bulgarian exchange student named Nikolay V. Dzhonev, 21, was in the custody of a Bulgarian consular official from Washington. As a condition of his release on a $100,000 bond, Mr. Dzhonev surrendered his passport and other travel documents and agreed to stay with Bulgarian officials until a court hearing on Oct. 23. Bulgaria will forfeit the $100,000 if Mr. Dzhonev violates the terms, officials said. The F.B.I. said Monday it found no evidence that Mr. Dzhonev was linked to terrorists when he was discovered Sunday with the concealed box cutters and a hidden pair of scissors. He told agents the box cutters were ''novelties'' he wanted to keep from his summer job. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RICHARD A., JUDGE
description: GOLDBERG - Richard A., Judge. The Board of Directors of the City College Fund mourns the loss of Judge Richard A. Goldberg, '51B, former Board member, and distinguished graduate of the City College of NY. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Stanley H. Kaplan, Chairman Herbert Robinson, Esq., Pres. James L. Schatz, Exec. Dir.

title: Eugene T. Reed Dies at 79; A Warrior for Civil Rights
description: Dr. Eugene T. Reed, a Long Island dentist who was a militant leader of the civil rights movement in the 1950's and 60's -- staring down rifle-bearing farmers in Mississippi and leading protests in New York -- died last Wednesday at his home in Amityville, N.Y. He was 79.

title: Westchester Budget Gap Fuels A Feud Over Who Is to Blame
description: Passing a county budget in Westchester is never a peaceful process, but a looming shortfall has gotten the bickering off to an early start.

title: Gore Urges Bush to Focus on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  One week after assailing President Bush's handling of Iraq, Al Gore today offered a scathing assessment of Mr. Bush's stewardship of the American economy, asserting that his policies had created a "crisis of confidence" across the world. He urged the president to convene Congressional leaders to pass a mid-course adjustment before Election Day.

title: Books Often Give History A Facelift
description: THE Texas Board of Education will soon decide which history textbooks may be used in the state. Activists on the left and right are lobbying the board, to influence its choices.

title: A River Reborn
description: Yesterday's Times carried a photograph of 20 or so muscular, blue-capped swimmers jumping into the Hudson River just south of the George Washington Bridge, about to embark on a 7.8-mile race downriver to Chelsea. The photograph was notable not only for what it said about the adventurous swimmers but for what it said about the river itself. The Hudson is a river reborn. Thirty years ago it was little more than a sewer along its entire 350-mile length, from the Adirondacks to the Battery, choked with untreated municipal waste and industrial chemicals. Nobody in his right mind would have jumped into its waters, let alone swum 7.8 miles. Today it teems with life. Its fish populations are healthier than they've been in years, boating is booming, towns that once turned their backs on the river are clogged with tourists.

title: Fannie Mae Acts to Curb Interest Rate Risks
description: Fannie Mae said today that it increased its protection against falling interest rates last month, easing concern that its profit margins would be squeezed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUHANA, ANNE
description: ROUHANA-Anne. On October 1, 2002, of Port Washington, NY, formerly of Brooklyn. Beloved wife of William. Loving mother of William Jr. (Amy), Debbie (Kevin), Stephen (Mary), Denise (Fred) and Claudia. Cherished grandmother of 13. Beloved sister of Albert Stephan (Carol). In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Wednesday and Thursday, 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 12PM, at Our Lady of Lebanon Church, Brooklyn Heights, NY, with interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington.

title: Bonds Hopes to Use Bat To Bury Playoff Ghosts
description: Barry Bonds hit his one and only postseason home run off the Braves' Tom Glavine in 1992. He has hit 437 home runs since then, but none in the playoffs.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Boys' Killer Sentenced
description: Kenneth Hansen, a 69-year-old former stable hand convicted of murdering three boys in 1955, was sentenced to 200 to 300 years in prison by Judge Mary Ellen Coghlan of Cook County Circuit Court. Mr. Hansen, who sexually assaulted at least one of the boys before leaving their strangled, naked bodies in a nearby ditch on Chicago's Northwest Side, will receive credit for eight years already served. A previous conviction was overturned in 2000 by a state appellate court that ruled the jury should not have been told he had molested boys before the killing. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Kim Puts Last Postseason in the Past
description: When Byung Hyun Kim secured a victory for Arizona at Yankee Stadium on June 12, he saved more than a game. He preserved his own tortured confidence as well. Grabbing a baseball, Kim flung it from behind the pitcher's mound over the wall in left-center field.

title: In Nassau, an Expensive Treasure Unfound by Divers, or by Swimmers
description: What if they built one of the biggest indoor pools in the Western Hemisphere but hardly anybody came to swim?

title: White House Pressured to End to Reopen West Coast Ports
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 2  Industry groups stepped up their calls today for President Bush to use his emergency powers to reopen 29 West Coast ports as the longshoremen's union canceled scheduled negotiating sessions with an employers group.

title: Johnson Fails Arizona In Game 1
description: He was Arizona's one sure thing. After so many injuries and the funk that settled on the ace Curt Schilling at season's end, the Diamondbacks were counting on Randy Johnson to right them by intimidating the St. Louis Cardinals with his scowl, his 6-foot-10 frame and a left arm that mimics a propeller.

title: U.S. Faulted Over Its Efforts to Unite Iraqi Dissidents
description: While endorsing ''regime change'' and democracy in Iraq, the Bush administration is stumbling in its efforts to forge a cohesive opposition to Saddam Hussein. According to Iraqi opposition leaders and experts on Iraq, its approach remains plagued by differences over who should lead the dissidents and who would rule the country most effectively if Mr. Hussein were overthrown.

title: Mother Kills Her Son, 8, In Accident In Driveway
description: A woman driving a minivan accidentally struck and killed her 8-year-old son on Monday as she arrived to pick him up from a play date at a friend's home, the police said.

title: Value of Playoff Experience Depends on Who Has It
description: On the one hand, Andy Pettitte said: "I think it's big. I think a lot of other people think that also. I think that's why everybody thinks Oakland is going to be so tough this year. It definitely makes a little bit of difference when it comes down to crunch time."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Baseball Shrine With a Hudson River View
description: YOU have to say this about F.illi Ponte, the old-school Italian restaurant overlooking the Hudson River: the owners really love Joe Torre. Pictures of the Yankees manager are everywhere, adorning the stairway to the second-floor dining room, surrounding the humidors in the fragrant cigar lounge and lining a hallway leading to private dining rooms. They capture Mr. Torre at various stages of his baseball career. They place him in exalted company (Frank Sinatra, for one). They even make a strong case that given the choice between pinstripes and loud black and white checks, apparently Mr. Torre's other favorite pattern, he should stick to pinstripes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBOWITZ, HERMAN
description: LEIBOWITZ - Herman. Of Hollis Hills, NY, succumbed to a long, debilitating disease at age 79 on October 1st, 2002. Beloved husband of Simone. Revered father and father-inlaw of Rochelle and Steven Kosowitz, Stacey and Steven Leibowitz, and Sandra Leibowitz. Dearest grandfather of 3. Born in Vienna, Austria, a veteran of WW II, a mechanical engineer specializing in power plants, who served for 29 years with Sanderson & Porter Inc., including as vice president. A fine example of professional achievement combined with unbendable moral rectitude and total devotion to the family. Funeral services at ''Schwartz Brothers,'' Forest Hills, New York, on October 2, 2002, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Jewish causes, especially those related to the Holocaust, greatly appreciated.

title: Clubby Branch Offices Challenge Banking's Grand Presence in Philadelphia
description: Not long ago, a trip to the bank frequently meant a visit to one of the most splendid buildings in town. Whether on a downtown street or in a granite quarry town in Vermont or a gold rush city in California, the bank was an imposing brick or stone fortress meant to inspire trust.

title: Fighting the First Gulf War
description: In August 1990 my Marine infantry battalion deployed to Saudi Arabia to defend the country from invasion by the Iraqi army. Iraqi soldiers had invaded Kuwait during the early morning of Aug. 2. For more than a week afterward we sat atop our rucksacks on the parade field at the Marine base at Twenty Nine Palms, Calif., waiting for transportation to Riyadh. From where we sat, the world looked amazingly black and white, with little room or need for diplomacy or cowardice. We were excited to retaliate against Saddam Hussein, to enter combat.

title: Health Insurance for Freelancers; A New Group Focuses on an Overlooked Group of Workers
description: Finding a silver lining in the events of Sept. 11, 2001, isn't easy, and capitalizing on it is even harder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMANN, ANNE
description: WEISMANN-Anne. On September 28, 2002 at age 72. Originally from North Carolina Mrs. Weismann was former head registered nurse at Doctor's Hospital, NY, NY. She did extensive volunteer work at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church. Beloved wife of the late Henri Andre Weismann. Loving sister of Mildred Roberts, Evelyn Deal, Lee Ballard, Joy Sloop and the late Lester Smith Jr. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Wednesday, October 2, 11:00 AM till noon, with service at 12 noon. Interment to follow at Trinity Mausoleum.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotel-Tavern Breakup
description: Six Continents, the world's biggest hotel owner, said it would split its hotel and pub businesses next April in its biggest shake-up since it sold its Bass brewery two years ago. After failing to find another hotel group to buy, the company, which owns the Inter-Continental and Crowne Plaza chains, said investors would receive shares in both businesses and 700 million ($1.1 billion) in cash, equivalent to 81 pence ($1.27) a share. But its share price fell by 10 percent because of a planned dividend cut. Six Continents operates about 3,280 hotels in 65 countries and has about 2,000 pubs, bars and restaurants. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTIS, JOHN WINTHROP
description: OTIS-John Winthrop. Died suddenly in Wilmington, North Carolina on September 10, 2002, at age 72. Born in Bronxville, NY on January 21, 1930, son of Courtlandt and Virginia McCauley Otis, he was graduated from the St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire, in 1948 and attended Princeton University. John was a leading copywriter in the advertising industry in New York City for many years. Among his associations were the Union Club, Society of Colonial Wars, St. Nicholas Society, numerous animal humane organizations, and various other charities. His companion, Gano R. Bailey, predeceased him. Survivors include his sister Helen Otis Pope, his niece Debra Chadwick, his nephew Gary Pope and his former wife Georgette Lachelier. A memorial service will be held at the Union Club of New York City on October 10th at 6PM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blood Tests For Unconscious Drivers
description: A new law allowing the police to direct doctors to take blood samples from unconscious drivers after car accidents drew complaints from civil rights campaigners. The law, part of the 2002 Police Reform Act, is meant to help identify drunk drivers responsible for crashes. Although the blood samples cannot be tested for alcohol or drugs until the subject gives permission, those who refuse will be subject to prosecution. ''Sticking needles into unconscious people without their consent and for no medical purpose isn't the way forward,'' said Mark Littlewood, of the civil rights group Liberty. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: New York Asks to Be Reimbursed for Lost Tax Revenues
description: Members of New York City's Congressional delegation introduced legislation in Washington today that could pave the way for the federal government to reimburse the city for some of the tax revenues it lost because of the World Trade Center attacks.

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTYRE, HELEN P.
description: McINTYRE-Helen P. Died on September 27. Beloved wife of Randall P. McIntyre. Devoted mother of Virginia McIntyre, Mark P. McIntyre and Archie McIntyre. Grandmother of seven. Sister of Warren B. Pond, Jr., and dear friend of many. Memorial service on October 5, 12:30 PM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests gifts to Helen's Fund at the Long Island Community Foundation, Jericho, NY.

title: Staying Steadfast and True, With Bravado at Full Tilt
description: There was exactly one pretentious moment in the three Rolling Stones concerts around New York: when an announcer at Roseland on Monday night said that the band was completing its ''New York trilogy.''

title: Businesses Drawing Up Contingency Plans
description: As the shutdown of West Coast ports continued, retailers and manufacturers began to focus yesterday on contingency plans to let them ship goods in case the ports remained closed for more than a few days.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: PROTESTERS ENTER U.S. COMPOUND Seven South Korean students scaled a wall of the American Embassy before police officers guarding the compound in central Seoul could respond, an embassy official said. The students were quickly arrested after dropping into the compound, according to the official. They had planned to burn the American flag above the embassy door to protest the fact that President Bush has not apologized for the deaths of two schoolgirls crushed by an American armored vehicle in June. American officials in South Korea have apologized and two Army sergeants face courts-martial. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Publisher Sues O'Donnell Over Demise of Her Magazine
description: Gruner & Jahr USA filed a lawsuit yesterday against Rosie O'Donnell for ending her relationship with Rosie, a magazine that she published with the company.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Raising Business Taxes
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman said he might call a special session of the Legislature after the Nov. 5 election to raise corporate taxes on large businesses. In a statement released by his campaign for re-election, Mr. Siegelman characterized ''giant out-of-state corporations'' that did not pay taxes as freeloaders. The session could come in December. Business groups support Mr. Siegelman's Republican opponent, Representative Bob Riley.

title: Why This Cheese Stands Alone
description: ALTHOUGH the American artisanal cheese movement has raised our national standard far above individually wrapped singles, there are still some varieties that seem to remain beyond its grasp. Cream cheese is one. It's easier to find lovingly tended, ash-covered logs of farmstead goat-milk cheese than an alternative to the usual gummy brick we spread on our bagels.

title: Recording Executive Will Lead Group That Runs the Grammys
description: Neil Portnow, a low-key record company executive, has been named president of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, the organization that runs the Grammy Awards.

title: Mets Close the Door on Valentine
description: Bobby Valentine met last week with Fred Wilpon, the owner of the Mets, and mentioned the possibility of his having a more expansive role in the team's personnel decisions for 2003, the final year of his contract. He said he received no response. Valentine also asked about renewing the contracts of his coaches. Again, Valentine said, Wilpon was silent.

title: Antismoking Bill's Chances May Hinge on Personalities
description: Relations between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and some members of the City Council have deteriorated to such an extent that Council leaders are warning that the mayor's prized antismoking legislation may be in jeopardy.

title: It's October, and Yankee Bats Rise to the Occasion
description: It was Manager Joe Torre's nightmare come true. The Yankees were not taking pitches. They could not score by any means but the home run. The Anaheim Angels were doing all the little things that mean so much in October, and they were one out from turning over the game to their indomitable closer, Troy Percival.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales Are Reported Up
description: The Semiconductor Industry Association, a trade group for makers of computer chips, said yesterday that the industry was in a broad-based upturn and pointed to an increase in sales figures. The group said worldwide sales of chips -- used in a broad range of products, like computers and phones -- hit $11.9 billion in August, a 2.2 percent rise over the previous month. It was a 14 percent rise over sales in August 2001. The industry association said sales had been particularly strong to makers of mobile telephones and also noted that there had been brisk sales in Asia to makers of consumer products like DVD's and digital cameras. The association said chip sales should total $143 billion for all of 2002. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Beckett's Earthy Idea Of Optimism
description: In the summer of 1961 a remarkable series of trans-Atlantic letters was exchanged between two eminent men of the theater in which the subject of dirt -- and how to use it -- was discussed in exacting detail.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Protesters Enter U.S. Compound
description: Seven South Korean students scaled a wall of the American Embassy before police officers guarding the compound in central Seoul could respond, an embassy official said. The students were quickly arrested after dropping into the compound, according to the official. They had planned to burn the American flag above the embassy door to protest the fact that President Bush has not apologized for the deaths of two schoolgirls crushed by an American armored vehicle in June. American officials in South Korea have apologized and two Army sergeants face courts-martial. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: It's October, and Yankee Bats Rise to the Occasion
description: It was Manager Joe Torre's nightmare come true. The Yankees were not taking pitches. They could not score by any means but the home run. The Anaheim Angels were doing all the little things that mean so much in October, and they were one out from turning over the game to their indomitable closer, Troy Percival.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pennsylvania Memorial To Include Steel From Trade Center Site
description: The fathers of two victims of the attack on the World Trade Center presented pieces of steel from the site to officials in Somerset County, Pa., for inclusion in the permanent memorial to be built at the site where United Flight 93 crashed. Tom Johnson's son Scott worked on the 88th floor of the south tower, and Lee Ielpi's son Jonathan was a firefighter with Squad 288. The fathers traveled to the crash site with representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation who are visiting memorial sites across the country as part of their planning for the memorial at the trade center site. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Carl McCall's Letters
description: New York State's comptroller, Carl McCall, finds himself in a mess in his gubernatorial race against George Pataki. And his efforts to deal with it seem only to make matters worse. Mr. McCall's main problem is that several years ago he wrote at least two letters on official stationery asking companies in which the state has major investments to help his relatives get jobs. Mr. McCall describes the stir as a mere distraction from the campaign. But the letters were inappropriate, and it is Mr. McCall himself who is providing extra traction for a fracas that his opponent is clearly enjoying.

title: SAKS WILL CUT AS MANY AS 295 JOBS IN CONSOLIDATION
description: Saks Inc. will cut as many as 295 jobs as it combines the headquarters of its Younkers stores with the Carson Pirie Scott division offices as part of its cost-reduction measures. Saks will eliminate about 270 positions at the Younkers office in Des Moines and 25 jobs at a division furniture warehouse and distribution center in Green Bay, Wis. The company has about 56,000 employees, a spokeswoman, Julia Bentley, said. The company will complete the consolidation by Feb. 1, the end of its fiscal year. The company is based in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JOYCE LENORE
description: ANDERSON-Joyce Lenore. On September 22, 2002. Beloved wife of Earl. Devoted mother of Mark, Wendy Petersen, and Scott. Loving grandmother of Brooke Paige and Danielle. Cherished sister of Susan Weiner. Daughter of the late Louis and Sarah Weiner. Born September 16, 1930 in Brooklyn, New York. Had 30 year career as a Homebound Teacher with the N.Y.C. Board of Education. Longstanding member of the Unitarian Church of Shelter Rock and member of the women's group. Private memorial service. Donations may be made in her memory to the American Cancer Society.

title: Democrats Vow to Pass New Security Agency Despite Filibuster
description: Senate Democratic leaders vowed today to approve a Homeland Security Department, even if that meant staying in session for weeks. But with no sign of a breakthrough in a partisan dispute over Civil Service protections, the prospect for passage by year's end appeared dim. Republicans refused today to end their filibuster against a Democratic plan to protect job security in the proposed antiterrorism department, defeating a motion to end debate.

title: In Strategy Talks in Trenton, Senator Began to See the End
description: In the end, it was Senator Robert G. Torricelli himself who decided he had to pull out of the race.

title: INSIDE
description: Communications Failure

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Expects Investment Loss
description: The Irish pharmaceuticals maker Elan, already dealing with accounting concerns and falling sales, may have to find more than $400 million to make up for a drop in investments, the company said. Elan, which is based in Dublin, said that the $840 million invested in its biotechnology funds, which it guaranteed to pay back by 2005, is now worth about $391 million. Product sales fell to $200 million in the third quarter from $375 million in the previous quarter, an Elan spokesman, Sunny Uberoi, said. Elan's muscle drug Zanaflex lost sales to generic drugs. The company will record third-quarter expenses of about $400 million related to the investments and will take a $142 million charge to pay off debt.

title: Golisano Proposes Free Tuition for Good Students
description: High school graduates with a B average or better would be guaranteed a spot in New York State's public colleges, tuition free, under a proposal to be unveiled today by Tom Golisano, the billionaire candidate of the Independence Party who is seeking a foothold in the governor's race.

title: Rare Feat for the Molinas
description: To the brothers, it's nothing special. They are just playing baseball, the game their father taught them in Puerto Rico.

title: Mystery of bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Acclaims Romare Bearden as a Native Son
description: If Romare Bearden were alive today, he might not regard the show of his work at the Mint Museum of Art here as a return to his native city. After all, in his later life he liked to say that he ''never left Charlotte, except physically.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, DR. MARTIN H.
description: BERMAN-Dr. Martin H. On September 30, 2002. Beloved husband of Hannah. Loving father of Judy and Paul Litner, and Larry Berman. Devoted grandfather of Drs. Barry and Rori Stevens, Jeffrey and Amy Stevens, Alan, Lorin, Steven and Rachel Litner, and Jamie and Arthur Rubin. Adoring great-grandfather of Joshua and Carly Stevens, Zachary, Rebecca, William and Jordan Litner, and Harris Phillips, and loving uncle of Janey Weinreb, Barbara Harris, Alan Feierstein and Susan Tornheim. He was loved by all who knew him and will be deeply missed.

title: New Drugs Show Signs of Helping Vision Problem for Elderly
description: Experimental drugs show preliminary signs of improving eyesight in some elderly people who suffer from a disease that causes blindness, scientists said at a conference here today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: A Step Toward Sainthood
description: The Vatican office in charge of determining saintliness authenticated a miracle attributed to Mother Teresa of Calcutta, putting the nun on what promises to be a fast track to sainthood. If Pope John Paul II approves the decision, Mother Teresa, who died in 1997, could be beatified -- a prerequisite to being canonized -- as early as next year. The miracle was the healing of a stomach tumor in an Indian woman who had prayed to the nun. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Rivals Once So Similar Now Vie in a House Race
description: In their six shared years in the House of Representatives, Nancy L. Johnson and James H. Maloney have never been all that far apart on the issues.

title: More Football Hazards
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Bank Stake Sale Planned
description: Taiwan plans to sell half of its 60 percent stake in the Taiwan Cooperative Bank, valued at 35.6 billion Taiwan dollars ($1 billion), by the end of 2003 as it tries to refinance a record national debt and pare the budget deficit. The government will offer shares in the bank to bank employees and domestic investors, starting with an initial share sale by next June, William Tseng, the bank's president, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, SEYMOUR J.
description: SIEGEL-Seymour J. Dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and friend. Passed away on October 1, 2002. He will be greatly missed by all who knew him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESKIN, CLAIRE
description: DESKIN-Claire. The Board of Trustees and the entire Abraham Joshua Heschel School community extend our sincere condolences to our true friend and supporter, Michael Steinhardt on the loss of his mother, Claire Deskin, and to our Trustee, Judy Steinhardt, on the loss of her mother-inlaw. Michael and Judy's work continues to have an enormous impact on the education of current and future generations of Jewish children. We send our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Shira Nadich Levin, President Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVAS, LIBBY JOSELOFF
description: NEVAS-Libby Joseloff. Age 87, of Westport, CT., died on Monday, September 30 at Norwalk Hospital. Mrs. Nevas was born in Waterbury, CT., daughter of Louis and Anna Needle Joseloff. She actively served as a volunteer for many years for several organizations including the Norwalk Hospital and the Connecticut Braille Society. She was a devoted and loving wife to Leo, mother to JoAnn and Michael, Bernard and Terry, Marc and Linda. Grandmother to Daniel, Rebecca, Rachel, Isaac, Joshua, Benjamin, Michael, David and his wife, Jennifer. Dear friend to Debbie Stewart, and sister to Hugh Joseloff and Miriam Abrahamson.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: When the Chemistry Just Didn't Work
description: ''The Misfits'' (1961) should have been the movie of the decade. All that award-winning, box-office-magic talent on one set. But its three top-billed stars were at crossroads in their lives, in danger or headed for it. Marilyn Monroe's last film. She was 34 during production, two years away from her death of a drug overdose. It was Clark Gable's last film, too. He was 59 and died of a heart attack shortly after filming was completed. His fifth wife was pregnant with his first child. Montgomery Clift was 40, struggling to maintain his career, which had been derailed by a car accident in 1956 that marred his matinee-idol-perfect face. Despite his reputation for alcohol and drug abuse and general self-destructiveness, he was the picture of professionalism and gentlemanliness on the set. Clift lived until 1966.

title: A Rustic Italian Spot Where the Pizza Oven Winks
description: IT takes some concentration to walk north on Amsterdam Avenue from 72nd Street, counting places where you might secure a plate of food or, failing that, an icy beer. The tally is 74 by 86th Street, with a majority north of 79th Street.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Ducasse Branching Out

title: McDyess Is Lone Bright Spot For Undermanned Knicks
description: A collection of role players ran the court at the College of Charleston this morning. These were the New York Knicks. Were it not for the presence of one dynamic, high-rising power forward, the group would have been as forgettable as the team's 2001-2 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAUF, VIORECA O.
description: SCHAUF-Vioreca O., also known to her friends as Riki. Daughter of the late Milian and Mary Oversia. Beloved wife of the late Robert William Schauf. Devoted mother of Robert W., Jr. and Michael Schauf. Loving grandmother of Jessica and Michael Schauf Jr. Memorial service in the Asbury Methodist Church, Crestwood, Yonkers, Saturday, October 5 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers friends may contribute to New York State Talking Book and Braille Library, Cultural Education Center, Empire State Plaza, Albany, NY 12230-0001, 1-800-342-3688.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ELEANOR
description: GOLDBERG-Eleanor. The Board of Governors and membership of Edgewood Country Club record with deep sorrow the death of Mrs. Eleanor Goldberg, an esteemed member and extend to her beloved husband, Calvin and family its deepest sympathy. Kenneth Apfel, President Andrew Muhlstock, Secretary

title: North Korean Fans Draw Crowds of Their Own
description: In a form of hospitality perhaps unique to this country, South Koreans have been hired to turn out in support of visiting nations' teams at virtually every contest in the Asian Games here this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, WILBUR E. (BILL)
description: PETERSON-Wilbur E. (Bill). We, his friends and neighbors at Fire Island Pines, mourn the loss of our exceptional Bill. We extend our condolences to his family and to our fellow Board member, his loving friend Alan Brockman. Congregation B'nai Olam, Fire Island Pines

title: Randolph Once Again Draws Some Interest
description: It is an annual ritual for the Yankees' third base coach, Willie Randolph. The regular season ends, a managerial job opens and Randolph interviews for it. It is as predictable a part of his off-season as Thanksgiving dinner.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Referendum In Chechnya
description: The head of the pro-Moscow government in Chechnya, Akhman Kadyrov, said a referendum would be held next spring on a new constitution that reaffirms the republic's membership in the Russian Federation. In 1991 Chechnya declared independence, which was not recognized, and rebels have been fighting against the Russian government since 1994. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: OIL RESERVE PLANNED China, which buys half its oil imports from the Middle East, plans to build a $1.5 billion emergency oil reserve in case war or other emergencies disrupt supply, the head of the International Energy Agency said. China, the second-largest energy user after the United States, would store about 50 million barrels of crude oil, or 25 days' worth of net imports, Robert Priddle, executive director of the agency, said after meeting Chinese officials. China, which is not a member of the agency, imports about 30 percent of its oil. (Bloomberg News)

title: Work Wear That Says Peekaboo, You See Me
description: Who is this woman? And what is her job description? The questions have been heard a lot, in one form or another, during Milan's fashion week, as retailers and journalists try to divine what in the fashion business is called the direction for spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, DORIS
description: HARRISON-Doris. (Formerly of Teaneck, NJ). Beloved wife of the late Milton G. Devoted mother of Linda Wisniewski and Philip Harrison. Dear sister of Fritzi Poppel. Loving grandmother of Lisa, Nicole, Glenn, Rachel and great grandmother of Benjamin Milton. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ, Thursday, 1-800-378-1892.

title: Farm Workers in California Cheered by Mediation Law
description: After 15 years without a contract, Baudelio Aguayo said today, he and his fellow mushroom pickers here in the hot, flat farmland north of Los Angeles despaired of ever getting a fair shake from their bosses.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is a willingness to accept inspections that has not existed before.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGETT, CHARLES, HON.
description: MARGETT - Charles, Hon. October 2, 1997. In loving memory. Remembered always. Your family

title: Decent Education, Figured in Dollars
description: With little fanfare, an independent panel yesterday began tackling a question at once so seemingly simple and yet so politically charged that it has confounded the courts, stymied legislatures and spurred litigation in nearly every state.

title: Recipe: Grape Hull Pie
description: Time: 1 hour 15 minutes

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clerical Jobs at Center Of West Coast Port Dispute

title: ISIS TO MANUFACTURE EXPERIMENTAL LUNG CANCER DRUG
description: Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. will manufacture an experimental lung-cancer treatment for Eli Lilly & Company in an agreement worth as much as $120 million, the companies said yesterday. Lilly will lend $21 million to Isis for a new plant to make the medicine, Isis said. Lilly will market the drug, called Affinitac, and plans to take over production after three years, Isis said. The value of the latest deal depends on Affinitac's meeting certain development goals, including getting federal approval for sale. The drug is in the last of three stages of required testing in humans.

title: Both Sides Say Protecting Voting Rights Is the Issue
description: The court battle will not begin until Wednesday. But there were dueling legal briefings around the state today as Republicans and Democrats tried to win an edge in the public debate over the Democrats' move to place a new candidate on the ballot to replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who ended his re-election bid on Monday.

title: 2 Outside Ties Cut by Chief Of Citigroup
description: The chief executive of Citigroup, Sanford I. Weill, said yesterday that he would resign from the boards of AT&T and United Technolgies, whose chief executives sit on the board of Citigroup.

title: Blair, at Party Conference, Reaffirms Support for U.S.
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair today confronted doubters in his Labor Party with his case for threatening to use force against Saddam Hussein and with his belief in steadfast alliance with America.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: No Charges In Boating Death
description: District Attorney Richard A. Brown said yesterday he would not file criminal charges against a teenager whose boat struck another on Little Neck Bay, killing two people. Robert Arnold, 18, had initially been charged with operating his boat while intoxicated after the July 11 collision, but that charge was soon dropped when a court-ordered blood-alcohol test showed he was legally sober. Mr. Brown said yesterday that an investigation by his staff found ''the evidence is legally insufficient to sustain the filing of criminal charges.'' Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: The Iraq Debate: Time of Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Salmon Shakes an Unwanted Tag in a Comeback Season
description: Tim Salmon has the longest tenure of any active Anaheim Angel  10 years and 45 days. Turns at Shawshank prison have seemed shorter than the fate of donning a halo on your hat, as Salmon has for his hitch during the Angels' mostly lean stay in the American League West.

title: Even After Poor Start, Jets Try to Be Optimistic
description: Jets General Manager Terry Bradway was unusually upbeat yesterday for a man whose team was 1-3 and whose star running back said the ship was sinking.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an effort by senators to revise a resolution supporting President Bush on Iraq misstated the rank of Richard G. Lugar of Indiana on the Foreign Relations Committee. Mr. Lugar, who joined Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware in proposing compromise language, is a senior member. (The ranking Republican is Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina.)

title: Security Bill Standoff In Senate Is Enduring
description: Senate Democratic leaders vowed to approve a Homeland Security Department even if means staying in session for weeks. But with no sign of a breakthrough in a partisan dispute over Civil Service protections, the prospect for passage by year's end appeared dim.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Verizon Expects To Meet 2002 Forecasts
description: Verizon Communications, the nation's largest local telephone company, said it expected to meet a forecast to earn $3.05 to $3.09 a share in 2002. The company also expects to have debt of $56 billion to $57 billion at the end of the year, down about $8 billion from the end of 2001, when it was $64.3 billion, according to a statement. Verizon shares rose $2.14, or 7.8 percent, to $29.58.

title: When the Frost Is on the Apple, And the Ice Wine Is From Quebec
description: Canada is the world's largest producer of ice wine. It figures. These sweet wines are made from grapes that are not picked until the dead of winter, after they freeze on the vines.

title: She's One Tough Woman, But Weak-Kneed in Love
