description: Kelly Price is an R&B singer with an extraordinarily powerful voice; her songs sound like stern warnings to men, letting them know that she will not tolerate waywardness. But most of her lyrics give the opposite impression: despite her commanding voice, she often finds herself begging for love -- wondering where it went and hoping it will return.

title: Giambi Right at Home In Crucible of Playoffs
description: It was all very familiar to Jason Giambi, the painful memories flooding back as he watched the Yankees' late-inning rally under a perfect October sky. Games that seem won disappear into this kind of night in the Bronx, and it was all so eerily similar that he could not have been blamed if he didn't realize that he was on the other side of it now.

title: Slow September Sales Lead to New Auto Incentives
description: The robust pace of auto sales slowed in September, causing a fresh round of big incentives from Ford and General Motors and debate from Wall Street about the industry's outlook.

title: Israeli Troops Close to Arafat Headquarters
description: Israeli forces took up positions in buildings near Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah today, two days after they complied with American demands and lifted a 10-day siege there.

title: GOODYEAR'S PRESIDENT TO BECOME CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's president and chief operating officer, Robert J. Keegan, will assume the added duties of chief executive on Jan. 1. The present chief executive, Samir G. Gibara, 63, will remain chairman, said Keith Price, a company spokesman. Goodyear said it also formed an executive committee of the board, which Mr. Gibara will lead. Mr. Keegan, 55, will be responsible for running a company hurt this year by product shortages and competitive pricing from rivals. Mr. Gibara, chief executive since 1996, will advise the company on strategy and other matters, Goodyear said.

title: The Iraq Debate: Time of Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: POWELL SAYS U.N. OUGHT TO HOLD UP IRAQ INSPECTIONS
description: Hours after Iraq agreed with United Nations officials that weapons inspectors could return in two weeks, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said tonight that any search of Saddam Hussein's arsenals should be delayed until the Security Council approves a ''new, strong, tough resolution'' setting terms.

title: Yuzhno-Kurilsk Journal; Between Russia and Japan, a Pacific Tug of War
description: Listing hulks of fishing boats rust in harbor waters here. On the potholed road to town, a crow perches on a car carcass. In the main square, weeds grow waist high through cracks in concrete. The town hall sits abandoned after a 1994 earthquake, its windows broken long ago by boys with rocks.

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Driver Charged In Collision That Hurt Girl
description: A Hasidic driver whose car struck and critically injured a 3-year-old black girl in Brooklyn in August surrendered yesterday to face misdemeanor criminal charges. The accident, resembling one that led to disturbances in Crown Heights 11 years ago, prompted several small protests. The driver, Solomon Stern, 42, was charged yesterday with third-degree assault, reckless driving and speeding in the Aug. 20 incident. If convicted, he could face up to a year in jail for each of the charges, brought after an investigation by the Brooklyn district attorney's office. Mr. Stern's car struck the child, Tiamani Gittens, as she crossed Lincoln Place in Prospect Heights. Mr. Stern's lawyer, Richard A. Finkel, said his client remained distressed about the girl and was pleased that she is recovering. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: DEMOCRATS SELECT LAUTENBERG TO RUN IN TORRICELLI SPOT
description: Former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg agreed late today to have his name placed on the ballot, ending a two-day search for a Democratic candidate to replace Robert G. Torricelli in the race for New Jersey's United States Senate seat.

title: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF M&F SHAREHOLDERS' SUIT
description: M&F Worldwide Inc. won a judge's approval to settle a lawsuit and cancel the company's $128 million purchase of the billionaire Ronald O. Perelman's stake in the movie-camera maker Panavision Inc. M&F, a licorice processor, and Mr. Perelman, the company's controlling director, were sued in Delaware Chancery Court in 2000 by shareholders who claimed the financier was selling his 83 percent stake in Panavision to get rid of an underperforming investment. After a two-part trial, interrupted by a settlement offer rejected by a judge, Mr. Perelman agreed in July to take back his Panavision shares and return the cash and stock, which was the basis for the court-approved settlement yesterday.

title: Randolph Is Once Again Drawing Some Interest
description: It is an annual ritual for the Yankees' third-base coach, Willie Randolph. The regular season ends, a managerial job opens and Randolph interviews for it. It is as predictable a part of his off-season as Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Is Big Brother Coming, or Is He Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Prefers to Bat Without Music Blaring
description: When Bernie Williams sauntered to the plate in the first inning against Anaheim last night, there were no manufactured sounds at Yankee Stadium. The same was true every other time he batted. Williams does not have a trademark song played as he digs into the batter's box and there are no canned sounds played during his at-bats. Williams wants silence, absolute silence, a rarity in this world of ear-numbing ballparks and noise-enticing scoreboards.

title: 2 Agencies Say Silence Prevented Pair's Tracking
description: The Transportation Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service told Congress today that they might have been able to track down two of the Sept. 11 hijackers before the terrorist attacks if their agencies had received intelligence information that was being shared elsewhere in the government.

title: Sleek Candles Unafraid Of Heights
description: Black steel votive candleholders that clamp onto the tables make an arresting light motif at L'Impero, the new Italian restaurant at 45 Tudor City Place (42nd Street). Vicente Wolf, the designer and a partner in the restaurant, devised them to reflect light into the mirrors and onto the slick white ceiling. The effect is candlelight without glare. He likes the holders so much that he is selling them in his shop, VW Home, 339 West 39th Street. They are 30 inches for $140 and 36 inches for $155.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHILEN, RONALD
description: SHILEN-Ronald. Died October 2, 1999. Husband of Lucy. Father of Mark. Grandfather of Alex. You are always in our memory.

title: Sticking to the Plan Is Costly
description: And Troy Percival still hasn't come out of the Anaheim bullpen.

title: Tone It Down a Notch
description: It's hard to believe that just a year ago, in the wake of 9/11, the French newspaper Le Monde carried the headline ''We are all Americans now.'' What a difference a year makes. Today, I figured, that headline would probably read: ''We are all anti-Americans now.'' So I called Alain Frachon, the senior editor of Le Monde, and asked him how his paper was viewing America today. I was close. He said: ''The same columnist who wrote that piece a year ago on 9/11 wrote another one this year on the first anniversary. This year, though, his headline was: 'We are all still Americans -- but not every day now.' ''

title: Foster's Beer Is Up for Review
description: The Miller Brewing division of SABMiller said yesterday that it had placed in review the assignment to create campaigns for Foster's beer, which has been handled for two years by the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group . Spending last year on the imported brand, which Miller distributes in the United States, was estimated at almost $14 million.

title: Iraq Agrees to Inspections of Some Sites
description: VIENNA, Oct. 1  Iraq said today that it was planning for the arrival of United Nations weapons inspectors in two weeks, promising them access to its most important sites.

title: Rogers Pleased to Land Among Old Teammates
description: Rodney Rogers was definitely not in Boston anymore, or Phoenix for that matter.

title: Wanted: Someone To Manage The Mets
description: Less than an hour after Bobby Valentine was dismissed as the Mets' manager yesterday, Buck Showalter was feeling extremely awkward discussing the possibility of being a candidate to replace him.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Aegis Group, London, acquired Inner Strategic Research, Madrid, a market research company, which will become part of the Synovate division of Aegis. Aegis is paying $4.7 million for Inner Strategic, which has revenue of $8.9 million, plus an additional amount payable over the next three years depending on the company's future performance.

title: Bylines Are Withheld In Protest by Journalists
description: Most reporters at The Washington Post withheld their names from articles the paper published yesterday as a labor protest.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Fighting West Nile
description: In an effort to contain the spread of West Nile virus, the House passed legislation that would provide $100 million for grants to develop mosquito-control programs. The measure, passed by a voice vote, would mainly be used in areas with high rates of mosquito-borne diseases. West Nile virus can be spread through mosquito bites. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says about 2,200 people in the nation have been infected with the virus this year. More than 100 people have died, officials said. The House would still have to approve money for the program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANZOSH, JOHN F.
description: TANZOSH-John F. On September 30, 2002. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Yurasits). Devoted father of Margaret, Barbara and John. Cherished grandfather of Paul, Michael, Kaitlin, Kevin, Kara, Eliza, Matthew, and Nicholas. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave., (at 20th St.), NYC, Wednesday 7:00-9:00 PM and Thursday 2:00-5:00 and 7:009:00 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 9:45 AM at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Astoria, NY. Interment, St. Charles Cemetery.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Plan To Trade Foreign Stocks
description: The Indian government has drafted a plan to allow trading of non-Indian stocks on the country's exchanges in the form of depository receipts, the way many foreign shares are traded in the United States. To qualify, a company would have to be listed on an international exchange and have reported profits for five years. Initially, the plan is expected to attract listings mainly from overseas companies run by expatriate Indians. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNOWDON, EDWARD WOODRUFF
description: SNOWDON-Edward Woodruff. Age 91, died September 27, 2002 at his home in Manalapan, FL. with his family in attendance. Mr. Snowdon graduated from Western High School in Washington, D.C. in 1929 and from Wesleyan University in 1933. He was a Captain in the U.S. Army Signal Corps during World War II and participated in the D-Day invasion and the Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded the Bronze Star and two Croix de Guerre from France for his service in liberation. Mr. Snowdon worked for the Charles L. Wagner Opera Company and Young and Rubicam in New York City until his retirement in 1972, when he and his late wife Lee Hill Snowdon moved to Manalapan, FL. from their longtime residence in Plainfield, NJ. He is survived by two sons, Richard of Washington, D.C. and Ted of New York City; a daughter Margot of Wilson, WY; five grandchildren and one great grandson. A memorial service will be held at 10 AM on Friday, November 1, 2002 at Bethesda by the Sea Church in Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the Snowdon Fund at the Community Foundation for Palm Beach and Martin Counties, 700 South Dixie Hwy, West Palm Beach, FL. 33401. Babione - Stephenson Funeral Home, Lantana, FL.

title: Bloomberg's Style
description: To the Editor:

title: A Foreigner Even Where Her Roots Are Buried
description: Oni Faida Lampley covers a lot of ground, in several senses, in ''The Dark Kalamazoo,'' a one-woman show that is something like watching your in-laws' vacation videos. There are nice stories and engaging humorous and dramatic moments, but there is also a lot that is meaningful primarily to the storyteller.

title: U.S. Dominates as Quest For America's Cup Begins
description: American yachts dominated the opening day of racing in the Louis Vuitton Cup, the qualifying competition for the America's Cup, winning three of the four races.

title: Powell Says U.N. Ought to Hold Up Iraq Inspections
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  Hours after Iraq agreed with United Nations officials that weapons inspectors could return in two weeks, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said tonight that any search of Saddam Hussein's arsenals should be delayed until the Security Council approves a "new, strong, tough resolution" setting terms.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Jersey Transit's new Montclair Connection service misstated the names of the historic railroad lines it joins and misidentified the junction. They were the Montclair Branch (not the Boonton line) of the former Lackawanna and the Greenwood Lake Branch (not the Midtown Direct line) of the former Erie. They join immediately north of the Bay Street station in Montclair, not a few miles northwest.

title: In Astoria's Clubs, a Taste of Istria
description: FROM outside, the Istria Sport Club looks like scores of other faceless, bunkerlike buildings in Astoria, Queens. But as soon as you walk through the door and downstairs to the dining room, you realize you've passed through a doorway to Istria, a 1,500-square-mile arrowhead-shaped peninsula south of Trieste, Italy, jutting into the northeastern end of the Adriatic Sea.

title: Two Builders Are Indicted In Fatality At Work Site
description: Two construction company officials were indicted yesterday on charges of manslaughter, assault and reckless endangerment in connection with the collapse of an Upper East Side building that killed one man and seriously injured three others in May.

title: Dow Rises 346 As Investors Find Bargains
description: After finishing its worst quarter since the 1987 crash, the stock market shot sharply higher yesterday, despite a negative report on manufacturing and the closing of 29 West Coast ports because of a labor dispute.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Literary Lights

title: The New York Times N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: Based on games through Sept. 30.

title: Creamed Corn? Really?
description: CHINESE cooking has devised some combinations that to many American palates may seem more bizarre than stewed pigs' ears. The first to come to mind is mayonnaise in fancy stir-fried dishes and dumplings. Equally odd is the recipe here, stir-fried chicken with creamed corn.

title: Tragedy Haunts Film on Afghan Diaspora; Friends of a Murdered Filmmaker Struggle to Finish His Work
description: Sometimes it seems to Jawed Wassel's Afghan-American friends in New York that his ghost hovers over his unfinished film, ''FireDancer.'' As they struggle to complete the editing of ''FireDancer,'' about the efforts of Afghans to assimilate into American culture, they say they feel the presence of its murdered creator among them. When there's a sudden gust of wind, an electrical short -- it is as if Mr. Wassel were sitting there with them, as still and as calm as ever in the midst of chaos, said Vida Zaher-Khadem, the associate director. ''I don't think I've ever believed that he is dead,'' she added.

title: A Day After Firing, Valentine Is Philosophical
description: One day after he was fired as the Mets' manager, Bobby Valentine was not combative, fiery or flip. He accepted his dismissal by Mets owner Fred Wilpon as the inevitable result of a misbegotten, 75-86 season, the second consecutive one in which the Mets failed to make the playoffs.

title: Hamilton to Lay Off 250
description: Hamilton Sundstrand, a maker of aircraft equipment, will dismiss 250 workers and close two offices to save money amid a slump in travel demand.

title: Yankees' Depth in Pitching Is a Plus in the Postseason
description: For all of their bullpen success over the past six Octobers, the Yankees have never had two proven starting pitchers to use in crucial postseason situations. They do now, with Jeff Weaver and Orlando Hernandez.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES INC., Murray Hill, N.J., the largest maker of telephone equipment, sold its stakes in two Chinese optical fiber ventures to Corning Inc., Corning, N.Y., the world's largest supplier of optical fiber and cable, for $200 million in cash and stock, plus $25 million in cash if the businesses reach certain, undisclosed milestones.

title: Immigrant Families Are Courted To Revive Canada's Hinterland
description: Lidia Tschritter comes to the door barefoot to meet her nine children as they return home from school. Her hair is tied in a kerchief and she wears a homemade flower-print dress that reaches her ankles just as she did in her native Mennonite village in Kazakhstan.

title: The Insider's Insider, Getting It Out on the Web
description: THE midterm elections loom a scant five weeks away, so ABC's Mark Halperin, whose infatuation with politics kicks into irrepressibly high gear in election years, has the morning trip to work pared to a hectic science. Has to. Mr. Halperin, a Bethesda-born Beltway baby with a New York City address, exudes urgency right to the hard-wired roots of his anchorman-approved haircut. He is, after all, in television; punctuality doesn't just count, it's a moral imperative.

title: Study Gives States Low Marks In Making College Affordable
description: Most states are doing better at preparing students for higher education but are making little progress in helping young people to enroll in, afford or complete college, according to a new study by the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, ROSE
description: BLAU-Rose. We are saddened by the passing of the mother of Harvey Blau, a longtime friend and generous philanthropist. We extend to Harvey, his wife Arlene and the family our heartfelt condolences. David and Earle Mack

title: American Grapevines Set Cooks Buzzing
description: ONE recent afternoon, the chefs Dan Barber and Michael Anthony were painting purple hues in the kitchen in Blue Hill, their restaurant in Greenwich Village. Mr. Anthony spooned onto a plate an indigo sauce he had reduced from a quart of ripe Concord grapes plus shallots, ginger and lemon grass, creating a pool for four barely steamed red Maine shrimp.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday with an article about the battle for Iowa's Second Congressional District misattributed an advertisement supporting Representative Jim Leach, the Republican. The ad, showing a woman in front of a flag-draped front porch, was produced by by the League of Conservation Voters, not by the State Republican Party and the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: CALENDAR
description: Peruvian Fare

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: ELAN EXPECTS INVESTMENT LOSS The Irish pharmaceuticals maker Elan, already dealing with accounting concerns and falling sales, may have to find more than $400 million to make up for a drop in investments, the company said. Elan, which is based in Dublin, said that the $840 million invested in its biotechnology funds, which it guaranteed to pay back by 2005, is now worth about $391 million. Product sales fell to $200 million in the third quarter from $375 million in the previous quarter, an Elan spokesman, Sunny Uberoi, said. Elan's muscle drug Zanaflex lost sales to generic drugs. The company will record third-quarter expenses of about $400 million related to the investments and will take a $142 million charge to pay off debt. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIT, SOL
description: LEIT-Sol. Happy 75th. We missed you at Rachel's Bat Mitzvah. We love you. Bobbie & Family

title: Arthur A. Lord, 60, Journalist With NBC
description: Arthur Lord, a television journalist who covered world events for NBC News for more than three decades, died last Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. A resident of Los Angeles, he was 60.

title: Fines Rise, Eyes Roll (Trucks Don't)
description: On any weekday morning, Midtown Manhattan can bear a strong resemblance to a lawless Dodge City. Instead of tumbleweeds, there is loose trash. Instead of gunfighters and rustlers, there are bus-lane blockers and cold-hearted double-parkers. And instead of the sheriff, there is Violet Biggs, traffic enforcement agent, with a white hat on her head and a ballpoint pen holstered on her hip.

title: 'Bloody Sunday' In Londonderry
description: In the writer-director Paul Greengrass's magnetic and impassioned melodrama ''Bloody Sunday,'' the re-creation of the 1972 outbreak of violence during a pro-I.R.A. civil-rights march in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, two contrasting points of view are presented immediately.

title: Stewart Broker Aide Said to Be Near Plea
description: The assistant to Martha Stewart's stockbroker is expected to plead guilty to a federal misdemeanor charge today as part of an agreement in which the assistant, Douglas Faneuil, may testify against Ms. Stewart and others involved in her sale of ImClone Systems shares last year.

title: Is Big Brother Coming, or Is He Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Kennedy Takes Post As Fund-Raiser for Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein appointed Caroline Kennedy yesterday to serve as chief fund-raiser for the New York City schools, a new post that he hopes will increase donations from the private sector and strengthen partnerships between the business community and the vast, cash-strapped school system.

title: In South Africa, Leaders Face Blacks' Ire
description: The black protesters marched by the thousands today through the gritty heart of this mining city. They shouted angry slogans, waved fiery banners and, for a moment, it felt like the old days when blacks took to the streets to oppose the white apartheid government.

title: AT&T Selects A President; Fills Other Jobs
description: By this winter, none of the four top executives at AT&T will have been at the company for more than two years.

title: Seeing a Ruin as a Dialogue With the Imagination
description: IN RUINS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, RUTH
description: HALPERN - Ruth, 95. Mourned by her children Miriam and Jerry Lewis; Charles and Janel Halpern. Adored by her grandchildren, Wendy (and the late Lori) Lewis; Meredith and Arthur Halpern. Shiva 180 West End Av, NYC.

title: Mystery Effect In Biotech Drug Puts Its Maker On Defensive
description: As director of hematology at the Htel Dieu hospital here, Nicole Casadevall had seen such cases before. A patient in her 60's had developed pure red cell aplasia, in which the body's germ-fighting defenses go haywire and attack its own bone marrow, leaving her severely anemic and facing a lifetime of transfusions to survive.

title: Grumbles Grow Louder in Quiet Rural Britain
description: Glyn Pearman has nothing against city dwellers per se, despite their infuriating tendency to come out for the weekend and complain that the noise from his tractor is ruining their rural experience.

title: Slow Going on Stem Cells
description: When Nancy Reagan, the State of California and leading medical scientists all express frustration within days of each other over the slow pace of stem cell research, it seems clear that the compromise approach toward this controversial research fashioned by President Bush is not working. If the National Institutes of Health, which is striving diligently to make more cell lines available, does not find a way to expedite progress, Congress may need to step in with remedial legislation.

title: Stop Those Presses! Blonds, It Seems, Will Survive After All
description: Apparently it fell into the category ''too good to check.''

title: Law Won't Alter U.S. Stand On Jerusalem, Officials Say
description: The Bush administration said today that it would ignore as unconstitutional new Congressional dictates that would require the United States to acknowledge Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. That put the administration in the unusual position of disregarding part of a law that Mr. Bush signed on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESORO, GIULIANA
description: TESORO-Giuliana. Formerly of Dobbs Ferry, NY on September 29, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Victor. Loving and caring mother of Claudia Tesoro and her husband Rick Greenstein and Andrew Tesoro. Dear grandmother of Deborah and Victor. Devoted sister of Giorgio Cavaglieri. Funeral Wednesday 12:00 PM Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry.

title: Wiz Chain Picks The Wolf Group
description: Nobody Beats the Wiz in Bethpage, N.Y., the electronics chain owned by Cablevision Systems , has named the New York office of the Wolf Group to handle creative duties on its account, which had no recent agency of record. Spending was estimated at $30 million to $40 million.

title: Text: Biden-Luger Proposal
description: Draft Biden-Lugar joint resolution September 30, 2002

title: Satirizing the Hollywood Way of Art
description: This is a guess, but all the evidence points to the playwright Jonathan Marc Sherman's having been disillusioned in Hollywood. Once a precociously irreverent voice on the Off Broadway scene in New York -- his plays include ''Sophistry,'' ''Wonderful Time'' and the Young Playwrights Award-winning ''Women and Wallace'' -- Mr. Sherman hasn't been heard from in these parts for a while, so the appearance of a new play qualifies as theater news. Unfortunately, the best one can say about ''Evolution,'' which opened at 45 Bleecker Street on Monday, is that it's probably good he's come back after what seems to have been a dreadful experience on the West Coast.

title: An Early Start Suits DiPietro Just Fine
description: So many things could have distracted Rick DiPietro today -- the 11 a.m. opening face-off, 16,000 shrieking schoolchildren, the crease-crashing Devils, a bothersome rash of penalties by his undisciplined teammates.

title: Jordan of Dodgers Has Surgery on Knee
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 (AP)  Dodgers outfielder Brian Jordan underwent successful surgery on his left knee today and was expected to be fully recovered in time for spring training.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline yesterday about tensions between Ted Turner, AOL Time Warner's largest shareholder, and Stephen M. Case, the company's chairman, characterized the relationship between the men incorrectly, overstating their closeness and exceeding the facts of the article. As the article said, Mr. Turner was indeed an ally of Mr. Case in the past, but not his ''No. 1 Ally.''

title: Owners Object To Designation Of Skyscraper As a Landmark
description: No matter how you look at 150 East 42nd Street -- a scintillating, diamond-faceted, stainless-steel butte or the towering version of a pressed-tin ceiling from an old Third Avenue bar -- it would make for an unusual landmark.

title: With Few Port Jobs at Issue, Economic Stakes Are Vast
description: In the tense standoff that has shut 29 West Coast ports and threatens to undermine the nation's economy, employers and union officials agree that the heart of the dispute involves just a few hundred jobs.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: VATICAN: A STEP TOWARD SAINTHOOD The Vatican office in charge of determining saintliness authenticated a miracle attributed to Mother Teresa of Calcutta, putting the nun on what promises to be a fast track to sainthood. If Pope John Paul II approves the decision, Mother Teresa, who died in 1997, could be beatified  a prerequisite to being canonized  as early as next year. The miracle was the healing of a stomach tumor in an Indian woman who had prayed to the nun. Frank Bruni (NYT)

title: Walter Annenberg, 94, Dies; Philanthropist and Publisher
description: Walter H. Annenberg, the philanthropist, art collector and former ambassador to Britain who at one time presided over a vast communications empire that included TV Guide and The Philadelphia Inquirer, died yesterday in Wynnewood, Pa. He was 94 and had homes there and in Rancho Mirage, Calif.

title: U.S. Charges a Former Top Enron Executive With Fraud
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron , was charged in a criminal complaint today with defrauding shareholders through a secret agreement guaranteeing that Enron would shield his LJM partnership from losses.

title: Morgan Stanley Will Pay S.E.C. $500,000
description: Morgan Stanley has agreed to pay $500,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission accusations that the firm failed to properly supervise a Florida broker whose actions resulted in customer losses of $15 million.

title: Japan Gives New Accounts of Abductees in N. Korea
description: FUKUOKA, Japan, Oct. 2 — Japanese diplomats today provided the first detailed accounting of the deaths of eight of their country's nationals, who were kidnapped by North Korea beginning in the late 1970's, and revealed that another missing Japanese woman was living, married to an American military defector for two decades.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Superfund Money Announced
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced $61.2 million in federal money to help clean up Superfund sites across New Jersey. Christie Whitman, the E.P.A. administrator and former New Jersey governor, said the money would go toward cleaning up four new sites and continuing work at others. Work is expected to begin next spring at the Chemical Insecticide Corporation site in Edison. Administration critics, like Phil Clapp, president of the National Environmental Trust, said the administration was taking advantage of Senator Robert G. Torricelli's withdrawal from the Senate race. A spokesman for Ms. Whitman denied the charge.

title: Young Ravens Regroup and Show Promise
description: Eighteen rookies: nine of them draft choices, a startling eight undrafted free agents and one player who was on the Chicago Bears' roster last season but did not play. Thirteen starters from a year ago gone in salary-cap cuts. An unproven quarterback and a slapstick offense. Young, green, not very talented and not feared.

title: Louisiana Girds for Hurricane Lili
description: LAFAYETTE, La., Oct. 2  Hurricane Lili surged toward the Gulf Coast this evening, a powerful Category 4 storm that threatened to cause more damage than any hurricane in decades.

title: Scallops So Fresh They're Still Shaking Off Drops of the Atlantic
description: On the fish counter at Agata & Valentina on the Upper East Side, fresh sea scallops nudge one another as their amber shells gape and close. These are live scallops, cultivated in the Atlantic off Nova Scotia and shipped to market within a day of harvest by Groupe Pec-Nord. They are relatively small, with a snowy muscle about the size of a Nantucket Bay scallop. "They're only three to four years old compared to eight or more years for a big diver scallop," said Katrina Besner, right, a sales manager for Pec-Nord.

title: But pact falls short of U.S. demands as 8 Saddam palaces are off-limits : UN and Iraq strike deal on inspectors
description: WASHINGTON:  Representatives of the United Nations and of Iraq announced Tuesday that they had agreed on the return to Iraq of UN weapons inspectors, who would be granted full access to all sites  but not to eight presidential palaces and compounds. An advance party could arrive in Baghdad within two weeks.

title: House Passes Bill to Combat Internet Gambling in the U.S.
description: The House passed legislation yesterday that would prohibit Internet casinos from taking payments from Americans and would require banks to prevent the use of their credit cards for such gambling. The bill could also require Internet access providers to block entry to gambling Web sites.

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Changes Beginning to Appear At Schools Albany Took Over
description: The changes are already visible here at Roosevelt Junior-Senior High School, the troubled heart of the first school district to be taken over by New York State.

title: In Pennsylvania, Ex-Mayor Stands Trial in a 1969 Death
description: In a painful dredging of the past, Charlie Robertson, a popular beat cop who went on to become mayor of this blue-collar city, began his murder trial today, accused of inciting and giving ammunition to white vigilantes who killed a black woman during a 1969 race riot.

title: Tasting Report: A Little Fizz to Go With the Apple Aromas
description: Rancho Zabaco: $13

title: Corrections
description: A map on the front page of The Metro Section yesterday about a plan to ban turns from 10 Midtown streets on workdays misstated the direction of traffic on six streets in some copies. On 54th, 50th and 46th Streets, it flows east. On 53rd, 49th and 45th Streets, it flows west.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCABE, THOMAS B. III.
description: McCABE-Thomas B. III. Age 50, on September 30, Haverford, PA. Survived by his wife, Anne (nee Edwards); their twin daughters, Catherine and Christina; and their son, Thomas IV. Funeral services will be Saturday, October 5, at 11 A.M., at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, 625 Montgomery Avenue, Bryn Mawr, PA. Contributions may be made in Mr. McCabe's memory to the McCabe Emergency Scholarship Fund at the Haverford School, Haverford, PA 19041, or the Agnes Irwin School, Rosemont, PA 19010, or Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA. 03142. For information contact Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA.

title: Latest U.S.-Britain Draft Of Resolution in the U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from a draft resolution on Iraq written by the United States and Britain, as authenticated by diplomats with direct knowledge of the text. Unmovic is the acronym for the team of inspectors to search for chemical and biological weapons; I.A.E.A. are the initials of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations nuclear watchdog, whose inspectors scrutinize Iraq's nuclear weapons program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCKSTADER, AVERY D.
description: HOCKSTADER - Avery D. Age 26. On September 26, 2002. Daughter of Diane Deschamps Hockstader and the late Leonard A. Hockstader, sister of Lee Hockstader and Kalen Holliday. Gifts in Avery's memory may be made to The Spence School, 22 East 91st Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Military Recruiters at Yale Law
description: Yale University yesterday became the latest university to agree to let the military recruit law school students through its placement office. Until now, the law school provided military recruiters with information about its students and allowed the recruiters to interview on campus. But the recruiters were not included in the law school's regular interviewing program because the ''Don't ask, don't tell'' policy, which bars openly gay or bisexual people from the military, did not meet the school's nondiscrimination policy for recruiters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, HAROLD A.
description: MANDELBAUM-Harold A. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 6th, 3 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Legal Aid Society, Antioch College, or the charity of your choice.

title: Bush Appears to Soften Tone on Iraq Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  President Bush seemed to soften his tone today about military action against Iraq, saying he was open to compromises with Congress and the United Nations as long as both passed "tough" resolutions that did not tie his hands if Saddam Hussein refuses to disarm. But his spokesman said later that Mr. Bush was still determined to oust Mr. Hussein, and urged the Iraqi people to rise up against Mr. Hussein and exile or kill him.

title: Bush Appears To Soften Tone On Iraq Action
description: President Bush seemed to soften his tone today about military action against Iraq, saying he was open to compromises with Congress and the United Nations as long as both passed ''tough'' resolutions that did not tie his hands if Saddam Hussein refuses to disarm. But his spokesman said later that Mr. Bush was still determined to oust Mr. Hussein, and urged the Iraqi people to rise up against Mr. Hussein and exile or kill him.

title: Iraq Hopes Oil Sways Russians On Vote in U.N.
description: A deputy oil minister from Iraq will come to Moscow on Wednesday for a two-day lobbying effort with Russia, as it decides how to respond to the Bush administration's proposed resolution on Iraqi weapons.

title: Croat Leader Says Milosevic Made 'Rivers Of Blood'
description: Two men intimately involved in dismantling the Yugoslav state came face to face today in a confrontation that was notable as a milestone in international law, and as the first encounter of two Balkan leaders in a court examining the region's wartime atrocities.

title: Military Recruiters at Yale Law
description: Yale University yesterday became the latest university to agree to let the military recruit law school students through its placement office. Until now, the law school provided military recruiters with information about its students and allowed the recruiters to interview on campus. But the recruiters were not included in the law school's regular interviewing program because the "Don't ask, don't tell" policy, which bars openly gay or bisexual people from the military, did not meet the school's nondiscrimination policy for recruiters.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Dow Jones to Buy 2 Newspapers in Oregon
description: Dow Jones & Company's Ottaway Newspapers unit, the publisher of southern Oregon's Medford Mail Tribune, agreed to purchase two papers in that part of the state from Lee Enterprises.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN - Aaron. Gone five years. Sorely missed. Remembered with love. Ruth, children, grandchildre

title: Text: Remarks from President Bush and Congressional Leaders
description: Following is a transcript of remarks by President Bush and Congressional leaders at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. With Mr. Bush were Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the speaker of the House; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader; and Senators John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia; Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut; and John McCain, Republican of Arizona:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Executions Suspended
description: The government has suspended executions, giving Congress ''a reasonable time to finish its review of pending resolutions asking for the abolition of the death penalty,'' the spokesman for President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo said. The death penalty was abolished in 1987 but it was restored in 1993 after a series of so-called ''heinous crimes'' shocked the country; most of those currently sentenced to death have been convicted of rape. According to Amnesty International, the Philippines has one of the largest per-capita death-row populations -- 1,180 out of about 83 million people. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: Is Big Brother Coming, or Is He Here?
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Crossing Head Offers Workers $25 Million
description: Even as he denied personal wrongdoing in the demise of Global Crossing, the chairman, Gary Winnick, told a Congressional committee today that he would write a check for $25 million to cover part of the retirement money several thousand employees lost when the stock collapsed.

title: Recipe: Steamed Ruby Red Shrimp
description: Adapted from Blue Hill

title: An Ugly Duckling Cuts a Swath
description: EXPERIENCED cooks know it is rare to find a gadget that is truly useful in the kitchen. The equipment you reach for time and again is tried and true: great pots and knives.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nintendo Cuts Outlook
description: Nintendo, the world's second-largest video-game maker, cut its full-year profit outlook 11 percent, blaming a stronger-than-expected yen and weaker sales of video game consoles and hand-held players. Group net income will probably be 80 billion yen ($657 million) in the 12 months ending March 31, down from the 90 billion yen the company previously estimated. Full-year sales will probably be 600 billion yen, 6.3 percent short of earlier forecasts. Nintendo makes the GameCube console. Nintendo's market share in the United States will rise to about 30 percent in the year-end shopping season, up from about 20 percent now, Nintendo's president, Satoru Iwata, above, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINDER, JOAN GOODMAN
description: BLINDER-Joan Goodman. On September 30, 2002. Beloved wife of the Hon. Albert Blinder. Loving mother of Peter M. Steinhaus, Richard Z. Steinhaus, Jr. and stepmother of Adam Z. Blinder. Services private. Memorial services to be announced.

title: HealthSouth Names New Board Member
description: As some shareholders met yesterday to discuss concerns over the HealthSouth Corporation's board and the depressed share price, the company named a new director who will oversee efforts to improve its corporate governance.

title: Man in the News -- Frank Raleigh Lautenberg; A Known Quantity, Ready for One More Senate Run
description: Two years ago, as Frank Lautenberg was preparing to trade in his Senate seat for retirement, he was already expressing regret for his decision not to run for re-election after 18 years in Washington. ''It feels lousy,'' he said at the time. ''I'm going to miss this place.''

title: Foster's Beer Is Up for Review
description: The Miller Brewing division of SABMiller said yesterday that it had placed in review the assignment to create campaigns for Foster's beer, which has been handled for two years by the Chicago office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Spending last year on the imported brand, which Miller distributes in the United States, was estimated at almost $14 million.

title: Flaws Found in Medical Care Given to Nassau Jail's Inmates
description: A federal report has found that major flaws in the medical care given to inmates of the Nassau County jail violate 34 of 40 standards set by a consent decree with the United States Department of Justice.

title: Politicus : Portrait of Jospin in defeat:his wife's diary doesn't dish
description: PARIS:  Broad folk wisdom has it that the former French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, came through as a stiff on TV; that he sprinted from confronting issues like crime in the streets or France's strained relationship with its Arab immigrants, and that his barely suppressed anger and ready righteousness struck the French as too tense and hyper to consider living with for a five-year term as president.

title: Fewer Calories Than Ice Cream, But More Than You Think
description: REMEMBER the ''Seinfeld'' episode where Jerry and Elaine enjoyed the fat-free yogurt at Kramer's friend's store so much that they ate it for breakfast, lunch and dinner? They grow suspicious as their clothes become tighter and tighter, and have the fat-free yogurt tested. It turns out that Kramer's friend had been cheating: the yogurt was full of fat.

title: Prices for commercials already vary widely as the season, with 38 new series, is barely under way.
description: AS the fall season gets under way for the broadcast television networks, Madison Avenue is already separating the bargains from the overpriced merchandise -- and determining which new shows will be tossed out altogether.

title: Rangers to Revise Waiver List
description: After signing the journeyman forward Dixon Ward to a one-year deal today, the Rangers will revise their protected list for Friday's waiver draft. The veteran defensemen Sylvain Lefebvre and Dave Karpa will most likely be left unprotected because of their contracts. Lefebvre, who turns 35 this month, is scheduled to make $2.5 million; Karpa, 31, is scheduled to make $1.7 million.

title: Knicks' Thomas Is Ordered To Stay Away From Wife
description: Kurt Thomas, the Knicks' starting center, was arraigned on an assault charge today and ordered by a Connecticut Superior Court judge to stay away from his wife and their Greenwich home.

title: Japan's Executives Fear Economy Is Slipping Again
description: Japanese executives now say the country's fragile nine-month old recovery is losing what little momentum it had, according to an influential quarterly survey published by the Bank of Japan.

title: Scallops So Fresh They're Still Shaking Off Drops of the Atlantic
description: On the fish counter at Agata & Valentina on the Upper East Side, fresh sea scallops nudge one another as their amber shells gape and close. These are live scallops, cultivated in the Atlantic off Nova Scotia and shipped to market within a day of harvest by Groupe Pec-Nord. They are relatively small, with a snowy muscle about the size of a Nantucket Bay scallop. ''They're only three to four years old compared to eight or more years for a big diver scallop,'' said Katrina Besner, right, a sales manager for Pec-Nord.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, CAROLYN A.
description: BLUMBERG-Carolyn A. On September 30, 2002. Beloved wife for 69 years of Edward J., devoted mother of Nancy & Bob. Loving grandmother of Lori, Todd, Gary, Julie and Karen. Her beauty, grace, kindness and wise serenity lit up our lives. Services and entombment at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Friday 2:30 P.M. The family will receive friends at home Thursday and Friday from 5-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: Market Place; AOL's chairman takes a few moments to define his role and to calm jittery investors.
description: STEPHEN M. CASE, the chairman of AOL Time Warner, under fire from some directors and major shareholders over the disappointing performance of its AOL division, yesterday laid out his continuing contributions as the leader of its board and an adviser to its management.

title: Barring the Gate to a Great Director
description: It's a mystery what the Bush administration thought it was protecting us from when it denied a timely visa to Iran's leading film director, Abbas Kiarostami. Surely not international embarrassment. The idea that the United States government is incapable of distinguishing between a potential terrorist and a renowned 62-year-old filmmaker who has been here seven times before without incident is not flattering to America's intelligence capacities or its reputation for cultural literacy.

title: Fassel Ponders Changes to Jump-Start the Running Game
description: According to Jim Fassel, the Giants' resident philosopher on offense: ''You run the ball to control the game and you throw the ball for points.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Reinstates Election Result
description: A local court in the Siberian Krasnoyarsk region overturned a decision by the election commission there to annul last month's gubernatorial election. The annulment had infuriated authorities in Moscow and raised concerns about election legitimacy in Russia. The court ruling affirmed the victory of Aleksandr Khloponin, a former businessman. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Executive Selected
description: The board of France Tlcom appeared set to announce the appointment of Thierry Breton as chairman and chief executive. Mr. Breton, 47, who made a name for himself reviving the fortunes of Thomson Multimedia, would succeed Michel Bon, who stepped down last month as France Tlcom struggled with a cash squeeze. The French government, which owns 55 percent of France Tlcom, is expected to approve the appointment at a cabinet meeting this morning, before the board gathers. Investors welcomed the likelihood, driving France Tlcom's share price up more than 10 percent, to 7.65 euros, in European trading. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Accused Of Violating Export Rules
description: The Commerce Department has accused Sun Microsystems of violating export rules in selling computers to Egypt in 1998 and Hong Kong in 1997, the company said yesterday. Sun, which made the disclosure in an annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that it faced potential fines and restrictions of exports and that the government had told it to expect additional charges. But Sun said it would seek a settlement. Separately, Goldman, Sachs, the investment banking concern, yesterday cited flagging sales at Sun and reduced its estimates for how Sun would perform in the first quarter. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPIN, JAMES B.
description: CHAPIN - James B. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Queens Borough Public Library mourn the passing of a dear friend and colleague. He was a tireless advocate for literacy and strengthened Queens Library with his wisdom and leadership. He served as a library Trustee from 1980 until his death and was Board President in 1993 and 1994. He was also a valuable member of the Queens Library Foundation Board. He will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Diana and the Chapin family. George Stamatiades, President, Queens Library Board Gary E. Strong, Library Director Members of the Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: A thumbnail sketch yesterday with a picture grouping of possible candidates to replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the New Jersey ballot referred incorrectly in some copies to the departure of Bill Bradley from the Senate in 1997. He finished his last term and did not seek re-election. He did not resign.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Steep Rise In Layoffs
description: Layoffs increased more sharply in New York than in any other state in August, according to new data from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of New Yorkers left jobless by layoffs of 50 or more workers rose by 5,035 compared with the same month last year. In all, 11,213 New Yorkers lost their jobs in August because of large layoffs. The state was the third-hardest-hit in total workers laid off, after California, with 34,590 workers laid off, and Texas, with 11,660. While most layoffs occurred in manufacturing, the bureau said, there were also big reductions at temporary-help agencies and in transportation. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: For a No-Nonsense Wine, a Rich Fish Like Salmon Is the Right Sidekick
description: PINOT GRIS is not the kind of wine that seduces you with dense, mysterious aromas. It has long survived on a more tidy and thrifty character. It gives you the taut aroma of green apples without a hint of evasion. And as our panel found, it leaves little room for indecision. You either like its candidness or want nothing to do with it.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Jersey Transit's new Montclair Connection service misstated the names of the historic railroad lines it joins and misidentified the junction. They were the Montclair Branch (not the Boonton line) of the former Lackawanna and the Greenwood Lake Branch (not the Midtown Direct line) of the former Erie. They join immediately north of the Bay Street station in Montclair, not a few miles northwest.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fair Lawn: Firefighter Dies Responding To Blaze At Building
description: A firefighter died last night on the way to a blaze at the historic Radburn Building, the authorities said. Another firefighter was injured, said Sgt. Carmine Moscatello of the Fair Lawn police. The firefighter, whose name was not released, died of a heart attack while traveling to the fire in his own car, said Garfield Assistant Fire Chief Richard Rothfritz. The fire was reported just after 5 p.m. and was still burning at 11 p.m., Sergeant Moscatello said. Firefighters from eight other towns were helping fight the flames. The fire was believed to have started in a restaurant in the basement of the building, a block-long office complex, Sergeant Moscatello said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the transit agency's Hudson-Bergen Light Rail misstated the location of a future stop, the Vince Lombardi Park and Ride. It is in Ridgefield, not Ridgefield Park.

title: Let Nature Choose a Salmon
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day After Firing, Valentine Is Philosophical
description: One day after he was fired as the Mets' manager, Bobby Valentine was not combative, fiery or flip. He accepted his dismissal by Mets owner Fred Wilpon as the inevitable result of a misbegotten, 75-86 season, the second consecutive one in which the Mets failed to make the playoffs.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: SUN ACCUSED OF VIOLATING EXPORT RULES The Commerce Department has accused Sun Microsystems of violating export rules in selling computers to Egypt in 1998 and Hong Kong in 1997, the company said yesterday. Sun, which made the disclosure in an annual report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that it faced potential fines and restrictions of exports and that the government had told it to expect additional charges. But Sun said it would seek a settlement. Separately, Goldman, Sachs, the investment banking concern, yesterday cited flagging sales at Sun and reduced its estimates for how Sun would perform in the first quarter.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Reserve Planned
description: China, which buys half its oil imports from the Middle East, plans to build a $1.5 billion emergency oil reserve in case war or other emergencies disrupt supply, the head of the International Energy Agency said. China, the second-largest energy user after the United States, would store about 50 million barrels of crude oil, or 25 days' worth of net imports, Robert Priddle, executive director of the agency, said after meeting Chinese officials. China, which is not a member of the agency, imports about 30 percent of its oil.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: BOYS' KILLER SENTENCED

title: Miscellany
description: * The Advertising Council, New York, which coordinates public service campaigns on behalf of the advertising industry, reported that media companies donated more than $100 million in commercial time and ad space from Sept. 21, 2001, through Sept. 11, 2002, for public service announcements produced in response to the terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFF, JOAN PENNYWITT
description: HAFF-Joan Pennywitt, 78. Of Hillsborough, CA, passed away peacefully September 27, 2002 after a courageous battle with cancer. She was born on August 19, 1924 in Yonkers, NY to the late John Pennywitt and Rosmand Runyon Pennywitt. Joan was the beloved wife of Theodore L. Haff Jr. for 55 years. In addition to her husband, Joan is survived by their three sons and their wives, Theodore L. Half III & Joy, John P. Haff & Sally and William H. Haff & Shaunna. She was a loving grandmother to Brian P. Haff, Michael R. Haff, Rachel N. Haff, Cody L. Haff, Julia E. Haff, John F. Haff and Kersten V. Haff and great-grandmother to Kayla N. Haff and Brett P. Haff. In addition, she was the beloved sister of Mary Pennywitt Lester, her husband Maxwell, as well as a loving aunt to Tara Lester Raynolds and Luke Lester. A graduate of Smith College, Joan's life was filled with the enjoyment of music, poetry, tennis and the boundless love and caring for her family and friends. Services will be held in San Mateo, CA. Memorials to Mission Hospice, 151 West 20 Ave, San Mateo, CA. 94403.

title: Torricelli Adds to Volatility In Battle for Senate Control
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli's stunning decision to drop his re-election bid has added new volatility to the battle for control of the Senate, with eight races now considered too close to call and Democrats in a fierce struggle to hang on to their precarious one-seat majority.

title: Don't Fiddle With Nature
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, SIDNEY J.
description: RAUCH-Sidney J. On October 1, 2002. Professor Emeritus of Hofstra University. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Marvin. Dear brother of Jean Baum. Services Thursday, 11 A.M. ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschen baum'' Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Bklyn, N.Y.

title: Clinton Supports Push for New U.N. Resolution on Iraq
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 2  Former President Bill Clinton today threw his support behind President Bush's push for a strong new United Nations resolution for arms inspections in Iraq, but he warned his successor that pre-emptive military actions held unwanted dangers.

title: 'Underground' Means Digging for Pleasure
description: High on Fire is the sludgy resin from 30 years of super-hard-rock history transubstantiated into three skinny, long-haired men from Oakland with low-slung jeans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASVOLL, HAL
description: PASVOLL-Hal. Best friends for 47 years. New Year's Eve won't be the same without you. You will be missed. Betty and Steven

title: Japan and U.S.: Bubble, Bubble, Toil and Trouble
description: With the American economy still sputtering and the Federal Reserve divided over whether to cut interest rates again, foreboding comparisons between the United States and Japan are gaining a renewed currency.

title: McCall Tries To Make Best Of Bad Week In Campaign
description: H. Carl McCall did not summon so much as a note of his customary preacherly inflection yesterday, and his jokes were halfhearted as he unveiled his state budget reform plan at a breakfast forum at the Sheraton New York Hotel and Towers in Manhattan.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Janitors Strike
description: Thousands of janitors picketed outside area office buildings on the first full day of a strike for higher wages, full-time work and health benefits. Talks between the union, Local 254 of the Service Employees International Union, and a cleaning contractor broke down after only two hours. The union, which represents more than 10,000 janitors, is demanding that many of the workers' part-time shifts be converted to full-time jobs with health insurance. A spokesman for the Maintenance Contractors of New England said that the switch to full-time work would mean that thousands of janitors would lose their jobs as the work was consolidated. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Sticking to the Plan Is Costly
description: And Troy Percival still hasn't come out of the Anaheim bullpen.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stricter Graffiti Law Planned
description: Gifford Miller, speaker of the City Council, left, and Eric Gioia, chairman of the Oversight and Investigations Committee, plan to introduce legislation requiring retailers to post signs outlining a prohibition on selling minors spray paint and permanent markers, considered graffiti paraphernalia, and doubling the fines for repeat offenders to $1,000 from $500. The move comes after a Council investigation found that half of the 70 hardware stores surveyed in the city sold aerosol spray paint to minors, while six out of the seven art stores surveyed sold them broad-tipped indelible markers. ''Nothing makes a good neighborhood look bad like graffiti,'' Mr. Gioia said. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: The Iraq Debate: Time of Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: As Congressional Support Builds, Bush Warns Hussein
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  With members of Congress from both sides of the aisle starting to line up behind him on the possible use of military force against Iraq, President Bush warned President Saddam Hussein today that his "only choice" was to comply with United Nations disarmament resolutions.

title: Bush Tells Congress to Move Quickly on Terrorism Insurance
description: President Bush urged Congressional leaders today to resolve their differences by the end of the week and adopt legislation to protect the insurance industry from losses from future terrorist attacks.

title: Local Television Stations Become the New Arbiters of Political Fair Play
description: Television station managers in small communities across the nation are being forced this fall to adjudicate a barrage of demands from Democratic and Republican Party lawyers pressuring them to pull political advertisements in closely fought Congressional races -- or face the risk of a defamation suit.

title: A Literary Review at Bellevue? Believe It
description: ''Just tell me a story,'' Dr. Danielle Ofri admonishes her medical students and interns at morning rounds. To Dr. Ofri, an attending physician at Bellevue Hospital Center, a part-time writer and the editor in chief of the Bellevue Literary Review, every patient's history is a mystery story, a narrative that unfolds full of surprises, exposing the vulnerability at the human core.

title: The Iraq Debate: Time of Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ROBERT MALLORY
description: KLEIN-Robert Mallory, 78, of New York City and Elmore, VT, passed away October 1, 2002 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Statesman, diplomat, artist and author. He began his career as a professor of economics at Hanover College where he taught and married Priscilla Chapman, his beloved wife of 50 years. He then taught at Middlebury College, and in 1962 began a career of service with the Department of State and the USAID Program. In this capacity he lived and served in Korea, Viet Nam, Philippines, Guyana and Mauretania. After settling in Elmore in 1981, he became a well known painter creating a series of paintings of the Northeast Kingdom. While residing in New York, he painted urban scenes and unique collages mirroring his life. His work has been shown in Shelbourne and Stowe, VT, Boston, Washington, DC and New York City. He was commissioned to write ''An American Century-The History of Massanutten Military Academy,'' published 2001. He was a graduate of the Academy and sat on their board. He was a man of great integrity and of many talents who will be forever remembered. He is survived by his daughter, Christine Scherman and her son Jason, both of New York City, his son Kurt and his daughters, Allison, Catherine and Anne, all of Chicago, his twin brother Kurt and his wife Phyllis of Hay Springs, NE, and his nephews and nieces and many friends. Services will be held at the White-Fiess Funeral Home, Morrisville, VT. For further information: 802-888-2865

title: GAS MAKER AGREES TO BUY AMERICAN HOMECARE SUPPLY
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc., which makes specialty chemicals and industrial gases, agreed to buy American Homecare Supply for $165 million in cash to expand into the home health care market. The closely held American Homecare, which sells home respiratory products like oxygen, has about $110 million in annual sales, Air Products said. With the acquisition, Air Products will serve more than 275,000 patients in 14 countries, the company said. Air Products is based in Allentown, Pa. American Homecare will remain based in the Philadelphia suburb of Conshohocken, Pa.

title: Our Towns; Yogi Berra For Senate? Say It's So
description: THIS may not surprise you, but the talent scouts who spent two days scrambling to replace Robert Torricelli were not thinking creatively enough.

title: Danger in a Fairy Tale Taken Seriously
description: Beware, gullible children of all ages, of the beautiful bedtime story, for it will only break your heart.

title: The Comforts of Home, And Fit for a Queen
description: WHEN my first book was being prepared for publication in the United States, I suggested that rather than proudly stamping ''British'' on the jacket, maybe it would be better to describe the thing as a ''European'' cookbook.

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about criticism of President Bush by Democratic congressmen who are visiting Iraq this week referred incorrectly to one of them, David E. Bonior. While he represents Michigan's 10th District, he is no longer the second-ranking Democrat in the House; he gave up the leadership post in January to devote more time to running for governor. (Nancy Pelosi of California took over the No. 2 job.)

title: National Briefing | West: Hawaii: Votes To Fill House Seat
description: The state is expected to hold two special elections to fill the vacancy left by the death on Saturday of Representative Patsy T. Mink. The first, to be held Nov. 30, will fill the remainder of Ms. Mink's term, which ends with the 107th Congress; the second would be held Jan. 4 to fill Ms. Mink's new term if she wins the Nov. 5 general election posthumously, as expected. Each election could cost roughly $2 million, state election officials said. Ms. Mink, who was 74, died on Saturday after a monthlong battle with pneumonia. Michele Kayal (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Too Hot to Handle

title: Between Alsace and Italy, the U.S. Pinot Gris
description: THE pinot noir grape gives us some of the world's finest red wines. True Burgundy lovers would drop the ''some of.''

title: Losing Memories But Gaining a Life
description: Amnesia, at least of the kind that tends to afflict characters in movies and books, is both a terrifying condition and, at the same time, an appealing one. The title character in Aki Kaurismaki's lovely new comic fable, ''The Man Without a Past,'' certainly does his share of suffering. A metal worker who arrives in a strange city by train, he is brutally mugged on a park bench and left for dead. His face shrouded in bandages, he stumbles out of the hospital and collapses on a river bank. When he comes to he has lost, in addition to his money and his shoes, his ability to recall anything about his previous life, including his name (the final credits identify him simply as ''M'').

title: Homers Don't Help Angels
description: When Troy Glaus crossed home plate for the second time last night, he fought off the idea that he might be the star of the first postseason game of his life.

title: The Speed-Reader
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chips With That Caviar?
description: In another sign that foreign investment is beginning to trickle into Russia, Frito-Lay will begin producing potato chips at a new factory south of Moscow tomorrow. The company has invested $60 million in the factory and in equipment and supplies for local potato farmers. Frito-Lay, which until now had imported chips from its plant in Poland, expects sales of $80 million in Russia this year, a 50 percent increase from last year. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

title: Taking Wrong Train to Game Doesn't Doom the Twins
description: The Minnesota Twins began the day in the manner of a man dancing with identical left feet.

title: Brazilian Oil Company Twists in Political Wind
description: Petrleo Brasileiro S.A., Brazil's biggest company, ought to be riding high on the recent run-up in world oil prices. But the growing likelihood that Brazil's presidential election will produce a left-wing government has put the company, still partly owned by the state, under a thick cloud of uncertainty, and investors have driven its stock down sharply.

description: To the Editor:

description: The authorities today charged a 27-year-old man on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder following the stabbing of the driver of a Greyhound bus traveling from Los Angeles on a rural stretch of Interstate 5.

description: Moments before Douglas R. Forrester made his first public comments about Senator Robert G. Torricelli's withdrawal from their race, a group of Democrats shouted to him Monday, ''What's your issue now, Doug?''

description: Following is the text of an address by President Bush in the Rose Garden of the White House Wednesday afternoon, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Powell's Point: The Need for a Much Stronger Resolution
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's remarks on Iraq, made at a State Department press briefing today. The full transcript is online at nytimes.com.

title: Brown and Princeton Restrict Early Applications
description: Two Ivy League universities, Princeton and Brown, have prohibited their early-decision applicants from applying to other institutions' early-action admissions programs this fall, defying the policies of the National Association for College Admissions Counseling.

title: Review/Fashion; Lolitas Dress for Homework
description: Sex used to be Versace's private domain, a little San Marino of sin and outlaw courage set down in the middle of a beige, beige country. But with so many others now crowding into Donatella Versace's turf, grabbing anything they can of the legacy of her late brother, Gianni, what else could she do except push back harder?

title: Can Hillary Upgrade?
description: Watching Robert Torricelli mist and mewl, as he was torn from the bosom of the Senate, gave me new pause over that old question: Are men biologically suited to hold political office and leadership positions?

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 14 Die As Kashmir Vote Continues
description: Militants opposed to state elections in Indian-ruled Kashmir killed at least seven civilians and seven paramilitary soldiers in separate attacks. Forty-one percent of the electorate turned out in the third phase of voting, slightly less than in the first two phases, Indian officials said. India and the United States have framed the elections in Kashmir, which is claimed by both India and Pakistan, as an essential step toward peace in South Asia. The voting ends next Tuesday. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Iraq Agrees to Inspections of Some Sites, But Draws Line at Surprise Visits to Palaces
description: Iraq said today that it was planning for the arrival of United Nations weapons inspectors in two weeks, promising them access to its most important sites.

title: A Political Tangle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, JEROME G.
description: SHAPIRO-Jerome G. Memoriam for Jerry May 12, 1924-October 2, 2001. Four seasons have passed without you but time has not healed our loss. We love and miss you still. Marjorie, Jeff and Terri, Jill, E. Noach and Monica, Norma and the grandchildren

title: It May Sound Like Faust, But the Body Is the Lure
description: The hero of ''The Man from Elysian Fields,'' directed by George Hickenlooper from a script by Philip Jayson Lasker, is a struggling novelist named Byron Tiller (Andy Garcia). In spite of appreciative reviews comparing the author to Hemingway, Byron's first book, ''Hitler's Child,'' quickly found its way to the remainder tables. His second, which has something to do with migrant farmworkers, is turned down by a snotty editor at Little, Brown, leaving Byron to wonder how he will support his adoring, almost pathologically devoted wife, Dena (Julianna Margulies), and their young son, Nathaniel Hawthorne Tiller.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets Go In Another Direction
description: TWO years ago, the Mets were playing the Yankees in the World Series. Now they are an organization that sacks a manager a few hours before the Yankees began their eighth straight postseason play in the usual manner.

title: Inquiries Underscore Fierceness of Competition to Lure Olympics
description: The Olympic fuss last week over possible rules violations by New York and San Francisco is only the latest indication that the race to become the United States candidate for the 2012 Summer Games has intensified.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL-Ike. 6/1/52-10/2/92. Ten years ago today You went away The pain is still intense Makes no sense Ten years ago today Always loving you, Mom

title: Here's Your Crumb Cake, New York, The Way It Really Should Be
description: Some households dote on brownies. I grew up eating crumb cake. For the crumbs more than the cake -- especially the fat nubbins scavenged from the box. But until Williams-Sonoma introduced New York-style crumb cake mix, I did not realize that crumb cake was a New York thing.

title: The Killing Fields
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: A crop of new desk chairs combine style and support.

title: Flower Arrangement in Paris
description: Now you can study with Christian Tortu, the top floral designer in Paris.

title: Vive L'Objet!
description: There was no gloom at this year's Maison et Objet home design show in Paris.

title: Iraqis Stall for Time, Playing Weak Hand Well
description: Iraq's decision to readmit United Nations inspectors has heightened differences between the United States and its allies and complicated the Bush administration's task of winning Security Council approval for a tough new resolution.

title: European Proposal Would Ease Merger Rules
description: The European Commission today proposed a law on takeovers that it hopes will lubricate the merger process in the 15-nation European Union.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition at the Whitney Museum by Helen Mirra misstated the title. As the picture caption said, the show is ''Declining Interval Lands,'' not ''Internal.'' The review also misstated Ms. Mirra's age and her exhibition history in New York. She is 31, not 32, and has shown her work several times in the city, not only once.

title: Campaign Season
description: Hispanic Frustration

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HON. RICHARD A.
description: GOLDBERG-Hon. Richard A. The Board of The City College Alumni Association is deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved past President, Judge Goldberg, Class of 1951. He rendered outstanding leadership and untiring devotion to the Alumni Association and CCNY. On November 14, Judge Goldberg was to have received the Townsend Harris Medal, our highest honor. ''In You, Honorable Richard A. Goldberg, Alma Mater Has Reason to Rejoice!'' We extend our heartfelt condolences to Lola, Evan, Glenn and the Goldberg family. Frank J. Sciame, President Donald K. Jordan, Exec VP

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Challenge To Police Search Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn has dismissed a claim by a drug courier who swallowed heroin that surgery to retrieve the drug amounted to an unconstitutional search and seizure. But he allowed part of the suit to advance. The courier, William Kanyi of Ghana, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport in 1998. In a civil suit filed in 1999, he said that federal agents had forced him to have an operation to remove bags of heroin he had swallowed. The judge, I. Leo Glasser, said Tuesday that the claim was barred because the government is immune from suits seeking damages based on alleged violations of the Constitution. The judge permitted some of Mr. Kanyi's claims against Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens, and a doctor, to proceed. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Berlin Ousts Opera Director
description: With Berlin's three opera houses struggling to survive on reduced subsidies from the hard-pressed city government, the German composer Udo Zimmermann was told this week that his seven-year contract as director of the Deutsche Oper will be terminated in July, five years earlier than expected.

title: In Search of Mice and Keys That Merit Kind Treatment
description: THOSE of us who work with computers touch few objects more often than a keyboard and mouse. Yet we treat these devices with little respect.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No noise, no smoking, what else is new.''

title: 2 Digital Cameras That May Surpass Film
description: REFLECTING a big leap in the technical capacity of digital cameras, Eastman Kodak and Canon have introduced digital cameras that both companies claim surpass film's ability to capture fine image details. Perhaps more surprising than the claims, however, is that the two new cameras rely on an image-sensing technology once thought suitable only for low-end applications like Webcams.

title: An Ex-Official Faces Charges In Enron Deals
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, was charged today with engaging in a vast scheme to use off-the-books partnerships to fraudulently disguise the company's financial performance while enriching himself with millions of dollars in Enron's cash.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankees a Tough Foe For Angels, or Mets
description: BOBBY VALENTINE held a 45-minute news conference yesterday, the day after he was dismissed after six-plus seasons as manager of the Mets. Most of us went in case he wanted to expand on comments he made Tuesday, when said he no longer wanted to be a yes man for all the changes that had been foisted on the team by Steve Phillips, the Mets' Teflon general manager. Phillips should have been tossed overboard with Valentine but escaped to face another season.

title: Giants Tinker With Offense By Limiting Number of Plays
description: The play list that Sean Payton carries through practices is handwritten across several pages, separated into sections for different game situations -- a group of plays for third down and short yardage, for instance, or for third-and-long. The papers are folded lengthwise, into halves, in Payton's hands, and he glances at them repeatedly.

title: From Wear for the Woman To Wares for Her Home
description: The crowds descending on Paris for the spring fashion shows this week are heading straight for the French designer Martin Margiela's all-white boutique, which opened this summer near the Palais-Royal. Mr. Margiela has branched out from up-to-the-minute women's wear to decorative objects like wine-bottle table lamps ($197) and vintage handbags covered in cotton (from $665). His minimalist snow globes (filled with nothing but fake snow, $19) are going to be the smart choice for Christmas. (Yes, it is that time already.) Decorative objects are available only in Martin Margiela shops in Paris, Brussels and Tokyo. A men's wear store will open up the street this month. Martin Margiela is at 25 bis, rue Montpensier; 011-33-1-40-15-07-55.

title: Flinging Billions to Acquire Assets That No One Else Would Touch
description: The criminal complaint filed today against Enron's former chief financial officer lays bare an ugly truth about what was once the country's seventh-largest corporation. During the years it was celebrated for its ingenuity, Enron was fundamentally mismanaged, entering into absurd business deals that could be hidden from the marketplace only by manipulations the government now says were crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ALEX Z.
