description: FRIEDMAN-Alex Z. Husband of Beverley. Father of Laurie and Paul Korngold. and Andrew. Pop to Adam and Evan Korngold. On September 29, 2002. Services 12 Noon, Friday, at Riverside Mount Vernon.

title: Hurricane Moves Inland From Low-Lying Louisiana Coast
description: ABBEVILLE, La., Oct. 3  Hurricane Lili slammed ashore in Louisiana today brandishing 100-mile-per-hour winds that ripped trees straight out of the ground, tore apart mobile homes and caused power failures that officials feared could last up to a week.

title: War, Murder and Suicide: A Year's Toll Is 1.6 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  Violence kills more than 1.6 million people each year, and suicide claims almost as many lives as war and homicide combined, according to a new report by the World Health Organization that experts say is the first comprehensive documentation of the problem of global violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLITZ, ZVI
description: KOLITZ-Zvi. Yeshiva University is deeply grieved by the passing of a cherished friend and honorary degree recipient, a highly respected scholar, author, film and theatrical producer, who taught Jewish studies at our undergraduate schools. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Mathilde; to his children Daliah, Elinoar, Sylvia, Irene, and Jonathan; brother, Chief Rabbi of Jerusalem Yitzhak Kolitz; sister, Rachel Margalioth, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: SEARS MOVES ACCOUNTING COSTS TO SECOND QUARTER
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it had shifted $191 million in costs related to an accounting change to the second quarter from the first after discussions with regulators. After the talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the shift was made and as a result, Sears increased first-quarter 2002 net income by $191 million, or 59 cents a share, and reduced second-quarter net income by the same amount. The change will not affect the earnings estimate for the year, said a spokeswoman, Peggy Palter. Sears first announced the cost in July, when it changed the way it accounted for the allowance of uncollectible credit-card accounts.

title: E-Mail Slips to the Bottom of City Hall's In Box
description: MOST mayors and city council members routinely receive e-mail from constituents. While they say the messages help them to understand public opinion better, they still give more weight to opinions expressed in meetings, letters and telephone calls, according to a study released yesterday by the National League of Cities and the Pew Internet and American Life Project.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telekom Jobs To Be Cut
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's biggest phone company, plans to cut 29,500 jobs at its fixed-line unit T-Com by 2005 to increase efficiency and reduce costs, the group said. Being the group's core profit division, T-Com was expected to finance the mobile business and to reduce the group's debt of more than 60 billion euros ($59.1 billion) but its earnings declined instead. The 29,500 job cuts include 7,200 that were part of a previously announced cost-cutting program. Deutsche Telekom said it planned to cut 14,000 jobs next year and another 8,500 the following year. The company lost a record $3.8 billion in the first half of this year, despite a pretax profit of $1.57 billion at T-Com. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDMAN, GERALD
description: LANDMAN-Gerald, 96. On Sunday, September 29. Devoted uncle, great-uncle, great-great uncle to Hans Hopf, the late Lore Schallinger and Werner Midas; their children and grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to Leo Baeck Institute Archives, 15 West 16 Street, New York, NY 10011.

title: Hartland Molson, Hockey Owner, 95, Dies
description: Hartland deM. Molson, a former owner of the Montreal Canadiens hockey team and an heir of one of Canada's oldest and most prominent business families, died on Saturday in Montreal. He was 95 and lived in Montreal.

title: Metro Matters; Looking Back, 2002 Was Just The Beginning
description: EVERYONE agrees that it all began nearly a decade ago, when a candidate in the Democratic primary for governor of New York looked at his tumble in the polls and pulled out of the race. That triggered a chain of events that brought us to where we are today, struggling with a chaotic system subject to manipulation and fraud.

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; A Delight for Each Of the Senses
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: A Megaship in Double Time
description: The Triumph cruise ship offers everything from dance lessons to midnight buffets on a five-night round trip from Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about logistical negotiations between Iraq and weapons inspectors from the United Nations and the International Atomic Energy Agency referred incorrectly to the status of a draft United Nations resolution intended to increase the inspectors' access. The resolution, which was being prepared by the United States and Britain, was not formally presented to the Security Council yesterday; as noted in other articles yesterday, the drafting is still in progress.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: BUDGET DEFICIT TO DEEPEN

title: Going to the Top for Help
description: AS the chairman of a high-priced, high-profile technological forecasting firm in Emeryville, Calif., Peter Schwartz charges corporate clients $2,000 an hour. He also receives as much as $75,000 for speeches to groups eager to tap his knowledge.

title: Forrester Rebuffs Reporters On Questions About Campaign
description: New Jersey Republican strategists have said repeatedly that their candidate for the Senate, Douglas R. Forrester, would welcome the chance to discuss issues vital to voters instead of dwelling on the ethical travails of Senator Robert G. Torricelli.

title: A Heretical Astronomer Rethinking His Revolution
description: When the Brooklyn Academy of Music started its Next Wave festival in 1983, it presented Philip Glass's ''Photographer'' as its inaugural offering. Mr. Glass's music was a huge draw by then -- particularly at the academy, which had staged his first two operas, ''Einstein on the Beach'' and ''Satyagraha'' -- and the furiousness of its detractors in the classical music mainstream gave it a hip patina. Mr. Glass has soldiered on, and although his detractors continue to denounce his work for its repetitiveness and easy consonance, his operas have found berths at many of the world's big houses, including the Met.

title: White Sits Out
description: Rondell White waited all year for his chance to play in the postseason. Through slumps and more slumps, he waited, then had his chance in Game 1 of the American League division series, responding with a home run to help the Yankees beat the Angels on Tuesday night. But White's window may have closed as quickly as it opened.

title: Knicks Do an About-Face: Sprewell Told to Stay Home
description: The Latrell Sprewell saga grew more curious today when the Knicks did an about-face concerning their star swingman's attendance at training camp. One day after Coach Don Chaney spoke about the importance of Sprewell's presence here despite his broken right hand, the club decided he should stay in New York.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Tuesday, about Linda LeRoy Janklow, emeritus chairwoman of Lincoln Center, included her erroneous recollection about Elizabeth Taylor's arrival with her husband, Mike Todd, at an Academy Award party. It was a party sometime in the 1950's -- not in 1960, when Ms. Taylor won her Oscar for ''Butterfield 8.'' (Mr. Todd died in 1958.) The article also misstated Ms. Janklow's title with ArtsConnection, the nonprofit education program. She is the founding chairwoman, not a founding partner.

title: Panel's Report Offers Details On 'Spinning' Of New Stocks
description: A Congressional committee is accusing the Goldman Sachs Group and two other investment banks of rewarding senior executives of their corporate clients with preferential allocations of new stocks, according to a committee document obtained yesterday.

title: New Details on Deaths of 8 Japanese Seized by North Korea
description: Japanese diplomats fresh from a visit to North Korea provided the first detailed accounting today of the deaths of eight of their compatriots kidnapped by the North Koreans beginning in the late 1970's.

title: Ellis Island's Database
description: To the Editor:

title: Randolph Meets With Tigers
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankees' third-base coach, spent three hours yesterday meeting with five representatives of the Detroit Tigers about their managerial vacancy.

title: Time and New Players Help the Cardinals Heal
description: In the weeks after Darryl Kile's death on June 22, nothing could color in the St. Louis Cardinals' emptiness, not the sound of a bat, not the thrill of a close game, not comfort food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, HARRIETTE K.
description: ASCH-Harriette K. Loving wife for 52 years of George. Treasured mother of Susan (Danial) Kessler, Douglas (Louise Wren-Jarvis) Asch, and Joseph (Christina) Asch. Doting Nana of Allison, Jared, Jacob, Geoffrey, and Mya. Dear sister of Morton Kurtz, Sylvia Herman and Harold Kurtz. Services Thursday, 12:30PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, (opposite the LIRR), Great Neck, N.Y.

title: 'Cost of One Bullet,' And Other Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: France and Germany Agree on Iraq
description: As Congress moved to accept a resolution giving President Bush latitude to strike Iraq if he concluded that United Nations diplomacy was stalled, the leaders of France and Germany said they opposed any effort to alter the conditions under which United Nations inspectors operate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PLACER DOME INC., Vancouver, British Columbia, a gold miner, said it extended its $887 million takeover bid for AurionGold Ltd., North Sydney, Australia, a gold miner, to Oct. 11 as it tried to win support from the company's shareholders.

title: Collegians Compete to Let the Sun Shine In
description: EQUAL parts architecture exhibition, science fair and Olympic event, the Solar Decathlon has engaged 14 college teams in a competition to build the ultimate solar home: well designed, energy efficient and capable of powering an American household with all the mainstream comforts.

title: IM Shortcuts in School
description: To the Editor:

title: Expedia Drops Northwest Air In Fee Dispute
description: Expedia, the biggest Internet travel agency, stopped selling tickets on Northwest Airlines at midnight Monday after contract negotiations between the companies broke down.

title: KPMG CONSULTING CHANGES ITS NAME TO BEARINGPOINT
description: KPMG Consulting Inc., which was spun off from the accounting firm KPMG L.L.P. in a $2 billion initial public offering in February 2001, has changed its name to BearingPoint Inc. to emphasize its independ ence. BearingPoint was selected from 550 names and suggests the company's ''commitment to set a clear direction for clients,'' the company said. The new name underscores the consulting and information-technology company's separation from KPMG's accounting functions, according to John Schneidawind, a BearingPoint spokesman. BearingPoint has said it expects to spend $20 million to $40 million in fiscal 2003 to change its name.

title: For Art: Destination, Queens; The Modern's Relocation Energizes Long Island City
description: For the last 20 years or so, Long Island City, Queens, has been on the verge of being ''discovered'' by the same combination of art and real estate that put SoHo and Williamsburg on the map.

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; Colorful Cutouts
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: PALM APPROVES REVERSE STOCK SPLIT Palm Inc. , the maker of hand-held computers and software, said yesterday that its board of directors approved a 1-for-20 reverse stock split. The move is intended to avoid a Nasdaq delisting by bolstering the company's share price. Palm, whose stock price has plummeted from $165 a share at its March 2000 initial public offering to 65 cents yesterday, has suffered from rollout problems, weak demand and stiff competition from Microsoft . Reverse splits reduce the number of shares outstanding, but do not alter the company's market value. The capitalization of Palm, which once exceeded that of Ford Motor , has buckled with the high-technology bubble. Palm, based in Milpitas, Calif., is now worth about $376 million and has reported losses in six of the last seven quarters. In August, Palm was removed from the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. "I am convinced that this decision, combined with continued strong execution by Palm's management team, will contribute to shareholder-value creation," said Eric A. Benhamou, Palm's chief executive.

title: Thousands Seek Safety as Hurricane Nears Gulf Coast
description: Highways across southern Louisiana and Texas were solid columns of steel today as more than half a million people grabbed their valuables and fled their homes, looking for higher, safer ground before Hurricane Lili hit.

title: 'This Weird House': Design School for the Nervy
description: HOMEOWNERS normally depend on contractor crews to work on their homes. Joseph Holtzman, the editor in chief of the idiosyncratic design magazine Nest, which has dwelled equally on Proust's bedroom and Farrah Fawcett memorabilia, took a different approach. He posted want ads at a dozen design schools.

title: Poet Laureate Stands By Words Against Israel and Won't Step Down
description: Amiri Baraka, the state's poet laureate, stood on the podium at a literary festival here today to say that he would not heed Gov. James E. McGreevey's demand that he step down for writing a poem that implied that Israel knew in advance about the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Microsoft Reports Progress In Averting Computer Crashes
description: Microsoft today released data about its Watson online error-reporting service, which the company says has had a significant impact on increasing the stability of its software.

title: U.S. Sees No Tie to Water Plan In Deaths of Fish in California
description: Federal officials said today that at least 20,000 chinook salmon and other fish died in the Klamath River in northern California in the last two weeks, but they were unwilling to attribute the deaths to water flows that had been diverted to farmers.

title: Throwing a Hissy Fit to Ease the Pain
description: Stephen Adly Guirgis would qualify as the poet laureate of the angry. He's interested in people who have a great deal to be angry about, and he has great empathy for them. Moreover, he makes anger as lyrical as it is likely to get.

title: Study Doubts Breast Self-Exams Cut Deaths
description: A large study in China on breast self-examination found no evidence that it prevented deaths from breast cancer.

title: Boston Market Chooses Arnold Worldwide
description: Boston Market, the restaurant chain owned by the McDonald's Corporation , said yesterday that it had selected Arnold Worldwide in Boston as its agency of record. Spending was estimated at $35 million.

title: Pataki Travels Around, Promising Money
description: No one pays much attention to this little village hard by the Hudson anymore. Once it produced all the bricks for Manhattan's brownstones. Now it is just a crumbling town on a shore of ruined piers and rusty fuel tanks, squeezed between a power plant and a quarry. The last light factory closed in 1995.

title: James John Peters, 57, Veterans Advocate
description: James John Peters, the executive director of the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association and a national voice to further research and treatment of spinal cord injuries, died Sept. 6 at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 57 and lived in Huntington Station, N.Y.

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Engineered for a Comfortable Sit
description: OH my aching back! That's the familiar refrain of office workers. A recent study by Steelcase, an office-furniture manufacturer, found that 26 percent of those surveyed missed work in the last year because of physical discomfort at the office. If you're a 9-to-5 sloucher, the best chair you can buy for your home office is one with the right lumbar support, height and armrest adjustments and backrest tilt.

title: Ads Aim at Shutting A-Plant
description: Environmentalists will start running a series of advertisements today to turn up the pressure on Gov. George E. Pataki to shut down the Indian Point nuclear power plant, which they call a terrorist target and a threat to millions of people.

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; Furnishing Foliage, for the Forest in the Home
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: The Bronx: Teacher Faces Rape Charges
description: A teacher at Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx has been charged with the statutory rape of a 16-year-old student, said Steven Reed, a spokesman for the Bronx district attorney's office, yesterday. The teacher, Mildred Colon, 34, of Broome Street in Manhattan, was arrested after the Archdiocese of New York notified the office that the child's parents had reported the crime, the authorities said. Ms. Colon has been charged with three counts of third-degree rape, which each carry a maximum sentence of four years in prison. The authorities said that she had sex with the teenager on April 5, June 8 and June 14 at the Capri Whitestone Motel on the Hutchinson River Parkway in the Bronx. The teacher was dismissed from the all-boys school on Tuesday after the student's family notified the school on Monday, said Joseph Zwilling, the spokesman for the archdiocese. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Nervousness from war talk contributes to the worst quarter in U.S. since 1987 : The global sell-off extends to Japan
description: While stock prices rebounded in most of the world, Japanese shares sank to a 19-year low Wednesday on concerns that the government's cleanup of bad loans could prompt the collapse of some listed companies.

title: Corrections
description: The introduction to an interview in Science Times on Tuesday with Steven M. Wise, a lawyer who specializes in animal rights, misstated his affiliation with Harvard Law School. He taught a course in animal rights law there in 2000; he is not now affiliated with Harvard.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: THE KOREAS: ENVOY READY FOR TALKS Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly said, "We've got a lot of work to do," as he prepared to meet North Korean officials today on the first mission to the country by a senior American official since the Clinton administration. Mr. Kelly, left, met senior South Korean officials in Seoul on Wednesday as hundreds of protesters battled police officers nearby in an unsuccessful effort to demonstrate against the presence of American troops in Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: MONTANA: DRUG TURNED CANDIDATE BLUE

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Soars To .198 In Playoffs
description: IT'S a start.

title: Keeping Windows XP From Dialing the Web
description: Q. I just got a computer with Windows XP installed on it, and every time I start it up, the modem automatically tries to dial up and connect to the Internet. How can I stop this?

title: Note to Democrats: Get a Defense Policy
description: Once again the Democratic Party finds itself on the defensive on defense. Congressional Democrats are responding to a Republican president's initiative, this time in Iraq. And we will continue to be on the defensive until we produce a cohesive foreign policy that spells out our plans for national security and homeland security and describes the circumstances under which American force can be used abroad.

title: Turkey, Mindful of Kurds, Fears Spillover if Change Washes Over Iraq
description: The traditionally rebellious Kurds of this hardscrabble hill town live hundreds of miles from the Iraq border, but tensions that bristle so obviously here could erupt into fresh violence against the Turkish government if the United States invades Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, DEBRA S.
description: NEWMAN-Debra S. tragically in St. Louis on October 1, 2002. Struck down in the prime of her life, Debra touched the lives of all she came in contact with. Born on June 13, 1980 to her proud and loving parents, Howard and Ann (Solomon) Newman. Debra graduated from Ethical Culture School in Riverdale, Hastings - on - Hudson High School, Cornell University, School of Industrial Relations and Washington University Law School, in St. Louis. Debra leaves behind her loving parents, loving grandfather Louis Solomon and dear aunt Sharon Solomon. Funeral Thursday, October 3, 2002, 1:00PM Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-onHudson, NY. Memorials can be made to the Debra S. Newman Memorial Fund in care of Temple Beth Shalom.

title: Beyond War's Hell, The Bedeviling Details
description: The military landscape of the new millennium is complex. Superpowers have learned that international stability is the best bet for maintaining order, peace and power. Now terrorists, maniacal rogue states and sadistic warlords are the new threat to freedom.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 5
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: New Devotees for the Furniture of Raphel
description: Raphal Raffel (1912-2000), left, known as Raphal, is the latest French interior designer to be rediscovered. His Paris shop (Josephine Baker was a customer) was an institution until it closed in 1983. Collectors are paying top dollar for the refined pieces he designed at midcentury from precious woods, leather and parchment. The Olivier Watelet Gallery (11, rue Bonaparte) will have a show from Raphal's own collection of his furniture from Oct. 10 to 26. He is the subject of ''Raphal,'' a book by Guy Bloch-Champfort (Amateur, text in French), with 300 photographs; this month at Archivia, the bookstore on the second floor at 1063 Madison Avenue (81st Street), for about $125; (212) 439-9194.

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Calling On Food Donors
description: Leaders in southern Africa gathered in the capital, Luanda, and called on foreign donors to help the region cope with severe food shortages. Erratic weather patterns, leading to severe drought and flooding, and government mismanagement have been blamed for the crisis. The United Nations says that about 14 million people are in need of emergency food in the region. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: France Tlcom Names a Chief
description: France Tlcom reshuffled its board today, naming Thierry Breton, the chairman of Thomson Multimedia, to run the company and find a way to lighten its crushing $70 billion debt load.

title: Sniper Hits a Teacher at Stuyvesant Town
description: A former city police officer who was dismissed for drug use opened fire with a rifle yesterday from the window of his Stuyvesant Town apartment, wounding a preschool teacher walking with children and transforming the densely populated complex into a ghost town as residents scurried for cover.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Former Radical Arraigned
description: Jamil Al-Amin, the former radical organizer known as H. Rap Brown in the 1960's, was arraigned in federal court in Montgomery on charges of shooting at federal marshals who were trying to arrest him in the killing of a deputy sheriff in Atlanta. Mr. Al-Amin is already serving life without parole for the killing of the deputy in 2000. Mr. Al-Amin could get 10 years in prison if convicted. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Lautenberg Celebrates His Return to Politics
description: After two years of self-imposed retirement, Frank R. Lautenberg made a triumphant return to public life this evening, mounting the stage of the Trenton War Memorial before an adoring throng of party stalwarts and union members who had come to celebrate his fledgling candidacy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Sells A Product
description: The Irish drug maker Elan will sell off Abelcet, an anti-fungal drug that it acquired in 2000, for $370 million as part of a plan to raise $1.5 billion before December 2003 by selling off noncore businesses. A manufacturing plant in Indiana and more than 150 employees will transfer to Enzon, the buyer, but Elan will retain European rights to Abelcet, and it will keep two related hospital products. The deal is subject to approval by Elan's shareholders, and is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Church Bill Fails
description: The House of Representatives defeated a bill that would have lifted a longstanding Internal Revenue Service rule that prohibits tax-exempt churches and houses of worship from endorsing political candidates or contributing money to their campaigns. The bill, introduced by Rep. Walter B. Jones Jr. of North Carolina, was defeated 239 to 178. It was supported by conservative Christian lobbying groups, but opposed by many religious denominations. Houses of worship may still support political causes, but not specific candidates. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; A Garden of Fabrics, A Graceful Cloak
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bond Sale Postponed
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd., controlled by Li Ka-shing, canceled a $1.45 billion bond sale. The move limits the financing options for Mr. Li, Asia's richest man, as he tries to sell mobile phone services linked to the Internet across Europe. Hutchison made the decision not to sell euro and sterling debt until markets stabilized after a severe drop in those bond markets, the finance director, Frank Sixt, said in a statement.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: TELEKOM JOBS TO BE CUT Deutsche Telekom , Europe's biggest phone company, plans to cut 29,500 jobs at its fixed-line unit T-Com by 2005 to increase efficiency and reduce costs, the group said. Being the group's core profit division, T-Com was expected to finance the mobile business and to reduce the group's debt of more than 60 billion euros ($59.1 billion) but its earnings declined instead. The 29,500 job cuts include 7,200 that were part of a previously announced cost-cutting program. Deutsche Telekom said it planned to cut 14,000 jobs next year and another 8,500 the following year. The company lost a record $3.8 billion in the first half of this year, despite a pretax profit of $1.57 billion at T-Com.

title: Back-to-Back Blasts Energize Angels
description: They came in perfect rhythm, one after the other, two shots into the October night that elevated a franchise, sent a jolt through its clubhouse and signaled the rebirth of a series.

title: Toughness on One Hand, Frankness on the Other
description: LEADERSHIP

title: On a Plain Vanilla Mouse, Some Decorative Child's Play
description: The DesignYourOwn mouse from KidzMouse, the same people who brought us MollyMouse and BenjiBee, is deceptively simple. It resembles the rest of the product's family -- small size, really big buttons -- but unlike the earlier models, this one is completely plain, an artist's blank slate.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Minister Named
description: President Eduardo Duhalde named a top aide, Anbal Fernandez, as minister of production, filling a post left vacant for months as Argentina endured the worst recession of its history. The nomination of Mr. Fernandez, the president's secretary, came as Argentina has started to show the first signs of economic recovery, posting a trade surplus of $10.9 billion from January to August, while maintaining a lid on inflation and keeping the peso more or less stable against the dollar. Mr. Duhalde's first minister to oversee the crippled industrial sector, Jos Ignacio de Mendiguren, resigned in April and the economy minister, Roberto Lavagna, took over the portfolio. The transitional government will hand over power to a new administration by May, after elections in March. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: In Real Life, Victory Margin Matters
description: Just because Steve Spurrier is in the National Football League and the computers used for the Bowl Championship Series no longer calculate margin of victory does not mean that college football teams have become more compassionate and less points-crazy against overmatched opponents.

title: Owners of Small Vacant Lots May See Huge Tax Increases
description: When Nassau County began its first property reassessment in decades this year, many residents feared that the tax bills on their homes would soar.

title: Sitting, None Too Prettily
description: A SHIPMENT of 1,050 Japanese tree peonies, offered as a gift of healing to New York after Sept. 11, is sitting on the dock at Long Beach, Calif., because of the shutdown of 29 West Coast ports in a dispute with the longshoremen's union.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Takeover Blocked
description: The Philippine tycoon John L. Gokongwei scrapped a $617 million purchase of the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company and a Manila developer from the First Pacific Company, stymied by a boardroom rebellion led by the chairman of First Pacific. The First Pacific executive, Manuel Pangilinan, left, won a four-month fight against Mr. Gokongwei, arguing that the purchase would be a conflict of interest since Mr. Gokongwei also controls Digital Telecommunications Philippines Inc., the nation's second-biggest land-line provider. First Pacific wanted to sell the long-distance company, which it acquired in 1998, to repay debt and pay a dividend for the first time since May 2001.

title: Scioscia Is Right On His Second Try
description: The Anaheim Angels gave their manager a second chance last night, and this time he -- and they -- got it right.

title: War, Murder and Suicide: A Year's Toll Is 1.6 Million
description: Violence kills more than 1.6 million people each year, and suicide claims almost as many lives as war and homicide combined, according to a new report by the World Health Organization that experts say is the first comprehensive documentation of the problem of global violence.

title: C.I.A. REJECTS CALL FOR IRAQ REPORT
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has refused to provide Congress a comprehensive report on its role in a possible American campaign against Iraq, setting off a bitter dispute between the agency and leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Congressional leaders said today.

title: Forbes ASAP Will Be Shut Down
description: The Forbes family, which owns Forbes magazine, announced today that they were closing Forbes ASAP, a magazine founded in 1992 to cover the digital economy.

title: Donor Passes Salmonella From His Pet Snake
description: An Oklahoma man who caught a salmonella infection from his pet snake passed the illness to two people through transfusions of his blood platelets, a doctor reported in a journal article published today. Both recipients became ill, and one died.

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; For a Clear Blue Glow
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: 'Les Miz' to Close in March As No. 2 in Broadway Shows
description: After 16 years of barricade storming and anthem humming, ''Les Misrables,'' the musical adaptation of the classic Victor Hugo novel about the French revolution, will close next March. By the time it shutters, it will be the second-longest-running production in Broadway history.

title: Don't Even Think About Turning Here
description: Getting across Midtown Manhattan can mean a commitment longer than some relationships. In its search to improve the quality of life for New Yorkers, the administration of Mayor Michael Bloomberg has come up with a well-intentioned but probably unworkable pilot plan to make auto and truck traffic flow quicker and safer.

title: McCall Tells Of 61 Letters Seeking Help
description: Seeking to put an end to a controversy that has dogged him for days, H. Carl McCall yesterday released 61 letters on official state stationery that included or mentioned other people's rsums, while maintaining that he had done nothing improper in writing them.

title: CITING BAD LOANS, COMERICA DECIDES TO REDUCE EARNINGS
description: Comerica Inc., a Michigan bank holding company, cut its second- and third-quarter earnings by $213 million because of bad loans and a decline in the value of its mutual fund unit. The company increased loan loss reserves by $207 million, before taxes, after a review by the Federal Reserve. The bank also lowered the value of its Munder Capital Management unit by $86 million because the firm, known for its Internet fund, is not worth what it paid. Borrowers in the retail, automotive and manufacturing industries are having more trouble paying their loans, the chief executive, Ralph Babb, said in a statement.

title: Telling Chile's Story, Even if Chile Has Little Interest
description: PARIS, Oct. 2  Five days after the Chilean army overthrew the elected Socialist government of President Salvador Allende Gossens on Sept. 11, 1973, Patricio Guzman was arrested by military intelligence officers. He was then interrogated in the national stadium in Santiago for two weeks before he was released and fled the country. He was lucky. While many Allende supporters were being jailed, tortured and killed, he escaped because he was "only" a documentary filmmaker.

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC pulled off a surprise TV ratings victory on Tuesday, with three new comedies in its lineup.
description: ABC, which has suffered through one of the longest runs of consistently bad ratings in recent television history, generated some buoyant news yesterday on two fronts.

title: It's All Done With Mirrors: A Canny Projector
description: When George Lucas was making the latest, entirely digital ''Star Wars'' film, he viewed rushes with projectors based on Texas Instruments' Digital Light Processing, or D.L.P., technology.

title: New Jersey Gets a Senate Race
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court made the right call yesterday when it ruled that the State Democratic Party could substitute Frank Lautenberg for the discredited Robert Torricelli as its candidate in November's election for the United States Senate. The ruling appears to clear the way for a vigorous if necessarily abbreviated campaign, thus giving New Jersey voters the choice they deserve.

title: Bush Unveils Upgrade of Amber Alert System
description: President Bush listened with tears in his eyes today to wrenching stories from the parents of missing or murdered children, then announced that the federal government would spend $10 million to improve the Amber Alert systems set up to notify the public about abducted youths.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Koreas: Envoy Ready For Talks
description: Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly said, ''We've got a lot of work to do,'' as he prepared to meet North Korean officials today on the first mission to the country by a senior American official since the Clinton administration. Mr. Kelly, left, met senior South Korean officials in Seoul on Wednesday as hundreds of protesters battled police officers nearby in an unsuccessful effort to demonstrate against the presence of American troops in Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: CHRYSLER EXPANDS INCENTIVES ON 2003 MODELS
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler is expanding the availability of some no-interest loans and lowering interest rates on other 2003 models as it adjusts its strategy of offering fewer sales incentives than General Motors and Ford Motor, its rivals in the United States. Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 automaker, will offer five-year no-interest loans on minivans and 2.9 percent 60-month loans on all 2003 cars that had carried 4.9 percent financing, said a spokesman, Marc Henretta. Cash rebates rose as high as $2,500 from $1,500, he said.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: DoCoMo To Write Off Losses
description: Japan's largest mobile phone company, NTT DoCoMo, said yesterday that it would write off 573 billion yen ($4.7 billion) in losses for the six months ended Sept. 30 to reflect the decline in value of its investments overseas. DoCoMo and its parent, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, have not calculated the impact of the write-offs on its earnings for the half-year or full year, which ends next March. DoCoMo will take a 339 billion yen loss on its share of AT&T Wireless Services and write down to zero its investment in KPN Mobile in the Netherlands. The company will also lower the valuation of its stake in Hutchison 3G UK Holdings, which is controlled by Hutchison Whampoa. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: In New Name, Museum Goes Contemporary
description: With a new building and new location in view, the American Craft Museum has decided to give itself a new name. Effective immediately, the institution is calling itself the Museum of Contemporary Arts and Design. This is the fourth time since its founding, in 1956, that it has tried to reinvent itself.

title: Hospital Mergers
description: To the Editor:

title: David vs. Goliath To a Rock Beat
description: It is not easy for a musician to fight the music business alone. Few have tried, and far fewer have succeeded. When Courtney Love filed a lawsuit against the Universal Music Group last year, threatening to expose record company contracts and accounting practices, it seemed as if some of the longtime grievances of musicians would finally have their day in court.

title: Silencing Bonds Is Not Enough
description: The first encounter between Tom Glavine and Barry Bonds took place when Bonds led off the second inning, and the fans at Turner Field responded with a mixture of boos and cheers. Glavine followed his normal approach and pitched him away, the first pitch called a strike and the second grounded meekly to second base. The crowd cheered and Glavine had notched his first big out in their eyes.

title: He Collides With Cars, and Wins
description: THE Bruce Springsteen of the American garage the motorcycle designer Jesse James -- stood inhaling a heady bouquet of oil, paint, gas and burning rubber floor mats from a disassembled S.U.V. ''Perfume for real men,'' he said.

title: Hamilton President Resigns Over Speech
description: The president of Hamilton College resigned on Tuesday, less than two weeks after admitting that he had failed to properly attribute the sources used in his Sept. 1 convocation speech to incoming freshmen.

title: Klein Is Said to Be Planning A Strategic Map for Change
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein is planning a top-to-bottom review of the New York City school system that will map strategies for improving curriculum and instruction, community involvement in the schools and even the system's structure, people who know details of the plan say.

title: Old Boys' Club Meets Its Match
description: Trifling with a woman's self-perception is never a good idea. But mocking a literary woman is truly unwise, as evidenced by 3,200 pages and nearly 12 pounds of anthology of Irish women's writing that has just been published here and in Ireland. That's surely a hellishly mighty way to whack the men who produced a three-volume anthology of Irish writing in 1991 with but a cursory nod to female authorship and traditions.

title: This Boy's Life, Turned Around by Books
description: To the Editor:

title: About Men, Choregraphed and Danced by Men
description: In the Company of Men, an annual showcase for male choreographers and male dancers directed by Charles Wright and produced by Betsy Hallerman, presented a gratifying program in the theater of the Riverside Church on Saturday night.

title: Study Doubts Breast Self-Exams Cut Deaths
description: Alarge study in China on breast self-examination found no evidence that it prevented deaths from breast cancer.

title: Iraq's Forgotten Majority
description: Last month, President Bush invoked the prospect of a democratic Iraq in his address to the United Nations General Assembly, while Secretary of State Colin Powell told Congress that he foresaw ''a government of Iraqis governing Iraqis in a democratic fashion.'' Yet the administration remains closest to Sunni Arabs, a minority group of Iraqis that has never shared power. This does not bode well for a stable post-Hussein Iraq.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Brandenburg Gate To Reopen
description: The Brandenburg Gate, the symbol of German division and reunification, will be reopened today after a major restoration project. Hidden behind scaffolding and protective covering for the past two years, the Berlin landmark had damage dating back to World War II repaired, and its sandstone exterior was cleaned. Today, the 12th anniversary of German reunification, dignitaries are to undo a giant zipper in the wrapping. Completed in 1791, the Brandenburg Gate is the only one of 18 original city gates still standing. On top of the structure is the Victory Quadria, the winged goddess of victory and a four-horse chariot, which was added in 1793. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 11 Accused Of Racketeering
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn filed racketeering charges yesterday against 11 people. The charges included extortion, illegal gambling and murder. Nine of those charged were members and associates of the Bonanno crime family, prosecutors said. One of those charged was Richard Cantarella, who prosecutors said is the family's acting underboss. The prosecutors said the murder charge involved the 1992 killing of a Bonanno family associate, Robert Perrino, who was a delivery superintendent at The New York Post. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A pop and jazz listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert by John Zorn's Masada String Trio with a screening of Aviva Slesin's film ''Secret Lives'' at the Center for Jewish History, in Manhattan at 15 West 16th Street, misstated the day. It is scheduled for Saturday, not tomorrow.

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; Flowers, Larger Than Life, to Light Up the Dark
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: Life in a Fish Tank Is Nothing New for Bloomberg
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a passion for tropical fish, which inspired Studios Architecture, designer of the new Paris offices of Bloomberg, the financial news company founded by the mayor. Tanks of coral and exotic aquatic creatures accent the surprising pinks (below), yellows and greens in the office. Plasma screens embedded in the floors, metal columns with news zippers and bright-colored furniture (bottom) give a 21st-century feel to the historic building near the Paris Opera. Not even the head of the company will get a private office: there are only glass partitions. The message is ''things are changing all the time, and you have to stay on top of them,'' said Sonia Jacobs, an architect from Studios Architecture. The firm, which has 200 architects working in Paris, London, San Francisco, Washington, New York, Los Angeles and Baltimore, also designed the Bloomberg offices in New York, Los Angeles and Brussels.

title: Shots Fired Outside U.N. Building
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 3  An armed man climbed a security fence at the United Nations today and fired several shots into the air, hitting the 18th and 20th floors, a United Nations spokeswoman said. No injuries were reported.

title: More Economic Turbulence
description: How unfortunate that Tuesday's 347-point bounce in the Dow Jones industrial average did not occur a day earlier. It might have made the third quarter slightly less painful for some investors. As it was, the quarter, which ended on Monday, was the worst for stocks since the 1987 crash, meaning that Americans will see significant declines in their retirement accounts when they receive their quarterly statements. Even with Tuesday's rebound, the Dow is still down 20 percent for the year, while the market as a whole, which resumed its losing ways yesterday, is closing in on its third consecutive year of declines. No wonder many investors are throwing in the towel.

title: 3 Fed Officials Say Rates Are Low Enough
description: Three Federal Reserve Bank presidents said today that interest rates were low enough to keep the economy expanding through a tepid recovery.

title: NEW JERSEY COURT LETS LAUTENBERG INTO SENATE RACE
description: New Jersey's Supreme Court unanimously ruled today that Democrats could replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli's name on this November's ballot, effectively clearing the way for former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg to enter the race.

title: INSIDE
description: Bosnian Serb Pleads Guilty

title: Pre-emptive Diplomatic Strike
description: Iraq's decision to readmit United Nations inspectors has complicated President Bush's effort to win Security Council approval for a tough resolution. News analysis, Page A16.

title: Jeter Fails, For a Change, In October
description: Give me the challenge. Give me the chance to be the hero. Give me the opportunity to win or lose the game for us. Derek Jeter lives by that mantra, constantly saying that he would rather be thrust into the most pressure-filled spot for the Yankees than be someone observing the drama from the dugout.

title: Devils Notice a Quiet Defenseman in Tverdovsky
description: Oleg Tverdovsky's N.H.L. career has best been described as quiet. For Anaheim, it was a bit too quiet for a defenseman whom the Ducks once picked No. 2 over all in the draft, and it became a big reason he landed in New Jersey in an off-season trade.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Government Criticizes Strike
description: Government officials assailed a national strike, which went into its second day, as futile and unproductive. Union leaders said 60 percent of employees stayed away from their jobs to protest against the government privatization policy and unemployment. Government officials said most employees ignored the strike. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: 2 Charged With Fraud in Missing Girl Case
description: Two caretakers for Rilya Wilson, the Miami girl who was missing for 15 months while in state custody before anyone noticed, were charged today with multiple counts of fraud for continuing to collect benefits for the child long after she vanished, according the Miami-Dade State Attorney's Office.

title: Man Accused of Shoe-Bomb Plot Says He Intends to Plead Guilty
description: The man accused of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives hidden in his shoes filed a motion today saying he intended to plead guilty to all the charges against him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERNIAK, IDA
description: CHERNIAK - Ida. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Arline and Sam Bleecker, Phyllis and Paul Landow, Steven and Stephanie Cherniak. Loving grandmother of Jamie and Andre, Lauren, Michael, Harlan and Spencer. Funeral services on Friday, 12 Noon, at Gutterman's Inc., 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: A Better War to Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Gibson Retrial Delayed
description: The retrial of former Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson on federal fraud and bribery charges was abruptly adjourned yesterday for two weeks. Lawyers for Mr. Gibson and his two co-defendants as well as prosecutors from the United States attorney's office would not comment on the reasons for the delay, which came on the day that jury selection was to begin. The previous trial, which lasted eight weeks, ended last December with a hung jury after eight days of deliberations. Mr. Gibson's engineering consulting firm was accused of using bribes to win a $50 million contract with the Irvington school district and then bilking the district of $1 million in illegal payments. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about two incumbent members of Congress from Connecticut who are now running against each other misstated the demographic change that caused the state to lose a seat through reapportionment. It was a slowing of population growth relative to other states, not a decline in population.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: KENYA: GENITAL CUTTING MAY HALT U.S. DEAL Somali Bantu families who rushed to put young women through ritual genital cutting before being resettled to the United States are likely to be excluded from the program, an American official said. About 12,000 Somali Bantu exiled in Kenya had been given priority for resettlement. But genital cutting, sometimes called female circumcision, is illegal in the United States, so many families hurried the procedure before leaving. (Reuters)

title: The Next Mets Manager? Form a Line, Take a Number
description: The Mets began life without Bobby Valentine yesterday, one day after they fired him as manager. Despite the team's problems, many of which were addressed by Valentine after he was fired, the vacancy is creating interest around baseball and at least two candidates have called the Mets' owner, Fred Wilpon, to express their interest in the job.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Captivate Network, Westford, Mass., reached agreements with five auto makers to advertise on the monitors that Captivate operates in elevators of office buildings. They are: the Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, Mich., for its Expedition sport utility vehicle; General Motors, Detroit, for its Hummer brand; Nissan North America, Gardena, Calif., for Infiniti; Toyota Motor Sales, Torrance, Calif., for Lexus; and the American Honda Motor Company, Torrance, for Acura. Terms were not disclosed.

title: On the Court, Thomas Does Fine
description: Kurt Thomas posted up Todd Lindeman, hit a turnaround jumper over the 7-footer's outstretched arms and jogged down the court shaking his head in he-can't-guard-me defiance. Making shots off the dribble and displaying proficiency down low, Thomas looked better than ever at this morning's practice.

title: A Good Result for Bill Gates, But in a Hopeless Contract
description: Somewhat oddly, the most famous player at the world championships in Montreal in August was not a famous player. He was Bill Gates, the founder of Microsoft. He played in the World Mixed Pairs with Sharon Osberg and scored well on the diagramed deal, although in a hopeless contract.

title: Jets Continue To Make Adjustments
description: Coach Herman Edwards, worn out from sleeping only about three hours a night for the last three weeks, announced more personnel changes today that were designed to give the Jets a jolt for what one player called a do-or-die game Sunday against the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: Fate Links 2 Democrats; Bad Blood Keeps Them Apart
description: It was a rivalry so bitter that it became the stuff of Washington lore: Frank R. Lautenberg and Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey senators who would not talk to each other.

title: Bad Users or Bad Design?
description: Last week, I shared some tales from my distant past as a personal trainer for first-time computer owners. In my view, a lot of the dumb user stories that circulate on the Web are, in fact, dumb design stories.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Output Down
description: For the second time in four weeks, the petroleum giant BP lowered its target for oil and gas output, blaming storms in the Gulf of Mexico. BP said the annual rise in production would be 4 percent rather than the 5.5 percent forecast in July. Over the last week, BP, Shell and other oil companies have evacuated workers from the gulf because of Tropical Storm Isidore. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: BUSH STRIKES DEAL FOR HOUSE BACKING ON ACTION IN IRAQ
description: President Bush reached an agreement today with House leaders on a proposal authorizing him to use force against Iraq, a deal that Democrats acknowledged cleared the way for approval of a joint Congressional resolution supporting action against Saddam Hussein.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Approves Reverse Stock Split
description: Palm Inc., the maker of hand-held computers and software, said yesterday that its board of directors had approved a 1-for-20 reverse stock split. The move is intended to avoid a Nasdaq delisting by bolstering the company's share price. Palm, whose stock price has plummeted from $165 a share at its March 2000 initial offering to 65 cents yesterday, has suffered from rollout problems, weak demand and stiff competition from Microsoft. Reverse splits reduce the number of shares outstanding but do not alter the company's market value. The capitalization of Palm, which once exceeded that of Ford Motor, has buckled with the collapsing high-technology bubble. Palm is now worth about $376 million and has reported losses in six of the last seven quarters. In August, Palm was removed from the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Artful Garden Dresses Anew For Autumn
description: WHEN Christopher Woods first came to Chanticleer 19 years ago, he tended a 31-acre country estate with tall tulip poplars and rolling lawns that had once been cut by a horse-drawn mower. His boss was Adolph Rosengarten Jr., then 80 and the grandson of George David Rosengarten, who had made his fortune on drugs -- first, in the 1820's, by making quinine and later adding opium, morphine, strychnine and codeine to his empire.

title: A Time for Debate and Reflection
description: With the White House and Capitol Hill approaching agreement on the language of a resolution authorizing the use of military force against Iraq, Congress is on the threshold of a solemn and rare occasion -- a debate over war and peace. Flag-waving sound bites with an eye to next month's hotly contested midterm elections will not be enough. There are too many crucial issues that require deeper examination than they have had so far. The debate should be a moment for the American public to take stock, perhaps the country's last real opportunity for measured deliberation.

title: Genetic Decoding May Bring Advances in Worldwide Fight Against Malaria
description: Scientists have decoded the genomes, or full DNA, of the main malaria parasite and the mosquito that spreads it, two major goals seen as likely to kick-start a new campaign against the resurgent disease. Deaths from malaria are thought to number about 2.7 million a year.

title: When Lightning Strikes
description: To the Editor:

title: Twin Towers Report
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; Serene Splash  Table
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: The Ruling: Allow Voters A Choice
description: Following are excerpts from the New Jersey Supreme Court decision yesterday on the Democratic request to substitute Frank R. Lautenberg for Robert G. Torricelli as its nominee for governor on the Nov. 5 ballot, as reported by The Associated Press. The full text is online at nytimes.com /metro.

title: Lagos Journal; Globalization of Beauty Makes Slimness Trendy
description: With no success, Nigeria had been sending contestants to the Miss World pageant for years. Winners of the Most Beautiful Girl in Nigeria went year after year to the Miss World competition, and year after year the beauty queens performed remarkably poorly.

title: Chavez Gives the A's a Fast Start
description: Eric Chavez, Oakland's slugging third baseman, seems to seethe beneath a pleasant demeanor when discussing one particular team participating in the American League playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, HAROLD A.
description: MANDELBAUM-Harold A. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 6th, 3 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Legal Aid Society, Antioch College, or the charity of your choice.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: GROUND ZERO CLEANING DEADLINE IS EXTENDED

title: From Humble Materials, a Burst of Power for Batteries
description: BATTERY development may have gotten a boost from an unexpected source. A research group at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has found that adding a pinch of a metal-containing compound to an inexpensive material greatly increases its conductivity.

title: Fly to Paris And Learn the French Art Of Flower Arrangement
description: Christian Tortu (above, right) has long been considered the top floral designer in Paris. Now you can study with Mr. Tortu and other couture florists like Stphane Chapelle and Fabienne Descamps at the new cole des Fleurs. The school's founder, Aude Zieseniss de Thuin, said that designers like Mr. Tortu, the school's creative director, are developing new techniques in flower arranging, which are influencing others around the world -- in the choice of flowers and in the style of bouquet. A two-hour course covers arrangements for all occasions, incuding intimate dinners and wedding receptions; window boxes with aromatic or medicinal plants; and unusual materials like branches or common wildflowers. You arrive empty-handed -- smocks, flowers and everything else are provided. You leave with an elegant bouquet made under the guidance of the stars of the floral world. ''Parisian florists have created the most important floral trends of the last 20 years,'' Ms. de Thuin said. ''I wanted to make their savoir-faire and creativity accessible to the public.'' Classes (starting at around $100) are in English, French and Japanese, held on Tuesdays and Thursdays -- when flowers arrive at the great Paris flower market, Rungis. L'cole des Fleurs, 7, rue Scheffer, 75116 Paris; 011-33-1-47-04-50-20; Fax: 011-33-1-47-04-50-21; www.ecoledesfleurs.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANGER, DAVID
description: GRANGER - David. The Trustees, Board of Regents and staff of The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine mourn the passing of David Granger, a former Trustee and Regent, and treasured member of the Cathedral family. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife and fellow Regent, Lee Granger, and to his entire family. The Rt. Rev. Mark S. Sisk, Chairman The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Kowalski, Dean Henry L. King, Esq., Pres.

title: Ex-Bosnia Serb Leader Enters Guilty Plea to The Hague
description: A Bosnian Serb leader today became the first high official to plead guilty of crimes against humanity and to express remorse publicly for the war and bloodshed in the Balkans.

title: Op-Art
Two Defensemen Left Unprotected
description: As expected, the Rangers did not protect two veteran defensemen -- Sylvain Lefebvre and Dave Karpa. Lefebvre, who turns 35 this month, is scheduled to earn $2.5 million this season; Karpa, 31, will earn $1.7 million. If Lefebvre is not claimed, he will open the season as one of the Rangers' regular defensemen. With a week to go until Wednesday's season-opener in Carolina, Karpa's status is much less clear.

title: Economic Scene; It's time for Bush to acknowledge that the economy is sick and offer a remedy.
description: IT is being said by some that President Bush has no economic policy. In fact, the administration does have one. But it is not working.

title: Industry Asks Bush to End Port Shutdown; Talks Are Set
description: Industry groups representing hundreds of businesses called on President Bush today to use his emergency powers to reopen 29 West Coast ports closed in a contract dispute, as the longshoremen's union and port operators agreed to meet with a mediator on Thursday.

title: Hotel Is Not Liable in Sex Attack, Jury Rules
description: A Manhattan civil court jury decided late Tuesday that the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel could not be held liable for the sexual assault of a professor who said that an intruder used an electronic key card to enter her hotel room and attack her seven years ago.

title: Shuttle Flight Rescheduled
description: The flight of the space shuttle Atlantis has been postponed until Monday because of the threat Hurricane Lili poses to the Johnson Space Center in Houston, the home of mission control for all human space flights, NASA officials said today.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: BRITISH BEEF IS BACK English roast beef has been allowed back on those French menus that will have it, thanks to the end of a six-year ban on imported meat from British cattle. France banned British beef in 1996 after an outbreak of mad cow disease in Britain and has resisted European Union calls to lift the embargo since 1999. France faced hefty fines if it did not lift the ban. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Nets Have Raised Expectations for Kittles
description: Kerry Kittles was the last player in the gym today, quietly working on his jump shot.

title: Boston Market Chooses Arnold Worldwide Shop
description: Boston Market, the restaurant chain owned by the McDonald's Corporation, said yesterday that it had selected Arnold Worldwide in Boston as its agency of record. Spending was estimated at $35 million.

title: How Not to Sell Obscure Junk on EBay
description: CLEARLY, the smart thing to do before listing various obscure items on eBay last week would have been to take my friend Dana's advice.

title: Market Place; Top Regulators Meet and Plan Unified Effort On Wall Street
description: The nation's three top securities regulators and the New York State attorney general are expected to announce a framework as soon as today for bringing a swift resolution to the multiple investigations into anti-investor practices at Wall Street firms.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: C.I.A. Rejects Request for Report on Preparations for War in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2  The Central Intelligence Agency has refused to provide Congress a comprehensive report on its role in a possible American campaign against Iraq, setting off a bitter dispute between the agency and leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Congressional leaders said today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: British Beef Is Back
description: English roast beef has been allowed back on those French menus that will have it, thanks to the end of a six-year ban on imported meat from British cattle. France banned British beef in 1996 after an outbreak of mad cow disease in Britain and has resisted European Union calls to lift the embargo since 1999. France faced hefty fines if it did not lift the ban. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Ex-Bosnian Serb Leader Enters Guilty Plea to The Hague
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 2  A Bosnian Serb leader today became the first high official to plead guilty of crimes against humanity and to express remorse publicly for the war and bloodshed in the Balkans.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden: Two Workers Electrocuted
description: Two men were electrocuted yesterday while they were power-washing a municipal building, the Meriden police said. The men, Eugeno Torres, 47, and Hector Leon, 50, both of New Haven, were using a cherry picker to wash a former police station, which now houses the traffic court, when they apparently came into contact with wires feeding the building at 165 Miller Street, Officer Mike Siegler said. The men were employed by Milestone Restoration of New Haven, the police said. Investigators from the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration were investigating the accident last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank To Cut Jobs
description: Capitalia, one of Italy's largest banks, said it planned to eliminate 3,700 jobs and sell assets as it tries to return to profit. It will also set aside as much as 500 million euros ($491 million) for possible loan losses. The bank, formerly known as Banca di Roma, will cut about 12 percent of its workers by 2005, it said. Capitalia aims to raise as much as 1.7 billion euros ($1.67 billion) by selling investments like its 14.5 percent stake in Italenergia.

title: Bomb Trial for 3 Settlers
description: The trial of three Jewish settlers accused of planting a bomb near an Arab girls' school in East Jerusalem opened today with the reading of charges.

title: Credit Suisse To Prop Up Insurer Unit
description: The Credit Suisse Group said today that it would pump fresh capital into its ailing insurance arm, Winterthur, for the second time in four months and suggested that even more may be needed to repair a business that has been hit hard by sour stock markets.

title: Arafat Group Drops the Idea Of a Premier
description: Yasir Arafat's Fatah movement has dropped the idea of creating the post of prime minister to take over governing tasks from the Palestinian leader, a step that had been discussed before a 10-day Israeli siege of his headquarters, officials of the group said today.

title: It Slices, Dices and Grabs Headlines in Germany
description: BERLIN  The German elite may be busy talking about damaged relations with the Bush administration after the narrow election in September, but the tabloids have moved on to the case of the Gurkenhobel  the cucumber slicer that has caused a new set of sharp insults to fly between eastern and western Germans.

title: Reimbursement Sought for Sept. 11 Tax Losses
description: Members of New York City's Congressional delegation introduced legislation in Washington yesterday that would enable the federal government to reimburse the city for some of the tax revenues it lost because of the World Trade Center attack.

title: 'Cost of One Bullet,' And Other Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: BOND SALE POSTPONED Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. , controlled by Li Ka-shing, canceled a $1.45 billion bond sale. The move limits the financing options for Mr. Li, Asia's richest man, as he tries to sell mobile phone services linked to the Internet across Europe. Hutchison made the decision not to sell euro and sterling debt until markets stabilized after a severe drop in those bond markets, the finance director, Frank Sixt, said in a statement. (Bloomberg News)

title: Judge Backs Informer Who Seeks To Move Family From Colombia
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday ordered prosecutors to recommend that the United States bring relatives of a Colombian drug informer to this country to protect them from what the informer claims are reprisals from members of a drug cartel.

title: Oh So Quietly, Fed Ponders What Follows Greenspan
description: It is one of the most delicate topics in Washington: how to plan for the day when Alan Greenspan, now 76 and in his 16th year as chairman of the Federal Reserve, is no longer at the economy's helm.

title: Valentine Comes to Terms With Decision He Calls Fair
description: One day after he was fired as the Mets' manager, Bobby Valentine was not furious, fiery or flippant. He accepted his dismissal by the Mets' owner, Fred Wilpon, as the inevitable result of a misbegotten 75-86 season, the second consecutive year the Mets failed to make the playoffs.

title: The Jersey Bounce
description: In baseball, when a left-handed pitcher throws a curveball to a left-handed batter, the ball will curve away from the batter and be slightly harder to hit. That's one reason a manager will often send in a right-handed pinch hitter against the lefty on the mound.

title: A Pro-American Forum
description: To the Editor:

title: From Enron Fast Track To Total Derailment
description: Those who know Andrew S. Fastow, the man at the center of the Enron scandal, say they often got the sense that he had something to prove.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Cleaning Deadline Is Extended
description: Residents of Lower Manhattan who want their apartments to be inspected for cleaning by the Environmental Protection Agency now have until Dec. 28 to sign up, the E.P.A. said yesterday. Only a quarter of the eligible residents have accepted the offer, which had been due to expire today. The government will conduct free cleaning and testing of apartments that may have been contaminated by dust and ash from the World Trade Center attack. Anyone living south of Canal, Pike and Allen Streets can request an air quality test and cleaning, or the test alone, by calling (877) 796-5471 or going online at www.epa.gov/wtc. Kirk Johnson (NYT)

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Cost of One Bullet,' and Other Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: Are These Folks Crazy, or Cordless? New Sets Make Wireless Weirder
description: Watching people speak on cellular headsets can be unsettling: it looks as if the world has gone mad and everyone is suddenly talking to himself. Two new Bluetooth headsets for cellphones are likely to make wireless communications seem even spookier.

title: Hamilton President Resigns Over Speech
description: The president of Hamilton College resigned on Tuesday, less than two weeks after admitting that he had failed to properly attribute the sources used in his Sept. 1 convocation speech to incoming freshmen.

title: An American Soldier Is Killed By a Bomb in the Philippines
description: An American soldier was killed in an explosion tonight in Zamboanga City, in the southern Philippines, the 11th American serviceman killed since the United States expanded its campaign against terrorism to this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARASICK, PAULINE
description: KARASICK-Pauline (formerly of New Rochelle). Beloved wife of the late Sol. Devoted mother of Carol Karasick and Helane Naiman. Services will be private. The family will receive friends at the home of Helane Naiman, Sunday and Monday, 12-7 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations please to the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter.

title: Teamsters Have Cleaner Union, Study Finds
description: In an unusual study commissioned by the Teamsters union, a team of 20 former prosecutors and F.B.I. agents has concluded that the union, once the nation's most mob-infested, has been largely purged of the influences of organized crime.

title: Town to Sue Rowland Over Losses In Enron Deal
description: A small town near Hartford plans to sue Gov. John G. Rowland to prevent Connecticut's trash authority from raising municipal trash-collection fees to recoup the nearly $200 million the state lost in a deal with Enron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECHT, ARLENE
description: HECHT-Arlene (nee Shotz). Wife of George Hecht, of San Diego, on September 16, 2002. With her husband she owned the Buyways Gallery for over 20 years, first in Greenwich Village, later in Sarasota. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her two sons, Donald Rosenberg and Fred Rosenberg, both of NYC, and two grandchildren.

title: James B. Chapin, 60, Political Analyst
description: James B. Chapin, a political analyst and historian who advised Mark Green when Mr. Green was public advocate for New York City, died on Monday in Andover, N.J., at a Chapin family residence. He was 60 and lived in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPIN, JAMES B.
description: CHAPIN-James B. WHY is deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and former Board Chairman, James Chapin, on Monday, September 30, 2002. Jim Chapin became a member of the board of WHY (World Hunger Year) at its founding in 1975, and served as Chair from 1980-2001, for 22 of its 27 years. Under his leadership, WHY rebounded from the death of its co-founder (and Jim's younger brother), Harry Chapin-and flourished. In his life, Jim Chapin has been an academician, an activist, a consultant, a politician, a government employee, and a journalist. But to us, he will always be known as ''The Chair.'' He will be greatly missed. WHY extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Diana, sons, Jim and David, his parents, brothers and sisters. Bill Ayres, Exec. Dir. WHY The WHY Board of Directors and Staff

title: LIBBEY'S DECLINE IN PROFIT EXCEEDS FORECAST
description: Libbey Inc., the country's biggest glassware maker, said third-quarter profit fell more than forecast as sales declined and expenses like provisions for bad debt increased. Profit dropped to 66 cents to 70 cents a share, from 90 cents a year earlier, Libbey said. Sales fell to at least $104 million from $107 million. Full results are expected about Oct. 25, Libbey said. Slower growth in the economy hurt sales last month, according to Libbey, which makes ceramic dinnerware and glass products for restaurants and hotels.

title: Schools Chief Is Put on Leave In Harrison
description: The superintendent of the Harrison public schools, where incidents involving alcohol abuse by students and a janitor have drawn publicity, has been placed on a paid leave of absence, his lawyer said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ARM Holdings Warns On Profits
description: A British maker of chips used in mobile phones, ARM Holdings, warned that its profit in the third quarter would be far lower than analysts had expected, a result of delayed orders by customers and a weakening American dollar. It expects to earn a pretax profit of 8 million ($12.5 million) for the quarter ended Sept. 30. ARM said the slowdown in licensing revenue had reduced its backlog. Shares plunged $4.19, or 66 percent, to $2.15 yesterday. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUFSON, MONROE H.
description: MUFSON-Monroe H., M.D., 76. Of Denville, NJ, passed away October 1, 2002, after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Born in the Bronx in 1925 and a graduate of New York University College of Medicine in 1947 at the age of 21, he was a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha Honorary Medical Society, Fellow of the American College of Cardiology, and Fellow of the American College of Physicians. Also Diplomate, American Board of Internal Medicine, and former director of medicine in cardiology St. Clare's Hospital, Denville, NJ. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, of 55 years, and brothers, Dr. Alan Mufson of Boonton Township, New Jersey, and Donald of Closter, New Jersey.

title: Gurkenhobel: It Slices, Dices, Causes a Fuss
description: The German elite may be busy talking about damaged relations with the Bush administration after the narrow election in September, but the tabloids have moved on to the case of the Gurkenhobel -- the cucumber slicer that has caused a new set of sharp insults to fly between eastern and western Germans.

title: Japan Looks to Eastern Russia for Oil
description: While the United States courts western Russia as a new source of non-OPEC oil, Japan is looking to the Russian Far East, ensuring that Sakhalin Island will become a major supplier of oil and gas to Japan within a decade.

title: Accounts
description: * Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, the lead agency on the United States Army account, named the Vital Marketing Group, New York, which specializes in campaigns aimed at young urban consumers, to help market the Army to potential black recruits. Vital Marketing will assist Muse Cordero Chen & Partners, Los Angeles, part of Muse Creative Holdings, which Burnett named last month as its subcontractor to handle the assignment. The Army spends $5 million to $10 million a year on advertising to attract black recruits, out of its estimated $95 million annual budget. Burnett is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PITSON, VICTORIA ZACHARIA
description: PITSON-Victoria Zacharia. Recording Secretary of The Ladies Auxiliary of The Sephardic Home For The Aged for over 25 years. We extend our deepest condolences to her children, Gabrielle, Daisy and Estelle and her entire family. She will be remembered for her dedication to the residents of the Home and to all who were privileged to know her. Board of Directors Of The Sephardic Home For The Aged and LASHA

title: Illy and the Artful Coffee Cup
description: For the last 10 years, the Italian coffee company Illy has carried cups and saucers designed by artists like Jeff Koons, available online at www.illyusa.com ($129 for six espresso cups and saucers). Now the French artist Louise Bourgeois has designed an espresso cup and saucer, above, which will be available this month on the Web site for $150 for a limited edition cup (they sell out quickly), or $150 for four regular cups. Illy has teamed up with the Palais de Tokyo, a grand art space near the Trocadro, for an installation of recent works on the theme of childhood by Ms. Bourgeois, 91, from Oct. 8 to Nov. 24. The Palais de Tokyo is at 13, avenue de President Wilson in Paris.

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Armored Archer Or Navy Seal? 2 Paths to Glory
description: SOCOM: U.S. NAVY SEALS

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the author and illustrator Glen Rounds on Saturday misidentified his first wife. She was Mary Lucas; Janet Barber was his mother's maiden name.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Public-School Booster
description: To the Editor:

title: Donor Passes Salmonella From His Pet Snake
