description: An Oklahoma man who caught a salmonella infection from his pet snake passed the illness to two people through transfusions of his blood platelets, a doctor reported in a journal article published today. Both recipients became ill, and one died.

title: Erroneous Order for Big Sales Briefly Stirs Up the Big Board
description: An errant order to sell $4 billion in stocks briefly roiled the market yesterday afternoon, providing another warning of how a clerical error can produce huge risks.

title: Navigating Rough Seas Of Coexistence
description: Borders and barriers, both physical and emotional, are the subject of two hourlong documentaries that open today as a double bill at the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village.

title: Yankees-Angels Draw Viewers
description: The Yankees' 8-5 victory over Anaheim in Game 1 of the A.L. division series Tuesday night on Fox attracted an average of 9.5 million viewers, up from 8.3 million for the comparable Game 1 last year between Oakland and the Yankees, which was played on a Wednesday night. Richard Sandomir

title: Paris Design Show: Vive L'Objet!; Warm Coats, and Polish
description: The Now! section of the Maison et Objet home design show in Paris last month was subtitled ''Happy Design for Happy People.'' The select group of products indicated a marked improvement in mood over the show in January, which was decidedly gloomy, with American buyers in short supply.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Threat From Computer Worm
description: A bugbear is causing trouble on the Internet. Bugbear is the name of a computer worm that, like the Klez program, blends several kinds of attacks into a single package that invades Windows-based personal computers and then uses mass mailings to send itself to everyone in the infected computer's address book. ''It's a more complex threat to detect and stop'' than simple viruses and worms, said Vincent Weafer, the head of Symantec Security Response, a unit of the Symantec Corporation. The company upgraded the threat assessment of the program yesterday to its second-highest rating because of its rapid proliferation. Major computer security companies like Symantec, however, have already made available updated virus blockers that will stop the rogue program. The program does not cause major damage but can leave entry points for hackers on infected computers and can record the victim's keystrokes. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: 5 People, Seemingly Picked at Random, Are Slain in Maryland
description: ASPEN HILL, Md., Oct. 3  Five people were killed in a series of sniper shootings over 16 hours in the suburbs north of Washington, prompting a frantic manhunt today throughout the region based on the barest of information.

title: An Israeli's Sorrowful Rule Over a Sullen Nablus
description: The Israeli colonel, the new master of this bruised Palestinian city, ordered his jeep to the curb today and leapt out to intercept two Palestinian teenagers walking by. He wanted to know where they were coming from, what they had in their book bags, what their identification cards revealed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EGENOLF, HERBERT
description: EGENOLF - Herbert. The Board of Directors and members of the International Fine Print Dealers Association note with sadness the passing of our colleague, Herbert Egenolf on August 31, 2002, in Dusseldorf, Germany. He was a world-renowned dealer, an expert in Japanese prints of the ukiyo-e world, respected for his integrity, connoisseurship, honesty and kindness. We extend our condolences to his business partner and friend Veronica Miller, who will carry on the branch of his gallery in Venice, California. President, Robert Newman

title: Footlights
description: Latin Beat

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Budget Deficit To Deepen
description: The state's budget deficit is getting worse, reaching $390 million, about $60 million, or 8 percent, more than previously projected, said Nancy Wyman, left, the state comptroller. In the fiscal year ending June 30, 2003, revenue from major tax categories, including income and corporate taxes, is dropping at a faster clip than previously thought, according to the state comptroller's office. Steve Jensen, a department spokesman, said Tuesday that Ms. Wyman was unsure if tax receipts would rise soon and had taken a ''less optimistic'' position than the governor's office. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: New Saint Reflects Lay Group's New Influence
description: Pope John Paul II has made so many saints at such a brisk clip that the ascension of yet another, at a ceremony scheduled to take place here on Sunday, would not automatically attract special note.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Businesses Urge Bush To Reopen Western Ports

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, MARTIN H.
description: BERMAN-Martin H., DDS. It is with great sadness and a deep sense of personal loss that we mark the passing of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Martin H. Berman, a loving, devoted and proud husband, father, grandfather, greatgrandfather, uncle and mentor to students of all ages. Marty served as Chief, Division of Prosthodontics, Department of Dentistry, for over 20 years enriching the lives of all who were fortunate to cross his path. His legacy shall endure in all of our hearts. Frederic R. Kunken, DMD Chairman, Department of Dentistry, North Shore University Hospital/Manhasset

title: Chargers Are No. 1 in Ranking
description: The San Diego Chargers were 5-11 last season, and in The New York Times computer's final N.F.L. power ratings of the season, only two teams finished lower.

title: New Installment of Linux Goes Beyond the Valley of the Geeks
description: Linux may be running behind Microsoft and Apple in the operating-system popularity contest, but a new release may appeal to curious computer users who want to sample this open-source software (and get some free tech support for it) without breaking the bank. Red Hat Linux 8.0, released this week, comes in a basic personal edition for $39.95, compared with $199 for the full version of Windows XP Home Edition and $129 for Mac OS X 10.2 from Apple.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Arrests In Bashing Case
description: The police have arrested two men in a random attack on a gay man in West Hollywood on Sept. 1. Investigators say they believe the two were involved with two other beatings in the city last month that left one man in a coma. A tip led to the arrest of the two -- Larry Walker, 29, and Vincent Dotsun, 18 -- in South-Central Los Angeles. They are charged with assault, attempted robbery and the commission of a hate crime. After interrogating the men, the police turned up an unidentified third suspect who was already in jail on car theft charges. The anonymous tipster will receive a $91,000 reward. Charlie LeDuff (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn with profound sadness the passing of Walter H. Annenberg, who for more than four decades demonstrated on a breathtaking scale his passion for art and his support of this institution. With his wife, Leonore, he based his philanthropy at the Metropolitan on the understanding that great museum collections remain great by continuing to evolve and to grow. Through a series of landmark gestures-gifts of works of art from masterpieces by Van Gogh to masterpieces of Asian sculpture, along with major grants for acquisitions-they have enhanced the very heart of the Metropolitan Museum, its collections, for generations to come. Walter Annenberg was involved in countless other ways as well: as a Trustee and benefactor; as a committed supporter of education in the arts; and as the donor of a major challenge grant that has enabled the Museum to build a new Center for Imaging and Photography. But his most spectacular gesture was the decision in 1991 to bequeath his collection of fifty-three Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, watercolors, and drawings to the Museum, the largest single gift of art to the Metropolitan in more than a quarter century. Since 1993, this outstanding collection has been in residence at the Museum for six months of each year for all to enjoy. Walter's motto was ''strength to strength,'' and his legacy of sweeping generosity will be held dear by us and by the museum-going public in perpetuity. We extend our deepest condolences to Mrs. Annenberg and to the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director David E. McKinney, President

title: Broker's Assistant Pleads Guilty in Stewart Case
description: The assistant to Martha Stewart's stockbroker pleaded guilty yesterday to concealing the reason behind the sale of Ms. Stewart's shares of ImClone Systems.

title: 'Wall' Sculpture vs. Walls of Ads; Pause in Landmark Fight So Mural's Real Wall Can Be Fixed
description: The battlefield is vertical. The fight is between art and commerce. But even the best fighters often have to be practical.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sales Drop At Advanced Micro
description: Advanced Micro Devices, which competes with Intel in the field of personal computer processors, said sales fell more than forecast in the third quarter. Advanced Micro had a ''substantial operating loss'' on sales of about $500 million, a spokesman, Morris Denton, said. He declined to say whether it would have a net loss. The company in July said revenue would rise from the $600.3 million in the second quarter.

title: U.S. Trade Panel Imposes High Tariffs on Steel Rods
description: A federal trade panel approved duties as high as 369 percent on imports of steel wire rods today, a move that will shelter American mills but which provoked angry protests from American companies that use the rods to make wire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERIAN, PETER G.
description: TERIAN-Peter G. Of Manhattan and East Hampton, passed away at home at the age of 65 on October 2, 2002, after a courageous battle with prostate cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife, Juliana Curran Terian, an architect, and by his beloved and cherished daughter, Olivia. Peter immigrated to the West Side of Manhattan from Paris, France, at the age of nine. Ten years later he cofounded Rallye Motors, one of the nation's most prestigious car dealerships, and served as its president to this day. He was a renowned collector of art, who frequently loaned significant pieces to museums worldwide, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he served as a William Cullen Bryant fellow. Peter was also on the board of the Dakota building, where he resided for many years. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Thursday, October 3, 5-9 PM. Service Friday, October 4, at 11 AM, at the City Church, 64th St. off Central Park West. Interment private. Donations in his memory may be made to the New York Foundling Hospital, a children's charity which was Peter's passion

title: Replay Is Ordered in Bronx Democratic Primary
description: Three weeks after a Democratic primary for an Assembly seat in the Bronx ended in a five-vote difference between candidates, a State Supreme Court judge ruled yesterday that a new election be held on Oct. 15.

title: No Easy Home for Priests' Group
description: A group of current and former priests has hit a snag in its efforts to organize resistance to what it says is unfair treatment by the church hierarchy over the sexual abuse scandal.

title: Clinton Tells Blair's Labor Party He Backs Tough U.N. Resolution on Iraq Inspections
description: Former President Bill Clinton expressed strong support today for President Bush's goal of a tough new United Nations resolution on arms inspections in Iraq, but he warned that pre-emptive military actions held unwanted dangers.

title: Killing Has Neighbors Shaking Their Heads
description: The sidewalks on this block of Brown Street, bracketed by liquor and grocery stores, draw the young and the troubled, drug dealers and drinkers, an uneasy mix that exploded on Sunday night when a mob of children and teenagers chased a passerby and beat him to death.

title: In 61 Letters, A Wide Web Of Contacts
description: It was not only family members.

title: Ellis Larkins, 79, Jazz Pianist Of Sensitive and Elegant Style
description: Ellis Larkins, a jazz pianist known for his understated elegance as an improviser and his sensitivity as an accompanist, died on Sunday at Maryland General Hospital in Baltimore. He was 79 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When Lightning Strikes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLINDER, JOAN GOODMAN
description: BLINDER-Joan Goodman. On September 30, 2002. Beloved wife of the Hon. Albert Blinder. Loving mother of Peter M. Steinhaus, Richard Z. Steinhaus, Jr. and stepmother of Adam Z. Blinder. Services private. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Egyptians See U.S. as Meddling in Their Politics
description: In his air-conditioned sanctuary atop the crumbling building of the Ministry of Youth, Ali Eddein Hilal Dessouki talked of that rare commodity in Egypt: democracy.

title: Agatha Christie's Posthumous Stay At the Pera Palace
description: The Chilean-born travel writer Francisca Matteoli, below, said that her latest book was inspired by ''my first French address -- the Htel du Louvre,'' just across from the museum. Her ''Hotel Stories: Legendary Hideaways of the World'' recounts the histories of grand addresses from Japan to Jamaica, each centered on a famous (or infamous) visitor. There's Truman Capote at the Plaza, Al Capone out of prison at the Biltmore in Miami, the director Luchino Visconti shooting ''Death in Venice'' at the Grand Hotel des Bains and the ghost of Agatha Christie -- that's the story -- materializing at the magnificent Pera Palace in Istanbul. ''Hotel Stories'' (Assouline, $34.95) is available at Barnes & Noble.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, NATHAN
description: ROSENFIELD-Nathan, Dr. Beloved and loving husband of the late Vivian. Devoted father of Carol Schneebaum, Deborah Hensler and Joanne Tahar. Proud grandfather of Katherine and Jessica Schneebaum; Benjamin and Rebecca Hensler and Matthew Gilbride. Delighted great-grandfather of Charlotte and Sophie Larish. Dearest companion of Shirley Barsky. A fine practitioner of oral surgery, he was able to continue teaching until his 88th year. He will be sorely missed by all of us who love him. Services at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York, at 11:30 AM, Friday, October 4.

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Endorsement by Gephardt Helps Propel Resolution
description: In a speech in early June, well before Iraq dominated dialogue in the capital, Representative Richard A. Gephardt endorsed the use of the military to disarm Saddam Hussein should diplomacy fail.

title: From 'Dilbert' to Oliphant: The Funny Page Redefined
description: If your favorite newspaper is the cartoon-challenged New York Times, or if your preferred daily perversely chooses not to carry your favorite comic strip, My Comics Page (www.mycomicspage.com) has a deal for you: for $9.95 a year, the site offers same-day access to 86 strips and nearly three dozen editorial cartoons, customized to your taste.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: ARRESTS IN BASHING CASE

title: Excerpts From Remarks by President and Lawmakers on Iraq Resolution
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush and Congressional leaders at the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. Among those with Mr. Bush were Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, the speaker of the House; Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader; and Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona. A full transcript is online at nytimes .com/politics.

title: Hundreds Line Up for Giuliani, the New Matinee Idol
description: Oh, how they love Rudy. They lined up in a neat row on 48th Street from Fifth Avenue to the Avenue of the Americas and around the corner to 49th Street, clutching copies of ''Leadership,'' a 407-page volume emblazoned with Rudolph W. Giuliani's portrait -- with his recently abandoned comb-over hairdo.

title: Canada's Leader Plans More Social Spending After Years of Cuts
description: In two speeches that broadly promised increases in spending for health care, transportation and low-income housing, Prime Minister Jean Chrtien signaled this week that he planned to leave office with a burst of social activism in the next 16 months.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Saltwater Quandary

title: World Court's Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Cost of One Bullet,' And Other Musings
description: To the Editor:

title: The Web Loves Babies, Especially at 4 in the Morning
description: IF there is one thing new parents love more than learning about what makes babies tick, it is recounting the experiences they have had with their own little treasures. New parents are up at all hours, with a lot of tales to tell, questions to ask and products to buy. I'm speaking from first-hand knowledge, being the father of a 10-month-old.

title: Telling Chile's Story, Even if Chile Has Little Interest
description: Five days after the Chilean army overthrew the elected Socialist government of President Salvador Allende Gossens on Sept. 11, 1973, Patricio Guzmn was arrested by military intelligence officers. He was then interrogated in the national stadium in Santiago for two weeks before he was released and fled the country. He was lucky. While many Allende supporters were being jailed, tortured and killed, he escaped because he was ''only'' a documentary filmmaker.

title: Russia, With Much at Stake, Takes Its Time Deciding
description: Russia is biding its time over whether to support the Bush administration in seeking a new United Nations resolution on Iraq, with parliamentary leaders saying today that the decision hinged on economic interests, and with the Kremlin still declining to lay out its terms in public.

title: More Good News for Notre Dame
description: Notre Dame got another break in its so far charmed season when Bowl Championship Series officials decided this week to allow its victory over Maryland in the Kickoff Classic to be counted toward the nine victories necessary to qualify for an at-large spot in the four sanctioned bowl games.

title: Ex-New York Police Official To Head Los Angeles Force
description: William J. Bratton, the former police commissioner of New York who claimed credit for the city's dramatic drop in crime in the mid-90's, has been chosen as the next police chief in Los Angeles, officials in the mayor's office said late today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Kidnapped Boy Killed
description: Prosecutors in Frankfurt said Jakob von Metzler, the 11-year-old heir to a German banking fortune who was kidnapped last week, was killed by his abductor two or three days before the payment of a nearly $1 million ransom. Authorities said the kidnapper, whose name has not been released, worked as a tutor for the boy's family. The slaying has revived memories of the 1970's and 80's, when several prominent German bankers and industrialists were abducted or killed by the radical Red Army Faction. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: 'Hey, Keep It Down, Will Ya?' Mayor's Noise Plan Insists on It
description: He has taken on diplomatic scofflaws. He has put smokers in his legislative cross hairs. And now Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is going after the noisy.

title: Gore Criticizes Bush on Creating Crisis Over Economic Leadership but Offers Few Suggestions
description: Ten days after criticizing President Bush's handling of Iraq, Al Gore offered a scathing assessment today of Mr. Bush's stewardship of the American economy. Mr. Gore said Mr. Bush's policies had created a ''crisis of confidence in U.S. economic leadership throughout the world.''

title: Mideast History: Facts and Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Isles Defeat Flyers
description: The Islanders won their third straight preseason game last night, and they avoided the kind of penalties that had clearly bothered Coach Peter Laviolette on Tuesday.

title: A 'Bounty Hunter' in Search of Human Justice
description: REED BRODY has a world map on the wall of his small office in the Empire State Building. It has about 50 tiny black and white photos of various dictators, warlords, generals and former heads of state tacked unceremoniously to their respective countries or places of self-imposed exile. Many of the most notorious killers on the planet are there, a kind of rogues' gallery, and this slightly rumpled lawyer is at the forefront of the effort to bring them to trial.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Choosing (Opposite) Sides

title: Spano Proposes 31.7% Increase In County Tax For Westchester
description: The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, today proposed a 31.7 percent increase in the amount the county raises through property taxes, the largest increase since 1968 and the second since Mr. Spano took office.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with an article about a new Canadian immigration policy that encourages foreign families to settle in rural areas located Vancouver erroneously. The city is on the Canadian mainland, not on Vancouver Island.

title: Angels Steal Page From the Yankees' Book
description: It was a muggy night at Yankee Stadium, and thunder struck shortly after 11. It came suddenly and without warning, from the bats of two Anaheim Angels, and it sent another surge through an electrifying American League division series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEVAS, LIBBY
description: NEVAS - Libby. American Jewish World Service mourns her loss. We extend our deepest sympathies to Leo, a member of our Board, and to the Nevas family. Ruth Messinger, President Martin Friedman, Chair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, SOL
description: RESNICK-Sol (Rush). Age 84. WW II combat artist, painter and sculptor. Survived by his wife June, daughters Tina and Tamar, grandchildren David and Maia and sister Anna and two nieces. For info ''Wien & Wien'', 800-322-0533.

title: CALENDAR
description: Victorian Brooklyn

title: Cellphones, and Then Some: The Latest Mergers
description: As aliens observe us through their intergalactic telescopes, they must laugh their little green heads off at certain illogical aspects of human behavior. We wash down a super-size pizza with a low-cal beverage; we pursue a love interest more intently the more we're rejected; and we buy high, sell low.

title: Appier Shows Anaheim The Way
description: He was the only one the Anaheim Angels could look to, the only one who could show them and tell them what October baseball means. All by himself, Angels starter Kevin Appier could stand on the mound at Yankee Stadium, sweat through his red Angels cap and be that pillar of strength as the only player on the active roster with playoff experience.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about logistical negotiations between Iraq and weapons inspectors from the United Nations and the International Atomic Energy Agency referred incorrectly to the status of a draft United Nations resolution intended to increase the inspectors' access. The resolution, which was being prepared by the United States and Britain, was not formally presented to the Security Council yesterday; as noted in other articles yesterday, the drafting is still in progress.

title: Nutrients by the Numbers
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Injury to Chrebet Adds to Jets' Woes
description: Wayne Chrebet limped toward the Jets' training room today, admitting that he felt like an old man. The bulky wrap around his right knee protected a microfracture of the femur and a deep bone bruise. It also revealed a serious problem for an offense that hardly needs another one.

title: Nuclear Stockpiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERIAN, PETER G.
description: TERIAN-Peter G. Of Manhattan and East Hampton, passed away at home at the age of 65 on October 2, 2002, after a courageous battle with prostate cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife, Juliana Curran Terian, an architect, and by his beloved and cherished daughter, Olivia. Peter immigrated to the West Side of Manhattan from Paris, France, at the age of nine. Ten years later he cofounded Rallye Motors, one of the nation's most prestigious car dealerships, and served as its president to this day. He was a renowned collector of art, who frequently loaned significant pieces to museums worldwide, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he served as a William Cullen Bryant fellow. Peter was also on the board of the Dakota building, where he resided for many years. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Thursday, October 3, 5-9 PM. Service Friday, October 4, at 11 AM, at the City Church, 64th St. off Central Park West. Interment private. Donations in his memory may be made to the New York Foundling Hospital, a children's charity which was Peter's passion.

title: Taking A Bite Out Of Crime
description: ''EVERY single victim lost a body part used in cooking,'' says the F.B.I. agent Will Graham (Edward Norton) to an esteemed forensic psychiatrist helping him track a serial murderer in the drearily derivative ''Red Dragon.'' The problem is, the doctor Graham is consulting has hard, appraising eyes and a tendency to roll vowels around in his mouth, savoring them as if they were a '79 Ptrus; it's Hannibal (the Cannibal) Lecter, played once again with relish -- and probably wasabi mayonnaise -- by Anthony Hopkins.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: A $115 Ticket Off Broadway

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Antitrust Chief Is Leaving For Job at ChevronTexaco

title: The S.U.V. Of R.V.'s: Lush Life On Wheels
description: FOR sale: luxurious one-bedroom home with designer interiors, solid oak cabinets, dishwasher, four-door refrigerator, washer-dryer, whirlpool bath, 52-inch retractable flat-screen TV, constantly changing views. Asking price: $1.2 million.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Contractor Is to Pay $75,000 Owed 18 Immigrant Laborers
description: A Queens contractor has agreed to pay a total of more than $75,000 in back wages to 18 immigrant day laborers who were paid less than the prevailing wage while building an animal shelter for the Town of Southampton, the state attorney general said yesterday.

title: New Scoring System, Nearly Ready for Unveiling, Is in Developing Stages
description: As a result of the biggest judging scandal in figure skating history, the International Skating Union is revamping its scoring system. And even those who can differentiate a lutz from a salchow are scratching their heads trying to figure out how this new system will work -- if it will work at all.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Sept. 19 about mysterious recorded music that stopped a performance of Handel's ''Giulio Cesare'' on Sept. 16 at the Opera Garnier in Paris misidentified the live orchestra at the performance. It was Les Musiciens du Louvre-Grenoble, not the Paris National Opera orchestra.

title: Another Chance to Mingle With Dinosaurs and Ape Men
description: For a planet whose every inch is under satellite surveillance, this one sure has a lot of lost worlds on it. There's the one Steven Spielberg explored in the ''Jurassic Park'' series. There's the one from the syndicated television show. There's the one Claude Rains found in the 1960 film. And as of Sunday there will be yet another, and a very stylish and watchable addition to the club it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, RICHARD A.
description: GOLDBERG-Richard A. The City College of New York mourns the passing of Judge Richard A. Goldberg, a graduate of the Class of 1951, past president of the CCNY Alumni Association and former Board member of The City College Fund. Judge Goldberg was a staunch supporter of his Alma Mater and the cause of public higher education. On behalf of City College's students, faculty and staff I wish to extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Dr. Gregory H. Williams President The City College of New York/CUNY

title: My Economic Plan
description: Although other news has been drowned out by the barking of the dogs of war, something ominous is happening on the economic front. It's not dramatic, but month by month the numbers keep coming in worse than expected. Let's put politics completely aside for once, and review where we are and what should be done.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: It's the Forsytes, Reduxing Again
description: Oh, the English and their wacky sense of humor! Mark Thompson, the chief executive of Channel 4 in Britain, recently gave a lecture about the state of television and said, ''When you're looking for ambitious, complex and above all modern TV, you find yourself watching not British, but American pieces.'' To American viewers that idea rings with a Monty Pythonesque absurdity that could keep us howling with laughter all season. If American television represents the avant-garde, we're all in very deep trouble (even though Mr. Thompson was right in citing the anomalous ''Six Feet Under'' and ''24'' as models of innovation).

title: Jim Shaw
description: Swiss Institute

title: When Fate Intrudes, Death on Screen as Well as Off
description: In ''Heaven'' the Australian dramatic chameleon Cate Blanchett gives the most compelling screen performance of her career as a principled terrorist whose desperate act of violence tragically backfires, leaving her broken and reeling with despair and self-loathing.

title: In Season of Tests, the Cardinals Pass Another One
description: If the Cardinals were unlucky after pitcher Chuck Finley left an impressive outing with a hand cramp, they must have felt the prick of voodoo pins when Arizona pinch-runner Alex Cintron collided with St. Louis third baseman Scott Rolen as Rolen charged a dribbler.

title: Shoe Bomber Admits He Tried to Blow Up Trans-Atlantic Jet
description: ABritish citizen who described himself as a follower of Osama bin Laden and an enemy of the United States pleaded guilty in Boston today to trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives stuffed into his shoes.

title: Washington United Way to Select New Board
description: The United Way of the National Capital Area, which is under investigation by a federal grand jury, the Internal Revenue Service and three other federal agencies over accusations of financial mismanagement and misconduct, adopted revised bylaws yesterday in an effort to streamline its board and enhance oversight.

title: Executive Is Promoted To Chief of Frankel
description: Frankel in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, said yesterday that Dick Thomas, 46, executive vice president, would be promoted to president and chief executive.

title: Mah-Jongg Madness: Have Tiles, Will Travel
description: It is a Wednesday afternoon in late August, and 89 of the most compulsive gamblers in Las Vegas can be found at the Golden Nugget on Freemont Street. But they are not within the velvet-rope alcoves reserved for high-stakes blackjack, or amid the flash and clang of the slot tournament in the lobby. There are no cocktail waitresses; those wanting a drink can help themselves to coffee or water.

title: City of Schemes
description: Aren't all these awful crooked C.E.O.'s and C.F.O.'s out in the sticks just . . . awful? How did this spirit of shameless greed come to infuse the corporate cultures of the heartland? Enron : Houston. Arthur Andersen: Chicago. WorldCom : Clinton, Miss. Adelphia: Coudersport, Pa. Tyco: Exeter, N.H., and Boca Raton, Fla. Here in New York City, we've spent the last year selflessly working together toward physical and psychic recovery, all of us engaged in a painful but glorious existential civic introspection. Meanwhile, out there, beyond the Hudson, in the vast unfathomable America of discount superstores and chain restaurants and sun-baked suburban business parks, a decadent amorality had worked its way like some malignant rot through the nation's fiber. Consumed with the struggle to rebuild, we New Yorkers were feeling fully American as we hadn't in decades -- and now, suddenly, the ''real'' America is revealed as a manic, festering hive of greed and corruption. It turns out all the Bedford Fallses are actually Pottersvilles. Which makes us, as we observe the mess from the Upper West Side and TriBeCa, feel all the more victimized and righteous. And by the way? For the record? We always had our doubts about the Internet and its associated financial madnesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWAB, DAVID
description: SCHWAB-David. April 11, 1921 to October 3, 2002. Loving husband, father, and grandfather. Talented diamond cutter, painter, and sculptor. Through his art he brought pleasure into the lives of others. He died at rest in his home. Funeral Friday October 4, 2002 at 1 PM, Schwartz Bros., 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills.

title: 2 Farm Acres Lost per Minute, Study Says
description: The United States is losing two acres of mostly prime farmland every minute to development, the fastest such decline in the country's history, a new study has found.

title: U.S. Seeks to Use Papers on Islam as Evidence
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers sparred here today over the significance of Islamic tapes and documents seized from six young men charged by the government as being part of a sleeper cell of Al Qaeda.

title: Ridley Howard
description: Fredericks Freiser Gallery

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: West Coast Raven Had West Nile
description: West Nile virus has been detected in West Coast wildlife for the first time. The Washington State Department of Health reported that a raven died of the virus in Newport, north of Spokane, near the border with Idaho and British Columbia. While California reported a human infection, the virus had not appeared in the region's wildlife until now. Judy Berck (NYT)

title: Disputed Pacts For Welfare Will Just Die
description: The Bloomberg administration has quietly decided not to renew one of the most contentious pacts to be awarded during the Giuliani era, a large welfare-to-work deal with Maximus, a Virginia-based company hired to help people on welfare find jobs.

title: On Fisher Island, You Need a Scorecard to Keep Track of the Lawsuits
description: WHOEVER said that golf was a gentleman's game has not been to Fisher Island lately. At this tony golf condominium community in Biscayne Bay just south of Miami Beach, there have been at least a dozen lawsuits filed over the last five years, including one in which the property's developer was accused of trying to run over a homeowner with a golf cart when he spotted him handing out leaflets to other residents.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Worldcom Network Problem
description: WorldCom, one of the leading Internet carriers, suffered a software problem with its Internet network yesterday, slowing access to Web sites hosted on its systems. The problem emerged around 8 a.m. and by 8:15 am, parts of WorldCom's network were losing almost one-quarter of the data sent across it, according to Matrix NetSystems, a company that monitors the Internet. When a piece of Internet data is lost, it must be resent, increasing the time it takes to communicate with a Web site. A WorldCom spokesman said in the afternoon that the problem was being fixed. About 4 p.m., Matrix NetSystems said that performance was returning to normal. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Gateway, Lands' End and Avaya, with budgets totaling $225 million, drop their agencies.
description: THE fourth quarter, typically a make-or-break time for advertisers, is under way with three large marketers deciding to break up with their agencies.

title: Buyout Firm Considers Selling Stake to Outsiders
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a leveraged buyout firm in New York, is discussing selling a stake in itself to outside investors for the first time, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Nuclear Stockpiles
description: To the Editor:

title: Justine Kurland
description: Gorney Bravin and Lee

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: TAX CHARGE REVIVED The Philippine Supreme Court has revived a case accusing one of the country's biggest tycoons of stealing public funds. The court nullified a decision by government prosecutors in 1997 to drop graft charges against Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., the chairman of the food and beer conglomerate San Miguel. Mr. Cojuangco, together with a former senator and 10 other people, is charged with misappropriating 9.6 billion pesos in taxes on coconuts during the rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Mr. Marcos was deposed in 1986.

title: Mets' Search for a Manager Starts One Step at a Time
description: As the Mets dealt with more fallout from the firing of Manager Bobby Valentine, General Manager Steve Phillips began gaining permission to speak with possible replacements and will interview his first candidate Friday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Housing Affordability Ranking
description: Nassau and Suffolk Counties combined ranked as one of the top 10 worst areas in the country for middle-income housing, according to an advocacy group, the National Low Income Housing Coalition in Washington. Nassau and Suffolk Counties comprise the seventh-least affordable area, while Stamford-Norwalk in Connecticut is the third and Westchester County is the eighth. The nation's least-affordable area is the San Francisco Bay area. Affordability was calculated based on the minimum hourly wage needed to rent a two-bedroom apartment. In 2002 on Long Island, for example, an hourly wage of $24.52, up nearly 4 percent from the year earlier, would be enough to rent such an apartment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Oliver Payne and Nick Relph -- 'Mixtape'
description: Gavin Brown Enterprise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, NATHAN
description: ROSENFIELD-Nathan, Dr. Beloved and loving husband of the late Vivian. Devoted father of Carol Schneebaum, Deborah Hensler and Joanne Tahar. Proud grandfather of Katherine and Jessica Schneebaum; Benjamin and Rebecca Hensler and Matthew Gilbride. Delighted great-grandfather of Charlotte and Sophie Larish. Dearest companion of Shirley Barsky. A fine practitioner of oral surgery, he was able to continue teaching until his 88th year. He will be sorely missed by all of us who love him. Services at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York, at 11:30 AM, Friday, October 4.

title: Angels Surprise A Storied Bullpen
description: The last time the Yankees were this surprised in a postseason game was . . . well, it wasn't all that long ago. It was last November, when Tony Womack drilled a game-tying double to right field and Luis Gonzalez looped a single to center that won the World Series for the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: Echoes of Bush v. Gore
description: Again?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNEY, HENRY
description: BERNEY-Henry. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and former Trustee and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Ken Simon, President

title: Disney and DVD Hit a Milestone
description: It was the ''last of the red-hot fairy tales,'' says Don Hahn on a new DVD of ''Beauty and the Beast,'' to be released Tuesday by Disney. Mr. Hahn, the film's producer, then ticks off three predecessors: ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' ''Cinderella'' and ''Sleeping Beauty.'' By 1959 Disney had bagged all three for animated features, but for various reasons the studio had held off on ''Beast.'' The right opportunity didn't jell until the late 80's, about the time of ''The Little Mermaid'' (1989), the first of the studio's new wave of animated films that appealed to older audiences as well as children.

title: Robotics Slumps, but Recovery Is Predicted
description: Investment in industrial robots plummeted in Japan and the United States in 2001, but a recovery is expected over the next three years, according to an annual survey by the United Nations Economic Commission.

title: Torben Giehler
description: Leo Koenig

title: G.O.P. Asks Justices to Halt Democrats' Ballot Swap
description: The New Jersey Republican Party asked the United States Supreme Court today to overturn Wednesday's unanimous State Supreme Court decision allowing former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg to take Senator Robert G. Torricelli's place on the November ballot.

title: Two Shows, Worlds Apart
description: The Morgan Library is exhibiting 111 master drawings and oil sketches from the collection of Eugene V. and Clare E. Thaw, including Rembrandt's ''Bulwark De Rose and the Windmill De Smeerpot in Amsterdam,'' above. The Metropolitan Museum is offering an exhibition of artifacts from the nomadic tribes of the Eurasian steppes, mostly collected by the Thaws.

title: Retrospective Salutes an Indian Actress and Activist
description: After watching a few films starring the Indian actress and political activist Shabana Azmi, you quickly learn to identify how she uses her eyes -- especially since she often plays characters who don't get to express their intelligence.

title: Corrections
description: An review in Weekend on Sept. 6 about exhibitions related to the Sept. 11 attacks referred incorrectly to David Margules, whose photographs of ground zero are on view at the New-York Historical Society. He is a freelance photographer; he does not work for The New York Post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, JAMES D.
description: JOHNSON-James D. The Officers, Members, Executive Board and Staff of RWDSU/ UFCW Local 338 regret to announce the passing of retired Secretary-Treasurer, James D. Johnson, on October 2, 2002. Mr. Johnson was a member of Local 338 since 1937, and served in a variety of positions. Finally, in 1977, he became Secretary-Treasurer until his retirement in 2000. All those whose lives he touched mourn his passing. He was a fighter for the rights of the working man and an ardent believer in the labor movement and its responsiblity to the working men and women it served.

title: Jury Awards Ex-Smoker Record Damages of $28 Billion
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4  A Los Angeles Superior Court jury awarded a staggering $28 billion in punitive damages to a smoker with lung cancer who accused Philip Morris Inc. of luring her into a lifelong tobacco habit with fraudulent advertising and marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMETH, ANNE
description: SAMETH - Anne. Passed away on October 2nd in her 83rd year. Beloved mother of Robert and Ellen, wife of the late Allan, sister of Mindy Brownstein and the late Evelyn Weinberg and grandmother of Alex and Ethan. She will be missed.

title: Fattening Up the Feathered, Not the Furred
description: OCTOBER is bird month, at least for humans. It's when the need to nurture kicks in, when people, as well as birds, flock to feeders, seed and suet.

title: Giants Facing Special Teams Test
description: Giants punter Matt Allen spun to snag an errant snap against Arizona on Sunday, and he must have felt as if he were standing on an interstate with his back to oncoming traffic. He was sure that about one ton of linebackers and linemen were about to converge on him, and Allen reacted the same way anyone with little N.F.L. experience would have reacted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEALCALA, BRUNETTA
description: deALCALA-Brunetta. Formerly of Glen Cove, NY, on October 1, 2002. Beloved mother of Brunetta Winthers, Christine Nagy and Donna and Joseph DeMatteo. Cherished Nanny Bruny to six grandchildren. Loving sister of Eleanor, Stella and the late Charles. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, October 4, 4-7 PM. Funeral service on Saturday, October 5th, 10AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Women Playing for T.I.M.E., 1405 South Orange Ave., Suite 300, Orlando, FL 32806, Attn: Zonetta Glenn

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: GOVERNOR SIGNS LENDING BILL

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: eBay Closes Paypal Deal
description: eBay, the world's largest Internet auctioneer, completed the $1.5 billion purchase of an electronic payments company, Paypal, yesterday. EBay said Matt Bannick, a senior vice president, would assume the duties previously handled by PayPal's chief executive, Peter Thiel, who resigned.The purchase closed after PayPal shareholders approved the swap of each of their shares for 0.39 share of EBay common stock, EBay said. Paypal shareholders also approved the purchase yesterday. Shares of eBay, based in San Jose, Calif., fell $1.40, to $51.90 on the Nasdaq. Paypal, based in Mountain View, Calif., fell 53 cents, to $20.22.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Makes Florida Look Good
description: President Vladimir V. Putin ended -- sort of -- a series of strange events surrounding the gubernatorial election in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, by appointing the winner acting governor. The Sept. 22 election, which a young former businessman, Alexander Khloponin, won, was annulled by the region's election commission. The annulment was dismissed by a court this week, but the commission responded by annulling the election again. Mr. Putin met with both candidates last night and appointed Mr. Khloponin acting governor. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: New Role for U.S. in Colombia: Protecting a Vital Oil Pipeline
description: Casting a wary eye for rebel snipers, Lt. Felipe Ziga and his counterinsurgency troops slog through the wet fields and patches of jungle here. Their mission has nothing to do with drugs -- until now, the defining issue in Colombia for American policy makers -- but instead with protecting a pipeline that carries crude to an oil-hungry America.

title: Revive Commuter Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Home Insurance Crisis Roils Residents and Top Race
description: Hundreds of thousands of homeowners in Texas are expected to lose their insurance coverage in the next year while others are seeing huge increases in premiums in a crisis that could harm the state's economy. It has already become a central issue in the governors' race.

title: Impasse Over Homeland Security
description: The prospect of war so dominates Washington that vital elements of the campaign against terrorism have fallen by the wayside. One victim is the drive to establish a new Homeland Security Department by consolidating disparate parts of the government into an agency to protect Americans from attack. Such a department has widespread support in Congress, but President Bush is foolishly holding up its creation by demanding complete freedom to hire and fire those working there. He claims that such power is needed to run the department properly. There is no basis for such a claim. Moreover, the Democrats have made key concessions on personnel management for the department in recent weeks that give the administration almost everything it wants. Yet Mr. Bush and his Republican allies are inexcusably filibustering a homeland measure that has a majority of votes in the Senate.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: 1974 Redux: Why Bear Market May Be Over
description: SCANDALS abound, and once-powerful men are negotiating plea bargains. The stock market has lost nearly half its value and has just endured its most volatile -- and worst -- quarter in more than a decade.

title: Pakistanis Are Skeptical of Musharraf's Promises
description: Shortly after Gen. Pervez Musharraf seized power three years ago, he promised a democracy, and in seven days, he said, when Pakistan elects its first Parliament since 1997, he plans to start delivering it.

title: George S. Kaufman's Jet-Paced Solo Flight
description: George S. Kaufman was known for his collaborations: with Moss Hart, Edna Ferber, the Gershwins and others. But it must have been that he got lonely; he didn't really need the help. His only solo venture as a playwright, ''The Butter and Egg Man,'' a fond and giddy sendup of the theater business that landed on Broadway in 1925, is a fast-paced hoot.

title: A 'Medea' Fit for the World of Today
description: The word has gone out in Corinth that there's a celebrity in pain in the vicinity. And when the groupies who sniff for blood wounds among the incredibly famous arrive at her house, Medea doesn't disappoint.

title: Reclaiming the Luster Of Hungarian Ceramics
description: About ceramics you don't often think Hungarian. Yet for more than 150 years, Hungary has had a highly productive art ceramics factory, the Zsolnay Manufactory of Pecs. If it has not always produced the most beautiful pottery in the world, the factory has managed to stay in business since 1853, making significant contributions to the country's artistic and economic well-being.

title: Jobless Rate and Payrolls Both Fall, Surprising Wall Street
description: The tentative economic recovery nearly came to a halt last month as business payrolls shrank for the first time in five months, the Labor Department said today.

title: Norman O. Brown Dies; Playful Philosopher Was 89
description: Norman O. Brown, an erudite and spectacularly playful philosopher whose attempt to psychoanalyze nothing less than history itself entranced intellectuals, beguiled New Age seekers and sold many books, died on Wednesday in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 89.

title: U.S. Hints Ex-Enron Accounting Chief Had Role in Fraud
description: Richard A. Causey, the former chief accounting officer at the Enron Corporation, never really fit into his company's aggressive corporate culture.

title: Seeking New Momentum, McCall Accuses Pataki of Patronage Hiring
description: H. Carl McCall went on the attack yesterday, accusing Gov. George E. Pataki of filling top positions in the state university system with unqualified political cronies and campaign contributors.

title: Stewart Quits As a Director Of Big Board
description: Martha Stewart, under ever-increasing scrutiny over the trading of her ImClone Systems shares, resigned yesterday from the board of the New York Stock Exchange -- immediately prompting questions from analysts about whether she will also step down as chief executive of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia.

title: Schumer Enters the Fray
description: H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and Democratic nominee for governor, on Wednesday released this 30-second advertisement, his first for the general election to feature Senator Charles E. Schumer. It is running on New York City stations. A second ad with Mr. Schumer, promising Mr. McCall would improve the economy and cut property taxes, began being broadcast upstate yesterday.

title: Dubai Journal; Living High and Aiming Higher, Come War or Peace
description: This thriving city-state on the crossroads between Asia and the Middle East likes to shock. In fact, it has made something of a business of shocking people.

title: Preventing Drug Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KART, HAROLD
description: KART-Harold. You left us too soon. The years we spent together will be cherished forever. We will miss your smiling face and your practical jokes. We will miss your sincerity, honesty, generosity and loving friendship. Your love for your family and friends will be admired forever. You have left a void in our hearts. We love you and will surely miss you. Hold a spot for us at the first tee! Roberta and Richie

title: A Family Cursed by a Saintly Mother
description: ''Give me some peace -- get out of my head,'' murmurs Leonardo (Alberto Mondini), the boy gesturing and pacing intently at the very beginning of Marco Bellocchio's latest work, an expansive, often inconsistent, yet still memorable film, ''My Mother's Smile.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about a new tree disease, sudden oak death syndrome, misidentified leaves that showed signs of infection. They were from a bay laurel, not a coast live oak.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Panama: Brewer Bought
description: Heineken, the world's third-largest brewer, and its Latin American partner, the Florida Ice and Farm Company, agreed to buy Cerveceras Bar-Panam, the second-largest brewer in Panama, for $56 million as part of their planned expansion in the region. (Bloomberg News)

title: For Koreans, Feast and Thanks
description: Sometimes you have to work a bit to find the Gotham moon, as it gets sandwiched between buildings. But when it's at its fullest, it lights up the night sky like a Broadway premiere. Many New Yorkers follow its waxing and waning with interest; some hear the voice of Frank Sinatra singing about flying there or of Neil Armstrong talking about his small step. Its fullness near the beginning of fall is a time of celebration for many ethnic groups, among them Chinese, who have the harvest moon festival; Jews, who observe the festival of Sukkot; and Koreans, who have Chusok, their Thanksgiving.

title: Residents at Some Golf Resorts Find the Traps Along the Greens
description: WHEN Shelby Yastrow retired as the general counsel of the McDonald's Corporation in 1998, he envisioned spending his free time lowering his handicap and enjoying the north Arizona pines. That's why Mr. Yastrow, a 66-year-old Scottsdale resident, bought a piece of property at the Rim golf resort, about an hour and a half away in Payson, Ariz. Houses sell for more than $1 million and the par 71 course (designed by Tom Weiskopf) ranks in the top 20 of Golfweek's Top 100 Modern Courses.

title: Kaspar Bonnn
description: DCA Gallery

title: Biotechnology Company's Shares Plummet 62%
description: Shares of Transkaryotic Therapies plunged 62 percent yesterday after it revealed that the Food and Drug Administration did not agree with the main data that the company was presenting in an effort to win approval for its first drug.

title: Missing Voices in Debate on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, MAURICE A.
description: POSNER-Maurice A., M.D. On October 2, 2002. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Jonathan and Daniel. Adoring grandpa of Alexander, Gabrielle and Emily. Services on Friday 9:45AM at Bethel Synagogue, New Rochelle, New York. He cared about people.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: An On-Air Acknowledgment

title: A Drain Is Cleared, A Bluff Is Called
description: The comedian Richard Lewis once joked that his overbearing mother had made the family dog so neurotic it coughed before it barked. ''Pipe Dream'' is just the opposite: though it's knee deep in a world of fulminating neuroses -- independent filmmaking -- it will lull audiences into indifference with its deep-breathing normalcy. This mild-mannered farce, directed by one of its writers, John C. Walsh, is corny in a way that bespeaks an expiration date passed a long time ago.

title: 17 Suits Name Former Priest In Sex Abuse
description: The defrocked priest at the center of a sexual abuse scandal here was named as a defendant today in 17 new civil lawsuits, filed by men who say he sexually abused them as children.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Fund Crisis At Conglomerate
description: Renong, an engineering conglomerate taken over by the Malaysian government a year ago, said it needed to raise 400 million ringgit ($105 million) to stay afloat, setting off a sharp decline in its share price. Renong fell for a second day, losing 11 sen, or 18 percent, to 50 sen at the close of trading. The company said it would sell new shares after financing costs related to an 8.4 billion ringgit bond sale in 1999 contributed to a second-quarter loss.

title: Ritualistic Themes for a Dedication
description: Dance Theater Workshop opened its handsome new building and theater in Chelsea on Wednesday night with Ronald K. Brown's ''Walking Out the Dark,'' a spellbinding ritualistic dance, both somber and joyful, that seemed aptly to consecrate a fresh beginning.

title: Bonuses for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the American Craft Museum's name change, to the Museum of Contemporary Arts and Design, misspelled the name of a brand identity firm in New York headed by a museum board member, Alan Siegel. It is Siegelgale, not Siegalgale.

title: Enough Gas? Eyes Right
description: Hop behind the wheel of Saturn's new Ion, and you immediately notice something out of place. The dashboard is blank where the speedometer and the fuel gauge should be.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: EMC Plans To Lay Off 1,350
description: EMC, the leading vendor of data storage systems, said late yesterday that sales had dropped off at the end of the third quarter, making it unlikely that the company could return to profitability this year, and that it would lay off 1,350 employees, or 7 percent of its work force. EMC estimated that it had revenue of $1.25 billion in the quarter, at least 10 percent less than Wall Street had expected. ''The harsh reality of reduced budgets and the uncertainty of the economic and geopolitical climate are weighing heavily on business confidence,'' said Joseph M. Tucci, chief executive of EMC, which is based in Hopkinton, Mass. EMC's shares, which closed at $5.01 in trading during the day, fell as much as $4.32 in after-hours trading. Shares of other data storage companies, including Emulex, Brocade Communications Systems, Network Appliance and McData also fell after EMC's report.

title: The Collections / Paris: From Galliano, hard core Dior
description: PARIS  'Gold power!" said John Galliano as he was snapped backstage by an ecstatic Penelope Cruz while fellow actresses Christina Ricci and Rosanna Arquette joined the congratulatory throng at Dior's spring/summer show Thursday.

title: John Weitz, 79, Fashion Designer Turned Historian, Dies
description: John Weitz, the fashion designer known for licensing a variety of products under his name and for his second career as a novelist and historian, died yesterday at his home in Bridgehampton, N.Y. He was 79.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You have to be scared. This stuff is random, and that can mean anyone, anyplace, anytime. Everyone's protecting their own right now.''

title: New Police Chief: Dedication With a Splash of Color
description: William J. Bratton is the kind of man, it has been said, who continued to work the night shift years after he quit the police force.

title: Lorian Marlantes, 59, President Of Rockefeller Group Since '95
description: Lorian L. Marlantes, president of Rockefeller Group International, a corporation with interests in commercial real estate and telecommunications, died on Saturday at his home on the Upper East Side after a long illness. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, EDITH
description: SALOMON-Edith. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our beloved, dedicated member Edith Salomon. We will miss her loyalty to our congregation and her participation in our Adult Choir. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her nephew, Marc Salomon, and all her dear ones. Robert N. Levine, D.D., Senior Rabbi Nancy Solomon, President

title: Baghdad Envoys Pitch 'Buy Iraq' Campaign in Russia
description: As the Bush administration lobbies Russia and other veto-bearing members of the Security Council to agree to a new resolution on Iraq, a delegation of Iraqi officials visited Moscow to appeal to business people and officials to resist the pressure.

title: Justice Dept.'s Antitrust Chief Is Leaving for ChevronTexaco
description: Charles A. James, the Justice Department antitrust chief who drew praise and scorn for his handling of the Microsoft lawsuit, announced today that he was resigning to join the ChevronTexaco Corporation.

title: Tokyo's Economic Team Talks Hard Line on Banks
description: On talk shows, Takeshi Kimura throws bombs on the delicate issue of Japan's huge, shaky stack of bad loans.

title: Weekender | Southold, N.Y.
description: IF the East End of Long Island conjures up images of hellish traffic, snobbish socialites and publicists behaving badly, you may be ready to discover Southold, on the North Fork. In the middle of Long Island's wine country and framed by the Great Peconic Bay and Long Island Sound, Southold has dazzling waterfront homes and acres of beaches -- but without the conspicuous consumption and bumper-to-bumper bottlenecks. It's a good spot for people who want a low-key, family-centered weekend community.

title: Hispanic Voters Hard to Profile, Poll Finds
description: Though Hispanic voters identify more with Democrats than they do with Republicans, they have little party loyalty and defy easy categorization on issues like taxes and abortion, according to a new poll by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: 2nd Convicted Felon Is Found Working in Harrison Schools
description: The police said today that they had uncovered a convicted felon who had been working in the cafeteria of the Louis M. Klein Middle School here. The finding was made while the police were helping the Harrison Central School District fingerprint dozens of employees this week.

title: Weber Listed as Day to Day
description: Angels reliever Ben Weber, who left the game Wednesday night after injuring the index finger of his right hand while trying to field a ground ball, underwent X-rays. They were negative. Weber is listed as day to day.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Tax Charge Revived
description: The Philippine Supreme Court has revived a case accusing one of the country's biggest tycoons of stealing public funds. The court nullified a decision by government prosecutors in 1997 to drop graft charges against Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., the chairman of the food and beer conglomerate San Miguel. Mr. Cojuangco, together with a former senator and 10 other people, is charged with misappropriating 9.6 billion pesos in taxes on coconuts during the rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos. Mr. Marcos was deposed in 1986.

title: Forbes Set To Cease Publication Of ASAP
description: In what has become a familiar story, a magazine formed to cover the rise of the digital economy has been done in by its decline. The Forbes family, which owns Forbes magazine, announced today that it was closing Forbes ASAP, a magazine founded in 1992 to cover the digital economy.

title: Residential Real Estate; 72 Condo Lofts Set for New Rochelle
description: A former Bloomingdale's branch, empty for 25 years in a once-bustling downtown neighborhood here, is being converted to 72 condominium lofts. City officials and lenders see the project as pivotal to a larger effort to restore economic vitality to the area.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: On first glance, rm is awfully reminiscent of Oceana, the opulent little seafood gem on East 54th Street. The front dining room bears a passing resemblance to a yacht, as does Oceana's, an effect augmented by the portholes on the doors to the kitchen. The seafood dishes, like Oceana's, are often complex and painstakingly constructed. It's no surprise that Rick Moonen, the executive chef and a partner at rm, was for years the chef at Oceana.

title: U.N. Tribunal, With Surprise Guilty Plea, Rivets Bosnians
description: Muslims in Bosnia, who were caught between Serbian and Croatian fronts during the wars that ripped up Yugoslavia in the 1990's, expressed surprise today at having seen the former Bosnian Serb leader Biljana Plavsic become the first high official to plead guilty of crimes against humanity before the United Nations tribunal in The Hague this week.

title: Two Pitches Have Made the Difference
description: Of the 323 pitches delivered in Game 2 of the Yankees-Angels division series, two stand out. Both were thrown by Troy Percival, the Angels' closer, whose appearance, or nonappearance, has been the talk of the series.

title: New President of Columbia Urges Affirmative Action
description: Lee C. Bollinger used his inauguration as president of Columbia University yesterday to reassert the value of affirmative action in college admissions, to speak of Columbia's need to expand physically and to press for Columbia's greater engagement with the local community and the world.

title: Six Accused of Bilking Mets
description: The Queens district attorney charged four former Mets employees and two vendors yesterday with faking invoices and inflating the price of office supplies in a six-year swindle that cost the Mets about $2 million.

title: French Union Members Protest Plan to Sell State-Owned Utilities
description: Tens of thousands of transportation, utility and postal workers marched through Paris today demanding that Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin abandon plans to sell state-owned industries to replenish the government's coffers.

title: Democrats Are Divided in Debate on Force Against Iraq
description: The debate in Congress over authorizing President Bush to use force against Iraq is deeply dividing Democratic lawmakers from the New York City region, reflecting the dilemma the party faces nationally over what to do about Saddam Hussein.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Ban On Foreign Workers
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon declared a ban on the entry of foreign workers as part of a drive to reduce their numbers. An estimated 250,000 foreign laborers work in Israel, more than half of them illegally. Many are employed as caregivers, or as construction and agricultural workers, replacing Palestinians whose entry to Israel has been barred. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

title: 3 Killed in Renewed Fighting Between Afghan Groups
description: Fighting has flared again in northern Afghanistan, killing three people in the second clash in the region in a week, despite United Nations-led efforts to mediate a cease-fire.

title: Caroline Kennedy's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: Enough's enough!It's time shopaphobes came out of the closet
description: PARIS  In these days when you're nothing if you don't have victim status or some kind of trendy social disease, with an influential support group, serious inequalities remain. Just as the only people you can make fun of anymore are (thin) WASP guys, the only people on the consumer end of the fashion biz who get no respect, no guide books, no counseling, are those wretched women who weren't, like their popular sisters, born to shop.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Taking On A Legend

title: Quick Escapes
description: Northampton, Mass.

title: Hague Tribunal Hears Arguments on Exempting Reporters
description: Lawyers representing 34 news organizations appeared at the war crimes tribunal today, urging the court to drop its demand that a former war correspondent testify against his will, but the issue may have become moot because the reporter may no longer be called as a witness.

title: Sports of The Times; Empty Seats Don't Bother Braves' Bats
description: IT'S baseball's enduring embarrassment: Turner Field's empty seats.

title: Up-Tempo Style Suits Eisley's Game
description: It was a terrible season, the worst of his eight-year N.B.A. career. Howard Eisley, who had been a solid contributor on two Western Conference championship clubs in Utah and a part-time starter on a Dallas Mavericks playoff qualifier, could not find his niche last season on a Knicks team that won 30 games.

title: Six Area Coaches To Be Honored
description: Six New York-area high school coaches with a combined 185 years of coaching experience have been chosen to receive Frank McGuire awards. The awards, which honor the memory of the Hall of Fame basketball coach at St. John's, North Carolina and South Carolina, will be presented at the Frank McGuire Foundation's annual dinner Nov. 7 at the New York Athletic Club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEMER, MILDRED SIMON
description: RIEMER-Mildred Simon. On October 1 at 98. A graduate of NYU and Columbia University School of Social Work, she worked in children and family services in NY, Washington, DC, and Cleveland for 45 years. In 1994 she became a member of the National Women's Hall of Fame. Ever learning, always caring, she was a compassionate person enriching the lives of those who knew her. Beloved wife of the late Mortimer Riemer, adored by her daughters and sons-in-law, Susan and Sanford Sacks and Connie and Tom Forster, and late son Richard S. Riemer, and grandchildren Lauren and Steven Sacks, and David Dunston; brother Father Raphael Simon and sister-in-law and husband Irma and Max Wender. The family welcomes friends for Remembrance on Sunday, October 6 at 2 P.M. at the Classic Residence, 655 Pomander Walk, Teaneck, NJ. Contributions may be made to Teaneck Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERMAN, WILLIAM
description: BIERMAN - William. Town and Village Synagogue-Tifereth Israel mourns the loss of its beloved long-standing member and officer and extends heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert Cantor Shayna Smith Dr. Roselyn Kolodny, Pres.

title: What Exit Do We Take For This Fun?
description: THIS is not an easy thing for a proud New Yorker to admit, but he has developed a severe case of New Jersey envy. Never mind all those lame jokes about toxic waste dumps, turnpike crazies and the Bada Bing. New Jersey is where it's happening.

title: Barry Zito: A Lefty's Lefty
description: When Barry Zito was born 24 years ago, his mother immediately noticed the large, dark birthmark just above his left wrist. She took it as an omen that her son would do something very special with that arm.

title: Death Penalty Allowed in 2nd Trial of Rabbi
description: A New Jersey appeals court ruled yesterday that state prosecutors could seek the death penalty against a Cherry Hill rabbi now awaiting a second trial on charges of hiring a friend to murder his wife in 1994.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPREN, SAMUEL M.
description: HALPREN-Samuel M. October 2, 2002, of Wynnewood, PA. Husband of Sylvia (nee Lubeck), father of Bruce (Diane) Halpren and Bennett Halpren. Grandfather of David (Corinne) Halpren and Michael Halpren. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Friday 1:30 PM at the Har Jehudah Cemetery, 8400 Lansdowne Ave., Upper Darby, Pa. The family will return to the residence of Mr. & Mrs. Bruce Halpren and respectfully request that contributions in his memory be made to a charity of the donor's choice. Joseph Levine & Son. www.levinefuneral.com

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: American Envoy Arrives
description: The assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, James Kelly, arrived in Pyongyang on the highest-level American mission since the final weeks of the Clinton administration. He met with Kang Sok Ju, first deputy foreign minister, who represented the North in talks with the Clinton administration. Details of the talks were not disclosed. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the announcement of a closing date of March 15, 2003, for the long-running musical ''Les Misrables'' misstated the period in which it is set. It depicts the French student uprisings of 1832 and the years leading up to them, not the French Revolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALTROW, BRUCE
description: PALTROW - Bruce. The Trustees, staff and artists of the Williamstown Theatre Festival are profoundly saddened by the loss of Bruce Paltrow. As a writer and director, Bruce demonstrated wit, grace and a passion to raise the stakes. Around the festival, he was a perpetual source of humor and warmth. He inspired us to greater achievement. Our heartfelt condolences to Blythe, Gwyneth and Jake. Ira S. Lapidus, President Michael Ritchie, Producer

title: Tolerance Plea Is Stirring Contention
description: On Monday, the American Jewish Committee will release a statement calling for ''intimidation-free'' campuses, signed by more than 300 university and college presidents.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Accused Of Assault
description: A suspended city police officer was indicted yesterday on charges of assault and criminal possession of a weapon. Prosecutors say the officer, Charles Dorcent, was captured on videotape this summer hitting a handcuffed man in the mouth with a police radio. The videotape was made by an acquaintance of the victim, Anthony Carty, who was arrested on Aug. 11 as the police tried to break up a fight on the edge of Prospect Park. If convicted, Mr. Dorcent could face up to seven years in prison. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Palestinian Urges Defiance; Plan to Grab Arafat Reported
description: Marwan Barghouti, a rising Palestinian leader on trial in Israel on charges of terrorism, today called on Palestinians throughout the West Bank to defy Israeli curfews, and an Israeli newspaper reported that the army has rehearsed an operation to snatch and deport Yasir Arafat.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Woman Is Fatally Shot Outside Her House in Brooklyn
description: A 50-year-old Brooklyn woman returning home from work was fatally shot in the driveway of her home on Wednesday by a tenant who had just argued with her son, the police said yesterday.

title: AIDS as a Threat to Global Stability
description: The AIDS epidemic is a humanitarian catastrophe. But as the virus spreads insidiously around the world, it is becoming something else -- a threat to global and regional stability, because of its potential to disrupt the economic, political and military structures of key countries.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Belterra Casino Resort, Vevay, Ind., to Schadler Kramer Group Advertising, Las Vegas, as its agency of record. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. Belterra, which had no previous agency of record, is part of Pinnacle Entertainment.

title: Pakistanis Test Ballistic Missile
description: Pakistan successfully test-fired its Shaheen-1 medium-range ballistic missile today, state television reported, the fourth in a series of tests since late May.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Commuter Wins $4.7 Million Award
description: A passenger who suffered permanent memory loss when she was hit in the face by a steel rod that smashed through a window of the commuter train she was riding has been awarded $4.7 million in damages. A Hudson County jury on Tuesday ordered New Jersey Transit to pay the passenger, Okhee Lee, 56, for lost wages and pain and suffering. The woman's husband was awarded $675,000 for loss of marital relations, their lawyers said. Ms. Lee, who was injured in 1998 on the Morris and Essex Line, has permanent memory and sensory loss and will never work again as a neurology nurse, her lawyers said. New Jersey Transit did not immediately return a call for comment. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: PENNSYLVANIA: OPPOSITION TO MOVING ART

title: CHIEF QUITS AT INSTINET'S ELECTRONIC TRADING UNIT
description: Island ECN, the electronic stock trading unit of Instinet, said yesterday that its president and chief executive, Matthew Andresen, had quit to become head of global trading at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Will Sterling, Island's chief technology officer, replaced Mr. Andresen as president, the company said. Instinet, an electronic trading network, completed its $568 million purchase of Island last month. Mr. Andresen, 32, helped form Island in 1997 when it was part of Datek Online Holdings.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Kosovo Refugees Sent Home
description: Under a new policy intended to reduce the number of refugees in the country, 42 ethnic Albanians from Kosovo who had sought asylum were sent home. The Interior Ministry said that the group, mostly young men, had withdrawn their applications for asylum and that their departure was voluntary. According to the ministry's directives, people judged by the authorities to have no prospect of asylum will be denied board and lodging in refugee centers. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, DEBRA S.
description: NEWMAN-Debra S. Tragically in St. Louis on October 1, 2002. Struck down in the prime of her life, Debra touched the lives of all she came in contact with. Born on June 13, 1980 to her proud and loving parents, Howard and Ann (Solomon) Newman. Debra graduated from Ethical Culture School in Riverdale, Hastings - on - Hudson High School, Cornell University School of Industrial Relations and was a 1L Student at Washington University in St. Louis. Debra leaves behind her loving parents, loving grandfather Louis Solomon and dear aunt Sharon Solomon. Memorials may be made to the Debra S. Newman Memorial Fund, C/O Temple Beth Shalom, 740 Broadway, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. 10706.

title: Tax-Plot Case Against Executive Is Tightening
description: Prosecutors in the city tax corruption scandal are tightening their case against Albert Schussler, an 86-year-old executive who investigators say was the mastermind behind a long-running bribery scheme in which he paid city employees to lower tax bills for his clients, some of the most wealthy and powerful real estate barons in Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Rutgers Stops Search
description: Rutgers University suspended its search for a new president and named a former administrator as acting president while it studies a merger with two other large schools that would significantly expand the president's responsibilities. Rutgers' board of governors yesterday named a former administrator, Norman Samuels, above, 65, who had been provost of Rutgers' Newark campus for 20 years, as interim president, effective Monday. On Tuesday, a report is due on the proposed merger of Rutgers with the New Jersey Institute of Technology and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. Francis L. Lawrence resigned as president of Rutgers in February to return to teaching.

title: The Stones of Baghdad
description: From their perch in Washington, President Bush and his advisers seem to have convinced themselves that an invasion will proceed easily because many Iraqis will dance in the streets to welcome American troops. That looks like a potentially catastrophic misreading of Iraq.

title: Six Finalists Are Selected for Design at Pentagon
description: The competition to design a memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the Pentagon has been narrowed to six finalists, officials of the Army Corps of Engineers said today.

title: Review/Fashion; Ah, Paris: Substance at Long Last
