description: To look at John Galliano's Dior show today was to imagine how Mr. Creosote, the engorged Monty Python diner, felt before he consumed his last bite. Everything was blown up, from the models' Kewpie-doll eyelashes to the gold buckles that spelled out DIOR across their half-naked bottoms. Not another morsel could be added to this fashion orgy. Then Mr. Galliano came out in an explosion of gold confetti, blasted in the direction of his audience.

title: New Roads in Old Country
description: You can never tell how Neko Case is going to sing a note. Sometimes she drops into it from above, as if she were playing a game. Sometimes she creeps up from below, exploiting the unsettling effect of dissonance. And sometimes she hits the note square and holds it, waiting for the suspense to build.

title: Trying to Add Pitching to the Duel
description: The first two games of this American League division series have had everything. Power and pinball. Injuries and intrigue. Comebacks and controversy. The Yankees and the Anaheim Angels seem to bring out the best in each other, but something is missing.

title: Two Czech migrs Who Try to Go Home Again
description: IGNORANCE

title: Twilight of the French Aristocracy and of a Reigning Tenor
description: The late sunlight falling across the stage illuminated the twilight of a regime. Two twilights, even. One was that of the French aristocracy, overthrown by the revolution in Giordano's ''Andrea Chnier,'' which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening. The late sun lights Act II of Nicolas Jol's 1996 production.

title: Who Says We Never Strike First?
description: In 1587, as Philip II massed a formidable fleet for the invasion of England, Queen Elizabeth did not wait to be attacked. Sir Francis Drake launched a pre-emptive assault and destroyed part of the Armada while it was still anchored in Cdiz. Partly as a result, England won a famous victory the following year.

title: Leaders of U.N. Weapons Inspection Teams Agree to Delay Their Return to Iraq
description: The leaders of United Nations weapons inspections teams, responding to intense pressure from the United States and Britain, said today that they would delay their return to Iraq until the Security Council gives them new instructions to guide their work.

title: Companies Gave to Pataki; State Aid Came Their Way
description: In the fall of 1997, five executives from Corning, the upstate New York manufacturer, made $17,000 in contributions to Gov. George E. Pataki's 1998 re-election campaign.

title: Senator Insists C.I.A. Is Harboring Iraq Reports
description: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee asserted today that the Central Intelligence Agency was cutting Congress off from information it needed to carry out its constitutional role as the nation decided whether to wage war against Iraq.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Scorpion King

title: Japan's invisible revolution
description: TOKYO  For all their dedication and commitment to fashion, it's only in the last decade or so that Tokyo women have added lingerie to their shopping lists. History, or lack thereof, has much to do with this.

title: TRIALS ARE HALTED ON A GENE THERAPY
description: Officials in the United States and France said today that they had suspended four gene therapy experiments because the treatment, which cured a 3-year-old boy of a fatal immune deficiency, may have given him an illness similar to leukemia.

title: Blix Prefers New Resolution Before Sending Team to Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 - The chief United Nations weapons inspector, Hans Blix, today endorsed the main demand of the United States that Iraq make a full declaration of its weapons programs before inspections resume.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Veritas Executive Quits Over Phantom M.B.A.
description: Veritas Software said yesterday that Kenneth E. Lonchar had resigned as executive vice president and chief financial officer after the company learned that he had ''misstated'' his educational credentials. Veritas, a maker of storage-management software, said Mr. Lonchar had falsely claimed to have an M.B.A. from Stanford University. ''While Ken's misstatement about his academic credentials is unfortunate, it has no bearing on the accuracy of our financial results or the quality of our financial procedures and controls,'' said Gary Bloom, the chairman, president and chief executive. Mr. Lonchar said he thought his resignation was in the best interests of all. Jay A. Jones, senior vice president and chief administrative officer, is now the acting chief financial officer. Shares of Veritas, based in Mountain View, Calif., slid following the news. They fell 19.1 percent, or $2.77, to $11.73, in early trading on the Nasdaq.

title: John Morris -- 'Drawings for the Austrian School'
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: Former New Jersey Official Admits Extorting Bribes
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive and one of New Jersey's top Democrats until he abruptly resigned a year ago and dropped out of sight, resurfaced today in a federal courtroom here, where he pleaded guilty to extortion and confirmed long-whispered rumors that he had been a government informer in other corruption investigations.

title: LAWMAKERS BEGIN PUSH TO GIVE BUSH AUTHORITY ON IRAQ
description: Congress began its push today toward granting President Bush the authority to use force against Iraq. An outnumbered but determined group of Democrats and some Republicans tried to buck the bipartisan sentiment to give Mr. Bush broad discretion to initiate military operations against Saddam Hussein.

title: Fixing the Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein did yesterday what many new, determined chancellors have done before: with great flourish, he announced a plan to study the school system and figure out, with the help of paid consultants, ways to make it better.

title: Millwood Helps Braves Draw Even With Giants
description: The blister could not have been better timed. Because Greg Maddux's right index finger had not healed sufficiently from the injury that has plagued him for two weeks, the Braves had to restructure their playoff rotation on Wednesday.

title: State Senator's Role in Grants Is Said to Be Before Grand Jury
description: Prosecutors here are conducting a grand jury investigation into State Senator Pedro Espada Jr.'s attempt to award $745,000 in no-bid state grants to a social service group he heads, officials involved in the inquiry said today.

title: Missing Voices In Debate on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Feuds, Food And Feudalism

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISS, SYLVIA
description: EISS-Sylvia. Mohegan Park Jewish Center mourns the passing of our devoted member and wife of our past president, Abe Eiss. Sylvia was the first lady of MPJC. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ALEX Z.
description: FRIEDMAN-Alex Z. Husband of Beverley. Father of Laurie and Paul Korngold. and Andrew. Pop to Adam and Evan Korngold. On September 29, 2002. Services 12 Noon, Friday, at Riverside Mount Vernon.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a bomb that killed an American soldier in the Philippines referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of American casualties there since the United States began sending troops to fight terrorism. The soldier was the 11th American serviceman to die, not the first; 10 were killed in a helicopter crash in February.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Nuclear Stockpiles
description: To the Editor:

title: American Who Served Taliban Sentenced to 20 Years in Prison
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Oct. 4 — A federal judge here sentenced John Walker Lindh to 20 years in prison today under a plea agreement in which Mr. Lindh admitted that he had served with the Taliban in Afghanistan and had carried a rifle and grenades.

title: Former Churches: A Home on God's Little Half-Acre, Loft Included
description: WHO: Pamela Morin, a designer, and Navin Sharma, who owns a database marketing consulting company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, HON. WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Hon. Walter H. Yeshiva University and its Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourn the passing of a dear friend and esteemed honorary member of AECOM's Board of Overseers. One of America's foremost philanthropists, he was a major Benefactor, both of AECOM and YU. He was among the handful of forward - looking personalities who encouraged the establishment of our medical school while it was still in the planning stages, and was one of the first members of its Society of Founders. He was named to the AECOM Board in 1954, a year before the medical school opened, and served with distinction until his death. An honorary alumnus of Yeshiva University, Walter Annenberg remained a staunch supporter and dedicated leader throughout his lifetime, continuing to divide his munificent support between AECOM and other schools of YU. He will be sorely missed, and his memory will be recalled with abiding reverence and gratitude. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Leonore, and to his entire family. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Robert A. Belfer, Chairman AECOM Board of Overseers Dr. Dominick P. Purpura The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean AECOM

title: Editorial Observer; Drivers, TiVos and Other Conundrums of the Digital Age
description: Technology and I are at our wits' end, our marriage on the rocks. I yearn for smarter electronic gadgets that will enable me to fulfill my potential. Meanwhile, my home is filled with gadgets yearning for a smarter master to enable them to fulfill their own potential. It's an awkward state of affairs.

title: Nepalese King Fires Prime Minister and Seizes Power
description: NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 4  The king of Nepal removed the country's elected prime minister tonight, seized power and postponed elections scheduled for next month, setting the stage for a political crisis in an impoverished Himalayan nation already beset by a Maoist insurgency.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Gannett Buys Interest In CareerBuilder
description: The Gannett Company in McLean, Va., has bought for $98.3 million a one-third interest in CareerBuilder, an online job search site that had been jointly owned by Knight Ridder and the Tribune Company.

title: Priests Seek to Assert Rights and Fight Church Abuse Policy
description: Venting feelings of anger, betrayal and sadness, Roman Catholic priests from across the New York metropolitan area formed a group yesterday to assert their rights in the face of strict new sexual abuse policies by the nation's bishops.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Governor Signs Lending Bill
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday signed New York's first law against predatory lending, or offering home loans with high costs and interest that borrowers cannot afford. Many people with poor credit buy homes with such loans and are forced into foreclosure or repeated refinancing, paying high fees each time. Consumer advocates who argued for the law said only two other states, Georgia and North Carolina, had rules as strict. Some lenders and financial-services companies that invest in mortgages lobbied against it. The law makes certain lending practices illegal and, under some circumstances, allows borrowers to claim predatory lending as a defense in court against foreclosure. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Revamping Operations
description: Nortel Networks said yesterday that it was revamping its operations in an effort to increase efficiency at a time when sales are declining. The company, based in Brampton, Ontario, is splitting its main unit, which makes equipment for large phone companies, into two divisions, one focusing on gear for communications systems in urban areas and the other on servicing large clients. Nortel also said that the unit's previous president, Frank Plastina, had left the company after 15 years. Nortel and competitors like Lucent Technologies and Alcatel of France are struggling with a slump in spending on network investments by large telephone companies. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Maine Race Is Focused On Region, Not on Iraq
description: For all the talk in Washington about war with Iraq, some Congressional races out in the country are focused on local issues and the economy. One is here in Northern Maine's Second District, where it did not take the latest recession to put people out of work.

title: Held in a Fatal Beating, Boys Express Their Sorrow
description: The children and young men who kicked and beat Charles Young Jr. to death with baseball bats, bricks, poles and shovels on Sunday said afterward that they were sorry he was dead. They told the police they did not think they had hurt him that badly.

title: Warren Buffett Moves to Help Group Trying to Reduce Nuclear and Biological Threats
description: In a small but significant philanthropic gesture, Warren E. Buffett is opening his huge wallet to help support a group founded by Ted Turner and former Senator Sam Nunn whose aim is to reduce the threat of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.

title: Soriano Will Play Despite Being Hit
description: Troy Percival did not hit a batter all season until his first-pitch fastball drilled Alfonso Soriano in the shoulder blade in the eighth inning of Game 2 on Wednesday. Soriano laughed when he learned of this today. ''I'm not lucky,'' he said.

title: Alison Smith; Ellen Altfest
description: Bellwether

title: A Mullinski as Mastermind Of a Heist That's a Bellini
description: ''Welcome to Collinwood'' is a chipper little picture about a motley crew of lovable criminals involved in a complicated, lucrative heist. This is not a genre niche that was exactly crying out to be filled, but it's the kind of story some people, filmmakers especially, can never get enough of. Last year, Stephen Soderbergh and George Clooney scored big with a pleasantly witty remake of ''Oceans Eleven,'' and now they have teamed up to produce ''Collinwood,'' an enjoyably half-wit remake of the venerable Italian comedy ''Big Deal on Madonna Street'' (which also inspired the first half of Woody Allen's ''Small Time Crooks,'' among others).

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: NURSING INFANT HAS WEST NILE The infant son of a Michigan woman whose breast milk showed traces of West Nile virus has the virus, almost certainly transmitted from his infected mother, federal health officials said. The child is healthy and his mother, who is believed to have been infected by a blood transfusion, is recovering, the officials, from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said. Doctors emphasized that breast milk is the healthiest food for babies and that mothers should not quit nursing because they fear transmitting the West Nile virus. (AP)

title: Turkey Drops Death Sentence for Kurd
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 3 (AP)  Turkey today formally commuted the death sentence of Abdullah Ocalan, the Kurdish rebel leader, to life in prison. Two months ago, Parliament abolished capital punishment as part of Turkey's bid to join the European Union. Turkey has not executed anyone since 1984.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHWALD, GERALD M.
description: HOCHWALD - Gerald M., MD. Died September 29, 2002. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of the NYU School of Medicine and the Members of the Department of Neurology mourn the loss of our friend and colleague Gerald M. Hochwald, MD, Professor of Neurology. A distinguished member of the Department for more than 40 years, Dr. Hochwald achieved international recognition for the results of his laboratory studies in the cerebrospinal fluid system, which he and his neurosurgical colleagues at NYU applied in the development of new treatments for infantile hydrocephalus. During this time, he continued to serve as an Attending Neurologist on the wards of Bellevue Hospital, where in his later years, he faithfully conducted daily rounds despite the burdens of physical afflictions. His colleagues remember him for this gallantry and for his many contributions to the field of neurology and extend deepest condolences to his sons Burt, Steven and Neal. Edwin Kolodny, MD, Chairman and the Department of Neurology NYU Medical Center

title: First Meeting With Mediator Is Held in West Coast Port Dispute
description: The longshoremen's union and port operators held their first talks with a federal mediator today as more businesses complained of economic damage from a labor dispute that has shut 29 West Coast ports.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the selection of Arnold Worldwide as the agency for Boston Market, the restaurant chain owned by the McDonald's Corporation, cited two companies erroneously among participants in a two-month review for the assignment. The participants were Arnold and two other agencies -- Leo Burnett USA and Wieden & Kennedy. DDB Worldwide and Fallon Worldwide did not take part.

title: The Rhythm of Utah's Highway 12: Climb, Turn, Gasp
description: UTAH took nearly four decades to build all 122 miles of its Highway 12. Sporadically from the 1940's to the 1980's, construction crews blasted, cut and paved their way through rugged hills and cliffs. Initially, the road was built to move cattle, supplies and mail for the people in five small towns in the southern part of the state -- even now, their total population is less than 2,000. But when the last stretch, over the massive and heavily forested Boulder Mountain, was finally paved in 1985, it didn't take travelers (and tourism promoters) long to discover that this two-lane farm-to-market road was also the best tour of Utah's red-rock desert that can be taken in a short trip, a weekend or even a single day.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK: RUTGERS STOPS SEARCH

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: A False Alarm Calls R.A.F. Over London
description: After a passenger aboard a British Airways flight from Baltimore overheard what was taken to be a suspicious conversation between two other travelers, Britain ordered warplanes into the skies today to escort the Boeing 767 to its landing site at Heathrow.

title: Corrections
description: An article, a map and a picture caption in The Arts yesterday about the borough of Queens as an arts destination misstated the name of a museum housed there temporarily. It is the Museum for African Art, not the American Museum of African Art.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Michelin To Exchange Shares
description: Michelin, the largest tire maker in Europe, said it was offering to exchange shares in its Swiss-based finance unit for shares in the main company to simplify its finance structure. The company will offer 13 shares of group stock for every share of Compagnie Financire Michelin, a 23 percent premium to the average September trading price, the company said. Compagnie Financire Michelin raises money on the financial and capital markets and lends it to the Michelin group. The group already owns 93 percent of the share capital. The offer is available Oct. 17 to Oct. 30 and might be extended, the company said.

title: Gala Night for Barenboim
description: Carnegie Hall opened its season on Wednesday night with a concert by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Iberian themes. The orchestra's music director, Daniel Barenboim, above, both conducted and performed as piano soloist in a program of works by Falla and Ravel.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 5
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: I.R.A. Men Accused of Aiding Rebels to Go on Trial in Colombia
description: Three members of the Irish Republican Army charged with having taught bomb-making techniques to Colombian rebels go to trial Friday in a case that has become an embarrassment to the I.R.A.'s political wing, Sinn Fein, during a difficult stretch in the Northern Ireland peace effort.

title: Pact Reached On Disposal Of River Silt From Hudson
description: Ending two years of legal wrangling over dredging in New York's harbor, the Army Corps of Engineers has agreed to a compromise that allows a company to dredge PCB-laced silt from its docks on the Hudson River but not to dump the silt into the ocean.

title: DOVEBID, AN AUCTION HOUSE, HALTS INITIAL STOCK OFFERING
description: DoveBid, an auction house that conducted the bidding for Enron's tilted ''E'' logo last month, is scrapping a $60 million initial public offering, extending to 10 weeks the drought in initial public offerings. DoveBid, the second company to pull an offering in two weeks, had planned to sell six million shares at $8 to $10 each on Wednesday. It put off the sale as a slide in the Nasdaq composite index eroded demand for new shares. The Nasdaq is down 40 percent this year. ''We've had such a long I.P.O. drought that it's very hard for companies to come public right now,'' said Paul Bard, a senior analyst at Renaissance Capital's IPO Plus Aftermarket fund.

title: United Voice on Iraq Eludes Majority Leader
description: Like his party, Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, seems to be struggling to find his voice as the Senate begins its debate on Iraq.

title: Harris Wants To Finish With Nets
description: Lucious Harris, the Nets' backup shooting guard and a key component to the team's run to the N.B.A. finals last season, says he wants to finish his career in New Jersey. He expressed disappointment yesterday that the Nets did not offer him a contract extension over the summer. He is hoping they can reach an agreement before the end of the coming season.

title: Four Plead Guilty In Printing Fraud Cases
description: Four executives and former executives have pleaded guilty in the last week to charges stemming from a continuing investigation by the Justice Department of the print-production industry and advertising agencies.

title: Doing a Dance to the Death In a Victorian-Style Update
description: Few operas are as dominated by one character as Strauss's ''Salome.'' An intriguing production, a strong supporting cast and an orchestra capable of executing Strauss's glittering score can all contribute to a successful performance. But without the right soprano in the title role, the opera doesn't work.

title: 40 People Unknowingly Got Tissue or Organs From Donor With Hepatitis C; 5 Died
description: Forty people received tissue or organs from an Oregon man who died two years ago with an undiagnosed case of viral hepatitis that can spread chronic liver disease, state health officials say.

title: Missing Voices In Debate on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat's Sales Fall
description: Fiat's car sales in Italy fell for a ninth month in September as the company, the country's largest manufacturer, failed to attract buyers with price cuts and no-interest financing for models like the compact Stilo. Sales of the company's Fiat, Alfa Romeo and Lancia cars slipped 7.5 percent in September. Car sales for all manufacturers in the month rose 3.4 percent, the first gain this year. Fiat's market share fell to a record low of 28.7 percent in September from 32.1 percent a year earlier, the transport ministry said.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Sisterhood Of Sargents

title: Sports of The Times; Talent Is Not an Excuse For Today's Bad Behavior
description: As Latrell Sprewell misses his second training camp in four years, we will also miss another veteran. His name is Accountability. He is retiring after a long, distinguished multisport career.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Museum Director To Leave
description: The director of the Wadsworth Atheneum, Hartford's signature cultural institution, has announced plans to resign. Kate M. Sellers, who has been director for less than two years, was the first woman to head the museum. The trustees said they would seek a successor immediately. She told her staff on Wednesday that she would resign on Jan. 31. Ms. Sellers, 50, cited the terror attacks on Sept. 11 as a factor in wanting to move closer to relatives. Her decision could leave the museum leaderless in the middle of a $120 million building campaign. Built in 1842, the museum is home to a noted collection of Hudson River School paintings.

title: The Bob Crane Story, Everything But a Hero
description: ''Auto Focus,'' Paul Schrader's inquiry into the tawdry life and sordid demise of the 60's sitcom star Bob Crane, begins with a burst of rat-pack style: a Saul Bass-inspired title sequence, in eye-popping pastel, full of martini glasses, hi-fi turntables and buxom pin-ups, scored to a naughty little faux-Dino ditty sung by Buster Poindexter. The credits drop us down in the bright sunshine of Los Angeles in 1964, when Crane (Greg Kinnear) was a peppy radio host with a wife (Rita Wilson), three children, a loyal agent (Ron Leibman) and the ambition to be the next Jack Lemmon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PAUL
description: COHEN-Paul. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Mark and Judy. Dear brother of Bernard Cohen and Elayne Zabelin. Services today 12:15 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Allies Drop Leaflets Urging Iraqis to Hold Fire
description: Allied warplanes attacked an air-defense headquarters south of Baghdad today after Iraqi attempts to shoot down a plane dropping thousands of leaflets urging Iraqi gunners to stop firing at American and British jets, military officials said.

title: Americans Are Arrested, Accused in Plot Against U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 - Federal officials said today that they had broken up a terrorist cell in Portland, Ore., arresting four native-born citizens accused of plotting after the Sept. 11 attacks to join with Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in a ``jihad'' against the United States.

title: Alex Grey
description: Tibet House

title: Brazil's Presidential Vote Hinges on Debate's Result
description: With the latest polls showing the main opposition candidate for president, the leftist labor leader Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, just a hair's breadth from a first-round victory in Sunday's election, he and his three main rivals clashed sharply tonight during a potentially decisive televised debate.

title: ABC Family Offers Familiar ESPN Look
description: Watch the baseball division series games on ABC Family, and all you see is ESPN. On yesterday's St. Louis-Arizona game, it was ESPN's music (''Love Theme for Karl Ravech'') graphics, production and announcers. ESPN's Chris Berman, the game's play-by-play voice, is big but does not moonlight on ABC Family's ''Braceface.'' Yet.

title: Stories Reveal Violence Behind Formal Pictures
description: A picture is not worth a thousand words. In fact, a picture is not worth even one. Pictures tell a certain story, words tell another. Case in point: You would never know just from looking at Fazal Sheikh's gorgeous portraits what hideous things they conceal. The pictures are calm. The stories behind them are full of violence.

title: Bruce Paltrow, 58, a Producer And Director on 'St. Elsewhere'
description: Bruce Paltrow, a producer and director who strove to incorporate social themes into his television series, most notably ''The White Shadow'' and ''St. Elsewhere,'' died yesterday at a hospital in Rome while there to celebrate the 30th birthday of his Oscar-winning daughter, Gwyneth Paltrow. He was 58 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, JEANNE C.
description: MALONEY-Jeanne C. Of Delray Beach, FL and Rye, N.Y. Formerly of Bronxville, N.Y. Died October 3. She is survived by her eight children, Edward, Jr. of Greenwich, CT, Barbara of Washington, D.C., Jimmy of Kent, England, Peter of Westport, CT, Maureen Bowen of Greely, CO, Jeffery of Hartsdale, N.Y., Mari of N.Y.C., Tara Parsley of Granville, OH. She is also survived by nine grandchildren, four great grandchildren, a sister Ida McLean of Jupiter, FL. She was predeceased by her husband Edward F. Maloney, a grandson Edward F. (Teddy) Maloney III. Calling hours are Sunday 2-5PM at Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home in Bronxville. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 A.M., Monday at St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Disease.

title: Heading to Spain by Way Of the Chicago Symphony
description: Over the last few years Carnegie Hall has practically been Daniel Barenboim's home away from home. He was back on Wednesday night with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra to open the new season of Carnegie Hall in a gala program of music inspired by Iberia.

title: Closer Ties With China May Help U.S. on Iraq
description: After a stormy start, the Bush administration's relations with China have improved to the point where senior administration officials and many China experts say they think Beijing may agree not to block a tough United Nations resolution on Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARZ, ALBERT.
description: GARZ-Albert. Died October 1st, 2002, at the age of 93. A noted race car driver of years past, he was one of the founding members of the Jaguar Club of North America. He will be greatly missed. The Bordin Family

title: Albany Republicans Hint That Perennial Gay Rights Bill Finally Has a Chance
description: A gay rights bill that has been stuck in the Legislature for decades and that died again earlier this year has been brought back to life, with Republicans sending signals they are likely to vote on the measure after the Nov. 5 election.

title: Sales explode to cater to wahines and their wannabes : Surfwear's making a big splash
description: PARIS  California, the pioneer of skater chic and sophisticated sportswear, has now sent out a tsunami of trendy surfwear for women. When most people think about women surfing, images of the 1960s Gidget films and Annette Funicello, the star of "Beach Blanket Bingo," come to mind  with men wearing wigs to double as the female stars for the necessary surfing shots.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: FIAT' S SALES FALL Fiat's car sales in Italy fell for a ninth month in September as the company, the country's largest manufacturer, failed to attract buyers with price cuts and no-interest financing for models like the compact Stilo. Sales of the company's Fiat, Alfa Romeo and Lancia cars slipped 7.5 percent in September. Car sales for all manufacturers in the month rose 3.4 percent, the first gain this year. Fiat's market share fell to a record low of 28.7 percent in September from 32.1 percent a year earlier, the transport ministry said. (Bloomberg News)

title: Regulators Unite to Press for Change in Wall Street Practices
description: Scrambling to restore investor confidence in Wall Street, the nation's top securities regulators and the New York attorney general said yesterday that they were working together to bring a swift end to their investigations into anti-investor conduct at brokerage firms.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: AES SAYS IT PLANS TO REFINANCE $2 BILLION IN DEBT
description: The energy company AES announced a refinancing plan yesterday to push back the maturities of more than $2 billion in debt over the next year. AES, a major provider of electricity in the United States, Britain and Latin America, opened a $1.6 billion secured credit facility to replace bank debt expiring next year and made an offer to exchange $500 million in bonds coming due over the next eight months for cash and new secured three-year notes. ''This will provide them with some breathing room,'' said a Fitch Ratings analyst, Mona Yee, adding that the company's ratings outlook may stabilize if the financing efforts are successful.

title: Authors, Take Note
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurricane Hits Gulf Coast, Weakened but Still Punishing
description: Hurricane Lili slammed into Louisiana today with tornado-force winds that ripped trees from the ground, smashed mobile homes and caused widespread blackouts that may last for weeks.

title: Jim Shaw; Iran do Esprito Santo; Alex Grey
description: Jim Shaw

title: Partners Promise New Tests of Cancer Drug
description: ImClone Systems and Bristol-Myers Squibb, under criticism from cancer patients for not moving swiftly enough, said yesterday that they would soon begin several clinical trials aimed at winning approval for their cancer drug, Erbitux. By the end of the year, they said, they also hope to begin a program to provide the drug to desperately ill cancer patients who are not in a trial.

title: An Egg-Wich in the Easter Basket
description: EVERY family has its traditions, particularly around holidays. Every couple has its traditional negotiation of the traditions. Frequently, in the stripe between negotiation and celebration, a third ritual is born: the Ritual of Getting There.

title: Conseco's Troubles Outlast Reign of a Would-Be Savior
description: Gary C. Wendt, the former General Electric executive who was hailed as a savior when he was hired to run Conseco, announced yesterday that he was stepping down as chief executive of the troubled financial services company. He said he would stay on as chairman, however.

title: Authorities in China Detain Millionaire
description: The Chinese police detained Yang Bin, a flamboyant Chinese multimillionaire appointed by North Korea to run a new capitalist enclave, shortly before he was scheduled to cross China's border with North Korea to inspect the new zone he is to rule as governor.

title: A Landlubber Whose Mind Is on the Harbor
description: SORRY ferry fans. Alan Olmsted, the man at the helm of New York City's effort to revive river commuting, is not a ferryboat kind of guy.

title: China Seizes Entrepreneur Named to Run North Korea Enclave
description: The Chinese police today detained Yang Bin, a flamboyant Chinese multimillionaire appointed by reclusive North Korea to run a new capitalist enclave, shortly before he was scheduled to cross China's border with North Korea to inspect the new zone he would rule as governor.

title: 1999 Transaction With Enron Keeps Dogging Merrill Lynch
description: The pressure is rising for Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Telecom Share Sale Canceled
description: Taiwan scrapped plans to sell a $1.6 billion stake in the island's No. 1 telephone company, the Chunghwa Telecom Company, to overseas investors this year after its shares fell to half the level of their initial public offering two years ago. The government, which has succeeded in selling only 5 percent of the former monopoly after six attempts in two years, planned to sell a 12 percent stake to help pay for a budget shortfall. ''We won't be able to go for it this year,'' said Shen Fu-Fu, a Chunghwa Telecom spokeswoman. The shares sold for 104 Taiwan dollars in October 2000 and closed yesterday at 47.6 Taiwan dollars.

title: Others Say It's Common To Do What McCall Did
description: Over the past week, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, said repeatedly that he had done nothing wrong by writing letters on official letterhead stationery seeking jobs for his family members. On Wednesday, he released 61 letters showing that he had passed along rsums for people from all walks of life. ''Most public officials do this,'' said Mr. McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor.

title: S.E.C. Chief Hedges on Accounting Regulator
description: Harvey L. Pitt, under pressure from Republicans and former clients in the accounting profession, is backing away from the choice he and other members of the Securities and Exchange Commission favored to lead the new federal agency that will oversee the industry.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Reinvigorating A Country Show

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. The Board of Directors and staff of the French-American Foundation express their great sadness at the passing of their distinguished friend, Board member and former president. Few people have done more in their lives to strenghten the ties between France and the United States. He was a man of great dignity, intelligence and generosity who will be missed by all of us. We offer our deepest sympathy to Liliane and to all of his family. Michael Patterson, Chairman Anthony A. Smith, Presient

title: Excerpts of Speeches Made on Senate Floor Regarding Resolution on Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from speeches yesterday by Senators Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, and Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, about the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Their remarks were addressed to the president pro tem of the Senate.

title: A Passion for Collecting And Sharing the Bounty
description: Art collecting, as someone said, is a form of enlightened opportunism. It's also an addiction. Unless you happen to be Peter the Great, with a taxable empire at your command, you have to strategize pretty carefully -- meaning, use your brains -- about what you pick up, how much you pay and where your shopping is taking you.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex and the College Newspaper; Student Columnists Explore a Familiar Campus Topic
description: It wasn't Natalie Krinsky's idea. But the editors at The Yale Daily News were sure she would be a natural: She was a good writer. She was funny. But most of all, she was not easily embarrassed.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Theme Park President Resigns
description: The president of Universal Studios Japan resigned to take responsibility for a series of scandals that have crippled the movie theme park. The executive, Akira Sakata, left, will be succeeded by Shin Sasaki, the former deputy mayor of Osaka, the park's largest shareholder. The number of visitors to the park has fallen 30 percent since this summer, when reports surfaced that expired food was being served, a fountain was connected to an industrial water supply and inordinate amounts of explosives were on hand for fireworks displays.

title: 36 Hours | Asheville, N.C.
description: ALTHOUGH Asheville sits in a valley by the north-flowing French Broad River, mountain peaks in variegated shades of blue are visible from nearly every corner, and mountain breezes cool the narrow streets. This city is home to passionate kayakers, climbers and mountain bikers, and black fleece is considered formalwear. Also well represented among the 69,000 residents are country club golfers, New Age healers, professed anticorporate anarchists, and gay and lesbian refugees from the small-town South. A little more than a century ago, the New York aristocrat George Vanderbilt brought hundreds of artisans here to build himself a castle, inspiring a taste for decorative architecture. The Art Deco buildings erected in the 1920's and early 1930's were never replaced by more modern structures, and their restoration continues. When walking around Asheville, you can never predict which era will dominate the next block. SUSAN BRENNA

title: Disney and DVD Hit a Milestone
description: It was the "last of the red-hot fairy tales," says Don Hahn on a new DVD of "Beauty and the Beast," to be released Tuesday by Disney. Mr. Hahn, the film's producer, then ticks off three predecessors: "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs," "Cinderella" and "Sleeping Beauty." By 1959 Disney had bagged all three for animated features, but for various reasons the studio had held off on "Beast." The right opportunity didn't jell until the late 80's, about the time of "The Little Mermaid" (1989), the first of the studio's new wave of animated films that appealed to older audiences as well as children.

title: Joe Drape's Top Matchups
description: Stanford (1-2)

title: Random Shootings Kill 5 in Washington Suburbs
description: Five people were killed at random Wednesday night and this morning across the northern suburbs of Washington, shot on quiet streets in separate attacks by what the police described as a skilled single-shot gunman who was still at large today despite an intense manhunt.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRELLBERG, MILDRED
description: KRELLBERG-Mildred. On October 2, 2002. Former resident of 200 West 108th St., NYC. Devoted wife of the late Sherman. Funeral service Sunday 12 noon at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 E. 87th St. NYC. Interment private.

title: Web Article Is Removed; Flaws Cited
description: The online magazine Salon has removed an article charging Thomas E. White, secretary of the Army, with participating in accounting practices that led to the collapse of Enron while he was vice chairman of Enron Energy Services.

title: Democrats' Ad Has Bush Mistreating Elderly
description: The image is stark. A cartoon rendition of President Bush saying, ''Trust me,'' as he shoves two people in wheelchairs down the jagged line of a chart. As the two figures tumble along the zigs and zags, a narrator describes Mr. Bush's proposal to permit the investment of retirement funds in the stock market as a threat to Social Security, noting how much the market has declined over the past two years.

title: Iran do Esprito Santo -- Parallel Reality
description: Sean Kelly Gallery

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about ''Leadership'' by Rudolph W. Giuliani and ''Worth the Fighting For'' by Senator John McCain misstated the title of another book by Mr. McCain. It is ''Faith of My Fathers.'' (''Flags of Our Fathers'' is a book by James Bradley about the World War II servicemen, including his father, who were photographed raising the flag on Iwo Jima.)

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: New Jersey's Poet Dilemma
description: You can't help wondering what the New Jersey committee that picked Amiri Baraka as state poet laureate was thinking. That he would dedicate himself to describing sunrises over Cape May? Offering tributes to state leaders?

title: Seeking Investment, Egypt Tries Patent Laws
description: As a high-level Egyptian delegation visits Washington this week to discuss increasing American direct investment in Egypt and bolstering the modest $3.1 billion in American-Egyptian trade, a battle is raging here over a new intellectual property rights law, which the United States had said was a prerequisite for a free-trade agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGEL, STANLEY M.
description: RIEGEL-Stanley M., age 76. Husband of Enid. Father of Norman and Edward. Grandfather of Michael, Joshua, Daniel, Tamar, Ian, Rachel and Lauren. On October 3. Services Friday, 12:15, at Sinai Chapel in Fresh Meadows. Burial to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery in Babylon.

title: Jarred by Noise, in So Many Ways
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: NURSING INFANT HAS WEST NILE

title: Bond Rally Makes a Case For Investing In Stocks
description: It no longer looks as if the Treasury market is the place to be.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Andreotti Trial Resumes
description: The trial of former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti on charges of colluding with the Mafia during his many years in office resumed in Palermo's appeals court after a summer recess. Mr. Andreotti, who served as prime minister seven times, skipped the hearing, choosing instead to take part in a Senate debate on Afghanistan. Mr. Andreotti, 83, was acquitted three years ago but prosecutors appealing that verdict are seeking a 10-year prison sentence. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: The Material Made Ethereal
description: AFTER four years of construction, the National Gallery of Art here has unveiled a stunning suite of renovated, redesigned and expanded sculpture galleries on the ground floor of its original West Building. Presenting some 800 objects spanning nine centuries in 22 beautifully proportioned and detailed rooms that total 24,000 square feet, these galleries are a sculpture lover's idea of heaven. That they are devoted predominantly to European sculpture from 1400 to 1900 is quite unusual, at least in this country.

title: Naming of New Police Chief Raises Minorities' Hopes
description: The nomination of William J. Bratton as police chief has raised tentative hopes among the city's minorities that what they call a pervasive culture of abuse will one day become a thing of the past.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a bomb that killed an American soldier in the Philippines referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of American casualties there since the United States began sending troops to fight terrorism. The soldier was the 11th American serviceman to die, not the first; 10 were killed in a helicopter crash in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, STEPHEN H.
description: FEINBERG-Stephen H. The Board of Managers and staff of Titan Outdoor and Outdoor Media Corp USA are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of Stephen H. Feinberg, our CEO and leader. Steve's dedication, commitment to excellence and love of life was a shining example that will endure in all of our hearts. He will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to his entire family. Board of Managers & Staff Titan Outdoor LLC

title: Central Bank Chides Koreans For Their Spendthrift Ways
description: As thousands of Korean consumers took advantage of the National Foundation Day holiday to swarm department stores today, the central bank railed against skyrocketing purchases of foreign luxury products, calling the buying a threat to economic well-being.

title: Executive Is Promoted to Chief of Frankel
description: Frankel in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe , said yesterday that Dick Thomas, 46, executive vice president, would be promoted to president and chief executive.

title: 3 Say a Brooklyn Principal Sent Sexually Explicit E-Mail
description: Three current and former teachers at Brooklyn Technical High School say the school's principal sent sexually explicit e-mail messages from his school computer to a group of school employees and others over nearly two years, from 1998 to 2000.

title: Those Great Movie Songs
description: Many witty songs have been written about Hollywood, but none has captured its loony magnetism with such an acute sense of the absurd as Richard Whiting and Johnny Mercer's barbed ode to Tinseltown, ''Hooray for Hollywood.'' And when the bluesy jazz singer Bill Henderson drawls out the line ''Go out and try your luck, you might be Donald Duck,'' then punctuates it with a ducklike squawk, the inspired lunacy of Mercer's lyric pops like a firecracker.

title: Text: Senator Carl Levin
description: CARL LEVIN (D - MICHIGAN). Mr. President, I come to the floor today to speak in support of an alternative resolution, which I will be introducing, and to explain why I believe it is the right way to go and is a better alternative than the White House approach.

title: Postal Worker Is Arrested After Shots At the U.N.
description: A postal worker protesting human rights abuses in North Korea jumped over the fence in front of the United Nations today and fired seven shots in the air and at the main tower before he was arrested by guards.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Units To Merge
description: Hitachi Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation will merge their high-end chip businesses next April. The new venture will produce large-scale integrated system chips used in many new electronic devices, including cellular phones. The new company will have a combined work force of 27,200 and aim for 900 billion yen ($7.3 billion) in sales by March 2004. Mitsubishi Electric also confirmed reports that its dynamic random access memory chip operations would be folded into Elpida Memory Inc., a joint venture of the NEC Corporation and Hitachi. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Text: Senator Jim Bunning
description: Mr. President, I rise in support of senate joint resolution 46 to authorize the use of United States Armed Forces against Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq.

title: INSIDE
description: S.E.C. Chief Reconsiders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, GERALD JOSEPH
description: HARVEY - Gerald Joseph. July 27, 1925-October 2, 2002. We mourn the loss of our loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. While we are deeply saddened, we are relieved that he no longer suffers. Jeff was a wonderful inspiration to those who loved him. His accomplishments include: Service in the U.S. Navy in WWII, a Bachelor's of Science Degree in Chemical Engineering from Tufts University, 50 years as Head of the Largest Testing Laboratory based in New York, Chairman of the American Society for Metals, L.I. Chapter, 1983-84, Chairman of the New York Chapter of the American Society for NonDestructive Testing. A world renowned disaster investigator he was also the author of numerous articles and holder of patents, including one of the first waste to energy systems ever developed. Gerald was the Chairman of two public companies which he launched, and was a pioneer in the environmental testing industry. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, children Karen, David and Beth, grandchildren Jessica, Halie, Julia, Mariel and Hunter, his sister and brother-in-law Betty and Robert Slegman of Shawnee Mission, KA, and brother and sister-in-law Roger and Ellen Harvey of Woodmere, NY. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 6, 2002, 9:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: YUGOSLAVIA: BOYCOTT COULD FORCE NEW VOTE The ultra-nationalist leader Vojislav Seselj urged his supporters to boycott the second round of Serbia's presidential election on Oct. 13, increasing the chance that the vote will be invalid. A turnout of at least 50 percent of all registered voters is required, and Mr. Seselj, left, finished third, with 23.2 percent of the vote, in the first round, when the turnout was 55.5 percent. President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia finished first with 30.9 percent and is facing Deputy Prime Minister Miroljub Labus in the run-off. If the turnout is under 50 percent, the law requires a new election.    (Reuters)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: META GROUP, Stamford, Conn., an information technology consulting firm, said it would buy an additional 40 percent of Meta Group, its unit based in Ismaning, Germany, for about $1.9 million, increasing its stake to about 96 percent.

title: Whats the Story?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Whisky A Go-Go
description: The artist Hope Atherton reinvents the salon.

title: Using a Peaceful Time to Reclaim a Painful Past
description: IN 1991, a band of artists, theater folk, a few children and an aged brown horse arrived here in a re-imagined Gypsy caravan. No one was sure what to make of them. But their leader, a man of quiet intensity named Krzysztof Czyzewski, remembers the locals' general reaction: ''The Jews are back.''

title: Defining Evil in The Wake Of 9/11
description: IT seems all too familiar: on a fall morning in a major city, civilization is disrupted. In less than a half-hour, buildings are destroyed, thousands are killed, the sky turns dark with dust. Philosophers and religious leaders invoke the concept of evil. Some blame the sinful behavior of the citizenry and cite divine retribution; others believe that civil society will soon restore itself.

title: In New Jersey Senate Race, Another Day Spent in Court
description: New Jersey Democrats asked the United States Supreme Court today to reject a Republican appeal seeking to block Frank R. Lautenberg from taking the place of Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the November ballot. They argued that the Republicans had neither shown any injury to their candidate or to the voters nor demonstrated a constitutional issue.

title: Bush Makes Rare Appearance in Politically Hostile Territory
description: President Bush made a rare visit today to one of the Democratic Party's biggest strongholds and raised a million dollars for Mitt Romney, arguing that the man whom he credited with saving the Olympics from bankruptcy could as governor save Massachusetts from fiscal disaster.

title: High School Should Not Have Banned 'Redneck' T-Shirt, Federal Court Says
description: A federal appeals court has ruled that a shirt featuring so-called redneck humor is protected by the First Amendment and should not have been banned by a rural New Jersey high school in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERIAN, PETER
description: TERIAN-Peter. The Parents, Teachers and staff of Park Avenue Christian Church Day School are deeply saddened by the death of Peter Terian. Devoted father of Olivia and beloved husband of Juliana Curran Terian. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KART, HAROLD
description: KART-Harold. You left us too soon. The years we spent together will be cherished forever. We will miss your smiling face and your practical jokes. We will miss your sincerity, honesty, generosity and loving friendship. Your love for your family and friends will be admired forever. You have left a void in our hearts. We love you and will surely miss you. Hold a spot for us at the first tee! Roberta and Richie

title: Lottery Profits and Tuition Aid
description: Tom Golisano, the New York Independence Party's self-financed billionaire candidate for governor, released this 30-second television ad on Wednesday, promoting a plan to use lottery money for college scholarships.

title: House and Senate Negotiators Agree on an Election Bill
description: House and Senate negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on a bipartisan bill to clean up the nation's voting procedures. Lawmakers said the measure would do more to protect the franchise than any law since the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEALCALA, BRUNETTA
description: deALCALA-Brunetta. Formerly of Glen Cove, NY, on October 1, 2002. Beloved mother of Brunetta Winthers, Christine Nagy and Donna and Joseph DeMatteo. Cherished Nanny Bruny to six grandchildren. Loving sister of Eleanor, Stella and the late Charles. Funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, on Saturday, October 5th, 10 AM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Women Playing for T.I.M.E., 1405 South Orange Ave., Suite 300, Orlando, FL. 32806, Attn: Zonetta Glenn.

title: Lindros Has 3 Goals In Return to Lineup
description: After missing four games with a hyperextended elbow, Eric Lindros returned to the Rangers' lineup last night and scored three goals, including the winner in overtime, in a 5-4 victory over the Florida Panthers in Sunrise, Fla.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: COLOMBIA: I.R.A. SUSPECTS DELAY TRIAL Three suspected members of the Irish Republican Army who are charged with having schooled Colombian rebels in bomb-making refused to attend the first day of their trial, throwing the proceedings into turmoil. The men told the judge in a letter that they could not attend because of political pressures, a reference to their claim that they cannot receive a fair trial. The trial was rescheduled for Oct. 16.    Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the resignation of Martha Stewart from the board of the New York Stock Exchange referred incorrectly to a line of furniture from her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia. It is not yet available and thus not being offered at Ethan Allen; no decision has been made on what retailers will carry it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERLINO, ANTHONY F.
description: MERLINO-Anthony F. On October 2, 2002. Of Pleasantville, N.Y. Husband of Jeanne, father of Frank and Maria. Grandfather of two and brother of Carmelo. Mass on Monday, at 10:30AM at Holy Innocents Church, Pleasantville. Reposing Saturday 7 to 9 and Sunday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at the Maher Funeral Home, Pleasantville. (914) 769-2044.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZ, JOHN
description: WEITZ-John. The directors, staff and residents of Phoenix House mourn the loss of a great spirit and good friend. A celebrated author, historian, designer and entrepreneur, John Weitz was an early supporter and longtime board member of Phoenix House. Committed to our work, he was a generous and imaginative benefactor, who shared with us his wit, elegance and humor, sense of style, and spirit of adventure. We will miss him. Edward D. Miller, Chairman George A. Kellner, Vice Chairman Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D. President

title: Excerpts From Senate Debate on Authorization to Use Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators Jim Bunning, Republican of Kentucky; Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan; George V. Voinovich, Republican of Ohio; Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts; and Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska.

title: Storm, Though Not a Killer, Leaves Big Mess in Louisiana
description: The troubles start on the mayor's desk, where there is a little dish of Chiclets, a ton of sticky notes and an empty plastic jug.

title: Chuck Howard, Ex-Designer, Is Dead at 75
description: Chuck Howard, one of the adventurous young designers who put a distinctly non-Parisian accent on American clothing in the 1950's and 60's, died on Monday at a hospital in Albuquerque. He was 75 and most recently lived in Santa Fe and on the island of Saba, in the Netherlands Antilles.

title: Gun Strategists Are Watching Brooklyn Case
description: A Brooklyn lawsuit has become a pivotal test that could affect civil suits against the gun industry nationally because the plaintiffs have, for the first time, obtained comprehensive government information tracing gun sales.

title: Guilty Plea in Airplane Plot
description: Admitting membership in Al Qaeda, Richard C. Reid pleaded guilty to charges of trying to blow up a flight in December with explosives hidden in his shoes. Page A11.

title: The Starters Keep Taking Early Showers
description: The Yankees' starting pitchers have shown a remarkable consistency in the division playoff series against the Angels. It's just not an admirable consistency.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: SWITZERLAND: CREDIT SUISSE ASSURANCES A 10 percent plunge that brought Credit Suisse's share price to its lowest point in nine years prompted the company to denounce the market action and deny that it had plans for a capital increase. The company said that it "is not aware of any objective reason prompting this development." It added, "The group's capital resources remain adequate, and as stated before, no capital increase of the group is planned." Credit Suisse shares tumbled after Standard & Poor's said on Thursday that it might downgrade the company's rating. The ratings agency said its move was based on Credit Suisse's injection of $1.35 billion into its Winterthur insurance unit. The company used its own liquidity for the insurer, but analysts fear Credit Suisse may now be forced to increase its own capital reserves.   Alison Langley (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Basically, I got on the plane with a bomb. Basically, I tried to ignite it. Basically, yeah, I intended to damage the plane.''

title: Manchester United Tour Set
description: Manchester United's first tour of the United States in more than 20 years will begin next summer with a game in Seattle on July 23 and end with a match at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Aug. 3.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jury Sets Punitive Damages At $28 Billion for Smoker

description: BASEBALL

description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. The Chapin School Community is deeply saddened by the death of Walter H. Annenberg, a Chapin grandfather and our school's friend and most generous benefactor. His many gifts to us include our spacious and beautiful library multimedia center, named in his honor. We extend our profound sympathy to his wife Leonore Annenberg, his step-daughter Elizabeth Kabler, Chapin Trustee, her daughter Elizabeth, Class of 2001 and the entire Annenberg family. Ella M. Foshay, Pres. of the Board of Trustees Cera B. Robbins, Trustee Emerita Sandra J. Theunick, Head of School

title: New Democratic Product: Campaign-in-an-Instant
description: To fully appreciate the tumult engulfing the Democratic establishment here, one need only visit the space that served as the re-election headquarters for Senator Robert G. Torricelli, until he dropped out of the race on Monday, and that now functions as the de facto command center for his replacement, former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg.

title: Chief U.N. Inspector Backs U.S., Demanding Full Iraq Disclosure
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspector, Hans Blix, today endorsed the main demand of the United States that Iraq make a full declaration of its weapons programs before inspections resume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CENEDELLA, ROBERT J.
description: CENEDELLA-Robert J. Age 90, on September 28, in Tucson. Husband of Betsy; father of Joan, Robert, Michael and Peter; grandfather of three. A much loved man. Contributions to The Actors Fund or Habitat for Humanity.

title: Steel-Beam Cross Considered for Memorial
description: A cross made of steel beams from the World Trade Center that has stood for a year at ground zero will be considered for inclusion in a permanent memorial to the victims of the attack on the World Trade Center, officials overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan said today.

title: Executive Is First Member To Back Women at Augusta
description: Cracking the code of silence among members of the Augusta National Golf Club, Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, offered his guarded support yesterday to the women's group that is pushing the club to admit women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGUET, SHEILA
description: HOGUET-Sheila, 78. Of New York City, died October 3rd. Survived by daughter, Denise, and son, Mark.

title: Masters of the Universe
description: The prime opinion-slinging show on Russian TV these days is called ''Svoboda Slova,'' ''Freedom of Speech.'' It's like ''Crossfire'' on steroids, with antagonists exchanging muscular polemics while a fever chart of audience opinion tells you who's winning the argument. The other day the subject was Iraq, and it was a depressing glimpse of how America looks these days from outside its sanctuary of self-absorption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLANTES, LORIAN L.
description: MARLANTES-Lorian L. The Board of Governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Lorian Marlantes. Lorian served on the Board of Governors with distinction from 1991 to 1997. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lorian's wife, children and the entire Marlantes family. Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President

title: Candidates in Tough Races Seem Mindful of Political Repercussions of Stance on Iraq
description: Representative Constance A. Morella, Republican of Maryland, is in a very close race for re-election. She is not rushing to embrace President Bush on his call to act against Iraq.

title: Outrage Over a Poet Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Sees Lower Operating Profit
description: The chairman of Bayer, Werner Wenning, warned that the company's operating profit would be lower this year compared with 2001, but reiterated net profits would be higher thanks to divestments of some 3 billion euros ($2.9 billion). In an interview with the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that appeared yesterday, Mr. Wenning said it was now correct to assume Bayer would not make up for its lower first-half operating profit in the second half. He added though that Bayer was sticking by its forecast of higher net profit this year, despite the ''volatility in the markets and the risks that exist at the moment for the world economy.'' In other news, it announced the sale of its rubber and plastics specialist supplier Rhein Chemie to a group of investors advised by Advent International of the United States for 215 million euros.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIEGEL, STANLEY M.
description: RIEGEL-Stanley M., age 76. Husband of Enid. Father of Norman and Edward. Grandfather of Michael, Joshua, Daniel, Tamar, Ian, Rachel and Lauren. On October 3.

title: JUDGE APPROVES RENT-A-CENTER SEX-BIAS SETTLEMENT
description: A federal judge approved a $47 million settlement of sex-discrimination lawsuits against Rent-A-Center Inc., the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said yesterday. The funds will be paid to women who were fired or forced out after Renter's Choice Inc. acquired the company in 1998, and to women who claimed they were demoted, denied promotions or sexually harassed. About 4,600 women who made such claims will receive payment, the commission said. The settlement also calls for Rent-A-Center to offer jobs to more than 1,100 women who claimed sex discrimination. Rent-A-Center is based in Plano, Tex.

title: A's Get Better of Metrodome's Quirks
description: Shortly before Game 3 of the American League division series today, Manager Art Howe of the Oakland Athletics complained about the Metrodome, the home of the Minnesota Twins. Like many in his sport, he dislikes the ceiling that makes it hard to see baseballs in flight, the artificial surface that makes them skip quickly along the ground and the reverberating noise that makes it difficult for players to communicate.

title: Football Is One of Madison's Interests
description: Here in the land of contentious government, where the student activism of the 1960's and 1970's evolved into a satiric comedy movement in the 1990's, where bratwurst and cheap brew thrive alongside a new wave music scene, one thing is terribly out of step in this vibrant capital and campus town.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUCKER, CLARISSA
description: TUCKER-Clarissa, December 14, 1910-August 4, 2002. Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. ''Omega Omega'' and Celebration of Life service on Sunday, October 6, 2002 at 3PM, Schomburg Center, West 135th St and Malcolm X Boulevard, New York City.

title: More Young Victims Falling On Front Lines in the Mideast
description: Fleeing a burst of gunfire from Israeli soldiers, a gaggle of Palestinian boys beat a hasty retreat to the Balata refugee camp today after surging toward an Israeli patrol, stones in hand, in defiance of a curfew.

title: Outrage Over a Poet Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Deal To Buy Littlewoods
description: David and Frederick Barclay, the millionaire British twins who own the Ritz Hotel in London, agreed to buy the closely held Littlewoods P.L.C. for 750 million ($1.2 billion) in cash. The company is Britain's No. 2 home-shopping business. The acquisition will take Littlewoods away from the Moores family for the first time since the company was founded by Sir John Moores as an operator of soccer betting pools in 1923. ''The Barclays like the business,'' said Simon Boadle, an adviser to the brothers, who also own newspapers. ''It's a very long-established, reliable business, has a good brand name and potential for growth.'' Littlewoods includes 170 Index catalog stores and 120 Littlewoods department stores across Britain. The Barclays plan to work with Littlewoods' management, led by the chief executive, Alistair McGeorge, to achieve growth, Mr. Boadle said.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Mining Law Is Signed
description: South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, signed into law the transfer of ownership of mineral deposits to the state from companies and said proposed legislation to increase black participation in mining was complete. The transfer of the world's biggest gold, platinum and chrome deposits to the state is part of the government's plan to increase black participation in the nation's biggest export industry. The targets for black participation in mining will be made public Wednesday, President Mbeki said. This is ''a very satisfactory compromise between the political ambitions of the government and commercial considerations,'' said Barry Davison, chief of Anglo American Platinum and president of South Africa's Chamber of Mines. President Mbeki said that owners of assets that are sold would be paid ''fair market value'' and that there would be no nationalization of assets.

title: 4 IN U.S. CHARGED IN POST-9/11 PLAN TO JOIN AL QAEDA
description: Federal officials said today that they had broken up a terrorist cell in Portland, Ore., arresting four native-born citizens accused of plotting after the Sept. 11 attacks to join with Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in a ''jihad'' against the United States.

title: Soul, Form and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Turk Van Lake -- Jazz Guitarist, 84
description: Turk Van Lake, a jazz guitarist and arranger of the swing era, died on Sept. 1 at a Staten Island nursing home. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHORN, HARRIET
description: STEINHORN-Harriet. Of Ellenville, New York and Aventura, FL., died October 2nd, 2002 in Port Chester, NY. She was the former owner and operator of the Grand Mountain Hotel in Greenfield Park, N.Y. She is survived by her loving daughter, Amy, & her husband, Brad Kreinces, one sister, Helen Haas, one brother, Howard Golden, and three adoring grandsons: Alex, Jason and Evan. Funeral and burial services were held on Thursday, October 3rd, in Ellenville, N.Y. ''She will always be in our hearts.''

title: The Script Gets Better as Willingham Faces His Old Team
description: Every now and then, Tyrone Willingham tosses his car keys to the side and plants himself on a mountain bike. From Juniper Road, which runs through the heart of the Notre Dame campus, he pedals past students and buildings that are no longer strangers to him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIGELMAN, JESSE
description: FEIGELMAN-Jesse. 10/5/70 to 7/12/02. To our Little Prince: you left too soon. We love you, your family

title: Progress Reported as Marathon Port Talks Roll On
description: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Port employers and union longshoremen on Saturday reported progress in marathon contract talks aimed at lifting the economically crippling lockout of U.S. Pacific ports, including an interim deal to resume cargo shipments to Alaska with Hawaii to follow.

title: Mentally Ill and Locked Away in Nursing Homes in New York
description: Hundreds of patients released from state psychiatric hospitals in New York in recent years are being locked away on isolated floors of nursing homes, where they are barred from going outside on their own, have almost no contact with others and have little ability to contest their confinement, according to interviews with workers and experts and visits to the homes.

title: The Dying Oaks of California
description: The forests and woodlands of America conceal a landscape of loss. The great elms and chestnuts are missing, lost in blights of the past. Hemlocks in the Northeast are under threat from the woolly adelgid, and environmental pressures are affecting other species as well. But the most volatile and in some ways most frightening scourge of trees at the moment is Sudden Oak Death, which has killed tens of thousands of oaks in coastal California in just a few years.

title: Health Aides To Get Raises And Benefits In Union Deal
description: The state's largest health care union has reached a tentative agreement with a company that employs 2,800 home health aides for higher wages and better benefits. It is the second such contract that the union, 1199/S.E.I.U., has negotiated in three weeks.

title: Some Urban Areas Find Ways to Grow
description: Despite the dearth of new jobs across much of the nation, some metropolitan areas around the country are growing again by selling themselves as lower-cost alternatives to more expensive cities.

title: Thanks to Angels, Yanks Are Facing an Early Exit
description: Darin Erstad loves all the red when the stands are packed at Edison Field. It reminds him of his days as a punter for the University of Nebraska, where he won a national championship. Erstad chose a baseball career and was sentenced to play for the Anaheim Angels, a franchise that has never won a playoff series. They are on the brink of doing that now, because the Yankees seem helpless to stop them.

title: Pentagon Report Based on Interrogation of Lindh
description: Following is a report from the Defense Department that is based on information from the interrogation of John Walker Lindh. It is in pdf format . Introduction

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dance review yesterday about Ronald K. Brown's ''Dancing Out the Dark'' misidentified the dancer who was paired with Diedre N. Dawkins in one passage. He was Mr. Brown, not Camille Brown. A picture caption with the review also misidentified a dancer. He was Arcell Cabuag; Daryl Spiers was barely visible behind another dancer.

title: Pataki Campaign Has 12 Times the War Chest McCall Has as the Race Winds Down
description: With 32 days until Election Day, H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, remains at a serious financial disadvantage. His rival, Gov. George E. Pataki, has 12 times as much money to spend in the final month of the campaign, according to documents filed yesterday.

title: Pursuing Two Love Affairs With Opposite Strategies
description: ''Turning Gate,'' a moody, elliptical reflection on missed romantic opportunities and fate, comes with two intriguing epigraphs: ''When people are free to do as they please, they usually imitate each other'' (Eric Hoffer), and ''Almost all absurdity of conduct arises from the imitation of those whom we cannot resemble'' (Samuel Johnson).

title: Seeking Campus Dialogue, Not Diatribe
description: Things got so bad at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor this spring that both Arab and Jewish students reported receiving death threats. In addition to the usual pro-Palestine and pro-Israel standoffs there, pro-Israel groups protested in March when students at a conference in support of Palestinian positions sold a book that called the Holocaust a myth.

title: Muslim Rebels Are Blamed For Bombing In Philippines
description: Two months after the United States ended a counterterrorism training mission in the Philippines by declaring that a band of Muslim guerrillas had been routed, the rebels have regrouped, and were probably responsible for an explosion on Wednesday that killed an American Green Beret, Pentagon and Philippine officials said today.

title: Belfast Police, in Unusual Move, Raid Sinn Fein Office and Homes
description: The police raided the legislative offices of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and the homes of party supporters in a series of operations across Belfast early this morning. Four people were arrested, and documents and computer disks were seized.

title: Student Drug Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Remember, Angels Have Passed This Way Before
description: EVERY year a segment of the baseball-loving world seeks a new contender, a team that will stand up to the Yankees and all their money.

title: Evangelical Figures Oppose Religious Leaders' Broad Antiwar Sentiment
description: Christian leaders and ethicists who represent a broad swath of the nation's Protestant, Catholic, Orthodox and African-American churches are speaking out against war with Iraq, a chorus of opposition that prompted five conservative evangelicals yesterday to announce their support for the president.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Portraits of Grief page on Dec. 15 included a biographical sketch of Juan Jose Borda Leyva, who was described as a 59-year-old Colombian immigrant missing since Sept. 11, 2001. It reported that he had left his mother's apartment saying he had a job interview at the World Trade Center.

title: Husband of a 9/11 Victim Is Told He'll Be Deported
description: When Vasiliy V. Ryjov lost his wife, Tatiana, in the World Trade Center attack, he was comforted by the knowledge that she would be honored in the country where they had struggled for so many years to build a life.

title: California Jury Allots Damages Of $28 Billion To Ill Smoker
description: A Los Angeles Superior Court jury awarded a staggering $28 billion in punitive damages to a smoker with lung cancer who accused Philip Morris Inc. of luring her into a lifelong tobacco habit with fraudulent advertising and marketing.

title: In Free-Market Slump, Brazil's Voters Look for Change
description: In each of Brazil's last two presidential elections, Ana Paula Borges voted for the government's candidate, swayed by promises of growth and stability. But after an eight-year experiment with free-market capitalism, the Brazilian economy has stalled, unemployment is climbing, the value of the national currency is sliding, and she is fed up.

title: Official Tells Catholics: Fight Abuse With Purse and Feet
description: Standing in this Boston suburb, at the epicenter of the sexual abuse scandal in the Roman Catholic Church, Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, chairman of a national board monitoring how the church handles the problem, did not mince many words.

title: Don't Bury West Street
description: In remaking Lower Manhattan, New Yorkers want to turn West Street, a busy thoroughfare that separates Battery Park City and the World Trade Center site, into a promenade.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KENNER, MORTON
description: KENNER-Morton. In loving remembrance of your Birthday, October 5. I miss you and love you every day. Edyth

title: Regretful Lindh Gets 20 Years In Taliban Case
