description: John Walker Lindh, the American who fought for the Taliban in Afghanistan, was sentenced to 20 years in prison today after sobbing through a 14-minute statement in which he repudiated terrorism, condemned Osama bin Laden and tried to explain why he joined the Afghan movement. But he stopped short of apologizing for anything other than causing his family so much pain.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: I.R.A. Suspects Delay Trial
description: Three suspected members of the Irish Republican Army who are charged with having schooled Colombian rebels in bomb-making refused to attend the first day of their trial, throwing the proceedings into turmoil. The men told the judge in a letter that they could not attend because of political pressures, a reference to their claim that they cannot receive a fair trial. The trial was rescheduled for Oct. 16. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Washburn to Start Saturday on Three Days' Rest
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 4  The third game of the American League division series was less than three hours away, and Yankees Manager Joe Torre still did not know who would be starting for the Anaheim Angels in Game 4 on Saturday. An hour into the game, Torre found out.

title: Reading Is Not a Drill
description: To the Editor:

title: American Crews Breezing While Italian Team Bickers
description: American crews kept rolling when America's Cup qualifying competition for the Louis Vuitton Cup resumed today, while the frustration continued for Prada of Italy both on and off the water.

title: Putin Annuls Decree Allowing Radio Liberty's Broadcasts
description: It was not the most dramatic symbol of the end of the cold war, but a momentous one nonetheless. In 1991, six days after the abortive putsch that signaled the end of the Soviet Union, President Boris N. Yeltsin issued a decree allowing Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty to broadcast from Russia.

title: Qaeda Man Pleads Guilty To Flying With Shoe Bomb
description: Admitting membership in Al Qaeda, Richard C. Reid pleaded guilty today to charges of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight in December with explosives hidden in his shoes.

title: Mayor to Make Olympic Pitch On Day of Vote
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will travel to Colorado Springs to make the final pitch to the United States Olympic Committee to choose New York City as the United States entry in the international competition to hold the 2012 Summer Games.

title: F.C.C. Says EchoStar-DirecTV Vote Is Near
description: The Federal Communications Commission is close to a vote on EchoStar Communications's proposal to buy its larger satellite television rival DirecTV for $23 billion, the commission's chairman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, GERALD JOSEPH
description: HARVEY - Gerald Joseph. July 27, 1925-October 2, 2002. We mourn the loss of our loving husband, father, grandfather and brother. While we are deeply saddened, we are relieved that he no longer suffers. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 6, 2002, 9:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, DEENA
description: BLOOM-Deena. We will miss you, our cherished friend, your beautiful voice and smiling face. Love Erma and Stan Sherwin

title: That Blonde At the Door? A Daughter!
description: So many fine performers have taken a shot at sitcom success and fallen flat on their faces: Nathan Lane, Bette Midler, Stockard Channing, Faye Dunaway. Even James Stewart had his own comedy series (''The Jimmy Stewart Show,'' NBC, 1971-72). Maybe the imposing Alfred Molina (''Chocolat,'' ''Murder on the Orient Express,'' the original Broadway cast of ''Art'') will have better luck.

title: A 'Picnic'-Style Hero Without the Torn T-Shirt
description: Although its tone is more dreamy than steamy, Tian Zhuangzhuang's film ''Springtime in a Small Town'' seems to have oddly sprung from the same heated template that produced the early 50's dramas of William Inge and Tennessee Williams in which a strutting sexual superman barges into a neurasthenic environment and wreaks chaos.

title: A New Shakeup at The N.E.A.
description: The National Endowment for the Arts is undergoing a quiet but significant shakeup that has led some arts advocates to conclude that federal financing is about to shift even further toward traditional cultural organizations like large museums and classical music ensembles. This would move the agency in a direction long favored by conservatives inside and outside the Bush administration.

title: Georgians to Extradite 5 Chechen Fighters
description: Georgia agreed today to extradite 5 of 13 Chechen fighters detained near the Russian border in August, bowing to pressure from President Vladimir V. Putin that Georgia do more to crack down on Chechens in Georgian territory or face pre-emptive strikes by Russian forces.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Panel To Study Reforms
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma has formed a commission of local and federal officials, members of Parliament and scholars to study constitutional reforms and electoral law amendments that would increase the powers of Parliament. Mr. Kuchma's decree, signed Thursday, said the goal is a ''European model'' of participatory democracy. His government has been accused of corruption, of human rights violations and, most recently, of selling weapons to Iraq, and is under attack by opposition politicians. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Religion Journal; An Appreciation Day Passes Quietly
description: The Rev. Ronald Emery has never heard of Clergy Appreciation Day. He has never received a ''Thank you, Pastor'' greeting card, a testimonial dinner from church members or a car wash for his 10-year-old Mercury. His name does not appear on an engraved Bible, free ticket to Hawaii or Clergy Appreciation Day potted plant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LEON
description: SCHNEIDER-Leon. January 30, 1924-October 3, 2002. We mourn the loss of our loving husband, father, grandfather, uncle and friend. Mr. Schneider was a partner in the wholesale meat business, FlushingZeger, and served as the president of the Board of Directors of the Hewlett Park Association. He was an avid advocate for the mentally retarded and for those with Alzheimer's. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Zeena, and her two sisters, Estelle Sobie and Madelaine Sheck; his son, Marc, his daughter, Beth and her partner, Susan; his grandson, Noah Kai; and his many nieces and nephews. Services on Sunday, October 6, 1:30 PM at Gutterman's Rockville Centre. Donations in his memory may be made to: The Association for Retarded Citizens, or The Rosenberg Fund for Children, East Hampton, MA.

title: An Asian Aphrodite Finds Instant Cosmic Love
description: A goddess of je ne sais quoi sits rocking in a large brass bowl and lures three tribesmen into thrusting their spearlike poles into the base of her, yes, vessel. They spin the arm-waving deity and her newfound radiating beams around.

title: Payrolls Drop As Economy Seems to Be At Standstill
description: The tentative economic recovery nearly came to a halt last month as payrolls shrank for the first time in five months, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Investor Appeals Ruling on Big Award
description: A Canadian investor whose landmark verdict against the Bear Stearns Companies was recently overturned has asked a federal appeals court to rehear his case.

title: What's Strong and Sweet As Fresh Homemade Jam?
description: The party music of yesteryear finds a charmed afterlife in the ever-expanding styles of jam bands, many of whose perpetual tours converged at Roseland for the third annual Jammy Awards on Wednesday night. Music that started out in the 1960's as a psychedelic free-form hybrid has only grown more omnivorous every year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALTROW, BRUCE
description: PALTROW - Bruce. The Trustees, staff and artists of the Williamstown Theatre Festival are profoundly saddened by the loss of Bruce Paltrow. As a writer and director, Bruce demonstrated wit, grace and a passion to raise the stakes. Around the festival, he was a perpetual source of humor and warmth. He inspired us to greater achievement. Our heartfelt condolences to Blythe, Gwyneth and Jake. Ira S. Lapidus, President Michael Ritchie, Producer

title: For Stalled Produce, Only Bite Is at Headquarters
description: Last Sunday, Tanimura & Antle Inc., one of the nation's largest vegetable growers, shipped 20 truckloads of broccoli to the Port of Oakland to be exported to Japan and Taiwan.

title: If Maddux Is Pitching, Lopez Isn't Catching
description: The question was asked of Atlanta Manager Bobby Cox shortly after the Braves' victory over the San Francisco Giants in Game 2 of the National League division series on Thursday. With catcher Javy Lopez having homered in the first two games of the series, was there any chance of Lopez catching Saturday when Greg Maddux would start for the Braves?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Financier Sells Chemical Stake
description: The Swiss financier Martin Ebner will sell his $575 million stake in Lonza, the Swiss maker of chemicals, and step down as its chairman, effective immediately. The fire sale of the 19.8 percent stake in Lonza, which will take place over the next few weeks, is an attempt to shore up Mr. Ebner's ailing BZ Group. Fears of sales by Mr. Ebner, above, have hurt the Swiss stock market and other companies in which his firm has shares, including the engineering giant ABB, Credit Suisse and Baloise insurance. The BZ Group has been hit hard by plunging stock markets. It sold its shares of four mutual funds, which had equity holdings totaling $2.03 billion, in July. A month later, a consortium of banks granted Mr. Ebner relief on loans. Lonza said that Sergio Marchionne, the former vice chairman of the board, will assume Mr. Ebner's position. Lonza shares dropped to a record low of 78.15 Swiss francs, but recovered to end down 1.7 percent, at 82.05. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DOW CHEMICAL CO., Midland, Mich., a maker of chemical, plastic and agricultural products, said it would eliminate about 110 jobs, or about 3.6 percent of the work force, at its Michigan Operations plant as part of a cost-cutting plan.

title: Convict Says Jogger Attack Was His 2nd
description: The man who has claimed sole responsibility for the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park in 1989 has also told investigators that he committed an identical crime two days earlier in the same area of the park. The man, Matias Reyes, a convicted murderer and serial rapist, maintains that he acted entirely by himself in both attacks.

title: Iceberg Battles Deep Fritz to a Draw
description: The world's reigning human chess champion, Vladimir Kramnik, a 27-year-old, 6-foot-4 Russian nicknamed the Iceberg, and the newest chess computer champ, Deep Fritz, drew their first game here today in what is being billed as the successor match to Gary Kasparov versus Deep Blue.

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Tribunal Asked To Drop Indictment
description: The government asked the United Nations tribunal in The Hague to drop its indictment of the country's popular former army chief on charges of crimes against humanity. The government, which promised to cooperate with the tribunal as part of its reformist agenda, is refusing to hand over Gen. Janko Bobetko, 83. Although indictments are occasionally annulled, the appeal is widely viewed as a stalling tactic to delay a handover that could bring down the government. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIPS, EDWARD U.
description: GIPS-Edward U. Loving brother of William M., brother-in-law of Joan, uncle of Kathy and Jim, great-uncle of Amy and Jonathan. Former executive director ASID, a Mason at King Solomon-Mt. Nebo Lodge, W.W. II veteran, Yankees fan. Funeral is on Sunday, October 6, at 11 AM, Linden Hill Cemetery. The family will receive friends at the home of William M. and Joan Gips, Sunday, October 6, after 2 PM and October 7-10 after 7:30 PM. Donations to Alzheimer's Association.

title: Widening Fears, Few Clues As 6th Death Is Tied to Sniper
description: A roving sniper who killed five suburban residents at random has extended his range into the District of Columbia, the police said tonight in linking the fatal shooting of a Washington pedestrian to the same gunman who has been stalking his victims with a high-powered rifle at distances of 100 yards or more in mundane settings of daily life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, RUBY
description: SCHWARTZ-Ruby. October 2, 2002 in Port Elizabeth, SA. Through her incredible love she touched all our lives.

title: Don't Let 'Profit' Spell Amtrak's Doom
description: To the Editor:

title: Carroll Going Long In New York
description: Indoors, Mark Carroll won the Wanamaker Mile in 2000 in 3 minutes 58.19 seconds. Outdoors, he holds the Irish records for 3,000, 5,000 and 10,000 meters. Now he has set his sights on a much longer race.

title: Iraq and the Campaign
description: While most members of Congress insist that there is no political calculation in the life-and-death subject of Iraq, the way most candidates in the nation's most competitive races are approaching the issue suggests they are mindful of potential political repercussions. And they are doing their best to limit any fallout.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro fell against the dollar after the Labor Department said the jobless rate in the United States unexpectedly declined in September. In New York, the euro settled at 97.98 cents, down from 98.66 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDREYER, CONSTANCE NANCY GRACE (NEE BARBER)
description: GOLDREYER - Constance Nancy Grace (nee Barber). A very young 71 years, she lived her life filled with smiles, love, enthusiasm and laughter. A spectacular wife, mother, grandma and great friend to so many. She is survived by her husband Len, daughters Nancy Davilman (Andrew) Jill Goldreyer (Gregory) and Jennifer. Extraordinary grandma to Samantha, Jack and Yara. Loving sister to Gene, Billy, Tony, Ann and the late Buddy. Receiving friends at home this Sunday 3-7PM, Monday and Tuesday from 7PM.

title: A Proud Badge In Hartford Is Tarnished Like So Many
description: For six years, Gregory J. DePietro was not just an ordinary cop. Working the toughest neighborhoods, he was considered an example of what was right with Hartford's embattled police force, hauling in some of this city's most violent drug suspects at a time when several colleagues were being indicted, tried and sent to prison for committing outrageous felonies on the job.

title: Invoking the Image of Hussein
description: Representative John Thune, the Republican running for the Senate in South Dakota, yesterday became the first Senate candidate to use the image of Saddam Hussein in a television advertisement. The ad, paid for by the Thune campaign, claims that Senator Tim Johnson, a Democrat, is soft on missile defense. It can be seen by viewers in half of South Dakota.

title: Chambliss Interviews For the Mets' Opening
description: The Mets began interviewing managerial candidates yesterday, meeting with the team's hitting coach, Chris Chambliss, for three and a half hours at their Shea Stadium offices. A week of interviews awaits General Manager Steve Phillips and his staff next week and, when teams are eliminated from the playoffs, more candidates will become available.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Toyota Recall In Europe
description: Toyota Motor, Japan's largest automaker, said it was recalling 277,000 Yaris cars sold in Europe to fix a tube that could freeze and cause brakes to malfunction. Owners are being notified to take the cars to dealers, where the rear brake tubes will be replaced, a Toyota spokesman said. The problem was discovered on mail trucks in Finland and has not caused any accidents. Toyota said earlier this week that it was recalling 421,542 vehicles in Japan for brake and steering faults.

title: Ex-Tyco Official Asks Special Bail Deal
description: The former chief financial officer of Tyco International, facing an indictment on corporate fraud charges, asked a judge yesterday to accept deferred compensation from the company as collateral for his $50 million bail.

title: Skakel Loses Bail Appeal
description: Michael C. Skakel, convicted in June of the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley, was denied bail today by the State Supreme Court.

title: College Football; Kickoff
description: JOE DRAPE'S TOP MATCHUPS

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia And Herzegovina: Election Today
description: Bosnians vote today for a government that will probably have to try to stand alone before the end of its four-year term, as Western aid and supervision slowly dwindle away. International officials, who are letting Bosnia's deeply divided Serbs, Muslims and Croats run an election for the first time since the war ended in 1995, are urging people to vote for moderate parties. But nationalist parties are expected to do well, particularly in the semi-autonomous Serb Republic formed under the Dayton peace accords. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Knicks and Controversy A Familiar Camp Theme
description: For the third training camp in four years, the Knicks appear to be in typical dysfunctional form. Not on the court, but off it.

title: Kill the Energy Bill
description: Negotiators from the House and Senate have been struggling to reconcile two different versions of a multibillion-dollar energy bill. They would do themselves and the nation a tremendous favor by junking the whole thing and agreeing to start all over again next year. Though the Senate bill is preferable to the House's, neither version would measurably improve the nation's energy security or lessen its dependence on Mideast oil now or in the future -- which is what the whole exercise was supposed to be about. Both are also suspect on environmental grounds.

title: Russia Recasts Bog in Caucasus as War on Terror
description: Three years after Russian forces poured into Chechnya for the second time, the war grinds on, but Russia's characterization of the fight without end has changed. No longer are 85,000 Russian troops and police officers simply engaged in crushing a battle for independence; instead, Chechnya has become Russia's war on terror.

title: Alcoa's 3rd-Quarter Profit Down 43%
description: Alcoa Inc. said third-quarter profit declined 43 percent because of low aluminum prices and falling sales to aerospace, energy and telecommunications customers.

title: Mayor Bloomberg Takes On Noise
description: If the experts are right, people will sleep better, overall health will improve, children will have a chance to learn more and job performance will go up -- all because Mayor Michael Bloomberg is putting the big ssshhh on New York City. In a welcome and targeted crackdown that could become a model for cities coping with mounting noise pollution, the mayor is putting a lid on the deafening din in 24 of the loudest parts of the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONCANNON, EDWARD H.
description: CONCANNON-Edward H., 77. Of Wilton, CT. Husband of Catherine McCabe Concannon. Father of Leslie Concannon of New York City and Carey McMillion of Mercer Island, WA. Brother of Joan Mannix of Grantham, NH and Nancy Concannon of Wabaw, MA. One grandchild and several nieces and nephews. A Memorial Mass will be held Monday, October 7th, 11AM at Our Lady of Fatima, Wilton, CT. Interment will be private. Friends may call on Sunday from 4-6 PM at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT.

title: Yankees Facing an Early Exit
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 4  Darin Erstad loves all the red when the stands are packed at Edison Field. It reminds him of his days as a punter for the University of Nebraska, where he won a national championship. Erstad chose a baseball career and was sentenced to play for the Anaheim Angels, a franchise that has never won a playoff series. They are on the brink of doing that now, because the Yankees seem helpless to stop them.

title: When Hospitals Merge
description: To the Editor:

title: The Trailing Upstate Economy
description: The state Democratic Party's Coordinated Campaign Committee released four 30-second advertisements attacking Gov. George E. Pataki's economic record upstate, each one slightly tailored to address local issues in Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo and Albany. The ads are meant to help H. Carl McCall, the Democrat who is running against Mr. Pataki.

title: The Starters Keep Taking Early Showers
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 4  The Yankees' starting pitchers have shown a remarkable consistency in the division playoff series against the Angels. It's just not an admirable consistency.

title: A Double Whammy on Long Island
description: Faced with sluggish sales tax revenues and soaring pension, health insurance and Medicaid costs, counties in the New York metropolitan region are facing cuts in popular services and hikes in local taxes to balance their budgets. And Albany isn't helping. On Long Island, the Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, confronts a fiscal double whammy. Not only must he surmount the current economic downturn, but he must do so even as he grapples with the financial crisis left behind by his Republican predecessor, Thomas Gulotta.

title: Line Drawn in Water Against a Predatory Fish; U.S. and Two States Renew Their Battle on Sea Lampreys in Lake Champlain
description: First came the lake, formed 10,000 years ago by a receding glacier. Then came the canals, linking the vast Lake Champlain to other waterways. Through the canals came the sea lampreys, and life in the lake has been out of kilter ever since.

title: China Holds Capitalist Chief Of North Korea Trade Zone
description: Yang Bin was gregarious right up to the moment of his arrest, chain-smoking cigarettes, boasting of his diplomatic status as North Korea's new economic eminence and making light of his tussles with Chinese authorities.

title: INSIDE
description: Angels Top Yanks; Lead, 2-1

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea's Turning Point
description: Today a first set of talks will conclude between James Kelly, assistant secretary of state for East Asia, and the government of North Korea. Although Chairman Kim Jong Il and his Communist regime are part of President Bush's axis of evil, Washington has opted to pursue regime transformation rather than regime change. This engagement has been a long time in coming. But North Korea has been trying for years, in its own awkward and eccentric way, to get closer to the outside world, and Washington, together with Tokyo, has finally chosen to respond.

title: A Mixed Picture of Oregon Suspects
description: In the quiet neighborhood here where three people accused of conspiring to wage war on the United States were arrested at dawn today, friends and relatives painted a mixed picture of the suspects, all of them American citizens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. The Board of Directors and President of INFORM express their sorrow at the loss of one of INFORM's founding Board members whose energies and vision shaped INFORM's environmental mission. We extend our sympathies to his wife Liliane and family. Joanna D. Underwood, Pres.

title: Man in the News; A Diplomat Who Won't Take 'No' -- Hans Blix
description: The Security Council meeting had been a multilateral wrestling match among the United States and other major powers, each pressing its interpretation of Hans Blix's report on meetings this week with Iraqi officials.

title: From Africa to America in a Pair of Premieres
description: The Charles Moore Dance Theater, augmented by its Youth Ensemble, presented a panorama of African and African-American dance traditions last Saturday night at Symphony Space.

title: Outrage Over a Poet Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in the Company News column on Thursday about a financial forecast by Charter Communications, the cable television company, misstated its expectation for operating cash flow in the current quarter. The company said it would fall short of a previously forecast 13.7 percent increase, but it gave no specific figure.

title: Mentally Ill and Locked Away in Nursing Homes in New York
description: Hundreds of patients released from state psychiatric hospitals in New York in recent years are being locked away on isolated floors of nursing homes, where they are barred from going outside on their own, have almost no contact with others and have little ability to contest their confinement, according to interviews with workers and experts and visits to the homes.

title: Hamilton Promises a Big Game Against Dallas
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel says defensive tackle Keith Hamilton is a man of his word. So Fassel was pleased with this week's message from Hamilton, an 11th-year pro known as Hammer.

title: A New Tack For Recovery Of Money Lost In Scandals
description: William S. Lerach, the scrappy lawyer whose shareholder lawsuits have turned him into one of corporate America's most despised enemies, has a new angle on shaking loose money for investors harmed by corporate scandals.

title: To Find Teachers, Raise Hand High and Yell, 'Me!'
description: Fulton County has gone digital in its search for teachers.

title: VERIZON WEIGHS SALE OF FOREIGN ASSETS TO TRIM DEBT
description: Verizon Communications Inc., which owns stakes in telephone companies in countries including Italy and Venezuela, may sell foreign investments to trim debt. ''We're reviewing all of our international properties,'' Peter Thonis, a spokesman for Verizon, the biggest local-phone company in the United States, said in an interview. Verizon owns 23 percent of Vodafone Omnitel, Italy's second-biggest wireless carrier. The Vodafone Group owns most of the rest. Verizon also owns 29 percent of Compaa Nacional Telfonos de Venezuela, that country's biggest phone company. Verizon, based in New York, is planning more than 8,000 job cuts by the end of the year and is selling assets to trim $61.6 billion in debt.

title: Nepal King, Urging Elections, Dismisses Premier and Takes Power
description: The King of Nepal dismissed the country's elected prime minister tonight and assumed direct power, setting off a political crisis in the impoverished Himalayan nation already beset by a Maoist insurgency.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: INFINEON ENDS VENTURE Infineon Technologies , a unit of Siemens and Europe's second-biggest semiconductor maker, ended a manufacturing venture with Mosel Vitelic Inc., a move analysts say may jeopardize the survival of Mosel, Taiwan's No. 5 memory chip maker. Infineon canceled an agreement defining the terms of the ProMos Technologies venture with Mosel "because of repeated breaches of contract," said a spokeswoman, Katja Schlendorf. Infineon intends to renegotiate a supply agreement with ProMos. Infineon owns 29.8 percent of ProMos and said in a statement that it remained a "major shareholder in the company." The six-year-old ProMos has been producing computer memory chips in Taiwan based on Infineon technology and selling the chips to the German company and Mosel.

title: Bowed Gongs in Lurid Red Light Set a Festival's Tone
description: George Crumb's musical reputation emerged some 40 years ago in an era of candles and incense. Both are still burning, that is if Sunday's large crowd at the Orensanz Center for the Arts on the Lower East Side had anything to tell us. Mr. Crumb's quasi-psychedelic extravagance was on parade for the third straight day. Old acolytes and young novitiates mingled to witness ''Black Angels,'' ''Dream Sequence'' and ''Ancient Voices of Children'' with wide-eyed admiration. The movement titles told most of the story: ''Night of the Electric Insects,'' ''Sounds of Bones and Flutes,'' ''Devil-Music.'' Gosh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCADAM, DENNIS F.
description: McADAM-Dennis F. Your valiant struggle is now over and at last you are at peace. Good-bye, dear friend. We will always miss you. Love, Nancy and Neil Koenig

title: Injury to Rolen Tests Cardinals' Belief in Destiny
description: As the stocky kid out of Jasper, Ind., with Busch Stadium ticket stubs for childhood keepsakes, it was natural for Scott Rolen to plunge right into Cardinal Nation after he was freed from purgatory in Philadelphia in a July trade.

title: Outrage Over a Poet Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Center-Right Coalition Set
description: After a surprisingly strong finish in last month's parliamentary elections, Prime Minister Mikulas Dzurinda said four center-right parties had reached agreement on a coalition that is expected to lead the country to membership in NATO and the European Union. The narrow victory by Mr. Dzurinda and his pro-Western allies blocked the return to power of the former prime minister, Vladimir Meciar, who has been accused of being undemocratic. The new government will include Christian Democrats, ethnic Hungarians and the pro-business party of a television magnate, Pavol Rusko. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: SMALLPOX VACCINE BACKED FOR PUBLIC
description: The nation's top public health officials said today that they favored offering smallpox vaccine to the public, even in absence of a bioterror attack, but only after up to 10 million health care workers are immunized and after a vaccine is licensed for general use, which is not likely until 2004.

title: Rutgers's Culley Breaks Meet Record
description: Julie Culley, a junior at Rutgers who sat out last year's cross-country season with a back injury, raced to a record-breaking victory in the 75th annual Metropolitan Intercollegiate Championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Patent Requests Withdrawn
description: Bell Labs is withdrawing six patent applications associated with work by Dr. J. Hendrik Schn, the scientist it fired last week for professional misconduct. When questions about Dr. Schn's research arose in May, Bell Labs, part of Lucent Technologies, asked the United States Patent and Trademark Office to put the applications on hold. Investigators reported last week that Dr. Schn had manipulated or invented data in 17 scientific papers published from 1998 to 2001. The withdrawn patent applications involved molecular-scale transistors, organic electronics and superconductivity. Corresponding foreign applications are also being withdrawn. Kenneth Chang (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: UKRAINE: PANEL TO STUDY REFORMS President Leonid D. Kuchma has formed a commission of local and federal officials, members of Parliament and scholars to study constitutional reforms and electoral law amendments that would increase the powers of Parliament. Mr. Kuchma's decree, signed Thursday, said the goal is a "European model" of participatory democracy. His government has been accused of corruption, of human rights violations and, most recently, of selling weapons to Iraq, and is under attack by opposition politicians.

title: Outrage Over a Poet Laureate
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Says North Korea Boat In Sea Battle Was a Spy Ship
description: Japanese officials formally identified today a North Korean boat as a ''spy ship'' as investigators started studying weapons, a Japanese cellphone and an underwater sled recovered from the ship, which was scuttled by crew members after an intense firefight last December with Japanese patrol boats.

title: Pakistan Stages Missile Test, First Since War Scare in May
description: Pakistan today staged what it called a routine test-firing of a medium-range missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, the first since it conducted a similar test in May at the peak of war tensions with India.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS RISES. Natural gas prices rose after the Interior Department said storms in the Gulf of Mexico cut production by 60 percent. Natural gas for delivery in November rose 1.5 cents, to $3.739 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: Richard A. Goldberg -- Judge, 71
description: Justice Richard A. Goldberg, an active justice on the New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died on Monday at a hospital in Warwick, N.Y. He was 71.

title: Scioscia Saga: The Dodgers' Loss Is the Angels' Gain
description: No doubt about it, Mike Scioscia was destined to be a major league manager.

title: Man Planned U.N. Attack for Months, F.B.I. Says
description: A postal worker who fired shots at the United Nations on Thursday as a political protest had planned his attack meticulously and taken precautions in case he was shot, officials said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Credit Suisse Assurances
description: A 10 percent plunge that brought Credit Suisse's share price to its lowest point in nine years prompted the company to denounce the market action and deny that it had plans for a capital increase. The company said that it ''is not aware of any objective reason prompting this development.'' It added, ''The group's capital resources remain adequate, and as stated before, no capital increase of the group is planned.'' Credit Suisse shares tumbled after Standard & Poor's said on Thursday that it might downgrade the company's rating. The ratings agency said its move was based on Credit Suisse's injection of $1.35 billion into its Winterthur insurance unit. The company used its own liquidity for the insurer, but analysts fear Credit Suisse may now be forced to increase its own capital reserves. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: German Aide's Remarks
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Statement by John Walker Lindh in Court
description: Following are excerpts from John Walker Lindh's statement yesterday in an Alexandria, Va., court, as provided by his lawyer:

title: Hopes and Limits of Bionic Parts
description: Dr. Willem J. Kolff, the inventor of the artificial kidney and the leader of the team that created the first artificial heart, was awarded the Albert Lasker Award for Clinical Medical Research last week. He is now working on a wearable artificial lung. Daphne Eviatar spoke with him.

title: A Swedish-American Team And Its Bid for a Top Cup
description: The most prestigious event at the world championships in August was the Rosenblum Cup, from which all the United States teams were surprisingly eliminated at a relatively early stage. But this does not mean that all Americans were eliminated.

title: Another Missing Piece For Jets Is the Big Play
description: The Jets have fallen so far in almost every offensive and defensive statistic that if it were not for the special teams, you might never see a Jet among the league leaders at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINSTOCK, HARRY
description: BINSTOCK-Harry. Age 88, formerly of the Bronx, died October 3, 2002, in Chapel Hill, N.C. Beloved husband of Leah. Caring father of David Binstock and Deborah Warren. Proud grandfather of Louisa and Roberto Warren and Jonah Binstock. Preceded in death by granddaughter Abigail B. Warren.

title: C.I.A. Says Iraq Revived Forbidden Weapons Programs After the U.N. Inspectors Left
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that Iraq had taken advantage of the withdrawal of United Nations weapons inspectors to resume the production of chemical arms, expand efforts to develop biological weapons and revive its program to make nuclear arms.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILNER, DR. ANTHONY
description: MILNER-Dr. Anthony, British composer, died suddenly in Spain. Memorial to be held later. Survived by his brothers, Dr. Paul Milner of North Carolina, Rev. Austin Milner O.P., West Indies; his sister, Mia McCarthy & Sr. Patricia Milner, H.C.J., both of Dublin.

title: Designers of Executive Salary Plans Fear More Abuses
description: The people who design and administer corporate pay plans say they bear some responsibility for excessive executive pay and they warned at a conference here that new and expected pay reforms can easily be abused to enrich executives unjustly.

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Love and the Single Misfit In a Topsy-Turvy World
description: No frogs fall from the sky in ''Punch-Drunk Love,'' Paul Thomas Anderson's new movie, the centerpiece of this year's terrific New York Film Festival. You may recall that ''Magnolia,'' the director's three-and-a-half-hour millennial collage of intergenerational misery, was punctuated by a torrent of slimy amphibians, a croaking, splattery illustration of the movie's ideas about chance, fate and the sudden intrusion of the miraculous into the slog of daily life.

title: Yankees Facing an Early Exit
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 4  Darin Erstad loves all the red when the stands are packed at Edison Field. It reminds him of his days as a punter for the University of Nebraska, where he won a national championship. Erstad chose a baseball career and was sentenced to play for the Anaheim Angels, a franchise that has never won a playoff series. They are on the brink of doing that now, because the Yankees seem helpless to stop them.

title: A Pension Fund Chief Bets on US Airways
description: In its new partner, the Retirement Systems of Alabama, US Airways is dealing with a pension fund that not only seeks out crafty investments but has another critical motivation: jobs for Alabamans.

title: How Will History Judge Us on Iraq?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rival Iraqi Kurdish Groups Meet to Resolve Differences
description: Ethnic Kurds opened a regional parliament meeting in northern Iraq today, hoping to unify rival factions whose infighting has repeatedly foiled Kurdish attempts to consolidate power over their traditional homeland.

title: Drug Makers Cutting Back On Discounts for the Elderly
description: Two of the nation's biggest drug companies are cutting back on discounts they promised to low-income elderly people, and other drug makers say they may follow suit.

title: PPL Says It Will Treat Options as Expense
description: The PPL Corporation, a supplier of electricity and natural gas to about 1.4 million customers in Pennsylvania, said today that it would treat stock options granted to employees as an expense beginning in January.

title: Another Sell-Off Brings Week No. 6 of Losses
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday, dragging the Dow Jones industrial average to its lowest point in almost five years and pushing the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest point in six years. The sell-off came after a mixed report about the job market and more corporate earnings disappointments.

title: Yankees Put Their Season In Hands of Savvy Wells
description: David Wells is used to pitching at this time of year. He pitched on three playoff teams in Toronto and one each in Cincinnati and Baltimore before even coming to the Yankees in 1997. He worked in two postseasons that go-round, but has not been back since the Roger Clemens trade that so famously broke his heart in spring training in 1999.

title: Indictments Expected From Former New Jersey Official's Information
description: Robert C. Janiszewski, the former Hudson County executive, has given federal investigators in New Jersey information about dozens of government contractors and political figures, according to people close to him, who say they expect many more indictments this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUGERMAN, CELIA
description: SUGERMAN-Celia. Beloved wife of Lewis. Devoted mother of Linda Mollick (Sheppard), Karen Snyder (Michael) and the late Jay Sugerman. Adored grandmother of Ethan Mollick (Lilach), Jordana and Ariel Mollick, Justin and Jonathan Gary. Services Sunday 12:15pm ''Sinai Chapels'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMRICH, MICHAEL J.
description: IMRICH-Michael J., Master Mariner, USMMC, Kings Point Class of '62 of Wyckoff, New Jersey and Whitney Lake, PA. on October 2, 2002 after a gallant battle with emphysema. Beloved husband of Claire (nee Kennedy), devoted father of Lauren and Michael. ''Fairwinds and Snug Harbors''. The family will receive friends Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. Funeral Mass Monday 11 AM at St. Elizabeth R.C. Church, 700 Wyckoff Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ. Private cremation was held. In lieu of flowers, donations to Starlight Children's Foundation, 1560 Broadway, Suite 600, New York, NY 10036

title: The Supreme Court's Unfree Speech
description: If recent history is any guide, the Supreme Court's new term, which begins Monday, promises to be another good one for freedom of expression -- except, that is, within the courtroom itself. The justices support a broad view of free speech in their rulings, but they practice something very different in their own court.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Infineon Ends Venture
description: Infineon Technologies, a unit of Siemens and Europe's second-biggest semiconductor maker, ended a manufacturing venture with Mosel Vitelic Inc., a move analysts say may jeopardize the survival of Mosel, Taiwan's No. 5 memory chip maker. Infineon canceled an agreement defining the terms of the ProMos Technologies venture with Mosel ''because of repeated breaches of contract,'' said a spokeswoman, Katja Schlendorf. Infineon intends to renegotiate a supply agreement with ProMos. Infineon owns 29.8 percent of ProMos and said in a statement that it remained a ''major shareholder in the company.'' The six-year-old ProMos has been producing computer memory chips in Taiwan based on Infineon technology and selling the chips to the German company and Mosel.

title: Ronald Moss, 72, New York State Official
description: Ronald J. Moss, a former advertising executive who was New York State commerce commissioner under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, died Sept. 3 at a nursing home in Port Jefferson, N.Y. He was 72.

title: P&O PRINCESS CRUISES FAVORS CARNIVAL AS SUITOR
description: P&O Princess Cruises said yesterday that the Carnival Corporation's hostile $4.1 billion bid is more attractive than a proposed merger with Royal Caribbean Cruises now that both transactions have won approval by United States antitrust enforcers. P&O Princess, the third-largest cruise line, said it would enter into negotiations with Carnival, the biggest, to discuss revising the takeover proposal P&O Princess had rejected on the basis that regulators would block it. P&O, which is based in London, issued a statement after the Federal Trade Commission said it had cleared both proposed combinations.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: American Sees No. 2 Official
description: An American envoy met North Korea's second-highest leader, Kim Yong Nam, in a courtesy call during a day of talks in the capital, Pyongyang, the official Korean Central News Agency reported. James Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for East Asia and the Pacific, is to end his two-day trip today and plans to brief South Korean and Japanese officials before returning to Washington. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Collections / Paris : Ungaro and Lagerfeld get the right mix
description: PARIS  What is the essence of glamour? Is it John Galliano in snow white suit and fedora descending from the heavens at the Paris Lido  to land among befeathered showgirls at the launch of Dior's Addict fragrance?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, BERTRAND J.
description: GILMAN-Bertrand J. Passed away on October 4, 2002, in his 76th year, leaving behind longtime companion William J. Stephens.

title: New Leads Surface in Plot By Gotti, Prosecutor Asserts
description: A federal prosecutor said yesterday that there were new leads in the investigation of whether Peter Gotti, the brother of the deceased crime boss John J. Gotti, had plotted a killing from the Brooklyn jail where he has been held since he was charged with racketeering in June.

title: TXU HALTS EUROPE PROJECTS AS BRITISH OPERATIONS FALTER
description: The TXU Corporation, the Dallas-based utility owner that entered the British market in 1998, halted European projects and said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell more than 25 percent, exceeding forecasts, amid tumbling electricity prices in Britain. Third-quarter profit fell to 90 cents to 95 cents a share, and fourth-quarter profit will be 60 cents to 65 cents, TXU said. It was expected to earn $1.54 in the third quarter and 99 cents in the fourth, the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company is the fifth-largest United States utility.

title: FOUR INDIAN TRIBES TO BUILD HOTEL IN WASHINGTON
description: A partnership of tribes from California and Wisconsin is investing gambling proceeds in a new Washington hotel as part of an effort to diversify sources of income for American Indians. Four Fires L.L.C., made up of representatives from four tribes, said yesterday that it would build a Marriott International hotel near the Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, which is under construction. The partnership is an attempt to create an economic base beyond gambling and other reservation-based enterprises, the tribal leaders said. Four Fires; the Donohoe Companies, a Washington builder; and Hospitality Partners of Bethesda, Md., will develop the Marriott Residence Inn Capitol, a $43 million hotel with 13 stories and 233 suites, the leaders said. The hotel is due to open in 2004.

title: From Teen Idol to Diva
description: The qualities that made Britney Spears accessible and popular as a teenage star may be precisely the ones choking her career as an adult.

title: Where Dcor and Flavors Say Thailand
description: THE vibrant hues of Thailand echo vividly inside and outside this refurbished corner spot in Sleepy Hollow. Masks of Buddha and large prints depicting scenes of idyllic village conviviality peek from behind exotic foliage lining every nook.

title: Joe Franklin Auctioning A Bit of Memory Lane
description: Finally, just in time to get rid of it, Joe Franklin tried to play the Tommy Dorsey trombone.

title: Our Towns; New Jersey Voters, Wishing for Dj Vu to Be All Over, Again
description: OTHER than that, it was a normal week for New Jersey politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, ROBERT ERIC
description: JENSEN-Robert Eric. On October 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted brother of Daniel C. Loving uncle of Danielle and the late Karen. His career in public relations included Vice President of A.J. Lazarus for 17 years, prior to that. Vice President of Gibbs and Soell for 10 years. In the words of his colleagues, ''You're head and shoulders above the rest,'' and ''Bob Jensen, you're the best PR writer in the country.'' In addition to his love of art, Bob enjoyed both jazz and classical music. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with a service Monday evening at 8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell. Interment will take place on Tuesday, at Evergreen Cemetery, Morristown, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or a charity of your choice.

title: Wall Street Suffers; New York Winces
description: IN Houston, you'd be hard pressed to find someone who doesn't know at least a little about the oil business. Ditto in Detroit with the auto industry. And in Washington, people are so informed about the federal government that they know the difference between a deputy assistant under secretary and an assistant deputy under secretary.

title: Angela Pierce and Erik Steele
description: THE time: a chilly November evening in 1999. The place: a beery downtown bar. The characters: two young actors about to fall in love.

title: A Writer's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZ, JOHN
description: WEITZ-John. The directors, staff and residents of Phoenix House mourn the loss of a great spirit and good friend. A celebrated author, historian, designer and entrepreneur, John Weitz was an early supporter and longtime board member of Phoenix House. Committed to our work, he was a generous and imaginative benefactor, who shared with us his wit, elegance and humor, sense of style, and spirit of adventure. We will miss him. Edward D. Miller, Chairman George A. Kellner, Vice Chairman Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D. President

title: Jeans in Distress, for Each Day of the Week
description: Time was, shoppers had only to choose between prewashed and unwashed jeans. Now, thanks to the denim explosion of the past few years, customers have a boundless, and often bewildering, array of choices. ''We constantly experiment with new washes to bring out the character of the denim,'' said Michael Glasser, a partner in 7 for All Mankind jeans. ''Character is ultimately what sells the jeans.''

title: Clothes for the 'Tween At a Rye Boutique
description: Girls between the ages of 7 and 13, hard to fit and hard to please, have a new shopping option with the recent opening of Sasha's in Rye. The store carries clothing in sizes 7 through 16.

title: Last Call for a Smoke
description: JOHN RYERSON, the owner of McGuire's Restaurant and Comedy Club in Bohemia, said he went $250,000 into hock two years ago to create a separate room for smokers.

title: Mourning 'Philly'
description: To the Editor:

title: Stephanie Feldman, Thomas Finkelstein
description: Stephanie Robyn Feldman, a daughter of Lynne M. Feldman and Edward S. Feldman of Leonia, N.J., is to be married this evening to Thomas Finkelstein, the son of Dr. Ilona S. Finkelstein and Dr. Eugene Finkelstein of Brooklyn. Rabbi David S. Halpern will officiate at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: At 77, Tony Curtis Still Likes It Hot
description: TONY CURTIS'S weight-control strategy, which seems to be working for him, is to avoid cooked foods as much as possible.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Once Revolutionary, Sector Funds Swoon
description: MORE than two decades ago, when Fidelity Investments brought out sector funds, they were in some ways revolutionary. The old concept of a mutual fund as a diversified portfolio, managed by a professional with the ability to move money around to meet market conditions, no longer seemed to apply.

title: Jennifer Cook, Bish McDonnell
description: Jennifer Colman Cook, a daughter of Laura Armour Cook of Washington and G. Bradford Cook of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Charles Edward McDonnell III, the son of Mary Davidson of Rye, N.Y., and the late Mr. McDonnell Jr. Canon Alan E. Tilson performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Anglican Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda.

title: Rejecting Boycott, Researchers Gather in Israel
description: Saying they are taking a stand against academic boycotts of Israeli institutions, a group of medical researchers in New York have organized a scientific conference this weekend in Eilat, Israel, drawing specialists from around the world to the resort by the Red Sea.

title: Abandon It, And They Will Come
description: This past summer, illegal squatters in 167 Lower East Side apartments became legal apartment owners, after New York City reversed its nearly two-decade-long policy of evicting inhabitants from abandoned buildings it had inherited through foreclosures. Now a deal negotiated by the nonprofit developer Urban Homesteading Assistance Board allows a squatter who, for instance, once voluntarily paid $250 a month in building dues for 800 square feet of space in the East Village to pay $750 a month in combined mortgage and operating costs. On the open market, an apartment of the same size in a co-op in that neighborhood could easily cost $2,300 a month ($800 alone on operating costs), according to Citi Habitats, a residential brokerage company. The squatters got a deal, but one with several catches. Owners can sell only to individuals or families making no more than 80 percent of the median income of New Yorkers, as arrived at by the federal department of Housing and Urban Development ($45,200 for a family of three, for example). And over the next three years, no former squatter can get more than $9,000 for a nonstudio apartment, a fraction of its worth. But after years and in many cases decades of renovating their apartments and putting in what they call sweat equity, the families, artists and middle-class pro-fessionals turned owners are for the moment content to enjoy the fruits of their labor.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: An Old-School Mind Not Fooled by the New Economy
description: WALL STREET these days often seems a place of utter venality in the service of executive greed. So it is refreshing to read of a successful American financier whose interests range far beyond making money. What's more, the self-effacing manner of that financier, Leon Levy, makes you wonder how he could have succeeded. Characteristically, he muses about this himself.

title: Who's to Blame For a School's Pain?; Casting a Vote For Tall Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: Colorado Makes the Biggest Plays
description: Is there anything in Colorado's playbook that it did not use against Kansas State today? Deep passes, reverses and trick plays near the goal line overloaded the mental computers of the Wildcats' defense. The football flew up and down the field as if it had a propeller.

title: Playground Of Billionaires
description: It is the end of a long day of racing in the Hauraki Gulf, and America's Cup racing boats are returning to Viaduct Harbor to be hauled ashore, hosed down and cloaked in skirts, to hide the secrets of speed that lurk below their waterlines. With their blunt bows, blade-like sails and carbon-fiber riggings tuned as precisely as a harp, the boats are among the most technologically advanced in the world.

title: Learning to Deal With Turbulence
description: Year in and year out, whether there are airline crashes or not, scores of people are hurt, and others are killed, by in-flight turbulence. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Federal Aviation Administration hope they will soon have sensing systems that could give 90 seconds' or two minutes' warning to an airline captain. But what could an airliner do with that amount of time?

title: Democrats' Moment
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopeful Germans Strain to Read Between Lines of Bush Letter
description: It was a simple letter from the American president to the German president, wishing his country well on the 12th anniversary of Germany's reunification. But to Germans, yearning to heal a rift with the United States, it looks like an olive branch.

title: It's Up to You, New York
description: The Panic of 1791

title: Who's to Blame For a School's Pain?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Greatest Englishman Since Newton'
description: CHARLES DARWIN

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 16 about Dr. Orvan W. Hess, obstetrician and gynecologist, misstated the significance of his work with the fetal heart monitor in 1957. He and Dr. Edward H. Hon were at the forefront of the development of clinically useful devices to record fetal heart rate patterns continuously during delivery to identify patterns that indicated fetal distress. They were not the first to detect and record electrical cardiac signals from the fetus.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about William Clay Ford Jr.'s management of the Ford Motor Company since he became chief executive last October misstated the year in which an explosion killed six workers at its River Rouge plant. It was 1999, not 1996.

title: Hogs on Wheels
description: HIGH AND MIGHTY

title: Home Dcor in a House Divided
description: ''HERE'S what we need for the house, honey, and this is how much you can spend: umbrella stand, $15,000; shower curtain, $6,000; antique toilet kit, $17,100.''

title: A Bandage That Just Fades Away
description: WHAT'S the worst part of wearing an adhesive bandage? Probably the ''ouch'' factor, while pulling it off.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Mercedes-Benz CLK500; High Style, Surgically Enhanced
description: A LOT of baby boomers are having ''some work done'' on their sagging bodies -- getting a tuck here and a nip there -- and some of their cars are going under the scalpel, too. The wraps have come off the Mercedes-Benz CLK, a favorite coupe of the country club set, and the results are stunning.

title: 13 Are Hurt as 2 Fire Trucks Collide in the Bronx
description: A firefighter was in critical condition this morning after surgery for injuries he sustained when two fire trucks collided at an intersection just south of Pelham Bay Park in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Adirondack Water Bottler Buys a Canadian Supplier

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARLEY, DONALD F.
description: HARLEY-Donald F., 66. Of Dover, N.H., died suddenly Wednesday, September 25, 2002. Born April 4, 1936 in Springfield, PA, he was the son of Frederick and Emily (Taylor Jones) Harley. A U.S. Army Veteran he served as a First Lieutenant at Fort Ord, CA. He was a graduate of Drexel Institute of Technology in 1959 with a degree in Business Administration. Mr. Harley was Controller for Holiday Inn, Colton Manor in Atlantic City, NJ, the Boston 1800, where he met his wife Jean, and Wentworth-By-The Sea in New Castle, N.H. For 25 years prior to his retirement in 1999 he was the Treasurer of Student Activity Fee at the University of New Hampshire. He was a much revered mentor to many U.N.H. Student Leaders. At the time of his retirement, they wrote of him in their publication, The New Hampshire, ''Sometimes the words ''Thank You'' cannot say enough. For 24 years and several months, one man was the lighthouse guiding students through the challenges of leadership. This man was Don Harley.'' An avid kayaker, runner and animal lover, he also enjoyed learning and reading Spanish. He will be dearly missed by his wife of 30 years Jean (Kennedy) Harley of Dover, a stepson Kenneth Moore of Pennsylviania, a brother Edward Harley of San Francisco, CA, two nieces Jannice and Ramona of San Francisco, as well as his many friends. He was predeceased by a brother David and his former wife Margaret (Delaney) Harley. Memorial contribtions in his memory may be made to the Donald F. Harley Scholarship Fund, University of New Hampshire Foundation, Elliot Alumni Center, 9 Edgewood Road, Durham, N.H. 03824.

title: Snapshots Fixed in Memory
description: IN my favorite family picture from the year we lived in India, I am wearing a white dress and sitting on a cane-work stool, next to my mother and my younger brother. I am 5 years old, I am smiling very slightly, and I look rather like a child from somewhat longer ago than 1963, perhaps like some relic of the Empire. Behind us stand my father, an anthropologist whose fieldwork had brought us to this fairly remote village in West Bengal, and his assistant, an intense young Indian man, all in white, arms folded, gazing off into the distance, as well as our cook, who looks less formal and more friendly. My father, who is wearing a short-sleeved polo shirt and pants with a black belt, looks very very young to me. He is my father at 36, stopped in time, his funny dark brush beard and mustache, his pen tucked neatly into his shirt pocket, his stick-out ears.

title: How Many Bulbs Does It Take To Light a 5-Foot Chandelier?
description: A mere $200,000 for a home in Chappaqua?

title: Shutdown of West Coast Ports Puts Asian Businesses on Edge
description: As the shutdown of West Coast shipping enters a second week, businesses from Japan to Pakistan are growing increasingly worried that a protracted dispute between American longshoremen and port operators could cripple Asia's economic recovery.

title: Ideas & Trends; A New Book, Featuring Another Spineless Woman
description: OH, where are the heroines of yesteryear? The strong, the virtuous, the impeccably competent: Antigone. Nancy Drew. Jane Eyre. And, most especially, Elizabeth Bennet, Jane Austen's model of admirable womanhood?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, MARILYN
description: NEWMAN-Marilyn. Passionate advocate for the blind. Leaves many friends and son Benjamin. Service St. Mark's Church October 12 at 4 PM.

title: Diane Cardwell, Eric Nonacs
description: Diane Cardwell and Eric Steven Nonacs were married yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club in New York. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor, officiated.

title: Campaign Season; True Colors? That Depends on How You Define 'True'
description: On his campaign Web site (www.richardpombo.com) last week, Representative Richard W. Pombo, Republican of California, had a picture of Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, that shows Mr. Daschle during the Pledge of Allegiance with his left hand on his chest. Under the picture is the caption, ''Tom Daschle shows his true colors.''

title: Campaign Season; Looking for Upsets in All Kinds of Places
description: Like touts at a racetrack, political operatives pride themselves on their ability to pick long shots. With that in mind, two top staff members who have been tracking House races all year -- Steve Schmidt of the National Republican Congressional Committee and Jennifer Backus of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee -- were each invited to identify three races where they would put money on their party's candidates to win even though independent handicappers expect those candidates to lose.

title: East Hampton's Stand Against Ferry Service
description: Re ''North Fork vs. South Over Traffic Plans'' [Sept. 29]: the comments of the East Hampton supervisor, Jay Schneiderman, in refusing to consider direct ferry service between New England and East Hampton are outrageous and elitist.

title: Nigerian Militias Wield Power Through Intimidation
description: Even by the standards of this most violent of cities, the killings at a busy junction one recent evening got people shouting.

title: A Hurdle Cleared on Riverfront Site
description: THE village of Sleepy Hollow and the General Motors Corporation officially ended the latest volley in their continuing David-and-Goliath legal struggle over control and development of the former automobile plant site, a 97-acre riverfront property that was closed in 1996 and has since been razed. The battle has been particularly heated because of the reverberations, both temporary and long term, for local school districts, Metro-North Railroad and the public riverfront.

title: Number Games: Slicing and Dicing a Savory Season
description: AFTER Barry Bonds was told last week that a Harvard statistics professor had devised a formula that rated Bonds's amazing 2002 season as the best in baseball history, the San Francisco Giants slugger swatted the news away like another hanging slider. ''He's from Harvard?'' Bonds harrumphed. ''There's some true idiots at Harvard.''

title: Public Opinion
description: WHEN IT comes to public art, sometimes it seems as if everybodys a critic. After the recent controversy over the Eric Fischl sculpture Tumbling Woman, the City section asked readers to nominate a work of public art they would like to see consigned to the dustbin. Their suggestions came from all around the city, although a certain installation on Union Square proved especially (un)popular.

title: 'Law in America'
description: At my university (Stanford) I teach a course to undergraduates called Introduction to American Law. On my way to class, on the first day-the class usually meets at nine o'clock, and it is a tough assignment to keep the students awake-I buy a copy of the Chronicle, the morning newspaper from San Francisco. When I begin the class, after the first few announcements and the like, I wave the paper in front of the class, and read some of the headlines. The point I want to get across to the students is that every domestic story in the front part of the newspaper, before you get to the recipes and the comics and the sports pages, has a legal angle-has some connection with the legal system. Of course, I have no control over the newspaper, but the trick never fails. Almost invariably, every story about public life in the United States, or private life interesting enough to get into the newspaper, will mention a law, a legal proposal, a bill in Congress or in the state legislature, or something a judge, a policeman, a court, a lawyer has done or said; or some statement from the president or other high officials, in any case always about some affair or situation or event done , with, through, or against the law. In the world we live in-the country we live in-almost nothing has more impact on our lives, nothing is more entangled with our everyday existence, than that something we call the law. This is a startling fact; and it gets the students attention-as it should.

title: America, the Beautiful And the Saccharine
description: The bassist Charlie Haden's new album, ''American Dreams'' (Verve), is probably his most stoutly commercial move in 33 years of making records under his own name. But it has a few tricks up its sleeve.

title: Knicks' Big Men Taking The Low Road in the Post
description: Kurt Thomas was full of himself on Friday afternoon and he made no attempt to hide it. After going 3-0 against Antonio McDyess's squad in the morning scrimmages, he boasted and laughed loudly at lunch.

title: Killer Guest List: Medea, Cinderella and Macbeth
description: CENTENNIAL tributes to Richard Rodgers are still happening everyday and, it seems, everywhere.

title: Fighting Unwelcome Geese
description: THERE are few things more moving than an autumn sky filled with migratory geese flying in V-shaped formations on their annual trek south for the winter. And there are few things more messy than having the whole honking flock make a pit stop on your property.

title: POET LAUREATE CONTROVERSY
description: The New Jersey poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, spent much of his week defending a poem he wrote about the Sept. 11 attacks, a poem that had Governor McGreevey calling for his resignation. The work, ''Somebody Blew Up America,'' implies that Israel knew about the attacks in advance. Mr. Baraka said that he would not resign and that the facts in his poem can be verified. There is no state law that can remove Mr. Baraka, 67, from the post but aides to Governor McGreevey said they would continue to urge him to resign. John Holl

description: When a team wins three successive World Series and four in six years, it doesn't face too many games where, as Derek Jeter said, ''Bottom line: you win or you go home.''

description: BOARD OF EDUCATION politics can be rough. Here, it is a blood sport.

description: Victor Hugo was born in the Franche-Comt region of eastern France. This fall his hometown of Besanon celebrates the 200th anniversary of his birth with a 19th-century-style street carnival and a museum show.

description: OF the 62 acres purchased two years ago by a developer in the town of Greenburgh, five miles north of New York City in Westchester County, only 10 are being developed -- creating 86 attached homes while preserving the rest as wooded open space.

title: 'Music of a Life'
description: Icould quite easily pinpoint the date of that encounter. It goes back at least a quarter of a century - more precisely, to the year when a celebrated Russian philosopher, then a political refugee in Munich, coined a phrase that quickly gained currency, an expression thinkers, politicians, and even mere mortals would go on using for a good decade or more throughout the world. The extraordinary success enjoyed his formula stemmed from one palpable merit: in two Latin words the philosopher had succeeded in summing up the lives of the 240 million human beings who, at that time, peopled the land of my birth. Men and women, children and adults, old people and newborn babes, the living and the dead, the sick and the healthy, innocents and murderers, the learned and the ignorant, workers in the depths of coal mines, cosmonauts in their celestial orbits - these and thousands of other categories of people were all linked to a common essence this innovative expression. They all began to exist under one generic name.

title: 'Jim Crow's Children'
description: one of us niggers never knowed nothin' 'bout readin' and writin'. Dere warn't no school for niggers den, and I ain't never been to school a day in my life. Niggers was more skeered of newspapers dan dey is of snakes now, and us never knowed what a Bible was dem days."

description: JAPAN'S economy may be in the dumps, but one industry here has taken the world by storm: trading-card games.

title: Ties Optional
description: Many businessmen discarded their neckties when companies encouraged ''dressing down.'' But ties have been rediscovered by inventive recyclers. Some women make them into skirts like the one at left. A young man, right, turned a bunch of ties into a kilt. Ties also show up trailing theatrically from a black coat, far right. The young woman at bottom right center appears to have tied herself up; in fact, she is wearing ties stitched to a deconstructed jacket. Then there are the walking spoofs of strict dress codes, which are being revived in some places: the two women below who cleverly attached shirt-and-tie sets to their tank tops, and the two young men, far left, who knotted ties over their T-shirts.

description: To the editor:

title: Dressing Italian
description: EUROPEANS, for all their gastronomic pedigrees, never had to improvise muffling devices for terrible alcohol, as Americans did during Prohibition, so they are generally relegated to spectator status in cocktail history. That being the case, it is wise to be suspicious of the origins of one of my all-time favorite cocktails, the Negroni.

description: Buckle Up, and Mind The Stradivarius
