description: AS the November election approaches, House and Senate stalwarts of Social Security privatization have backed away from the issue as if it were toxic.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Ideas & Trends; Lousy Childhoods Ain't What They Used to Be
description: REMEMBER phonies? They drove Holden Caulfield crazy. They were dishonest and self-involved and distant, loaded with lousy values and crumby tricks. Take the phony who said ''How marvelous to see you!'' to Holden when she really meant ''How's your big brother?'' And yet the phonies of J. D. Salinger's preppie-meltdown classic are looking pretty good these days.

title: In China, Catholic Churches Flourish, but Under Controls
description: Han Tingming, 64, beamed as he regarded the gleaming white church spires that shoot up toward heaven from this village of simple mud-brick homes, towering over the wheat fields.

title: Jennifer Caulfield, Stephanie Scott
description: Jennifer Katherine Caulfield, a daughter of Robert L. Caulfield of San Francisco and the late Susan Johnson Murphy, affirmed her partnership yesterday with Dr. Stephanie Anne Scott, the daughter of Margaret A. Dufault of Birmingham, Mich., and N. David Scott of Boyne City, Mich. Dr. Louis Cubba, a minister of the Universal Life Church and a friend of the couple, led a commitment ceremony at the Headlands Center for the Arts in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTLIEB, ELIZABETH
description: GOTTLIEB-Elizabeth. October 4. Wife of the late Sergius. Beloved mother of Carl Gottlieb and Jane Goldberg. Grandmother of Ari, Shoshana, Benjamin and Talia. Great-grandmother of Zachary, Maya and Alexandra.

title: Little Grown-Ups Live Here
description: Sometime in the early 1950's, a young artist and illustrator slid a drawing of two little girls -- a scruffy little ruffian carrying a club and a fluffy one with an enormous pink hair bow -- under the door of his neighbor, a fashion editor at Harper's Bazaar. It was a game between them, a joke. The neighbor introduced the illustrator, Hilary Knight, to her great and glamorous friend Kay Thompson, who lived at the Plaza Hotel and had had a long, varied career that included being Judy Garland's vocal coach and inventing her own wildly successful nightclub act. Thompson, also as a game, for years had been improvising a 6-year-old alter ego she called Eloise to amuse her celebrated friends on movie sets and at parties; Eloise offered hilarious advice over the phone as well. Knight's little girls, it seemed to the neighbor, were kindred spirits to Thompson's alter ego.

title: High School Confidential
description: TEACHER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, EDWARD H.
description: SCHILLER-Edward H., 80. Of Sarasota, FL, formerly of Roslyn Heights, Long Island, and Santa Barbara, CA., died in Sarasota. Boy's High, WWII Trailblazers, consummate teacher, (Professor of History, Nassau and Santa Barbara Community Colleges) with a passion for the ''world of ideas,'' social justice, humanistic values, a man full of love, warmth and wit. Wife of 47 years, Roselle Lind, died 1991 in Santa Barbara. Survived by second wife, Evvie Gross. A loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, and devoted friend, he is deeply missed. Please write a favorite moment to daughter Leslie at fishernest@aol.com

title: Top Performers
description: PASSING FANCY

title: Brazil May Not Stay Upright on a Shaky Global Stage
description: No matter who wins the Brazilian presidential elections on Sunday, the biggest loser could end up being the American recipe for globalization.

title: Ideas & Trends: The Monster of Id; I Am Japan, Hear Me Roar
description: FORGET economic statistics, academic journals and earnest college professors. Those wondering what obsesses and unnerves the Japanese have long known to look no further than the latest Godzilla film for answers.

title: The Nation; The Court: Same Time Next Year. And Next Year.
description: IMAGINE going to work every day with the same eight people: laboring together on joint projects, eating together in a small private dining room, huddling together for hours every week behind a locked door that discourages all but the most urgent interruptions.

title: Finding a Lost World Where Others Feared to Tread
description: IN 1911, in a London lecture hall, Prof. George Challenger produces a map he claims shows the way to a mysterious ''lost world'' somewhere in the uncharted depths of the Amazon jungle. His requests for participants and financial backing are met with heckling from his more conventional colleagues - until Lord John Roxton, a renowned biggame hunter, signs up for the expedition. Soon, Prof. Leo Summerlee, Challenger's archrival, and Edward Malone, a young reporter, are clamoring to join in the adventure. Little do they know that far beyond the smog and gaslights, exists a forgotten land - populated by terrifying ancient creatures - from which they may never return.

title: Private Sector; Swapping Music for Film
description: With his company dissected in bankruptcy court, Shawn Fanning, who battled the music industry with his file-sharing software Napster, may have found a new career: movie star.

title: A 'Let's Try This' Approach to Musicals
description: EVER since the movie musical fell out of commercial favor in the late 1960's, filmmakers have dreamed of salvaging the genre by reinventing it. The rock 'n' roll era brought with it the jukebox musical (not strictly a musical, since the characters didn't sing), which culminated with ''Saturday Night Fever.'' A few years later, the rise of MTV inspired ''Flashdance'' and ''Footloose,'' streamlined confections whose prerecorded scores and aerobic choreography only underlined the obsolescence of the cumbersome book musical peopled by characters who actually broke into song.

title: 'Inventing America'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Married Man'; Opera DVD's; Kim Delaney
description: `MARRIED MAN'

title: Homecoming Queen
description: I WAS walking out the door on my way to see the movie ''Sweet Home Alabama'' on its opening night when the phone rang. ''So how long after this movie are you going to break up with me?''

title: Big-Time Drug Dealers Thinking Small
description: STANDING at the intersection of Quinnipiac and Washington Streets in downtown Wallingford is a two-floor apartment house that is often littered with children's bicycles, rakes and a cooler on the lawn in the backyard. The yellow apartment house is next to the Old Dublin, an Irish bar, and down the street from the Mexican Grocery.

title: Kimberly Sturz, Gregory Gaynor
description: Kimberly Deering Sturz, the daughter of Laura J. Sturz and Paul L. Sturz of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to N. Gregory Gaynor, the son of Pamela S. Gaynor and Norman J. Gaynor III of Hartville, Ohio. The Rev. David J. Lucey officiated at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: The World; Will the Real Saddam Hussein Please Step Down
description: IN a rhetorical turn that conjured Clint Eastwood, Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, suggested last week that the estimated cost of a war in Iraq -- tens of billions of dollars by most counts -- might be needlessly high. ''The cost of one bullet,'' Mr. Fleischer said, ''if the Iraqi people take it on themselves, is substantially less than that.''

title: Alison Larkin, Michael Becker
description: Alison Jean Larkin, the daughter of Jean and Alan Larkin of Manchester, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Taylor Becker, the son of Elizabeth Cardwell Becker of Atlanta and Roger Taylor Becker of Kalamazoo, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Alan C. Mermann performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ Congregational in Norfolk, Conn.

title: Campaign Season; Looking Back, and Ahead, in Laughter
description: When she was first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, left, seemed to change her hairstyle weekly. Since she has been in the Senate, Mrs. Clinton has kept the same hairdo -- short, blond and TV-ready. She has also worked to dispel the notion that she is humorless.

title: Dedicating a Site Where the Redcoats Won
description: IN the early 1990's a group of residents of Fort Montgomery, a small town on the Hudson a mile north of Bear Mountain in Orange County, formed an association to restore and preserve the site of a bloody Revolutionary War battle there in 1777.

title: Celebrities Known for Political Outspokenness Have Little to Say About Iraq
description: Warren Beatty, his wife, Annette Bening, and other Hollywood liberal luminaries gathered on Wednesday night for a talk by Scott Ritter, the former United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq whose recent statements about Saddam Hussein's weapons programs had undercut the Bush administration's arguments for a pre-emptive attack.

title: SUPERFUND MONEY
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency announced last week that New Jersey would receive $61.2 million in federal financing to help clean 10 of the state's 115 Superfund sites. Christie Whitman, the agency's administrator, said some of the money was earmarked for cleaning up contaminated soil at the former Chemical Insecticide Corporation site in Edison and Burnt Fly Bog in Marlboro and to remove tainted groundwater in Evesham, Medford, Howell and Buena Borough. The E.P.A. also proposed more restrictive rules for the ocean dumping of PCB-laden soil off the state's coast. Jeremy Pearce

title: Police on the Watch at Smith Haven Mall
description: THANKS to shoplifters, some would-be vampires this Halloween may have to go toothless.

title: TRYING TO SPY A TIGER IN THE WILD
description: ''THIS is the forest primeval.'' The voice of my eighth-grade teacher chanting Longfellow's ''Evangeline'' floated back to me as I gazed at the jungle from the banks of the Kabini River in the deep south of India. The Nagarahole National Park, also known as Rajiv Gandhi National Park, in Karnataka is a long way from Nova Scotia, Longfellow's Acadia. But it has a better claim to look the way the world did before man came on the scene.

title: Ineffable Sounds in a Haunted Place
description: FEW corners of Germany are more remote. The Usedom Music Festival, already out of the way, opened its season last weekend with a major commemorative performance of Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem'' in this village at the northern tip of the island of Usedom in the Baltic Sea, within shouting distance of Poland.

title: Mutual Funds Report; The Bright Side of Losses: Years of Tax Savings
description: MUTUAL fund investors have not had much good news lately, but there is a glimmer of sunshine: some of their big losses of the last two years could be a big benefit in the long run.

title: Irked Georgia Beats Alabama on Good-Looking Kick
description: Georgia place-kicker Billy Bennett got a haircut this week, not to keep his curly bangs out of his eyes, but to make sure he looked good on television for interviews after a game-winning kick against Alabama.

title: Unveiling Hidden Gems, Courtesy of Collectors
description: GREENWICH is known for displaying its prosperity rather conspicuously, so the first half of ''Pleasures of Collecting'' at the Bruce Museum confirms that there is a rarer aspect to its reputation. It is an exhibition mostly made up of work from private collections in town that has not been exhibited before.

title: News of Race's Demise May Not Be Premature
description: PARIS, Oct. 5  This obituary would have been unimaginable a few years ago. The Grand Prix Midi Libre, one of France's most enjoyable bicycle races, died last month after a short and complex ailment. It was 53. Never more than the fourth-ranked multiday race in the country, it was nevertheless known for attracting top riders as a tuneup to the Tour de France, for the hospitality of its organizers and for the enchanting countryside it covered. The race leaves many friends.

title: International Datebook: Oct. 24 to Nov. 17
description: OCT. 24 TO 28, PARIS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, JULIUS (JULIE)
description: HOROWITZ - Julius (Julie). 10/13/31 - 10/6/97. Remem bered today and everyday with much love. Jean

title: In Nassau, Ripples From Refinancing
description: WITH interest rates low and the stock market shaky, Long Islanders are buying real estate and refinancing their homes at an accelerated pace. Nassau and Suffolk counties report that the number of residential mortgages and mortgage refinancings have doubled in two years, going from 54,003 for the first six months of 2000 to 114,317 for the same period this year.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: AFTERGLOW

title: The Orpheus Mystique (and Myths)
description: IT is hard to believe that Orpheus turns 30 this season and is pondering how to regenerate itself after its oldest members begin to retire. But this cooperatively run, conductorless chamber orchestra, a musical child of the counterculture, has matured in more ways than one.

title: Brawling With Barbra Online
description: THE Internet is a terrific place to have a brawl, at least if you want a crowd. Post, riposte, with a potential audience of millions.

description: Angela Pamela Hach, the daughter of Lilo Blumenthal of Diez, Germany, and Maciek Rybczynski of Kaiserslautern, Germany, was married yesterday to Robert Linus Higgs, the son of Shelby and John Higgs of Richmond, Va. The Rev. Eidan Cannon performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Peebles, Scotland.

title: Fatal Shooting in Belfast Raises Concern That Feud Is Growing
description: Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing, held demonstrations today to protest the police raids of its parliamentary offices on Friday, while Protestant hard-liners continued to use the raids to attack Sinn Fein.

title: Fern Berman, Faith Middleton
description: Fern Berman and Faith Middleton are to celebrate their relationship with a commitment ceremony today at Le Cirque 2000 in Manhattan. The Rev. Bruce Clements, a retired minister of the United Church of Christ, will officiate with Cantor Ellen L. Stettner.

title: When Perks Influence the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: World-Class, But California In Spirit
description: A RECENT publicity photograph for the San Francisco Ballet features an exuberant blond dancer being embraced by her partner as they sit on top of a red convertible, her long legs stretched over the back seat, her feet in pristine white point shoes. She is also wearing a lime green tutu that looks like a flying saucer.

title: Rockville Centre Halts a Regents Exam
description: WHEN Tom Hennessey and Mike Book saw the results of the Regents exams in physics that their students took in June, they thought something was wrong.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; FAILED THERAPY
description: Gene therapy suffered a serious setback when authorities in France and the United States announced that the field's first and only successful experiment may have given a 3-year-old boy an illness similar to leukemia. Four studies have been suspended. The Food and Drug Administration is planning to investigate further. Sheryl Gay Stolberg

title: REAWAKENING THE GLORIES OF BUDDHIST KINGDOMS
description: THEY were among the world's first great Buddhist kingdoms, but civil war has kept them off the tourist map of Asia for decades. Now, in the dry expanses of central Sri Lanka, a remarkable cluster of ruined ancient cities, palaces and gardens can again offer a glimpse of life under kings who created an irrigation system to make the landscape bloom, then crowned its rocky outcroppings and fertile valleys with magnificent temples and royal residences.

title: Tracey Budzinski, Neil Burke Jr.
description: Tracey Lee Budzinski, the daughter of Sandra and Robert C. Budzinski of Ipswich, Mass., is to be married today to Neil Anthony Burke Jr., the son of Catherine M. McDowell of Vero Beach, Fla., and Mr. Burke Sr. of Swampscott, Mass. The Rev. James J. Harrington is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.

title: Ousted by King, Nepal Premier Asks for Support
description: Twenty-four hours after being summarily dismissed as prime minister, Sher Bahadur Deuba appeared visibly shaken tonight, nervously playing with his wedding ring and lighting up a cigarette to calm his nerves.

title: Rapture And Rupture
description: There was a time in Washington when the word ''rapture'' was used to refer to rapscallion senators chasing exotic dancers, or a president enjoying a pizza with an intern.

title: Jennifer Siegel, John McNamara
description: Jennifer Kate Siegel, the managing attorney of the New York City Commission on Human Rights, and John Frederick McNamara, a New York City firefighter, were married on Friday at George Washington Manor in Roslyn, N.Y. Steven G. Leventhal, the acting justice of the Village of Oyster Bay Cove, N.Y., officiated.

title: POSTINGS: At Madison Avenue and 128th Street; First Permanent Office For Legal Aid Society
description: While a couple of high-profile developments in Harlem have been canceled or shelved recently, foundations were being poured at Madison Avenue and 128th Street for the Legal Aid Society's new five-story, $18 million neighborhood office.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Phantom Mailbox

title: Campaign Season; This Special Guest May Have Been a Little Too Special
description: Rick Clayburgh, the Republican challenging Representative Earl Pomeroy for North Dakota's lone House seat, had a fund-raiser in Washington last week where, according to the invitation, John T. Korsmo, chairman of the Federal Housing Finance Board, was the ''special guest.'' Officials of home loan banks, which are regulated by the board, were invited to cough up $500 to attend the event and hear Mr. Korsmo speak.

title: Just a Little Six-Course Meal I Threw Together
description: IT is a rare kitchen island that threatens to show up an art collection that includes paintings by David Hockney, Robert Rauschenberg and Richard Serra. But that is just what happened last week when 30 guests gathered at the Pacific Palisades home of Howard Sadowsky.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHY on earth, many have asked, would David Lynch, prince of cinematic darkness, make a movie about an old man driving a lawn mower to Wisconsin? Actually, why would anybody make a movie about an old man driving a lawn mower to Wisconsin? The film in question, THE STRAIGHT STORY (1999), stars Richard Farnsworth as an Iowa farmer without a driver's license, desperate to see his estranged brother, who has had a stroke. The farmer's trip, especially the shots of rolling fields and farming, is poetry, sometimes as hypnotic as a drug. Mr. Farnsworth received an Oscar nomination for his performance and died, by his own hand, eight months later. He had been battling cancer - Sunday at 8 and 11:45 p.m. and Monday at 6 p.m. on IFC.

title: The View From/Newtown; Over the Guardrail, The Other Side of Paradise
description: WHEN Peggy and Gary Fillion moved into the Riverside section of Newtown last June, they thought they had just purchased a small piece of paradise. Nestled along the shore of the Housatonic River, they enjoy the river as their backyard. A pine forest where eagles roost frames the background.

title: Corrections
description: Picture and illustration credits were reversed in Long Island copies last Sunday with an article about meditation spaces at office buildings, and the illustration credit was incomplete. The photographer was Maxine Hicks, for The New York Times, and the illustrator was Jane Sanderson, for T. Weiss Realty.

title: Drawing Board Beckons Yankees
description: Shortly after losing the World Series last fall, the Yankees' top baseball officials met in Orlando, Fla., and devised a plan to correct what ailed the team. The Yankees had failed to win the World Series for the first time since 1997, and the consensus was that the team needed to improve its on-base percentage.

title: Burial Ground of Unkept Promises
description: It has been more than a decade since contractors excavating for a federal office tower in Lower Manhattan came upon a Colonial-era cemetery for slaves and others of African descent. It was a remarkable discovery offering opportunities for research as well as for a belated show of respect to those whose remains had been disturbed. Agreements were made and deadlines set time and again. The delays must not be permitted to go on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUERER, MIRIAM ROSANES
description: KUERER-Miriam Rosanes. On September 10, 2002, after a brave battle with cancer. Survived by husband Frank, daughters Barbara Gangi and Vicki Levine, brother Irving, and granchildren Jess Gangi, Theo Gangi and Alexandra Levine.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; SUSPECT RELEASED
description: Swedish authorities released Kerim Sadok Chatty, 29, who was arrested last month after he tried to board a Boeing 737 with a loaded gun in his carry-on luggage. Investigators said they did not have enough evidence to indict him on hijacking charges.

title: What Bush Can Learn From Truman
description: Is George W. Bush another Harry S. Truman? He and we should surely hope so. While Truman waged bruising domestic political battles and suffered long bouts of public unpopularity, he is viewed now as having presided over the most creative and productive period in American diplomatic history. In these perilous and fateful times, President Bush would do well to absorb key elements of Truman's approach to national security policy.

title: East Hampton's Stand Against Ferry Service
description: The Sustainable East End Development Strategies initiative may be guilty of political miscalculations and even some down-home naivet, but the claim by the Southold supervisor, Josh Horton, of a coverup is inaccurate. I should know: I worked part-time for the East End Transportation Council to assist in coordinating this complex procedure from January 2001 until August 2002.

title: College, 25 Years and a World Apart
description: LIFE has a funny way of coming full circle. This fall, I have a daughter applying to college at the same time that I am helping plan my 25th college reunion. The dovetailing of the two events has put both rites of passage in perspective.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: UP IN THE AIR, by Walter Kirn. (Anchor, $13.) Ryan Bingham, this novel's troubled hero, is a career transition counselor (which means he crisscrosses the country firing people) who is desperately trying to amass one million frequent flier miles before he leaves or is himself downsized. A denizen of ''Airworld,'' a parallel universe with its own language, culture and architecture, Bingham ''is as original and cool a character to come along in American fiction in a while,'' Christopher Buckley wrote here in 2001. ''Kirn is such a sharp writer he gives your brain paper cuts.''

title: A Poet of Love And Chaos In the Valley
description: PAUL THOMAS ANDERSON, 32, is the unofficial poet laureate of the San Fernando Valley.

title: New York
description: The bottom of this city of cities may not possess the high fashion of Fifth Avenue, the glitter of Times Square or the uptown constellation of museums and concert halls. But Lower Manhattan is where to go, simple as that.

title: INTERIM RUTGERS PRESIDENT
description: The board of governors of Rutgers University last week named the former provost of the university's Newark campus as the university's interim president. Norman Samuels, 64, who was head of the Newark campus for 20 years, will become president of the 50,000-student state university tomorrow and remain until a permanent replacement for Francis L. Lawrence, who announced his resigned in February, is found. The designation of an interim president gives the board of governors time to assess the results of a proposal to merge Rutgers with the New Jersey Institute of Technology and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. John Holl

title: No Clues On Why Wells Lost His Touch
description: It was the time of year when David Wells so often shines: playoff time with the Yankees, where Wells yearned to be for the last three seasons since his favorite team traded him in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, SHEILA
description: BRAND-Sheila. On June 4, 2002. Beloved wife of Justin Larkman, devoted daughter of Mildred Brand, sister of Carol Rose, beloved aunt of Melissa, Giles, Bryony, Oliver, Robert and Monica. Grant them rest, eternal rest.

title: Haldane Girls' Soccer Picks Fall Competition
description: IT wasn't really a vote.

title: Deirdre Dunphy, Matthew Hill
description: Deirdre Annemarie Dunphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Don Dunphy Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y., was married yesterday to Matthew Thomas Hill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Hill of Westbury, N.Y. The Rev. Ralph Sommer performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Brigid in Westbury.

title: Commuters to Washington Are Buying in Baltimore
description: IN the spring of 2001, Christine Pierpoint and her husband, Gary, both in their 30's, decided they had had enough of Rockville, Md., a Washington suburb. ''We had been living in a little house there for three years and we hated it,'' Ms. Pierpoint said. ''It took us over an hour to drive 15 miles to work in Washington. But we couldn't afford to live in the city.''

title: Murder Charge in Queens
description: A man was arrested yesterday after fatally stabbing the woman he had been living with in Queens for three weeks, the police said.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Value Funds a Haven? In This Slump, Hardly
description: THE bargain hunters never bargained for this.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, AMBASSADOR WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG - Ambassador Walter H. The Trustees and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of Walter H. Annenberg, an Emeritus Trustee and a member of the Joint Committee of the Trustees of our Annenberg School for Communication. Ambassador Annenberg was a loyal alumnus and dedicated benefactor who, with his wife, Leonore, made contributions of profound importance to the University and society. We remain forever indebted to him for his generosity and vision in founding on our campus in 1958 the Annenberg School for Communication, to promote the highest standards of professionalism and ethics in the fields of communication and journalism. By adding substantially to the original endowment through the Annenberg Foundation, to support among other things the Annenberg Institute for the Study of Democratic Institutions and Goverment and the Institute for Adolescent Risk Communication, he ensured the school's vitality and efficacy well into the future. Further demonstrating his commitment to higher education, he established 16 professorships at Penn, thereby strengthening schools, centers, and programs throughout the University. He funded the Annenberg Scholars to provide financial assistance to students who would not otherwise be able to afford undergraduate and graduate education. In addition, he was instrumental in the founding of the Center for Advanced Judaic Studies, the only institution in the world devoted exclusively to post-doctoral research on Jewish civilization in all its historical and cultural manifestations. He also founded here in 1970 the Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts, which continues to serve the University and the greater Philadelphia community. Walter Annenberg's name is forever linked to the history of this institution, having dramatically increased its ability to advance learning and culture throughout the world. The Penn community mourns the death of our friend and extends our profound sympathy to Leonore Annenberg and to the entire Annenberg family. Judith Rodin, President James Riepe, Chairman

title: Daring to Live Bigger
description: BACK in the 60's, I was content to be a faculty wife after I had my two boys, John and Tom. My husband, Harry, taught at Yale, and I stayed home and cooked and cleaned while my children crawled around on the kitchen floor.

title: What Becomes a Legend More?
description: ''Winners always write the history, and the Yankees have written more than their share,'' Glenn Stout writes in YANKEES CENTURY: 100 Years of New York Yankees Baseball (Houghton Mifflin, $35). He devotes plenty of space to the Yankees before they were winners -- they didn't hit pay dirt until 1921, their 19th season. As late as 1920, The Sporting News referred to the Yankees' ''Old Jinx,'' as the franchise seemed to be perpetually afflicted with debilitating injuries and various other forms of bad luck. That ended, of course, soon after the acquisition of Babe Ruth in 1920, though Stout refutes the oft-told story about the Boston Red Sox owner Harry Frazee selling the Bambino in order to finance a Broadway production of ''No, No, Nanette.'' Not to be confused with ''Yankees Century'' is A YANKEE CENTURY (Berkley, $26.95), a haphazard primer by Harvey Frommer on the franchise's history. THE NEW YORK YANKEES ILLUSTRATED HISTORY (St. Martin's, $29.95), on the other hand, is like a lovingly constructed family photo album, the margins filled with stories told by a few of your more interesting uncles, in this case The New York Times's sportswriters Dave Anderson, Murray Chass, Robert Lipsyte, Buster Olney and George Vecsey. Here are the familiar images -- Ruth watching his 60th homer sail over the fence; Lou Gehrig watching infield practice before the first game in nearly 15 years in which he didn't play; Casey Stengel gazing into his crystal baseball; Billy Martin and Reggie Jackson nearly coming to blows -- but there are others, both less familiar and more revealing. Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle are depicted in 1951 (DiMaggio's last season and Mantle's first). DiMaggio's smile appears forced, and he looks at neither the camera nor his understudy. As Lipsyte writes, ''Despite the hype or maybe because of it, the great DiMaggio never gave Mantle the time of day.'' Rob Neyer

title: What Reputation?
description: NOW that Robert Torricelli has made the quickest exit from a New Jersey political campaign since, oh, since Donald DiFrancesco, Douglas Forrester had better go back to the drawing board -- and the history books.

title: Will an Imperial Boss Bend With the Times?
description: OVER the years, Richard M. Scrushy, a founder and the chairman of the HealthSouth Corporation, has been criticized for running the company more as his own empire than as a public entity.

title: . . . and in West Farms, A Hotel With Brisk Turnover
description: Natalie Vsquez is not sure what went on inside the Alps Hotel, just down the block from her apartment, but the 17-year-old knows one thing: the prostitutes and pimps who hung out on nearby streets have not returned since the police padlocked the place Sept. 19.

title: Little Fish, Little Teeth, Big Appetite
description: For most of my life I have retained a haunting image from an old Tarzan movie: piranhas, those vicious little fish with the arrowhead-shaped teeth, devouring a pig.

title: At 54, a Troubadour Teams Muse With Marketer
description: JAMES TAYLOR'S home in the Berkshires is secluded in a way that suits the deeply personal nature of his songs. A driveway three quarters of a mile long leads through a dense canopy of maple trees to a modest, split-level house, where Mr. Taylor lives with his wife, Kim, and their 18-month-old twin sons. The talk there is of bear sightings, home renovations and a two-foot-long snake that had slithered into the garage. When Mr. Taylor spotted the snake near some garbage cans, it seems, he had calmly picked it up and tossed it writhing onto the lawn.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Investors and Businesses Trying Real Estate Hedge
description: IN an uncertain economy, some investors are trying to hedge against the ups and downs of their portfolios and businesses with Long Island real estate, which has been relatively stable over the years. Economists and real estate experts say, however, that potential investors should proceed with caution.

title: When Perks Influence the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Riddle in Seattle: Is Man Held by U.S. a Terrorist or Just a Hustler?
description: By the time James Ujaama returned here three months ago, he knew that federal agents had been following him for months and that his past would soon be interpreted in a way that would shock people here in his hometown, his friends said.

title: A Polish Master's Last Collaboration
description: FILM is more than 100 years old, which means that any film swims in a sea of references to films or performances or shots past. Sometimes whole films are remade, either to bring a classic up to date (''Cape Fear'') or to translate a usable script for another audience (''Three Men and a Baby'').

title: Convicted, Condemned And Innocent
description: COERCED confessions, conflicting DNA evidence and overturned convictions are the subjects of newspaper headlines. They are also elements of ''The Exonerated,'' a play about six wrongfully convicted death row inmates, starring Richard Dreyfuss, Jill Clayburgh and Sara Gilbert. Developed by two young actors from interviews with former prisoners, it opens on Thursday at 45 Bleecker Street under Bob Balaban's direction.

title: Jordan Gremp, Timothy Sullivan
description: Christine Elizabeth Jordan Gremp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Gremp of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Evan Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael B. Sullivan of Palo Alto, Calif. The Rev. Alan J. Lamica performed the ceremony at St. Brendan's Roman Catholic Church in Keene, N.Y.

title: It Growls, It's Creepy, It's at Your House
description: WHEN it comes to Halloween, Kenneth and Tracy Koessler admit they go to extremes. It's not just that Mr. Koessler once turned their front lawn into a haunted graveyard -- with a grave-size hole for himself so he could rise from the ''dead,'' scaring the kidneys out of young trick-or-treaters. The Koesslers have also spent thousands of dollars on the kinds of animated props once found only in movies and spook houses. There's the creepy shipping crate that shakes and growls at anyone who comes near and that cost nearly $3,000. That's tame next to the $5,000 Deep Fryer, a full-size model of a man in an electric chair who writhes and smokes.

title: Anna Ackerberg, Bryan Garsten
description: Anna Ruth Ackerberg, the daughter of Sylvia Lipnick of Huntington, N.Y., and Robert Ackerberg of Massapequa, N.Y., was married last evening to Bryan David Garsten, the son of Marion and Joel Garsten of Cheshire, Conn. Rabbi David B. Kudan officiated at the Mansion on Turner Hill in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Hard-to-Find Restaurant Is Worth the Trip
description: THERE may still be some golden autumn days conducive to outdoor dining at Aqua in Oceanside, but first you'll have to find the restaurant, and that's an adventure in itself. Virtually no one just stumbles upon this still-new restaurant at 92 New Street (516-766-9567). Diners must travel along a rutted, pocked street, flanked by auto parts businesses , junkyards and boatyards. But at the end of this commercial-industrial stretch, travelers will come upon an unexpectedly upbeat canal-side spot with valet parking, decks both open and under peaked canvas tents, an indoor dining room, oil cloth-covered tables, wicker chairs and an often-gentle sea breeze.

title: The Failure of Breast Self-Exams
description: For decades now many women have been scrupulously probing their breasts for suspicious lumps every month, using a rigorous approach developed to ensure that all areas of the breast are inspected carefully. They have performed this 15-minute ritual at the behest of health authorities and in the not unreasonable belief that such diligent searches may detect cancers early, when they are most curable. But last week researchers announced that a large and lengthy study in Shanghai had found no evidence that breast self-examinations reduced deaths from breast cancer. That could speed the demise of a practice that has become widely entrenched because it seemed intuitively sensible, offered women a tool to combat a fearsome disease and fit in with popular movements to give patients more control over their own health and bodies.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Fund Firm Weathers A Year of Big Losses
description: NAME some of the biggest companies involved in scandals over the last year, and chances are that Alliance Capital Management, one of the nation's largest investment companies, was one of the top shareholders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, SEYMOUR
description: SCHUMAN-Seymour. On October 5, 2002, at age 86. Born in NYC, attended City College, founder and Chairman of Propper Manufacturing Company, real estate developer in Long Island City and winner of the Tom DeLay Business Leadership Award. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Ina (and her husband Daniel Ebenstein), Jane Schuman and Marian Schuman Brennan. Adoring grandfather of David, Julie, Andrew and Stacy Ebenstein, Joseph Schuman, Elizabeth, Alex and Carolyn Schuman Brennan. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, Monday, October 7th, 10 AM. Interment to follow, Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Pennington Studied, Waiting for This Day
description: It began on the weekends in the house by a lake in Knoxville, Tenn. Elwood Pennington would settle into his recliner to watch football -- college on Saturdays, professional on Sundays -- and his 2-year-old son, Chad, a University of Tennessee helmet perched on his tiny shoulders, would assume his place on the floor of the den.

title: Spanish Colonial Art in a Santa Fe Setting
description: When the Spanish colonized the area around Santa Fe, N.M., in 1598, they transplanted not only their religion, language, crops and livestock but also an eclectic globe-girdling culture and style of art and design that came to be known as Spanish Colonial.

title: Defending Barbirolli
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: FREE FOR ALL

title: Private Sector; How to Score a Best Seller
description: By now, many people know that Arthur Levitt, former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has written a tell-all book for the small investor about what happens in the interconnected worlds of chief executives and Wall Street deal makers. At a party last week to celebrate the book's publication, Mr. Levitt was happy to call upon a high-powered connection of his own.

title: Who's to Blame For a School's Pain?; Drinking Coffee With Cause
description: To the Editor:

title: Athletics Unravel Quickly As Twins Force a Game 5
description: Heading back to Oakland by charter flight for the fifth and deciding game of their American League division series, the trainers for the Athletics and the Minnesota Twins packed the usual gear: bats, balls, gloves, whoopee cushions, handshake buzzers and exploding cigars.

title: 'The Autograph Man'
description: You're either for me or against me, thought Alex-Li Tandem, referring to the daylight and, more generally, to the day. He stretched flat and made two fists. He was fully determined to lie right here until he was given something to work with, something noble, something fine. He saw no purpose in leaving his bed for a day that was against him from the get-go. He had tried it before; no good could come from it.

title: A Stocking Stuffer For a Big Stocking
description: Neiman Marcus is preparing to take orders for a limited-edition version of the 2004 Cadillac XLR sports car, selected as the featured car in Neiman's holiday catalog this year. But buying one won't be as simple as shopping for cashmere socks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASTRACHAN, DR. BORIS M.
description: ASTRACHAN-Dr. Boris M. Died on September 21 at the age of 70. A national leader in the field of administrative and community psychiatry. Former director of the Connecticut Mental Health Center and deputy chairman Yale Psychiatry Department. In 1990, he became professor and head of the Psychiatry Department at the University of Illinois at Chicago. Beloved husband of Batja, brother of Samuel. Devoted father of David (Karen), Joseph, Michael (Bethany), and Ellen (Tony). Adored by his ten grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Johns Hopkins Pancreatic Cancer Research, Bunting-Blaustein Cancer Research Building, care of Dr. E. Jaffee, Room 4M-07, 1650 Orleans Street, Baltimore, MD. 21231.

title: Sirens and Serenity
description: JUST as I can no longer hear the sound of a jet flying overhead without freezing, I can no longer hear the plaintive wails of nearby sirens at Indian Point without panicking. That's what happened when I heard the first siren scream on a recent Friday morning, a little before 10 o'clock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONCANNON, EDWARD HURLEY
description: CONCANNON-Edward Hurley. Memorial Mass Monday, October 7, 11 AM, Our Lady of Fatima Church, Wilton, CT. Visitation Sunday, 4-6 PM, Hoyt Funeral Home, New Canaan, CT. Contributions may be made to the Connecticut Junior Republic Fund for Troubled Youth, PO Box 161, Litchfield, CT 06759.

title: Anti-Abortion Ads, Banned From Air, Take to Streets
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Oct. 4  On most mornings over the last three weeks, 14-year-old Jay Lewis and other students arriving at Marina High School in Huntington Beach have been confronted by graphic images: the severed parts of a fetus next to a dime or a quarter; emaciated concentration camp prisoners; a lynching victim hanging from a noose.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Falling Shares As a Symptom Of Something Bleaker
description: MAYBE the stock market really has been predicting the future of the economy.

title: Thanks To Defense, Irish Are Still Perfect
description: As the long shadows made their way across a hushed Notre Dame Stadium today, Coach Tyrone Willingham kept his jacket off and his sunglasses on, a poker face to the last. The home team was down, 7-3. Willingham's offense was going nowhere against the Stanford Cardinal, Willingham's former team, and the fans who had started to believe in magic were silent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERIAN, PETER G.
description: TERIAN-Peter G. The Board of Trustees, Staff, Administration and Families at the New York Foundling Hospital mourn the loss of Peter G. Terian, whose generosity of spirit so enhanced the lives of the thousands of children in our care. We send our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Juliana, daughter, Olivia, and to his friends and associates. Carol Anne Barnes, SC Chair New York Foundling 590 Avenue of the Americas New York, NY 10011

title: Of Ravel's Many 'Students,' the Real One
description: VLADO PERLEMUTER, the fastidious French pianist, died last month at 98. He wore the title Student of Ravel. More precisely, he was the one true student of Ravel.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; MIGRANTS PREVAIL
description: The United Farm Workers won a hard-fought victory when Gov. Gray Davis of California signed two bills giving them the right to mandatory mediation in disputes with farm operators. The farm workers are seeking improved working conditions and higher wages. The growers say the measures will add to their costs, raise retail produce prices and drive small farmers out of business. John M. Broder

title: A Changing of the Guard in Testy Times
description: WHEN David Alpert became the Democratic county chairman six years ago, Westchester had long been Republican country. The G.O.P. had an almost unbroken string of electing county executives and a majority in the county legislature.

title: When Perks Influence the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Even Hannibal Lecter Needs a Broker
description: SOMETIMES, it seems that our lives are so filled with advertising and product placements that we'll wake up one day with the Pepsi logo tattooed to the inside of our eyelids, visible every time we blink.

title: Fresh Voices And a Way With Words
description: THE Brooklyn Academy of Music will present its Next Wave of Song series next weekend, celebrating, for the second year, what it calls ''innovative, contemporary singer-songwriters.'' Ben Folds, Stephin Merritt and Marc Anthony Thompson are this year's featured performers.

title: Isn't Life Grand? Let's Complain About It
description: LOOKING at this year's Mayor's Management Report, which came out two weeks ago, I made some paradoxical observations.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: University Merger Closes In on Reality
description: DESPITE vehement opposition from politicians and some quarters of the medical establishment, sources close to Governor McGreevey said last week that a commission was poised to recommend a merger between Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey and the New Jersey Institute of Technology.

title: Laura Gardner, Jay Remington
description: Laura Colleen Gardner, the daughter of Carol and James Gardner of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Fitch Remington, the son of Chelsey and David Remington of Harvard, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Charles T. Rush, an American Baptist minister, performed a nondenominational Christian ceremony at Christ Church.

title: The Mayor's Out; The People Are In
description: Looking far richer but feeling a bit emptier than it has in generations, a thoroughly refreshed Gracie Mansion is beginning its third century cast in every familiar role -- historical museum, ceremonial hall, civic showpiece, high-level lodging and government meeting place -- but one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KART, HAROLD
description: KART-Harold. You left us too soon. The years we spent together will be cherished forever. We will miss your smiling face and your practical jokes. We will miss your sincerity, honesty, generosity and loving friendship. Your love for your family and friends will be admired forever. You have left a void in our hearts. We love you and will surely miss you. Hold a spot for us at the first tee! Roberta and Richie

title: 'Tricky Business'
description: THE CAPTAIN PUNCHED in a number and held the phone to his ear. He looked out over Biscayne Bay, which was choppy, toward the sky over the Atlantic, which was dark.

title: Op-Art; The Subway Stroll
Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, RAYMOND T.
description: McNALLY-Raymond T. Of Newton, MA, October 3. Husband of Carol (Maymon). Father of Michael of Chalfont, PA; Catherine McNally of Larchmont, NY; Brigitte McNally of Hull, MA; Tara McNally of Holland; and Patrick of Newton, MA. Brother of Doris Shell of Cleveland, OH. Funeral Mass Monday, October 7, at 11 AM in St. Ignatius Church, Chestnut Hill, MA. Donations may be made to Boston College in Memory of Raymond T. McNally, 140 Commonwealth Ave, More Hall, Rm 220, Chestnut Hill, MA 02467. For information: Eaton & Mackay Funeral Home, Newton Corner, MA.

title: Lollie Low, John Mathews
description: Loretta Ann Low, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ethelbert Holland Low of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to John Barrett Mathews, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J. Mathews of Fayetteville, N.Y. The Rev. James Mathews, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Longmeadow. The Rev. James Monroe, an Episcopal priest, took part.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 6, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Sin-City Exhibitionist
description: Q: You're the executive curator of New York's -- and the country's -- first sex museum, affectionately nicknamed MoSex. What are some of the challenges of the job?

title: REPLACING BREATHALYZERS
description: New Jersey, which is one of the last states to replace the old-fashioned Breathalyzers used by the police to test suspected drunken drivers, is awaiting court approval of a new machine that should be more accurate and require less training to operate, according to John Hagerty, spokesman for the state Division of Criminal Justice. The new machine, an Alcotest 7110 MKIII-C, made by a Durango, Colo., company, has been used in a trial run by the Pennsauken police department since November, and has been used in 20 drunken driving arrests. Its is being questioned by defense lawyers, and Superior Court Judge Francis J. Orlando Jr., sitting in Camden, is expected to rule sometime next year on whether the machine can be used in New Jersey courts. If it is approved, the machines will replace the 1950's-era Breathalyzers in the 465 police departments in the state. Breathalyzers depend on the operator reading a color change in chemicals, while the Alcotest uses infrared energy and a fuel cell and produces an automatic readout. Karen DeMasters

title: Tough Senate Race in Texas Gets Bush in Gear
description: Probably no race in the nation has drawn more interest and energy from President Bush than the fight for the Senate seat in Texas that Republicans have held for more than 40 years. The Republican candidate, John Cornyn, is a friend of the president, and as Mr. Cornyn observed recently, the Republicans have little chance of winning back the Senate if they cannot hold the seat in the president's home state.

title: Mentally Ill, and Locked Away in Nursing Homes
description: Hundreds of patients released from state psychiatric hospitals in New York in recent years are being locked away on isolated floors of nursing homes, where they are barred from going outside on their own, have almost no contact with others and have little ability to contest their confinement, according to interviews with workers and experts and visits to the homes.

title: How Do You Say Fusion in Paris? Unlike Anywhere Else
description: THE French always manage to do it their way, and when it comes to the growing trend of fusion fare in Paris restaurants, the chefs are calling the shots.

title: INSIDE
description: Seventh Target of Sniper

title: Congress Seeks F.B.I. Data On Informer; F.B.I. Resists
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation had a confidential informer who rented rooms in California to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers, but the bureau is resisting a request from the Congressional committee investigating the attacks to interview the informer and his F.B.I. handler, government officials said.

title: A Little One Is Transformed
description: When decanted for 45 minutes, Le Pigeoulet (Provenal for little one) en Provence becomes a captivating big one: meaty, rustic, gutsy. A ruby 2001 vin de pays -- country wine -- from Vaucluse, it suits game, lamb or onion soup.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; MALARIA DNA DECODED
description: The genomes of the main parasite that causes malaria and of the mosquito that carries it have been decoded by two international teams of scientists. The genomes will reveal new targets for drugs and perhaps a vaccine, researchers hope. Malaria, once curbed by DDT, now causes 2.7 million deaths a year, mostly in sub-Saharan Africa. Nicholas Wade

title: What's to Like?
description: DESOLATION

title: Cosmetic Work Done, Boston Hotel Reappears
description: The Ritz-Carlton, Boston, is scheduled to reopen tomorrow, exactly a year after it shut down for a face lift.

title: Amy Nadler, Andrew Horowitz
description: Amy Caryn Nadler, a daughter of Donna Nadler Gould of New York and David A. Nadler of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Andrew David Horowitz, a son of Lorie Horowitz and Dr. Alan E. Horowitz, both of West Bloomfield, Mich. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Once a Sure Bet, Utilities Funds Now Pose More Risks
description: INDIVIDUAL investors have been moving out of utility mutual funds, one of the worst-performing sectors recently. But some fund companies are joining the exodus, too.

title: I Love F.D.N.Y.
description: I bought an F.D.N.Y. T-shirt online to benefit a firefighters' fund. When I wore it to lunch, I wasn't charged for drinks, supposedly because my order was slow. But then I overheard the waitress tell the manager, ''I didn't charge that nice firefighter for his beers.'' I bought this shirt to support firefighters, not to impersonate one. I don't want favors under false pretenses. This wasn't the only time people were almost too cordial when I wore this shirt. Should I be reluctant to wear it? Vince Leskosky, Cleveland

title: When Perks Influence the Doctor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 16 about Dr. Orvan W. Hess, obstetrician and gynecologist, misstated the significance of his work with the fetal heart monitor in 1957. He and Dr. Edward H. Hon were at the forefront of the development of clinically useful devices to record fetal heart rate patterns continuously during delivery to identify patterns that indicated fetal distress. They were not the first to detect and record electrical cardiac signals from the fetus.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; MONEY PIT
description: Where is the bottom for the stock market? The Dow Jones industrial average fell to near a five-year low, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped to a six-year low. Any hope that the market reached bottom in the summer have now been dashed. With corporate earnings deteriorating, with economists reducing their economic growth forecasts for the next six months and with a war with Iraq on the horizon, it may be some time before the selling is over. Jonathan Fuerbringer

title: My Downtown: Just as I Like It
description: MY 5-year-old daughter and I have had a particular ritual for as many years as she could talk. Each time we drive down the main street of Merrick, our hometown, we try to guess the color of the gown in the ever-changing display in the dress-shop window.

title: Azaleas' Colorful Foliage Is Autumn's Surprise
description: LATE in August, as I was strolling through the grounds of Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island, I came across a shrub with deep burgundy foliage. Curious, I looked at the label and, much to my surprise, saw that the plant was a native azalea (Rhododendron vaseyi), a deciduous member of the rhododendrum family.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter to the editor last Sunday misstated the intention of a proposed state law to preserve nighttime vistas in rural areas, including Accabonac Harbor in East Hampton. It is the natural darkness, not light pollution, that the writer said is ''being restored through legislation.''

title: In Harrison District, Fingerpointing and Queries
description: IT has not been the easiest of times for the Harrison school district. Last spring, a high school senior, Robert Viscome, died after a fight at an unsupervised drinking party at a private home. Last month, nine high school football players were suspended from school after they attended an unsupervised party where alcohol was served.

title: The Wrap Says It All
description: On the heels of last year's Squibnocket Cards -- a line of text-heavy greeting cards that became popular material at poetry slams and rap concerts -- arrives a selection of quippy paper goods. One company, Sajedesign, has retro-graphic gift wrap ($4 a sheet) printed with phrases like ''If you don't like it, I'll keep it'' and ''Love what you've done with the place.'' Jane Wagman, an owner of the company, said the inspiration sprang from customer demand. ''They wanted cleverness, but didn't have time to come up with it themselves,'' Ms. Wagman said. Custom paper for those who want to write their own wrap is offered, too (50-sheet minimum; to order, 212-334-1296).

title: A Platform for the Blues
description: You've seen them. On this day, they're performing just beyond the end of Track 3 on the shuttle platform at Grand Central, seated on folding chairs near a banner that reads ''Music Under New York: Carolina Slim, Society Blues.'' The older one, who wears a black hat and is singing, plays a white electric guitar; the younger one is on washboard. They're in black pants and short-sleeved shirts with collars identically spread.

title: Boys' Case Is Used in Bid to Limit Trials of Minors as Adults
description: People across the country are consumed with the fates of Alex and Derek King.

title: The Youngest Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Baker's 10-Year Marriage With the Giants May Be Heading for a Breakup
description: Five of the six teams that finished last this year fired their managers, some of them twice. And then there's Dusty Baker.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you look at the number of people who went through the Al Qaeda training camps, and there are literally thousands who did, it stands to reason that a certain percentage of them are in this country.''

title: Portuguese Seafood Surprise in Freeport
description: PIER 95, a new seafood spot on the Hudson Canal in Freeport, doesn't sound Portuguese, but savvy diners will pick up the clues. Even those who don't know that John Silver, the chef and co-owner, cooked for the Portuguese ambassador to the United Nations and that Mr. Silver's partner, Ramiro Santos, owned the Portuguese restaurants Atlantis and Lareira, both in Mineola, will see signs and taste some of the flavors of Portugal.

title: The Israeli Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: A Neighborhood Duel, Pickles at the Ready
description: Don't call it a war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAKTER, WALTER JAY
description: PAKTER-Walter Jay. Of Berkeley, CA, on October 2nd at 59 years of age. A native of New York, living in Berkeley, CA for the past 28 years. Practice as an attorney in aviation law in Oakland, CA. A graduate of City College, subsequently earning his PhD at Johns Hopkins in Medieval History; a D.Phil. in Roman Law from Oxford University and an LLM from Boalt Hall. His publications include ''Jews and Medieval Cannon Law'' and ''Casebook of Comparative Law''. He was most proud of his assistance to victims of aviation accidents. Survived by his beloved wife Nancy Baumgardner Pakter for 35 years. Father of Alexander (Jill Nagle), David and Byron Pakter; son of Selma Mednikov Pakter and the late Paul D. Pakter; brother of David and Robert Pakter and Sheila Willner, Laura Fernandez and Leone Wollenberg. Services were held under the direction of Sinai Memorial Chapel-Lafayette, CA. Donations in his memory may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: The Nation; Public Schools Look Beyond the Bake Sale
description: INSCRIBED in nearly every state constitution is the promise of an education. Schooling must be ''thorough and efficient'' in Ohio, cultivate ''morality and intelligence'' in South Dakota, while bestowing ''wisdom and knowledge, as well as virtue'' in Massachusetts. Then there is New York, typically blunt in its guarantee of ''free common schools,'' though nobody seems to agree on exactly what that means.

title: Annabelle Brown, Gregory Fowlkes
description: Annabelle Elizabeth Brown, the daughter of Mrs. William W. Cowan of Fort Worth and H. L. Brown Jr. of Midland, Tex., was married last evening to Gregory Gilles Fowlkes, a son of Martine Andriveau Beuttler of La Mole, France, and J. Winston Fowlkes III of Washington, Conn. The Rev. Christopher N. Jambor officiated at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Fort Worth.

title: Rangers Expect Bure To Start the Season
description: Glen Sather, the Rangers' president and general manager, said tonight that right wing Pavel Bure, who underwent knee surgery on Sept. 26, would be ready to play in the regular-season opener Wednesday against the defending Eastern Conference champion Carolina Hurricanes.

title: The Last Laugh Goes to Lautenberg
description: Loyalty in politics is a fleeting thing, as Senator Robert Torricelli learned last week, with the shelf life of a bagel. Not 24 hours after Mr. Torricelli dropped out of the Senate race with the hope that his replacement would not be Frank R. Lautenberg -- his former Democratic Senate colleague and avowed enemy -- Democratic leaders announced that their new candidate would be none other than Mr. Lautenberg.

title: Who's to Blame For a School's Pain?
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking for Upsets in All Kinds of Places
description: Like touts at a racetrack, political operatives pride themselves on their ability to pick long shots. With that in mind, two top staff members who have been tracking House races all year  Steve Schmidt of the National Republican Congressional Committee and Jennifer Backus of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee  were each invited to identify three races where they would put money on their party's candidates to win even though independent handicappers expect those candidates to lose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. The partners, associates and staff of Shearman & Sterling mourn the death of their distinguished colleague and friend. A visionary, Ed Tuck opened Shearman & Sterling's first overseas office in Paris in 1962. Always at the forefront of international relations and understanding, he was named a Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur by the French government for his role in fostering French American cooperation. Over his illustrious career, he forged countless relationships from around the world that he nurtured throughout his life. His generosity, vitality and panache will be sorely missed. We wish to extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Liliane, and his children and grandchildren.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5; COMING UP
description: President Bush plans to visit Cincinnati on Monday to discuss the threat Saddam Hussein poses to the United States. The House and Senate will spend several days debating plans for granting Mr. Bush the authority to use force against Iraq. The Supreme Court begins its new term on Monday.

title: Double Talk on Democracy
description: The Bush administration likes to say that the establishment of a democratic government in Iraq could be a model for political reform in the Islamic world. That is no doubt true, and a desirable objective. Unfortunately, while the United States is preparing to fight a war in Iraq in part to achieve that goal, it is doing little to address undemocratic practices nearly everywhere else in the region.

title: Sounding the Human Quest
description: DECADES ago, the conductors Leopold Stokowski, Dimitri Mitropoulos and Leonard Bernstein proved that American orchestras could play the symphonies of Ralph Vaughan Williams as well as their English counterparts. But the lesson failed to stick. So a new recording of Vaughan Williams's First Symphony with Robert Spano conducting the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra (Telarc CD-80588) seems something novel rather than a belated link in a little-appreciated chain.

title: Campaign Season; A Familiar Name at an Unfamiliar Game
description: On his campaign stationery, David Scott, the Democratic nominee in Georgia's 13th District, lists Hank Aaron as his campaign treasurer. He is the real McCoy, the Hank Aaron who holds the major league record for career home runs. Mr. Scott is married to Mr. Aaron's sister Alfredia.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Monmouth Beach; A Town Where Water Lovers Abound
description: IN some ways, the one-square-mile borough of Monmouth Beach seems like a prototypical small town. Mayor James P. McConville III points out that the elementary school is small, parents are involved in Little League activities, the business district consists of about a dozen stores and neighbors rally around one another in times of need.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: They got it right the first time. New York was the capital of the nation at its birth. The first presidential inauguration, in 1789, wasn't far from ground zero, and the first presidential residence, at 3 Cherry Street, was on a spot now occupied by one of the supports for the Brooklyn Bridge. George Washington slept there, but not for long. In a political deal purportedly made on a downtown sidewalk, Alexander Hamilton traded away the location of the capital to Thomas Jefferson to entice the South to give the federal government power to assume state debts. A year later, Congress and the president decamped to Philadelphia, and a decade after that, they settled into a new federal city next to which the City of Brotherly Love seems like Shangri-La. As Jack Lait and Lee Mortimer, two New York tabloid reporters of a later day, would assess the fateful final choice of a national capital in their 1951 best seller, ''Washington Confidential'': ''The founding fathers, whose infinite wisdom gave us a Constitution and form of government well nigh perfect, located the seat of that government in a stinking, steaming swamp.''

title: No Big Fall in Mosquitoes After Communities Spray
description: MOSQUITO populations did not drop notably after trucks sprayed pesticides in Greenwich and Stamford, where people have caught the West Nile virus, the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station said.

title: Business; Chips With Muscle Set Off a Market Tug of War
description: IN the early 1990's, Sabrina Kemeny was among the researchers at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California who made spacecraft smaller and cheaper. The key was discovering how to build an optical sensor on a single semiconductor, allowing for smaller components that consumed less power.

description: ON a third-floor window of a corner building, high above the thrum of Audis and Jaguars cruising the length of Millburn Avenue, is a painted silhouette of a couple and the words Royal Ballroom.

description: Biljana Plavsic, a former Bosnian Serb leader indicted by the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, became the first high official to plead guilty to crimes against humanity. Mrs. Plavsic, 72, expressed remorse for her role in the persecution and deportation of uncounted Croats and Muslims.

title: Falling for a Children's Tale of an Age-Old Wish
description: IN 1975, the children's author Natalie Babbitt published a slim, ruminative novel called ''Tuck Everlasting.'' From the moment it appeared, it has been fiercely loved by children and their parents for its honest, intelligent grappling with aging and death. It seems appropriate, then, that the novel's new film adaptation had its genesis (more than 10 years ago) not at a power meeting in a Hollywood studio but during a family discussion.

description: By dispatching upstart Connecticut with ease tonight, Miami can focus on next Saturday's game against Florida State at the Orange Bowl. Never mind that the Seminoles struggled on Thursday night with Clemson and have lost to Louisville.

description: The Giants lacked identity when training camp opened in July, then slowly a faceless team created its self-portrait, with subtle augmentation through the preseason and the early weeks of the season.

description: Combe Inc., a White Plains-based company that makes niche products like Odor-Eaters and hair color products that include Just for Men and Grecian Formula, is expanding its holdings.

description: For every giant, there seems to be a giant killer -- or at least one person willing to chuck a well-aimed stone.

description: Princeton committed three turnovers, had a punt blocked for a safety, gave up five sacks and twice failed to convert on fourth down. But the Tigers still managed to ruin homecoming for Columbia, scoring two fourth-quarter touchdowns to rally past the Lions, 35-32, yesterday at Wien Stadium.

title: Train Crashed While Nearing Its Top Speed, Officials Say
description: The AirTrain that derailed on a curve during a test at Kennedy International Airport nine days ago was traveling near its top speed of 60 miles per hour, and though designed for automated operation, was being run manually by the driver who was killed, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.

title: OUT THERE: Paris; A Club With a One-Track Mind: Chocolate
description: LE CLUB DES CROQUEURS DE CHOCOLAT does not accept just anyone with a sweet tooth. Normally, only about 10 positions open each year, and membership is limited to 150. Hershey fans need not apply. Those who know their ganache from their gianduja stand a better chance of passing the interview.

title: CRIME
description: I'm a sucker for old cops, cold cases and any excuse to get out of town; and so, it turns out, is Sue Grafton, who hooks up her ever-game private eye, Kinsey Millhone, with two crotchety homicide detectives in Q IS FOR QUARRY (Marian Wood/Putnam, $26.95) and packs them off to a rural California backwater to sift through the ashes of an unsolved mystery dating back to 1969. Although she's always big on small details, Grafton puts a lot of particulars into the Jane Doe case that still haunts Lt. Con Dolan and his pal Stacey Oliphant. With both of these lovable geezers knocking hard on death's door, it falls to Kinsey to dig out the musty evidence and talk up residents with long-buried memories of the young woman whose body was dumped in a forgotten quarry, unknown and still unclaimed after all these years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEUNING, DOROTHEA MAE (NEE SMELTZER)
description: SCHLEUNING - Dorothea Mae (nee Smeltzer). Died October 1, 2002, at her home in Ramsey, NJ. She was born October 7, 1906, daughter of Chester A. Smeltzer, former Mayor of Ramsey and Bergen County Freeholder and Mary Elizabeth Winters, a descendant of 17th Century Bergen County families, James Christie, a dispatch writer in the American Revolution and James Young, Esq. of Campgaw, a writer of biblical commentaries. Her late husband Hubert Schleuning, Professor of Physics at Polytechnic University of Brooklyn, predeceased her in 1998. They had been married 66 years. She grew up in Brooklyn, NY, graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1928 an economics major. She was president of her class, won the ''Venus'' Cup for physical excellence and sang in the glee club. She was awarded the Alumnae Medal of Honor for her services to the college and was a member of the New York and Bergen County Mount Holyoke Clubs. After living in Brooklyn for 40 years, she and her husband moved in 1971 to the Winters/Smeltzer family home in Ramsey built in 1889. Following graduation she joined R.H. Macy's Training Squad and became a lingerie buyer for Macy's. After her marriage she became an active volunteer for Children's Services of the Salvation Army, serving for 60 years. For many years she was a lay member of their Board, retiring recently as an Honorary member. After moving to Ramsey, she and her husband became members of the First Presbyterian Church of Ramsey. In 1976 she and her sister published their father's posthumous book ''The Birth of Ramsey.'' She is survived by her sister Marjorie Smeltzer-Stevenot of Sloatsburg, NY, niece Margot Stevenot Graettinger, her husband, John S. Graettinger Jr. and their children Mary Elizabeth, John Smeltzer and Anna Graettinger of Wilmette, IL, and relatives of her husband's family. Interment of cremains will be private. A celebration of her life will be held on October 26, 2002, at 2 PM at the First Presbyterian Church. Memorial donations may be made to the First Presbyterian Church, Shuart Lane, Ramsey, NJ. For more information call the Van Emburgh - Sneider Funeral Home, Ramsey, NJ, 201327-0030.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOUGLAS, MALCOLM E. (''TED'')
description: DOUGLAS - Malcolm E. (''Ted''), 58. Of Dedham, MA, on September 30, 2002 from cardiac failure. Beloved son of the late Katherine Willauer Douglas and Edward Mills Douglas, fond stepson of Jane Connor Douglas, Vinyard Haven, MA., dearest brother of Elizabeth Mills Douglas, Waukesha, WI., and Katherine Douglas Romanski, Hales Corners, WI. Favorite uncle of Thomas A. Romanski, Pleasant Prairie, WI. Mourned and sadly missed by numerous other relatives and friends. Ted's business, Western Chrome, took him across the highways and byways of the USA where he collected friends from all walks of life joined by their mutual passion of the classic American automobile. A memorial service will be held October 28, 2002, at St. Paul's Church, Dedham, MA. at 3:00 PM. Contributions made be made to the Ted Douglas Scholarship Fund at the Hurricane Island Outward Bound School, 75 Mechanics Street, Rockland, ME. 04841.

description: THE DAEDALUS Quartet, a chamber ensemble that has scored impressively in string quartet competitions, has been around for only two years, but its origins can be traced to 1988 and a music practice room at Bellport High School.

title: Word for Word/Exit Speeches; Sorry If Anyone Was Offended. But You'll Miss Me When I'm Gone.
description: YOU could tell that something was troubling Senator Robert G. Torricelli last week. When Mr. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, announced that he wouldn't seek re-election because his campaign had been hobbled by questions about improper gifts he had accepted from a contributor, he admitted to ''most certainly'' having made some mistakes in life. But he wondered aloud about the price he was paying. ''When did we become such an unforgiving people?'' he asked.

title: A Marriage On a Course For the Rocks
description: FOUR movie stars appeared last year in an HBO film version of ''Dinner With Friends,'' which won the Pulitzer Prize for Drama in 2000. That's as much buzz as a four-character play, modestly produced off-Broadway, can generate.

title: OneWorld Improves to 3-0
description: OneWorld, the Seattle yacht, went 3-0 on the third day of America's Cup qualifying races Saturday, gaining the seventh United States victory in eight starts. OneWorld sits in first place on the early leader board for the Louis Vuitton Cup. Meanwhile, Stars & Stripes lost its first race and Prada of Italy won its first, on a day that produced the first protests and on-water penalties in the challengers' series.

description: Many city parents have a hard time choosing a place to take their children out to eat. Here are some child-friendly spots.

title: They Are It
description: Andy Warhol would have been eager to take snapshots of the Strokes -- and not just because, musically speaking, they are the kids of his kids, the Velvet Underground. Warhol would have liked their look, the slept-in T's and high-top Cons and Paris-'68 hair, vigilantly unkempt. He would have been drawn to the state they're in just now, the echt Next New Band situation: anxiously thriving in a moment between underground status and pop fame. (It's the moment of maximum rock 'n' roll glamour.) He would have really gone for this thing that three or four of the five of them seem to have when they get drunk sometimes of kissing one another fully on the mouth and then rating the kisses -- post-gay-consciousness hetero bonding, or something. And he would have appreciated their ambition, which is to be a disaffected downtown New York band that is also a big-time rock band, something no band of its kind has ever pulled off. (Downtown bands are influential: big after the fact.)

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: INTERNATIONAL; U.S. EXEMPTED FROM COURT
description: The European Union agreed to exempt American soldiers and government officials from prosecution for war crimes at the International Criminal Court. The decision by the 15 member nations would prevent the extradition of American suspects, as long as the U.S. government guaranteed that the suspects would be tried in an American court. The Bush administration fears that Americans in peacekeeping or overseas military operations could become targets of politically motivated trials.

title: Chechen Refugees Wary of Resettlement
description: The tent camp at Aki-Yurt is not as squalid as some refugee camps around the world. The 2,700 Chechens there have electricity and gas and even men's and women's steam baths. The Danish Council for Refugees provides flour, oil, sugar and salt, much of it from the United States. An Austrian organization, Hilfswerk, built a wooden school last year for the camp's 415 children.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; SMALLPOX VACCINE
description: The nation's leading public health officials said they favored offering smallpox vaccine for the first time to the general public, but only after up to 10 million health care workers had been immunized and after a vaccine was licensed for general use, which is not likely until 2004. It was the first time federal officials said the public should have access to the vaccine, which carries significant risk of serious side effects.

description: AFTER almost a year of ceaseless and stupefying scandal, investors know that if trust is to be restored in the financial system, radical change must come from executives, Wall Street and the accounting industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN NORDEN, MONTAGNIE
description: VAN NORDEN-Montagnie on Tuesday, October 1, 2002. Cherished husband for 52 years of the former Gwendolyn Olson (Joy). Devoted father of Montagnie Van Norden, Jr., of Concord, MA, Adam Van Norden of Reno, NV, Kristina Van Norden Anderson of Cincinnati, OH and Juliana Van Norden Wynne of Westport, CT. Beloved and caring grandfather of Christopher and Katherine Van Norden, Emilia and Benjamin Anderson, and Henry and Grace Wynne. He was born in New York City March 26, 1923, the son of the late Warner Montagnie Van Norden and the late Grace Talcott Van Norden and brother of the late James Talcott Van Norden. He was a graduate and trustee of the Browning School and a graduate of Princeton class of '45. He served in WW II first in the 463rd parachute battalion and was then assigned to the 101st Airborne in the Battle of the Bulge at Bastogne. He joined Merrill Lynch in 1949 and retired in 1990. His interests were varied, ranging from history, poetry and mathematics to hunting and fishing throughout the world. He lived his entire life in New York but maintained homes in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida and ''Sand Pond'' in Willowemoc, New York. A Memorial Service in celebration of his life will be held on Thursday, October 17 at 3PM at St. Vincent Ferrer 66th Street and Lexington Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70th Street, NYC 10021 (attn: Carolyn Diehl) or to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

description: RONALD FELDMAN's art gallery is 30 years old, and he's not happy about it.
