description: IGNORANCE

title: A Lesson in Unintended Consequences
description: For much of 1968, J.H.S. 271, a junior high school in the impoverished central Brooklyn neighborhood of Ocean Hill-Brownsville, served as the command center for one of the great, agonizing racial psychodramas in New York history. It was from here that a ''planning council'' of activists and parents ran the local schools in an experiment, financed by the Ford Foundation, in ''community control.'' The premise of community control was that ghetto children were failing in school, not because of the terrible problems of inner-city life but because of neglect, even hostility, from the system's overwhelmingly white teachers and administrators. Community control, or, as it came to be known, decentralization, would empower those who cared most about the children -- parents, elders, neighborhood leaders -- to guide their education.

title: In Districts Drawn by Democrats, Georgia G.O.P. Puts Up Surprising Fight
description: The fight for Georgia's four open Congressional seats was supposed to be over before it began: all are in districts that were carefully drawn by Democrats for Democrats to elect Democrats.

They had supported her decision to leave Belgium for college in the United States, despite her position on the Belgian junior national women's volleyball team.

title: The Show That Made Everybody Sweat
description: ''SOAP'' was a comedy, but for Billy Crystal the laughs could be unsettling. ''My skin would crawl sometimes,'' he said, remembering the derision studio audiences would direct at his character, Jodie, the gay son of a blue-collar Connecticut family. Like the time Jodie's ex-boyfriend told him, ''I love you and I want you back.'' ''The audience hears that and they go nuts,'' Mr. Crystal said. ''They start tittering and laughing.'' In such scenes, he said, ''If there was an isolated camera on me, you would have seen me getting red and sweaty, thinking, 'What am I doing here?' ''

title: The Difficult Balance Between Liberty and Security
description: Even more than last year, the Supreme Court's new term begins in the shadow of Sept. 11, 2001. The terrorist attacks led Congress to pass laws that increase the ability of federal officials to investigate not just terrorists but all Americans. While the Supreme Court may begin to hear challenges to those laws later in its term, which begins tomorrow, it already has on its docket several cases that could reveal how it draws the line between liberty and security.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; TORRICELLI BOWS OUT
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, ended his re-election campaign after acknowledging that his candidacy had become overwhelmed by questions about improper gifts he had accepted from a contributor. The questions led to a rebuke by the Senate Ethics Committee in July and the release of a damaging memorandum from federal investigators.

title: Bush Tells Critics Hussein Could Strike at Any Time
description: President Bush today offered a new argument for acting quickly against Iraq, saying that Saddam Hussein ''has a horrible history'' of striking without warning. Mr. Bush emphasized that should military force be required to oust Mr. Hussein, the United States would ''help the Iraqi people rebuild and form a just government.''

title: The Union Label For Young Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Loose Lips Sink Cruise Ships
description: TRICKY BUSINESS

title: New York, Continued
description: What has changed about New York? A reasonable answer might be ''everything.'' A special issue of The Times Magazine suggests, however, that New York is still essentially, vitally itself. As writers like Frank Rich, Kurt Andersen and Walter Kirn discover, most of the city's traditional narratives, processes and dreams are still standing.

title: 'Desolation'
description: The garden-all me.

title: Heather Adler, Frank X. Schoen
description: Heather Gale Adler, the daughter of Karen and Edward A. K. Adler of Sands Point, N.Y., was married last evening to Frank X. Schoen, a son of Linda and Frank Schoen of Shamong, N.J. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at the New York Yacht Club.

title: It's Over for Diamondbacks as Cards Take a Big Step
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks' shelf life as defending World Series champions expired abruptly tonight in a three-game sweep by a St. Louis Cardinals team that has turned its resilience into a folk tale, rising up from the saddest June to feel joy in October.

title: The Changing Face of the Suffolk Harvest
description: KIM WESTFIELD travels from North Carolina to Long Island every summer. But unlike many visitors she does not come to relax and cool off by the water. Instead, she spends most of her days working in the fields.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; ENRON OFFICIAL CHARGED
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, was charged with fraud, money laundering and conspiracy for allegedly using off-the-books partnerships to disguise the energy company's poor financial performance while enriching himself with millions of dollars. Accusations in the government's complaint implicate other executives and financial institutions in criminal activities.

title: Tests Link Seventh Victim To Gun Used in Sniper Spree
description: Detectives confirmed tonight that the sniper who has killed six people in the Washington suburbs ranged farther afield and wounded a woman in a Virginia shopping center parking lot.

title: When Gambling Sidetracks Both Life and Career
description: TEN years ago, she was a vice president with a major commercial bank on Long Island who spent most of her weekends gambling in Atlantic City. She went so often that the Taj Mahal casino sent a stretch limousine to her home on Friday afternoons. Once at the casino, her meals were free, and she was even given the services of a personal assistant for the weekend.

title: Suzanne Boudreau and Brian Doherty
description: Suzanne Catherine Boudreau, a daughter of Susan and Donald L. Boudreau of Larchmont, N.Y., was married on Friday in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Brian Andrew Doherty, a son of Patricia and John Doherty of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Walter L. Pitman officiated at the Scarsdale Congregational Church. The Rev. Joseph S. Dietz, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Commercial Property; Brokerages: More Than Nameplates Are Changing
description: FOR the major real estate service companies in New York the last few months have been a time of unusual ferment, as a number of prominent executives have changed employers and some companies have moved to broaden their ownership or re-examine their strategies.

title: South Of Border, Prospects And Pitfalls
description: IT has been a difficult decade for Latin American markets, and this year, so far, has not been any better.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Seeking Terrorist Plots, the F.B.I. Is Tracking Hundreds of Muslims
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is trying to make an open book of the lives of hundreds of mostly young, mostly Muslim men in the United States in the belief that Al Qaeda-trained terrorists remain in this country, awaiting instructions to attack.

title: Treating Health Care
description: RISA LAVIZZO-MOUREY was in middle school when she had her first lesson in the economics of health care. The Boeing Company was laying off workers, leaving them without health insurance. Her parents, both doctors practicing in a fairly poor Seattle neighborhood, had to decide each month which patients to bill.

title: Dance Listings
description: RONALD K. BROWN/EVIDENCE  "Walking Out the Dark." Dance Theater Workshop, 219 W. 19th St. (212-691-6500) Today, next Sun., 2; Wed.-Sat., 7. Through Oct. 20.

title: The Long View
description: When I left New York for Montana in 1990, I wasn't planning to stay away forever, ending up as one of those sad, displaced sophisticates who can't eat a corned beef sandwich at the truck stop without telling everybody sitting nearby that real New York Reubens use Swiss cheese, not Velveeta -- and by the way, did you know I sang on Broadway once? No, I was merely waiting for prices to drop. Having moved to the city from the Midwestern farm belt, I believed that the prices of basic urban commodities like restaurant meals, movie tickets and top-floor lofts obeyed the same boom-and-bust rhythms as pork and soy. The trick, I believed, was to take what little remained of the fair money I'd squandered on rides and candy during my feverish five years in Manhattan, let it compound in a passbook savings account and pray for a drought that would devastate Greenwich Village. In the meantime, I'd visit three or four times a year -- for work, and to scout out the town house I'd one day buy from some ruined gallery owner or wine importer.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: INTERNATIONAL; AFRICAN FERRY DISASTER
description: The Senegalese government concluded that the country's worst ferry disaster, which claimed most of 1,034 passengers, was a result of overcapacity, bad weather and the crew's failure to observe proper safety procedures. Close to 400 corpses have been recovered and almost all the others are thought to have perished on board, where the bodies remain trapped.

title: Poly Prep Foils Last Play To Turn Back Delbarton
description: Poly Prep took the lead late in the game and then withstood a rally in the last minute to come away with an 18-15 victory yesterday over Delbarton of New Jersey in front of a home crowd in Brooklyn.

title: Liena Zagare, Benjamin Smith
description: Liena Zagare, a daughter of Dr. Ruta Zagare of Riga, Latvia, was married yesterday evening to Benjamin Eli Smith, a son of Dian G. Smith and Robert S. Smith of New York. Ruth Goldston, an aunt of the bridegroom, solemnized the marriage by special permission of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts at the family home of the bridegroom in Lenox, Mass.

title: U.S. Envoy Tells North Korea of Arms Concerns
description: A senior State Department envoy to North Korea said today, at the end of a three-day visit, that he had useful talks with the country's leaders.

title: Women, Cuba and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Bates Appears to Be Bargain As a Wing on Yashin's Line
description: The Islanders appear to have found a left wing for Aleksei Yashin, and they did not have to bust their budget on the free-agent market to do it. The wing, Shawn Bates, will make $550,000 this season, and he is grateful to play next to a creative center making 13 times as much.

title: From Tickets to Souvenirs, Arts-Related Spending Rises in County
description: THE role of the arts in Westchester County's economy increased by 71 percent between 1995 and 2000, according to a study conducted by the Westchester Arts Council in cooperation with the county's Office of Tourism.

title: POSTINGS: 27th Street Between 7th and 8th Avenues; New Buildings For F.I.T.
description: There has not been major construction at the Fashion Institute of Technology since the campus at 27th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues was completed in 1975. But on Oct. 17, a groundbreaking ceremony is to mark the start of a 10-year expansion that is to begin with two new two-story buildings scheduled for completion in December 2003.

title: Just Add Adjectives
description: IF you've been feeling dour about the state of dinner in central New Jersey, wishing that someone with your food philosophy (local food, global influences, superb preparation from starters to desserts, service with a smile and style) had a restaurant on the west side of the Garden State Parkway, let me remind you: The restaurant is Stage Left. It's been open for a decade, but with Dan Wood at the stove, it's new again and you need to go.

title: Fitting Mates
description: Marriage can be as fulfilling for wines as for individuals. Especially whites that feel pointedly incomplete without food, like Castello di Borghese's nonvintage Chardonette and Lieb Family Cellars's 2000 reserve chardonnay.

title: Remember World War I
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees' Pitchers Not Earning Their Keep
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 5  George Steinbrenner is paying more than $60 million to his pitchers this season. Inside his mind, that figure may be blinking red as he watches the Yankees' American League division series with the Anaheim Angels.

title: Personal Business; How to Find Insurance That Fits
description: ABOUT one-third of all employees never bother to shop for a health insurance plan, opting to stick with their old plans year after year, according to a recent survey of 750 employees by Cigna Healthcare. But as employers change options -- as many plan to do this month -- it's important to at least review the offerings. Following are some questions to consider:

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: NATIONAL; SNIPER AT LARGE
description: Law-enforcement officials say a sniper who killed five suburban Maryland residents at random with a high-powered rifle has extended his range into the nearby District of Columbia. The police said ballistics tests indicated that a 72-year-old Washington resident shot to death had been the sixth victim of an obviously skilled marksman still at large in the Washington metropolitan area.

title: Hard Lessons in Bronxville
description: NO school district looks forward to construction projects. Even under the best circumstances, they can be costly, disruptive and glacially paced. Children's classrooms are uprooted, teachers compete with jackhammers and delays in completion are almost de rigueur.

title: Lust, Greed and Other Familial Feelings
description: A RUTHLESS, controlling family in which money and loyalty mean everything. An ill-tempered, sometimes violent husband and his despairing wife. A world where a code of silence and proscribed rituals dictate social behavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JOHN PAUL
description: MURRAY-John Paul. Age 79. Retired Lt. Commander, U.S.N. Died October 3, 2002 in Atlanta, GA. of heart and kidney complications. Devoted husband of Doris Frances (Hester) Murray. Beloved father of Sheila Shapiro, Patrick Murray, Mark Murray and James Kevin Murray and grandfather to Ryan, Matthew and Amber Murray and Ian Shapiro. A colorful father-in-law to Linda Chancey Murray and Hy Shapiro. Interment will be at Ft. Mitchell National Cemetery in Alabama. Donations in Lt. Commander Murray's memory will be welcome by the Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Drive, Atlanta, GA. 30319.

title: The Nation: War Party; How the Republicans Got a Chestful of Medals
description: DEMOCRATS may mock President Bush's political mastermind Karl Rove as ''General Rove'' these days, but their derision is wrapped in envy. For most of the 50 years since a real general -- Dwight D. Eisenhower -- last won the White House, polls have shown that Americans ''trust the Republican Party to do a better job of protecting and strengthening America's military might and thereby protecting America,'' as Mr. Rove told party leaders in January.

title: Star Turn
description: The AUTOGRAPH MAN

title: Indian Girl, 15, Is Awarded The Title of Grandmaster
description: It's a long, long way from May to September. Humpy Koneru of India had completed her third and final norm for grandmaster rank in the Elekes Memorial Tournament in Budapest May 18 to 28, but she was not officially awarded that honor until Sept. 8 at the International Chess Federation convention in Russia. At 15 years, 1 month and 27 days, that makes her the youngest woman to obtain that high status. She breaks Judit Polgar's record of 15 years, 4 months and 28 days.

title: From Welfare to Work, and Then, to What?; Women Describe Their Lives Off Public Assistance, for Better and Worse
description: Few disappearing acts have been as astonishing as the evaporation of hundreds of thousands of people from New York City's welfare rolls.

title: Not So Fast: Theories Vary On Express Checkout Lines
description: Venantis Miskinis stopped by the D'Agostino's at Columbus Avenue and 91st Street the other day with one goal: grapefruit juice. Easier said than done. Mr. Miskinis got stuck in line behind a couple with a full shopping cart, and since that D'Agostino's, like many of the chain's supermarkets, has no express lane, all he could do was wait.

title: Azaleas' Colorful Foliage Is Autumn's Surprise
description: LATE in August, as I was strolling through the grounds of Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island, I came across a shrub with deep burgundy foliage. Curious, I looked at the label and, much to my surprise, saw that the plant was a native azalea (Rhododendron vaseyi), a deciduous member of the rhododendrum family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINHORN, HARRIET
description: STEINHORN-Harriet. Of Ellenville, New York and Aventura, FL., died October 2nd, 2002 in Port Chester, NY. She was the former owner and operator of the Grand Mountain Hotel in Greenfield Park, N.Y. She is survived by her loving daughter, Amy, & her husband, Brad Kreinces, one sister, Helen Haas, one brother, Howard Golden, and three adoring grandsons: Alex, Jason and Evan. Funeral and burial services were held on Thursday, October 3rd, in Ellenville, N.Y. ''She will always be in our hearts.''

title: P.S.; A Blanket Reborn
description: The classic Hudson's Bay point blankets were reinterpreted in past seasons in the form of fur coats and dresses by designers including Michael Kors. Now they have been transposed by Kule to an even smaller scale: children's wear.

title: Modest Halloween Plans
description: With the threat of war and a sluggish economy, few people may feel like celebrating. But many households plan to continue the traditions and festivities of Halloween this year; they're just not going overboard.

description: EISEMAN-Alfred. Age 83, on October 1st, in Westport, CT., beloved husband of Alberta Eiseman, father of Margot Eiseman and her husband Robert Benedict, Nicole Eiseman, grandfather to Rachel and Laura Benedict, Lily and Jack Fitch. Memorial services Sunday, October 6th at 1:00 PM from Abraham L. Green & Son, 88 Beach Road, Fairfield, CT.

description: THE EMPIRE State Carousel, an 18-year project that has been called a museum to ride on, has finally found a home.

description: DADS can crack jokes that make their daughters squirm, especially at work.

title: Private Sector; Will the Dinner Guests Want to Eat and Run?
description: If you're a banker, here's a recipe for indigestion. Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, will be the keynote speaker at American Banker's Banker of the Year awards dinner in December. Mr. Spitzer's aggressive investigations of conflicts on Wall Street have caused much anxiety in the industry, and he is in the midst of a broad inquiry into Citigroup's investment bank that has contributed to a 41 percent drop in the parent company's shares this year.

title: Eleanor Heard, Daniel Gilbane
description: Eleanor Anne Heard, the daughter of Mary Ray Heard of San Antonio and the late Oliver Samuel Heard Jr., was married yesterday to Daniel Monroe Gilbane, a son of Mary Gilbane and Thomas Gilbane Jr. of Providence, R.I. Msgr. Liam Brosnam performed the ceremony at Mission San Jos in San Antonio.

title: Nominee for Court Is Open-Minded
description: To the Editor:

title: QUICK BITE/Gillette; Apples and Cider Without the Haunted House
description: Skeeter Kielblock wants you to know there will not be any sideshows like talking scarecrows and haunted houses when you come apple picking at his farm. There also will not be traffic back-ups and parking problems. Just walk into the front barn, parts of which are 150 years old, get your basket and head out to the orchards. On busy weekends in October, Mr. Kielblock will shuttle you up to the far orchard by tractor, but on weekdays, you can walk right down the hill to the nearest grove. Almost all the apple trees on the 57-acre Hillview Farm are dwarfs, which make them perfectly suited for children to pick. No need for unwieldy picking poles or climbing the trees, which can cause harm to next year's crop (and this year's humans).

title: Loving Guns To Death
description: Making fun of Canada is such an all-American pastime that watching Michael Moore's ''Bowling for Columbine'' with a Canadian crowd at the Toronto International Film Festival last month felt like payback. Mr. Moore's latest gadfly documentary, opening in New York and Los Angeles on Friday, tackles America's love affair with guns and its egregious number of gun deaths -- more than 11,000 annually -- compared with that of other countries. The comparison he finds most telling is with hunting-happy Canada, where there are 7 million guns for a population of 33 million -- a ratio similar to our own -- but fewer than 400 deaths a year. So you might say that the joke's on us.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: YANKEES CENTURY

title: Amy Sorokolit, Timothy McCooey
description: Amy Lee Sorokolit, a daughter of Susan and Robert Sorokolit of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Timothy Joyce McCooey, a son of Mary Joyce McCooey of Rye, N.Y., and the late Robert H. McCooey. The Rev. Joseph Hughes performed the ceremony at Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Perches for Watching Birds
description: October is hawk watching time in New Jersey, and the tail end of the songbirds' fall migrations. For 15 years, ''A Guide to Bird Finding in New Jersey,'' by William J. Boyle Jr., published by Rutgers University Press, was the classic guide to finding them. This month, the book appears in its first update. There are at least 400 species in the state, Mr. Boyle says, and an active birder can see 300 of them in a year. The new edition includes all new maps -- 95 of them -- and some new illustrations. The book describes 130 birding spots, from High Point State Park with its northern waterthrush, to the Great Swamp with perhaps 100 species nesting May through July, to Cumberland County and the Johnson Sod Farm with its sandpipers. The 496-page book is $24 in paperback and $50 hardcover.

title: Competition? Sure, but Not in My Backyard
description: DO people in big business really believe in free enterprise? The latest argument to the contrary comes from airline chief executives, who told Congress recently that their industry needs relief -- again -- from the consequences of 9/11.

title: There's Something Wrong With Evil
description: CONSIDER the power of the word ''evil,'' fast edging out ''regime change'' as the buzzword of the year. It can stop objection cold; it can taint as cowards those accused of failing to grasp it. ''We refuse to ignore or appease the aggression and brutality of evil men,'' says George W. Bush, and who would disagree?

The vineyard's 2001 Reserve Pinot Noir had just won a gold medal in London, 11,000 miles to the northwest.

description: FOR the vast majority of mutual fund investors, the third quarter was a period of dismal superlatives.

description: As Long Island regional director of the Anti-Defamation League from 1973 to 1983, I was deeply involved in the work of the Catholic-Jewish Relations Committee of the Diocese of Rockville Centre. Catholics and Jews engaged in a dialogue built on mutual respect while agreeing to disagree on some issues. The committee was nurtured by the late Bishop John McGann's commitment to the teachings of Vatican II.

title: Deep-Sea Joint Venture: Britain and U.S. Company in a Treasure Hunt
description: The American company that discovered the lost ship with what may be history's richest sunken treasure has signed an agreement with the British government, which owns it, to raise it from the bottom of the Mediterranean and split the proceeds.

title: Most of All, He Sounds Like Burns
description: FRANK GORSHIN is up for anything. You need someone to dance wearing a loincloth in a monster movie? No problem. How about a nightclub act in Vegas? Done. Talk show guest? Stage cameo? Video game voiceover? Tell him where and when, and he'll be there.

title: Cindy Lin, Roderick Chin
description: Cindy Shin-Yee Lin, the daughter of Yuh-Pyng Lin and Dr. Mou-Ching Lin of High Bridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Roderick Wayne Chin, the son of Martina and Howard Chin of Paramus, N.J. The Rev. C. Russell Ditzel, a priest of the Federation of Christian Ministries, officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

description: IN 41 years of commuting on the New Haven line, Richard F. Bebon has learned these things:

title: 'Silence on the Mountain'
description: All I knew when I began was that a house had burned down. And not just any house. This was the house of the patron - the casa patronal - on a coffee plantation named La Patria.

description: In today's competitive job market, what you wear on an interview may make the difference between landing a position or leaving disappointed.

description: Around Ptzcuaro

title: A Chariot of the Imagination
description: DAVID HENRY HWANG, the playwright and screenwriter, has a power spot, a place where he is so at ease that his mind roams freely, without stress, without distraction. That spot is an Art Deco chair of anonymous provenance but specific charm. It has a round wood frame and a scalloped back, and is upholstered in a dusky blue-gray velvet with a thick silvery fringe on the bottom.

title: Packed Houses
Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; SHOE-BOMBER PLEA
description: The man accused of trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives hidden in his shoes pleaded guilty to all eight charges against him, including attempted murder. Richard Colvin Reid, a British citizen, admitted to prosecutors that he was a member of Al Qaeda. Officials called it the first successful prosecution of a Qaeda member in the U.S. Pam Belluck

title: Christina Kang, Usman Mazhar
description: Christina Insum Joo-Hee Kang, a lawyer, and Usman Arfin Mazhar, a tax consultant, both in New York, are to be married today at the Fairmont Hotel Macdonald in Edmonton, Alberta. The Rev. Paul P. Ryu, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Hedy Ann Hartman and Andrew Howard Chait misstated part of the name of the Manhattan art and antiques business operated by the bridegroom's family. It is Ralph M. Chait Galleries, not Gallery.

title: Korean Premier Confirmed
description: South Korea's conservative-dominated National Assembly today approved by a wide margin President Kim Dae Jung's selection for prime minister.

title: Sports of The Times; Augusta National's Neighbors Wonder What All the Fussin' Could Be About
description: AT the leafy entrance to the Augusta National Golf Club, the green iron gate next to the sentry box is slammed shut, barring access to Magnolia Lane and the white plantation clubhouse above the course where the Masters is played every April. Along the property's perimeter, green canvas covers the tournament's parking-lot gates between the tall pine trees and thick bushes that tower above the traffic on Washington Road.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; LINDH SENTENCED
description: John Walker Lindh, the American who fought for the Taliban in Afghanistan, was sentenced in Virginia to 20 years in prison. In his statement, he repudiated terrorism and condemned Osama bin Laden, but did not apologize for his actions.

title: A Sacrifice in Mississippi Remembered on a New York Mountain
description: The 1964 murder of Andrew Goodman prompted the most aggressive investigation of the Ku Klux Klan up to that time and, two decades later, inspired the movie ''Mississippi Burning.'' The killings of Mr. Goodman and two other young volunteers who were registering blacks to vote is viewed as a turning point in the civil rights movement.

title: The Trend in Tea: Shaken, Not Stirred
description: In America, convenience is king, even when it comes to a tradition-bound drink like tea. Over the last five years, sales of ready-to-drink teas have risen 41 percent, helping overall tea sales grow by 13 percent. Rapidly growing brands like Snapple and Arizona, with their flavor-infused concoctions, have changed the market, said Kim Feil, an analyst at Information Resources Inc. A recent push by tea makers and trade associations, like the Tea Council, to trumpet tea's health benefits, has also spurred sales.

title: United Air's Family Is Anything But
description: WHY does Patrick Palazzolo gripe about his job?

title: Anyone Seen Any Democrats Lately?
description: Ever since President Bush took office I've had this feeling that the only serious opposition party in America, at least in foreign policy, was made up of three people, and none of them were Democrats. The only three people Mr. Bush really worries about -- the only three people who could take big constituencies with them if they openly parted company with the president on an issue like Iraq -- are Colin Powell, Tony Blair and John McCain.

title: Why Dec. 31 Is a Good Day to Stay Out of the Market
description: RECENT research into mutual fund trading helps to explain why one quarter's top funds tend to continue winning for only a few weeks before reversing course.

title: 'Paradise Alley'
description: He is coming.

title: Personal Business; Health Plans Are Offering Fewer Choices and Higher Costs
description: SHALIA WATTS, a government employee from Sacramento, received some upsetting news in June: the health maintenance organization to which she belongs, Health Net, will no longer be available through her employer next year. At the same time, she said, she found that the monthly premium for the Blue Shield H.M.O. she chose as a replacement would be $110, almost double what she pays now. Co-payments for her prescription-drug plan already rose this year, she said, from $5 to a scale ranging from $10 to $30.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Investors With a Cause Hold Their Own
description: LIKE most other investors, managers of mutual funds that regard themselves as ''socially responsible'' have been struggling. As a group, their returns mirror those of fund managers in general.

title: Private Sector; Trying a New Medium On for Size
description: WHEN his business associates began sliding guns onto the negotiating table during cash settlements, Jeff Clanagan recalled of his days as a concert promoter in 1989, the work ''became unfun.'' Then violence erupted at his urban music shows as crack cocaine hit the streets, and he decided to get out of rap.

title: Whiskey  Go-Go
description: To understand why, as people say, ''it's all about'' Hope Atherton this season, let us try to explain how so-called New York society is constituted.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about cuts in a Nassau County home-care program for the elderly misstated the residence of Jennifer Cona, a lawyer with clients enrolled in the program. She lives in Huntington, not Garden City.

title: 'Ignorance'
description: hat are you still doing here?" Her tone wasn't harsh, but it wasn't kindly, either; Sylvie was indignant.

title: The Dursts Have Odd Properties
description: Over the course of the last decade, a new Times Square has grown up in the place of the old -- a global entertainment-finance-media nexus of glass towers, with themed restaurants and megastores on their ground floors offering a wholesome and, on the whole, ingeniously engineered version of the famously carnivalesque atmosphere of the seedy Times Square of generations past. It is, by now, an almost wholly self-consistent world -- ''totalized,'' as the academics say. But the bubble has not yet fully closed; a few oddities still flourish. Immediately to the east of the immense, glittering bulk of the Cond Nast Building, which is on the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Broadway, is a peculiar little arts complex situated in a string of dingy buildings. Until a few months ago, the sign above the little structure next door to the Cond Nast Building featured a version of the American flag, an outline of a hand clutching a can of spray paint and the slogan, ''Declare Independence From Corporate Rule'' -- a furious protest at all that Times Square has become.

description: The traditional town-gown friction pitting Morningside Heights residents against Columbia University has turned upside down, with neighbors praising the university and developers criticizing it. The sore point concerns Teachers College, which is affiliated with the university but separate from it.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: FINDERS KEEPERS

title: Off and Running for the Silk Stockings
description: ON Gail Hilson's wish list for last January, you won't find the plans that some of her friends might have jotted down. There is no mention of skiing in Aspen, relaxing in St. Bart's or getting a little work done around the eyes.

title: A Sly Assault Launched From Inside Oxygen's Tent
description: LIZZ WINSTEAD has a gift for ridicule. She was a co-creator and the head writer of Comedy Central's nightly newscast, ''The Daily Show,'' when it began six years ago and started treating pop culture with the absurdity it deserved. As in the correspondent Brian Unger's report on the shocking anti-Latino bias that had kept the cartoon character Speedy Gonzalez in the shadows.

title: Your Family and How It Works
description: I DON'T KNOW HOW

title: Admiring Mies and Modernism, Up Close
description: IF you sign up for the occasional urban architectural tour, you have most likely noticed that modern buildings tend to get short shrift. Tour guides typically offer vague apologies when standing in front of a tinted glass monolith, as if accounting for an uncle who's eccentric but not in a particularly interesting way.

title: Azaleas Surprise With Colorful Fall Foliage
description: LATE in August, as I was strolling through the grounds of Old Westbury Gardens on Long Island, I came across a shrub with deep burgundy foliage. Curious, I looked at the label and, much to my surprise, saw that the plant was a native azalea (Rhododendron vaseyi), a deciduous member of the rhododendrum family.

title: Private Sector; Tugging on Wall Street's Heartstrings
description: William Baldwin, of the acting Baldwin brothers, was having trouble quieting a crowd of more than 1,500 stock traders on Thursday night at the Marriott Marquis hotel in Manhattan. Then he showed a video about his old schoolmate Michael Beier, now 39 and a trader for Credit Suisse First Boston, who was stricken with Lou Gehrig's disease two years ago.

title: So Will It Be M.I.T., U.C.L.A. Or T.C.N.J.?
description: A few columns ago I made a snide passing remark about the College of New Jersey in Ewing. I said it has a dumb name. It does. I stand by my story.

title: With Their Honor
description: To the Editor:

title: Skin's Final Frontier
description: When the debate about hormone-replacement therapy hit the news last summer, the beauty industry took new notice of its older customers. The result is an array of products marketed to the thousands of women who reach menopause every day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDREYER, CONSTANCE NANCY GRACE (NEE BARBER)
description: GOLDREYER - Constance Nancy Grace (nee Barber). A very young 71 years, she lived her life filled with smiles, love, enthusiasm and laughter. A spectacular wife, mother, grandma and great friend to so many. She is survived by her husband Len, daughters Nancy Davilman (Andrew) Jill Goldreyer (Gregory) and Jennifer. Extraordinary grandma to Samantha, Jack and Yara. Loving sister to Gene, Billy, Tony, Ann and the late Buddy. Receiving friends at home this Sunday 3-7PM, Monday and Tuesday from 7PM.

title: Hell on Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Band, After a Series Of Small Steps
description: THERE'S a bit of lunacy in starting a big band these days. It is a bad economic moment for jazz, and the appetite for large-ensemble jazz is probably at its lowest.

title: Taking Bach To the Bowery And the Bar
description: The young cellist Matt Haimovitz has been taking Bach to unlikely places in recent years: bars, cafes and other alternative, nonclassical spaces. (Well, not entirely unlikely if you subscribe to H. L. Mencken's cherished notion that Bach's ''natural solvent'' is beer.) Now, in perhaps his most unusual venture yet, Mr. Haimovitz is playing Bach suites on Friday night at the rock mecca CBGB on the Bowery.

title: Campaign Season; Getting Up to Speed, but Not for a Race
description: Like President Bush, America's jogger in chief, Senator Daschle has been running for decades, almost always outdoors. But there he was at 6:50 a.m. on Friday at Tenley Sport and Health, a gym of choice for Washington's political elite, clomping furiously away on a treadmill.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUCKER, CLARISSA
description: TUCKER-Clarissa, December 14, 1910-August 4, 2002. Delta Sigma Theta Sorority Inc. ''Omega Omega'' and Celebration of Life service on Sunday, October 6, 2002 at 3PM, Schomburg Center, West 135th St and Malcolm X Boulevard, New York City.

title: How Hipness Moves
description: 1910's: Greenwich Village is widely known as America's bohemian enclave, with cheap rents, for writers and artists.

title: Maria-Claudia Duque, Benjamin Dannhauser
description: Maria-Claudia Duque, the daughter of Martha L. Salazar and Dr. Cesar Mendoza of New York and Rolla, Mo., was married yesterday to Benjamin John Dannhauser, a son of Beth and Stephen J. Dannhauser of New York. The Rev. Daniel S. Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Swiss Call a Meeting to Re-examine the Geneva Conventions
description: Switzerland will convene a meeting of officials from a representative group of countries in January to try to update how the Geneva Conventions, the nearly 150-year-old rules of warfare, are applied.

title: Alana Kaufman, Stuart Hirsch
description: Alana Rebecca Kaufman, the daughter of Debra R. Kaufman and Michael W. Kaufman of Newton, Mass., was married last evening on Cape Cod to Stuart Charles Hirsch, the son of Doris S. Hirsch and Dr. Jack Hirsch of New York. Rabbi Karen E. Landy officiated at the Wequassett Inn in Chatham, Mass.

title: A French Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: OneWorld Goes to 3-0
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sunday, Oct. 6  OneWorld, the Seattle yacht, went 3-0 in the third day of America's Cup qualifying races Saturday, gaining the seventh United States victory in eight starts. OneWorld sits in first place on the early leaderboard for the Louis Vuitton Cup. Meanwhile, Stars & Stripes lost its first race and Prada of Italy won its first, in a day that produced the first protests and on-water penalties in the challengers' series.

title: CANCER INSTITUTE DESIGNATION
description: The Cancer Institute of New Jersey in New Brunswick last week was designated a comprehensive cancer center by the National Cancer Institute, the highest ranking a cancer center can obtain. The institute is the only New Jersey cancer treatment center with the designation, which puts it on par with Memorial Sloan-Kettering in New York City, Fox Chase in Philadelphia, and 37 other comprehensive cancer centers. Karen DeMasters

title: BackTalk; Memo to Hootie Johnson: Augusta's Time Is Up
description: Hootie is turning out to be a hero of fair play whether he wants to be or not.

title: Is That Legal?
description: LAW IN AMERICA

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZEITLIN, FERRIN
description: ZEITLIN-Ferrin. My darling Ferrinyou will be my hero forever. Love, Grandm

title: The World; Putin Has His Own Candidate for Pre-emption
description: While working to slow down the Bush administration's campaign against Saddam Hussein, Russia has for weeks waged a campaign of accusation and intimidation against neighboring Georgia, where some Chechen fighters have taken refuge. It's not the first such outburst by Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, against his Georgian counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze. But Russia's pitch-perfect parody of American antiterrorism policy has commanded Washington's attention and could even derail Russian-American cooperation.

title: Drugs in The Blood
description: Drew can't remember the first place he lived, an abandoned house on Cedar and Evergreen in Bushwick, Brooklyn, where he and his parents and four brothers squatted with three other families for a few years after he was born. There was room for everyone, unlike the dark apartment -- just blocks away -- where Drew lives now with his siblings and his father, Cuba, 68. His mother, Tata, 44, is currently in residential drug rehab, via prison. Drew, 15, leaves his cramped apartment early and usually stays out late. He's always looking for something to keep busy, something -- anything -- to do. Boredom leads straight to Dodworth Street.

title: Correction
description: Areview on Sept. 15 about ''Sharon: Israel's Warrior-Politician,'' by Anita Miller, Jordan Miller and Sigalit Zetouni, misstated the nationality of the victims of a massacre in Beirut in 1982 for which an Israeli government inquiry found Ariel Sharon ''indirectly responsible.'' They were Palestinians, not Lebanese.

title: AN OCTOBER SURPRISE
description: On television commercials, Disneyland is where champions go. For the Yankees, it is where a championship dream died. For the first time since 1997, the Yankees will not be in the World Series. They will not even play in the second round of the playoffs. It's an October without them, after all.

title: Mentally Ill and Locked Up In New York Nursing Homes
description: Hundreds of patients released from state psychiatric hospitals in New York in recent years are being locked away on isolated floors of nursing homes, where they are barred from going outside on their own, have almost no contact with others and have little ability to contest their confinement, according to interviews with workers and experts and visits to the homes.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Brendan Meyers, Dwight Smith, Emily Cross, Fencers Club, New York, Aug. 14, 2002

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OSTROW, DEBORAH
description: OSTROW-Deborah; Age 46. Died on August 25, 2002 in Galveston, TX. Born and raised in New Rochelle, NY. Courageous and bright. She will be missed by her many friends, her father Jack Ostrow and his wife Anita and brother Alex Ostrow and his family.

title: Paintings That Reflect an Artist's Inner Landscape
description: Linda Gottesfeld: Landscape Paintings, After the Fall

title: Off The Dime
description: A ''senior aide'' to Secretary of State Colin Powell -- that's usually his pal and deputy, Richard Armitage, cloaked in the rules of background -- was quoted in The New York Times this spring saying that Powell thought that the Arabs and Israelis ''have to move the situation off the dime.''

title: Hitler's Architect
description: SPEER

title: Penn State Turns to Offense To Shut Off Wisconsin Rally
description: Mike Allen had just kicked a 48-yard field goal to bring Wisconsin within 5 points of Penn State early in the fourth quarter. On the sideline, Joe Paterno gave an order that longtime watchers of Paterno, who has more victories than any other coach in Division I-A, may find surprising. He told his offensive coordinator, Fran Ganter, to open up the offense.

title: The Public School Bulge Is Reaching State Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Dark, Big-City Dreams
description: I FIRST noticed it years ago, soon after I began writing my book ''Celluloid Skyline: New York and the Movies.'' Presented with the inevitable question -- What are you working on? -- I summarized the book's premise: that alongside the real city in which we live there exists a mythic New York, a dream city, brought to life in thousands of feature films, which for generations has captured the imagination of people all around the world.

title: Putting On Airs
description: Last fall, a new face appeared in New York society when a woman named Nydia Neubauer started shopping for real estate. In November, Kevin Corrigan, a broker for the Lerner Group, was showing Neubauer penthouse apartments in Trump Palace and in luxury buildings on the Upper East Side. In the course of their dealings, Corrigan encouraged Neubauer to buy tickets to the Denim and Diamonds dinner, a fund-raiser for Denise Rich's charity, the G&P Foundation for Cancer Research. Neubauer purchased two tickets and attended the gala in early November, later pledging $150,000 to the foundation.

title: Fans Face the Unthinkable: A Fall With No World Series
description: For Yankees fans it was a bitter dose of reality, delivered in unambiguous terms. Could the team really go down so fast?

title: Caroline Sincerbeaux, Lewis King
description: Caroline Connell Sincerbeaux, the daughter of Katherine Sincerbeaux and Richard Sincerbeaux, both of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Lewis King, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Davis King of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. James L. Burns performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: A New 92nd Street Y? Almost
description: ELEVEN years ago, a group of mostly Jewish families from the Upper West Side chose the southwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street on which eventually to build what they had already named the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan. The organizers had just begun meeting informally, and they expected to spend years borrowing space in other people's buildings. Still, they longed for one of their own.

title: Schoolyard Superstar Aims For a Second Act, as an Adult
description: Britney Spears, the pop star who brought sizzle to the schoolyard with glitter T-shirts and short shorts, strode onto a Milan runway last Tuesday evening in a $23,000 rainbow-spangled gown by Donatella Versace.

title: 2 Questioned In a Sailor's Fatal Fall
description: Two enlisted Navy men were being questioned by the police last night in connection with the death of a fellow sailor, a 30-year-old woman, who fell to the sidewalk early yesterday morning from the sixth floor of a Times Square hotel.

title: Even if Heads Roll, Mistrust Will Live On
description: SINCE midsummer, they have come every few weeks, with the predictability of a returning phase of the moon: A corporate ''perp walk,'' in which the government's latest white-collar defendant is handcuffed and escorted to the courthouse, with photographers snapping shots as once highflying executives face the ultimate humiliation.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: INTERNATIONAL; SIEGE HALTED
description: Pressure from the Bush administration forced Israel to withdraw from Yasir Arafat's compound in Ramallah. The 10-day siege, imposed after a suicide bomber killed six people in Tel Aviv, had interfered with Washington's attempt to rally support against Iraq and had stalled Palestinian reform efforts. After the Israelis retreated, Mr. Arafat's Palestinian leadership rejected the idea of creating a new post of prime minister, a central demand of the Americans and Israelis. The leadership said the new post must await the creation of a Palestinian state. James Bennet

title: DataBank; Profit News Sends Stocks Tumbling Again
description: The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index fell again last week, leaving investors wondering again where the bottom of the market might be.

title: Business; Mad Money Galore: A Cash Cow of a Play
description: MARILYN ABRAMS figures that her little company has had a return on invested capital of 101 percent a year for 23 years. That's not counting the laughs.

title: Fighting to Save a Doo-Wop Diner
description: THE Surfside Restaurant sits like a hearty smile on the Doo-Wop stretch of Ocean Avenue here. It is all aqua and orange and melon and bubble gum pink, with an angular roof and hexagonal body, a wonder of mid-20th-century commercial architecture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DEUSEN, JOHN F., JR.
description: VAN DEUSEN-John F., Jr. In Old Saybrook, CT, October 1, 2002. John F. Van Deusen Jr. of 2 Downing Way, Madison, CT, formerly of Rye, NY. Husband of Dorothy Stroud Van Deusen. Father of John S. Van Deusen of Bel Air, MD, Susanna V. Walden and Laura H. Van Deusen both of Guilford, CT. Six grandchildren. Pre-deceased by daughter Carol V. Casey. His early career in advertising, marketing and sales was spent in New York City with Vick Chemical Company, Ted Bates & Company as Vice President, Cunningham & Walsh, and Grey Advertising. In 1970 he became Vice President of Counting Devices, Inc. of North Branford, CT, a family owned manufacturing company. He later became President of Counting Devices and remained so until its sale in 1999. Funeral service Friday, October 11, at 10 AM, First Congregational Church, Guilford, CT. Contributions in his memory may made be to Fr. Michael McGiveny Center for Cancer Care, Hospital of St. Raphael, 1450 Chapel St., New Haven, CT 06511. For further information contact Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St., Guilford, CT.

title: N.F.L. Pressured On Black Coaches
description: The National Football League is pondering meeting with two lawyers who seek increases in head coaching opportunities for African-Americans.

title: A Collaboration
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Farrell, Thomas Maiden
description: Jennifer Elizabeth Farrell, the daughter of Brenda Waters of Norfolk, Va., and John Patrick Farrell of Annandale, Va., was married last evening to Thomas Tupper Maiden, a son of Rosalind Tupper Maiden of Englewood, N.J., and Michael Sayre Maiden of Los Angeles. The Rev. James M. Wood Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Norfolk.

title: City of Schemes
description: Aren't all these awful crooked C.E.O.'s and C.F.O.'s out in the sticks just . . . awful? How did this spirit of shameless greed come to infuse the corporate cultures of the heartland? Enron: Houston. Arthur Andersen: Chicago. WorldCom: Clinton, Miss. Adelphia: Coudersport, Pa. Tyco: Exeter, N.H., and Boca Raton, Fla. Here in New York City, we've spent the last year selflessly working together toward physical and psychic recovery, all of us engaged in a painful but glorious existential civic introspection. Meanwhile, out there, beyond the Hudson, in the vast unfathomable America of discount superstores and chain restaurants and sun-baked suburban business parks, a decadent amorality had worked its way like some malignant rot through the nation's fiber. Consumed with the struggle to rebuild, we New Yorkers were feeling fully American as we hadn't in decades -- and now, suddenly, the ''real'' America is revealed as a manic, festering hive of greed and corruption. It turns out all the Bedford Fallses are actually Pottersvilles. Which makes us, as we observe the mess from the Upper West Side and TriBeCa, feel all the more victimized and righteous. And by the way? For the record? We always had our doubts about the Internet and its associated financial madnesses.

title: Connie Shoemaker and Jeff Collier III
description: Connie Jean Shoemaker, a daughter of Judy and Leo Shoemaker of Birmingham, Ala., was married last evening to James Francis Collier III, a son of Dee C. Collier of Haddonfield, N.J., and the late Dr. Collier. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Edward J. Coughlin, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Emily Newman, Clifford Bond
description: Emily Newman, a daughter of Cynthie and Lloyd Newman of Katonah, N.Y., is to be married today to Clifford Russell Bond, the son of Melinda Bond of Lake Worth, Fla., and Jerry Bond of Freehold, N.J. Rabbi Andrea Myers will officiate at Round Hill House in Washingtonville, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about growing hostility between Marriott International and owners of hotels managed by Marriott referred incorrectly to two members of the family whose trust owns a Marriott hotel in Quincy, Mass. It was Thomas J. Flatley, as chief executive of the Flatley Company, who hired Marriott to manage the hotel. (His son John J. Flatley oversees the family trust and is the plaintiff in its suit against Marriott.)

title: Rehab Fab: Go Early, Go Often
description: Not long ago, a well-connected and fit young friend told me he had spent July at the Silver Hill clinic in New Canaan, Conn., because he'd been drinking too much. My reaction to his news wasn't great concern. It was more like ''So who was there?''

title: Peer Review and Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Jane Nelson, Ren Milln
description: Sarah Jane Nelson and Ren Milln, actors in New York, were married yesterday by the Rev. Dee Dee Autry, a United Methodist minister, at the Thorncrown Chapel in Eureka Springs, Ark.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POLLOCK, JIMMY
description: POLLOCK-Jimmy. You came into our lives 40 years ago today. We are grateful for the 19 years we had with you. We remember your wit, intelligence and sweetness everyday. Mom, Dad, Andy & Bobby

title: Corrections
description: The NYC column on Friday, comparing the political scenes of New Jersey and New York, gave an incorrect age in some copies for H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee for governor of New York. He is a few weeks shy of 67, not a few weeks shy of 66.

title: The Nation: The $100,000 Longshoreman; A Union Wins the Global Game
description: TO American unions, globalization is a nefarious force that has wiped out the jobs of millions of well-paid blue-collar workers.

title: Those Naughty Victorians Find New Takers
description: MIDWAY into ''Possession,'' the movie based on A. S. Byatt's novel about the parallel love affairs of a pair of Victorian poets and two uptight modern scholars who are their counterparts, the Victorians have a tryst. Christabel (Jennifer Ehle) pushes aside her heavy braid, giving Randolph (Jeremy Northam) access to her corset, a chaste contraption that Mr. Northam approaches reverently, undoing its fretwork of lacing with a slow hand.

title: Underground Movement
description: One shift started at 7 in the morning, the other at 7 at night. Twenty-four hours a day in this past summer's sweltering heat, crews of ironworkers, masons, laborers, carpenters and other tradesmen rebuilt 1,980 feet of subway track destroyed by the World Trade Center attack. ''We never had anybody walk off the job because of the heat,'' said John Pegno, the president of A. J. Pegno Construction, who oversaw the venture with Peter Tully of Tully Construction. ''I didn't pay them any more than any other job. That's saying a lot.'' In many ways, this was a job unlike any other, as a general foreman from the Timbermen's Local Union 1536, Dante Rufo, explained: ''What was unusual was there was nothing to contend with -- usually there are utilities, gas mains, electric lines, but this started as just a big empty space after the demolition crews cleaned it up. I think that left a mark on everyone.''

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Kimberly Bush, Thomas Caldara
description: Kimberly Laura Bush, a daughter of Barbara and William Bush of Irvington, N.Y., was married last evening to Thomas Patrick Caldara, a son of Bart Caldara of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and the late Pamela Caldara. The Rev. Wayne Meisel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Lyndhurst, the Jay Gould house in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing oversight, a review on Page 16 of the Book Review today about ''High and Mighty,'' by Keith Bradsher, cites an author error erroneously. In fact the book does not say what car won the 24-hour race at Le Mans in 1966. Such an error occurred in the reviewer's advance proof, but it does not appear in the finished book, which should have been checked during editing. (The race winner was a Ford GT, not a Mustang. As the book notes, a GT won the race for the next three years as well.)

title: Ageless Work, an Ageless Dancer
description: At 82, Ni Ketut Cenik is the most venerated dancer in Bali. When she takes part in the ''Master Dancers of Bali'' program presented by the World Music Institute on Friday at Symphony Space in Manhattan, she will be performing outside her homeland for the first time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRATAKIS, SOPHIE
description: STRATAKIS-Sophie, at age 98. Christopher Stratakis and his family announce with deep sadness the death of their beloved mother, grandmother and great grandmother, of Woodside, NY. May her memory be eternal.

title: Joyce Laskowski, Craig Bustin
description: Jocelyn M. Laskowski, the daughter of Esther J. Laskowski of Macomb, Mich., and the late Edmund R. Laskowski, is to be married today to Craig Douglas Bustin, the son of Betty C. Bustin and Hugh J. Bustin of Holliston, Mass. Dennis Kovarik, a minister of the Universal Life Church, is to officiate at A Hollywood Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas.

title: The Last Man Standing
description: AT first glance, the sweeping plateau of freshly churned soil resembles an instant community being carved into a Californian hillside. Dump trucks rumble across the rutted surface, piles of construction materials are jumbled nearby and a cluster of beige trailers sit on the far edge. With a panoramic view that takes in swaying grasslands, vivid blue water and a distant skyline, this looks like a suburban dream waiting to happen.

title: 'Charles Darwin'
description: IF CHARLES DARWIN had spent the first half of his life in the world of Jane Austen, he now stepped forward into the pages of Anthony Trollope.

title: 'Something to Declare'
description: Ifirst went to France in the summer of 1959 at the age of thirteen. My pre-adolescence had been car-free and island-bound; now there stood in front of our house a gun-metal-grey Triumph Mayflower, bought secondhand, suddenly affordable thanks to a £200 grant from Great Aunt Edie. It struck me then - as any car would have done - as deeply handsome, if perhaps a little too boxy and sharp-edged for true elegance.; last year, in a poll of British autophiles, it was voted one of the ten ugliest cars ever built. Registration plate RTW1, red leather upholstery, walnut dashboard, no radio, and a blue metal RAC badge on the front. (The RAC man, portly and moustachioed, with heavy patched boots and a subservient manner, had arrived to enrol us. His first, preposterous question to my father - 'Now, sir, how many cars have you got?' - passed into quiet family myth.) That cars were intended not just for safe commuting but also for perilous voyage was endorsed the Triumph's subtitle, and further its illustrative hubcaps: at their centre was an emblematic boss depicting, in blue and red enamel, a Mercator projection of the globe.

title: Beautiful in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A review on Sept. 15 about ''Sharon: Israel's Warrior-Politician,'' by Anita Miller, Jordan Miller and Sigalit Zetouni, misstated the nationality of the victims of a massacre in Beirut in 1982 for which an Israeli government inquiry found Ariel Sharon ''indirectly responsible.'' They were Palestinians, not Lebanese.

title: Will Democrats Be Punished For 11th-Hour Switcheroo?
description: It was almost a tender moment in all the hurly-burly of last week's political drama when Peter G. Sheridan, the lawyer for the state Republicans, argued before the State Supreme Court that the Democrats' fast-footed substitution of Frank R. Lautenberg for the tarnished Robert R. Torricelli had somehow infringed on the rights of his client, Douglas R. Forrester.

title: Thanks for Renovating the Place. Please Note Your Rent Increase.
description: Last year, after a $1.4 million renovation, the Gravesend branch of the Brooklyn Public Library reopened with a new rain canopy, windows, furniture and elevators.

title: Examination Anxiety
description: JEANNE RICHARDS is an ardent believer in mammography. During a routine mammogram in 1995, doctors discovered a lump deep in her left breast. It turned out to be a benign cyst. But since then Mrs. Richards, 57, has received a mammogram twice a year though the American Cancer Society recommends only one annually.

title: MIDTOWN TRAIN FROM MONTCLAIR
description: The Montclair Connection, New Jersey Transit's direct train service from Montclair to Midtown Manhattan, began service last week and was used by 1,600 people a day during its first week, according to the agency. About 1,000 of the riders were people who normally took the train to New York City but had to change trains in Hoboken. About 600 new daily passengers were using the line, and that number is expected to grow, transit officials said. Karen DeMasters

description: TESTED: 2002 Freightliner Sprinter

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERRARA, RONALD A.
description: FERRARA-Ronald A. October 6, 1938-November 22, 1994. On your birthday and each day you are missed and remembered with love. You are always with me. Jane

description: To the Editor:

title: A Double Standard For Executive Women?
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL SET TO USE NEW MISSILE SHIELD TO COUNTER SCUDS
description: Israel has deployed an operational missile defense and is ready to use it to protect Tel Aviv and other major population centers if they come under fire from Iraq's arsenal of Scud missiles.

title: Ralph Lee, a King of the Road, Is Dead at 99
description: Ralph Lee, a celebrated knight-errant of the British road, who built his own vacation trailer in 1931 and went on to pull it and its 10 successors a distance equal to 20 trips around the world, died on Sept. 18 in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, England. He was 99.

title: Dempsey-Tunney: A Daughter's View
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; CELL BROKEN UP
description: Federal officials said they had broken up a terrorist sleeper cell in Portland, Ore., arresting four people accused of plotting after the Sept. 11 attacks to join forces with Al Qaeda and Taliban fighters in a ''jihad'' against the U.S. The F.B.I. also began searching for two other people linked to the case, both of whom are believed to be overseas.

title: A Collage in Which Life = Death = Art
description: LIFE itself might be a work of art. That is modern art's most radical proposition. Art doesn't have to be a painting or drawing. It can be the way an artist acts and speaks. Andy Warhol was Andy Warhola's masterpiece. Joseph Beuys played the role of Professor Beuys. There have been more extreme cases, too: artists who shot or mutilated themselves.

title: Nicole Behrendt, Thomas Martin IV
description: Nicole Fugazy Behrendt, a daughter of Susan and Jeffrey E. Behrendt of Northport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lt. Thomas S. Martin IV, the son of Lorena Martin and Mr. Martin III of Cary, N.C. The Rev. Edwin F. O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Most Holy Trinity at the Military Academy in West Point, N.Y.

title: The Kid And His Council
description: It's easy to underestimate Gifford Miller, the 32-year-old speaker of the New York City Council. Riding the elevator on a visit to Con Ed headquarters on Irving Place, Miller stands dwarfed between the two security agents who escort him everywhere. On the short side, with a baby face framed by jug ears, he looks like a boy on a school field trip -- an impression hardly softened by his account of an Abba concert he attended the night before on Coney Island. ''It was, like, not really Abba,'' he says. ''It was some of the original supporting band members and then, like, look-alikes -- which was better actually.''

title: Travelocity Tackles 'Hidden Price' Problem
description: One of the most troublesome aspects of booking car rentals online is the ''hidden price'' problem, whereby most Web sites fail to disclose the actual cost of renting a vehicle until late in the purchase process.

title: A Catholic Education at a Price That's Right
description: SURROUNDED by his 11 fifth-grade charges, Brother Richard Lalime sat at a child's desk in a large, sunny classroom in Freeport, reading a scary play.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: FORTRESS FOR LESS -- The 33-room Chteau de la Chvre d'Or, in the medieval hilltop village of ze, overlooking the Mediterranean along the Cte d'Azur, is offering three nights for the price of two. It is valid Sunday through Thursday nights through Nov. 12. The hotel has a pool, and a Michelin two-star restaurant. Rates begin at about $260 a night; subject to availability. Information: (888) 989-1768 or www.chevredor.com.

title: Among the Cave Dwellers
description: THE FORGOTTEN MEMOIR

title: Last Call for Matthew Scudder's Favorite Saloon
description: Everybody was there, except maybe Matthew Scudder, the hard-drinking ex-cop who gave the place its literary cachet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ELAINE
description: FRIEDMAN-Elaine. Passed away on September 30, 2002 at the age of 79. She was the beloved wife of Martin Friedman, mother of Lois Herzeca and the late Kenneth Friedman, mother-in-law of Chris Herzeca and grandmother of Jane and Nicholas. Her love, generosity and humor will be remembered always.

title: In the Glare of the Spotlight
description: THE MONTCLAIR Art Museum is presenting a double feature, but both parts run simultaneously in the same exhibition and in the same galleries.

title: Elizabeth Carder, Larry Thompson

title: Adaora Udoji, Ron Allen
description: Adaora Udoji and Ron Allen, television news correspondents, were married yesterday by the Rev. Kenneth W. Phifer at the First Unitarian Universalist Church in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Wynton Marsalis; A Trumpeter, His Tie and Friends Who Love to Hang
description: THE trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, who on Monday night was due at a party downtown, at a dinner Midtown and at a jam session in Harlem, keeps a frenetic schedule befitting a political candidate. But, said Mr. Marsalis, who has three sons by two former girlfriends, he would never be able to run for office.

title: In the Region/Westchester; New Life for Rundown Site on Yonkers Waterfront
description: The $53 million Larkin Center the new home of the Yonkers Public Library and the city's Board of Education -- opened late last month, offering hope for the long-awaited rebirth of this city's downtown waterfront.

title: Shoot the Pianist
description: MUSIC OF A LIFE

title: Law to Protect Debtors Can Be a Windfall for Lawyers
description: Hugh D. Brauer, 73, has a one-man legal practice in Highland, Ind. He does a little debt collection for a nearby furniture store, and he says he tries to treat people fairly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINDELL, ALMA
description: SINDELL-Alma. Of Miami, Florida, passed on Wednesday, October 2, 2002. Devoted mother to Brian, Sam, and Ina. Devoted grandmother to Jaime, Jordan, Jessica, Bradley, and Brittany. She was a beautiful and fearless lady and a real survivor. We will always love and miss her. The memorial service will be held at the Roof Lounge at 1735 York Avenue on October 7 and 8, from 6 PM-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, please forward any donations to the American Heart Association, www.americanheart.org.

title: Nation's Memory of 9/11 Colors the Debate on Iraq
description: As it echoed down a highway that straddles the continent from suburban New Jersey to San Francisco, the national conversation about war in Iraq was dominated this week by images of smoldering buildings in New York and Washington.

title: Hip-ification
description: There are countless reasons that certain neighborhoods become hip -- why Fort Greene, say, or NoLIta suddenly buzzes with a new energy. And in the constant flux of the city, it's difficult to pinpoint the moment any newly revived neighborhood turns that vital corner. But something happened on Clinton Street three and a half years ago, something small and unexpected, that would transform that fusty old part of the Lower East Side for years to come. This is what happened: Dewey Dufresne went walking.

title: In Park Slope, A 'Pussycat' That Is No Pet Store . . .
description: To the regret of some, the Pink Pussycat, across the street from Middle School 51 in Park Slope, is not a pet store. The cat in the window is plaster, and any fur inside the store comes attached to sheer nightgowns in red and black.

title: Bodies Flying, With John Woo's Name Attached
description: ''JOHN WOO'S ONCE A THIEF'' is very likely the first action series that has ever included a reference to Tristan Tzara. And you might think you're in Dada land when you see the members of a Maoist cell (without an Asian in the bunch) berating a bound woman for being an enemy of the people and wearing an expensive red dress that could feed villages. Did I mention that this scene takes place in Montreal?

title: It's Still Audrey's College, Even If Her Name Is Gone
description: Stephen Greenwald has worked as a lawyer on death-penalty cases. He has produced movies for Martin Scorsese. He has designed a curriculum for a master's degree in media management. As a professor at Audrey Cohen College, he once took students on a field trip to Cannes.

title: Above the Hudson With the Broad-Winged Hawk
description: The walk up to the top of Hook Mountain in Upper Nyack is only 15 or 20 minutes. It is steep enough to be aerobic, though, and I sometimes think I ought to climb to the top every morning. The mountain is not far from my home, and climbing it daily would be a great way to get in shape.

description: After playing the understudy throughout his career, Lucious Harris felt the crowd's instant love for a star one magical night last May.

description: ''Growing Up in Massapequa, and in the Mafia'' [Sept. 29] will surely titillate all those who habitually conflate fact, factoid and fantasy when it comes to vilifying the scions of Italy.

description: WHEN the Norwalk Symphony put the word out that it was looking for a new music director in 1968, there were 12 responses. Last year, the symphony's search committee was inundated with 185 applications, many of them from overseas.

description: SOMETHING TO DECLARE

description: Bosnia's divided Serbs, Croats and Muslims voted for a new government today, under Western pressure to reject the nationalist parties that led this country into a brutal war in 1992.

description: To the Editor:

title: Defusing the Situation
description: The Bomb Squad doesn't pick up bombs. The Bomb Squad picks up packages, and since Sept. 11, 2001, the Bomb Squad is picking up a lot more packages than usual -- on some days 200 percent more, as many as 50 a day. ''We're running busy,'' says Lt. Jerry Sheehan, the commander of the 38-person New York City Police Department Bomb Squad. A lot of the packages are packages that turn out to be just packages: packages that appear sinister to a New Yorker on a higher alert. ''We don't mind that -- we're not inconvenienced by it,'' Sheehan says. Then again, some of the packages turn out to be bombs: pipe bombs, bombs made with dynamite, bombs filled with nails, all the evil explosive things that people come up with to kill people, although the Bomb Squad doesn't use the word ''evil.'' ''We call it good for business,'' Sheehan says.

title: A Double Standard For Executive Women?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutually Assured Democracy
description: ON Oct. 2, the New Jersey Supreme Court gave its O.K. to what could be the start of a candidate ''arms race'' between the two major political parties in the Garden State.

title: Haunted by the Bad Old Days, Some Want to Nip Drugs in the Bud
description: You won't find any bullet shells. Sushi bars have replaced empty storefronts. A college dormitory is going up. But one thing about the block of West 109th Street between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway may have gotten worse recently.

title: The Small Stuff Can Save a Trip
description: TRAVEL can sometimes feel like losing control: One is confined for hours in speeding machines, obliged to sleep in strange surroundings and eat food prepared by unseen hands. So it's not surprising that seasoned travelers have a trick or two to defeat the forces of discomfort and carve out a bit of individual privilege. These little tips can be the difference between misery and mastery.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; MOUSSAOUI TRIAL DELAYED
description: Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, won a pair of surprising legal victories, acting as his own lawyer. Judge Leonie M. Brinkema granted his request for a six-month delay in the trial, and she also agreed to move him to a larger cell. Philip Shenon

description: Emily Arnone, the daughter of Deanna and Cyrus Arnone III of Rockville Centre, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to Christopher Robert Cottrell, the son of Natalya Cottrell of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Raymond Cottrell of Las Vegas. Lisel Burns, the leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated at Astra, an event space in Manhattan.

description: THE stock market's continuing slide pulled the returns of all stock mutual fund categories into negative territory in the third quarter, including sector funds and those that invest in overseas markets or that combine stocks and bonds in one portfolio.

description: Giants Manager Dusty Baker emerged from the home dugout facing a crucial decision with the bases loaded and his team tied with the Braves in the sixth inning today. Baker also carried with him a history of being second-guessed after early postseason exits.

title: Mutual Funds Report; U.S. Funds Wary Of Foreign Adventure
description: AMERICAN investors, and the fund managers who look after their money, have often ignored overseas markets. Such parochialism would have proved costly during the last year, as stocks in the United States performed far worse than those of many foreign markets, although the American market narrowed the gap slightly in the last quarter.

title: Canada's Rising Economic Tide Also Lifts Its Ruling Liberals
description: TORONTO, Oct. 5  It only takes a look at this city's fast-changing skyline to see that Canada is defying the slowdown throttling much of the world economy.

title: A Fiery First Encounter for Senate Candidates
description: While legal teams for the Republican and Democratic parties fight three separate legal battles over the United States Senate race in New Jersey, the two main candidates had their first face-to-face encounter today, and it ended, not surprisingly, with enough shouts and posturing for a professional wrestling match.

title: Sept. 29-Oct. 5: FRONT LINES; U.N. PRESSES IRAQ
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspector, Hans Blix, endorsed the key American demand that Iraq make a full declaration of its weapons programs before any inspections resume. Dr. Blix also said there was ''very broad support'' in the Security Council for a new resolution setting tough terms for inspections. In addition, he endorsed the threat of consequences if Iraq fails to disarm. Iraq had hoped for inspections under less stringent conditions.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Bond Funds for the Ultra-Impatient
description: THE once-obscure category of ultrashort-term bond funds is attracting new money, and for two reasons: Mutual fund investors -- their long patience with the faltering stock market severely strained -- see them as havens. And more fund companies, including Fidelity and Dreyfus, have recently begun to market the investments.

title: Habitats/West New York, N.J.; Three Canadians Decide To Teach in the Bronx
description: JODY BILLINGSLEY and MARYANN MORGAN both graduated from Simon Fraser University in Vancouver last year, and both wanted to be teachers. But jobs in Vancouver were scarce, so the two college roommates had to settle for taking work as substitutes, when they could find it.

title: Counting Votes at Co-op Elections
description: Q: At the annual election of our co-op's board, two shareholders counted the votes, announced the results, and went home to their apartments. The meeting was adjourned. The managing agent then took the ballots and the paperwork to his office. Three weeks later, a member of the board who is also an employee of the managing agent called the vote counters to say that he had put the votes into a spreadsheet and come up with different results. What is the status of the board elected at the shareholders' meeting? . . . Michael Kaplan, Forest Hills, N.Y.

title: No Labels, No Boundaries: An Artist of the Moment
description: IN a darkened room at the 303 Gallery in Chelsea, several elliptical screens hang from the ceiling, momentarily gray as they await the start of the next cycle of Doug Aitken's video installation, ''New Skin.'' Arranged in a hovering X shape, like a ghostly lotus blossom unfolding in the middle of the dim space, this multifaceted array suddenly brightens with images of a digital timer, its white numerals rushing backward toward zero.

title: Corrections

title: A Tour of Clinton Street
Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MONROE (MONTE)

Survived by his wife Myrna, children Debi, Danny, Aimee and Gary, his grandchildren Jon, Lindsay, Jeff, Allison and Carly.

title: Sports of The Times; Cowboys' New Surface Anything but Real
description: IT'S called RealGrass, but it's not. It's just the latest high-tech artificial surface. In the Giants' 21-17 struggle over the Cowboys yesterday, the new green-as-grass carpet in Texas Stadium was under inspection only hours after its installation and paint job were completed Saturday night.

title: People
description: * Marsha Young was named to head Maritz Brand Alignment, Fenton, Mo., a new division of Maritz Inc., as president. She had been president at Delve, a division of Maritz.

title: The Hudson at Risk
description: This time of year most lawns suddenly sprout election placards. But in Columbia County, N.Y., the election placards stand alongside signs that say either ''Stop the Plant'' or ''Support the Plant.'' The plant is a proposed coal-burning cement manufacturing facility that would be built, if approved, along the Hudson River near the city of Hudson and the town of Greenport. In effect, St. Lawrence Cement, which is owned by the Swiss company Holcim, would create an industrial city on the waterfront, including 40 acres of buildings, a 1,200-acre open-pit limestone mine, a new dock, a two-mile-long conveyor belt and a smokestack that would stand 400 feet high. The plant is inappropriate, and Gov. George Pataki and his environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, must stop it.

title: Corrections

It appeared in The York Daily Record as well as The York Dispatch.

description: Jessica Guzman is serious about her hair. Every two months, she takes a day off work to get her dark curls lightened by the colorist that she has seen for the last two years. She spends over an hour -- and close to $200 -- at the salon.

Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, EUGENE E.
description: DANIEL-Eugene E. Of Fair Lawn, NJ, on Sunday, October 6, 2002. description: Zorach Warhaftig, a rabbi from Byelorussia who persuaded a Japanese diplomat to defy his government's orders and help save several thousand Jews during World War II, died on Sept. 26 in Jerusalem. He was 96.

The Twins are a low-budget operation, relatively speaking, and Commissioner Bud Selig had threatened last winter to close the franchise because, he said, finances made it difficult for the Twins to compete.
