title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARTEN, JULIA
description: KARTEN-Julia. Of Spring Valley and New York City died on October 5 at Mt. Sinai Hospital. She was surrounded by her beloved children and grandchildren. Only 16 at the outset of WWII, Julia, who met her husband Isidore in the Polish underground, fought by his side in the Jewish Resistance. Coming to America with only a borrowed blouse on her back, Julia managed to rebuild her life. Landing at Pier 56 in New York Harbor, at 20 years of age with a newborn child, no close relatives and not a word of English, Julia became the nurturing life force at the center of her family. She was truly a woman of valor. Equally adept at running a business as she was at running a home, she brought her intelligence, sensitivity, artistic talent, and concern for people to everything she did, whether it was volunteering to be a Girl Scout leader or managing a successful textile business and a high-rise apartment building in the heart of Manhattan. But one of Julia's biggest sense of achievements came from her and Izzy's active involvement in a multitude of philanthropies, including education in the form of scholarships, Benefactor of the International Society of the Yad Vashem both in America and Israel, as well as the endless donations to hospitals, schools, and synagogues around the world. Julia is survived by her loving children, Berne and Jim Bookhamer, Marcia and Yakov Toledano, and Harry and Danielle Karten as well as her eight dedicated grandchildren. She was above all a strong, courageous woman who fought until the end. Funeral services will be held on Monday, October 7, at 12:30 PM at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street. Donations can be made to the Alzheimers Foundation, the Scholarship Fund at Park East Day School and the American Diabetes Foundation.

title: For Next Spring, a Little Seriousness and a Lot of Play
description: The invitation to Hussein Chalayan's spring 2003 show, held here on Friday night, showed a picture of a smiling little girl in a red smock dress. What made this little girl different from other little girls is that her eyes were blindfolded and she held a Smith & Wesson pistol in her hands. Mr. Chalayan, one of fashion's greatest talents, has never seemed like the sort of designer who would provoke gratuitously, and one assumed he would not start now -- an assumption based in some part on the fact that he is a serious, saturnine-looking fellow who often seems to be carrying a metaphoric backpack filled with the weight of the world's misunderstood.

description: Having vanquished the music swapping service Napster in court, the entertainment industry is facing a formidable obstacle in pursuing its major successor, KaZaA: geography.

description: All along the fertile valley of the Kunduz River, farmers were bringing in the harvest this week, carrying great sheaves on their backs from the fields and driving their oxen in circles in an ancient method of threshing.

title: A Spirited Race for Congress Brings Politics to the Arizona Desert
description: The other night George Cordova came to the public library here pursuing votes in one of the more improbable battlegrounds in the fight for control of Congress. Sedona's serene and otherworldly red-rock buttes in the high Sonoran Desert have long lured visitors, retirees and New Age spiritualists seeking to get away from it all. This year they are luring the politicians.

title: Debate to Intensify on Copyright Extension Law
description: The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments this week over the constitutionality of a 1998 law that extended copyright protection by 20 years. Experts on both sides of the closely watched case say that its outcome could reshape the way cultural products are consumed and how their profits are divided.

Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, may ''empower other C.E.O.'s'' who are members of Augusta to speak out.

title: Giants Play With Verve And Get Back On Track

But Brown glanced back and there was only Bryant, sprinting full speed, pursuing the long pass meant to beat the Giants.

title: Broncos Offer the Chargers a Dose of Reality on Offense
description: Marty Ball is ugly ball. Marty Ball could be best described as 3 yards and a cloud of dust, only that would be an insult to the clouds and the dust. In Marty Ball, the fullback position is sexy and a stiff-arm goes well with a good Chianti.

description: PEARSON - Mary Esther (nee Smalley). Of West Cornwall, CT, and formerly of North Massapequa, NY, age 84. Lived a wonderful life and died peacefully on October 5, 2002. Cherished wife for 57 years of George E. Pearson. Loving mother of George Jr., Donald, Ann, John (deceased) and Mary. Beloved sister of Arthur Smalley (deceased), John Smalley, Ruth Smalley and Joan Walsh. Devoted grandmother of Joe and Laura. You will always be in our hearts. Visiting Tuesday, October 8, 2002, at Knowles Funeral Home, Port Washington. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, October 9, 2002, at St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington.

title: Corrections

He said that the campaign against terror ''is now the focus of my administration'' -- not ''my presidency.'' A reader who is a researcher noticed the error recently and alerted The Times.

Her housecleaning and restaurant jobs have never provided health insurance. Few local facilities have Spanish-speaking staff members. Even making an appointment, given her limited English skills, is a daunting, often humiliating, experience.

title: Oyez! Oyez!
description: It is the first Monday in October, which means the new Supreme Court term starts today. After the traditional call of oyez that brings the court to order, the justices will consider a docket that looks relatively routine, including cases on intellectual property and elements of criminal law. But what many court watchers expect to see added over the coming months could make this a year of landmark significance. The justices may be presented with their first chance to weigh in on post-Sept. 11 issues like secret detentions and closed-door deportation hearings. The critical question is how willing the court will be to trim the Constitution to fit post-Sept. 11 fashions.

title: MediaTalk; Field and Stream Names New Editor
description: Sid Evans, who was shot off his horse as editor of Men's Journal, will be the new editor of Field and Stream, Time Inc.'s hunting-and-fishing magazine. Back in August, Mr. Evans was replaced by Robert L. Wallace at Wenner Media's Men's Journal.

title: Fear in a Sniper's Wake: 'This Guy's Our Neighbor'

A week after Sprewell arrived for training camp with a broken hand, the Knicks said today they had fined him $250,000 for not reporting the injury in a timely manner.

description: The Fulton Street Mall in downtown Brooklyn is an epicenter of New York hip-hop, and on a crowded afternoon last week the strip roiled with theories about Tupac Shakur and the Notorious B.I.G.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 4 Still Hospitalized After Fire Trucks' Collision
description: Three New York firefighters remained hospitalized yesterday, a day after their engine truck collided with a ladder truck. Both rigs careered into a 2000 Saturn car occupied by a 38-year-old pregnant woman and her 4-year-old son. The boy suffered minor injuries but the woman is hospitalized. The crash is under investigation, but no summonses have been issued. Both trucks were rushing to a reported house fire on Saturday that turned out to be a false alarm, officials said. Lt. Michael Roy and Firefighters Brian Ragano, Victor Bene and Charles Pettigano, of Squad 61, suffered multiple injuries and were in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, said Pedro Ceniza, a hospital administrator. Last evening, however, one of the men left against doctor's orders, said a hospital spokeswoman, who declined to say which one. The spokeswoman also said that one of the other firefighters was in critical but stable condition. The injured woman, Monica Flynn, was listed as stable last night, Mr. Ceniza said. Twelve firefighters in all were injured, officials said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: New Economy; Intriguing possibilities in sensors, an on-ramp for electronics and biotechnology.
description: TRADE shows do not get much more obscure than Sensors Expo and Conference. The semiannual gathering assembles scores of little companies -- or little-known divisions of large ones like General Electric -- that make devices to measure heat, pressures, speed, voltage, acceleration and scores of other conditions that are vital to machines and people.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On 9/11 Aid
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the effectiveness of aid programs for small businesses following the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. City Council chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7722.

title: Changes in Media Accounts
description: Accounts

title: Fraudulent Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Should Baby Web Sites Reach Out to Dad?
description: Should Web sites that sell baby clothes, toys and pacifiers start posting up-to-the-minute college football scores and pictures of swimsuit models? That might be one way to help expectant fathers make the transition to spit bibs from sports and to parenting from pornography.

title: Giants Willing to Give Bonds Meaningless Hits
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6  The Braves' Gary Sheffield was Barry Bonds's guest last winter, working out with Bonds in the Bay Area. When the Giants and Braves were pitted against each other in the National League division series, Sheffield invited Bonds to his Atlanta home, and Bonds played with Sheffield's children and had dinner with him before Game 1.

title: J. P. Morgan Plans Job Cuts Up to 4,000, Executives Say
description: J. P. Morgan Chase is planning to cut as many as 4,000 employees, including many managing directors, from its investment banking operation over the next several weeks, executives with the firm said yesterday.

title: Beleaguered Conservatives in Britain Open Conference
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, Oct. 7  Britain's Conservative Party opened its annual conference in this English Channel resort today against a backdrop of plummeting poll ratings, fresh reminders of sex scandals from its recent experience and speculation over efforts to oust its new leader, Iain Duncan Smith.

title: Nonalcoholic brew is shedding its flat image : A lush market for near beer
description: FRANKFURT:  As professor emeritus of brewing sciences, Anton Piendl knows more than the average barstool philosopher about beer aroma, flavor and foam. But when Piendl, author of a seven-volume beer encyclopedia, swills a cold Pilsener, it's an alkoholfrei Clausthaler Premium.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, VINCENT J.
description: CARROLL-Vincent J. Of Williston Park, NY died peacefully at his home. Past president of St. Aidan's Parish Council, member of St. Aidan's Holy Name Society. Retired Air Corpsman WWII the European and Pacific Theatre. He was a leading authority of the use of antibiotics to treat agricultural diseases. Devoted husband of the late Elizabeth (nee Willett), loving father of Vincent, Margaret Foehr, Ann, Mary, A. Patricia Roszkowski, Elizabeth Cunningham, Martha Mixa, James, and Marion O'Sullivan. Proud grandpa of 26 grandchildren. Caring brother of Kathryn Healy, Agnes Leahy, Marion DeHaven and the late James Carroll and the late Margaret Bracken. Dear brother-in-law of John Leahy, Cecelia Carroll and William DeHaven. Reposing at the Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Avenue, Williston Park, Monday and Tuesday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, St. Aidan's Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to his Alma Mater, Class of '41, Xavier High School, 30 West 16 Street, New York, would be appreciated.

title: Lessons From Wars of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: MediaTalk; A New Vocabulary at Headline News
description: Wassup with the recent decision at CNN Headline News to put slang and hip-hop phrases into its on-screen graphics and headlines?

title: Corrections
description: An ''If You Go'' guide in Escapes on Sept. 27 with an article about traveling the northernmost 690 miles of the Appalachian Trail misspelled the name of the county for Monticello, Me. It is Aroostook, not Aroostock.

title: Asia Gains in Chip Market
description: The America's share of the $131 billion worldwide semiconductor market has continued to plummet this year, dropping to only 22 percent of worldwide revenue in the second quarter of 2002, as communications and other high-technolgy companies cut costs by sending more of their chip making offshore. (The data, compiled by the market research firm InStat/MDR, groups North, Central and South America; the United States' chip output represents the vast majority of the region's total.)

title: Death of Disgraced Priest Brings Conflict Over Burial
description: Last Monday, 82 years after his birth, 52 years after his ordination, 14 years since his retirement, 11 years since his suspension from the Roman Catholic priesthood and almost 3 years after the flood of lawsuits accusing him of molesting more than 40 boys, the Rev. Maurice Grammond died in a Portland, Ore., Alzheimer's care home.

title: Brazil's Markets Wait To Exhale After Vote
description: With the outcome of Brazil's election leaning toward a second round between the left-wing front runner, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, and the governing coalition's candidate, Jos Serra, markets were expected to call a truce on Monday and give the country's embattled currency and bonds a chance to recover.

title: Metro Matters; If Nobody Lifts An Umbrella, Can It Rain?
description: YOU can tell that Election Day is just a month away, with the major candidates for governor competing energetically over such matters as who can raise and spend more (Gov. George E. Pataki) and who can suffer the most self-inflicted wounds (Comptroller H. Carl McCall, virtuoso of that fine political art of writing for jobs).

title: McCormack Wins With Riverdance
description: Kristy McCormack, 18, of Clermont, N.J., rode her horse, Riverdance, and three others to victory in the annual United States Equestrian Team Talent Search Competition for young riders at the team's training center in Gladstone, N.J. McCormack beat a field of 53 qualifiers in the four-phase event. McCormack, who finished seventh in the 1999 talent search and 11th last year, said that she would turn professional at the end of this season. Alex Orr Jr.

title: Swipe at Record Labels In Ads for Rolling Stone
description: In the current cover of Rolling Stone, a Rolling Stone poses with a guitar, staring unapologetically at the camera and daring the viewer to giggle at the sight of an old man with his shirt off. With the leathered skin of a lizard and a disposition to match, Keith Richards is in no mood to apologize for the fact that he still rocks. Neither, apparently is the magazine he shares a brand name with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWSON, ERICA
description: LAWSON-Erica. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the sister of its esteemed Board of Trustees member and Gabbai, J. Peter Lunzer. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Rachel Lurie, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KART, HAROLD
description: KART-Harold. A prince among men. So we bid you goodnight, sweet prince. You have left a void in our hearts that can never be filled. Ellie and Marvin

title: Helen Dudar; Cultural Writer, 78
description: Helen Dudar, a prolific New York journalist and freelance writer on cultural subjects, died on Aug. 1 at Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. She was 78.

title: Defense Throws Water on Pennington's Spark
description: The Jets caught a tantalizing glimpse of their future today, but even Chad Pennington's electrifying premiere at quarterback could not put enough of a gleam on what remains a dismal present with a 29-25 loss to Kansas City.

title: MediaTalk; Vivendi's Music Unit Is Rising Above Fray
description: In Paris, Vivendi Universal executives are figuring out how to slice up their ailing empire. But despite the uncertainty, the company's music division appears to be doing just fine.

title: Pass Records Aside, Penn Still Relies on Defense
description: Pennsylvania received career highs of 428 yards passing and 4 touchdown completions from Mike Mitchell in a 49-14 rout of Dartmouth on Saturday. But Mitchell's emergence does not signal a change from Penn's emphasis on defense.

title: Texas and Oklahoma Stay Unbeaten, Barely
description: Here are a couple of sure bets for this week: the calls and the letters from Texas about how the Longhorns have been slighted by the New York Times computer ranking will slow significantly, and a bushel of college place-kickers will endure some lonely, tense practices.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is what democracy is all about. I'll stay up all night if I have to, but I'm not going to sleep until I know if this is all over or not.''

title: With Blanks to Fill, Yankees Look Ahead
description: The marquee atop Yankee Stadium shouted this message to motorists on the Major Deegan Expressway yesterday morning: ''GOOD LUCK ANKS.'' There it was, a fitting metaphor for the abrupt end of the season; quite literally, the Yanks had fallen apart.

title: Fixed-Income Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week include today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill to be auctioned tomorrow.

title: Guys Seeking Someone Who'll Care
description: It's official: Men have feelings, too. Since the dawn of grunge a decade ago, rockers have been letting the world know about their insecurities, wounded hearts and growing pains, loudly declaring how sensitive they feel. Hoobastank, a band from California that performed at the World on Tuesday night, flaunts confusion and self-pity in songs that skillfully bundle the latest agonized-guy styles along with the classic pop ingredient: melody.

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Real Estate column on Sept. 20, about the recent conversion of 327 Central Park West to a condominium, misstated the discount offered to current tenants who bought apartments. It was 40 percent, not 22 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PAUL
description: MILLER-Paul. On October 5, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Marilyn. Devoted father of Ellen, Steve and Laurie. Dear brother of Eileen Warner. Loving grandfather of Eli, Jacob, Nikki, Geoffrey and Ethan. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Bank of Ireland Is Said to Be in Merger Talks
description: The Bank of Ireland has approached Abbey National of Britain about a potential merger, people close to the discussions said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, JEANETTE (NEE PFEFFER)
description: COHEN-Jeanette (nee Pfeffer). On October 4, 2002. Beloved wife of the late William J. Devoted mother of Stephen and Robert. Dear mother-in-law of Sherry and Sallee. Proud grandmother of Alyssa, Kara, Faran and Jayme. Dear sister of Marion Blum and Ethel Lerner. Services at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave, Tuesday, 9:30 AM.

title: That Left Turn May Cost You, Bub
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Fashion; Raw and Untamed, An Appeal To the Romantic
description: Big Bertha pantaloons, sensual Eastern robes, corsair pirate coats over lacy skirts -- Balzac's ghost must have been howling as a gust of 19th-century Romanticism whipped through the spring 2003 collections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, RUTH
description: WHITE-Ruth. Our darling sister died on Sunday, October 6, after a long illness. Ruth was an advertising executive but her first love was the theater. Known as Joniruth White in the theater she was an original member of the Roundabout Theater Company, toured France and Italy with Robert Wilson's production of ''Edison'' and appeared in John Waters' cult film ''Polyester.'' Ruth is survived by two sisters, Sylvia White Eisenberg of San Francisco, Janet White Loeb of New York, and a brother, Lawrence White. Services will be private

title: The Day After, Steinbrenner Grins but Can Hardly Bear It
description: More subdued than seething, more reasoned than ranting, George Steinbrenner swallowed what must have felt like a softball yesterday, bit his tongue and worked diligently to sound like a gracious loser. It is not in Steinbrenner's demanding personality to accept the Yankees fizzling in October, and to accept that it happened in a shocking manner, but he tried. He really tried.

title: No. 10 May Make Fans Forget No. 16
description: There were hundreds, perhaps thousands, of Jets fans wearing No. 16 Vinny Testaverde jerseys inside Giants Stadium yesterday. There were, at most, two dozen fans in No. 10 Chad Pennington jerseys.

title: Justices Turn Down Case on Disciplining of Federal Judges
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  The Supreme Court today turned back a constitutional challenge to the law that authorizes the federal judiciary to discipline its own misbehaving members, short of removal from the bench.

title: Sports of The Times; A.L. Champion to Have Underdog Pedigree
description: LIKE a rambunctious puppy who shakes the rain off himself in a posh living room, the Minnesota Twins have now sprayed Champagne all over the baseball establishment.

title: Pre-Race Crash Scrambles Nascar Leaders
description: When Winston Cup stock cars line up to race at Talladega Superspeedway, there is always anticipation of the Big One, the horrific wreck that has become routine at a track where speeds approach 195 miles an hour on the backstretch.

title: E-Commerce Report; Software that 'hijacks' links to online merchants is at the center of a war for sales commissions.
description: EARLY next month, leaders from the Internet's ''affiliate marketing'' community plan to meet with merchants and vendors of online shopping technology to seek peace after months of sniping. But given the remarks of various parties recently, the negotiations could be bitter and, perhaps, fruitless.

title: Daschle Predicts Broad Support For Military Action Against Iraq
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, predicted today that the Senate would soon pass a resolution authorizing President Bush to take military action against Iraq, that it would win with broad bipartisan support and that he would probably vote for it even without restrictions that he personally favors.

title: October Heroics in Anaheim? In the Bronx, It's Blasphemy
description: Somewhere heroes fought on. Somewhere dreams were still alive. But in the Bronx, it was all over yesterday. The Yankees, whose season ended abruptly in an obscure town in California Saturday night, came home on the red-eye, their mystique in tatters, their fans a shattered army.

title: MetroStars' Diallo Joins Saudi Club
description: Last Monday, Mamadou Diallo was honored as the MetroStars' most valuable player. On Wednesday, Diallo, a 31-year-old striker from Senegal, will be playing his first game for his new club in Saudi Arabia after his transfer was completed yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONIN, WILLIAM J.
description: CRONIN-William J. Of Spring Lake, NJ, and formerly of Larchmont, NY, on Friday, October 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Giannotti) Cronin, devoted father of Leigh Anne, Allison, Will Jr., and Bonnie, dear brother of Jessie McCabe, proud grandfather of six. Mr. Cronin had a distinguished 30 year career with IBM in New York. Funeral service Tuesday, October 8, 2002, at 9 AM, from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd, Wall, NJ, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 9:30 AM, at St. Catharine's RC Church, Spring Lake. Visitation Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Committal private at the convenience of the family. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to VNA of Central Jersey, Hospice Division, 141 Bodman Pl, Red Bank, NJ 07701.

title: Bill Clients. Kiss the Kids. Spa. If Time, Ponder It All.
description: I DON'T KNOW HOW SHE DOES IT

title: Market Place; The Baby Bells shake the industry as they lose ground to local phone companies.
description: WHAT should be done with, or for, the Bells?

title: Senate Race Begins Again With Quarrel Over Debates
description: The two main candidates in the United States Senate race in New Jersey finished their first weekend campaigning against each other today by bickering over a proposed schedule for debates.

title: This Week
description: At First Sight

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGUET, SHEILA
description: HOGUET-Sheila, 78. Of New York City, died October 3. Survived by daughter, Denise, and son, Mark. Funeral services Tuesday, October 8, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th and Lexington, 10 AM. Reception 3-6. 212-879-8445.

title: Alternative Weeklies Divide Turf
description: Stung by brutal competition and an even tougher economy, the raging rock throwers of alternative media are behaving like civilized monopolists, dividing up markets and cutting their losses.

title: Stretching Their Way To Revelry and Rivalry
description: Imaginative choreographers can adapt and combine source materials in multitudinous ways. Quasar, the Brazilian troupe that danced on Friday night at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, showed its artistic indebtedness to traditional Brazilian dance and martial-arts forms and also to international modern-dance techniques and gymnastics.

title: Northern Ireland Peace Accord Is in Danger, Britain Warns
description: Britain said today that the Northern Ireland peace accord was in danger of imminent collapse and that prompt action by Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army, was necessary to save it.

title: Gloved One? Or Fugitive Of Boy Band? Some Wonder
description: Did Michael Jackson release a new single?

title: I.B.M. Business Unit Will Focus on Electronics Companies
description: I.B.M. will today take the wraps off a business unit that sells design help, production management and other services to electronics companies and to manufacturers looking to outsource the creation of advanced electronics for their products.

title: McCall, Citing Report, Criticizes Pataki on Care for the Mentally Ill
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, seized on a news report about mentally ill people kept in locked wards in nursing homes yesterday to criticize Gov. George E. Pataki as lacking ''care or compassion.''

title: Brief and Cordial Confirmation Hearing for F.D.A. Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  President Bush's nominee for commissioner of food and drugs, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, appeared before the Senate today for a brief and cordial confirmation hearing that seemed to clear the way for his confirmation by the Senate.

title: Fire on French Tanker Off Yemen Raises Terrorism Fears
description: A French oil tanker was on fire off the southeastern coast of Yemen after an explosion this morning as it headed for an oil terminal in the Gulf of Aden. By late tonight, the cause of the blast aboard the tanker Limburg was still unclear, but the incident immediately raised fears that terrorists had attacked one of the most vulnerable links in the oil-dependent global economy two years after an explosive-filled boat in nearby waters ripped a hole in the United States Navy destroyer Cole.

title: Giants' Baker On Mets' List
description: The Mets will likely contact Giants Manager Dusty Baker after the playoffs. Baker, who is in the final year of his contract, has expressed interest in evaluating his options.

title: Political Memo; As Polls Talk, Losers Walk, And Early
description: Whatever happened to the iron law of politics: winners never quit and quitters never win?

title: W. S. Raines; Businessman, 95
description: W. S. Raines, a retired businessman and investor in real estate in Alabama and Florida, died yesterday at his home in Birmingham. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Sept. 24 about physicists' selections of the 10 most beautiful experiments misstated a portion of Newton's theory of gravity, cited in a discussion of Cavendish's torsion-bar experiment. Newton held that the strength of attraction between two objects increases with the product of their masses, not with the square of their masses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. The Drawing Center is deeply saddened by the loss of their distinguished Board member, Edward Tuck. Mr. Tuck had been a Board member since the founding of The Drawing Center in 1976. He also served as Chairman of the Board during the institution's first five critical years. Through his leadership, loyalty and impeccable judgement, he made immeasurable contributions to The Drawing Center, for which we will always be indebted. We extend our sympathies to his wife Lily, and to his entire family. Board of Directors & Staff The Drawing Center

title: Hope in a Ruined Land
description: When I first arrived in northern Afghanistan in October of last year I, was amazed by how different it was from any other country I've seen. It's mysterious and captivating, and one thing that struck me was how friendly the people were despite their difficult conditions. I'm Tyler Hicks, a photographer for The New York Times, please click on the links to left see and hear about how Afghanistan has changed in the last year.

title: Paris Mayor Recovering After Being Stabbed During Festival
description: The mayor of Paris, Bertrand Delano, was out of danger after being stabbed in the abdomen in City Hall early today by a man who later told the police that he disliked politicians and homosexuals.

title: That Left Turn May Cost You, Bub
description: To the Editor:

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Michael Allen, lead strategist at Rare Method Interactive Studios, Calgary, Alberta, was named to the new post of vice president for strategy. Rare Method is part of Rare Method Capital Corporation.

title: The Miami Offense Hogs the Spotlight, and the Ball
description: For having just beaten the defending Super Bowl champion today, Miami Dolphins linebacker Zach Thomas felt strangely as if he almost had the day off. That is because the Dolphins now boast an offense to complement their heralded defense. That offense controlled the ball for a striking 39 minutes 59 seconds in allowing the Dolphins to seize sole possession of first place in the American Football Conference East with a 26-13 victory over the New England Patriots before 73,369 at Pro Player Stadium.

title: Shipmates' Fight Cited in Fatal Midtown Plunge
description: Lisa R. Tedstone struggled with heroin addiction, failed romances and single motherhood in Greenville, S.C. But shortly before Sept. 11, 2001, she joined the Navy, and her life seemed to be turning around.

title: Lessons From Wars of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: RECONSIDERING `SMART GUN' LEGISLATION Legislation requiring "smart gun" technology in handguns will be considered again by state lawmakers today. The technology allows only recognized users to fire the guns. The bill, which is meant to prevent children from using guns, passed the Senate in previous sessions but was not considered by the Assembly. The legislation was amended last week and is expected to be voted on today. Sponsors of the bill said childproof handguns would not be mandated until the technology was commercially available and proven to be reliable. Opponents say the technology does not exist and would be risky anyway.   (AP)

title: Calibrating Next Step for 'The Sopranos'
description: So, what next for ''The Sopranos''?

title: Lessons From Wars of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: That Left Turn May Cost You, Bub
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC SAYS BUSH NEEDS TO PAY HEED TO WEAK ECONOMY
description: A majority of Americans say that the nation's economy is in its worst shape in nearly a decade and that President Bush and Congressional leaders are spending too much time talking about Iraq while neglecting problems at home, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Anaheim vs. Minnesota
description: Angels (99-63, A.L. wild card)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENT, EVELYN ENDRESEN
description: KENT-Evelyn Endresen. Of Greenwich, CT, and Vero Beach, FL, died Saturday, September 28, 2002. An Eileen Ford model, she is survived by her husband, Dr. Edwin H. Kent and her three children.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Compressed Data column of Business Day last Monday about an online game called Torture a Spammer, operated by the company Marketing Sherpa, misstated the number of its customer e-mail addresses that had fallen into the hands of online mass mailers, or spammers. While the spammers did obtain a list of 10 million addresses, only about 100,000 belonged to Marketing Sherpa's customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, GLORIA BEVERLY
description: KLEIN-Gloria Beverly. In loving memory of wife, mother and grandmother. December 9, 1929-October 4, 2002. Mother of Phillip, Rena and Debbie and grandmother of Jessica, Gregory and Alexandra. May we always remember her dignity and grace. We will miss her.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDREYER, CONSTANCE
description: GOLDREYER - Constance. We will misss you, our cherished friend. Love, Jayne and Susan

title: U.S. 'Troubled' by Israeli Raid That Killed 13 Palestinians
description: KHAN YUNIS, Gaza Strip, Oct. 7 - An Israeli helicopter gunship appeared over a crowded dirt street here before dawn today and fired a single missile, killing 10 people at the end of a raid by troops and tanks that left at least 13 dead and brought rare criticism from the Bush administration that Israel was endangering civilians.

title: Chiefs Saved the Best Option for Last
description: In the Kansas City Chiefs' playbook, the play is called 999. It is a pass designed for one of four potential receivers with perhaps a fifth option. As it turned out today, the pass went to that fifth option, the running back, and with 27 seconds left in a game that was slipping away, he turned it into the winning touchdown for the Chiefs and a heartbreaking loss for the Jets.

title: Lessons From Wars of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Cites Iraqi Threat Posed to U.S. and Allies
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 - President Bush declared tonight that Saddam Hussein could attack the United States or its allies ``on any given day'' with chemical or biological weapons. In a purposeful argument for disarming Iraq or going to war with that country, he argued that ``we have an urgent duty to prevent the worst from occurring.''

title: Kidd Shows He Intends To Improve His Shooting
description: Jason Kidd did not appreciate it when the roster hopeful John Celestand held him down in a scrimmage. So Kidd pushed him and glared at him, the two entangling for a split-second before Celestand came to his senses and slapped Kidd on the rear in apology.

title: LEFTIST CANDIDATE TAKES A FIRM LEAD IN BRAZIL ELECTION
description: Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the leftist Workers' Party surged to an emphatic lead in Brazil's presidential election Sunday. But with returns still pouring in early today, it appeared increasingly likely he would be unable to obtain the majority he needs to avoid a runoff in three weeks.

title: Angry at U.S., Palestinians Ratify Capital In Jerusalem
description: At a meeting suffused with anger over United States Congressional legislation declaring Jerusalem to be the capital of Israel, the Palestinian parliament today ratified a bill signed by Yasir Arafat designating the city as the capital of a future Palestinian state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENSEN, ROBERT ERIC
description: JENSEN-Robert Eric. On October 4, 2002. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted brother of Daniel C. Loving uncle of Danielle and the late Karen. His career in public relations included Vice President of A.J. Lazarus for 17 years, prior to that. Vice President of Gibbs and Soell for 10 years. In the words of his colleagues, ''You're head and shoulders above the rest,'' and ''Bob Jensen, you're the best PR writer in the country.'' In addition to his love of art, Bob enjoyed both jazz and classical music. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, with a service Monday evening at 8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell. Interment will take place on Tuesday, at Evergreen Cemetery, Morristown, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society or a charity of your choice.

title: New Jersey Redraws Party Lines
description: Senator Robert G. Torricelli's withdrawal from the New Jersey race last week could mean defeat for the state's Democrats. Not only did they lose the advantage of incumbency, but the legal and political battles over his replacement could linger through the remainder of the campaign.

title: Stem Cell Sidestepping
description: To the Editor:

title: A Glut of Sept. 11 Books Cuts Into Sales
description: The anniversary of Sept. 11 may have prompted American publishers to produce more titles on a single subject in a single month than ever before, and the American consumer's appetite was quickly sated, according to publishers and booksellers interviewed this week.

title: Senators See Support For Iraq Resolution
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, predicted that the Senate would soon pass a resolution authorizing President Bush to take military action against Iraq. Other senators of both parties made similar predictions, indicating a consensus that the Senate would approve the resolution by a wide margin.

title: Following Divergent Paths In the Comptroller's Race
description: Their campaigns have so far earned them little attention from the news media. But John J. Faso and Alan G. Hevesi, the two candidates for state comptroller, are pursuing distinctive strategies to get the public to focus on a race that has been overshadowed by the campaign for governor.

title: Accounts
description: * The CIT Group, Livingston, N.J., a commercial and residential lender, to the New York office of the Wolf Group as agency of record. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $10 million. The account had been handled by the New York office of Draft Worldwide, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: The Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYConsumer BorrowingAug.

title: Greeting The Dawn Of the Future With a Shrug
description: The writer and director Abderrahmane Sissako's newest film, the lovely and muted ''Waiting for Happiness,'' takes you by the face, strokes your cheeks and coos beseechingly at you: slow down, shake off your tensions and take this picture at its own breezy, distracted rhythms. Because if you're looking to ''Waiting for Happiness,'' which has its premiere today as part of the New York Film Festival, for an intricately worked-out story with a standard plot overlay, you're going to be caught off guard. Instead, its intricacy comes from the lives of the people in the small village; each of them contributes to the town like the movement of a well-engineered watch, except the irony is that in ''Happiness,'' time doesn't matter.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review of ''Happy Days'' on Wednesday misstated the location of the American premiere of another Samuel Beckett play, ''Waiting for Godot.'' It was in Miami, not on Broadway.

title: American and 2 Britons Win Nobel for Studies on Cell Death
description: An American and two Britons won the 2002 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for their discoveries, made largely in studies of a tiny worm, of how healthy cells are instructed to kill themselves. The process, called programmed cell death or apoptosis, is necessary for the proper tissue and organ development, but also plays a role in many diseases.

title: The Crux Of Reform: Autonomous Stock Rating
description: After the series of embarrassing revelations about conflicts of interest among stock analysts, critics say the time has arrived for Wall Street to do something it is loath to do: consider making some radical changes in the way it conducts its business.

title: As Ads Dwindle, Mutual Funds and Upside Magazines Close
description: Two magazines that celebrated the prosperity of the late 1990's  Mutual Funds and Upside  announced today that they were closing, as the nation's economic boom gave way to a sharp and sustained downturn on Wall Street and in the digital economy.

title: White House Letter; Quietly, the First Lady Builds A Literary Room of Her Own
description: David Levering Lewis, the Pulitzer Prize-winning biographer of W. E. B. Du Bois and an eminent black historian who considers President Bush's policies on Iraq ''a menace,'' was flabbergasted when he received an invitation from Laura Bush's office to be the keynote speaker at a White House symposium on the writers of the Harlem Renaissance.

title: Israeli Raid in Gaza Kills 9 And Hurts 50, Witnesses Say
description: Israeli tanks backed by helicopters raided a neighborhood in the Gaza Strip town of Khan Yunis overnight, killing 9 Palestinians and wounding more than 50 others, according to reports from Palestinian medical officials at the scene.

title: College Football | Wrapup; MONDAY MORNING QUARTERBACK
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Publisher of Fitness Magazines Is for Sale
description: Weider Publications, a niche publisher of fitness and body-building magazines, is for sale, two bankers who expect to be involved in bids said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUMAN, SEYMOUR
description: SCHUMAN-Seymour. On October 5, 2002, at age 86. Born in NYC, attended City College, founder and Chairman of Propper Manufacturing Company, real estate developer in Long Island City and winner of the Tom DeLay Business Leadership Award. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Loving father of Ina (and her husband Daniel Ebenstein), Jane Schuman and Marian Schuman Brennan. Adoring grandfather of David, Julie, Andrew and Stacy Ebenstein, Joseph Schuman, Elizabeth, Alex and Carolyn Schuman Brennan. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65 St, Monday, October 7th, 10 AM. Interment to follow, Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Sharon Tells Cabinet to Keep Quiet on U.S. Plans
description: Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, warned his cabinet ministers today not to talk about American plans for Iraq, urging them to overcome for the good of the possible war effort what often seems a national compulsion to share one's insights as widely as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, JOHN D.
description: FLANAGAN-John D. Born in Washington D.C. on September 21, 1918. Died peacefully at home on October 5, 2002. Attended college at Rutgers University, veteran of WWII 4th Armored Division and retired Chairman of the Board of Authenticolor, Inc. Survived by his wife Kathleen, his children Christopher and Karen and four grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Validating Opus Dei, the Pope Makes Its Founder a Saint
description: Before a hushed crowd of hundreds of thousands in St. Peter's Square, Pope John Paul II today made a saint of the founder of Opus Dei, a deeply conservative Roman Catholic lay group that has grown steadily in influence and stirred considerable controversy over recent years.

title: Madrid Journal; Trying to Quiet Another City That Barely Sleeps
description: With the roar of traffic in the very heart of Madrid it is hard to make out the murmur of voices coming from a group huddled on the pavement, but as the volume increases the babble rises to an incomprehensible if audible peak and then fades into shushing, followed by a staccato chorus: ''Listen. To. Your. Noise. Control. Your. Noise.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the battle for control of the United States Senate misstated the given name of the Democratic candidate in Colorado who is in a dead heat against the Republican incumbent, Wayne Allard. He is Tom Strickland, not Ted.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: H.M.O. Customers Suspect a 23% Profit
description: Many customers of health maintenance organizations say they believe that half of their premiums go toward H.M.O. expenses and profit rather than medical care, according to a poll sponsored by a health insurance provider. The poll, conducted by Zogby International from Sept. 16 to Sept. 21, surveyed 802 BlueCross BlueShield customers in upstate New York. The average respondent said 26.8 percent of premiums was spent on business expenses, 23.7 percent became profit, and only 49.5 percent of premiums was spent on medical care. Excellus Inc., which runs BlueCross upstate and sponsored the poll, said it spent 90 percent of premiums on medical care. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Equity Offerings for Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Lessons From Wars of the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Claus von Amsberg, 76, Popular Dutch Prince
description: Prince Claus von Amsberg, husband of Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands, died tonight in Amsterdam after a long illness. He was 76.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the battle for control of the United States Senate misstated the given name of the Democratic candidate in Colorado who is in a dead heat against the Republican incumbent, Wayne Allard. He is Tom Strickland, not Ted.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Thousands at Central Park Rally Oppose an Iraq War
description: Those old enough to know said that yesterday's Central Park rally to protest a United States invasion of Iraq drew a larger crowd than similar gatherings in the mid-1960's by those who did not want the United States to get further involved in Vietnam.

title: Zimbabwe's Novels of Reckoning; Writers Explore Despair and Violence Under Black Rule
description: Every year after the dry, hungry winters, old women pray for the spring rains to cleanse the earth and revive parched fields. The first rains, known as gukurahundi in the Shona language, are usually hailed as a symbol of life, fertility and prosperity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, LESTER
description: WEISSMAN-Lester. Of Tenafly, NJ, passed away October 6, 2002, at the age of 80. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Vivian, his sisters Blanche (Leif) and Martha of Queens, NY, and his son Robert of Sunnyvale, CA. A graduate of City College of New York, he was a successful businessman and owner of the retail stores Danforth Factory Outlet in Jersey City, NJ, and Danforth Wearhouse in Closter, NJ, until his retirement in 1984. A devoted patron of the arts, he loved the theater and museums of New York, fine literature, and music of all sorts. He was as admired for his wit and humor as for his business acumen. He was greatly loved and will be greatly missed. Private services to be held.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEITZ, JOHN
description: WEITZ-John. The directors, staff and residents of Phoenix House mourn the loss of a great spirit and good friend. A celebrated author, historian, designer and entrepreneur, John Weitz was an early supporter and longtime board member of Phoenix House. Committed to our work, he was a generous and imaginative benefactor, who shared with us his wit, elegance and humor, sense of style, and spirit of adventure. We will miss him. Edward D. Miller, Chairman George A. Kellner, Vice Chairman Mitchell S. Rosenthal, M.D. President

title: Sprewell Situation Hangs Over Knicks
description: The training camp that Don Chaney had such high hopes for ended today, and while Chaney, the Knicks' eternally optimistic coach, would never admit it, the camp was incredibly disappointing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MURRAY
description: FRIEDMAN-Murray. He is best known for his building of a company that was the largest importer of men's fashion footwear in the U.S., and that enabled innumerable families to partake of the fruits of its success. He was ''Murfrini,'' the King. As a salesman he was unstoppable. His charities were legion: The Murray Friedman Foundation of 210 Associates, Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County, Associate Trustee of North Shore University Hospital, Founder of Westhampton Synagogue, Lion of Judah Palm Beach, Cystic Fibrosis, and The Holocaust Museum. He leaves a legacy of unconditional love and respect by all who knew him.

title: War Horse on the Loose, With Exuberance to Spare
description: For his second program as music director of the New York Philharmonic Lorin Maazel put his conductorial stamp on three repertory staples. As with his debut program, he coaxed the orchestra into technically brilliant and eerily controlled performances that lacked breadth and spontaneity.

title: Specter of War Sets Debate In a Tight Race in Minnesota
description: The local television reporter had two questions for Senator Paul Wellstone after his visit Friday morning to Brigham Upholstery, an eight-person company in Duluth, Minn., that makes airplane seat covers.

title: A Tangle of Middle Eastern Hate and Love
description: Elia Suleiman's new film, ''Divine Intervention,'' which will be shown today and tomorrow at the New York Film Festival, is subtitled ''a chronicle of love and pain.'' This is accurate enough; Mr. Suleiman does touch upon a son's grief after his father's death, and on the wordless longing of two lovers. But the description is also a little misleading: those large emotions -- and a smoldering political anger about Palestinian life under Israeli occupation, as well -- are refracted through a series of quick, mordant vignettes, some of which are like cinematic riddles and visual puns, delivered in elegant deadpan.

title: Richelieu, Politician as Connoisseur
description: ''Richelieu: Art and Power,'' an exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts here, is both original and provocative, panoramic and full of surprises. Organized in partnership with the Wallraf-Richartz Museum in Cologne, the exhibition is an overview of French high culture from 1624 to 1642, when Cardinal Richelieu was the most powerful man in France.

title: Law Bars a National System for Tracing Bullets and Shells
description: The technology exists to create a national ballistic fingerprint system that would enable law enforcement officials to trace bullets recovered from shootings, like those fired by the Washington-area sniper, to a suspect.

title: Manchester United Banks on a World Tour
description: Manchester United wants to rule the world.

title: Judging McCall By the Numbers: Scrutinizing A Pension Fund
description: The charge is one of the nastiest anyone can make against a political candidate in upstate New York: he blew a chance to create jobs.

title: Miscellany
description: * Radio Advertising Bureau, New York, reported that ad revenue for radio improved in August, continuing a trend, increasing 5 percent from August 2001, though the rate of growth slowed from July. Local ad revenue rose 4 percent, the bureau reported, and national revenue rose 9 percent. For the first eight months of 2002, according to the bureau, ad revenue increased 3 percent from the same period last year, as local ad revenue rose 2 percent and national ad revenue rose 7 percent.

title: A Hidden Cost of War on Iraq
description: One of the most appealing thoughts about a possible war with Iraq is that it could help spread democracy, transforming a rotten political order in the Middle East. But more likely, such a war would render the Middle East more repressive and unstable than it is today. Democracy cannot be imposed through military force, even if force is used successfully to oust antidemocratic dictators. And our vital aims in fighting terrorism, securing oil supplies and protecting the lives of American soldiers will, in the context of the Middle East, almost certainly ensure that the spread of democracy will again take a back seat to our national priorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, VIVIAN
description: GOLDSMITH - Vivian. A mother, stepmother and grandmother who loved life and children very much. She will be missed and her memory will be cherished by us all. James and Monica, William, Victoria and Lloyd, Grace, Spencer, Regina and Robert

title: Dad's Paris Apartment, Complete With Former Owner
description: O.K., class, here's the set-up: an old woman, her daughter and a strange man in an apartment. Your assignment? Create a plausible circumstance that explains what they are doing there and what keeps anyone from leaving. Invent a back story whose revelations move the characters from general resentment to familial affection.

title: Protesting the Big Brother Lens, Little Brother Turns an Eye Blind
description: Confronted with the unblinking eyes of surveillance cameras, Michael Naimark believes he can hide in plain sight with the aid of a $1 laser pointer.

title: That Left Turn May Cost You, Bub
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, JEROME
description: HABER-Jerome. Of Teaneck, on October 6. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Bayard). Devoted father of Daniel Bayard Haber and Sara Pfeiffer. Loving grandfather of Miriam Schulman, Amy Kotler, Jeffrey Pfeiffer and Dhyna Haber, and greatgrandfather of Talia Schulman, Seth Schulman and Hannah Kotler. Services ''Gutterman - Musicant,'' Hackensack, on Tuesday, October 8, at 10:30 AM. Contributions to American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Detecting Breast Cancer Before It Starts
description: This has been a bad year for proponents of early detection of breast cancer. Not only have we seen debates about the effectiveness of mammography but last week a study published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute found that breast self-examination did not prevent deaths from breast cancer.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Real Sweat and Fire for Make-Believe Games
description: New York City films well -- a face with a million good sides. So what better way to sell the idea of New York City playing host to the 2012 Olympics, the thinking goes, than to make a video pretending it has already happened?

title: Buccaneers' Toughness Trumps Falcons' Tricks
description: The Atlanta Falcons were cruising in this pressured meeting with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers today, one that would help decide which team belongs atop the National Football Conference South. It was a 3-3 game at halftime and each time the Bucs pushed, the Falcons pushed back. Whenever the Bucs' intensity rose, so did the Falcons'.

title: Teens on Trial
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Mets Interview Showalter for Manager's Job
description: Buck Showalter has become the second candidate to interview for the Mets' managerial job, meeting yesterday with team executives at Shea Stadium. Showalter, who took the Yankees and the Diamondbacks to the playoffs, interviewed with the Cubs on Sunday and is probably the prime candidate available.

title: Home Is Where the Harm Is
description: As many as 20,000 Americans died in accidents at home in 1998, a new survey reports, and an additional 7 million were hurt.

title: Upgrading the Way We Vote
description: Congress now seems on the verge, at long last, of passing meaningful legislation to improve the reliability of American elections.

title: Governor and Challenger Clash in First of Four Debates
description: In a debate tonight that often degenerated into acerbic exchanges, Gov. John G. Rowland did his best to portray his Democratic challenger, William E. Curry Jr., as a dilettante unfit to hold high office, while Mr. Curry tried to paint the governor as an ethically challenged insider who has failed Connecticut's families.

title: Art Treasures Shown, but Few Behold Them; At St. John the Divine A 9/11 Gift From Spain
description: The story of how 101 artistic treasures from a Spanish province -- including several masterpieces that have rarely if ever been released from their cloistered convents -- ended up on display at the cavernous Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, seat of New York's Episcopal Diocese, is not the typical story of a New York art exhibition.

title: Jets React Coolly to Robinson's Latest Suggestions
description: After six games last season, with the Jets' defense struggling to stop opposing offenses, free safety Damien Robinson went to the defensive coordinator Ted Cottrell's office and implored him to make changes. Cottrell did, incorporating more blitzes and man-to-man coverage, and the defense ended up carrying the Jets into the playoffs.

title: Bargaining With Russia
description: At last week's meeting of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, the Russian delegation insisted that the terms of reference for arms inspection in Iraq already provide adequate legal basis for access to relevant sites. The Russians believe that negotiation of a new resolution would only delay further the return of the inspectors. They have in private questioned the validity of the Bush administration's assertion that Iraq is stockpiling weapons of mass destruction.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plan For Tighter Asylum Rules
description: The government proposed that asylum claims from the 10 countries expected to join the European Union by 2004 be automatically presumed unfounded because the countries are ''safe.'' The proposal, part of an immigration and asylum bill wending its way through Parliament, is intended to make it harder for asylum seekers to enter and settle in Britain. Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, an advocacy group, said the proposal is ''a fundamental breach to the very core of the United Nations Refugee Convention, as it can never be said that any country is safe for all people at all times.'' The countries are Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia.

title: Senate Race in New Jersey Is On As Courts Reject G.O.P. Appeals
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear a challenge by New Jersey Republicans seeking to prevent former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg from replacing Senator Robert G. Torricelli on the ballot for United States Senate.

title: President Bush's Speech on the Use of Force
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech on Monday night about the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Shuttle Blasts Off for Space Station
description: A four-month hiatus in space shuttle flights ended today when the shuttle Atlantis blasted off into a blue Florida sky on a mission to expand the International Space Station.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNTING, NATALIE AUGUSTA
description: BUNTING-Natalie Augusta. Of Hudson View Gardens, NYC, on October 5, 2002, at Calvary Hospital at the age of 82. Survived by Mary Bunting of Arizona and several nieces an nephews. Mrs. Bunting worked for the National Council of Churches as well as the United Board for Christian Education. Mrs. Bunting was a graduate of Hunter College. She was a lifelong patron of the arts. Donations in her memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461, or the American Cancer Socity, or any hospice of your choice. Memorial services wil be held at a later date. Mrs. Bunting will be missed by her family and many of her dear friends.

title: McGreevey Could Fire Poet Under Proposed Legislation
description: A bipartisan group of legislators said today that they would introduce measures that would give Gov. James E. McGreevey the power to strip Amiri Baraka of his position as New Jersey's poet laureate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, GOLDIE (HELLER)
description: GREENBERG-Goldie (Heller). Of Nashua, NH, formerly of New York City, on Sunday, October 6, 2002. She was an Advertising Vice-President and was one of the first Art Directors to help Andy Warhol get started. Beloved wife of the late Edward W. Greenberg. Devoted sister of Eileen Heller of Salem, MA., June Rogoff of Nashua, N.H., Inez Dolin of Hartford, CT., and the late Arnold Heller. Loving aunt of Barry Rogoff, Scott Dolin, Cheryl Dolin, Elizabeth Heller, Julie Heller, John Heller and Paul Heller. Dear friend of Bonnie Villers. Graveside Services at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA, on Wednesday, October 9 at 1:45 PM. Memorial observance will be private. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the charity of your choice. For further information Levine Chapels, Brookline, MA.

title: Praise Must Be Earned
description: To the Editor:

title: Shining a Light on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Time-Tested Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I've Become My Mother'
description: ''The Common Thread: Mothers, Daughters and the Power of Empathy,'' by Dr. Martha Manning, William Morrow/HarperCollins, $39.50.

title: 2 Companies Seek to Delay Merger Ruling
description: Scrambling to save their proposed merger from rejection by regulators, EchoStar Communications and Hughes Electronics urged the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to delay a decision on the $26 billion deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, COL. LEO L.
description: HOFFMAN-Col. Leo L. In his 96th year, on October 6, 2002. Adored husband and extraordinary partner to his wife Grace. Loyal and loving to all who knew him. He was a valiant soldier, a brilliant lawyer and a faithful friend. Private services were held.

title: Environmentalists Identify New Menace: Discarded Cellphones
description: As the nation's fondness for cellphones grows, the environmental effects do, too.

title: Texas Republican to Join UBS After He Retires From Senate
description: Senator Phil Gramm, an author of legislation that helped to create financial conglomerates like Citigroup, said yesterday that he would become a vice chairman of the UBS Warburg investment bank after retiring from the Senate.

title: Attack Is Mounted On Campaign Rules
description: Sponsors of the new federal campaign-finance law plan to announce a two-pronged strategy on Tuesday to overturn rules written by the Federal Election Commission. The rules, the sponsors say, would seriously undermine provisions intended to eliminate the role in federal elections of unrestricted donations of soft money by unions, corporations and individuals.

title: Nature All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Civil Rights Groups Say Voter Bill Erects Hurdles Before Ballot Box
description: Just days after House and Senate negotiators agreed on a bill to revamp the nation's election procedures, civil rights groups said today that they had grave concerns about the measure because they believed that major provisions would make it harder to register and to vote.

title: Firefighters Heed City's Plea to Move Rally
description: After Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a personal appeal to the new president of the union representing New York City firefighters, the union agreed yesterday to find somewhere other than Times Square to hold a large rally for better pay.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Joseph LeDoux; Taking a Clinical Look at Human Emotions
description: On a recent balmy evening, Dr. Joseph LeDoux, a professor of neuroscience at New York University, strode to the stage of the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village and read from his latest book, ''The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are.''

title: Wrigley wants you to forget your parents' chewing gum.
description: REMEMBER the Doublemint twins? Remember jingles like ''Hi, ho, hey, hey, chew your little troubles away''? The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company is working hard to make you forget them faster than your chewing gum loses its flavor on the bedpost.

title: Noise and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: AIRLINE ORDERS JETS Taiwan's largest carrier, China Airlines, said it would buy jets from the Boeing Company and Airbus of Europe in a $4 billion decision that appeared to strike a balance between politics and business. Roger Han, a spokesman for China Airlines, said the company would sign deals to buy 10 Boeing 747-400's and 12 Airbus A330-300's before the end of the month after details are worked out. "We have been evaluating for some time now; we think this would benefit China Airlines the most," Mr. Han said, ending months of speculation about the multibillion-dollar jet order. (Reuters)

title: U.S. Joins Investigation of Washington-Area Sniper
description: The federal government has officially joined the investigation into the attacks linked to a roving sniper who has killed six people and wounded two others, including a 13-year-old student, in the Washington suburban area.

title: This Killer Doesn't Fit The Expected Profile
description: Experts in mass murder and the profiling of killers say the sniper who has killed six people in the Washington metropolitan area does not fit the usual categories, and that may make the case much harder to solve.

title: Additional Support For Change At Augusta
description: Lloyd Ward, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee and one of the few African-American members of the Augusta National Golf Club, said yesterday that he would ''work aggressively'' to include women as members.

title: Judiciary's Right to Punish Judges Is Affirmed
description: The Supreme Court today turned back a constitutional challenge to the law that authorizes the federal judiciary to discipline its own misbehaving members short of removal from the bench.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Technology Briefing column of Business Day on Wednesday about the purchase of PentaSafe Security Technologies by the NetIQ Corporation, a software maker, misstated the amount of revenue that NetIQ expects to add next year because of the deal. It is $25 million, not $125 million.

title: Former F.B.I. Director Rejects Criticism on 9/11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  The former F.B.I. chief, Louis J. Freeh, who has been blamed in Congress for failing to grasp the rising threat of terrorism in the 1990's, told a congressional panel today that he struggled throughout his tenure at the F.B.I. to make terrorism a higher priority.

title: Teenagers' Binge Leads Scarsdale to Painful Self-Reflection
description: These are soul-searching days in this Westchester County village, where teenage drinking has long been a fixture, as in other affluent suburbs. Last month's homecoming bacchanal here, which left scores of students falling-down drunk, 27 with three-day school suspensions and five hospitalized with acute alcohol poisoning, has Scarsdale shamefaced and reeling.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Russian Hacker Gets 3-Year Sentence
description: A Russian hacker who was arrested based on evidence gained by F.B.I. agents who hacked into his own computer late last week has received a three-year prison sentence and nearly $700,000 in fines. Computer intrusions by the defendant, Vasily Gorshkov, were uncovered after the Federal Bureau of Investigation lured him to the United States with a fake company called Invita, which offered Mr. Gorshkov a job interview in Seattle. The agents then recorded his keystrokes as Mr. Gorshkov logged into his computer in Russia and used the passwords to break in themselves and build a case. Russian authorities expressed anger over the incident and issued an indictment against the F.B.I. agent who performed the trans-Atlantic intrusion. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: From Japan, a Guitar That Keeps Chaos Under Control
description: Melt-Banana, an art-punk band from Tokyo that has been around for nearly 10 years, makes fast, controlled chaos. Hard-core punk is the group's high-performance engine, but the total vehicle is super-detailed -- shiny, attractive, bizarre.

title: Court to Rule on Dutch Nurse Accused in 13 Deaths
description: In her diaries, Lucy de Berk freely jotted down her feelings about her life as a hospital nurse and, at times, as a prostitute for an escort service.

title: Former F.B.I. Director Rejects Criticism on 9/11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The former F.B.I. chief, Louis J. Freeh, who has been blamed in Congress for failing to grasp the rising threat of terrorism in the 1990's, told a congressional panel today that he struggled throughout his tenure at the F.B.I. to make terrorism a higher priority.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARTEN, JULIA
description: KARTEN-Julia. The Officers and Board of the American Society for Yad Vashem mourn the passing of Julia Karten. Julia, with her late husband Isidore Karten, Vice Chairman of the American Society, survived as partisans and became leaders in Holocaust Remembrance. They were Benefactors twice at Yad Vashem, of the Valley of the Communities, and the Partisans Panorama. Condolences to their children, Berne and James Bookhamer, Marcia and Ya'akov Toledano and Harry and Danielle Karten, and grandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Eli Zborowski, Chairman Joseph Wilf, Sam Skura Vice Chairmen American Society for Yad Vashem

title: In Olive Groves of the West Bank, a Harvest of Fear
description: Fear kept the olive pickers off the terraced hillsides today in this village set among the groves and stony hills of the northern West Bank.

title: Subway Stair Workout
description: To the Editor:

title: Test of a Hostile Workplace, Even Beyond the Body Slams
description: The lawyer for a former wrestler asked the jurors in her sexual harassment case yesterday to separate the scripted antics in professional wrestling from what she said was the real-life outrageous conduct of some very large men.

title: Graffiti's Life After Death; Bronx's Grim Reapers of Paint Now Work for MTV
description: It is hard to complain about losing money when you make your money painting death.

title: World Jitters Darken Mood at Spring Shows
description: Throughout this somewhat lackluster fashion season, the overall mood has had the fevered aspect of a jittery bunch of troupers doggedly going through the motions. The show must go on, people seemed to be saying, or else.

title: Four Executives Open An Agency in Denver
description: Four longtime agency executives have opened their own shop in Denver, Thomas Taber & Drazen.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Less Hawkish On Georgia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin significantly softened his tone toward Georgia yesterday, a day after he and President Eduard A. Shevardnadze met in Moldova and agreed to conduct joint patrols along Georgia's border with the breakaway Russian republic of Chechnya. Mr. Putin said it would not be necessary to carry out his threat to mount military strikes against Chechen fighters in Georgia if Mr. Shevardnadze's government carried out the agreement. It remains to be seen whether their meeting will ease tensions. Only hours after they met, Georgian officials said, Russian helicopters once again crossed into Georgian airspace without permission. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Letters
description: Praise Must Be Earned

title: Transcript: Confronting Iraq Threat 'Is Crucial to Winning War on Terror'
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech last night about the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Ulster Leader Urges Blair to Oust Sinn Fein From Parliament
description: LONDON, Oct. 8 -- David Trimble, the first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, called on Prime Minister Tony Blair today to evict Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army, from the power-sharing government in Belfast that he heads.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: American Advertising Federation, Washington, named seven people to join its Advertising Hall of Achievement, honoring executives 40 and younger. The 2002 inductees are: Alex Bogusky, partner and creative director at Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami; Jeannine Shao Collins, vice president and group publisher at The Ladies' Home Journal and More magazines, New York, published by the Meredith Corporation; Linda De Jesus, president at the Bravo Group, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group; Scott Donaton, editor, Advertising Age, New York, published by Crain Communications; Earl G. Graves Jr., president and chief operating officer, Black Enterprise magazine, New York, published by Earl G. Graves Ltd.; Richard Stoddart, marketing communications manager at the Ford Motor Company, Dearborn, Mich.; and William Wrigley Jr., president and chief executive at the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, Chicago. The seven executives will be honored at a luncheon on Nov. 19 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York. Mr. Graves will also be presented with the 2002 Jack Avrett Volunteer Spirit Award.

title: McCall Calls for Disclosures On Units Holding Mentally Ill
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, called on Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday to make public documents related to his administration's policy of releasing hundreds of patients from state psychiatric hospitals to locked units in nursing homes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Military Contract
description: A Russian military contractor is set to sign a $4 billion contract with the United Arab Emirates for development and delivery of an air defense system, according to a report in the Russian daily Kommersant. The company, Almaz, which refused to confirm or deny the report, is expected to sign the contract for the system in 2003. The United Arab Emirates is an infrequent but not completely new client: it purchased rocket launchers and infantry vehicles from Russian producers in 2000 and in the mid-1990's. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALISH, POLA
description: KALISH-Pola. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Pola Kalish. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, WILLIAM
description: WILSON-William. The Bard College community deeply mourns the passing of William Wilson '48, a beloved teacher of literature and the humanities for four decades at Bard. He was a dear friend of the college and, above all, an inspiring teacher and advisor. Generations of Bard students are indebted to his guidance and to his enthusiasm and sharp insight. As a colleague, friend, neighbor and alumnus, his life and work were deeply woven into the fabric of the college. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his entire family. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman

title: Prime Time Gets Real With a Plump Heroine
description: When a friend warns Claudia, a plump office assistant, that her cutthroat newsroom colleagues would feed her ''to the wolves,'' Claudia retorts: ''Do you think that will make me thinner? Because I'll try anything -- except diet and exercise.''

title: Our Moral Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Angels vs. Twins
description: Having validated their 99-victory season by mugging the Yankees in a stunning four-game division series, the Angels are closer to the World Series than they have been since Donnie Moore had two outs and two strikes on Dave Henderson in the ninth inning of Game 5 of the 1986 American League Championship Series.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Scansoft To Buy Royal Philips Business
description: ScanSoft, a maker of document- and photo-scanning software, yesterday agreed to buy the speech-recognition unit of Royal Philips Electronics for $35.4 million to add customers like General Motors. The purchase price consists of $3 million in cash, $4.9 million in a 5 percent note due at the end of next year and $27.5 million in a three-year note convertible into ScanSoft shares at $6 each, the company said in a statement. ScanSoft, whose software converts paper documents and photos into digital documents and images, has been adding programs that can translate the spoken word.

title: Bush Moves Toward Halting Port Shutdown
description: President Bush took the first step yesterday toward seeking an injunction that would end the shutdown of 29 West Coast ports, acting just hours after negotiations between port operators and the longshoremen's union had broken off.

title: Nancy S. Nichols, 57, Executive Recruiter for Cultural Elite
description: Nancy Stephenson Nichols, an executive recruiter who helped stellar educational and cultural institutions find stellar executives to lead them, died last Wednesday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. She was 57 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Clinton Corners, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: A Dim Outlook For Electronics
description: A leading Japanese electronics maker, the Toshiba Corporation, said demand for its products might slow in the first half of 2003. While Toshiba's sales of notebook personal computers and chips used in televisions and DVD players will rise until Christmas, the outlook for demand in the first half of 2003 is unclear, the chief executive, Tadashi Okamura, said while attending the World Economic Forum's East Asia meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. ''I expect 2003 will be better than 2002, but the first half of 2003 is very difficult,'' Mr. Okamura said.

title: Paths for America, Other Than War
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitters Had Edge in Division Series
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 7  The Yankees, with baseball's deepest starting rotations, became regulars in the World Series, winning four of the last six. The Arizona Diamondbacks, riding the arms of Curt Schilling and Randy Johnson, knocked off the Yankees last fall. And the Atlanta Braves, the most consistent winners in the National League, with pitchers like Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and John Smoltz, captured 11 straight division titles.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA GAINS. Cocoa prices surged to 16-year highs on concern that fighting in the Ivory Coast would disrupt the supply of beans. In New York, cocoa for December delivery rose $26, or 1.2 percent, to $2,250 a metric ton.

title: Ex-Official Of WorldCom Pleads Guilty To Fraud
description: WorldCom's former director of general accounting pleaded guilty yesterday to securities fraud, saying that he inflated earnings, following orders that originated ''at the highest levels'' of the company.

title: Pechiney to Cut 202 Jobs
