description: The aluminum maker Pechiney announced today that it would cut 202 jobs at its unprofitable Ravenswood plant in West Virginia by the end of the year at a cost of about $9 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Aid to Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Returnees to Lower Manhattan Will Be Exempt From Tax on Aid
description: The Internal Revenue Service plans to exempt Lower Manhattan residents from most if not all taxes on government money given to them to stay in or move to the area, the office of Senator Charles E. Schumer said last night.

title: Views From the Other Side of the Bar
description: Usually it's the customers who bend the bartender's ear, but at the Phil Bosakowski Theater, upstairs at 354 West 45th Street, it's the bartenders who are doing the bending -- and all the drinking.

title: S.E.C. Appears Split on Board To Oversee Accountants
description: Scrambling to stamp out a political firestorm, Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, abruptly postponed a scheduled trip to Europe today to search for candidates to fill the new board that will oversee the accounting profession.

title: Smoking Banned in Nassau Bars and Restaurants
description: Nassau County tonight became the first county in New York to extend its ban on smoking in the workplace to cover all bars, restaurants, bowling alleys and bingo halls.

title: Where Biking Blossomed, Now the Wheels Come Off
description: In this, the land where the automobile is king, at the busiest human crossroads in the world, the lowly bicycle had a brief moment of glory. For a time, two wheels were faster than four.

title: Banged Up and Bruised, Giants Don't Look as if They Won
description: The protective boot housing Jeremy Shockey's left foot pulled at his stride like a ball and chain as he walked out of the visitors' locker room at Texas Stadium after the Dallas game Sunday. He stared at the ground as he moved, beneath a cap turned backward; Shockey wanted to be dragging defenders in his rookie season, not his leg.

title: Oil Markets Aren't Rattled by Explosion on Tanker
description: World oil markets, already reflecting jitters about a possible showdown in the Middle East, shrugged off an as yet unexplained explosion Sunday on a French tanker near the coast of Yemen.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Blair Tries To Save Ulster Accord
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair urged Northern Ireland's Protestant politicians to resist appeals from hard-liners that they withdraw from the power-sharing government because of raids and arrests that turned up information indicating that the Irish Republican Army might have been running spy operations out of the legislative offices of its political wing, Sinn Fein. ''The prime minister is completely seized of the gravity of the current situation,'' a spokesman said. He said Mr. Blair had scheduled emergency meetings with the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams; Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland; and the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble. In what is seen as the gravest crisis since the Northern Ireland peace accord of 1998, Protestant politicians are threatening to bring down the government unless Mr. Blair evicts Sinn Fein from it.

title: Bonds Powers the Giants Past History and the Braves
description: Barry Bonds and the San Francisco Giants have spent much of their postseason history mired in failure. For all of his home run and offensive records, he had never been on a winning team in the postseason.

title: 3 Win Nobel for Work on Suicidal Cells
description: An American and two Britons won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for their discoveries of how healthy cells are instructed to kill themselves.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Charged With Desecrating Human Remains
description: A father and son were arrested yesterday and charged with desecrating human remains and receiving them as stolen property, the police said. Remains of dogs, cats, birds and chickens were also found in the basement and backyard of the Central Avenue home where the two men, Eddie Figueroa Sr., 56, and Eddie Figueroa Jr., 35, were arrested, said Detective Todd McClendon. The police said the remains might have been used in the practice of the Afro-Caribbean religion Santera. The arrests came after a yearlong investigation of thefts from graveyards, the detective said. The police said the human remains are being studied to determine whose they are. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Telescopes Find a Miniplanet At the Solar System's Edge
description: Looking beyond the known planets of the Sun, out among an orbiting multitude of small icy bodies, astronomers have seen and measured a miniplanet, more than half the size of Pluto, that is the largest object in the solar system to be detected since the discovery of Pluto in 1930.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, MARTHA (NEE HURLEY)
description: MORAN-Martha (nee Hurley). On October 6, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Kevin Peter. Devoted mother of Nicholas Martin. Sister of the late Eleanor Michael. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20 St), N.Y.C. Thursday, 79PM. Funeral Mass Friday, 11AM at Epiphany R.C. Church. Funeral services will conclude at the Church. Interment private.

title: Missile Crisis Cited to Make Opposite Points
description: President Bush and one of his leading Democratic critics, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, both invoked the memory of 1962 Cuban missile crisis tonight to drive home sharply divergent views of how to handle Iraq.

title: Sports of The Times; Sprewell Wearing Out His Welcome
description: AS it is written, the Knicks have reaped what they sowed. Apparently, Latrell Sprewell violated his contract, which demands that he let the team know immediately if he gets injured, and was unfit to attend training camp last week. Yes, the Knicks fined him and told him that they don't want to lay eyes on him again until he behaves like a responsible adult. But he's been violating his contract one way or the other in numerous instances since he joined the Knicks in 1999.

title: Big Investors Push for Disclosure Of How Venture Firms Are Faring
description: Stung by accounting scandals, institutional investors in several states are pushing for greater transparency and disclosure not just from public companies, but from private equity and venture capital firms, which have long operated outside the public eye.

title: Jealous? Maybe It's Genetic. Maybe Not.
description: Jealousy, according to evolutionary psychologists, evolved a million or so years ago on the African plain, where life was no picnic.

title: An Iraqi Man of Letters
description: Iraq's best-selling novelist is also a poet who enjoys strumming the lute and is passionate about Hemingway. He is a patron of the arts, with a fine appreciation for modern painting, sculpture and architecture.

title: Sniper at Large
description: The recent shootings in the Washington area, including an attack on a high school student yesterday that the police say is linked to them, has left the region nearly numb with fear. To be out and about feels like an unwarranted risk, as though the most innocuous places were also the most dangerous. Virtually the only thing certain about the killer so far is the caliber of his rifle, the skill with which he uses it and the fact that he seems to have found a way to shoot and then vanish in plain sight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, RAYMOND L.
description: COHEN-Raymond L. October 8, 1946-May 10, 2001. Remembered and loved every day

title: Black Panthers, Gone Gray, Fight Rival Group
description: His hair has gone gray and he suffered a heart attack last year. He worries about ordinary things like his daughter's college tuition. At 65, he takes to the stairs with a slight hesitation. But Bobby Seale, a founder of the Black Panther Party and an icon of the 1960's, has a voice that still thunders with the might of a gun-wielding revolutionary.

title: Paths for America, Other Than War
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: Court Upholds Bilingual Ban
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld the constitutionality of a statewide voter initiative that replaced bilingual education in public schools with an English immersion program. Voters approved the initiative, known as Proposition 227, by a wide margin in 1998, but opponents claimed it was discriminatory, particularly against the state's large number of Spanish speakers. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit concluded there was ''an undeniable racial dimension'' to the initiative, but ruled ''the reallocation of political authority at issue in Proposition 227 operated solely to address an educational issue, not a racial one.'' Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Scandals and Squabbles Weigh Down Britain's Sinking Tories
description: Britain's Conservative party opened its annual conference in this English Channel resort today against a backdrop of plummeting poll ratings, fresh news of a sex scandal and speculation over efforts to oust its leader, Iain Duncan Smith.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Friday about ''Pipe Dream,'' directed by John C. Walsh, misstated its rating. It is R (under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), not PG.

title: A Mistitled List
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Debate on Senate Floor on Use of Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania; Max Cleland, Democrat of Georgia; Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, and Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska.

title: House, 2-0, Passes Bill to Review Federal Agencies' Privacy Rules
description: Without dissent, the House passed legislation today to require federal agencies to review the effects on personal privacy of any new regulations that they propose and to let individuals go to court to attack those reviews as inadequate.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: EXCHANGE CHAIRMAN TO LEAVE The chairman of the London Stock Exchange said he would step down from that post when his three-year term expires in July. "I have informed the board that I do not wish my name to go forward for another three years," Don Cruickshank, the chairman, said, explaining that he would give up his job at the exchange's annual general meeting scheduled for July. A date for the meeting has not yet been set. Mr. Cruickshank, who presided over the exchange's failed attempt to merge with the Deutsche Borse, said it was time for him to pursue "new challenges."

title: Corrections
description: A fashion review yesterday about the spring collections in Paris referred incorrectly to Beatrix Miller, a former editor of British Vogue, who was said to avoid hiring anyone who had not read ''The Wilder Shores of Love,'' a tetralogy by Lesley Blanch that could have well inspired the unfettered emotion in these collections. Ms. Miller is still living.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Archbishop Apologizes
description: The Archbishop of Dublin, Cardinal Desmond Connell, apologized to people who were sexually abused as children by Roman Catholic Church officials and said he would cooperate with the government's investigation. ''I want to apologize again from my heart for the terrible betrayal they have suffered,'' he wrote in a letter read at Masses in Dublin on Sunday. ''In the past, we have not always responded as quickly or as appropriately as we should.'' Some analysts interpreted the letter as a response in advance of a scheduled television program about the church's handling of abuse accusations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Fool Me Once
description: Quite a few people rubbed their eyes back in July when accounting reform legislation sponsored by Senator Paul Sarbanes became law, not as the Sarbanes Act but as the Sarbanes-Oxley Act. It was, if you knew anything about Michael Oxley's legislative career, as if Prohibition-era Chicago had passed a Ness-Capone clean government ordinance.

title: The Joys of the Drug Trade, With a Staccato Beat
description: How did Pharrell Williams become one of the most influential figures in popular music? He's known for his mesh and foam baseball caps, his out-of-tune singing and his three-note synthesizer lines.

title: AOL Latin America To Convert Stock
description: AOL Latin America said today that its two largest shareholders would convert their preferred shares into common stock as the Internet service struggles to keep enough equity in the open market.

title: Miscellany
description: The golfer Tiger Woods agreed to endorse watches made by TAG Heuer, part of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, beginning in January, after five years of serving as an endorser for the Rolex Watch Company. Terms of the multiyear deal for Mr. Woods were not disclosed.

title: Stern Tones, Direct Appeal
description: In stern but subdued tones, President Bush declared tonight that war with Iraq was neither desirable nor inevitable. Yet he left no doubt that if Saddam Hussein did not disarm, the United States would strike against him.

title: Chinese Court Voids Death Sentences on 5 Christian Leaders
description: BEIJING, Oct. 8 -- In a rare reversal for a politically sensitive case, a Chinese appeals court has overturned the death sentences given last December to five leaders of a defiant evangelical Christian group, court officials in Hubei Province said today.

title: Knicks Fine Sprewell $250,000 and Say Stay Away
description: Latrell Sprewell and the Knicks, who together reaped the benefits of Sprewell's resurrected basketball career in New York, are now at odds in what threatens to be a rancorous showdown. A week after Sprewell arrived for training camp with a broken hand, the Knicks said today that they had fined him $250,000 for not reporting the injury in a timely manner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTSCHMIT, MARVIN
description: GUTSCHMIT - Marvin. Of Spring Lake, New Jersey, died Saturday, October 5, at home. He was 76 years old. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he grew up in New Brunswick, NJ. He was a Navy Veteran serving in the South Pacific in WWII. Mr. Gutschmit lived in Elmsford, NY, and New York City before retiring to his home in Spring Lake. He was founder of Marcrest Knitting Mills of New York and President of the company until his retirement. An avid fisherman he also founded the Runaway Marine Corporation in Point Pleasant, NJ, where he designed and built the sport fishing boats of that name. He will be deeply mourned by his mother Lillian, his wife Paula, daughter Lisa Martin and her husband John of Spring Lake, daughter Lauren Goodsmith of Baltimore, MD, son David and his wife Mimi of Tokyo, Japan, and his beloved grandchildren Brianna and Nathaniel Martin and Nicholas and Rachel Gutschmit. He was predeceased by his brother Alan of Troy, NC. A celebration of his life will be announced at a future date. Contributions in his name may be made to the Salvation Army, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Text: Congressional Debates on Use of Force in Iraq
description: Following are extended excerpts from the Senate debate on Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Lackawanna Journal; Waiting Uneasily on Bail Ruling in Al Qaeda Case
description: The vividly painted storefront of the Arabian Foods deli that was a magnet for news photographers has been painted over. Worshipers at the mosque mostly come and go without being stalked by reporters. And the local Yemeni-American soccer team practices as if nothing ever happened.

title: New Official Tells Japan's Banks to Prepare for Pain
description: Japan's newly appointed chief financial regulator, Heizo Takenaka, threw a scare into the teetering banking industry today by saying in interviews published over the weekend that no bank or borrower was too big to be allowed to fail, and that cleaning up the mountain of nonperforming loans would inevitably increase unemployment and bankruptcies.

title: Bush Sees 'Urgent Duty' to Pre-empt Attack by Iraq
description: President Bush declared tonight that Saddam Hussein could attack the United States or its allies ''on any given day'' with chemical or biological weapons. In a forceful argument for disarming Iraq or going to war with that country, he argued that ''we have an urgent duty to prevent the worst from occurring.''

title: Unexpected Outcomes Creating More Interest
description: Years ago, when revenue sharing was only a dream of the poorer teams, one of them being Calvin Griffith's Minnesota Twins, George Steinbrenner had a favorite line when anyone asked him about the topic.

title: Candidates for California Governor Debate, at Least Once
description: Gov. Gray Davis and his Republican challenger, Bill Simon Jr., accused each other today of being out of touch and ethically challenged in the first and probably last formal debate of the California governor's race.

title: Fired Executive Sues Ovitz
description: Michael Ovitz has been sued by a former executive who contends she was dismissed after telling auditors at Vivendi Universal that the movie unit of Mr. Ovitz's Artists Management Group was misusing money from a joint venture.

title: Tunnel Vision; Left Outside Looking In: Lateness Becomes Art
description: If it is true that great art is born of great suffering, what happens when there is only a little suffering?

title: Delicate Moral Questions Under the Nazis in France
description: Bertrand Tavernier is not often thought of as a man of passion. Even ''Round Midnight,'' his 1986 film on an alienated bop musician, seemed remote and grim textured. His enthusiasms are evident from the subjects he chooses rather than their substance; with the exception of the artful and laconic ''A Sunday in the Country,'' they serve mainly as a backdrop. But in ''Safe Conduct,'' this French filmmaker's newest work, which will be shown today and Thursday at the New York Film Festival, the heat of the moment prevails. It cooks ''Conduct'' in a low, smoky and inviting sizzle.

title: DEVELOPMENT COMPANY BUYS RIVAL JDN REALTY FOR STOCK
description: The Developers Diversified Realty Corporation has agreed to buy a rival shopping-center developer, the JDN Realty Corporation, for $436 million in stock to expand into the Southeast. Developers will pay 0.518 share for each share of JDN, which values JDN at $10.95 a share. Developers will also assume $584 million of debt and pay $50 million of preferred stock, said Michelle Mahue, a spokeswoman for Developers, which is based in Beachwood, Ohio. The acquisition will permit Developers to expand by 24 percent and own or manage 77 million square feet of shopping centers in 44 states. JDN is based in Atlanta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUCHAN, MIRIAM
description: SLUCHAN-Miriam, 83. Well known in the labor field as secretary to two presidents of the ILGWU. Survived by sister Lillian, brother Stanley, nieces and nephews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. The Members of the Board of Directors of the Belgian American Educational Foundation mourn the loss of their colleague and friend, deceased in New York City. Edward Tuck served as Director of B.A.E.F. for 46 years. His strong support and wise counsel will be sorely missed. The Board extends its sincere condolences to his wife and family. Belgian American Educational Foundation.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cab Riders' Complaints Drop By A Third
description: Complaints against New York City taxi drivers have dropped by nearly a third from their peak two years ago, the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission said yesterday. The peak year for complaints against medallion drivers was the year that ended in June 2000, when complaints totaled 14,129. For the most recent reporting year, which ended in June, there were 10,183, complaints. Commissioner Matthew W. Daus said complaints about rudeness, refusal of service and overcharges had all fallen, even though ridership rose. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSMITH, VIVIAN
description: GOLDSMITH-Vivian, 66. Of Englewood, New Jersey, on October 5, 2002. Beloved wife of Stuart. Devoted mother of Gary & Rick Binstein, Robyn Zeller and Elizabeth McGee. Dear stepmother of Victoria Goldman, Jim and Bill Goldsmith. Loving grandmother of twelve grandchildren. Services were held at ''Gutterman-Musicant,'' Hackensack. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, C/O Dr. Daniel Coit.

title: Mideast Destinies
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Plains: North Dakota: More Drug Raids
description: The number of methamphetamine laboratories raided so far this year is more than double the number for last year, the state's Bureau of Criminal Investigation said. There have been 192 such raids this year, up from 89 in 2001, 46 in 2000 and 17 in 1999, the bureau said. The state attorney general has attributed the jump to the increased prevalence of the drug, more public awareness about the laboratories, and growing efforts by drug task force agents and local law enforcement agencies.

title: Canada Economy Grows Where Others Falter
description: It only takes one look at this city's fast-changing skyline to see that Canada is defying the slowdown throttling much of the world economy.

title: Boston Panel Urges Listing Abuser Priests
description: A commission appointed by Cardinal Bernard F. Law to help prevent sexual abuse by priests recommended today that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston compile a registry of accused priests and pass information about them to employers.

title: INSIDE
description: A Nobel for Cell Research

title: Together, In Loving And Dying
description: For 15 years, my father and stepmother enjoyed their life together immensely. They traveled to Europe and gambled in Atlantic City. They drank and bickered and smoked together and doted together on their two grandchildren, whom they adored.

title: Healthy, Tasty Alternatives
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Envoy Angers North Korea
description: In a heated reaction to its first substantive discussions with the Bush administration, North Korea said today that Washington had approached the talks with a ''hard-line policy of hostility.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHLER, SYLVIA
description: EICHLER-Sylvia. On October 3. Beloved wife of Samson. Dear mother of Barry and Linda of Wynnewood, PA., and Joel and Lois of Chestnut Hill Mass. Adored grandmother of Estie Abadie, Rachel Maron, Sara Eichler, Ra'anan, Jeremy, and Gabriel. Cherished great grandmother. Dear sister of Jack Finkelstein, Deborah Werner, Bernard Finkelstein, and Marcy Feinman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARSON, MARY ESTHER (NEE SMALLEY)
description: PEARSON - Mary Esther (nee Smalley). Of West Cornwall, CT, and formerly of North Massapequa, NY, age 84. Lived a wonderful life and died peacefully on October 5, 2002. Cherished wife for 57 years of George E. Pearson. Loving mother of George Jr., Donald, Ann, John (deceased) and Mary. Beloved sister of Arthur Smalley (deceased), John Smalley, Ruth Smalley and Joan Walsh. Devoted grandmother of Joe and Laura. You will always be in our hearts. Visiting Tuesday, October 8, 2002, at Knowles Funeral Home, Port Washington. Funeral Mass on Wednesday, October 9, 2002, at St. Peter of Alcantara Church, Port Washington.

title: Richard T. Foster, Architect, Is Dead at 83
description: Richard T. Foster, an architect who collaborated with Philip Johnson in reshaping the New York University campus in the 1970's, died on Sept. 13 in Danbury, Conn. He was 83 and lived in Wilton, Conn., in a revolving house of his own design.

title: Coca-Cola to Start Harry Potter Promotion
description: The Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta will begin the second round of an advertising and promotional campaign tied to the Harry Potter films being released by Warner Brothers.

title: Sharon Calls Gaza Strike a Success; Says More Will Follow
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today praised an Israeli raid on Monday into the Gaza Strip that left 15 Palestinians dead and dozens wounded, expressing regret for civilian lives lost but brushing aside international criticism as he promised more such attacks.

title: Marine Killed as Unit Is Attacked During Training in Kuwait
description: U.S. Marines came under small arms fire Tuesday during war games in Kuwait. One Marine was killed and a second was wounded. The two attackers were wounded and captured by U.S. forces.

title: Women Can Fight an Almost Secret Syndrome
description: It may seem hard to believe that a disorder first identified nearly 70 years ago that affects as many as 10 percent of women would still be unrecognized by many doctors and in most of those who have it.

title: Ulster Leader Urges Blair to Oust Sinn Fein From Parliament
description: LONDON, Oct. 8  David Trimble, the first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, called on Prime Minister Tony Blair today to evict Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army, from the power-sharing government in Belfast that he heads.

title: After 2 Visits, Taking On Japan at War
description: Martin Cruz Smith, the best-selling author known for works like ''Gorky Park,'' detective thrillers that use Russia for a backdrop, set a huge challenge for himself with his newest novel and first book on Japan, ''December 6.''

title: Sharks Are Hungry for More
description: The National Hockey League begins its 2002-3 season tonight with protective netting at both ends of the ice and a commitment to quicker games with more offense. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish.

title: VITAL SIGNS: Rx MONEY; When People Sell Their Kidneys
description: Some advocates of loosening laws against selling kidneys for transplants describe such agreements as winning arrangements. Some people improve their economic standings with few risks to their health. The others receive organs that can mean the difference between life and death.

title: Diving and Surfacing
description: Q. If a submarine has to release air in order to sink, how does it get it back in order to ascend?

title: Shining a Light on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: French labels challenge Italian invasion : Paris's boutiques battle
description: PARIS  While Italian brands continue their invasion of Paris, with Gucci and Dolce & Gabbana recently opening luxury boutiques, the French are mounting a counterattack for the destination shopper.

title: Opposition could benefit from scandal over 2000 summit : Payoffs to North suspected in Seoul
description: SEOUL:  Allegations of payoffs by President Kim Dae Jung's government in exchange for acquiescence by the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, to host him at their summit meeting in June 2000, threaten to explode into an investigation that could influence the December presidential election.

title: Just Missing Victory, Brazil Leftist Faces Runoff in 3 Weeks
description: After narrowly missing outright victory in presidential elections on Sunday, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the leftist Workers Party predicted today that he would triumph in the Oct. 27 runoff against Jos Serra, the government's candidate.

title: 3 Networks Skip Bush's Talk, Citing Absence of Request
description: Three major broadcast networks ABC, CBS and NBC -- chose not to carry the president's speech live tonight, despite much advance news coverage and the growing sense that the nation may soon be at war.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Turns Game 5 Into Sleepy Showdown
description: AT its best, sports is a survival of the fittest. But in last night's decisive Game 5 in their division series, the Giants advanced to the National League Championship Series against the St. Louis Cardinals with a 3-1 triumph over the Braves in a survival of the sleepiest.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OAK TECHNOLOGY, Sunnyvale, Calif., agreed to buy TeraLogic, Mountain View, Calif., for $50 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: Shining a Light on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVATORY
description: A River of Ice Goes Into Reverse

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: IRELAND: ARCHBISHOP APOLOGIZES The Archbishop of Dublin, Cardinal Desmond Connell, apologized to people who were sexually abused as children by Roman Catholic Church officials and said he would cooperate with the government's investigation. "I want to apologize again from my heart for the terrible betrayal they have suffered," he wrote in a letter read at Masses in Dublin on Sunday. "In the past, we have not always responded as quickly or as appropriately as we should." Some analysts interpreted the letter as a response in advance of a scheduled television program about the church's handling of abuse accusations.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel To Sell Unit To Bookham
description: Nortel Networks said yesterday that it was selling operations that produce optical components for $108 million to Bookham Technology of Britain. That is a fraction of the $3 billion Nortel paid JDS Uniphase for the assets in early 2001. Investors welcomed the deal as a way for Nortel to reduce spending in relation to the unit, which is based mainly in Zurich and manufactures small lasers, although concern remained over Nortel's commitment to continue buying equipment from the operation. Bookham is paying a combination of stock, debt and cash for the unit. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Deep Change Ahead for Corporations
description: SOUTH BEACH is looking a little anxious and tapped out these days -- sort of like a Bourbon Street with better shoes and haircuts. So it was probably an appropriate spot for a gaggle of travel professionals and writers to gather last week to gaze at the horizon and speculate.

title: A 2nd Look By Officers In Intern Case
description: The police say they want to question again a man interviewed previously about the killing of the former Congressional intern Chandra Ann Levy.

title: People
description: Brian Carty, executive vice president at the San Francisco office of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, was named president at the New York office. He succeeds David Wecal, who continues as creative director and becomes an executive vice president. Hill, Holliday is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Not on Three Networks
description: The ABC, CBS and NBC television networks did not carry President Bush's speech live. The White House did not formally ask them to broadcast it, the usual practice.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen hit a three-month low against the dollar after a report signaled that Japan's economy could contract and Tokyo's market declined. In New York, the yen settled at 124.26 to the dollar, from 123.22 on Friday.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Topping His 10 Most Wanted

title: Bertelsmann Offers Regret For Its Nazi-Era Conduct
description: The German media conglomerate Bertelsmann expressed regret today for its conduct under the Nazis, and for later efforts to cover it up, as a group of scholars issued an extensive report documenting the company's collaboration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Piscataway: College Student Accused Of Murder
description: A 20-year-old honors student at Rutgers University was ordered held in $250,000 bail yesterday on charges that he fatally stabbed a 19-year-old man. The Middlesex County prosecutor's office said the victim, Angel M. Lopez 3rd, of Bridgewater, was stabbed several times at a party about 3:45 a.m. Sunday. Prosecutors said Mr. Lopez and the suspect, Alex Levine, of Piscataway, had argued before Mr. Levine stabbed him with a pocketknife. Mr. Levine's lawyer, Michael F. Lombardi, said his client acted in self-defense. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused Of Selling Fake Art
description: A 53-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny he was accused of selling selling fraudulent African artwork, the police said. Mourtala Diop, 53, of East 54th Street, was arrested after a 74-year-old man who lives on the Upper East Side complained that Mr. Diop had sold him a fake statue. Mr. Diop's residence and workplace were searched, and a second victim was discovered, who said Mr. Diop had sold a statue for $300,000 to $500,000 that was not worth that, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: New Jersey Pushes for a Piece Of Sept. 11 Rebuilding Funds
description: Members of New Jersey's Congressional delegation have begun a drive to share in Federal Emergency Management Agency grants set aside for rebuilding Lower Manhattan.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Emergency-Readiness Hearing
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on the city's readiness for large-scale disasters. The committees will hear testimony from Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta and Commissioner John T. Odermatt of the Office of Emergency Management. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (212) 788-7121.

title: Hillary Clinton Helps Raise $1 Million for McCall Camp
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton came to the rescue of H. Carl McCall yesterday, extracting about $1 million in pledges from a group of her supporters to help replenish the dwindling campaign treasury of the Democratic candidate for governor.

title: BOY, 13, WOUNDED IN EIGHTH ATTACK LINKED TO SNIPER
description: A 13-year-old student was shot and critically wounded this morning at the entrance of his school here in the eighth attack linked to a roving sniper who has killed six adults in the Washington suburban area.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Agnellis Bid For Retailer
description: The Agnelli family of Italy and Auchan of France offered to buy the rest of La Rinascente, Italy's biggest traded retailer, for 735.4 million euros ($722 million), giving them more flexibility to forge alliances. The holding company of the Agnellis, Ifil, and Auchan, a family owned French supermarket chain, offered 4.45 euros for every Rinascente common share and 4.15 euros for each saving share, the companies said. ''The acquisition will give greater freedom in managing agreements and financial and industrial alliances,'' the statement said.

title: Congressman Defends Effort Against Paper
description: Representative Dick Armey, the House majority leader, was acting in the best interest of his constituents when he tried to promote legislation that would force the Belo Corporation, the parent company of The Dallas Morning News, to divest one of its three media properties in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, his spokesman said yesterday.

title: DRUG SERVICES COMPANY CUTS EARNINGS FORECASTS
description: West Pharmaceutical Services, a medical packaging and services company, cut its forecasts for third-quarter and full-year profit yesterday because of lower sales from a unit that develops ways to administer drugs. The company now expects a third-quarter profit, excluding one-time gains, of 21 cents to 23 cents a share, compared with 28 cents in the year-earlier period. The company reported net income of $5.9 million, or 41 cents a share, a year earlier. The company expects 2002 profit, excluding items, of $1.25 to $1.30 a share, compared with $1.46 in 2001. The company is based in Lionville, Pa.

title: A Nation Wary of War
description: Not quite four decades ago, Lyndon Johnson learned to his and the nation's sorrow that taking a reluctant country to war can severely damage the body politic. President Bush must be mindful of that danger as he draws the United States ever closer to military conflict with Iraq. Americans are worried about Saddam Hussein and his weapons of mass destruction, but are also concerned about the anemic state of the nation's economy, and seem uncertain how best to deal with Iraq. A New York Times/CBS News poll published yesterday, and other surveys, support the sense of many around the country that Mr. Bush still has work to do if he hopes to persuade Americans of the need to use military force to disarm Iraq.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: House Passes Bill On Net Radio
description: A bill granting a reprieve from fees that threatened to drive small Internet radio companies out of business was passed yesterday by the House of Representatives. The bill, which has not yet been passed by the Senate, would let operators of Internet radio companies that make less than $500,000 pay artists and labels a percentage of their revenue instead of a flat per-song fee. Larger Internet radio companies, like America Online or Yahoo, and midsize companies, like Live365, would still be required to pay the fees set in June by the Librarian of Congress. Both the recording industry and Internet radio companies have challenged those fees, which hold radio stations responsible for paying about one-fourteenth of a cent for each song heard by each listener over the Internet. Last month, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, above, introduced legislation that would have delayed payments for all Webcasters by six months, a move that helped spur the deal reflected in the House bill. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Even With Peca Injured, Islanders Feel Confident
description: The Islanders have progressed to the point where they insist that they do not want Michael Peca to rush back into action. Think about that for a minute. This is the same franchise that would have thrown a parade on Hempstead Turnpike had Peca been their No. 1 center two years ago.

title: Man in the News; Workingman President, Maybe -- Luiz Incio Lula da Silva
description: As a child, he labored as a farmhand at his mother's side; as a teenager, forced to drop out of school by poverty, he worked 12-hour shifts in factories. But now, at 56, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva stands just a step away from becoming the first workingman to be elected president of Brazil.

title: Doctors With Keys to the Cabinet
description: Prescription drug abuse among anesthesiologists, who have access to some of the most powerful and addictive medications in a hospital, remains a problem, despite increased prevention efforts, a new study reports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINS, ESTHER
description: PRINS-Esther. On October 6, 2002. Loving mother of Betty and Fred, cherished grandmother of Rich, Noel, Kevin, Billy and Kenny, adored Auntie of Monique, sister of Shelly, sister-in-law of Mimi, and a loving great grandmother. She was loved and will be missed by all. Funeral service was held Monday.

title: Deal Revives Delayed Plan For Train Hub
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has struck an agreement with the United States Postal Service to buy the James A. Farley Building on Eighth Avenue to turn the two-block-long building into a new glass-covered Pennsylvania Station.

title: Cleanliness, Godliness And Parking
description: THE floors were clean on two subway trains ridden yesterday morning. Streets in Midtown and on the Upper West Side did not seem bad, either. Not immaculate, that's for sure, but not bad.

title: Beethoven, Frankenstein, High Hopes
description: Headlines have followed the movement of marquee conductors to new cities: Simon Rattle to Berlin, James Levine to Boston and Lorin Maazel to New York. Quieter has been the accession of Franz Welser-Mst as music director of the Cleveland Orchestra. The choice has inspired surprise and doubt, but hopes for the long term as well. Mr. Welser-Mst was at his new job at Severance Hall on Saturday.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS IN DEAL FOR HEART TESTS AND MEDICINES
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company and Celera Diagnostics will cooperate to develop treatments and tests for heart disease and diabetes. Bristol-Myers will have rights to any medicines based on the research by Celera Diagnostics, a joint venture of the Applied Biosystems Group and the Celera Genomics Group, divisions of the Applera Corporation. Celera Diagnostics will sell products used to identify the disorders, Celera said. The companies plan to focus on genes that may be linked to the illnesses, Celera said.

title: A Muse of Gunfire for Harry, England and St. George
description: David Fuller, the producing artistic director of the Jean Cocteau Repertory, opens the company's new season with a rolling roar: screaming artillery explosions and bomb bursts as soldiers in modern combat dress and carrying automatic weapons storm down the aisle onto the stage, dropping and dying in the onslaught.

title: Sailor Charged in Shipmate's Fatal Fall From Midtown Hotel Room Is Held in $250,000 Bail
description: A United States Navy petty officer charged on Sunday with shoving a shipmate to her death from a sixth-floor window of a Midtown hotel was being held in $250,000 bail yesterday, officials said.

title: Israeli Military Kills 13 in Raid On Gaza Town
description: In what it called a new strategy to place the Islamist group Hamas on the defensive, the Israeli Army sent dozens of tanks backed by helicopter gunships into this densely packed Gaza town early today, killing at least 13 people.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an explosion on a French tanker approaching a Yemeni oil terminal misstated the number of Bulgarians among the crew. It was 17, not 7. With the eight French crew members, they brought the total to 25, as given in the article.

title: At the Health Department, the Messengers Still Stumble
description: Providing information about an outbreak of communicable diseases -- quickly, candidly and in plain language -- is essential in gaining public trust, and in a public health emergency it can be a matter of life and death.

title: Market Place; Documents Suggest Credit Suisse Linked Banking and Stock Ratings
description: Credit Suisse First Boston used its research analysts' rosy stock ratings to attract investment banking fees from companies hoping to raise money from investors, according to documents obtained by securities regulators investigating the firm and its research practices.

title: MEMO PAD
description: New Northwest System For Internet Bookings

title: 'Game On' in New Jersey
description: A tumultuous week in New Jersey ended yesterday as it should have. The United States Supreme Court wisely declined to hear a Republican challenge that sought to block the Democrats from placing former Senator Frank Lautenberg on the ballot to replace the disgraced incumbent, Robert Torricelli, who withdrew last Monday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, ARTHUR
description: BERGEN - Arthur. Temple Shaaray Tefila is grieved to record the passing of its dedicated member. To his wife Edie and daughters Rebecca and Emily we express our profound sympathy. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael H. Laufer, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUCHS, STANLEY
description: FUCHS-Stanley. A retired Professor Emeritus from Fordham University, passed away on Saturday, October 5 in Needham, MA. He was 68. A Brooklyn native, Fuchs was born on July 21, 1934. He graduated with high honors in English from City College of New York in 1955. Mr. Fuchs received his L.L.B. and his J.D. from Brooklyn Law School in 1959, and was awarded his M.B.A. from Long Island University in 1969. After a 20-year tenure at Fordham University, Fuchs was elevated to Chairman of the Legal and Ethical Studies Department in 1990. He was the recipient of the prestigious Benemerenti Award in 1991, and was named Professor Emeritus in May 2002. Fuchs served on the American Arbitration Association and was a judge for the City of New York. He is survived by his loving daughters: Belinda of South Boston, MA, and Melissa of Jamaica Plain, MA; and his siblings: Rosalie Berle of Scarsdale, NY, and Arnold Fox of Brooklyn, NY. Services will be held Tuesday, October 8 at 11:30 A.M. at The Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, New York, 800-448-1939. A scholarship will be established in Mr. Fuchs name; for donation information, please contact the funeral home.

title: Uzbek Militants' Decline Provides Clues to U.S.
description: The mountain trails crisscrossing this nation's eastern borders were quiet this summer, except for occasional blasts of Uzbek land mines killing civilians or livestock. The guerrillas the mines were meant to deter have not appeared.

title: Postseason Minus Pinstripes for Fox
description: In each year that Fox Sports has carried the World Series (1996, 1998, 2000 and 2001), the Yankees have appeared, winning three of four.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Planned Power Substation Criticized
description: A Consolidated Edison plan to build an electrical substation on West 31st Street was criticized last night at a public hearing. Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, Democrat of Manhattan, and several business leaders said they were worried about environmental damage, and about a tennis court and parking lots that would have to be demolished. Residents of the area also expressed concern that their neighborhood, in the West 30's, would suffer to meet the energy demands of Chelsea and Kips Bay, which the substation would serve. The substation would be between Fifth Avenue and Broadway. A plan to build a substation in Chelsea was voted down last spring by the Board of Standards and Appeals. A West 31st Street substation does not need board approval because the area is zoned for manufacturing. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Factory Orders Rise
description: German factory orders were stronger than expected in August with a monthly increase of a seasonally adjusted 1.7 percent, the government said. According to the preliminary data published by the economics ministry, foreign orders rose 2.6 percent and domestic orders 1.1 percent from July. The increase was helped by orders for capital goods, which were up 4.2 percent, while orders for consumer goods fell 1.7 percent. It was the first advance for industrial goods orders in three months. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: That Big D in Devils Still Stands for Defense
description: It is easy to look at the Devils and concentrate on what has changed, by comparing them unfavorably with the Devils team that won a Stanley Cup two years ago and by considering the off-season purge prompted by the disappointing end to last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBNICK, BERNARD
description: DUBNICK-Bernard. Age 74, of Old Tappan, NJ, on October 7, 2002. Survived by his wife Selma, children Joshua, Jeffrey, Ruth Levy and Deborah Levy, sister Edith Berger and three grandchildren Micah, Gabriel and Luka. Services are Wednesday, 12 Noon at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the possibility that China might support the United States in its plans against Iraq now that American-Chinese ties have improved misstated the location of a collision 18 months ago between an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter. It was over international waters. (The damaged plane landed on Hainan Island, leading to a standoff over its return.)

title: Nassau Fiscal Monitors Approve Budget, but With Reservations
description: The state fiscal monitors who oversee Nassau County endorsed its proposed 2003 budget today but pointedly withheld full approval of its four-year recovery plan, citing future risks that one member called frightening.

title: Footlights
description: Going Up

title: Anthony Campbell, 63, Acclaimed Preacher
description: The Rev. Anthony C. Campbell, a Baptist minister who gained international acclaim for his powerful oratory and his pluralistic message, died on Sept. 27 at a Boston hospital, three days after a stroke, his family said. He was 63 and lived in Boston.

title: House Republicans Push Bills To Benefit Small Investors
description: Republican leaders in the House began a push today to help investors by allowing them to write off more of their stock market losses and giving them more flexibility to manage their retirement savings.

title: Manhattan Leads a Surge in Lower-Cost Hotels
description: Although Bob Risse, a venture capitalist in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., often flies first class, his accommodations in Manhattan are anything but. He stays at the Ramada Inn Eastside, at Lexington Avenue and 30th Street, usually for $89 a night.

title: $500,000 Should Buy a Few Body Doubles
description: THE morning after Stanley Nelson discovered that he was, to his acute disbelief, the recipient of an unprecedented windfall in the form of a $500,000 MacArthur fellowship -- according to him, under-the-radar documentary filmmakers never receive windfalls -- he was right back at work by 5 a.m. Work was, in this case, standing in front of cameras on location in a Mississippi cotton field in a pair of overalls, his face out of the frame but his bare, dirty feet very much in focus, for a scene from his newest film, ''The Murder of Emmett Till.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MURRAY
description: FRIEDMAN-Murray. On October 5th, 2002. Beloved and devoted husband of Evelyn. Wonderful father to Jackie and Kathy, David and Dennis. Fabulous grandfather of Jamie, Jodi, Jason and Kim. Loving brother of Howard and Muriel Friedman, Eunice and Dr. Solomon Kaplan, and the late Carol and Dr. Morton Silverman. May his love surround us all forever. Services were held Monday, October 7, 2002.

title: Moving to the Rhythm of the Urban Jumble
description: Dagmar Spain conjured up the mystery, menace and excitement of cities in ''Appearances,'' which her company, Dance Imprints, presented on Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. The production, choreographed by Ms. Spain, a Czech-born dancer, and directed by Francine Roussel, a French stage director, also acknowledged both the vulnerability and the resilience of city dwellers.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Wednesday with an article about the possible effect of a war against Iraq on the oil markets mislabeled the figures for consumption by the leading importers of Iraqi oil. The figures represented barrels a day, not thousands of barrels.

title: One Bullet Extends the Fear to Children
description: At the garden apartments near Dodge Park Elementary, the grassy mounds that usually ring with children's voices were silent this afternoon. Tense and fearful after a 13-year-old was shot at a middle school not far from here, parents scurried to pick up their children when school closed, shepherding them to the safety of home straight away.

title: Noise and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants vs. Cardinals
description: San Francisco (95-66, N.L. wild card)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: WISCONSIN: ARSON AT HOUSE WHERE MAN WAS KILLED An arson fire broke out at the Milwaukee house where a man was beaten to death a week ago. There were no injuries in the fire. The police said the blaze on Sunday was in the upstairs part of the house where Charles Young Jr., 36, was beaten on Sept. 29. Another house in the area that belonged to the same owner burned on Wednesday night as a result of arson. The police would not comment about a possible a connection between Mr. Young's death and the fires. (AP)

title: Travelers in a Giving Mood, But Agonizing on the Way
description: YOU SHALL KNOW OUR VELOCITY

title: Taking Life to the Edge, And Spins and Jumps, Too
description: It is always the same memory that comes back. When Mat Hoffman emerges from unconsciousness, he will not know who he is or what he has done. But he will remember that he is alone. His mother is dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKINS, DR. DEBORAH B.
description: ELKINS-Dr. Deborah B. Of Manhattan, age 90, on October 3, 2002. Beloved sister of Vivian Elkins, Henrietta & Joseph Gitlin and predeceased by her adored sister Gertrude Elkins. Cherished aunt of Ronna & Dana Woodward and Drs. Karen & Richard Weiner. A dynamo with a magnetic personality and insatiable appetite for life and learning, Deborah was a well known and loved educator, mentor, friend, colleague, author and philanthropist. She was a passionate and prolific artist as well as a patron of the arts. Deborah was a Professor Emeritus of Queens College. A service in honor of her life will be held Tuesday, October 15, 2 PM at the Weill Art Gallery, 92nd St Y. Contributions to a charity of the donor's choice. Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER
description: ANNENBERG-Walter. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the death of Walter Annenberg. Deeply committed to humanitarian causes, he was a Founder of the Museum, and his personal commitment to the cause of Holocaust remembrance and to the Museum's mission will be greatly missed. The Museum extends its deepest condolences to his family and friends. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Ruth B. Mandel, Vice Chair Sara J. Bloomfield, Director

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Nashville; There's the Country Music And Other Good Stuff, Too
description: Nashville is called Music City for its recording studios and music clubs and the Athens of the South for its breadth of higher education (it is home to half a dozen four-year colleges and universities, led by Vanderbilt and Fisk). ''There is a very hip culture there,'' said Steve Schnur, a former recording industry executive who now oversees music for Electronic Arts, the computer game company.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: HOUSE PASSES BILL ON NET RADIO A bill granting a reprieve from fees that threatened to drive small Internet radio companies out of business was passed yesterday by the House of Representatives. The bill, which has not yet been passed by the Senate, would let operators of Internet radio companies that make less than $500,000 pay artists and labels a percentage of their revenue instead of a flat per-song fee. Larger Internet radio companies, like America Online or Yahoo , and midsize companies, like Live365, would still be required to pay the fees set in June by the Librarian of Congress. Both the recording industry and Internet radio companies have challenged those fees, which hold radio stations responsible for paying about one-fourteenth of a cent for each song heard by each listener over the Internet. Last month, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, above, introduced legislation that would have delayed payments for all Webcasters by six months, a move that helped spur the deal reflected in the House bill.

title: Timeline: Life With an Artificial Heart
description: July 2001

title: A Region's Hospital Supplies: Costly Ties
description: Struggling hospitals in the New York area may be overpaying millions for medical supplies because their trade group promotes a purchasing agent with financial ties to the group and at least one of its top executives, according to records and health care officials.

title: U.S. Magistrate in Buffalo Denies Bail for 5 of 6 Terror Suspects
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 8  A federal magistrate today denied bail to five of the six American citizens charged with being members of an Al Qaeda sleeper cell, saying he was troubled by the unexplained nature and true purpose of their trip to a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan in the spring of 2001.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about suggestions for change in the way Wall Street conducts its business misattributed remarks about investment banking research. It was Peter J. Solomon, not Sanford I. Weill, who expressed the view that the only purpose of such research was to attract banking clients. Mr. Solomon, chairman of an independent advisory firm bearing his name, said Mr. Weill, chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, had told him that such research had no value.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, NANCY
description: NICHOLS-Nancy. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our friend Nancy Nichols, cherished wife of our former colleague Rodney W. Nichols, longtime Executive Vice President of The Rockefeller University. Energy, grace, and intelligence were manifest in Nancy, along with a warm and loving heart. her courageous struggle with a devastating illness over the past several months was inspirational. We share the Nichols family's pain over their enormous loss. Along with the entire Rockefeller University community, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Rod, Courtney, Lindsay and Christopher. Thomas P. Sakmar Acting President Joshua Lederberg, Frederick Seitz, and Torsten Wiesel Presidents Emeriti William O. Baker Chairman Emeritus David Rockefeller Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

title: Manchester United Banks on a U.S. Tour
description: Manchester United wants to rule the world.

title: In Battle for Cruise Line, More Is Likely to Beat Less
description: Here is a lesson from Mergers and Acquisitions 101: A deal that offers a premium tends to beat a merger-of-equals deal without one. The long-running battle for control of P&O Princess Cruises is looking like a case in point.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the effect of the Iraq debate on the campaign for the Senate seat in Minnesota held by Senator Paul Wellstone -- who opposes unilateral action against Iraq -- misstated his victory margins in 1990 and 1996. Mr. Wellstone won with 50.4 percent of the vote in 1990 and 50.3 percent in 1996. He did not receive less than half the vote either time.

title: On Medicine's Frontier: The Last Journey of James Quinn
description: On the day his doctors disconnected his artificial heart, ending his life, James Quinn gave them one final scare.

title: Exhilarating Journeys To the Mountaintops
description: Wisdom is simple. Things just are so, it says, and the surprise is that we were unable to recognize the obvious before.

title: International Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco Chief Pessimistic On Recovery
description: The chief executive of Cisco Systems, John T. Chambers, said yesterday that a recovery in the telecommunications industry would lag behind a rebound in the broader technology industry by two to six quarters. Chief executives ''are probably the most cautious I've seen in my business career,'' Mr. Chambers said at a Gartner Inc. conference in Orlando, Fla. Mr. Chambers was referring to his peers' ability to forecast their business prospects, a spokeswoman, Abby Smith, said. Shares of Cisco, the world's largest maker of communications equipment, have tumbled 28 percent in the last three weeks. Mr. Chambers said he could not predict when the industry's prospects would improve. Shares of Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., dropped 38 cents, to $9.08.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHS, MOSES
description: WACHS-Moses. The Officers and Directors of Metropolitan Jewish Health System sadly mourn the untimely passing of Moses Wachs, beloved former executive director of Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center. For nearly three decades he demonstrated a true and real concern for the needs and dignity of elderly residents. A man of vision, he held a constant view towards the changing needs of the aging population and sought innovations in patient care. His leadership, integrity and a determination to achieve, were hallmarks of his success, and resulted in the excellent reputation of the facilities under his administration. We were privileged to work alongside of him, sharing common goals. He will be greatly missed. May his legacy act as a source of inspiration to all those whom he touched. Our profound sympathy and sincere condolences to the family. Steven L. Topal, Chairman of the Board Eli S. Feldman, President Chief Executive Officer

title: Nara Journal; Japanese Masters Get Closer to the Toilet Nirvana
description: Japan's toilet wars started in February, when Matsushita engineers here unveiled a toilet seat equipped with electrodes that send a mild electric charge through the user's buttocks, yielding a digital measurement of body-fat ratio.

title: Nationalist Parties Set to Regain Power in Bosnia
description: The three nationalist parties that led Bosnia into war 10 years ago were poised today to regain power after winning the most votes in elections on Saturday, despite international efforts to marginalize them.

title: Awakening From 'Bad Dream,' Yankees Know Changes Loom
description: A small red-and-white cardboard box on Joe Torre's desk held the most prized keepsake of the Yankees' season. On the top of the box, in black ink, it said ''100th victory 2002.'' There will be no rings to commemorate a World Series title or an American League pennant, just a ball in a box from a game in late September. The off-season has arrived shockingly soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADE, BRENDA B.
description: MEADE-Brenda B. Devoted wife of Gary. Loving mother of Colleen Edwards, Daria Connolly and Bevin Gibbons. Cherished daughter of Harriet Delargy. Loving grandmother of Jack Edwards. Dear sister of Donald Delargy and Sheila Fahey. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Reposing at Papavero Funeral Home, 7227 Grand Avenue, Maspeth. Funeral Mass Thursday St. Joan of Arc Church, 10:15 AM. Visiting 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Borders to Return Downtown With New Store, Prompting Hope for Retail Revitalization
description: Borders Books and Music, whose flagship downtown store at the World Trade Center was destroyed in the attack last year, is returning to Lower Manhattan, where it signed a lease last week to open a store in a landmark building on Broadway.

title: The F.C.C.'s Duty
description: Late last month the former controller of WorldCom pleaded guilty to criminal fraud in connection with the company's accounting scandal and bankruptcy. It has also come to light that government reports unintentionally dignified WorldCom's incorrect claim that Internet traffic was doubling every 100 days. The government thus contributed to the hype that caused billions of dollars to be invested in long-distance fiber optic networks that go unused. Federal and state law enforcement agencies have been investigating WorldCom. The Federal Communications Commission, which regulates the industry, has the authority and the responsibility to do so as well.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Tire Appeal
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal from a tire maker of a $3.3 million jury award in the 1995 highway death of a Mississippi woman.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, ISIDORE
description: BECKER-Isidore. You took part of me with you. Having a rough time without you. We love you and miss you. You are always in our hearts. Adele, Children and Grandchildren

title: Visions of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Debate on Senate Floor on Use of Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania; Max Cleland, Democrat of Georgia; Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, and Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska.

title: OneWorld Wins, Setting Up Race Of Unbeatens
description: The OneWorld Challenge team led by Craig McCaw and Paul Allen whipped Team Dennis Conner in shifting winds on the Hauraki Gulf on Monday, setting the stage for a showdown today with another American boat and a fellow tycoon, Oracle and Larry Ellison.

title: Two Magazines Are Shut And Red Herring Is Sold
description: Mutual Funds magazine, a personal finance magazine owned by AOL Time Warner, and Upside magazine, a privately held publication in Silicon Valley, announced yesterday that they were shutting down. And Red Herring, another Silicon Valley publication, announced that it was selling itself to a majority investor in an effort to restructure financially.

title: Coca-Cola to Start Harry Potter Promotion
description: Coca-Cola to Start Harry Potter Promotion

title: Polygraph Is Poor Tool for Screening Employees, Panel Says
description: In a report to the government, a panel of leading scientists said today that polygraph testing is too flawed to use for security screening. The panel said lie detector tests do a poor job of identifying spies or other national-security risks and are likely to produce false accusations of innocent people.

title: Fitness Guide for Brain
description: ''Saving Your Brain,'' by Dr. Jeff Victoroff, Bantam Books, $25.95.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Telekom Bidders Selected
description: Germany's largest telecommunications operator, Deutsche Telekom, said it had selected three bidders as potential buyers of its six regional cable networks. Deutsche Telekom started to look for a new buyer after the German cartel office blocked the Liberty Media Corporation's full purchase of the cable TV units in February. Forced to reduce its huge debt of 64.2 billion euros ($63 billion), the group needs a quick sale as much as a good price. Deutsche Telekom did not disclose details of the bids or the names of the bidders. The company was initially hoping for 2.5 billion to 3.5 billion euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Talks With U.S. On M.I.A.'S
description: North Korean and American officials met in Bangkok to discuss further searches for the remains of 8,000 missing United States servicemen from the Korean War. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Jerry D. Jennings also sought to set up a way to resolve reports that some American defectors or prisoners may be alive in North Korea. Since missions began in 1976, American teams have recovered 170 sets of remains, with 10 being identified and returned to families. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Government Joins Investigation of Sniper Attacks
description: The federal government has officially joined the investigation into the attacks linked to a roving sniper who has killed six people and wounded two others, including a 13-year-old student, in the Washington suburban area.

title: Vick Is Listed as Doubtful for Sunday's Game
description: When Michael Vick arrived at the Falcons' practice facility today, he said he had been unable to reach down and put on his socks this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITAL, HARRIET A.
description: WITAL-Harriet A., 86. Of Silver Spring, MD, formerly of Deerfield Beach, FL. Beloved wife of the late Gene Wital, loving mother of Janis Wital and Ruth (Fred) Skolnick, loving grandmother of Eric and Lisa Skolnick. Memorial donations may be made to: Jewish Community Hospice Music Fund, 6123 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD. 20852.

title: Shining a Light on the Court
description: To the Editor:

title: First Boston To Cut 1,500 From Payroll
description: Credit Suisse First Boston told its employees late yesterday that it planned to eliminate an additional 1,500 jobs in an effort to trim $500 million from its budget.

title: Senate Hears Bush Nominee For F.D.A.
description: President Bush's nominee for commissioner of food and drugs, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, appeared before the Senate today for a brief and cordial confirmation hearing that seemed to clear the way for his confirmation by the chamber.

title: Nature All Around
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bush Takes Steps to End Lockout at Western Ports

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENNER, JACK
description: PRENNER-Jack. On October 7, 2002, age 94. Dear uncle of Edward Prenner and loving great-uncle of Emily and Elizabeth. An extraordinary musician and a link to the great days of the Broadway musical theatre, where for many years he was the coach and rehearsal pianist for Rodgers, Hart, Hammerstein, and many others. For funeral information please call Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Chapels, (718) 263-7600.

title: More Traffic Cops
description: To the Editor:

title: CASINO BUILDER WANTS TO RAISE $470 MILLION IN I.P.O.
description: Steve Wynn, who built such Las Vegas casinos as the Mirage and Treasure Island, plans to raise $470 million for his latest casino venture by selling stock in the slowest market for initial public offerings in 25 years. Mr. Wynn wants to sell about a one-third stake in Wynn Resorts, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The 20.5 million shares will be priced at $21 to $23 each. Mr. Wynn's record of building profitable casinos may give his sale a boost, investors said. He was chairman of Mirage Resorts until the company was sold to MGM Grand in 2000 for $6.4 billion. Proceeds from the stock offering will help pay for Le Reve, a $2.4 billion casino to be built on the north end of the Las Vegas Strip.

title: Lawmakers Make Their Cases as Votes on Use of Force Draw Near
description: Prominent Democrats offered a broad critique of President Bush's approach to foreign policy today. They said he risked alienating allies and making it more difficult to hold together a coalition against terrorism.

title: Canadian Phone Giant Trims Forecast
description: The telecommunications company BCE Inc. said today that third-quarter earnings were at the bottom of its projected range because of slow sales of Internet services. It also trimmed its forecast for the year.

title: Minnesota Winning With Merry Pranksters
description: Enter the Minnesota Twins' clubhouse at your peril. Pranksters and jokers abound, starting with Manager Ron Gardenhire. Almost nothing is off limits.

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: CISCO CHIEF PESSIMISTIC ON RECOVERY The chief executive of Cisco Systems, John T. Chambers, said yesterday that a recovery in the telecommunications industry would lag behind a rebound in the broader technology industry by two to six quarters. Chief executives "are probably the most cautious I've seen in my business career," Mr. Chambers said at a Gartner Inc. conference in Orlando, Fla. Mr. Chambers was referring to his peers' ability to forecast their business prospects, a spokeswoman, Abby Smith, said. Shares of Cisco, the world's largest maker of communications equipment, have tumbled 28 percent in the last three weeks. Mr. Chambers said he could not predict when the industry's prospects would improve. Shares of Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., dropped 38 cents, to $9.08.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Economic Official
description: Under pressure to revive the country's stagnant economy, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder appointed an influential state premier, Wolfgang Clement, left, to run a newly combined economics and labor ministry. Mr. Clement, 62, who leads Germany's most populous state, North Rhine-Westphalia, will be expected to carry out labor-market reforms to reduce the country's jobless rate of four million. Fears about unemployment almost cost Mr. Schrder re-election last month. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Banyan Tree As a Symbol Of Past And Present
description: Vidya Murthy and Parul Shah are two young Indian classical dancers raised in the United States whose strong creative edge and respect for tradition add up to an exciting appeal with a difference.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, JOAN D.
description: DONOVAN-Joan D., 76. Died September 17, in Scottsdale, AZ. She was preceded in death by her beloved husband of 47 years, Dr. Raymond J. She was born in Queens, NY, graduated from Woodhaven High School, the College of New Rochelle, and received her Master's Degree from Columbia University. She was a teacher in the NYC school system and later an office manager in her husband's medical practice. She also served as a Eucharistic Minister at The Franciscan Renewal Center in Paradise Valley. She is survived by three loving sons, Raymond G., Thomas C., Gerard J., and five grandchildren. Graveside memorial service to be held at the Most Holy Trinity Cemetery in East Hampton, LI, at 11 AM, on Thursday, October 10, 2002. Donations may be made to the American Diabetes Association, Arizona Affiliate, 9034 N. 23rd Ave, #

title: A New Look at Old Data May Discredit a Theory on Race
description: Two physical anthropologists have reanalyzed data gathered by Franz Boas, a founder of American anthropology, and report that he erred in saying environment influenced human head shape. Boas's data, the two scientists say, show almost no such effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DORIS HYMAN
description: MILLER-Doris Hyman. On October 7. Hunter College High School Class of '29 and Barnard College Class of'33. Beloved wife of the late Myron. Devoted mother of Ralph Miller and his wife Avis and Cia Elkin and her husband Larry Gadd. Loving grandmother of Ethan, Jeremy, Gavi, Justin and Ezra Miller and Noah and Sam Elkin and Rachel Kaufman. Adoring great grandmother of four. Services Wednesday, October 9, at ''The Riverside'' 76 & Amsterdam Ave, 11:30AM.

title: Ocean Township Mayor Admits Wrongdoing and Resigns
description: The mayor of Ocean Township, N.J., who also serves as the city manager for Asbury Park, unexpectedly resigned both posts today, saying he had committed ''illegal actions'' connected to his job as mayor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the possibility that China might support the United States in its plans against Iraq now that American-Chinese ties have improved misstated the location of a collision 18 months ago between an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter. It was over international waters. (The damaged plane landed on Hainan Island, leading to a standoff over its return.)

title: F.B.I. Agent Tells of Ground Zero Crystal Theft
description: The Justice Department's inspector general is investigating an F.B.I. agent's complaint that an F.B.I. evidence recovery team stole a Tiffany crystal globe paperweight from the rubble of the World Trade Center, government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGUET, SHEILA
description: HOGUET-Sheila, 78. Of New York City, died October 3. Survived by daughter, Denise, and son, Mark. Funeral services Tuesday, October 8, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th and Lexington, 10 AM. Reception 3-6. 212-879-8445.

title: Chinese Court Voids Death Sentences on 5 Christian Leaders
description: BEIJING, Oct. 8  In a rare reversal for a politically sensitive case, a Chinese appeals court has overturned the death sentences given last December to five leaders of a defiant evangelical Christian group, court officials in Hubei Province said today.

title: Arab Leaders Glumly Brace for Inevitable War, With an Eye to Anger in the Streets
description: America's allies in the Arab world are positioning themselves to go along with a United States-led war against Iraq, driven by their need for American strategic and economic assistance, officials and diplomats in the region said.

title: Report Finds Lapses in Program To Deport Criminal Immigrants
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service fails to identify and deport criminal immigrants in a timely fashion, costing millions in unnecessary detention expenses and keeping immigrants in custody beyond their legal sentences, according to an audit released today by the inspector general of the Department of Justice.

title: Fertility Clinics Begin to Address Mental Health
description: In the past decade, fertility experts have made major advances in reproductive technology. They have learned how to inject a single microscopic sperm into an egg to ensure fertilization; they can retrieve an egg from one woman, fertilize it and implant it into another's uterus; and they have succeeded in freezing a young woman's eggs so she could have access to them later in life when she is ready to reproduce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YERUSHALMI, DANNY
description: YERUSHALMI-Danny. Our sunshine died on October 5th at the age of 19-1/2. Danny, your purity, laughter and light will always remain with us. We love you so deeply. Thank you for touching everyone's life in a most tender way. Rest peacefully. Mommy, Daddy, Cheni and Dari

title: A Snake Out of Place, in a Park Full of Sculptures in Queens
description: A boa constrictor as long as a man is tall -- though small for a snake of its type -- sidled into the Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, on Sunday, giving some visitors a fright. But the park's artist in residence nonchalantly let the six-foot snake give him a squeeze.

title: Noise and the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: No One Charged In Secret Taping About Iowa Race
description: State and federal prosecutors said yesterday that they would not file criminal charges in the taping scandal that has disrupted the Senate campaign in Iowa.

title: Fox Hunting's Supposed Benefits Dismissed
description: In the debate over fox hunting in Britain, there is plenty of emotion to go around. Opponents argue that unleashing a pack of hounds to pursue and kill a fox is the height of cruelty. Supporters, including the 400,000 who protested parliamentary proposals to ban hunts by marching in London late last month, say that nothing less than the future of the British countryside is at stake.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, JOHN D.
description: FLANAGAN-John D. Born in Washington D.C. on September 21, 1918. Died peacefully at home on October 5, 2002. Attended college at Rutgers University, veteran of WWII 4th Armored Division and retired Chairman of the Board of Authenticolor, Inc. Survived by his wife Kathleen, his children Christopher and Karen and four grandchildren. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment private.

title: Checkpoints in Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Exchange Chairman To Leave
description: The chairman of the London Stock Exchange said he would step down from that post when his three-year term expires in July. ''I have informed the board that I do not wish my name to go forward for another three years,'' Don Cruickshank, the chairman, said, explaining that he would give up his job at the exchange's annual general meeting scheduled for July. A date for the meeting has not yet been set. Mr. Cruickshank, who presided over the exchange's failed attempt to merge with the Deutsche Brse, said it was time for him to pursue ''new challenges.'' Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am not willing to stake one American life on trusting Saddam Hussein.''

title: A Singer and Her Band Find A Place at the Edge of Jazz
description: A lot of negligible pop music gets passed off as ''jazzy''; a couple of diminished chords is all you need. But the singer Rebecca Martin, who seems to have the outer sensibility of a pop singer and the inner resources of a jazz musician, can get close to jazz, and both sides of the equation make out well.

title: Bush Intervenes to Halt West Coast Port Dispute
