description: President Bush announced this afternoon that he would seek a court injunction to end the 11-day shutdown of 29 West Coast ports and halt the fast-growing damage it is doing to the nation's shaky economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANGER, CARL LEWY
description: ZANGER-Carl Lewy. Died October 6, 2002, born in New York City in 1931, graduate of Hamilton College, Harvard Law School. He also served in the U.S. Army. Served as Chairman of the Committee on Art Law of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at a time when important legislation was considered and enacted relating to artists and galleries. Under his leadership, the Committee had a major role in shaping legislation in New York and nationwide. A solo practitioner representing clients in a wide range of personal and business matters, an anachronism in today's world. Carl is survived by Sandra, his wife of 36 years, his three sons Sam, Hugh and Jesse and his brother Walter and sister Judith Segal. Memorial Service arrangements to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, JEROME D.
description: HABER-Jerome D. The Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the untimely passing of Jerome D. Haber and offer our deepest sympathy to his wife Dorothy, his children and the entire Haber family. Mel Konner, President

title: Paths for America, Other Than War
description: To the Editor:

title: Flyers' Tough Guy Is Hitchcock
description: The National Hockey League begins its 2002-3 season tonight with protective netting at both ends of the ice and a commitment to quicker games with more offense. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish.

title: Nonalcoholic brew is shedding its flat image : A lush market for near beer
description: FRANKFURT:  As professor emeritus of brewing sciences, Anton Piendl knows more than the average barstool philosopher about beer aroma, flavor and foam. But when Piendl, author of a seven-volume beer encyclopedia, swills a cold Pilsener, it's an alkoholfrei Clausthaler Premium.

title: Review/Fashion; Galliano Sends Up a Smiley Face Trial Balloon
description: Every six months, a handful of influential designers, most of them men, attempt to play with the female psyche. ''Now you are a goddess!'' ''Now you are a marvelous slave girl!'' This sort of sartorial hocus-pocus doesn't work on many women, and it's probably why they sit on the fashion sidelines, or shop at Target.

title: Accounts
description: LCA-Vision, Cincinnati, to Zimmerman & Partners, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle media duties for the account of the LasikPlus vision-correction centers, with spending estimated at $12 million to $15 million. The duties had been handled by Green & Associates, Baltimore. Zimmerman is part of the Omnicom Group.

title: With Stroke Drug, Errors Aplenty
description: Drugs known as clot-busters have the potential to save the lives of untold people brought to emergency rooms after suffering strokes. But many doctors continue to use the drugs incorrectly, often with serious consequences, a new study reports.

title: Doctors Urge Caution on Smallpox Vaccinations
description: Leading medical groups are urging caution in the use of smallpox vaccine, particularly if no cases of the disease occur.

title: Bure Goes Back to Practice
description: Two days before the Rangers' 77th N.H.L. season opener, in Raleigh, N.C., Pavel Bure practiced today for the first time since having arthroscopic knee surgery on Sept. 26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACKAR, HEATHER HAZELL
description: BACKAR-Heather Hazell. Of New York City, interior designer, on October 6, 2002 after a long and valiant struggle with cancer. Her beauty, generosity and good humor were appreciated by clients, family, friends and those that had the good fortune to know her. She leaves behind her adoring, heart broken husband and life partner, Andre O. Backar, a brother William Hazell of Victoria British Columbia, stepson Zachary Backar of New York City, stepdaughter, Janet Backar Papi of Aix En Provence, France, as well as two stepgrandsons and two nieces. Born in Toronto Canada she lived most of her life in New York City with frequent travel all over the world. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Wednesday, October 9, 6-9PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, 428 East 72 St. Suite 300, New York, New York 10021.

title: For the Ozone Layer, a New Look
description: Is the ozone layer healing? Satellite observation of the hole that developed over Antarctica in the mid-1980's shows that it has split in two and has shrunk considerably since last year, making it the smallest it has been since 1988.

title: Out of This World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Travel Group Executive Quits
description: The chief executive of the MyTravel Group Tim Byrne, stepped down after the company cut its profit forecast last week for the second time in four months. The chairman, David Crossland, scheduled to retire next month, plans to stay on for as long as 12 months to help oversee the search for Mr. Byrne's replacement, a spokesman said. MyTravel is Europe's third-largest travel company.

title: Bush Back in Tennessee to Raise Money and G.O.P. Numbers
description: On his second trip in three weeks to this state, President Bush raised nearly a million dollars today on behalf of the Republican candidate for governor, Representative Van Hilleary, who is in a tight race.

title: Behind Door No. 2, Less 9/11 Aid; Line Separates Merchant From Others Being Helped
description: The way Alex S. Ferkov sees it, his takeout food shop and cafeteria is being unjustly deprived of money on ''nitpicking technicalities.''

title: La Russa Throws Mental Brushback
description: Tony La Russa is the only lawyer who has been a manager in major league baseball in the last 73 years, but yesterday he tried his hand at becoming the only psychologist.

title: Price of Truffles Drops To Half a King's Ransom
description: FRESH white truffles seem to be keeping pace with Wall Street. Wholesale prices for these tubers have plummeted to about half of what they were the last two years, down to $750 to $1,200 a pound from $1,500 to $2,000.

title: Israel Defiantly Warns of More Antiterror Raids in Gaza
description: Shouldering aside criticism from the Bush administration, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon today warned of more Israeli raids into the Gaza Strip like the one that left 16 Palestinians dead on Monday, calling the strategy a necessary bulwark against terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARATTINI, PAUL A.
description: BARATTINI-Paul A. Beloved husband of Christine (nee Esposito). Devoted father of Geraldine Silver. Loving father-in-law of Saul Silver. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St, NYC. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:15AM Our Lady of Pompei RC Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting Wednesday 2 to 9PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Our Lady of Pompei Church, 25 Carmine St, NY, NY. 10014, would be appreciated.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Dispute Over Contribution
description: A police organization that is supporting Bill Simon Jr., the Republican candidate for governor, released a five-year-old photograph that it said showed his opponent, Gov. Gray Davis, accepting a campaign contribution on government property, which is illegal. The photograph, dated 1998, when Mr. Davis was lieutenant governor, shows the head of the group, the California Organization of Police and Sheriffs, handing him a $10,000 check. The current director of the group, Monty Holden, said the picture was taken in the lieutenant governor's office in the Capitol. Garry South, Mr. Davis's chief political adviser, said the room in the picture was not the lieutenant governor's office. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: Ode to a Worm
description: When the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to two Britons and an American this week, it should also have gone to a fourth contributor that made their pioneering research possible, the tiny soil worm known as Caenorhabditis elegans, or C. elegans for short. Over the past three decades this unassuming creature has elbowed its way to the forefront of laboratory specimens, joining the legions of rats, mice, fruit flies and bacteria that serve as convenient model organisms for studying the processes of life.

title: Campaign Season; Hillary Clinton Helps a Long Shot
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has her own political action committee, called Hillpac. So far, she has handed out more than $250,000 to Democratic candidates for the Senate and House, including $5,000 to Jan Schneider, a Yale Law School classmate.

title: Big luxury labels are losing cachet
description: LONDON  It used to be that fashion buyers could carry on like Texan businessmen on a Las Vegas weekend. Their idea of a buying appointment would be to slap down $35,000 on Armani (or the label of the day) as if they were putting stacks of chips on black, which given the limited color palette of the early '90s was often quite literally the case.

title: Clean Coal Effort Planned
description: Clean Coal Power Resources, which opened this year and is closely held, announced today that it planned to spend $4.5 billion to build plants to make natural gas from coal and generate power in Fayette County, Ill., near Vandalia.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 30 about Erna Furman, a child psychoanalyst and an expert on grief, gave a misspelled name in some references to the center where she practiced. It is the Hanna Perkins Center for Child Development, not Hannah. Because of an editing error, Mrs. Furman's maiden name was misspelled. It was Popper, not Poppe. The article misstated the timing of Mrs. Furman's immigration to the United States. It occurred in the 1950's, not the 40's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACKAR, HEATHER HAZELL
description: BACKAR-Heather Hazell. Of New York City, interior designer, on October 6, 2002 after a long and valiant struggle with cancer. Her beauty, generosity and good humor were appreciated by clients, family, friends and those that had the good fortune to know her. She leaves behind her adoring, heart broken husband and life partner, Andre O. Backar, a brother William Hazell of Victoria British Columbia, stepson Zachary Backar of New York City, stepdaughter, Janet Backar Papi of Aix En Provence, France, as well as two stepgrandsons and two nieces. Born in Toronto Canada she lived most of her life in New York City with frequent travel all over the world. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St., Wednesday, October 9, 6-9PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Anne Moore Breast Cancer Research Fund, 428 East 72 St. Suite 300, New York, New York 10021.

title: Education Continues For Vick in Atlanta
description: Groups of Atlanta Falcons hopped into six vans early last month and drove to different sites in Atlanta for a get-to-know-you session with their fans. It was meant as a measure of good will, a hint of the ''New Falcons.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Stake In Insurer Bought
description: HSBC Holdings, a leading European bank, agreed to buy a 10 percent stake in the Ping An Insurance Company of China for $600 million to gain access to one of the world's fastest-growing insurance markets. The investment in Ping An, China's second-biggest insurer, is subject to regulatory approvals, HSBC said. HSBC will provide technical assistance to the insurer.

title: Indian Pt. Ad Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: Reality TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors Throw Wrestler's Harassment Claim Out of the Ring
description: A Federal District Court jury in Brooklyn yesterday rejected a former professional wrestler's claim that she had been sexually harassed on the job, with several jurors saying they had concluded that her charges had been invented to try to win a big verdict.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREUDENHEIM, RICHARD
description: FREUDENHEIM - Richard. Beloved husband of Francine. Dear brother of Jean Paulsen Topal & Ted. Loving uncle of nieces and nephews. For information, contact Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Suburban Chapel, Livingston, New Jersey.

title: The Procrastinating Idol Of an Opera-Mad World
description: PUCCINI

title: Speech Had Big Audience Despite Networks' Action
description: ABC, CBS and NBC may not have covered the president's speech in Cincinnati on Monday night, but it was still one of the most-watched television events of the evening.

title: Sports of The Times; David Chase Presents Fall Season
description: THINGS aren't the same without Paulie.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Endorsements In Race For Governor
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and his Democratic challenger, William E. Curry Jr., a former state comptroller, left, each announced new endorsements yesterday from groups they said were emblematic of their growing support. Mr. Curry received the support of the Uniformed Professional Fire Fighters Association and the Hartford Fire Fighters Association, which together represent about 4,660 firefighters across Connecticut, the Curry campaign said. Governor Rowland announced that he was being endorsed by five former Democratic state senators who served in that chamber with Mr. Curry in the 1980's. Mr. Curry dismissed the cross-party endorsement as no surprise, because he disagreed with the former colleagues then and now. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Mutombo, Star on Defense, Will Now Answer to Magic
description: As the last of the Rwandan rebel troops pulled out of Congo last Saturday, Dikembe Mutombo finished reviewing the Nets' offense and called his father to rejoice.

title: TNT Wins Rights To British Open
description: TNT acquired the cable rights to the British Open yesterday and ended a 20-year period during which ESPN carried the Open's two early rounds.

title: What They're Eating On the Other Side Of the World
description: An introductory course in the foods of the world could use ''The Foodlover's Atlas of the World'' by Martha Rose Shulman (Firefly Books, $35) as its textbook.

title: Thousands Will Honor Fire Department's Dead
description: Tens of thousands of firefighters, some traveling from as far away as Ireland and Japan, are expected to fill Madison Square Garden and the surrounding blocks on Saturday as the Fire Department holds an official memorial service for members who died in the attack on the World Trade Center.

title: Top Democrats and White House Battle Over S.E.C. Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The search by the Securities and Exchange Commission for a new top accounting regulator turned into a political brawl today, as administration officials defended the chairman of the commission while prominent Democrats called for his removal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHKOWITZ, SYLVIA
description: HERSHKOWITZ-Sylvia, 87, on October 7. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Irving Hershkowitz and beloved mother of Rhona and Jay. Dear friend of many. Her great spirit and courage, her sense of humor and her love of life will always be remembered.

title: Hallelujah, He's Still a Bum, But a Bit Sweeter This Time
description: Al Jolson was a vexatious man, and ''Jolson & Company'' is a vexatious musical.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bridgewater: More Charges In Robberies
description: The authorities said three men who were accused last week of trying to rob a fast-food restaurant are also responsible for holding up four motels and assaulting a clerk during a one-night robbery spree last month. The Somerset County prosecutor's office charged that on Sept. 25, the men -- Kahleel L. Butts, Marcus A. King and Saeed I. Nurideen -- stole more than $1,000 from motels in New Jersey. A man identified as a Howard Johnson's clerk was struck in the face and suffered facial injuries, the prosecutor's office said. The prosecutor charged that the three also tried to hold up a McDonald's. Mr. Butts and Mr. King were arrested after a McDonald's employee used the store's intercom to alert a police officer, a customer at the time. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Conill Advertising, New York, part of the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of the Publicis Groupe, hired four employees for new posts. Pablo Buffagni was named creative director; he had been creative director at Montemayor, San Antonio. Arturo Jara was named associate creative director; he had been a copywriter at the Mexico City office of a sibling agency, Nazca Saatchi & Saatchi. Tom Lanktree was named strategic planning director; he had been group director for client services at Nazca Saatchi & Saatchi, San Juan, Puerto Rico. And Don Lupo was named interactive manager; he had been a freelancer for Conill. Mr. Buffagni and Mr. Lupo are based in the Conill Los Angeles office; Mr. Jara and Mr. Lanktree are based in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Friday about Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein's plans to use consultants to study the New York City public school system misstated the title of one of them, Libia Gil. She is chief academic officer for New American Schools; the chief executive officer is Mary Anne Schmitt.

title: Kelly Has No Regrets a Year After Resigning
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 8  The Twins' sudden success is no surprise to the former manager Tom Kelly. And Kelly, who managed Minnesota to world championships in 1987 and 1991, doesn't regret resigning after last season, when the Twins posted their first winning record after eight consecutive losing seasons.

title: Viacom is planning a multimedia campaign against AIDS.
description: VIACOM plans to focus its various media properties on a single public service campaign with an AIDS-awareness and education effort.

title: Market Place; A Car Shipper Sold Shares; S.E.C. Implies It Sold Illusions
description: The revenue from a major line of business did not exist, the company did not own the major asset it showed on its books, and its bank account documents were forged. The auditor did not bother to check anything before giving the company a clean bill of health.

title: Mia Slavenska, 86, Celebrated Ballerina
description: Mia Slavenska, a ballerina celebrated both for her authoritative technique and for her red-haired beauty, died on Saturday at a retirement center in Los Angeles where she had lived in recent years. She was 86.

title: Recipe: Potato Gratin
description: Time: 1 hour

title: New Name, Expanding Mandate
description: Audrey Cohen College in Lower Manhattan has a new name: Metropolitan College of New York. The school's president, STEPHEN R. GREENWALD, said the name change was meant to reflect the school's more diverse student body and its focus on business and human services. AUDREY COHEN started the school in 1964. She named it the Women's Talent Corps, but in 1970 it was renamed Audrey Cohen College. The school, with an enrollment of 1,700 students, follows Ms. Cohen's theories that education should not be abstract but instead closely linked to clearly understood purposes. Students must either work at a job or hold an internship while attending classes full-time for three semesters a year. Lia Miller

title: The Collections / PARIS: Sex vs. sport:Fords YSL is surreal
description: PARIS  Sex and sport are this millenniums bread and circuses and fashion has followedsuit. In the spring/summer 2003 shows,the battlebetween the stiletto and the sneaker was played out between Yves Saint Laurent, where Tom Ford had a Freudian fashion moment; and Yohji Yamamoto, who rolled out his firstY3 collaboration with Adidas.

title: Reopening the Ports
description: President Bush rightly intervened yesterday in the labor dispute between shipping companies and dockworkers that has shut down operations at 29 West Coast ports. The disruption of a substantial amount of the nation's trade posed a serious threat to an already ailing economy.

title: Thurmond Castigates Judiciary Chairman
description: Senator Strom Thurmond told the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee today that he was ''hurt and disappointed'' by the chairman's postponement of a vote on the judicial nomination of a former Thurmond aide.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 2 Accused In Shooting Of Policeman
description: The police arrested two men in connection with the shooting and wounding of an off-duty Newark police officer who the authorities said tried to stop them in the course of a street robbery and stolen-car spree in which they stole two cars. Officer Michael White, 38, a seven-year veteran of the police department, was shot once in the groin and was listed in stable condition late yesterday. Samad Brown, 23, of East Orange, was arrested and charged with attempted murder. Also arrested on illegal weapons charges in the case was Rasheed Miller, 32, of Irvington. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.F.L. To Run Tourism Commercials
description: The National Football League will run free advertisements promoting tourism in New York City during the remainder of its 2002-3 season, beginning on Sunday. The advertisements, which city officials estimate will reach 120 million people, are worth about $4 million in paid commercial television time, N.F.L. officials said. The advertisements feature football fans with painted faces from various cities with N.F.L. teams praising New York. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: 2 new books scrutinize a traditional Gallic obsession : Why France disdains America
description: PARIS:  Two new books by French authors, one at the top of the best-seller list, the other described as a work of exceptional scholarship, are confronting the French with the proposition that their anti-Americanism is a self-inflicted national illness.

title: Another Welcome to the Club
description: The chairman and chief executive of American Express voiced his support yesterday for the inclusion of women as members at Augusta National Golf Club. The executive, Kenneth I. Chenault, is the latest Augusta member to make public his endorsement of the campaign by the National Council of Women's Organizations to persuade the club to admit women by next year's Masters.

title: Campaign Season; In Minnesota, Recipes for Victory?
description: Mary Kiffmeyer, running for her second term as Minnesota's secretary of state, is concentrating on bread-and-butter issues. Cinnamon-honey-butter, to be precise. The back of the business cards she passes out at political rallies has her recipe for the special butter, which she makes with honey harvested from bees on her property in Big Lake: 1 pound butter, 3/4 cup honey, 2 or 3 tablespoons cinnamon. Whip together for two minutes. Refrigerate.

title: Judge Denies Bail for 5, Citing Community Safety
description: A federal judge here refused bail today for five of the six men accused of being members of a sleeper cell of Al Qaeda, but agreed to free one under a set of stringent conditions that limit his movements and ability to communicate.

title: Human Rights Law at Work
description: ROBERT L. LIEFF, a 1961 graduate of Columbia Law School, and his partners at Lieff, Cabraser, Heimann & Bernstein have donated $1.5 million earned in litigation with Swiss banks over Holocaust-era assets to endow a clinical human rights chair at the school. MORRIS A. RATNER, the firm's lead lawyer on such cases, said it was important that the money go for a clinical chair rather than an academic chair, ''so they won't just be studying human rights in the classroom but will be working on behalf of human rights victims.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Banker Signals Steady Rates
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, told the European Union's economic and monetary affairs committee that he felt interest rates in Europe were appropriate, disappointing those who were hoping for a cut. In a speech in Brussels, he reiterated the central bank's focus on maintaining price stability and reminded the member governments to ''finally embark on ambitious structural reform programs'' in response to the slow growth in the euro zone. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Human Rights Law at Work
description: ROBERT L. LIEFF, a 1961 graduate of Columbia Law School, and his partners at Lieff, Cabraser, Heimann & Bernstein have donated $1.5 million earned in litigation with Swiss banks over Holocaust-era assets to endow a clinical human rights chair at the school. MORRIS A. RATNER, the firm's lead lawyer on such cases, said it was important that the money go for a clinical chair rather than an academic chair, "so they won't just be studying human rights in the classroom but will be working on behalf of human rights victims."

title: East and West Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Food Unit Sold
description: Novartis, the Swiss chemical company, said it had sold its food and beverage division, which includes Ovaltine, known as Ovomaltine in some countries, to Associated British Foods for 272.5 million Euros ($267.2 million). Novartis had said in February that it wanted to divest itself from nonessential divisions and concentrate on its core business of pharmaceuticals. The sale of its worldwide food and beverage business, which does not include the United States or Puerto Rico, needs regulatory approval. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: McCall Letters Surfaced After G.O.P. Made Copies
description: The State Republican Party spent nearly $500 on photocopies at the New York State Archives two days before The New York Post published the first of a series of letters from the archives written by H. Carl McCall.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the last line was truncated in the Arts Abroad article yesterday, about Martin Cruz Smith and his novel ''December 6.'' The article ended with a quotation from Mr. Smith: ''The trick is to walk around Tokyo with your eyes open so you can see the variety in the multitude, not the sameness.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Suspect In Girls' Killing To Stand Trial
description: A court ruled that a school custodian accused of murdering two 10-year-old girls this summer in a case that gripped the country was mentally fit to stand trial. Ian Huntley, 28, is accused of murdering Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman in August. His companion, Maxine Carr, 25, has been charged with conspiring to pervert the course of justice in connection with the killings. Mr Huntley was moved from a high security hospital to a prison. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arts Club Official Pleads Guilty
description: The manager of the National Arts Club dining room has confessed to stealing more than $160,000 in state and city sales taxes, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. The manager, Joseph Frappaolo, pleaded guilty Monday to third-degree larceny, admitting that he had skimmed sales taxes collected for club functions between September 1998 and September 2001. He agreed to repay the money, which, with interest and penalties, comes to about $340,000, Mr. Morgenthau said. A separate investigation into the financial affairs of the historic Gramercy Park club and its principals is continuing. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ELIZABETH ''KATE'' (BALL)
description: DAVIS - Elizabeth ''Kate'' (Ball) of Orleans, September 21, 2002, 84. Beloved wife for 54 years of Charles S. Davis of Orleans. Mother of Charles S. Davis III and wife Betsy of Los Angeles, CA. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, October 19th at 11 o'clock at The Federated Church of Orleans, 162 Main Street, E. Orleans, MA. There are no visiting hours and burial was private. Memorial donations can be made to the Cape Cod Symphony Orchestra, 712A Main St., Yarmouthport, MA. 02675, to the League of Women Voters of Cape Cod Chatham, MA. 02633, or the Association for the Preservation of Cape Cod P.O. Box 398 Barnstable, MA 02630. For information Richard Davis Funeral Homes of Plymouth and Manomet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: President Retiring at Newspaper Group
description: The Newspaper National Network in New York, a sales and marketing division of the Newspaper Association of America, said that Nicholas Cannistraro Jr., president and general manager since 1997, would retire at the end of the year.

title: Soccer at Haverford: More Than a Game
description: Christy Morris sat in the stands at Haverford soccer matches, his slender frame slightly stooped, his face wrinkled, one of many old men who attended every home game, when he was first spotted in the early 1960's by Greg Kannerstein, then a freshman.

title: Ohnesorg Resigns Post in Berlin
description: Editors' Note Appended

title: Excerpts From the Debate in the Senate on Using Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate on Iraq yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators James M. Jeffords, independent of Vermont; Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho; Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana; Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut; and John McCain, Republican of Arizona.

title: Republicans See Opening for the State Senate in Brooklyn
description: As he stood behind the turnstiles on a rattling elevated subway platform in Brooklyn yesterday morning, State Senator Vincent J. Gentile encountered few if any riders who had time to stop and speak. So, Mr. Gentile, a three-term Democrat, was left to bark out a few salutations at his constituents.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Sony Invests $20 Million In PalmSource
description: Palm Inc. said yesterday that Sony had made a $20 million minority equity investment in PalmSource, Palm's software division, which is scheduled to be spun off as a separate company within three months. Sony now owns approximately 6 percent of Palm's software unit. Sony, the second-biggest consumer electronics maker, will also expand its business and technical collaboration with PalmSource as part of the deal. PalmSource makes the operating system software for hand-held devices and mobile phones. The latest version of the software, Palm OS 5, was released in June. Sony, which makes the Cli personal organizer, has licensed Palm's operating system software since 1999. Palm has been looking for deals that will help it expand its market presence and lift its stock price, which was once $165 a share. Shares in Palm rose 6 cents, to 67 cents. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Korean Stocks Feel Pinch From Troubles in U.S.
description: Korea's stock index, until recently the star of Asian markets, has gone so sharply downhill that corporations and the firms that invest in them wonder if another bubble is bursting.

title: Rebuilding Defense May Be Focus Again
description: Last season, some Jets took offense when it was suggested that, with a new coaching staff, everyone was auditioning for a job.

title: We, the People of Lower Manhattan . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Hearing In Paramilitary Case
description: The man accused of heading the Real I.R.A., the dissident republican group that killed 29 people in a car-bomb attack in Omagh in 1998, appeared in court for preliminary hearings before he is tried on charges of directing a terrorist organization. Lawyers for Michael McKevitt, 51, are questioning the admissibility of evidence from David Rupert, an F.B.I. agent who infiltrated the paramilitary group. Prosecutors said Mr. Rupert would provide details of the paramilitary group's leadership meetings, including plans for an Internet hacking unit and a possible assassination attempt on Prime Minister Tony Blair. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: A Turbulent Awakening From a Dream Come True
description: As befits an actress defending a stage by herself, Charlayne Woodard has a full arsenal of high-voltage facial expressions, looks specifically programmed to melt frozen audiences. But the one that probably serves her best at the Manhattan Theater Club, where her ''In Real Life'' opened last night, is a smile that mocks itself.

title: Lautenberg Plays Offense With Attacks On Forrester
description: After months of answering questions about Senator Robert G. Torricelli's ethics and a week fending off legal challenges to prevent Frank R. Lautenberg from replacing him on the ballot, Democrats finally found themselves in a position today to play offense in New Jersey's United States Senate race.

title: A Melding of Residential and Commercial in One Shop
description: Geoffrey P. Wharton has spent most of his professional life in commercial real estate, most recently as the managing director of the World Trade Center redevelopment program for Silverstein Properties and before that as manager of the renovation of Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building for Tishman Speyer Properties.

title: Smoky. Hot. Crowded. Inspirational.
description: One way people who watch fashion only on television get gypped is that they see mostly runway shots. To really appreciate these spectacles, a phenomenon peculiar to our time, you have to be there.

title: Hot Way to Cool Off
description: If President Bush faces any downside to seeking an injunction to end the West Coast port shutdown, it is that he will face the wrath of organized labor.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: The Play's His Thing, Even if You Never Heard of It
description: CONSIDER, now, the unglamorous problems of Dan Wackerman, artistic director of the Peccadillo Theater Company, which produces forgotten and rarely seen American plays.

title: Chinese Court Overturns Death Sentences of Christian Leaders
description: In a rare reversal for a politically sensitive case, an appeals court has overturned the death sentences given last December to five leaders of a defiant evangelical Christian group, court officials in Hubei Province said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about trouble in the homeowners insurance industry, which has become an issue in the campaign for governor in Texas, included an erroneous reference from The Dallas Morning News to Gov. Rick Perry's relationship with an insurance company and referred incompletely to the policies the company sold. Mr. Perry left as an unpaid advisory board member of the company, Citizens Inc., in April 1996, but was not a director when a class-action suit alleges the company committed fraud, after August 1996. And the company sold life insurance, not home insurance.

title: People
description: * Robert Philpott, director at Asia Market Intelligence, Hong Kong, part of Aegis Research, was named chief executive at a sibling, Market Facts, Arlington Heights, Ill. He succeeds Larry Labash, who left. Aegis Research is part of the Aegis Group.

title: An Ode to Sloppy Joe, a Delicious Mess
description: SOME foods are memory triggers, meals that send you back to long-forgotten moments in your life. The sloppy Joe sandwich is one such time machine. Finding it on the menu at Drew Nieporent's sunny version of the neighborhood deli, TriBakery, took me back to the lunchroom of my elementary school in Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, JOSHUA AARON
description: ROTHSTEIN-Joshua Aaron, 15, tragically struck by an automobile. Infinitely cherished son of Steven and Nancy (nee Horwich). Adored brother of Caroline and Natalie. Dear grandson of Adrienne and the late Joshua Rothstein and Layne and the late Harris Horwich. Beloved nephew of Ken (Sarah Schoen) Rothstein, Jeff Rothstein, Judy (Doug) Wertheimer, Laurie (David) Matasar. Loving cousin of Jamie, Tracy, Scott, Jonathan, and Mikey. Services Thursday 10:30 AM at North Shore Congregation Israel, 1185 Sheridan Rd., Glencoe, IL. Interment Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to The Food Allergy Initiative, 625 Madison Ave., 4th Floor, New York, NY 10022. Info Piser Funeral Services, (847) 679-4740.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: FORD TO OFFER SIRIUS RADIO SERVICE IN '03 The Ford Motor Company will begin offering radio and news programs from Sirius Satellite Radio in some cars in 2003. Sirius's shares rose 17 percent. This is Ford's first statement on when it plans to install the radios since it struck its initial agreement with Sirius in June 1999. The service will be sold for some Ford, Lincoln, Mercury, Jaguar, Volvo and Land Rover cars, the companies said in a statement yesterday. Sirius and its rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings , deliver music and news via satellite to car stereos for a monthly fee. They are both seeking agreements with automakers in a bid to add customers and become profitable.

title: State Gives Empire Blue Cross Approval for a For-Profit Switch
description: The New York State Insurance and Health Departments gave final regulatory approval yesterday to the latest plan by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, a nonprofit insurer, to turn itself into a profit-making company.

title: Giants' Duels in the Sun Were Nearly Too Much
description: Keith Hamilton and Michael Strahan have taken about 10,000 snaps together in the N.F.L., many more in practices, and in one wearied moment late in last Sunday's game, Hamilton glanced at Strahan, both broiling in the Texas heat.

title: Sprewell Still Focal Point For Knicks
description: One day after fining Latrell Sprewell $250,000 and barring him from practices and games, Scott Layden, the Knicks' president and general manager, gave him assurances that his future was still in New York.

title: 2 Accused of Storing Stolen Remains for Rituals
description: A Newark man and his son were charged with desecration of graves and possession of stolen property today after a police search of their home turned up a cauldron holding human skulls and other bones that investigators suspect came from a spate of recent grave and mausoleum robberies here.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rally By Kin Of The Kidnapped
description: About 60 elderly people demonstrated in Seoul against North Korea, trying to burn a North Korean flag and a photograph of Kim Jong Il, the country's leader. They demanded that South Korean leaders try to find out what happened to relatives who they say were among several thousand South Koreans kidnapped and taken to North Korea since the Korean War. Demonstrators said President Kim Dae Jung had failed to tackle the issue while pursuing his policy of reconciliation with the North. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: As Teachers Back Pataki, McCall Questions Motives
description: As Gov. George E. Pataki picked up the endorsement of the teachers' union in Yonkers -- and with the New York City teachers' union expected to follow suit imminently -- H. Carl McCall joined several educators yesterday to denounce the governor's education record.

title: Pale Cranberries, Picked Before Ripeness, For Understated Turkeys
description: No, it's not too early to start thinking about Thanksgiving, especially if you might go for something a little different this year, like white cranberries. The berries, actually a pale yellowish green, are picked before they fully ripen and turn red. You might think they would be more astringent than a red berry, but the ones harvested by American Cranberry in South Jersey are not, and they have a nice herbaceousness besides. American Cranberry dry-harvests its berries instead of flooding the bogs and scooping up the floating fruit, so the berries do not spoil as readily. They can be frozen. Gourmet Garage stores sell white cranberries for $4.99 a quart. Use them for a relish. It won't stain the tablecloth.

title: Robert H. Fust -- Municipal Advocate, 78
description: Robert H. Fust, who was executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities for two decades and built it into an effective advocate for the state's cities and towns, died on Oct. 4 at a hospice in Denver. He was 78.

title: Wines of the Week
description: Since October is National Pizza Month, it's time to lift a glass  and a slice  in honor of the humble cheese pie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLEUNING, DOROTHEA
description: SCHLEUNING-Dorothea. A lovely lady will be remembered with love by the members of the former Faculty Wives Club of Polytechnic University.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Lucent And MetroPCS Extend Pact
description: Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, said yesterday that MetroPCS, a wireless carrier based in Dallas, had agreed to extend a purchasing agreement. MetroPCS, which provides wireless service in Atlanta, Miami, San Francisco and Sacramento, will buy equipment valued at $190 million through 2004. MetroPCS specializes in providing unlimited local calls for a flat monthly rate of $35. The deal is an important win for Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., and is struggling to recover from a decline in sales. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Anthony Mazzocchi, 76, Dies; Union Officer and Party Father
description: Anthony Mazzocchi, a longtime union official who was a pioneer in the occupational safety movement and the founder of the six-year-old Labor Party, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, NANCY
description: NICHOLS - Nancy. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sadness the loss of their great friend, Nancy Nichols. From her personal generosity to her hand in shaping our staff, her mark on the institution is indelible. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, New York

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sales Up At Clothier
description: Pursuing a recovery, Marks & Spencer, Britain's biggest clothing retailer, said second-quarter sales rose 10 percent, twice the rate forecast by analysts and ahead of the 7.7 percent growth reported in the first quarter. The leap surprised investors after Next, Marks & Spencer's rival, reported falling sales a week ago, blaming unseasonally warm weather. Marks & Spencer's shares rose by as much as 7.2 percent. Its sales have grown for five consecutive quarters after several years of decline. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Sept. 23 with an article about Afghan women who were learning to read and write referred incorrectly to the lesson written on a blackboard in a class in northern Afghanistan. The chalked characters were numbers, not letters.

title: 3 Scientists Win Nobel Prize in Chemistry
description: Three scientists share this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing techniques to identify and map proteins, carbohydrates, DNA and other large biological molecules.

title: Packing in the Murder and Masochism
description: The new Off Broadway musical ''Call the Children Home'' has been crammed into the tiny theater at Primary Stages like too many towels stuffed into a dryer. Maybe that's why it's such a soggy and unwieldy bit of business. The close quarters don't help, that's for sure. But it's unlikely that the show could ever find a theater with enough air in it to elevate this long-winded and convoluted tale involving murder and revenge, whoremongering and extortion, racism and masochism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHET, LUCILLE A.
description: BLANCHET-Lucille A., 92, of New York City, on October 7. Mother of Lucille Conklin, Beverly Reiss, Margaret Ann Blanchet, Sr. Rosamond Blanchet, RSHM, and Carole Brown, 11 grandchildren and 12 great grandchildren. Visitation 7-9PM Thursday, John Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass 10AM Friday, Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ. Entombment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Las Vegas Makes Shopping a Sport
description: Construction of shopping centers has slowed to a crawl in the rest of the country, but not here, where shopping, not gambling, has become the fastest-growing game in town.

title: Global War Against AIDS Runs Short of Vital Weapon: Donated Condoms
description: Donations of condoms from rich nations to poor ones, already deeply inadequate, have declined over the past decade, just as a few countries have successfully used them to fight the ever-worsening AIDS epidemic.

title: SBC SAYS IT IS LOSING BUSINESS TO PHONE RIVALS
description: SBC Communications, the local-telephone service provider for the Midwest and the West, said yesterday that its profit per share would be at the low end of the range it previously forecast for this year as it loses customers to rivals. Full-year profit, before one-time costs, will be $2.26 a share, matching the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, SBC said. The company said in July that its profit would be $2.26 to $2.35 a share, down from a previous estimate of as much as $2.51. SBC, which is based in San Antonio, said that it had lost about 4.2 million lines to competitors.

title: The Struggles of Democracy and Empire
description: A year after a tiny band of religious zealots managed with stunning audacity to mutilate the face of America, the world's sole superpower trembles on the threshold of a new imperial season. That America, despite its great power, ''goes not abroad, in search of monsters to destroy,'' has been a cherished truism of our foreign policy, central to how Americans look at themselves and at their role in the world. Until yesterday John Quincy Adams's words could still be thought true. Tomorrow, if America invades and occupies Iraq, they no longer will be.

title: Mays Gives the Angels That Sinking Feeling
description: Do not overanalyze every misplaced pitch. Do not obsess over every mistake. Do not exacerbate a perilous situation by dwelling on what went wrong. Two days before the hardly imposing Joe Mays started for the Minnesota Twins in Game 1 of the American League Championship Series, Manager Ron Gardenhire offered him that advice.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Seafood in Midtown

title: David Charnay, 90, TV Production Chief
description: David B. Charnay, former chief executive of Four Star Television Productions, died last Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 90 and lived in Calabasas, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KONKOY, WILLIAM J.
description: KONKOY-William J. Forever in my heart

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Sell New Office Software
description: Microsoft, which is trying to reverse slowing growth in its Office suite of software, will announce a new Office program today that makes it easier for employees to add data into corporate programs and databases. The program, code-named XDocs, will be available in the middle of next year, said Scott Bishop, a Microsoft Office product manager. Microsoft's sales of Office and other desktop applications increased less than 1 percent, to $9.6 billion, in the 12 months ended June 30. XDocs will let companies create electronic forms that workers can fill out to add or update information automatically in various programs and databases and to circulate that data to co-workers. The software makes it easier to collect and share information with greater accuracy, Microsoft said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Al Qaeda type organizations, state sponsors of terrorism like Iran and the threats they pose to America are beyond the competence of the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. to address.''

title: Dropout Rate Is Climbing And Likely to Go Higher
description: WITH so much attention paid to test scores, an equally important gauge of school performance has mostly been overlooked. High school dropout rates seem to have jumped.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil's Front-Runner Gets Backing
description: Ciro Gomes, the last-place finisher in the initial balloting in Brazil's presidential election on Sunday, announced his ''unrestricted and enthusiastic support'' today for Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the leftist Workers' Party in a runoff scheduled for late this month.

title: How Much Trouble's That Nude in Window?
description: One after another the S.U.V.'s and luxury sedans pull up to the curb for a quickie. Windows glide down and necks crane out as the occupants guiltily ogle the scantily clad maiden before zipping away. Mothers strolling down Arnold Avenue are forced to shield innocent eyes as they pass the shop with the nudity in the window. Sometimes an outraged passer-by will poke a head inside to tell Dennis Foy that he is a craven pornographer.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: EAST TIMOR: AGREEMENT WITH INDONESIA The United Nations' newest member and its former ruler, Indonesia, agreed to settle border disputes by the middle of next year. "We agreed to finalize the negotiations on our land border, in particular the demarcation," said Indonesia's foreign minister, Hassan Wirajuda. After the tiny territory voted to split from Indonesia in 1999, pro-Indonesia militias killed more than 1,000 people, according to United Nations estimates, and some still exist in the border areas, leading to heavy security there. But East Timor's foreign minister, Jose Ramos Horta, said demilitarization of the border was now justified because the militia activity had stopped. (Reuters)

title: What's New This Season
description: CRACKDOWN ON OBSTRUCTION -- To improve the flow of the game and increase scoring chances, the N.H.L. plans yet another crackdown on obstruction tactics. This is not the first such attempt and probably will not be the last. The idea is to let offensive players skate more freely and to let defensive players forecheck more aggressively. If past crackdowns are a guide, skepticism is invited here.

title: INSIDE
description: Nobels for Three Physicists

title: Pentagon Links Kuwaiti Gunmen to Al Qaeda; More Gunfire Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The two assailants who killed a United States marine in Kuwait on Tuesday received training at an Al Qaeda camp in Afghanistan last year, and carried out their attack with methodical planning, Pentagon and American intelligence officials said today.

title: New Coach, With Classic Lines, Is Ready to Roll With Red Wings
description: From his leather bag, the new coach of the Detroit Red Wings pulled out a new book and placed it on his new desk in his new office. The title was ''Joe Torre's Ground Rules for Winners'' and the bookmark indicated that Dave Lewis was more than half-finished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLISH, HARRY J.
description: COLISH-Harry J. A resident of New York City died on October 7th. Mr. Colish wishes to thank his friends for the kindness and affection they have shown to him over the past few years, with special thanks to those friends with whom he was closest in his later life. Funeral services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Recipe: Roasted Red Beet and Red Onion Salad
description: Time: 1 hour 15 minutes

title: Scholarships for Future Doctors
description: Ten students at the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Engineering at the City University of New York Medical School have been awarded $30,000 scholarships for their next four years of medical studies. The Leonard and Sophie Davis Scholarships are awarded on the basis of academic achievement, financial need and a commitment to the medical field. All the recipients have pledged to work in areas of New York City.

title: Daniel Deverell Perry -- Architect, 97
description: Daniel Deverell Perry, a Long Island architect who created the marble temple of art housing the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., died Oct. 2 in Woodstock, N.Y. A longtime resident of Port Jefferson, N.Y., he was 97.

title: Excerpts From House Debate on the Use of Military Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Speakers included Representatives Ron Paul, Republican of Texas; Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California; Eddie Bernice Johnson, Democrat of Texas; Ellen Tauscher, Democrat of California; and Tammy Baldwin, Democrat of Wisconsin. Fuller excerpts are online at nytimes.com/national.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Farmers in Afghanistan Face Fields of Bombs
description: Maldud Halimi looked with dismay at the plowed field here and the ripening watermelons. ''This whole field is a cluster bomb site,'' he said. ''I told the farmer with my own tongue not to plant this field. It is very dangerous.''

title: Excerpts From the Opinion Allowing Closed Hearings
description: Following are excerpts from the opinion by a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit allowing closed deportation hearings, as well as excerpts from a dissenting opinion. The full text is online at nytimes.com/metro.

title: Law Firm Sued by Ex-Partner Over Statements
description: Frode Jensen, a former lawyer at Pillsbury Winthrop, sued the firm yesterday for sending out a news release last month that said his departure came ''on the heels of sexual harassment allegations'' and ''a significant decline in his productivity.''

title: Unwarlike Phrase Pleases Many Abroad
description: Whether President Bush intended it or not, much of the world praised his speech on Iraq on Monday not for its toughness but for its suppleness, lighting upon the idea that he might not be fixated on going to war after all.

title: Pakistan Stages 2nd Ballistic Missile Test
description: Pakistan carried out a second test today involving a medium-range missile designed to carry a nuclear warhead, military officials announced. The test was dismissed by India, Pakistan's nuclear-armed rival, as meaningless.

title: Rabbit, Gift-Wrapped in Ribbons
description: ''THE thing to do here is to get the meat started first,'' Barbara Lynch said, browning pieces of rabbit in a pan, ''and while it's sitting in the oven, where you can pretty much ignore it, make the pasta.''

title: Irish Protestant Leader Issues Ultimatum on Sinn Fein Ouster
description: David Trimble, the first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly, said today that he and his fellow ministers of the province's main Protestant party would stage a mass resignation that would cause the legislature to collapse unless Britain throws Sinn Fein out of the Assembly by early next week.

title: 3 Nobels for Solving Longstanding Mysteries of the Cosmos
description: Two scientists who used underground vats of water and cleaning fluid to see into the hearts of stars and a third, who deployed X-ray sensors in space to detect the invisible violence rattling the cosmos, won the 2002 Nobel Prize in Physics yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELWEG, THEODORE (TED)
description: HELWEG-Theodore (Ted), 78. Of NYC, on October 6. Husband of Ellen Robbins; father of Randall Helweg, Kristin Hanson, Gretchen Helweg/Carroll, Kimberly Garcia, Cameron Helweg; step-father of Susan Delepine, William, James, John & David Robbins; grandfather of eight. Served in the Army Air Force as a pilot in WWII, during the Korean War and in Minnesota National Guard. Retired from Citibank; formerly a managing engineer with Univac; held executive positions at Farrington, Ticketron, American Express. Memorial service in chapel at St. Bartholomew's, Park Ave. and 50th St, NYC, at 2PM on Tuesday, October 15. Memorial donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd., Bronx, NY 10461.

title: President Retiring At Newspaper Group
description: The Newspaper National Network in New York, a sales and marketing division of the Newspaper Association of America, said that Nicholas Cannistraro Jr., president and general manager since 1997, would retire at the end of the year.

title: Europeans Want Swiss To Tell All
description: The European Union has sharply stepped up the pressure on Switzerland to alter its strict banking secrecy laws and give its neighbors much more cooperation in catching tax evaders, threatening economic sanctions if the Swiss do not relent. But Switzerland is stubbornly resisting, saying its economic survival is at stake, and the European Union's 15 member nations are divided on how far to push the dispute.

title: Aguacate Journal; Cuba's Bittersweet Move to Trim Its Sugar Crop
description: The steam whistle that summoned generations of workers to the cavernous and bustling Rubn Martnez Villenas sugar mill is silent. Inside, amid a tangle of rusted pipes and man-size gears, the damp aroma of molasses has given way to the electric odor of sparks as welders dismantle the mill that long sustained not only this town, but a sizable slice of Cuba's economy.

title: Authors, but Not You
description: To the Editor:

title: Door Locked, Blinds Drawn, And Students Kept Inside
description: With helicopters rumbling above and police cars guarding access roads to schools, children returned to their classrooms today, many accompanied by parents holding fast to the sanity of normal routines at an insane moment: the day after a serial sniper shot a 13-year-old boy outside his school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLETTA, FRANK A.
description: BALLETTA-Frank A. How do I thank you for being such a great friend. Yours was the unique quality of taking care of your family and friends, and everybody's family and friends. I will always miss you. M.P.K.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, HOPE T.
description: BECKER-Hope T. Of New Rochelle, NY died courageously after a hard fight with liver cancer on October 2, 2002. A memorial mass will be offered at St. Michaels Church in Greenwich at 11:30 on October 11, 2002. Donations can be made in lieu of flowers to the Coast Guard at Gifting Alternatives Foundation, Hope Becker Fund, 45 Hunter Street, Ossining, NY 10562, or Jensen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main Street, Tuckahoe, New York 10562.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, SAM
description: SILVERSTEIN-Sam. Age 93. Devoted husband of Theresa. Father of Ellen and Michael. Grandfather of Aaron and Rebecca. For information ''Weinstein - Garlick - Kirschen baum'' Chapels 1-800-556-7799

title: Council Toils Over Wording Of Resolution Aimed at Iraq
description: The five permanent members of the Security Council negotiated hard today behind closed doors to forge compromises that might clear the way for the ''very different'' resolution on Iraqi disarmament that President Bush demanded on Monday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teacher Accused Of Sexual Assault
description: A junior high school teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that he forced a 13-year-old boy to perform a sex act in a closet at the school, the police said. Jose Segarra, 42, who told the police he had been a teacher for 22 years, was charged with first-degree sodomy and first-degree sexual abuse, said Lt. Christopher Stahly, the commanding officer of the Manhattan Special Victims Squad. The police said Mr. Segarra had sexually abused and sodomized the boy, a student, about 10 a.m. on Monday inside the school, Junior High School 117 on East 109th Street, and on two other occasions in the last two weeks. Mr. Segarra was arrested at the school, where he had taught since 1996. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Bilingual Education on Ballot in Two States
description: All across this Boston suburb, lawns are dotted with signs promoting candidates running in the election next month. But there is virtual silence on a ballot measure that could change the lives of more than 35,000 students in the state.

title: Ottawa to Ease Effect of U.S. Lumber Tariff
description: Canada announced an aid package today valued at 247 million Canadian dollars ($155 million) to help part of the nation's lumber industry and small sawmill communities overcome the effect of punitive duties on Canadian lumber that the United States imposed in May.

title: Met's 15th-Century 'Adam' Shatters as Pedestal Collapses
description: A 15th-century marble statue of Adam by the Venetian sculptor Tullio Lombardo crashed to the ground in the Velez Blanco Patio at the Metropolitan Museum of Art sometime Sunday evening, scattering its arms, legs and an ornamental tree trunk into dozens of pieces.

title: 9/11 Lessons Seen in Reaction to Sniper
description: When an unknown killer began mailing anthrax to East Coast targets last October, the government's slow and disjointed response set off recriminations from the White House and finger-pointing among investigators.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer's Death Believed a Suicide
description: A police officer who had just reported to her station house for roll call died of a gunshot wound to the head yesterday afternoon, in what the police said was apparently a suicide. The shooting occurred about 4 p.m. at the housing bureau station house at 2860 West 23rd Street in Coney Island, the police said. ''It was out of character,'' a police official said. ''No one knew she was depressed. No one can believe this.'' Her name was not released last night. The officer, who was born in 1973, had been in the department four years. She had a brother who is also a police officer, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, MARY T. (NEE DILLON)
description: ROBINSON-Mary T. (nee Dillon), age 72, died on Monday, October 7, 2002 at her home in Middletown, NJ. She was predeceased by her husband Francis X. Robinson Sr. in 1994, and her son Ned Robinson in 1995. Her late husband retired from Time, Inc., NYC, in 1986. She is survived by her three sons, seven daughters, four daughters-in-law, six sons-in law, 20 grandchildren, two brothers, one sister, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. For service, interment and donation information, please contact the John E. Day Funeral Home at (732) 747-0332.

title: Let's Hear It for a Homemade Potato Chip, Tangy, Smoky and Free at the Bar
description: Big, beautifully bronzed, randomly ruffled potato chips, crisp to be sure, are piled invitingly in bowls on the bar at @SQC, 270 Columbus Avenue (72nd Street), calculated to suggest a refill of that martini. They go beyond even the homemade chip. They are glazed with tangy four-year-old cheddar from Grafton, Vt., which the chef, Scott Campbell, lightly smokes in his kitchen, and they are sprinkled with Hungarian paprika. The potato chips are free at the bar but $5.50 an order at tables. They can also be bought to go, $5.50 for a big bag.

title: Supreme Court Hears Copyright Challenge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  No member of the Supreme Court had a good word to say today for the 1998 law that added 20 years to all existing copyrights. But that did not make the job any easier for Professor Lawrence Lessig of Stanford Law School, who faced an uphill battle to persuade the justices that the extension, which Congress adopted at the behest of the Walt Disney Company and other powerful corporate copyright holders, was not only bad policy but unconstitutional.

title: Bacon With Meat to It
description: THOUGH I've never met a piece of bacon I didn't like, not all bacons are created equal. Some are wafer-thin and salty, frying up like crunchy potato chips. Some are meatier and smokier, with a toothsome quality reminiscent of ham.

title: After 9/11, A Question Of Command
description: After the World Trade Center attack, New York City's police and fire officials came under criticism for lapses in command and communication in their response to the disaster. A private consultant told the city that catastrophes of this size required a unified command overseeing the numerous emergency agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, FRANCES FABYAN (FUZZ)
description: DAVIS - Frances Fabyan (Fuzz), of Tivoli, NY, 85, October 4 after a short illness. Predeceased by husband Howland after 60 years of marriage. Dedicated and untiring force in the service community with Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, Leake & Watts Children Services, Citizens Committee for Children and Havens Relief Fund. Member of Edgewood Club, Cosmopolitan Club and St. Nicholas Society. Survived by four children, Howland S. II, Robert L., George F., F. Dennie, five grandchildren, five great grandchildren. Services on October 11 at 11AM in St. Paul's Church, Tivoli, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either Leake & Watts Children Services, 463 Hawthorne Ave., Yonkers, NY 10705 or to Tivoli Free Library, One Tivoli Commons, Tivoli, NY 12583.

title: Science Teacher Gets Big Results at a Tiny School
description: Last year, 13,000 science projects were submitted to the Connecticut State Science Fair. Of the 97 finalists, 6 were from Hillel Academy, a tiny private school here whose entire science department consists of one woman: Karen Howell.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: SALES UP AT CLOTHIER Pursuing a recovery, Marks & Spencer , Britain's biggest clothing retailer, said second-quarter sales rose 10 percent, twice the rate forecast by analysts and ahead of the 7.7 percent growth reported in the first quarter. The leap surprised investors after Next, Marks & Spencer's rival, reported falling sales a week ago, blaming unseasonally warm weather. Marks & Spencer's shares rose by as much as 7.2 percent. Its sales have grown for five consecutive quarters after several years of decline. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Korea's Real Rage for Virtual Games
description: Throughout the year they have been dating, Jang Min Ji and Jung Tae Kyun have met almost every afternoon at online video game clubs, where they while away the hours zapping bad guys, dodging flame-breathing monsters or playing cards against anonymous strangers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Inquiry Into Tycoon Hired By North Korea
description: The government confirmed that it was investigating on suspicion of ''illegal activities'' the man North Korea chose to head a new capitalist economic zone but played down the possibility of a diplomatic rift with its neighbor. The foreign ministry spokeswoman, Zhang Qiyue, said Yang Bin, a Chinese flower tycoon with Dutch and North Korean citizenship, was under ''house supervision'' while the authorities look into his business dealings. She did not give details about possible charges. Ms. Zhang sidestepped questions about North Korea's response to the arrest but said China supports ''further cooperation'' between the countries to support economic development in the region. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: C.I.A. SEES TERROR AFTER IRAQ ACTION
description: The Bush administration pushed Congress today for a broad vote to authorize the president to use force against Iraq.

title: PepsiCo Reports Earnings Rose 14% in the 3rd Quarter
description: PepsiCo reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 14 percent on the strength of sales in its beverage division and cost savings related to the acquisition of Quaker Oats.

title: Two Chefs Free to Cook as They Please
description: LIKE the movies, the restaurant business thrives on the high concept. Just as a film called ''Gladiator'' suggests immediately that you are in for sweat and loincloths, many believe a new restaurant's name ought to telegraph its premise. Even casual diners can assume Le Bernardin is French, or Mesa Grill Southwestern. They may not be so sure about a restaurant called Babbo or Town, but once they enter the dining room and examine the menu, they are on solid ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKINSON, SAMUEL DEXTER
description: PARKINSON-Samuel Dexter. Age 80, of Lyme, CT, and formerly of Laurel Hollow, New York, died October 7th 2002. He was born August 7, 1922 in Stockton, California. His wife of 48 years Ann, children, Elizabeth Terry Smith and husband Brant, of Essex, CT, Louisa Evans and husband Robert of Fishers Island, NY, Andrew Parkinson & wife Elizabeth of Winnetka, IL., and Thomas Parkinson & wife Jennifer of Winnetka, IL, 11 grandchildren and his two sisters Nancy Brennan and Jean Carey, survive him. Services will be held on Friday, October 11th, at 11 A.M., St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, Connecticut. He was greatly loved and will be sorely missed.

title: Our Towns; Buffalo Cell? This Kind Has Steel Bars
description: THE judge played his moment for all it was worth.

title: U.S. Assesses Afghans' Needs
description: The secretary of health and human services, Tommy G. Thompson, arrived here today with a pledge that the United States would not abandon Afghanistan now that the Taliban are gone.

title: Library Grows at College in Bronx
description: Nearly 500 students, faculty and graduates of Manhattan College in the Bronx gathered outside the school's newly expanded library on Saturday for a dedication ceremony. Reopened in August as the O'Malley Library, it underwent extensive renovations over the last year, financed, in part, by a $7.5 million donation from THOMAS D. O'MALLEY, an alumnus and oil industry executive. Mark Glassman

title: What They're Eating on the Other Side of the World
description: An introductory course in the foods of the world could use "The Foodlover's Atlas of the World" by Martha Rose Shulman (Firefly Books, $35) as its textbook.

title: $3.4 Million for Teaching Fellows
description: The federal government has pledged $3.4 million to help pay for master's degrees in education for New York City Teaching Fellows. Until now, most teaching fellows -- people changing careers who agree to work in the city's toughest schools while the Department of Education pays for their master's programs -- have attended the City University of New York. The federal grants will help 800 fellows get master's degrees at private colleges and universities over the next five years. Abby Goodnough

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DORIS
description: MILLER-Doris. The Society for the Advancement of Judaism records with profound sorrow the death of our longtime, devoted member Doris Miller. We extend our condolences to her entire family. Michael Strassfeld, Rabbi Abraham Clott, Bd. Chm.

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: LUCENT AND METROPCS EXTEND PACT Lucent Technologies, the nation's largest maker of communications equipment, said yesterday that MetroPCS, a wireless carrier based in Dallas, had agreed to extend a purchasing agreement. MetroPCS, which provides wireless service in Atlanta, Miami, San Francisco and Sacramento, will buy equipment valued at $190 million through 2004. MetroPCS specializes in providing unlimited local calls for a flat monthly rate of $35. The deal is an important win for Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, N.J., and is struggling to recover from a decline in sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDREYER, CONSTANCE
description: GOLDREYER-Constance. A warm, loving and generous aunt. Afternoons at your house were our favorite. The kids adored you. You will be missed. Sally, Michael, Justy, Jake

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIEL, EUGENE E.
description: DANIEL-Eugene E. The Board of Directors and management of Catholic Guardian Society acknowledge with deep regret the sudden passing of our esteemed colleague, Eugene E. Daniel. He was both a valued member of our Board and a dear friend whose wisdom and support will be greatly missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Eileen, and their family. John P. Tricamo, President John J. Frein, Executive Director

title: Many Fear Mideast Unrest Could Force Up Oil Prices
description: Jacques Torres, host of the ''Watch Chocolate'' TV show on the Food Network, does not seem to have the type of job that would lead him to worry about a war in Iraq. After all, he is consumed by creating chocolates.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about three television networks' decision against broadcasting President Bush's speech about Iraq omitted a reference to one cable channel that did carry it. Along with MSNBC and Fox News, CNN covered the speech live.

title: Verdict Delayed for Dutch Nurse Charged With Killing 13
description: A Dutch court delayed a verdict today in the trial of a hospital nurse charged with killing 13 patients, saying it wanted to reinvestigate aspects of the ''complex'' case.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MERITAGE CORP., Scottsdale, Ariz., a homebuilder in the southwestern U.S., said it had bought the closely held Perma-Bilt Homes, Las Vegas, a builder of single-family homes, for about $46.6 million in cash and debt to expand its operations into the Las Vegas area.

title: 2 Americans Awarded Nobel for Economics
description: Two Americans have won this year's Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for trying to explain idiosyncrasies in people's ways of making decisions  research that occupies the nexus of psychology and economics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. The Trustees and staff of the British Museum, the Chairman and staff of the British Museum Development Trust and the Directors and staff of the American Friends of the British Museum, record with great sadness the death of Walter H. Annenberg. He was a great man and a much valued friend of Britain who left an indelible mark on British life, not least in the arts and education. Together with his wife Leonore he did so much to enhance the cultural scene in Britain, both during his Ambassadorship to the United Kingdom and indeed ever since. Mrs. Annenberg is President of the American Friends of The British Museum and a source of constant inspiration. Mr. Annenberg's generosity was of a unique scale, discriminating and matched by the passion with which he gave and the pleasure he derived from seeing the impact of his support. The professionalism he brought to his philanthropy was well known, as was the charm and sense of humour he was imbued with. The generosity of the Annenberg Foundation towards the British Museum has been of seminal importance, per manently recognised in the Walter and Leonore Annenberg Information Centre. This is located in the Museum's Round Reading Room, and epitomises the visionary support that characterised Walter Annenberg's philanthropy, and was most notably opened by HM The Queen. We send our heartfelt sympathy to Mrs. Annenberg and the Annenberg family. Sir John Boyd, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the British Museum Neil MacGregor, Director Lord Moser, Chairman British Museum Development Trust Judith Ogden Thomson Chairman of the American Friends of the British Museum

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: TAX BREAK APPROVALS

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: MACHINERY ORDERS FALL Orders for new machinery, a crucial gauge of business investment, had their worst decline in five and a half years as companies braced for another slowdown in the economy. Orders fell a worse-than-expected 13.6 percent in August from July, the first decline in five months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Hudson Valley Apple Farms Wrestle With Slim Pickings
description: THERE are hardly any apples at Breezy Hill Orchard here. A year ago Elizabeth Ryan, who owns Breezy Hill, a 45-acre farm in Dutchess County, walked aisles of Jonagold, Macoun, McIntosh and Golden Russet trees that groaned under the weight of their fruit. It was one of the best years ever, she said last week.

title: 2 Top Executives at Gemstar Resign After Pressure by Murdoch
description: Henry C. Yuen, chief executive of Gemstar-TV Guide International, and Elsie M. Leung, the company's chief financial officer, announced yesterday that they would resign.

title: Tribulation Worketh Patience
description: W.W.J.D. at the F.D.A.?

title: U.S. Marine Is Killed in Kuwait As Gunmen Strike Training Site
description: One United States marine was killed today in Kuwait and another was wounded after two gunmen infiltrated a military training exercise and attacked the troops in what Kuwaiti officials called a terrorist act.

title: U.S. Troops Were Subjected To a Wider Toxic Testing
description: Acknowledging a much wider testing of toxic weapons on its forces, the Defense Department says it used chemical warfare and live biological agents during cold-war-era military exercises on American soil, as well as in Canada and Britain, according to previously secret documents cleared for release to Congress on Wednesday.

title: Campaign Season; Diminished Outrage Over Political Travel
description: Four years ago, during the last midterm election campaign, President Bill Clinton and Vice President Al Gore barnstormed the country on behalf of Democratic Congressional candidates, just as President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney are doing for Republicans this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDSTON, LEONA B.
description: REDSTON-Leona B. On Oct. 7. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Robert D. Redston. Devoted mother of Terry Cohen and Audrey Iselin. Dear motherin-law of Rabbi Norman J. Cohen and David Iselin. Loving grandmother of Abby, Noah, Josh and Alex, and step-grandmother of Leora, Mali and Ilan. Dear sister of Mildred Bialor and the late Stanley Bell, and sister-in-law of Jacque Bell. Proud great grandmother of Emily Rina. Services at Ballard Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, Wednesday at 11 AM.

title: Washington Area Unites in Sniper Hunt
description: The suburban sniper who has killed six people with harrowing efficiency continued to elude a widespread manhunt today, with 195 detectives searching for any promising clue in thousands of tips and pleas pouring in from an alarmed public.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 2 Top Gemstar Executives Have Agreed to Step Down

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Legacy of Hell

title: Casino Earnings Decline
description: ALTON, Ill., Oct. 8 (Bloomberg News)  Argosy Gaming , an owner of riverboat casinos in the Midwest and South, earned less than analysts expected in the third quarter because of higher taxes and greater competition in Illinois.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Commentary : The ethnicity question:New York and Europe take different line
description: NEW YORK  When the designer Miguel Adrover mounted his spring 2003 runway presentation in September, he exuberantly reflected the most culturally diverse world that he could. From the look of his models to the sources of his inspiration, Adrover strove to portray the motley mix of New Yorkers that he saw in his day-to-day life. And on the New York runway, that is a rarity.

title: Breakfast as the New Cure-All
