description: IF you prefer Nestl's Crunch to kale crunch and think a potato salad is no place for a sunflower seed, you've probably never heard of Mollie Katzen. You wouldn't have responded to the singles ad, recently placed in a San Francisco weekly, in which a woman described herself as ''working out like Jane Fonda, looking like Holly Hunter and cooking like Mollie Katzen.'' But if you're on the Atkins diet, her recipe for green and white beans under garlic mashed potatoes would most certainly be your fever dream.

title: Supreme Court Seems Skeptical Of F.C.C. Position on Next Wave
description: The Supreme Court gave a skeptical hearing today to the Federal Communications Commission's contention that it acted within its rights in 1998 when it confiscated more than 200 valuable wireless communications licenses from NextWave Telecom, which had won them at auction but fell behind in its payments and filed for bankruptcy protection.

title: A Count of U.S. Jews Sees a Dip; Others Demur
description: A major survey released yesterday estimated the Jewish population in the United States at 5.2 million, a decline of 300,000 from 10 years earlier. Other studies last month had reported figures of more than 6 million.

title: More Wine for the Tasting: One Shop Moves to a Larger Space And Another Finds Its Niche
description: The Burgundy Wine Company in Greenwich Village seemed almost like a private club, operating more from its newsletter than from walk-in trade, dealing less in that bottle for dinner than with case lots for the cellar, and specializing in the wines of Burgundy, the Rhne and Oregon. Now, it has moved to 143 West 26th Street, in a space three times as large as the original, and has not lost its focus. The owners, Geraldine Tashjian (top, left), and Albert L. Hotchkin Jr., display about 200 wines, and with the additional space they are planning more tastings and other events.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Possible Computer Services Merger
description: Two European technology services companies, CMG and Logica of Britain, confirmed yesterday that they were considering a merger. Once archrivals, the two companies have turned to each other to get through the global meltdown in technology, analysts said. Both companies install and manage corporate computer systems, among other services, and a merger could help them reduce overhead costs. European stock exchanges reacted positively to news of a possible merger. CMG's shares rose 18.25 pence, or 46 percent, to 58.25 pence. The companies issued a statement stressing that merger talks were still in their early stages. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Survey Finds Loan Losses Rose Sharply
description: Loan losses continue to rise at banks and other institutions, mostly because of faltering telecommunications and cable companies, according to a survey by bank regulators released yesterday.

title: Campaign Season; Poll's Familiar Refrain for Bush
description: A survey of voters in the 40 most competitive Congressional districts by the Republican pollsters Fabrizio, McLaughlin & Associates found that 68 percent had a favorable view of Mr. Bush and only 28 percent had an unfavorable one. Opinions about Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the majority leaders, were more mixed. Mr. Daschle's score was 31 percent favorable, 35 percent unfavorable. Mr. Gephardt's was 34 percent favorable, 28 percent unfavorable.

title: An Affectionate Tribute to an Artist's Artist
description: A mystery. Elusive. Isolated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Takeover Expected
description: Shares of Abbey National rose 3.5 percent to 5.54 ($8.60) on the hope that it would receive other takeover offers now that it has rejected an approach from the Bank of Ireland. Abbey National's executives were concerned that the Bank of Ireland was trying to take advantage of its weakened position, given that the approach came while Abbey was searching for a new chief executive and while its shares remained depressed, a person close to the bank said. Analysts said they expected other suitors to appear. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Louisville Wins Behind Ragone
description: Dave Ragone led Louisville to three touchdowns in the third quarter last night and the Cardinals hung on for a 38-32 victory at Memphis.

title: PUTNAM HIRES A CO-CHIEF OF INVESTMENTS
description: Putnam Investments said yesterday that it had hired Charles E. Haldeman Jr., the chief executive of Lincoln National Corporation's money management business, to become its co-head of investments. Mr. Haldeman, 53, will share his new role with Steve Oristaglio, currently Putnam's deputy head of investments, the company said. Both executives will report to Lawrence J. Lasser, Putnam's president and chief executive. Putnam, which is based in Boston, is owned by the Marsh & McLennan Companies. Lincoln National, which is based in Philadelphia, said Jude Driscoll, currently head of fixed income, was named interim chief executive of Delaware Investments and Lincoln National Investment Companies.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Accused Of Hauling Drug Cache
description: A man and a woman were charged yesterday with transporting 182 kilograms of cocaine from Texas to New York City hidden inside a couch aboard a U-Haul trailer. The drugs were discovered after the trailer was abandoned. The Texas couple, Eddie Gutierrez and Susan Hernandez, were arrested in El Paso last month, and federal charges were filed yesterday, the authorities said. If convicted, each would face a maximum sentence of life imprisonment. The trailer was discovered by a police officer in April on Second Avenue, where it had been abandoned. The truck had parking tickets dating to March 28, and Mr. Gutierrez's name was handwritten on the trailer's temporary Texas license plate. U-Haul took the trailer back and left the couch for trash. Sanitation workers discovered the cocaine. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESS, MARION
description: RIESS-Marion, 90, on October 5, 2002. Beloved and devoted wife of the late Chester Riess. Cherished mother of Claudia Wasserman and Jonathan Riess, grandmother of Eric Wasserman, Lise Luftschein, and Christopher Morgan-Riess, great grandmother of Emily and Brian Wasserman, and Danielle and Gabrielle Luftschein. For 25 years, until her retirement in 1980, Marion headed the circulation department of the Library of Long Island University's Brooklyn Center. She will be dearly missed and remembered always by those touched by her love, wisdom and charm. A private memorial service will be held at the Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice of Cincinnati, 4310 Cooper Road, Cincinnati, OH 45242

title: The Nays Won't Have It; The Ayes Talk Anyway
description: Borrowing a bit of historical gravity from a previous century, Representative David Dreier, Republican of California, invoked the struggles that led to the Civil War. Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York, made comparisons to the 1991 Persian Gulf debate.

title: Martha Stewart and Kmart Hold Fast, for Now
description: Only a few months ago, the new management of Kmart went out of its way to sing the praises of Martha Stewart, who designs an exclusive line of housewares, garden tools and other products for the chain.

title: From Candy to Chromosomes in Cambridge
description: Making the grandest entry into the Boston area real estate market in memory, the Swiss drug maker Novartis has leased 764,000 square feet of costly lab space, much of it for 45 years. It will invest about $750 million to develop, equip and staff what will be the Novartis Institute of Biomedical Research.

title: Artist Guilty in Tax Case
description: An artist renowned for carving gemstones into sculpture pleaded guilty yesterday to evading more than $650,000 in city and state taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANTZ, LEROY JR.
description: FRANTZ-Leroy Jr., 74. Longtime Greenwich resident. October 5th at his home in Washington Depot, CT. Beloved husband of Sheila. Father of Ted, Scott, Chris, Stephanie, Joanie and Heather. Services at St. Barnabas Church in Greenwich, today, 11AM. Donations to New Milford Hospital Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENN, GERARD D.
description: GLENN-Gerard D., 74. Of Park Ridge, NJ on Tuesday, October 8, 2002. Beloved husband of Margaret (nee Bock). Devoted father of Thomas Glenn of No. Haledon, NJ. Dear brother of Floria Dignam of Asbury Park, NJ. Funeral Mass 9:30 Thursday at Our Lady of Mercy R.C. Church, Park Ridge, NJ. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9PM Wednesday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. Interment George Washington Memorial Park Paramus, NJ. In lieu of flowers kindly make donations to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087. Before retiring, Gerard was a Printer for Virgil Mountain Press, NYC for many years. He was a former Governor of the NY Athletic Club, NYC and an 8 time winner of the National 3-Cushion Billiard Championship. He was a U.S. Army Veteran of World War II.

title: EchoStar's Gain Could Be Cablevision's Gain, Too
description: Charles F. Dolan may have lucked out.

title: Where Autumn's Longest Shadow Is a Gunman's
description: For seven strange days, each more jittery than the last, a macabre lottery has been playing in Washington and its well-groomed suburbs.

title: Sometimes Even the Mayor Would Prefer a Squeegee Man
description: A cast of accomplished actors is having a good time on the stage of the Kraine Theater in the East Village.

title: Pay Heed, Wine World: Parker's Watching
description: EVERYBODY knows about Robert M. Parker Jr. Everybody, that is, who has ever pulled a cork, squeezed a grape or bought or sold a bottle of wine. He is the former Baltimore lawyer who, through the pages of his innocent-looking every-other-month newsletter, The Wine Advocate, holds sway over the wine business from Sonoma to Stellenbosch, from Montrachet to Monterey, from the Barossa Valley to Burgundy. He may even be, as The Los Angeles Times decreed in a flight of soaring hyperbole, ''the most powerful critic of any kind, anywhere.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGGERT, MICHAEL LOUIS
description: BIGGERT-Michael Louis, 47. Of Manhattan, died suddenly over the weekend at his home. Son of the late Colonel Joseph Biggert and the late Lynda Jean Biggert (nee Simmons). A graduate of Brooklyn College with a career spanning over 20 years, Michael recently retired as an assistant vice president of Spear, Leeds, Kellogg in New York City. An avid technology and science fiction fan, Michael was generous and loving with his family and friends. He is survived by two sisters, Linda Howell of Albuquerque, Judith Weinberg of New Rochelle and a brother, Joseph of Santa Fe. Also surviving are a niece, four nephews, two great-nieces and one greatnephew. Visitation at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. & 76 St, Thursday 2-4 & 6-9pm. Funeral Services at the 5th Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55 St, 1 PM Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 23 with an article about Afghan women who were learning to read and write referred incorrectly to the lesson written on a blackboard in a class in northern Afghanistan. The chalked characters were numbers, not letters.

title: Germany Opens New Front on Joblessness
description: Few Germans give Chancellor Gerhard Schrder high marks for economic policy. But even his critics concede that the chancellor, who narrowly won re-election last month, is an agile politician.

title: Trend-setting new illustrators making a mark
description: LONDON  From the editorial pages of style magazines to the luxurious world of ready-to-wear, hand-sketched fashion plates are back in vogue as an effective alternative to the glossy fashion photograph.

title: KINDER MORGAN PROFIT ROSE 32% FOR QUARTER
description: Kinder Morgan, the pipeline operator that controls Kinder Morgan Energy Partners L.P., said yesterday that profit rose more than expected for both companies during the third quarter. Kinder Morgan profit exceeded 63 cents a share, up more than 32 percent, and the energy partnership's profit exceeded 44 cents a unit, a jump of more than 17 percent, the company said. Kinder Morgan did not provide more details. Both companies expect profit this year to exceed the forecasts of analysts. Kinder Morgan Energy plans to raise its fourth-quarter cash payout to 62.5 cents a unit from 61 cents, the company said. The companies are based in Houston.

title: Radiant Art Honors a Murdered Reporter
description: When members of a committee at The Wall Street Journal began contemplating a memorial for their murdered colleague, Daniel Pearl, they knew that they did not want an ordinary plaque that would gather dust. Mr. Pearl was the Journal reporter who died after being kidnapped in Pakistan in January. He was investigating connections between Muslin extremists and Richard C. Reid, who pleaded guilty this month to trying to blow up a trans-Atlantic flight with explosives in his shoes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: Orders for new machinery, a crucial gauge of business investment, had their worst decline in five and a half years as companies braced for another slowdown in the economy. Orders fell a worse-than-expected 13.6 percent in August from July, the first decline in five months. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Chicken  l'Iraq
description: To be successful in dealing with Iraq, President Bush has to tread the most unusual line one could imagine for a statesman: He has to be wild, but not crazy.

title: National Briefing: South
description: TENNESSEE: TAX SYSTEM OVERTURNED

title: Two Games Tonight, Same Time
description: In a scheduling oddity, tonight's American and National League Championship Series games will be carried simultaneously by the Fox network on broadcast television and by Fox Sports Net on cable.

title: Campaign Season; Parties Predict Upsets for Governor
description: Nearly all the races for the House and Senate this year promise to be blowouts, but most of the 34 races for governor are competitive. That means upsets are likely. B. J. Thornberry, executive director of the Democratic Governors Association, and Kirsten Fedewa, spokeswoman for the Republican Governors Association, were each invited to pick three long shots, races where the conventional wisdom is that their party's candidate is losing but where they are betting their candidate will win.

title: Hold the Mayo. And the Rye Bread. Five Types of Mediterranean Tuna
description: This is not tuna to mash up with mayonnaise and pile on rye. The Sicilian tunas in olive oil packed in jars by La Compagnia dell'Olio, an importer in Miami, deserve a carefully assembled salade nioise. The fish is also worthy of a garlicky white bean salad or fresh-cooked bucatini, olives and herbs. There are five kinds: a rich, fatty ventresca, the equivalent of toro; succulent red tuna with cherry tomatoes or just in oil; and pale, more delicate, albacore and amberjack varieties. The jars, 10.58 ounces, are $16 to $26 at Dean & DeLuca, A. L. Bazzini and Fairway in Manhattan; Bierkraft in Park Slope, Brooklyn; and Sapori di Ischia in Woodside, Queens. Also available from www.vinoeolio.com.

title: Corrections
description: Part of a word was omitted yesterday from the transcript of President Bush's televised speech on Monday night. Discussing the danger of an Iraqi attack, he said, ''And of course sophisticated delivery systems aren't required for a chemical or biological attack; all that might be required are a small container and one terrorist or Iraqi intelligence operative to deliver it.'' (He did not say ''are required.'')

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Next Flight Is One-Way
description: A man who brought six knives and a box cutter past a checkpoint at O'Hare International Airport near Chicago last fall pleaded guilty to a federal weapons charge and will soon be deported to his home country, Nepal. The man, Subash Gurung, who also had a stun gun and pepper spray in his carry-on bag and two long hunting knives in his checked luggage, was trying to board a United Airlines flight to Omaha on Nov. 3. Mr. Gurung, 27, whose lawyers said he was suffering from mental illness at the time, was sentenced to six months in prison, which he has already served. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKING, DR. VIRGINIA NICHOLS
description: WILKING-Dr. Virginia Nichols, died in Greenville, DE on October 7. Virginia Center Nichols was born in NYC on Jan. 13, 1920. She was educated at the Brearley School in Manhattan and graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1941. Dr. Wilking received her medical degree from the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1944. After post-graduate training at Columbia Presbyterian she received board certifications in psychiatry, pediatrics and neurology. She served on the staff at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and was later director of the Child Psychiatry Clinic of the Frank Hague Center in Jersey City, NJ. Dr. Wilking was appointed Chief of Child Psychiatry at Harlem Hospital in 1963, where she remained until her retirement from full-time practice in 1982. Until 1999 she was a consultant in child psychiatry for the State of Delaware and worked on a part time basis at the Terry Center in New Castle, DE. Dr. Wilking is survived by her husband Leo; her sons, Spencer, Andrew, Leo and Frank; and her daughter, Nora. Funeral services will be held at St. Thomas Church at 5th Avenue at 53 Street at 11 A.M. on Thursday, October 10.

title: Campaign Season; The Legislature May Choose in Vermont
description: One of the oddest races for governor is in Vermont, where there are three strong candidates: a Democrat, a Republican and an independent. The Democrat, Lt. Gov. Douglas Racine, is expected to finish first, but is unlikely to win a majority. The governor would then be chosen by the newly elected state legislature on a secret ballot. Republicans will probably have a majority in the legislature. But the prevailing view is that the lawmakers will choose whoever finished ahead at the polls.

title: Clemens May Not Hit Milestones in Pinstripes
description: When he was 41, Nolan Ryan signed with the Texas Rangers for what would be the final stop of his remarkable career. Ryan won his 300th game, got his 5,000th strikeout and went into the Hall of Fame as a Ranger.

title: Less Brain Volume Found in Youths With Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
description: The brains of children and adolescents in whom attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is diagnosed are on average 3 percent to 4 percent smaller in volume than those of children without the condition, according to a large-scale government study whose findings were reported today.

title: Chief Refuses Comment on Tarot Card Reports in Sniper Hunt
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 9  The hunt for the suburban sniper became more macabre today with the unauthorized disclosure that the gunman may have left a Tarot death card openly challenging the police at the scene of his latest shooting Monday when a 13-year-old student was critically wounded.

title: World Briefing | World: Species Face Extinction, But Two Rise From Dead
description: Some 11,170 plant and animals species face extinction including the Iberian lynx, which could become the first cat species to die out in 2,000 years, the World Conservation Union said. The group, based in Switzerland, said that the most threatened mammals and birds lived in Brazil, China, India and Indonesia. Plants are dying out most rapidly in South and Central America, Africa and Southeast Asia. Two species believed to be extinct have been rediscovered, the group said. The last Lord Howe Island stick insect of Australia was not devoured by rats in 1920, and the Bavarian pine vole did not die out in 1960. At least 60 have been found in Austria. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Former F.B.I. Director Faults Lawmakers on Terror Fight
description: Former Director Louis J. Freeh of the F.B.I., who has been blamed by some in Congress as failing to grasp the threat of terrorism in the 1990's, faulted lawmakers today for failing to approve bigger budgets that he said were vital to the F.B.I.'s antiterror effort.

title: Merrill Lynch Will Cut Back Nasdaq Trading Drastically
description: Two years after paying more than $900 million to buy a company that specialized in trading Nasdaq stocks, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would merge the business into its trading operation and shrink the number of stocks it trades by 76 percent.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Tax Break Approvals
description: The House Ways and Means Committee approved bills that would provide tax breaks for investors, sending them to the House floor for a vote that could come as soon as Friday. The legislation would allow investors to deduct more of their capital losses on their income taxes, allow workers to contribute more to 401(k) and individual retirement accounts and give retirees more flexibility about when to withdraw money from the accounts. In the Senate, the Democratic majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, announced that his party would hold a forum on Friday to draw attention to economic issues. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Germ Warfare Tests In U.S. Are Disclosed
description: The Defense Department used chemical and live biological agents during cold war-era military exercises on American soil, as well as in Canada and Britain, according to documents cleared for release today to Congress.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Bit Smaller Party

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESS, BELLE
description: PRESS-Belle. Beloved mother, wife, grandmother, sister and aunt. Services Gramercy Chapel, 152 2nd Avenue, Wednesday, October 9 at 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNGOLD, POLA
description: KORNGOLD-Pola. Of NYC. Passed away September 21, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Israel Korngold. Devoted mother of Manya, Aaron and Marsha. Cherished motherin-law of Barry and Israel. Proud grandmother of Daniel, Lauren, Lisa and Eric. Her zest for life, courage and caring will be deeply missed. In life she was an astute businesswoman and delighted in world travel. As she was a survivor of the Holocaust, the family asks that contributions be made to Simon Wiesenthal Center, Shoah Foundation, or Holocaust Museum, Washington, DC.

title: Selig Takes In a Game In Hostile Territory
description: The Minnesota Twins took batting practice in a nearly empty Metrodome today and the Anaheim Angels followed them, but Commissioner Bud Selig did not witness any of it. Selig did not see a Twins fan with a banner that said, ''Contract-ulations,'' a way of congratulating Minnesota and reminding everyone that Selig tried to eliminate the Twins before their magical season started.

title: Sleepless and Wordless, He Leaves 'Em Speechless
description: With Charlie Chaplin as his grandfather and Eugene O'Neill as his great-grandfather, it seems only natural that James Thirre should be pulled hither and yon by the forces of light and darkness.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Cantonese Old-Timer Changes Boroughs, Not Bean Sauce
description: FOR 30 years or more, Sun Lok Kee sat at the bottom of Mott Street, near the Bowery, serving fine and inexpensive Cantonese meals late into the night. For at least the last 15 of those years, the restaurant was no more than a squalid, fluorescent-lighted hole, with worn linoleum and surfaces stained to the color of sesame oil, nicotine or Scotch.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Hewlett In Supply Deal With Home Depot
description: Hewlett-Packard said yesterday that it had won a deal to supply 40,000 personal computers for use in 1,456 Home Depot stores, beating out Dell Computers for the account. An executive for Hewlett-Packard told Bloomberg News that the contract was worth ''tens of millions of dollars.'' The Evo D150 computers, made by Compaq Computer, with which Hewlett just merged, are to be used primarily to upgrade and standardize computers inside Home Depot stores, and they will also be used for electronic and online training for store employees. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: A Storyteller Tells His Own Story; Garca Mrquez, Fighting Cancer, Issues Memoirs
description: He had always been the most disciplined of writers, sitting early in the morning before his trusty Macintosh, the magical, poetic words that have defined Latin America spilling from his head. That part never changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, LESTER
description: WEISSMAN-Lester. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our long time member, Lester Weissman, husband of Vivian. Heartfelt condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi Stuart Himmelfarb, President George Bean, President Barry Zeveloff, President

title: Recipe: Steaks Marinated With Mustard, Garlic and Bay Leaves
description: Time: 25 minutes plus 2 hours' marinating

title: Before the Pumpkins Come the Pucks
description: The National Hockey League begins its 2002-3 season tonight with protective netting at both ends of the ice and a commitment to quicker games with more offense. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish. By JASON DIAMOS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, EMMANUEL J.
description: KRAMER-Emmanuel J. Of Lake Worth, Florida, passed away on Monday afternoon, October 7. He was the beloved husband of Sally Kramer to whom he was married 60 years. Wonderful father of Howard, David and Fred Kramer and loving brother to Ruth Perlman and Helen Bader. Cherished grandfather of Nathaniel, Katie, Idria and Jarrett. Services will be held Wednesday afternoon, October 9 at Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, JOHN B.
description: ALFIERI-John B. Of New York City, died on Tuesday October 8, 2002, at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Born to Mary and Victor Alfieri on January 16, 1928. He graduated Bronx High School of Science, University of Notre Dame, and Brooklyn Law School. He practiced commercial and international law for fifty years, recently leading Alfieri, Frohman and Primoff, and serving on The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Disciplinary Committee, and The Board of Governors of The Metropolitan Club. The winner of The Ellis Island Medal of Honor Award, and The Order of Merit Award from The Italian Republic. He is survived by his former wife, June Nigro Alfieri, three sons, John, of New York City, Tony, of Coral Gables, FL, and Michael, of Larchmont, NY, and three grandchildren, Amelia, Adrin, and Angelina. Funeral Service at The Church of Saint Thomas More on Friday October 11, 2002 at 10 A.M. at 65 East 89th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The John B. Alfieri Fellowship Fund at The University of Miami School of Law Center For Ethics and Public Service.

title: Understudies With Crunch
description: GREEN papaya salad is a standard in Vietnamese restaurants, and though its makeup is transparent -- shredded unripe papaya, bean sprouts, herbs, a lime nam pla dressing and some form of protein -- I had made it only once or twice. This wasn't because I didn't crave it, but because green papayas are not commonly sold in supermarkets, and even the Asian groceries in my area don't often stock them.

title: Giants vs. Cardinals
description: This is the third time in the eight-year history of the wild-card format that baseball is one round away from an all-wild-card World Series. It hasn't happened, but the Giants would be happy to join the Anaheim Angels in making this year's World Series a first.

title: Court Upholds Secret Hearings On Deportation
description: The federal appeals court in Philadelphia ruled yesterday that the Bush administration had acted lawfully in holding hundreds of deportation hearings in secret based on its assertion that those detained might have links to terrorism.

title: Review/Fashion; At Saint Laurent, A Nod to Surrealism
description: As the spring 2003 ready-to-wear season ended, Tom Ford gave a Surrealist rendition of ''The Vagina Monologues'' in a collection for Yves Saint Laurent that fell short of his creative powers, while Karl Lagerfeld breezily led a master class in sporty chic at Chanel.

title: House Passes Bill on Medical Technology
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  The House passed a bill today to speed the approval and marketing of a new generation of medical technology that promises better diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses.

title: Congress Limps Toward Home
description: Although the majority leader, Tom Daschle, threatens to keep the Senate in business until Election Day, the 107th Congress is running out of time to redeem its thin, disappointing legislative record. Congress approved useful measures on trade, corporate reform and, barring last-minute snags, ballot reform. It failed completely to deliver on its promises for a patients' bill of rights, prescription drug coverage, welfare reform and an innovative energy strategy. Even vital measures directly related to Sept. 11 -- bills providing for homeland security and terrorism insurance -- have stalled over needless ideological bickering.

title: Trottier Is Ready to Coach After Years of Patience
description: Bryan Trottier was prepared to wait. Even as he was passed over for National Hockey League head coaching jobs time and again, Trottier stayed patient, and he says he actually could have waited some more.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Home Video column in Weekend on Friday about the film ''Big Bad Love'' misstated the director's name. He is Arliss Howard, not Harold Arliss.

title: No Bail for 5 in Buffalo
description: A federal judge in Buffalo refused bail for five men accused of being members of a sleeper cell of Al Qaeda. He agreed to free a sixth under a set of stringent conditions that limit the defendant's movements and ability to communicate. The judge cited ''clear and convincing'' evidence that the men had attended a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan in 2001.

title: Taking On Iraq: The President Makes His Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Lie-Detector Tests Found Too Flawed To Discover Spies
description: In a report to the government, a panel of leading scientists said yesterday that polygraph testing was too flawed to use for security screening. The panel said lie-detector tests did a poor job of identifying spies or other national-security risks and were likely to produce accusations of innocent people.

title: For the makers of cool, a hip vs. heritage dilemma
description: LONDON  Refreshing a fashion house that's lost its bloom of youth is not dissimilar to contemplating cosmetic surgery. The luxury goods industry uses "cool" the way society dames use Botox. Injecting too little cool into an ailing label is ineffectual. Too much is freakish and freezes the lifeblood of the label.

title: G.M. SAYS COST-CUTTING IS INCREASING PROFIT MARGINS
description: The General Motors Corporation is increasing profit margins this year through cost-cutting and sales of more expensive models, its chief executive, Rick Wagoner, said yesterday. The company is benefiting from rebates and no-interest loans that draw affluent customers to new models like the Hummer H2 and Cadillac Escalade sport utility vehicles, with prices that start at $48,000, he said.

title: Leader of Islamic Charity Charged With Funding Al Qaeda
description: Saying "it is sinister to prey on good hearts to fund the works of evil," Attorney General John Ashcroft announced in Chicago today the indictment of the leader of an Illinois-based charity on charges of providing money for terrorist organizations.

title: Click to Download Scores By New American Composers
description: In March 1939 Aaron Copland convened a meeting of activist New York composers at his studio on West 63rd Street in Manhattan to discuss challenges facing American music and strategize. Like his colleagues at that gathering (Otto Luening, Harrison Kerr, Marion Bauer, Quincy Porter and Howard Hanson), Copland believed that after decades of struggle, American music was finally overcoming the widespread assumption that composers of concert music by definition must be European.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: OFFICER'S DEATH BELIEVED A SUICIDE

title: A Mansion Attracts Art Lovers; Thieves Love It, Too
description: The art and antiquities division of the Irish police gave art lovers reason to rejoice late last month. Their raid on a house in Dublin recovered two paintings -- Thomas Gainsborough's ''Madame Baccelli'' and Bernardo Bellotto's ''View of Florence,'' together valued at about $3.4 million -- that had been stolen in 2001 from Russborough House, a sprawling 18th-century countryside estate in Blessington, about 20 miles southwest of Dublin.

title: Fairfield Exchange With Russia
description: Over the next three years, 12 professors from four universities in Russia will spend a semester each at Fairfield University learning about American culture and teaching methods under a program sponsored by the State Department. The university, in Fairfield, Conn., received a $294,806 federal grant for the program. For the last three years, Fairfield has had an exchange program that sent professors to Herzen University in St. Petersburg for two weeks. Lia Miller

title: WorldCom's Board Won't Oust Member
description: The board of WorldCom discussed removing one of its own directors, Stiles A. Kellett Jr., at a meeting yesterday, but essentially concluded that it did not have the power to do it, people close to the company said.

title: U.S. Presses for Total Exemption From War Crimes Court
description: A top State Department envoy left for Europe today to try to persuade several governments to ignore a recent European Union compromise on the international criminal court that would exempt only some Americans from prosecution.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tripling of Profit Reported
description: NASHVILLE, Oct. 8 (Bloomberg News)  American Healthways , a provider of services for diabetes and heart-disease patients, said fiscal fourth-quarter revenue rose 71 percent and profit more than tripled after the company sold more services to established customers.

title: C.I.A. Letter to Senate on Baghdad's Intentions
description: Following is the text of a letter dated Oct. 7 to Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida and chairman of the Intelligence Committee, by George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, about decisions to declassify material related to the debate about Iraq:

title: The Truth About My Dinner Party
description: A FEW years ago it would have been impossible to imagine New Yorkers leaving the city to shop for groceries. Outside the city were chains where exotic lettuce was more likely to mean romaine. Serious home cooks shopped at Greenmarkets for the best vegetables, Citarella for fish and Fairway for imported cheeses. When they needed paper towels and dish soap, they went to their local Gristede's or Korean grocer and bought in small quantities.

title: Zambrano Dismissed As MetroStars Coach
description: The MetroStars, one of only two teams in Major League Soccer not to make the playoffs this year, dismissed Octavio Zambrano as coach yesterday.

title: Day Care Teachers, 21 Months With No Contract, Threaten Strike
description: Workers who care for 60,000 children in New York City-sponsored day care have threatened to strike later this month because they have been unable to get a new contract.

title: News Corp. Expects 10% Operating Growth
description: The News Corporation, which last year had the biggest loss in Australian history, can achieve operating profit growth of at least 10 percent this fiscal year, its chief executive, Rupert Murdoch, said today.

title: Leader of Islamic Charity Charged With Funding Al Qaeda
description: Saying "it is sinister to prey on good hearts to fund the works of evil," Attorney General John Ashcroft announced in Chicago today the indictment of the leader of an Illinois-based charity on charges of providing money for terrorist organizations.

title: Alomar's Option Picked Up By Mets
description: As he searches for a manager, Mets General Manager Steve Phillips is also consulting with his staff about the makeup of next season's roster. Some moves do not have to wait for the new manager to be in place.

title: With a Burst of Violence, Voting Ends in Kashmir
description: With a final spasm of violence, voting in Kashmir's pivotal election -- staggered over three weeks to improve security -- concluded today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIMBOL, GERALD
description: CIMBOL-Gerald. The Jewish Labor Committee family, deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, Jerry Cimbol, extend heartfelt condolences to his devoted wife and our beloved friend and colleague, Natalie, their children Deborah and Jeff Weintraub, William and Robyn Cimbol, David and Sharon Cimbol, grandchildren Rebecca, Jacob, Michelle, Lauren, Sara and Josh, sisters Rose and Ruth. We will miss him and will always be grateful for his cheerful presence, and generous involvement in many areas as a volunteer consultant. Stuart Appelbaum, Pres. Avram B. Lyon, Exec. Dir

title: Superheroines vs. Crime in the Big City
description: Leaping from rooftop to rooftop above the dark streets of New Gotham, the crimefighter known as Huntress has everything a supermodern superheroine needs: smart-mouthed dialogue and a really great costume. The daughter of Batman and Catwoman, Helena Kyle transforms herself into Huntress with a black bustier, leather pants and a sheer, full-length black coat that Christian Lacroix might be proud of. She crouches and springs like a cat, flies like a bat and complains to her guardian when she can't find any peanut butter in the house, ''You try fighting the forces of evil when your blood sugar's low.''

title: Cameo Appearance by Iraq in a New Mexico Race
description: Steve Pearce, a decorated Air Force veteran who says his Democratic opponent is weak on Iraq, is a rarity in the national battle for the House, which seems focused on domestic issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDMAN, HARRY W.
description: RUDMAN-Harry W. Age 94, died Oct. 7, 2002. Survived by wife Judith, daughters Janet, Margery (Ormond) and Anita (Sid) & adored grandchildren Naomi, Jacob and Rachel. Professor Emeritus CUNY 1929-1977; author, historian & World War II Army Air Force Veteran. He wrote the history of the Fifth Air Force in New Guinea & Japan and specialized in combat intelligence. He survived a kamikaze attack and Dengue fever during the Leyte Campaign. Services will be held Thursday noon at Gutterman's at Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Exhorting The Spirit In Harmony
description: A singer was down on the floor among the audience at the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, lifting his voice in long, rasping hollers and clear, airborne declarations as he strolled through the dancing crowd with a helper. He wasn't a rocker working a mosh pit. He was a blind gospel singer in his 70's, Jimmy Carter of the Blind Boys of Alabama, and as he praised the Holy Ghost and called out ''Do you feel the power?,'' he seemed to grow more vigorous with every exhortation. It was gospel music as incantation and ecstatic possession, perfected by experience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CYMBOL, IRWIN P.
description: CYMBOL - Irwin P., 65. Passed away October 7, 2002. Loving father of Todd and Bradley Cymbol. Cherished father-in-law of Nina Cymbol. Devoted husband. He will be remembered in the early years for his dedication and sacrifice to his sons on and off the playing fields. In the latter years, for his courage, strength and determination. The Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, October 9th at 11:15AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, N.Y.

title: PRESIDENT INVOKES TAFT-HARTLEY ACT TO OPEN 29 PORTS
description: President Bush intervened in the 11-day shutdown of 29 West Coast ports today, successfully seeking a court order today to halt the employers' lockout of 10,500 longshoremen, because the operation of the ports is ''vital to our economy and to our military.''

title: New York's Mentally Ill Deserve Better
description: It's bad enough that thousands of patients have been released from New York State psychiatric hospitals without plans for their continued treatment or follow-up by state workers. It's worse still that hundreds of them are being locked in special unregulated units of nursing homes without the chance to contest their confinement. These patients -- there may be as many as 1,000, but state officials can't say for sure -- aren't violent. Nor are they a threat to themselves or others, the standard for involuntary confinement. They're just the inconvenient byproduct of the state's shameful efforts to get out of the mental health business.

title: Queens Parents Are Charged In Imprisonment of Teenager
description: The parents of a 15-year-old Queens girl were charged yesterday with unlawful imprisonment after the girl told the police that she had been confined to the family's Jackson Heights apartment almost constantly since January.

title: RAYTHEON PLANS TO LAY OFF 500 EMPLOYEES
description: The Raytheon Company said yesterday that it planned to lay off about 500 workers in Massachusetts and California to adjust for the loss of a satellite contract and to improve organization. Headquarters staff and engineers will be eliminated in Marlborough, Mass., and El Segundo, Calif., starting next month, a spokeswoman, Amy Hosmer, said. They account for less than 1 percent of the company's work force of 77,500. Raytheon, which is based in Lexington, Mass., said last month that it would split its military and air-traffic control work into seven businesses.

title: Fireplaces, Alfresco
description: The outdoor fireplace, long regarded as a California fixture, is catching on elsewhere, often in a portable form.

title: A Warehouse of Contemporary Goods
description: Hip Brooklyn homesteaders will now have their own ABC Home store, in a warehouse in Dumbo.

title: An Experiment, Finished
description: Pure architectural theory rendered on a domestic scale.

title: Prize-Winning Profiles
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Girl, 15, Raped By Student, Police Say
description: A 15-year-old girl was raped by another student in the basement of Sheepshead Bay High School yesterday afternoon, the police said. At about 2 p.m., she went with a 16-year-old she knew to the basement of the school, at 3000 Avenue X. He then raped her and ran away, the police said. The victim was taken to Coney Island Hospital for observation. The police said they were still looking for the boy last night. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Winds Are Light, Cup Rivalry Remains Heated
description: Racing in the America's Cup challenger series was postponed Wednesday for lack of wind on the Hauraki Gulf. But while breezes were in short supply, hot air was not.

title: Sour Notes for Reed And the Twins' Defense
description: The hand-drawn banner hanging from the upper deck along the left-field line was new to the Metrodome, but the nickname on it was not. Frank Viola, the former Twins pitcher who threw out the ceremonial first pitch tonight, answered to Sweet Music in the late 1980's, after leaving St. John's University. But for Game 2 of the American League Championship Series, the banner identified a new one: Rick ''Sweet Music'' Reed.

title: Chief Vents Full Spectrum of Emotions
description: In the frustrating manhunt for the suburban sniper, Chief Charles A. Moose has cycled a gamut of emotions, from humor to tears to outspoken worry that the stress among the residents he is sworn to protect here in Montgomery County has been ''ramping up'' with each of the six, and possibly seven, deadly shootings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, KENNETH M.
description: KRAUS-Kenneth M. On October 8, 2002. Of Lattingtown, L.I. Adored husband of Susan. The best dad to Elizabeth and Gisbert, Jennifer and Elan. Our most cherished friend now and forever. He is also survived by his mother, Marion Kraus and his brother Robert Kraus. He will always be in our thoughts and in our hearts. Services Friday, 12 Noon, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, L.I.

title: House Passes Iraq Resolution With 296 to 133 Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 - The House voted convincingly today to authorize President Bush to use force against Iraq, while the Senate gave its own strong show of support by clearing the way for the measure's final passage.

title: Man Beaten and Left for Dead By Grandchildren, Police Say
description: A stroke victim's granddaughter and his three young grandsons have been accused of beating him after he refused to divulge his bank card PIN, and then trying to bury him alive in a South Jersey woods, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook; The 20th Next Wave Is a Lot Like The First
description: Anniversaries are artificial, especially when they are trumpeted by a performing-arts institution for promotion and fund-raising. Every five years can be the milestone for another round of self-celebration. Hence the much-trumpeted 20th anniversary of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival provokes a slightly cynical response at the outset. They're no doubt already gearing up for the 25th.

title: WHX TO CLOSE FACTORIES IN NEW JERSEY AND ENGLAND
description: The WHX Corporation, whose Wheeling-Pittsburgh steel unit filed for bankruptcy protection in 2000, said yesterday that its Handy & Harman business would sell a stainless-steel-wire plant in New Jersey and one in Britain, eliminating 100 jobs. The closings, in Willingboro, N.J., and Liversedge, England, will result in $7 million to $8.5 million in costs for the third quarter, and $4 million to $4.5 million in severance costs for the fourth quarter, WHX said. The company will keep open its plants in Cockeysville, Md., and Oriskany, N.Y., a spokeswoman said. WHX, based in New York, also said it would have an additional third-quarter expense of $5 million for excess inventory and ''doubtful accounts'' from telecommunications customers.

title: Touch and Tell in Philadelphia
description: AN interactive show that lets visitors touch materials and test household products, and then offer feedback, opens tomorrow at the Philadelphia University Design Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARELL, CONSTANT
description: DARELL - Constant. Died peacefully on October 5, 2002 in New York Presbyterian Hospital after a brief illness. Devoted husband of the late Hedy (nee Gunther), to whom he was married for fifty-six years. Beloved father of Edward, loving father-inlaw to Joan. Proud grandfather of Jason and Nicholas. He was a man of remarkable intelligence, strength and resourcefulness, qualities that helped him and Hedy face dangerous and difficult times in wartime Poland. Though he was constitutionally unable to crack a smile before a camera, he had a warm and generous heart, a fine sense of humor and a gift for telling stories far into the night. He was a complex and compelling man and will be greatly missed. His remains have been cremated and a memorial service is planned for the future. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to the Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 E. 65th Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10021.

title: A Ballet Heritage, But No Fear Of the New
description: The San Francisco Ballet, one of the world's great classical dance companies, returned to City Center on Tuesday night with New York premieres by Christopher Wheeldon, Mark Morris and Yuri Possokhov, better known as the troupe's Bolshoi-trained dramatic star.

title: National Briefing | South: Kentucky: Ban On Ten Commandments Monument
description: A monument bearing the Ten Commandments may not be displayed on the State Capitol grounds in Frankfort, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled. The court held that the size and placement of the monument conveyed official endorsement of a religious message, an action the court said violated the First Amendment. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Researchers Test Old Smallpox Vaccine, Just in Case
description: Jesse Grey, a 24-year-old graduate student in chemistry at Vanderbilt University, rolled up his sleeve today, and Dr. Kathryn Edwards scrubbed his upper arm with a gauze pad soaked in acetone.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Congressional election in New Mexico's Second District misstated criticism made by the Democratic candidate, John Arthur Smith, against his opponent, Steve Pearce. Mr. Smith said that as a state legislator, Mr. Pearce always voted against the state budget, not for it.

title: Changing Channels, On the PC
description: AMONG the members of the Society of Working Americans Resenting Microsoft (Swarm), the chief gripe is that Microsoft has gotten obscenely rich by exploiting the innovations of others. Such people grumble that Microsoft rarely breaks new ground on its own.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the testing of chemical and biological agents by the Pentagon during the cold war referred incorrectly in some copies to the panel headed by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, who called on the government to assist any veteran made ill by the tests. He is chairman of the House Veterans' Affairs Committee, not of its subcommittee on health.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Oil Chief Arrested
description: The former director of Mexico's state oil company, Pemex, was arrested in Houston and faces extradition in a corruption investigation. Rogelio Montemayor, a fugitive since May, faces charges of funneling tens of millions of dollars from Pemex to the Institutional Revolutionary Party during Mexico's 2000 presidential election campaign. The party's candidate, Francisco Labastida, was defeated by President Vicente Fox. Four of Mr. Labastida's campaign aides are under investigation. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Arguments in Copyright Case
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the arguments today before the Supreme Court in Eldred v. Ashcroft, as recorded by the Alderson Reporting Company. The Times has supplied the identities of the justices because that information is not part of the transcript.

title: Accounts
description: * National City Corp., Cleveland, to Campbell-Ewald, Warren, Mich., to handle its account, estimated at $10 million to $15 million, which had been at Doe Anderson, Louisville, Ky. Campbell-Ewald is part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, JOHN B.
description: ALFIERI-John B. Of New York City, died on Tuesday October 8, 2002, at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Born to Mary and Victor Alfieri on January 16, 1928. He graduated Bronx High School of Science, University of Notre Dame, and Brooklyn Law School. He practiced commercial and international law for fifty years, recently leading Alfieri, Frohman and Primoff, and serving on The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Disciplinary Committee, and The Board of Governors of The Metropolitan Club. The winner of The Ellis Island Medal of Honor Award, and The Order of Merit Award from The Italian Republic. He is survived by his former wife, June Nigro Alfieri, three sons, John, of New York City, Tony, of Coral Gables, FL, and Michael, of Larchmont, NY, and three grandchildren, Amelia, Adrian, and Angelina. Funeral Service at The Church of Saint Thomas More on Friday October 11, 2002 at 10 A.M. at 65 East 89th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The John B. Alfieri Fellowship Fund at The University of Miami School of Law Center For Ethics and Public Service.

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: At Ever-Contrary Augusta, Even Ike Didn't Hold Sway
description: It was 1956 and Cliff Roberts, the longtime domineering chairman of Augusta National Golf Club, was feeling pressure from an authoritative source: President Dwight D. Eisenhower, who just before his second term took the floor at a meeting of the club's board of governors.

title: Jets Hash Out Comments on Pass Rush
description: Free safety Damien Robinson addressed the rest of the Jets' defense today to clear the air about comments he made Monday in which he said the team needed to improve its pass rush to have a better defense. The remarks, which were widely construed as finger-pointing at the defensive line, angered the defensive coordinator Ted Cottrell, to whom Robinson also spoke.

title: The Collections / Paris : An exceptional season offers imagination and creativity
description: PARIS  A monumental Paris season is winding down and spring/summer 2003 will remain in the collective fashion memory as the strongest in at least a decade. There has been an overall dynamism and energy not seen in fashion  meaning clothing  since the handbag took over.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Gov. James E. McGreevey's effort to fire New Jersey's poet laureate, Amiri Baraka, over his references to Jews in a recent poem referred imprecisely to the role played by the New Jersey Council for the Humanities and the State Council on the Arts in his selection. While they jointly appointed and advised the independent selection panel, the councils remained officially neutral; they did not endorse Mr. Baraka.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Upper Nyack: Student Charged In Fatal Plunge
description: A student at a school for troubled children was charged with second-degree murder yesterday in the fatal plunge of his roommate from a second-story window, the Rockland County district attorney's office said. The student, Ian Sinovoi, 17, is accused of pushing Jeremy Gaulin, 15, last Thursday evening from the window of the dormitory room the two shared at the Summit School for only a day or two, said Michael E. Bongiorno, the district attorney. Mr. Gaulin of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., suffered head injuries and died on Saturday at Nyack Hospital. Mr. Sinovoi, of Manhattan, was first charged with assault. But yesterday a Rockland County grand jury indicted him on a murder charge. Investigators were still searching for a motive. ''There was no conflict that we can uncover so far,'' said Sgt. Bernard Cummings, a detective in the Clarkstown Police Department, which covers Upper Nyack. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSON, SHEILA R. (NEE WASSERMAN)
description: ALSON-Sheila R. (nee Wasserman). Devoted mother of Rebecca and Jesse AlsonMilkman. Caring mother-inlaw of Craig. Beloved daughter of Rosaline. Loving sister of Carol and Pamela. Fond sister-in-law of Robert and Michael. Dear aunt of Melissa and Daniel. Also survived by many loving friends in many places. Services Friday 10:30AM-12 Noon at Beth Abraham Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker St, NY, NY. Tel: 212-614-2300. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, L.I.

title: Democracy by Force
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Utility Reform Advances
description: A disputed plan to overhaul Russia's vast electricity grid passed an early hurdle today in the lower house of Parliament. The Duma, in a preliminary vote of 261 to 150, endorsed passage of a set of bills that would put the legal framework in place to reorganize the electricity monopoly, Unified Energy System. The company is one of the most actively traded on the Russian stock market. Minority shareholders, including foreign investors, have opposed the reorganization saying it will dilute their holdings. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: United Is in Separate Talks With Unions on Concessions
description: United Airlines said last night that it was starting to negotiate separately for concessions with each of its five unions, even though the unions had formed a coalition to present a single concession plan to executives.

title: Parents in Harrison Voice Safety Concerns to School Board
description: Dozens of parents gathered at a Board of Education meeting here tonight and voiced concern for their children's safety. School district officials assured them that they were taking measures to strengthen background checks on employees after two were discovered to have criminal records.

title: A Designer's Eye Directed at Brooklyn
description: Two weeks ago, J. R. Sanders, left, a designer of museum exhibitions, opened his second home-accessory shop. Called Extraordinary, it is on Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn, which he calls ''an up-and-coming avenue in Park Slope.'' (His first store is on 57th Street in Manhattan.) Among the selection of trays is a dried, varnished banana leaf (right) for $45 and a wood-framed mosaic of lacquered egg shells (inset right, $98). The Chinese poetry vase in porcelain (inset right) is $60. Extraordinary is at 195 Fifth Avenue (Berkeley Street), (718) 230-9503.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Combined AT&T And Comcast To Cut Jobs
description: AT&T and the Comcast Corporation said yesterday that 1,700 jobs, or 30 percent of the work force, would be cut at AT&T's cable unit based in Englewood, Colo., after the companies merge. The cuts, which were first announced to workers Tuesday in a memo, will mostly affect executive and management positions. The jobs of 675 employees will end once the deal closes. The remaining 1,025 workers will be laid off during the postmerger transition period. AT&T Broadband, which has about 40,000 employees nationwide, said the cuts were a result of redundancies. Comcast has about 38,000 employees, with 20,000 in the cable unit. The new AT&T Comcast, based in Philadelphia, would be the largest cable TV provider in the nation, with 22 million subscribers. Shares in AT&T fell 8 cents, to $10.75. Comcast shares fell 46 cents, to $17.40.

title: Big Hopes for Commuting by Bike
description: For decades the bicycle industry has drawn its inspiration from the racing world. But this year the stars of the industry's annual trade show, the International Bicycle Expo held here this week, were closer in spirit to Volkswagens than Ferraris.

title: Two Collectors Discover Quality In South America
description: Notus Arts, a new showroom near Boston, has antique colonial furniture and accessories from Brazil and Argentina. The owners, Julie Sherlock and her husband, Stephen Hurrell, started collecting South American furniture while traveling there. ''We found tremendous quality,'' he said, ''and they were as yet undeveloped as exporters.'' A Brazilian rosewood and cedar bench (inset) is $3,600; a Portuguese-colonial-style leather and hardwood chair (circa 1900) from Brazil is $300; contemporary coffee tables from Argentina, with braided leather tops, are 24 by 40 inches ($1,200) or 24 by 70 inches ($1,600). Notus Arts is at 11 Beach Street, Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass.; (866) 236-1070 or www.notusarts.com.

title: Islanders Keep Hunter On the Roster, for Now
description: Islanders right wing Trent Hunter was goaded by his teammates into shaving his head this week. He was going to be noticed anyway.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: An Increase in Advertising Drives a Rebound at Yahoo

title: Magazine Ad Pages Rose in September
description: The number of advertising pages in magazines rose in September after declining in August, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

title: Reviving Jolt for the Baroque
description: Cecilia Bartoli's fascination with Baroque and early Classical opera is particularly welcome, not only because the music itself deserves a reviving jolt from a superstar with a sincere interest but also because she sings this music with such a sense of excitement and joy. For anyone hoping to revive a forgotten repertory for large audiences that would be just as happy to hear her repeat Rossini and Mozart favorites for the rest of her career, those qualities are crucial. And Ms. Bartoli drew on them as well as a remarkable virtuosity when she sang arias by Vivaldi, Bononcini, Broschi and Gluck at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening,

title: Looking for a Leader, Looking to McDyess
description: Last season, when the Knicks were spiraling downward in their worst season in 15 years, the situation cried out for a leader to step forward. But as the Knicks shakily approach a new season, Coach Don Chaney said that there was no one in the locker room who could have done it.

title: Yahoo's Profits and Sales Are Better Than Expected
description: Yahoo Inc. posted better-than-expected sales and profits yesterday as it gained market share in both advertising and job listings from its rivals.

title: Conflict on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLS, NANCY
description: NICHOLS-Nancy. The Board of Directors, Scientific Advisory Committee, Fellows and staff of the Irvington Institute for Immunological Research extend their deepest sympathies to our friend and colleague, Rodney Nichols, on the untimely loss of his beloved wife, Nancy. Our heartfelt condolences are with his family at this difficult time. Mrs. John J. Veronis Chairman Patricia W. Chadwick President

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the Garden Q.&A. column on Sept. 12 misspelled part of the name of a yellow flower with petals turned back like those of a coneflower. It is Rudbeckia Herbstsonne, not Herbstonne.

title: Social responsibility is becoming a major selling point : Making clothes with a conscience
description: NEW YORK  Ruth Meza-Orozco, 23, works six days a week in a Taiwanese clothing factory in Managua's Free Trade Zone. On Sundays, she studies. "My salary doesn't help me with anything," said Meza-Orozco, who has been working in the Free Trade Zone since she was 18. "I don't even have a house."

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Accusation About Gov. Davis Backfires in California Race
description: In leveling an accusation of illegal fund-raising against Gov. Gray Davis this week, his Republican challenger, Bill Simon Jr., said pictures never lie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, SIDNEY
description: ROTH-Sidney. Beloved husband of Maria Roth died on August 20th, 2002. Loving husband, brother, brother-in-law and uncle. A simple, generous man with a firm handshake and an easy smile, he was most at home on the open road. He served his country with honor and distinction, first in the U.S. Army during W.W. II and then in the Cold War as a member of the Counter-Intelligence Corps. He is survived by: his wife, Maria, brother, Melvin, brother-in-law Rabbi Julius Neumann (Esther), sisters-in-law Lily Gruen (Rabbi Isadore), Dr. Elizabeth Neumann, nieces, Frances, Nina, Veronica and nephews, Stanley, Tully, and Jeffrey. His wit and laugh will be missed.

title: The New York Times N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: Based on games through Oct. 7.

title: U.S. INDICTS HEAD OF ISLAMIC CHARITY IN QAEDA FINANCING
description: The leader of a prominent Islamic charity was indicted on conspiracy and racketeering charges today in Chicago in what officials said was the most significant criminal case that federal officials have brought as they seek to shut down Al Qaeda's terrorist money pipeline.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ILLINOIS POWER, Decatur, Ill., a provider of electricity and a unit of Dynegy Inc., Houston, said it would sell its high-voltage 1,700-mile, electric transmission system to Trans-Elect Inc., Washington, an owner or general partner for 12,600 miles of transmission lines, for $239 million.

title: Moussaoui Condemns Jail Search
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9  Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks, says his trial preparations have been thrown into "chaos" as a result of the government's repeated search of his jail cell last summer for classified F.B.I. reports, according to court documents made public today.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Goverment Agrees To Resume Talks
description: The government has agreed to return to peace negotiations a month after calling a halt to them because of military victories by rebels in the south. Sudanese officials said they had recaptured the southern town of Torit from the Sudan People's Liberation Army, which said that the government had lost a series of important battles. Despite the continued fighting, analysts consider the talks a breakthrough in ending one of Africa's most intractable conflicts. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Realistic War Games

title: No E-Mail In Listings By Verizon
description: VERIZON has stopped offering residential telephone customers the option of adding an e-mail or Web address to their phone-book listings.

title: Citigroup Removing Officials From Salomon Unit
description: Citigroup said late yesterday that it was removing two executives from the stock research division of Salomon Smith Barney, its investment banking unit. The changes come at a time when the conduct of Salomon's analysts is under investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUTTENBERG, JERRY
description: SUTTENBERG-Jerry. At age 75, loving husband of the late Joyce and the late Liz, devoted father of Marla (Randy) Klein, Howard (Jill) Suttenberg, and Richard (Gwynne) Suttenberg, adored and cherished grandfather of Jenny, Danielle, Valerie, Stephanie, Joshua, Allison, and Lauren. We will miss your warmth, kindness, generosity, and humor. Services on Thursday, October 10th, 2002, 11:15 A.M. at the ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapel'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Guerrilla Warfare, Waged With Code
description: WHEN the reports started trickling out in early September, they were met with disbelief and then outrage among technophiles. The Chinese government had blocked its citizens from using the popular search engine Google by exercising its control over the nation's Internet service providers.

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: The Foreign Language of Computers
description: Two weeks ago, I wrote up a few "dumb user stories" from my days as a personal computer trainer, concluding that many of them were actually "dumb design stories." Then, last week, I reported that the flood of e-mail feedback was unanimous in agreement with that conclusion.

title: 2 Altered Genes Are Linked To Congestive Heart Failure
description: People who inherit common variants of two genes have 10 times the risk of developing congestive heart failure, a condition that afflicts five million Americans, researchers say.

title: Cardinals, in a Close Call, Place Rolen on the Roster
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9  As recently as Monday, the chances looked slim for third baseman Scott Rolen to remain on the Cardinals' roster for the National League Championship Series, which began tonight against the San Francisco Giants.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills One and Injures 12 in Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 10  The man slipped as he leaped at rush hour this morning for the bus's closing rear door, falling backward and striking his head on the pavement. So Baruch Neuman, the driver, set his handbrake and ran to help, with a medic who happened to be nearby.

title: Desperately Seeking French Legs
description: A YEAR ago we sat at our old kitchen table -- vintage 40's, all wrong for our renovated kitchen -- and dreamed up its replacement: just big enough for four elbows and a newspaper, with trestle legs to prevent knocked knees. Cozy but able to sustain chopping and kneading. And we wanted it before the holidays: a year later, as it turned out.

title: Macabre Clue In Sniper Case: A Tarot Card
description: The hunt for the suburban sniper grew more macabre on Wednesday with the disclosure that the gunman seemed to have left a tarot death card openly challenging the police at the scene of a shooting Monday in which a 13-year-old student was critically wounded.

title: Bristol-Myers Faces Inquiry In New Jersey Over Inventory
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb, already the subject of an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into its inventory practices, faces an additional inquiry on the issue by the United States attorney for New Jersey, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MARION FENNER (MICKY)
description: LEVY - Marion Fenner (Micky). After a long illness and a brave struggle. Adored wife and best friend of Richard F. Levy for 49 years. Beloved and wise mother of Laura (David) Slusher and Lenore (Paul) Lupie. Cherished sister of James Fenner and devoted grandmother to Jacob Benjamin Lupie. Funeral services will be held at the Boulevard Chapel in Hewlett, NY, Friday, October 11th at 2:15 P.M.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Asbury Park: $1.2 Billion Development Plan
description: The Asbury Park City Council on Tuesday formally introduced a $1.2 billion waterfront revitalization plan, the day after the city manager, a chief negotiator of the plan, resigned after admitting corruption charges. The plan calls for building a hotel, restaurants and about 3,200 condominiums. It is scheduled for a public hearing and vote later this month. The project's chief developer, Asbury Partners, would pay the city $7 million, which would go toward developing low- and middle-income housing, said James Famularo, assistant city manager. The Asbury Park city manager, Terrance D. Weldon, quit after admitting ''illegal acts'' on his second job as mayor of nearby Ocean Township. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: An Updated Compression Tool Is Handy for Viewing Old Files
description: It is not only in the Manhattan apartment market that space is at a premium -- many a hard drive has also suffered from overcrowding.

title: Memory Cards as Kin That Can't Get Along
description: Q. Digital cameras and other electronic devices come with so many different kinds of removable memory cards. Are any of them interchangeable?

title: Wired, Yes, but Drawing the Line
description: SATJIV CHAHIL stopped traveling with a laptop computer because he didn't want to be part of the teeming masses he sees in airports carrying black cases with Dell on the side.

title: NBC Will Replace Executive Producer at 'Today'
description: Despite racking up the biggest ratings lead over its rivals in five years, NBC's ``Today'' show will make a change in its most important production position, replacing the current executive producer, Jonathan Wald, an NBC executive said today.

title: Brickbats (And Praise) For Budget In Nassau
description: Nassau County legislators heard sharply contrasting reactions today to the county's proposed new budget: a Wall Street bond-rating company praised it, but the county's chief assessor said that it had illegal provisions.

title: Both Sides Explore Settlement In Suit Over School Financing
description: Lawyers on both sides of a suit accusing the state of shortchanging New York City's schools have agreed to explore a settlement.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Art of Expression

title: Nets' Team Chemistry Is Still Experimental
description: This time last year, the Nets barely knew who they were, let alone what they would become.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a survey by regulators that showed an increase in problem loans at banks and other institutions worldwide referred incorrectly to an 11 percent figure. That was the amount of the increase in such loans at United States banks -- not the share of soured loans held by American banks.

title: A North Wind Heats Up Manhattan
description: STUDENTS at the Parsons School of Design are studying the W Times Square Hotel, which opened in December. ''There is something about it that seems it's from some other place,'' said Wid Chapman, chairman of interior design at the school. That place would be Toronto.

title: Review/Fashion; Distress Signals, Pacing The Runway
description: In the eight years he has been turning out collections in Tokyo, Jun Takahashi, who showed here for the first time last week, has given them names far removed from the typical fashion show theme, say, ''Gidget Goes to Bahia.'' His spring 2002 collection was titled ''The Illusion of Haze,'' for example, and it included tuxedo shirts, floral prints and skirts, all stapled to overlays of fabric as transparent as Saran wrap. This time out, he chose to call his collection ''Scab.''

title: Showalter Attracts More Than Mets' Eyes
description: Nine days have passed since the Mets fired Bobby Valentine and began a search to replace him. The Mets have yet to offer the job to anyone, still have interviews with candidates remaining and their top two choices, the Mariners' Lou Piniella and the Giants' Dusty Baker, are unavailable for now. But they already have competition for one of their leading candidates, Buck Showalter.

title: For Construction at Trade Center Site, the Future Is Now
description: WHAT does tomorrow hold for the World Trade Center site?

title: Drug Release To Be Delayed Once Again, Akzo Says
description: Akzo Nobel announced today that it was forced to delay for at least another year the release of an anti-depressant drug it is testing.

title: On Eve of Elections in Pakistan, Musharraf Hails Nation's Gains
description: Extolling the achievements of his government and urging Pakistanis interested in reform to vote for ''new faces,'' Gen. Pervez Musharraf delivered a nationwide address tonight on the eve of the first legislative elections since he seized power in a bloodless coup three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFF, LEONARD
description: RAFF-Leonard. On October 8, 2002. Loving father of Susan and her husband Kevin Pflaumer, adoring grandfather of Jared and Sofia, dear brother of Irma Nemoytin and the late Siena. He worked for CBS News in New York for 53 years as a broadcast editor. He covered history making events like the Vietnam War, the Kennedy Assassination, President Nixon's visit to China and the Iran hostage crisis. Veteran of WWII proudly serving on the U.S.S New Jersey. Service Friday 2PM at the ''Riverside'', 76th St., and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, FRANCES FABYN
description: DAVIS-Frances Fabyn. The Board of Directors, staff and residents of Leake and Watts Services, Inc., Yonkers, N.Y. mourn the loss of a dear and good friend. ''Fuzz'' was elected to the Board in 1957, served as President from 1972 to 1977 and worked on numerous committees through the years. She became an Honorary Director on December 12, 2001. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her family. ''Fuzz'' will be deeply missed. Her contributions were endless. William A. Kirk, Jr. President James J. Campbell Executive Director

title: Better Laws to Settle the Port Labor Dispute
description: The last time a president tried to invoke the Taft-Hartley Act, which provides for federal intervention if a strike or lockout threatens ''national health or safety,'' he failed. In 1978, a federal judge rejected President Jimmy Carter's effort to use the act to halt a coal miners' strike.

title: A Warehouse of Contemporary Goods Anchored at the Manhattan Bridge
description: Hip Brooklyn homesteaders will now have their own ABC Home store, in a warehouse in Dumbo at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge. The facade is decorated with colorful supergraphics on 12 loading-dock doors (below). ''The furniture in the Dumbo store will be more contemporary than in our other branches,'' said Skye Kirby, vice president of ABC's stores. ''It will also address the needs of small-space living.'' Among the offerings will be carpets and rugs, bedding, accessories and Mitchell Gold upholstered pieces but no tableware or dishes. The vintage Egg chair by Arne Jacobson, (above left) will sell for $7,800; the white Corona chair (above right), $5,000. ABC Home, 20 Jay Street, will open Oct. 19.

title: Angels Find Their Form And Torment the Twins
description: They had smart, productive at-bats. They hit long, loud home runs. They played slick, crisp defense. They pitched effectively. These were the Anaheim Angels who began October by torturing the Yankees. These were the same Angels who awoke tonight from their brief malaise and did a little tormenting of the Minnesota Twins.

title: In a Multiplayer Universe, Gods Bow to the Masses
description: GAUTE GODAGER has more power over his economy than Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board does. He has more influence over global politics than Kofi Annan, secretary general of the United Nations. For the inhabitants of his world, Mr. Godager is nothing less than an all-powerful god.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cabdriver, 44, Is Shot to Death In a Robbery On Long Island
description: A Long Island cabdriver was fatally shot in Roslyn Heights early yesterday by one of two men who tried to rob him, an attack that happened two days after another cabdriver was shot in Suffolk County, the police said.

title: Miscellany
description: * Nielsen Outdoor, New York, part of the VNU Media Measurement and Information Group of VNU, will test a service to measure audiences for signs and billboards. The test will be held in Johannesburg, South Africa. The principal competitor of Nielsen, Arbitron, is also testing a ratings service for outdoor ads, in Atlanta.

title: Billions of Blinks From a Laser to Keep Computers in Time
description: ATOMIC clocks may be the world standard in timekeeping, but they have a number of drawbacks, not the least of which is the space they take up. They range from shoebox-size (for use in satellites) to boxcar-size (for global timekeeping).

title: F.B.I. Urges Heightened Vigilance as Result of Videotaped Threats
description: The F.B.I. warned law enforcement authorities today to take ''additional prudent steps'' to detect and deter potential terrorist attacks.

title: That Final Flourish, The Music
description: If you wanted to track trends in fashion, you could do worse than keeping an ear out for what Frederic Sanchez is playing. Mr. Sanchez is an international D.J. whose clients this past season have included Marc Jacobs, Anna Sui, Narciso Rodriguez, Calvin Klein, Prada and, today, Jean Paul Knott, the designer brought in to energize the house of Louis Fraud. Mr. Sanchez also operates a record shop on Rue Ste.-Anastase in the Marais, in partnership with Fred Bladou; the two are known locally as the Two Freds.

title: Learn How to Win the Battle In the Conference Room
description: Computer games have taught players how to slay dragons, build empires and blow up tanks, but they can also be used to teach more mundane skills. Virtual Leader, corporate training software from SimuLearn, is designed to teach managers how to run a business meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ALBERT A.
description: WALSH-Albert A. Of Red Bank, NJ formerly of Crestwood, NY on October 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Nan. Loving father of Maryellen, Nanette, Mark and the late Gregg Walsh.
