Dear grandfather of Michael, Stephen and Mark. Devoted brother of Sister Marie Albert, O.S.U. and Roslyn Gilligan. Also surviving are many nieces and nephews. Mr. Walsh was a senior partner at Seward & Kissel law firm of New York City. He is a distinguished graduate of Fordham Law School, Class of 1954. Mr Walsh is a veteran of the first Rockefeller Administration, a former Administrator of the New York City Housing and Development Administration under Mayor Lindsay, and at one time the Chairman of the New York City Housing Authority. He was a past president of The National Realty Committee in Washington, D.C. Mr. Walsh served in The Submarine Service of the U.S. Navy from 1946 to 1948. Calling hours at the Thompson Memorial Home of Red Bank, NJ, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Thursday. Further visitation at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hours of 6 to 9 PM Friday. A Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood on Saturday October 12, at 10:30AM. Donations may be made to The Friends of Incarnation Children's Center, C/O Msgr. Tom Leonard, 213 West 82 St., New York, NY 10024, or The Ministry of Caring, 506 North Church St., Wilmington, DE. 19801, or VIP Community Services, 1910 Arthur Ave., Bronx, NY 10457.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRUMHOLZ, BESSIE
description: KRUMHOLZ-Bessie. Dec. 1892 to Oct. 10, 1942. Time diminishes neither our love nor our tears. Better to have been your kids than to have gained the world. Claire, Fran and Si

title: Reporter's Notebook: Limits to a National Poll
description: It has become one of the more intriguing contradictions of this somewhat odd congressional campaign season. The consensus among Democratic and Republican political leaders is that what should be a powerful issue for the Democrats, the ailing national economy, has been eclipsed by the talk of war. That is why, many Democrats say, their optimistic talk of this past August has disappeared in the final weeks of the fall campaign.

title: As Expected, New York City Teachers Union Endorses Pataki
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election bid received the widely anticipated endorsement of the United Federation of Teachers yesterday, with union officials reporting that at least 80 percent of union delegates meeting last night voted to back the governor.

title: Stepping Into a Recording, as Romantic Soloist
description: In ''On the Waterfront,'' Marlon Brando's character declares, ''I coulda been a contender.'' In my house the line becomes, ''I coulda been a tenor.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Gesture To North Korea
description: The military announced that it would hold joint naval exercises with North Korea for the first time, another sign of deepening relations with a country the Bush administration has called part of an ''axis of evil.'' The commander of Russia's Pacific fleet, Adm. Viktor D. Fyodorov, said the Navy would conduct exercises and make port calls in North Korea, though he did not say when. After a cooling of relations owing to the collapse of the Soviet Union and warmer ties with South Korea, the government has significantly improved ties with the North in what officials have said is an effort to promote peace on the Korean Peninsula. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: The Devils Ponder What the Season Holds
description: The Devils will stick their collective toe into the water of their regular season tonight, with not much more of an idea about what is under the surface than anybody else.

title: Palm-Size Ultrasound Scans Safely in a Flash
description: The same wave of innovation that has driven miniaturization for the last few years in laptop computers and digital devices like personal organizers, video camcorders and portable music players is significantly shrinking some medical equipment once so large that it had to be wheeled into action on carts.

title: Panel Lists More Stock Sales at ImClone Before Its Shares Fell
description: Executives, directors and employees of ImClone Systems sold nearly $74 million in company stock in December in the weeks before the biotechnology company suffered a regulatory setback that sent shares into a tailspin, according to information released today by a Congressional committee.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Parole Denied For Lennon's Killer
description: Mark David Chapman, left, the man convicted of fatally shooting John Lennon, was denied parole yesterday, coincidentally on what would have been Lennon's 62nd birthday. Mr. Chapman, 47, was convicted of gunning down Mr. Lennon in 1980 in front of the Dakota, the apartment building on Central Park West where Mr. Lennon lived. Mr. Chapman will be eligible for parole again in two years. He has served 22 years of his sentence of 20 years to life. The New York State Division of Parole noted that Mr. Chapman had planned the murder for several months and had used hollow-point bullets he knew to be particularly destructive. The board said Mr. Chapman's release at this time would diminish the seriousness of his crime. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the testing of chemical and biological agents by the Pentagon during the cold war referred incorrectly in some copies to the panel headed by Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, who called on the government to assist any veteran made ill by the tests. He is chairman of the House Veterans' Affairs Committee, not of its subcommittee on health.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Merry, Merry, Mary

title: The Way That You Say It
description: For Democrats confused over how to talk about Iraq with an election approaching, Representative Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut has some advice.

title: Paterno's Unabated Passion
description: The enduring memory of this resurgent Penn State season is not elation over four victories, but wrath over the lone defeat. Upset about two calls made in an overtime loss at home to Iowa, Joe Paterno chased and grabbed Referee Dick Honig, first in a dyspeptic trot, then in an incensed sprint, his anger seeming to build with his speed.

title: Democrats Want Change At the S.E.C.
description: The search led by Harvey L. Pitt for a new top accounting regulator turned into a political brawl today as administration officials defended him against prominent Democrats who called for Mr. Pitt to be removed as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: 'Sopranos' Are in Parade. What Are You Gonna Do?
description: The boss says that he will march in a parade with anyone he pleases. Got that?

title: White House Joins Fight Against Electric Cars
description: The Bush administration went to court today to support the automobile industry's effort to eliminate requirements in California that auto manufacturers sell electric cars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEE, EUGENE
description: SWEE-Eugene, of Riverdale, NY, passed away October 6, at age 83. He is survived by his wife, Joan; two siblings, three children, and six grandchildren. He was an international businessman, owned several companies, actively supported the arts, and rooted for NY teams. He loved jazz, international travel and modern novels.

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: Godzilla: Part 26
description: The 26th film in the Godzilla series is set for release in December. The new film brings back Mechagodzilla, a mechanical version of the monster.

title: Fans' Notes
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including comments on postseason baseball disappointments and the United States Senate race in New Jersey.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Kidnapping Victims Can Go Home Again
description: Five Japanese citizens abducted by North Korea will be allowed to go to Japan next week for a two-week stay that will be their first visit home in a quarter-century. The visit, timed to precede the resumption of talks between Japan and North Korea on establishing diplomatic relations, is seen as a sign of North Korean eagerness to ease Japanese anger over the abduction of at least 13 people beginning in the late 1970's. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Expects Lower Profit
description: One of Japan's few large profitable banks, the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company, said it expected to report that its first-half profit fell by more than half because of losses on its stockholdings. The bank, Japan's sixth largest, cut its profit forecast 54 percent to 6 billion yen ($48.3 million) in the six months ended Sept. 30. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Israel Begins Effort to Remove Illegal Settler Outposts in the West Bank
description: The Israeli Army dismantled two uninhabited settlement outposts in the West Bank today in what defense officials said was the start of a campaign to take down more than 20 illegal encampments.

title: Russia's View of Chechnya Clashes With Reality
description: This is how the commander of Russian forces in Chechnya, Col. Gen. Vladimir I. Moltenskoi, sees life here.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: Guilty Plea In Assault On Girl
description: A 75-year-old man has pleaded guilty to sexual assault after it was determined he had fathered the child of a 10-year-old girl, the state's attorney's office said. The man, Jimmie Kave, of Bridgeport, admitted to the sexual assault Tuesday after DNA samples confirmed he was the father. Mr. Kave baby-sat for the 10-year-old; she and her baby are in state custody. Mr. Kave said that the girl had seduced him and that he had bought the 10-year-old clothes and presents in exchange for sex. He will be sentenced on Nov. 15. The state is recommending that Mr. Kave serve 15 years in prison. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Grief Therapy for Plants
description: DAN HINKLEY, the plant explorer and nurseryman, likes to say, ''been there, killed that,'' about the rare plants he has tried to grow in his Kingston, Wash., garden. Taking a risk by growing a new plant may be a necessary part of the learning process. But I take no comfort from well-meaning people who say, ''now you have room for something new.'' If something is dead or dying, I want to know why -- if not for this plant, then for the next.

title: Sports of The Times; A Time To Refocus Priorities
description: YANKEES fans have been sleep-deprived for most of the past seven years. Like it or not, the Yankees have dominated our consciousness: 5 World Series appearances, 4 championships and 685 regular-season victories.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Case of Losing

title: NBC Will Replace Executive Producer at 'Today'
description: Despite racking up its biggest audience totals in five years, NBC's "Today" show will make a change in its most important production position, replacing the current executive producer, Jonathan Wald, an NBC executive said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METCALF, MARY K.
description: METCALF-Mary K. Of Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Lawrence, NY. Died October 5, after a brief illness. Born Mary Dorothy Keresey on March 21, 1926, Mimi was the daughter of the late Henry Donnelly Keresey and the late Mary Dorothy Kelley, and the granddaughter of the late Cornelius Francis Kelley, chairman of The Anaconda Company, and the late Mary Tremblay. She attended the Marymount and Spence Schools, and was a graduate of Briarcliff College. Beloved wife of the late Mahlon W. Edmonson and the late Harris Metcalf. An earlier marriage to William Dayton Holmes ended in divorce. She is survived by four children, Mary E. White, Deborah E. Drake, Mahlon W. Edmonson, Jr., and Anne E. Kerr, two brothers H. Donn Keresey and Michael M. Keresey, stepdaughter Shepley Metcalf and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 street on Tuesday, October 15, at 1:30. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers a donation in her name can be made to The Riverside Theater, 3250 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, FL. 32963.

title: An A.T.M. for Digital Photos Makes Them Pretty as a Pixel
description: In their eternal quest for instant gratification, people have found that digital cameras have certainly helped, by providing electronic copies that can easily be transferred to a computer and e-mailed to friends. Without a photo-quality printer, however, getting a decent hard copy of those photogenic moments can be problematic. Sony hopes to change all that with the PictureStation, which can make getting finished prints as easy as going to an automated teller machine for cash.

title: Revenge of the Accountants
description: After a summer in which it seemed as if Harvey Pitt might be getting religion on accounting reforms, he has now reverted to form. Mr. Pitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is on the verge of botching one of its most pressing missions -- the creation of a credible oversight board for the accounting profession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNELL, MARION
description: SCHNELL-Marion. Of Houston, Texas. Formerly of Richmond Hill N.Y. On October 7, 2002. Wife of the late Edward B. Reposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119-04 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill. Service Friday 7:30 PM. Funeral Saturday 10 AM. Interment to follow Lutheran All Faiths Cemetery. Visiting hours Friday 2:30 to 5 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Fewer Offices, More Options In Planning for Ground Zero
description: Officials overseeing the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan agreed yesterday to give designers more flexibility in planning the future of the World Trade Center site, reducing by 40 percent the amount of the commercial space that must be included in plans for it.

title: Chuck Rayner, 82, Star Goalie for Rangers
description: Chuck Rayner, the Hall of Fame goaltender who starred for usually lackluster Rangers teams in the decade after World War II, died last Sunday at his home in Langley, British Columbia. He was 82.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: KIDNAPPING VICTIMS CAN GO HOME AGAIN Five Japanese citizens abducted by North Korea will be allowed to go to Japan next week for a two-week stay that will be their first visit home in a quarter-century. The visit, timed to precede the resumption of talks between Japan and North Korea on establishing diplomatic relations, is seen as a sign of North Korean eagerness to ease Japanese anger over the abduction of at least 13 people beginning in the late 1970's.

title: World Court Rules for Cameroon in Border Dispute With Nigeria
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 10  The World Court ruled at The Hague today that Cameroon ought to be given possession of a disputed oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea that had long been claimed by Nigeria, a decision that could affect some oil interests in the region.

title: Sitting Pretty on Goddess Cloth, Cotton From the Coast of India
description: Exactly when ethnic accessories seem to be in vogue, along comes a store selling richly patterned Indian textiles. Niti Seth, a psychologist from Bombay who teaches at Harvard and practices psychotherapy in a Boston suburb, also owns Coromandel, a small shop in Cambridge, Mass., which has a vast collection of reasonably priced bedspreads, place mats, napkins and pillows. For Ms. Seth, above, the shop was a way to support crafts by women in Indian villages. The idea for Coromandel came to her after traveling in Gujarat, a state in western India, where she did research for a doctoral dissertation on fertility among women in rural Indian villages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSS, PETER A.
description: RUSS-Peter A. Born March 10, 1945, and died October 9, 2002. He is survived by his loving family, Jill Baker-Russ, Jordan E. Russ, Carey P. Russ and Aero Sebastian. Please join us to celebrate his life on Friday, the 11th of October, 1:30 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: EX-OIL CHIEF ARRESTED The former director of Mexico's state oil company, Pemex, was arrested in Houston and faces extradition in a corruption investigation. Rogelio Montemayor, a fugitive since May, faces charges of funneling tens of millions of dollars from Pemex to the Institutional Revolutionary Party during Mexico's 2000 presidential election campaign. The party's candidate, Francisco Labastida, was defeated by President Vicente Fox. Four of Mr. Labastida's campaign aides are under investigation.

title: Negative News From Some Blue Chips Takes Heavy Toll
description: Investor nervousness pushed stock prices lower yesterday and sent signals of distress through the corporate bond market.

title: Malaysia Deports Suspected American Islamic Militant to U.S.
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 10  The Malaysian government deported a suspected American Islamic militant, Ahmed Ibrahim Bilal, to the United States today to face charges of conspiring to fight with Al Qaeda and the Taliban in Afghanistan, officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schrder's Tiny Margin
description: Final results of the Sept. 22 elections showed that with more than 48 million votes cast, the Social Democratic Party of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder won just 8,864 more than the Christian Democrats and their sister party, the Christian Social Union. The Social Democrats won 251 seats to 248 for the Christian Democrats and Christian Social Union. The Social Democrats' partners, the Greens, won 55 seats, giving the coalition a majority in the 603-member Parliament. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: U.S. Aides Split On Assessment Of Iraq's Plans
description: A letter to Congress from the director of central intelligence has brought into public view divisions within the administration over what intelligence shows about Iraq's intentions and its willingness to ally itself with Al Qaeda.

title: Explosion in Chechnya's Capital Kills at Least 9
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 10  An explosion tore through a district police station this evening in Chechnya's capital, Grozny, killing at least nine and leaving many more people missing in the building's ruble, according to officials and news reports.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility To Start Privatization
description: The government's Korea Electric Power Corporation will begin the process of privatization today by asking potential investors for letters of intent stating their desire to take over one of its five divisions. The company hopes to earn several hundred million dollars by selling as much as 51 percent of Korea South-East Power to a private company. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: UTILITY REFORM ADVANCES A disputed plan to overhaul Russia's vast electricity grid passed an early hurdle today in the lower house of Parliament. The Duma, in a preliminary vote of 261 to 150, endorsed passage of a set of bills that would put the legal framework in place to reorganize the electricity monopoly, Unified Energy System. The company is one of the most actively traded on the Russian stock market. Minority shareholders, including foreign investors, have opposed the reorganization saying it will dilute their holdings. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: U.S. and France Agree to Keep Searching for Accord on Iraq
description: President Bush and President Jacques Chirac of France, moving to avert a collision in the Security Council over Iraq, agreed today to keep negotiating to find a compromise for a tough resolution to force Baghdad to disarm, a spokeswoman for Mr. Chirac said.

title: A Clash of Styles Seen Behind Ohnesorg Resignation
description: Franz Xaver Ohnesorg's abrupt resignation Tuesday as general manager of the Berlin Philharmonic has cast an embarrassing shadow over Simon Rattle's arrival as the orchestra's new principal conductor and has drawn fresh attention to the recent troubled history of Berlin's musical institutions.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: PERMITS FOR MEALS FOR HOMELESS

title: Hand-Held Unit and Keyboard Part Ways, Linked by Infrared
description: Most keyboards for hand-held organizers require that the organizer be carefully placed in the flimsy data bracket at the top of the unit -- a delicate process somewhat akin to slipping the Oxford English Dictionary onto a music stand: it should work, but you get the feeling it wasn't meant to.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, CONSTANCE LA GIOIA
description: BROWN-Constance La Gioia. Passed away peacefully at home in Walnut Creek, California after a gallant battle with cancer on October 4, 2002. Beloved and loving wife of Tom; loved and devoted mother of Elizabeth and Katherine; treasured daughter of Giulia and Frank; loved sister of Giulie Waddell; dear aunt of Joshua and Geoffrey (d.) Waddell. We miss you, brave heart. You loved greatly, lived fully and died gracefully. You will be dearly cherished forever. The Funeral Mass will be held on Friday, 11th October at 7:00 PM at Newman Hall Holy Spirit Parish, 2700 Dwight Way, Berkeley, CA. Friends may send a memorial donation to Connie's alma mater: The Constance La Gioia Brown Fund, Manhattanville College, 2900 Purchase Street, Purchase, New York 10577.

title: Germ Warfare Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Filmmaker to Look at Racy Magazine for Ideas
description: In search of synergy between print and film -- and maybe a touch of sex appeal -- New Line Cinema, a division of AOL Time Warner, has turned to Maxim magazine, the bawdy runaway newsstand success from Dennis Publishing US.

title: Powell Finesses a Sour Note from Harry Belafonte, 'a Friend'
description: Harry Belafonte, the singer and liberal political advocate, denounced Secretary of State Colin L. Powell in a radio interview this week, likening him to a plantation slave who abandoned his principles to ''come into the house of the master.'' Mr. Powell called the characterization ''unfortunate.''

title: Tape Spurs Terror Warning
description: Federal officials issued a new warning about possible terrorist attacks, based on threats in a tape they believe was made by Osama bin Laden's top aide. Page A19.

title: INSIDE
description: Nobels Are Awarded In Economics and Chemistry

title: Laura Bush's Literary Salon
description: As almost every occupant has discovered, the learning curve at the White House depends on who you were before you got to Pennsylvania Avenue. This is no less true in the East Wing, where the first lady goes about her business, than it is in the West Wing, where the president goes about his. For Laura Bush, it seems, the transition has been seamless, perhaps because her professional concerns, as a former teacher and librarian, fit perfectly within the traditional sense of the first lady's job.

title: Defense Dept. Offers Details Of Toxic Tests Done in Secret
description: The Defense Department gave them colorful names, incuding Green Mist, Red Cloud and Rapid Tan. Some borrowed from nature, as in Tall Timber and Swamp Oak. Others were ominous: Devil Hole and Night Train, for example. A few were stark, even cryptic, as in Deseret 69-75.

title: With Time Now Short, Many Bills Fade
description: With Congress consumed by Iraq and striving to bring its session to a close, much of the legislative agendas of both parties, including security proposals prompted by the Sept. 11 attacks, is falling by the wayside.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the renovation of a house in Ghent, N.Y., belonging to Joseph Holtzman, editor in chief of Nest magazine, misstated the type of artwork by Matisse that was sold to help pay for the property. It was a bronze sculpture, not a painting.

title: House Panel Seeks Release of Presidential Papers
description: A House committee voted without dissent today to overturn President Bush's executive order that delayed release of President Ronald Reagan's papers and allowed relatives of future presidents to keep papers secret.

title: On a Quest: 600,000 Wines, Few Clues
description: A PRENUPTIAL agreement was my husband's idea. The terms were succinct: ''Neither spouse will force the other to visit more than one museum per year. The means you.''

title: The New York Times N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: Based on games through Oct. 7.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Saturday about Hans Blix, who heads the United Nations weapons inspectors, misspelled the name of a former inspector who recalled having been scolded by Mr. Blix for confronting an Iraqi official during nuclear inspections in 1991. The former inspector is David Kay, not Kaye.

title: Peddling Junk on EBay
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ALBERT J.
description: WALSH-Albert J. What a great shock and what a great loss to the people of The City of New York. Al was the premier expert in the field of subsidized housing for persons of limited income. Having served as Deputy Commissioner of The State Division of Housing, and Community Renewal, and thereafter, as Commissioner of Housing for The City of New York, Al was the power behind many of the large-scale subsidized housing developments in our City that made available much - needed, affordable housing. ABO was honored that he served as our Chairman for our Mitchell-Lama Housing Committee. He was a special talented and rare human being whom we shall miss deeply. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his charming and devoted wife, Nan. Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York Jerome Belson, President Michael Kerr, Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairman Nick LaPorte, Executive Director

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Mixed News On High-Technology Jobs
description: Some mildly encouraging news on high-technology jobs is scheduled to be released in a report today from the American Electronics Association. The report, based on an analysis of government statistics, shows that high-tech employment dropped by 450,000 jobs, or 8 percent, from the peak in February and March 2001 to June 2002. Still, job losses almost stopped from May to June, the most recent month tracked. Manufacturing jobs have been hardest hit during the slump. The category that has not shed jobs, even gaining slightly, is ''software services,'' mostly programmers. The 5.27 million people in the high-tech sector represent less than 5 percent of the nation's workforce, and high-tech output is less than 6 percent of the gross domestic product. But technology looms large as a share of total private investment, still over 50 percent. Steve Lohr(NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLISH, HARRY J.
description: COLISH-Harry J. A resident of New York City died on October 7th. Mr. Colish wishes to thank his friends for the kindness and affection they have shown to him over the past few years, with special thanks to those friends with whom he was closest in his later life. Funeral services Wednesday, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: This TV Fills a Void on Your Wall But Puts One in Your Wallet
description: With sufficient wall space and indifference to sticker shock, consumers can now hang a 63-inch flat-panel plasma television on the wall of the family room. Samsung is shipping what the company says is the largest flat-panel plasma screen available for consumers. The HPM6315 has a very wide screen, but is only three and a half inches deep. It has a resolution of 1366 by 768 pixels and can display 15 million colors.

title: Buick uses a mid-20th-century designer to lure younger buyers, but also brings out the skeptics.
description: TO try to revive its image among younger car buyers, Buick is taking the unusual step of resurrecting an old hero. Buick, a division of General Motors, is rolling out an advertising campaign built around Harley Earl, the Hollywood-trained style wizard who oversaw the creation of G.M.'s grandest designs.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Different Court For A Princess
description: A senior member of the royal family may appear in court for the first time in more than a century. Princess Anne, the daughter of Queen Elizabeth and younger sister of Prince Charles, the heir to the throne, was told she and her husband must appear at a court in Berkshire on Nov. 21 to answer charges that her bull terrier attacked two children in April. The last royal family member to appear in court is believed to have been the Prince of Wales, the future King Edward VII, who testified in a case in 1890. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Game Wizard Who Cannot Play
description: THE challenge taken on by players of PaletSoft's DinoEggs, a video game for cellphones, is to destroy dinosaur eggs before they hatch into hungry raptors. Gary Letourneau, the creator of Dino Eggs, faces a more formidable challenge: designing games he can never play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, JOSH AARON
description: ROTHSTEIN - Josh Aaron. We are deeply saddened by the untimely loss of this caring and gracious young man. His energy, enthusiasm and passion will be remembered forever. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family and friends, and all who share in this loss. Sharyn Mann, Todd Slotkin, and Amie Rappoport, The Food Allergy Initiative

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SROL, NATHAN (NAT)
description: SROL-Nathan (Nat), 95. On October 8, 2002. Beloved uncle of Myrna Sameth, Dr. Cheryl and Richard Hack, and Kathy and Rev. Paul Sutcliffe. Adored great uncle of Bo, Leonard and Luke Wholey and Jacob and Jessica Hack. Service Friday 9:30 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. at Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in Nat's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 2 Jefferson Plaza, Suite 203, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: Decorating Recipe: Take New Orleans, Blend With France
description: Vieux Carr, an antiques shop, opened last week in Greenwich Village. The owners, Michelle Gauthier and Chad Chaison, have combined the relaxed style of their hometown, New Orleans, with traditional yet affordable French furniture. They buy in the South, where ''prices are still good,'' Mr. Chaison said. Vieux Carr offers furniture and lighting from the late 19th century to the 1960's. ''We are not dealing with real period furniture,'' he explained. ''Most of our pieces were made after 1900 in the antique styles.''

title: Listen, City Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Children Set Homeless Man On Fire
description: A group of children set a homeless man on fire as he was sleeping in a hallway in East New York yesterday evening, the police said. The man, Steven Williams, 48, was sleeping in the second floor hallway of a residential building on Linden Boulevard about 7:35 p.m. when a group of three to five children threw a match on his abdomen, the police said. It was not known last night how old the children were, or if they used an accelerant, said Detective Robert Price. Mr. Williams was taken to the burn unit at New York Weill Cornell Center in stable condition, the police said. No arrests have been made.

title: Wild West Desperado Cast as Political Terrorist
description: JESSE JAMES

title: New Chief at Stratford-Upon-Potomac
description: ''I was the kid with my nose in the book,'' Dr. Gail Kern Paster said. ''It didn't matter what I was reading, as long as I was reading something.''

title: Once Powerful Banker Jailed in China
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 10  Zhu Xiaohua, the former president of China's sixth-largest bank and previously one of China's leading financial officials, was convicted today in Beijing on bribery charges and sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: House Acts to Speed Medical Devices' Approval
description: The House passed a bill today to speed the approval and marketing of a new generation of medical technology that promises better diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses.

title: Market Place; Ford Motor's Legs Are Wobbly Under Finance Unit's Debt Load
description: What made shares of the Ford Motor Company plummet yesterday for the second consecutive trading session? The answer, investors and credit analysts say, was nothing and everything.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Death Penalty Recommendation
description: A jury in San Jose recommended that a former handyman be sentenced to death for the murders of three tourists who had been at a lodge where he worked in Yosemite National Park. The handyman, Cary Stayner, was already serving a life sentence for the murder and beheading of a fourth person at the park. All the killings were in 1999. Mr. Stayner's parents had pleaded with the jury to spare his life, saying he had mental problems since birth. A judge has scheduled sentencing for Dec. 12. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Admits Surveillance Excess
description: An F.B.I. memorandum recently provided to Congress disclosed that the bureau exceeded its mandate on several occasions in 2000, when it put in place secret surveillance operations against foreign agents.

title: SunTrust Falls Short Of Forecasts by 1 cents
description: SunTrust Banks reported today that its third-quarter earnings rose 2.7 percent, missing analysts' forecasts by a penny a share, as the bank set aside more for bad loans.

title: A Nobel That Bridges Economics and Psychology
description: Two Americans have won this year's Nobel award in economics for trying to explain idiosyncrasies in people's ways of making decisions, research that has helped incorporate insights from psychology into the discipline of economics.

title: A White Elephant Reincarnated
description: WHEN John Makau called a Vermont real estate broker two years ago, he wasn't thinking trophy house. He simply wanted to build a summer home near Sugarbush. But Mr. Makau, a retired furniture manufacturer, couldn't round up a work crew. Then his wife, Lydia, saw a broker's ad with a small photograph. ''There's your house, John,'' she said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IVIN
description: MANN-Ivin. On October 8, 2002. Former President of the Board of Trustees of Fountain House, Inc., having served as a Trustee for over 50 years. He is survived by his sons Henry and Peter, his grandchildren Jennifer and David, and his loving companion of many years, Elaine Felsher. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fountain House Inc., 425 West 47th St., NYC, 10036. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Gains in Precision Bidding After a No-Trump Opening
description: Most world titles have had winners from many countries. One exception is the World Women's Pairs, which has been won seven times by the United States, three times by Britain, and once by the Netherlands. In Montreal in August, Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H., became the first player to win with two different partners: She was successful with Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., at 34 the second-youngest player ever to win the title. McCallum also won in 1990 with Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHEN ARNOLD
description: WEISS-Stephen Arnold. Of North Salem, NY on October 9, 2002 at his home following a courageous fight with cancer. A lifelong athlete and horseman, he was Joint Master of the Golden's Bridge Hounds in North Salem. He enjoyed running every morning on the dirt roads surrounding his home. In winter, he skied the mountains of Vermont, Colorado and Utah. As a competitive off-shore sailor, his racing yacht, Christopher Dragon, was well known in the waters of New York, Connecticut and Rhode Island. Born September 9, 1934 in New York City to Marcel Cetalie Weiss. After graduating from Dartmouth College in 1957, he joined his family real estate development and construction business. Throughout a career that spanned 4 decades, he built hundreds of multi-family buildings in five states. Stephen is survived by his beloved wife Gretchen; children Chip, Cindy, Andrew, Amy, Jocelyn, Megan, Caleb, Gavin and Blair; grandchildren Jared, Geoffrey, Zander, Christopher, Kaitlyn, Lucas, Hanna, Kirstyn and brother Robert. Funeral service will be held at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 89 Baldwin Road, Mount Kisco, New York, 11AM, Friday, October 11.

title: 2 Key Senate Critics Back Bush Over Iraq
description: With Congress pushing toward a vote on whether to authorize military action in Iraq, President Bush gained some support from two of the Senate's most outspoken critics of the administration's policy. John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, both prominent Vietnam War veterans, announced for the first time their support for allowing the use of force.

title: 3 Whose Work Speeded Drugs Win Nobel
description: Three scientists share this year's Nobel Prize in Chemistry for developing techniques to identify and map proteins, carbohydrates, DNA and other large biological molecules.

title: Democrats Fault Decision to Move Mentally Ill
description: Democrats in the New York Assembly said yesterday that they would investigate the Pataki administration's decision to release hundreds of patients from state psychiatric hospitals to locked floors of nursing homes, contending that it had been carried out in secret and should have been approved by the Legislature.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Permits For Meals For Homeless
description: The Santa Monica City Council passed two ordinances on the homeless that require charities that offer free outdoor meals to have Health Department permits and make it illegal to sit or lie in doorways downtown at night. The city proposes to link social service agencies with indoor programs to address a growing problem with aggressive panhandlers. Advocates for the homeless said the city was criminalizing the feeding of the poor. Catherine Billey (NYT)

title: Venezuela Braces for a New Round of Antigovernment Protests
description: With its armed forces deployed in the capital, the government of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela braced for an antigovernment march today that might be the largest since the April 11 demonstration that briefly toppled him.

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: Text of F.C.C. News Release
description: The following is the text of a news release announcing the Federal Communications Commission ruling.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Danger Sign
description: Investors pushed stock prices down yesterday and sent distress signals through the corporate bond market, reflected in the growing gap between goverment and corporate bond yields. Page C11.

title: Albert Walsh, Who Created Cheaper Housing, Dies at 74
description: Albert A. Walsh, a top New York housing official in the Rockefeller and Lindsay administrations who helped bring public and private interests together to build cheaper housing, died yesterday in Red Bank, N.J. He was 74 and lived in Red Bank.

title: Argentina and Foreign Banks at Odds
description: Just when the crippled banking system of Argentina looked set to start winning back the confidence of long-suffering savers, an attack by nationalist politicians on three foreign banks has again put a question mark over the future of the financial system.

title: Golisano (Saw Him on TV!) Visits 2 Schools
description: This is a time when studies show that more than half of the high school students in the country do not know basic facts about American history and that some cannot name their United States senators.

title: European Union Prepares To Add 10 Nations in 2004
description: The European Union took a significant step toward unifying the Continent today when its executive body announced that 10 countries, mostly from the former Communist bloc in the eastern half of Europe, are set to become members in 2004.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Jail Terms For Opposition Politicians
description: Two opposition politicians were given jail terms up to five weeks for holding a rally in May after they were denied a permit. It is the third time the country's most vocal gadfly, Chee Soon Juan, has been jailed for speaking in public without a permit. Also sentenced was Ghandhi Ambalam, a fellow member of his tiny Singapore Democratic Party. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Excerpts From Senate Debate on Iraq Policy
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on using military force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine; Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; and Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska.

title: Fiat Wants to Cut 20% of Italian Work Force
description: Fiat, struggling with slumping auto sales and a sinking stock price, said today that it would eliminate as many as 8,100 jobs, or more than a fifth of its Italian work force, an unusually large downsizing in Italy.

title: Excerpts From Senate Debate on Iraq Policy
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate yesterday on using military force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts; Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine; Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont; and Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska.

title: Knish Fulfillment: Defending Los Angeles Delis
description: Are Jewish-style delicatessens in Los Angeles as good as or -- perish the thought! -- better than those in New York?

title: In Harlem, A Mission Plain And Patient; Mennonites Reach Out To Some Skeptical Souls
description: Fred and Agnes Schrock left the Cumberland hills of Tennessee three years ago to do missionary work in New York City on behalf of their conservative sect of Mennonites, a branch of the Pennsylvania Dutch. They ended up settling last year in Harlem, in a turn-of-the century row house in Sugar Hill, at St. Nicholas Avenue and 148th Street, right in the neighborhood to which Duke Ellington took his jazzy A train.

title: Economic Scene; Even without law, contracts have a way of being enforced.
description: WOULD you lend a complete stranger $10,000? How would you get your money back?

title: Fears of a Hard Landing Rattle Tokyo
description: As Tokyo markets veered down yet again today, investors bailed out, tightened their safety belts or begged the government to avoid the dreaded ''hard landing'' of bankruptcies and unemployment.

title: Rift Over Plan to Impose Rule on Iraq
description: The Bush administration is considering plans to create a provisional government for Iraq that could provide a base for opposition to President Saddam Hussein and form the core of a new government if Mr. Hussein is ousted, senior administration officials said.

title: Islamabad Journal; Sometimes in Pakistan It's One Voter, 2 ID Cards
description: Pakistani politics, like many a Pakistani, is a flexible creature, adaptable to crisis, forgiving of transgression. Politicians fall in coups, only to leap back into the fray with their own parties. Candidates switch allegiances in midcampaign.

title: A Message of Discontent From Brazil
description: Luiz Incio Lula da Silva did not win the first-round victory he had hoped for in Brazil's presidential election last Sunday. But he came close. His 46 percent of the vote, double the score of his nearest rival, makes this charismatic left-wing populist the man to beat in the Oct. 27 runoff.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: No Bond Payment
description: Argentina's cashshort government says it will not pay $250 million due Tuesday on bonds guaranteed by the World Bank, meaning creditors will have to turn to the bank for payment. A statement issued by the Economy Ministry said that ''paying these bonds would imply special treatment of some creditors over others.'' The economy minister, Robeo Lavagna, who is seeking relief from the International Monetary Fund, has said the country will no longer use its central bank reserves to meet payments to multilateral agencies like the World Bank and the I.M.F.. Tony Smith (NYT)

title: Peddling Junk on EBay
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Acting to Forestall an Issue in Texas
description: The White House moved quickly tonight to quash a politically embarrassing problem with one of President Bush's nominees to a federal court seat.

title: Wondering About Mind And Method Of a Killer
description: Even here, in a state with some of the nation's toughest gun-control laws, it is easy to find a place to shop for a Beretta, a Savage or a box of ammunition or to spend the afternoon at a shooting range firing shotguns, pistols and rifles at paper targets.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: WARILY, THE ECONOMY GROWS The Japanese economy continued to improve but faces growing risks from tumbling share prices and slowing growth in the United States, the government said in a monthly report. Though the economy expanded 0.6 percent in the second quarter, the government said the main driver of that growth, exports, was weakening. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: After Indictment, Protesters Rally
description: Chanting and waving signs, demonstrators gathered outside a downtown federal building today to oppose war against Iraq and protest the indictment here of a Muslim charity's leader on charges of funneling money to Al Qaeda.

title: How Many Russians? Let Us Weigh the Count, Cooperation or No
description: All across Russia this morning, an army of students, pensioners, homemakers and others began knocking on doors for Russia's first post-Soviet census. Although the first census takers went to Russia's most remote and freezing regions in the relative heat of July, the official count began today.

title: Corrections
description: Aprofile on Saturday about Hans Blix, who heads the United Nations weapons inspectors, misspelled the name of a former inspector who recalled having been scolded by Mr. Blix for confronting an Iraqi official during nuclear inspections in 1991. The former inspector is David Kay, not Kaye.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINCOFF, DAPHNE DORAN
description: LINCOFF-Daphne Doran. 80. Of New York City, on October 7, 2002. Beloved mother and grandmother. Her family and many cherished friends greatly miss her.

title: Excerpts From House Debate on the Use of Military Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Speakers included Representatives Pete Stark, Democrat of California; Michael N. Castle, Republican of Delaware; Silvestre Reyes, Democrat of Texas; Earl Pomeroy, Democrat of North Dakota; Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin; John E. Sununu, Republican of New Hampshire; and Robert W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: LEBANON: DISPUTED WATER PROJECT TESTED In its first test of a project that has angered Israel, Lebanon pumped water from a tributary of a river that feeds the Jordan River, a major source of Israel's fresh water. An official said the four-minute test of a project to supply water from the Wazzani springs to southern villages was "very successful." Israel has said it takes a "grave view" of Lebanon's plans to use the water, which Lebanon says it is entitled to under international law.

title: Met Studies 'Adam's' Neighbors for Stress
description: As part of its investigation into the collapse of a 15th-century marble statue of Adam on Sunday, the Metropolitan Museum has temporarily removed five other Renaissance statues that were nearby in the gallery, the Velez Blanco Patio.

title: Tie to Terrorists in Attack Is Asserted and Disputed
description: The police rounded up dozens of people here for questioning today after two young Kuwaiti men shot at American marines on Tuesday, killing one and wounding the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERINO, FRANK JOSEPH
description: MERINO - Frank Joseph. Died Saturday, October 5, 2002, tragically struck by an automobile while riding his bicycle. Graduated from Browning High School and Fordham University. Proud parent of Daniel and Jessica Merino. Successful businessman in Novato, CA. Dear and devoted son of Drs. Francisco and Rose Merino of La Jolla, CA, and formerly of New York City. Memorial Mass at St. Vincent's Church in San Rafael, CA, on October 10 at 1 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the San Diego Hospice.

title: U.S. Open Is Returning To Bethpage Black in '09
description: The United States Open will return to Bethpage State Park's Black Course on Long Island in 2009, United States Golf Association and New York State officials said yesterday.

title: Jousting Over Inviting Minor Party Candidates to Debates
description: The argument about who will be on the United State Senate ballots is over, but the battle over who will be in the debates is just beginning. Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democrat, today insisted that four minor party candidates take part in debates, while the Republican, Douglas R. Forrester, demanded a debate with Mr. Lautenberg only.

title: 2 Critics of Bush Iraq Policy Say They'll Back Resolution
description: As Congress pushed toward a vote on a resolution authorizing military action in Iraq, two of the Senate's most outspoken critics of the Bush administration's Iraq policy -- both prominent Vietnam War veterans -- announced for the first time today their support for allowing the use of force.

title: Striking Several Chords: 'The Full Monty' in Japan
description: And the male characters are often demoralized and cynical, two traits avoided in polite circles here. But the show's multilayered discussions of parenthood, friendship and hard economic times resonated with Japanese audiences.

title: Losing Farmland in All the Wrong Places
description: To the Editor:

title: Measuring the Distance Across the Sea of Japan
description: The Sea of Japan is easy to sail across. From the sixth century to the 10th, the young state of Japan exchanged emissaries with the Koguryo, Pakchae and Shilla, kingdoms that emerged on the Korean peninsula. Japan traded with Korea's ancient empires across the sea and through them with China, absorbing that advanced civilization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, JOSEPHINE ''JO''
description: CAMPBELL-Josephine ''Jo''. Rye, NH. Died October 4. Wife of Keith Eveland. Mother of Gary and Reid Giacomarra and Leslie, Bradley & Katy Eveland. A memorial celebration October 26, 4PM, Unitarian Universalist Church, 292 State Street, Portsmouth, N.H. Contributions to Habitat for Humanity, Southeast New Hampshire, 33 Pleasant St, Portsmouth, NH 03801. Additional information available through the Robert K. Gray Jr. Funeral Home, 24 Winnacunnet Road, Hampton NH 03842. Tel 603 926-2248.

title: The Go-Ahead at Penn Station
description: In May 1999 this page described impressive plans to create a new Penn Station in Manhattan's General Post Office and indicated that it would be nearly finished in 2003. A lot has happened since then, not including this project. Sept. 11 left a gaping if temporary hole in such ambitious civic proposals, and negotiations with the Postal Service over the General Post Office, also known as the James A. Farley Building, proved unexpectedly difficult. Those negotiations are now at a fitting end.

title: For Bonds, Patience Is Greatest Of Virtues
description: Six of the first seven pitches Barry Bonds saw tonight were balls, and he watched them pass as he waited for something from Cardinals pitcher Matt Morris to drive.

title: Video on Demand Is Ready, but the Market Is Not
description: FOR years, video on demand has been a couch potato's dream. By pushing a few buttons on the remote control, a viewer would be able to order a movie and then sit back and watch as it unfolded immediately on the screen, pausing, rewinding or fast-forwarding at will. Movie-watching would be on the schedule set by the viewer, not the broadcaster or cable company. No need even to get up from the couch to insert a tape or DVD.

title: Regressive for Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Identity Theft Ringleader Pleads Guilty
description: The leader of a ring that used personal information stolen from tens of thousands of consumers to buy computers and cellphones pleaded guilty yesterday. The admitted ringleader, Henry Cutts, 48, of the Bronx, pleaded guilty to grand larceny and scheming to defraud, both felonies. Mr. Cutts is to be sentenced Nov. 26; prosecutors have recommended 6 to 12 years in prison and $100,000 in restitution. Since at least 1999, Mr. Cutts used state employees, video-store clerks and a janitor at a radio station to obtain actual names and Social Security numbers. Investigators said the ring used the data, some of it from bank accounts and credit cards, to buy expensive electronic equipment on the Internet and then resell it for cash. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: COLT CONCERNED ABOUT ITS DEBT The telecommunications provider Colt Telecom Group, which supplies services to businesses in 13 European countries, said it would fight a bondholder's attempt to appoint an administrator to run the company. The bondholder, Highberry Ltd., a hedge fund based in New York, has contended that the company will not be able to repay or refinance its 1.2 billion ($1.86 billion) of bonds when they mature from 2005 to 2009, a Colt spokesman said, adding that "allegations made by Highberry are entirely without foundation. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUDES, LEON
description: HUDES-Leon. Aged 93, of New York City and Florida. Died October 8, 2002. Cherished husband of Sylvia, devoted father of Laurie and Richard Weinman, loving grandfather of Jessica Weinman and Jonathan Weinman. Remembrances to a local hospice of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, RUTH
description: KAMINSKY-Ruth. Age 87. Beloved mother of Mark and Deborah, loving grandmother of Jennie, Sarah, David, Mia and Lucy. Funeral services Friday, October 11, at 11:15 AM at the ''Riverside'' Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NY. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If Israelis killed him or Israelis were after him, I wouldn't be crying. But Palestinians are after him!''

title: A Writer Who Couldn't Shake 11 Gruesome Words
description: WILLIAM MASTROSIMONE, author of the 1982 Off Broadway hit ''Extremities,'' has been creeping across the country this week talking about the power of words, specifically about a few he heard three years ago tossed casually over his dinner table: ''I'm going to kill everyone in class and the teacher, too.''

title: Excerpts From House Debate on the Use of Military Force Against Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Speakers included Representatives Pete Stark, Democrat of California; Michael N. Castle, Republican of Delaware; Silvestre Reyes, Democrat of Texas; Earl Pomeroy, Democrat of North Dakota; Gerald D. Kleczka, Democrat of Wisconsin; John E. Sununu, Republican of New Hampshire; and Robert W. Goodlatte, Republican of Virginia.

title: Sehorn and Zeigler May Ease Injury Pileup
description: Jason Sehorn and Dusty Zeigler have had parallel lives in a year that began with microfracture knee surgery for each. The two went through months of arduous rehabilitation, and as their recoveries lasted longer than the Giants expected, they were keenly cognizant of the pain they felt and stubbornly resisted the implicit pressure to return to action before they felt ready.

title: Hungarian Novelist Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: PARIS, Oct. 9  Imre Kertesz, a Hungarian novelist and Holocaust survivor with a small but devoted readership in Europe, today won the 2002 Nobel Prize for Literature for what the Swedish Academy described as writing that "upholds the tragic experience of the individual against the barbaric arbitrariness of history."

title: Lying 'Lie Detectors'
description: Longtime readers of this column have noticed some recurring themes: I'm for personal privacy and have an affinity for the often-betrayed Kurdish people. I despise state-sponsored gambling as well as the form of torture that calls itself the ''lie detector.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Warily, The Economy Grows
description: The Japanese economy continued to improve but faces growing risks from tumbling share prices and slowing growth in the United States, the government said in a monthly report. Though the economy expanded 0.6 percent in the second quarter, the government said the main driver of that growth, exports, was weakening. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Blair Warns Sinn Fein Leader on Paramilitary Activity
description: LONDON, Oct. 10  Prime Minister Tony Blair told Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, today that Irish republicans had to abandon their "dual strategy" of combining paramilitary activity with participation in politics if peace in Northern Ireland is to be assured.

title: Teenage Choices: One Mother's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: AT HOME WITH: Chris Van Allsburg; Bad Things Happen To Good Houses
description: WHEN the crockery hit the floor in the kitchen last week, it was an accident, as it might have been in any house.

title: Mexico City Vendors Survived Corts, but Now . . .
description: The heart of this capital is a jumble of cathedral spires and cracked sewers, ruined temples and taco stands, priceless art and plastic junk.

title: Overreaction to Pitch Sets an Angry Tone
description: In Bob Gibson's day, the pitch would have been higher and tighter, and if the batter had reacted as Kenny Lofton did, the next one would have been even higher and even tighter.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shoots a Man During a Fight at a Midtown Bar
description: An off-duty New York City police officer shot and critically injured a man during a fight at a Midtown nightclub early yesterday, the police said. The officer told the police that the man had pushed him down and choked him.

title: Radio Pretoria's Niche
description: To the Editor:

title: Route Over Ruined Irish Castle Stirs Protest
description: After recent disclosures of corruption in government planning and zoning decisions, protesters have tapped into a groundswell of public support as they demonstrate against construction of a highway over the remains of a 14th-century castle in this city's affluent southern suburbs.

title: Bush's Science Advisers Drawing Criticism
description: The Bush administration's choice of science advisers on matters varying from reproductive medicine to lead poisoning in children is drawing criticism from some Democrats in Congress, who complain that the advisers are being selected for their ideology and ties to industry rather than their scientific expertise.

title: Teenage Choices: One Mother's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Elections in Pakistan
description: To the Editor:

title: CUMMINS TO TRIM 200 PRODUCTION JOBS IN INDIANA
description: Cummins Inc., a maker of heavy-duty diesel engines, plans to cut as many as 200 jobs as it moves production of some heavy-truck engines from Indiana to New York to reduce costs by trimming capacity. The company may eliminate as many as 400 jobs at the Indiana plant, which is in Columbus, through retirements, voluntary separations and layoffs, a spokesman said. The New York factory, in Jamestown, where ISX heavy-truck engine output is being consolidated, will add about 200 workers. The net loss in jobs would be less than 1 percent of Cummins's 24,900 workers. The Columbus plant will still make cylinder heads and engine blocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUB, RUTH (SCHOENBERG)
description: TAUB-Ruth (Schoenberg). On October 9, 2002. After a courageous battle with cancer. She left this world the way she lived it, with dignity and gentle humor. Beloved wife of the late Melville Taub. Devoted mother of Mark (Maxine), Terry (Fred) Klein and Sande (Robert) DeStefano. Adored Nana of Jessica, Joshua, Lisa, Matthew, Justin and Robert. Funeral services Thursday, October 10th, 10:30AM, Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51 St., NYC.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SUDAN: GOVERMENT AGREES TO RESUME TALKS The government has agreed to return to peace negotiations a month after calling a halt to them because of military victories by rebels in the south. Sudanese officials said they had recaptured the southern town of Torit from the Sudan People's Liberation Army, which said that the government had lost a series of important battles. Despite the continued fighting, analysts consider the talks a breakthrough in ending one of Africa's most intractable conflicts. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Executive Faults Licensing Plan
description: Microsoft's chief executive, Steve Ballmer, said yesterday that his company made mistakes when it moved to a new licensing plan this year that angered customers, some of whom had to pay more. ''With 20-20 hindsight, I probably wouldn't have made any of these changes when the economy was going to go south,'' Mr. Ballmer said in an interview at a conference sponsored by the market researcher Gartner Inc. in Orlando, Fla. Microsoft switched to the new plan Aug. 1 to try to make its software licensing programs easier to understand and cheaper for some customers. The plan requires clients to buy maintenance contracts, which cost at least 25 percent more than the software alone, or to pay more for upgrades to new programs. Analysts have estimated that most customers will end up paying more, and some clients have said they are looking at competing programs.

title: G.O.P. Inquiry Lists Gifts To Clintons in White House
description: Denise Rich, Malcolm S. Forbes, Nelson Mandela and other friends and supporters of the Clintons showered the couple with roughly $1 million in previously unreported gifts during the Clinton presidency, according to documents released by Republican Congressional investigators.

title: AETNA REPORTS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: Aetna, the health insurer, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit was higher than expected as it controlled medical expenses and increased premiums. Aetna said its full-year profit would also beat estimates. The chief executive, John Rowe, is eliminating jobs and has promised to trim $300 million from operating costs this year. The company has shed five million customers who were too expensive to insure and reduced costs by making customers pay more for care. Aetna, which is based in Hartford, announced its forecast after the close of market trading. Its shares, which fell $1.41 and closed at $31.69, traded for more than $35 a share in after-hours trading.

title: Reuse of Needle at Hospital Infects 50 With Hepatitis C
description: More than 50 people at an Oklahoma hospital have been infected with hepatitis C after a nurse repeatedly used the same needle and syringe to give drugs, area health officials say.

title: Victims With Nothing in Common Save an Awful, Unexpected Encounter
description: The differences in their lives show the randomness of the killings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN NORDEN, MONTAGNIE
description: VAN NORDEN-Montagnie. The Browning School Community notes with sadness the death of Montagnie Van Norden '41, brother of James '42 and father of Montagnie, Jr. '70 and Adam '73. Mr. Van Norden was a loyal alumnus and an active and effective trustee for the decade of the 60's. James S. Chanos, President, Board of Trustees Stephen M. Clement III Headmaster

title: Weak Ad Revenue Is Causing Dow Jones to Plan More Job Cuts
description: Dow Jones & Company, which has eliminated more than 1,000 jobs from a work force of 8,000 over the last two years, will make a new round of layoffs in the coming months because advertising revenue at its leading newspaper, The Wall Street Journal, continues to lag even the modest expectations of the early months of 2002, senior executives said yesterday.

title: Congress Must Resist the Rush to War
description: A sudden appetite for war with Iraq seems to have consumed the Bush administration and Congress. The debate that began in the Senate last week is centered not on the fundamental and monumental questions of whether and why the United States should go to war with Iraq, but rather on the mechanics of how best to wordsmith the president's use-of-force resolution in order to give him virtually unchecked authority to commit the nation's military to an unprovoked attack on a sovereign nation.

title: New Jersey Transit Is Backing Study of a New Rail Tunnel
description: A decade-old proposal to build an additional rail tunnel to carry passengers between New Jersey and Midtown Manhattan got a boost today as state officials said the project would now top their list of transportation priorities.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Partner For GM Daewoo
description: Another Asian partner has agreed to join General Motors in the consortium that it has formed to assume a controlling stake in GM Daewoo Auto and Technology. China's state-owned Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation, a joint venture partner with General Motors, has agreed to pay $59.7 million for 10 percent of the newly formed company, which is taking over three major plants in Korea from the bankrupt Daewoo Motors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: The Debate Over Breast Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting the Glow in Golden October
description: THESE days, decks and patios tend be furnished like outdoor living rooms, with teak furniture upholstered in decorator fabrics. So it only makes sense that they should have their own glowing hearths. The outdoor fireplace, long regarded as a California fixture, is catching on elsewhere, often in a portable form. What better way to prolong the pleasure of this year's unusually warm autumn?

title: Fighting Mayor's Proposed Smoking Ban Not on the Basis of Health, but of Economics
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and smoking opponents will face off with restaurant, nightclub and bar owners today at the first hearing on the mayor's proposal to ban smoking in all public places in New York City, which would be one of the strictest antismoking laws in the country.

title: City Budget Gap Grows, and Visions of the 70's Grow Vivid
description: New York City's fiscal watchdogs and budget mavens have been known to cry wolf. Year after year, they sound alarms about yawning deficits, heavy debt, draconian cuts just down the road, giant tax increases just around the corner. They invoke the early 1990's, the 1970's. But somehow the city always seems to muddle through.

title: Metro Matters; Separating The Leaks From the Bilge
description: THIS being a campaign season, a primer on the more colorful campaign tactics, starting with the current favorite, the leak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONALDSON, KENNETH T., M.D.
description: DONALDSON-Kenneth T., M.D. Age 89, died on October 6, 2002 in Palm City, FL. Practiced medicine at Roosevelt Hospital in New York City for 40 years. Survived by his wife, Betty, his children Linda, Bob and his wife Amy and Tom and his wife Theresa. and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on October 19, 2002, at 11 A.M. at Sandhill Cove in Palm City.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Proposed Merger of Satellite TV Giants
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10  Federal regulators today blocked the merger of the two largest satellite television broadcasters while moving closer to approving another proposed deal to create the nation's largest cable television company.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Leo Burnett USA, Chicago, promoted two employees to vice presidents. They are Joe Duncan, director for innovation and technology for print management, and Bruce Williams, director for print production design. Burnett USA is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe.

title: St. Patrick's Day Parade Groups Settle Feud
description: Two Irish-American organizations that have feuded over who has the right to put on the city's St. Patrick's Day Parade have settled their differences and promised to work together in the future.

title: UNOCAL TO BUY REMAINING SHARES OF PURE RESOURCES
description: Senior managers at Pure Resources Inc. agreed to sell their shares in the company, an oil and natural gas explorer and producer, after the Unocal Corporation raised its bid for the 35 percent of the company it does not already own. Pure Resources executives accepted a bid of 0.74 Unocal share for each of theirs, the companies said. The revised offer is for $376.9 million, or $21.48 a share, based on Unocal's closing price yesterday. Unocal is seeking full ownership of the company, which it helped create in May 2000 when it combined its West Texas oil and gas unit with Titan Exploration. Unocal, based in El Segundo, Calif., already owns 65 percent of Pure.

title: Panel Says Mixed Signals Have Eroded U.S. Status in the U.N.
description: The United States has lost influence within the United Nations because of years of ambivalence towards the organization and should re-engage it forcefully to build a coalition of democratic nations, says a report to be issued on Thursday by a bipartisan task force.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Production Rises
description: German industrial production rose in August for a second month in three, as companies made more cars and computer equipment. Production at factories, construction sites, utilities and mines gained 1.8 percent from July, the Finance Ministry said, adding the figure may be revised downward. Economists expected a 0.3 percent decline.

title: JetBlue Opens Brash Challenge to Southwest
description: After warily circling each other, JetBlue Airways and Southwest Airlines are finally stepping into the ring, the veteran prizefighter vs. his eager protg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNON, ELIZABETH M. (NEE CONNELL)
description: LENNON-Elizabeth M. (nee Connell). On October 9, 2002. Retired teacher, New York City Board of Education. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Loving mother of Mary Lennon, SSND and Thomas J. Fond mother-in-law of Maryellen. Dear sister of Terence Connell, Catherine Hubbard and the late John. Proud grandmother of Eileen Thomas, Terence, Colleen and Caroline. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4 Ave, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday 10 AM, St. Anselm's Church.

title: The New York Times N.F.L. Computer Ranking
description: Based on games through Dec. 2

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHET, LUCILLE A.
description: BLANCHET-Lucille A., 92, of New York City, on October 7. Preceded in death by husband G. Arthur Blanchet. Mother of Lucille Conklin, Beverly Reiss, Margaret Ann Blanchet, Sr. Rosamond Blanchet, RSHM, and Carole Brown, 11 grandchildren and 12 great grandchildren. Visitation 7-9PM Thursday, John Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Funeral Mass 10AM Friday, Holy Cross Church, Rumson, NJ. Entombment Mt. Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ.

title: Dispute Lingers as Longshoremen Return to Work
description: Erik Ragland was among the thousands of longshoremen who returned to work today along the West Coast under a federal court order. His sweaty handshake and the sheet of perspiration seeping from beneath his hard hat were proof enough of that.

title: A Reassuring Visit From Masur
description: The place and the faces were different, but Kurt Masur was a familiar and reassuring presence for New Yorkers on Monday and Tuesday nights. The London Philharmonic was in town, playing in Carnegie Hall and offering the rapt, informed audiences and congenial acoustical space that his years at the New York Philharmonic were hard-pressed to provide. Mr. Masur is currently the London orchestra's principal conductor.

title: Justices Hear Arguments On Extension Of Copyrights
description: No member of the Supreme Court had a good word today for the 1998 law that added 20 years to all existing copyrights. But that did not make the job any easier for Professor Lawrence Lessig of Stanford Law School, who faced an uphill battle to persuade the justices that the extension, which Congress adopted at the behest of the Walt Disney Company and other powerful corporate copyright holders, was not only bad policy but unconstitutional.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Moving the Plum

title: Realistic War Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Curious to Turn Down A Job Offer From Hitler
description: It probably makes sense for filmmakers not to prod an 81-year-old woman too hard, and the gentleness extended to the subject of ''Blind Spot'' seems to grow out of such courtesy. That 81-year-old woman, though, is Traudl Junge, and the full title of the documentary, which plays today at the New York Film Festival, is ''Blind Spot: Hitler's Secretary.'' She served as secretary to Adolf Hitler from 1942 through the end of the war. The access the directors gained to Ms. Junge is remarkable, and it compensates for a lack of filmmaking flair; it's concrete, cold and hard, with Ms. Junge speaking about being a few feet away from arguably the worst tyrant of the 20th century.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Colt Concerned About Its Debt
description: The telecommunications provider Colt Telecom Group, which supplies services to businesses in 13 European countries, said it would fight a bondholder's attempt to appoint an administrator to run the company. The bondholder, Highberry Ltd., a hedge fund based in New York, has contended that the company will not be able to repay or refinance its 1.2 billion ($1.86 billion) of bonds when they mature from 2005 to 2009, a Colt spokesman said, adding that ''allegations made by Highberry are entirely without foundation.

title: Messier Leads Rangers to Victory in Trottier's Debut
description: Mark Messier added a page to his storied career tonight to celebrate Bryan Trottier's debut as a head coach in the National Hockey League.

title: Forum Asks, Who Owns A Dance?
description: Authenticity was once the burning issue in American dance. When works from earlier eras were revived, how much of the original were dancers performing and audiences watching? And then, as the years passed and fashions changed, it became increasingly difficult even to see work by choreographers of the 1930's and 40's, many of them pioneers of American modern dance. Now the questions revolve around whether choreographers in fact own their own dances and even wanted those dances to be seen after their deaths, a central issue most recently in the contentious Martha Graham case.

title: Death and Revenge: Palestinian vs. Palestinian
description: In Gaza, where private pain often has political causes and consequences, it should perhaps come as no surprise that the grief of the Akel family has brought Palestinians to what they call the brink of civil war.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page yesterday about scholarships awarded to 10 medical students misstated part of the name of a unit of the City University of New York. It is the Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education, not Biomedical Engineering.

title: Magazine Ad Pages Rose in September
description: The number of advertising pages in magazines rose in September after declining in August, according to data released yesterday by the Publishers Information Bureau in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUCK, HENRY R.
description: CHUCK-Henry R. Of Brookline, MA. formerly of New York City on Wednesday, October 9th. Beloved husband of the late Jessika (Kolken) Chuck. Loving father of Bill and his wife Maxine of Brookline, MA. Adored grandfather of Elizabeth and Jennifer. Services in Brookline, MA. on Friday, October 11th. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to The Museum of the City of New York, 1220 5th Ave, NY, NY 10029. For further information please call: 617-277-8300

title: Doing Battle for Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Companies Relieved over Reopening of U.S. Ports
description: Businesses across East Asia expressed relief today after President Bush won a temporary court order to reopen 29 West Coast ports in the United States, although worries persisted that the underlying labor dispute had not been resolved.

title: At California's spas, many paths to nirvana
description: SAN FRANCISCO  At Spa Claremont in Berkeley, a thoroughly modern urban resort in the landmark Claremont Hotel, you get cucumber slices in the ice water, pyramids of rolled white towels, and the smell of eucalyptus in the steam bath. And tapes of rainforest pipes and twinkling celestial harps play all day long.

title: Pataki Proposes Breaking Major Impasses in Albany
description: With the election a month away, the Pataki administration has been quietly trying to negotiate solutions to some longstanding impasses on issues of importance to urban voters, which the Democrats have been using to criticize the governor.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Strikers Lose Contract
description: The state has ended its contract with a company whose janitors have struck and will instead seek a contractor that guarantees health benefits to its employees. The move by Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift prevented picketing of the Statehouse by employees of the company, Unicco. Hundreds of employees are demanding health care, increased pay and full-time work. About 80 janitors, all in Service Employees Union Local 254, clean the Statehouse and three other large buildings in Boston that house state offices. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, MARY T. (NEE DILLON)
description: ROBINSON-Mary T. (nee Dillon), age 72, died on Monday, October 7, 2002 at her home in Middletown, NJ. She was predeceased by her husband Francis X. Robinson Sr. in 1994, and her son Ned Robinson in 1995. Her late husband retired from Time, Inc., NYC, in 1986. She is survived by her three sons, seven daughters, four daughters-in-law, six sons-in law, 20 grandchildren, two brothers, one sister, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. For service, interment and donation information, please contact the John E. Day Funeral Home at (732) 747-0332.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Electronics Retailer Acquired
description: Britain's biggest electronics retailer, Dixons Group, agreed to pay 368 million euros ($360.3 million) to gain control of UniEuro, Italy's most profitable chain of domestic-appliance stores. The purchase of the 71 percent stake, raises the stake that Dixons holds to about 96 percent. Dixons expects the addition to increase earnings per share before good will amortization by as much as 3 percent this fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLETTA, FRANK A
description: BALLETTA-Frank A. S & M Klein Company will deeply miss the skills, loyalty and friendship of Frank A. Balletta. We are grateful that he played a part in leading us into the 21st Century. Steven J. Klein Martin P. Klein

title: Chicken and Turkey Recalled After Contamination Is Found
description: The Pilgrim's Pride Corporation, the country's second-largest poultry producer, said today that it had recalled 295,000 pounds of ready-to-eat turkey and chicken that might be contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes.

title: Corrections
