description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the growth of shopping areas in Las Vegas misstated the ownership of the Forum Shops at Caesars. They are owned by the Simon Property Group. (Park Place Entertainment owns Caesars Palace.)

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about President Bush's intervention in a lockout that closed West Coast ports omitted part of two sentences in some copies. The passage should have read: ''Union officials said the workers were merely observing safety precautions, because five longshoremen have died on the job this year. The union said the lockout was a management ploy intended to have the president intervene.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Garden Q.&A. column on Sept. 12 misspelled part of the name of a yellow flower with petals turned back like those of a coneflower. It is Rudbeckia Herbstsonne, not Herbstonne.

title: Gun Discharges In Court Scuffle After Verdict
description: A man who had just been convicted yesterday in Manhattan Criminal Court on a drug dealing charge tried to seize a court officer's gun, which was fired once during a struggle before other officers subdued the convicted man, the authorities said. No one was seriously injured.

title: Text of Statements by F.C.C. Commissioners
description: The following is the text of statements by Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, as well as the three commissioners, Kathleen Q. Abernathy, Michael J. Copps and Kevin J. Martin. This text was taken from the commission's web site, fcc.gov.

title: In Campaigns Nationwide, Plans for Social Security Become a Focus of Ads
description: For years, Republicans have privately fumed over the predictable barrage of election commercials by Democrats on Social Security, while doing little to fend off the blows.

title: Marshall's Gains An Off-Price Toehold In Harlem
description: Manhattan's new source for bargains is its first Marshall's, which is in Harlem. ''We always look for a place that has a large population of people who live and work in the neighborhood,'' said Colleen Healy, a spokeswoman for Marshall's, which has 600 off-price stores in 40 states. For baby's room, wares include a white wooden storage bench (above) with a 15 1/2-inch-high seat and yellow duckling decoration, $79.95; there is also a child-size club chair in chenille. The tabletop department sells Johnson Brothers dinnerware with a pattern of English castles. Marshall's is at 125 West 125th Street (Lenox Avenue); (212) 866-3963.

title: Pressing Cases
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Brother to Brother
description: A dynasty of Bronx-born dynamos, whose style comes from substance.

title: 'Pokmon 4Ever'
description: Directed by Kunihiko Yuyama

title: Court Rules for Cameroon In Oil Dispute With Nigeria
description: The World Court ruled at The Hague today that Cameroon was the rightful owner of an oil-rich peninsula in the Gulf of Guinea that had long been claimed by Nigeria.

title: Pakistani Fundamentalists and Other Opponents of Musharraf Do Well in Elections
description: Both Islamic fundamentalists and secular opponents of President Pervez Musharraf appeared to fare well in national elections on Thursday, in a vote that could complicate the American-led campaign against terrorism, according to unofficial results released early today.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded to Carter With Criticism of Bush
description: PLAINS, Ga., Oct. 11 - For his peacemaking and humanitarian work over the last 25 years, former President Jimmy Carter was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, and the Nobel committee used the occasion to send a sharp rebuke to the Bush administration for its aggressive policy toward Iraq.

title: John Bankston -- 'The Capture and Escape of Mr. M., Chapter 2'
description: Jack Shainman Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTT, JEROME M.
description: COTT-Jerome M. A devoted and loving husband, father, grandfather and brother, passed away on October 8, 2002 in Dallas. He was born March 15, 1938, in Port Chester, NY to Harry and Vera Cott. Jerry graduated from Dartmouth College in 1959 and married Lynn Roth in 1957. Jerry was a former City of Denton Councilman for many years and an executive with Kayser-Roth Corporation. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Lynn; sons, Peter, Jonathan, and Daniel; daughters - in - law, Pamela, Leda, and Shaun; grandchildren, Sara, Allix, and Victoria; brothers, Edward, Dennis, and David; sister, Andy, their families, and a special friend Demi. Funeral services will be held at 12:00 pm, Sunday, October 13, at Sparkman/Hillcrest Northwest Highway Chapel in Dallas. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma Society in memory of Jerry Cott.

title: William Anthony -- 'Once More With Feeling'
description: Dorfman Projects

title: Accenture Posts Quarterly Profit
description: Accenture, the world's largest computer and business consultant, had a fourth-quarter profit as cuts in salaries offset a 3.1 percent decline in sales.

title: Smallpox: Preparing for the Worst
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Enron Papers Allowed To Stay Secret
description: A state panel ruled that the quasi-public state trash authority, which lost nearly $200 million last year in a transaction with Enron, does not have to release eight documents related to the deal. The Journal Inquirer of Manchester had asked the panel, the Freedom of Information Commission, to force the authority to release records of its communications with Gov. John G. Rowland's office since January 1998, more than two years before the authority agreed to pay Enron to buy steam electricity from its trash-burning operation. On Wednesday, the commission decided that seven of the documents were exempt from disclosure because of attorney-client privilege, and that the eighth was exempt because it involved pending court cases. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Bikes That Collapse For Weekend Getaways
description: BIKES rule on weekends. Just ask a country-house squire, sometime mariner, recreational vehicle owner or Tour de France dreamer. Bikes go to the beach, to the village cafe, down rural lanes and along their assigned paths. But to get to their weekend lives, bikes often have to fit into cars, and from Monday to Friday, there's the problem of stowing them.

title: The Lonely Voice Of Senator Byrd
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Station Blast Kills 9 in Chechnya
description: A powerful explosion tore through a police station this evening in Grozny, the Chechen capital, killing at least nine and burying many under rubble, according to officials and news reports.

title: Rome Journal; Pinocchio Infatuates Italians (and That's No Lie)
description: His likeness is everywhere, beaming impishly from the covers of books, the pages of magazines and the posters at countless bus stops and street corners.

description: 20 Texas (5-0)

title: Police Confirm Sniper's Link To 7th Killing
description: The sniper had already moved on hours earlier in the rain by the time ballistic experts finally confirmed his seventh killing in eight days. Washington area residents were already deeper into their fears, waiting for his next move.

title: Follow the Flock; Where the Birds Are, From Sandhill Cranes to Tundra Swans
description: IF you are interested in following the migration of birds this fall and winter, there are several good options around the country:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest Rate Unchanged
description: With no sign of an economic upsurge, the Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent for the 11th consecutive month. Britain has recorded stronger growth than other major European economies, but the recovery has been gradual and economists are not expecting changes in the rate until next year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Throngs Again Demand Venezuelan Leader Quit
description: Banging pans, blowing whistles and demanding that President Hugo Chvez leave office, hundreds of thousands of protesters marched through this capital today as tensions persisted six months after Mr. Chvez was briefly overthrown in the aftermath of a similar protest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMUTTER, HOWARD L.
description: PERLMUTTER-Howard L. Of Fair Lawn, New Jersey, on Thursday, October 10, 2002. Husband of Elaine, father of David Perlmutter, Carol Berley and Betsy Sonnenblick, grandfather of Seth & Joshua Perlmutter, and Joel, Rachel, Lili and Fran Berley, and Esti, Avi and Eli Sonnenblick. Services 10 AM, today, at Louis Suburban Chapel, 13 - 01 Broadway, Fair Lawn, NJ.

title: Pegging a Party as Quitters
description: This advertisement, titled ''The Lesson,'' is the first commercial that the New Jersey Republican Party has released since the Democratic incumbent, Senator Robert G. Torricelli, dropped out of the race for the United States Senate. It was released yesterday and is scheduled to run only on cable television stations across the state for a short time this week.

title: Seeking a Smoking Gun in U.S. Violence
description: Michael Moore's new documentary, ''Bowling for Columbine,'' rapturously greeted at the Cannes Film Festival in May, opens today in New York City and Los Angeles in an atmosphere of intense political polarization. Not that Mr. Moore, a cheerful rabble-rouser and author of the best seller ''Stupid White Men,'' would have it any other way. But in times of political anxiety and global insecurity -- most times, in other words -- arguments have a tendency to turn into shouting matches.

title: Revolving- Door Monsters
description: President Bush and Vice President Cheney portray Saddam Hussein as so menacing and terrifying that one might think they've lain awake at night for years worrying about him.

title: Dockworkers' Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Do-It-Yourself Contractor: A Hat Hard to Wear
description: SO what could be so tough about being her own contractor, Jody Cukier Siegler thought. Didn't she have two degrees from Harvard? Wouldn't she be supervising just a minor renovation of her weekend home, Botox as opposed to a face-lift?

title: Sports of The Times; Messier Is Now a Part Of the City
description: THE jutting jaw, the chiseled chin, the deep creases that line his face have seen as much action as the half-moon area in front of the goal. It's a face everyone knows, the distinctive mug belonging to Mark Messier.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Trims Management
description: Vivendi Universal plans to cut 152 jobs at its Paris headquarters to help save 140 million euros ($138 million) a year. The company, which has headquarters in Paris and New York, will concentrate management tasks in the French office. New York will become a representative office, primarily responsible for North America, Vivendi said.

title: Oracle-BMW Boat Suffers First Loss
description: It had the makings of a thrilling race, for three-quarters of a leg. Ernesto Berterelli's Alinghi Swiss Challenge sailed today against Larry Ellison's unbeaten Oracle-BMW Team on the Hauraki Gulf off New Zealand in winds between 8 and 15 knots, in a matchup of money, spinnaker-sized egos and hired sailing talent.

title: Holiday on Monday: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES Closed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sampling Imre Kertesz
description: These are excerpts from novels by Imre Kertesz, translated by Christopher C. Wilson and Katharina M. Wilson, and published by Northwestern University Press.

title: Ben Eastman, 91, Runner and Former World Record-Holder
description: Ben Eastman, who became the world's fastest quarter-mile and half-mile runner 70 years ago only to meet frustration in the Olympics, died Sunday at his home in Hotchkiss, Colo. He was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SOL
description: BERMAN-Sol, 94 years old of Palm Beach, Florida, on October 10. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Adored father, grandfather and great-grandfather of Gail & Alan Levenstein, Barbara and Martin Weinburg, Arthur Rosenstein, Miranda, Jessica & Antony Levenstein, Bonnie and Scott Rogoff and family, Susan and Adam Hurwitz and family, Robert and Jean Rosenstein. Brother of Sylvia Weinberg. Dear uncle and great-uncle. He will be missed.

title: Fatal Shooting Intensifies Hunt for Suburban Sniper
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 11 - The shooting death of another gas station customer sent hundreds of police today into a frantic, guns-drawn dragnet across Washington's highways in a fruitless search for the suburban sniper who has stalked one victim after another across the region.

title: At Korean DMZ, South takes lead in mine-clearing
description: DORASAN, South Korea:  While South Korean soldiers cleared away mines in the Demilitarized Zone with the latest heavy-duty equipment, North Koreans not much more than a kilometer away worked with picks and shovels at repairing a bridge blown up in the Korean War.

title: Madden's Two Goals Help The Out-of-Sorts Devils
description: John Madden watched his slap shot slide inside the right post of Ottawa's net. From the bench, Devils Coach Pat Burns said he saw it clear as day.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about New York City women who left welfare for work misstated a phrase in the name of an organization that provided job counseling for one of the women. It is the Women's Housing and Economic Development Corporation, not Educational Development. The article also misstated the organization's relationship with city government on that program. It is the main contractor, not a subcontractor.

title: Japan Vows A New Effort On Bad Debt
description: After years of half-hearted measures and political infighting, Japanese policy makers appear to be inching closer to a unified plan to rid the nation's banks of their nonperforming loans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DR. JACK
description: GOLDMAN-Dr. Jack. Beloved husband of Bea. Devoted father of Stuart, Susan and Ronald. Cherished brother of Saul. Dear grandfather of Jessica, Paley and Michael. Services are today 2 PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED With no sign of an economic upsurge, the Bank of England left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent for the 11th consecutive month. Britain has recorded stronger growth than other major European economies, but the recovery has been gradual and economists are not expecting changes in the rate until next year.

title: How to Say 'Enough,' Gracefully; Trinity Church Ponders Future of a Sept. 11 Memorial
description: One of the longest lasting, most-visited grass-roots memorials to the Sept. 11 attacks, at the fence surrounding St. Paul's Chapel near ground zero, still grows daily. Visitors stop to drape a signed T-shirt across the bars, place a ball cap atop an iron spike, leave their mark on what has become the world's guest book. New York City, We're thinking of you. Love, Everyplace Else.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Oil At Caspian Sea Site
description: An international consortium of oil companies that includes Exxon Mobil announced it had discovered new oil and gas reserves in the Kazakhstan sector of the Caspian Sea. The seven-company consortium, which is led by Eni of Italy, said initial drilling indicated an oil flow rate of 2,300 barrels a day. The field is about 50 miles from Kashagan, the largest discovery in the Caspian Sea in recent history, also in the Kazakh section. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Big Shareholder Seeks to Lead Class Action Against El Paso
description: Oscar S. Wyatt Jr., the Texas oil executive and one of the largest shareholders in the El Paso Corporation, has moved to join a group of class-action lawsuits that accuse the company of misrepresenting its finances and misleading investors.

title: Moving a Spanish Magazine Up in the World
description: YOU don't trail behind Lisa Quiroz, the founding publisher of People en Espaol. You are swept along. She's a compact dynamo in a gray Brooks Brothers pantsuit and Prada heels. On a recent afternoon, she's on a brisk stroll through the Midtown offices that house the popular spinoff of Time Inc.'s People magazine.

title: 'The Transporter'
description: Directed by Cory Yuen

title: F.C.C. Blocks EchoStar Deal With DirecTV
description: The Federal Communications Commission blocked the merger of the nation's two largest satellite television broadcasters today, the first time in 36 years that the agency has challenged a large corporate deal for being anticompetitive and against the public interest.

title: Rodriguez Gives Miami Program a Financial Lift
description: Saying the University of Miami's Mark Light Stadium was his Yankee Stadium as an area youth, the Texas Rangers' Alex Rodriguez pledged $3.9 million over six years yesterday to help the Hurricanes' baseball program. Much of the money will be used to renovate the stadium, which ultimately will be called Alex Rodriguez Park.

title: 3rd-Quarter Profit Doubles at First Data
description: GREENWOOD VILLAGE, Colo., Oct. 10 (Bloomberg)  The First Data Corporation , a leading money transfer service, said today that its third-quarter profit more than doubled as it expanded its Western Union business in Mexico, China and Eastern Europe.

title: Moles At Work
description: So here's my theory: Michael Oxley, Harvey Pitt and George W. Bush are all Communist moles who have worked their way into the center of the capitalist system in order to destroy it. How else can you make sense of their actions?

title: Charles Guggenheim, Filmmaker, Dies at 78
description: Charles Guggenheim, an Oscar-winning documentary filmmaker who focused on American life and who was an early producer of advertisements for political campaigns, died on Wednesday in Washington. He was 78.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means tickets were at the booth for last Friday night only.

title: Cairo Finds a Place With the Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS

title: He Made Presidents Smile And They Remember Him
description: President Bush put aside official duties for two hours this morning to attend the funeral of Harold W. Hancock, a White House elevator operator who took the president up to his private quarters each evening at the end of his workday in the Oval Office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMONDSTEIN, CHARLOTTE BERTHA ETTA KRAUS
description: DIAMONDSTEIN - Charlotte Bertha Etta Kraus, 85. Of Trenton, NJ, formerly of Commack on October 9, 2002. Wife of the late Saul. Mother of Ronni Diamondstein and Karen Goldberg. Sister of Gerry Girshek, grandmother of Katie and Rachel Goldberg. Funeral 11:15AM Sunday, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. For further information, call Mt. Sinai Memorial Chapels, 732-390-9199

title: Lunch Aid Cut By Assistance For Drought, 2 Senators Say
description: Two Democratic senators accused the Bush administration today of spending money needed for school lunch and child nutrition programs on emergency drought assistance for ranchers.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Posts 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: Network Associates, a maker of antivirus computer software, had a third-quarter profit after cutting costs, selling assets and completing the purchase of McAfee.com. Its shares rose as much as 28 percent. Net income was $9.09 million, or 6 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $11.3 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier, the company said in a statement. Sales rose 13 percent, to $232.2 million from $205.6 million. ''For the first time, we are one company,'' the chief executive, George Samenuk, said in a conference call. ''For the first time, all three business units are profitable.''

title: Aurilia's Blasts and Schmidt's Arm Give Giants the Edge
description: The St. Louis Cardinals neutralized Barry Bonds tonight, surviving their strategy of pitching to him by holding him to one walk in four plate appearances. But even with Bonds faded into the background, the San Francisco Giants continued to pound on the Cardinals.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: IOWA: FARMERS KEEP JUDGMENT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAIMOVICI, DR. ROBERT
description: HAIMOVICI-Dr. Robert. Of Weston, Massachusetts, on Wednesday, October 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Jeanne Ackman Haimovici. Loving father of Claudia and Andrew. Dear son of Herman and Renee Haimovici. He was dedicated to his family, friends and profession. Services will be held on Friday. For further information please call 617-277-8300.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, KENNETH
description: KRAUS-Kenneth. We are saddened by the loss of our magical friend. His good humor, generous spirit and sage advice were but a few of the qualities from which we benefited and which we will now miss. Our sincerest condolences to Susan, Elizabeth, Gisbert, Jennifer and Elan. Arlyn, Owen, Sally and Hank

title: PFIZER SAYS DRUG REDUCES HEART ATTACKS AND STROKES
description: Pfizer said yesterday that a study had found that its Lipitor cholesterol drug reduced heart attacks and strokes, suggesting that lowering cholesterol helps decrease risks stemming from hypertension. The study involved almost 20,000 patients with high blood pressure and was intended to compare the effects of new hypertension medicines with standard treatments in reducing heart risk, Pfizer said. Pfizer, which financed the research, said the Lipitor portion of the study was stopped because the drug demonstrated a significant benefit. The findings suggest that hypertension patients could benefit from aggressively treating even moderately elevated cholesterol levels. Pfizer said it had no plans to change the Lipitor label to reflect the findings.

title: The Economy Is Better Than It Looks
description: A sense of gloom permeates most conversations about the economy, but our current situation is not as dire as some would have it. We may not be growing at the heady rates of the late 1990's, but we're a long way from a Japan-like bubble economy or even a double-dip recession.

title: Pepn Osorio
description: Ronald Feldman Gallery

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal Dismisses Lawyer
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal fired a Dutch lawyer attending the trial of Slobodan Milosevic as a ''friend of the court,'' saying he had created an impression of being biased. The lawyer, Michail Wladimiroff, said that he had been misquoted by a Dutch newspaper that reported he had said the court already had enough evidence to find Mr. Milosevic guilty. But the court said the perception had been created that he was not neutral. The tribunal had appointed three ''friends of the court'' to help guarantee a fair trial for Mr. Milosevic, who acts as his own lawyer. Mr. Wladimiroff will not be replaced, court officials said. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Big Donors' Dealings With State Give Pataki Big Advantage
description: Two terms in an office that controls tens of billions of dollars in spending and his status as the front-runner have given Gov. George E. Pataki an extraordinary advantage in the contest to pull in the buckets of cash needed to run a modern-day political campaign.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: 'It Was a Weird Journey, Really'

title: Playing Tricks With Reality and Realism
description: THE nation's capital may be the single biggest political power generator on earth, but its grip on reality can seem mighty relaxed. Never mind the government, just look at the city: so rich but so poor; so monumental but so run down. Does anyone ever know what's really going on? Anyway, it makes sense that reality, or maybe realism, is the underlying theme of exhibitions at three of the city's major museums.

title: ANTIQUES
description: Let Them Sit On Chaises

title: 'Multitudes'; John Bankston; Pepn Osorio
description: 'Multitudes'

title: Corrections
description: An erroneous set of mutual fund tables appeared in Business Day yesterday, carrying week-old data, for trading on Oct. 2. The correct tables are online today, at nytimes.com/business. Readers wishing copies by mail may telephone (212) 556-1992 or write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; e-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: CONGRESS AUTHORIZES BUSH TO USE FORCE AGAINST IRAQ, CREATING A BROAD MANDATE
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly early this morning to authorize President Bush to use force against Iraq, joining with the House in giving him a broad mandate to act against Saddam Hussein.

title: Giuliani Firm Gets Contract To Advise Mexico City Police
description: Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that his consulting firm had signed a contract to advise Mexico City's police officials on crime-reduction techniques to deal with an epidemic of kidnappings, murders and robberies.

title: Editorial Observer; Moral Perfection and the Incorrigible Franklin
description: Lately I've been reading Edmund S. Morgan's new biography of Benjamin Franklin. And when I'm not actually reading the text of this book, following the evolution of Franklin's protracted diplomatic career, I find myself staring at the man on the dust jacket -- Franklin as he was portrayed in 1785, age 79, by the painter Joseph Siffrede Duplessis.

title: Panel Advises Resuming Gene Studies
description: Despite new evidence that a French gene therapy experiment caused a 3-year-old boy to develop an illness similar to leukemia, a government advisory panel recommended today that similar studies proceed, with some restrictions, because they offer hope to children with fatal immune deficiencies.

title: Discovering Rap Music Together, Then a Bit More Than Friendship
description: An amiable uptown remake of ''My Best Friend's Wedding,'' Rick Famuyiwa's ''Brown Sugar'' follows the evolving relationship between Sidney (Sanaa Lathan), an attractive young woman who has just been appointed the editor of the hip-hop review XXL, and Dre (Taye Diggs), a music producer who has been bound to Sidney since they were children.

title: Eight Ears, Four Stations
description: Face it, drivers. It may be a long time before 500 channels appear on your in-car entertainment system. For now, two seems extravagant, letting Mom and Dad tune in the radio while the children watch a video in the back.

title: Truman's World View
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Corporate Sale With Personality

title: Texas Democrats Pin Hopes on a Big Spender
description: Not so very long ago, Tony Sanchez was just a fabulously wealthy businessman, known in Texas business and political circles but unknown to the voting public. He fancied his thin mustache and wore aviator-styled glasses. He was supposedly a Democrat, but he also gave generously to George W. Bush.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EDS, Plano, Tex., the claims processor, received a renewal on its contract to service California's Medicaid program.

title: The Hazardous Path Ahead
description: With war resolutions from the House and Senate now in hand, President Bush has won the Congressional assent he requested for a military showdown with Iraq. That makes it all the more important that Mr. Bush and the nation consider the dangers that lie ahead. As lawmakers were debating this week, new information came to light that made plain just how difficult it will be to manage an escalating crisis with Iraq in ways that assure a constructive outcome.

title: You Only Live Once, But You Can Make It Last
description: The Tucks are an odd lot: a family of four, headed by gentle Angus (William Hurt) and girlish Mae (Sissy Spacek) and completed by the dreamy teenager Jesse (Jonathan Jackson) and his surly older brother, Miles (Scott Bairstow). They've been living in their simple cabin in the woods, somewhere in the vicinity of the small New England town of Treegap, for quite a while now -- about a hundred years, according to Mae, as the story opens in 1914.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Vote For The Czar
description: A member of the lower house of Parliament proposed erecting a monument to Russia's last czar, Nicholas II, on the empty pedestal on Lubyanka Square in Moscow where a statue of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the founder of the Soviet secret police, once stood. Last month, the mayor of Moscow, Yuri M. Luzhkov, announced that the city planned to restore Dzerzhinsky's statue in front of the former headquarters of the K.G.B., prompting protests and a rebuff from the Kremlin. The monument was pulled down after the collapse of the August 1991 coup, which hastened the end of the Soviet Union. Aleksandr M. Fedulov said Parliament would consider a resolution on the alternative monument next week, explaining that a statue of Nicholas would represent Soviet crimes against the royal family. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: I.M.F. and Argentina Are Close to Accord on Debt Repayment
description: The International Monetary Fund is edging closer to a deal on stretching out payments on nearly $11 billion in loans to Argentina, according to officials at the fund as well as in the Argentine government.

title: 36 Hours | Sacramento
description: THE 100-degree days are gone, and so are the lobbyists and politicians who normally snap up tables in Sacramento's best restaurants -- it's campaign season. The winter rains haven't arrived, the Sacramento River cruises are still running, and you can have Old Sacramento, the obligatory visitors' stop, almost to yourself. In Midtown, the quirky shops and small galleries are open, and the flat, quiet streets invite bicycling. You won't get lost, whether walking, biking or driving; in 1848, when thousands of manic gold seekers were debarking from steamboats here for the overland rush to mining country, the new city of Sacramento was laid out in a neat grid, with north-south streets numbered and east-west streets lettered. You can also find something here that California isn't known for: fall color. After a walk down streets shaded by hardwoods, palms and conifers, you'll be ready to believe a hard-to-verify local claim: that Sacramento, with one million trees and 407,000 people, has more trees per capita than any other city in the world. BARBARA IRELAND

title: Mets Holding Out For Baker
description: The Mets believe that Buck Showalter has been offered a job elsewhere, but they are willing to wait for San Francisco Giants Manager Dusty Baker to become available for an interview.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: FIREFIGHTERS' UNION REJECTS WAGE PLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, STEPHEN ARNOLD
description: WEISS-Stephen Arnold. His fellow members and Joint Masters of the Golden's Bridge Hounds are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. We will remember and honor his dedication and love for our sport and countryside. Our sincerest condolences to his beloved wife Gretchen and children.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Slows
description: The Singapore economy unexpectedly slowed in the third quarter to an annual pace of 3.7 percent, less than the second quarter's rate of 3.9 percent and much slower than forecasts for growth of 6.5 percent. The report, released by the Trade and Industry Ministry, said industries that produce goods expanded 7.8 percent from a year earlier, the same pace as in the second quarter. Services grew 1.8 percent, more than the 1.6 percent growth in the previous quarter, the report showed.

title: National Briefing: Science and Health
description: DROUGHT IN WEST MAY BE EASING New federal research suggests the worst of the drought may be over for Colorado and the Southwest, with a new occurence of El Nino potentially bringing more snow this winter. But scientists with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration cautioned that it would take a while to recover from the drought, one of the most severe on record. El Nino, which started in April, is a warming of the large area of water in the tropical Pacific.

title: Many Mysteries Can Fit Inside a Single Submarine
description: David Twohy is turning out to be one of those rare screenwriters who are actually better as directors. As the author of the scripts for ''The Fugitive'' (1993), ''Waterworld'' (1995) and ''G.I. Jane'' (1997), Mr. Twohy has an impressive list of Hollywood credits.

title: Pedestrian Bridge Collapses, Killing One and Injuring 9
description: A worker was killed and nine other people were injured this morning when a pedestrian bridge collapsed during construction outside of Utica. A state bridge inspector was among the injured, said officials with the State Department of Transportation.

title: Precise Classical Technique That Transmutes Into Art
description: Helgi Tomasson brought the San Francisco Ballet up to an international standard after he became artistic director in 1985. He did so by raising the level of its classical dancing.

title: Communing With Oddballs on a Midlife Odyssey
description: Every morning, Vincent (Jacques Bidou), the melancholy hero of Otar Iosseliani's ''Monday Morning,'' awakens at 6 o'clock to the jangle of three alarm clocks and sets off for the factory where he works as a welder. His jowly face and stooped shoulders suggest a man worn down by routine, not so much miserable as alienated from his capacity for joy.

title: 9/11 INQUIRY EYES POSSIBLE 5TH PILOT
description: The authorities interviewing a member of Al Qaeda in military custody overseas are investigating a new theory of the Sept. 11 plot: that the suspect, Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah bin al-Shibh, was planning to pilot a fifth hijacked plane to strike the White House.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a speech by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan on the eve of the first legislative elections since his seizure of power three years ago misstated the day of the balloting for a national parliament and provincial assemblies. It was yesterday; it is not today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the Online Diary column in Circuits yesterday omitted a period in the Web address for a survey of North American English dialects. The site is www.hcs.harvard.edu/golder/dialect.

title: A Little Something in Reserve
description: It is only October, but Michael Jordan, a possible sixth man for the Washington Wizards, was asked what he sees in the future for his team, as far ahead, say, as June?

title: The N.C.A.A. Selects Brand As Its Chief
description: When Myles Brand, the Indiana University president, fired the basketball coach Bob Knight in September 2000, the decision prompted a student protest. In riot gear, the police guarded Brand's home.

title: A Stand-Up Guy Again
description: Jerry Seinfeld reflects on the serious business of making people laugh in ''Comedian,'' a documentary that examines how an entertainer follows an act in which he's reached the top. The answer is that the star of the 90's television mega-hit reinvents himself on the comedy-club circuit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLETTA, FRANK A.
description: BALLETTA-Frank A. S & M Klein Company will deeply miss the skills, loyalty and friendship of Frank A. Balletta. We are grateful that he played a part in leading us into the 21st Century. Steven J. Klein Martin P. Klein

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about Merrill Lynch's decision to reduce the number of stocks it trades to 2,400 from 10,000 by the end of the year referred imprecisely at one point to the larger number. The 10,000 figure included stocks traded on the OTC Bulletin Board and in the so-called Pink Sheets. They were not all issues traded on the Nasdaq market.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about predictions by several senators that Congress would act quickly on Iraq omitted the name of the television program on which Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said Democrats should be more aggressive and support President Bush. It was ''Fox News Sunday.''

title: Preliminary Investigation Indicates Oil Tanker Was Attacked
description: The French government said tonight that the explosion that crippled a French supertanker in Yemen on Sunday was most likely caused by a terrorist attack.

title: McCall Calls for U.S. Investigation of State's Policies on Treatment of the Mentally Ill
description: The treatment of the mentally ill became the central topic of the governor's race yesterday, as the Democratic candidate, H. Carl McCall, called for a federal investigation into the Pataki administration's practice of releasing patients from state psychiatric hospitals to locked floors in nursing homes.

title: Two Nods to Feminism, Long Snubbed by Curators
description: Most of the interesting American artists of the last 30 years are as interesting as they are in part because of the feminist art movement of the early 1970's. It changed everything.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SINGAPORE: ECONOMY SLOWS The Singapore economy unexpectedly slowed in the third quarter to an annual pace of 3.7 percent, less than the second quarter's rate of 3.9 percent and much slower than forecasts for growth of 6.5 percent. The report, released by the Trade and Industry Ministry, said industries that produce goods expanded 7.8 percent from a year earlier, the same pace as in the second quarter. Services grew 1.8 percent, more than the 1.6 percent growth in the previous quarter, the report showed. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paintings That Recall Their Time, Now Gone
description: An exhibition at the Jewish Museum won't do for Adolph Gottlieb's reputation what a recent retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art did for Barnett Newman's. The Philadelphia exhibition made a convincing case for Newman as an enduring Modernist classic. With Gottlieb, we have art that is more of its own moment; it looks dated. Yet while Gottlieb's painting may not have aged well, the show is still interesting for the light it shines on a period of tremendous creative ferment.

title: Putin Offers Qualified Support for U.N. Proposals for Iraq
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11  President Vladimir V. Putin said today that Russia was prepared to support new United Nations Security Council resolutions on Iraq, but only to strengthen the work of inspectors searching for its weapons programs and not to authorize the use of military force.

title: Corrections
description: The Books of The Times review last Thursday, about ''Leadership'' by Rudolph W. Giuliani and ''Worth the Fighting For'' by Senator John McCain, referred incorrectly to Morris K. Udall, for whom Mr. McCain's book expresses admiration. He served in the House, not the Senate.

title: Text: Statement From Carter Accepting Prize
description: Following is the complete text of the statement from former President Jimmy Carter today in accepting the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize, as distributed by The Carter Center in Atlanta:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Aid From U.S. To Clear War's Legacy
description: The United States has begun delivering $1.5 million worth of mine detecting equipment as part of a program aimed at clearing some of the 5 million land mines and up to 800,000 unexploded bombs that still litter Vietnam 27 years after the end of the war. An initial shipment of mine detectors is to be followed by personal protection equipment, deep metal detectors, unexploded-ordnance disposal tools and underwater mine-clearing equipment. Hundreds of people are killed each year by wartime explosives. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: THE HAGUE: TRIBUNAL DISMISSES LAWYER The United Nations war crimes tribunal fired a Dutch lawyer attending the trial of Slobodan Milosevic as a "friend of the court," saying he had created an impression of being biased. The lawyer, Michail Wladimiroff, said that he had been misquoted by a Dutch newspaper that reported he had said the court already had enough evidence to find Mr. Milosevic guilty. But the court said the perception had been created that he was not neutral. The tribunal had appointed three "friends of the court" to help guarantee a fair trial for Mr. Milosevic, who acts as his own lawyer. Mr. Wladimiroff will not be replaced, court officials said. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Afrikaners Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Just a Nobody, He's a Wilde Man
description: A wistful, simple melody on a lonely flute; a beaten-down man reciting ecstatic poetry; a host of eccentric-looking common folk in a ''This Is Your Life'' tableau: a promise of savory, hokey sentimentality whispers through the opening moments of ''A Man of No Importance,'' the self-effacing new musical that opened last night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Maryland Republicans Fear Killings Will Influence the Race for Governor
description: The fatal sniper attacks that have gripped this state could recast what has already been one of the more unusual races for governor between Lt. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend and Representative Robert L. Ehrlich Jr., who hold sharply contrasting views on gun control.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Good Ol' Boy on Good Ol' Girls

title: Cowart Adjusting As Time Goes By
description: Linebacker Sam Cowart, who has just 44 tackles in five games, said he was still trying to find his comfort zone with the Jets' defense, a telling indicator of the unfamiliarity that has hindered the unit so far. With Buffalo, Cowart played in a 3-4 defense. Here, he is the weakside linebacker in a 4-3 scheme.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford Appeals for Patience As It Attempts Turnaround

title: Jim Seymour, 60, Chronicler Of Personal Computers' Rise
description: Jim Seymour, an early and influential technical writer who explained the benefits and headaches of personal computers for two decades in enthusiasts' periodicals like PC Week and PC Magazine, died on Tuesday in Austin, Tex., where he lived. He was 60.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Shakespeare Gets a Shot

title: Halt Paramilitary Activity, Blair Tells Irish Republicans
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair told Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, today that Irish republicans had to abandon their ''dual strategy'' of combining paramilitary activity with politics if peace in Northern Ireland was to be assured.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It's quite possible to have lived in New York City for decades and still not have a clue about how to find Tudor City. I'm not proud of this, but to pretend otherwise would be unworthy. Luckily on a recent rainy evening I had one of those ideal New York cabbies who not only knew of Tudor City, a leafy residential enclave on a rise near the United Nations, but also knew a shortcut for getting to Tudor City Place, a quiet north-south thoroughfare that runs from 40th to 43rd Streets between First and Second Avenues.

title: Ranch Houses: At Home on the Range, Deer and Antelope Included
description: WHO: Kathleen West, 43, general manager of a mountain resort lodge.

title: Indict Individuals, Not Charities
description: On Wednesday, the government indicted Enaam M. Arnaout, the leader of the Benevolence International Foundation, a prominent Muslim charity, on charges that he helped finance Osama bin Laden's terrorist activities.

title: F.C.C. Approves a Digital Radio Technology
description: The Federal Communications Commission unanimously approved a method yesterday for broadcasting digital radio within current analog channels.

title: 2 Ex-Officials Of WorldCom Plead Guilty
description: Two former executives of WorldCom Inc. pleaded guilty yesterday to fraud and conspiracy charges stemming from a scheme to hide $7 billion in expenses that forced the company into the biggest bankruptcy case in history.

title: An Abuse of Copyright
description: Four years ago, after vigorous lobbying by media corporations, Congress extended copyrights on everything from ''Mickey Mouse'' to ''The Sun Also Rises'' by 20 years. This was a bad idea. It restricts the public's access to vast numbers of works and limits the ways contemporary artists and writers can borrow from them.

title: Smallpox: Preparing for the Worst
description: To the Editor:

title: Marketers gather to talk of coping with tough times.
description: GROWING doubt about the course of the economy has dimmed the mood of consumer marketers as they gather for the first meeting of their trade association in two years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Wheat For U.N. Food Agency
description: For the first time Russia will donate food to the United Nations World Food Program, the agency's executive director, James T. Morris, said. During talks with Mr. Morris in Moscow this week, Russian officials pledged to contribute 30,000 metric tons of wheat in the coming year to the agency's relief programs in southern Africa, Afghanistan and North Korea. The donation reflected bumper crops of wheat and other grains in recent years that have helped Russia jump from being a recipient of food aid to a donor. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: In California, Bars Live On Without Their Indoor Smog
description: There is something missing from a barfly's hands when cigarettes are taken out of the picture.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Aurilia's Blasts and Schmidt's Arm Give Giants the Edge
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10  The St. Louis Cardinals neutralized Barry Bonds tonight, surviving their strategy of pitching to him by holding him to one walk in four plate appearances. But even with Bonds faded into the background, the San Francisco Giants continued to pound on the Cardinals.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Deluxe Doll Store To Open In Midtown
description: A toy maker plans to open in a prime area of Midtown a five-story store carrying mainly expensive dolls for pre-teenage girls. The toy maker, the Pleasant Company, a Mattel Company division, plans to open the store next fall at 609 Fifth Avenue at 49th Street, near Saks Fifth Avenue. The toy maker is known for its mail-order American Girl dolls, which come with illustrated storybooks, have costumes and accessories, and sell for $84 and up. Called the American Girl Place, it will also have a cafe, a doll hospital and a theater. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: When Brightest Fall Reds Are Brake Lights Ahead
description: LAST Saturday, 13 tour buses lumbered through Montpelier, Vt., to Burr Morse's maple sugar farm, three miles out of town, for a look at antique tractors, a slide show on the history of maple sugaring and a close-up view of his blushing sugar maples, now in what Mr. Morse called ''total brilliance.'' The buses were joined on the road to Mr. Morse's by a parade of cars on similar missions. The maple sugar was a sidelight. These sojourners were roaming the roads in search of the Peak.

title: NBC to Change Top Executive at 'Today'
description: Despite reporting its biggest audience totals in five years, the ''Today'' show on NBC will make a change in its most important production position, replacing the current executive producer, Jonathan Wald, an NBC executive said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IVIN
description: MANN-Ivin. On October 8, 2002. Former President of the Board of Trustees of Fountain House, Inc., having served as a Trustee for over 50 years. He is survived by his sons Henry and Peter, his grandchildren Jennifer and David, and his loving companion of many years, Elaine Felsher. Contributions in his memory may be made to Fountain House Inc., 425 West 47th St., NYC, 10036. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Stock-Car Series Mulls Rule Change
description: Officials from the ARCA stock-car series are considering a rules change after the death of the driver Eric Martin. Martin was killed Wednesday during a practice session at Lowe's Motor Speedway in Concorde, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIST, VERA GLASER
description: LIST-Vera Glaser, 94. Of Greenwich, CT, on October 10, 2002. Survived by three daughters and their spouses, Carol and Eric Schwartz of Denver, CO, Olga and George Mack of NYC, and Viki Laura List of Rosemont, PA. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. Predeceased by her husband, Albert A., daughter, Jo List Levinson, grandson, Michael Israel and brother, Samuel. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at List Hall, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, NYC. Burial, Fall River, MA. Shiva at the Macks, 980 5th Ave. (79th St.), on Monday and Tuesday, 1-5 and 7-9 PM, and at 201 Byram Shore Road, Greenwich, CT. Wednesday, 1-6 P.M. Inquiries to Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 212769-4400. In lieu of flowers, make donations to the Vera List Scholarship Fund at the New School University, 66 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011, would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: More Political Prisoners Freed
description: In the latest of a string of releases, the military government said it had freed 31 political prisoners including 7 elderly officials of the pro-democracy party, the National League for Democracy. At the same time, the Paris-based human rights group Reporters Without Borders said about 30 people were arrested last month for possessing or distributing underground opposition publications. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Aurilia's Blasts and Schmidt's Arm Give Giants the Edge
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10  The St. Louis Cardinals neutralized Barry Bonds tonight, surviving their strategy of pitching to him by holding him to one walk in four plate appearances. But even with Bonds faded into the background, the San Francisco Giants continued to pound on the Cardinals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVIN, MARGARET
description: GARVIN-Margaret. NYC2012 extends deepest sympathies to our dear friend, Alexander Garvin, on the death of his beloved mother, Margaret, a woman truly ahead of her time. Daniel L. Doctoroff, Founder Jay L. Kriegel, Exec Dir

title: Bus Driver's Frantic Struggle Averts Bloodbath in Tel Aviv
description: The man slipped as he leaped at rush hour this morning for the bus's closing rear door, falling backward and striking his head on the pavement. So Baruch Neuman, the driver, set his handbrake and ran to help, with a medic who happened to be nearby.

title: Weekender | Garrison, N.Y.
description: GARRISON is a great place to disappear. Benedict Arnold knew it: after he tried to surrender West Point to the British he escaped up a carriage road in Garrison.

title: The Fall of Adam
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Family Fundamentals'
description: Directed by Arthur Dong

title: 'No Greater Love: Abstraction'
description: Jack Tilton/Anna Kustera Gallery

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: BRIBERY ARRESTS

title: Roland Flexner; Iona Rozeal Brown
description: Caren Golden Fine Art

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Price-Fixing Investigation
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, TotalFinaElf and other companies said European officials searched their offices as part of a price-fixing inquiry in the asphalt markets. Exxon said European Union regulators searched its office in Hamburg last week. Royal Dutch/Shell said European officials inspected its bitumen department in the Netherlands. The commission also investigated Royal BAM NBM and the Hollandsche Beton Group, the two biggest road builders in the Netherlands. The investigation is focusing on accusations of price fixing in the bitumen industry, the commission said. Bitumen, a byproduct of processing crude oil, is used primarily in the construction industry for surfacing roads and waterproofing.

title: Study Sees Cancer Survival In a More Optimistic Light
description: ''It's malignant? Then give it to me straight, Doc. How long have I got?''

title: Madden's Two Goals Help the Out-of-Sorts Devils
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 10  The Devils played their season opener tonight looking very much like a work in progress. Their top-line forwards literally tripped over each other. They spent much of their time on the power play just trying to get the puck out of their own end.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: JUNIPER LOSS WIDENS ON HIGHER COSTS Juniper Networks , the world's second-largest maker of equipment to direct Internet traffic, had a wider third-quarter net loss on costs related to its July acquisition of Unisphere Networks . The loss was $88.3 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $29.7 million, or 9 cents, in the quarter a year ago, Juniper said in a statement. Sales fell 25 percent, to $152 million from $201.7 million, and will be unchanged this quarter. Excluding severance and other acquisition-related costs and a gain, Juniper said, it had a loss of 2 cents a share, the first on that basis since 1999. Shares of Juniper, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose 7 cents, to $5.25, in extended trading after the report. They rose 58 cents, to $5.18, at the close of regular trading. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTWIN, HARRIET (NEE GOLDING)
description: LITTWIN-Harriet (nee Golding). Wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Steven and the late Cookie and Ruth. She is also survived by her sisters, Ruth and Florence, as well as many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Services today, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Shiva will begin Saturday evening, 3725 Henry Hudson Parkway, Riverdale, Apt. 6E.

title: Resurrection Comes as a Surprise For an Angel in Hell's Kitchen
description: As a director, writer and actor, Edward Burns never seems to tire of depicting his own sensitivity. In the romantic comedies he has made -- from ''The Brothers McMullen'' (1995) to ''Sidewalks of New York'' (2002) -- he positions himself as the exemplary blue-collar male, a sad-eyed hunk who believes in love, marriage, children and two-car garages but has a hard time finding someone who shares his vision among Manhattan's pool of shallow career women.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union Energy Plan
description: The executive arm of the European Union announced a new element in its strategy to wean the union off fossil fuels, promising more money for research into renewable energy sources and for the development of what it calls a ''hydrogen based'' economy. The European Commission's plan aims to link union transport and energy policies to advances in the use of hydrogen as a way of both storing and generating clean energy. The commission said it would bolster research into fuel cells that run on hydrogen, which is combined with oxygen in the air to produce electricity. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Ex-Mayor Convicted in Bribes 3 Days After Resigning Office
description: Three days after resigning as mayor of Ocean Township, Terrance D. Weldon pleaded guilty today in federal court to extorting nearly $70,000 in bribes from developers in exchange for successfully shepherding their projects through the approval process.

title: A Tempting 13% Yield, but Is It Secure?
description: DO these people know what they are doing?

title: When the Magic of Youth Turns Into Midlife Misery
description: JULY, JULY

title: Text: Announcement of 2002 Nobel Peace Prize
description: Following is the complete text of the Norwegian Nobel Committee's announcement of the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize today as distributed by the committee:

title: JUDGE DISMISSES 2,600 CLAIMS AGAINST EXXON
description: Exxon Mobil said yesterday that it had won a judge's dismissal of about 2,600 asbestos complaints, ending its role in a West Virginia trial that once involved 8,000 plaintiffs and hundreds of company defendants. The company settled 132 claims, agreeing to pay about $2,000 each to plaintiffs with lung cancer who were exposed to an Exxon asbestos product, an Exxon lawyer said. In dismissing the 2,600 claims on Tuesday, a state court judge ruled that the workers did not have enough evidence to prove that asbestos in an Exxon caulk caused their lung illnesses, the lawyer said. The Union Carbide unit of Dow Chemical is now the only defendant in the trial, which began Sept. 23.

title: Roy Lichtenstein -- 'Times Square Mural'
description: Mitchell-Innes & Nash

title: Residential Real Estate; A Relocation Company To Handle Everything
description: Venturing into a real estate market disconcertingly different from others, Mike Kryza moved to New York from Cincinnati in July, but only after overcoming his fears.

title: Success at Bethpage Made Return Inevitable
description: It often takes years for the United States Golf Association to decide where to hold its signature event, the United States Open. But it took only four months for the association to decide to bring the Open back to Bethpage State Park's Black Course, where it was held in June.

title: An Early Kung-Fu Classic, Newly Restored and Kicking
description: The 1965 classic film ''Come Drink With Me'' sounds like a swaggering parody of a Sinatra song. And the picture, which plays tonight in a stunningly restored print as part of the New York Film Festival, does have a ring-a-ding glow.

title: Chechens, Take Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: He's No Dutch Master: A Belgian Gets His Due
description: It's one of those sad, old art-world stories that in the 20th century took a turn for the better. Michael Sweerts (1618-1664), a contemporary of Rembrandt and Vermeer, shone in his day as a portrait and genre painter. But after his death his name faded, and a lot of his work got confused with that of others.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Democracy Campaigner's Sentence Ends
description: The 13-year prison sentence of Chen Ziming, a dissident intellectual authorities labeled a principal ''black hand'' behind the 1989 democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square, officially ended yesterday, his relatives told reporters. Mr. Chen, 50, spent the last several years under strict house arrest so he could receive medical treatment. It was not clear how free he will be to speak or write, and fellow dissidents speculated that the government would try to force him into exile. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Lofton Irritates Cardinals in a Different Way
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Miramax Blinks, and a Double DiCaprio Vanishes
description: Hollywood executives have made sport since early summer predicting which studio -- Miramax Films or DreamWorks -- would back down and change the Christmas Day release of its blockbuster contender, preventing a duel between films starring Leonardo DiCaprio.

title: Experts Debate the Sniper's Links to Popular Culture
description: A frustrating lack of clues in the sniper shootings has prompted speculation about links to popular thrillers, the language of video game enthusiasts and, of course, decks of tarot cards, in particular, the death card, which was found near a school where a 13-year-old boy on Monday became the sniper's eighth victim.

title: White House Blocks Deal By Congress On 9/11 Panel
description: Hours after Congressional Republicans and Democrats announced that they had agreed on the terms of an independent commission to investigate the Sept. 11 attacks, the White House raised fresh objections late today and held off on a final agreement.

title: Astronauts Install Girder on Space Station
description: Astronauts working inside and outside the International Space Station expanded it today by installing a 45-foot-long, 15-foot-wide girder assembly in a long and laborious operation.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: COOLING-OFF PERIOD FOR PORTS

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Twins' Milton Hopes to Revive Past Success Against Angels
description: Like a man who fell dizzy for a woman who would dump him, Eric Milton has the red, white and blue ''top hat'' logo of the Yankees tattooed on his upper back. Undeterred after the Yankees shipped him away in the Chuck Knoblauch trade in 1998, Milton had the Minnesota Twins' stylized ''m'' zapped onto his right biceps.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Juniper Loss Widens On Higher Costs
description: Juniper Networks, the world's second-largest maker of equipment to direct Internet traffic, had a wider third-quarter net loss on costs related to its July acquisition of Unisphere Networks. The loss was $88.3 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $29.7 million, or 9 cents, in the quarter a year ago, Juniper said in a statement. Sales fell 25 percent, to $152 million from $201.7 million, and will be unchanged this quarter. Excluding severance and other acquisition-related costs and a gain, Juniper said, it had a loss of 2 cents a share, the first on that basis since 1999. Shares of Juniper, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., rose 7 cents, to $5.25, in extended trading after the report. They rose 58 cents, to $5.18, at the close of regular trading.

title: Chuck Connelly
description: Lennon Weinberg Gallery

description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: Giants' Campbell Fills Several Roles
description: The question is not who is Dan Campbell, but what is Dan Campbell.

title: Holiday on Monday -- Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Madness Without a Pattern
description: It is among the strangest, most horrible set of events any of us here can imagine. ''He's playing God,'' say the crime experts being interviewed on television. On Tuesday police found a tarot card with the words ''Dear policeman, I am God'' at the scene of a shooting in Prince George's County, Md.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, JOHN B.
description: ALFIERI-John B. Of New York City, died on Tuesday October 8, 2002, at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Born to Mary and Victor Alfieri on January 16, 1928. He graduated Bronx High School of Science, University of Notre Dame, and Brooklyn Law School. He practiced commercial and international law for fifty years, recently leading Alfieri, Frohman and Primoff, and serving on The Supreme Court, Appellate Division, Disciplinary Committee, and The Board of Governors of The Metropolitan Club. The winner of The Ellis Island Medal of Honor Award, and The Order of Merit Award from The Italian Republic. He is survived by his former wife, June Nigro Alfieri, three sons, John, of New York City, Tony, of Coral Gables, FL, and Michael, of Larchmont, NY, and three grandchildren, Amelia, Adrian, and Angelina. Funeral Service at The Church of Saint Thomas More on Friday October 11, 2002 at 10 A.M. at 65 East 89th Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The John B. Alfieri Fellowship Fund at The University of Miami School of Law Center For Ethics and Public Service.

title: Someone Else Committed Their Crimes
description: One of them says that as soon as he returns home, his instinct is to lock his door because it has become natural for him to feel locked up. Another describes the daily ordeal of taking a shower and seeing his scars, including the obscene words that were carved into his buttocks by fellow prisoners. ''The State of Texas executed me over a thousand times, man,'' he says, ''and it just keeps doin' it.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an outbreak of hepatitis C caused by an Oklahoma hospital nurse's reuse of a hypodermic needle misstated the nurse's specialty and the name of a professional association that reminded its members not to reuse needles. The specialty is nurse anesthetist, not anesthesiologist; the group is the American Association of Nurse Anesthetists, not Anesthesiologists.

title: Jerry Seinfeld, a Stand-Up Guy Again
description: Back in the late 1990's, when I was a book reviewer for another newspaper, my editor called me up one day with with some constructive criticism. ''Do you really need to have a 'Seinfeld' reference in every single piece?'' she asked. I shamefacedly admitted that no, I probably didn't, but I doubt I was alone in using the show as a crutch to hobble through the zeitgeist -- a handy source of one-liners, second-hand insights and yadda yadda yadda. (Sorry. Old habits die hard.) Since the show went off the air, I've managed to move on. ''The Simpsons'' continues to supply a steady diet of sitcom allusions; John Stewart on Comedy Central satisfies the need for a horse-faced New York comedian; and Larry David, the minence grise of ''Seinfeld's'' glory days, is on HBO, playing a character so dyspeptic and unpleasant that he makes George, Jerry, Kramer and Elaine look like Teletubbies by comparison.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: PHILIPPINES: SIX KILLED IN BOMBING Six people were killed when a bomb exploded at a bus station in the southern city of Kidapawan and officials said it could be the latest in a series of terrorist acts by Muslim separatists in the area. The bombing came one week after another bomb in the southern Philippines killed an American soldier and three other people in an attack United States officials attributed to Al Qaeda.

title: House Panel Chides ImClone Over Conduct Of Its Founder
description: Directors of ImClone Systems acknowledged today that Samuel D. Waksal, the company's former chief executive, was allowed to remain at the company even after the board learned of two incidents in which he may have forged signatures, once back in 1986.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Judge Rules Against Intel On Itanium Chips
description: The Intel Corporation's Itanium chips use technology invented by Intergraph, a computer services company, a judge ruled yesterday, in a decision that will cost Intel, the world's largest chip maker, as much as $250 million. Judge T. John Ward of Federal District Court said Intel had infringed upon two patents owned by Intergraph, said Jeannie Robison, a spokeswoman for Intergraph, based in Huntsville, Ala.

title: Democratic Foes of Resolution Are Pleased by Totals
description: They huddled on the House floor and in the hallways today, bucking one another up, trying not to get spooked by two antiwar protesters who were removed from the galleries. The Democrats who voted in surprising numbers not to authorize military action in Iraq needed some encouragement to withstand the majority's tide, and they found it today in a loose coalition of colleagues whose makeup transcended obvious patterns.

title: Overload Is a Tonic For Some
description: College football is a menace to our minds and to our sanity. With ESPN and ESPN2 invading our homes with games on weeknights (in what used to be Bowden-free zones) we get at least a dozen more games on Saturdays, which can be seen by anyone with cable TV, a remote and enough ibuprofen to deal with the baying campus fans behind the traveling stars of ESPN's ''College Gameday.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Rates Steady
description: The Bank of Korea decided not to raise interest rates after the Korea stock price index fell 5.79 percent. The bank governor, Park Seung, said a rate increase ''could augment economic anxiety as the world economy sputters and the domestic stock market is languishing.'' The index closed at 584.04, its lowest in about a year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Ford to Meet Major Investors in an Attempt to Ease Concerns
description: With Ford stock in rapid retreat, senior executives plan to meet with major investors next week to appeal for patience as the company tries a turnaround. But a warm reception from Wall Street seems unlikely, analysts say.

title: Excerpts From the Senate Debate on Authorizing Use of Force in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate about the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota; Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas; and John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRY, HELEN L.
description: BARRY-Helen L. Of Miami, and Pelham, NY, died October 1, 2002, surrounded by her adoring family. Born September, 1923 in Brooklyn to Miriam (nee Anhalt) and Joseph Shapiro. She is survived by children, Karen Mayer, Michael and Jonathan Barry, brothers Jay and, Emmanuel Shapiro. Interment October 28 at Arlington National Cemetery. Please send donations to The Cancer Support Team in Mamaroneck, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Executive Resigns
description: TD Bank Financial said today that A. Charles Baillie, right, its chairman and chief executive the last six years, would turn over the chief executive post to Edmund Clark, currently the bank's president and chief operating officer, on Dec. 20, Mr. Baillie's 63rd birthday. Mr. Baillie will stay on as chairman until 2004 and then yield that post to Mr. Clark as well, the company said. During Mr. Baillie's tenure, TD Bank Financial, with assets of 310 billion Canadian dollars ($194.13 billion), was among the fastest-growing of Canada's five biggest banks. But it reported a loss in the latest quarter after write-downs on its sizable exposure to troubled borrowers in the telecommunications sector. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: A Trip to the Moon, Alice, But No Gossamer Wings
description: What's that clich about imitation and flattery? It is disproved in a big way on Sunday when CBS offers ''Gleason,'' because while Brad Garrett's impersonation of Jackie Gleason is top notch, this made-for-television movie creates a portrait of the famous comedian that is as unflattering as it can be.

title: Lofton Irritates Cardinals in a Different Way
description: Busch Stadium fans couldn't get enough of Kenny Lofton last night. But in the end they got too much of him.

title: Montana Candidate, Citing Smear Campaign, Ends Senate Bid
description: A Republican lawmaker from Montana who was seeking to unseat Senator Max Baucus, a four-term Democrat, abruptly dropped out of the race yesterday, saying a new television advertisement sponsored by Democrats had destroyed his reputation by suggesting he was gay.

title: Roche Increases Reserves For Price-Fixing Lawsuits
description: The giant chemical and pharmaceutical maker Roche Holding said today that an image-bruising vitamin price-fixing case from the 1990's was taking a growing toll on its finances.

title: Excerpts From the House Debate on Authorizing Use of Force in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Speakers included the minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri; the majority leader, Dick Armey, Republican of Texas; the Republican whip, Tom DeLay of Texas; and Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California.

title: Prime-Time Role Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Borders Will Install Wireless Service In Cafes
description: Borders Group will install high-speed wireless service in cafes in all domestic Borders Books outlets by mid-2003, the company announced yesterday. T-Mobile USA, a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom, will install the service and handle billing. Borders currently has 387 stores in the United States and plans to have more than 400 by year's end. T-Mobile offers wireless access using the Wi-Fi standard, which works with laptops and hand-held models equipped with an adapter. T-Mobile has service at more than 1,600 locations. That includes 1,200 Starbucks stores, a number projected to increase to 2,000 stores by 2003. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Farmers Keep Judgment
description: The State Supreme Court has upheld a $700,000 award to a farm couple who said power lines decreased milk production in their cows. The couple, Daniel and Colleen Martins of Monona in northeast Iowa, had sued the owners of the lines, the Interstate Power Company, 13 years ago. The cows were later moved to a nearby farm and are now doing fine, Mrs. Martins said. The power company, now part of Alliant Energy, said the problem was caused by poor wiring on the Martins farm.

title: Shoppers Take A Holiday
description: The country's largest retailers reported September sales so dismal that they were only slightly better than sales a year before, when many shoppers stayed away from stores after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Shares Recover
description: Commerzbank shares advanced for a second day and were the biggest gainer in Germany's DAX index as concern about profit subsided. The shares, which have lost two-thirds of their value this year, advanced 15 percent in Frankfurt. Commerzbank's corporate banking business was profitable in the third quarter, the chief executive, Klaus-Peter Mller, told the business daily Handelsblatt. Mr. Mller said yesterday that the company's financial standing was sound after investors dragged the company's shares down to 20-year lows.

title: Raptors at Rush Hour, Homeward Bound
description: THE augurs of ancient Rome predicted fortune and ruin based on the flight and behavior of birds, believing that bird activity revealed the hidden patterns of life and the plans of the gods. Hawks and eagles portended the destiny of kings. The sight of hundreds of sharp-shinned hawks riding a northeasterly wind, or a peregrine falcon dropping into a 140-mile-an-hour stoop to nab a songbird, would give even the most seasoned soothsayer pause. But on the beach in Cape May, N.J., on a mid-September day, these were merely signs that summer was ending.

title: New York Police Step Up Security After Warning by the F.B.I.
description: The New York Police Department said yesterday that it had increased security around bridges, tunnels, financial centers and landmarks in response to an F.B.I. warning that the local authorities should take ''additional prudent steps'' to detect and deter potential terrorist attacks.

title: It's Like a Gallery, but You Can Sleep on the Art
description: Did the one-of-a-kind, king-size birchbark-and-twig mosaic bed in your $600-a-night suite at the rustic Lake Placid Lodge catch your eye?

title: For Strangers in the Night, Gridlock Is an Opportunity
description: What could be more romantic than the zipless encounter of two attractive strangers who, after exchanging only a few words, end up sharing a blissful night of passion (interrupted by a scrumptious Italian dinner) in a cozy hotel room before going their separate ways? That scenario is the essence of Claire Denis's surreal erotic fantasy ''Friday Night,'' which the New York Film Festival is showing tonight and tomorrow.

title: Man Attacks 3 Officers In Courtroom, Biting an Ear
description: A man on probation for an assault conviction attacked three court officers yesterday in a Queens courtroom, biting off a piece of one officer's ear and injuring two others before he was subdued, the authorities said.

title: Refugees Back Effort to End Hussein's Rule Despite Risk to Relatives
description: They have immigrated to the United States by the thousands over the years, many with still-fresh memories of terror, torture and killing in their homeland. For them, there is no debate over the rightness of America's going to war with Iraq, and they say they need no more reminders from President Bush why Saddam Hussein should be removed from power.

title: Low Expectations
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a speech by President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan on the eve of the first legislative elections since his seizure of power three years ago misstated the day of the balloting for a national parliament and provincial assemblies. It was yesterday; it is not today.

title: S.E.C. FILES CIVIL COMPLAINT AGAINST LERNOUT & HAUSPIE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint yesterday against Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, accusing it of inflating revenue by hundreds of millions of dollars. The company, a developer of speech and language technologies that is being liquidated, lost $8.6 billion in market value when its stock fell 99 percent after its scheme was reported in the news media in 2000, the S.E.C. said. The company, which was based in Ieper, Belgium, and Burlington, Mass., created bogus customers, booked circular transactions with shell companies and recorded loans as sales from 1996 to 2000, the S.E.C. said. The S.E.C. said it was not seeking a fine, only to subject Lernout to stiffer sanctions if it commited similar violations in the future. The company has sold most of its assets to former competitors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWITT, ELIZABETH EARNEST
description: NEWITT-Elizabeth Earnest. On October 3rd. Much loved and sadly missed mother of Cyrus and Margaret Newitt, beloved grandmother of Jeanine Colombi and Elizabeth Laura Newitt. Longtime performer and member of The Snarks, Ltd, and Associate Member of the Amateur Comedy Club. Her loss is deeply felt. Memorial donations may be made to the Princeton Medical Center, Princeton, New Jersey.

title: Subculture of Snipers Disowns a Marksman
description: For the state of the art in personal firearms, few weapons can top the Robar RC-50. Though it weighs 25 pounds, it has few peers when it comes to accuracy. In steady and experienced hands, it can propel a devastating .50-caliber round into a helicopter or armored vehicle up to a mile away.

title: She Stoops to Stoop-Shop
description: IN a beautifully renovated brownstone on a tree-lined street of Park Slope, I finally found what I've been hunting for every weekend for weeks now: the kitchen of my dreams. Incredibly, right in front of my eyes stood the double oven, double sink, fully stocked refrigerator, roomy microwave and cupboard space I'd been pining for, all in a handsome (if a bit grimy) blue-and-white motif. Sure, the counters were only two feet off the ground and there was no running water, but to me, there was only one thing wrong with this kitchen.
