title: Slowly, A Princess Turns Into An Urchin
description: ''Her beauty was like the edge of a very sharp knife,'' Astrid Magnussen, the teenage narrator of Janet Fitch's best-selling novel ''White Oleander,'' observes of her charismatic mother, Ingrid. A Los Angeles poet with a Nietzschean belief in her superiority to ordinary mortals, Ingrid whistles through the novel like a scorching Santa Ana wind, even though much of what we know of her in the book comes only from the letters she writes her daughter from prison, where she is serving time for murder.

title: Rodriguez Is a Fantasy Player Like No Other
description: Everything is moving so fast for Francisco Rodriguez in this blur of a baseball fantasy. Everything he says, everything he sees, everything he throws. Fast, faster, fastest.

title: Virginia Tech Runs Over and Around Boston College
description: Thanks to the relentless running of Lee Suggs and Kevin Jones, Virginia Tech escaped Boston College with its unbeaten record intact.

title: Results Are Glum at Dow Jones, and Outlook Is Gloomy
description: Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, reported third-quarter net income yesterday of $2.4 million, a drop of about 85 percent from the $16.7 million in the quarter a year ago. Revenue fell about 11 percent, to $352.4 million from $397.6 million a year earlier.

title: JUDGE RESCINDS ADVERTISING BAN ON GLAXO'S DRUG PAXIL
description: The drug maker GlaxoSmithKline is no longer barred from advertising the antidepressant Paxil as ''nonhabit forming,'' a federal judge ruled yesterday. The judge, Mariana R. Pfaelzer of United States District Court in Los Angeles, issued a one-paragraph ruling rescinding an order she issued in August. The earlier order was stayed at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, which determined that the ads were not false or misleading. The ad restriction was sought in a lawsuit by about 35 Paxil users who contend that some patients experience withdrawal symptoms like nausea and insomnia when they stop using the medicine.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing the European Union's steps to expand by 10 nations in 2004 and by two more in 2007 misstated the current population of member nations. It is 378.7 million, not billion.

title: The Lonely Voice Of Senator Byrd
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Maxine Reed, Winner Of Sex Discrimination Suit
description: Mary Maxine Reed, who in 1971 won a landmark Supreme Court case that struck down dozens of state laws discriminating against women, died on Sept. 26 near Boise, Idaho.

title: S.E.C. Chief Promises To Cooperate With Europe
description: Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, may be under increasing fire in Washington, where Democratic leaders accuse him of having been too soft on corporate wrongdoing. But he won praise from European policy makers here today when he promised to seek their cooperation on a broad range of new accounting standards and regulatory measures.

title: Smallpox: Preparing for the Worst
description: To the Editor:

title: United to Meet With Machinists; Talk of a Bankruptcy Persists
description: United Airlines and the machinists' union said yesterday that they would begin negotiations over cost cuts next week. The announcement came as analysts tried to gauge how the need to have talks on concessions with each union would affect United's chances of avoiding a bankruptcy filing.

title: Cultural Groups and Charities Are Feeling Each Bump on Wall Street
description: The plunging stock market is taking philanthropy and the institutions it supports down with it.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Boston

title: Contractor Faces Charges In Collapse
description: A construction contractor was indicted yesterday on charges of manslaughter and assault in connection with the collapse of a scaffolding at a Gramercy Park office building last October that killed five workers and seriously injured four.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ALBERT J.
description: WALSH-Albert J. What a great shock and what a great loss to the people of The City of New York. Al was the premier expert in the field of subsidized housing for persons of limited income. Having served as Deputy Commissioner of The State Division of Housing, and Community Renewal, and thereafter, as Commissioner of Housing for The City of New York, Al was the power behind many of the large-scale subsidized housing developments in our City that made available much - needed, affordable housing. ABO was honored that he served as our Chairman for our Mitchell-Lama Housing Committee. He was a special talented and rare human being whom we shall miss deeply. Our sincerest condolences are extended to his charming and devoted wife, Nan. Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York Jerome Belson, President Michael Kerr, Arnold Sollar, Co-Chairman Nick LaPorte, Executive Director

title: Israeli Police Close Site to Muslim Men Under 40
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 11  Israeli police closed one of Islam's holiest sites to Muslim men under the age of 40 today, a week after stone throwers attacked police at the adjacent Western Wall, a site holy to Jews.

title: USA Interactive Ends Bids for 2 Companies
description: USA Interactive backed down yesterday from its proposal to buy all of two online travel companies it partly owns -- Expedia and Hotels.com -- but it did reach an agreement to buy the public shares of Ticketmaster.

title: Baker and La Russa Fined for Arguing
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 10  Tony La Russa and Dusty Baker played for the Atlanta Braves 31 years ago, and La Russa went on to be Baker's last manager in the major leagues. La Russa, now the manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, and Baker, the manager of the San Francisco Giants, were reunited this week in the National League Championship Series and spoke of their histories and friendship like two fraternity buddies showing off their tattoos.

title: Early Seasons Of TV Favorites
description: For television on DVD, this is the season. On Tuesday, Universal will release ''Law & Order: The First Season,'' which was 1990. At Movies Unlimited, a large mail order company in Philadelphia, the top 10 television shows on DVD include the first season of ''Friends,'' the first season of ''The Simpsons,'' the first season of ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' the first and second seasons of ''Sex and the City'' and the first and second seasons of ''The Sopranos.''

title: Europe Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
description: Despite the economic clouds gathering over Europe and new signs of strain among the nations using the euro currency, the European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.25 percent today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SROL, NATHAN (NAT)
description: SROL-Nathan (Nat), 95. On October 8, 2002. Beloved uncle of Myrna Sameth, Dr. Cheryl and Richard Hack, and Kathy and Rev. Paul Sutcliffe. Adored great uncle of Bo, Leonard and Luke Wholey and Jacob and Jessica Hack. Service Friday 9:30 AM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. at Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in Nat's memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 2 Jefferson Plaza, Suite 203, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: He Who Steals From a Thief Will (Pow! Splat!) Regret It
description: Out of the Hollywood fantasyland of action without consequences comes the high mortality, low logic ''Knockaround Guys.''

title: 'A Cuban Legend -- 'The Story of Salvador Gonzlez'
description: Directed by Bette Wanderman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUHNS, MARGARET
description: KUHNS-Margaret. Services were held on Wednesday in Pittsburgh for Margaret Heuer Kuhns, 91, who died on Saturday, October 5th from complications caused by a 4year bout with Alzheimer's. Raised in East Pittsburgh, PA, Mrs. Kuhns was the daughter of the late George and Marie Heuer. She was married for over 25 years to the late E. Lindley Kuhns of Pittsburgh. Mrs. Kuhns worked as a fine arts appraiser and for many years served as Managing Director of the Haugh & Keenan Galleries in Pittsburgh. She was also a fine violinist who once played with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, and was an avid golfer during her retirement. Surviving Mrs. Kuhns' are her son, David L. Kuhns, a grandson, John L. Kuhns, and a granddaughter, Katherine A. Kuhns, all of Bronxville, NY. Memorials may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 2 Jefferson Plaza, Suite 203, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601-4027.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, FRANCES FABYAN
description: DAVIS-Frances Fabyan. Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies mourns the passing of Mrs. Frances (Fuzz) Fabyan Davis, a highly respected and beloved friend. Mrs. Davis was a member of our Board and Council for over 27 years, where she served on the executive, public social policy and planning committee. She was Co-Chair of our Harvest Ball benefit and a devoted supporter who was loved by her colleagues and staff. Her generosity and contributions will be long remembered. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALLMAN, JONATHAN
description: KALLMAN - Jonathan. Of Highland Park, NJ. Wife Amy, children Natasha and Joseph, parents Audrey and the late David, and sisters Sandy and Evie mourn the loss of Jonathan. Mr. Kallman was associate director of market regulation at the Security and Exchange Commission in Washington, DC., instrumental in developing T+3, and a principal architect of SEC oversight program changes in response to the 1987 market break. In 1996 Mr. Kallman joined Morgan, Lewis, and Bockus where he practiced securities law. Interment is at Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: New Releases
description: Scooby-Doo

title: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Talks To Resume Tomorrow
description: Negotiators from North and South Korea are to resume talks tomorrow at Mount Kumkang resort in North Korea. The talks, scheduled for three days, will focus on the rail and road connections that the countries have agreed to open. More meetings are set for Oct. 25-27, when negotiators will meet in Kaesong, North Korea, to talk about building an industrial park there. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: China Sentences Former High-Ranking Bank Official to 15 Years
description: Zhu Xiaohua, the former president of China's sixth-largest bank and previously one of China's leading financial officials, was convicted today in Beijing on bribery charges and sentenced to 15 years in prison.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Six Killed In Bombing
description: Six people were killed when a bomb exploded at a bus station in the southern city of Kidapawan and officials said it could be the latest in a series of terrorist acts by Muslim separatists in the area. The bombing came one week after another bomb in the southern Philippines killed an American soldier and three other people in an attack United States officials attributed to Al Qaeda. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: A Right to Bias Is Put to the Test
description: A lawsuit filed in Georgia recently may help answer this open legal question: Do religious institutions that are ordinarily free to discriminate in hiring on the basis of religion lose that freedom by accepting government money?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firefighters' Union Rejects Wage Plan
description: A day before a planned rally in Central Park to protest firefighters' wages, the Uniformed Firefighters Association yesterday rejected a city wage proposal to increase their pay by 11.5 percent over 30 months. By a vote of 365 to 2, the union's delegates rejected the proposal, which was originally made last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said the mayor was disappointed by the rejection of a contract proposal that had been agreed to by the union's previous executive board. ''The city's fiscal crisis severely limits what we can afford,'' Mr. Skyler said. Stephen J. Cassidy, the union president, said his 9,000 members have been working without a contract for 29 months and deserve a larger raise, especially after their sacrifices on Sept. 11. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERSON, EMERY LANCASTER
description: PIERSON-Emery Lancaster. Of Claryville, NY, on October 4. Contributions to the Emery Pierson Memorial Fund, Recovery Center, 11 Hamilton Ave, Monticello, NY 12701.

title: Germany Arrests Moroccan Suspected in Sept. 11 Attacks
description: German police officials said today that they had arrested a Moroccan man suspected of involvement in the Hamburg cell of Mohamed Atta and others believed to have planned and carried out the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Nobel for Hungarian Writer Who Survived Death Camps
description: Imre Kertsz, a Hungarian novelist and Holocaust survivor with a small but devoted readership in Europe, today won the 2002 Nobel Prize for Literature for what the Swedish Academy described as writing that ''upholds the tragic experience of the individual against the barbaric arbitrariness of history.''

title: Smallpox: Preparing for the Worst
description: To the Editor:

title: By Wide Margin, House Passes 2 Military Spending Measures
description: As Congress debated the prospect of war with Iraq, the House overwhelmingly approved two military spending measures today that would help to finance any conflict.

title: Islanders' Opening Loss Is Their Worst Since '84
description: Islanders Coach Peter Laviolette is no blabbermouth, but his postgame analysis was virtually nonexistent after a humiliating 5-1 loss tonight to the Buffalo Sabres in the season opener.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 60 Indicted In Drug Case
description: Sixty people were indicted yesterday on drug trafficking charges after a six-month investigation led to the breakup of five gangs that prosecutors said terrorized a Brooklyn housing development. The initial arrests took place at the Cypress Hills housing complex in late September. The investigation also led police to make arrests in Fulton County, N.Y., where some of the men had begun selling crack, Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, said yesterday. Since the arrests, no major crimes have been reported in Cypress Hills, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said. The indictment contains more than 200 counts relating to various drug trafficking charges. If found guilty, the defendants face terms of 25 years to life. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: At British Tory Conference, the Leader Describes His 'New' Party
description: Iain Duncan Smith set out today to erase doubts about his leadership of Britain's Conservatives, telling the party it had to cease dwelling on outdated glories if it was to avoid repeats of its two overwhelming electoral defeats.

title: It's Red Ink or Pain
description: New York City's budget crisis may or may not be the worst in its history, as some top city officials suggested this week, but an examination of some of the city's options for closing its second $5 billion shortfall in two years shows just how tough a task it is.

title: Bloomberg, Heckled, Presses Smoking Curbs
description: City Council hearings are sometimes important. They are occasionally well attended. But they rarely feature the mayor, a roomful of his hecklers and a man dressed as a giant cigarette.

title: About 5,000 Fans Watch Nets Practice
description: A raucous crowd packed into both sides of the lower bowl yesterday for the first glimpse of the Nets at Continental Arena since the N.B.A. finals.

title: Excerpts From the Senate Debate on Authorizing Use of Force in Iraq
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate about the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. The speakers included Senators Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota; Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas; and John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia,

title: Strep Throat Sidelines Bure
description: The Rangers will most likely have to wait until next week for Pavel Bure to make his season debut. Bure was told he had strep throat yesterday, a day before the Rangers' home opener tonight against the Montreal Canadiens.

title: The House Makes Its Decision: 'Let Us Take This Stand Against Terror'
description: Following are excerpts from the House debate yesterday on the use of force against Iraq, as recorded by The New York Times. Speakers included the minority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri; the majority leader, Dick Armey, Republican of Texas; the Republican whip, Tom DeLay of Texas; and Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITTER, DEAN MORGAN
description: SCHMITTER-Dean Morgan, 85, October 9th, after a brief illness. Professor Emeritus, English Literature, Columbia University, 1947-1986. Appeared on radio and television, 1938-1962. WWII Navy fighter pilot, 3 Air Medals, Distinguished Flying Cross. Survived by wife Barbara, daughter Amy, sister Letha, brother Doyle and a close extended family.

title: Camby Accuses Knicks of Mistreating His Injury
description: The Knicks have gone through a week of camp and two preseason games and basketball has yet to take center stage.

title: U.S. Has a Plan To Occupy Iraq, Officials Report
description: The White House is developing a detailed plan, modeled on the postwar occupation of Japan, to install an American-led military government in Iraq if the United States topples Saddam Hussein, senior administration officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Voters Rebuke Musharraf

title: No Madonna Is an Island
description: THERE must be moviegoers out there who have been longing for an English-language remake of ''Swept Away . . . by an Unusual Destiny in the Blue Sea of August,'' Lina Wertmller's tart, schematic 1974 comedy about class struggle and sexual combat on a deserted Mediterranean island. There are also probably some die-hard fans who have been waiting with bated breath for Madonna's next big movie role, or for the chance to see whether her husband, the British director Guy Ritchie (''Snatch,'' ''Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels''), can do something besides fast-paced, stylish Cockney gangster comedies. All three constituencies -- and we must be talking about literally dozens of people -- will find their curiosity, if little else, satisfied by the new ''Swept Away,'' a soggy and superfluous motion picture that washes ashore nationwide today.

title: Lucent Cuts 10,000 Jobs
description: Lucent Technologies , the largest maker of equipment for telephone companies, said today that it would cut 10,000 more jobs, as the telecommunications industry suffers through its most severe pullback in spending since the Depression.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The first button, the second button, the third button -- and then we saw the belt.''

title: Early Seasons of TV Favorites
description: For television on DVD, this is the season. On Tuesday, Universal will release "Law & Order: The First Season," which was 1990. At Movies Unlimited, a large mail order company in Philadelphia, the top 10 television shows on DVD include the first season of "Friends," the first season of "The Simpsons," the first season of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," the first and second seasons of "Sex and the City" and the first and second seasons of "The Sopranos."

title: Ad by Republicans Continues to Stress the Democrats' Ballot Switch
description: Hoping to keep voters' attention focused on the ballot switch in which former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg replaced current Senator Robert G. Torricelli as the Democratic candidate in New Jersey, Republicans today began broadcasting a television commercial ridiculing Mr. Lautenberg's entry in the race.

title: A Merger Unlikely, What's Next for EchoStar?
description: So what is Charles W. Ergen's Plan B? If Mr. Ergen, the chairman of EchoStar Communications, is unable to persuade the Federal Communications Commission to reverse its rejection of his company's proposed acquisition of Hughes Electronics, he readily acknowledges that he has no backup plan.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Barbara Box, executive vice president at Golin/Harris International, Chicago, was named to the new post of worldwide director for healthcare. Golin/Harris is part of the Advanced Marketing Services division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ruling Kashmir Party Suffers Severe Setback at Polls
description: Voters in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir appear to have ejected from power the family dynasty that has dominated their politics for more than five decades, a verdict that could substantially alter the dynamics of both this troubled border region and a tense subcontinent.

title: George Burns Takes the Stage, Just as He Might if He Could
description: All you need to know about the level of sophistication of ''Say Goodnight Gracie,'' which opened on Broadway last night at the Helen Hayes Theater, is that it begins with George Burns talking to God.

title: 'Multitude'
description: Artists Space

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, ERWIN
description: YOUNG - Erwin. Beloved soulmate of Francene Tobias. Devoted father of Evalynn Scharf, Marissa Sacher and Dr. Alexander Young. Cherished grandfather of Seth, Faith, Joshua and Samuel. Dear brother of Gloria Goldstein. Service Friday, October 11th, 10:15 AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York

title: When a Fight Is a Thrill And Sex Is Just a Bore
description: Like a lapsed vegetarian on a carnivorous bender, James Van Der Beek, the milk-and-cookies star of ''Dawson's Creek,'' ravenously sinks his teeth into the vampirish role of Sean Bateman, a drug dealer and lothario slithering through a New England college campus in ''The Rules of Attraction.'' Much of this screen adaptation of Bret Easton Ellis's 1987 novel of collegiate depravity and anomie finds Sean half dazed from the combinations of drugs and booze he ingests with an alarming nonchalance.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Westbury: Teenager Accused Of Credit Card Fraud
description: An intern with access to credit-card information at a J. P. Morgan Chase bank branch on Long Island has been arrested and accused of using the data to go on a $30,000 buying spree. Since August, Bryant Alexander, 16, had worked as an intern at a branch in Hicksville under a program organized through his school, Westbury High School. A Nassau County detective, Richard Massa, said that Mr. Alexander mailed copies of customers' credit cards to himself, then went shopping. Mr. Alexander was arrested Tuesday. He could not be reached for comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Opinion Article About Israelis In School Paper Is Denounced
description: An opinion article in a Brooklyn high school newspaper this week expressing sympathy for the suffering of Palestinians and accusing Israeli soldiers of raping Palestinian women drew criticism yesterday from a Brooklyn assemblyman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. The Members of the Royal Academy of Arts, the Trustees of the Royal Academy Trust and the Trustees of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust express great sadness at the passing of Ambassador Walter H. Annenberg. During their tenure at the Court of St. James's and in the years following, Ambassador and Mrs. Annenberg earned the deep affection and admiration of British society for their understanding and appreciation of British culture and their magnanimous efforts to preserve and promote British heritage. In May of this year, HM Queen Elizabeth II formally named the forecourt of Burlington House, the home of the Royal Academy, the ''Annenberg Courtyard'' in honor of the Annenbergs, whose generosity made possible the renovation of this magnificent public space. Throughout London, we enjoy the Annenbergs' beneficence, including the transformation of Winfield House into one of the most sumptuous residences in London. We are privileged that Mrs. Annenberg, who was a profound support in her husband's life, serves as a Trustee of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust. Ambassador Annenberg enriched us with his presence; he has left as his legacy those many gifts to the British people that will forever grace our lives. Prof. Phillip King, CBE, President of the Royal Academy of Arts Simon Robertson, Chairman of the Royal Academy Trust The Hon. Philip Lader, Chairman of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust

title: Issue Is Clear: Other Side Is Wrong
description: THE defenders of virtue battled the forces of darkness at City Hall yesterday. The hard part was figuring out which was which.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: 3 Church Leaders in China Are Sent to Prison for Life
description: After a new trial lasting less than two days, three leaders of an underground Christian church whose death sentences were overturned by an appeals court were resentenced today to life in prison.

title: Suburban Rail Merger Plan Draws Praise and Concern
description: A plan announced on Wednesday to merge the problem-riddled Long Island Rail Road with the relatively civilized Metro-North Railroad has drawn both raised eyebrows and tentative praise.

title: The Lonely Voice Of Senator Byrd
description: To the Editor:

title: The DNA Of a Fading Motor Skill: R-1-2-3-4
description: MY mother was at the wheel of our blue Chevrolet and my father was next to her, yelling, ''More gas, more gas!'' It was 1953, and Mom was getting a driving lesson at a time when for most people, driving still required shifting the gears of a manual transmission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ASHLEIGH
description: DAVIS-Ashleigh. The Board of Directors and members of The Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our member, Ashleigh Davis, daughter of Martin and Zehava Davis. Her fun loving sense of spirit and strength will always be remembered. Our deepest sympathy to the family. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary

title: The Ad Campaign
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACHTMAN, LEAH
description: TRACHTMAN-Leah. On October 11, 2002. Formerly of Ozone Park, NY. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Dear mother of Muriel Hirt and Paula Trachtman Butscher. Loving grandmother of Victoria Hirt and the late Amy Rothholz and great-grandmother of Devin. Funeral service Sunday, 2PM, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Old or New? Debate Rages Over Transit Downtown
description: At an exuberant news conference in August overlooking the World Trade Center site, federal, state and city officials announced that $4.55 billion had been set aside for transit in Lower Manhattan -- one of the biggest single sums ever available for city transportation and enough, officials assured, to remake a crucial part of the system.

title: Greenwich's Star Center, at 6-4 and 280, Doesn't Give an Inch
description: John Sullivan knows that the offensive line is not a position for those seeking statistics or glory. Sullivan, a senior center at Greenwich High School in Greenwich, Conn., does not mind. He has his own way of earning the respect of his teammates and his opponents.

title: Sports of The Times; N.C.A.A. Needs An Iron Fist
description: COLLEGE football season is in full stride, basketball practice begins today, but the most important news in intercollegiate sports unfolded Thursday when Myles Brand, the president of Indiana University, was named the president and chief executive of the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: Move in Japan to Aid Banks Plagued by Bad Debt
description: Japan's central bank moved today to force a much faster clean-up of the country's ailing banking system. It said it would spend $16 billion of its own money in a highly unorthodox plan to buy stocks from threatened banks, and it called on the government to use tax money to absorb much more of the banks' losses on bad loans.

title: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded to Carter, With Jab at Bush
description: PLAINS, Ga., Oct. 11  For his peacemaking and humanitarian work over the last 25 years, former President Jimmy Carter was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, and the Nobel committee used the occasion to send a sharp rebuke to the Bush administration for its aggressive policy toward Iraq.

title: 'Zombified Addicts,' or Just Ardent Fans?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Big Band Powered By a Bass
description: You could hear the Dave Holland Big Band while blindfolded and know that a bassist runs the show: strong odd-meter vamps, guided by Mr. Holland's big, thick bass tone, are the backbone of the music. It takes a long time before the melodic material arrives, and in this 13-piece band the melodies are often what would have served as connective portions or countermelodies in big bands. Mr. Holland is dogged about putting the groove up front and center.

title: Breast Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SOL
description: BERMAN-Sol, 94 years old of Palm Beach, Florida, on October 10. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Adored father, grandfather and great-grandfather of Gail & Alan Levenstein, Barbara and Martin Weinburg, Arthur Rosenstein, Miranda, Jessica & Antony Levenstein, Bonnie and Scott Rogoff and family, Susan and Adam Hurwitz and family, Robert and Jean Rosenstein. Brother of Sylvia Weinberg. Dear uncle and great-uncle. He will be missed.

title: EL PASO AGREES TO SELL ITS INTEREST IN A PIPELINE
description: The El Paso Corporation, the largest United States pipeline owner, agreed to sell its 14 percent interest in a natural gas pipeline, a gas liquids plant and other related assets to its partners for $170 million. One partner, Enbridge Inc., will get half of El Paso's stake in the Alliance Pipeline's United States and Canadian segments, and another, Fort Chicago Energy Partners, will buy the other half, the companies said. Each will pay about $85 million. El Paso, based in Houston, is trying to sell $4 billion in assets to trim debt amid lower energy prices and a slump in energy trading. Last month, the company cut its 2002 earnings forecast by more than 20 percent.

title: Pentagon Aide, a Cuban Spy, Is Described as Unapologetic
description: A high-ranking Pentagon intelligence analyst who spied for Cuba because she opposed American policies toward Latin America ''in no measure apologizes for her betrayal of the United States,'' federal prosecutors said in a court document filed yesterday.

title: Hearing on Promotion for Commander of Slain Gay G.I. Is Closed
description: Groups that oppose the promotion of an Army general who commanded a base where a gay soldier was beaten to death failed today to have the nomination hearings opened. The groups wanted to express their anger over the incident.

title: Single Girls: Sex but Still No Respect
description: Contemporary culture has never lacked for compelling images of the single woman. They've run the gamut from glamorous to Gidget, from the original Cosmo girl to Carrie Bradshaw and company on ''Sex and the City.'' And while such thoroughly modern millies as the singleton Bridget Jones or the sex-addict Samantha are hardly real-life role models, they represent the idea of the single woman as a viable and even enticing entity, one that needs no more justification or documentation, say, than the domestic habits of the dedicated bachelor. But apparently this female demographic still requires a bookshelf all its own.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Spare Times for Children column of Weekend yesterday about ''The Little Prince,'' at the Atlantic Theater Company in Chelsea, misstated the address. It is 336 West 20th Street, not 236.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: What Makes a Deli
description: To the Editor:

title: Phyllis Calvert, 87, Virtuous Heroine of Wartime Melodramas
description: Phyllis Calvert, a ladylike actress who packed British movie theaters in the darkest days of World War II with her performances in wildly melodramatic, escapist costume dramas, died on Tuesday in London. She was 87.

title: 5 Little Oryxes and the Big Bad Lioness of Kenya
description: Having been nurtured on nature shows, tourists to Africa typically relish a good kill: a cheetah chasing down a gazelle, a jackal devouring the carcass of a wildebeest, a lion pouncing on a squirming oryx.

title: Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Household to Pay Record Fine and Change Lending Practices
description: Household International Inc. said today that it would pay a record fine of as much as $484 million to settle allegations that it had misled borrowers in more than a dozen states into paying mortgage rates that in some cases were almost twice what was promised.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Pipeline Is Planned
description: Petrleo Brasileiro S.A., Brazil's state-controlled petroleum producer, plans to build a $1.1 billion pipeline linking offshore oil wells to refineries near So Paulo to handle rising output. The 450-mile oil line network should begin operating in 2005 and will include a pumping platform to send the oil from wells in the Campos Basin to the coast, a spokesman, Celso Mansur, said. The pipeline is a part of Petrobras's $33 billion plan to increase output by another 40 percent, to 2.5 million barrels a day by 2006. Petrobras now relies on ships to take crude to a port near refineries in So Paulo.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: 4 Christians Sent To Labor Camp
description: When three leaders of an underground Christian church were sentenced to life in prison on Thursday, four other worshipers were cleared of criminal charges and released by a court in Hubei Province. But their freedom was brief. That same night the police rearrested the four -- women who had helped publish a magazine for the banned South China Church -- and sent them without trial to a ''re-education through labor'' camp for three years. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, HERBERT
description: RICE-Herbert. We mourn the passing of Herbert Rice, the father of our esteemed partner, Glenn B. Rice. Herbert Rice was a war hero and a man of integrity who had a zest for life. Our thoughts and sympathies are with Rhoda, Herbie's wife of 40 years, Glenn and his wife Daryle, Amy and Fred Gold, Susan and Rick Mosley, and Herbie's grandchildren, Nikki, Max, Jennifer and Stacy. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C.

title: National Briefing: New England
description: MASSACHUSETTS: DEALING WITH A BUDGET GAP

title: Seeds of Protest Growing on College Campuses
description: Mike McLinn never showed the faintest interest in political protest, but he has plunged headfirst into the effort to prevent an American attack against Iraq.

title: Leave Hypocrisy And Pohlad Behind
description: Carl Pohlad and Bud Selig were ensconced in Pohlad's private suite during Game 1 of the American League Championship Series on Tuesday, guiltlessly watching the plucky team that Pohlad, the owner of the Minnesota Twins, and Selig, the commissioner of baseball, worked feverishly to eliminate less than a year ago. Brazen, no? Actually, that is a kind description.

title: Nobel Achievements; The Human Element in Economics
description: If you ask the man or woman on the street, he or she will tell you that economics is more likely to be the study of the behavior of money than the study of the behavior of people. And yet the Nobel in economic science this year has been awarded to two American economists, Daniel Kahneman and Vernon L. Smith, whose work describes the gap between predictions of human behavior according to economic theory and the way humans really act. It turns out, in effect, that money would behave logically, just the way theory predicts, if humans weren't the ones responsible for handling it.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: 4 CHRISTIANS SENT TO LABOR CAMP When three leaders of an underground Christian church were sentenced to life in prison on Thursday, four other worshipers were cleared of criminal charges and released by a court in Hubei Province. But their freedom was brief. That same night the police rearrested the four — women who had helped publish a magazine for the banned South China Church — and sent them without trial to a "re-education through labor" camp for three years.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: CONFIRMING POLICE CHIEF

title: Hollywood Journal; On the Boulevard, the Nights Are (Still) Hard
description: There is a new hustle on Hollywood Boulevard, a hustle not yet seen on the sophisticated streets of Manhattan.

title: Injuries Have Haunted Giants' Draft Choices
description: There were no quarterbacks available, so Jeremy Shockey, the tight end who remade the Giants' offense, scrounged around for anyone to throw him a football at practice Thursday. Shockey, wearing a protective boot over his left foot, played catch with tackle Luke Petitgout, defensive lineman Matt Mitrione and anyone else who could spare a moment, looking the ball into his hands, as he does habitually.

title: Rabbi Convicted of Sexual Abuse Is Freed on Bail Pending Appeal
description: A New Jersey appeals court has allowed the temporary release of a rabbi convicted of sexually abusing two teenage girls at a religious school where he was the principal.

title: Ulster's Fragile Peace
description: Northern Ireland's Good Friday agreement, which has brought four and a half years of peace to that troubled province, faces a grave crisis. The British and Irish governments must do everything possible to maintain the momentum of peace while trying to re-establish some trust between the province's leading Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists, and Roman Catholic politicians, especially those from Sinn Fein, the Irish Republican Army's political wing.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: AQUILA SELLS ITS 70% STAKE IN ELECTRICITY DISTRIBUTOR
description: Aquila Inc., a United States utility owner, said yesterday that it had completed the sale of its 70 percent stake in New Zealand's largest electricity distributor to Vector Ltd. for $503 million. The sale of its stake in the distributor, UnitedNetworks, will result in a fourth-quarter gain of about $28 million for Aquila, the company said. Proceeds of about $362 million will be used to pay off debt Aquila used to acquire UnitedNetworks and other utilities in Australia, Canada and Britain. Aquila, based in Kansas City, Mo., is trying to sell $1 billion in assets this year to strengthen its balance sheet.

title: When Bloomberg, Under Siege, Went Undercover
description: He may not look much like Frank Serpico. But Michael R. Bloomberg can play an undercover agent when he has to, according to court papers filed last week.

title: Satellite Operator's Profit Tops Forecasts After Cutting Costs
description: PanAmSat, the big satellite operator that is set to be acquired by the EchoStar Communications Corporation, slashed costs to report third-quarter results yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations by 3 cents a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSAEL, BERNARD
description: ASSAEL - Bernard. The Board of Governors and the members of the Seawane Club record with sorrow the loss of our beloved member, Bernard Assael. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Diana, and family. Stuart Herz, President

title: A Writer Who Followed His Own Clues to Fame
description: THERE are would-be writers who never get going, has-been writers who peak too soon and always-on-the-verge writers who trudge, sentence by sentence, toward the top of the hill.

title: The Catch-22's of Recovery
description: Jennifer Dworkin's compelling documentary ''Love and Diane'' immerses you so intensely in the problems of the Hazzards, a troubled New York family living on public assistance, that by the end of its two and a half hours you feel almost like a member of the household.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBRIN, HARRY L. JR.
description: DuBRIN-Harry L. Jr. Age 81. Of Altamont and NYC died Friday, Oct. 11, 2002 in Albany. He was the Managing Director of Pension Assets for Metropolitan Life Insurance Company & former Assistant Director and Legal Counsel for New York State Teachers' Retirement System. He is survived by his wife, Carolyn DuBrin & family. A memorial service Sat., Oct. 19th, 2PM at the Altamont Reformed Church, Altamont, N.Y.

title: Parking on Holidays
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COTT, JEROME M.
description: COTT-Jerome M. Farewell to our beloved cousin. We will remember you always. Carol and Barry

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Moroccan in Germany on charges that he had prior knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States and provided logistical support to the hijackers misstated his age. The man, Abdelghani Mzoudi, is 29, not 22.

title: The Survivor Who Survived
description: Nearly 60 years after the liberation of the death camps, Holocaust survivors continue to show themselves to be a durable, sometimes tragic, lot. On Thursday, Imre Kertesz, a Hungarian novelist and essayist who outlasted both the Nazis and the Communists, received the Nobel Prize in Literature. As a teenager he survived Auschwitz and Buchenwald; after the war he remained in Communist Hungary and survived once more.

title: Education in Rural France: A Portrait of Dedication
description: In ''To Be and to Have'' the French documentarian Nicolas Philibert takes us, on tiptoe, into a small school in a rural part of the Auvergne to observe the lives of a dozen children (ranging in age from 4 to 11) and their teacher, Georges Lopez. The film, which will be shown this afternoon at the New York Film Festival, is as quiet, patient and tenacious as Mr. Lopez himself, who approaches his difficult, endless work with remarkable serenity and discipline.

title: South Korea May Allow a Rise In Stock Held by Pension Funds
description: The South Korean government announced a sweeping plan today for injecting new life into the sagging stock market to combat the effect of the sluggish United States market, the prospect of war in Iraq and the danger that any conflict would pose for oil imports.

title: Russia Taken Off Money Laundering Blacklist
description: Russia was released today from an international blacklist of countries with inadequate monitoring of money laundering, in a move seen in part as a political gesture to President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: A Mainstream Cult Band
description: Are the Counting Crows too mainstream for the mainstream? The group writes jangly, earnest songs that might appeal to young listeners everywhere, if only young listeners weren't more interested in hard rock, hip-hop, dance pop and other genres that aspire to novelty or innovation.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Firm Buys Iraqi Oil
description: The Russian commodities trading firm Alfa-Eco concluded its largest oil contract with Iraq ''over the past several days,'' under a United Nations program that allows the regime of Saddam Hussein to sell oil and use the proceeds to buy food. A spokesman said Alfa-Eco would buy 20 million barrels of oil from Iraq. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Refugees From North Arrive
description: Twenty North Korean refugees, 15 women and 5 men, arrived early today at Inchon International Airport from Manila, where they had stopped briefly en route from China. They had been staying in the South Korean consulate in Beijing after entering by posing as Chinese citizens of Korean origin seeking visas. South Korean television showed the smiling refugees walking to a bus that was to take them to a government center where they will be indoctrinated on life in South Korea. This year more than 100 North Koreans have received permission to leave China after getting past guards and entering embassies or consulates. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Edward H. Tuck, 75, Lawyer
description: Edward H. Tuck, a New York lawyer who specialized in international business and helped advance the development and application of international business law, died on Oct. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 75.

title: Honor goes to Carter; 'kick in leg' to war plan
description: PARIS:  Jimmy Carter was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize on Friday for his "untiring effort" to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts, and the head of the committee that granted the prize said the decision "can also be interpreted as criticism" of the Bush administration's policy on Iraq.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Eric Hoskins, 38; Rapped as Money Ray
description: Eric Hoskins, the rapper known as Money Ray who performed with the Cold Crush Brothers, an influential early rap group, died on Oct. 3 in the Bronx. He was 38.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the release of the single ''Like I Love You'' by the singer Justin Timberlake misstated the ownership of his label, Jive Records. BMG, a division of Bertelsmann, owns 20 percent of Jive's parent, the Zomba Music Group. Jive is not a label of BMG. BMG is in the final stages of buying Zomba, but the deal has not been completed.

title: A New Face Signals Political Change in Embattled Kashmir
description: In 1989, anti-Indian militants in Jammu and Kashmir State kidnapped Mehbooba Mufti's sister. In return for her safe return, their father, a government minister, agreed to release four imprisoned militants.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPKINS, MILTON
description: LIPKINS-Milton. In our hearts forever. Edna, Judith, Stephen and Stace

title: Bush Will Use Congress Vote To Press U.N.
description: President Bush moved today to use a vote in Congress giving him overwhelming support to attack Iraq as leverage to push for a tough new United Nations resolution forcing Saddam Hussein to disarm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIST, VERA GLASER
description: LIST-Vera Glaser, 94. Of Greenwich, CT, on October 10, 2002. Survived by three daughters and their spouses, Carol and Eric Schwartz of Denver, CO, Olga and George Mack of NYC, and Viki Laura List of Rosemont, PA. Also survived by 11 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren. Predeceased by her husband, Albert A., daughter, Jo List Levinson, grandson, Michael Israel and brother, Samuel. Services Sunday, 9:30 AM, at List Hall, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, NYC. Burial, Fall River, MA. Shiva at the Macks, 980 5th Ave. (79th St.), on Monday and Tuesday, 1-5 and 7-9 PM, and at 201 Byram Shore Road, Greenwich, CT. Wednesday, 1-6 P.M. Inquiries to Plaza Jewish Memorial Chapel, 212769-4400. In lieu of flowers, make donations to the Vera List Scholarship Fund at the New School University, 66 West 12th Street, NY, NY 10011, would be appreciated.

title: Justice Dept. To Scrutinize Confinement Of Mentally Ill
description: The United States Justice Department has opened a review of the Pataki administration's policy of releasing hundreds of patients from state psychiatric wards to locked units in nursing homes, seeking to determine whether conditions in the units violate federal civil rights laws, officials said yesterday.

title: Prudential Loses Class-Action Suit
description: Prudential Securities, a unit of Prudential Financial Inc., was ordered to pay $261.7 million in damages to investors who accused their broker of selling stock without their permission.

title: Larger Visions for Downtown
description: Six teams of internationally renowned architects yesterday accepted New York City's challenge to create a grand plan for ground zero. Their task over the next two months will be to come up with dramatic ways to revitalize Lower Manhattan while honoring those who died on 9/11. The authorities have finally provided these talented people with a set of flexible instructions that allow them to think beyond simply replacing what was there 13 months ago.

title: INSIDE
description: Sills to Be Met Chairwoman

title: Ruling Backs Some Patents on a Leading Ulcer Drug
description: A federal judge last night upheld at least partly the patent protection of Prilosec, an ulcer treatment made by AstraZeneca of Britain that is one of the best-selling prescription drugs.

title: The Right Hand Explains What the Left Hand Is Doing
description: There is an old riddle that remains mysterious even after it is explained: ''If a mirror reverses right and left, why doesn't it also reverse up and down?'' The body facing us in a mirror, for example, raises its left arm when we raise our right; ordinary writing is also reversed in direction. Yet there is no similar reversal when we shake our heads. However topsy-turvy the looking glass world appears, one can stand upright in it with some confidence.

title: For More, Look on the Web
description: This is a new 30-second commercial released today by H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, for statewide broadcast.

title: Bush Says U.S. Won't Force Its Ways on a Beaten Iraq
description: President Bush offered assurances today that the United States would ''never seek to impose our culture or our form of government'' on another nation. His aides insisted that even if the United States military were to take over the administration of Iraq after an invasion, it would be as a liberation force, not an occupation force.

title: Firefighters Rally to Demand Higher Pay
description: Ed Walsh says he cannot afford to buy a house. Lenny Cimadomo says that to get by, he works as a roofer to supplement his city wages. And Dan Archbold says that after 20 years on the job, he still has not saved any money in the bank.

title: Muslim Parties' Election Strength Weakens Musharraf
description: Results in Pakistan's first nationwide voting in seven years have left the country's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, in a weakened political position to crack down on Islamic militancy along the Afghan border, analysts said on Friday when near-final tallies were announced.

title: National Briefing: South
description: KENTUCKY: LOWERING CREDIT RATING

title: Exotica of 1928, With Bits of Homer and Euripides
description: In January 2000 Leon Botstein gave New York opera lovers a chance to hear a seldom-performed late Strauss work when he conducted a concert performance of ''Die Liebe der Danae'' with the American Symphony Orchestra and a strong cast at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Botstein was back at the hall with his orchestra on Sunday afternoon for a concert performance of another Strauss rarity, ''Die gyptische Helena'' (''The Egyptian Helen''), with Deborah Voigt, no less, the Strauss soprano of our time, in the title role.

title: Guards Stop Suicide Attack Near U.S. Embassy in Israel
description: Security guards outside the United States Embassy in Tel Aviv today captured a would-be Palestinian suicide bomber who fled a crowded seaside cafe after his explosive belt was detected, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLDEN, BERT
description: OLDEN-Bert, 85. Of New York City, died in his home of a heart attack on October 10, 2002. His humor, generosity, integrity and adventuresome spirit made him a unique and specially loved man. His loss is mourned deeply by his daughters, Melanie and Dany, his relatives in California, and the friends who were also his beloved family. A memorial will be held on Monday, October 14 at Riverside Memorial, 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue at 1:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BACHI, CHARLES J.
description: BACHI-Charles J., 68. Of Basking Ridge, NJ formerly of Scotch Plains, NJ, retired Senior VP of Shearson Lehman Bros, on October 10, 2002. For service information, call Memorial Funeral Home, Fanwood, NJ at 908-322-4350.

title: L. H. Fountain, 89, Lawmaker Who Led 60's Fraud Inquiry
description: L. H. Fountain, a former North Carolina congressman whose investigation first exposed the scope of the Billie Sol Estes scandal of the 1960's, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Raleigh, N.C. He was 89 and a resident of Tarboro, N.C.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: YUGOSLAVIA: CONVICTIONS IN KOSOVO KILLINGS A Serbian military court jailed two Yugoslav Army officers and two former soldiers for three to seven years for the murders of two Kosovo Albanian civilians in April 1999. The war crimes trial was the second to be heard in Yugoslavia, a federation of Serbia and Montenegro, since NATO's bombing campaign ended Serbia's repression of the majority Albanian population in Kosovo in the summer of 1999. A third case, against two former Serbian policemen charged with killing 19 Albanian civilians in March 1999, opened this week.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VORNADO REALTY TRUST, New York, the city's largest commercial property landlord, bought the 1.5-million-square-foot Monmouth Mall in Eatontown, N.J., for $164.7 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Convictions In Kosovo Killings
description: A Serbian military court jailed two Yugoslav Army officers and two former soldiers for three to seven years for the murders of two Kosovo Albanian civilians in April 1999. The war crimes trial was the second to be heard in Yugoslavia, a federation of Serbia and Montenegro, since NATO's bombing campaign ended Serbia's repression of the majority Albanian population in Kosovo in the summer of 1999. A third case, against two former Serbian policemen charged with killing 19 Albanian civilians in March 1999, opened this week. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: A Contest of Wills, Wall Street Style
description: For many of his years on Wall Street, ''Tough Guys Finish First'' was Lawrence Auriana's advertising slogan. And he appears to have lived up to that motto by ousting from the Columbus Day Parade another steely Wall Street character, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Sniper Appears to Want To Create Fear, Not Pain
description: There is one thing about the sniper in the Washington region that jumps out at experts on mass murderers and serial killers. He seems to be killing to create public fear rather than to settle a grudge or inflict pain on his victims.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Profit Zooms
description: The German carmaker Porsche A.G. increased its pretax profit by 40 percent, to 828.9 million euros ($817.7 million) for the fiscal year 2001-02, exceeding by far the preliminary figures and market expectations. By July 31, the group's net profit rose 70.8 percent, to 462 million euros ($455.8 million), benefiting from Germany's corporate tax overhaul, the company said. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: China May Slightly Relax Rules on Currency
description: China's government may be closer to allowing its main currency to be traded by investors outside its borders, if only in a limited way.

title: Accommodating Fears in a Sniper's Killing Field
description: Ashley Neece called her boyfriend as she drove to get gas on Leesburg Pike near the entrance to the Beltway today. She hung up the phone to pump, then called him again as soon as she was done. ''He said to call him and let him know I was O.K.,'' she said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 3rd-Quarter Profit at G.E. Increases by Nearly 25%

title: Separating Pretenders From Contenders
description: This college football season has opened with much intrigue but little resolution. At the midway point, the predictable contenders are still bunched near the top of the polls, records unblemished but their viability for a national championship still unknown. That will begin to change today when at least one of the hopefuls topples like a milk bottle on the midway of the Texas State Fair.

title: Tree-Munching Asian Beetles Are Discovered in Jersey City
description: A wood-munching beetle that has destroyed thousands of trees in New York City and Chicago has been found in New Jersey, causing concern that its damage may spread.

title: A Time When Loyalty Overrides Love
description: Like all great doomed affairs, ''Talk to Her,'' the closing-night presentation of the New York Film Festival, is full of lovely, sweet suffering. And when it's over, the realization of how much the movie means to you really sinks in; you can't get it out of your heart.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ARGENTINA: PRESIDENT FAILS TO UNSEAT COURT Congress has shelved impeachment proceedings against all nine justices of the Supreme Court, which President Eduardo Duhalde sought earlier this year after his efforts to prevent depositors from withdrawing money from their bank accounts were ruled unconstitutional. Since then the high court has thwarted Mr. Duhalde at almost every turn, reversing government-decreed increases in utility rates and salary and pension cuts, and leading the International Monetary Fund to complain that a lack of political consensus was impeding a new loan agreement with Argentina.    Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurance Shares Rally
description: Shares in Zurich Financial Service got a much needed lift after the insurance company's stockholders approved a request to raise $2.5 billion to make up for capital lost by falling stock markets. Stocks rose 12 percent immediately after 95 percent of the company's investors approved the move. The insurance company offered shares to the public at 65 Swiss francs ($43.39) each, at a 50 percent discount from yesterday's closing price of 130 Swiss francs. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Confirming Police Chief
description: William J. Bratton, former New York City police commissioner, was confirmed by the Los Angeles City Council, 14 to 1, as police chief. Nate Holden, a supporter of former Chief Bernard C. Parks, was the lone member to vote against Mr. Bratton. He was confirmed after three hours of testimonials from citizens' groups and mostly gentle questioning from council members. ''Enjoy this day,'' Councilwoman Ruth Galanter told Mr. Bratton. ''It is probably the last love fest you'll get from us.'' John M. Broder (NYT)

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 20 Texas (5-0) vs. 7 Oklahoma (5-0)

title: Miami's Defensive Line Puts Surplus of Talent to Good Use
description: Three of the University of Miami's four starting defensive backs last season were selected in the first round of the National Football League draft in April. Miami figures to raise eyebrows again in this year's N.F.L. draft; this time, the Hurricanes have six draft-worthy defensive linemen.

title: B. H. Ridder Jr., 85, News Executive, Dies
description: Bernard H. Ridder Jr., a third-generation newspaper executive who spent the years after college moving westward to help manage Ridder Publications' new properties and eventually rose to be the company's president and chief executive, died on Thursday at his home in San Mateo, Calif. He was 85.

title: A Bitter Harvest For the Losers; Some Ask Why Compromise Doesn't Protect Their Gardens
description: The agreement to preserve some 500 of the city's community gardens and allow about 150 others to be developed into housing seemed to many a fair solution to a long dispute.

title: Making My Own Music
description: Every night before I go to bed I take one of my music CD's and insert it into my computer. While I sleep my computer translates the music into a compressed digital format onto my computer's hard drive. Over the course of the past year I have been steadily building my own personal jukebox from the 300 CD's I own. I can now listen to only my favorite songs on an album, rearrange songs into my preferred order, or move them to a portable player. Besides my own virtual personal radio station, I also have an index and catalog of the music I have bought.

title: Nortel Revenue Falls 36%
description: Nortel Networks, North America's second-biggest maker of phone equipment, said today that its third-quarter revenue fell about 36 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, REV. WILLIAM T., S.J.
description: WOOD-Rev. William T., S.J. On October 10, 2002. Survived by his nieces Rosemary Petrie, Maureen Koenke, Kathleen Roberts and Mary Ellen Galasso, 12 grand nieces and nephews and seven greatgrandnieces and nephews. Reposing at St. Ignatius Loyola Rectory, 980 Park Avenue, Sunday, October 13, 3-5 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY.

title: San Franciscans' Friends, Old and New
description: The first of Michael Tilson Thomas's performances at Carnegie Hall with the San Francisco Symphony, on Wednesday evening, invited listeners to consider the degree to which he has remade the orchestra since he became its music director in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Lucy de Berk, a Dutch nurse charged with having killed 13 patients, carried an incorrect dateline. It was written in The Hague last Saturday, not on Monday.

title: Testaverde Isn't Ready To Pack It In for Good
description: Great athletes always say they will know when it's time to retire. When it does come time, though, they are often ushered out kicking and screaming.

title: Political Memo; But It's Not the Economy, So Far
description: Twenty years ago, in the campaign for the 1982 midterm elections, Democrats concentrated on the weakness of the economy and President Ronald Reagan's economic policies, and gained 26 seats in the House of Representatives.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Kidnapped Actress Freed
description: Kidnappers released Laura Zapata, a well-known Mexican actress, after 18 days of captivity. Her sister, Ernestina Sodi, kidnapped with her, remained missing. Both women are sisters of another prominent Mexican performer, known as Thalia, who is the wife of Tommy Mottola, the chairman of Sony Music. The kidnappers had demanded $1 million ranson, though it was unclear whether any was paid. Kidnappings have become a recurring problem in Mexico City, whose government has retained Rudolph W. Giuliani as an anticrime consultant. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Money Manager Admits to Kickbacks
description: The former money manager Alan B. Bond admitted that he had accepted millions of dollars in illegal kickbacks, federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Fox Re-evaluating Sniper Film's Release
description: Executives at 20th Century Fox were huddled today to decide what to do about ''Phone Booth,'' a thriller about a man terrorized by a sniper, whose plot is a little too close to the killing spree in suburban Maryland and Virginia.

title: Reopening a Mormon Murder Mystery; New Accusations That Brigham Young Himself Ordered an 1857 Massacre of Pioneers
description: On Sept. 11, 1857, a group of California-bound pioneers camping in southern Utah were murdered by a Mormon militia and its Indian allies. The massacre lasted less than five minutes, but when it was over, 120 men, women and children had been clubbed, stabbed or shot at point-blank range. Their corpses, stripped of clothes and jewelry, were left to be picked apart by wolves and buzzards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORWIN, ROSE ANN
description: NORWIN-Rose Ann, 70. Died October 11, 2002. Beloved wife of the late William Heyman. Cherished mother to Laurie (Gerardo) Pina, Mitchell (Joan) Norwin and Wendy (Wayne) Zeilner. Adored grandmother to Mariel, Alyssa and Kevin. Loving sister to Richard (Sulamita) Heyman and nephew Paul Heyman. Visiting hours Sunday, 11AM3PM at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue at South Broadway, White Plains, New York. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambivalence in Kuwait
description: As an attack this week on United States marines showed, anti-Americanism is growing in Kuwait, a country rescued from Iraqi domination just over 11 years ago.

title: Angels Break Through on Late Homer
description: It was the kind of moment even Troy Glaus could get excited about. Glaus, the Anaheim Angels' stoic third baseman, pounded the air with his fist as he rounded first base in the eighth inning of Game 3 of the American League Championship Series tonight. He waved his arm a little bit longer, elated at what he had done. Game-winning home runs have that effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBER, ARTHUR
description: LEBER-Arthur. On Thursday, October 10, 2002. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, October 13, 2002 at Boulevard Riverside Funeral Home 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, (516) 295-3100.

title: Nobel Committee Wins Praise and Criticism for Prize to Carter
description: PARIS, Oct. 11  The Norwegian Nobel Committee assured itself extra publicity and sympathetic headlines across Europe today when, in awarding the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize to Jimmy Carter, it suggested that it was also sending a political message criticizing the Bush administration's policy towards Iraq.

title: Beliefs; Across four decades, just what has been the legacy of the Second Vatican Council?
description: Forty years ago yesterday, the Second Vatican Council opened. The 2,540 bishops who gathered in St. Peter's Basilica from around the world were about to make one of the greatest peaceful revolutions in history.

title: Pataki Agrees to Debate, But on a Crowded Stage
description: For the first time in his three campaigns for governor, George E. Pataki will debate his opponents tomorrow. But he has insisted on including all seven of the candidates actively running, ensuring a cluttered event in which challengers will have a hard time distinguishing themselves.

title: Public Frustration Persists Over 9/11 Relief Program
description: Seizing a rare opportunity to confront officials with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, scores of Lower Manhattan residents expressed frustration and continuing anger yesterday over the relief agency's financial assistance programs for those affected by Sept. 11.

title: 'Sopranos' Uninvited, Mayor Finds a Parade He Can Refuse
description: A New York parade without politics is like pretzels without beer -- the former without the latter is hardly worth having. The Columbus Day Parade on Monday will be no exception: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will not be marching, the first time in recent memory that the city's mayor has skipped the event out of pique.

title: A Short History of a Small Island
description: In 1708, after the Dutch had departed and the British had begun settling their governors on Nutten Island, the celebrated dandy Lord Cornbury had his residence built overlooking Buttermilk Channel. Not inaptly the funds used to construct the exquisite Queen Anne residence there were provided by taxing people who wore pearl rings and periwigs. A small town grew, wonderfully appointed and spaced, on what the British renamed Governors Island.

title: Likely U-Turn By Prosecutors In Jogger Case
description: A sweeping re-investigation of the 1989 Central Park jogger attack, including new DNA tests and admissions from a murderer never suspected in the crime, has persuaded senior prosecutors and detectives in Manhattan that the convictions of five Harlem teenagers cannot stand, according to three officials involved in the inquiries.

title: Praise and Blame for Prize to Carter, and Message to Bush
description: The Norwegian Nobel Committee assured itself extra publicity and sympathetic headlines across Europe today when, in awarding the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize to Jimmy Carter, it suggested that it was also sending a political message criticizing the Bush administration's policy towards Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Tobacco Company To Buy Shares
description: The government failed to persuade foreign investors to buy 8.1 million shares of Korea Tobacco and Ginseng, the huge state monopoly that manufactures cigarettes and also markets ginseng, the traditional root product that is said to have aphrodisiacal and medicinal qualities. The finance ministry said yesterday that of the 26.33 million shares offered in the 103-year-old state company, 18.2 million shares were sold. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Angels' Bullpen Features Some Unlikely Stars
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 11  They wear glasses. Their uniform numbers are closer to 100 than 1. They have both served time in an independent league. One was a replacement player, the other an alumnus of the Taiwanese professional league. Both are important members of the best bullpen in the American League.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucent to Cut 10,000 Jobs As Its Losses Keep Mounting
description: Lucent Technologies, the largest maker of equipment for telephone companies, announced plans yesterday to cut an additional 10,000 jobs and forecast a larger-than-expected quarterly loss, signaling that its problems are far from over.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: President Fails To Unseat Court
description: Congress has shelved impeachment proceedings against all nine justices of the Supreme Court, which President Eduardo Duhalde sought earlier this year after his efforts to prevent depositors from withdrawing money from their bank accounts were ruled unconstitutional. Since then the high court has thwarted Mr. Duhalde at almost every turn, reversing government-decreed increases in utility rates and salary and pension cuts, and leading the International Monetary Fund to complain that a lack of political consensus was impeding a new loan agreement with Argentina. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: $5 Million Bail Accepted for Tyco Executive
description: The former chief financial officer of Tyco International, Mark H. Swartz, who has been charged with helping to loot $600 million from the company, was allowed to remain free yesterday after a judge accepted $5 million in bail put up by his parents and other family members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BATES, VICTORIA FRELING HUYSEN
description: BATES - Victoria Freling huysen. Of Brielle, NJ, died at her residence on Wednesday, October 9, 2002. Widow of John Glenville Bates Jr. Mother of Emily Bates Douglas of Stanford, CT, Anita B. Glasson of Pine Beach, NJ, Joseph S.F. Bates of Parkdale, OR, and the late John G. Bates III. Sister of Joseph S. Frelinghuysen Jr. of Far Hills, NJ, and Emily B. McFarland of Basking Ridge, NJ. Grandmother of the late Boulton Frelinghuysen Bates, also survived by 11 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 15, 2002, at 11 A.M. in St. Bernard's Episcopal Church, 88 Claremont Rd, Bernardsville, NJ. Interment in St. Bernard's Cemetery. Relatives and friends may call at the Layton Funeral Home, 475 Main St, Bedminster, NJ, on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Memorial gifts may be made to the charity of one's choice.

title: Russia May Support New U.N. Efforts on Iraq
description: President Vladimir V. Putin said today that Russia was prepared to support new United Nations Security Council resolutions on Iraq, but only to strengthen the work of inspectors searching for its weapons programs and not to authorize the use of military force.

title: McCall Criticized on Education
description: This is a new 30-second commercial released yesterday by Gov. George E. Pataki. In addition to this spot, which focuses on the record of the governor's Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, the Pataki campaign re-released an older advertisement emphasizing the environment, health care and education. Both ads will be broadcast downstate.

title: Nobel Achievements; A Lifetime of Public Service
description: Jimmy Carter well deserves the Nobel Peace Prize awarded him yesterday. In four years as president and more than twenty as the most active and civic-minded ex-president of modern times, he has contributed substantially to peace, democracy and human rights. Not all of Mr. Carter's peacemaking efforts have succeeded, and his activities have often put him at odds with his successors. His own presidency was complicated by economic tribulations, the Iranian hostage crisis and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. But the totality of his career has significantly enhanced the cause of peace.

title: Investors Bid Up G.E. Shares As Earnings Post 25% Gain
description: General Electric, managing to offset profit declines in many units with several one-time gains, said yesterday that it earned $4.09 billion, or 41 cents a share, in the third quarter, and confirmed its expectations of earning $1.65 a share for the year.

title: ROYAL CARIBBEAN CRUISES RAISES ITS EARNINGS ESTIMATE
description: Royal Caribbean Cruises, which wants to sell itself to P&O Princess Cruises, raised its earnings estimates yesterday for the third quarter and the year because of cost cutting and increased sales of trips. Earnings for the quarter will be 98 to 99 cents a share, the company said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 86 cents. The full earnings report will be released Oct. 23. Royal Caribbean, the second-largest cruise company, is in a battle with Carnival, which is No. 1, to merge with P&O Princess. The earnings improvement may make Royal Caribbean more attractive to P&O Princess's shareholders after regulators said last week that they would not block either transaction for antitrust concerns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLIEDMAN, RICHARD
description: GLIEDMAN - Richard. De parted suddenly on October 10, 2002. Our beloved friend, husband of Carole, father of Shari, Lesley - Anne and Pamela. Brother of Monroe. Adoring grandfather of Zachary, Ethan and Lindsay, Jack and Josephine, Maxwell, Benjamin, Zachary and Alexandra. Graduate of Bronx High School of Science and M.I.T. Graduate and professor for 47 years at Columbia School of Dental and Oral Surgery. Served as a Naval Lieutenant in World War II. Loved by all for his stories and jokes. Admired for his intellect and interest in collecting. He will be missed forever. Service Sunday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in his memory may be made to Israel Emergency Campaign, UJA Federation.

title: New Slogan, Same Old Result for Rangers
description: The Rangers unveiled their new slogan last night in their home opener at Madison Square Garden, with two banners announcing, ''Hockey's Different Here.''

title: Fatal Shooting of Driver at Gasoline Station Intensifies Hunt for Suburban Sniper
description: The shooting death of another gas station customer sent hundreds of police today into a frantic, guns-drawn dragnet across Washington's highways in a fruitless search for the suburban sniper who has stalked one victim after another across the region.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in Business Day on Thursday with an article about the two winners of the Nobel award in economics this year misattributed remarks by one of them. It was Vernon L. Smith, professor of economics and law at George Mason University -- not Daniel Kahneman, professor of psychology and public affairs at Princeton -- who said it had taken him several years ''to realize that the textbooks were wrong.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Death Sentence For Nerve Gas Attack
description: A leader of the Japanese cult that killed 12 people and sickened thousands in a gas attack on Tokyo's subway system in 1995 was sentenced to death yesterday. Seiichi Endo, the so-called health minister of the Aum Shinrikyo cult, was convicted of murder after admitting to producing the sarin gas used in the attack. Mr. Endo, 42, said he had acted on the instructions of Shoko Asahara, the cult's founder, and had no idea the gas would be used in the attacks. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When I got the call this morning at 4 a.m., I thought it was a joke. I didn't even know this was the day the prize was announced.''

title: A Time of Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMONDSTEIN, CHARLOTTE KRAUS
description: DIAMONDSTEIN - Charlotte Kraus, 85. Of Trenton, NJ, on October 9, 2002. Wife of the late Saul. Survived by children Ronni Diamondstein, Karen and Robert Goldberg, granddaughters Katie and Rachel Goldberg and sister, Geraldine Girshek. Private service. Donations may be made to Greenwood House, Trenton, New Jersey.

title: In Deference To the Chief
description: When the shouting finally dies down and the moment of decision arrives, it is almost always the president who determines whether or not the country faces a clear and imminent danger to its national security. Congress may have doubts, but the White House perspective prevails.

title: Devils Still Trying to Figure Out Their New Coach
description: For all his rock-solid traits -- that withering stare, a stubborn set of principles, a booming voice that cuts through the sounds of a hockey practice the way a jackhammer cuts through street noise -- Pat Burns can be elusive.

title: Toll Rises in Bombing of Chechnya Police Station
description: The death toll in the bombing of a district police headquarters in Chechnya's capital on Thursday evening rose to at least 22 today, as Russian officials angrily accused Chechen separatists of having infiltrated parts of the pro-Moscow government there.

title: Democracy and Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing at an Indonesian Resort Leaves at Least 58 People Dead
description: Apowerful car bomb detonated in front of a discotheque on the popular Indonesian resort island of Bali late last night, killing at least 58 people and wounding more than a hundred, Indonesian and Western officials said.

title: Redskins Hope Ramsey Provides Some Stability
description: Patrick Ramsey had an inauspicious start as a rookie quarterback for the Washington Redskins this season.

title: Enough Retirement Already: Beverly Sills to Be Met's Chairwoman
description: Beverly Sills, the longtime opera diva, director and master money-raiser who stepped down as chairwoman of Lincoln Center last May, is un-retiring at 73 to become chairwoman of the Metropolitan Opera, which had once spurned her singing.

title: That Spanish Temptress, Competing With Animals
description: Franco Zeffirelli's 1996 staging of ''Carmen'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Monday evening, complete with dogs, horses and donkeys, and crowds of oddly gesticulating choristers pretending there's a reason to mill about the stage: all the things that make Mr. Zeffirelli's productions what they are. Rolled into this mock-cinematic package is Bizet's score, which can be tantalizing enough to overcome a great deal of directorial silliness, especially when the casting lets it work its full magic.

title: Merger Talks Are Revived By Two British TV Powers
