description: Granada and Carlton Communications, the joint owners of Britain's largest commercial television network, said today that they had reopened merger talks and that the discussions were at an advanced stage.

title: Rage Then Tears for a Troubled Teenager
description: ''Bang Bang You're Dead'' is an eloquent and moving plea for understanding. Is it a fully formed drama? That would be too much to ask. So don't ask. Just accept this film for what it is: a rare chance to look through the eyes of a troubled teenager. It's a disturbing view.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: ITALY: FIAT WEIGHS OPTIONS WITH G.M. The ailing Italian automobile giant Fiat played down reports that it was planning to sell the remainder of its auto division to its partner General Motors , while factory workers across the country went on strike against Fiat's proposal to cut 20 percent of its 36,000 work force in Italy. A Fiat spokesman, Raffaelo Porro, said that comments made yesterday by Fiat's chairman, Paolo Fresco, above, indicating the high likelihood of the sale reflected only one extreme option. "Many options are being studied," Mr. Porro said.   Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Cardinals Still Thinking Positive
description: They were cast as a team of destiny, and when the Cardinals left St. Louis late Thursday night for a flight to San Francisco, a few fans clad in Cardinal red already had their tents propped up at Busch Stadium awaiting the sale of World Series tickets Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, MARJORIE LYDIA
description: FOSTER-Marjorie Lydia, 92. Of New York City, died on September 4, 2002. She was born in Bristol, CT on March 1, 1910 to the late James and Laura (Gilbert) Foster. A graduate of Wellesley College, she lived in New York all her adult life. She worked for the New York Public Library in acquisition research for over 25 years. She was predeceased by a sister, Katherine Williams and a brother, Harlan Foster, both of Collinsville, CT. She is survived by a step-nephew, Huntington Williams of West Cornwall, CT, and several cousins. Services are private. For information, contact Funk Funeral Home, 35 Bellevue Ave., Bristol, CT.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Sept. 21 about American scholars who gained access to a trove of Ernest Hemingway's papers in Cuba misstated the precedents. At least one person has indeed been allowed to see them; Norberto Fuentes, a Cuban writer who has since immigrated to the United States, reviewed the material more than 20 years ago for his book ''Hemingway in Cuba'' (Lyle Stuart, 1984).

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Proposal To Replace Mediobanca Chairman
description: A leading shareholder of Mediobanca, Italy's largest investment bank, has nominated a former Italian Treasury official to succeed the current chairman, reflecting shareholder ire with recent management decisions. UniCredito, the third-largest bank in Italy and one of Mediobanca's major shareholders, proposed a former treasury under secretary, Piero Giarda, for the top spot. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: 2 Senators Say White House Is Thwarting 9/11 Inquiry
description: Two prominent senators from opposite parties accused the White House today of deliberately sabotaging their efforts to create an independent investigation of the Sept. 11 attacks, suggesting that the administration was afraid a commission might turn up embarrassing government mistakes.

title: Yonkers Mayor Accused of Putting Relatives on City Payroll
description: The mayor of this city, the state's fourth largest, is at the center of a local ethics investigation examining the number of his relatives who are on the city payroll or who benefit from city spending.

title: House Vote on Iraq Resolution
description: The 296-to-133 roll call on Thursday by which the House voted for a resolution to authorize President Bush to use military force in Iraq. A yes vote is a vote to approve the resolution. Voting yes were 81 Democrats and 215 Republicans. Voting no were 126 Democrats, 6 Republicans and one independent. There are three vacancies in the 435-member House, and there were three not voting.

title: A Journalist's Memorial, but Hardly Sad
description: Music journalists aren't usually popular with rock stars, but Timothy White, author, radio host and the editor in chief of Billboard magazine, was different. He became a confidant and adviser to some of the musicians he wrote about for Rolling Stone and Crawdaddy, and he made Billboard, the music-business trade magazine, a watchdog for the rights of musicians. When White died in June at 50, his platinum-selling admirers volunteered to play benefit concerts for his family.

title: Corrections
description: An erroneous set of mutual fund tables appeared in Business Day yesterday, carrying data for trading on Wednesday, not Thursday. Correct tables are online today, at nytimes.com/business. Readers wishing copies by mail may telephone (212) 556-1992 or write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; e-mail: quality@nytimes .com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Democrats Try to Refocus On a Domestic Agenda
description: Democrats in Congress sought to turn public attention from Iraq to the economy today, saying President Bush must work with them to create more jobs, protect retirement savings and guard against corporate fraud.

title: Showalter To Rangers; Mets Wait For Piniella
description: Three years ago, Seattle Mariners officials flew across the country for what would become a sad routine for the franchise. Another postseason took place without the team and the organization was forced to try to persuade one of its stars to stay. In 1999, the star was Ken Griffey Jr. The next year, it was Alex Rodriguez. Yesterday, it was Lou Piniella.

title: Democracy and Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Fiat Weighs Options With G.M.
description: The ailing Italian automobile giant Fiat played down reports that it was planning to sell the remainder of its auto division to its partner General Motors, while factory workers across the country went on strike against Fiat's proposal to cut 20 percent of its 36,000 work force in Italy. A Fiat spokesman, Raffaelo Porro, said that comments made yesterday by Fiat's chairman, Paolo Fresco, above, indicating the high likelihood of the sale reflected only one extreme option. ''Many options are being studied,'' Mr. Porro said. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, HON. WALTER.
description: ANNENBERG-Hon. Walter. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our dear friend, Walter Annenberg. His generosity, and deep knowledge of and love for the arts have set an extraordinary example for future generations. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his wife, Leonore, his family, and friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Maxwell L. Anderson, Director

title: Saved by U.S., Kuwait Now Shows Mixed Feelings
description: Muhammad al-Mulaifi, head of the information department at Kuwait's Ministry of Islamic Affairs, tried momentarily to suppress a smile, then broke into a broad grin when asked if he supported the terrorist attacks on the United States last year.

title: Hollywood Haunts an Empty Hotel
description: If there were more experimental films as entertaining as ''The Decay of Fiction,'' Pat O'Neill's luminous Hollywood ghost story, the notion of a thriving avant-garde cinema might not be so intimidating to the moviegoing public. The 73-minute movie, which the New York Film Festival is showing tonight as part of its annual Avant-Garde Visions series, is a semi-abstract film noir shot largely in the empty corridors and bare peeling rooms of the Ambassador, a once-grand Los Angeles hotel that went spectacularly to seed after closing in 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, ALBERT A.
description: WALSH-Albert A., The Partners, Counsel, Associates and Staff of Seward & Kissel LLP deeply mourn the passing on October 9 of Albert A. Walsh, our esteemed partner and friend. Al was a valued member of the Firm's Real Estate practice for over 25 years and his contribution to the practice of law will be greatly missed by his many clients, colleagues and friends. We extend our sincerest condolences to Nan, and the entire family. Seward & Kissel LLP New York & Washington, D.C.

title: Fire Razes a Pioneering Rap-Music Recording Studio
description: A fire early this morning ravaged the Sugar Hill Studio, the birthplace of rap music's first Top 40 hit, ''Rapper's Delight,'' more than 20 years ago.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Jersey Says Its Pension Funds Lost 9.4% in the Last Quarter
description: New Jersey's pension funds lost $6 billion, or 9.4 percent of their value, in the quarter ending Sept. 30, State Treasurer John E. McCormac announced today.

title: A Night Spent Tossing and Turning
description: Natalia Makarova's staging of the 19th-century divertissement from ''Paquita'' for the San Francisco Ballet will make you smile with pleasure this weekend at City Center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10, 15

title: Reviving a Hard-to-Undercut Staple by Mozart
description: If any opera can be regarded as foolproof, it is Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro,'' a work that has so much to offer, both musically and in its sparkling da Ponte libretto, that neither loopy productions nor dull performances can quench it entirely.

title: KMART ASKS FOR COURT APPROVAL TO SELL INTERNET UNIT
description: Kmart said yesterday that it had asked for court approval to sell its BlueLight.com Internet access business to United Online for $8.4 million. The sale would not affect Kmart's online shopping site, kmart.com. The companies expect no disruption in service or changes in e-mail addresses for the business's 165,000 subscribers, BlueLight.com said. The offer was announced last month. Kmart expects the bankruptcy court in Chicago to consider its request by the end of the month. Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., filed for bankruptcy protection in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, JOHN B.
description: ALFIERI-John B. Our partner for many years, John was a superb professional, a wise counselor and a man of the greatest integrity. But more than that, he was a close, dear, and loyal friend. We mourn him deeply. Alfieri, Frohman & Primoff, LLP

title: Committee's Citation of Carter
description: Following is the Nobel Peace Prize citation for former President Jimmy Carter:

title: PENTAGON PLANS SMALLPOX SHOTS FOR UP TO 500,000
description: With the Bush administration moving closer to military action against Iraq, the Pentagon is expected to begin vaccinating up to half a million troops against smallpox as soon as the vaccine is licensed in mid-November, military and administration officials said today.

title: Young, Gifted and Going To China for Championships
description: The future of the United States on the international bridge scene is bright, judging by recent junior results by players under age 26.

title: ROCHE AND TRIMERIS WIN PRIORITY REVIEW OF AIDS DRUG
description: Roche Holding and its partner Trimeris won a faster-than-usual review in the United States for their AIDS treatment Fuzeon, the first in a new class of drugs that prevent H.I.V. from infecting healthy cells. The Food and Drug Administration will review the medicine by March 16, Roche said yesterday. The company, based in Basel, Switzerland, has said the new treatment may have peak sales of 1 billion Swiss francs ($674 million). Fuzeon would be Trimeris's first marketed drug.

title: Iraq's Response to the U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from a letter from Amir Hammudi al-Saadi, an adviser to Saddam Hussein, to United Nations agencies involved with weapons inspections, as translated from Arabic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, GERTRUDE
description: FEDER-Gertrude. Age 93, died on October 11, 2002, at The Hebrew Home of Greater Washington, in Rockville, Maryland. Devoted mother of Sam and Phyllis, Jack and Carol and the late Lenora Bucholtz. Beloved grandmother of Barri Eastwood, Jody and Art Greason, Robin and Todd Copeland and Eric, Alex and Amanda Feder. Cherished great-grandmother of Paige Eastwood, Hayley and Tyler Greason and Jessica & Jacob Copeland. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave, at 1 PM on Sunday, October 13, 2002. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Congregation B'nai Jeshurun or The Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center.

title: Stocks Surge, Ending Streak Of Six Weeks With Losses
description: The stock market shot up drastically for a second session yesterday as prices continued to rally from the five-year lows reached on Wednesday. Some fresh economic reports were better than expected, but the rally, which spanned the globe, appeared to be more of a sign that prices had fallen too far than an indication that economic growth was poised to rebound.

title: The Giants Are More Than a One-Man Team
description: Barry Bonds could play the piano, the trumpet, the trombone, the saxophone, the flugelhorn and the drums, and he still wouldn't be a one-man band.

title: A Sluggish Oracle Loses Its Second Straight
description: The British syndicate GBR Challenge pulled off a stunning defeat of the Oracle-BMW team today in a thrilling day of racing on the Hauraki Gulf.

title: IRAQ BACKS AWAY FROM U.N. DEMAND TO SET ARMS TERMS
description: Iraq, ignoring rising global pressure for thorough inspections of its weapons programs, has backed away from agreements reached last week on minimum conditions for the inspectors to carry out their work, diplomats said today.

title: It's the War, Stupid
description: As soon as President Bush rolled out his new war on Iraq, the Democrats in Washington demanded a debate, and debates they got, all right. There was the debate between Matt Drudge and Barbra Streisand about the provenance of an antiwar quote she recited at a party fund-raiser. There was the debate about whether Jim McDermott, Democratic Congressman from Washington, should have come home from Baghdad before announcing on TV that we can take Saddam Hussein's promises at ''face value.'' There were the debates about why Al Gore took off his wedding ring, why Robert Torricelli took a Rolex, and why Al Sharpton and Jesse Jackson took noisy offense at so benign and popular a Hollywood comedy as ''Barbershop.''

title: A U.S. Agency Is Accused Of Collusion in Land Deals
description: A congressionally sanctioned consultant hired by the Bureau of Land Management to evaluate its land-exchange policies has found that agency officials collude with private developers to trade away government land at below market value.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about H. Carl McCall's news conference in front of a state-regulated adult home in Brooklyn referred to it incorrectly. It was a home for the mentally ill, not the aged.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Hard-Liners Quit Government
description: The two government ministers in the Northern Ireland government from the Rev. Ian Paisley's hard-line Democratic Unionist party resigned and urged the more moderate Ulster Unionists of First Minister David Trimble to follow them and bring about the immediate collapse of the Catholic-Protestant administration. Instead, Britain is expected to suspend the assembly and reimpose direct rule on Monday. That action would give the government a chance to resume in the future. Police raids a week ago resulted in charges against members of Sinn Fein, the political party of the Irish Republican Army, who were accused of involvement in a spy operation. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Goldman Wooed A Star Analyst, Documents Show
description: Jack B. Grubman, the former star analyst of telecommunications stocks, was such a controversial figure on Wall Street that executives of the Goldman Sachs Group had a heated debate about whether to hire him four years ago, according to internal documents and people close to the firm.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Lautenberg Shifts Stance And Backs Iraq Resolution
description: Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic nominee for Senate, said today that he unequivocally stands behind the Senate resolution giving President Bush the authority to act against Iraq, as he and the Republican candidate, Douglas R. Forrester, spent the day focusing on the potential war.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Immigrants Found Dead In Truck
description: The police in Algeciras, a southern port, found the bodies of five north African men, believed to be illegal immigrants, in the back of a refrigerated truck carrying vegetables from Morocco to Spain. The five are believed to have died after inhaling fumes from a fire in the truck's refrigeration system. At least nine would-be immigrants drowned off the Spanish coast on Tuesday when an overloaded boat sank as it ferried them across the Strait of Gibraltar from Morocco. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENDAR, SYLVIA
description: SENDAR-Sylvia. On October 10, 2002. Loving aunt of Carol, Michael, Neil, Marsha and Mark. Great aunt of Shawn and Jake. Rest in Peace. A service Sunday, October 13, 1:00 PM at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, NY.

title: Wall Street and Brazil Are Far Apart on Outlook
description: Wall Street investors, stung by recent losses in Argentina and wary of the outcome of presidential elections in Brazil, are once again diverging from their Brazilian counterparts in their outlook on the nation's ability to avoid a crippling financial crisis.

title: Canadian Immigrant Arrested At J.F.K. Is Deported to Syria
description: A Canadian citizen suspected of having ties to terrorist organizations was deported to Syria on Thursday, two weeks after he was detained at Kennedy International Airport as he tried to catch a connecting flight to Canada.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: Out Front in Brazilian Runoff, Leftist Is Wary of a Spill
description: Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the left-wing Workers' Party won twice as many votes as Jos Serra in the first round of Brazil's presidential election last Sunday. So the logic of numbers would seem simple and irrefutable: Mr. da Silva will coast to victory in the runoff scheduled for Oct. 27.

title: Democracy and Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: Nobel Peace Prize Awarded To Carter, With Jab at Bush
description: For his peacemaking and humanitarian work over the last 25 years, former President Jimmy Carter was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize today, and the Nobel committee used the occasion to send a sharp rebuke to the Bush administration for its aggressive policy toward Iraq.

title: Chaney Chooses Ward, For Now
description: The Knicks have made little effort to conceal their interest in upgrading at center and point guard, but they have come up empty on the trade front. And the two point guards they chose in the draft are hardly in position to make an impact -- Frank Williams of Illinois fractured his left wrist in the Boston Summer League and Milos Vujanic will spend at least one more season playing in Yugoslavia.

title: MAYTAG TO CLOSE A PLANT, CUTTING 1,600 JOBS
description: The appliance maker Maytag said yesterday that it would close a refrigeration-parts plant in Galesburg, Ill., eliminating 1,600 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force. The company said it planned to start closing the plant next year and complete the shutdown by late 2004. Some salaried workers from the factory will be offered jobs at other Maytag locations, a company spokesman said. The closing is part of a plan to cut expenses and to make refrigerators more cheaply and efficiently, Maytag said. Maytag, based in Newton, Iowa, also said it planned to open a new refrigeration plant in Reynosa, Mexico, by late next year.

title: Marbury Tries to Escape the Shadow of Off-Court Turmoil
description: Stephon Marbury began the off-season recovering from surgery on his ankles and watching in pain as the Nets romped to the N.B.A. finals, led by Jason Kidd, the player for whom he was traded.

title: Milestone on Iraq: Voices of Caution and Doubt
description: To the Editor:

title: MONSANTO LOWERS ITS EARNINGS OUTLOOK FOR THE YEAR
description: Monsanto, the biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, reduced earnings forecasts yesterday because demand in the United States has slowed for its Roundup weed killer and sales of seeds have dropped in Latin America. Full-year profit, excluding some costs, will be $1.15 to $1.23 a share, compared with a previous estimate of $1.50, Monsanto said. Losses from unpaid bills in Argentina will take 38 cents a share off net income and reorganization costs will slice off 32 cents more, it said. Shares of Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, rose 92 cents, to $16.47.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the arrest of a Moroccan in Germany on charges that he had prior knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States and provided logistical support to the hijackers misstated his age. The man, Abdelghani Mzoudi, is 29, not 22.

title: Comiskey Fan Indicted On 4 Counts in Attack
description: A man who ran onto the field at Comiskey Park with his son and attacked a Kansas City Royals coach was indicted yesterday in Chicago on three counts of aggravated battery and one of mob action.

title: His Gentler Side
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: During Bye Weekend, the Jets Are Focusing on the Cures
description: Jets Coach Herman Edwards will not watch any National Football League games today because he does not want to feel his colleagues' pain during his bye week.

title: Robyn DeMarco, Martin Alperin
description: Robyn Marie DeMarco, an executive at MTV, and Martin Aaron Alperin, a financial analyst, were married yesterday at St. Charles Borromeo Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Thaddeus Grzelak, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: BackTalk; Coutts Represents a Landlocked Nation, Hoping to Beat His Old Team on the Sea
description: When the last America's Cup ended on March 2, 2000, with New Zealand's successful 5-0 defense over Prada of Italy, the winning skipper, Russell Coutts, said at a crowded news conference in Auckland, ''We have a long-term vision.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, CHRISTINE G.
description: STEVENS-Christine G. On Thursday, October 10th, 2002 of Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late Roger L. Stevens. Beloved mother of Christabel Gough. Services are private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers to honor her memory donations may be made to The Animal Welfare Institute, PO Box 3650, Washington, D.C. 20027. For further information please contact Joseph Gawler and Sons.

title: Cynthia Bunn, Matthew Raney
description: Cynthia Gill Bunn and Matthew Christopher Raney were married yesterday in Southport, Conn. The Rev. Paul D. Whitmore, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Southport Congregational Church.

title: 40th Reunion
description: Brigitte Lacombe's photographs were brilliant in your Portfolio (Sept. 22). The fact that only 3 of the 12 were women was mildly irritating, but as a woman over 50, for me the truly aggravating part was that not one older woman made the cut, apart from the picture of Hanna Schygulla on your contents page. Of the nine men, five are gorgeous in their maturity, while the three women depicted are beautiful and young. I don't think you intend to be discouraging; I think you merely overlooked those who are routinely overlooked.

title: Consensus Is Near On Underhill Tract
description: ENVIRONMENTALISTS, local officials and the developers of what may be Nassau County's largest piece of undeveloped land say they are close to reaching an agreement that would put an end to a dispute over its use that has lasted for more than 20 years.

title: Ayala Cohen, John Podhoretz
description: Ayala Rae Cohen, a daughter of Rabbi Burton I. Cohen and Mrs. Cohen of Woodmere, N.Y., is to be married this evening to John Podhoretz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Podhoretz of New York. The bride's father will perform the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhust, N.Y.

title: Another Preseason Loss As McDyess Hurts Knee
description: It was the final minutes of a preseason game. Antonio McDyess should probably have been on the bench relaxing, his 23 points and 15 rebounds proving his point for the night in a 94-87 preseason loss to the Phoenix Suns. But as the Knicks' best hope to reverse their fortunes, he rose with 1 minute 55 seconds left to slam in a missed shot, landed awkwardly and fell grasping at his surgically repaired left knee.

title: Shipshape
description: I thought, after living in New York for six years, that I'd learned well what it meant to live in a cupboard. I am 30, single and a freelance writer.

title: The World: Strange Brew; Oil and Water: Why Prizes and Science Don't Mix
description: NOBEL fans have stopped being surprised when, come October, they learn who has won the prize for literature. Often it's someone hopelessly obscure (quick -- name your favorite work by Kenzaburo Oe, Wislawa Szymborska or this year's laureate, Imre Kertesz). Or the winner is so well known -- Ernest Hemingway, John Steinbeck, Toni Morrison -- that literary snobs can think of a dozen more deserving writers.

title: Investing; FedEx Has Hit the Ground Running, but Will Its Legs Tire?
description: THE economy refuses to perk up. There is a chance of war in Iraq. Consumers may be latching their purses. It is probably a horrid time to tie up money in shares of a cyclical company.

title: Pond Proud
description: THERE is something rather God-like about ordaining a body of water to appear on your land. And in creating an Eden-like garden setting where plants and animals will thrive.

title: Straight Talk on Bonds
description: Corporate executives don't often warn that it isn't a good time to buy their hottest-selling product, but that, in effect, is what the Vanguard Group has been doing.

title: Where a Well-Dressed Vampire Shops for Fangs
description: Fans of the Manhattan-based Ricky's stores, which stock Halloween costumes, theatrical makeup, and things like fake fangs year round in their nine locations, can now shop for Halloween in Westchester. Ricky's has opened a seasonal outpost of its signature funky shop in the Midway Shopping Center in Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUERSTEIN, RUTH
description: FEUERSTEIN - Ruth. Be loved mother of Barbara, Linda and Howard. October 2, 2002 in Queens, New York.

title: McGreevey Aide Returns To His Roots . . . in Trenton
description: When he was working as a special counselor to Governor McGreevey, Golan Cipel was accused by a pressroom full of reporters of being inaccessible. They never had phone calls returned, and in fact were rarely able to even find him at his desk.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; SECRECY UPHELD
description: The federal appeals court in Philadelphia ruled that deportation hearings may be held in secret, based on the Bush administration's assertion that detainees may have links to terrorism. That decision is at odds with another federal appellate ruling, which held that the government must prove that secrecy is required case by case. The U. S. Supreme Court is likely to consider the subject. Adam Liptak

title: Golden Rules
description: THIS city works too hard and too late to make sunset-watching a priority. But at dusk, on busy street corners where there is open sky, people will look up, point west at a fuchsia smear and shake their heads, as if to ask, ''Where did that come from?''

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: IN THE RIVER SWEET

title: The World: Enduring Freedom; In Afghanistan: What's Past and What's Still to Come
description: A YEAR after the United States attacked Afghanistan, more than 9,000 American forces remain inside the country, hunting down remnants of Al Qaeda, building roads and schools, and struggling to adjust from a combat role to what looks more like a nation-building mission.

title: F. X. Barron, 80; Studied Science of Creativity
description: Frank X. Barron, a psychologist whose work on creativity influenced a generation of researchers, died on Oct. 6 in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 80.

title: Pacer Seeks to End Talk About Weight
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 12 (AP)  Oliver Miller's trip back to the N.B.A. has been as wide as his 6-foot-9, 325-pound frame.

title: After Torricelli, Race Now Suits The Democrats
description: In the two weeks since Senator Robert G. Torricelli abruptly ended his bid for re-election, the race for his seat has been transformed into a contest that is less predictable, less expensive and more likely to focus on issues favorable to Democrats, officials with both parties say.

title: Deconstructing Duffy
description: Last month the fickle finger of fashion poked me in the eye -- I landed on People magazine's Worst Dressed list. The full-length photograph of me was featured in the category ''Head to Toe Horrors.'' In the event that I may have overlooked it, my best friend generously taped the page to my front door. I also noticed that more people called to let me know they had seen my photograph in the issue than called me upon reading the announcement of my marriage.

title: 'Step Across This Line'
description: Out of Kansas

title: Emotional Visit to Ground Zero for Architects Hoping to Build a Future Out of a Horrific Past
description: They had seen the pictures of the planes hitting the towers, of the faces of the thousands buried in the rubble, of the emergency workers and then the construction workers as the twin towers evolved from a graveyard to an empty pit.

title: Small Kansas Towns With a Big Impact
description: WE have a home in the East, friends in the West and a penchant for driving. As a result, my husband and I have crossed Kansas seven times in the past 10 years. After the first trip -- 423 monotonous cornfield miles on the Interstate -- we began varying our route.

title: Why Consumers Should Keep Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Benjamin in a Familiar Spot: At Top of the State Tourney
description: The longest-running annual tournament in the United States, and maybe anywhere, celebrated its latest number at the Hudson Valley Resort in Kerhonkson, N.Y., Aug. 30 to Sept. 2. It was the 124th edition of the New York State Championship. Jos Raul Capablanca won it in 1910 on the way toward beginning the career that lead to his capturing the world championship in 1921. Many of the notables in American chess have won it at one time or another.

title: Sexed Ed
description: Congratulations to Margaret Talbot for her clearsighted article about the push to educate boys and girls separately. (The Way We Live Now, Sept. 22). Whatever arguments may or may not apply in favor of preserving particular cultures, men and women did not develop separately but rather, like males and females of every species, evolved into what they are entirely in relation to each other. You can view this as a beautiful pas de deux or more critically. However, separatism advances nothing. Particular boys and girls may exhibit dysfunctional behavior toward each other, in which case corrective action is required. But this conclusion supports educating them together, where problems can be addressed, rather than through quarantine, papering problems over.

title: Chasing After Songs He Hears in His Head
description: Daniel Bejar has led a revolving line-up of musicians through five albums under the name Destroyer, and with each he has gotten closer to achieving the sound he hears in his head.

title: Too Much Sex, Lots of Lies and Plenty of Videotape
description: After a recent advance screening of Paul Schrader's ''Auto Focus,'' a man who looked to be in his 30's muttered to his companion, ''I'm never going to have sex again.'' Mr. Schrader's movie, which begins in 1965, when the Playboy ethos was at its peak, can do that to people.

title: The Mystery Woman
description: Artists usually don't live pretty. They arrange their environments primarily to service their work. And in this, Leonora Carrington is no exception. When your mind is peopled with strange beings enacting cryptic and symbolic dramas on imaginary stages that only you can see, it stands to reason that your actual living space is besides the point.

title: Carolyn Cavicchio, Alan Matthews
description: Carolyn Cavicchio and Alan Stewart Matthews were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Trinity Center for Urban Life in Philadelphia.

title: Campaign Season; Looking for Alternative to California Candidates
description: Unfortunately, someone will become the next governor of California. That seems to be the attitude of California voters as this year's contest is well on its way to setting records for voter turnout (low) and discontent with candidates (high). Recent statewide surveys show that more than half the respondents are less enthusiastic about voting than usual and 65 percent wish they had different candidates to choose from. In addition, 51 percent had unfavorable opinions of both Gov. Gray Davis, a Democrat, and his Republican challenger, Bill Simon.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Lenny Kravitz's acid blues riffs and soul-inflected voice are throwbacks to classic 1960's rock 'n' roll. While his 1989 debut album, ''Let Love Rule,'' was criticized by some for being too derivative, with four Grammys and 20 million albums sold, Kravitz has successfully introduced the MTV generation to a radio-ready blend of rhythm and blues, reggae, rock and even hip-hop. His 1991 Curtis Mayfield-styled hit, ''It Ain't Over 'Til It's Over,'' remains his most commercially successful song. The retro rock-and-soul vibe of the 70's, Kravitz's favorite era, permeates his design aesthetic as well.

title: Iraq Tour of Suspected Sites Gives Few Clues on Weapons
description: If Iraq is developing nuclear weapons, American officials say, its plans almost certainly involve a sun-beaten, dust-blown, ill-kept industrial plant at Al Furat, a bleak site near this town southwest of Baghdad.

title: New Reasons To Travel Light
description: AIRLINE passengers accustomed to checking excess or overweight baggage without penalty may soon start to feel like teenagers whose long-flouted curfew is suddenly being enforced.

title: The Rights Of Renters In Co-ops
description: ONE of the most common -- and potentially contentious -- business relationships is that of tenant and landlord. And while such relationships are frequently frustrating, often anxiety-producing and at times antagonistic, the potential for problems increases when the rental tenant is living in a co-op building.

title: Dreams Born On Big Screens and Small; In Public Art, Accentuate the Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Congress Lets Slip The Dogs of War
description: IN the Congressional debate over empowering President Bush to wage war against Iraq, much of the argument centered on which words to use. Would they give the president too much power or too little?

title: James Searles, 90, a Master of Lightning-Fast Checkers, Dies
description: James Searles, who elevated the lightning-fast form of checkers played mainly by black men in barbershops, parks and sidewalks to the province of an exclusive if distinctly clamorous society  the Brooklyn Elite Pool Checker Club  died in Brooklyn on Oct. 5. He was 90.

title: Mother's Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: After Some Early Success, Simms and Texas Unravel
description: After scoring the first points early in today's 97th meeting between Texas and Oklahoma, Longhorns quarterback Chris Simms turned to the sea of Texas fans at the Cotton Bowl with his arms raised.

title: Kenya's Leader to Step Down but Not Out
description: President Daniel arap Moi decided to hold a low-key Moi Day this week, his final one as president of Kenya. In the past, he has staged a giant festival in a downtown stadium, extolling his accession to power nearly a quarter century ago. This year, he kept largely to himself, avoiding the hecklers he would inevitably encounter.

title: Top Performers
description: BADGER BEATER

title: Sleeping Boy, 13, Is Wounded When Gunman Fires Into House
description: A 13-year-old Long Island boy was shot in the back with a shotgun early yesterday morning as he slept at a friend's home, the police said, and a 22-year-old neighbor was charged with the shooting.

title: Campaign Season; Addressing Gender Roils Governors' Debates
description: First, there was ''ma'am'' from Maryland. Then came ''Jennifer'' from Michigan.

title: Stealing Home
description: JACKIE ROBINSON AND THE INTEGRATION OF BASEBALL

title: A Student Paper Savors Its Past, and Its Stars
description: WHEN the first issue of The Horace Mann Record appeared during the 1902-03 school year, the publication was a sports-oriented magazine that cost 10 cents, included ads for items like ''Gildersleeve's Latin Grammar,'' and, in the lead article, reported that the private school's football team ''never lacked a goodly crowd of 'rooters' who cheered on the team at every occasion.'' The publication, which became a newspaper in 1911, has over the century of its existence had more than its share of famous alumni on its staff.

title: Paige Fitzgerald, Dan Froomkin
description: Paige Michelle Fitzgerald, a lawyer for the Justice Department, and Dan Froomkin, an editor, were married yesterday in Washington. Judge John M. Mott of the District of Columbia Superior Court officiated at the Dacor Bacon House, a historic house.

title: For Giants To Pounce, All It Takes Is One Twitch
description: The line of scrimmage is the poker table that separates linemen, and if you have played in the National Football League for a decade or more like Keith Hamilton and Michael Strahan, you can stare across and see traces of intent.

title: Michelle Weissman, Jeffrey Feig
description: Michelle Cori Weissman and Jeffrey Ori Feig are to be married today by Rabbi Norman Patz at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Akiva Mann, a cousin of the bridegroom, will take part in the ceremony.

title: INSIDE
description: Remembering Sacrifice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, FLORENCE (LIZ)
description: BLOOM-Florence (Liz). Of Roosevelt Island, NY, died Tuesday, October 8, 2002, at 82. The cherished daughter of Pauline and Jacob Brill and beloved sister of Harold and Hy, she was married for 55 years and adored by her family and many friends. Liz leaves her husband Jules, her daughters Janet and Amy; her sister Malvina; son-in-law Terry; grandchildren Mara and Lauren; sisters-in-law Adele and Donna; brothersin-law Joe and Sam; nieces Rona (Michael) and Debby (Allison); and nephews Warren, Matt, Harry (Trish), Ron, Paul (Ellen), William and Edward. Liz was also the devoted and much loved aunt of nine great-nieces and nephews, one great-great-niece, and many cousins. Liz was an indefatigable and early fighter for social justice. An avid gardener, cook, reader of mysteries and magician of crossword puzzles, she was a woman of great charm, curiosity, wit and gentle humor whose love, energy, optimism and joy will be deeply missed. Services will be held at 11AM, Sunday, October 13, 2002, at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, L.I. In lieu of flowers, a contribution might be made to an environmental protection group or any charity you deem worthy.

title: TV's Damaged Detectives Are Sherlock's Children
description: THERE is an eccentric new generation of crime fighters in prime time -- brilliant, obsessed and, if not dysfunctional, then at the very least damaged. They are modern descendants of the detective story's greatest hero, Sherlock Holmes. And by reaching back to this early model, their creators have revitalized the genre, reclaiming it from several decades of psychic charlatans, grandmotherly amateurs and foot-weary plodders with booze on their breath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FECHHEIMER, JAMES A.
description: FECHHEIMER-James A., 89. Of Glen Head, NY, on October 6th, 2002. Former NYC school teacher. Beloved uncle of Constance Knowlton and grand-nephews, Timothy and James Knowlton. Special friend of Peter Eustance.

title: A State Attorney's Office Without the Chief
description: THEY keep phoning the office, even after hearing that John M. Bailey Jr., the chief state's attorney for the past nine years, said he was leaving his job because he was ill. They are ordinary people, not usually found in the corridors of the State Capital, which Mr. Bailey often stalked like his father and sister before him, or at cocktail parties in Madison, where the Bailey clan has a summer house. Just folks with legal problems, who knew no matter how much money they had or what they did for a living, he would pull up a chair for them in his Rocky Hill office to listen.

title: Samantha Liebowitz, Neal Kaufman
description: Samantha Jill Liebowitz, a daughter of Susan Liebowitz and Dr. Solomon Liebowitz of New York, is to be married this evening to Neal Scott Kaufman, the son of Dr. Judy Kaufman and Dr. Stephen Kaufman of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan Stein is to officiate at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: And Now, Air Rover
description: For traveling pet owners who refuse to pack precious Fido in the cargo hold, Companion Air, which plans to begin flying at the end of the year, may be just the ticket.

title: Living Large; Getting the Cheesecake Shot
description: THE skin is taut and glistening, a russet glow emanating from every pore. The curves are inviting, voluptuous, hinting at the incomparable bliss to be found in the inner core.

title: Armor Against Stains
description: A LITTLE club soda may erase that wine stain, but if the fabric had been based on new polymer technology, the stain would not have been there in the first place.

title: Whoosh! A Show of Dominance at Lunch
description: RICHARD CONNIFF, a natural history writer who has tracked leopards through the Okavango Delta in Botswana, documented penis displays of vervet monkeys and followed the migration of Irish elk, trekked to Manhattan last week to share his expertise about the behavior patterns of a species indigenous to large American cities. Rather than hunker down in Central Park to observe pigeon pecking orders, Mr. Conniff planted himself at a discrete corner table in the Four Seasons on Park Avenue.

title: Budgets Made to Be Broken
description: Nearly two-thirds of holiday shoppers plan to set budgets for gifts this year. But nearly 40 percent of those who set them acknowledge that they are unlikely to stick to them, according to survey results released last week by Champion Mortgage.

title: Loyal Buyers for Picky Pets
description: Brand loyalty can be fleeting. Most consumers will switch products in a heartbeat, if it means saving money. But they make exceptions, and one of them involves their pets.

title: Mary Highet, William Schwarz
description: Mary Marshall MacInnes Highet, the daughter of Mrs. David Butler Vietor of Edgartown, Mass., and the late Gilbert Keith MacInnes Highet, who lived in Washington, is to be married today to William Kord Schwarz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Schwarz of Atlanta. The Rev. John D. Schule, a minister of the United Church of Christ, is to perform the ceremony at the Old Whaling Church in Edgartown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERPLANCK, WILLIAM S.
description: VERPLANCK-William S., 86, September 30th, 2002, at St. Mary's Hospice, Knoxville, Tn. Eminent psychologist, educator, author, beloved friend and colleague. A memorial party will be held at 7PM, November 2, at The Foundry in Knoxville.

title: Nubbiness and Old Lace
description: As the Granny Redux look hits its stride with lace-up boots and crochet trim, boucl fabric is enjoying a revival. The tightly looped wool or wool-mix weave was made famous by the classic boucl wool Chanel suit. It is now showing up in the form of sexy separates and coats with unconventional linings and detail. Moschino uses boucl in a salt-and-pepper sleeveless dress ornamented with small knotted jabots (right, $475) and a form-fitting blazer ($1,050, both at Saks Fifth Avenue). Luisa Beccaria's nubby lavender jacket is lined in silk paisley ($1,465 at Bergdorf Goodman). Lycra puts some snap in J. Crew's stretch boucl turtleneck ($54) and slash-front crewneck ($48); Urban Outfitters' cabled gray hoodie has sweatshirt-style pockets ($64 at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass., 413-528-9455). At Marc Jacobs, the traditional peacoat is recast in boucl with antique buttons, for a surprisingly modern effect ($1,100). As a bonus, this may be a look that actually has longevity, as evidenced by the pastel boucl pencil skirts and jackets in Mr. Jacobs's spring 2003 collection.

title: Islanders' Home Opener: No Victory, Many Boos
description: The puck somehow deflected onto Jaromir Jagr's stick with time running out in a tight game. Chris Osgood, hunched inches away, realized at that moment that fate would not be kind to him or the Islanders.

title: Market Shift Foils Area Energy Plans
description: ONCE the wave of the energy future, independent power plant projects that were supposed to bring competition to Long Island are on the ropes, and their developers are turning to the Long Island Power Authority for help.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 5 of Arts & Leisure today about the Hartford Stage Company production of "Edgardo Mine," a play based on the 1858 kidnapping of a young boy by agents of Pope Pius IX, refers incorrectly to part of the political backdrop  the form of government under which Italy was about to be unified. It was a constitutional monarchy, not a republican state.

title: Greater Hartford Open to End If It Fails to Find a Sponsor
description: The uncertain future of the Greater Hartford Open may deny Suzy Whaley her chance to make golf history.

title: Word for Word/The Cuban Missile Crisis; When the World Stood on Edge And Nobody Died Beautifully
description: FORTY years ago this week, the United States and the Soviet Union went eyeball to eyeball. Moscow had smuggled nuclear missiles into Cuba. Washington wanted them out. One wrong move and World War III would be at hand.

title: Lisa Caputo, Richard Morris
description: Lisa Maria Caputo and Richard Allen Morris are to be married today by the Rev. Dr. Eileen W. Lindner, a Presbyterian minister, at the Wainwright House, a holistic education center in Rye, N.Y.

title: Making Money Backwards
description: A LAWYER'S LIFE

title: Inviting White Rieslings
description: Bidwell Vineyards, in Cutchogue on the North Fork, is a textbook case of hiding one's light under a bushel.

description: THE NEW BIOGRAPHICAL

title: Drinking, Dancing, And Sometimes a Crime Scene
description: On most Friday and Saturday nights, there's drinking, dancing and good times at Moonlighting, a bar on Amsterdam Avenue near 85th Street that is popular with a young Latino crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUFFER, DR. RUTH RICE
description: PUFFER-Dr. Ruth Rice. Biostatistician at the Pan American Health Organization, World Health Organization, died September 2, 2002, at her home in McMinnville, Oregon. She was 95. Dr. Puffer served as Chief of the Department of Health Statistics of the Pan American Health Organization 1953 - 1970, where she was the prime mover behind the InterAmerican Investigation of Childhood Mortality. Her studies, ''Patterns of Urban Mortality'' (1967) and ''Patterns of Mortality in Childhood'' (1973), are still considered path-breaking classics of scientific literature and have had an impact on health services throughout the hemisphere. She is one of eleven distinguished individuals selected by the Pan American Health Organization in 2002 to receive the honor of ''Public Health Hero of the Americas''. A celebration of her life will be held at the Francis E. Rice Chapel, First Parish Church, Berlin, Massa chusetts at 4 P.M. on October 19, 2002. Anyone wishing to contribute to her memory may send a contribution to the Ruth Rice Puffer endowment fund at Johns Hopkins University, School of Hygiene and Public Health, 615 North Wolfe Street, Baltimore, Maryland 21205-2179.

title: Out of the Shadows, And Into the Spotlight
description: SOMETIMES a museum show can be upgraded from an exhibition to a major event. This is the case with ''Michael Sweerts 1618-1664'' at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. It's not that Sweerts has been freshly discovered; in fact the Wadsworth owns two of his paintings. But he has never before gotten his due.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNENBERG, WALTER H.
description: ANNENBERG-Walter H. It is with great sorrow that the American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the death of Walter H. Annenberg, an Academy Fellow, who passed away October 1, 2002. Ambassador to Britain during the Nixon presidency, Annenberg was an art collector and renowned publisher whose visionary philanthropy has left an indelible mark on arts and educational institutions across the country. His generosity helped the American Academy launch its Visiting Scholars Program, created to nurture a new generation of scholars. The Academy extends its condolences to his wife, Leonore, his family, and all those who shared his passion for art, education, and international understanding. Patricia Meyer Spacks President Louis Cabot, Vice President Emilio Bizzi, Secretary Peter Lynch, Treasurer Leslie Berlowitz Executive Officer

title: The Smallpox Decision
description: President Bush faces a momentous public health decision: whether to make smallpox vaccine available to all who want it or limit its use to the health personnel who would have to cope with any bioterrorist attack. The issue is fraught with difficulties. If Mr. Bush makes the vaccine widely available, there will be severe side effects in a small percentage of recipients. If 100 million people chose to be vaccinated, perhaps 100 of them might die and many more could be severely injured. But these casualties would pale in comparison with the toll that would be exacted by a smallpox attack. Should a smallpox epidemic spread out of control, it could kill tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of unvaccinated people.

title: The Mentally Ill In Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: In Canada, the Accent Has Been on Controversy
description: FOR half a century, Canadians have seized every opportunity to devour television from the American side of the border while Americans have pretty well ignored Canadian TV. But for the next three and a half months, the Museum of Television and Radio will be taking a small step toward correcting that imbalance, by marking the 50th anniversary of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's television service with a mammoth retrospective of notable shows.

title: How Laura Bush Lets Literature Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Wobbling Heights
description: The skirt is back and not just on the runways. Women attending the spring shows in Paris last week displayed multiple hemlines, although no one wore the absurdly short minis the designers are proposing. The eye was captivated by what went with them, high heels and bare legs. The guests' strappy stilettos gave their mostly knee-length skirts a different look from those worn in the 1960's with boots, flat-heeled shoes and dark stockings. Women on their way to the shows could be seen gingerly navigating cobblestone courtyards. They laughed at themselves, but no one changed into jogging sneakers. Vanity won again.

title: How Laura Bush Lets Literature Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Angels' Pitchers Have Taken Control of the Twins' Bats
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 12  Kirby Puckett was dressed all in black, but that was the extent of the funereal tone in the Minnesota Twins' post-game locker room on Friday.

title: Dunks and Slapshots Under Wraps
description: WHEN I was a teenager, living in Westchester, I made silent vows to leave this backwater and never return. The problem was the utter lack of a single, solitary thing to do. But even back then, I would gladly offer kind words about the place on one subject: When it came to professional sports, there was no place like home.

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; DOCKS UNLOCKED
description: With fruit rotting and 200 ships unable to unload, President Bush invoked the Taft-Hartley Act to reopen 29 West Coast ports, which handle $300 billion in cargo each year, and end the lockout of 10,500 longshoremen. Organized labor is angry at Mr. Bush for invoking Taft-Hartley; he was the first president to do so since Jimmy Carter. Steven Greenhouse

title: In the Scuffed Shoes Of Women Scraping By
description: THE stage adaptation of ''Nickel and Dimed'' begins with a frantic whoosh of coffee shop bustle, as uniformed waitresses sprint from table to table, barking out orders and quips.

title: 'Blue Shoe'
description: The world outside the window was in flames. The leaves on the pistachio trees shone fire-red and orange. Mattie studied the early-morning light. She was lying on the side of the bed where her husband should have been sleeping. Those trees were one reason she'd moved back into her parents' old home after leaving Nicholas, these trees and the sloping grassy hillside behind the house. Also, there was no mortgage: her parents had paid it off during the course of their marriage. She and her brother, Al, had grown up playing on the hill and in the buckeyes with their low, broad branches; her six-year-old, Harry, played there now, and her daughter, Ella, two, would also climb one day soon. The leaves of the delicate Japanese maple between Mattie's window and the wobbly fence were still green, but elsewhere in the garden were russets and butterscotch-oranges, other trees giddy with color, almost garish, like gypsy dresses. When she strained to listen, she could imagine them saying, We gave you shade, and now we'll give you a little kick-ass beauty before we die. A choir of chickadees and finches sang above the sounds of a quiet neighborhood waking up, the cars of people heading to work and school, the clatter and thumps of the recycling truck, a dog barking, leaves rustling in a gentle wind, silence. A moment later she heard the rats in the walls begin to stir.

title: A Fighting Man's (and Woman's) Work
description: THIS is a loose-cannon sort of piece,'' Steve Reich said a few months ago at his country home in Rochester, Vt. ''If you're a composer and you start writing opera late, you've been around a long time, you've seen the world, and you want to say big things about what you've seen.''

title: Nyack Theater Names a New Chief
description: THE Helen Hayes Theater Company in Nyack announced last week that it had reached across the state line into New Jersey for its new executive director.

title: DataBank; For a Change, Main Gauges Turn Positive
description: On the strength of big rallies on Thursday and Friday, the three big stock gauges rose for the week, an achievement that had eluded them since August. The gains came after lackluster sessions early in the week. As late as Wednesday, all three indexes had fallen to multiyear lows.

description: IDEALLY, good bars should age like rock stars. The wood grain may weather and the cushions might start to sag, but a certain swagger and attitude should always remain. After all, if Ozzy Osbourne can make a comeback, who's to say that an over-the-hill former hot spot can't muscle its way back onto the scene?

Power of Lovettsville, Va. Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: A Few Bright Spots in Toyland
description: Retailers have no illusions about the holidays. The weak economy and falling stock market will undoubtedly mean lackluster sales -- except, perhaps, for certain toys. A recent survey of toy and video game retailers shows healthy sales so far for educational toys, video games and licensed toys, in particular. The survey of more than two dozen national chains and specialty shops was conducted by PlayDate, a marketing firm in New York.
