title: Taking (And Using) Sept. 11 Personally
description: THE choreographer Stephen Petronio began his ''City of Twist'' shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks. Known for abstract, irreverent dances, he had never responded creatively to a specific event. But he called his six dancers together to create a dance that would be relevant to the tragedy.

title: Footlights
description: Movie Music

title: Commercial Property/Lower East Side; Gritty Neighborhood Is Looking Better to Retailers
description: THE search for affordable rents has driven small independent retailers to unlikely parts of the city, such as the meatpacking district around 14th Street on the far western part of Manhattan and NoLIta, the northern part of Little Italy, east of Lafayette Street between Houston and Canal Streets.

title: Seeking a Synergy Of Ballet and Beatle
description: THIS week, American Ballet Theater plans to rock out. For the company's City Center season, the artistic director Kevin McKenzie commissioned David Parsons, Ann Reinking, Natalie Weir and Stanton Welch to find inspiration in the music of George Harrison. No concert T-shirts, no lighters, no marijuana. Just the trailing scent of Chanel and ballet patrons, clad in black tie, playing air guitar in the aisles. The mind reels.

title: Vintage Chic
description: With its glass walls that double as doors, split-levels and relentless cool yet surprising coziness, this house in the serene foothills of the Los Feliz section of Los Angeles is a shrine to the promise of Southern California. Cross-ventilated breezes drift through the aerie -- built long before feng shui became a twinkle in the eye of every trendy type this side of Fred Segal -- bringing with it monarch butterflies and birds. By comparison, the buttoned-up mansions of Beverly Hills seem woefully sad, if not cynical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, EVERETT
description: O'CONNOR-Everett. Of Anapolis, MD. Died on September 26, 2002. Born in NYC on November 6, 1905. Survived by two daughters, Evelyn O'Connor of NYC and Karen M. Mongelli of Anapolis, MD, four grandchildren, one great grandchild and a sister.

title: A World Series Played by Two Wild-Card Teams Wouldn't Faze Many
description: Baseball's wild card is growing up quickly. In fact, this year's World Series could feature the two wild-card teams for the first time in the format's eight-year history.

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; COMING UP
description: President Bush is scheduled to meet with the Israeli prime minister at the White House on Wednesday. He plans to make campaign trips to Michigan on Monday, to Georgia on Thursday and to Missouri and Minnesota on Friday. Congress will try to wrap up its business before its election recess, considering legislation on homeland security, terrorism insurance and on a continuing budget resolution.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-8

title: Pan-Asian Cuisine Makes a Statement
description: WILD GINGER has taken root in Great Neck. This pan-Asian offshoot from New Canaan, Conn., where the first Wild Ginger opened, was under siege in September, when I visited about three or four weeks after it opened. And no wonder -- it is the least expensive of the Island's strikingly exotic spots. (Entrees start under $10 and with one exception top out at $19.50) and its emphatically Asian dcor is gorgeous.

title: Amanda Howard, Avshalom Kalichstein
description: Amanda Anne Howard, a daughter of Nancy S. Howard and J. Norman Howard of Tupper Lake, N.Y., is to be married there today to Avshalom Yitzhak Kalichstein, a son of Rowain and Joseph Kalichstein of Maplewood, N.J. Rabbi Alec Friedmann will perform the ceremony at Historic Beth Joseph Synagogue.

title: 40th Reunion
description: Swell pictures. But why are all the men clothed and the women (apparently) naked? The men are portrayed with their wrinkles and personal idiosyncrasies intact. But the women are youthful, attractive and unclothed. It's no excuse that a woman took the pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FARRAH, JERE T.
description: FARRAH-Jere T. A memorial service will be held for Jere Tiffin Farrah on Monday, October 21, 10 AM at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, 112th Street.

title: Private Sector; Martha's Blunders, Served With Relish
description: It was billed as a panel of experts who would discuss flaws in the traditional way of advertising. But the eight-member panel could have been called ''What Martha Stewart Did Wrong.''

title: 2nd Iraq Letter Stops Short of Reconfirming Pacts
description: Iraq sent a second, more conciliatory letter to the chief United Nations weapons inspectors yesterday, but once again stopped short of fully reconfirming agreements the two sides made earlier in the week.

title: Helping Parents Tell A Child About Sex
description: PARENTS in Pelham and Rye are doing it. Those in Chappaqua and Bronxville did it last year, and they may very likely do it again.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Monsters Onscreen And Within
description: IF you had wanted to see Gary Sherman's hideously poignant 1972 subway cannibal picture, ''Raw Meat'' (also known as ''Death Line''), in New York City in the early 1970's, you would have had to trek to one of many grindhouses on the Deuce (42nd Street); weave your way around grisly placards festooned with phrases like ''Blood-curdling!'' ''Beyond belief!'' and ''Too depraved!''; and push your way past people in the aisles hawking drugs as if they were peanuts, to a squeaky seat with worrisome stains.

title: POSTINGS: At Melrose Commons Project; 61-Unit Rental In South Bronx
description: The first rental apartment building in the Melrose Commons redevelopment project opened last week. It is the latest addition in the 35-block renewal area in the South Bronx where the first for-sale homes went on the market two years ago. The seven-story structure, called La Puerta de Vitalidad (the Door to Vitality), has 61 one- to three-bedroom apartments, which rent for $545 to $759 a month to low-income and formerly homeless families. The $14 million project, at 3103 Third Avenue and East 158th Street, was developed by the not-for-profit Phipps Houses, with Nos Quedamos (We Stay) the community sponsor.

title: In the Region/Long Island; The Lineup of 'Lifestyle' Communities Is Growing
description: FOR 35 years, Loretta and Victor Iamunno lived in South Wantagh, where they raised their two daughters and operated a nearby restaurant-pizzeria.

title: Investing; A Time to Bail Out? Some Clues
description: WHEN is it time to sell a mutual fund? For Kevin Kuta, it was when his normally cast-iron stomach began to turn in knots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELDA, EMANUEL
description: GELDA-Emanuel. Of Newton, MA. Formerly of New York. On October 9, 2002. Husband of Shirley (Willer). Father of Steven and Philip. Brother of Stanley. Grandfather of Lizzie and Jinny. Services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island today, 11 A.M.

title: With Few Jobs Being Created, Pain Is Felt Far and Wide
description: Almost a year after the economy began growing again, the nation continues to suffer through a broad jobs slump that has spread the pain more evenly than almost any downturn on record.

title: Erin Flanagan, Corey Lind
description: Erin Susan Flanagan, a daughter of Elizabeth Skillin Flanagan and John Augustin Flanagan of Upper Montclair, N.J., is to be married today to Corey Tyson Lind, a son of Karen and Stephen Lind of Pleasanton, Calif. Corey Vaughan, a minister in the Universal Life Church, will officiate at Shadowbrook, a restaurant and caterer in Shrewsbury, N.J.

title: Any Other Positions They'd Care to Discuss?
description: Talk about hot-button issues.

title: King Lear in Bombay
description: FAMILY MATTERS

title: A Small-Stakes Poker Player Takes a Pot From Vegas Sharks
description: THE SETTING -- Tatiana, a Russian restaurant on the boardwalk in Brighton Beach. Late last month, above an enormous illuminated tank of koi carp set into the floor, 40 of Robert Varkonyi's closest friends toasted his unlikely victory in a big game: the World Series of Poker in Las Vegas.

title: Lessons in Cultural Diversity, With Hulks
description: PLEASE take the following test to determine if you are a snob.

title: Investing; Nasdaq Considers a Lower Standard
description: WITH most Nasdaq stocks trading for less than $5 and several hundred worth less than $1 a share, managers of the Nasdaq stock market are considering lowering their standards.

title: Brothers Linked In Mystery Recalled
description: Linked together by mysterious events in the South Pacific this summer, the former N.B.A. player Bison Dele and his brother, Miles Dabord, were linked together again today.

title: To Each His Own Hell
description: To the Editor:

title: WATERFRONT PLAN
description: The Asbury Park City Council formally introduced a $1.2 billion waterfront revitalization plan last week. It calls for building a hotel, restaurants and about 2,200 condominiums. It is scheduled for a public hearing and vote later this month. The project's chief developer, Asbury Partners, would pay the city $7 million, which would go toward developing low- and middle-income housing, said James Famularo, assistant city manager.

title: An Ugly Defeat, Even by Rutgers's Low Standards
description: For the longest time, it has not been whether Rutgers loses, but whether it gets embarrassed. Score a few points, hang around for a while and it does not seem so bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, REV. WILLIAM T., S.J.
description: WOOD-Rev. William T., S.J. On October 10, 2002. Survived by his nieces Rosemary Petrie, Maureen Koenke, Kathleen Roberts and Mary Ellen Galasso, 12 grand nieces and nephews and seven greatgrandnieces and nephews. Reposing at St. Ignatius Loyola Rectory, 980 Park Avenue, Sunday, October 13, 3-5 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street. Interment Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY.

title: Nets' Collins Becomes 7-Foot Forward
description: After contending with the Los Angeles Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal for four games in the National Basketball Association finals last season, it was no surprise that Jason Collins didn't mind trying another position.

title: A Number Story About Polls, Millions of Dollars and Angst
description: As he trudged along press row in the State House last week to hand out his newest numbers, Clay F. Richards, the assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Poll, was droopy around the eyes, having just pulled an all-nighter.

title: Gold Coast Servants' Quarters: Less Gilt
description: THREE distinct faces stare unobtrusively into the formal gardens of Coe Hall, an Oyster Bay mansion that splendidly recalls Long Island's Gold Coast estate era. The faces are easily missed, yet they speak volumes about a bygone day.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: HATESHIP, FRIENDSHIP, COURTSHIP, LOVESHIP, MARRIAGE: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Vintage Contemporaries, $14.) Many of the central characters in these nine tales start out by having a harsh hand dealt them, whether it's cancer, the suicide of an ailing husband or Alzheimer's disease, but somehow manage to find enduring value in their lives as they struggle through their darkest moments. This collection, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2001, is ''surely Munro's best yet,'' William H. Pritchard wrote here. Her ''vivid, external perceptions are complemented and balanced by a more exploratory, inwardly poetic kind of writing.''

title: After 14-Year Career, Jalabert Bids Adieu
description: TOURS, France, Oct. 12  The 25 teams in the Paris-Tours bicycle race mounted the podium before the start and their riders were introduced by name and major laurel, with nearly everybody getting his 15 seconds of fame.

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; TWO GENES, ONE HEART
description: Two variant genes, acting together, increase the risk of congestive heart failure 10-fold, researchers found. One floods the heart with a hormone that makes it contract, and the other makes it respond more forcefully to the hormone. The combination may eventually injure the heart. The gene variants are more common in blacks than whites, and blacks are twice as likely to have congestive heart failure, a leading cause of death. Gina Kolata

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, ROSE
description: FISCHER-Rose. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Rose Fischer and extends heartfelt sympathy to her entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Ferne Skiba, President

title: Toyota's Image Wins in Slow Formula One Start
description: As the season starts its final laps, one of the Goliaths of the world automobile industry finds itself trailing even the David of Formula One.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 13, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Sports of The Times; Bring Extra Clothes And Cash for Playoffs
description: DON'T forget to pack.

title: Gazeteer
description: 2-bedroom, 1-bath colonial at 238 Westervelt Avenue, $193,900.

title: Fuel Gauge Is Near 'E' For the Big Three
description: SINCE 9/11, major auto companies have relied heavily on zero percent financing to bolster sales.

title: Laurie Costa, Simon Mendez
description: Laurie Anne Costa, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Costa of Kings Park, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Simon John Mendez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Mendez of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Canon Peter Larom, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Church.

title: Dreams Born On Big Screens and Small
description: To the Editor:

title: Small Favors, Large Stories, Tough Questions
description: SHOULD politicians get jobs for doormen?

title: Kristin Brenneman, Sean Eno
description: Kristin Sanders Brenneman and Sean Maloy Eno were married yesterday in Shelby, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Fred Rose, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's parents, Katherine Brenneman and Dr. Dwight Sanders Brenneman.

title: National Forecast
description: Gusty winds from the northwest will drive cool air from the northern Plains into the upper Midwest behind a strong cold front. Snow showers will be common near the shores of the northern Great Lakes as the cold air gathers moisture over the milder lake waters. Meanwhile, cool air will also spill south across the southern Plains and lower Mississippi Valley. Low clouds and a few showers will occur in the cooler air from New Mexico across southern Texas.

title: Stronger Than Death?
description: To the Editor:

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Almodvar Gang; Tapas, No Subtitles
description: THE actors in Pedro Almodvar's new film, ''Talk to Her,'' know how to let down their hair -- even the two male leads, who don't have too much of it. The five stars, ages 27 to 58, wound up on Thursday evening drinking, smoking and munching through five triple-tiered trays of bite-size lounge food.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: What Will Rise Where the Gas Tanks Loomed?
description: Until they were torn down in 1996, the venerable Elmhurst gas tanks at 80th Road and 57th Avenue served two purposes. They stored large amounts of natural gas, and they gave motorists something to look at while they stewed in rush-hour traffic on the Long Island Expressway.

title: RAIL TUNNEL PROJECT
description: A decade-old proposal to build an additional rail tunnel to carry passengers between New Jersey and Manhattan got a boost last week when state officials said the project would top their transportation priorities. The board of New Jersey Transit voted to spend $4.9 million on an environmental impact study of the project. New Jersey Transit's executive director, George D. Warrington, said another tunnel, with an inbound and an outbound tube, would in effect double the number of trains operating between New Jersey and Pennsylvania Station during peak hours.

title: Village Is More Global, Language Is More Vital
description: GNIESZKA OSSOLINSKA-JASKOWSKI didn't have work experience in the legal field. She didn't have any important contacts in the legal business. And she didn't yet have a diploma from Montclair State University in New Jersey, where where she was studying to be a paralegal.

title: D.W.D. Means Driving While Distracted
description: THE body language speaks volumes about the call. With their heads ducked low and their eyes darting across their windshields and up to their rearview mirrors, the drivers slouch to the side, cradling their cellphones.

title: Art for Heart's Sake
description: In his memoir ''Flying Colors: The Story of a Remarkable Group of Artists and the Transcendent Power of Art'' (Beacon, $25) Tim Lefens and his students, who use wheelchairs, confront the limitations of the physical world with the what he calls the ''language of abstraction.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 5 of Arts & Leisure today about the Hartford Stage Company production of ''Edgardo Mine,'' a play based on the 1858 kidnapping of a young boy by agents of Pope Pius IX, refers incorrectly to part of the political backdrop -- the form of government under which Italy was about to be unified. It was a constitutional monarchy, not a republican state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLENDON, ROBERT G.
description: McLENDON-Robert G. The Board of Directors and the shareholders of the 180 Tenants Corporation record with deep sorrow the loss of our beloved neighbor, friend and Board President. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara and family.

title: A New Penn Station
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: October 13, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Corrections
description: The Residential Sales listing last Sunday misstated an address in the City Island section of the Bronx and the dimensions of a lot in Port Washington, N.Y. The house on King Avenue in City Island is at 416, not 415. The lot at 64 Reid Avenue Port Washington is 100 feet by 125, not 25.

title: Ipsita Ghoshtagore, Chad Smolinski
description: Ipsita Ghoshtagore, the daughter of Dr. Srirupa Ghoshtagore of Columbia, Md., and Dr. Rathindra Ghoshtagore of Ellicott City, Md., was married on Friday evening in Oxon Hill, Md., to Chad Christopher Smolinski, the son of Teri Clark Smolinski and Robert Smolinski, both of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. John P. Gaffney, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at Oxon Hill Manor, where Dr. Kanai Mukherjee, a Hindu priest, later presided over a Hindu ceremony.

title: It's a Snake-Eat-Frog-Eggs World
description: WE fell in love with our house on a cold, snowy day in January and closed on it the first week in May. Hidden by the snow and ice had been a pond, bigger than a puddle and smaller than a lake.

title: POSTINGS: At Bard College; Arts Center Designed by Frank Gehry
description: Bard College, a private liberal arts school 90 miles north of New York City at Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., has long been known for its performing arts programs. Among its events is a summer music festival whose orchestra concerts and other large offerings have always been held under a tent.

title: Where The Really Wild Things Are
description: Clive Barker is not a scary guy. At 50, he is tanned and buff and amiable -- his big vices are cigars and endless cups of strong tea. With his trimmed goatee and twin hoop earrings he looks like a pirate who is settling into middle age after years of successful plundering. But when he cracks open the door to one of his Beverly Hills houses -- Barker owns three of them, all in a row, all with wide-angle views over Century City -- and croaks, ''Welcome to the inside of my head,'' I can't help it: I get a little creeped-out anyway.

title: Calpers Wears a Party, or Union, Label
description: THE California Public Employees' Retirement System, perhaps the nation's most prominent champion of shareholder rights, has never suffered from an ill that plagues corporate America: a supine board, unable to thwart managers' worst instincts.

title: Fennell Wins Manhattan Meet
description: Brenden Fennell, an unbeaten senior from Pearl River (N.Y.) High School, raced to the fastest time yesterday in the 30th Manhattan College Scholastic Cross-Country Invitational Meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: BENDING HEAVEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METCALF, MARY K.
description: METCALF-Mary K. Of Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Lawrence, NY. Died October 5, after a brief illness. Born Mary Dorothy Keresey on March 21, 1926, Mimi was the daughter of the late Henry Donnelly Keresey and the late Mary Dorothy Kelley, and the granddaughter of the late Cornelius Francis Kelley, chairman of The Anaconda Company, and the late Mary Tremblay. She attended the Marymount and Spence Schools, and was a graduate of Briarcliff College. Beloved wife of the late Mahlon W. Edmonson and the late Harris Metcalf. An earlier marriage to William Dayton Holmes ended in divorce. She is survived by four children, Mary E. White, Deborah E. Drake, Mahlon W. Edmonson, Jr., and Anne E. Kerr, two brothers H. Donn Keresey and Michael M. Keresey, stepdaughter Shepley Metcalf and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81 street on Tuesday, October 15, at 1:30. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers a donation in her name can be made to The Riverside Theater, 3250 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, FL. 32963.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Rachel Kellerman, Stephen Miller
description: Rachel Volusher Kellerman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Kellerman of Cherry Hill, N.J., is to be married there today to Stephen Aaron Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Miller of Lexington, Ky. Rabbi Steven Lindemann will officiate at Temple Beth Sholom.

title: Along the Bowery, Skid Row Is on the Skids
description: SAY, kid, been down on the Bowery lately? You know, skid row, desolation street, the end of the road?

title: The Most-Wanted List
description: INTO LEATHER

title: Perfect Georgia Gives Fans Plenty to Cheer About
description: In the 20 seasons since the Heisman Trophy winner Herschel Walker led Georgia to its last Southeastern Conference championship, Bulldogs fans have tried to measure a number of their teams for conference championship rings. The expectations never matched the result.

title: Arts Center in Sacramento; Water Taxis in New York; Ruins in Rome
description: Near Sacramento, Finally, a Big-City Arts Center

title: Rope-A-Dope
description: In casting a heavy aspersion on Saddam Hussein's word, the presidential press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said, ''He has a history of playing rope-a-dope with the world, while all the time developing a more powerful punch.''

title: Remembering the Little Things; Older Monuments Guide Planners of Sept. 11 Memorial
description: Shoes. Abandoned haphazardly in the middle of the street, buried in ash along curbsides, dug from the mountains of rubble formed by the collapse of the World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARASON, FRANCES
description: SARASON-Frances. A joyful artist, talented designer, world traveler and connoisseur of music and the visual arts. An innately curious individual who took great delight in her international arena of friends, family, artists, activists and intellectuals. Her youthful spirit and passion for social justice will continue to inspire nieces Patti Treger and Barbara Fresko and numerous beloved friends. We mourn her sudden death on October 6, 2002 and invite friends to visit on Sunday, October 20, from 2-6 PM to share memories, laughter and tears.

title: Dog Bites Dog
description: Aren't the citizens of Indianapolis concerned that this kind of antisocial conduct will build up over time? Psychiatric studies of serial killers show a pattern of childhood cruelty to animals. It is a derogation of common sense to call this cruel and cowardly activity a sport.

title: Waiting
description: I had been hosting a radio call-in show in China and listening to women tell me their stories for three and a half years when I went to visit Tangshan in 1992. The city had been rebuilt after the terrible earthquake of 1976, in which as many as 300,000 people may have died. Once there, I heard about an unusual orphanage founded and run by mothers who had lost their children during the disaster. One mother agreed to recount her tale as long as I promised her anonymity. Since the tragedy, she had been asked many times about her loss. She wanted this time to be the last.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 8 about the coming film ''Frida'' referred incorrectly to its screenplay credits. The writers are Diane Lake, Gregory Nava, Clancy Sigal and Anna Thomas. The writer of the original draft of the script is not credited on the film. And a correction in this space on Sept. 15 misidentified that writer. He was David Stevens. (Rodrigo Garca wrote a later draft.)

title: The Brothers Huvane
description: It was just one of those typical fashion conversations: lots of rhyme, not much reason. I was talking to myself.

title: Shabana Is Late For School
description: Susan Dominus simply has to follow Shabana and let us know what happens to this spirited girl and her family. The next time I am assigned to substitute-teach at a middle school, I will take this article along and read it to the students. Perhaps they will gain a new appreciation of school.

title: Shabana Is Late For School
description: To see these young women once again enjoy the intellectual challenge, peer interaction and opportunities that come from the daily routine of going to school gives one hope for Afghanistan's future. It was wonderful to read that many of these girls want to be doctors and teachers to help rebuild their country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENZWEIG, MARTIN
description: ROSENZWEIG - Martin, 83. Artist of Kings Point, NY, of congestive heart failure on Friday, October 11, 2002. In a career that spanned 50 years in graphic arts, he created films, designed magazines, books and exhibits, and specialized in drawings of the human figure. He obtained a BS from City College and an MA from the Institute of Design. His clients included RCA, NBC, IBM, Life Magazine and Time Life Publications. He was respected for his business acumen and loved for his warmth, wit, wealth of information, and wonderful repertoire of songs. He is survived by his wife of 50 years Betty, daughter and son-inlaw, Micki and Richard Tiffen of Norwalk, CT, son and daughter-in-law, Tony Rosenzweig and Debra Weinstein, as well as five grandchildren, Leah, Paul and Alison Rosenzweig, Ross and Jesse Tiffen; brother and sister-in-law, Max and Mae Rosenzweig. Missed but never forgotten. Memorial services will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Chinese Transplant With a Warming Soul
description: EVERY morning, Kevin Esteban and Bob Siciliano have coffee in their tiny Upper West Side garden, under the fragrant white flowers of their seven-son flower tree (Heptacodium miconioides). Their voices are hushed, reverent. This is their morning worship service.

title: Autumn Arts
Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDER, RUSSELL JAMES
description: CALDER - Russell James. Humanitarian and leader/ educator in the residential interior design community, died at his home on October 8, 2002. Born in New York City on August 16, 1949 to Ang J. Calder and Dorothy (Teddee) E. Calder. Mr. Calder was educated at Southampton College of Long Island University, obtaining a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1971. He is survived by his life-time companion, Jack ''Chip'' Tharp, his parents, and sisters, Debra Calder Brandt, and Kim Cordero, and his niece and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 16, 10:30 am at St. Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Ave., at 66 St., in Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to Puppies Behind Bars, an organization where prisoners train dogs to become guide dogs for the blind, 99 Madison Avenue, 2nd Floor, NY, NY 10016.

title: The Nation; The Need to Test Evidence
description: IN the wake of Sept. 11, circumstantial evidence is being widely used -- and misused -- across America. The Federal Bureau of Investigation has put hundreds of young, mostly Muslim men under dragnet surveillance in a search for Al Qaeda operatives, resulting in a series if indictments in upstate New York, Seattle, Detroit and, most recently, Portland, Ore. But might this aggressive use of circumstantial evidence run the risk of mistaken identity? Consider the following examples.

title: Polygamy Jolts Campaign for Governor
description: As if a staggering budget deficit and troubled educational system were not enough campaign fodder for Arizona's leading candidates for governor, this week they found a new issue. Rather, it found them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, PHYLLIS
description: GORDON-Phyllis. It is with deepest sadness that we acknowlege the death of Phyllis Gordon mother of our student Remy and Jeffrei. Phyllis was a devoted and loving mother and valued member of our community. Our hearts go out to Phyllis' family and we extend the condolences of our students, teachers and parents. May the memory of the righteous be a blessing. The Solomon Schechter School of Westchester M. Mac Schwebel Chairman, Board of Trustees James M. Dubin Vice Chairman, Board of Trustees Dr. Elliot Spiegel Headmaster Rabbi Shira Leibowitz Principal, Lower School

title: Common Talk
description: With an election only three weeks away, there may be no better way to be heard above the din of war preparations than with a populist rallying cry. The United States has the most unequal distribution of wealth in the Western world. In a recent book, ''Wealth and Democracy,'' Kevin Phillips argues that America is now approaching the historic levels of inequality reached before the adoption of the federal income tax in 1913, when the top 1 percent of citizens owned more than half the nation's wealth. (The figure is now 40 percent.) And the 10-year, $1.35 trillion tax cut passed by the Bush administration will transfer more wealth to the top 1 percent than virtually any act of fiscal policy in history. Yet as we approach the midterm election, inequality is a nonissue.

title: Sexed Ed
description: If we're going to choose schools for our children on the basis of fuzzy evidence, here's my piece of lint: keep boys and girls together in elementary school -- socialization patterns between the sexes are set there -- and separate them in high school. As a graduate of an all-girl high school and a former teacher in a coeducational high school where the pheromones leaked through the cinder blocks, I am convinced that readiness for the world of choices is best cultivated in same-sex high schools.

title: Isn't that Special
description: Don't call me quaint.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Office Vacancies Continue in Rise in Parsippany
description: THE commercial real estate market in New Jersey continues to ''reach for new depths,'' according to Cushman & Wakefield's third-quarter report, and Parsippany is a perfect example of some unfortunate trends. On the other hand, this city -- northern New Jersey's third-largest submarket -- exhibits qualities that experts say position it well for a rebound, including excellent highway access, diverse kinds of commercial space and no overbuilding.

title: A New Best Friend
description: YOU never forget your first kiss. But as close as people are to their cellphones -- kissing distance -- they forget the first call received on their cells. I remember mine because it was so recent. Using a cellphone was easy for me to resist, for a long time, even after my car broke down on the Taconic State Parkway, when a phone would have saved me serious stress.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: WHEN a pretty ingenue who has just arrived in Los Angeles and a mysterious amnesia victim have their first lesbian encounter in MULHOLLAND DRIVE (2001), the wide-eyed ingenue (Naomi Watts) asks the other woman, ''Have you ever done this before?'' The amnesiac (Laura Elena Harring) answers, logically, ''I don't know.'' Some of David Lynch's fans had given up on him after the opaque ''Lost Highway'' (1997). But then came ''The Straight Story'' (1999) and then this piece of dreamlike brilliance, which was a hit at the Cannes International Film Festival. Ann Miller plays the landlady, and Justin Theroux a director who knows how to get even with a cheating wife. Nothing is what it seems (in Hollwyood, it never is), and the film contains the funniest accidential homicide since John Travolta's gun went off in the car in ''Pulp Fiction'' - Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:45 a.m. on Starz.

title: Anxiety Rises as Officials Link 8th Killing to Sniper
description: Stymied police were out in force across the Washington region today as a fear-tinged weekend dawned with confirmation that the roving suburban sniper had killed his eighth victim.

title: Almost Mainstream But Still Extreme
description: BILLED as ''the Olympics of action sports,'' the Gravity Games entered its fourth year this summer - and the taped coverage of the games, which began last week on NBC, will continue through Nov. 16 in 90-minute segments shown Sundays at 4:30 p.m., with a final, two-hour segment on NOv. 24 from 1 to 3 p.m.

title: It Must Be Picture Day
description: WENDY CROWELL knelt in front of a small girl with a nimbus of ringlets, gently combed stray tendrils into place, and guided her back into the line of other well-scrubbed, dressed-up children here at the Bedford Hills Elementary School.

title: Anastasia Cavanagh, John Coleman III
description: Anastasia Cavanagh, a daughter of Anne E. Cavanagh and Dr. James J. Cavanagh of Point Lookout, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Aloysius Coleman III, the son of Joan Coleman of New York and the late Mr. Coleman Jr. The Rev. Mark Stephen Massa, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; KUWAIT KILLING
description: A U. S. marine was killed and another was wounded after two Kuwaiti gunmen sneaked into a military training exercise on Failaka Island in the Persian Gulf. American officials called the shooting a terrorist act. Pentagon officials said the gunmen, who were shot dead, may have trained in Afghanistan at Al Qaeda camps. Eric Schmitt

title: Demonstrating the Power of a Positive Hattitude
description: THE semiotics of hats can go over one's head. A piece of textile with a brim, for many people, is simply a fashion accessory with a certain retro panache. But ''Crowns,'' a play with music and dance that begins performances on Tuesday at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., demonstrates that a hat can be more: an expression of faith, a symbol of triumph in adversity and a testimonial to African-American history and culture.

title: The Shock of the Familiar: New Jaguar Looks Like Old Ones
description: THE next-generation Jaguar XJ8 is likely to draw double-takes when it reaches American showrooms next spring. The new model, which made its public debut at the Paris auto show last month, is scarcely distinguishable from the current car -- itself a clear descendant of the original XJ6 of 1968.

title: The Sunshine Warrior
description: How far should we trust Paul Wolfowitz's judgment on Iraq? Allow me to offer a small footnote to Bill Keller's article. On my way out to take charge of the United States Embassy in Ethiopia in the spring of 1982, I stopped by to see Wolfowitz, then head of the State Department's office of policy planning. Wolfowitz delivered a stern lecture on the critical importance of Somalia to the United States position in the Persian Gulf and more broadly in the Middle East. During the decade of the 1980's, we poured hundreds of millions of dollars into Somalia, built military facilities there and armed Mohammed Siad Barre's forces, only to see it all collapse into bloody chaos without ever having derived strategic advantage from our investment there -- and at substantial later cost in lives, American as well as Somali.

title: The World; Incoming
description: An asteroid that entered the Earth's atmosphere last June and exploded with a burst of energy comparable to the first atomic bomb over Hiroshima could have set off a nuclear war between Pakistan and India .

title: NO BOARDWALK SMOKING BAN
description: The Ocean City City Council reversed its opinion and voted last week not to ban smoking on its Boardwalk. The ban had been proposed after it had been found that cigarette butts had started two fires on the Boardwalk this summer, one of which destroyed two businesses. The proposed legislation would have banned all smoking on the two-and-a-half-mile Boardwalk and the adjacent Music Pier. After a majority of the seven-member Council had supported the ban, it reconsidered and decided instead to better enforce litter laws. Robert Strauss

title: Campaign Season; Debut Outshines Preview of Texas Democrat
description: The first televised debate in the Texas governor's race was held on Wednesday night, and much was at stake for the Democratic candidate, Tony Sanchez. Mr. Sanchez is a businessman who has spent more than $53 million of his own money in his race against Gov. Rick Perry, a Republican.

title: The Angels Are Drawing Closer to a Surprising Destination
description: Bud Black wanted his pitchers to remember something when he gathered them together before the American League Championship Series. Black, the Anaheim Angels' pitching coach, did not like what he had seen in their division series against the Yankees. But the Angels had won, and that is what mattered now.

title: BackTalk; A Journey With Wilt Chamberlain Through Sport and Life
description: Wilt Chamberlain died three years ago yesterday as something of a joke of his own making. His boast of having slept with 20,000 women led wags to crack that it explained what the Big Dipper was doing when he should have been practicing his woeful foul shooting. The statistic obscured his 100-point game and his 23,924 rebounds, both records.

title: When a Democracy Weighs War
description: To the Editor:

title: Independent Directors, Whatever They Are
description: Portfolio managers and analysts at financial institutions say a majority of a company's directors should be independent, but they don't agree on how to ensure that independence, a survey has found.

title: On the Seas Again, Guided By a Star
description: RUSSELL CROWE peeled off his British naval tunic, slipped a pack of cigarettes into his pocket and pulled himself onto the thick rigging running up the starboard side of the H.M.S. Surprise. ''You want to go up?'' he asked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, SIDNEY
description: SOLOMON-Sidney. October 9, 2002 after 91 years. Survived by his wife, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and countless students and friends.

title: Views of New York, in Moorestown
description: IN the 1830's, New York City was already seen as ''a frisky young giantess, bustling with energy.'' The metropolis became the city of cities. On Sept. 11, 2001, this American icon was wounded, but New York demonstrated extraordinary bravery, compassion, and resilience.

title: Taking on Tolstoy
description: To the Editor:

title: New Roles, Old Stereotypes
description: IN the late 1940's, when Lea Serra was a 6-year-old living on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, a child actress on a popular Italian-language radio soap opera got sick. Ms. Serra was a native New Yorker, but she had learned fluent Italian from her parents, and she was asked to fill in. Her debut was a success, and soon she joined the Italian Actors Union, an organization founded in 1937 to support performers for New York's Italian-language theater and radio audiences.

title: Performance Art In and Out of the Classroom
description: THE old rule in creative writing is tell what you know, mine your past for material. But mavericks say just the opposite -- sever all links to the past and leap into the void. Lenora Champagne, a playwright, performance artist and teacher, has made a career balancing between both camps. While the most personal questions inform her work, her career itself could not be farther from Ms. Champagne's hometown roots in Port Barre, La., population 2,000.

title: All That Rain Breaks a Record, And Begins to Fray Tempers
description: The rain that began on Thursday and extended through the weekend matched a record on Friday, with 3.06 inches. The last time it rained so much on Oct. 11 was in 1871.

title: Honolulu
description: Gidget, Elvis and surfboards made Honolulu famous. But an art explosion is about to make it a cultural playground, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSOVA, ZARA
description: NELSOVA-Zara. It is with profound sorrow the Violoncello Society of New York mourns the loss of our esteemed President, distinguished soloist and teacher. She was an inspiration to our musical world.

title: Cara Aidone, John Huzinec
description: Cara Marie Aidone, the daughter of Barbara and Clement Aidone of Irvington, N.Y., is to be married there today to Capt. John Milton Huzinec, a son of Carolyn and George Huzinec, also of Irvington. The Rev. Raymond J. Byrne will perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception.

title: Madden Accepts Role as Defensive Center
description: Afew years ago, John Madden saw himself as the Devils' next great scorer, a center whose worth would be counted in goals and assists, a regular on the power play.

title: Pope vs. Parents in a Struggle for a Child and His Soul
description: MILITARY agents of a volatile theocracy make a late-night raid on a private home, kidnapping a young boy with the intention of converting him to the state religion. His mother faints. His father tries to reclaim the child, but the parents are told that the only way to get their son back is to renounce their faith. They refuse, and the family is never reunited, sparking an international scandal that contributes to the fall of the government.

title: A World to the Wise
description: Looming over Savannah's East Taylor Street from the veined pink marble steps of his 1869 Second Empire town house, the 6-foot-7 map dealer, shopkeeper and unofficial town historian John Duncan scratches his Confederate-era white beard, shrugs the midafternoon drizzle from his seersuckered shoulders and glances around Monterey Square, canopied by live oaks heavy with Spanish moss.

title: WHAT THEY'RE READING
description: Eric W. Bonabeau, 35

title: Amy Handler, Philip Oppenheim
description: Amy Elisabeth Handler, a cartoon developer in Atlanta, and Philip Everett Oppenheim, a cable television executive in Atlanta, are to be married today. Rabbi Joshua C. Lesser will officiate at the Trolley Barn, a catering hall in Atlanta.

title: Catches by Resurgent Battle Give Irish a Lift
description: It has long been said that Arnaz Battle has the best hands at Notre Dame, but they were expected to build his reputation as a quarterback, not a receiver.

title: A Chinese Transplant With Flowers of Ivory
description: EVERY morning, Kevin Esteban and Bob Siciliano have coffee in their tiny Upper West Side garden, under the fragrant white flowers of their seven-son flower tree (Heptacodium miconioides). Their voices are hushed, reverent. This is their morning worship service.

title: A Chinese Transplant With Flowers of Ivory
description: EVERY morning, Kevin Esteban and Bob Siciliano have coffee in their tiny Upper West Side garden, under the fragrant white flowers of their seven-son flower tree (Heptacodium miconioides). Their voices are hushed, reverent. This is their morning worship service.

title: Christiane Ebsworth, Mark Ladd
description: Christiane Suzanne Ebsworth and Mark Jasper Ladd were married yesterday by Msgr. Kenneth Velo at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago.

title: Dinner Is in the Details
description: ''THESE are all my best friends,'' Paige Peterson said of the eight people expected for dinner. She describes herself as a single mother, a painter, an interior designer, a book illustrator and a party-giver. She is also a former actress (on ''The Edge of Night'') and is comfortably divorced.

title: Anderson Helps Angels Maintain Stoic Front
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: When a Democracy Weighs War
description: To the Editor:

title: Serbia's Runoff Candidates Fight Voter Apathy
description: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 12  Serbia will vote on Sunday for a new president, faced with a choice between rival reformers who united to topple Slobodan Milosevic  one a conservative nationalist, the other a pro-Western liberal.

title: The Ballpark of Memory
description: EVERY month they gather on the Upper West Side, and no matter what the season, the subject is always the same: baseball.

title: Before Baby's First Step, Driving Shoes
description: The new babies' crib shoes from Tod's are a miniature version of the company's classic driving moccasins, right down to the pebbles on the soles. In blue, pink, white, yellow and purple, the hand-stitched booties were originally made as a baby gift for Madonna; the ensuing demand inspired Tod's to sell them in stores. Liz Hurley and Kelly Preston are among the mothers who were unable to walk away without a pair.

title: Hellman vs. McCarthy
description: To the Editor:

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; TERROR ON TANKER
description: The French government said that an explosion on a French tanker, the Limburg, off the coast of Yemen, was probably caused by a terrorist attack. One crew member was killed and 12 others injured.

title: Living in a Sniper's Shadow With Defiance and Fatalism
description: As the sun peeped out over the rain-slicked pavement today, people across this sniper-wary region found themselves unwittingly hopscotching through a series of mental calculations in going on about their day.

title: Cleveland Fans Say Their Piece, Couch Says His
description: A bizarre situation unfolded in Cleveland last week, but that has been the climate surrounding the Browns since their return in 1999.

title: Huntington Bookstore As Celebrity Magnet
description: THEY started lining up three hours before the actress Julie Andrews Edwards, and her daughter, Emma Walton Hamilton, were scheduled to appear at the Book Revue, a bookstore in Huntington. The line stretched to the corner of New York Avenue and down Main Street. Little old ladies, some clutching worn albums from ''The Sound of Music'' and ''Mary Poppins,'' and families with small children in tow, all holding bags with newly purchased copies of the two women's latest children's book, ''Dumpy and the Big Storm.''

title: Raising Paolo
description: BORN TWICE

title: Campaign Season; Amusing or Tasteless Bush Bashing?
description: The Democratic National Committee and its Republican detractors are fighting over a fund-raising appeal posted on the Democrat's Web site. The cartoon video depicts President Bush saying ''trust me'' as he shoves two people in wheelchairs over a jagged downward slope signifying the declining stock market. A narrator warns that Mr. Bush's proposal to allow private investment of retirement money could threaten Social Security.

title: The French Spar Over Sex: There's a Limit, No?
description: Suddenly, France is seized with whether to wage war not against Iraq, but against sex.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions today in Home Design, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about the Los Angeles home of Cameron Silver and Jeffrey Snyder, misidentify the designers of five chairs. The wood chair on Page 97 was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, not Rudolph M. Schindler. The designer of the set of four stacking chairs on Page 98 is unidentified.

title: Judith Hecker, Matthew Furman
description: Judith Bryna Hecker, a museum curator, and Matthew Scott Furman, a lawyer, are to be married today in Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Alice R. Dubinsky, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate at Bernard's Inn at Ridgefield.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; U. S. TERROR UPDATE
description: The Senate and the House gave President Bush the authority to use force against Iraq. But divisions ran deep among Democrats. While the party's presidential hopefuls supported Mr. Bush, their vote separated them from the rank-and-file majority of the party in the House.

title: Divine Cheat
description: We recently discovered that the senior pastor at our large parish has never written his own sermons, a requirement of his job. He has been taking them from Web sites and preaching them word for word. He then has them printed up and handed out under his name. Is this man to be trusted with a congregation? What is your opinion of this? Ruth Klarner, Mableton, Ga.

title: Elizabeth Wagley, Joe Conason
description: Elizabeth Horan Wagley, a fund-raising consultant to nonprofit organizations, and Joe Conason, a columnist and political reporter, were married yesterday in Nantucket, Mass., at the home of Ann Gund and Graham Gund, an aunt and uncle of the bride. The Rev. Dr. Tim W. Jensen, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: October 6 - 12
description: U. S. TERROR UPDATE The Senate and the House gave President Bush the authority to use force against Iraq. But divisions ran deep among Democrats. While the party's presidential hopefuls supported Mr. Bush, their vote separated them from the rank-and-file majority of the party in the House.

title: 'Family Matters'
description: ASPLASH OF LIGHT from the late-afternoon sun lingered at the foot of Nariman's bed as he ended his nap and looked towards the clock. It was almost six. He glanced down where the warm patch had lured his toes. Knurled and twisted, rendered birdlike by age, they luxuriated in the sun's comfort. His eyes fell shut again.

title: Sarah Fels and George Steel
description: AS burgeoning student musicians at the schools of the Washington National Cathedral, George Robert Steel and Sarah Brook Fels were separated by mere yards and three grades, but never met.

title: Deconstructing The Bing
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Radio That Breaks His Heart
description: ROCK musicians make a show of defying authority, but rare are the ones who vent any misgivings about the radio stations that can turn their songs into hits. Elvis Costello did it with ''Radio, Radio,'' and on Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers' new album, ''The Last D J'' (Warner Brothers), Mr. Petty bemoans big media with the album's title song, a tribute to ''the last DJ who plays what he wants to play.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEWIS, ARTHUR E. JR.
description: LEWIS-Arthur E. Jr. Jan 4, 1933 to Oct 13, 2001 Always in my heart, Laur

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEBAN, MILTON
description: KLEBAN-Milton. In loving remembrance of his 100th birthday, October 12.

title: Satire, Set to Music
description: HAVE you ever worn an atrocious seafoam meringue of a bridesmaid's dress? Were cheerleaders the bane of your adolescence? Do your measurements leave you with feelings of dismay? If so, Deirdre Flint has a song for you.

title: Bob Crane
description: If you don't receive thousands of responses to Lynn Hirschberg's article on Bob Crane (Sept. 29), I'll be sorely surprised. Not only did this dysfunctional father show videos of himself engaging in group sex to his children, the children (now grown) are so confused that their value systems are twisted eight ways from Sunday. Whew! The older son says he feels he's O.K. because he was paid the $20,000 as consultant on a movie that obsesses about his father's dark side, and the other son, well, to quote the older son, ''Get a job.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GELLMAN, ARCHIE
description: GELLMAN-Archie. October 11th, 1960. Beloved father, eternally missed. Gloria and Howard

title: Pursuing Both Fish And Birds in Fall
description: Offering some of the best angling of the year as well as the start of upland bird and waterfowl seasons, fall in the Northeast is often more than one who both hunts and fishes can successfully embrace.

title: New York's Homeless, Back Out in the Open
description: During his routine of supervising the McDonald's in Pennsylvania Station each day, Julio Velandia, the assistant manager, says he sees more homeless people than he did a year ago. ''Those kind of people bother the customers,'' he said, ''and they have a bad smell.''

title: More Than a Conspiracy Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: What Is A European
description: In 1948 at the Congress of Europe, Winston Churchill said, ''We hope to see a Europe where men of every country will think of being a European as of belonging to their native land, and . . . wherever they go in this wide domain . . . will truly feel 'Here I am at home.''' The exiled diplomat Salvador de Madariaga said: ''This Europe must be born. And she will, when Spaniards say 'our Chartres,' Englishmen 'our Cracow,' Italians 'our Copenhagen,' when Germans say 'our Bruges.' . . . Then will Europe live. For then it will be that the spirit that leads history will have uttered the creative words: fiat Europa.''

title: Corrections
description: The byline on an article last Sunday about Gail Hilson, a prominent society figure who is the Republican Party candidate for State Assembly in the 73rd District in Manhattan, misspelled the writer's surname. She is Nancy Hass, not Haas.

title: Afterglow: A Last Conversation With Pauline Kael
description: By Francis Davis

title: INVESTING WITH/Julie M. Van Cleave; Mason Street Growth Stock Fund
description: PICKING stocks is a lot like competitive swimming, says Julie M. Van Cleave, who runs the $55 million Mason Street Growth Stock fund.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bringing Back the Jump

title: Bonfire of the Vanities
description: EXTRAVAGANCE

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Letters
description: The case made by Paul Wolfowitz for war with Iraq failed to sway readers, who did not share his confidence that toppling Saddam would improve prospects in the Middle East. Portfolio was a big hit, though readers wondered why only the girls got naked.

title: The Month for Beer
description: In this month of Oktoberfests it's time to focus on beer. Here are places with strong lists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSDEN, KLEINHANS, ELI ZABETH (BETTY)
description: COSDEN - KLEINHANS - Eli zabeth (Betty). (Nee Elizabeth J. Easton). Of Darien, CT on October 4, 2002. Mother of Edward D. Cosden, Jr. Wife of the late Edward D. Cosden and Richard Kleinhans. Sister of the late Elwood M. Easton, Jr. Grandmother of two. Memorial service will be held on October 21, 2002 at 11:00 AM in the Chapel of Noroton Presbyterian Church, 2011 Post Road, Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, CT 06820; AmeriCares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT. 06840 or Voluntary Services for the Blind of Fairfield County, 945 Summer Street, Stamford, CT. 06905.

title: The World: At the Brink, Then and Now; The Missiles of 1962 Haunt the Iraq Debate
description: FOR 13 days starting Oct. 16, 1962, ''the world stood like a playing card on edge,'' as Norman Mailer put it, while President Kennedy and his closest aides faced down the threat of Soviet missiles in Cuba. Forty years later, Washington and the world are again on the brink, and debates about the lessons of that long-ago October are as fresh as the morning headlines.

title: Sculpture of Sound In a Downtown Space
description: THE composer Laurie Anderson ran into her brother Chris Anderson, an investment specialist, on a recent visit to the Winter Garden. She was there to appraise the space for her contribution to ''Sonic Garden,'' a sound installation by four artists commissioned by the World Financial Center Arts and Events Program and the public-arts presenter Creative Time.

title: Antiwar Stance Proves Popular in Iowa Race
description: It ought to be dangerous for a Republican congressman in a competitive election to break with his president and vote against a resolution authorizing the use of force against Iraq. That, at least, is what the conventional wisdom in Washington would hold.

title: Another Legal Path For Investor Complaints
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Day Of Debating Over Debates
description: Seeking as much time in public view as he can squeeze into 24 more campaign days, Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican Senate candidate in New Jersey, tried today to goad his Democratic opponent, former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, into debating him, going so far as to say that he would accept a format including the four minor-party candidates.

title: Vernica Ruiz, J. J. Sutherland
description: Vernica Mara Ruiz Contreras, the daughter of Nydia and Rafael Ruiz of Brooklyn, was married on Friday to Jeffrey Victor Sutherland Jr., a son of the Rev. Arline Conan Sutherland and Dr. Sutherland of Somerville, Mass. The Rev. Robert Lawsine officiated at St. Saviour's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DYM, JEAN C.
description: DYM-Jean C. October 11, 2002. Devoted wife of the late Elias (Al). Cherished mother of Carol Abrams and Marcia Yatter. Adored grandmother of Carise and Douglas Yatter. Beloved mother-in-law of Ron Yatter. Loving aunt to Leonard Romm. Her warmth, humor and practical insights will be deeply missed.

title: Living Large; Atomic Weight: We Gain, But What Loses?
description: IT is the most rigid of cosmic laws: there is no free lunch. In the sense understood by physicists and chemists, it means that matter and energy can never be created or destroyed, and if they turn up in one place, they must be taken away from another.

title: Musical Colloquies With Muted Politics
description: Daniel Barenboim, a citizen of Chicago and Berlin, is also a citizen of the world, and surely of New York these days. He recently opened the Carnegie Hall season as both conductor and pianist with the Chicago Symphony. He seems to have graduated from his former Perspectives series at Carnegie to an emeritus presence, collaborating with various singers in Wolf songs tomorrow and in February, and closing the season in June with all the Beethoven piano sonatas.

title: Swinging With the Masters
description: DON BRADEN, a tenor and soprano saxophonist, flutist, composer and arranger, leads professional jazz bands at Manhattan clubs and international festivals. He also cues beginners -- groups that cannot find the end of a song, or whose drummer decides to take an unorthodox solo in the leadoff spot.

title: Living Large; Our Just (Burp!) Desserts
description: IN the fast-food industry, cleanliness may be next to godliness, but portion control is not far behind. To maintain financial health, a restaurant has to know precisely how much food it is giving to each customer. So McDonald's chicken nuggets, for example, are bits of meat, pressed and formed into shapes of standard weight, rather than actual pieces of chicken. Left alone, nature is just too variable for the bottom line.

title: Spano Turns to TV Ads to Push Tax Plan
description: ANNOUNCING tax hikes can be rough on a politician's image. So, when Westchester County Executive Andrew J. Spano recently announced a projected 31.7 percent increase in county property taxes for next year, both Democrat and Republican politicos began scrambling to make the most of the situation.

title: Emma Pilkington, Todd Goergen
description: Emma Jane Pilkington, a daughter of Carolyn C. Pilkington of New York and Alan R. Pilkington of Redstone, Colo., was married yesterday to Todd Andrew Goergen, a son of Pamela M. Goergen and Robert B. Goergen of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Jeffrey Walker performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Michael Moynihan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: A Bit of Brooklyn In Larchmont
description: With its carefully orchestrated collection of vintage-looking women's and children's clothing, vintage tablecloths and other linens, new pillows and baby blankets made from vintage fabrics, original jewelry and the like, the newly opened Avenue P store in Larchmont evokes the kind of eclectic shop that flourished for years deep in the heart of Brooklyn.

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; NO TRUTH TO TELL
description: Lie detectors lie, a panel of scientists said in a government report on security screening. The panel said polygraphs did a poor job of identifying spies and were likely to produce many false accusations. Federal officials said they were studying the 245-page report, by experts convened by the National Research Council, an arm of the National Academy of Sciences. Private experts said the report was most likely to affect federal agencies, which use polygraphs tens of thousands of times a year to screen prospective and current employees for espionage. William J. Broad

title: Envisioning a New Jersey Triangle
description: IN 1861, on the way to his inauguration, Abraham Lincoln addressed the New Jersey State Senate and spoke about the spirit of Trenton. He was referring to the Battle of Trenton, the turning point of the Revolutionary War -- an event that had burned itself into his consciousness when he was a boy.

title: Shoreham Steps Back From the Brink
description: THIS was the village that had everything: sweeping vistas from the bluffs above Long Island Sound, an out-of-the way location to reduce development pressure, even a resident fairy godmother.

title: Festival's Highlights Tinged With Unease
description: FOLLOWING on the heels of better-known events in Toronto, Telluride, Colo., and New York, the Hamptons International Film Festival, now in its 10th year, has always had a hard time snagging splashy premieres or grabbing headlines. With the debut in May of the heavily publicized TriBeCa film festival, the competition for intriguing discoveries has become even more intense.

title: INTERNATIONAL: October 6-12; ATTACK AND RESPONSE
description: Israeli forces killed 17 Palestinians in a raid into Khan Younis in the Gaza Strip. Israel said the attack was part of a new strategy to put pressure on Hamas, but it brought sharp international criticism, including a rebuke from the State Department. Hamas swore retaliation, and a suicide bomber tried unsuccessfully to board a bus outside Tel Aviv. He still blew himself up, killing a 71-year-old woman. James Bennet

title: 'Sandy Koufax'
description: Three decades after he threw his last pitch, Sandy Koufax was back in uniform at Dodgertown, a rare occurrence given his belief that baseball uniforms do not flatter those of a certain age. This is where he made his debut in the spring of 1955 and Vero Beach is where he has chosen to make his after-baseball home - an odd choice for a man said not to like the game and the attention it brings him. Mornings when he's in town, he works out in the training room. The clubhouse guys gave him a key. He brings the bagels.

title: I Like Me, I Really Like Me
description: BLUE SHOE

title: Italian Red With a Ph.D.
description: Remo Farina's 2000 Valpolicella classico superiore ripasso is to a trattoria's carafe Valpolicella as a Ph.D. is to a grammar school diploma. Farina's version -- elegant, deep, firm, ageable for years -- is what savvy diners from Verona find at smart Lake Garda restaurants. For $14, this fruity, appetite-sharpening red is an outstanding buy at Best Cellars, 1291 Lexington Avenue (87th Street). HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: T.C.N.J. Offended Trenton By Changing Its Name
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Democracy Weighs War
description: To the Editor:

title: Smallpox Plan Delays
description: A White House debate over the scope of a smallpox vaccination program has resulted in confusion and indecision, participants say, with some, including President Bush, disturbed about the vaccine's risks.

title: Kinder and Gentler, but Still Rudy
description: LEADERSHIP

title: Menacing Pitches In the Line of Fire
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSAEL, BERNARD
description: ASSAEL-Bernard. On October 10, 2002. Beloved husband of Diana. Devoted father of Ivan, Stacey and Yianni, and Dawn. Adored Pa Bernie to Bryan and Ian and adored Grandpa to Kristina and Brandon. We will never forget your warm smile, gentle touch, and most of all your love. You will always be in our hearts. Rest in peace.

title: RUMSFELD ORDERS WAR PLANS REDONE FOR FASTER ACTION
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he had ordered the military's regional commanders to rewrite all of their war plans to capitalize on precision weapons, better intelligence and speedier deployment. That way, he said, the military could begin combat operations on less notice and with far fewer troops than thought possible -- or even wise -- before the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Slowdown on U.S. Visas Stalls Business, Science And Personal Travel Plans
description: A global slowdown in the issuing of American visas to foreigners is disrupting lives in the United States and abroad. It is interfering with scientific research and business deals, forcing some people to postpone medical treatment and weddings and stranding others away from their homelands, say government officials and advocates for immigrants.

title: Michelle Hsu, Leo Chang
description: Michelle Diane Hsu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas K. Hsu of Los Angeles, was married on Friday to Leo Shang-hua Chang, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Wey-tyng Chang of Holmdel, N.J. The Rev. Carl Hansen performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Carmel, Calif.
