title: Lawyer Seeks Exoneration Of 5 Convicted In Jogger Case
description: The lawyer and a sister of one of the five Harlem teenagers convicted in the 1989 attack on a jogger in Central Park said yesterday that the apparent willingness of Manhattan prosecutors to vacate the convictions on a legal technicality is not enough. They said they want the young men to be declared innocent.

title: Phony Science
description: Q: Within 24 hours, you, a theoretical physicist, won your MacArthur grant and a panel of experts announced that another physicist, J. Hendrik Schn, had committed fraud at Bell Labs. Do you see any cosmic connection between the two events?

title: Ruby Kam, William Woo
description: Ruby Ying Kam, the daughter of Shuet Fong Kam and Hon Kwong Kam of Burlington, Mass., was married yesterday to William Cheung Woo, the son of Dr. Wanho Cheung Woo of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., and the late Se Hyung Woo. Sue A. Anderson, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: U.S. Eases Way for West to Control Big Volumes of Water
description: The Bush administration has opened the way for Western states to gain control over enormous volumes of water previously claimed by the federal government. That would shift the balance in a long battle over control of a scarce resource.

title: Private Sector; From Merrill, Canine Appeal
description: Merrill Lynch has gone to the dogs. No, that's not a reference to government inquiries into possible conflicts of interest by analysts or dealings with Enron.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
description: This

title: Court Rules That Lawyers May Keep Clergy Off Juries
description: A Florida appeals court has ruled that clergy members may be excluded from juries because they tend to be too sympathetic to criminal defendants, a decision that legal experts say raises questions about the role of religious belief in the justice system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERMELIS, FRANCOIS GEORGE
description: KERMELIS - Francois George. Died unexpectedly on Wednesday October 9th at New York United Hospital Medical Center in Port Chester, New York. He was 55 years old. Francois George was of Greek descent and immigrated to the United States in 1968, receiving his United States citizenship in 1993. He graduated from high school and college with high honors, obtaining a degree in Mechanical Engineering as the Valedictorian of his class. Although trained as a Mechanical Engineer, Francois George made his mark in society as an entrepreneur and successful businessman. He was fluent in eight languages and at home on any continent. He has been a resident of Rye, New York since 1978. Francois George loved to be surrounded by his family and friends. A kind and gentle man, he took pleasure in entertaining at his home in Rye or at his home in the Hamptons. He loved the ocean, whether being on his boat or taking long walks along the beach. Francois George is survived by his wife of 31 years Minna Margaretha, Demitri and Erica, Ina, Christian and Carmen, Sophia, Francoise and Dimitri, other family members and countless dear friends. His son Christian who passed away on October 9, 1999 predeceases him. Visitation will be held on Saturday October 19, 2002 (5:00 to 9:00 PM) at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, New York, 10543 (914) 698-5968. Funeral service is Sunday October 20, 2002 (2:00 PM) at Rye Presbyterian Church, Rye, New York, 10580 (914) 967-0842. Burial will be private. The family would appreciate contributions made to ''The Christian Kermelis Knaust Scholarship Foundation,'' to benefit college athletes in financial need. Contributions can be forwarded in care of Christian Knaust, 115 Central Park West, Apt 28EF, New York, New York 10023.

title: The World; In France, Glory Meets Fear
description: LAST week, French viewers were mesmerized by the most expensive production in their nation's television history, a $40 million series about Napoleon. One Paris tabloid ran man-on-the-street interviews that posed the question, ''What inspires this universal infatuation with Bonaparte?''

title: Executive Life: The Boss; Forget the Uniform
description: I GREW up in the central district of Seattle. It was all-American; we played kickball in the street. But we weren't wealthy, and everything was a hustle. I think that's why I'm successful; I learned early how to get people to do things for me.

title: INTERNATIONAL: October 6-12; JUST SHY OF VICTORY
description: In Brazil's presidential election, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the left-wing Workers' Party won 46.4 percent of the vote, but failed to get the majority he needed to become the country's first working-class president. Mr. da Silva, a former farm laborer and factory worker, is the favorite in an Oct. 27 runoff against Jos Serra of the centrist Social Democratic Party. Larry Rohter

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Film Openings and Film Series Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Business; Marriott's Baroque Finances Draw Complaints
description: LIKE unwanted guests who persist in returning, awkward questions about the true strength of earnings at Marriott International, the giant hotel-management company, keep popping up.

title: A Setting a Hobbit Would Find Homey
description: TUCKED into an earthen bank on a pastoral stretch of Old Route 22, the cellar restaurant at the Old Drovers Inn works hard to preserve a quirky charm. Frette linens, glittering glassware and a wood-burning hearth play counterpoint to low ceilings, tiny paned windows and dim recesses. With its pewter mugs and red brocade draperies, the place is a dead ringer for a hobbit hole.

title: 'Tenderness of Spirit'
description: To the Editor:

title: Fordham Gets a Handle on the Ball and on Brown
description: Brown's passing attack was a dud and Fordham receiver Javarus Dudley was not having an easy time either. Kevin Eakin had thrown two perfect strikes to Dudley in the end zone, and Dudley dropped both of them.

title: SMART GUNS
description: A bill requiring handguns to be sold with increased safety measures passed the State Senate 29 to 3 last week. Lawmakers said that so-called smart gun technology would help make guns childproof and allow only their owners to fire them. The bill specifies that all handguns sold in New Jersey carry the safety measures starting three years after the technology is perfected. It is scheduled for review by an State Assembly committee this month. Jeremy Pearce

title: At a Yale Gallery, Furniture to Learn By
description: FURNITURE groupies, antiques collectors, dealers, writers and scholars who obsess about American household objects made from 1650 to 1950 dote on a Yale University art gallery resource called ''the furniture study.'' This 10,000-square-foot space in New Haven is filled with chests, tables, chairs, desks, clocks, sideboards and looking glasses. There are about a thousand objects in all, most of them American.

title: Our Towns; Chanting 'No, We Won't Go' . . . to War or to This Drugstore
description: ''WE shouldn't picket until 6 o'clock,'' Toby Heilbrunn said Thursday afternoon, cutting short the daily demonstration at the locally loathed CVS drugstore. ''We should conserve our energy for tonight.''

title: 'Extravagance'
description: In September of the year 169-, I, William Tobias Merrick-twenty years old and possessed of more sense and education than prospects-was sent from my father's house at Exeter to live with my bachelor uncle, a prominent wine merchant of Wapping, near London. It was thought that I, being the fourth son in a family whose brickworks would only comfortably support three, might learn something there of the shipping trade, my uncle's connexions in this area being quite extensive. Neither my father nor my uncle saw fit to consult me in this matter. Having assumed that any young man should welcome the chance to work amid great seagoing ships, they regarded my opinions as settled beforehand. Thus it never came into their consideration that I disliked the sea above all things, and had once resolved, during an intolerable bark crossing from Cardiff to Portishead some years past, never to set foot on the boards of a ship again.

title: A Debut Is No Laughing Matter
description: BRIDGEPORT is in the throes of a cultural renaissance, we are told.

title: Seeking Equality On Elder Care
description: Re ''Balancing the Budget on the Backs of Elderly,'' Sept. 29: Having seen my aunt's house sold to pay the expense of her nursing home, and having visited patients at A. Holly Paterson and private nursing homes, and having explored insurance for long-term care for myself, I was surprised to learn that some lucky old folks were living at home with round-the-clock health care and that Nassau residents are paying for it.

title: Donna Friedman, Gadi Meir
description: Donna Lauren Friedman and Gadi Eliezer Meir are to be married today by Rabbi Margery Jacobs at Vine Hill House, a private residence in Sebastopol, Calif.

title: Mexico Struggles for the Attentions of a Preoccupied U.S.
description: Mexico wants to talk to the United States about the flood of migrants illegally crossing the Rio Grande. The United States wants to talk about its rights to the river's water.

title: Rehnquist's Law
description: FIRST AMONG EQUALS

title: Gabriela Schwed, Robert Underhill
description: Gabriela Schwed and Robert Underhill were married last evening at Loft Eleven, a party space in New York, where Judge Sidney H. Stein of the United States District Court in New York officiated.

title: Chapel's Memorial Fence
description: To the Editor:

title: BENEFITS
description: Educational Images

title: An Audit Could Tip The Scales On Tyco
description: THE giant accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers is in the midst of its annual audit on Tyco International. What inquiring minds want to know is whether the accountants, who missed some of the recent shenanigans at the company, will go easy on Tyco this year. Or will they try tough love in their audit?

title: Foreseeing a Bloody Siege in Baghdad
description: Advocates of regime change in Iraq have presented an optimistic view of the coming war. Most assert that the Iraqi military will not fight. A dazzling attack by smart weapons and computer viruses will shut down Iraq's military nervous system. Western forces will dash for key military and political centers, cutting the Iraqi military up into isolated fragments. Most troops will surrender; a few diehards will huddle with Saddam Hussein and patiently await their destruction by a second wave of smart bombs.

title: Living for Today, Every Day
description: IN 1962, when I was 11, a neurosurgeon told my parents I had a progressive spinal condition that would kill me before I reached my 20's. My parents' reaction was predictable: they fell apart, then they put on a good face, and then they took me to Disneyland. We must have dashed off at the first opportunity. We didn't just go to Anaheim, but we also went to Chicago, to the Seattle world's fair, to San Francisco, to Las Vegas. It was a huge trip and an extravagant one. We flew everywhere, sometimes first class. We stayed in fancy hotels with doormen and bellhops. We ate at famous restaurants. We even went to nightclubs.

title: Oh, That's Why the Yankees Got Whacked in the Playoffs
description: Forget the curse of the Bambino. This one's the curse of ''The Sopranos.''

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: When you work at a car dealership, you spend a lot of time standing around, but that does not mean you relax. How can you, with the manager constantly hovering over you and the strains of ''We Will Rock You'' or some other sales-meeting anthem ricocheting around your brain? You've got to be on, you've got to be pumped, you've got to be ready to pursue a car that noses into the lot, and then be standing right there, hand extended, when the wary customer steps out. Body language is vital. Philip Reed, a writer who last year posted a diary on the Internet about his stint as a car salesman, described a seminar in which he was taught how to shake hands -- with a ''slight pulling motion'' that represents ''the beginning of your control over the customer.'' Reed observed that the car salesmen he worked with shook hands with one another often, too, practicing for ''Mr. Customer'' and ''staying loose.'' There was also a lot of ''high-fiving, fist-bumping, back-slapping and arm-squeezing'' and during slow periods a lot of ''tie-pulling, wrestling and shadowboxing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINUS, RABBI SETH
description: BINUS-Rabbi Seth. Passed away on September 27, 2002, 21 Tishrei, 5763, Hoshanah Rabah. Loving husband of Deena Binus. Adoring father of Sarah Devora and Shulamis Yaffa. Beloved son of Alixandra Kolbe and Gregory Binus, Peter Kolbe, Gale Binus. Loving son-in-law of Phyllis, James Frank. Devoted brother of Ari Binus and Yoni Binus. Half-brother of Josh. Step-brother of Lisa, Andrew Parker, Andrea Kolbe. Brother-in-law of David, Miriam, Naomi Frank, Malka, Tuvia Stern. Uncle of Oudle, Nachman Stern. Adoring grandson of the late Ruth and Moses Naftalin a'h, and also of Ruth, Henry Binus a'h, Bessie, Joe Frank a'h, Louis, Rose Kanter. He loved Judaism. He loved his family, and we, in turn, loved him. He did more for humanity in his thirty years of life on this Earth than most people do in a longer lifetime. For further information, please contact Deena Binus, C/O Kolbe Associates, POB 610409, Newton Highlands, MA. 02461.

title: Home Design
Linking Cruel To Unusual With an 'And'
description: A measure on the November ballot in Florida seeks, among other things, to change one word of one phrase of the state constitution as it applies to the death penalty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALFIERI, JOHN B.
description: ALFIERI-John B. Our partner for many years, John was a superb professional, a wise counselor and a man of the greatest integrity. But more than that, he was a close, dear, and loyal friend. We mourn him deeply. Alfieri, Frohman & Primoff, LLP

title: Woman Stabbed by Robber
description: A 26-year-old New Jersey woman was stabbed in the chest in the lobby of a friend's East Village apartment building in what the police said yesterday was a robbery.

title: Rock 'n' Real Estate
description: Midway through his July 19 concert at the open-air Jones Beach Theater on Long Island -- which is to say, somewhere between ''Are You Gonna Go My Way'' and ''American Woman'' -- Lenny Kravitz looked out at some 14,000 rain-drenched fans huddled before the Slip 'n Slide-style stage he was clearly having a bit of trouble navigating, and took pity on the wet wretches. So, he leaned into the microphone as if he were going to lick it -- which was not as unsavory as it may sound -- and suggested, in that low, throaty, hey-baby drawl of his, that everyone come back to his place (actually, he may have used the word ''pad'') so they could all dry off and finish up the concert in comfort.

title: Seeing Today's Rome In Ruins of the Past
description: In contemplating the Villa Giulia or the Pantheon, do you long for something more than the cursory guidebook text or the routine tour-guide patter?

title: When a Democracy Weighs War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLIVE, ROBERT
description: CLIVE-Robert. Passed away on October 4, 2002. Bob had a distinguished career as Art Director of Life Magazine, the Best of Life, Time Magazine, the Daily News Magazine and Ogilvy & Mather. During his latter years, he returned to his roots as an artist and sculptor. Survived by Mella, Peter, David (Valerie), Paul, Adam (Melissa) Clive. Grandfather of Sarah and Rachel. Brother of Herb and Lea. Companion of Ellen Kostroff. Donations may be made to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714. Bob was loved by all those whose lives he touched.

title: Breast Cancer Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Too Much Crime Lead to Punishment?
description: PRIME-TIME lineups teeming with cops and criminals are certainly not unusual. ABC still clings to ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.'' Fox recently introduced a flashy, youth-oriented detective series, ''Fastlane.'' And at last check NBC was up to three ''Law and Order'' shows, along with the sophomore series ''Crossing Jordan'' and the new drama ''Boomtown.'' It's rare, however, for a network to go on the sort of crime spree CBS has indulged in this season.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/St. George, Staten Island; Hills and Harbor and a Variety of Housing
description: SARAH POWER was happy living in a Staten Island rental apartment that was high on a hill with lots of light and sweeping views of New York Harbor. And at $750 a month for about 1,000 square feet of space, the price was right.

title: You Can Go Home, And Write About It
description: WHEN Kevin Coyne is sitting in his home office surrounded by walls of novels and history books, you do not immediately notice the similarities between him and Freehold's most famous son, Bruce Springsteen.

title: The View From/Cromwell; Where Florists Bloom And Bouquets Flourish
description: MICHELLE LATANA has worked as a florist for more than a year, but she is only now finding out what the job entails.

title: Ivy Goldberg, Andrew Rosen
description: Dr. Ivy Gale Goldberg, the daughter of Judyth and Michael Goldberg of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Andrew Lawrence Rosen, the son of Carolyn Rosen and Dr. Barrett Rosen of Nashville. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at the 200 Fifth Club in New York.

title: Out of the Ordinary: Art From the Byways
description: THE bust of a saluting Civil War soldier -- it's actually a beehive carved from a hollowed log by an anonymous artist around 1900 -- was found in the 1980's in DeKalb County, Ga. The surface is crazed, or crackled, and the paint -- Union blue over Rebel gray -- is fading. But the hive's entrance, a slot in the soldier's belt buckle, remains intact.

title: When Big Voices Meet Little Songs
description: YOU need to take time with the voice,'' Thomas Quasthoff, the German bass-baritone, said the other day in a friend's apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. ''That's why I started doing these bigger things only about four years ago.''

title: Where The Scallops Still Roam
description: ON any given summer's day, Hallocks Bay will see a few boats pass by and maybe a clammer or two. The fishing is marginal, the beaches are lined with marsh and the bay bottom is an uninviting plain of shells, mud and seaweed.

title: Bonds Splashes Homer, but Cardinals Keep Giants at Bay
description: Somehow, the St. Louis Cardinals had gotten away with their sloppy play. They had knocked out the San Francisco Giants' starter, Russ Ortiz, and had built a three-run lead.

title: A Promise to Love, Honor and Bear No Children
description: TO the women he dated, Jeff Gundersen was all things wonderful. He was handsome, athletic and successful, a Wall Street headhunter who lived in a garden apartment on Gramercy Park. At 50, Mr. Gundersen, a divorced father of three, wanted to remarry, but there was a catch: he didn't want more children.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Sept. 29 about the new arts center in Singapore (known as Esplanade -- Theaters on the Bay) referred incompletely to the design of the concert hall. Besides the acoustician Russell Johnson, the creators were a theater design firm -- Theater Projects Consultants -- and two architecture firms: Michael Wilford & Partners and DP Architects.

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: At Work, at Ease: McPartland, 84, Remains a Perfect Foil
description: ALTHOUGH Marian McPartland tapes her popular radio program, ''Piano Jazz,'' at a Manhattan recording studio, the atmosphere of the show is so relaxed that the setting could be the living room of her home, with each weekly guest simply dropping by to play music and talk.

title: The Restaurateur
description: Silvano Marchetto is a colorful character in every way. A native of Florence, Mr. Marchetto, 55, is the owner of Da Silvano, a Tuscan restaurant in Greenwich Village whose regular customers include Gwyneth Paltrow and Calvin Klein. Known for his bright pants, Mr. Marchetto cuts an eye-popping swath through restaurant crowds. ''The customers say, 'Look, how nice' as I go back and forth to the kitchen,'' he said. ''I dress to be different. All my life, I've worn red or yellow shoes. They're more alive.''

title: Working 9 to 5, Give or Take
description: Blame the boss's style, or perhaps the e-mail server that keeps crashing. Whatever the reason, American businesses are unproductive 38 percent of the time, losing the equivalent of 86 workdays this year, a new study says.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about plans for the site of a former General Motors plant in Sleepy Hollow misstated the make of the vehicles last manufactured there. It was Chevrolet. (Chrysler is a competing company.)

title: Anthony Hopkins; 'Imaginary Friends'; Al Jolson
description: ANTHONY HOPKINS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD
description: TUCK-Edward. North Country School and Camp Treetops would like to express their deep sorrow at the loss of Edward Tuck. Ed was on the Board of Trustees from 1975 thru 1986, serving as Board Chair from 1978-1986. We thank Ed for his many years of support and service to NCS and CTT, and extend our thoughts and prayers to his family at this time.

title: Private Sector; Health Care, From Both Sides Now
description: As a senior executive of Aetna U.S. Healthcare, Dr. Arthur Leibowitz used to offer doctors a choice: our way or the highway. Now, in a surprising switch of a sort more common among lawyers than doctors, he is using his insider's knowledge on the other side of the table.

title: Devils Rekindle Spark That Had Been Missing
description: It hardly qualified as a crisis, being tied with the Columbus Blue Jackets in the third period of the second game of the season, but the Devils did not like how it felt, so they decided to define it as a challenge.

title: Habitats/Brooklyn Heights to Bermuda to Colombia to Queens; Adventure on the Water Leads to a River View
description: IT was just about a year ago that Wendy and Claude McKernan set sail. They didn't know where their 47-foot boat would take them, nor how long they would be gone. Neither did they imagine the adventure ahead, nor its sudden end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUVIVIER, MAX U.
description: DUVIVIER-Max U. The faculty, administration, students, alumni and staff of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University offer our heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Roger Duvivier, president of the Einstein Alumni Association and member of the Class of '74, on the passing of his beloved father in Haiti on September 29. We also extend our condolences to all the members of the Duvivier family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

title: INTERNATIONAL: October 6-12; MAYOR ATTACKED
description: The ''Sleepless Night'' cultural festival in Paris was in full swing when a man stepped out of the crowd in City Hall and stabbed Mayor Bertrand Delano. The assailant later told police that he hated politicians and, in particular, homosexuals. Mr. Delano, 52, one of France's few openly gay politicians, underwent three hours of surgery before being pronounced out of danger. The attack, which came less than three months after President Jacques Chirac escaped assassination during a Bastille Day parade, raised new fears about the safety of public officials in France. Alan Riding

title: Cuba Can't Ignore a Dissident It Calls Insignificant
description: For someone the Cuban government disparages as insignificant, Oswaldo Pay has been attracting a great deal of international attention.

title: Deconstructing The Bing
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about studio construction credited the design incompletely for the CNN studios in the Time & Life Building and in the AOL Time Warner Center. The Production Design Group was responsible for scenic design.

title: When Moviemaking Was a Form of Resistance
description: BERTRAND TAVERNIER may be the only filmmaker alive with enough daring, prestige and just plain contrariness to have made ''Safe Conduct.''

title: Editorial Observer; Lessons in Brutal Honesty at the Barbershop
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's attempt to kill off the hit movie ''Barbershop'' is not going well. This raucous comedy about an African-American barbershop in Chicago entered the theaters as a natural for black hip-hoppers in their teens and 20's, who would be drawn to Ice Cube and Eve, two rap stars who appear in the film. But the fuss that Mr. Jackson and the Rev. Al Sharpton have kicked up over risqu jokes about Rosa Parks and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has heightened the movie's profile, helping to make it a box office hit and the crossover film of the season.

title: Risa Aronson, Andrew Premisler
description: Risa Amy Aronson, a daughter of Aline R. Finkelstein and Stephen J. Aronson, both of New York, was married last evening to Andrew Mark Premisler, a son of Nancy and Michael M. Premisler of New York. Rabbi David Gelfand performed the ceremony at the Westhampton Bath and Tennis Hotel in Westhampton Beach, N.Y.

title: Bangkok's Back Streets: An Altar, A Cafe, a Massage
description: I WAS the first person to hop on the $2 bus from Don Muang Airport to downtown Bangkok. I got a good seat, or so I thought, but the bus quickly filled with international 20-somethings in shorts and sandals, and my legs were squished together behind a heap of dusty, bursting backpacks.

title: In Quest for a New Identity, a Theater Stages a Tryout
description: ''TAP YOUR TROUBLES AWAY'' sounds like the title of the quintessential get-happy show tune. But then, so does ''I Promise You a Happy Ending.''

title: Power and Glory in Sisterhood
description: IF ''Gloria: Another Look at Feminist Art in the 1970's'' conjures up several pop culture associations from that era, then it has probably served its purpose as the title of a show of historic feminist art at White Columns in the West Village. The title intentionally does triple duty.

title: Adventures in the Rear-View Mirror
description: PEOPLE think that driving a school bus is a sedentary job, but you have to be alert and physically fit. Every two years, drivers have to take an endurance test and drag a 120-pound bag of weights backward across a 40-foot-long floor. Last time, we had a contest to see who could do it fastest. There were all these big, strong guys, but the person who won was a tiny woman with an injured back. Her time was 11 seconds.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Hyundai Tiburon; Hot Date That's Willing To Make a Commitment
description: FOR 20-year-olds with 20 grand to spend on a sporty coupe, life keeps getting better. In this intensely competitive class, where ''best of'' titles fall as quickly as Hollywood's summer box-office records, the Hyundai Tiburon GT V-6 has come out of nowhere -- actually, out of South Korea -- to run with the best competitors that Japan and America can muster.

title: Amy Duddleston, Hilary Schroeder
description: Amy Elizabeth Duddleston and Hilary Jean Schroeder, both freelance film editors, affirmed their partnership yesterday at the Wattles Mansion in Los Angeles. Deb Gordon, a minister of the Universal Life Church, performed the commitment ceremony.

title: Just One Red Alert Left in This Series
description: The setting is so much different for the Anaheim Angels at Edison Field in this merry and magical month. So many thousands of fans are wearing red shirts, red caps and red jackets that you could drop a paper airplane from 1,000 feet and be guaranteed of striking something red. Red Alert, the banners warn, accurately and ominously.

title: Dog Bites Dog
description: I suppose I should thank you for exposing the barbarity and stupid cruelty of the dog-fighting world, but reading Shane DuBow's article (Sept. 29) made me sick and ashamed that no one seems to care about the welfare of these poor dogs. As for the subhumans involved, of course they will go on to be violent toward people too. That fact seems to motivate some concern in society. As for me, abusing animals is reason enough to jail anyone involved and to throw away the key.

title: Turning Away From U.S., Pakistan's Elite Gravitate Toward Islamic Religious Parties
description: Seated on the front lawn of his father's palatial house in a leafy enclave here, Ehsan Ijaz, a 20-year-old junior at Georgia Tech, explained this afternoon why other members of the Pakistani elite have turned against the United States.

title: Diamonds, Money and Madness In Brutal African Wars
description: THERE is a grim resolve to the quest of some reporters to reach the dark core of their story, their personal addition to the canon established by Joseph Conrad.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer malfunction, a picture on Page 19 of the Connecticut section today with an article about furniture at a Yale University gallery is obscured in some copies. It shows a chair designed by Charles and Ray Eames. Readers wishing corrected copies of the page may telephone (212) 556-1992 or write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; e-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: 50 Years Later, Bethpage Coach Reaches Milestone of 300 Victories
description: Howard Vogts began coaching football at Bethpage High School in 1952. Fifty years and 300 victories later, he is still there.

title: When a Democracy Weighs War
description: To the Editor:

title: Sake Goes Clubbing
description: I ASSOCIATE sake with two-handed sipping and head-bowing ceremony, not a harmonica-happy Stevie Wonder mix. But if you visit Remedy, a restaurant and lounge that opened last month in New York, you'll find sake is running hard with a different posse these days -- the thirsty warlords of the drinks-and-dating scene, hands on hilts as they put their best muscle on getting past the door.

title: Julieta Stack, Tim Page
description: Julieta Alison Stack and Tim Page were married yesterday by the Rev. Fred Taylor, a Baptist minister, in the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park in Maryland.

title: Firefighters Pay Tribute To Their Dead
description: Legions of white-gloved firefighters, a solemn brotherhood from across the nation and around the world, gathered under weeping gray skies in New York City yesterday for an outpouring of remembrance and farewell for 356 comrades killed in the World Trade Center attack and in other recent tragedies.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION
description: THE GREEN HOUR

title: Out of the Deep
description: The most famous work of American art that almost nobody has ever seen in the flesh is Robert Smithson's ''Spiral Jetty'': 6,650 tons of black basalt and earth in the shape of a gigantic coil, 1,500 feet long, projecting into the remote shallows of the Great Salt Lake in Utah, where the water is ros red from algae.

title: Last Place Aside, Underdogs Relish Roles
description: Xavier De Lesquen, the bespectacled 40-year-old administrative judge who heads the French America's Cup team -- which has yet to win a race -- is finally smiling.

title: His Job: Chasing Wall Street Deadbeats
description: MICHAEL S. COLOMBO is a debt collector, but not one who goes after small fry -- people who refuse to pay for their magazine subscriptions or for credit-card charges that have gotten out of hand. Instead, he pursues stockbrokers and investors who owe money on loans or margin calls. And he does this through the art of firm persuasion.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Factory-wise, there are no jobs out there. I don't think there's even much retail work out there. And that wouldn't pay my bills anyway.''

title: Cellist's Block
description: Isabel Masurovsky, the narrator of DISTURBANCE OF THE INNER EAR (Carroll & Graf, $25), Joyce Hackett's strange and intermittently lovely first novel, is a onetime child prodigy, a brilliant cellist who has been artistically blocked for a decade. When Isabel was 14, on the night of her Carnegie Hall debut, her parents died in a car crash. She hasn't played well since. She awakens on the book's first page in a Milan hotel to discover that her septuagenarian lover, the only person who remembers her illustrious past, has died. Stranded in Italy with no family, little money and an exceedingly delicate temperament (she finds the crunching required to eat an apple unendurably violent), Isabel proceeds to make a series of mysterious and haphazard choices. She begins an uneasy romance with a surgical resident who sidelines as a gigolo, and takes work tutoring a troubled adolescent boy with a taste for dog biscuits. The boy's father owns an exquisite 16th-century cello, the same instrument, Isabel suspects, that was confiscated by the Nazis from a famous Jewish musician. Isabel is powerfully drawn to the cello, which, like her, hasn't made music in years. The Holocaust casts its long shadow over them both: Isabel's father, a pianist and a concentration camp survivor, has left his daughter a legacy of crushing anxiety. When she was a child, he told her ''that bad people crumbled if they heard Beethoven or Bach,'' and that only her musical virtuosity would protect her. The novel is breathless, opaque and hard to track; it is also singular and sometimes haunting. Jennifer Marie Reese

title: Novel Ideas
description: ALL IS VANITY

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the diverse attractions of the year-old Jewish Community Center on Amsterdam Avenue misstated the location of the swimming pool in the eight-story building. It is on the sixth floor, not the roof.

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; SNIPER ANXIETY
description: The victims could not be less provocative, going about the simplest outdoor missions of daily life but meandering into the sights of the suburban sniper terrifying the Washington area.

title: The Forgotten Domestic Crisis
description: If it weren't for the steady beat of war drums, health care would be front and center in this fall's political debate. And war or no war, politicians will not be able to avoid it much longer. As John Breaux of Louisiana, long one of the most conservative Senate Democrats, recently told the press, ''The system is collapsing around us.''

title: How Laura Bush Lets Literature Ring
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the marketing of James Taylor's new album, ''October Road,'' misidentified the general manager of the Tower Records store near Lincoln Center, who described the turnout for an appearance by Mr. Taylor. He is Tim Devin. (As noted elsewhere in the article, Jim Ryan is the station manager of WLTW-FM who discussed the album's appeal to women.)

title: Coping With New Federal Corporate Ethics Law
description: IN two conferences last month sponsored by local law firms, panelists from the fields of accounting, corporate law and insurance warned that the effects of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, passed by Congress on July 30 in response to the wave of corporate ethics scandals that have shaken the stock market, will be far-ranging and transforming.

title: RESOURCES
description: PAGES 24-28

title: Streetscapes/Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument, at 89th Street and Riverside Drive; A 1902 Memorial to the Fallen of the Civil War
description: IT took nearly a decade to build the white marble Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument, at 89th Street and Riverside Drive. Locations had been suggested all over Manhattan by those eager to have the monument in their neighborhoods -- and by those who weren't.

title: INFECTION KILLS 7
description: Seven New Jersey residents have died and 14 others have become ill from a bacteria infection. It is the same infection, mainly from tainted delicatessen lunchmeat and soft cheese, that has sent at least 44 people to the hospital in the northeast since July. Last week, the New Jersey infections from the listeria bacteria prompted Clinton R. Lacy, the state commissioner of health and senior services, to warn the elderly, pregnant women and people with weakened immune systems to avoid or thoroughly heat delicatessen luncheon meats, particularly turkey, which has has been identified as the most likely cause of infections. Karen DeMasters

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about ''Imaginary Friends,'' a new play by Nora Ephron about the writers Lillian Hellman and Mary McCarthy, included a quotation in which Ms. Ephron reversed the almost identical given names of McCarthy's first husband and of a character (also a first husband) in McCarthy's novel ''The Group.'' McCarthy's first husband was Harold; the character in the novel was Harald.

title: Deportation Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Way of Life Hangs On
description: A LONG with its stone walls, covered bridges and town greens, an enduring symbol of New England and its Yankee ways is the general store. Often spotted in small towns while out leaf-peeping this time of year, the general store is almost a comfort zone, a step into a way of life many of us never experienced, but long for nonetheless. There are actually a few left in Connecticut, but their numbers, and even their reasons for existing, are fading.

title: Signs of Revived Qaeda Are Seen In Latest Strikes and New Tapes
description: American officials say they fear that terrorist attacks in the past week and taped messages from leaders of Al Qaeda signal the beginning of a new wave of terrorist activity and possibly a large-scale attack.

title: In Lynbrook, a New Italian Says Welcome
description: BENVENUTI'S name and attitude say welcome. The host of the new Lynbrook Italian extends a warm greeting, which is echoed by the rest of the friendly staff. As soon as diners are seated, a plate of free appetizers arrives: bruschetta, chunks of nutty Parmesan and a scattering of plump, green olives. At the end of the meal, a platter of fresh fruit puts in an appearance, along with a small bowl of almond-flavored macaroons. And don't be surprised if there's an offer of an after-dinner drink on the house.

title: Janitors Air a Dispute At Mercy College Gate
description: Janitors trying to get their jobs back and to bargain for a new contract have been standing vigil at the gate of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry for more than a month.

title: Luxury Hotels Feel Sting Of Fewer Business Guests
description: THE Sept. 11 terrorist attacks brought leisure travel almost to a standstill and worsened the slowdown in business travel, which had been limping along since early that year. Now that leisure travel has been inching up in recent months, midscale and economy hotels are showing slight improvement. Luxury hotels have also begun to show some improvement, at least in number of occupied rooms, though they have had to make sharp discounts.

title: Height of Parapet Walls on Roofs
description: Q. I recently visited my son's girlfriend's corner apartment, on the eighth and ninth floors of a nine-story building. The apartment is a small duplex that has a top-floor deck on the ninth floor. When I went out on the deck, I was surprised by the low wrap-around brick wall and iron bar (with a space between the two), which was only as high as the middle of my thigh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, MARTHA
description: WEISBERG-Martha, 73. Of New York City, a designer in fashion and the decorative arts, died on September 27. Her style, creativity and honesty will be deeply missed by all who loved and knew her. A dear friend, she leaves a loving husband of 54 years, Robert Weisberg, a daughter Carla Weisberg, and a sister Ida Nishenshal. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cooper Union Annual Fund. A memorial service will be held October 15, 6PM, at the National Arts Club, 20 Gramercy Park South.

title: Cedric the Entertainer, The Old-School Comedian
description: 'What we're doing here is a big old-school live variety show -- lots of jokes, lots of music, lots of beautiful dancing girls.'' Your host, Cedric the Entertainer, born Cedric Kyles in Missouri 38 years ago, is still a relatively young man, but he is the very embodiment of old school, trotting out from behind the curtain to welcome all the good people out there in TV land to his new series. Everything about ''Cedric the Entertainer Presents,'' one of the few certified network hits of this bumpy season, hums with a timeless, slightly corny show-biz vibe, from the host's natty sharkskin suits and fedoras to his penchant for sipping cocktails with the audience between skits.

title: Some Ways to Keep Cold Out and Cash In
description: About this time each year, energy companies and conservation groups offer suggestions for lowering home heating bills. Heeding them may be particularly beneficial this year as winter approaches.

title: In 2nd Spacewalk, Astronauts Do the Plumbing
description: A pair of astronauts emerged from the space shuttle Atlantis today to connect and repair plumbing on the International Space Station and its latest 14-ton addition.

title: My Excellent Brylcreem Adventure
description: I HEFTED my shopping basket at a pharmacy on the Sunset Strip and began unloading. One bottle each, Vitalis and Wildroot. One tube Brylcreem. Bottles of British Sterling and Canoe. A Burma-Shave shaving brush and a cake of Colgate Shaving Mug Soap.

title: White House Debate on Smallpox Slows Plan for Wide Vaccination
description: Intense debates in the Bush administration over smallpox vaccinations have delayed critical decisions in the nation's program against germ terrorism for months, participants say.

title: Your Call. Everybody's Business.
description: CELLPHONES are allowing just about everyone to air his private business in public. On a commuter train or in a restaurant, it's common to overhear someone, phone in hand, discussing a topic that traditionally he would reserve for private conversations with his wife, or cosmetic surgeon.

title: Janine Flory, Matthew Murray
description: Dr. Janine Dyck Flory and Matthew J. Murray were married last evening at the Frick Art Museum in Pittsburgh. Brian Dyck, a minister of the Mennonite church and a brother of the bride, officiated.

title: Pointing the Way To Easier Map Use
description: Two new products, a guidebook series and a familiar atlas, have been designed to make city maps easier to use.

title: A Keeper
description: On the face of it, there really isn't anything extraordinary in the facts of D.D. Smalley's life. His birth name, David David, after a grandfather and an uncle, was a little eccentric, and his marriage to the sister of the sheriff of the Texas town nicknamed Six-Shooter Junction had a certain romantic quality, but everything else seemed conventional, even verging on the prosaic. He was born in 1889 and died in 1963, and along the way he had a good job as a mapmaker for the Southern Pacific Railroad, an admiring wife, a son and a daughter and a bungalow in Hyde Park, a sweet little neighborhood near downtown Houston. He taught Sunday school and spent his time tinkering, collecting and entertaining his grandchildren.

title: Private Sector; A Bit of Snapping and Snarling For Two of Detroit's Top Dogs
description: Detroit loves a good brawl between automakers, and it looks as if one is brewing between Chrysler's chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, and Robert Lutz, the General Motors vice chairman.

title: Taking The Money And Not Exactly Running
description: The problem facing octogenarian bank robbers is that they don't move as fast as they used to. That apparently was the case with John Anthony Sadowy's holdup-gone-wrong at the Greenpoint Savings Bank on Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPPE, VICTOR VINCENT
description: LAPPE-Victor Vincent. ''The Mad Russian'' of Tenafly, NJ on October 11, 2002. Beloved husband of 31 years to Elaine (nee Tahan). Devoted father of Victor Wesley and Katherine Julia. Dear brother of Dorothy Pelick, Henry Langan and the late Walter Lappa. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on Sunday and Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Tuesday 11 A.M. Mt. Carmel Church, Tenafly, NJ. Interment private. Donations to The American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St., Hackensack, NJ 07601 would be appreciated. For directions, visit www.barrettfuneralhome.net

title: To Be Rich, Chinese and in Trouble: 3 Tales
description: THE actress and businesswoman Liu Xiaoqing may have crossed the line when she proclaimed herself, apparently optimistically, as China's first female billionaire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, ROSE
description: SEGAL-Rose. Of Teaneck, NJ on October 11, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Cherished mother of Howard W. Segal, Elinor Hirsch and the late Norman H. Segal. Devoted mother - in - law of Robert, Ronnee, and Gail. Loving grandmother of Karen, Elizabeth, Eric, Jeffery, Stephanie, Phoebe, Alexis and Sophie. Great-grandmother of Ethan, Jamie and Rachel. Long time friend of Bernice Young. Services Monday 11:30 AM, ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to ''The Jack Segal Family'' at JCC Center of Palisades, Tenafly, NJ.

title: The Traffic Goes in Circles, But the Plan Marches On
description: Columbus himself would have gotten lost. For 15 years, the city has been trying to unravel the traffic knot that is Columbus Circle, where pedestrians compete with six lanes of traffic around a tight rotary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOW, JEROME M.
description: ROSOW-Jerome M. At 82, President and founder of Work in America Institute on Friday evening, October 11, 2002. Devoted and beloved father of Michael and Joel. Service Monday Ballard-Durand Mortuary, White Plains, 914-949-0566.

title: Near Sacramento, Finally, a Big-City Arts Center
description: With its 1,800- and 250-seat theaters, the new Mondavi Center for the Performing Arts at the University of California at Davis takes the burden off the Sacramento Community Center Theater, which was the venue for nearly all the local arts organizations, touring events and the university's student productions.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: When I started reading science fiction more than 50 years ago, no major publisher had any interest in the genre. For the latest Robert Heinlein, Isaac Asimov and Arthur C. Clarke, you turned to monthly magazines like Astounding Science Fiction and The Magazine of Fantasy and Science Fiction. There you found short stories of varying lengths along with ''serials,'' novel-length narratives broken into two, three or more installments. Each installment began with a brief synopsis so densely packed with information as to be virtually unintelligible. If for some reason you missed the beginning of a serial, you had to piece together what was happening from clues embedded in the latest installment. Even many of the ostensibly stand-alone short stories belonged to loosely connected series, set in societies, worlds or universes that the writer had used before. (Anyone who has tried to create a fictional but plausible world from scratch will appreciate the economies involved.) Since these stories typically assumed familiarity with the series background, you learned to be alert for details that related the action at hand to a grander context.

title: To a Painter, Words Are Worth a Thousand Pictures
description: IN the beginning for the artist Jane Hammond is the word. It's impossible to talk about her painting without resorting to literature (not to mention Santa Claus, molecular biology, phrenology, Mao Zedong and the American flag). She'll pillage anything from her eclectic library or her notebooks of names, from those of pets to those of English castles.

title: Vintage Chic
description: With its glass walls that double as doors, split-levels and relentless cool yet surprising coziness, this house in the serene foothills of the Los Feliz section of Los Angeles is a shrine to the promise of Southern California. Cross-ventilated breezes drift through the aerie -- built long before feng shui became a twinkle in the eye of every trendy type this side of Fred Segal -- bringing with it monarch butterflies and birds. By comparison, the buttoned-up mansions of Beverly Hills seem woefully sad, if not cynical.

title: Dance Listings
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER  World premieres and a tribute to George Harrison. Tue., 7: Opening night gala; Wed.-Fri., 8; Sat. 2 and 8; next Sun., 2 and 7:30. Through Oct. 27.

title: In Their Own Defense
description: AFTER almost 10 years on the campus police force at Purchase College, Cindy Markus Jones, then a corporal, felt that there was something she and her fellow officers lacked in their training.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 11 about restaurants near Paris misstated the availability of a $38 lunch menu at Tastevin in Maisons-Laffitte. A reader's e-mail message on Sept. 26 pointed out that it was offered on weekdays only, not weekends only.

title: Kick the Tires At Your Own Risk
description: Car dealers are usually ready for a bit of high-pressure selling, but they generally stop short of making, shall we say, an offer you can't refuse. Until now, that is.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Wars Of Nerves
description: Living in Montgomery County, Md., these days with a sniper on the loose is an unnerving experience. We've all gotten to know our police chief, Charles Moose, through his news conferences during the past two weeks of random shootings. We've also gotten to know our pizza deliveryman better. Last Monday night my wife ordered pizza from the California Pizza Kitchen. When the deliveryman arrived, I was in the living room watching President Bush address the nation about Iraq. As my wife paid the pizza guy, she remarked to him that the pizza smelled great, ''but I don't think my husband will get up because he's watching the news conference.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENROW, LOTTE
description: LENROW-Lotte. To our dear mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, memories of you will be with us forever. Your loving children

title: The Rangers Already Have Cause For Concern
description: The hockey was not very different here from the Rangers' point of view.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DR. MATTHEW
description: FELDMAN - Dr. Matthew. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ on October 11, 2002. Beloved husband of Shirley (nee) Zarin. Devoted father of Ellen, Alan, Laurie and Margery. Dear brother of Emmanuel, Myron and Edward. Loving grandfather of six. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack, NJ on Sunday October 13, at 1:30 PM.

title: 'All Is Vanity'
description: IWAS A PROMISING CHILD. When I was seven, I spent an entire week hunkered down on the cranberry red carpeting in my father's study, building a scale model of the Temple of Athena at Paestum. I carved the columns out of Ivory soap with a paring knife and pushed red clay through my Play-Doh press to tile over the Styrofoam roof. I painted a frieze, which was cheating and ultimately unsatisfactory, since it was not authentically three-dimensional. My father wondered why not the Parthenon, but I wasn't interested in the obvious.

title: Northern Lights
description: ANYONE who dines out in this state knows you can get great food just about anywhere. Setting may be a costly fetish in Manhattan and an irrelevance in the heartland; in New Jersey, it's pot luck, sometimes integral to the experience but more often an afterthought.

title: Collectors Shake, Rattle And Watch Those Bankrolls
description: WHILE cleaning out his house for a moving sale last summer, David Aguilar found a dozen concert posters advertising his long-disbanded rock group, the Chocolate Watchband, which played during the 1960's. Hardly nostalgic, he put the fluorescent red, yellow and purple prints out for sale in front of his Boulder, Colo., home, but the only people interested were three little girls who happened by. ''They laughed at the goofy art and colors,'' said Mr. Aguilar, 54, who is now a public affairs director for a nonprofit organization in Cambridge, Mass. ''So I sold them to them for a nickel apiece.''

title: Do Women Lack Drive? Or a Wife?
description: FIRST, meet Kate Reddy, a high-powered, ambitious achiever, who is also conflicted, exhausted and stressed. She is the mother of two, and when we first see her she is in the kitchen (at 1:30 a.m.) beating store-bought pastries with a rolling pin to make them look homemade for the school Christmas party.

title: What's My Mania?
description: BILLY HIBBLE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRESTYN, ALAN K.
description: TRESTYN-Alan K. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Jonathan and Erica. Dear son of Mildred and Helga. Loving brother of Beverly and Cary. He was dedicated to his family, friends, and his profession. Alan always gave of his good humor, generous spirit, and sage advice. Services will be held today at 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Wide Right or Wide Left, the Seminoles Lose Their Way Again
description: Miami quarterback Ken Dorsey could not look as Florida State's Xavier Beitia lined up for a potential game-winning 43-yard field-goal attempt today. Neither could split end Andre Johnson, who went behind the Hurricanes' bench, dropped to his knees and began praying.

title: Cars Injure 3 Officers and a Horse; 2 of the Drivers Face D.W.I. Charges
description: Three police officers -- and one police horse -- were struck and injured by drivers in unrelated accidents late Friday and early yesterday, the police said.

title: Into the Woods
description: The first words that come to mind are ''cozy'' and ''quaint,'' even -- banish the thought -- ''cute.'' But the diminutive-looking building, sited, forgive me, oh-so-cutely on a gentle hill under the sheltering arms of tall, tall trees, with its stone walls and stuccoed tower, looks right out of a fairy tale.

title: Putting My Driving in Freud's Lap
description: WHEN I'm behind the wheel, the words just fly out of my mouth. I can't seem to help it.

title: A Watchdog Whose Bite Makes Some See Red
description: EVEN the members of Concerned Citizens for Open Space concede that at times they are as bothersome as gadflies, although, they add, for good reason: saving this city of 53,000 from the ills of overdevelopment.

title: Jennifer Smith, John Burke
description: Jennifer Marie Smith and John Michael Burke, lawyers, were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at Round Hill House in Washingtonville, N.Y.

title: Artful Dodger, Damn Yankee
description: SANDY KOUFAX

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SOL
description: BERMAN-Sol, 94 years old of Palm Beach, Florida, on October 10. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Adored father, grandfather and great-grandfather of Gail & Alan Levenstein, Barbara and Martin Weinburg, Arthur Rosenstein, Miranda, Jessica & Antony Levenstein, Bonnie and Scott Rogoff and family, Susan and Adam Hurwitz and family, Robert and Jean Rosenstein. Brother of Sylvia Weinberg. Dear uncle and great-uncle. He will be missed.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for DEAN R. O'HARE; How to Tally the Costs of War?
description: WITH President Bush threatening to attack Iraq, former Secretary of State James A. Baker III, an old friend of the president and his father, expressed his solidarity in a speech last week to the nation's property-casualty insurers. He cautioned that a war with Iraq could be long and costly, but he received a warm response from the insurers, gathered at a conference in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. One of those applauding was Dean R. O'Hare, chief executive of the Chubb Group of Insurance Companies, an insurer of businesses, homes and cars. Mr. O'Hare talked later about the business and economic implications of a war. JOSEPH B. TREASTER

title: Sexuality and the City
description: REREADING SEX

title: Bon Jovi Learns the Value of Staying on Message
description: THE fleet of helicopters transporting Bon Jovi from the west side of Manhattan to Giants Stadium was crossing the Hudson. Just minutes before, the band had finished headlining a free concert in Times Square to kick off the National Football League season. With help from Eve and Enrique Iglesias, it had shut down Midtown this September afternoon. Then it took to the skies to get to the Giants' season opener by halftime so it could play its new single, ''Everyday,'' for a prime-time television audience.

title: Introduction
description: The case made by Paul Wolfowitz for war with Iraq failed to sway readers, who did not share his confidence that toppling Saddam would improve prospects in the Middle East. Portfolio was a big hit, though readers wondered why only the girls got naked.

title: Too Much Energy Spent Knocking N.J.
description: To the Editor:

title: Cablevision Ends Dutchess News Program
description: ABOUT 9:30 a.m. on a Thursday last month, reporters for News Center 6 reviewed what would be on that night's telecast. On the list were the construction of a new gas station and a pilot program at the Culinary Institute to train new military recruits to serve as chefs at sea.

title: Changing Places
description: MY OWN MEDICINE

title: Health Food Fails Test At School In Berkeley
description: Vincent Trahan, owner of Doggie High, a hot dog joint across the street from Berkeley High School, has a theory about why a school lunch program featuring organic chicken, stir-fried tofu and pesticide-free produce wilted like two-day-old lettuce.

title: A Nixon Myth
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Boys of Winter Face Some Decisions
description: IT'S not even halfway through October, but New York's big ballparks are empty. That's not unusual for Shea Stadium, but at Yankee Stadium it's strange.

description: IN recent weeks, throughout the public discussion of Iraq's weapons capabilities, Americans have heard the word ''nuclear'' pronounced ''NOO-kyuh-luhr'' by the president, many members of Congress, a general or two and even a few news anchors.

title: Libert! galit! Thrapie!
description: EQUALS

title: Some Ways to Keep Cold Out and Cash In
description: About this time each year, energy companies and conservation groups offer suggestions for lowering home heating bills. Heeding them may be particularly beneficial this year as winter approaches.

title: Green Gwen Grows Riper
description: THE LOST GARDEN

title: Leading by 21 Points, Lions Cannot Hold On
description: Lafayette, which trailed by 21 points in the first half, scored two touchdowns in the final eight and a half minutes yesterday to defeat Columbia, 28-21, at Wien Stadium.

title: 'The Blank Slate'
description: Everyone has a theory of human nature. Everyone has to anticipate the behavior of others, and that means we all need theories about what makes people tick. A tacit theory of human nature-that behavior is caused by thoughts and feelings-is embedded in the very way we think about people. We fill out this theory by introspecting on our own minds and assuming that our fellows are like ourselves, and by watching people's behavior and filing away generalizations. We absorb still other ideas from our intellectual climate: from the expertise of authorities and the conventional wisdom of the day.

title: Debating The Numbers On Goals For Growth
description: HOW fast does the economy have to grow to reduce the unemployment rate?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAXE, EDWARD L.
description: SAXE-Edward L. War Intelligence, CBS Executive, MoMA Director, Harvard Club of New York President, Architectural Consultant, died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering July 27, 2002 at age 86. Loving husband, father, grandfather and friend, Edward L. Saxe was born on January 17, 1916 in Boston, MA., attended Boston Latin School, Harvard '37 and Harvard Business School. He was a 48-year resident of Westport, Connecticut. A Memorial Service will be held in his honor with a reception to follow on Thursday, October 17th at 2 P.M. at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue and 53rd Street, NYC. Mr. Saxe is survived by his wife of 56 years, Anthea; a son Andrew Saxe predeceased him at age 50. Also surviving are a son Christopher Saxe of Weston, CT. and three grandchildren: Caroline of Westport, CT., Madeleine and Adam of NYC. In lieu of flowers, it is asked that donations be made in his name to AmeriCares, 161 Cherry St., New Canaan, CT. 06840-4831.

title: Christine Ryan, Robert Harland
description: Christine Marie Ryan and Dr. Robert Carl Harland were married yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., an American Baptist minister, performed a nondenominational ceremony at Riverside Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUCHAN, MIRIAM
description: SLUCHAN-Miriam. 83, a great New Yorker, passed on October 7. Secretary OSS UNRRA and Ambassador to Norway WWII. Secretary to two presidents ILGWU. Survived by nieces, nephews, sister Lillian & brother Stanley.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; With Land Scarce, Million-Dollar Condos Flourish
description: WHEN a rare patch of vacant land appears in Fairfield County's upscale towns or a few parcels seem ripe for cobbling together, usually by knocking down a building or two, it is likely that a new condominium project will soon rise, with units starting at $1 million and selling like ice cream in August.

title: Debate Among the Candidates for Governor
description: Following is a transcript of the debate yesterday among candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator for the debate was Bill Ritter of WABC, Eyewitness News.

title: MAYOR RESIGNS
description: Terrance G. Weldon resigned as Ocean Township mayor and Asbury Park city administrator last week, less than three days before pleading guilty in United States District Court in Newark to three counts of extortion in connection with taking more than $60,000 in kickbacks from land developers in Ocean Township. He is scheduled to be sentenced Jan. 7. Karen DeMasters

title: Campaign Season; Trying to Track a Minnesota Tracker
description: A political battle that usually happens behind the scenes is the subject of a new DVD released by the Minnesota Republican Party (not available in stores), called ''What Are They Hiding?''

title: The Guardian Angels of Abandoned Dogs
description: A BACK door at the Bridgeport Animal Shelter flies open and a 75-pound Great Dane and bulldog mix that looks like he could guard the gates of hell pulls 100-pound Alexis Elder outside by a leash. Ms. Elder's earlier advice to never approach a dog head-on suddenly seems moot.

title: Independent Directors, Whatever They Are
description: Portfolio managers and analysts at financial institutions say a majority of a company's directors should be independent, but they don't agree on how to ensure that independence, a survey has found.

title: Wearable Attitude
description: Last summer, Rebecca Sgan-Cohen, an aspiring young filmmaker, decided to try a different way to earn some much-needed money: selling T-shirts on the street. Ms. Sgan-Cohen, a 26-year-old New Yorker, had been making hand-dyed shirts for herself for years, decorating them with her own poems and sayings in the tradition of artists like Jenny Holzer and Andy Warhol. Her handiwork was often admired by friends and strangers, so she set up a stand on Prince Street in SoHo in late August.

title: Taking Stock In Hoboken
description: IT has, at times, seemed as if this city with its row after row of tree-lined streets was being consumed by girders and cranes and dust. That alone makes the bustling city on the Hudson an oddity in a state with more than its share of industrial dinosaurs.

title: Texas On The Tigris
description: This has always been a place where people say the opposite of what they mean. But last week, the capital soared to ominous new Orwellian heights.

title: 'The New Biographical Dictionary of Film'
description: A

title: Vera G. List, 94, Is Dead; Philanthropist and Collector
description: Vera G. List, a forward-looking philanthropist whose causes included contemporary art, opera, education and social justice, died Thursday at her home in Greenwich, Conn. She was 94.

title: INTERNATIONAL: October 6-12; NOBELS HERE AND THERE
description: Imre Kertsz, a Hungarian novelist and Holocaust survivor, won the Nobel Prize for literature, and two Americans, Daniel Kahneman at Princeton University and Vernon L. Smith at George Mason University, won the economic prize for explaining idiosyncrasies in the way people made decisions.

title: THE GUIDE

title: America's For-Profit Secret Army
description: WITH the war on terror already a year old and the possibility of war against Iraq growing by the day, a modern version of an ancient practice -- one as old as warfare itself -- is reasserting itself at the Pentagon. Mercenaries, as they were once known, are thriving -- only this time they are called private military contractors, and some are even subsidiaries of Fortune 500 companies.

title: After a Slow Start, Michigan Wins in a Frantic Finish
description: Penn State Coach Joe Paterno is loquacious when he chooses to be. Today, he chose to be brief and gruff in his comments. After his Nittany Lions lost a thriller to Michigan, 27-24 -- their second overtime defeat in the last three games -- Paterno spoke for less than three minutes and refused to let his assistants or players say anything more.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. Before opening Decades, his trendsetting vintage boutique in Los Angeles, in 1997, Cameron Silver traveled around North America singing German cabaret, and while on tour, refused to speak during the day to protect his voice. To amuse himself on those silent days, Silver combed thrift stores for old Pucci ties, and was ultimately inspired to make vintage clothes a career. ''I bought three things,'' he recalls of his ''Eureka!'' shopping moment in 1996. ''A Rudi Gernreich kabuki dress, an apple-green Trigre spring coat and a 1970's navy YSL suit.'' Nowadays, Silver says, he's too old to go thrift shopping, but he still hand-picks every item of 60's and 70's style that he sells at Decades (8214 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles) and at Barneys New York (660 Madison Avenue).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, RONALD
description: ROGERS-Ronald. Beloved friend, inspiring musician and devoted Wagnerite. Died in Northport, FL, October 4, 2002. Memorial service pending. We love and miss you. Tom and Maris

title: Neighbors Defend Park From a Soccer Invasion
description: It was always a matter of turf.

title: A Medieval Mission In Poitou-Charentes
description: LIKE a child's drawing of an improbably neat countryside, fields of sunflowers and grapevines stretch for miles in the Poitou-Charentes. Every so often a cluster of limestone houses and a steeple rears up, and it's possible to walk from one hamlet to the next without encountering more than a few cars. The traffic was heavier in the 11th and 12th centuries, when the road from Tours in the Loire Valley southwest through Poitiers and Saintes was one of France's four main routes to Santiago de Compostela in Spain. The tomb of St. James (Santiago in Spanish, St. Jacques in French) was Europe's premier pilgrimage site, and places of worship were essential along the route. As a result, this placid southwestern region has a saint's ransom of Romanesque churches.

description: ROOMBA will dispel any doubts you might have about the legitimacy of nuevo Latino. It is the hottest restaurant in New Haven, and with good reason: the food is bold, flavorful and different.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; TERROR MONEY
description: Enamm M. Arnaout, a Syrian-born Chicago resident, was so close to Osama bin Laden in the late 1980's, F.B.I. officials say, that he once looked after one of his wives. Mr. Aranout's alleged links to Al Qaeda led to his indictment, which alleged that as the leader of an Islamic foundation, he diverted money to Al Qaeda. Lawyers for Mr. Arnaout called the charges baseless. Eric Lichtblau

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORAN, RICHARD A.
description: HORAN-Richard A., age 60. Of Indianapolis, IN, formerly of Brooklyn, NY, and New Haven, CT. Died suddenly Sunday, October 6, in Indiana. He was the son of the late Harold A. and Helen M. Horan. Survived by his former wife, Mary Lou Horan of New Haven; two sons, Thomas C. of NYC, Gregory M. of New Haven; beloved brother, Robert A. of Woodbury, CT. He was predeceased by a brother, Harold. Mr. Horan was a graduate of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and NYU Graduate School. He served as an officer in the U.S. Air Force during the Vietnam War. He was employed as an engineer at the Allison Division of Rolls Royce Ltd of Indianapolis. A Mass of Christian burial was held from Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Washington, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ROBERT E., M.D.
description: GREEN-Robert E., M.D., 81. Of Short Hills, N.J. died October 8, 2002. Born in Brooklyn on March 30, 1921, a son of Bud, a well-known song and movie music writer, and Nan, a Ziegfield show girl. He was a practicing neurosurgeon (1951-1992); Chief of Neurosurgery at Saint Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, N.J., and The Hospital Center of Orange, Orange, N.J. (1964-1992), and active at other Essex County hospitals. He was board certified in Neurosurgery and Neurology. Dr. Green was truly a pioneer in his field, introducing surgical procedures to a newlyemerging medical specialty and dedicated mentor to countless young physicians. His many passions included: his family, the Confrerie de la Chaine des Rotisseurs, music and, for 73 years, The New York Yankees. A graduate of Columbia University (B.A.); Cornell Medical School (M.D.); University of Chicago Clinics (internship and residency); Johns Hopkins Hospital (residency); Diplomate of the American Board of Neurological Surgery; founding member of the NJ Neurosurgical Society (President 1961 to 1962). U.S. Army 194648. Dr. Green was Asst. Professor of Neurosurgery at UMDNJ (1988 to 92); and a Trustee of Saint Barnabas Medical Center (1980 to 89). His beloved wife Beverly (nee Horn) predeceased him in 1986. Surviving are his loving children: James K. Green, of Colorado; Gwynneth M. Jakober and her husband Lambert A. of Sparta, N.J.; Dr. Thomas C. Green, Seattle, Wash.; Cathlin L. Kagan, and her husband Richard, of Boca Raton, Fla.; his adoring grandchildren: Danielle and Brett Green, Christel and Monika Jakober, Lauren and Kathryn Petersen-Green; devoted brother, Wallace Green of Yonkers, N.Y. Contributions in his memory may be made to Robert E. Green, M.D., Memorial Fund, Saint Barnabas Development Foundation, Livingston, N.J. 07039. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, November 15 at 10 am in the Islami Auditorium, Saint Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston, NJ. For information please call the Saint Barnabas Development Foundation at (973) 322-4330.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAY, HARRIET
description: FAY-Harriet. At age 65. On October 11. An accomplished orchestra leader, jazz pianist, and cabaret performer, she was predeceased by her son, Michael Cohen. She is survived by her daughter Alice Cohen, three brothers, Dr. Stuart Levin, Charles Levin, and Myron Levin of Los Angeles, eight nieces and nephews and four great-nieces and nephews. Memorial donations to Keystone Hospice, 8765 Stenton Avenue, Wyndmoor, PA. 19038.

description: ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 12 — In the 20 seasons since the Heisman Trophy winner Herschel Walker led Georgia to its last Southeastern Conference championship, Bulldogs fans have tried to measure a number of their teams for conference championship rings. The expectations never matched the result.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; BAIL DENIED
description: A federal judge in Buffalo refused bail for five men accused of belonging to an Al Qaeda sleeper cell. He freed a sixth, but limited his ability to communicate. The judge cited ''clear and convincing'' evidence that the men, from the Yemenite community in nearby Lackawanna, had attended a terrorist training camp in Afghanistan in 2001.

title: Turning Green
description: For years my friend the writer Elaine Shannon and I joked that one day we would write a cookbook called ''Kill That Taste!'' The idea was born from the fact that the refrigerator in Elaine's Washington kitchen was filled almost exclusively with powerful condiments: lime pickle, chutneys and relishes, capers, mustards and, because she is a good Georgia girl, a vast array of hot sauces. The idea was that anything accompanied by one or some combination of the above would be made better or, at the very least, unrecognizable. Even -- or especially -- foods people hate.

title: Koizumi, Popular Again, Pushes Economic Change
description: For several weeks now, this country has been watching, rapt, what looks like the unfolding of a rare second act in Japanese politics.

title: Waiting for a Big Rebound in Profits? Wait Longer
description: CORPORATE profits season goes into full swing this week, but results for the third quarter -- and the outlook for the fourth -- are not likely to be upbeat.

title: When a Smoking Ban Limits Freedom of Choice
description: ''Last Call for a Smoke'' [Oct. 6] states that ''economic arguments are colliding with increasing concerns about the health risks to workers exposed to secondhand smoke for long periods.'' What about the freedom and choices of the patrons and employees? Should not the restaurant and bar owners decide what rules apply to smoking in their restaurants and bars? Liberty, the most fundamental American ideal, dictates that all Americans and, yes, Long Islanders as well, have an inalienable right to open a restaurant or bar with rules allowing patrons to smoke and breathe secondhand smoke.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 11 about restaurants near Paris misstated the availability of a $38 lunch menu at Tastevin in Maisons-Laffitte. A reader's e-mail message on Sept. 26 pointed out that it was offered on weekdays only, not weekends only.

title: SEXUAL ABUSE GUIDELINES
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Camden said last week that it would move to defrock any priest found guilty of sexual abuse. The diocese said new guidelines concerning sexual abuse made public last week were stricter than those adopted by a national convention of bishops this summer. The guidelines also call for the removal of priests who withhold information about the sexual abuse of a minor to protect another priest. The guidelines were drawn up by a board whose chairman is the former Camden County prosecutor, Edward F. Borden Jr. Robert Strauss

title: Vanishing Behemoths
description: THEY were the big brothers of the transformers that powered the model trains underneath the Christmas tree. Starting a century ago, 75 thick-walled buildings known as substations began to dot the city, providing the power that made subway trains go. Hidden behind their undistinguished facades were switches, lights and dials that resembled a mad scientist's lab. In the center of each substation was a massive rotating drum that converted electricity from alternating current, like that found in wall outlets, to direct current.
