title: The Myth of '18 to 34'
description: Who says Shakespeare doesn't matter to young people anymore? On a recent episode of ''Gilmore Girls,'' the hourlong flagship drama of the Warner Brothers television network, Rory Gilmore's high school English class performed scenes from the Bard. Rory, cast as Juliet opposite the handsome and frequently suspended Tristan as Romeo, fretted that the heat of their onstage kiss would expose to her current boyfriend, Dean, the fact that Rory had once kissed Tristan at a party when she and Dean were temporarily broken up. Still, the performance had to be convincing, because it counted for 50 percent of her grade. ''People who fail Shakespeare don't get into Harvard,'' admonished the group's alpha female, named Paris -- who, upon seeing that their rehearsal space has not yet been vacated by an adult aerobics class, remarks, ''What's with the cast from 'Cocoon'?''

title: In New York City, Cries of 'Cab, Ahoy!'
description: A private company has recently started a water taxi service in New York City, offering connections between neighborhoods, parks and cultural attractions along the West Side, Lower Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn waterfronts.

title: FRONT LINES: October 6-12; FREEH SPEAKS
description: Ending his silence, Louis J. Freeh, the former F.B.I. director, responded to complaints that he had underestimated the domestic terrorism threat. Testifying before Congress, Mr. Freeh blamed Congress for repeatedly rejecting his requests for more agents. David Johnston

title: NATIONAL: October 6-12; A.D.D. AND THE BRAIN
description: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is linked with slightly smaller brain volume in children and adolescents, researchers reported. The government study found that children with the disorder had brains that were on average 3 percent to 4 percent smaller, as measured on brainscans, than those of children without the condition. Medications commonly used to treat the problem were not the cause of the disparity, the study found. Erica Goode

title: The Sunshine Warrior
description: Paul Wolfowitz believes that the United States can instill democratic values in Iraq using militant and imperialistic means (Bill Keller, Sept. 22)? How can a democracy be planted within an ancient authoritarian tradition, even using a peaceful approach? And Wolfowitz is the intellectual of the group? These refugees from ''Team B'' need serious lessons in reality. Keller sheds light on Wolfowitz's dangerous policies, and I urge everyone who can to protest this administration's fatalistic course against Iraq.

title: Kuwaiti Dedicated Attack That Killed Marine to Qaeda
description: The Kuwaiti leader of an attack that killed an American marine here this week left a videotape indicating that he was a member of Al Qaeda, Kuwait's interior minister said today.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: BRITRAIL OFF PEAK: All BritRail Classic Passes or FlexiPasses bought between Nov. 1 and Feb. 28 for train travel completed by Feb. 28 will be discounted 25 percent. The Classic pass provides unlimited travel on national railways in England, Scotland and Wales in increments of 4, 8, 15 or 22 consecutive days or one month. The FlexiPass provides 4, 8 or 15 days of unlimited travel, distributed at the holder's choice over a two-month period. At the discounted prices, a four-day Classic is $139 in standard class, $224 in first class for adults; a 15-day Classic is $299 standard, and $449 first class. A four-day FlexiPass is $176 in standard, $262 in first class for adults. Passes must be purchased in North America. Information: (877) 677-1066 or www.britrail.com.

title: Addicted to the Flick Of a Mercedes Flint
description: SMOKE screen? Smoke signal? Like many an artist -- and many a smoker -- Tracy Emin is a curious mixture of the self-effacing and the self-promoting. To those familiar with her career in England over the last decade, it may seem that she excels more at the self-promotion, given that the most intimate (that is to say, sexual) details of her life have routinely become fodder for her art. That fact was notoriously illustrated in a 1995 piece, a pup tent appliqud with 102 names titled, bluntly, ''Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 1963-1995.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBERT, RUTH
description: COBERT-Ruth. On October 11, 2002. Beloved mother of Barbara November. Wonderful friend and mother-in-law of David. Adoring grandmother of Tania. Dear wife of the late Edwin Cobert. She leaves many treasured friends. Lover of life, friendship, justice, books, theater and music. She cared about the world and gave with all her being. Retired NYC guidance counselor, impassioned activist of democratic ideals and human rights. Tireless fighter against prejudice and hatred. Defender of Israel. Longtime President, Riverdale American Jewish Congress; VP, AJC Metropolitan Council; Member of AJC National Governing Council. Director, Riverdale Jewish Community Council; Delegate, Jewish Community Relations Council; Executive Board, Riverdale B'nai B'rith; ADL, and The Bronx Riverdale UJA. Activist in the coalition to free Soviet Jewry. Founder of Annual Riverdale Conference on Human Rights. Member of Community Board 8, where she focused on aging, health and social services. Brandeis Women's Group Literature Leader. Recipient of the Riverdale B'nai B'rith Humanitarian Award. She leaves us inspired by her love, compassion and ideals. Service today 2 PM. Riverside Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Tucked away in an otherwise grim report on endangered species last week was news that two humble creatures long thought to have vanished have resurfaced.

title: Obsession
description: You're probably not going to believe this, but I don't have an obsession. I don't dream about Ruhlmann chairs or blue-and-white china, nor do I plan my vacations around the Brimfield antiques fair or a visit to an out-of-the-way stately home. I've never even been (quel horreur!) to the Paris flea markets, but I'd love to hear what you bought there. I may not be obsessed, but I'm grateful for those who are.

Not only has he returned to directing series television this fall with CBS's ''Robbery Homicide Division'' -- the first show he's created for TV since ''Crime Story,'' an epic conflation, and conflagration, of Fassbinder and Chester Gould -- but he's finally become something of an institution as well.

title: Shabana Is Late For School
description: It was heartwarming to see the young women in Susan Dominus's article (Sept.29) yearn for an education. But where are we with our supposed support for their endeavors? The news media, the government, even my friends and neighbors are concentrating on nation-destroying (Iraq), not nation-building (Afghanistan). Please continue to make the public aware of our pledge to rebuild.

title: Bombing at Resort in Indonesia Kills 150 and Hurts Scores More
description: A powerful car bomb detonated in front of a discothque on the popular Indonesian resort island of Bali late last night, killing at least 150 people and wounding more than 200 others, Indonesian and Western officials said.

title: What They Were Thinking

title: QUICK BITE/Bernardsville; A Station Worth a Stop for a Burger
description: In the noble and endless search for that great burger served with crispy fries, one stop should be the town of Bernardsville, and the Station Bar and Grill. No, not the railroad station, although it is across the street. This Station is on the corner of Mine Brook Road (Route 202) and Claremont Road. You enter the 102-year-old building with its fieldstone walls and planked floors, and settle in a booth that might have once held your great-great-grandmother, if your family went back that far in Somerset County. Take a peek into the minuscule kitchen. Large enough for just two people, it is the launch site of the famous Station Burger ($5.75), served with bacon, lettuce, tomato, mayonnaise, raw or fried onions and American or Swiss cheese. A plain burger is $4.50, a cheeseburger with American or Swiss is $4.75, and a cheddar burger is $4.95. But all is not burgers. There is the Invention ($5.50), with house-prepared hot roast beef, American cheese and fried onions between two slices of grilled rye, and the Station Steak Sandwich served with six ounces of sliced top round on a hard roll ($5.75). On the back of the menu are the sides, like a mass of onion rings ($4.25), a large order of fries ($2.75) and cheese fries ($2.50 small). To wash it all down there are beers, soft drinks (pitcher $6.50 ), or coffee or tea ($1). Desserts are not an option, unless you bring your own, and some customers do. Millicent K. Brody

title: On Eve of Debate, Little Action on the Campaign Trail
description: The candidates for governor campaigned quietly yesterday, making few appearances and sticking to familiar themes, as though storing up their energies for the long-awaited debate that is scheduled for today.

description: CLASSES were over for the year, making this second Thursday in May a particularly festive one last spring for the students at Princeton University. The ''street'' was in full swing, with music and bodies bursting from the stately eating clubs that line Prospect Avenue.

description: WALSH-Albert A. The housing community has lost a true giant in the field. His legacy has inspired a generation to share his commitment for decent and affordable housing for New Yorkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEET, JOSEPH MARK
description: SWEET-Joseph Mark. 43, of Minneapolis, MN died suddenly on October 4th 2002. Born on September 13th, 1959 in Hartford CT, Joe grew up in South Windsor. Joe pursued a successful career in advertising for over 20 years, with the multiple award-winning BMW short film series as his most recent creative collaboration. Joe recently wrote, produced and directed a feature length film, ''How To Kill A Mockingbird''. Joe is survived by his wife Germaine Deagan Sweet, parents Julia and Mark Sweet, his brother Jim, his sisters Jennifer Sweet and Susan Warmington and brothers - in - law, Derrik Woodbury and Bill Warmington and nephews Christopher, Teddy and Gus. He will be sadly missed by his aunts, uncles, cousins and many friends. A memorial foundation to award grants to aspiring and independent filmmakers is being established in Joe's name. Contributions may be sent to ''Joe Sweet Film Fund'', 3820 Vincent Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55410.

title: A True Fish Story
description: For years, marine biologists have lamented the alarming decline of commercially important fish species, as well as the terrible toll that pollution, indifferent regulation and overfishing have generally taken on marine life. It is thus encouraging to note a major success story, the striking if still incomplete recovery of North Atlantic swordfish. This is the best news for fish since the striped bass recovery of the late 1980's, and the lesson for future recoveries is much the same: if you leave the fish alone, or at least give them some space, they will repay the effort.

title: A New Musical by Rodgers and Hwang
description: AS a young Chinese-American growing up in Los Angeles in the 1960's, I would go out of my way not to watch movies or television shows featuring Asian characters. If asked to explain, I might simply have replied that they made me feel ''icky.'' They were consistently inhuman: either inhumanly bad (Fu Manchu, Japanese soldiers) or inhumanly good (Charlie Chan, Asian ingnues who died for the love of a white B-movie actor). There was also the cook on ''Bonanza,'' but he didn't exactly qualify as a role model.

title: With Glaus in a Groove, Angels Are Optimistic
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 12  Troy Glaus wasn't caught looking this time. Everybody else was. And what they saw, an opposite-field blast to right in the eighth inning of Game 3 of the American League Championship Series Friday night, was another sign of a maturing player with tremendous potential.

title: Pipeline Dream Sets Backdrop In Alaska Race
description: In a week when every man, woman and child who has lived in Alaska long enough to prove it received a $1,540 check just for hanging around another year, the dreams of yet one more jackpot from the Last Frontier State die hard.

title: More Is More: Repetition Adds Dimension to Patterns
description: 'Accumulations'

title: About the Size of It
description: THE MEASURE

title: Dandelions Pale Next to These
description: ALIEN invaders are nibbling away at the northwest corner of Connecticut. They are also storming the state's wetlands, watersheds and river valleys and making a mess of the forest understory.

title: The Permeable Frontier
description: STEP ACROSS THIS LINE

title: Ancient Tombs In Timeless Landscapes
description: IGNORING the gusty wind, I balanced my camera on the roof of my rented Ford, pressed the self-timer button and ran like crazy. The resulting photo, a little off-center, shows some spidery hedgerows, pastureland and me, arms flung wide in victory as if I were showing off big game, my shadow rippling across a giant granite boulder. What you can't see is that the massive, mottled stone, the color and texture of elephant hide, is actually a capstone sitting atop squat stone legs.

title: Living Large; Sizing Up Teenagers
description: AS much as the fashion industry worships the rail-thin woman, it also believes in making money. And with its sales growing ever smaller and the average teenager growing ever larger, it has begun to make trendy body-conscious clothes for adolescents who idolize Britney, but don't look like her.

title: Lightning Rod on the Seaports
description: JOSEPH MINIACE'S 15 minutes of fame began two Sundays ago -- his 58th birthday -- when he made perhaps the toughest decision of his life, closing 29 West Coast seaports and locking out 10,500 longshoremen.

title: Names Fade From a Street, But Not From Memories
description: The road to freedom still recalls fallen heroes, but their names are fading from the sidewalk.

title: Romanesque Churches in Poitou-Charentes
Sports of The Times; For Giants, a Season Without the Hammer
description: KEITH HAMILTON'S helmet was on its hook. His otherwise empty locker was strewn with a dozen pairs of football shoes, sweat clothes and a pair of headphones. But he was gone.

title: Sharon Calls On Palestinians to Change Their 'Murderous Regime'
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 14  As he prepared to leave Israel for a meeting with President Bush, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon called on Palestinians today to change their "murderous regime," saying that the coming year could be "a year of change."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 3 about the decoding of the malaria parasite's genome and an unrelated graph that day comparing worldwide causes of death by violence and disease showed differing figures for annual deaths from malaria. Statistics for the disease vary widely because records are inadequate. The estimate of 2.7 million annual deaths was the upper range provided by the genome researchers. (That figure was repeated in The Week in Review on Oct. 6.) The World Health Organization gives a more conservative estimate -- 1 million dead a year, most of them children in Africa.

title: 10th Victim Is Recalled As Motivator On Mission
description: Bearing dishes of chicken salad, lasagna and carved turkey, friends and relatives of Kenneth H. Bridges gathered yesterday at his three-story gray stone home in the East Germantown section of Philadelphia.

title: Saints Know How to Welcome a Novice Quarterback
description: The New Orleans Saints' defensive linemen gave the Washington Redskins' rookie quarterback, Patrick Ramsey, a proper welcome to the N.F.L. today. They sacked him seven times and grabbed four interceptions in the Saints' 43-27 victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHLER, THOMAS J.
description: EICHLER-Thomas J. On October 11, 2002. Retired Vice President of Bankers Trust Company. Survived by his loving wife Clare, five children, and three grandchildren.

title: An Underdog for a Change, Harvard Adds to Its Offense
description: Harvard (3-1) will be in the rare position of underdog Saturday against Northeastern, but the Crimson will have a revamped weapon at its disposal.

title: Waiter, Somebody Stole My Wine
description: Diners, beware. Don't lift that spoon. Distrust that soup. Eye waiters suspiciously. Maybe you had better avoid restaurants altogether.

title: Excerpts From the Debate Among the Candidates for Governor
description: Following are excerpts from the debate yesterday among the candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The participants were H. Carl McCall, Democratic Party; Gerard J. Cronin, Right to Life Party; George E. Pataki, Republican Party; Thomas K. Leighton, Marijuana Reform Party; Scott Jeffrey, Libertarian Party; Stanley Aronowitz, Green Party; and Tom Golisano, Independence Party. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: Unknown Colombian Teaches Unexpected Lesson
description: It was not the postfight setting the Olajide family could have envisioned. Tokunbo Olajide, who had been knocked out in the first round yesterday, was being examined by a doctor as his brother, Michael Olajide Jr., and father, Michael Sr., watched with concern.

title: Trends That Worry Some U.S. Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Endeavour's Wake: A Voyage to the 1760's
description: With all the solemn reality shows around, it's nice to see one group flagrantly breaking the rules and having a grand old time.

title: Retreat on Clean Air
description: The Bush administration has taken another step backward in the fight against air pollution. Last week, it joined the automobile industry in a lawsuit charging that a California program encouraging manufacturers to sell cleaner, more fuel-efficient ''hybrid'' vehicles -- cars powered by a combination of gasoline and electricity -- usurped federal authority.

title: White House Keeps a Grip On Its News
description: When he stands before the blue curtain of the White House press briefing area, Ari Fleischer, President Bush's press secretary, often seems downright chummy with reporters as they quiz him about the news of the day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPES, CELIA
description: ZIPES-Celia. Born September 5, 1912, died of complications October 12, 2002. Beloved and adored mother of Phyllis Lakow, Jack Zipes, Richard Zipes, Iris Egan, Gerald Lakow, Carol Dines, Denise Gannon and Robert Egan. Much loved grandmother of Michael and Debra Lakow, Lisa and Daniel Stamatelos, Debra and Eric Dorfman, Wendy and John Hunter, Natasha, Candice, Hanna and Phillip Zipes. Devoted great - grandmother, much loved and always missed.

title: Corrections
description: A rock review on Oct. 2 about a performance in Brooklyn by the band High on Fire at Northsix misstated the date of its previous New York appearance. It was in June, not two years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Group Seeks Prosecutor Oversight
description: A black police officers' group called yesterday for a state law to place prosecutors under independent oversight after doubts about the guilty verdicts in the 1989 Central Park jogger attack. The group, 100 Blacks in Law Enforcement Who Care, said it would send a letter to the State Legislature asking for a permanent panel with subpoena power to review cases after they have gone to trial, said Lt. Eric Adams, left, a spokesman. Five young black and Hispanic men were convicted in the attack. But another man, Matias Reyes, 31, recently said he alone committed the crime, a claim supported by DNA evidence. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: States Forfeit Unspent U.S. Money for Child Health Insurance
description: Large amounts of federal money intended to provide health insurance to children are going unused, federal officials say, even though 8.5 million children are uninsured.

title: Senate Rivals In New Jersey Trade Attacks
description: Calling his Democratic opponent a milquetoast on terrorism and a weakling on national defense, Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican Senate candidate in New Jersey, spent much of the day criticizing Frank R. Lautenberg's record during the 18 years he served in the Senate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an F.B.I. warning to law enforcement agencies to increase their vigilance against terrorist attacks referred incorrectly in some copies to the cause of the alert. (The error also appeared in the headline, in all copies.) It was an audiotape -- not video -- made in recent weeks by a top leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahiri.

title: Old and New Bowie In Every Borough
description: For most of a career that's now in its fourth decade, David Bowie sought to outpace pop, fashion and his own past. He kept sloughing off styles and personas and revamping his music; more than once he declared he would no longer play his older songs. Lately, however, he has been looking back on his achievements and finding them more satisfactory, and with his current album, ''Heathen'' (ISO/Columbia), and on tour this year, he has allowed himself to revisit his strongest music, in which funk and noise battle melodrama.

title: On Windy Day, Radcliffe Breezes to Record
description: In form and fashion, Paula Radcliffe might never be expected to hold the women's world record in the marathon. Her head bobs awkwardly, as if she is always tired and running uphill. And she wears flesh-colored knee socks to support her calf muscles, attire more suitable to a pensioner than an elite runner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIST, VERA
description: LIST-Vera. New York Chapter of Hadassah mourns the passing of Vera List, mother of Olga Mack, a past Chapter President and Special Hadassah friend and supporter. Roberta Yagerman, Pres.

title: 18-Year-Old Wins National Horse Show
description: Maggie Jayne, 18, of Elgin, Ill., defeated a field of 253 qualifiers from 31 states, Canada and Bermuda to win the Equestrian-USA Equitation Medal final at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show in Harrisburg.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Trends That Worry Some U.S. Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Go Full Circle In Blowing This One
description: An unmistakably upbeat air was evident among Giants fans yesterday as they strolled into Giants Stadium. On a gray day, there was a feeling among them that this game against the Atlanta Falcons would wind up bright and just right.

title: INSIDE
description: Third Campaign, First Debate

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Editor's Note

title: Small Organic Farmers Pull Up Stakes
description: A curious thing happened on the way to a national organic standard: the small farmer, once at the heart of the organic movement, got left behind.

title: Immigrant's Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; An Eventful Off-Season Takes Yet Another Twist
description: NOW what, Scott Layden?

title: Market Place; AstraZeneca has won a battle, but its war with generic drug makers is continuing.
description: WHILE AstraZeneca scored a victory on Friday in its battle to keep generic drug makers from undermining its $5.7 billion franchise in Prilosec, the popular ulcer treatment, it was hardly a complete one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, CHRISTINE G.
description: STEVENS-Christine G. On Thursday, October 10th, 2002 of Washington, D.C. Beloved wife of the late Roger L. Stevens. Beloved mother of Christabel Gough. Services are private. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers to honor her memory donations may be made to The Animal Welfare Institute, PO Box 3650, Washington, D.C. 20027. For further information please contact Joseph Gawler and Sons.

title: Mets Awaiting Piniella's Move
description: The Seattle Mariners will most likely grant Lou Piniella's wish to be let out of the remaining year on his contract and are in the initial stages of allowing him to speak to other teams, opening the door for the Mets to begin their pursuit.

title: At Cuba Conference, Old Foes Exchange Notes on 1962 Missile Crisis
description: Dino Brugioni had spent decades poring over every detail from the spy plane photographs of Soviet missiles whose discovery here, 40 years ago this weekend, brought the superpowers to the brink of nuclear holocaust. But today the former Central Intelligence Agency officer learned a few things that had eluded even his careful eye, thanks to none other than Gen. Anatoly Gribkov, who was the Soviet officer who supervised the construction of missile bases in Cuba in 1962.

title: Excerpts From the Interview With H. Carl McCall
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and the Democratic candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times.

title: Sports of The Times; Angels Win for Themselves, and History
description: BEHIND home plate, a fan held up a sign that said: ''Lord, Take Us to the Promised Land.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKOWN, FAYETTA C.
description: McKOWN-Fayetta C. 79 died at Connecticut Hospice in Branford, CT, Saturday, October 12, 2002. Beloved aunt of Kathy McLennan of Old Greenwich, CT, and sister of Elizabeth McCarthy of Wilmington, NC. Retired English teacher at Choate-Rosemary Hall in Wallingford, CT. Remembered fondly by many former students and colleagues. Services later. For information call 203-698-0604.

title: EARLY VOTING PUTS MANY  CANDIDATES IN EARLY OVERDRIVE
description: Election Day may be more than three weeks away. But in supermarkets, libraries, county clerks' offices, shopping center parking lots and mailboxes, Americans have already begun to vote in this midterm election, a phenomenon that is recasting the way campaigns are being conducted in the nation.

title: Publicis to Announce A Reorganization
description: The Publicis Groupe in Paris is expected to announce, perhaps as soon as this week, details of a sweeping reorganization that has been expected since its acquisition of the Bcom3 Group was completed last month, advertising executives who were told about the plans said on Friday.

title: Low Turnout Invalidates the Results of Serbia's Election
description: Weary of political infighting and unsure of which reformist faction to support, more than half the Serbian electorate did not vote in today's presidential election, rendering the result invalid.

title: Economy Lurks Over the Races For Governor
description: Gov. Jim Hodges positively glowed the other day as he and BMW executives announced a $400 million investment in an auto production line near Greenville, where 400 more workers will soon be hired to turn out Z4 roadsters, at wages twice the state's average. But the state's largest newspaper greeted the news by somberly noting that BMW alone could not stanch the flow of jobs from South Carolina.

title: Terrorism Goes Local
description: In the endless media psychoanalysis and police profiling of the random murderer striking fear near the nation's capital, one possibility is rarely mentioned: that the sniper may be a terrorist affiliated with Al Qaeda or otherwise inspired by Osama bin Laden.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Looking for Laughs in the Capital and on a Cruise Ship
description: NO WAY TO TREAT A FIRST LADY

title: It's a Site for the Truly Geeky, And It Even Makes a Few Bucks
description: The front door to the office of Slashdot bears a nerdy little joke. A computer key is glued to the door: ''Enter.'' The other side of the door has an old ''Return'' key.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: County Worker Accused Of Theft
description: A contract worker for the Nassau County Department of Social Services has been arrested on charges that she stole more than $3,000 from welfare recipients, said Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau district attorney. Over at least two months, the authorities said, the worker, Natalie Robinson, 23, duplicated temporary A.T.M. cards that welfare recipients initially receive to collect their cash benefits, then used the duplicates to withdraw cash. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Indonesia Blames Al Qaeda for Bali Bombing
description: BALI, Indonesia, Oct. 14  In the government's most explicit acknowledgment to date that Al Qaeda is operating in Indonesia, the defense minister linked the terrorist group today to a nightclub explosion on Saturday that killed and injured hundreds people on this resort island.

title: Penn Station: A Start
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing in Bali Seen as Opening New Front in Fight on Terror
description: The blast that killed nearly 200 people on the Indonesian resort island of Bali this weekend is a different type of terrorism from what the Bush administration has campaigned against, and will open a new geographic front in that campaign, Western officials said yesterday.

title: Pataki Joins Crowded Field In First Debate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki stood behind his record over two terms yesterday during a debate with six other candidates for governor that offered a range of solutions to New York State's ills -- from cutting taxes to regulating marijuana -- but little opportunity to scrutinize them.

title: RUMSFELD FAVORS FORCEFUL ACTIONS TO FOIL AN ATTACK
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, in a personal set of guidelines for committing forces to combat, wrote that America's leaders must quickly judge when diplomacy has failed, then ''act forcefully, early, during the precrisis period'' to foil an attack on the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAHY, MURIEL G.
description: LEAHY-Muriel G. on October 12, 2002. Beloved daughter of the late Charles and Louise, graduate of Hunter High School and Hunter College, class of 1928. Devoted teacher of speech at William Cullen Bryant High School. Chairperson of the Speech Department at Grover Cleveland High School, Queens, NY. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights, NY, on Monday, 7-9pm and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11am, St. Joan of Arc Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: In a Return Tour at Cond Nast, Mr. Big Seems a Little Less So
description: For much of the 1990's, Ronald A. Galotti hacked a singular path through the New York media. As a general in the Cond Nast publishing empire, Mr. Galotti treated ad sales as an all-out war and took on the prerogatives of the publishing life -- limousines, parties and celebrity -- with stylistic aggression.

title: Conflict in Oslo Over a Pointed Peace Prize
description: The Norwegian Nobel Committee had a problem, the committee's urbane secretary, Geir Lundestad, said this weekend. Its name was James Earl Carter.

title: At an industry gathering, the emphasis is on reasserting the power of brand-name products.
description: THE anxiety among consumer marketers over the sputtering economy was palpable throughout the 2002 annual meeting of the Association of National Advertisers here, as speaker after speaker offered unusually frank admonitions to concentrate scarce corporate resources on reasserting the power of name-brand products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, WALTER
description: WEISS-Walter. On October 12, 2002 at 80 years of age. We mourn the passing of our beloved husband, father, and grandfather. His unique zest for life and 54 year devotion to the ''21 Club'' were unparalleled. He will forever remain in our hearts and will be lovingly remembered. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Tuesday morning October 15, 2002. The Weiss & Mannino Family

title: Attack in Indonesia linked to terrorism : 'Cowardly,' Bush says
description: WASHINGTON:  U.S. and Australian officials Sunday angrily denounced the weekend explosions on Bali as acts of terror, urged the Jakarta government to crack down on possible Al Qaeda allies and cautioned their nationals to avoid the area.

title: Patents; In tense times, making ballistics forensics more accurate by putting tiny bar codes on bullets.
description: BALLISTICS forensics -- the comparison of microscopic markings on bullets or bullet fragments -- has long been a cornerstone of police work. It has helped establish, for example, links among the recent sniper murders in the Washington suburbs.

title: The Specter of a New and Deadlier Smallpox
description: Smallpox, or variola virus, is considered by many doctors to be the pathogen most dangerous to the human species. The virus was eradicated as a natural disease 25 years ago, and is now stored legally at only two sites: in a freezer at the Atlanta headquarters of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and at a Russian government laboratory in Siberia. Research on the virus is being conducted at both sites, but is tightly restricted by the World Health Organization. In 1972, the United States stopped giving routine vaccinations for the virus.

title: Budget Illusions
description: For those who remember the fiscal misery of the 1970's in New York City, it was sobering to hear Mayor Michael Bloomberg and City Council Speaker Gifford Miller agree that the city's current budget crisis -- fueled by a second consecutive $5 billion shortfall -- is likely to get worse. Given the huge predicted gap in the state budget, New Yorkers now have a glimpse of the future, and it's not pretty.

title: New Economy; The intellectual property debate takes a page from 19th-century America.
description: IN the 19th century, the United States was both a rapidly industrializing nation and -- as Charles Dickens, among others, knew all too well -- a bold pirate of intellectual property.

title: Auditors Say U.S. Agencies Lose Track of Billions
description: Year after year, auditors studying the financial records of federal government departments find many of them so disorganized, even chaotic, that the agencies cannot account for tens of billions of dollars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Under Ruling, Prilosec May Still Face Generic Rival

title: Falcons' Understudy Handles the Lead Role With Ease
description: The only thing anyone seemed to know about Doug Johnson was that he wasn't Michael Vick. That he was a three-year starter at the University of Florida, has a strong arm or was once drafted by the Tampa Bay Devil Rays mattered not a bit.

description: To the Editor:
