description: To the Editor:

title: Those Are the Bad Breaks: Suffering a 10 (or Tennyson)
description: When Tennyson demanded ''Break, break, break,'' he might well have been a bridge player studying his trump suit. That gives rise to an interesting question: Is it better to have a bad break in the trump suit or in a significant side suit? There is no clear answer, but the diagramed deal sheds a little light.

title: Debt Sales Are Set For Current Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill being auctioned on Tuesday.

title: The Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYNone

title: Shots Again Fired at United States Forces in Kuwait
description: KUWAIT CITY, Kuwait, Oct. 14  Gunmen fired at American troops in northern Kuwait early today, the United States embassy here said.

title: Act Two: An 'American Idol' Tops the CD Charts
description: Call her Kelly ''Ka-ching'' Clarkson.

title: Bloomberg Says He Does Not Think Homeless Population Has Risen
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he believed that the number of homeless people on the city's streets was holding steady, and possibly declining.

title: Lesser-Knowns Still Detect No Respect
description: Usually, third-party candidates are the ones who say that they are not treated with the respect they deserve.

title: Cancer Vaccine Test Has Promising Result
description: A cancer vaccine developed by Antigenics, a New York biotechnology company, virtually eliminated tumors in 2 of 28 patients with advanced melanoma, a deadly skin cancer, according to the results of a clinical trial in Italy published Saturday in the Journal of Clinical Oncology.

title: In Rumsfeld's Words: Guidelines for Committing Forces
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumseld, as provided by the Department of Defense. The full text can be found online at nytimes.com/international.

title: Format Leaves Little Room For Debate
description: THE political process is important, it really is. It seems wrong to laugh at it, it really does. It also seems impossible not to, when it takes the form of a seven-way debate marked by careful answers, evasions, 10- and 15-second "lightning rounds" and not one focused exchange between the two leading candidates for governor, because a seven-way debate isn't. A debate, that is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBERG, MICHAEL
description: LINDENBERG - Michael. Loving and beloved husband of May. Adored and loving father of Karen Baye (Sumner). Cherished uncle of Marty, Jamie and Matthew and brother-in-law of Sylvia and Harvey Levine. Graveside service Monday, October 14, 2 PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Rosary to Undergo First Change in Centuries, Vatican Says
description: ROME, Oct. 14  Time and again, Pope John Paul II has boldly gone where other popes have not: a synagogue, a ski slope, distant countries with tiny populations.

title: Rumsfeld Favors Forceful Actions to Foil an Attack
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, in a personal set of guidelines for committing forces to combat, wrote that America's leaders must quickly judge when diplomacy has failed, then "act forcefully, early, during the precrisis period" to foil an attack on the nation.

title: War Crimes Court
description: To the Editor:

title: A Devastating Invader Behind Closed Doors; Asian Beetles May Be on Private Property, But Inspectors Often Can't Get In to Check
description: More than half of the estimated five million trees in New York City grow behind walls, guarded by doormen or locked doors. It is the job of Kittzie Gonzalez and Laura Osanitch, inspectors for the United States Department of Agriculture, to check each one for signs of the Asian longhorned beetle, one of the most destructive arboreal pests to reach North America.

title: White House Letter; They Serve the President by Always Staying a Few Steps Ahead of Him
description: At 8:30 yesterday morning in Michigan, a Navy officer responsible for food security for President Bush was already knocking on the hotel room door of Therese Burch, the White House official in charge of preparations for the president's trip to Dearborn today. Mr. Bush actually had no plans to eat the breast of chicken at tonight's political fund-raiser at the Ritz-Carlton (he plans to dine on the way home on Air Force One), but the officer needed to know how to get to the hotel kitchen to oversee the presidential dinner plate just in case Mr. Bush got a spontaneous hunger pang.

title: Many Are Wireless in the South
description: More than half the people in the United States now own a cellphone, according to data from Telephia, a wireless research company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSOW, JEROME M.
description: ROSOW-Jerome M. 82, died October 11, 2002, following heart surgery. Chairman and founder of Work in America Institute in Scarsdale. He committed his life to improving the work lives of all Americans and the productivity of the U.S. economy. Assistant Secretary of Labor 1969-1971. Chair, President's Advisory Committee on Federal Pay 1971-1984. Career in employee relations for Exxon for 24 years in Caracas, London, and New York. President, Industrial Relations Research Association 1979. Director, U.S. Business and Advisory Committee of OECD, Paris. Chairman, European Employee Relations Council. Advisor to the ILO, Geneva. Author on teamwork, labormanagement relations, training, health care, and productivity improvement. A native of Chicago and graduate of the University of Chicago. His greatest joy was his family: Devoted husband and partner of Raye Levin Rosow, father of Michael and Joel, grandfather of Lori, Alison, Chad, and Kyra Rosow and Nick Stableski. A visionary, a patriarch, a loving, giving and supportive man. He is sadly missed. Contributions to Work in America Institute or UJA. Services Monday, 11:00 AM, Ballard-Durand, White Plains.

title: Bush Says 'Pattern of Attacks' Raises Concern About Qaeda
description: WATERFORD, Mich., Oct. 14  President Bush said today that the terror attack in Indonesia last weekend appeared to be the work of Al Qaeda and that the bombing was part of "a pattern of attacks" that included recent violence in Kuwait and Yemen. Taken together, he said, the incidents indicate that Al Qaeda is on the rise and promises to be a continuing threat to the United States.

title: Fresh Start at Covent Garden; Leading the Royal Opera, Unknown but Undaunted
description: Antonio Pappano was 27 when he conducted his first opera, at the Norske Opera in Oslo. Five years later, in 1992, he was named music director of Belgium's main opera house, the Thtre Royal de la Monnaie in Brussels. Now, in a new career leap, he has just taken up the high-profile, high-risk post of music director at the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden.

title: In Rumsfeld's Words: Guidelines for Committing Forces
description: Following is the text of a memorandum, "Guidelines to be Considered When Committing U.S. Forces," written by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumseld in March 2001 and revised as recently as this weekend. This version was provided by the Department of Defense.

title: Playwrights With the Glow of Youth
description: Any playwright can invent a scene about a drug dealer with a collection crisis: two customers who can't pay. But only a very young playwright would think of making the dealer furious about the interruption because he has a test the next morning.

title: Britain Taking Back Political Control of Northern Ireland
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Northern Ireland, Oct. 14  Britain announced today that it was taking back political authority over Northern Ireland, saying it was doing so with regret but saw no other way to preserve a future for the province's elected government that shares power between its Catholic minority and its Protestant majority.

title: Roll-Your-Owns Cut Taxes
description: Dave Eget doesn't do it because it's supposed to be cool. And he certainly doesn't do it because it looks as if he's using marijuana, since he paid for that particular aspect of his habit last spring by having his car searched by the police.

title: Free to Smoke, Forced to Cough
description: To the Editor:

title: ESPN Brings Video Clips To High-Speed Net Users
description: The sports Web site ESPN.com plans to introduce a free video-clip service to high-speed Internet users in the next few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  XENIA, ROSE
description: XENIA-Rose. Celebrate having been blessed by having known her. October 16th, 5PM. Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street.

title: Ever-Changing Modern Music, Controlled by a Cursor
description: Giovanni Gabrieli was among the first to compose music for a specific space. The works he wrote for St. Mark's Cathedral in Venice, where he became an organist in 1585, often incorporated call-and-response passages that made dramatic use of the balconies arrayed around the mammoth church. Four centuries later the English composer Sam Hayden and a team of artistic collaborators have boldly created music for a new kind of space: a Web site on the Internet. ''3D Music,'' an interactive orchestral work written specifically for the vast expanse of cyberspace, makes its debut today at www.ntlworld.com/3dmusic.

title: Another German Publisher Mulls Its Wartime Past
description: Over the last five years, while a group of independent scholars conducted a very public investigation into the Nazi-era history of Bertelsmann, the German media conglomerate, another prominent German publisher has been quietly exhuming its own wartime past.

title: Stress and Joy of Concert Recording
description: The adventurous San Francisco Symphony is one of a small group of orchestras that have decided to bypass the struggling major recording companies and produce their own CD's, drawn from live performances. In general this is a great idea. The San Francisco Symphony, on its SFS Media label, has already had a solid success with its live recording of Mahler's Sixth Symphony, the first installment of a planned survey of the complete Mahler symphonies conducted by the music director, Michael Tilson Thomas, to which a Mahler First has recently been added.

title: Details on Abbey Deal
description: The Bank of Ireland is expected to publish details this week of its offer to buy Abbey National, the large British bank, in an effort to win the support of Abbey's shareholders after the bank's management rejected the bid last week as too low.

title: Authorities, Deluged With Sniper Tips, Set Up Post Office Box
description: The authorities investigating the sniper shootings in the Washington area offered a new way for people to communicate with them about the case today  a post office box number.

title: Issues in Search of a Campaign
description: Rarely has the mood of American voters been as inscrutable as in the current election cycle. What issues will the midterm election turn on: a new war with Iraq, the war on terrorism, a sagging economy, a stock market boom gone bust, one of the biggest business scandals in American history, or the old domestic agenda lost in the fog of the shattering events of the past 13 months?

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP: MAULING RENEWS FOCUS ON TIGER PRESERVE A tiger attack that left a man hospitalized has brought renewed scrutiny to the Tigers Only Preservation Society. The injured man, the husband of Joan Byron-Marasek, who opened the compound in 1976, was in stable condition last night at the Jersey Shore Medical Center's surgical intensive care unit. Jan Marasek, 70, was bitten on his upper left arm and suffered head injuries as he fed the tigers Friday afternoon. State wildlife officials determined the compound's 24 tigers were all accounted for. Ms. Byron-Marasek was under orders to close the facility after a Bengal tiger that had been found roaming the nearby woods was shot and killed by authorities in 1999. But the orders have been tied up in court. Judge Eugene D. Serpentelli of Superior Court was notified of Friday's attack and has set an Oct. 25 hearing.   (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAHAM, JAMES A., SR.
description: GRAHAM-James A., Sr. On October 10, 2002. Beloved husband of Alice (nee Dietz). Retired Leasing Specialist for the Office of Legislative Service in New Jersey and previously Vice President in the Real Estate Division of Chemical Bank. For information, please call Par-Troy Funeral Home (973)887-3235.

title: Just Cuddle Up With a Novel And Read a Movie
description: In a dozen short silent movies in the 1920's, Hector Mann was uproariously comic as a dapper man of the world who is a magnet for bad luck. As Paul Auster writes in his new novel, ''The Book of Illusions,'' ''Doors slam on his fingers, bees sting him on the neck, statues fall on his toes, but again and again he shrugs off his misfortunes and continues on his way.''

title: This Week
description: Art of Terpsichore

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A huge, massive flame erupted from the floor like a volcano.''

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 26 about Bob Wallace, a software pioneer who was an early Microsoft employee, referred incorrectly to the file retrieval and editing system, or Fress, a 1960's software development project at Brown University in which he was involved. The software researcher Ted Nelson, who coined the term ''hypertext,'' was not involved in the Fress project, and his coinage predated the Fress effort.

title: Officials Say 2 Men Scaled Fence And Took Snapshots at the U.N.
description: For the second time in 10 days, security at the United Nations was breached early yesterday, when two men from Long Island climbed over a fence at the complex -- apparently to take each other's photographs -- the authorities said.

title: Free to Smoke, Forced to Cough
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Venture in Korea
description: The General Motors consortium that is taking over the three key Korean plants of bankrupt Daewoo Motors acquired a strategic partner in China today in the form of the state-owned Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation.

title: Stephen Ambrose, Historian Who Fueled New Interest in World War II, Dies at 66
description: Stephen E. Ambrose, the military historian and biographer whose books recounting the combat feats of American soldiers and airmen fueled a national fascination with the generation that fought World War II, died yesterday at a hospital in Bay St. Louis, Miss. Mr. Ambrose, who lived in Bay St. Louis and Helena, Mont., was 66.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ELINOR LEE
description: FRIEDMAN-Elinor Lee. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Murry Friedman, adored mother of Amy, Betsy, Geri & Nancy. Cherished grandmother and mother-in-law. Died peacefully on October 10th in Longboat Key. She will be in our hearts forever. Contributions in her memory may be made to Habitat for Humanity.

title: Bowden Waiting for Law of Averages to Kick In
description: A day after seeing a failed late field-goal attempt dash his team's chance to defeat Miami -- the fourth time a missed kick has foiled his Florida State squad against the Hurricanes since 1991 -- Coach Bobby Bowden was asked where Saturday's 28-27 loss ranked among his toughest defeats.

title: New Campaigns Section Introduced
description: Dear Readers,

title: Survivors of Indonesia Blast Are Left Stunned and Searching
description: In the dark and the screaming chaos, said one survivor today, it was sometimes hard to know whether the man who appeared to be running toward him through the flames was alive or already dead.

title: Editorial Observer; Policing a Fine, Porous Line Across the Perilous West Desert Corridor
description: It's a 40-mile walk across some of the world's most oppressive desert landscape from the Mexican border to the patch of desert near the highway where the Border Patrol chopper hovered above the exhausted group of young men. The 21 Mexicans pursuing the American dream -- the $5-an-hour version -- had almost made it.

title: Remember the Dead, Celebrate the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Columbus Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Glamorous Chameleon, Catching All the Nuances
description: As a chamber ensemble conducted by Andrew Lippa played a fragment of ''Glitter and Be Gay,'' Kristin Chenoweth sashayed onto the stage of the John Jay College Theater on Friday evening looking like Botticelli's Venus. Wearing a spangled powder-blue gown slit to the hip, her blond hair cascading down her back, this diminutive Broadway singer (''You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown'') from Broken Arrow, Okla., was every inch the modern screwball glamour girl.

title: With New Stadium, St. John's Has Lofty Ranking
description: It is 7:15 a.m. and the drivers on Union Turnpike are already getting aggressive -- they are on the offensive, fighting for every inch and straining to shave precious seconds off their daily commutes.

title: This Time, Santiago Provides the Drama
description: Benito Santiago turned on Rick White's pitch in the eighth inning tonight and twisted his body, slowly backpedaling as he moved up the first-base line. The crowd at Pacific Bell Park roared, then quieted with confusion and finally came to life again, increasing its volume as Cardinals left fielder Eli Marrero made his way to the left-field wall.

title: In Letter to Sharon, U.S. Criticizes Killing of Civilians
description: In a message to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon before his planned visit to Washington this week, the Bush administration has criticized Israel for killing Palestinian civilians during its military operations and for maintaining crippling restrictions on movement in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: 2 Publishers May Revive Biographies
description: Atlas Books and HarperCollins Publishers are in talks to revive a series of minibiographies that married famous authors with famous subjects -- like Mary Gordon with Joan of Arc or Garry Wills with St. Augustine.

title: At the Heart of a Nuclear Power Plant Ticks a Pitchman's Soul
description: Give him a chance, and Fred Dacimo will try to convince you that the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant is not so bad. He will tell you that it generates power for hospitals and police stations, not to mention your air-conditioner on hot, sweaty days.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an F.B.I. warning to law enforcement agencies to increase their vigilance against terrorist attacks referred incorrectly in some copies to the cause of the alert. (The error also appeared in the headline, in all copies.) It was an audiotape  not video  made in recent weeks by a top leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahiri.

title: E-Commerce Report; Complications with cookies arise over privacy policies that don't mesh.
description: AS more people adopt the latest version of Microsoft's market-dominant Internet Explorer Web browser, its privacy features are creating unintended consequences for users, information publishers and advertisers.

title: For the Homeless, a Haven Becomes Less Sure
description: On the wide front lawn at City Hall, dozens of homeless people gather in an orderly, patient line every Saturday morning for a modest meal, provided free by a church group and a small cadre of cheerful volunteers.

title: Eddie Hausner, 76, Who Held Lens to the News for Decades
description: Eddie Hausner, a photographer for The New York Times whose subjects over a five-decade career ranged from poor people in the South to Joe Namath with a white llama rug, died on Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 76 and lived in Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Free to Smoke, Forced to Cough
description: To the Editor:

title: James Searles, 90, a Master of Lightning-Fast Checkers
description: James Searles, who elevated the lightning-fast form of checkers played mainly by black men in barbershops, parks and sidewalks to the province of an exclusive if distinctly clamorous society -- the Brooklyn Elite Pool Checker Club -- died in Brooklyn on Oct. 5. He was 90.

title: In Rumsfeld's Words: Guidelines for Committing Forces
description: Following is the text of a memorandum, "Guidelines to be Considered When Committing U.S. Forces," written by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumseld in March 2001 and revised as recently as this weekend. This version was provided by the Department of Defense.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about gifts received by Bill and Hillary Clinton during the Clinton presidency included an erroneous identification, from a list supplied to congressional investigators by the Clinton White House, for the donor of a Navajo chief's blanket. It came from Laurance S. Rockefeller; Larry Rockefeller is his son.

title: World Donors Praise Kabul's Budget and Development Plans
description: The Afghan government won a resounding endorsement from international donors today for its budget and development plan to lift Afghanistan out of destitution and work toward self-sufficiency, positioning it well to win badly needed long-term assistance.

title: TXU Europe at Risk of Losing Cash Infusion
description: TXU, the former Texas Utilities, is poised to withdraw a promised $700 million lifeline to its troubled European subsidiary, people close to the company said today.

title: Endless Frustration But Little Evidence In Search for Sniper
description: It is a migraine of a manhunt. It is the frantic, intensifying search here for a nimble killer, the serial sniper who leaves investigators with almost nothing to go on but requires that they be almost everywhere.

title: Remember the Dead, Celebrate the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Oct. 3 about Reed Brody, who oversees investigations at Human Rights Watch, misstated the year that Chad's former dictator, Hissne Habr, the subject of one case, was arrested for murders and torture. It was 2000, not 1990.

title: The Outer Limits of Optimism; How AOL's Sunny Forecasts Outshined the Gloomy Facts
description: Six months after America Online bought Time Warner, the merged company's top executives rejected arguments from its chief financial officer that they should back down from their ambitious promises to Wall Street, three senior executives involved in the company's deliberations now say.

title: Glass Slipper Fits the Angels at Last
description: It took 42 years of revisions and rewrites, piles of crumpled paper by the trash can. The original owner, the movie star Gene Autry, never quite made it work. The next owner, the Walt Disney Company, never got its Hollywood ending. Hearts were broken, curses were blamed. But something happened on the way to oblivion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, JAMES DAVID
description: ABELES-James David. Age 86 of Basking Ridge, NJ on October 9, 2002. Beloved husband of Mary Elizabeth (Campbell) Abeles, devoted father of Elizabeth Kirkland Heald, grandfather of two and step-grandfather of four. He was predeceased by first wife Elizabeth Brunet Abeles and his son James Brunet Abeles. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:00 AM on Wednesday, October 16, 2002 in St. Bernards Episcopal Church, Claremont Road, Bernardsville. Memorial contributions can be made to the College of the Atlantic, Eden Avenue, Bar Harbor, ME 04609.

title: McDyess's Knee Injury Buckles The Knicks
description: His rousing dunks and prodigious rebounding had created an optimism that not even the craziness of the Latrell Sprewell saga could diminish. The Knicks might be good after all, went the thinking, what with Antonio McDyess dominating the frontline like a czar.

title: Crisis Comes Early For Rangers' Trottier
description: Three games into their season, the Rangers have already reached a critical point. The euphoria from their 4-1 season-opening triumph at Carolina on Wednesday night seems like ancient history after consecutive losses by a combined score of 10-1 on Friday and Saturday nights.

title: LL Cool J Tries to Find A Way Back
description: LL Cool J kept announcing, ''I'm back!'' when he performed at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Wednesday night. He didn't have to tell a room packed mostly with women.

title: Illinois Moves to Center Of Death Penalty Debate
description: It has been 25 years since Illinois re-established the death penalty. It has been almost three since exonerations based on DNA evidence prompted Gov. George Ryan to halt executions. Six months have passed since a commission called for a sweeping overhaul of the state's capital punishment system.

title: London Journal; A Word-Slinging Spat, Invoked by Stalin's Sins
description: Are the sins of the left commensurate with those of the right? Is it just to speak of Stalin's evil in the same breath as Hitler's? Have two gilded Englishmen -- author and polemicist, novelist and activist -- fallen terminally from each other's favor over these heady and tormented questions?

title: Shining on Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: College Football: Wrapup; MONDAY MORNING QUARTERBACK
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Free to Smoke, Forced to Cough
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats in Bronx Assembly Primary Gear Up Again
description: By lunchtime one recent afternoon, Assemblywoman Carmen E. Arroyo had already greeted subway riders at dawn, pumped the hands of parents taking their children to school and visited three senior centers in the Bronx. She went on to walk door-to-door in several apartment buildings, and then returned to the subway stations in the evening.

title: 'Whatever Works' Is Working for Devils
description: After two games, many of the preseason concerns about the Devils have come true: their revamped offense has struggled, their power play is almost punchless and the low expectations were reflected in the thousands of empty seats in the Devils' home and road openers.

title: Australia Waits, Fearing a High Death Toll
description: Australians long thought their geography guarded them from international terrorism. They woke on Sunday to find they were not immune.

title: The Troubles in Ulster Shift From Street to the Assembly
description: Jas Mooney is the son of a Belfast man whose pub was bombed repeatedly in the 30 years before the 1998 Northern Ireland peace agreement, when sectarian violence took on such a sense of permanence in this society that it was referred to simply as The Troubles.

title: Golisano to Take to Airwaves To Condemn Rockefeller Laws
description: Staking out a far more sweeping position on the Rockefeller drug laws than either of his opponents in the race for governor, Tom Golisano will call today for the laws' repeal, his campaign aides said.

title: Pataki Joins Crowded Field in First Debate
description: Gov. George E. Pataki stood behind his record over two terms yesterday during a debate with six other candidates for governor that offered a range of solutions to New York State's ills  from cutting taxes to regulating marijuana  but little opportunity to scrutinize them.

title: Metro Matters; Format Leaves Little Room For Debate
description: THE political process is important, it really is. It seems wrong to laugh at it, it really does. It also seems impossible not to, when it takes the form of a seven-way debate marked by careful answers, evasions, 10- and 15-second ''lightning rounds'' and not one focused exchange between the two leading candidates for governor, because a seven-way debate isn't. A debate, that is.

title: World Series Summary
description: Game 1

title: CBS to Present New Faces And Format for 'Early Show'
description: After months of planning, CBS News is expected to announce as soon as today a new format and hosts for ''The Early Show,'' the morning news program that started with so much promise three years ago but did not live up to network and advertiser expectations.

title: Benes's Exit Opens La Russa to Critics
description: Three times in the previous six years, Tony La Russa directed the St. Louis Cardinals to the playoffs but could not maneuver them into the World Series. They're here again this year, but as a result of managerial strategy gone awry, La Russa and the Cardinals are only one loss away from making it four times in seven years.

title: Injuries and Miscues Send the Giants Reeling
description: Michael Strahan knocked the ball from the hands of Atlanta quarterback Doug Johnson early in the first quarter today, and as Brandon Short reached for the recovery, he could not have known that he was really pursuing a twist of fate. He could not have known how this game -- how the Giants' season -- would veer on this play, the first wobble before the wreck.

title: Favre Leaves the Patriots Twisting in the Wind
description: Brett Favre has spent his professional life making defenses do what they do not want to, forcing them into awkward positions, like a puppeteer yanking on strings.

title: Twins Are Stopped, But Oh, What a Run
description: The three Minnesota outfielders gathered in center field seconds after watching little Adam Kennedy play Barry Bonds for a memorable afternoon by smashing his third homer yesterday, their body language telling the sad, stunning story of a game that would end the Twins' glorious season. Slumped shoulders, hands on hips, heads shaking, minds surely drifting.

title: Police Limit Briefings, Fearing They Aid Sniper
description: Leaders of the manhunt for the suburban sniper have decided to tone down their news media presence amid concern that the gunman might be taking cues and encouragement from multiple daily police news conferences.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEIN, JOSEPH
description: STEIN-Joseph. October 13, 2000. Dad, in loving remembrance of your second birthday in heaven. Love, Mom and the kid

title: Remember the Dead, Celebrate the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: McMurray, Another Rookie, Wins Winston Cup Race
description: The youth movement that has emerged in Nascar's Winston Cup series over the past few seasons has a new champion to add to its ranks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEW, EMIL
description: LOEW-Emil. Society of American Magicians (PA #

title: The Need for Pediatric Drug Tests
description: The Senate will have a chance this week to push ahead with legislation that would require all drugs to be tested for safety and efficacy in children, not just in adults. This is the kind of worthy but narrow legislation that can easily get lost at the end of a session that is already running behind schedule and has been focused in recent weeks on a possible war with Iraq. As they struggle to catch up with overdue appropriations bills and other pending measures, senators need to speed the pediatric drug testing bill on to the House in a form that can readily win passage this session.

title: Times's Ranking Leaves Many Mystified
description: According to the news media members who vote in the Associated Press poll and the coaches who vote in the USA Today/ESPN poll, No. 1 Miami and No. 2 Oklahoma are on a collision course toward the Fiesta Bowl on Jan. 3 in Tempe, Ariz. -- an everything-in-the-kitty, $26 million donnybrook between two of the nation's college football superpowers.

title: Challenge in Copyright Case May Be Just a Beginning
description: At 11:01 a.m. last Wednesday, at the conclusion of the Supreme Court arguments over the constitutionality of a law that extended copyrights for 20 years, the statute's challengers knew they had not scored a decisive victory.

title: 'Where Are the Sopranos?' Is Refrain at Bronx Parade
description: There was something bothering Charlie Romano yesterday about the mayor, the parade and the Mafia television show.

title: Only the Pitiable Are Invited to a Party Given by Do-Gooders
description: The early part of the Off Broadway season has been plentiful in resurrections, that is, revisits to plays assumed dead, or at least buried. None, however, have been dredged up from deeper in obscurity than ''The Charity That Began at Home,'' which was written in 1906 and has never been seen before in New York. The Mint Theater Company -- which is responsible for its worthwhile exhumation and worthy reanimation, directed by Gus Kaikkonen -- says the play hasn't been seen anywhere since an English production in 1917.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Bombing in Bali
description: A massive bomb attack outside a nightclub in Bali killed more than 180 people Saturday night.

title: Recurring Nightmares
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASSAEL, BERNARD
description: ASSAEL-Bernard. The Officers and Members of The New York Skirt and Sportswear Association, Inc. record with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard Assael, esteemed Board Member and Officer for many years. To the bereaved family, we extend our heartfelt sympathy.

title: Cuomo and McCall Assail Pataki at Parade
description: Andrew M. Cuomo returned to the campaign trail yesterday with his former Democratic Party rival, H. Carl McCall, to accuse Gov. George E. Pataki of dodging one-on-one debates and failing to specify plans for a third term.

title: Quick Tax Relief for an Ailing Economy
description: Three weeks before Election Day, most American households are still mired in recession. The American economy lost 43,000 jobs in September, the biggest drop since last February. Many people who were looking for jobs last year have given up. The ratio of jobs to potential workers continues to drop. Meanwhile, take-home pay is going nowhere; last year median household income dropped for the first time in a decade. Workers dependent on overtime, commissions or bonuses are watching paychecks shrivel. And ever-bigger portions of their paychecks are going for health insurance -- single coverage is up an average of 27 percent from last year, family coverage up 16 percent.

title: New Jersey Plans Merger Of Universities
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today endorsed a sweeping reorganization of the state university system that would consolidate its research universities, including Rutgers, and establish three largely independent campuses.

title: Abducted a Lifetime Ago, 5 Japanese Come Home for a Visit
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15  Speaking rusty Japanese, sporting red North Korean flag lapel pins and looking older than their years, five middle-aged Japanese men and women stepped off an airplane today and into a Japan they had not known in a quarter of a century.

title: F.B.I. Aids Pakistan in Arrest of 4 Afghans Linked to Qaeda
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 15  The Pakistani police, accompanied by F.B.I. agents, arrested four Afghan men suspected of ties to Al Qaeda in a refugee camp near the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said today.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Cleveland; Working To Regroup Around Technology
description: Built on the steel, auto and chemical industries, Cleveland thrived through the 1950's -- and dived in the 1970's. A private-public partnership to revive the city brightened parts of downtown by adding three sports stadiums and two museums, resurrecting shopping and converting warehouses into lofts. But that revival has been staggered by the loss of some corporate sponsors and the humbling of others.

title: A Green Foothold in the Downtown Concrete; Apartment High-Rise Will Set an Environmental Benchmark Near Ground Zero
description: In the nerdy world of green construction, 20 River Terrace was already an address with a big reputation -- even before everything changed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE - Frances. Happy nineth birthday in heaven, Grandma. Love, Michae

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, MARJORIE
description: FEINBERG - Marjorie. Be loved wife of the late William, treasured mother of Anne (Arnold) Kopelson and Barry (Patricia Thayer) Feinberg, adored grandmother of Benjamin and Gabriel Feinberg, Peter, Evan and Stephanie Kopelson, loving sister of Harry (Hannah) Ostrow, Sol Ostrow, Mina Ostrow and Loretta Grant. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to University Synagogue, 11960 Sunset Boulevard, Los Angeles, CA. 90049.

title: Al Qaeda Evolves Into Looser Network, Experts Say
description: Since the rout of Al Qaeda last year in Afghanistan, intelligence and law enforcement officials in the United States and elsewhere have been forced to redefine their thinking about the organization and the threat it represents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  XENIA, ROSE
description: XENIA-Rose. Celebrate having been blessed by having known her. October 16th, 5PM. Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street.

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: The Need to Know Who, What, Where and When
description: ABOUT halfway through her 12-hour day shift Saturday, Jennifer Barnabee picked up the first indication there was trouble brewing in Indonesia.

title: Sharon Urges Palestinians to Replace 'Murderous Regime'
description: As he prepared to leave Israel for a meeting with President Bush, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon called on Palestinians today to change their ''murderous regime,'' saying the coming year could be ''a year of change.''

title: An Effort to Undo an Old Reservoir
description: An old black and white photograph hangs behind the bar at the Evergreen Lodge, a rustic roadside establishment just outside this park. It shows wildflowers dancing in the thick grass. A river glides between a pair of imposing granite walls.

title: Particulars Slow Compromise On Extension of Welfare Law
description: Facing an impasse on welfare, Congress is weighing a three-year extension of the existing program, with tougher work requirements and more money for child care, lawmakers and Bush administration officials said today.

title: Christine Stevens, 84, a Friend to the Animals
description: Christine Stevens, who devoted her life to protecting all creatures -- elephants, whales and laboratory animals -- died last Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital. She was 84 and lived in Washington, where she was a leader of social life.

title: Big Question About Smallpox: What if . . . ?
description: One recent Saturday at the gym, Dr. William Schaffner looked around at all the other sweaty people working out and playing basketball in tank tops. What would happen, he wondered, if some of them had recent smallpox vaccinations? What if sweat made the dressings fall off their vaccinations and they brushed up against other people?

title: Wolpe at 100, Still Full of Ideas and Anger
description: The season-long celebration of Stefan Wolpe, in honor of his centenary, got off to an exhilarating start with four programs at Merkin Concert Hall last weekend. They were stuffed with rarities, from among Wolpe's works and those of his forebears, pupils and colleagues.

title: A Look Deep Into Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, ROSE
description: SEGAL-Rose. Of Teaneck, New Jersey on October 11, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Cherished mother of Howard W. Segal, Elinor Hirsch and the late Norman H. Segal. Devoted mother-inlaw of Robert, Ronnee, and Gail. Loving grandmother of Karen, Elizabeth, Eric, Jeffery, Stephanie, Phoebe, Alexis and Sophie. Great-grandmother of Ethan, Jaime and Rachel. Longtime friend of Bernice Young. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant''. Contributions to ''The Jack Segal Fund'', JCC on the Palisades, Tenafly, New Jersey.

title: Buenos Aires aims to cut dropout rate
description: BUENOS AIRES  In an attempt to halt a steep decline in educational standards and a massive dropout rate from high schools, the city of Buenos Aires in September became the first region in Latin America to make at least 12 years of education compulsory for all.

title: Facing Budget Gap, McCall Says All Areas of Spending Could Face Trims
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller and the Democratic candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: Deutsch Is Named to Lamisil Account
description: Novartis Pharmaceuticals in East Hanover, N.J., has named Deutsch in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies , to handle the account of Lamisil, a drug for toenail fungus. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Operator Chosen For .Org Domain
description: The group that oversees the Internet's address system has selected the Internet Society as the future operator of the .org domain. The Internet Society was chosen out of 11 bids to take over responsibility for .org addresses from VeriSign, which agreed to relinquish .org at the end of 2002 as part of an agreement allowing the company to continue managing the lucrative .com domain. The Internet Society, a nonprofit organization involved in developing technology standards for the Internet, has established a separate nonprofit organization, the Public Interest Registry, to serve as the .org operator beginning Jan. 1, 2003. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Traffic Cameras Could Be Pressed Into Duty to Help Criminal Investigators
description: It may seem impossible to pick out a serial killer roaming the highways of a sprawling metropolitan region, but the task is far from hopeless.

title: With West Nile, Few Are Banking Their Blood
description: The discovery that West Nile virus can be transmitted by donated blood has not radically changed the behavior of people who expect to need transfusions, blood bank officials say.

title: Inquiry Into Suspected Ukraine-Iraq Deal
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 14  Teams of British and American military investigators in several Ukrainian regions opened a formal inquiry today into charges that Ukraine may have sold sophisticated air-defense radars to Iraq two years ago in defiance of a United Nations embargo.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Case of Agent 007 And Metal-Toothed Worm

title: Police Tie Killing of Virginia Woman to 8 Others by Sniper
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Oct. 15  This time the roving sniper left more clues, with a number of witnesses getting a better, more chilling glimpse of him and his getaway van as they looked beyond his latest victim bleeding to death on the parking garage floor.

title: Announcing Teams Are Vastly Different
description: Among the many qualitative differences between Fox's American and National League Championship Series announcing teams is how each one uses baseball history.

title: HEAD OF DRUG RESEARCH COMPANY ASKS TO BUY IT
description: The chairman of the Quintiles Transnational Corporation offered yesterday to buy the company, a provider of drug research and marketing, for about $1.3 billion. The chairman, Dennis Gillings, bid $11.25 a share, or about 35 percent more than the stock's closing price of $8.31 on Friday. Mr. Gillings controls about 5.5 percent of the company's shares. The company's stock price has fallen almost half this year as sales slowed. Some investors said the bid was too low because Mr. Gillings might be able to use the cash of Quintiles to help finance the transaction. Mr. Gillings has formed a company, Pharma Services, to acquire Quintiles. Pharma Services has a commitment for debt financing and is discussing equity financing, Quintiles said. Shares of Quintiles rose $1.65, or 20 percent, to $9.96 a share.

title: Excerpts From Candidate's Old Columns
description: Following are excerpts from columns written by Douglas R. Forrester for The West Windsor-Plainsboro Chronicle, a weekly newspaper.

title: CONTRACTOR FOR ENERGY INDUSTRY CUTS PROFIT FORECAST
description: The Shaw Group, a construction company for the energy industry, cut its profit forecast for this fiscal year yesterday as power-plant owners cancel and delay projects. Earnings in fiscal 2003 will be $1.92 to $2.08 a share, down from a forecast of $2.72 to $3, Shaw said. The company gave the reduced forecast after reporting that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose 62 percent, helped by the acquisition in May of the IT Group. Power companies accounted for 71 percent of Shaw's revenue last year. Shaw, based in Baton Rouge, La., said the IT Group does environmental cleanup for the federal government.

title: Columbus Day Parade Goes On, as Mayor and Sopranos Dine in the Bronx
description: The Columbus Day Parade crawled up a brilliantly sunny, crisp Fifth Avenue like a society dinner, with fine music and fabulous gowns, and hearty disparagement of people who were not there.

title: Costs of Health Benefits Are Seen Rising by 15%
description: The cost of health benefit plans at big companies will rise more than 15 percent next year on average, according to a study by Hewitt Associates Inc., a private human resources consulting firm.

title: Consumer Groups Accuse U.S. of Negligence on Food Safety, Leading to Meat Recalls
description: Consumer and environmental groups blamed the Bush administration today for the nation's largest meat recall, saying the administration had failed to set adequate safety standards for the meat industry. Officials at the Agriculture Department flatly denied the accusation.

title: Tunnel Vision; Feel a Breeze? See the Mice? Ah, the Train Is on Its Way.
description: If you are standing on a subway platform in London or Barcelona or Washington and wondering when the next train will arrive, there is generally no great effort involved in finding out: look up at the colorful screens, the ones that want you to have a nice day, and watch as the electronic seconds count down to your ride.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: OPERATOR CHOSEN FOR .ORG DOMAIN The group that oversees the Internet's address system has selected the Internet Society as the future operator of the .org domain. The Internet Society was chosen out of 11 bids to take over responsibility for .org addresses from VeriSign , which agreed to relinquish .org at the end of 2002 as part of an agreement allowing the company to continue managing the lucrative .com domain. The Internet Society, a nonprofit organization involved in developing technology standards for the Internet, has established a separate nonprofit organization, the Public Interest Registry, to serve as the .org operator beginning Jan. 1, 2003.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Auto Venture
description: Hyundai Motor says it is teaming with Beijing Automotive Industry Holding to begin producing cars in China. Although Beijing Automotive is the partner, the products will be Hyundai Sonatas and Elantras. Hyundai, Korea's dominant manufacturer of motor vehicles, plans to produce 2,000 cars in China by the end of this year and 500,000 a year by 2010. After an initial $100 million investment, Hyundai said, it will eventually pour in more than $1 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: South Africa struggles to offer quality education to blacks : Nurturing 'expectations in life'
description: UMTATA, South Africa  Every Friday afternoon pupils at the Mandela Park Junior Primary School pack up their textbooks and chalkboards and move their desks and chairs into the corner of the room. That's because the school, established six years ago by residents of a nearby squatter camp, has no permanent facilities and holds classes in two agricultural halls that are used for other purposes on weekends.

title: From Plays To Fiction: Thanks, Dad; Sam Shepard's Rascals Are Inspired by Memories Of a Mysterious Father
description: Arriving in New York, Sam Shepard looked, as always, like a cowboy in the city, someone who would prefer to be home on his farm in Minnesota. On this particular day, however, he seemed relaxed and in a salutary mood. He was here not as a playwright or actor, but in a less familiar role as a writer of fiction. He has a new book, ''Great Dream of Heaven,'' a collection of short stories. In common with his plays, these are tales from the frontier of his imagination, richly populated by rascals and renegades.

title: Before Adam and Eve, the Farmers Were Termites
description: Sometime, perhaps about 50 million years ago, farming was invented. Not by human beings of course, but by ants, termites and beetles, each of which developed forms of fungi gardening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, ROBERT T.
description: MADDEN-Robert T. Husband of Michelle. Father of Robert, Joshua, Mark, Melissa, the late Richard (WTC, Sept. 11, 2001). Brother of Richard, the late MaryCarolyn Ewald and James. Grandfather of three. Reposing McNamara, 460 Washington St., Brighton, MA. Mass on Wednesday, at 10 A.M. St. Ignatius Church, Chestnut Hill, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, RUTH KLEINBERG NEE SEIDENBERG
description: VOGEL-Ruth Kleinberg nee Seidenberg of Lauderhill, FL. Devoted mother of Barbara Freed. Loving grandmother of Shawn Frankel. Cherished great-grandmother of Jack and Griffin. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' Tuesday, 2 PM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemtery, Queens. For info: 800-322-0533.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Equipment For the North
description: South Korea has agreed to provide the North with $25 million in equipment and supplies for clearing mines and then building rail and road links on the North Korean side of the military demarcation line down the center of the four-kilometer-wide demilitarized zone between the two Koreas. South and North Korea agreed last month on a timetable for rebuilding road and rail links destroyed in the Korean War. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Indonesia Stocks Fall 10%; Others in Asia Off Modestly; Severe Tourism Losses Seen
description: The explosions on Saturday night in Bali set back financial markets across the region today, and brought warnings for increased security around production sites and tankers for the oil and gas industry that is the mainstay of Indonesia's already tottering economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADUE, RUSSELL MORSBY
description: LaDUE-Russell Morsby. On October 14, 2002. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. His sweet nature, intelligence, love of life, gentle good humor and genuine affection for others, made Russ an adored figure to all who knew him. The family will be home to visitors from 4 PM-8 PM Wednesday, October 16th and Thursday, October 17th. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to The Neighborhood Playhouse, 212688-3770.

title: Huntington Town Supervisor Switches to the Democrats
description: Joining a quirky trend in Suffolk County politics, a leading Republican announced today that he had become a Democrat.

title: Bush to Get Options on Revamping Tax System
description: The White House will soon begin reviewing specific options to overhaul the federal tax system, edging into one of the most volatile economic issues, administration officials said today.

title: Almost Solo, Ryan Adams Gives Songs a New Edge
description: Less was plenty when Ryan Adams performed at the Beacon Theater on Thursday night. In what was billed as a solo show, he had occasional help from a second guitarist, a cellist and a violinist who also sang backup vocals. But Mr. Adams kept the songs stark and his voice exposed. That strategy can reveal the weaknesses of a singer or a song, yet for Mr. Adams it did the opposite: it revealed the mournful and contentious individuality of songs that sound more conventional on his albums.

title: Sports of The Times; Chaney Is Looking For a Silver Lining
description: ''IF I were a new coach,'' Don Chaney was saying, ''I'd be terrified.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAINER, HERMAN L. (HY)
description: SAINER-Herman L. (Hy). Beloved husband of Janet Sainer for 61 years; devoted father of Alicia, Elliot, and Debbie and their spouses, Richard, Marcia and Dennis; proud grandfather of Todd, Diana and Rachel; dear brother of Viola Harris. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Wednesday, October 16, at 12:45 P.M.

title: National Briefing | Health and Science: United Way Proposes New Rules
description: One of the United Way's governing bodies, the National Professional Council, has recommended strengthening the organization's reporting standards and eliminating some practices that have been called into question after a recent scandal at the Washington, D.C., United Way. The proposal calls on local United Ways to report their fund-raising to the United Way of America, the umbrella organization, through a centralized data base; refrain from charging donors more than once for the same service; and submit more extensive financial reports. The proposal will be presented for the approval of the United Way's 1,400 member organizations in the spring. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: Knicks Are Counting On Unorthodox Lineup
description: At one point in a scrimmage today, the Knicks' first unit included two 6-foot-2 guards, Charlie Ward and Howard Eisley, and two 6-6 forwards, Allan Houston and Shandon Anderson. It was as unorthodox as it gets, but indicative of how the Knicks hope to overcome the devastating loss of power forward Antonio McDyess.

title: Some Anxiety in Russia As Monopoly Nears End
description: Russia got a new start last week on one of its boldest economic reforms in years: breaking up its vast electricity monopoly.

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Introduce New Cellphone Technology
description: Intel plans to announce today a new generation of semiconductor technology aimed at the cellphone industry. The new products will highlight a new generation of its flash memory chips, based on its most advanced 0.13-micron process technology, which saves battery life and adds memory capacity. The new memory chips are available in densities of 64, 128 and 256 megabits. The company has also introduced a new stacked packaging technology for cellphones, a method that will allow it to package most of the microelectronics needed for a modern cellphone in a single semiconductor device. The packages are called Systems-in-a-Package and include up to four silicon chips seated one on top of the other. The stacking technology is based on the company's XScale microprocessor, Intel's licensed version of the ARM chip design. The processors will give cellphone users the ability to execute such performance-intensive applications as MPEG4 video, speech and handwriting recognition, and Java software. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Anaheim Journal; Angels-Crazy Suburb Longs for an Ending Right Out of Disney
description: The Anaheim Angels' success in the American League playoffs is not just a victory for a long-suffering baseball franchise. It is a vindication for the strip malls, the used-car lots, the smog-shrouded freeways, the housing tracts and the past-their-prime downtowns throughout Southern California.

title: The Issue of Fox Hunting
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ENGLEWOOD: MUSIC STUDIO FIRE RULED ACCIDENTAL A fire that destroyed the studio where rap music's first hit was recorded 23 years ago has been ruled accidental, the Bergen County prosecutor said yesterday. "It's not official yet, but it appears that it was not arson," said Prosecutor John L. Molinelli. The fire, which began Friday morning in one of several recording suites on the studio's second floor, destroyed the Sugar Hill Studio in Englewood, where "Rapper's Delight" was recorded in 1979. Mr. Molinelli said it appeared the fire started at a studio console, and maybe in an electrical component. More details will be available today, after Mr. Molinelli receives a complete briefing from investigators in his office's arson squad. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: BMC WILL MANAGE SYSTEMS AT DELL BMC Software, the computer-management program maker whose sales have fallen in nine straight quarters from a year earlier, said yesterday that Dell Computer had agreed to manage its systems with BMC's products and resell them. The deal to supply software for Dell's internal networks has a multimillion-dollar value, a BMC spokeswoman, Jane McMillian, said, declining to elaborate on either agreement's terms. A Dell spokesman, Mike Maher, would not comment either. BMC's software will replace products by various rivals now used to manage systems at Dell, which is the world's second-largest maker of personal computers and is known for efficient operations. In the last four quarters, the average number of days it took Dell to sell its inventory was four days, compared with 12 for Gateway and 55 for Hewlett-Packard , Bloomberg data shows. BMC's software will be used in Dell's systems around the world. Dell data centers in Europe already use BMC's software to automate computer-system management and monitor operations, BMC said. Shares of BMC, based in Houston, rose 21 cents, to $13.20. Dell shares rose 24 cents, to $26.65. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZNELSON, SYLVIA
description: KATZNELSON - Sylvia. On October 13. Devoted wife of the late Fishel, loving mother of Rena and Ira. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Thoughtful teacher. Services Tuesday, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Burry Port Journal; Sniff. What's Cooking? Funny Fuel, That's What.
description: Mayor Pat Jones would hate to give the impression that her town is some sort of hotbed of tax evasion.

title: If You Watch for a Wench, You Might Miss Your Mrs.
description: Mistaken identity has been a staple of stage comedy since Shakespeare, and there are few plays in which identities become more embarrassingly mistaken than in Oliver Goldsmith's ''She Stoops to Conquer,'' an 18th-century comedy of manners the Pearl Theater Company is staging in a smart and energetic revival that is also quite funny.

title: Analyst Dropped Enron, but Her Firm Loaded Up
description: Months before a star money manager at Alliance Capital Management, one of the nation's largest investment companies, bought millions of Enron shares last year, Alliance's own energy analyst had downgraded the stock, causing the fund she helped manage to sell all of its holdings.

title: Stung by Courts, F.D.A. Rethinks Its Rules
description: After losing a series of court decisions that found it in violation of the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of speech, the Food and Drug Administration has begun a wide-ranging review of regulations that control what the makers of drugs, supplements, food and cosmetics can say about their products.

title: Sidestepping of New School Standards Is Seen
description: Less than a year after passage of No Child Left Behind, the sweeping overhaul that promised a new era of accountability in public education, federal, state and local officials are taking steps that threaten to weaken crucial elements of the law.

title: Ernst Finances Are Disclosed In Documents In a Divorce
description: Some of the most closely guarded financial secrets of the accounting firm Ernst & Young, a private partnership, have been disclosed in divorce proceedings involving its new chief executive, including how it valued the consulting practice it sold in 2000, its total capital and how much it pays its chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AKIN, ADOLPH
description: AKIN-Adolph. ''How do I love thee let me count the ways...'' Your sweet soul, handsome face and the love in your eyes will never leave me. Evy

title: Pope Is Adding New Mysteries For the Rosary
description: Time and again, Pope John Paul II has boldly gone where other popes had not: a synagogue, a ski slope, distant countries with tiny populations.

title: Terror's Calling Card in Bali
description: The weekend massacre at an Indonesian nightclub on the idyllic island of Bali, apparently the work of Al Qaeda and local allies, is a horrifying reminder that Islamic extremists who take aim at America and the West may be on the run but are not defeated. Even as the Bush administration readies for confrontation with Iraq, it must take new steps to combat a resurgent international terrorist threat with no single address or state sponsor.

title: Islanders' Hunter Goes From Starter to Minors
description: It had been only five days since Islanders Coach Peter Laviolette put the rookie right wing Trent Hunter on his second line and promoted him as a top-six N.H.L. forward. But yesterday, Hunter became an American Hockey League forward.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE GAINS. Coffee rose on speculation that dry weather will reduce the size of the crop in Brazil, the world's largest grower. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 5.45 cents, or 9.5 percent, to 62.8 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANTORO, EUGENE
description: SANTORO - Eugene. We mourn the passing of our friend and partner Eugene Santoro, October 12, 2002. Kellner, DiLeo & Co., L.P.

title: In Senate Race, Textiles, Tobacco and Tart Words
description: They held a debate between North Carolina's candidates for the United States Senate today, and nobody came. Nobody even knew where it was going to be, exactly, or on what day, or at what time.

title: Amsterdam and the Sea Conspire to Build a Neighborhood
description: Once a year the Venetians used to stage a festivity where they sailed out onto the Adriatic to toss a wedding ring overboard, shouting ''Nuptuamus te, Mare'' (''We marry you, Sea''). That was to keep the sea friendly for another year.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Hewlett And Emachines Settle Patent Dispute
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and EMachines, a unit of EM Holdings, yesterday settled a patent dispute that led a court to order EMachines to remove some features of its low-cost personal computers, Hewlett-Packard said yesterday. Court records show the two companies agreed to dismiss the suit, pending in Federal District Court in Houston; the suit was originally filed by Compaq Computer, now part of Hewlett-Packard. A federal judge in July said EMachines computers used technology covered by nine Compaq patents without permission. Financial details are not being released, a Hewlett-Packard spokeswoman said. She said the settlement involved cross-licensing agreements. EMachines was ordered to stop selling computers that had features covered by a patent for a password system that improves computer security and by another patent that covers technology to help computers work faster. EMachines was challenging the validity of the other seven patents.

title: Annan Warns China of an AIDS Epidemic
description: ''China stands on the brink of an explosive AIDS epidemic,'' the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, warned in a speech today in Hangzhou as he began a two-day visit to China.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARGILL, Wayzata, Minn., agreed to acquire Peter's Chocolates, a unit of Nestl, Vevey, Switzerland. Cargill plans to keep the Peter's brand and sales force but shift production to its Wilbur Chocolate subsidiary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAS, TRACY A.
description: KARAS-Tracy A. Loving brother of Steven and Peter Karas, died on October 13, 2002, after a gallant five year battle with cancer. We have always been so proud of you. Your blithe spirit will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Giants Seek Their Own Mediocre Level
description: Jim Fassel posed a loaded question to his players today, its implication double-barreled in the aftermath of Sunday's 17-10 defeat. ''Did we lose that game because of injuries?'' he said.

title: Teenage Binge Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Hindu rewriting of history texts splits India
description: NEW DELHI  One out of three people in India cannot read nor write. At least 100 million children are out of school. And 45 percent of those who join school drop out before finishing even five years of basic schooling.

title: Another Wagner's Debut, Turning the Plot Around

Daland, her father, is a slick operator who's happy to forge a passport or even prostitute his daughter if the price is right. And the dapper Flying Dutchman is a wanted man who is ultimately beaten to death by skinheads wielding baseball bats.

description: And on the 16th day, traders rested.

title: As Sharon Arrives in U.S., Israel Hints at New Pullout
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15  Israel's defense minister suggested today that the army might withdraw from a second West Bank city by the weekend, sounding a conciliatory note as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon arrived in Washington to meet with President Bush.

title: With Linguini Like This, Who Needs Marching?
description: Meanwhile, in the Bronx, there was stuffed artichoke and linguini with clams, and Dominic Chianese on the guitar singing Neapolitan folk music. Lorraine Bracco wore an expensive white suit and proclaimed her adoration for the mayor, a sausage purchase was made and scores of people gathered along Arthur Avenue to see the famous guests.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the car bombing in Bali that killed more than 180 people gave an incorrect name in some copies for one of two discos that were destroyed. The two were Sari and Paddy's, not Padi's.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the investigation of the sniper shootings around Washington misstated the location of one county affected. Spotsylvania is in Virginia, not Maryland.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: SHOOTING SUSPECT ARRESTED IN ARIZONA One of four men wanted for questioning in the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old Bronx girl in August was captured in Douglas, Ariz., on Saturday trying to walk across the border from Agua Prieta, Mexico, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Enrique Sanchez, was in custody in the Cochise County Jail, in Bisbee, Ariz., yesterday and was expected to waive extradition and return to New York today, said Deputy Chief Joseph J. Reznick, commander of the Bronx detectives. The capture of Mr. Sanchez, 21, who is not the suspected gunman, leaves three others still wanted for questioning in the Aug. 18 shooting of the girl, Malenny Mendez, above, outside a church in Parkchester. All three are believed to be in Mexico, the police said. Mr. Sanchez, of Morris Avenue in the Bronx, faces charges of criminal trespass and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: You Call That a Debate?
description: Sunday's ''debate'' among seven candidates for governor of New York State was a light political merry-go-round, a 90-minute whirl in which each candidate had no more than a dozen minutes to address issues great and incredibly minor. George Pataki, the incumbent, had insisted that all third-party candidates be included. The governor should get points for politeness, but it was obvious that his real goal was to drain the event of any import.

title: Big-Game Pitcher, And Souvenir Hunter
description: Troy Percival's hobby is collecting autographed baseballs from other closers. It is his little nod of appreciation to the relief pitchers who understand his feelings, who know what it is like to search for the final three outs every tense game and who also know the agony of failing to get them.

title: Accounts
description: Six Flags, Oklahoma City, the amusement park chain, to the Los Angeles office of Initiative Media North America, to continue handling media buying duties on its account after a review, with spending estimated at $60 million to $80 million. Initiative Media North America is part of Initiative Media Worldwide, a division of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Ackerman McQueen, Tulsa, Okla., continues handling the creative duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACKBURN, SARA
description: BLACKBURN-Sara. Died on October 12 at age 66. We mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend. We will miss her wise counsel, her deep intelligence, and her sharp wit. As an editor and writer, she was the midwife to innumerable books and manuscripts. As a friend, she nurtured and tended her relationships in a magnificent way. She showed profound interest in each person she met and had the unusual ability to make each person in her life feel special and important. The world has lost a great human being; we have lost a great friend. A memorial will be held at a future date. For information, Email: forsara@postinbox.com

title: AurionGold to Accept Placer Dome Offer
description: After resisting a hostile takeover bid from Placer Dome Inc. of Canada for almost five months, AurionGold, one of Australia's biggest gold producers, has abandoned its opposition.

title: Partial Plea Of Guilty Seen For Ex-Chief Of ImClone
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, is expected to plead guilty today to many of the charges against him, people close to the case said yesterday.

title: Airbus Gets Big Order From Easyjet; Boeing Out
description: Airbus announced yesterday that EasyJet, the low-cost airline based near London, had agreed to buy 120 passenger jets from Airbus and had taken an option to buy 120 more at a fixed price over the next decade. That is the largest order placed for commercial aircraft this year, and it comes as a big blow to the Boeing Company, which had also been negotiating with EasyJet.

title: Walter Weiss, 80, Longtime Matre d'Htel and Arbiter of Standards at '21'
description: Walter Weiss, the legendary matre d'htel at the ''21'' Club, who juggled tycoons, movie stars and politicians to answer a terrifying question -- who gets the best table and who goes to Siberia? -- died on Saturday in White Plains. He was 80 and lived in Whitestone, Queens.

title: Religious Leader in Pakistan Sets Moderate Tone After Vote
description: Qazi Hussain Ahmed, a Pakistani religious leader whose sudden popularity here is making generals in Islamabad and Washington nervous, says he has a message for the American people. We do not dislike you, he says, we dislike what your president is doing.

title: Nursing and Cancer
description: Q. Has anyone done research to show whether breast-feeding reduces the risk of breast cancer?

description: WHEELER-Ira B. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, October 20th, 3 PM at Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street.

title: Airborne Express Cuts Profit Expectations
description: Airborne Inc., the parent company of the No. 3 express-delivery service Airborne Express, said today that it expected its third-quarter earnings to miss Wall Street estimates, partly because of a $3.1 million charge for the early retirement of an aircraft and rising fuel costs.

title: Britain Reasserts Ulster Rule, Suspending Elected Assembly
description: Britain took back political authority over Northern Ireland today, saying it was doing so with regret but saw no other way to preserve a future for the province's elected government, which shares power between its Catholic minority and its Protestant majority.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: EAST HARTFORD: 2 STUDENTS DIE IN CRASH Two seniors at East Hartford High School were killed early yesterday when the car they were in smashed into a tree, the police said. The car, owned by Phillip Dyson, 17, struck the tree, on Forbes Street, about 1 a.m. Mr. Dyson was pronounced dead at the scene. The other occupant, Scott Cattanach, 18, died later at Hartford Hospital. (AP)

title: Putting Cancer Screening to the Test
description: Popular methods of screening for breast cancer and prostate cancer are coming under fire. Recent studies have suggested that the techniques -- including mammograms, breast self-examinations and blood tests for prostate-specific antigen, or P.S.A. -- do little to improve survival rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINK, JACOB
description: FINK-Jacob. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Jacob Fink. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Danny Hiller, President Gary Miller, Chairman of the Board

title: WAL-MART SAYS SAME-STORE SALES MET FORECAST
description: Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, said sales last week at stores open at least a year rose within the company's forecast. Wal-Mart has forecast a 2 percent to 4 percent gain in October same-store sales. The latest results were for the week ended Friday, Wal-Mart said. The retailer missed its original estimate for the last three months. Retailers had their smallest sales gains in a year last month.

description: As Yogi Berra might have put it, it sure got late early for New York sports fans.

description: Hughes Electronics, the operator of the DirecTV satellite television service, said today that its third-quarter loss had narrowed to $13.6 million after it added customers and reduced expenses.

description: ''The V Book: A Doctor's Guide to Complete Vulvovaginal Health,'' by Dr. Elizabeth Gunther Stewart and Paula Spencer, Bantam Books, $13.95.

title: Saddam, the U.S. Agent
description: Terrorists once more fired at American troops here in Kuwait on Monday, although no one was injured this time. As with last week's attack, in which two Kuwaiti men shot one American marine to death and wounded another, we don't know whether the shooting was sponsored by Al Qaeda or was a purely home-grown affair.

title: Still Living Dangerously
description: A smart terrorist understands that he is not engaged in conventional warfare. Instead he kills to call attention to his cause, to radicalize moderates, to disrupt the lives and livelihoods of those who would prefer not to be involved, to provoke his opponents into actions that drive more people into his camp.

title: Corrections
