title: Sharon Plans Talks in U.S. on Keeping Iraq at Bay
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel plan to discuss strategies to neutralize the threat of an Iraqi missile attack on Israel in order to avoid the need for Israel to retaliate against Iraq itself in the event of a war, administration officials said today.

title: Florida Panther's Great Leap Hits a Wall
description: The Big Cypress Swamp region of Southwest Florida is a vast, wet, mysterious land of biological exuberance and subtle beauty. It is, as well, the last redoubt of the Florida panther, the stealthy and powerful cat that roamed the southeastern United States until hunting and development isolated it here by the mid-20th century.

title: Knight Ridder Profit Up 1.5% As Results From Ads Are Mixed
description: Knight Ridder said today that its third-quarter profit rose 1.5 percent as businesses spent more advertising their goods but help-wanted advertisements continued to drop.

title: Lacking Money or Clinton's Help, Rowland's Challenger Lags in Governor's Race
description: With the latest polls showing him about 20 points behind, William E. Curry Jr., the Democratic nominee for governor, is working without the three things that political analysts say could put him within striking distance of Gov. John G. Rowland: money, loyalty and, rather conspicuously, Bill Clinton.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: AUTO VENTURE Hyundai Motor says it is teaming with Beijing Automotive Industry Holding to begin producing cars in China. Although Beijing Automotive is the partner, the products will be Hyundai Sonatas and Elantras. Hyundai, Korea's dominant manufacturer of motor vehicles, plans to produce 2,000 cars in China by the end of this year and 500,000 a year by 2010. After an initial $100 million investment, Hyundai said, it will eventually pour in more than $1 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: His Reputation Is Shredded. What About His Papers?
description: Bell Labs fired Dr. J. Hendrik Schn immediately after its investigatory panel delivered its final report on the evening of Sept. 24. Since then, Dr. Schn's mark on science has begun to be be erased.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: A Push To Curb Phone Use In Cars
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey said yesterday that he would support legislation to ban talking on hand-held cellphones while driving and would like to see a law in place by January. If such legislation becomes law, New Jersey will be the second state in the nation, after New York, to approve such a ban. The New York law fines drivers up to $100. Several cellphone bills have already been introduced and legislators are scheduled to consider them in the next several weeks. The governor is reviewing two cellphone bills, but a spokesman for the governor said he had not yet decided which to support.

title: Threat of Deportation Is Eased For Husband of a 9/11 Victim
description: An illegal immigrant who faced deportation after he lost his wife in the World Trade Center attack will most likely be allowed to stay in this country with his two sons, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday.

title: Detention Camp Commander Is Removed
description: The task force commander who oversaw the expansion of the detention camps at the United States Naval Base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has been relieved of his duties in what officials said was an effort to streamline operations there.

title: Fassel Picks Up The Pieces
description: Keith Hamilton chatted briefly with his young teammate Cornelius Griffin in the parking lot at Giants Stadium today and assured him that he would be O.K., encouraging Griffin to worry about something else.

title: Fuel of Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Pluto's Plight
description: Things are looking bleaker than ever for Pluto, the most disrespected of the nine planets that we learned about in elementary school. Back then we thought we knew what a planet was, namely a spherical object that revolved around the sun and reflected its light. That fourth-grade version of Pluto even had an exotic cachet about it. It was so small and remote that it was not identified until 1930, after decades of fruitless searching for a mysterious (and much larger) Planet X that was believed to lie beyond the planet Neptune.

title: Before Congress Leaves
description: With the country focused on Iraq, the Democrats keep complaining that they can't get any traction on economic issues despite widespread public concern about jobs, pensions and the sluggish economy in general. Here's a suggestion: In the few days remaining before Congress goes home to campaign, Democratic leaders should push as hard as they can for two measures that will bring economic benefits to the country and credit to those who secure their passage. Each will require some legislative gymnastics. Both could be successful.

title: Gore Uses Disputed Count to Encourage Iowa Turnout
description: Al Gore campaigned across Iowa today on behalf of Democratic Congressional candidates, lacerating the record of President Bush and invoking his own bitterly disputed loss in Florida in 2000 as he urged Democrats to vote.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: POPULATION AND POLITICS IN CHECHNYA Preliminary census results show that 1,088,816 people live in war-torn Chechnya, 205,000 of them in Grozny, the capital, according to the republic's prime minister, Stanislav V. Ilyasov. The population has fallen from 1.2 million in 1994, before two wars devastated the republic, but the number is higher than Chechen officials had believed. Russian officials seek to portray life in Chechnya as slowly returning to normal and are likely to use the census figures to bolster their argument that Chechens are returning to their homes. The census, being carried out across Russia over eight days, was conducted in Chechnya in just two days under heavy security. About 68,000 Chechens live as refugees in a neighboring republic, Ingushetia; thousands more have moved elsewhere or disappeared.    Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, MILDRED M.
description: KAHN-Mildred M. On October 13 at age 100. Devoted mother of Joan (Murray Fox) and Julius (Isabel). Grandmother to six and greatgrandmother to nine. Private services today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, AUDREY RENEE
description: ROSEMAN-Audrey Renee. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Roseman, beloved and devoted mother of Donna and Jeffrey, dear sister of Ellie and Gerald, loving motherin-law of Ted and proud and adoring grandmother of Emma Faye, passed away peacefully after a long illness. Her grace, intelligence, beauty, humor and creative flare touched all those who knew her. Private funeral services will be held. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the New York Chapter of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Mixed Welcome as Somalis Settle in a Maine City
description: Rumors began running through this overwhelmingly white working-class city after a stream of Somali immigrants started arriving a little over a year ago.

title: St. John's Pins Hopes On New Point Guard
description: You have to look pretty hard to find any holes in Marcus Hatten's game or in his St. John's dossier. Starting at point guard last season, he led the Red Storm in scoring (20.1 points a game), steals (3.3) and assists (4.5), and he was second in rebounding (5.3). Hatten was asked to handle the ball, score, defend and even rebound. There were, of course, four other players on the court. Sometimes, though, it didn't seem that way.

title: Miscellany
description: American Honda Motor Company, Torrance, Calif., part of Honda Motor, is presenting what the company describes as the first commercial to be filmed in the 70-millimeter, large-screen format used by the Imax Corporation. The spot was created by the Honda agency, Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica, Calif., and will appear before showings of ''Pulse: A Stomp Odyssey,'' an Imax movie sponsored by Honda.

title: Kenya's Ruling Party Picks Kenyatta Son to Succeed President
description: The party that has ruled Kenya since its independence was split in two today after it picked the son of the nation's founder as its candidate to replace retiring President Daniel arap Moi, who has led Kenya since 1978.

title: On Scientific Fakery and the Systems to Catch It
description: In some ways, the pivotal figure in the research misconduct case at Bell Labs was not Dr. J. Hendrik Schn, the scientist fired last month for fabricating and manipulating data, but Dr. Bertram Batlogg, the man who hired him in 1998.

title: So the Mayor Wouldn't March . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Found Dead In a Rail Car In Rural Iowa
description: Up to 11 badly decomposed bodies were discovered yesterday afternoon in a grain hopper car in Denison, Iowa, the authorities said. They appeared to be Mexican immigrants, the Mexican consul in Omaha said.

title: Alphonse Chapanis Dies at 85; Was a Founder of Ergonomics
description: Alphonse Chapanis, a founder of ergonomics, a branch of engineering that considers product and workplace design from the physical point of view of the actual user, died on Oct. 4 in Baltimore. He was 85.

title: Plan for School In Courthouse Is Up in Air, Educators Say
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced plans last March to move the Department of Education to the Tweed Courthouse, he said he would put a school on the first floor ''so that all of the administrators every day get reminded why they have jobs.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, KENNETH
description: KRAUS-Kenneth. We mourn the passing of our dear friend of over 35 years Ken Kraus. Our holidays & family events will not be the same without you. We will miss you and we will remember you always. Love, Pommy, Jerry, Jackie, Deena & Brett.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry's Sales Rise
description: Bucking a trend of sales declines by many luxury goods retailers, the Burberry Group reported a 15 percent sales increase for the first half of the year and said it would open eight new stores later this year. Sales at the company's retail stores for the six months ended Sept. 30 rose 17 percent, helped by five new stores, including locations in Barcelona, Spain; Hong Kong; and Coral Gables, Fla. Wholesale orders increased 8 percent in the period. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A New Drug Means a New Venue
description: A new drug and changes in federal regulations should help move treatment of heroin addiction out of methadone centers and into doctors' offices, the author of an article being published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine says.

title: Jones Leads Galaxy Into M.L.S. Title Match
description: It seems that COBI JONES has always been a part of the institutional memory of American soccer.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Population and Politics In Chechnya
description: Preliminary census results show that 1,088,816 people live in war-torn Chechnya, 205,000 of them in Grozny, the capital, according to the republic's prime minister, Stanislav V. Ilyasov. The population has fallen from 1.2 million in 1994, before two wars devastated the republic, but the number is higher than Chechen officials had believed. Russian officials seek to portray life in Chechnya as slowly returning to normal and are likely to use the census figures to bolster their argument that Chechens are returning to their homes. The census, being carried out across Russia over eight days, was conducted in Chechnya in just two days under heavy security. About 68,000 Chechens live as refugees in a neighboring republic, Ingushetia; thousands more have moved elsewhere or disappeared. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDFORD, PAULINE (NEE ALLALOUF)
description: BEDFORD-Pauline (nee Allalouf). Age 77, passed away October 11, 2002 after a brave battle. Paula was raised on the Lower East Side, was a truly devoted mother, and never knew how smart she was. She is survived by brother Maury Allalouf, and son & daughter Robert and Felice Bedford. Service on October 16, at 11:30 AM at Nieberg's Midwood Chapel, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBOTSKY, ESTHER B.
description: REBOTSKY-Esther B., 91. Passed away on October 13, 2002 surrounded by her loving family. Beloved wife of Hyman, devoted mother of Sam and Joyce, Ruth and Walter, Marilyn & Kenneth, adoring grandmother of Jonathan and Shelley, Lisa and Mike, Lori and Alison and great grandmother of Max. Sister of Anne, Marvin and Atarah, Shirley and Sunny, and Max (predeceased). We will deeply miss you. Contributions in Esther's memory can be made to AMIT care of Kate Chudy, 152-72 Melbourne Av, Apartment 3-H, Flushing, N.Y. 11367. Services today, 12:15PM at Parkside Chapels, 98-60 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, 718-896-9000. A Shiva will begin on Tuesday, 44-65 Kissena Boulevard, Apartment 2-C, Flushing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUNSELMAN, DIANE L. (TITONE)
description: COUNSELMAN-Diane L. (Titone), 52. Died October 4th in Seattle, WA in a boating related accident. Ms. Counselman grew up in Morristown, NJ and graduated from Rutgers University. She moved to Manhattan in 1980 where she worked as a management and information technology consultant. The majority of her professional career was spent at Merck, Coopers & Lybrand and Digital Equipment Corporation. She moved to Seattle in 2001. Ms. Counselman is survived by her mother, Patricia Titone; sisters, Cheryl and husband John Peterson, Patricia and husband David Butts; brother, Charles and wife Maryann; cousins, Gail, John and Bobby Fialk and Gary Boland. She will be remembered lovingly as ''Auntie Di'' by nieces, Alexandra and Courtney, and nephews, Dylan, Tyler, Spencer and Jayson. Private services were held on October 5th. Donations may be made in her memory to the Make A Wish Foundation of America (1-866-880-1382).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, HARRIET (NEE ZICHLINSKY)
description: COHEN-Harriet (nee Zichlinsky). Beloved wife of Ben. Beloved mother of David, Elon and Ami. Beloved sister of Elliott Zichlinsky; beloved mother-in-law of Leah and Shanit; adored grandmother of Daniel, Joshua, Debbie, Coral and Mirell. She was our rock, our center, the glue that kept us all together. She will be in our hearts forever. Services ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave, Tuesday 1 P.M. Memorial contributions may be made to the Habonim Dror Foundation.

title: A New Hat for a Bishop, but Perhaps Not a Red One
description: FOR 16 years, Archbishop Renato R. Martino -- depending on whom you ask -- has either served as the life-affirming conscience of the United Nations, or sought to impose the strict moral doctrines of the Roman Catholic Church on a secular world.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Case Of the Suicide Pact
description: A Lansing woman accused of driving her son and his wife to an abandoned farmhouse and supplying them with drugs for a suicide pact was sentenced to 15 to 30 months in prison. The woman, Kathleen Kay Holey, 43, pleaded guilty in August to a reduced charge of attempted assisted suicide in the incident last April in which her son, Patrick, 19, died, and his wife, Jennifer, survived. The mother appeared before Judge Randy Tahvonen of Clinton County Circuit Court and was given credit for 180 days already served in jail. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Critic's Notebook; A Look Back at Spring Shows Reveals a Romantic Streak
description: To some of the old-timers viewing the latest round of collections, editors who could recall Gianni Versace's first show or the season that Vivienne Westwood and Malcolm McLaren put tiny phallic symbols on buttons, there was nothing new to report from the spring 2003 shows. Sex had surfaced again, and as a sign of how little things had changed, designers were trying to grab headlines with hemlines, a ploy that hasn't worked since the 1980's.

title: Gunfire Erupts Again in Kuwait
description: Gunmen fired at American marines in northern Kuwait early today, the United States Embassy here said, less than a week after a marine was killed in an attack here by a man professing allegiance to Osama bin Laden.

title: A Nervous Public Wonders, Is the Sniper That Guy One Bar Stool Over?
description: With no physical description available of the elusive sniper, who the police say may have struck again tonight, some spooky questions are rippling through the minds of many here: Are you the sniper? Are you or you or you?

title: People
description: Arlo Oviatt was named senior vice president and executive creative director at Bernstein-Rein Advertising, Kansas City, Mo. He assumes duties that had been handled by Jeff Bremser, senior vice president and chief creative director, who is shifting his focus to strategic duties, the agency said. Mr. Oviatt had most recently been group creative director at the St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Publicis Groupe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TULIPAN, ANNETTE BAKER
description: TULIPAN - Annette Baker. Died peacefully October 13, the 62nd anniversary of her wedding to the late Ira Tulipan. Born November 14, 1914 in Hudson, NY and graduated from Cornell University, she lived her adult life in New York and London and since 1993 at Wake Robin in Shelburne, VT. Loving mother of Jane and Al Hobart; grandmother of Alison Hobart and Mike Riddell, Jessica Hobart and Alexander Pivovarsky; great-grandmother of Ethan and Lydia Riddell. Memorial at Wake Robin, Friday October 18, 2 PM. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, or the Mastocytosis Society, POB 9369, Coral Springs, FL.

title: Vivendi Said to Be Delaying Auction of Unit
description: Vivendi Universal has delayed the auction of its publishing business, which includes Houghton Mifflin, as it continues to squabble with potential buyers over the dwindling value of their bids, executives involved in the process said yesterday.

title: A Look Deep Into Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Publicis begins an extensive, and risky, reshuffling of accounts and people.
description: IN one of the most sweeping post-acquisition reorganizations by an agency company, the Publicis Groupe in Paris is embarking on an ambitious -- and risky -- reshuffling of assets, accounts and employees that affects some of the biggest names in marketing like General Motors and Procter & Gamble.

title: CBS's New 4-Seat Morning Format Faces Serious Tests
description: CBS is betting that three women and a man can do for it what neither ''Captain Kangaroo'' nor Bryant Gumbel was able to achieve: make it competitive with NBC's ''Today'' show.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: More Tensions With Russia
description: Relations worsened when the Holy See denounced a ''despicable operation'' to undercut the Catholic Church in Russia. Joaqun Navarro-Valls, the pope's spokesman, issued a statement citing the Russian news media's coverage of a Moscow apartment, rented out for charitable purposes by a Franciscan order, that became a brothel. He complained that news organizations had used deceptive imagery of religious figures ''in immoral poses.'' The Russian Orthodox Church has long charged the Vatican with poaching its followers and has recently expelled Catholic clerics. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  XU, SHUBO
description: XU-Shubo. On October 12, 2002, Shubo, beloved husband of Chan Zhang Xu. Devoted father of Zhigang (Tiger) Xu. Loving son of Dixin and the late Luzhen Xu. Also survived by fifteen brothers and sisters. Services will be held Sunday, October 20, 2002 at 2 P.M. from The Slack Funeral Home P.A. 3871 Old Columbia Pike, Ellicott City, MD. Interment private.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Squabble Over Bids Delays Sale at a Vivendi Business

title: An Endlessly Repeated Tale That Never Reaches an Ending
description: Tom Murphy's ''Bailegangaire,'' first performed in 1985 in Galway and now at the Irish Repertory Theater, will remind some theatergoers of ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' by Martin McDonagh. It involves, after all, a lonely middle-aged Irishwoman, in this case a former nurse named Mary, who is trapped in a rural cottage with a dependent relative. But Mr. Murphy has grander, more poetic intentions than Mr. McDonagh had, and his play is more difficult.

title: Deutsch Is Named To Lamisil Account
description: Novartis Pharmaceuticals in East Hanover, N.J., has named Deutsch in New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle the account of Lamisil, a drug for toenail fungus. Billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about international reaction to the Nobel Peace Prize honoring former President Jimmy Carter omitted the surname of the Norwegian Nobel Committee member who disagreed with its chairman on criticizing the Bush administration's approach toward Iraq. She is Hanna Kristine Kvanmo.

title: Belatedly, Indonesians Concede Nation Faces a Terrorist Threat
description: In the aftermath of the Bali bombing, top Indonesian officials have begun to concede that their country, the world's most-populous Muslim nation, faces a terrorist threat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Shooting Suspect Arrested In Arizona
description: One of four men wanted for questioning in the fatal shooting of a 10-year-old Bronx girl in August was captured in Douglas, Ariz., on Saturday trying to walk across the border from Agua Prieta, Mexico, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Enrique Sanchez, was in custody in the Cochise County Jail, in Bisbee, Ariz., yesterday and was expected to waive extradition and return to New York today, said Deputy Chief Joseph J. Reznick, commander of the Bronx detectives. The capture of Mr. Sanchez, 21, who is not the suspected gunman, leaves three others still wanted for questioning in the Aug. 18 shooting of the girl, Malenny Mendez, above, outside a church in Parkchester. All three are believed to be in Mexico, the police said. Mr. Sanchez, of Morris Avenue in the Bronx, faces charges of criminal trespass and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Practicing Religion While on the Go
description: When he travels on business, Rick Surratt, a salesman in St. Louis, always brings along his Bible.

title: Front Row
description: ''We'll take the check please -- we're in a hurry,'' said Candy Pratts Price, addressing a waitress at 44, the restaurant at the Royalton Hotel.

title: Scott Gives Knicks An Elbow
description: After the Nets' victory against Cleveland last week in their first preseason game, Coach Byron Scott met with the team's president, Rod Thorn, and told him he was limiting his starters' playing time to reduce the risk of injury.

title: Goodbye to the Vietnam Syndrome
description: I recently returned to live in the Chicago neighborhood where I went to college over a decade ago, during the first President Bush's crusade against Saddam Hussein's Iraq. It was different then: I remember the passionate handbills clogging university cork boards; my proud participation in antiwar demonstrations on campus; and, most dramatically, the civil disobedience, as when militants desperate to change the debate over war in Iraq snarled traffic downtown by lying in front of cars on the busiest streets.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's going to take a while to fully rout Al Qaeda. We just learned a lesson this week. It's going to take a while to succeed.''

title: For Pfluger, a Career of Achievement
description: When Christie Shore stepped into the recruiting office at the College of New Jersey a few years ago, she stared at the trophies covering the tabletops and at the all-American certificates and coaching awards that seemed to paper the walls.

title: Warriors And Bees From Bali
description: Dance in Bali is an art for people of all ages, and Balinese companies that have visited New York in the past have often included both young children and venerable adults. But the accent was entirely on authority and experience in Master Dancers of Bali, the program the World Music Institute presented on Friday night at Symphony Space.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steel Maker's Profit Rises
description: Pohang Iron and Steel, widely known as Posco, posted a net profit of $300 million for the third quarter, nearly double its net of $165 million in the third quarter of last year, on a 12.1 percent increase in sales for the period. The company attributed the profit in part to an 8.3 percent price increase along with a rise in production, to 7.3 million tons from 6.9 million tons, accompanied by cost-cutting measures. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Heightened Sense of Australia's Vulnerability
description: Painfully counting its losses, Australia is preparing national and private mourning for scores of victims of the bombings in Bali that some now link to Al Qaeda.

title: Accuracy of Energy Prices Is Under Review
description: The Mirant Corporation and rival energy traders are reviewing the accuracy of prices used to set energy contracts after Dynegy and the American Electric Power Company disclosed that they provided false data to trade journals.

title: Correction
description: An editorial yesterday erred in saying that Pluto differed from the other planets in that its orbit is elliptical rather than circular. All the planets have elliptical orbits; Pluto's is the least circular.

title: In Asia, the English imperative
description: KUALA LUMPUR  After years of promoting a public education system based on use of the national language, Malay, the Malaysian government recently created a storm of controversy by seeking to promote the use of English, the former colonial language, in schools and universities.

title: Dutch Designs for Cities Built on Ideas and What-If's
description: For a small country, the Netherlands packs a wallop on the architectural scene worldwide. And while the paterfamilias of Dutch design, Rem Koolhaas, may already be as familiar as a Prada handbag in the United States, other Dutch firms are gaining prominence here through high-profile commissions and exhibitions.

title: Seeking Names for Bali's Anonymous Dead
description: ''Identity unknown,'' reads a hand-written sign posted on a wall of Bali's largest hospital. Then comes a description so vivid that it is almost possible to see the carefree young woman dancing, late into the night, just before the bomb went off.

title: CONTAINER MAKER CUTS FORECASTS FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
description: Silgan Holdings, a maker of containers for food and cosmetics, cut its forecast yesterday for third-quarter and full-year profit. The company projected a third-quarter profit of $1.30 to $1.35 a share, compared with an earlier forecast of $1.40 to $1.60. Annual profit before one-time items will be $2.70 to $2.90 a share. The company had projected $2.85 to $3.05. Profit in the plastic containers business fell while sales rose, as Silgan sold less-profitable items, the company said. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said it expected those conditions to continue this quarter, hurting annual results. Silgan's stock fell $6.64, or 25 percent, to $19.79 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURECK, MICHAEL
description: TURECK-Michael. Beloved husband for 65 years of Yetta. Cherished father of Arlene (Joseph) Crystal, Robin (Lester) Rackoff and Jeffrey (Sharyn) Tureck. Loving grandfather of Lori, Robert, Jamie, Brett, Brian, Matthew, Deborah. Adoring Big Poppa of Jaylin and devoted younger brother of Irving. He will be sorely missed by his relatives and friends.

title: Forrester on Defensive for Old Newspaper Columns
description: Douglas R. Forrester, New Jersey's Republican nominee for the United States Senate, found himself on the defensive today about several newspaper columns he wrote more than a decade ago opposing drunken-driving checkpoints, criticizing New Jersey's ban on assault weapons and saying that Atlantic City had ''the subtle beauty of a streetwalker.''

title: McCall Charges Pataki Created A Fiscal 'Mess'
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, said yesterday that Gov. George E. Pataki had mismanaged the state's response to the slumping economy, leaving Albany facing huge deficits and unable to take on bold new initiatives.

title: Working to Put Blacks on France's Agenda
description: ''They say, France is one and indivisible,'' said Dogad Dogoui, with characteristic deadpan humor, as he poked at a lunch of fish recently. ''I say, yes, and with lots of people who are invisible.''

title: At Lawrence Berkeley, Physicists Say a Colleague Took Them for a Ride
description: It's often said that the greatest thrill in science is to be first to observe a new phenomenon of nature. For nuclear physicists that means being present at the creation of an element, glimpsing for an instant a new kind of matter.

title: Cost of TV Ads Grew 8% in 2001
description: The average cost of producing a 30-second national television commercial increased 8 percent in 2001 from 2000, according to an annual survey by the American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York.

title: For Warts, the Duct Tape Cure
description: An article being published today adds one more item to the list of uses for duct tape. Now, it turns out, it helps get rid of warts.

title: So the Mayor Wouldn't March . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Mom, Dad and the Kids Reclaim TV Perch
description: For years, the family comedy, among the oldest staples of network television, has been looked upon as a creaky relic in a state of permanent decline. It has been described as out of touch with the times and especially with the audience that networks and advertisers crave -- younger adult viewers who have been presumed to be searching only for more offbeat fare like reality television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSES, RUTH
description: POSES-Ruth. October 13, 2002. Residence: Tiverton, RI, former of Brooklyn, NY. Wife of the late Abraham L. Poses. Mother of Dr. Roy Poses of Barrington, R.I. Sister of Miriam Lish of Stamford, CT. Grandmother of Daniel. Graveside services Tuesday in R.I. For information call Shalom Memorial Chapel, Cranston, R.I. (401) 463-7771

title: Astronauts Complete Space Station Work
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 14  Two astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis went on a third and final spacewalk from the International Space Station today, converting a newly installed girder into a functional part of the orbital complex.

title: National Briefing | Health and Science: Astronauts Complete Work
description: Two astronauts from the shuttle Atlantis went on final spacewalk from the International Space Station, converting a newly installed girder into a functional part of the complex. Dr. David A. Wolf and Dr. Piers J. Sellers, attached ammonia hoses running between the 45-foot-long girder and a similar station segment, part of an air-conditioning system for the structure. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant to remove heat from the station.

title: Tons of Smallpox, Unaccounted For
description: THE DEMON IN THE FREEZER

title: Gene Jugglers Take to Fields for Food Allergy Vanishing Act
description: The soybeans growing on a test plot in Hawaii look, grow and taste like other soybeans. But some people who eat them will notice a big difference, because the beans have been genetically engineered to cause fewer allergic reactions.

title: New Law Is News To Many
description: Nearly half the parents of children attending schools in poor urban areas have never heard of No Child Left Behind, the federal education law, a new survey has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERN, WILLIAM JOSEPH
description: ALPERN-William Joseph, 77. On October 13, 2002. Former Financial Analyst and Vice President, Prudential Securities in New York City. Longtime resident Greens Farms, Connecticut. World War II veteran. Pi Lambda Phi fraternity. B.A. Brown University. M.A. Columbia. Loving father of Timothy Lee, of England. Dear brother of Ann Alpern Kass and Elinor Alpern, both of New York City. Services were private.

title: The Jogger Convictions
description: To the Editor:

title: TXU's Abrupt Exit Roils Britain's Energy Market
description: The British power market was roiled today, as TXU, the former Texas Utilities, said that it would withdraw financial support from its European subsidiary and put the unit up for sale.

title: ANDRX SHARES PLUNGE AFTER IT LOSES PATENT LAWSUIT
description: Stock in the Andrx Corporation, a maker of generic drugs, fell 40 percent yesterday after the company lost a court fight for rights to make a version of Prilosec, a popular ulcer medicine. The sell-off came after Friday's ruling in Federal District Court in Manhattan that Prilosec was protected by patents held by its maker, AstraZeneca. Andrx said it was considering appealing the ruling and would take a third-quarter write-down of undetermined size to cover supplies of the drug that it had made before the ruling. Stock in Andrx, based in Davie, Fla., fell $7.99, to $12 a share. Shares in AstraZeneca, based in London, rose 12.4 percent in London.

title: INSIDE
description: Threat to Education Law

title: Iraqis Cheer for Their President, But Real Mood Is Hard to Read
description: At the floodlit Stadium of the People, the organizers of a rally today on the eve of a referendum on the presidency of Saddam Hussein had one point to make, and they made it with all the subtlety of a hammer hitting an anvil.

title: Brazil Raises A Key Rate By 3 Points
description: Brazil's central bank surprised investors yesterday and raised a crucial interest rate by three percentage points, continuing an aggressive effort to halt the decline in the value of the nation's currency.

title: Heir to Power and to Kenya's Great Name
description: Uhuru Muigai Kenyatta introduced himself at a cocktail reception not long ago and received a blank stare from a woman, an expatriate new to Kenya, standing before him. ''Uhuru,'' he said, pronouncing his name, oo-who-roo.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: BMC Will Manage Systems At Dell
description: BMC Software, the computer-management program maker whose sales have fallen in nine straight quarters from a year earlier, said yesterday that Dell Computer had agreed to manage its systems with BMC's products and resell them. The deal to supply software for Dell's internal networks has a multimillion-dollar value, a BMC spokeswoman, Jane McMillian, said, declining to elaborate on either agreement's terms. A Dell spokesman, Mike Maher, would not comment either. BMC's software will replace products by various rivals now used to manage systems at Dell, which is the world's second-largest maker of personal computers and is known for efficient operations. In the last four quarters, the average number of days it took Dell to sell its inventory was four days, compared with 12 for Gateway and 55 for Hewlett-Packard, Bloomberg data shows. BMC's software will be used in Dell's systems around the world. Dell data centers in Europe already use BMC's software to automate computer-system management and monitor operations, BMC said. Shares of BMC, based in Houston, rose 21 cents, to $13.20. Dell shares rose 24 cents, to $26.65.

title: Footlights
description: Earful

title: Giants Make It a Wild-Card World Series
description: Barry Bonds is the most feared and most famous member of the Giants, but his teammates have helped carry him to his first World Series.

title: MEMO PAD
description: For U.S. Airlines, Daunting Numbers

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about international reaction to the Nobel Peace Prize honoring former President Jimmy Carter omitted the surname of the Norwegian Nobel Committee member who disagreed with its chairman on criticizing the Bush administration's approach toward Iraq. She is Hanna Kristine Kvanmo.

title: BUSH TIES BOMBING AT BALI NIGHTCLUB TO QAEDA NETWORK
description: President Bush said today that the bombing on the Indonesian island of Bali appeared to be the work of Al Qaeda and that the attack was part of a pattern that included recent attacks in Kuwait and Yemen.

title: So the Mayor Wouldn't March . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferreting for Facts in the Realm of Clinical Trials
description: Millions of women discovered a basic in medicine, much to their dismay, this summer when the Women's Health Initiative study showed that postmenopausal hormone replacement did not prevent heart attacks. Only clinical trials, they learned, can establish a definitive fact about the effectiveness and safety of a diagnostic technique, preventive method or treatment.

title: Doctor and Patient Wage Tug of War on Antibiotics
description: As flu season approaches, doctors and patients are gearing up for the annual antibiotic battle, when miserable patients, coughing and sniffling, demand antibiotics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, WALTER
description: WEISS-Walter. '21' Club mourns the loss of Walter Weiss, maitre d' extraordinaire and beloved family member for over 54 years. He will be sorely missed by the habitues of '21' and, most certainly, by every member of the '21' staff who worked with him over the years. '21' joins together in sending heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathy to Walter's wife Frances and their family.

title: After a Stroke, a New Accent
description: Some stroke or accident victims lose the ability to produce speech; others, their ability to understand it. But in an extremely small group, the brain injuries produce a shift in pronunciation known as foreign accent syndrome.

title: His Fortes Are Forte, His Pianos, -Issimo
description: The program was making a calculated statement: here comes a new virtuosic and versatile Russian-school pianist. It ran the gamut from Bach (French Suite No. 2) to Shostakovich (Sonata No. 2), with a healthy admixture of Fantasies (Chopin's Opus 49 in F minor and Schubert's ''Wanderer'') and a topping of Ravel (''La Valse''). In other words it represented a range of styles and a high level of technical challenge in a repertory safely positioned before the second half of the 20th century.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRUSSELS: DE BEERS APPROVAL IS EXPECTED A plan by De Beers, the world's leading supplier of diamonds, to expand its direct influence on gem retailing by locking in some distributors with preferred-supplier contracts is probably going to be approved by European Union officials, according to people close to the union's antitrust investigation of the plan. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Earnings Reports Ignite Rally and Stocks Gain More Than 4.5%
description: Stock prices soared today, with the leading market indexes jumping more than 4.5 percent, as investors celebrated upbeat earnings reports from two of the nation's largest financial institutions and began to shift their views from gloomy to hopeful on other companies' earnings prospects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARAS, TRACY A.
description: CARAS-Tracy A. A valued friend, colleague and partner at Whitman & Ransom, Whitman Breed Abbott & Morgan and Winston & Strawn, died on October 13, 2002 after a long courageous fight with brain cancer. We will miss him.

title: Mariners Allow Piniella to Go, With a Big String Attached
description: The Seattle Mariners yesterday granted Manager Lou Piniella's wish to seek a job with a team closer to his Florida home, but with one catch: the Mets and any other teams interested in pursuing Piniella will have to agree to compensation with the Mariners before being allowed to speak with him.

title: Linking Airplanes to Test Scores
description: After Munich moved its airport in 1992, scores on reading and memory tests went up near the old airport and down near the new one, a recently published study reports.

title: WOMAN IN VIRGINIA IS SHOT TO DEATH; SNIPER SUSPECTED
description: A woman was fatally shot in the head tonight outside a suburban Virginia store, unleashing a frantic highway dragnet for the roving suburban sniper who has killed eight people in the Washington area in two weeks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S.-FRENCH SPLIT ON IRAQ DEEPENS
description: The impasse between the United States and France over military action in Iraq has deepened in recent days after an effort to reach a compromise stalled, with the French insisting that the Americans must come back to the United Nations Security Council before they can use force, diplomats said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Brussels: De Beers Approval Is Expected
description: A plan by De Beers, the world's leading supplier of diamonds, to expand its direct influence on gem retailing by locking in some distributors with preferred-supplier contracts is probably going to be approved by European Union officials, according to people close to the union's antitrust investigation of the plan. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Angels in the Outfield, Devil in the Details
description: Bill Stoneman found a dry spot in the delirious Anaheim Angels clubhouse Sunday, behind the protective plastic by the door to Manager Mike Scioscia's office. Stoneman, the general manager, was describing Scioscia's virtues -- ''He's good in all facets of managing'' -- when Scioscia scurried past him, tapped him on the shoulder and said, ''Thanks for the players.''

title: F.A.A. PROPOSES FINING NORTHWEST AIRLINES $230,000
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation may be fined $230,000 for violating rules on cargo shipments, the Federal Aviation Administration says. The F.A.A. proposed a $130,000 civil fine for record keeping at an airport near Knoxville, Tenn. In a July 2000 inspection, Northwest was unable to show that 22 customer-service agents and 4 air-freight workers had received the required training to handle dangerous goods, the agency said. The agency also proposed a $100,000 fine after a January 1998 assessment at a Nashville airport found that Northwest had failed to obtain cargo security documents and had not screened a cargo shipment. ''Northwest has corrected the training deficiencies and the company remains committed to the handling of hazardous materials,'' a spokeswoman for the company, based in St. Paul, said.

title: The Hunt for a Random Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Poll On Politicians' National Prospects
description: A poll released yesterday says Americans are not thrilled about the idea that Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor, and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton might run for national office. The poll by Marist College says 69 percent of registered voters nationwide feel Mrs. Clinton should never run for president, against 26 percent who think she should. Voters offered no more encouragement to Mr. Giuliani, when asked what he should do next. Just 20 percent said he should run for president in 2008, or replace Dick Cheney on the 2004 Republican ticket. But Mr. Giuliani retains the popularity he gained after Sept. 11, and is far better liked than Mrs. Clinton; 78 percent of voters surveyed have a favorable opinion of him, and 37 percent for her. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Lofton Rewards Baker's Faith With a Hit
description: Dusty Baker did not see the need to issue an all-points bulletin for Kenny Lofton yesterday. Nor did the San Francisco Giants list Lofton as missing in action. But the St. Louis Cardinals had done a pretty good job of making Lofton, the Giants' leadoff hitter, disappear in the National League Championship Series.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Now Showing, Plenty

title: Twins' Ryan Set To Return
description: Terry Ryan, the Minnesota Twins' general manager, plans to sit down with the team's owner, Carl Pohlad, and negotiate a new agreement now that the Twins have been eliminated from the playoffs.

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Finally Goes Deep Into October
description: BARRY BONDS said his career would not be cheapened if he never played in a World Series. No doubt he meant it. Now he does not have to talk about it.

title: Where Sounds of the 80's Provide a Starting Point
description: What does electroclash mean? The term describes a genre of songs that borrow heavily from 1980's hits, with synthesizer bass lines, simple beats and deadpan vocals. It also describes a social scene; an electroclash party is an excuse for hipsters, drag queens, punk rockers and aspiring pop stars to come together for a night of dancing.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pressplay Adds BMG Tracks To Catalog
description: Pressplay, an online music service that offers consumers the ability to listen to and download more than 100,000 songs for a monthly fee, said yesterday that it had added tens of thousands of tracks distributed by BMG, part of Bertelsmann, to its catalog. The Pressplay service already includes songs from the two major music companies that own it, Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group, part of Vivendi Universal, as well as from EMI. Pressplay is expected to announce a deal with Warner Music Group, part of AOL Time Warner, shortly, a move that would make it the only service to offer the ability to download music from all five major recording companies. But only a limited number of Pressplay's songs can be copied onto CD's or transferred to portable devices by a customer. Listen.com, whose Rhapsody service offers the ability to hear songs from all five labels, is expected to let consumers start copying songs next week. Amy Harmon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PREISKEL, BARBARA SCOTT
description: PREISKEL-Barbara Scott. A memorial service for Barbara S. Preiskel will be held on Wednesday, October 16, 4:30 PM, at the New York City Bar Association, 42 West 44 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to The New York Community Trust, 2 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10016, for the Barbara S. Preiskel Memorial Fund.

description: It was a chaotic season with sequins found everywhere.

title: Uncertain Times: Impulse Buyers Replace Ticket Subscribers
description: The season subscription plan, which for generations has balanced the books of symphonies, nonprofit theaters and opera and ballet companies, seems to be losing favor with audiences around the country as single-ticket sales increase in popularity.

title: From the Far Side Of Long Island Fjord
description: For more than 10 years Scandia Food and Gifts has had stores in Farmington and Norwalk, Conn. But when the company set up a Web site, www.scandiafood.com, its owner, Peter Bjernestad, discovered that he had thousands of customers on the Upper East Side. So that is where he has just opened his third store, at 1685 First Avenue (87th Street). In the back, past the clogs and crystal, is a food section with flatbreads and crackers, jams, honeys, mustards, pancake mixes, candies and pickles. A freezer case offers bags of classic Swedish meatballs ($7.20 a pound) and sweetly briny shrimp, with heads, to steam, peel and eat ($11.95 for one and a half pounds). Jars of herring, smoked seafood spreads and cheeses are also sold.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. Forever in my heart and thoughts. Not a day goes by. Love & kisses. Sherry

title: Hamilton, Awaiting Surgery, Wonders About His Future
description: Keith Hamilton's instinct was to try to walk off the field Sunday, even when intense pain told him something was seriously wrong with his right leg. Similarly, when the diagnosis of a torn Achilles' tendon was confirmed Monday, Hamilton immediately said he would fight to come back in 2003.

title: Upstairs, Hot Pastrami; Downstairs, Jalapeos
description: FOR 21 years, I've wondered why it is so hard to get great Mexican food in New York. I grew up in Arizona eating tortillas and frijoles in neighbors' kitchens, trading cookies for empanadas, living for the days when someone made tamales. Why did nothing here compare?

description: To the Editor:

title: Smallpox Vaccine Data Show Small but Serious Risk of Infecting Others
description: A new report on millions of smallpox vaccinations given in the 1960's confirms that there is a small but significant risk that newly vaccinated people can make others seriously ill by infecting them with vaccinia, the virus used in the vaccine.

title: 142 Clemency Hearings in Illinois Also Revive 142 Cases of Horror
description: Long before the woman in the blue velour pantsuit took the microphone, everyone could see she was the mother.

Funeral services Friday 11 AM, The Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 E. 74 St, New York City. Friends may call Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9PM Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Says Economy Won't Hurt His Party at Polls
description: The Republican national chairman today dismissed the Democratic Party's response to the nation's economic problems as ''impotent,'' and said he did not believe that a fall campaign revolving around the economy would hurt his party's Congressional candidates.

title: Devils Waive Salomonsson
description: The Devils put forward Andreas Salomonsson on waivers yesterday and he was picked up the Washington Capitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARAS, TRACY A.
description: CARAS-Tracy A. Loving brother of Steven and Peter Caras, died on October 13, 2002, after a gallant five year battle with cancer. We have always been so proud of you. Your blithe spirit will live on in our hearts forever.

title: Italy Plus Asia Plus Latin America Plus Chocolate Fondue
description: ''SO tell me why you're getting bored with Brian,'' a woman said to her friend, the two of them clad in matching cardigans and eating matching endive salads ($7) with grilled Roquefort and brioche sandwich fingers buried within them. This was at Wyanoka, on Mott Street, a 19th-century Irish workingman's club that became an Italian social club in the 1920's and a restaurant in 2000, all of them with the same American Indian name. It was unclear if she meant a beau or a boss.

title: Homeland Security Fight Returns to Fore
description: Debate over the Homeland Security Department, languishing while Congress focused on Iraq, returned to a boil today, as the White House and Senate Democrats exchanged criticism over the cause of the stalemate. The intensity of the accusations reflected the increasingly prominent role of the issue in Congressional races.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: UKRAINE: JUDGE ORDERS INQUIRY OF PRESIDENT An appeals court judge ordered prosecutors to open a criminal investigation into President Leonid D. Kuchma, saying accusations that Mr. Kuchma approved illegal arms sales to Iraq and was tied to the murder of an opposition journalist were crippling Ukrainian politics and should be laid to rest. Mr. Kuchma's presidency has been in shadows for more than a year since secretly recorded conversations appeared to implicate him in illegal acts. His aides called Judge Yuri Vasylenko's move unconstitutional but the five opposition members of Parliament who asked for the order hailed it as a breakthrough for democracy. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: E-ZPass Users in New Jersey Will Get Replacement Devices
description: More than 200,000 E-ZPass users in New Jersey are scheduled to get free replacements for their windshield transponders, after transportation officials found that the devices were wearing out sooner than expected and resulting in hundreds of thousands of mistaken violation notices being issued.

title: Sniper Left Clues This Time, and Police Report Progress in Inquiry
description: This time the roving sniper left more clues, with a number of witnesses getting a better, more chilling glimpse of him and his getaway van as they looked beyond his latest victim on the floor of a parking garage.

title: With Only One Choice, Iraqis Give Hussein a New Term
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 16 - In a result that was a foregone conclusion, Saddam Hussein was overwhelmingly returned to power as president of Iraq, a top official here said today.

title: Suit Says 42 Were Abused by Clergymen
description: A lawyer representing 42 adults who say Roman Catholic clergy members in Brooklyn groped, raped and abused them when they were children filed a civil complaint in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Bill Green, Former Congressman, Dies at 72
description: Bill Green, a United States representative from Manhattan who served for seven terms and was dedicated to the liberal Republican tradition of Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Senator Jacob K. Javits, died on Monday at New York-Presbyterian Hospital. He was 72.

title: Time to Reflect Is Over as Pennington Prepares for Vikings
description: Quarterback Chad Pennington went to Vermont over the bye weekend, escaping the Jets' fall from grace for fall foliage. But as rocky as the Jets' season has been so far, Pennington's first start went so smoothly that it has nearly been overshadowed by the team's staggering defense.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bill For Business Groups
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday authorizing 19 business improvement districts to increase the amount that they can request of their members for annual expenses. The districts' budgets would range from from $85,000 to $11 million. The bill, brought to the City Council at the mayor's request, was needed, Mr. Bloomberg said, because operating costs for districts have increased and the organizations have plans for enhanced services and programs. The bill applies to 19 of the 44 BID's. Most of the affected BID's have not increased their budgets for at least four years, and this is the first increase for six of them. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: POLO RALPH LAUREN TO REACQUIRE JAPANESE LICENSES
description: The Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation, the clothing maker, will pay about $70 million to reacquire some Japanese licenses and gain greater control over the distribution and production of its apparel. Polo will buy 50 percent of its Japanese master license from Seibu Department Stores, which has sold Polo items since 1978. Polo is also acquiring an 18 percent stake in a new company that will make and sell some of its clothing in Japan, Polo said. The transactions are expected to add to profit in fiscal 2004, Polo said.

title: Shaping Strategy With Israel
description: As a potential target of Iraq's unconventional weapons, Israel is a crucially interested party in America's looming confrontation with Baghdad. When Prime Minister Ariel Sharon meets with President Bush today in Washington, the two leaders need to discuss ways that Israel can defend its citizens without undercutting American diplomatic and military strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON DER OSTEN, LEO F.
description: von der OSTEN-Leo F. On Sunday, October 13th, 2002. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Eric. Memorial mass Friday, 10 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JENSEN, JIM
description: JENSEN-Jim. Still. Always. Rachel

title: Campus Hypocrisy
description: The Washington Post recently reported that students and faculty at a growing number of universities are pressuring their schools ''into selling their holdings in companies that do business with Israel, prompting a counter-campaign among Jewish groups that consider the effort part of a creeping tide of anti-Semitism on campus.'' Here's what I would say to both sides on this issue:

title: This Little Piggy Went . . . Well, a Little Crazy
description: You won't find Peter Callahan, who owns Callahan Catering in Manhattan and Philadelphia, making mundane triangles of smoked salmon on dark bread. He likes to rethink the hors d'oeuvre repertory, so for a winsome and savory cocktail nibble, he spreads thin pumpernickel with a film of cream cheese, tops it with smoked salmon and cuts it in the shape of a pig, then adds a black sesame-seed eye and a broad green belt of wasabi-flavored tobiko (flying fish eggs). Through Thanksgiving, he is selling the pink pigs for $48 a dozen, plus shipping. The minimum order is four dozen. They are frozen and well sealed, so they can be kept on hand for holiday parties, and they thaw in less than an hour. Orders: (212) 327-1144.

title: Auto Workers and Daimler In Tentative Deal in Canada
description: Less than a half-hour before picket lines were set to go up at five DaimlerChrysler plants in Canada, the Canadian Auto Workers union said tonight that it had reached a tentative agreement with the company on a new three-year contract covering 13,000 workers.

title: Of Gift Horses And Close Looks
description: AT a meeting of foundation executives last week, Secretary of Education Rod Paige was asked how school superintendents should handle philanthropists. Dr. Paige replied that they should be more willing to turn away donors whose offers do not advance a district's own priorities.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, HYMAN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Hyman R. Though the years pass your love remains forever in my heart. Ruth

title: Gephardt Offers Tax Cut in Economic Plan
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt set out a Democratic proposal today to stimulate the economy, calling for $75 billion in one-time tax cuts and $125 billion in new spending as part of a strategy to create jobs and restore growth.

title: Global Condom Hunt
description: To the Editor:

title: Creating Noise, and an Uproar
description: They are the noisiest things in baseball since Harry Caray's play-by-play -- inflatable plastic balloons that, when whacked together by 50,000 fans, create a wicked wall of sound.

title: Standing Out in Its Industry, Johnson & Johnson Reports Strong Quarter
description: In sharp contrast to its struggling rivals in the pharmaceutical industry, Johnson & Johnson reported double-digit earnings growth yesterday and told analysts to expect strong results for the year.

title: Keith W. Uncapher, Networking Pioneer, 80
description: Keith W. Uncapher, an engineer who oversaw seminal work in computer networking, especially on the underpinnings of what became the Internet, died last Thursday. He was 80 and lived in the Playa del Rey district of Los Angeles.

title: Ex-ImClone Chief Admits Some U.S. Charges
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the founder of ImClone Systems, pleaded guilty yesterday to six charges, including securities fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice, stemming from his role in a flurry of stock sales that occurred late last year.

title: Calories Do Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Seymour Rexite, 91, Star of Yiddish Stage, Dies
description: Seymour Rexite, a onetime matinee idol of the Yiddish theater and radio, died on Monday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 91, his nephew Mel Friedman said.

title: Youths' Denials in '89 Rape Case Cost Them Parole Chances
description: While they were in state prison, three of the five Harlem teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park insisted that jury verdicts, history books and their own videotaped statements had it entirely wrong: they actually had nothing to do with the attack.

title: McDyess to Have Surgery Today
description: Antonio McDyess received second and third opinions on his fractured left kneecap today, and they agreed with the diagnosis of the Knicks' physician, Dr. Norman Scott. McDyess will undergo surgery, performed by Scott, on Wednesday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: BORENSTEIN-William. To my beloved friend Bill, your courage and strength has been inspirational. Knowing you has enriched my life and I will cherish our friendship forever. Ira Rubenstein

title: Our Towns; From Bottom Of Bird Cages, An Issue Rises
description: THE problem with writing a newspaper column is that you are forced to be wise and provocative on deadline, whether or not you feel wise and provocative at that moment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Missile Officer Apparently Defects
description: In an unusual incident reminiscent of the cold war, the government said that a lieutenant in its missile command, Wang I-hung, flew to China with his family on Oct. 2 during a vacation in Thailand. Without actually declaring him a defector, the army said it had issued a warrant for his arrest and had reprimanded six officers, including the head of the missile command. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, RONALD H.
description: PHILLIPS-Ronald H. Of New Orleans, LA. Formerly of New York City, died on October 10, 2002. He was 70 years old. Ron was the General Manager of the Fountain Bay Club in New Orleans and an executive at CBS, ITC and Columbia Screen Gems in New York City. He is survived by his children Christopher and Pamela. We will miss his humor, his love and his smile. At Ron's request there will be no services but donations can be made to The American Diabetes Association.

title: Percussion And Flute As Stars
description: James Levine's concerts with the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall have become fairly hot tickets, and with good reason: Mr. Levine has transformed his opera orchestra into one of the finest ensembles in the country, and opportunities to hear it outside the pit -- where it can shine on its own, instead of helping singers shine -- come only a few times each season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, MORRIS
description: ROTHENBERG-Morris. Age 84, died on October 11 at The Daughters of Israel in West Orange, N.J. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Brown. Father of David. Grandfather of Adrienne. Brother of Anita Stark and the late Helen Polsky.

title: A Swedish Tasting Tour
description: SWEDISH food has moved beyond white fish and potatoes. Following are the restaurants in and around Stockholm and Goteborg mentioned in this article.

title: A Smaller Loss Than Expected At Delta Sends Shares Up 21%
description: Delta Air Lines reported a deeper loss yesterday, reflecting a summer in which passengers -- worried about the shaky economy and inundated with talk of war and terrorism -- failed to return to the skies at the rate executives had hoped for.

title: In the High-Tech Sector, Optimism Is Just a Faded Memory
description: At this year's Agenda conference, traditionally an upbeat gathering of the computer and Internet industries' elite, attendance was low and the mood even lower. Executives engaged in a hunt for the bottom of the decline with few seeing even a hint of new growth on the horizon.

title: Third Team Enters Pursuit Of Piniella
description: While the Mets were waiting to hear from the Seattle Mariners on what form of compensation they would take to sign Lou Piniella, an unidentified third team emerged yesterday seeking Piniella's services as manager.

title: Bure, in Season Debut, Ignites Rangers' Offense
description: Pavel Bure, who missed the first three games of the Rangers' season, was asked before last night's game how he felt against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden.

title: Have You Hugged A Fish Today?
description: Three years ago the Audubon Society's Living Oceans program introduced a seafood wallet card, shaded in various colors to show which kinds of seafood are in danger of being depleted or harm the environment, and which ones are in good supply and have no such ill effects. Now there is a card specifically for fish commonly available in the New York region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUB, LOLA (NEE LEVINE)
description: LAUB-Lola (nee Levine), 72. On October 14. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Monica and Roberta. Loving stepmother of Steven, Susan and son-in-law Mitchell. Cherished sister of Sarah, Mary and brother-in-law Joseph. Also survived by loving family, Jeryl, Debbie, Michael and David. Services on Thursday 12PM ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Crisis Centers Could Share Office Space
description: The Bloomberg administration is considering a cost-saving plan that would require the Office of Emergency Management to share its proposed new command center with a new backup office for the 911 emergency telephone system, administration officials said yesterday.

title: Museum Gives Voice to Doubts on Dr. King's Killer
description: James Earl Ray, a drifter and ex-convict, shot and killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a single bullet here on an April evening in 1968.

title: DUPONT DELAYS DEAL FOR CHEMFIRST AFTER BLAST AT PLANT
description: The DuPont Company's plan to purchase ChemFirst Inc., a specialty chemical maker, for $408 million was suspended until further investigation of an explosion at a ChemFirst plant in Mississippi, the companies said yesterday. Three employees were injured Sunday in an explosion at the plant in Pascagoula, Miss. Federal, state and local authorities are investigating whether there was environmental damage at the site, ChemFirst said. ChemFirst is cooperating with DuPont to provide information on the accident and the recovery process, the companies said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Carmaker Suspends Production
description: Russia's biggest carmaker, Avtovaz, said it would temporarily stop car production after a sudden rise in the number of imported foreign cars created a glut in the market. Avtovaz will close its plants from Oct. 26 to Nov. 9, a break that Vladimir Savov, an analyst at the Brunswick UBS Warburg investment bank in Moscow, estimated would erase about $2.5 million in profits from the company's books by year-end. The Russian government recently increased import duties on foreign cars older than seven years, which are the main competitors for new Russian cars. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/40-10/20/90. Cherished mother, you are always with me. Alliso

title: Ruling Opens New Arena In the Debate on Abortion
description: A pregnant woman may use deadly force to protect her fetus even when she does not fear for her own life, the Michigan Court of Appeals has ruled. Legal experts say the decision has opened another front in the legal wars surrounding abortion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets Continue to Rise On Upbeat Earnings Reports

title: Everything Is Finally Up to Date in the A.F.C.
description: Peyton Manning arrived in this quiet town from Indianapolis yesterday to shoot a commercial in a cozy park for a throwback jersey clothing line. To conclude the shoot, Manning offers his jersey to a child, saying, ''It's a classic -- it's all yours.'' The child responds, ''Thanks, but I'd rather get my own.''

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Teenager Falls Down Shaft At High School
description: A 16-year-old Bronx boy was critically injured yesterday when he slammed into a closed set of elevator doors, which opened suddenly, sending him falling three stories to the basement of his high school, the authorities said.

title: A Mercenary Prometheus Serving Iraq's Nuclear Ambitions
description: The central figure in ''Stealing the Fire,'' a video documentary by John S. Friedman and Eric Nadler that opens today at the Cinema Village, is one Karl-Heinz Schaab, a deceptively drab German technocrat whose only discernable character trait is a weakness for bad wigs.

title: Tel Aviv Journal; Once Taboo, a Gay Israeli Treads the Halls of Power
description: Uzi Even seemed a bit apprehensive, even as he received another delivery of flowers from well-wishers.

title: Beijing Says Chinese Muslims Are Among Detainees in Cuba
description: The United States is holding more than a dozen Uighur Muslims from western China at its terrorist detention center in Cuba, China's top foreign policy official said in an interview published here this week.

title: Of Unicorns and Satyrs and Things With No Knees
description: BAUDOLINO

title: A Mental Health Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: The Reel Thing

title: Bush Places Senate's Delays on Judicial Appointees at Core of Campaigning
description: President Bush's ability to shape the federal bench, at stake in the November election, is heating up this year's election campaigns.

title: Bless Butter, Cream And Simple French Fare
description: DOES anyone really eat French food anymore?

title: A Tiny Harvest of Tiny Bay Scallops
description: THE bay scallop industry, once a $4 million a year business on the East End of Long Island, is heading into another bad year, baymen say, with this year's harvest of sweet Peconic Bay scallops expected to be no better than last year's, when less than 2,000 pounds was available for sale to stores and restaurants.

title: Women of Rock With a Tale to Tell
description: Like a lot of rock bands, the female trio Betty has had its disappointments on the road to stardom. What with shortsighted record company executives, the rigors of low-budget touring, the humiliations of opening for bigger-name bands, not to mention the internal rivalries and personal crises that arise with long association and not-so-good times, Betty has nearly come apart more than once -- evidently as recently as last year -- since it was formed in a suburban basement in Fairfax, Va., in 1985.

title: WORLDCOM GETS APPROVAL FOR $1.1 BILLION LOAN
description: WorldCom Inc. won a bankruptcy judge's approval of a $1.1 billion loan to help finance its reorganization and reassure vendors and customers. Judge Arthur Gonzalez of United States Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan turned aside the objections of several creditors who argued the financing might favor lenders over creditors. The loan will give confidence to vendors and comfort to customers, Marcia Goldstein, WorldCom's bankruptcy lawyer, told the court. Without it, WorldCom's ability to get the goods and services it needs using trade credit would be severely limited, jeopardizing the company's chances of emerging from Chapter 11, she said.

title: Protests Swirl Around Jogger Case
description: The growing controversy over new developments in the Central Park jogger case brought several protests and calls for action yesterday as news conferences and shouting matches spun in downtown Manhattan like little twisters around a big storm.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He leaned down and hugged me and said, 'I'm sorry to have worried you.'''

title: Kids, Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice in the Central Park Jogger Case
description: New York City is revisiting the 13-year-old case of the Central Park jogger and the five young men who were convicted in that sensational trial of beating and raping her. A convicted serial rapist and murderer, Matias Reyes, now says he and he alone stalked and attacked the woman, leaving her for dead. The young men, all of whom have completed their sentences, are asking to have their convictions set aside. The hysteria that surrounded the case may have contributed to a grave injustice. If so, their names should be cleared of the felony convictions that require sex offenders to register and make them ineligible for certain jobs.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Move to Brooklyn

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Judge Orders Inquiry Of President
description: An appeals court judge ordered prosecutors to open a criminal investigation into President Leonid D. Kuchma, saying accusations that Mr. Kuchma approved illegal arms sales to Iraq and was tied to the murder of an opposition journalist were crippling Ukrainian politics and should be laid to rest. Mr. Kuchma's presidency has been in shadows for more than a year since secretly recorded conversations appeared to implicate him in illegal acts. His aides called Judge Yuri Vasylenko's move unconstitutional but the five opposition members of Parliament who asked for the order hailed it as a breakthrough for democracy. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, CHARLOTTE R.
description: WEISSBERG-Charlotte R. Of Newton, MA, formerly of New York City, on Friday, October 11, 2002. Loving mother of Alexander Weissberg Walker and Marya Weissberg Walker, both of Newton, MA. Devoted sister of Dr. Michael P. Weissberg & his wife Susan of Boulder, CO. Beloved aunt of Nico Weissberg. Former wife of Allen Walker. Daughter of the late Gustav & Bella (Trachtenberg) Weissberg. Dear friend of Richard Ward, Janet Mendelsohn and Peter Rutter. Services at the Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, on Friday, October 18 at 10:00 AM. Interment at the Newton Cemetery, Walnut Street, Newton, MA. Memorial observance Friday only, immediately following the interment, at the home of Janet Mendelsohn and Marc Levitt. In lieu of flowers remembrances may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Man in Hospital After Attack by Pit Bulls
description: A Willingboro, N.J., man who was attacked by two pit bulls in his house on Monday remained hospitalized in stable condition yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Philips Narrows Loss
description: A costcutting program helped Royal Philips Electronics narrow its third-quarter loss to 330 million euros ($326 million) from the 736 million euros ($727 million) it lost in the period a year earlier. The news helped push Philips shares traded in Amsterdam up 15 percent, to 17.19 euros ($16.96). Sales rose 2 percent, with increases in semiconductors, components and domestic appliances among others. But the company said sales for equipment used in wireless phones and digital networks fell sharply. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, ANNE (NEE KLEIN)
description: HOCHBERG - Anne (nee Klein). Longtime early childhood and reading teacher, P.S. 152. Beloved wife of Harold. Devoted mother of David and Maryann, and Gary and Lee. Loving sister of Nellie Sandler. Cherished grandmother of David and Joseph. Services 1 P.M. Thursday, Riverdale Temple, 246th Street and Independence Ave. Donations to National Parkinson's Foundation.

title: Lack of News Doesn't Deter Coverage
description: All but one of this area's local television stations broke into their regular programming today to broadcast yet another sniper news conference by Chief Charles A. Moose of the Montgomery County police.

title: Mixed Results In Revenue And Profit At Motorola
description: Motorola reported late yesterday that it had slightly exceeded investors' diminished earnings expectations for the quarter that ended Sept. 30 but that it had fallen well short of Wall Street's revenue projections.

title: Prize Is Awarded To Book on Dance
description: The Dance Perspectives Foundation has announced that its Jos Rollins de la Torre Bueno Prize in Dance Literature, which honors the most original book of dance scholarship published in English during the previous year, will go to Michele Temple for ''The Middle Eastern Influence on Late Medieval Italian Dances: Origins of the 29,987 Istampittas,'' published by the Edwin Mellen Press in Lewiston, N.Y.

title: Teenager Held In Bombing That Killed 7 At Finnish Mall
description: The police detained four Finns, three of them teenagers, in connection with the bombing at a crowded shopping mall last Friday that killed seven people and wounded as many as 100 in a suburb of Helsinki. Three of the four were later released.

title: When the people who make ad decisions gather, they are sitting ducks for hard and soft sells.
description: HERE are some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights from the 2002 conference of the Association of National Advertisers, which took place Thursday through Sunday in Naples, Fla.

title: Miscellany
description: * Will Vinton Studios, Portland, Ore., spun off Character, a consulting company focused on developing and revitalizing brand characters in advertising campaigns. David Altschul is president.

title: Loner, Teenager or Hunter? Experts Offer Three Profiles
description: Who is the phantom sniper? An icy loner? A macho hunter? A teenager with a friend?

title: Tears and Hugs as 5 Abducted Japanese Go Home to Visit
description: On the tarmac of Tokyo's domestic airport, tears and long hugs contrasted today with the festive red-and-white Japanese flags and the homemade banners reading ''Welcome Home.''

title: Matching the Singer's Spirit To That of the Composer
description: Ann Hampton Callaway

title: The Uninvited Pest
description: New York City is a land of captive trees, whether you think of the nearly natural expanses of Central Park and Prospect Park or the private gardens that thrive on terraces and rooftops. But to an Asian longhorned beetle, wood is wood, and with 5.2 million trees, New York has a lot of wood to offer. Half of its trees grow on private property. The beetles have no trouble getting access to the private gardens, but the Agriculture Department's inspectors who are desperately trying to contain this menace do.

title: Black Heart, White Van
description: Chief Moose says he's looking for ''closure.'' I wish he'd simply look for sniper.

title: Al Qaeda Ties Are Suspected
description: F.B.I. agents and Pakistani police arrested four Afghan men today who were suspected of having ties to Al Qaeda in a refugee camp near the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said.

title: Mayor Faults Council on Building for Homeless
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg criticized the City Council yesterday for moving to block the construction of a new building in East Harlem that would provide permanent apartments and social services for mentally ill homeless people.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a French immigrant who is leading a drive to involve more blacks and Arabs in French politics misspelled the given name of a jazz musician who was among the talented black Americans welcomed in Paris over the years. He was Sidney Bechet, not Sydney.

title: Pilot Training and Reaction Are Focus in Queens Crash
description: With hearings into the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 set to open later this month, investigators have turned up new information that has led them to focus more intensely on pilot training and performance as they try to explain the disaster that left 265 dead in Queens last November.

title: Court Ruling Limits Prosecutors' Access to Patient Records
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that prosecutors cannot demand hospital medical records in their efforts to seek criminal suspects who have been wounded, because doing so infringes on patient confidentiality.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, MORRIS
description: BLASER-Morris. October 16, 1966. We love you always. We never forget you. Love, The Blaser Family

title: Terror's Aftermath in Indonesia
description: After Sept. 11, there was a sense among Americans that the country had to come together for comfort, for protection and for rebuilding. The reaction in Indonesia to the Bali bombings has been very different, and it speaks to the lack of faith that Indonesians have in their own government. It also suggests that the United States and other nations with a significant presence in Indonesia should redouble efforts to strengthen political institutions here and demand accountability from government.
