Without more popular support, the war on terror here is not going to be won.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LADUE, RUSSELL MORSBY
description: LaDUE-Russell Morsby. On October 14, 2002. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. His sweet nature, intelligence, love of life, gentle good humor and genuine affection for others, made Russ an adored figure to all who knew him. The family will be home to visitors from 4 PM-8 PM Wednesday, October 16th and Thursday, October 17th. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name may be made to The Neighborhood Playhouse, 212688-3770.

title: INSIDE
description: Judges a Campaign Issue

title: Corrections
description: A roll-call listing on Friday for the House vote authorizing military action against Iraq misstated the given name of one representative in some copies. He is Lane Evans, not Land. It also misstated the party affiliation of Heather Wilson, who voted for the resolution -- she is a Republican -- and gave erroneous state identifications for some members. A corrected listing appeared on Saturday and may be found online today, at nytimes.com/corrections.

title: Accounts
description: * Four European divisions of Sony consolidated the media planning and buying duties on their accounts at the London office of OMD, part of the Omnicom Group. They are Sony Europe, Berlin; Sony Music Entertainment Europe, London; Columbia TriStar Film Distributors International, London; and Columbia TriStar Home Entertainment, London. Advertising Age estimated that the divisions spent $500 million a year on European advertising. The media duties had been divided between offices of OMD, which handled assignments for Sony Europe and much of Sony Music, and the Zenith Optimedia Group, which handled assignments for the Columbia units. Zenith is owned by the Publicis Groupe and by the Cordiant Communications Group.

title: Turning Phrase to Wrest Social Security Issue From Democrats
description: When a Congressional candidate begins her speech to the party faithful by saying, ''I want you to know that I oppose the privatization of Social Security,'' she sounds like a Democratic candidate getting ready to denounce the Republicans on an old issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILBERG, RUTH (POOPSIE)
description: MILBERG-Ruth (Poopsie). Beloved wife of the late Saul Allen. Loving mother of Claire, Florence, Marlene and Mark. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother.

title: A Buffeted Troupe of Women Show Resilience but Not Chaos
description: Gina Gibney Dance

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Airline Investment
description: Taiwan's main air carrier, China Airlines, won approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs of Taiwan to buy a 25 percent stake in China Cargo Airlines in Shanghai. The deal has been under discussion for two years and is the first investment by a Taiwan carrier in China's aviation industry. Beijing gave its approval last summer. China Airlines will pay $49 million for its stake in China Cargo, which has three MD-11 freighters and had revenue last year of $151 million. China Eastern, a Chinese airline, controls the small cargo airline. Taiwan's government has been grudgingly approving deals with mainland companies despite concerns that the economy is becoming highly dependent on the mainland, from which Taiwan broke away politically in 1949, at the end of China's civil war. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: White House Sends Mixed Signal on Backing a System That Ties Bullets to Their Guns
description: With the Washington region reeling from the sniper shootings, the White House said tonight that it had asked federal law enforcement experts to study whether creating a national computerized system for tracing bullets and shell casings to the guns that fired them would be an effective crime-fighting tool.

title: New Head for Hebrew Union
description: RABBI DAVID ELLENSON was inaugurated on Sunday as the eighth president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion. He succeeds DR. NORMAN J. COHEN as head of the institution, which provides academic and professional training for the Reform movement's rabbis, cantors and educators and has campuses in New York, Cincinnati, Los Angeles and Jerusalem.

title: SPX BUYS VANCE INTERNATIONAL FOR $67 MILLION
description: The SPX Corporation, whose security unit provides security services, bought a closely held security provider, Vance International Inc., for $67 million. SPX said Vance had revenue of about $95 million a year and would join SPX's Security and Investigations unit. Under the Vance trade name, the SPX unit will focus on protection services and security consulting.

title: Secret Military Spy Planes Enlisted in Hunt for Sniper
description: The Pentagon agreed today to patrol the skies over the nation's capital with secret surveillance planes -- now used to combat drug lords in Colombia and track military movements in North Korea -- as part of a broadening effort to catch the sniper in the Washington area.

title: Stylish, and So Cool You May Need a Parka
description: DR. JOYCE F. BROWN has her vermilion manicure wrapped around the remote control that operates the gale-force air-conditioning system that keeps her office at SUNY's Fashion Institute of Technology, where she became president in 1998, more than fashionably cool. Cold.

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Aucoin's Score Early in Overtime Caps Islanders' Rally
description: Adrian Aucoin said he simply did what defensemen are told and flipped a long, hard wrist shot toward the inside of the goal post. And in an abrupt turnaround for the luckless Islanders, the shot went in and the game was over.

title: N.Y.U. to Study Learning
description: New York University has received a $2.5 million grant from the National Science Foundation to study how culture may influence academic performance. Psychologists, economists and sociologists at the Center for Research on Culture, Development and Education will track the scholastic performance and motivation of children from various racial and ethnic backgrounds in the next five years. The goal of the center is to pinpoint the variables, like home life, behavior with peers and TV, radio and newspaper exposure, that affect scholastic achievement, and to examine how those factors might vary across cultures. Mark Glassman

title: North Korea Says It Has a Program on Nuclear Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 - Confronted by new American intelligence, North Korea has admitted that it has been conducting a major clandestine nuclear-weapons development program for the past several years, the Bush administration said tonight. Officials added that North Korea had also informed them that it was terminating a 1994 agreement with the United States to freeze all of its nuclear activity.

title: Gannett's Profit Climbs 52% on Strong Television Ad Sales
description: The Gannett Company said today that its third-quarter profit increased 52 percent as advertising sales at its television stations rose and costs fell.

title: Recipe: Salsa Verde
description: Adapted from Antonio Martinez of Artie's Delicatessen

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAINER, HERMAN L. (HY).
description: SAINER-Herman L. (Hy). Beloved husband of Janet Sainer for 61 years; devoted father of Alicia, Elliot, and Debbie and their spouses, Richard, Marcia and Dennis; proud grandfather of Todd, Diana and Rachel; dear brother of Viola Harris. Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Wednesday, October 16, at 12:45 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SUSSMAN - Gertrude. Be loved wife of the late Dr. Ralph Sussman and Leopold Sneider. Devoted mother of Elizabeth and Edward Stevens, Agnes and Henry Gottlieb, and Elizabeth Socolow. Fond mother-in-law of Lee Sneider Poates. Sister of Jeanette Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Clara, Michael, Catherine, Annie, Daniel, Thomas, David, Erin and Seth. Great grandmother of Stephen Ernest. Services 11 AM Wednesday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice or Cancer Care.

title: PLANT SHUTDOWNS AT OSTEOTECH REDUCED ITS EARNINGS
description: Osteotech Inc., which recalled human tissue for transplants last month because of sterility concerns, said a shutdown of some processing reduced third-quarter earnings by 5 cents a share. Osteotech lost $1.34 million in sales during the shutdown, and that reduced net income by 2 cents a share. A reserve of about $540,000, or $900,000 pretax, for costs related to quarantining some donor tissue reduced net income another 3 cents, said Osteotech's chief financial officer, Michael Jeffries. In September, Osteotech stopped processing some human tissue for transplants because of concern about possible contamination. The Food and Drug Administration completed an inspection this month related to the suspension, and the company resumed tissue-segment processing on Oct. 8 at its Shrewsbury, N.J., plant. Processing at Osteotech's Eatontown, N.J., plant will resume by the end of the month, the company said.

title: Northern Lights: The New Flavors of Sweden
description: IN one corner of Stockholm's dill-perfumed Ostermalm market, which was built in 1888, Dieter Berner presides over a mini-mesa of shaved ice. Every day, for the delectation of his discriminating customers, he arranges on it a magnificent piscatorial still-life -- trout and cod, perch and pike, sole and lemon sole, hake and brill and arctic char, eel and shrimp, crab and langouste and scallops, immense turbot, glacier-white halibut, hideous anglerfish, elegant silver-skinned wild salmon with underslung jaws, and that great Scandinavian favorite, plaice, with little orange-red spots that look uncannily like measles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, AUDREY RENEE
description: ROSEMAN-Audrey Renee. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Roseman, beloved and devoted mother of Donna and Jeffrey, dear sister of Ellie and Gerald, loving motherin-law of Ted and proud and adoring grandmother of Emma Faye, passed away peacefully after a long illness. Her grace, intelligence, beauty, humor and creative flare touched all those who knew her. Private funeral services will be held. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the New York Chapter of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Buys 20% Stake In Mobile Digital
description: Palm Inc., the largest maker of hand-held computers, bought 20 percent of the closely held software publisher Mobile Digital Media Inc. yesterday to develop new applications and increase hardware sales. Mobile Digital, started earlier this year and run by Barry Cottle, a former chief operating officer of Palm, publishes and distributes software for hand-held computers and mobile telephones. It has 13 employees. Palm is searching for a way to lift demand and combat declining sales and losses that totaled $734.9 million in the last seven quarters.

title: One 15th-Century Print Does a Star Turn in Cleveland
description: In a museum known for picking outstanding single works by great artists, a show based on one medieval engraving is especially appropriate.

title: What to Do Downtown
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Scene, Tears Shed For the Dead And Bali, Too
description: The blackened shells of two shattered nightclubs were filled with activity again this evening, not with the hundreds of partygoers who died here in a terrorist attack three days ago but with their memories.

title: Two Composers' Homages To Famed Artist Friends
description: It is an old conundrum. Two of the pieces in Speculum Musicae's concert at Merkin Concert Hall on Monday were homages to artists with whom the composers enjoyed friendship and mutual respect, and yet the work of Earle Brown and Arthur Berger is far less well known than that of Robert Rauschenberg and Robert Motherwell.

title: German Funds Pour Money Into U.S. Properties
description: When the Commonwealth Tower just across the Potomac River from Washington in Rosslyn, Va., changed ownership in July for $106.7 million, the buyer was a German investment fund. And so was the seller.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TEMPLE-INLAND INC., Austin, Tex., a maker of lumber and boxes, agreed to sell Mid-America Packaging, a bag-making business, and a paper mill in Pine Bluff, Ark., to an undisclosed buyer for $41 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, JANET PRICHARD
description: WAGNER-Janet Prichard. On October 13, 2002, at 77. Survived by her children, William Wagner, Elizabeth Wagner Vaughan. Devoted grandmother of Becket Wagner and Breck Parsons. Sister of Elizabeth Prichard. A graduate of Adelphi College and a master's degree from NYU School of Education. Board member of the Myasthenia Gravis Alliance.

title: U.S. SAYS IT TOLD INDONESIA OF PLOT BY TERROR GROUP
description: The United States repeatedly warned the Indonesian government in the weeks before the bomb blast that killed more than 180 people in Bali that a group linked to Al Qaeda was planning attacks to kill Americans and other Westerners, Bush administration officials said today.

title: Surfing, Teaching and Rugby Drew 3 Americans
description: The three Americans who are thought to have been killed in the Bali bombing represented the diverse reasons that send people to the far corners of the earth.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by Gov. James E. McGreevey to reorganize the New Jersey university system misstated the response of officials at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark. They have said the proposal is worth consideration; they do not oppose it.

title: Ferocious Child Abuse, Without Common Consequences
description: Van Fischer's independent feature ''Blink of an Eye'' begins with its protagonist, surly Tommy (Frank John Hughes) being released from a California prison after serving seven years for running drugs across the Mexican border. Mr. Fischer shoots the sequence through an amber filter, giving it the warm, gold-tinged look generally reserved for nostalgic flashbacks.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Ex-Guard Kills Seven
description: A former security guard heavily armed with automatic weapons killed his ex-wife and six other people before fatally shooting himself in a suburb of Turin in northern Italy. The police said Mauro Antonello, an avid gun collector, also killed his former mother-in-law and several of her neighbors in the town of Chieri. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: U.S. Stance On Antisedition Law
description: The State Department has drafted a formal position on Hong Kong's plans for antisedition legislation, calling for the law to build ''upon existing legislation where possible and providing a clear and narrowly drawn definition of offenses.'' The draft stops short of endorsing the position of Hong Kong's democracy advocates, who contend that no antisedition legislation should be introduced even though it is called for in the Chinese territory's constitution. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Skeletons Tell Tale of Gamble By Immigrants
description: About four months ago somewhere along a stretch of railroad tracks in Texas, perhaps, or Mexico, 11 people took a death-defying gamble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, KATHERINE M.
description: JOHNSON-Katherine M. October 15. Daughter of Gladys and John Johnson, both deceased. Dear friend of Mary McGloin. Visiting 11-Noon, Funeral at Noon, Friday, October 18, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W 55 St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODEN, JAMES R.
description: GRODEN-James R. On October 12, 2002 of Yardley, PA. Beloved husband of Diana. Devoted father of Matthew. Dear brother of Lewis. James was a second degree black belt in Tang Soo Do karate, and an avid surfer, boater, motorcyclist and loyal friend. Services Wednesday 1PM at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpk, Woodbury, LI.

title: Candidates For Governor Are at Odds Over Nursing
description: Accusing Gov. George E. Pataki of ''putting politics before patients,'' H. Carl McCall warned yesterday that the state had failed to stem a nursing shortage that national experts have said contributed to death and injury of hospital patients.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Oct. 1 about Linda LeRoy Janklow misstated her title with the nonprofit education program ArtsConnection. She is the founding chairwoman, not a founding partner. A correction in this space on Oct. 3 misidentified the organization for which she is chairwoman emeritus. It is Lincoln Center Theater, not Lincoln Center.

title: A Union of Word and Sound In a Jungle of Sung Poetry
description: Wolfgang Holzmair, baritone

title: A Flourish At the Finish
description: DINNERS that seem so oppressive in midsummer, not only to cook but to eat, are welcome the instant the weather breaks. For instance, braising, a nearly insane form of cooking for about a third of the year, returns this month, putting aromatic humidity in the air and tender meat on the table. And like most braised dishes, this stew of pork teamed with garlic, red wine and coriander takes time but, once the initial browning is done, very little work.

title: Signature Move by the 49ers' Owens Creates a Stir
description: Terrell Owens, who ranks among the N.F.L. leaders in catching passes and celebrating in strange ways, has emerged from his latest escapade with a light warning from the league.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Bodega Owner Killed
description: The owner of a Bronx bodega was fatally stabbed during a robbery early yesterday by one of three men who were apparently lying in wait for him when he returned home, the police said. The men fled with about $140 in cash and jewelry after the attack about 1 a.m., the police said. The bodega owner, Juan Madera, 38, who was stabbed in the stomach, was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he died about 3:40 a.m., the police said. The three attackers confronted Mr. Madera and two of his employees and demanded money, the police said. The employees were not injured. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: U.N. Disease Fund Opens Way to Generics
description: A $2 billion global fund to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria will encourage poor countries to buy cheap generic medicines instead of expensive brand-name ones, its director said yesterday.

title: U.S. Says Meat Plant's Products Are Probable Source of Bacteria
description: Turkey and chicken products of the Pilgrim's Pride Corporation are likely to have been a source of the listeria that caused seven deaths in seven Northeast states, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Giants Turn to Legree At Defensive Tackle
description: Lance Legree was on the field when it happened.

title: Pilson to Aid I.O.C. With TV Talks
description: Neal Pilson, who successfully negotiated the rights to three Winter Olympics television contracts when he ran CBS Sports, will advise the International Olympic Committee on its future United States network negotiations.

title: Capezio Group Gives Dance Award
description: Michael M. Kaiser, president of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, has been chosen to receive the 51st annual Capezio Award. The award, which includes a $10,000 cash prize, is to be given to Mr. Kaiser on Oct. 25 at the Kennedy Center. Established by the Capezio Ballet Makers Dance Foundation, it is one of the most prestigious awards in dance, honoring significant contributions to the art.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAIRD, EARL S.
description: BAIRD-Earl S., 98, formerly of Baird-Patrick & Co., Inc, died October 12, 2002.

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Revisit Prickly Issue of States' Immunity to Lawsuits Beyond Their Borders
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can be sued without its consent in another state's courts.

title: President Bush Signs Iraq Resolution
description: President Bush signed the Congressional resolution today that gives him the authority to use military force, if necessary, to strip Iraq of biological and chemical weapons that the White House says Saddam Hussein's government has collected, and to disband Baghdad's purported nuclear weapons program.

title: Time Inc. to Close Sports Illustrated Women
description: Sports Illustrated Women, a monthly magazine, is closing, a senior Time Inc. executive said late this afternoon.

title: Escaping the Grip of Cancer, Only to Die at a Sniper's Hand
description: It was a tumultuous year for Linda Franklin. But hers were not just the stresses of working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the time of terror, or the reflexive motherly worries about her children and the health of a first grandchild about to be born.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Editor's Note

title: Prohibition's Nectar (A Manhattan With a Twist of Peru)
description: In Lima, Peru, they know about the cocktail called El Capitan. It looks like a Manhattan, but in place of the whiskey that's usually mixed with the vermouth, this version calls for Pisco, the Peruvian brandy. The drink is lighter tasting than a Manhattan and delicious, as people who tried it at Peruvian lunches in the Delegates' Dining Room at the United Nations recently discovered.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the Congressional election in New Mexico's Second District referred incompletely to the presence of Hispanic candidates in the campaign for governor, which could influence the Congressional voting by increasing Hispanic turnout. The Democratic candidate for governor, Bill Richardson, is not the only Hispanic in the race; the Republican candidate, John Sanchez, is another.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HERMAN
description: MILLER-Herman. On October 15, 2002. Devoted husband of Frieda, father of Barbara Tancil and Myron Miller. Caring grandfather of Mark and Jeffery Tancil and Matthew, David and Tamara Porter Miller. Memorial service, October 16, 9:45 AM at Riverside Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam.

title: The Latest in Luxury: Haggling; In a Slow Economy, Some of the Best Stores Bargain
description: Roseann Hirsch was at Bloomingdale's shopping for furniture for her new Park Avenue apartment not long ago when she saw some Louis XVI-style couches. The ultrasuede couches, originally priced at $5,600 each, had been marked down to $3,360.

title: Sudan Government and Rebels Agree to Cease-Fire
description: The Sudanese government agreed today to a cease-fire with the rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation movement, a hopeful sign in the 19-year conflict that comes as negotiators for both sides resume peace talks this week in Kenya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBBY, RUTH G.
description: LIBBY-Ruth G. On October 13, 2002. Of Douglaston NY. Loving wife of the late F. Meredith Libby. Beloved mother of Alice Libby and Barbara Ferency. Dear sister of Claire Mielke and Albert Guilford. Also survived by 8 cherished grandchildren, fourteen great-grandchildren and one great-great-grandchild. Visiting at the Doyle B. Shaffer Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Blvd, Little Neck NY on Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9. Funeral service Friday, 1PM in the Community Church of Douglaston, Douglaston, NY. Interment Zion Cemetery, Douglaston.

title: Wild-Card Series: A New Paradigm For an Old Game
description: A relative newcomer to the wild-card format of sports playoffs, Major League Baseball stands ready to celebrate the first wild-card World Series in history. Not everyone is ecstatic about the development, however.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Like Father, Like Son

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Financier Quits A Board
description: The Swiss billionaire Martin Ebner, left, abruptly resigned from the board of ABB, the Swiss engineering company, saying he needed to spend more time getting his own company, BZ Holding, back on track. Shares in ABB were suspended briefly, then soared on the news when trading resumed. BZ Holding has been the most recent victim of the bear markets. The company was forced to sell its stake in the Swiss chemical company Lonza earlier this month. BZ officials refused to speculate on the future of its 10 percent holding of ABB. BZ also has a large ownership in Credit Suisse and the Baloise insurance company. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Saudis Foil Hijacking Of Airliner
description: A Saudi man armed with a pistol tried to hijack a Saudi Arabian Airlines jet carrying 204 people today shortly after it left Khartoum, Sudan, but guards overpowered him and the plane returned safely to the airport, the airline and Sudanese officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, S. WILLIAM (BILL).
description: GREEN-S. William (Bill). On October 14, 2002. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Freiberg). Devoted and cherished father of Cathy Green and Louis Green. Dear brother of Cynthia Green Colin. Fond brother-in-law of Carole and Marvin Leichtung. Loving uncle of nieces, Julie, Laura, Ann and Betsy, and nephew, Jim. A native of New York City, he served his city and his country in many capacities, both before and after representing the East Side of Manhattan in the House of Representatives from 1978 to 1992. He was a graduate and loyal alumnus of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Tuesday, October 15, and Wednesday, October 16, from 7 PM-9 PM. Services Thursday, October 17, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a French immigrant who is leading a drive to involve more blacks and Arabs in French politics misspelled the given name of a jazz musician who was among the talented black Americans welcomed in Paris over the years. He was Sidney Bechet, not Sydney.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, CARL T., M.D.
description: WOLFF-Carl T., M.D. Passed away with valor in the face of colon cancer on October 14 at the age of 71. Beloved husband of Carolyn Chaliff. Devoted father of Leslie Culhane, Andrew E. Wolff and Jonathan M. Wolff. Admired father-in-law of Myles Culhane. Proud grandfather of Jackson Culhane. Cherished uncle of Ilana and Jeffrey Previdi. Treasured friend and trusted advisor to many. A man of great accomplishment, Carl, above all, loved and protected his family. He brought a passionate enthusiasm to an array of interests: the arts, the wilderness, the cello, golf, gardening, travel, Proust, Wagner, and the Yankees. A 1949 graduate of the Horace Mann School, Carl led his class as an athlete and scholar. He majored in English at Yale University, from which he graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1953. He was awarded a medical degree from the Harvard Medical School in 1957. From 1960-1964, he interned at the Massachusetts General Hospital, was a resident at the Massachusetts Mental Health Service, and served with the National Institute of Mental Health in Washington, D.C. In 1964, he returned to New York City as Instructor at the Downstate Medical Center. He continued his training at the New York Psychoanalytic Institute from 1966 until 1971 and maintained a private practice in psychiatry and psychoanalysis until his retirement in 1998. Carl found inspiration in the planet's abundant beautyfrom the tundra of the Arctic Circle to the corn patch in Pound Ridge, from the mountains of Nepal to the dunes of Amagansett. An expansive humanist, he believed in science and intellectual inquiry as powerful ways to savor and decipher the mysteries of the universe. His embracing spirit will continue to nourish us always. Contributions in his memory to Lewa Wildlife Conservancy, a rhino sanctuary in Kenya (c/o Helen Christian; P.O. Box 368; Marshall, VA 20116), or to a charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 20, at 4:30 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Execution Recommended
description: A Vinton County jury has recommended that Gregory McKnight, 25, be executed for killing a student at Kenyon College in Gambier in 2000. The student, Emily Murray, 20, had been missing for a month when her body was found in Mr. McKnight's trailer, 80 miles away in Ray, south of Columbus. The case attracted attention in August, when Judge Jeffrey L. Simmons of the Court of Common Pleas in Vinton County told prosecutors that he would not allow them to seek the death penalty because the cost of defending a capital case was too high for the county to bear. The judge later reversed himself. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Fusing the Beat of Africa With the Power of Rock
description: For the greatest African rock musicians, every homecoming carries back something new. Salif Keita, from Mali, led his band on Sunday night at Irving Plaza in songs that seemed to have all of Africa, and beyond, at their fingertips. He has constantly hybridized his music, and with his current band he folds all his exotica into arrangements that only seems traditional.

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance
description: CABARET

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Threats Against Denver Water
description: Water officials in the ski resort town of Winter Park said a group has threatened to destroy two underground water storage tanks owned by the Denver Water Board as a protest over barring access to the land above the tanks. The tanks supply water to Denver, 40 miles to the east. A letter making the threat was turned over to the Denver office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which said it has begun investigating. A radical environmental group, Earth Liberation Front, denied published reports that it was involved in the threat. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Deep Pockets Aside, Forrester Is Short on Donors
description: Douglas R. Forrester has raised barely $1 million from individual donors since winning the New Jersey Republican Senate primary in June, according to campaign records filed with the Federal Election Commission today. The sum is considerably less than political analysts had expected and raises questions about how well his campaign will be able to compete as the Senate race goes into its final three weeks.

title: SUNY Enrollment Is Up
description: Enrollment at the State University of New York rose 3.5 percent this year, to 402,111 students, ROBERT L. KING, SUNY's chancellor, has announced. Enrollment of full-time students hit a record 269,324, a 6.1 percent gain over last year. Community college enrollment grew to 198,823, a 5.2 percent increase from last year, while enrollment at SUNY's four-year colleges grew 2 percent, to 203,288. A recent study by the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government found that more than one million students were enrolled in colleges and universities in the state in 1999.

title: Bush's Domestic Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: An Influx of New Talent, Courtesy of the San Francisco Ballet
description: The San Francisco Ballet should visit us more often. The expense of a self-produced season might dictate otherwise but a major company should be followed, not merely glimpsed, in an international dance center like New York.

title: The Watchful Society
description: To the Editor:

title: After 5 Years, 7 Are Charged In Death of Girl Who Vanished
description: Nearly five years after a 13-year-old girl from New Milford, Conn., disappeared, the authorities yesterday announced the arrests of four men and three women in what they described as a horrific case of kidnapping, sexual assault and murder.

title: Earnings Up at Citigroup Despite Other Woes
description: Citigroup reported a 23 percent increase in third-quarter profit yesterday, providing a welcome distraction to investors anxious about numerous investigations involving the company's investment banking business.

title: A Ball in the Hand Is Worth a Lot -- to the Lawyers
description: The San Francisco Giants are in the World Series for the first time since 1989, when play against the Oakland Athletics was interrupted by an earthquake.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: PHILIPS NARROWS LOSS A cost- cutting program helped Royal Philips Electronics narrow its third-quarter loss to 330 million euros ($326 million) from the 736 million euros ($727 million) it lost in the period a year earlier. The news helped push Philips shares traded in Amsterdam up 15 percent, to 17.19 euros ($16.96). Sales rose 2 percent, with increases in semiconductors, components and domestic appliances among others. But the company said sales for equipment used in wireless phones and digital networks fell sharply.

title: CALENDAR
description: Tasting at Grand Central

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Prohibition's Nectar: A Manhattan With a Twist of Peru
description: In Lima, Peru, they know about the cocktail called El Capitn. It looks like a Manhattan, but in place of the whiskey that's usually mixed with the vermouth, this version calls for Pisco, the Peruvian brandy. The drink is lighter tasting than a Manhattan and delicious, as people who tried it at Peruvian lunches in the Delegates' Dining Room at the United Nations recently discovered.

title: Chief of Advertising Sales Is Leaving CBS
description: Joseph D. Abruzzese, who has led the advertising sales department at CBS for the last 12 years, will leave the network to join the Discovery Networks of cable television as president of sales.

title: A Definition at Last, but What Does It All Mean?
description: AFTER 30 years of ridicule, indifference and sometimes downright hostility from the government, the organic food movement has triumphed over the bureaucracy. Starting Monday, all foods labeled ''organic'' must comply with rigorous national standards that the movement has sought for years.

title: A Red Wine With Enough Muscle to Take On Any Food
description: IF you were brought up on big, buttery California reds, Riojas, even the reservas, will seem coarse and a little ratty. The tannins are edgy and the acidity can be blunt.

title: Learning to Work in an Heirloom After Life in a Warren
description: Six weeks into its reincarnation as the headquarters of the New York City school system, the Tweed Courthouse has forced its 600 new inhabitants to make major adjustments.

title: Military Recruiters Are Allowed
description: Columbia Law School last week agreed to treat military recruiters the same as other recruiters, even though its ''Don't Ask, Don't Tell'' policy, which bars openly gay people from the military, does not comply with the school's nondiscrimination policy. Columbia's decision followed similar actions by other law schools, including Harvard's and Yale's, that have bowed to the government's threat to withdraw hundreds of millions of dollars in federal research money if military recruiters are not treated equally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Officer Dies After Shooting
description: A Philadelphia police officer was fatally shot at his ex-girlfriend's home on Monday after returning with their 7-year-old son from a custody visit, the White Plains police said yesterday. The police officer, Sgt. Jeffrey Troebs, 41, died at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla yesterday, a day after he was shot in the head with a semiautomatic handgun owned by his ex-girlfriend, Pia Stefanelli. The White Plains police are investigating the case, and would not say who fired the shot. William Nardozzi, an administrator in the Westchester County Emergency Services Department, was also in the apartment at the time. The police described him as Ms. Stefanelli's boyfriend. No charges had been filed by last evening. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Security Problems At Agency
description: The Department of Transportation said yesterday that it was working to repair security problems at motor vehicle offices. According to an internal memorandum to the state transportation commissioner, James P. Fox, left, a state police investigation found that the offices had inadequate storage vaults and door locks to protect key documents. The police also found important documents stored in unsecured areas that could be easily opened by cleaning crews and others, the memorandum said. The problems were first reported in The Record of Hackensack. Micah Rasmussen, a department spokesman, said new security measures would cost $10 million to $20 million. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: AIRLINE INVESTMENT Taiwan's main air carrier, China Airlines, won approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs of Taiwan to buy a 25 percent stake in China Cargo Airlines in Shanghai. The deal has been under discussion for two years and is the first investment by a Taiwan carrier in China's aviation industry. Beijing gave its approval last summer. China Airlines will pay $49 million for its stake in China Cargo, which has three MD-11 freighters and had revenue last year of $151 million. China Eastern, a Chinese airline, controls the small cargo airline. Taiwan's government has been grudgingly approving deals with mainland companies despite concerns that the economy is becoming highly dependent on the mainland, from which Taiwan broke away politically in 1949, at the end of China's civil war. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: G.M. Offers Investors a Bag of Mixed Messages
description: For a company that is selling sport utility vehicles and pickups at a blistering pace and making progress in cutting costs that were out of control a few years ago, General Motors offered investors an oddly mixed outlook today.

title: Celtics-Nets Rivalry Changes
description: May is a memory, bitter and sweet. In the blink of a short and shorter off-season, the Celtics and Nets were back again tonight, opening their eyes to find change coloring their newfound rivalry.

title: Marymount Manhattan Head
description: JUDSON R. SHAVER will be inaugurated Friday as the seventh president of Manhattan Marymount College in New York City. He will be the first man to be president of the 2,500-student college, which was a women's college until 1970. Dr. Shaver holds a Ph.D.in Christianity and Judaism in Antiquity from the University of Notre Dame. Before going to Manhattan Marymount, he was provost and head of academic affairs at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. Lia Miller

title: Businesses Feeling Downdraft as Customers Stay Away
description: Early this morning, employees posted handwritten signs outside the Home Depot store here saying, ''Thank you Reston for shopping with us!''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Car Venture Approved
description: The Chinese government approved a plan by Toyota Motor to build a factory in Tianjin. The plant is Toyota's second in the country and will be used to build cars jointly with the First Automotive Industry Company in China. In the venture, Toyota and First Auto plan to build up to 400,000 cars a year. Toyota started making small cars last week with a subsidiary of First Auto. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A Show of Loyalty (Just Say Yes) In Iraq Vote for the One and Only
description: If there is a reliable hard core to the support for Saddam Hussein among ordinary Iraqis, it is here on the baking flatlands of north-central Iraq, where the Iraqi leader was born.

title: Brooklyn Deliveryman Is Fatally Shot
description: A man delivering food to an apartment building in Brooklyn was shot to death last night, the police said.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOMALIA: NEW EFFORT TO END CONFLICT Somalis began peace talks in the latest effort to end a decade of anarchy. Some 350 delegates including faction leaders, government officials and civic groups are due to gather over the coming weeks in the Kenyan town of Eldoret for the conference, which follows a series of failed peace initiatives. Diplomats say the talks are one of the most serious attempts to bring peace to Somalia, which has been carved into fiefs by warlords competing in the power vacuum left by the overthrow of the dictator Mohammed Siad Barre in 1991. (Reuters)

title: Account Changes
description: Accounts

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Troubled Crime-Fighters
description: A report issued by a special commission says the Suffolk County Sheriff's Department is ''deeply troubled,'' severely mismanaged and rife with political favors. The report comes three weeks after the sheriff, Richard J. Rouse, announced plans to take an early retirement. The commission was appointed by Jane Swift, the acting governor, last year after accusations that a prisoner had became pregnant after sex with numerous corrections officers and that several inmates had been beaten by guards. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Risks Rise
description: The Bank of Japan said in its monthly economic report that the risks to recovery were rising as a global slowdown depresses exports and output and holds down stock prices and consumer confidence. The bank said the economy had stabilized but it did not see clear signs of recovery, a more pessimistic view than the government's. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYNARD, AUGUSTA POE
description: MAYNARD - Augusta Poe. Died peacefully at her home in Southampton, New York on October 8, 2002. She was the much loved wife of the late Walter Maynard of Water Mill, New York, and New York City. She is survived by her stepsons, Walter Maynard, Jr. and John Maynard, her stepdaughter Sheila M. Platt, her nieces, Sallie Worthington and Jean Neer, and six step grandchildren.

title: In Israel and Lebanon, Talk of War Over Water
description: To hear the soft gurgle of Wazzani Springs, stand knee-deep in the cool, rock-bottomed creek that meanders through the hills of Lebanon's southern frontier.

title: The Two Faces of Rioja
description: NEW wine districts -- or old ones rediscovered -- have been proliferating in Spain like mushrooms under damp autumn leaves. Today, Rueda, Ribera del Duero, Priorato, La Mancha, Jumilla, Valencia, Toro, Catalonia, even Majorca, all proudly claim their place under the Iberian sun. Almost overlooked in the excitement is Rioja, still the most famous Spanish wine region and still, as the Dining section's tasting panel found, producing wines that are not only big, fruity and food-friendly, but often reasonably priced as well.

title: STOCKS SHRUG OFF RECENT BATTERING WITH A BIG SURGE
description: Stocks soared almost 5 percent yesterday as investors celebrated upbeat earnings reports from two of the nation's biggest financial institutions and began to shift their views from gloomy to hopeful on other companies' prospects.

title: Led by China, World Steel Output Rises
description: World steel production will probably reach a record this year, led by Chinese output that will soar 18 percent, MEPS International Ltd., a British steel industry analyst and consultant said today.

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Midtown Express Lanes? On Day 1, Not Quite
description: Workers in the Bloomberg administration hope new traffic rules that went into effect yesterday will transform 10 streets in Midtown into dreamy ''express'' routes that will ease the maddening bumper-to-bumper crush of crosstown traffic.

title: People
description: * Rick Bendel, regional chairman for the British and Nordic region operations of Publicis Worldwide, part of Publicis Groupe, will fill the new post of chief operating officer. He will work with Maurice Lvy, chairman and chief executive at Publicis Worldwide and Publicis. Mr. Bendel, now based in London, will divide his time between London and Paris, where Publicis is based.

title: Speaking the Language, and the Issues, Pataki Makes Inroads With Latino Voters
description: It seemed like another routine appearance for Gov. George E. Pataki last month when he showed up at a Manhattan restaurant to give a short speech in honor of Hispanic Heritage Month. But in a few minutes the well-heeled celebrators in the crowd were putting down their sangria glasses, shouting ''All right!'' and applauding wildly.

title: Gutsy Pairings in a Stylized Rustic Setting
description: LET'S begin with the peculiar name, industry(food). Here is the official explanation, put forth by Alex A. Freij, the executive chef and an owner: ''It began as an idea to have a chef's club, where people of the culinary industry could dine. The idea then evolved to serve people of every industry industry-quality food, a place where chefs would choose to dine.''

title: Time Warner Expanding Video on Demand Service
description: Time Warner Cable, the biggest cable television provider in New York City, said yesterday that it would begin offering video on demand to hundreds of thousands of homes by the end of this month and to more than one million by the end of the year.

title: REGIONAL MARKET -- Hell's Kitchen; Where F-Stops Have Replaced Pit Stops
description: Now that Hell's Kitchen is dotted with high-rise apartment buildings with rents to match, the neighborhood is frequently referred to as Clinton. Yet despite the more dignified name, parts of the neighborhood -- within the shadow of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center -- have retained a blue-collar character.

title: Sports of The Times; In Times Like These, 'Let's Go Nets'
description: FIRST it was Sprewell's pinkie, then McDyess's kneecap. No manager in Queens, no Series in the Bronx and a lot of bad football at the Meadowlands in between.

title: Patricia Labalme, 75, Educator And Scholar of the Renaissance
description: Patricia Hochschild Labalme, an executive and a trustee of foundations that give major support to education and scholarly research as well as a scholar of the Renaissance, died on Friday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 75 and also lived in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Irish Bank Discloses Details of Bid For Abbey
description: The Bank of Ireland published details of its $16 billion cash-and-stock offer for Abbey National, the British bank, today, and Abbey once again rejected the proposal as insufficient.

title: Dot-Com Desserts, From Connecticut
description: Until now you had to go to the Aux Dlices shops in Greenwich or Riverside, Conn., to buy Debra Ponzek's intense but delicate single-layer chocolate torte cake or her light lemon crme frache cake, shown above. The store now takes orders on the Internet, at www.auxdelicesfoods.com. The cakes ($22 each, plus shipping) are fresh, not frozen, and serve 8 to 10. Cookies, preserves, condiments and gift baskets are also sold.

title: AOL Says It Will Eliminate Some of Its Pop-Up Ads
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that its AOL service would eliminate pop-up advertisements for other companies as it sought to revive the allegiance of its members, reinvent its fading advertising business, and fend off an assault from Microsoft's MSN service.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Court Rules Against City
description: New York's highest court yesterday upheld the state's policy of making New York City, alone among municipal governments, pay for liability costs resulting from failure to maintain state highways. New York's big cities must maintain the highways within their borders, and the state insures them against resulting lawsuits -- all except New York City. The policy, set 50 years ago and written into law in 1987, was estimated by a lower court to cost the city tens of millions of dollars annually. The city claimed that it, too, was covered by the 1987 law. Yesterday, the Court of Appeals ruled unanimously that New York City was excluded, though it added that the state had offered no justification for the policy. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: BEST BUY ADDS DIVERSITY OFFICER TO RECRUIT EMPLOYEES
description: The Best Buy Company, the electronics retailer, said yesterday that it had named a chief diversity officer to better recruit employees and expand sales among minority customers. The position is a new one for Best Buy, which has more than 1,900 stores in the United States and Canada, a spokeswoman, Lisa Hawks, said. The position is to be filled by Herschel Herndon, who held a similar position at Stanley Works, the maker of hand tools. Mr. Herndon will become a vice president for talent relations, the company said.

title: Intel Profit Is Far Short Of Forecasts
description: Striking a sour end note to a day when the stock market rallied, the Intel Corporation, the world's largest maker of computer chips, reported earnings that sharply missed Wall Street expectations. The company said its fortunes were not likely to turn around next quarter, and that it was not seeing signs of a larger economic recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLK, THELMA
description: WOLK-Thelma. On October 15, 2002. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Phyllis and Mark Rosenblum. Cherished grandmother of Samantha, Jared & Brandon. Dear sister of Irwin Toporoff. Service Thursday, October 17, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (opposite Kings Plaza).

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Profit Rises
description: Korea's second-largest commercial bank, Woori Bank, posted a net profit of just under $80 million for the third quarter, up from $51 million a year earlier. The bank, formed from two failing banks that were taken over by the government in 1998, attributed the increase largely to an increase in consumer borrowing. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: OHIO: EXECUTION RECOMMENDED

title: Wild Card Matchup In the World Series
description: The Giants-Angels matchup will be the first World Series with no team that finished in first place in its division during the 162-game regular season. Both San Francisco and Anaheim secured wild-card spots to the playoffs. This will be the first Series for the 42-year-old Angels, who a year ago finished last in the American League West. The Giants made it for the first time since 1989, when the Series was interrupted by an earthquake.

title: 'Nuclear' Isn't the Only Word We Mangle
description: To the Editor:

title: Scott Elected to the Hall of Fame
description: Four retired athletes, led by the miler Steve Scott, were elected yesterday to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame.

title: Sinn Fein's Commitment
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Stalemate In Kashmir
description: Five days after election results were announced in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, the two parties expected to form the core of a coalition government -- the Indian National Congress and the People's Democratic Party -- have yet to agree on which will choose the state's chief minister. If they cannot agree today, the state's governor could impose governor's rule, stripping the current chief minister of his power, or ask the ruling National Conference, which was routed in the elections but still holds the most seats in the assembly, to try to form the government. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Messages From the Bali Bombing
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wal-Mart Plans DVD Rental Services
description: Wal-Mart said yesterday that it had begun testing a mail-order DVD rental service through its Web site, Walmart.com. The service, which will be made available to all customers early next year, costs $18.86 a month for unlimited rentals. Wal-Mart said it could offer more than 12,000 titles, about 12 times the number that is carried in an average rental store. With the move into mail order DVD rentals, Wal-Mart directly takes on earlier entrants into the market like Netflix, Blockbuster, CafeDVD, QwikFlicks and DVD Avenue. Netflix, the market leader, mails out about 190,000 discs each day to its 670,000 monthly subscribers. Wal-Mart has long been acclaimed for the advanced inventory systems in use in its 2,800 retail stores. The company is hoping to replicate that success online with DVD rentals. ''Our customers have long counted on Wal-Mart for quality family entertainment,'' said Gary Severson, a senior vice president at Wal-Mart. ''With our online DVD rental service, we will be able to deliver even greater convenience and selection to our customers.'' Netflix, however, has a head start on Wal-Mart. In an effort to cut down rental turnaround times, Netflix added 10 new regional distribution centers in June. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REBENFELD, ELLEN VOGEL
description: REBENFELD-Ellen Vogel. Died at the Medical Center in Princeton, NJ, on Monday, October 14, 2002, after a brief illness. Born and raised in New York she had been a resident of Princeton since 1954. She was the wife of Dr. Ludwig Rebenfeld, the former President and Director of TRI/Princeton (formerly Textile Research Institute) and for many years a member of the faculty of the Department of Chemical Engineering at Princeton University. Mrs. Rebenfeld was a graduate of Barnard College and worked in Technical Editing at McGraw Hill in New York before joining TRI in 1954 as Production Editor of Textile Research Journal. She and Dr. Rebenfeld were married in 1956. In Princeton Mrs. Rebenfeld served for many years as a volunteer at the Princeton Hospital and at the local unit of Recording for the Blind. In addition to her husband she is survived by a nephew Frederick Vogel in Connecticut, a niece Carol Vogel Heneage in New York and a cousin Ellen Viner Seiler in Princeton.

title: Cancer Detection
description: To the Editor:

title: Recipe: Staff Meal Chicken
description: Adapted from Antonio Martinez of Artie's Delicatessen

title: Fannie Mae's Earnings Decrease On Revaluing of Rate Hedges
description: Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of mortgages in the nation, reported today that its third-quarter earnings fell as it reduced the value of derivatives it uses to protect itself from interest rate swings.

title: University Merger Plan Has Support as Well as Concerns
description: While Gov. James E. McGreevey promoted his plan for a new state university system, many in New Brunswick and Newark said today that they were reluctant to see their schools folded into something called the University of New Jersey.

title: Chief Weapons Inspector Urges Iraq to Accept New Rules as Team Awaits Resolution
description: The chief of the United Nations weapons inspectors appealed to Iraq today to agree to arrangements for new inspections but said his weapons teams would only return to Iraq after the Security Council adopts a resolution giving them a new mandate.

title: Executive Quits Miramax Films To Join Stratus
description: Mark Gill, a senior Miramax Films executive regarded as a marketing expert, has left to join the Stratus Film Company, a finance and production company started by the producer of ''Saving Private Ryan.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A good World Series for California, and maybe for Wall Street.
description: WHY is it that the World Series pits Northern California against Southern California only when Wall Street has been beaten down?

title: AstraZeneca Alters Cancer Drug Label
description: The pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said today that it would make a warning on the label of its lung cancer drug Iressa more prominent after several patients in Japan suffered pneumonia and some died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, EDWARD T.
description: ROSS-Edward T., 72. Of Glen Cove, NY on October 15, 2002. Cherished husband of Bonnie, (and the late Barbara Furgatch), beloved father of David, Stephen and Debra; stepfather of Cheryl Yifrach, Michelle Ressel and Julie Avenarius. Treasured grandfather of nine. Services Thursday, October 17, noon at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, LI. Interment Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Farmingdale. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, NY 11590.

title: Flood Cleanup Is Slow Along Prague Riverside
description: The better-traveled residents of Karlin, the old blue-collar district, used to call their neighborhood the Brooklyn of Prague, with its dozens of small pubs, crumbling century-old buildings and abandoned factories, and the laid-back air that comes from being just outside the city's bustling commercial center.

title: A Jersey Sloppy Joe
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Recruiters Are Allowed
description: Columbia Law School last week agreed to treat military recruiters the same as other recruiters, even though its "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy, which bars openly gay people from the military, does not comply with the school's nondiscrimination policy. Columbia's decision followed similar actions by other law schools, including Harvard's and Yale's, that have bowed to the government's threat to withdraw hundreds of millions of dollars in federal research money if military recruiters are not treated equally.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Oct. 1 about Linda LeRoy Janklow misstated her title with the nonprofit education program ArtsConnection. She is the founding chairwoman, not a founding partner. A correction in this space on Oct. 3 misidentified the organization for which she is chairwoman emeritus. It is Lincoln Center Theater, not Lincoln Center.

title: Europe Pushes for Renewable Energy
description: Romano Prodi has seen the hydrogen-powered light.

title: French Aid to State Utility May Come Under Scrutiny
description: The president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, said today that he favored opening an investigation into the government aid received by the state-owned French power monopoly, Electricit de France. Mr. Prodi said the commission, the executive body of the 15-nation European Union, would decide at a meeting on Wednesday whether to begin a formal inquiry.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Tobacco Companies Said To Thwart Treaty
description: The head of the World Health Organization, Gro Harlem Brundtland, said tobacco companies were trying to undermine efforts to draft a treaty that would control the sale and use of tobacco. In a speech at a negotiating session among organization members in Geneva, she said 4.9 million people die each year from tobacco-related illnesses and accused the industry of encouraging young people to start smoking. The health organization, a United Nations agency, hopes the treaty will impose hefty tobacco taxes, ban adverstising and encourage strong regulations for clean indoor air. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Scandal Lets Malaysia Prove Its Mettle
description: Next to the fantastic severance packages given to executives at other scandal-ridden companies like Enron and WorldCom, the $6.2 million that Tajudin Ramli paid himself on the day in July that he was ousted as chairman of Malaysia's second-largest cellular operator was small change.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Steady Economic Growth
description: The Bank of Korea said the economy had maintained a growth rate of 6.3 percent in the third quarter, the same as in the second quarter. The central bank predicted the economy would grow 6.5 percent for the year even though some analysts had said such forecasts might be overly optimistic in view of the worldwide global downturn and concerns about war in Iraq. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Dangerous Chickens
description: This week's recall of 27.4 million pounds of cooked turkey and chicken products might have been avoided if the Bush administration had instituted rules designed to protect consumers from a dangerous bacteria called Listeria monocytogenes.

title: Judge Rules Diaz Is Winner Of Senate Primary in Bronx
description: After nearly three weeks of legal disputes and court-supervised ballot counting, a State Supreme Court judge in the Bronx ordered yesterday that the Board of Elections certify Ruben Diaz Sr. as the winner of the Democratic primary for a State Senate seat. He had a lead of 97 votes over the incumbent, Pedro Espada Jr.

title: A Face-Off Between the Stars Of the Communication Line
description: The National Hockey League opened its regular season last week with rules designed to speed up play and with safety netting at each end of the rink. The New York Times invited Bobby Holik of the Rangers, Scott Stevens of the Devils and Aleksei Yashin of the Islanders -- to a roundtable discussion with reporters and editors. Following are excerpts from the hourlong conversation, which took place Monday.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday erred in saying that Pluto differed from the other planets in that its orbit is elliptical rather than circular. All the planets have elliptical orbits; Pluto's is the least circular.

title: Israeli Hints at Withdrawal From a 2nd West Bank City
description: Israel's defense minister suggested today that the army might withdraw from a second West Bank city by the weekend, sounding a conciliatory note as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon arrived in Washington to meet with President Bush.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: North Hills: Gunfire Along Expressway
description: The Nassau County police said yesterday that they were exploring several possible explanations for gunfire along the Long Island Expressway on Sunday. One bullet hit a car passing Exit 36, at Searingtown Road, and another bullet apparently passed over the head of a pedestrian on nearby Sparrow Drive, the police said, adding that no one was injured. A bullet fragment was recovered from the car's passenger door. The situations the police said they were exploring ranged from random shooting to illicit target practice to copycat sniper fire meant to mimic the fatal shootings in the Washington area. Residents of the area reported noises like fireworks, and the shots appeared to have come from south of the expressway, near Searingtown Road, the police said. The bullet in the car was not discovered until Monday afternoon, and it was then reported to the police. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: New York Winners Are Coming Back
description: Last year's winners of the New York City Marathon are returning for another try Nov. 3.

title: China Reshaping Military to Toughen Its Muscle in the Region
description: A new generation of Chinese generals is fast reshaping China's bloated and outdated armed forces into a modern, integrated fighting force that is emerging as a regional power, according to Western experts.

title: Riding High With a Big, Bouffant Hit; After 25 Years of Paying Dues, an Independent Producer Scores With 'Hairspray'
description: It was spring of 2001, and ''The Producers'' had just taken Broadway by storm, opening to rave reviews and breaking box-office records. Margo Lion, an independent producer, walked into the office of Rocco Landesman, one of the show's producers, and said she had accepted that she would never have a hit like his.

title: Aggressive Cost-Cutting Lifts Merrill's Earnings by 22%
description: Merrill Lynch & Company reported today that its third-quarter earnings rose 22 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIST, VERA G.
description: LIST-Vera G. The Board and Congregation of Temple Sholom, Greenwich, CT. mourn the loss of our longtime member and benefactor, Vera G. List. Vera List and her late husband Albert List were devoted and generous supporters of this institution for more than half a century. We will always be indebted to them. Our heartfelt condolences go out to the entire List family. Greg Kandel, President Mitchell Hurvitz, Rabbi Temple Sholom

title: Different Strokes
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Wrought From Stuff Both Useful and Used
description: A converted factory in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is the home and showroom for furniture made from unusual materials.

title: The Aftermath
description: A powerful car bomb killed over 180 people detonated in front of a discothque on the popular Indonesian resort island of Bali.

title: For Ford and G.M., the Problems Ahead Have Different Sources
description: While the stocks of General Motors and Ford Motor are falling almost in tandem, the risks seen in the two American automakers are divergent. For Ford, there is worry about its auto business; for G.M., there is worry about much besides its auto business.

title: Pennsylvania Regulators Sue Deloitte & Touche in the Collapse of Reliance Insurance
description: Stepping up efforts to recover money in the collapse of the Reliance Insurance Company, insurance regulators in Pennsylvania have turned their sights on the company's auditor, Deloitte & Touche, one of the country's largest accounting firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, GEORGE ALEXANDER
description: MICHEL-George Alexander. On Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2002. Beloved brother of Thalia and her husband Stanley Ciaputa. Adored uncle of Alexander, Daria, Georgia and Lydia Ciaputa. Funeral services Friday 11 AM, The Holy Trinity Cathedral, 319 E. 74 St, New York City. Friends may call Wednesday 7-9 PM and Thursday 2-5 & 7-9PM Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Rates Unchanged
description: The Bank of Canada left its crucial lending rate unchanged because of a weak global economy that has led central banks in other industrial nations to keep borrowing costs steady. Canada's central bank left its benchmark target rate for overnight loans between banks at 2.75 percent.

title: A Chip of Rubber, With Tiny Rivers Running Through It
description: THESE are not your typical circuits. Pressurized fluids, not electrons, run through them; the pathways are made of rubbery silicone, not rigid silicon; and the on-off controls are valves, not logic gates.

title: A Robotic Pet Gains an Independent Streak
description: A SERIES of improvements Sony is introducing this month for Aibo, its dog-like robot, highlight the Japanese company's uncertainty over whether the product is primarily a substitute pet or the foundation for a family of mobile electronic servants.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Next Step for Winona Ryder

title: Rosie Magazine Staff Laid Off
description: Almost the entire staff of Rosie magazine  120 people  was laid off this morning at Gruner & Jahr USA. The layoffs were announced at a staff meeting at 10 a.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, JOSEPH ALBERT III
description: CUTLER-Joseph Albert III of New York City passed away October 13, 2002. Born May 1, 1930 in Evanston, IL. Upon graduation from the University of Wisconsin, he entered the Navy and served during the Korean War on the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard in 1955, after serving in the Navy, he joined Johnson Controls, maker of HVAC products, and for 27 years enjoyed a distinguished career, retiring in 1973 as Branch Manager, Union, NJ. Following his career with Johnson Controls, he founded Copeland Cutler Travel, and for the remainder of his life operated a successful travel business. He loved to travel and did so extensively. Nature was a favorite of his. In addition to his business career, he served on many ballet and opera organizations in both Albany and New York City. Joe is survived by his aunt, Bernice Nelson Cutler, nephews, James (Jay) and Donald (Dee) Hawthorne; their wives, Celeste and Kimberly; great niece Noelle, and nephews, Patrick and Jake (James Jr.). He was preceded in death by parents, Joseph A. Cutler and Bernice Jacobs Cutler, and his sister, Patricia Cutler Hawthorne. Joe was an extremely honest, caring, and sincere man who will be dearly missed by his family and colleagues who were fortunate enough to experience his personality and wit. May your garden grow forever. In honor of his life, a memorial will be held at the Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, on Friday, October 18, 2002, at 4:00PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Some Yelp as Microsoft Squeezes
description: Microsoft's plan to impose a new pricing program has been prompting a chorus of complaints from corporate and government customers for several months. But early results, analysts say, indicate that the move was shrewd financially -- at least in the short run.

title: Fire Kills Mother and Children at Home
description: A mother and her five children were engulfed in flames and killed early this morning in a house fire that neighbors said was set by drug dealers who were seeking revenge.

title: Iraq's Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Season; G.O.P. Candidates Taking Streisand Shots
description: Barbra Streisand has been a Democratic star since the days of John F. Kennedy, but this fall, she has become the favorite Republican shorthand for limousine liberal. In a debate on Monday in the race for senator from New Hampshire, Representative John E. Sununu mocked the Democratic candidate, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, saying, ''I, unfortunately, didn't spend the summer raising money with Barbra Streisand and Al Gore.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Drops Listing Plan
description: The sports-car maker Porsche said yesterday that it had decided against listing shares on the New York Stock Exchange to avoid ''considerable extra costs'' resulting from a new financial oversight law. The chief executive, Wendelin Wiedeking, said in August that Porsche was delaying plans to list shares in New York because of the new law.

title: Campaign Season; For Longtime Friends, It's Been a Long Time
description: When former Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana took the chairmanship of the Republican National Committee last year, insiders said one asset was a close friendship with President Bush, forged when both were governors. Weeks before the appointment, the Racicots shared a fish dinner with the Bushes at the White House.

title: Havana Enshrines Heroes of Espionage
description: Ren Gonzlez's smiling face beams from several small picture frames in his family's living room, where his 4-year-old daughter, Ivette, scampers about with her friends. When his wife, Olga Salanueva, takes Ivette outside, she has to explain why Papi's portrait appears, with four others, on T-shirts, billboards and book covers.

title: Studio Withdraws Movie About a Sniper
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 — The release of "Phone Booth," a movie thriller about a deranged sniper, has been postponed indefinitely by 20th Century Fox over concerns that its plot too closely mirrors the actual shootings terrorizing the Washington area.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: REGIS CORP., Minneapolis, the world's largest operator of hair salons, said it had purchased 59 salons in seven transactions. The salons, in Missouri, Kansas, Arizona and North Carolina, are expected to generate $21 million a year in revenue. Terms were not disclosed.

title: A Satellite and Thou: Web Browsing in the Wilds
description: ''BROADBAND'' and ''high-speed Internet access'' are not words you hear much in the countryside. Moving to a bucolic setting generally means not only escaping the urban din but also leaving behind zippy cable and digital subscriber line Internet services. Living without a constant online connection can be onerous for anyone trying to work out of a country office or trying to telecommute on extended weekends. But there is a wireless option: two-way satellite service.

title: Jets Consider Deactivating Their No. 1 Draft Selection
description: The rookie defensive end Bryan Thomas has been such a nonfactor this season that the Jets are thinking about deactivating him for their game Sunday against the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Revolution's Nicol Named Top Coach
description: Steve Nicol was named winner of the Major League Soccer coach of the year award yesterday after taking over the struggling New England Revolution and leading it to the championship game.

title: Dayne Seems to Accept Ever-Diminishing Role
description: Ron Dayne's career is evaporating like an ice cube on a sidewalk: Seventeen carries in the last three games, an average of about eight carries per game this season, a stunning descent for a running back drafted in the first round by a team that has relied throughout its history on a strong rushing attack. Sometimes he struggles, sometimes he runs effectively, and always he's a bit piece in the offense, coming off the field after short or longer runs.

title: Campaign Season; Another First for Clinton
description: Bill Clinton racked up no shortage of firsts -- good and bad -- in his eight years in the White House. But on Saturday night in Little Rock, the 42nd president will claim another when he becomes the first white person inducted into the Arkansas Black Hall of Fame.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Australian Says, Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia Links Muslim  Group With Terrorism
description: The Indonesian government, under pressure from the United States to act decisively against terrorism here, took a major step today toward declaring a fundamentalist Islamic group, Jemaah Islamiyah, a terrorist organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MORTON J.
description: LEVY-Morton J. Of the Berkshires and Boca Raton, FL, after a valiant battle with cancer. Born and raised in NYC. Saw distinguished service as Army Air Force pilot with 62 missions over enemy territory in WWII. Married in 1943 to Georgette Rosenthal. He was the third generation of his family in the toy industry. He formed his own business, Gabriel Industries. After retiring he attended Fordham College at Lincoln Center at age 60 and graduated magna cum laude. He formed and chaired the Board of Advisors at Fordham College at Lincoln Center. Former member of the Board at New York Hospital. He chaired the Board at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, MA for nine years and was a distinguished member of the Board of the Austen Riggs Center in Stockbridge, MA. Former Chairman of the Board of the Boca Raton Venue of the Florida Philharmonic. He was a friend and mentor to many. Beloved husband of Georgette (Rosenthal) Levy for nearly 60 years. Adoring father of Ellen Levy-Lanciano (Tobi) and the late Leon J. Levy. Proud grandfather of David Dahari (Brandi) and Jonathan Lanciano. Loving brotherin-law of Beverly (Rosenthal) Mazursky and caring uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Funeral service at Hevreh, Great Barrington, MA Friday at 10 AM. Interment New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Glendale, NY at 2 PM. Contributions to the Fordham College at Lincoln Center, Morton J. Levy Scholarship Fund, 113 W. 60 St, NYC 10023 or to the charity of choice

title: Merrill Lynch Tops Forecast Because of Cuts in Expenses
description: Third-quarter profit at Merrill Lynch & Company rose more than expected, the firm said yesterday, but the gain was a result of aggressive cost-cutting, not an upturn in Merrill's basic businesses.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Gangsters Attack Governor's Palace
description: In their latest show of strength, criminal gangs fired machine guns at the governor's palace in Rio de Janeiro, threw a hand grenade at a large shopping center and assaulted police stations and patrol cars. The wave of attacks followed a failed morning raid on a maximum security prison in what officials said was an attempt to free drug lords. Saying that ''we will not be intimidated,'' Gov. Benedita da Silva vowed ''no cease-fire in combat against organized crime.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Keeping the Lighting Turned Up and the Budget Down
description: Architects are often asked to provide more design for less money. That was the challenge that faced Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis, architects in Manhattan, who designed the new Lozoo Chinese Kitchen Restaurant and Bar. One ceiling was too low to install overhead lighting, another so high that sound bounced mercilessly. ''The goal with all these rooms is to play up their peculiarity,'' said Paul Lewis, a principal, above at left, with his partners, Marc Tsurumaki, center, and David J. Lewis, his brother. They made inventive use of inexpensive materials like felt and acrylic to make five odd-shaped rooms jell.

title: La Vie de Bohme (Without the Grit)
description: A CONFESSION: I grew up wearing Earth Shoes on the Upper West Side and living in a brownstone with brass beds and, in the bathroom, denim-patterned ceramic tiles. I'm not the only one with a Nehru jacket in the closet, but mine was at least custom-made in Calcutta. Paola Antonelli, curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, recalls the peasant blouses and long skirts of her youth.

title: Stocks Plunge As Earnings Disappoint
description: Stocks plunged yesterday as an onslaught of negative earnings news damped the spirits that had powered a four-session rally that sent the Dow Jones industrials up 13.3 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUY, EDWARD
description: GUY-Edward, 88. Of Somers, NY, October 13, 2002. Beloved husband of Alice; cherished father of Joyce, Christine and Peter; devoted grandfather of Melissa, Kristopher, Kimberly and Adam. Graduate of Hamilton College and Harvard Law School. Thirty-nine year career in the Federal Reserve System, where he was Senior Vice President and General Counsel of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Served in the U.S. Navy as an officer of OSS in the Mediterranean during World War II. Known for his intellect, integrity and quiet tenacity. Loved for his generosity, kindness and passion for jazz and gardening. He will be in our hearts forever.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trading Company Downgraded
description: The credit rating of the Mitsubishi Corporation, Japan's largest trading company, was cut one notch by Moody's Investors Service because of a faltering business climate and risks on the company's balance sheet. In lowering the company's long- and short-term rating to A3 from A2, the ratings agency said Mitsubishi was burdened by many unprofitable investments and the weak state of Japan's economy. Japanese trading companies have traditionally provided financing for international trading operations, a role that is increasingly being filled by the capital markets. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRAH, JERE T.
description: FARRAH-Jere T. A memorial service will be held for Jere Tiffin Farrah on Monday, October 21, 10 AM at The Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, 112th Street.

title: Rosie, the Magazine, Lays Off Staff
description: Almost the entire staff of Rosie magazine -- 120 people -- was laid off this morning at Gruner & Jahr USA. The layoffs were announced at a staff meeting at 10 a.m.

title: Shift to Starter Is Nothing New to Lucas
description: Ray Lucas, preparing to replace the injured Jay Fiedler as the Miami Dolphins' starting quarterback, said today that he was confident the Dolphins' offensive schemes already in place would help him meet the challenge.

title: 'Quiet' Finland, a Bomb, and a Freaky Subculture
