description: For months, the brilliant chemistry student who called himself RC had been discussing bomb-making techniques with other enthusiasts on a Finnish Internet Web site devoted to bombs and explosives.

title: Chancellor Speaks Up for Charter Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that he hoped to create a more welcoming environment for charter schools, in which they ''can feel supported and can thrive.''

title: Newark Council Approves Plan to Finance New Arena
description: The Newark City Council approved plans tonight to help pay for the construction cost of a long-sought arena in the city's downtown for the New Jersey Nets and Devils sports teams.

title: Footlights
description: Date Night

title: Oil Prize, Past and Present, Ties Russia to Iraq
description: As Russia defends its position during a two-day United Nations debate on Iraq, one thing will weigh on the minds of Russian diplomats: oil.

title: New Incentives for Pilots of Remote Plane
description: The new technology of warfare is presenting an unexpected challenge for the Air Force as it expands a fleet of unmanned reconnaissance planes: How to attract -- and satisfy -- pilots who would rather strap into a cockpit and punch holes in the sky at Mach speeds than sit in a trailer watching video to guide a remote-controlled plane.

title: Bluetooth, Do You Read Me? Wireless Typing and Clicking
description: Microsoft's Wireless Optical Desktop for Bluetooth is not just another wireless computer keyboard and mouse. It is the first to rely on the Bluetooth protocol to connect components wirelessly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REMLER, IRVING
description: REMLER-Irving. Of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. on October 16. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father of Jane Remler Blank and Philip N. Remler, dear brother of Sam and Norman Remler and Mildred Baum, loving grandfather of Levi and Benjamin. Services New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y., Friday, 2 P.M. For information ''Wien & Wien''.

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Squabbling Dutch Government Collapses, Forcing New Election
description: The short-lived conservative government of the Netherlands fell today, undermined by the continuous infighting of its members, above all among the inexperienced followers of the slain politician Pim Fortuyn.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Gets $1.4 Million Gift From Handyman
description: A Minneapolis handyman who managed to amass a fortune from scavenging and who rewrote his will after the Sept. 11 attacks to make New York City his sole heir has made his final bequest -- more than $1.4 million. The handyman, Joe Temeczko, 86, at left, died on Oct. 14, 2001, after leaving the value of all his possessions, including the lawn mowers, small appliances and VCR's that jammed his house, his garage and a neighbor's garage. One year and one day later, his lawyer, William K. Wangensteen of Minneapolis, mailed a check for $1,414,356.46 to the city. How the city will spend it is unclear. ''We owe it to Joe Temeczko's memory and legacy to make sure that this money is allocated in an appropriate manner,'' said Jonathan Greenspun, commissioner of the mayor's community assistance unit. Carla Baranauckas (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHTEL, LILLIAN R.
description: WACHTEL-Lillian R. On October 15, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Allen. Dear mother of Norman and Andrea, and mother-in-law of Robin. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Charles and Cristal. Service private.

title: Splitsville, U.S.A.
description: With the Southern states threatening secession in early 1861, Lincoln's top military adviser, Gen. Winfield Scott, suggested they be given a friendly wave goodbye: ''Wayward sisters, depart in peace.''

title: Act II: Enter the Computers
description: IT'S not often that a graveyard steals the show, but then again, it's not often that a graveyard flies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHON, MIRIAM
description: GERSHON-Miriam. Her extended family at Music Theatre International deeply mourns her passing. Our heartfelt sympathy to the Gershon family.

title: Vodafone Moves to Acquire Control of Cegetel of France
description: The Vodafone Group moved to tighten its grip on the European wireless market today, with an offer to buy the 85 percent of Cegetel, France's second-largest phone company, that it does not already own for 13 billion euros, or about $12.8 billion.

title: Medical Use Of Marijuana Gains Support
description: Flanked by terminally ill people who told tales of unrelenting pain, Tom Golisano today endorsed the medical use of marijuana, and lashed out at Gov. George E. Pataki for blocking a state program to provide the drug to patients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYTTLE, HANNAH
description: LYTTLE - Hannah. Sister hood of Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of our past President. Our condolences to her family.

title: Hampson Embraces Verdi in Vienna
description: The baritone Thomas Hampson has a reputation as an intellectual and a lied specialist. Verdi's operas, by contrast, call for large voices and big, visceral emotion. Yet Mr. Hampson's fairly recent album of Verdi arias indicated that Verdi might be a good direction for him, not least because he is a singer who seems to do best when he's pulled outside himself, beyond the limits imposed by his own veneer of control. Mr. Hampson must think so, too. Recent role debuts include both ''Macbeth'' and ''Simon Boccanegra,'' which he essayed for the first time at the Vienna State Opera here on Monday night.

title: A Retiree's Crusade: No More Falling High-Rises
description: EVEN though the crisp blue commander's uniform now hangs in a closet and his radio and helmet have been turned in, Vincent Dunn is, at heart, still on the job. A firefighter, he says, until the day he dies.

title: Wrought From Stuff Both Useful and Used
description: A converted factory in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is the home and showroom for Stephen Szczepanek, at left in inset, and Andr Joyau, at right, and reclamation is at the heart of their work. Mr. Szczepanek's Sri Studio makes rugs, draperies, quilts and hangings inspired by Asian textiles, especially patchwork quilts from northern Japan and Korean wrapping cloths known as pojagi. In his studio, Mr. Joyau uses recycled building materials to make rustic but refined furnishings with a Japanese sensibility. But he said his work has its rough-hewn roots, if anywhere, in his native Sarthe region of France.

title: Most of the Dead in Bali Go Unidentified
description: Stacks of plywood coffins fill a parking lot behind Sanglah Hospital here on the island of Bali. All are empty. The bodies that should fill them, 140 of them, lie frozen inside refrigerated trucks that could be their resting place for weeks or months to come.

title: A New Type of Killer Brings a New Way of Life to Edgy, Impatient Suburbs
description: Linda Hunter stood outside a Barnes & Noble store this afternoon, sucking on a cigarette, shaking her head. Just behind her was the Home Depot where the sniper killed the latest victim on Monday night and then vanished, despite an intensive dragnet that shut down roads in the Washington area for hours.

title: Australians Wait and Hope for Miracles After Blast
description: Without word from her brother since a powerful bomb ripped through a nightclub in Bali last weekend, Nicole Lewis has spent this week pacing the arrival lounge of this city's airport, begging strangers for news.

title: Testimony From the Joint Intelligence Committee
description: Following is the full text from testimony on Thursday by Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, before the joint House and Senate select intelligence committee investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. They were questioned by Representative Richard Burr, Republican of North Carolina.

title: Former Felons Have a Right to Vote
description: A criminal released from prison has paid his debt and we hope to integrate him back into society. Yet in most states, released felons are deprived of the right to vote, in some cases for the rest of their lives. In the past five years, five states have rescinded or modified their laws, restoring the vote to more than 450,000 people. Other states, and the federal government, should join this trend. Disenfranchising felons is an archaic practice, at odds with basic American values about both punishment and democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, ROBERTA ''BOBBI''
description: MEYERS-Roberta ''Bobbi'', nee Beerman, 62. Died October 3. Wife of Carl, mother to Ellen, and Lisajane and Kevin Romer. Grandmother to Mathew, Jeffrey, Alexis.

title: Report Says Saudis Fail to Crack Down on Charities That Finance Terrorists
description: Al Qaeda's terror network derives most of its financing from charities and individuals in Saudi Arabia, but the kingdom has ''turned a blind eye to this problem,'' according to a new report by experts on terrorist finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PILANDE, CATALINA C., M.D.
description: PILANDE-Catalina C., M.D. 62. Of Elmhurst, Queens, passed away October 12, 2002. Viewing at Freeman Funeral Home, 4-8 PM, October 17 and 18, 344 Route 9 North, Manalapan, NJ 07726, 732-972-8484. Special Mass on October 18, 7 PM. Funeral services at St. Rose of Lima Old Church at 16 McLean St. Freehold, NJ 07728 on October 19, at 10 AM. Interment will follow at St. Rose Cemetery, 299 Freehold Englishtown Rd, Freehold, NJ 07728.

title: Iraq States Its Case
description: After so many years of fear from war, the threat of war and suffering, the people of Iraq and their government in Baghdad are eager for peace. We have no intention of attacking anyone, now or in the future, with weapons of any kind. If we are attacked, we will surely defend ourselves with all means possible. But bear in mind that we have no nuclear or biological or chemical weapons, and we have no intention of acquiring them.

title: Yanks Inquire About Defector
description: The Yankees have made initial contact with the agent for Jos Contreras, the right-handed pitcher who defected from Cuba.

title: Smallpox Inoculation Urged For Employees of Hospitals
description: A panel of specialists advising the government on smallpox vaccinations recommended today offering the immunization to an estimated half-million emergency room and other hospital workers because of the possibility of a bioterrorist attack.

title: Up Against the Wall-to-Wall
description: ONCE there were two Shirleys in my life, and they took care of all my home-decorating needs.

title: Australian Says, Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: National Book Award Finalists
description: Works by three first-time authors were among the fiction nominees announced yesterday for this year's National Book Awards.

title: Dynegy Says It Will Exit the Energy Trading Business
description: Dynegy announced yesterday that it would close its energy trading operation and revamp its business as part of an effort to cope with declining prices, a junk credit rating and a stock price that has fallen more than 98 percent over the last year.

title: Poll Finds New Yorkers Give High Marks to Pataki
description: While New Yorkers have growing concerns about the state's economy, and criticize the Governor's handling of it, George E. Pataki continues to receive high marks for his performance as governor, according to the latest statewide New York Times poll. He is seen as having made some progress in improving public schools, protecting environment and reducing taxes.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: HealthSouth Suspends Plan To Spin Off Surgical Unit

title: For the Nets' Mutombo, Glass Ceiling Vanishes
description: ''Rebounding, I think that's what makes me be Dikembe Mutombo,'' the Nets' newest 7-foot-2 center said, as if there were any doubt.

title: Insuring Against Terrorism
description: In discussing what Congress must do to help the economy, President Bush invariably mentions the need to create a federal program to provide ''terrorism insurance'' that would indemnify insurance companies against some of the huge costs of another terrorist attack. If Mr. Bush truly believes this to be a vital priority, he should press House Republican leaders to make a deal with Senate Democrats before everyone heads home to hit the campaign trail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, ANNE (NEE KLEIN)
description: HOCHBERG - Anne (nee Klein). Longtime early childhood and reading teacher, P.S. 152. Beloved wife of Harold. Devoted mother of David and Maryann, and Gary and Lee. Loving sister of Nellie Sandler. Cherished grandmother of David and Joseph. Services 1 P.M. Thursday, Riverdale Temple, 246th Street and Independence Ave. Donations to National Parkinson's Foundation.

title: Lawyers For Louima Spar in Court Over Fees
description: A prominent New York lawyer found himself in an unusual place yesterday: the witness stand in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, where he joined in a bitter battle over nearly $3 million in legal fees for work on Abner Louima's civil suit against the city.

title: Ad Campaign Leaves Pie on Microsofts Face
description: People accuse Microsoft of devious tactics all the time. Flanked by the best lawyers that money can buy, Microsoft generally denies the accusations, and thats that.

title: Snow, Islanders' No. 1A, Gets a Start
description: Garth Snow, the carefree and popular veteran whom the Islanders like to think of as their second No. 1 goalie, will get his first start of the season Thursday.

title: Sports of The Times; The N.F.L.'s New Twist On Fun
description: COMMISSIONER PAUL TAGLIABUE is expected to send a stern memo to all 32 National Football League teams today, warning them that Terrell Owens's behavior on ''Monday Night Football,'' and anything like it, will not be tolerated.

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of applications for mortgages fell last week from the highest level in more than a decade of record-keeping as refinancing and purchase orders slipped.

title: A Manager at His Peak
description: When the San Francisco Giants bat in the coming World Series, Dusty Baker will stand in the dugout and flash signs to his coaches for them to relay to the team's batters and runners. In Baker's life, though, it has been the signs he has received, not given, that have been most significant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: BORENSTEIN-William. Age 59. Passed away on October 15, 2002 after a brief illness. Devoted husband of Laura Nowak, loving father of Lea and Lou, cherished brother of Reva Metzger, Elie Rosenberg and Ruth Maass. Contributions in his name may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Hospital.

title: New Housing Rises 13.3% Despite Troubled Economy
description: With storms gathering elsewhere, the housing industry continues to shelter the economy during its halting recovery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REXSITE, SEYMOUR
description: REXSITE-Seymour. It is with great sorrow that the members of the Hebrew Actors Union mourn the death of our president, Seymour Rexsite.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAINER, HERMAN L.
description: SAINER-Herman L. The Board and staff of Citymealson-Wheels send their heartfelt sympathies to Janet Sainer on the passing of her beloved husband Hy. As the former Commissioner of the New York City Department for the Aging and a leading expert on aging issues, Janet has been a guide and inspiration to Citymeals for more than twenty years. We will miss Hy's smile and gentle humor at all Citymeals' gatherings. Gael Greene, Chairman Joseph M. Cohen, President Marcia Stein Executive Director Citymeals-on-Wheels

title: Candidates for Senate in New Jersey Duke It Out Over Views They Held a Decade Ago
description: Douglas R. Forrester's musings in a weekly paper a dozen or more years ago continued to provide fodder for Frank R. Lautenberg in his Senate campaign today, while Mr. Forrester pressed his criticism of Mr. Lautenberg's record in the Senate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Pipeline Contract Awarded
description: Japan's largest steel maker, the Nippon Steel Corporation, has won a contract to design and build a 230-mile oil pipeline to connect undersea oil fields off Sakhalin Island to an oil storage base on the mainland of Russia. The three-year contract, estimated to be worth more than $400 million, was awarded by the Sakhalin Oil and Gas Development Company, an international group operated by an Exxon Mobil unit. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, HANS P.
description: DEUTSCH-Hans P. Passed away on October 16, 2002 at the age of 78. Born in 1924 in Vienna, Austria and immigrated to Mexico in 1939. He graduated from the Mexican Polytechnic School as a Chemical Engineer, after which he owned and operated a glass factory. In 1977 he moved to New York where he continued to work in the glass industry. He is survived by his loving wife, Lore Simon Deutsch and his daughters, Judith Stern and Sandy Angevine, and his grandchildren, Sarah and Daniel Stern, and Jake Angevine.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: A Lift For Presidential Candidate
description: The independent presidential candidate Chung Mong Joon, who promises ''revolutionary change in politics,'' gained strong support when nine members of the National Assembly said they were quitting the governing Millennium Democratic Party to support him. Roh Moo Hyun, the Millennium Democratic Party candidate, said he would not withdraw despite the threat of more defections. Polls show Mr. Chung, whose father founded the Hyundai business empire, almost equal in popularity to Lee Hoi Chang, the candidate of the opposition Grand National Party. Both are well ahead of Mr. Roh. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: HealthSouth Suspends a Plan To Spin Off Surgery Centers
description: HealthSouth, the nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics, said yesterday that it was suspending its plan to spin off the surgical centers that are its most lucrative business.

title: In the Council: Pleas for Unity and a Debate on Resuming Arms Inspections
description: Following are excerpts from statements made before the Security Council yesterday during open debate on ''The Situation Between Iraq and Kuwait,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Films With War Themes Are Victims of Bad Timing
description: A cataclysmic event can change the fate of a movie. One example is ''The Quiet American,'' the Australian director Phillip Noyce's adaptation of Graham Greene's 1955 novel. In the three days between its rough-cut preview on Sept. 10, 2001, and a Miramax strategy meeting, the story of a war-tangled Saigon love triangle morphed from hot Oscar prospect to problem child.

title: Notes From Los Angeles; A Gray Future for California Voters
description: My liberal friends insist that my soul is doomed to eternal damnation because I worked for Ralph Nader in the 2000 election that threw the presidency to George W. Bush. They're probably right. There are nights when the Devil's pitchfork keeps me awake because I, having reached for the third-party lever, made John Ashcroft our top law officer and war with Iraq a religious crusade.

title: On Park Ave., Armory Is the Battleground; Taking the Offensive in a Conflict Over a Historic Fortress
description: Up at the armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street, things are finally back to normal.

title: Statements Put White House Into a Gun Control Debate
description: The White House found itself embroiled today in a combination of volatile gun control politics and the public's anxiety over the sniper in the Washington area.

title: Campaign Season; Gore Is Back in the (Wedding) Ring
description: On his political trip through Iowa this week, Al Gore drove the highways in a rented green Pontiac Grand Prix. He was mostly alone, but reporters trailed him, even to a rest stop where Mr. Gore paused to buy a Diet Dr Pepper for the road.

title: Red Sox Have Time To Go After Piniella
description: No, Larry Lucchino said, neither he nor any other executive of the Boston Red Sox had contacted the Seattle Mariners to express interest in pursuing Lou Piniella as a possible manager.

title: Bush Garners Little Support At U.N. for an Attack on Iraq
description: The Bush administration's push for an early American-led war against Iraq drew broad opposition today in an unusual open debate in the Security Council. Many countries backed weapons inspections, and Arab states said they would not support an attack without United Nations endorsement, considering an attack only as a last resort.

title: Australian Says, Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TELEVISION ACQUISITION As British television companies battle for ratings, Granada, the biggest commercial broadcaster, said it had agreed to buy a rival, Carlton, to create a single owner of the Independent Television network, in which they are the major stakeholders. The stock-and-cash deal values Carlton at $1.5 billion. Granada shareholders will get 68 percent of the new company and the equivalent of $310 million in cash. Carlton shareholders will receive 32 percent in a stock swap. Shares in both companies rose slightly. The broadcasters hope the combination, which still requires regulatory approval, will help them compete with the public broadcaster BBC and Rupert Murdoch's British Sky Broadcasting pay televeision venture. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Relying on Business Clients, AMR Posts a Loss
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, reported a third-quarter loss yesterday that was more than double its loss in the period a year ago. The company's dire financial numbers are expected to be among the worst for the airline industry this week, as the biggest carriers report earnings.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the plan to deploy federal surveillance aircraft in the hunt for the Washington area sniper omitted a word in some copies, reversing the meaning. In explaining why they were not treating the shootings as terrorist attacks, the authorities said they had ''no evidence to suggest an organized, politically motivated operation.'' (The omitted word was ''no.'')

title: Moss Presents a Challenge To Jets and Vikings Alike
description: Sam Garnes was on the field when Randy Moss disappeared in the 2000 N.F.C. championship game against the Giants -- 2 receptions for 18 yards -- and he was on the field when Moss exploded last season for 10 receptions, 171 yards and 3 touchdowns.

title: Parents of Sickened Children Ask for Tighter Rules on Food
description: The parents tell similar accounts of children who suddenly fall ill with stomach aches, fever and diarrhea. In days, the children are in pediatric intensive care units, and doctors are explaining that the cause is E. coli bacteria, probably from tainted meat.

title: Time Inc. Is Closing Sports Illustrated Women
description: For the second time this month, Time Inc. has shut down a money-losing magazine. Sports Illustrated Women, published 10 times a year, ceased publication yesterday.

title: Baseball and the Market
description: Historically, the average gain for the Dow Jones industrial in the year after an all-California World Series has been 7.9 percent.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Comsat Buys Latin American Assets From Lockheed
description: Comsat International Holdings, an investor group based in Washington, is expected to announce this week that it has completed the acquisition of telecommunications assets in several Latin American countries from Lockheed Martin. Under the deal, C.I.H., formerly known as World Data Consortium, will take 81 percent control of satellite and fiber optic operations that provide communications services to companies in six nations, including Brazil, Argentina and Colombia. ''Mentioning Latin America and telecommunications in the same breath is viewed as a death sentence in some places because of their respective crises,'' Tim Harmon, C.I.H.'s chief executive, said in an interview. ''We think it's an opportune time to get into both areas, when others are running out of the fire.'' Mr. Harmon declined to disclose the value of the deal but he said C.I.H. was planning to use the transaction as a starting point for other acquisitions in the region. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Navy Pilots Fall in Love, Acting Out Manliness
description: ''Burning Blue'' by D. M. W Greer is a flat-footed drama about a Navy investigation of an air crash that turns into a witchhunt for homosexuals.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Plan Would Give More Power To Regions
description: Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin presented to his cabinet a plan to strip some powers from the central government and give them to the regions. The plan would allow regional authorities to bypass the government on some aspects of tax collection and spending: Brittany might be allowed to administer its own water supply, Alsace could decide how to spend regional funds from the European Union and Burgundy could choose how to promote its tourist trade. Critics have called the plan a veiled plot to slash jobs in France's enormous state bureaucracy and a threat to the country's national identity. In the Constitution, the description of France as ''an indivisible, lay, democratic and social republic'' would be amended with the addition of ''Its organization is decentralized.'' Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLLUB, DR. SEYMOUR
description: GOLLUB-Dr. Seymour. Beloved husband of Edith. Loving father of Marc and Erica Gollub Messiah. Dear brother of Raphael. Cherished grandfather of Luka Emanuel and Adrian Laurent Gollub Messiah. Service Friday, 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Editor's Note

title: Tatyana M. Velikanova, 70, Soviet Human Rights Activist
description: Tatyana M. Velikanova, a Soviet human rights activist who was a leading editor of the most important samizdat journal of human rights abuses and spent nearly nine years in prison camp and exile, died of cancer on Sept. 19. She was 70 and lived in Moscow.

title: Japanese Minister Pushes, And the Banks Push Back
description: Japanese bankers are digging in to oppose vociferously efforts by Japan's new chief financial regulator, Heizo Takenaka, to force a faster resolution of the country's bad-loan crisis.

title: Lull in Regatta: Some Regroup, Some Rebuild
description: It was just two weeks ago that the boats left Viaduct Harbor for their first battles in the three-month slog that is the America's Cup challenger series. The first of two round robins is now over, and the nine syndicates competing for the right to race in February against the Cup defender, Team New Zealand, have revealed, if not their keels, at least their identities. They have separated into three distinct packs: the rockets, the duds and the emergency cases.

title: National Briefing: Health and Science
description: WIDOW SUES OVER ARTIFICIAL HEART The widow of a James Quinn, a Philadelphia man who grew to regret his decision to accept an experimental artificial heart, has filed suit against the heart's manufacturer and the hospital that provided her husband's care, saying the experiment stripped Mr. Quinn of his "essential human dignity." The suit, filed by his widow, Irene, seeks damages in excess of $100,000 from Abiomed of Danvers, Mass., the maker of the heart; Hahnemann University Hospital and its owner, the Tenet Healthcare Corporation ; Drexel University College of Medicine; and Dr. David Casarett, a geriatrician assigned by Abiomed to serve as a patient advocate for the Quinns.

title: Bullets, Values and the Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; A Confession That Clarifies Nothing
description: THE emergence of an imprisoned murderer and serial rapist who says he beat and raped the Central Park jogger seems to bring clarity to a heinous crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, WALTER
description: WEISS-Walter. Legendary ''21'' maitre d'. Save a good table for us. Love, Nancy and Bill

title: Settlers' Stand Ends in Deal With Army
description: A demonstration by hundreds of young settlers protesting eviction from this illegal Jewish outpost ended without confrontation today when the protesters left under an apparent compromise with the army.

title: A Digital Pen That Recalls Your On-the-Run Jottings
description: The digital age may have the world tapping on keyboards or barking commands at voice recognition software, but one big maker of computer peripherals is not ready to count out pen and paper. Next month Logitech plans to release the Io Personal Digital Pen, which allows users to store and retrieve their handwritten information digitally.

title: Mariners And Mets Exchange Proposals
description: The Mets continued discussions with Seattle executives yesterday regarding the compensation that would be necessary for the Mets to speak with Mariners Manager Lou Piniella, and for the first time, they exchanged proposals that included players' names.

title: Shedding Egos, Joining Forces; Museums Team Up to Foot the Bill and Find the Space for Art
description: When the pioneering video artist Bill Viola's biggest and most important work was up for sale at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery in London last year, several major museums coveted it. But the work, ''Five Angels for the Millennium,'' a 13-minute video depicting figures sequentially ascending and descending into pools of water, did not come cheap.

title: For a Two-Digit Price, A Two-Button Palm
description: AT this point in the information age, it has become clear that the high-tech industry operates according to certain unwritten laws. For example, there is Sony's Law: Smaller always costs more. There is Symantec's Law: Good tech support is hard to find. And above all, there's Microsoft's Law: Each version of a product must offer a longer feature list than its predecessor, even if the overall result isn't an improvement.

title: The Electric Car Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9 Accused Of Stealing $28 Million
description: Nine men were indicted yesterday on charges that they stole nearly $28 million from companies that had turned to them for help with bankruptcies. If convicted, the men would face up to 25 years in prison. The defendants, who were charged with racketeering, formed what prosecutors called a criminal enterprise known as the Calibso group. The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said the defendants specialized in what is known as the workout business, helping troubled companies reorganize or sell their assets. But, he said, the defendants turned to crime, including stealing cash and lying to companies and creditors about auction proceeds. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Another Rescue For Retailer
description: The Development Bank of Japan said it might invest in a fund that would help prop up Daiei, a Japanese retailer that has become a test case of the government's willingness to let debt-ridden companies fail. The aid would be the second bailout this year for Daiei and its first infusion of public money. The Development Bank, which is financed by public pensions and government-run postal savings accounts, would join Daiei's lenders in a 60 billion yen ($480 million) fund to support the retailer. Daiei's debts total about $17 billion. Such a use of public money may indicate that Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, above, is willing to exempt major employers like Daiei, which has 96,000 employees, from recent pledges by the government to force banks to cut off weak borrowers.

title: A Kuwaiti and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Delays Budget Until After Election
description: Confronted with a budget impasse and an approaching election, Congress agreed tonight to finance government agencies until late November and put off much of an unfinished legislative agenda to a post-election lame-duck session.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRENBAUM, ADA
description: BIRENBAUM - Ada. Died peacefully Wednesday age 91. Beloved mother of Daniel (Monique), adored grandmother of David and Efrat. Funeral Thursday 10:15 AM Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: For McDyess, It's Wait Till Next Season
description: Antonio McDyess will not swoop in with a cape in March to power the Knicks to a late-season playoff run. After McDyess, a 6-foot-9 power forward, underwent surgery today to repair his fractured left kneecap, the Knicks announced that he would miss the season.

title: Bullets, Values And the Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullets, Values And the Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: The Courage to Compete Before an Impossible Crowd
description: Elephant Man was dressed for combat. Protected by shin pads, shoulder pads and a helmet, he swung a baseball bat and shouted, ''Me a come prepared!'' He's the leading dance-hall reggae vocalist, and on Saturday night at Amazura, in Jamaica, Queens, he was the host of a boisterous competition called World Clash 2K2.

title: Court Revisits Question of Jury Selection Bias
description: The issue of discrimination in jury selection returned to the Supreme Court today, 16 years after the justices specified procedures for detecting the unconstitutional practice of picking or excluding jurors on the basis of race.

title: Sniper Hunt
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including comments on using the military in the sniper search and a comparison of delis in New York versus Los Angeles.

title: Mavericks Let Wang Go to the Clippers
description: Wang Zhizhi is headed to the Los Angeles Clippers after the Dallas Mavericks decided yesterday not to match a three-year, $6 million offer sheet.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday with an article about Kenya under nearly a quarter-century of leadership by Daniel arap Moi included an outdated population figure. The figure of 28.8 million was based on a 1999 census; the more accurate figure of 31 million, cited in the article, is an update based on a 2001 government survey.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: FASTER MICROCHIP PROTOTYPES DEVELOPED Lucent Technologies said yesterday that Bell Labs, its research arm, had developed compact, energy-efficient prototypes of microchips that receive data and interactive services on cellphones and laptop computers up to eight times the speed of today's most advanced mobile consumer devices. The speed advantages would be less in rural areas but the range for wireless communications would be extended, Lucent said. To achieve the benefits, base stations that handle wireless traffic would have to be upgraded to take advantage of the chips' capacity to run data through multiple antennae at one time. Lucent and other equipment makers are negotiating standards for such technology, which could provide a relatively inexpensive way to sharply increase the capacity of existing wireless networks.  Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: A Pop Diva With Armenian Roots, and She Isn't Cher
description: Fans were turned away by the hundreds at her concert here, crowded the stage to sing with her in Chicago and filled the aisles in Boston. Autograph seekers lined up everywhere; parents hurriedly snapped pictures of their children with her, then changed places to pose themselves. During the last four weeks Nune, a diminutive singer from Yerevan, the Armenian capital, held court among Armenian-Americans from Fresno, Calif., to Washington.

title: Ambivalent About U.N.?
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Completes Financing For Auto Venture in Korea
description: General Motors lined up the final piece of financial support today for its plan to transform most of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor into a viable new competitor in the rapidly growing East Asian vehicle market.

title: A Retiree's Crusade: No More Falling High-Rises
description: EVEN though the crisp blue commander's uniform now hangs in a closet and his radio and helmet have been turned in, Vincent Dunn is, at heart, still on the job. A firefighter, he says, until the day he dies.

title: A Challenge on Policy Shifts
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Family,'' is being shown in North Carolina media markets on behalf of Erskine B. Bowles, the Democratic nominee, by the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Dr. Frank X. Barron, a psychologist who was an expert on creativity, misstated the location of research he conducted on psychedelic drugs. It was Harvard, not the University of California at Berkeley.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Victor Botnick, 47, Youthful Adviser to Koch
description: Victor E. Botnick, who at age 32 was one of Mayor Edward I. Koch's most influential aides and head of the New York City's hospital system, died yesterday in an ambulance on the way to a hospital in Yonkers. He was 47.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, AUDREY RENEE
description: ROSEMAN-Audrey Renee. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Roseman, beloved and devoted mother of Donna and Jeffrey, dear sister of Ellie and Gerald, loving motherin-law of Ted and proud and adoring grandmother of Emma Faye, passed away peacefully after a long illness. Her grace, intelligence, beauty, humor and creative flare touched all those who knew her. Private funeral services will be held. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the New York Chapter of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, OLIVIA PETERS
description: HENRY-Olivia Peters, 84. Died October 16, New York City. Widow of S. Morgan Henry. Children: Olivia and Morgan. Son-in-law: Tim Gurshin. Three grandchildren. Active in the Colonial Dames of America, the Church Women's League and the City Garden Club. Friends luncheon October 21, 1 PM, The Colony Club, 564 Park Ave., NYC. Private service in MA. Donations to Mt. Vernon Hotel Museum and Garden, 421 East 61 St., NY, NY 10021.

title: Tragedy Chose a Place of Quiet Serenity
description: With snowflakes falling on a cold gray day, the scent of tortillas and spice from El Burrito restaurant drifted onto Main Street this morning. A few doors down, inside Tienda Vaquera, a country-and-western store, the scent of leather boots -- crocodile, lizard and ostrich -- filled the air. The owner, Rogelio Cabrera, stood proudly behind the counter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOR, JUDITH ROSS
description: CONNOR-Judith Ross. Wife of Stanley Epstein, mother of Ethan, Seth and Andrea Connor, grandmother of Olivia. Services 11 AM Friday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Feeling That Witnesses Need a Hand, Police Offer One
description: In what appeared to be a bit of a breakthrough, the latest sniper killing, on Monday night at a Home Depot in Falls Church, Va., yielded several witnesses, the police said. This was different from the other 10 shootings, when the sniper disappeared before anybody could be certain that he was there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSIER, BELLE (NEE MERL)
description: ROSIER-Belle (nee Merl). Age 93 of Scottsdale, Arizona, formerly of New York City. On Wednesday, October 16, 2002. Beloved mother of Paul of Phoenix & Robert (Linda) of N. Caldwell, NJ. Much loved grandmother of Philip (Christine), Linda (Andrew), Richard (Michelle) and Jeffrey (Allison). Loving greatgrandmother of Julia, Zoey, Natalie, Adrian, Stephanie and Jordan. Devoted sister of Irving Merl of Florida. Predeceased by her husband George & a twin sister Cecille. Graveside services Friday, October 18 at 10 AM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. Jewish Memorial Chapel, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Bush Backs Retaliation By Israelis If Iraq Attacks
description: President Bush said today that he fully expected that Israel would aggressively retaliate after any unprovoked Iraqi attack.

title: In a Mississippi Town, a Little Boy's Murder Spells the Death of a Family
description: THE LITTLE FRIEND

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: JAMAICA: VOTING FOR NEW PARLIAMENT After a campaign that focused on the sluggish economy and rampant crime, people formed long lines to vote yesterday in an election for all 60 seats in Parliament. Prime Minister P. J. Patterson, whose People's National Party held a slim edge in polls, was trying to become the first Jamaican leader to win three consecutive terms. His opponent, former Prime Minister Edward Seaga, said his Jamaica Labor Party would revive the moribund tourism industry, create jobs and curb a high homicide rate attributed largely to drug traffickers. (AP)

title: Panoramic Sheds Earle Palmer Office
description: The breakup of the agency company Panoramic Communications continued yesterday as it disposed of one of two remaining offices of its flagship, Earle Palmer Brown, in a deal with Havas. Terms were not disclosed.

title: From Ice Cubes to Games, a Fridge That Delivers
description: When more than two manufacturers announce a new product category, it starts to look like a trend. By that reckoning, Internet-enabled refrigerators have reached trend status: LG Electronics and Samsung have joined Daewoo by announcing entries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, S. WILLIAM (BILL)
description: GREEN-S. William (Bill). On October 14, 2002. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Freiberg). Devoted and cherished father of Cathy Green and Louis Green. Dear brother of Cynthia Green Colin. Fond brother-in-law of Carole and Marvin Leichtung. Loving uncle of nieces, Julie, Laura, Ann and Betsy, and nephew, Jim. A native of New York City, he served his city and his country in many capacities, both before and after representing the East Side of Manhattan in the House of Representatives from 1978 to 1992. He was a graduate and loyal alumnus of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Tuesday, October 15, and Wednesday, October 16, from 7 PM-9 PM. Services Thursday, October 17, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Hang Up Your Hat and Get Comfortable
description: The love seat, called Mouth (above right, $5,672), dressed in bordello-red upholstery, looks like a casting couch for ''Sex and the City.'' The hat tree (center, $2,550), is called Cactus. The chair (left, $4,734) is the Meadow and is made of three-foot-high blades of grass. They are from Gufram's Multipli Collection, which made its debut in the 1960's. ''They are all icons,'' said Pina Manzone, sole distributor of the 11-piece collection, which has not been available in America for more than a decade. The pieces, water-resistant and washable and for indoor and outdoor use, range from $400 to $5,000. Multipli is available only at Signorello of Westport, 11 Wilton Road, Westport, Conn.; (203) 221-3200 or www.gufram.com. N. C. MAISAK

title: El Paso Lawsuits To Move Ahead
description: A California judge ruled late yesterday that a handful of antitrust lawsuits against the El Paso Corporation and two other energy companies could move forward.

title: Timken Expands Market Share By Acquiring a Bearings Unit
description: The Timken Company, which makes steel alloys and roller bearings, agreed yesterday to acquire the Ingersoll-Rand Company's precision bearings and motion-control components and assemblies unit for $840 million in cash and stock.

title: One Down, 31,999 to Go: Surrendering to a Solitary Obsession
description: IT keeps office workers from concentrating on their jobs. It deprives children of parental attention. It estranges husbands from wives. It gives writers an excuse not to write.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the first homeland visit by five Japanese who were abducted by North Koreans more than 20 years ago referred incorrectly in some copies to the background of Charles Robert Jenkins, who married one of them in North Korea. He deserted the United States Army while stationed in South Korea, but it was in 1965, not during the Korean War.

title: You Oughta Be In Print
description: AFTER spending a year trying to sell her book to publishers and receiving 70 rejection letters as a reward, Laurie Notaro, a newspaper columnist in Phoenix, decided to do it herself. Working with iUniverse, one of many companies that offer ''print on demand'' services, Ms. Notaro paid $99 to have her book designed, laid out, stored as a digital file and printed and bound only as copies were ordered. Several months later she sold the rights to her book, plus the concept for a new one, to a major publisher for a six-figure sum.

title: Economic Scene; Music sales slump, concert ticket costs jump and rock fans pay the price.
description: IF you have gone to a rock 'n' roll concert lately, you probably noticed that the price of tickets has been rising faster than the decibel level. Although concert prices have always grown somewhat faster than inflation, from 1996 to 2001 the average price soared 62 percent, while the Consumer Price Index increased just 13 percent and the price of sporting events, movies and theater rose 24 percent.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the first homeland visit by five Japanese who were abducted by North Koreans more than 20 years ago referred incorrectly in some copies to the background of Charles Robert Jenkins, who married one of them in North Korea. He deserted the United States Army while stationed in South Korea, but it was in 1965, not during the Korean War.

title: Viennese Revival: A Riot of Flowers
description: IN the past year, New Yorkers have witnessed a replay of the old conflict between Nothingness and Stuff. If we build on ground zero, one argument goes, we are materialists. If we don't, we are people of the spirit, the soul, or some other morally superior class of being.

title: Market Place; Morgan Chase Says Its Profit Tumbled 91%
description: J. P. Morgan Chase said yesterday that its profit plummeted 91 percent last quarter, largely because of bad loans to telecommunications and cable companies, and that it would cut more than 2,000 jobs from its investment bank.

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Faster Microchip Prototypes Developed
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that Bell Labs, its research arm, had developed compact, energy-efficient prototypes of microchips that receive data and interactive services on cellphones and laptop computers up to eight times the speed of today's most advanced mobile consumer devices. The speed advantages would be less in rural areas but the range for wireless communications would be extended, Lucent said. To achieve the benefits, base stations that handle wireless traffic would have to be upgraded to take advantage of the chips' capacity to run data through multiple antennae at one time. Lucent and other equipment makers are negotiating standards for such technology, which could provide a relatively inexpensive way to sharply increase the capacity of existing wireless networks. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: In the Thick Of Great Grasses
description: WHEN Kurt Bluemel arrived in the United States more than 40 years ago, most gardeners thought grass was just another word for lawn. Fresh from working among the 6,000 different plants at the Arnold Vogt nursery near Zurich, Mr. Bluemel went to work for a nursery in Monkton, Md., whose plant list filled one page. Mr. Bluemel, now 70, is today considered one of America's foremost nurseryman and, many would say, the king of ornamental grasses.

title: 2 Washington Fixtures Aim for Down-Home Image
description: They are inescapable, provided that the television set is on and the remote control is out of reach. Elizabeth Dole and Erskine B. Bowles are all over the dial in North Carolina, attacking each other as heartless hypocrites and tools of big business in 30-second fusillades from the ''Today'' program to ''The Late Show.''

title: DELIA'S, A CLOTHING RETAILER, HIRES ADVISORY FIRM
description: The Delia's Corporation, a retailer of clothing and accessories for teenagers and young women, hired the Peter J. Solomon Company as an adviser as the company considers alternatives including a sale. The review may not result in a transaction, Delia's said. Delia's, which is based in New York, has not set a timetable for completion of the review, a spokeswoman, Amanda Mullin, said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the bandleader Ray Conniff by The Associated Press on Tuesday omitted some survivors. Besides his wife, Vera, and a daughter, Tamara Conniff, they include a son, James L., and three grandchildren.

title: A Representative Nobel
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESS PASSES BILL TO CLEAN UP ELECTION SYSTEM
description: Congress gave final approval today to a bill to clean up the nation's election procedures, nearly two years after a breakdown in Florida balloting muddled the results of the 2000 presidential election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, GERTRUDE
description: SUSSMAN - Gertrude. Be loved wife of the late Dr. Ralph Sussman and Leopold Sneider. Devoted mother of Elizabeth and Edward Stevens, Agnes and Henry Gottlieb, and Elizabeth Socolow. Fond mother-in-law of Lee Sneider Poates. Sister of Jeanette Cohen. Cherished grandmother of Carla, Michael, Catherine, Annie, Daniel, Thomas, David, Erin and Seth. Great grandmother of Stephen Ernest. Services were held. Contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice or Cancer Care.

title: Cuomo Ready to Talk Politics, Except for Issue of His Future
description: After a while, it was hard to remember that Andrew M. Cuomo is not a candidate anymore.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Suspect Charged In Terror Attacks
description: A woman linked to the November 17 urban guerrilla group has been charged with complicity in two deadly attacks, including the assassination of a British brigadier two years ago. Angeliki Sotiropoulou was also charged with taking part in a bungled bomb attack in June, which led to a police crackdown on the group. Since then, 17 suspects have been jailed. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Candidates Disagree Sharply On Gloomy Ledger in Albany
description: Spending by New York State is up sharply this year, receipts are down just as steeply, and the state's balance sheet looks even worse over all than the gloomy predictions made earlier this year.

title: ATLAS AIR TO RESTATE 2001 AND 2002 RESULTS AFTER AUDIT
description: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings Inc. said it would restate results for the last two years, reducing profit in the period by as much as $65 million, based on discussions with its new auditors. Its shares fell 31 percent. Atlas, the largest hauler of freight for other airlines will change the way it accounts for value of inventory, with an allowance for bad debts and maintenance expense. The company estimates that profit will be reduced for 2000 and 2001 and raised by $5 million to $10 million for this year, a spokeswoman, Rachel Berry, said. Stock in Atlas, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., fell 79 cents, to $1.80 a share. Atlas hired Ernst & Young to replace Arthur Andersen as auditor in April, and company employees found the accounting issues a few days ago, Ms. Berry said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Television Acquisition
description: As British television companies battle for ratings, Granada, the biggest commercial broadcaster, said it had agreed to buy a rival, Carlton, to create a single owner of the Independent Television network, in which they are the major stakeholders. The stock-and-cash deal values Carlton at $1.5 billion. Granada shareholders will get 68 percent of the new company and the equivalent of $310 million in cash. Carlton shareholders will receive 32 percent in a stock swap. Shares in both companies rose slightly. The broadcasters hope the combination, which still requires regulatory approval, will help them compete with the public broadcaster BBC and Rupert Murdoch's British Sky Broadcasting pay televeision venture. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Ronald A. Malt, 70, Is Dead; Innovator in Reattaching Limb
description: Dr. Ronald A. Malt, a Boston surgeon who made medical history 40 years ago when he oversaw the first successful reattachment of a human limb, died on Oct. 5 in Wellesley, Mass. He was 70.

title: New York Winners Are Coming Back
description: Last year's winners of the New York City Marathon are returning for another try Nov. 3.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Grades After Exam Complaints
description: After a review of final exams in many high schools, examiners gave improved grades to almost 2,000 of some 91,000 students who had complained of their grades being lowered in tests crucial for university entrance. The issue had threatened to undermine confidence in Britain's higher education and caused a political furor. But the regrading showed that the impact on college entrance had been limited to 168 students who failed to secure places at their universities of first choice and a further 73 who had been denied entry to their preferred courses of study at their first-choice universities. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: U.S. Is Putting Heavy Pressure on France and Other Skeptics for a U.N. Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16  The Bush administration is mounting a campaign of public pressure and private diplomatic and economic concessions to persuade France and other skeptical members of the United Nations Security Council to go along with a single resolution threatening military force against Iraq.

title: Interpublic Group surprises investors with yet another warning of financial setbacks.
description: THE Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which had previously warned of earnings disappointments and accounting irregularities, has surprised Wall Street again with disclosures of additional financial shortfalls and setbacks. The unexpected announcements, made yesterday after the stock market closed, threaten to unleash a firestorm of criticism that is likely to reach the highest levels of the agency company.

title: Police Plan to Focus on Burglary And Pursue Repeat Offenders
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday that he would seek to cut the number of burglaries in the city, in part by compiling a list of serial burglars and making teams of detectives available to help burglary investigators in certain cases.

title: Successor to Ancient Alexandria Library Dedicated
description: President Hosni Mubarak and other dignitaries from around the world descended on this port today to inaugurate what has been nicknamed the Fourth Pyramid, a long-awaited successor to one of the classical world's great and lamented intellectual marvels, the library of Alexandria.

title: Now Playing: Mickey, Goofy, Donald and You
description: KINGDOM HEARTS

title: Woods Suggests Sides Bend a Little on Augusta
description: As the world's top golfer and perhaps its most recognizable athlete, Tiger Woods has generally been daring with his game and guarded with his public comments. But today, Woods, whose multiethnic background has always been notable in a sport lacking diversity, offered a more elaborate opinion on golf's most vexing issue -- the exclusion of women as members at Augusta National Golf Club, home of the Masters.

title: Panel Questions Value of Hormone Therapy
description: A medical panel that helps set government policy has joined the growing ranks of experts registering doubts about the value of hormone replacement therapy in preventing many of the chronic diseases associated with aging.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: A LIFT FOR PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE The independent presidential candidate Chung Mong Joon, who promises "revolutionary change in politics," gained strong support when nine members of the National Assembly said they were quitting the governing Millennium Democratic Party to support him. Roh Moo Hyun, the Millennium Democratic Party candidate, said he would not withdraw despite the threat of more defections. Polls show Mr. Chung, whose father founded the Hyundai business empire, almost equal in popularity to Lee Hoi Chang, the candidate of the opposition Grand National Party. Both are well ahead of Mr. Roh. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Pinwheel For Your Oranges
description: ITEMS designed by Dagobert Peche have been reproduced for the tiny, well-appointed shop on the Neue Galerie's main floor. A 1922 ceramic bowl, below, with a pinwheel pattern, has been reissued by the same company in Vienna that made the original. It is large enough for a dozen oranges and costs $420.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page yesterday about the planned inauguration of Judson R. Shaver tomorrow as a college president reversed the parts of the college's name. It is Marymount Manhattan.

title: A Tricky Maze for Consumers
description: Businesses, responding to lawmakers and consumers, say they are giving customers more ways than ever to control how their personal information is used and sold. But, in fact, many companies all but frustrate their customers' attempts to exercise that control.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: PLAN WOULD GIVE MORE POWER TO REGIONS Prime Minister Jean-Pierre Raffarin presented to his cabinet a plan to strip some powers from the central government and give them to the regions. The plan would allow regional authorities to bypass the government on some aspects of tax collection and spending: Brittany might be allowed to administer its own water supply, Alsace could decide how to spend regional funds from the European Union and Burgundy could choose how to promote its tourist trade. Critics have called the plan a veiled plot to slash jobs in France's enormous state bureaucracy and a threat to the country's national identity. In the Constitution, the description of France as "an indivisible, lay, democratic and social republic" would be amended with the addition of "Its organization is decentralized." Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Surviving a Northeast Winter

title: AT HOME WITH/Aviva Slesin; Sharing the Secrets of the Hidden Children
description: THERE is a stunning moment in ''Secret Lives: Hidden Children and Their Rescuers During World War II,'' a new documentary about Jewish children hidden by non-Jewish families in the hope that they would survive the Nazis.

title: By Saying Very Little, Pataki Sticks to Script
description: Few politicians go far without knowing how to sidestep a tough question, put off a painful decision with a blue-ribbon panel or avoid taking a strong position until the winds of popular opinion blow one way or another.

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. to Meet With Group On Minorities
description: The National Football League will meet Tuesday with a group that seeks more head coaching opportunities for African-Americans and increased minority hirings throughout the league.

title: Assemblywoman Wins in Bronx In Second Democratic Primary
description: Carmen E. Arroyo, an assemblywoman from the South Bronx, has won an unusual second primary election to become the Democratic Party nominee for the Assembly seat, defeating former City Councilman Pedro Gautier Espada by 151 votes, the Board of Elections said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Camden: Death Penalty Urged In Commuter Murder
description: Camden County prosecutors say they will seek the death penalty for two men accused in the murder of a Washington Township woman who was abducted from a parking lot at a commuter rail station last year. The men, Ryshaone H. Thomas, 24, and Marcus D. Toliver, 23, both of Camden, face numerous murder, robbery and weapons charges related to the Nov. 12 slaying of the woman, Christine L. Eberle, 27. Ms. Eberle was returning home from her job at a Philadelphia investment firm when, prosecutors said, the pair seized her at the Ferry Avenue station of the Port Authority Transit Corporation's Hi-Speedline. Prosecutors said that the men beat and strangled her. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: 9 ACCUSED OF STEALING $28 MILLION Nine men were indicted yesterday on charges that they stole nearly $28 million from companies that had turned to them for help with bankruptcies. If convicted, the men would face up to 25 years in prison. The defendants, who were charged with racketeering, formed what prosecutors called a criminal enterprise known as the Calibso group. The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said the defendants specialized in what is known as the workout business, helping troubled companies reorganize or sell their assets. But, he said, the defendants turned to crime, including stealing cash and lying to companies and creditors about auction proceeds. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: 11 Million Voters Say the Iraqi President Is Perfect
description: Iraq said today that Saddam Hussein had scored a perfect 100 percent of the 11.4 million votes cast in a presidential referendum on Tuesday, thus securing -- from a field that consisted only of himself -- a further seven years as Iraq's leader. In the process, he sought to deliver a warning to the United States of the popular resistance it would face if it stages a military invasion.

title: Revisiting Florida's Chads, Seeking Lessons and Jokes
description: ''Who Counts?,'' tonight on PBS, is a jarring blend of civics lesson and satire. It's a look back at the unresolved questions of fairness and procedure that still cling to the 2000 presidential vote in Florida. In between the expected segments of recap and talking heads, Darrell Hammond of ''Saturday Night Live'' shows up in the guises of Bill Clinton, Al Gore and Dick Cheney to comment on the commentary. His Clinton says of Mr. Gore: ''He lost by 537 votes. I myself voted that many times for the new M&M color.''

title: Selling Furniture From the Hot Seat
description: There were bets that she wouldn't show up at all, at the country's most important furniture market. But Martha Stewart arrived here today, only slightly late because a private jet was delayed by rain in Westchester.

title: Woman Accused of Luring A Deliveryman to His Death
description: A day after the ambush killing of a Chinese food deliveryman in Brooklyn, a 19-year-old woman and a 16-year-old boy were charged with murder and attempted robbery in the case yesterday. A third suspect remained at large.

title: Despite the Warnings, the First Northeaster Is Mostly Bluster
description: The first northeaster of the season, which was expected to wreak havoc yesterday as it hit New York City and its suburbs with driving rains and severe winds, ended up producing just a wet and windy day.

title: Results at I.B.M. Defy the Slump in Technology
description: I.B.M. reported earnings and revenues yesterday that slightly surpassed Wall Street's expectations. The results provide another sign that the company's emphasis on services and software is enabling it to withstand the continuing slump in technology spending better than most of its rivals.

title: 3 Rivals in Brooklyn Race See Council Issues Alike
description: The dominant political figure in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, for the past several years has been Angel Rodriguez, a city councilman who was once a leading candidate to be the Council's speaker. But Mr. Rodriguez pleaded guilty in a federal bribery case in August and resigned.

title: Stocks Close Higher After Yesterday's Drop
description: Stock prices rose more than 2 percent today, bouncing back from Wednesday's sell-off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTNICK, VICTOR
description: BOTNICK - Victor. Beloved husband of Lee. Devoted father of Mark and Seth. Son of Eva. Brother of Karen. Funeral service October 17 at 11 AM at Young Israel Ohab Zedek, 6015 Riverdale Ave., Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Governor Shows How It's Done
description: Two weeks ago a reporter at the Capitol asked Gov. George E. Pataki if he had ever written letters on behalf of friends seeking jobs, as his Democratic opponent, H. Carl McCall, had done for his daughter. The day before, the governor had said that he did could not recall writing similar letters.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: CHINA: ECONOMIC GROWTH China's economic growth accelerated in the third quarter to 8.1 percent from 8 percent in the second quarter, the government said. Yao Jingyuan, the chief economist of the National Bureau of Statistics, which released the figures, said the expansion might slow to 7.9 percent in the final three months of the year as government spending falls, state companies lay off workers and the gap between the rich and poor grows. (Bloomberg News)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KURTIN, BERNARD
description: KURTIN-Bernard. On the first anniversary of your death, Jeanie, Owen, Sabryna, Jean-Michael, Noah and Dora miss, remember and love you

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Brewery Stake For Busch
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the maker of Budweiser, will sign an agreement to raise its stake in the Tsingtao Brewery Company during President Jiang Zemin's visit to the United States later this month, said Xu Peifeng, the division chief of the trade department in Qingdao, where Tsingtao is based.

title: Celebrating That Great Pas de Deux, Love
description: Boy meets girl is ballet's eternal theme, or so American Ballet Theater suggested on Tuesday night in a high-energy gala that opened its two-week season at City Center. There was an exceptional performance led by Angel Corella, Ethan Stiefel and Jos Manuel Carreo in Jerome Robbins's ''Fancy Free,'' more than brilliantly staged by Jean-Pierre Frohlich from the New York City Ballet.

title: 90 Years Of New Poems
description: Ezra Pound, in a typically forceful letter, wrote that ''every literaryism, every book word, fritters away a scrap of the reader's patience'' -- that is, put nothing on paper one couldn't ''ACTUALLY say.'' He then went on to write poetry so complex it seemed the reader had to know the entire history of civilization and several languages, some possibly extinct, to understand his work.

title: A Way to Trace Bullets
description: Nervous citizens can only hope that the Bush administration is serious about exploring the possibilities of a computerized national system for tracing bullets and cartridge casings to the guns that fired them. The public is surely interested in such a system, which would probably be a great help in tracking down criminals like the sniper who has terrified metropolitan Washington. But Ari Fleischer, the president's spokesman, seemed determined this week to emphasize the potential drawbacks. Fortunately, White House aides have partially reversed course and asked the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to explore the feasibility of ''ballistic fingerprints.''

title: Children Learn Design's DDD's
description: A new Web site, www.3d-i.org (right), is intended to help children ''design anything from watches to shoes to logos and vehicles,'' said Immy Humes, a Manhattan filmmaker who helped create it. On the site, which was financed by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, children can click on three color-coded letter d's -- Discover (orange, where they can explore different design origins), Design (green, where they can make their own designs and compare them with others) and Discuss (blue, what is your dream house?). Chichi Pierce, who also worked on the site, had planned a television program on design, but learned that more and more 9- to 12-year-olds were spending time online. Now, children can learn about Frank Gehry and design their ''personal explorer pod.'' ELAINE LOUIE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABALME, PATRICIA HOCHSCHILD
description: LABALME-Patricia Hochschild. On October 11, 2002, at the age of 75. She was the wife of George Labalme Jr., mother of Jennifer R. Labalme, Henry G. Labalme, Lisa G. Osterland & Victoria A. Labalme, grandmother of six, and sister of Ann H. Poole, all of whom mourn her passing. A graduate of the Brearley School and Magna Cum Laude graduate of Bryn Mawr, she held an M.A. and Ph.D. from Harvard, where she was awarded the Caroline A. Wilby prize for her doctoral dissertation as ''the best original work in any department.'' Among her many professional activities, Patricia Labalme was Associate Director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, (1982-1988) and Secretary of the Corporation (1982-1992). From 1992-1997, she was Assistant to the Director, Dr. Phillip A. Griffiths. Most recently, she was a Visitor in the School of Historical Studies, at the IAS. Known also for her dedication to independent school education, she was, among her many affiliations, president of the Brearley Board of Trustees (1978-1982). She was also a trustee of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation (1979Present), the American Academy in Rome (1979-1999), the first female trustee of the Lawrenceville School (1985-1996), and a trustee of the Renaissance Society of America (1982-Present). She was also a member of the Ateneo Veneto and the Istituto di Scienze, Lettere ed Arti, both in Venice, and Director of the Quantum Chemical Corporation. Her passion for humanism was formed by her lifelong friendships with professors Werner Jaeger, Myron P. Gilmore, Helen Maud Cam, Paul Oskar Kristeller, Vittore Branca and Felix Gilbert. It was Gilbert, her professor at Bryn Mawr and her colleague at the IAS, who, after three decades of encouragement, persuaded her to start her book on Marino Sanudo's diaries. At the time of her death, Dr. Labalme was close to completing this book, which received initial funding from the NEH. The book will be published posthumously under a unique arrangement in which the IAS has created a special position, a Director's Visitor, to be held by Professor Laura S. White, who will oversee the book's completion. A private service was held at the family home in West Cornwall, CT, on October 14. A memorial service will be held at the Marciana Library in Venice. In addition, a New York City memorial service will be held at the Brearley School at a later date to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the Brearley School, attention: Alumnae Office, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, for the benefit of faculty salaries.

title: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT HAS A PROGRAM ON NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Confronted by new American intelligence, North Korea has admitted that it has been conducting a major clandestine nuclear-weapons development program for the past several years, the Bush administration said tonight. Officials added that North Korea had also informed them that it has now ''nullified'' its 1994 agreement with the United States to freeze all nuclear weapons development activity.

title: Bush Garners Little Support at U.N. for an Attack on Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 16  The Bush administration's push for an early American-led war against Iraq drew broad opposition today in an unusual open debate in the Security Council. Many countries backed weapons inspections, and Arab states said they would not support an attack without United Nations endorsement, considering an attack only as a last resort.

title: Ex-U.S. Aide Sentenced to 25 Years for Spying for Cuba
description: A former Pentagon intelligence analyst who spied for Cuba for 16 years said as she was sentenced today that she had wanted to help the island's Communist government defend itself against unjust American policies.

title: Indian Government Announces Pullback From Pakistan Border
description: The Indian government announced tonight that it would pull back troops from its border with Pakistan in its most substantial step to reduce a military buildup begun 10 months ago that helped bring the two nations to the brink of war.

title: Yemen Says Ship Was Attacked
description: SANA, Yemen, Oct. 16  Yemen acknowledged today that an explosion aboard a French oil tanker almost two weeks ago as it headed into a Yemeni port was the work of terrorists.

title: Beating a Favored Team From Both Sides of the Table
description: The names of bridge players sometimes give officials and journalists trouble. An extreme example at the world championships in Montreal in August concerned a Swedish player previously listed as Peter Stromberg. He was recently married to a Norwegian woman whose grandmother was distressed that her name, Bertheau, was disappearing. She persuaded her daughter and granddaughter to change their names, and Stromberg agreed to take the name Bertheau at his marriage. His new mother-in-law, who had switched reluctantly, then reverted to her previous name.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Harris Lowers Profit Forecast
description: The Harris Corporation, a maker of communications equipment, lowered its fiscal-year profit forecast and plans to cut jobs because of lower industry spending as it said first-quarter profit rose 16 percent. The shares fell as much as 27 percent. Shares of Harris fell $5.75, or 17 percent, to $28. The stock fell as low as $24.60, the lowest price since April 2001. Profit for the year ending in June is expected to be about $1.30 to $1.40 a share, excluding costs related to the job cuts. The company's previous estimate was $1.50 to $1.60 a share. Harris, which is based in Melbourne, Fla., will trim engineering staff at its microwave telecommunications division as it consolidates three United States research and development sites into one East Coast location. The actions will cost about $7 million to $8 million during the current fiscal year. A company spokesman, Tom Hausman, declined to give details on the job cuts since employees were still being notified of the decision.

title: Memorial Vision: Out of One Light, Many
description: To the Editor:

title: Acquiring the Essential Trappings of the Genteel Nomad
description: IF traveling in Peru for a couple of months is not in your near future, here are places to explore your inner hippie.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Boy's Condition Still Critical After Fall
description: A 16-year-old Bronx boy remained in critical condition yesterday after falling three stories down an elevator shaft at his high school. City officials continued to investigate whether there was a critical flaw in the elevator doors. Metal wheels on the top and bottom of the elevator at Harry S. Truman High School in Co-Op City snapped when the boy, Jason Ford, slammed into it shortly after noon on Tuesday while roughhousing with a friend. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: After 8 Arrests, Working to Learn Details of a Girl's Killing
description: Minutes before she disappeared five years ago, Maryann Measles, a scared young girl from the wrong part of this wealthy town, had a feeling that the people she sometimes called friends wanted to kill her.

title: The Pact That the Koreans Flouted
description: The nuclear agreement signed by President Clinton and North Korea in 1994 was reached after many months of fitful negotiations that came after North Korea had threatened to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and had halted international inspections of a nuclear reactor.

title: City Gets $1.4 Million From Handyman
description: AMinneapolis handyman who amassed a fortune from scavenging and who rewrote his will after the Sept. 11 attacks and made New York City his sole heir has made his final bequest  more than $1.4 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Economic Growth
description: China's economic growth accelerated in the third quarter to 8.1 percent from 8 percent in the second quarter, the government said. Yao Jingyuan, the chief economist of the National Bureau of Statistics, which released the figures, said the expansion might slow to 7.9 percent in the final three months of the year as government spending falls, state companies lay off workers and the gap between the rich and poor grows.

title: CUNY Getting Money to Nurture High-Tech Firms
description: The State Assembly will give the City University of New York $7.5 million to create a network of incubators for small, high-technology businesses, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said yesterday.

title: For Your Pearl of a Laptop, An Ergonomic Oyster
description: When some laptop computer users are working from their home base, they slip their machines into to a docking station that links to a desktop monitor, full-size keyboard and mouse. The Oyster from Tcom International is a less of a docking station than an ergonomic laptop cradle and cable management system. Instead of buying a monitor, users can elevate their laptop screens for comfortable desktop viewing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're trying to tell everybody, 'Get your checks in before November 5th,' because there's no more soft money after that.''

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Sniper Sighting Fails to Create A Clear Picture
description: The police announced today that they had no sketch to offer the public in their hunt for the suburban sniper because witnesses who saw him kill his latest victim could not agree on details in the mayhem of the shooting scene.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe To Dismiss Workers In 4th Quarter
description: Adobe Systems, the world's biggest maker of graphic-design software, will lay off workers this quarter after a decline in sales. An Adobe spokeswoman, Holly Campbell, declined to say yesterday how many of the company's 3,500 employees will lose their jobs. Jay Vleeschhouwer, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, said he expected the cuts to be ''in the neighborhood of 250 jobs.'' Adobe wants to protect profit levels after sales of its Photoshop picture-editing software fell to $118.2 million in the quarter ended Aug. 30, from $125.5 million a year earlier. The company laid off 247 workers, or 8 percent of its work force, late last year as demand for software to design brochures and Web sites fell.

title: New Moves for Nervous Merchants
description: EVERY year Jonah Zuckerman, a furniture maker in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, participates in the Art Under the Bridge festival, a weekend when artists and craftspeople open their studios to the public. His goal in the past was to spur interest in future commissions. But when the festival kicks off tomorrow, he will have a different agenda: to sell all the showroom samples at his company, City Joinery. ''I'm anticipating being slow for a while,'' he said of his first-time effort to sweep out everything. He said he hopes to generate cash so that he can ''make a lot of new things'' while he waits for business to pick up again.

title: A Counterattack, Maybe
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, began broadcasting yesterday in upstate New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $1.5 Million In Jewels Stolen
