description: Investigators were hunting yesterday for whoever stole about $1.5 million worth of jewelry from a Midtown store, the police said. Diamonds and gold settings for rings were among the items stolen from the 12th-floor offices of the Epsilon Jewelry Corporation at 70 West 40th Street sometime between 11 p.m. Monday and 6 a.m. Tuesday, the police said. The thieves probably entered through a fire door and forced open the vault door in the shop's safe room, the police said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Kidnapped Japanese Stay Evasive About Others in North Korea
description: Visiting Japan after 24 years in North Korea, five Japanese kidnapping victims are proving to be tight-lipped, family members said today. They don't want to talk about their kidnappings. They don't want to talk about returning to live in Japan. And they don't want to talk about other Japanese people they may have met in Pyongyang.

title: Scott Is Elected To the Hall of Fame
description: Four retired athletes, led by the miler Steve Scott, were elected yesterday to the National Track and Field Hall of Fame.

title: READER'S DIGEST REVISES PLAN AFTER LAWSUITS
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that it had revised a stock-conversion plan that was opposed by some investors. The revised plan, which would replace two classes of shares with a single class, calls for Reader's Digest to buy 4.6 million Class B shares from its main shareholders, the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund and the DeWitt Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund. The company will pay $21.75 a share, or $100 million, Reader's Digest said. Three of the parties involved in the lawsuits have entered preliminary agreements to settle the cases, the company said. Each remaining Class B shares, held by the Wallace funds and other investors, would be exchanged for 1.22 shares of new common stock.

title: In Iraqi's Words: White House Seems to Be Caught in 'Hysteria of War'
description: Following are excerpts from the speech yesterday by Iraq's ambassador, Mohammed Aldouri, to the United Nations Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: An Insufferable Risk
description: On Sunday, in Denison, Iowa, a worker at the Farm Service Co-op and Archer Daniels Midland elevator siding examined a sealed grain hopper that had been brought in after spending the summer in a storage yard in Oklahoma. Instead of a clean, dry rail car, ready to be loaded with corn or soybeans, he found the skeletal remains of 11 people who had died in the dark, unable to open the grain hatch from inside. It was the heat and lack of water -- and possibly despair -- that killed them.

title: Big Ten Coaches Press for Officiating Review
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's longtime football coach, is normally an affable man, but this season he has been enraged by officiating that he believes contributed to his team's two losses. Last month, the 75-year-old Paterno provided a striking image when he chased and grabbed an official after a loss to Iowa.

title: INSIDE
description: Flight Time on the Ground

title: Hints, but No Evidence of Terrorism
description: The methodical cold-bloodedness of the shootings in the Washington area, the inexplicable targeting of victims and the elusiveness of the gunman have stirred speculation that the killings could be the work of a terrorist.

title: Testing Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Eliminating the Flicker: DVD's Progressive Scan
description: Q. What is the ''progressive scan'' function that is advertised as a feature of some DVD players?

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Recorder That Is Friendly To Formats New and Old
description: With so many labels like R and +RW to choose from, the prospect of an incompatible format can strike fear in the heart of a computer owner seeking a DVD recorder whose discs will work on other computers and DVD players. The DRU-500A DVD recorder by Sony may dispel that worry, because it can play and record several of the most common DVD formats, including DVD-R, DVD-RW, DVD+R and DVD+RW. The drive can also read and record compact discs in the CD-R and CD-RW formats.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sales Down At Reuters
description: Shares in Reuters, a leading provider of financial information, lost more than one-fifth of their value and hit their lowest level in 12 years after the company reported weaker sales in the third quarter and forecast falling revenue through the first half of next year. Reuters, based in London, which sells data and news to financial institutions, has been hit by a global decline in markets and mergers, which has forced its clients to cut spending. The shares dropped after the company said third-quarter sales fell 7 percent, to $1.33 billion. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Pope Vows To Keep Going
description: Pope John Paul II celebrated his 24th anniversary as leader of the Roman Catholic Church, vowing to serve ''until the end the mission with which Christ entrusted me.'' The pope, who also signed a document on changes in the rosary, told a huge crowd at Saint Peter's Square that he had entrusted the Virgin Mary with his future. The 82-year-old pope's reign is the fifth longest in history and despite frailty and illness he shows no intention of stepping down. Vatican officials say that another foreign pilgrimage, to Croatia, is planned. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALVOCORESSI, JOHN L.
description: CALVOCORESSI-John L., 85. Died October 14 in Middle Haddam, CT. He is survived by a daughter, J. Zelie Tourais of Kingwood, TX; two sons, Leonidas J. Calvocoressi of Watertown, CT, and Thomas J. Calvocoressi of Berlin, CT, one sister, Helen Offenhauser of New Canaan, CT. He was predeceased by his wife, Frances Whitall Calvocoressi. A memorial service will be held October 26, at 11:00 AM at Spencer Funeral Home, 112 Main St., East Hampton, CT. Donations to Riverfront Recapture LLC, 1 Hartford Sq. West, Hartford, CT. 06106-1984.

title: Half Price on Madison Avenue: A Shop With a French Pedigree Starts a Flea Market in a Tent
description: Hlne Benhamou, the owner of a French home furnishings store on Madison Avenue called  la Maison, has opened a tented flea market, Les Puces, in its backyard. From 1992 to 1998, Ms. Benhamou had a store in the Paris Flea Market at the Porte de Clignancourt, where she also served Sunday brunch to shoppers. Since then she has been selling French housewares and some antiques at her Madison Avenue store. As items go on sale, at 50 percent off, they will move to the tent. Some items there this week are blue and gold St. Petersburg-pattern dinnerware, above, by Limoges, at $84 for a five-piece place setting. Engraved Champagne flutes are $6.50. A four-piece silverplated tea set is $120. Customers can enter through the store, at 1078 Madison Avenue (82nd Street); (212) 396-1020. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Lovers' Journey, From Smitten Bliss to Rueful Parting
description: Though an acoustical marvel, Carnegie Hall is too big for a song recital. All the wonderful aspects of Monday night's performance of Hugo Wolf's ''Italienisches Liederbuch'' by the bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff, the soprano Angela Denoke and the pianist Daniel Barenboim would have registered better had the recital been in a smaller hall.

title: Uncertainty in PC Industry Keeps Apple Earnings Flat
description: Fighting off a deepening technology recession, Apple Computer reported essentially flat revenue today for its fourth quarter of 2002. But a one-time write-down of investments resulted in a net loss for the quarter.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about trading in the stock market on Tuesday misstated the gain of the Dow Jones industrial average in the four days ended April 22, 1933. It was 15.31 percent, not 13.28 percent. The 13.3 percent in the four trading sessions ended Tuesday was the largest such gain since 1933.

title: U.S. Is Putting Heavy Pressure on France and Other Skeptics for a U.N. Resolution
description: The Bush administration is mounting a campaign of public pressure and private diplomatic and economic concessions to persuade France and other skeptical members of the United Nations Security Council to go along with a single resolution threatening military force against Iraq.

title: Schrder, Once Bold, Now Offers a Modest Plan for Germany
description: Four years ago, Chancellor Gerhard Schrder came to power as a new-style Social Democrat, pledging to cut taxes and shake loose Germany's calcified labor market.

title: Lumpectomies Seen As Equal in Benefit To Breast Removals
description: After monitoring more than 2,500 breast cancer patients for 20 years, researchers have concluded that women fare just as well with an operation that removes the cancerous lump as they do by having the entire breast removed.

title: Soft Money Rolls Into Coffers While It Can
description: In one of the largest donations on record, Fred Eychaner, a Chicago businessman, wrote a $3 million check last month to the Democratic National Committee.

title: Israel's Critics and Defenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLT, WARING INGE
description: HOLT-Waring Inge. Died on October 13, 2002, Waring Inge Holt of Point Clear, Alabama, formerly of New York. Survived by her husband, Thaddeus Holt of Point Clear, and children Sarah Holt of Washington, D.C., and Harrison Holt of Point Clear. Funeral arrangements private.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: DEAL FOR SAN DIEGO WATER Southern California water agencies reached a tentative agreement to shift millions of gallons of Colorado River water used by desert farmers to fast-growing urban San Diego. The plan is a major step in an effort to reduce the state's reliance on the river. Under the agreement, reached after four days of negotiations, farmers in the Imperial Valley will use about 2 percent less water from the river each year, which will go to the three million people around San Diego. The state has an end-of-the-year government deadline to create a plan showing how it will reduce its use of river water. (AP)

title: Making an Issue of Truth
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Family Company,'' is being broadcast across North Carolina by Elizabeth Dole, the Republican nominee for the Senate seat held by Jesse Helms.

title: Coke's Glum Forecast Sends Stock Down 10%
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings increased 8 percent. But its stock fell more than 10 percent, the steepest one-day decline in four years, after Coke said it would not meet earnings projections for the year because of weakness in Latin America and difficult weather conditions in some other foreign markets.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Microsystems' Credit Rating Lowered
description: Sun Microsystems Inc.'s credit rating was reduced by Standard & Poor's yesterday on concern about weak demand for the company's products, including server computers that run business networks and Web sites. Sun's rating was cut to a BBB, still investment grade, from BBB+, affecting $1.4 billion in debt. The operating margin, a profitability measure, will remain low because operating systems from Microsoft and Linux cost less and are gaining acceptance over Unix, which Sun computers use, S.& P. said. A Sun spokesman, Martin Chorich, declined to comment immediately. The shares of Sun, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell 29 cents, or 9.4 percent, to $2.80. The stock has lost 77 percent of its value this year.

title: A $4.6 Million Judgment In a Battle of Sports Agents
description: Eric Fleisher, the former agent for Kevin Garnett and several other N.B.A. players, won a $4.6 million judgment yesterday against his former protg, Andy Miller, and two businesses.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief article in The Arts on Oct. 9 reported the resignation of Franz Xaver Ohnesorg as director of the Berlin Philharmonic, two years after his departure as executive director of Carnegie Hall. The article also recalled the forced departure of Kurt Masur from the New York Philharmonic this year and cited suspicions that both events in New York were evidence of anti-German feelings. The article should have made it clear that this was a perception encountered in Germany -- not one in evidence at the Philharmonic.

title: Step-by-Step Prompts Put the Blind on Track
description: AN interactive personal navigation system developed at the University of Florida could someday guide blind people through corridors and along busy city sidewalks.

title: Mexico City Journal; A Town on the Wild Side Awaits Sheriff Giuliani
description: Back in 1519, Hernando Corts, a foreigner with some fairly severe ideas about law enforcement, came to clean up this city, vowing to ''chastise evildoers'' and to ban ''human sacrifice and robbery.'' He wound up destroying the city to save it.

title: 8 Wounded By Explosives In Parcels In Karachi
description: Just after one o'clock this afternoon, a messenger from a private courier service delivered a thick 10-by-12-inch manila parcel to Waqar Abassi, a 35-year-old father of three and a civil servant at police headquarters.

title: Reduced-Price Sales Of Furniture and Carpets
description: Cassina's warehouse sale, Oct. 25 through Oct. 27, will offer high-quality modern dining tables, chairs, sofas and consoles at reduced prices. It will include leather cab chairs (above): without arms, regularly $825, now $400, and, with arms, down from $1,245 to $600; the LC/5 sofa by Le Corbusier (regularly $4,540, down to $2,200) and a Philippe Starck sofa ($6,000, down to $4,000). At the Metropolitan Pavilion, 110 West 19th Street. Information, (631) 423-4560.

title: National Briefing | Health And Science: Widow Sues Over Artificial Heart
description: The widow of a James Quinn, a Philadelphia man who grew to regret his decision to accept an experimental artificial heart, has filed suit against the heart's manufacturer and the hospital that provided her husband's care, saying the experiment stripped Mr. Quinn of his ''essential human dignity.'' The suit, filed by his widow, Irene, seeks damages in excess of $100,000 from Abiomed of Danvers, Mass., the maker of the heart; Hahnemann University Hospital and its owner, the Tenet Healthcare Corporation; Drexel University College of Medicine; and Dr. David Casarett, a geriatrician assigned by Abiomed to serve as a patient advocate for the Quinns. Sheryl Gay Stolberg (NYT)

title: Hepatitis Cases May Be Linked To Reuse of Needles at Clinic
description: At least 10 cancer patients treated at a Nebraska clinic have contracted hepatitis C, possibly because of hypodermic needle reuse there, and the number of those infected could rise, a state health official said yesterday.

title: McGreevey Comes to the Defense Of State's Embattled Police Chief
description: Gov. James E. McGreevey today defended his state police superintendent, Joseph J. Santiago, after new questions about Mr. Santiago's background, and, according to one official close to the governor, persuaded him not to resign.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 7
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Inquiry Into 1989 Rape Case
description: Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, yesterday answered criticism of the way his office is handling new developments in the 1989 Central Park jogger attack. He said more forensic tests needed to be completed and that some witnesses remained to be interviewed. ''I want to assure everyone that this complex and time-consuming investigation is moving forward as quickly as possible,'' Mr. Morgenthau, above, said at a news conference for an unrelated indictment. Protesters, pointing to doubts about the guilty verdicts, have asked that the five men who were convicted be officially exonerated. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Reading Clues
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Anguish and Fear
A Deadly Attack
Beene's Hawaiian Hideaway
description: Designer Geoffrey Beene muses on his first love: fashion.

title: In Country
description: William Eggleston's newly recovered photographs of the American South, from 1965 to 1974.

title: Don't Touch 'Play'! It Could Be Fatal
description: ''Before you die, you see 'The Ring,' '' as the ads for this American remake of a famous Japanese suspense film tell us. With ads like this, the movie has certainly built up a lot of anticipation. But while impressively made, this impassive and cold feature fails, in a spectacular fashion, to deliver the thrills.

title: Police Say Sniper Witness's Account Isn't Credible
description: Stymied leaders of the manhunt for the suburban sniper had to discredit a crucial witness today as detectives revisited the scene of the latest killing in search of fresh evidence.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: A TREE DWELLER MOVES; ANOTHER STAYS PUT

title: The Tracks of Snakes, The Innards of Rabbits
description: Adam Fuss gives me the creeps. His exquisite images of bunny guts, darting snakes, transparent dresses, flapping bird shadows, squirming infants, human skulls, dead swans, rotting mushrooms and tunnels of light suggest that he spends a frightful amount of time thinking about birth and death, fecundity and rot. Is he a melancholy baby or just a fool for metaphors?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLTON, BEATRICE C.
description: KARLTON-Beatrice C. It is with great sadness we announce the passing of Beatrice C. Karlton. Devoted wife of the late Sydney M. Karlton. Beloved mother to Cindy and Ken Klein and Linda and Arthur Brainson. Beloved grandmother to Jill and Mark Berger, Sharon and Richard Pogostin, Mitchell and Tami Barak and David and Daphna Brainson. Beloved great grandmother to Austin, Kody, Bradley, Lauren, Gabriel, Liora & Matan. We will miss her very much. Service Friday 10AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMAN, MARGARET
description: HEIMAN-Margaret, of Santa Monica, California, New York and Erfurt. Born in 1906 in Leipzig. Passed away peacefully on October 14th, 2002. We mourn our beloved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother. She is survived by her son Peter, and daughter-in-law Annabelle, grandchildren Bruce and Diane, Roberta, Deborah and Jeremy, great - granddaughters Allison and Carolyn.

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; 'NY' Hearts Still Beat For Giants
description: WITH the San Francisco Giants in the World Series, their ancestors, New York's baseball Giants, are alive again.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights. ++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: Indonesian Finance Chief Warns Of Need for More Foreign Aid
description: Indonesia's finance minister warned today that the deadly bomb blast in Bali last weekend would force the government deeper into the red next year, raising the cost to the international community of keeping Indonesia afloat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a federal program to eradicate Asian longhorned beetles misstated the title of Christine Markham, an official in the Agriculture Department. She is the program's national director, not a regional director. The article also misstated the amount spent on the effort in New York and Illinois by federal, state and city governments. It is $110.9 million, not $2.4 billion.

title: On the Iraq Issue: Comments by the Council Members Holding a Veto
description: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, and by Israel and the Palestinians, on ''The Situation Between Iraq and Kuwait,'' as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Carriage Houses: Great-Granddad's Garage Moves to the Foreground
description: WHO -- Steven Prior, a building contractor.

title: More of Those in Foster Care Are Teenagers, Report Says
description: Teenagers are a rapidly increasing percentage of the New York City foster-care population, and the city needs to restructure its programs if it is to meet their needs more adequately, according to a report released yesterday by two urban-policy research groups.

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about the Palm Zire hand-held computer, described the screen display incorrectly. It is monochrome; some other Palm models have gray scale screens, providing multiple shades of gray.

title: 36 Hours | Ann Arbor, Mich.
description: ON a game day in Ann Arbor, you don't have to know your way to the stadium. Just plant yourself somewhere near the sprawling University of Michigan campus and wait to be carried along in the stream of students, fans and alumni heading for the city's main event: Big Ten football in the largest stadium in college athletics. (With 107,501 seats, it could almost hold Ann Arbor's entire population of 110,000.) The night before a home game (next week's is against Iowa), you can join the festivities already in full swing at the bars and restaurants along State Street on campus and Main Street downtown. Watch out -- the elderly alumni dressed in blue blazers and U. of M. neckties can be just as boisterous, chanting ''Go Blue'' while drinking frosty mugs of beer, as the students who have painted their faces maize and blue. On Saturday morning, join the tailgaters putting the finishing touches on their picnic fare at the farmers' market, or remember those golden student days as you wander streets carpeted with falling leaves, past fraternities' pregame parties spilling out onto front lawns. If you're more interested in the festive spirit than the actual game, you can have the shops and boutiques all to yourself all Saturday afternoon, and the top restaurants will be happy to serve you a leisurely lunch. Just don't complain if your waiter insists on checking the score from time to time. JENNIFER CONLIN

title: A Sad Song for the Ronettes: Court Reverses Royalty Rights
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that the Ronettes, the 1960's singing trio known for worldwide hits like ''Be My Baby,'' do not have the right to share the money earned by their producer through the use of the group's songs in movies, television and advertising.

title: Peter Saul
description: Nolan/Eckman Gallery

title: A Vestige of King Cotton Fades Out in Mississippi
description: The Port Gibson Oil Mill died in June. The steam whistle that once summoned all 50 workers at 7 every morning -- and woke everyone else in town -- is silent. The day-and-night din of machines crushing cottonseeds is gone, and with it the comforting odor of the seeds cooking. The big tractor trailers have all moved on.

title: Iraq's Use of Nerve Gas
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea's Revelations Could Derail Normalization, Its Neighbors Say
description: Japanese and South Korean officials said today that North Korea's self-confessed pursuit of nuclear weapons could derail efforts to normalize relations and jeopardize the promise of billions of dollars in economic aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHON, MIRIAM
description: GERSHON - Miriam. The Board and staff of ArtsConnection are saddend by the news of the death of Miriam Gershon, mother of our devoted Board member, Freddie Gershon. Our deepest sympathies to Freddie and the entire Gershon family on their loss. Linda LeRoy Janklow, Chairman Steven Tennen, Exec. Dir.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Jobless Rate In City Hits 8-Month Low
description: New York City's unemployment rate dropped sharply in September, to 7.1 percent from 7.6 percent, its lowest level since January, the New York State Department of Labor announced today.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Retrospective That's a First

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Follows House on the Road Out of Washington and Plans to Return on Nov. 12
description: Congress called it quits today, as both parties gambled that they would be in a stronger legislative position next month after the elections that will determine control of the House and Senate.

title: 'Jonah' -- 'A Veggie Tales Movie'
description: Directed by Phil Vischer and Mike Nawrocki

title: Zara Nelsova, 84, a Cellist Who Worked With Bloch
description: Zara Nelsova, a prominent cellist who recorded Ernest Bloch's ''Schelomo'' for cello and orchestra with the composer conducting, and appeared with major orchestras in North America and Europe, died on Oct. 10 at her Manhattan home. She was 84.

title: Rosanjin Kitaoji
description: Franklin Parrasch Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, S. WILLIAM (BILL)
description: GREEN-S. William (Bill). On October 14, 2002. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee Freiberg). Devoted and cherished father of Cathy Green and Louis Green. Dear brother of Cynthia Green Colin. Fond brother-in-law of Carole and Marvin Leichtung. Loving uncle of nieces, Julie, Laura, Ann and Betsy, and nephew, Jim. A native of New York City, he served his city and his country in many capacities, both before and after representing the East Side of Manhattan in the House of Representatives from 1978 to 1992. He was a graduate and loyal alumnus of Harvard College and Harvard Law School. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., on Tuesday, October 15, and Wednesday, October 16, from 7 PM-9 PM. Services Thursday, October 17, at 11:30 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Scott Is Quick To Share Opinions
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott was smirking when he handed a folded Ben Franklin to Lucious Harris after the Nets' morning shoot-around.

title: A Poet Finds His Past Is Just Where He Left It
description: ''The Business of Fancydancing,'' the directorial debut of the novelist and screenwriter Sherman Alexie, is an often affecting, low-budget melodrama that is occasionally sabotaged by its economy of means: the image quality is sometimes so poor that it's like watching the pixel breakup on digital cable. But although the film is initially clumsy and a little hard to follow, Mr. Alexie takes his time in setting his characters in play, and the visual clunkiness becomes secondary to the eloquent emotional desolation.

title: Sears Earnings Will Be Hurt By Credit Unit
description: Sears, Roebuck, midway through a crucial effort to attract more shoppers to its stores, said yesterday that its credit division had suffered unexpected losses from delinquent cardholders that would depress earnings for the rest of the year.

title: Bloomberg's Shift of Homeless to Hotels Alarms Some Neighborhoods
description: From Richmond Nelson's porch, the building across the street looks like just another hotel in a strip of five imposing hotels north of Kennedy International Airport, a place where you might find globetrotters resting for the night. The sign near the roof still says ''Best Western.''

title: Palestinians And Israelis Clash in Gaza; At Least 6 Die
description: Israeli tanks battling Palestinian gunmen fired cannon and machine guns into the densely populated Rafah refugee camp in the southern Gaza Strip today, killing at least 6 people and wounding 60 others, the director of the local hospital said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSECO, Carmel, Ind., the insurance and finance company trying to restructure $6 billion in debt, said it had reached an agreement with creditors to give it until Nov. 26 to negotiate $1.5 billion in loans.

title: Inquiry Shows Speed of Test Run Caused Derailment of AirTrain
description: The AirTrain that derailed late last month near Kennedy International Airport, killing its driver, ran off the tracks because it was traveling too fast on a downhill curve not intended to handle trains at that speed, accident investigators have found.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Pact For Actors At Ellis Island
description: Actors Equity has reached a contract agreement for the actors at the Ellis Island Immigration Museum. The 12 actors, who joined the union in August, perform in ''Embracing Freedom,'' a story of immigrants' coming to America. Under the contract, the actors' daily salary will rise to $115 from $113, with a 3 percent raise next year. Daily pay for understudies, formerly $78, will also climb to $115. The new agreement includes health insurance, pensions, paid sick days and a promise from management to do its best to provide two dressing rooms near the theater. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: U.S. Proposes Regulations to Restrict Some Tax Shelters for High-Income People
description: The Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service are proposing rules to force high-income people and corporations to disclose their participation in potentially abusive tax shelters.

title: Scouting Report
description: Pitching

title: Burnett Plans To Combine Units
description: Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago will combine various direct, digital and database marketing units into a single network called iLeo. The reorganization comes a month after the acquisition of the Burnett parent, the Bcom3 Group, by the Publicis Groupe.

title: Judge Throws Out Brothers' Murder Convictions
description: The judge who tried two teenage brothers in the bludgeoning death of their father threw out their murder convictions today, saying the prosecution's ''unusual and bizarre'' decision to try another man in the killing before the boys' trial violated their rights to due process.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a fire in Englewood, N.J., that razed Sugar Hills Studio, where many of the first rap recordings were made, referred incorrectly to a pioneering group that recorded there. It was Grandmaster Flash & the Furious Five -- a single act, not separate ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, HAROLD J.
description: SIMON-Harold J., 85. Of Ft. Lee, NJ. Survived by his wife Evelyn, daughter Wendy, son Richard, brother Jack and granddaughter Lauren. Services today 1:30 PM Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. 4 (east), Paramus.

title: Nightclub Blasts Leave Carefree Crowd Less So
description: If there is any place on earth where war and terror could be forgotten it should be this carefree seaside town where the only imperative is self-indulgence.

title: Somalis in Maine
description: To the Editor:

title: Straight to Video
description: Other new titles of interest, some of which may have had a theater release, appeared on television or been on videocassette or DVD in earlier editions.

title: CROWN CORK LOWERS ESTIMATED TOTAL FOR STOCK SALE
description: Crown Cork and Seal expects to raise as much as $216 million by selling stock in a unit that makes plastic soda bottles, or $24 million less than the estimate released last month. Crown Cork lowered the number of shares to be offered in the unit, Constar International, to 12 million from 16 million, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It also raised the anticipated per-share price for Constar's initial public offering to $15 to $18, from $12 to $15. Crown Cork expects the offering and sale of notes to begin next week.

title: U.S. Said to Offer France Final Compromise to End Iraq Resolution Impasse
description: The United States today offered France what it called a final proposal for a Security Council resolution to disarm Iraq, seeking to break a deadlock that threatened to paralyze the Council.

title: War Looms but God Is With Us, Hussein Tells Iraqis
description: President Saddam Hussein warned Iraqis today that they might have to endure war with the United States, but he assured them that Divine Providence would ensure their victory.

title: Protecting Navajos at Work
description: At RD's Drive-In, a small family-owned diner in northeast Arizona, most of the employees and customers are Navajos. Two years ago the owners, who don't speak Navajo, decreed that, ''while the owner is paying you as an employee, you are required to use English at all times'' -- except to non-English-speaking customers.

title: Making Medieval Music (and Marketing It, Too)
description: The singers in Anonymous 4 have discovered in their 16 years as a touring early-music vocal ensemble that fame has its pitfalls and that they are not always what one expects.

title: Giants Continue To Nurse Injuries
description: The Giants' practices have had more medical implements than footballs over the last month, players adorned with protective boots and crutches and heavy knee wraps. But Coach Jim Fassel is optimistic that by next week, almost all of the injured parties on his roster should be ready to participate in practice, including tight end Jeremy Shockey and cornerback Will Peterson.

title: Allen Read, 96, the 'O.K.' Expert, Is Dead
description: Allen Walker Read, a playful prospector of the American tongue who hunted down the source of words like Dixie and Podunk, phrases like the almighty dollar and, most famous of all, those ubiquitous initials, O.K., died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 96.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIVAK, MYRA
description: SPIVAK-Myra. On October 16, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Devoted mother of Michael. Cherished grandmother of Scott. Graveside service Friday, 11 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: 8 Accused In Burglary Ring
description: The authorities have arrested eight men who prosecutors say ran a burglary ring so sophisticated that the police called them ''The James Bond Gang.'' Prosecutor John L. Molinelli of Bergen County said yesterday that the ring burglarized more than 100 homes in Bergen, Monmouth and Morris Counties, as well as on Staten Island and Long Island. The thieves stole more than $1 million in cash and jewels over two years, Mr. Molinelli said. The police named the suspects after Agent 007 because they used high-technology equipment like a BMW equipped with oil-squirting devices.

title: Saturday's Top Matchups
description: 1 Notre Dame (6-0)

title: Jitish Kallat -- 'First Information Report'
description: Bose Pacia Modern

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: DRUG MAKER POSTS PROFIT India's biggest drug maker, Ranbaxy Laboratories, reported a 78.9 percent increase in quarterly profit compared with a year ago, driven by rising exports of a generic antibiotic to the United States. Ranbaxy's managing director, D. S. Brar, said in a statement that the results indicated the increased momentum of the company's business in international markets. "Our sales in the United States are reaching the desired critical mass," Mr. Brar said. Ranbaxy's net profit rose to 1.59 billion rupees ($33 million) in the quarter ended in September from 891 million rupees ($18.5 million), in the quarter a year ago.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Adient, Parsippany, N.J., hired one employee and promoted another. Marion Crabbe Chaplick was named vice president and account group supervisor; she had been vice president and associate group supervisor at Lyons Lavey Nickel Swift, New York, part of the Omnicom Group. Also, Virginia Rossy, senior art director, was named art supervisor. Adient is part of the CommonHealth unit of the WPP Group.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Travel Agent Slips
description: Europe's third-largest tour operator, MyTravel, warned for the third time in five months that its profit would fall short of its forecast, setting off a 62 percent decline in its already battered share price. The company, which ousted its chief executive, Tim Byrne, after an earlier warning, said pretax profit for 2002 could be $31 million lower than a $141 million forecast barely two weeks ago. MyTravel, formerly called Airtours and based in Manchester, England, blamed lower summer sales and costs related to an accounting change. The company's shares have lost 90 percent of their value since the start of the year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Weekender | Easton, Conn.
description: ''EASTON is the black pearl of Fairfield County,'' a resident of Greenwich, Conn., recently observed while addressing a local citizens' group. That may be just a bit too highfalutin a notion for residents of this bucolic enclave, rated by Connecticut Magazine in 2001 as the No. 2 town with a population between 4,700 and 10,000 in the state. (Top honors went to neighboring Redding.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: SoHo Bloomingdale's Plan Advances
description: Bloomingdale's is proceeding with plans to open a store in SoHo next fall, despite failing to win tax relief and other incentives from city and state agencies. Company executives signed an agreement yesterday to open a six-level store in the building that now houses Canal Jeans. The 124,000-square-foot store will be in an 1860 cast-iron-and-stone building on Broadway between Spring and Broome Streets. Federated Department Stores, the parent company of Bloomingdale's, had sought incentives even though the store will be outside the zone established for businesses hurt by the Sept. 11 terror attack. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Schools Got Some of Meat Now Recalled
description: Secretary of Agriculture Ann M. Veneman said today that some of the ready-to-eat turkey now recalled for the possibility of listeria contamination had been sent to schools across the country. She ordered immediate new government testing of all plants that produce ready-to-eat meats.

title: Intel's Real Problem: It Spends Too Much
description: WHEN the downturn came a couple of years ago, Intel stood firm. It would grow its way through the recession.

title: Laurent Millet
description: Robert Mann Gallery

title: Georgia Wins Bidding War For a DaimlerChrysler Plant
description: The latest bidding war between Southern states for a new auto manufacturing plant was resolved today in Georgia's favor when DaimlerChrysler said it had chosen a site near Savannah over one near Charleston, S.C., to assemble two types of vans now made only in Germany.

title: 'The Debut'
description: Directed by Gene Cajayon

title: Edwin Hale Lincoln -- 'No Record So True'
description: Richard York Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABALME, PATRICIA HOCHSCHILD
description: LABALME-Patricia Hochschild. On October 11, 2002, at the age of 75. She was the wife of George Labalme Jr., mother of Jennifer R. Labalme, Henry G. Labalme, Lisa G. Osterland & Victoria A. Labalme, grandmother of six, and sister of Ann H. Poole, all of whom mourn her passing. A graduate of the Brearley School and Magna Cum Laude graduate of Bryn Mawr, she held an M.A. and Ph.D. from Harvard, where she was awarded the Caroline A. Wilby prize for her doctoral dissertation as ''the best original work in any department.'' Among her many professional activities, Patricia Labalme was Associate Director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, (1982-1988) and Secretary of the Corporation (1982-1992). From 1992-1997, she was Assistant to the Director, Dr. Phillip A. Griffiths. Most recently, she was a Visitor in the School of Historical Studies, at the IAS. Known also for her dedication to independent school education, she was, among her many affiliations, president of the Brearley Board of Trustees (1978-1982). She was also a trustee of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation (1979Present), the American Academy in Rome (1979-1999), the first female trustee of the Lawrenceville School (1985-1996), and a trustee of the Renaissance Society of America (1982-Present). She was also a member of the Ateneo Veneto and the Istituto di Scienze, Lettere ed Arti, both in Venice, and Director of the Quantum Chemical Corporation. Her passion for humanism was formed by her lifelong friendships with professors Werner Jaeger, Myron P. Gilmore, Helen Maud Cam, Paul Oskar Kristeller, Vittore Branca and Felix Gilbert. It was Gilbert, her professor at Bryn Mawr and her colleague at the IAS, who, after three decades of encouragement, persuaded her to start her book on Marino Sanudo's diaries. At the time of her death, Dr. Labalme was close to completing this book, which received initial funding from the NEH. The book will be published posthumously under a unique arrangement in which the IAS has created a special position, a Director's Visitor, to be held by Professor Laura S. White, who will oversee the book's completion. A private service was held at the family home in West Cornwall, CT, on October 14. A memorial service will be held at the Marciana Library in Venice. In addition, a New York City memorial service will be held at the Brearley School at a later date to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the Brearley School, attention: Alumnae Office, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, for the benefit of faculty salaries.

title: Excerpts From Testimony by C.I.A. and F.B.I. Leaders About Sept. 11
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and George J. Tenet, director of central intelligence, before the joint House and Senate select intelligence committee investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. They were questioned by Representative Richard Burr, Republican of North Carolina. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/international.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Landlord Is Denied Parole
description: Robert Rodriguez, a landlord who has been under suspicion in the disappearance of a Manhattan couple in 1997, has had a favorable parole decision reversed in an unrelated case.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Court To Weigh Ban On Basque Party
description: The Constitutional Court has agreed to hear the regional Basque government's appeal against a law that bans the militant separatist party Batasuna on the ground that it is part of the violent Basque nationalist group E.T.A. The Basque government, led by a moderate nationalist party, has also filed suit against Judge Baltasar Garzn, accusing him of perverting the course of justice by issuing a ''politicized'' judicial decree suspending Batasuna's activities. The move is not linked to the judge's latest decree, issued on Wednesday, which accuses the party of ''low-intensity ethnic cleansing'' and crimes against humanity for maintaining ''a climate of pressure and intimidation,'' which the judge says has forced many non-nationalist Basques into exile. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Man Arrested for Misleading Account in Sniper Case
description: Aman who claimed to be a witness to the most recent killing in the series of sniping attacks in suburban areas around Washington was arrested today after doubts were raised about his account.

title: McCall Accuses Pataki of Using 9/11 Emotions to Distract Voters From His Failings
description: H. Carl McCall said yesterday that Gov. George E. Pataki had been using the emotions stirred up by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks as an excuse not to deal with the state's problems.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Uniondale: LIPA Calls For New Power Plant
description: The Long Island Power Authority yesterday released its proposed long-range master plan, which calls for building another power plant on Long Island. The authority's chairman, Richard M. Kessel, left, said he was reviewing several proposed plants, including one to be built by KeySpan in Melville and another by American National Power in Yaphank. He said that by year's end he would support one of the proposed plants. The master plan, which extends to 2011, also emphasized improving transmission systems and existing power plants on Long Island. Mr. Kessel said he was interested in developing clean-energy initiatives and creating an incentive plan for thrifty electric users. Public hearings on the draft plan will be held beginning next month. A copy will be available at www.lipower.org. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Evoking a Medieval Sound
description: Members of the early-music vocal ensemble Anonymous 4 rehearse for their Sunday concert in Manhattan, ''La Bele Marie: Songs to the Virgin From Medieval France.'' It is based on venerations of Mary couched in the courtly tradition of Northern French poet-musicians.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBASH, ROSLYN, M.D.
description: BARBASH-Roslyn, M.D. 1/05/11-10/18/85. Wise physician, environmentalist, loving wife and mother, loyal friend, who touched many lives and made a difference in them.

title: ROME WITHHOLDING FULL ENDORSEMENT OF U.S. ABUSE PLAN
description: The Vatican is not fully backing some of the American bishops' stricter prescriptions for punishing sexually abusive priests and has expressed deep concern that the bishops went too far in devising their abuse policy in Dallas last summer, according to Roman Catholic officials familiar with a formal Vatican response to be released on Friday.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Governor's Son Faces Vandalism Charges
description: Gov. Bill Owens's 16-year-old son, Mark, has been charged with burglary and criminal mischief, both felonies, after vandalism on school property. The authorities said Mark Owens and two teenage friends stole baseball bats and softballs from a storage shed and used them to break windows on school vehicles in July. Governor Owens, a Republican, has said his son has paid $1,468 for the damage. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Mr. Big's New Act

title: Knicks Plan to Catch Opponents Dozing
description: With 26 seconds left in Wednesday's preseason game against the Sacramento Kings, Charlie Ward leaned out of the Knicks' huddle, smiled and said to the reporters sitting at the scorer's table, ''Don't sleep on the Knicks.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLUM, RICHARD
description: ROSENBLUM-Richard. On October 15, 2002 of Brooklyn. Most loved husband, father, brother, grandpa and friend. Talented artist, children's book author and illustrator, professor, enthusiastic birder. Your humor, charm and many interests enriched the lives of all who knew you. Your loving nature, warmth and creative spirit will be so missed by those who love you and you will be forever in our hearts. He is survived by his wife Barbara, daughter Anne, sister Debby, son-inlaw John, and granddaughters Juliet and Skye. There will be a memorial Saturday November 23, 11 AM, Guild Hall, Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: COCAINE TESTS RULED ILLEGAL

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKHURST, BARBARA GOLDBERG, PH.D.
description: PARKHURST-Barbara Goldberg, Ph.D. On October 16th, 2002 after a valiant battle against brain cancer. Beloved wife of Charles. Dear daughter of Murray and Mollie Goldberg. Cherished mother of Joshua and Justin. Loving sister of Laura Goldberg. Beloved friend. Barbara was an esteemed speech-language educator and clinician for 40 years. Services Sunday, October 20th, 3:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made in Barbara's name to Lincoln Center Theatre, 150 W. 65th St., NY NY 10023 where there will be a plaque installed in Barbara's name.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: International Fine Art and Antiques Dealers Show; Doug Aitken
description: International Fine Art and Antiques Dealers Show

title: Accounts
description: * St. Paul Cos., Minneapolis, to Fallon Worldwide, Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe, as agency of record for the commercial insurance and asset management company. The account had been at Campbell Mithun, Minneapolis, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. St. Paul spent $7.4 million last year to advertise in major media, according to CMR, a unit of Taylor Nelson Sofres.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Cocaine Tests Ruled Illegal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., held that the police in Charleston, S.C., had performed unconstitutional searches by having a hospital test the urine of pregnant women for cocaine. The court answered a question left open by the Supreme Court last year when it held that the tests were subject to constitutional limitations on searches and would be lawful only if the women had consented. The appeals court held that the women did not know that their urine was being tested for evidence of crimes and that their consent was not informed consent. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Overuse leading to food shortages, study warns : Less water  and less to eat
description: PARIS:  The world will experience serious food shortages within the next few years because of "heavy and unsustainable" use of fresh water, according to a study published Wednesday.

title: London Journal; Diana's Faithful Butler: In the End, Was He False?
description: Diana called her butler, Paul Burrell, her ''rock'' for his steadfast support after her separation. The last night of her life, he said, she called from Paris and pleaded, ''Promise me, Paul, you will always be there.''

title: Sniper Investigators Say a Witness Lied
description: Leaders of the manhunt for the sniper in the Washington area had to discredit a crucial witness to the latest killing on Monday night, saying the witness proved to be fabricating a tale.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With the recent opening of Aix, Didier Virot's Provenal restaurant at Broadway and 88th Street, and the arrival last year of Ouest, Tom Valenti's restaurant at Broadway and 84th Street, much talk has been heard about the pioneering discovery of the Upper West Side by the high end of the restaurant business.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 7 about an explosion on the French supertanker Limburg off Yemen confused two ways of measuring the ship's size. The Limburg weighs 341,097 tons fully loaded; 298,997 tons is its deadweight tonnage, or the total possible weight of its cargo, fuel, stores and everything else removable from the ship.

title: Bullet Prints, And Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Heavy Memories, Dragged From the Cultural Revolution
description: ONE MAN'S BIBLE

title: Poet Laureate Returns Critics' Rage
description: The revolutionaries, with a little more gray in the hair and a little less grip in the fist, had come down to the Bowery to support the poet. They believed the man had him up against the wall.

title: Rosie, the Magazine, Lays Off Its Staff
description: The entire staff of Rosie magazine -- 120 people -- was laid off yesterday at Gruner & Jahr USA, killing any chance that the magazine would live on in some form after the departure of its joint venture partner, Rosie O'Donnell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEMAN, AUDREY RENEE
description: ROSEMAN-Audrey Renee. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence Roseman, beloved and devoted mother of Donna and Jeffrey, dear sister of Ellie and Gerald, loving motherin-law of Ted and proud and adoring grandmother of Emma Faye, passed away peacefully after a long illness. Her grace, intelligence, beauty, humor and creative flair touched all those who knew her. Private funeral services will be held. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to the New York Chapter of The National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Voting as Civic Duty (That Was Then . . .)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JACOB L.
description: HOROWITZ-Jacob L. Died October 16, 2002. Husband of the late Helen Krasna Horowitz. Father of Bertha H. (Henry) Kressel and Avram (Esther) Horowitz. Grandfather of Aron and Lois Kressel, Kim and Ze'ev Ephrat, Judy and Avrumy Safrin and Benjy and Amy Horowitz. Greatgrandfather of Ariel, Yonatan, Dalia and Noam Ephrat, Melanie, Daniel and Perri Kressel, Meir, Ayelet and Atara Safrin. Survived by brother Joel Hart of Sarasota, FL, and sister Leah Bronner of West Hartford, CT. Funeral services were held October 17th, 2002. Shiva will be observed at the home of the deceased.

title: Detective Accused of Threatening Reporter
description: An unlicensed private detective has been charged with threatening a Los Angeles Times reporter working on a story about the actor Steven Seagal's allegation that he was extorted by the Mafia, investigators said yesterday.

title: Stocks Climb as Investor Gloom Appears to Ease
description: Stocks rose more than 2 percent yesterday while bond prices continued their slide, indicating that investors may be losing some of their gloom over the economy. In the last six trading days, longer-term interest rates have risen nearly two-thirds of a percentage point, while the Dow Jones industrial average has climbed 13.6 percent.

title: At Cambridge, furor over royalties
description: LONDON  Researchers at the University of Cambridge are angry over a policy being mooted by administrators whereby the university would retain rights to all intellectual property produced there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTENS, FREDERICK W. JR., MD.
description: MARTENS-Frederick W. Jr., MD. Passed away October 16th in his NYC home. Born in 1925 in Whitestone, NY, he served in the Naval Air Corps in 1944-45. He graduated from Cornell Medical School in 1957, joined the OB/GYN practice of Martens, Ryan, Steadman, and became a full professor of Cornell in 1985. He served on the vestry of St. Bartholomew's Church and was Commodore of Larchmont Yacht Club at the time of his death. His wife of 54 years Joan, his sons Frederick William III and David Byron; his daughters-in-law Muriel Anderson and Julie Ann; and five grandchildren will miss his strength, courage, wisdom and guidance. A Memorial service will be held at 2 PM October 21st at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave and 50th St. Donations may be made in lieu of flowers to the Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Cornell, Attn: Dr. F. Chervenak, MD, Rm J130, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: INCREASE IN AUTISM BAFFLES SCIENTISTS
description: Trying to account for a drastic rise in childhood autism in recent years, a California study has found that it cannot be explained away by statistical anomalies or by a growing public awareness that might have led more parents to report the disorder.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Aid For Small Businesses
description: The city has announced an aid program to reduce by up to 15 percent the electric bills for nonretail small businesses in Lower Manhattan. The program, created with Consolidated Edison, covers the next three years. It will apply to businesses from Houston Street to the Battery that meet particular electricity-use requirements and that have qualified for aid under either of two other programs, the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program and the Small Firm Attraction and Retention Grant program. The city's Economic Development Corporation said it would soon notify about 2,300 businesses that it believes are qualified. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Forrester and Lautenberg Duel Over Their Abortion Positions
description: Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democratic nominee for the Senate, and his Republican opponent, Douglas R. Forrester, sparred at long range today over the abortion issue.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Lender's Earnings Rose
description: India's top home lender, the Housing Development Finance Corporation, said its profit for the quarter that ended last month rose 21 percent from a year ago. The company has had a spurt of growth in the last couple of years as falling interest rates and tax breaks encouraged home buying. Profits at Housing Development rose to 1.67 billion rupees ($34 million) from 1.38 billion rupees ($28 million). Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Complaint Expected to Be Filed Against Credit Suisse First Boston
description: Massachusetts securities regulators who have been investigating Credit Suisse First Boston and its research practices expect to file an administrative complaint against the firm, perhaps as early as Monday, according to a person close to the inquiry.

title: G.O.P. Election Strategy on Economy: Accentuate Positives, Ignore the Rest
description: After surveying public opinion about the sluggish economy, President Bush's pollster, Matthew Dowd, provided the Republican National Committee with a compelling if somewhat self-serving conclusion last weekend: Democrats hold no advantage on the issue and Republicans should not shy away from talking about it.

title: Gov. Bush's Daughter Is Sentenced to Jail
description: Gov. Jeb Bush's daughter, Noelle, was sentenced today to 10 days in jail for violating the terms of a court-ordered drug treatment program that she entered to avoid trial on charges of trying to buy an antidepressant drug with a fraudulent prescription.

title: Newark Arena Deal Allows For Talks With the Teams
description: The three-year effort to find public financing for a new sports arena in downtown Newark cleared a high hurdle Wednesday night as the Newark City Council voted to let the city provide the public portion of the money. But there are still several, though lower hurdles ahead for the estimated $355 million project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, EDWIN
description: THORNE - Edwin. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Medical College, and Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the passing of Edwin Thorne. Mr. Thorne was elected a Governor of the Society of the New York Hospital in 1968, a Life Governor in 1984, and a Life Trustee of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital in 1997. He continued an exemplary record of service begun by his father, Langdon Thorne, who also served on the Board of Governors. He participated fully in the activities of the Board, particularly the Investment Committee, for which he served as Chairman. The Hospital benefited from his unfailing dedication, leadership, and wisdom. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, particularly his four sons: Brinkley, Peter, Gordon, and Edwin, Jr.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the naming of finalists for this year's National Book Awards misstated the date of the presentation. It is Nov. 20, not Nov. 12.

title: Pataki Viewed Favorably in Poll, Despite Qualms About Economy
description: New Yorkers give Gov. George E. Pataki high marks over all, especially on his response to the World Trade Center attack and its aftermath, despite some misgivings about his handling of the economy, a New York Times poll shows.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Blair Pushes Peace Effort
description: In a surprise visit to Belfast, Prime Minister Tony Blair said that the 1998 Northern Ireland peace accord is the only way forward for the British province and that the Irish Republican Army must cease all paramilitary activity for it to proceed. Britain resumed direct rule of Northern Ireland on Monday after the local government, in which Protestants and Roman Catholics share power, was suspended for the fourth time in response to accusations that the I.R.A. was spying on British officials. ''The British Government will simply not countenance any path other than implementing the agreement,'' Mr. Blair told business group. ''But we cannot carry on with the I.R.A. half in, half out of this process.'' Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSCHULTZ, SIDNEY
description: LIFSCHULTZ-Sidney. The Propp Family mourns the passing of our cherished friend, a true gentleman. Our sincere condolences to Marsha, David, Larry, and Bruce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLTER, HERBERT H.
description: BOLTER-Herbert H. Passed away Wednesday, October 16, 2002. He was 86 years of age and a devoted husband of the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Bruce, Gladys Koenig (Randy) and Marilyn Leshowitz (Bruce). Loving grandfather of Jonathan (Gina) Cooper, Robin Cooper and Allison Leshowitz. Great grandfather of Alyssa Kelly Cooper. Herbert is also survived by his sister Esther Bergstein (Abe). A 10AM chapel service is scheduled for today at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle, N.Y. 914-632-0324. Interment to follow at Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Bullet Prints, and Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Close Monitoring Is Planned For Smallpox Vaccinations
description: Federal health officials said today that a network of experts would be made available for consultation at any hour in case of bad reactions to smallpox vaccine, which may be given soon to a half-million hospital workers.

title: Euro sags as Prodi laments lack of flexibility in rules : EU leader says pact on budgets is 'stupid'
description: BRUSSELS:  Calling the budgetary rules that underpin Europe's common currency "stupid" and inflexible, the president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, lashed out at the European Union's Stability and Growth Pact on Thursday and sided with France and Germany in calling for "more intelligent" fiscal rules for the euro.

title: C.I.A. Puts Risk Of Terror Strike At 9/11 Levels
description: The director of central intelligence, George J. Tenet, told a Congressional panel today that the risk of a new terror attack inside the United States was as grave and immediate as it was before the Sept. 11 hijackings, even though American intelligence agencies have vastly expanded their counterterrorism efforts in the past year.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Lawmaker Resumes Taking Gun-Group Donations
description: Representative Tom Tancredo, a Republican whose district includes Columbine High School, is again accepting campaign contributions from the National Rifle Association. After the 1999 shootings at the school, which left 15 dead, Mr. Tancredo returned $1,000 to the group and said he would not to take donations from gun proponents in his 2000 campaign. After accepting $1,500 from the rifle association in September, Mr. Tancredo said he had not promised never to take money from the group. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Times Co. Has 34% Rise In Earnings For Quarter
description: The New York Times Company posted a solid increase in third-quarter profit yesterday on growth in advertising and subscription revenue, despite the sluggish economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, ABRAHAM
description: ALPERT-Abraham. Emunah of America mourns the loss of our highly esteemed and generous benefactor, Abraham Alpert, who together with his wife Sunny, a National Vice President, were founders of our organization and established the Tova Chapter in Manhattan. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Israel. Marcia Genuth, National Pres

title: INSIDE
description: Off to the Hustings

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Residential Real Estate; Making a Change in Chelsea: Rentals Go Co-op
description: The 16-story Marais building nearing completion at 520 West 23rd Street in the western corner of Chelsea was intended to be a rental, but when the building opens next month, its 107 apartments will be for sale.

title: Powell Shows Lighter Side At Annual Political Dinner
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell sat next to Cardinal Edward M. Egan. Gov. George E. Pataki sat a few feet from H. Carl McCall, who is angling for his job.

title: Early Warnings on Moussaoui Are Detailed
description: The Central Intelligence Agency warned its stations around the world in August 2001 that Zacarias Moussaoui had been arrested in Minnesota after raising suspicion at a flight school there and that he was a ''suspect airline suicide hijacker,'' Congressional investigators reported today.

title: Stark Differences Define 2 Candidates in a Close Race in Michigan
description: On Monday, President Bush came to the Detroit suburbs and raised $500,000 for Thaddeus G. McCotter, the Republican candidate for the House of Representatives in an open seat created by redistricting.

title: TV Weekend; Hussein's Contradictions: Reformer and Feared Killer
description: The relentless television coverage of the current United States-Iraq crisis has been dominated by sound bites, file clips of Persian Gulf war maneuvers and simplistic analysis. So it is refreshing to see a television program that tries to put things into a historical context and explain the situation. That's what ''Behind the Headlines,'' tonight's two-part, two-hour program on the Discovery Channel, does effectively.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Quarantine For A Fourth Deer Farm
description: A fourth whitetail deer farm was quarantined after state officials learned that its animals might have come into contact with deer infected with chronic wasting disease. The brain disease has not been found on the farm, in Dane County, but the exposure means its deer might be slaughtered. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Peace, Calm . . . Then Thwack!
description: I AM incapable of sitting still. This self-revelation is now unfolding with stunning clarity as I sit cross-legged in the meditation hall at the Zen Mountain Monastery, a Buddhist training center in the Catskill Mountains of New York. I have no other task but to be completely still in a traditional meditative sitting pose. Stillness, however, is losing ground to my quivering spine. I have been in zazen, or sitting meditation, for close to an hour -- or, more precisely, for three minutes and 11 seconds -- and my back is beginning to bow. My left knee is throbbing. My right knee is aching. Even G.I. Joe can't be bent into this position.

title: Rutgers's Wright Out to Prove Less Is More
description: Rutgers is pinning its success this season on the less-is-more equation: Making fewer mistakes, especially on the road, where the Scarlet Knights averaged 20 turnovers last season. And having less angst shooting the ball. Rutgers made only 40 percent of its field-goal attempts.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Soldier Changes Testimony
description: A former British paratrooper broke ranks with the official army version of how 14 unarmed people were killed by soldiers in Londonderry in 1972 by telling the ''Bloody Sunday'' inquiry that he did not believe anyone shot at troops before they fired at the marchers. The man, identified only as Soldier 027 and testifying from behind a screen that hid his identity, said he had fabricated his testimony at an inquiry 30 years ago that supported the official view that soldiers fired only after being attacked. He was the first former soldier and the 582nd witness to testify at the new inquiry, which is two years old and has at least a year to run. It was moved from Londonderry to London this fall because paratroopers feared testifying in Northern Ireland. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Bulgari Touch In Cadillacs
description: A car for the status-conscious deserves a high-status dashboard, and Cadillac has commissioned Bulgari, the Italian maker of jewelry and watches, to design the gauges and clocks in some of its new models.

title: New Coat of Paint for Old Pagoda
description: IF any girl needed a makeover in the competitive, fast-changing world of big-time musicals, it was Mei-Li, the winsome little heroine of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''Flower Drum Song.'' As embodied by Miyoshi Umeki in the original Broadway and film versions of the show some 40 years ago, this newly arrived Chinese immigrant was so quaintly modest, it was scary, with her downcast eyes and submissive stoop. What's more, she kept saying embarrassing things like ''My back is wet'' (read: ''I'm a wetback'') in a thick accent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANOLICK, LUCILLE
description: ANOLICK-Lucille on October 15. Beloved wife of the late Thomas, adored mother of Jerrold and Gilbert and the late Renae Siegel, cherished sister of Sally Fox, loving grandmother of Alex, Josh, David, Michael, Matthew and Rebecca and great grandmother of Avery, Ethan and Justin. Services Friday 1PM Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road & Queens Blvd in Forest Hills.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Woman Has Human Form Of Mad Cow Disease
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention confirmed that a 22-year-old British woman living in Florida had symptoms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, the human form of mad cow disease. But the agency said the woman was probably exposed to the infectious protein that causes the disease before she moved to Florida in 1992. No other cases have been found in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, RABBI CHARLES D. R.H.
description: LIPPMAN-Rabbi Charles D. R.H. Your love, wisdom and courage continue to inform, guide and inspire me. You are deeply missed but you will forever live in my heart. Your, Allan

title: Rangers Tie As Lindros Scores Two
description: Maybe it is not time yet for Bobby Holik to put his imprint on the Rangers' locker room, but it may be getting close.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Who's going to squeal now? I got four little desks empty in my school. Why wouldn't that intimidate you?''

title: Movie Service Closes in Studio Dispute
description: Intertainer, a Los Angeles company that distributes movies over the Internet and cable television networks, said yesterday that it would close its service, citing licensing practices by the major movie studios that it said were unfair.

title: G.O.P. Campaign Leader Faults Candidate
description: The Republican House leader in charge of his party's Congressional campaign committee said today that the Republican candidate for California governor, Bill Simon Jr., was running the single-worst campaign in the country this year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VERDON, GWEN
description: VERDON-Gwen. Lovingly remembered. Pau

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 7 about an explosion on the French supertanker Limburg off Yemen confused two ways of measuring the ship's size. The Limburg weighs 341,097 tons fully loaded; 298,997 tons is its deadweight tonnage, or the total possible weight of its cargo, fuel, stores and everything else removable from the ship.

title: Ashes and Tears in Lost Battle of Drug War
description: Inside the blackened shell of a home at 1401 East Preston Street is one of the saddest stories a city can tell.

title: For Browne, Kicking Is a Two-Sport Skill
description: When the Texas Christian football team turned out for practice on Wednesday, three days before its biggest game of the season to date, against Louisville, the Horned Frogs' star place-kicker, Nick Browne, was kicking all right -- on a nearby field in a Conference USA soccer game against the University of Alabama-Birmingham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSOVA, ZARA
description: NELSOVA-Zara. In loving memory of our late, gracious friend Zara Nelsova, brilliant performer, inspiring teacher, perhaps the greatest female cellist of the 20th century, who concentrated all of her intelligence, physical energy, and artistry into every performance, and gave so generously to her art and to all those who knew her. From her students and faculty colleagues, who plan a musical tribute to her early in 2003. Dept of Music, Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University

title: Citified Yet Never Civilized
description: Mark Catesby's hand-colored bullfrog, right, from 1771, is among the exotic and familiar creatures in ''Urban Neighbors: Images of New York City Wildlife,'' a show of drawings, paintings and photographs at the New York Public Library.

title: From Good Ol' Girl to Glitter In a City Full of Yankees
description: Sweet Home Alabama

title: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
description: PANASONIC REACHES PACT ON DIGITAL SERVICES Panasonic yesterday became the first major television manufacturer to strike a deal with the cable television industry to make televisions that can display digital television services without requiring a set-top box. Panasonic, which is the United States subsidiary of Matsushita of Japan, announced yesterday that it had received the required certification from CableLabs, the cable industry's research consortium. While many modern televisions can decode analog cable television signals without a set-top box, they still require the device to view digital cable.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Enron Trader Pleads Guilty To Conspiracy
description: A former senior trader at the Enron Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to engaging in a conspiracy that illegally manipulated the California power market during the state's energy crisis, driving up prices and generating millions of dollars in excess profits for his employer.

title: Sexuality From France, Arriving by Helicopter
description: Everything by the French choreographer Angelin Preljocaj is of interest, and that includes his ''Rite of Spring,'' which begins with six women dropping their underpants to their ankles. There is also his new ''Helikopter,'' a visually stunning piece set to the wonderful, if overwhelming, mix of strings and helicopter sounds in Karlheinz Stockhausen's ''Helikopter Quartet.''

title: Yankees Seem Intrigued By Two Foreign Players
description: It has been a trademark of the Yankees' blueprint in recent years, as much a part of their plan as signing free agents and retaining their own drafted players. An aggressive approach on high-profile international talent has brought the Yankees stars like Alfonso Soriano and Orlando Hernndez, but also flops like Hideki Irabu and Andy Morales.

title: PIEDMONT IS BUYING 2 VENTURES FROM PROGRESS ENERGY
description: Piedmont Natural Gas, a natural gas distributor, agreed to pay $425 million to Progress Energy for a gas distribution subsidiary in North Carolina and a stake in a joint venture. Piedmont's revenue is expected to increase 29 percent, to $1.43 billion, after the purchase. Piedmont, which already has 454,000 customers in North Carolina, will add 176,000 through the acquisition of Progress Energy's North Carolina Natural Gas business. Piedmont will also get Progress's stake in EasternNC, a joint venture with the Albemarle Pamlico Economic Development Corporation to provide natural gas to 14 counties in eastern North Carolina.

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Top universities shed cyber wariness : Online degrees multiply
description: PARIS  The broad and bubbling world of online education is a wide-open frontier for hucksters as well as social innovators, but it is now clear that top-flight universities, long wary of diluting their pedigrees with the new technologies, are actively staking out their ground in cyberspace.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: New Trial Set In Crown Heights Case
description: A federal judge reopened a chapter of New York's history yesterday by scheduling a new trial for Lemrick Nelson Jr., who was convicted in 1997 of civil rights charges in the killing of a Hasidic scholar, Yankel Rosenbaum, 29, during racial violence in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn in 1991. The trial would be Mr. Nelson's third. In January a federal appeals court overturned his civil rights conviction, citing problems with the way the jury was selected. The federal case followed a state trial in 1992 in which Mr. Nelson was acquitted. Yesterday, Judge Frederic Block of United States District Court in Brooklyn scheduled jury selection for March 24. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Faldo and Campbell Tied After 42 Holes
description: Nick Faldo and Michael Campbell were still tied after playing 42 holes on the first day of the world match play championship in Wentworth, England, the most holes for the 39-year-old event.

title: Jets Missing Out On Tackles, And Turnovers
description: The run defense had just pulled itself out of the league cellar and the pass defense was still mired with a ranking in the 20's, besieged by missed tackles.

title: Drugs, Guns, Car Chases And a Chemist in a Kilt
description: The United States and England may, as George Bernard Shaw observed, be divided by a common language, but if ''Formula 51'' is any indication, they are joined by a shared taste for an especially versatile expletive. It cannot, of course, be printed here, but the word and its variants account, by my conservative estimate, for about two-thirds of the dialogue in this new movie by Ronny Yu. If it were edited down to a PG-rated version, the picture would be about 10 minutes long, but not otherwise improved, since it is a witless, gruesome barrage of jokey violence and lame trans-Atlantic humor, kept moving by the pointless, derivative kineticism of Mr. Yu's hyperactive cuts and splices.

title: Burnett Plans to Combine Units
description: Burnett Plans

title: Same-State Series Have Been TV Losers
description: The Anaheim-San Francisco World Series, which Fox will televise, is the fifth Series since 1985 to be played in one state.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Western Digital Results Beat Estimates
description: Western Digital, a hard-drive disk maker, reported fiscal first-quarter profit yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, as revenue surged 32 percent. The news caused Western Digital's stock to jump 75 cents, or 15.2 percent, to $5.70. Net income climbed 8.3 percent, to $22.2 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 27, compared with $20.5 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The mean estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was for first-quarter earnings of 6 cents a share.

title: U.S. Presses for Deal on Iraq
description: The United States offered France what it called a final proposal for a Security Council resolution to disarm Iraq, seeking to break a United Nations deadlock. Page A10.

title: An Uprising at Auschwitz, With Emphasis on Realism
description: It takes a movie like ''The Grey Zone,'' a harrowing Holocaust drama based on true events, to bring home the limits of screen realism.
