The film, set almost entirely in the Auschwitz death camp in the autumn of 1944 (it was filmed in Bulgaria), tells the story of the 12th Sonderkommando, the next-to-last of the camp's 13 special squads of Jewish prisoners, who in exchange for helping the Nazis exterminate fellow Jews in Auschwitz were given special privileges along with several more months of life before themselves being dispatched. This particular group participated in a partly successful plot to blow up the crematories.

title: Keep Drug Makers Honest
description: The Food and Drug Administration's drug labeling and marketing regulations play a critical role in protecting the public from dishonestly advertised and unsafe drugs. Partly as a result of recent court rulings, the agency is now re-evaluating these consumer protections. It must be careful not to water down its rules in a way that would endanger public health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELLER, FRED
description: ZELLER-Fred. Died with dignity on October 16th, 2002. Beloved husband of Bertha. Devoted father of Jane, Alice and Rita and father-in-law of Kenneth and Michael. Adoring and proud grandfather of Michael, Rachel, Aaron and Jason. He served as Vice President of J.B. Lippincott and President of Churchill Livingston, Inc. After his retirement, he began a long tenure as President of the Colostomy Society of NY. His memory will be carried on by all of us-the friends and family he left behind. Services will be held on Friday, October 18th, at 11:30 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., NYC. Donation in Fred's honor can be made to Colostomy Society of NY, Box 517, G.P.O., NYC 10116 and the Rogosin Institute of New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Net Up At Electronics Maker
description: LG Electronics, South Korea's second-largest manufacturer of electronics products after Samsung Electronics, posted a third-quarter profit of $93 million in contrast to a loss of nearly $400 million a year earlier. LG made much of the profit from cellular telephones, an area where it competes directly with Samsung. Unlike Samsung, LG has no concerns about the low price of semiconductors, which it does not produce. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Philip Morris Profit Rises; Foreign Sales Offset Lag in U.S.
description: The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased, largely on the strength of sales in foreign markets. But domestic business continued to show signs of weakness as cigarette taxes rose sharply in more than a dozen states and the proliferation of cheaper brands hurt sales of higher-priced products like Marlboro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIETRI, JULIA
description: PIETRI-Julia. On October 15, 2002. Beloved wife of Louis F. Sharpe. Loving mother of Martin and Felipe Gonzalez and mother-in-law of Angie Gonzalez. Grandmother of Nellie, Martin and Michael. Great-grandmother of Sean and Steven. We will miss you, Julia.

title: Power Bill Under Protest, Customer Under Arrest
description: A frustrated shopkeeper who says he has written numerous protest notes on his monthly electricity bills finally got a response this week, but it was not what he expected. He was arrested and charged with aggravated harassment.

title: Angels Facing a Challenge: To Go At, or Around, Bonds?
description: Barry, Barry, Barry, Barry, Barry, Barry, Barry, Barry. Everybody's talking about Barry.

title: Tentative Deal Is Reported on $100 Billion in Aid to Insurers Facing Terror Claims
description: After months of bickering, House and Senate negotiators said tonight that they were close to a final deal on legislation to provide up to $100 billion of support to the insurance industry for future terrorist attacks.

title: Embracing Sensuality and Transports of the Spirit
description: The morning I went to see ''The Ages of Mankind: Time to Hope'' at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, I got the impression that at least a few of my fellow visitors were thinking exactly the same thing I was: This? Here? How? It's one of those shows. All but unheralded, it seems to have dropped into place like an unbidden gift.

title: Javier Tllez -- 'Alpha 60 (The Mind-Body Problem)'
description: White Box

title: A Selective Portrait of Castro and Cuba's Revolution
description: Estela Bravo's new documentary, ''Fidel,'' poses an apparently straightforward question. Is its subject, Fidel Castro, who has ruled Cuba since 1959, ''a demon or a symbol of resistance and social justice''? But the phrasing of the question gives away the answer: this is an exercise not in biography but in hero worship.

title: Nokia Shows Way to Profit In an Industry In a Slump
description: Nokia, the world's largest cellphone maker, appears to have mastered a trick that has eluded one competitor after another: making money in a deep industry slump.

title: Bullet Prints, And Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: In Memory of an Ancient Library
description: Every modern library is a successor of the ancient library at Alexandria, Egypt, just as that library, founded by Ptolemy I, was a successor of Aristotle's Lyceum. For at least 250 years, from its founding in 306 B.C. until its partial destruction in 47 B.C., Alexandria served as the center of learning in the extended Mediterranean world. Its librarians made every effort to gather the whole of Greek literature, driven by a sense of its passing glory, to catalog it, to establish accurate texts and, ultimately, to come to some decisions about which works mattered most.

title: Faso Effort in Comptroller Race Contrasts With Hevesi Approach
description: Almost every day, John J. Faso's campaign for state comptroller issues statements announcing endorsements and, with increasing intensity, criticism of Mr. Faso's Democratic opponent, Alan G. Hevesi.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the emerging portrait of Petri Gerdt, the 19-year-old Finnish student who set off a bomb in a shopping mall near Helsinki, killing himself and six other people, misspelled the name of a Finnish newspaper that published an interview with one of his friends. It is Ilta-Sanomat, not Ilto Sanomat.

title: National Briefing: Rockies
description: COLORADO: LAWMAKER RESUMES TAKING GUN-GROUP DONATIONS

title: Uncovering Art in the Ache of Being Spied Upon
description: AN artist sees beauty where others may not. In the case of Arnold Mesches, in his F.B.I. files.

title: Overhead and Underfoot, The Other New Yorkers
description: It was the butterflies that took me by surprise. I've always savored the interplay between nature and books about nature. Sometimes I think I enjoy the bird books as much as the birds. But ''As Nature Shows Them: Moths and Butterflies of the United States'' was in a class all by itself.

title: Sweatshop or College? Guess Which One Mom's Pushing
description: ''Real Women Have Curves'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Elvis Mitchell's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22; the full text is at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Matching India's Move, Pakistan Will Pull Troops From Border
description: Matching a move made Wednesday by India, Pakistani officials announced today that they would begin withdrawing hundreds of thousands of troops massed on the countries' border since last winter.

title: Springtime for Hitler
description: You may recall that George W. Bush promised, among other things, to change the tone in Washington. He made good on that promise: the tone has certainly changed.

title: The 'Bhajan Belt': Serenity in the Catskills
description: EVERYTHING you need to know about the spiritual rhythms of the Catskill Mountains is spray-painted on a rock face along Route 28. It's the sign for om -- the mystic syllable of Hinduism -- and it's a subtle suggestion of the energy that vibrates throughout the region.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: LOBSTERMEN PROTEST AT CAPITOL

title: COLGATE REPORTS PROFIT INCREASE AND 3 PROMOTIONS
description: Colgate-Palmolive reported a 12 percent increase in quarterly profit yesterday and the fastest rise in sales in five years. Net income climbed to $330.7 million, or 57 cents a share, from $296.2 million, or 49 cents, a year earlier, and sales increased 3.3 percent, to $2.38 billion. The company also said that it had promoted three top managers in advance of the eventual retirement of its chairman, Reuben Mark, 63. The executives are Lois D. Juliber, Javier G. Teruel and Ian M. Cook. Ms. Juliber, chief operating officer, will become responsible for the Latin American unit as well as research and technology. Mr. Teruel will oversee the Asian business and the Hill's pet food unit, while Mr. Cook will supervise the European business as well as the North American operations.

title: Ignoring Brazil's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Talks on Russian Entry Into W.T.O. Hit Snag
description: Russia, whose economy is by far the largest outside the World Trade Organization, has hit an impasse in talks with major trading partners about joining the group.

title: F.B.I. Paid $7 Million for File On American Spying for Russia
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation paid $7 million to a former Russian intelligence officer to smuggle out of Moscow a secret K.G.B. file that unmasked a veteran F.B.I. agent as a spy for Russia, according to a new book about the case.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Pardons For 4 Cleared By DNA
description: Gov. George Ryan has pardoned four men who were wrongly convicted in the 1986 rape and murder of a medical student in Chicago. The men, Marcellius Bradford, Calvin Ollins, Larry Ollins and Omar Saunders, were released from prison in December. Two months later, two other men, Eddie Harris and Duane Roach, were charged on the basis of DNA evidence. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Spotlight on Gun Control
description: This ad, titled ''Dangerous,'' is the first television commercial to be shown on behalf of Frank R. Lautenberg since he replaced Senator Robert G. Torricelli as the Democratic nominee for United States Senate earlier this month. It is being paid for the Democratic State Committee and began running on stations in New York and Philadelphia on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about North Korea's admission that it has a nuclear weapons programs misspelled the name of the American diplomat who went to North Korea this month to confront the government with American intelligence data. He is James A. Kelly, not Kelley.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: WESTERN DIGITAL RESULTS BEAT ESTIMATES West- ern Digital, a hard-drive disk maker, reported fiscal first-quarter profit yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, as revenue surged 32 percent. The news caused Western Digital's stock to jump 75 cents, or 15.2 percent, to $5.70. Net income climbed 8.3 percent, to $22.2 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 27, compared with $20.5 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The mean estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was for first-quarter earnings of 6 cents a share. (Dow Jones/AP)

title: Cranberries join the list of crops that growers are promoting with an emphasis on health benefits.
description: THE most news media attention that cranberry growers once could hope for was a brief spike in consumer awareness around Thanksgiving. But new research suggesting that cranberries may help prevent ailments like ulcers and periodontal disease could make the fruit a year-round journalistic staple.

title: Michael Not Going to Red Sox
description: The Yankees would probably not have allowed the Red Sox, their main rival, to hire their top scout to be Boston's general manager, but Gene Michael made it official yesterday when he withdrew his name from consideration.

title: Leader Charged With Extortion And Misconduct
description: Prosecutors filed felony charges of extortion and misconduct in public office today against the majority leader of the Wisconsin Senate, saying he routinely traded legislative favors for campaign contributions, used state employees to do political work and flouted the state's campaign finance laws.

title: The Sniper Next Door
description: One of the many threadbare jokes I used to hear, going back to my earliest days of running around with cops, was that a shooting victim ''died of lead poisoning.'' I used to roll my eyes at the stupid joke. But I'm not now. For the first time in my life, I realize it is possible for a people to be poisoned by a single round. One shot, two shots, eleven shots fired by someone with an AK-47 or some other high-powered rifle with a scope rips the life from another of our neighbors and sends the rest of us indoors.

title: In Suburbs, Old Wheels Keep On Turning
description: KRISTEN JONES, 32, of Fairfield, Conn., who works for a direct marketing agency, hopes no one notices when she slinks around town in a rusty 1987 Chevy Celebrity, a hand-me-down from her grandmother. Despite having been driven only about 50,000 miles, the Celebrity is a hideous abstract art statement, blending two shades of gold paint (one liberally applied from a touch-up can) and edged by bright brown rust. Fabric from overhead has come unmoored and hangs in the driver's eyes.

title: Bullet Prints, And Other Ideas
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwaiti Youth Arrested With Firebombs
description: Kuwaiti police officials said they arrested a teenager today as he drove a cargo of gasoline bombs near a housing complex where some American military officers live.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: EMC Makes a Small Profit, Thanks Solely to a Tax Benefit
description: EMC, the leading supplier of data storage systems for large corporations, said yesterday that it eked out a profit in the third quarter thanks to a one-time overseas tax benefit but that business conditions worsened as the quarter drew to an end.

title: For $2, the World on a Plate; Bronx Chef Is Culinary Travel Guide for Elderly Diners
description: ''I cook Chinese, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Latin American, Russian, Japanese and a few more, too,'' Jaime Zurita was saying, quite modestly, as he stood in front of a half-dozen steamy serving tins of Venezuelan beef stew. ''Let's see, what else?''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Drug Maker Posts Profit
description: India's biggest drug maker, Ranbaxy Laboratories, reported a 78.9 percent increase in quarterly profit compared with a year ago, driven by rising exports of a generic antibiotic to the United States. Ranbaxy's managing director, D. S. Brar, said in a statement that the results indicated the increased momentum of the company's business in international markets. ''Our sales in the United States are reaching the desired critical mass,'' Mr. Brar said. Ranbaxy's net profit rose to 1.59 billion rupees ($33 million) in the quarter ended in September from 891 million rupees ($18.5 million), in the quarter a year ago. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Another Threat From the 'Axis'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARMESEY, TILLIE
description: GARMESEY - Tillie. Our mother, a feisty, optimistic lady who had inner strength, honesty and love of God. As well as a loved mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother, she was a friend. Love forever. Adrienne & Marty & family Jamie and David and family

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Another Beloved Extraterrestrial

title: Revelation Elicits Ire And Disdain In Seoul
description: The news that North Korea had admitted to having a nuclear weapons program reverberated here, unsettling many people after months of glowing reports of warming relations between the two Koreas.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Union Rally Set For Today
description: Two labor organizations plan a multiunion rally today near Bryant Park to protest what they call unfair corporate policies. The organizations, the New York City Central Labor Council and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., are calling the event ''No More Business as Usual.'' It will focus on the Enron and WorldCom scandals and will protest high salaries paid to corporate executives, large-scale layoffs at scandal-plagued companies, and the damage to workers' retirement plans. The rally is scheduled for 5:30 p.m. outside Verizon's headquarters at 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: North Korea's Nuclear Secret
description: North Korea has stunned the world by acknowledging that it has been working to produce nuclear bomb fuel despite a 1994 agreement with the United States to freeze nuclear weapons development.

title: A Rush Play For Madden: Coast to Coast In 50 Hours
description: FEAR of flying has allowed John Madden, the 66-year-old analyst on ABC's ''Monday Night Football,'' to fulfill a youthful fantasy. ''My all-time favorite book is 'Travels With Charley' -- that's my motivation,'' Mr. Madden said over the phone a few weeks ago. The enthusiasm in his familiar deep voice is contagious, just as it is when he's on air, describing a gravity-defying overtime touchdown catch by the underdogs. ''You have got to read it! John Steinbeck had a motor home, and he was going to take a year and just go. He ended up going with his dog. I thought, 'Someday I would like to do it.' ''

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: NORTHERN IRELAND: SOLDIER CHANGES TESTIMONY A former British paratrooper broke ranks with the official army version of how 14 unarmed people were killed by soldiers in Londonderry in 1972 by telling the "Bloody Sunday" inquiry that he did not believe anyone shot at troops before they fired at the marchers. The man, identified only as Soldier 027 and testifying from behind a screen that hid his identity, said he had fabricated his testimony at an inquiry 30 years ago that supported the official view that soldiers fired only after being attacked. He was the first former soldier and the 582nd witness to testify at the new inquiry, which is two years old and has at least a year to run. It was moved from Londonderry to London this fall because paratroopers feared testifying in Northern Ireland.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article by Dow Jones in Business Day yesterday about a California judge's ruling that lets antitrust lawsuits against energy companies go forward included one company erroneously among the defendants. They do not include Coral Energy Resources, an affiliate of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.

title: Officer Charged in Murder
description: A police officer has been charged with murder in the strangulation of a woman he lived with, law enforcement officials said last night.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 7
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Roche's Drug Approved
description: The Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche Holding said that it had received approval to sell its hepatitis C treatment Pegasys in the United States. It was the first new drug approval for Roche in more than a year. Roche expects approval for the drug's use in combination with ribavirin by the end of the year. Roche hopes the drug can eventually produce annual sales of 1.5 billion Swiss francs ($1 billion). Pegasys has already been approved for use in Europe. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Housing Starts Jump 13.3%, Helping Lift The Economy
description: With storms gathering elsewhere, the housing industry continues to shield the economy during its halting recovery.

title: New Trial Ordered for Officer Convicted in a Suspect's Death
description: The Connecticut Appellate Court today ordered a new trial for a former New Milford police officer convicted of using unreasonable deadly force during a confrontation with a suspect almost four years ago.

title: Mets Waiting For Piniella While Alfonzo Waits for Mets
description: Fred Wilpon, the owner of the Mets, worked last night to forge an agreement on compensation with the Seattle Mariners that would give his team the right to speak with Manager Lou Piniella. Also, the Mets have decided to wait in determining the future of one of their longtime players.

title: More Greens? A Red Light From Martha's Vineyard
description: Golf, when it is played by rich newcomers, has been ruled a development evil here on Martha's Vineyard.

title: STARBUCKS GIVES POST TO EXECUTIVE OF PATHMARK
description: The Starbucks Corporation named James L. Donald president of its North American business as of Nov. 1. Mr. Donald, the chief executive of Pathmark Stores, will succeed Howard Behar, who led Starbucks North America on an interim basis. Mr. Behar will remain on the board of Starbucks and its international subsidiary. Mr. Donald will oversee Starbucks's 4,574 company-owned and licensed stores in the United States and Canada. Pathmark, a supermarket chain based in Carteret, N.J., said that Eileen Scott would become chief executive and Frank G. Vitrano president.

title: New Date for DiCaprio's 'Gangs' Film
description: Miramax Films, which last week shifted the release of ''Gangs of New York'' from Dec. 25 because another high-profile Leonardo DiCaprio movie was also scheduled to open then, today named its new opening date: just five days earlier.

title: Swordplay and Foreplay: A Swashbuckler Gets Even
description: In the entry on Philippe de Broca in The New Biographical Dictionary of Film, the critic David Thomson writes that ''when the cinema of charm is assessed, de Broca must always be remembered.'' De Broca's ''On Guard,'' which opens today in Manhattan, provides rousing support for this assertion.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: TRAVEL AGENT SLIPS Europe's third-largest tour operator, MyTravel, warned for the third time in five months that its profit would fall short of its forecast, setting off a 62 percent decline in its already battered share price. The company, which ousted its chief executive, Tim Byrne, after an earlier warning, said pretax profit for 2002 could be $31 million lower than a $141 million forecast barely two weeks ago. MyTravel, formerly called Airtours and based in Manchester, England, blamed lower summer sales and costs related to an accounting change. The company's shares have lost 90 percent of their value since the start of the year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Hindu rewriting of history texts splits India
description: NEW DELHI  One out of three people in India cannot read nor write. At least 100 million children are out of school. And 45 percent of those who join school drop out before finishing even five years of basic schooling.

title: Retreat From the Wild Shores of Abstraction
description: ''DRAWING NOW: EIGHT PROPOSITIONS'' at the Museum of Modern Art, Queens, is sometimes, but not consistently, an outstanding exhibition whose shortcomings are almost as interesting as its triumphs. This automatically means it is above average among big surveys of contemporary art in major New York museums, and makes it required viewing for anyone remotely interested in the art of the moment.

title: Sluman, on a Ride, Shares the Lead at Disney
description: In a place known for good times, Jeff Sluman had another enjoyable day.

title: 'Take Care of My Cat'
description: Directed by Jeong Jae-eun

title: Missing in Bali
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTIQUES
description: Grand Objects, Minimal Settings

title: Weighing 'Deterrence' vs. 'Aggression'
description: The Bush administration responded today to the disclosure of North Korea's nuclear weapons program with a strategy of urgent diplomatic pressure free of military threats or even a tone of crisis. It was a marked contrast with the drumbeat of warnings about force and the mobilization of troops against Iraq, also a member of the ''axis of evil'' identified by President Bush, but one he says poses the most serious danger to the United States.

title: Text: Extended Excerpts From Golisano Interview
description: Following are extended excerpts from an interview yesterday with Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, RALPH E.L., BSC., M.D., C.M., F.A.C.S.
description: HERTZ-Ralph E.L., BSc., M.D., C.M., F.A.C.S., Died on October 14th at his home in Mooloa Farm, of Ulupalakua, Maui, Hawaii, formerly of Pelham, New York. Dr. Hertz is survived by his wife of 56 years Mary M. ''Mackie'' Edwards. Dr. Hertz was a surgeon at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital Cancer Center; Clinical Instructor of Surgery at Cornell Medical School; Chief of Service at Polyclinic Hospital and Consultant at Strang Clinic. Following retirement he was appointed to the Emeritus Medical Staff of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases and to the Emeritus Staff of Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Born in Greensburg, Pennsylvania on August 6, 1920 to the late Ralph and Lucille DeLage, he obtained his BSc. and M.D.C.M. degrees from McGill University, Montreal Quebec. He was a King (Eagle) Scout and carried the Canadian flag at the opening ceremonies of the World Jamboree in Washington, D.C. in 1937. During World War II he served as a Captain in the Royal Canadian Medical Corps. He entered into private practice in New York City in 1954 and specialized in direct patient care. He was a member of the New York Athletic Club and the Larchmont Yacht Club. He leaves his children Beatrice of Ottawa, Canada, Louise White of Pelham, NY, Frank of Mount Kisco, NY, Dr. Christine Wolf (Doug) of Atlanta, GA., Ralph (Nancy) of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Margaret McClendon (Bernie) of Elko, NV, James (Bronwyn) of Cranford, NJ, Kenneth of Maui, HI, Dorothy Topham (Patrick) of Nantucket, MA., Virginia of Maui, HI, Donald of Pelham, NY, Jennifer Libsack (Jamy) of Portland, ME, and 30 grandchildren. He is predeceased by his son Henry. He is survived by his sister, Olivette Stricker of Wilkes-Barre, PA. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor, NY. on Monday October 21st at 10 AM followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive friends on Sunday 2-4 and from 7-9 PM at the Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Avenue, Hawthorne, NY. 914-769-4404. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to Boy Scouts of America Westchester/Putnam Council, 41 Saw Mill River Road, Hawthorne, New York, 10532, or Maui Hospice, 400 Mahalani Street, Wailuku, HI 96793, would be appreciated.

title: U.S. SAYS PAKISTAN GAVE TECHNOLOGY TO NORTH KOREA
description: American intelligence officials have concluded that Pakistan, a vital ally since last year's terrorist attacks, was a major supplier of critical equipment for North Korea's newly revealed clandestine nuclear weapons program, current and former senior American officials said today.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panasonic Reaches Pact On Digital Services
description: Panasonic yesterday became the first major television manufacturer to strike a deal with the cable television industry to make televisions that can display digital television services without requiring a set-top box. Panasonic, which is the United States subsidiary of Matsushita of Japan, announced yesterday that it had received the required certification from CableLabs, the cable industry's research consortium. While many modern televisions can decode analog cable television signals without a set-top box, they still require the device to view digital cable. Seth Schiesel(NYT)

title: Memos on Enron Deal Released; No Mention of Rowland Role
description: Seeking to allay questions about Gov. John G. Rowland's possible involvement in its failed $220 million deal with Enron last year, Connecticut's state trash authority today released a series of executive memos that made no mention of the governor nor any hint that he might have known about the deal.

title: Technology's March, Surreal and Grim
description: ''Naqoyqatsi,'' the third collaboration of the director Godfrey Reggio and the composer Philip Glass, is a solemn, highbrow mood movie with a difference. The final part of the team's celebrated Qatsi Trilogy, which includes ''Koyaanisqatsi'' (''Life Out of Balance'') and ''Powaqqatsi'' (''Life in Transformation''), it is by far the grimmest of these nonnarrative, nonverbal cinematic tone poems with epic ambitions. Although none of the three could be described as cheery, ''Naqoyqatsi,'' whose title is the Hopi Indian term for war as a way of life, reeks of doomsday.

title: Quick Escapes
description: Atlanta

title: She Has It All: Beauty, Brains, a Stalker
description: ''Abandon'' features another score by a winning young actress who seems incapable of making a wrong move. But it's not by the star of the picture. That notable performance comes from the capable Zooey Deschanel playing a supporting role as a pleasure seeker with a quick, unembarrassed smile and a way with a line that takes the sting out of an insult -- almost. She and several other actors almost rescue the meagerly plotted ''Abandon'' -- a picture so moody that physicians might want to prescribe Prozac for it.

title: Clearly Organic
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, WILLIAM
description: BORENSTEIN-William. His friends and neighbors at 143 West 13 Street mourn the untimely passing of the President of their cooperative. His boundless energy, total dedication and warmth of spirit will be sorely missed by all of us. Our love and comfort to Laura, Lea and Lou. The Village Mews Housing Corporation

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway's Results Meet Expectations
description: Gateway Inc., the struggling maker of personal computers, reported a loss of $50 million, or 15 cents a share, yesterday, on quarterly revenue of $1.12 billion. A year ago, the company had a net loss of $519.7 million, or $1.61 a share, and revenue of $1.41 billion. The results met analyst expectations. Those polled by Thomson First Call predicted an average loss of 15 cents a share. The company sold 729,000 units during the third quarter, a 19 percent decrease from the previous year, but a 12 percent increase from the most recent quarter. Shares in Gateway, which reported its most recent earnings after the end of the trading day, closed yesterday at $2.95, up 26 cents, or 9.67 percent. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Profit and Revenue Rise In Quarter for Microsoft

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Profit Rises At Novartis
description: Firm growth in Novartis's banner drugs pushed up third-quarter profits, but the strong Swiss franc hurt revenue. Novartis had net income of 1.76 billion Swiss francs ($1.2 billion), or 71 centimes a share, up from 1.68 billion francs, or 66 centimes. Revenue fell 2 percent, to 7.99 billion. Though the news was within market expectations, shares of Novartis, Switzerland's largest drug company, fell because the company also said that it would introduce its pain relief drug Prexige a year later than previously planned. Prexige, a pain reliever that does not cause gastro-intestinal problems, is one of 67 products Novartis has in the pipeline. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Sandow Birk -- 'Maximum Security: New York Landscapes'
description: Debs & Company

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Reports 11th Quarterly Net Loss
description: The Nortel Networks Corporation, the second-biggest North American supplier of telephone equipment, reported its 11th straight quarterly net loss as sales tumbled 36 percent. The third-quarter loss narrowed to $1.80 billion, or 42 cents a share, from $3.47 billion, or $1.08, in the year-earlier period. Sales fell to $2.36 billion from $3.69 billion, the company said. The chief executive, Frank Dunn, is eliminating 7,000 jobs to meet his goal of posting a profit by June. Nortel is based in Brampton, Ontario.

title: Fire Dept. Delays Hiring In Bid to Cut Its Budget
description: The city's Fire Department is postponing the hiring of 300 firefighters as part of the department's effort to cut 7.5 percent of its budget this year, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, JACK AR MOND
description: ARMSTRONG - Jack Ar mond, 77. Of Bath, OH, died peacefully on October 15, 2002 surrounded by family members. He served his country on Iwo Jima in WWII; he worked for the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co for 40 years. He leaves behind his wife of 55 years, Marva (nee Bartholomew), his children Patrice Clareman, Ralph, Robert and Thomas Armstrong; his children-in-law Lloyd Clareman, Susan, Tracy and Robbi Armstrong; and his grandchildren Billy, Rebecca and Bart Clareman, Jenny, Sam, Heath, Maddie, Emma and Cole Armstrong-all of whom adored him and mourn his loss.

title: President's Help for His Governor Brother Includes More Than Campaign Stops
description: President Bush returned to Florida today to try to lift the re-election prospects of his brother Jeb Bush, the state's governor.

title: Bait and Switch
description: Listen to the American hawks after a few glasses of wine, and you might be seduced into thinking that after overthrowing Saddam Hussein we're going to turn Iraq into a flourishing democracy.

title: Despite Perfect Start, Burns Is Looking for Better
description: Whatever superstitions Devils Coach Pat Burns may have, they do not prohibit him from tinkering with his lines after a victory.

title: Smoking and Sinning
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Reports Strong Revenue and Net Income Even Though the Economy Was Weak
description: Microsoft reported a remarkably strong quarterly performance yesterday with both profits and revenue up sharply at a time when the economy is weak and technology spending is depressed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Policemen Fired For Aiding Sex Traffic
description: The United Nations fired 11 local policemen for frequenting brothels and tipping off their owners about raids to crack down on trafficking in sex workers. The United Nations mission has now dismissed about 20 policemen for similar offenses; many others are thought to have links to the lucrative trade in trafficked women, mostly from Eastern Europe. Weak law enforcement and porous borders since the war in the early 1990's have made Bosnia a favorite transit route and market for criminals involved in human trafficking. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Panel Is Set to Prescribe Japan's Economic Medicine
description: Japan is set to announce on Friday a series of measures aimed at supporting an economy that is likely to be hurt in the near term by the government's plan to speed up write-offs of bad loans by the nation's banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEINE, EDWARD J. JR.
description: HEINE-Edward J. Jr., 77. Of Spring Lake, NJ on Thursday October 17, 2002. Dear husband of the late MaryJane (nee Day) Heine. Devoted father and father-in-law of Edward J. III and Kerry, Timothy and Sue, Christopher and Pam, Kevin and Elizabeth, and Brian and Bernadette. Beloved brother of James E., Richard P., and the late Frank and George Heine and grandfather of 10. Funeral service Monday October 21, 2002 at 8:45 AM from the O'Brien Funeral Home, Hwy 35 at New Bedford Rd., Wall. Followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 9:30 AM at St. Catharine's R.C. Church, Spring Lake. Visitation Saturday 7-9 PM only & Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Interment St. Catharine's Cemetery, Seagirt. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the New Jersey A.P.D.A. Chapter (Parkinson's Disease), P.O. Box 5273, Kendall Park, NJ 08824, in his memory.

title: Border Tension a Growth Industry for Kashmir
description: As one might expect of a place racked by 13 years of conflict, the road from the airport into this summer capital is lined with troops.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JAMES
description: COOK-James. A leading figure in the growth of Forbes Magazine and the magazine's executive editor until his retirement in 1992, died Wednesday of pneumonia in New York City. He was 75 and had been battling pulmonary fibrosis for many years. Jim graduated from Bowdoin College, Class of 1948, and earned a Master's Degree in dramatic literature from Columbia University. He taught English at midwestern colleges before chucking academia for journalism. He joined Forbes in 1955 and rose through the ranks, along the way penning a record number of cover stories. His skeptical mind and his broad concept of what constituted business journalism greatly influenced both his style and the philosophy of the publication as it is today. Throughout his life Jim retained a lively interest in the theater and in the novel. After his retirement he published in 2000 ''Fellow Travellers'', a novel based loosely on the family of controversial financier Armand Hammer; Cook knew Hammer well and had frequently written about him for Forbes. Cook is survived by his wife, Claire, and daughters, Karen and Cassandra, all of New York City. A memorial service will be held in the Forbes Magazine Galleries at a date to be announced. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to the New York Chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: Cradled by the Music of the River
description: The view from Fulton Ferry Landing has a way of beckoning the eyes upward and outward. Almost directly above you, the Brooklyn Bridge vaults majestically over the water toward Manhattan, reaching into the sky with its colossal granite towers, bejeweled at dusk by countless pearls of light. It is a thrilling vista -- the curve of the bridge framing the gleaming city in the distance -- and it can bring a magical sense of panorama and possibility.

title: Two Officers in Louima Case Will Not Face Charges Again
description: Federal and state prosecutors in Brooklyn say they do not plan to file new charges against two former police officers in connection with the torture of Abner Louima or efforts to hamper the investigation of the assault more than five years ago.

title: Documentary Realism Becomes Opera
description: The paradox of the fascinating digital documentary video opera ''Three Tales'' -- something its married creators, the composer Steve Reich and the video artist Beryl Korot, openly embrace -- is that while the work explores the perils to humanity of unchecked advances in technology, it uses those advances toward innovative artistic ends. That unsettling paradox makes you squirm through all 70 minutes of ''Three Tales,'' which received its premiere at the Vienna Festival in May and arrived at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday night as part of its Next Wave Festival (with additional presentations tonight and tomorrow). Yet the work's conflicted attitude toward technology also prevents it from slipping into polemics, which could easily have been a problem.

title: Doug Aitken
description: 303 Gallery

title: Corrections
description: A fashion review on Oct. 8 about collections shown in Paris by John Galliano and four other designers misspelled the given name of a performance artist who was suggested as a possible inspiration for some of Mr. Galliano's creations. He is Leigh Bowery, not Lee.

title: U.S. Customs Will Remain In Manhattan
description: The United States Customs Service intends to maintain its pre-Sept. 11 presence in New York City, preferably in a new Custom House in Lower Manhattan, the Customs commissioner said yesterday, allaying concerns that the service was planning a move to New Jersey.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Woody Allen, Stage Director

title: Goodbye, Little Ghost: Halloween Goes Hollywood
description: I WAS sifting through the mail on a sweltering August day when my 7-year-old son, Charlie, elbowed me aside. He grabbed something with a bright orange cover and waved it triumphantly: the season's first Halloween catalog.

title: China Frees Dissident Tibetan Nun 9 Years Ahead of Schedule
description: A young Tibetan nun imprisoned nearly a decade by China for ''counterrevolutionary'' crimes, was released today, nine years ahead of schedule, according to the United States-based Dui Hua Foundation, which had pressed for her freedom.

title: Islanders Dig 2-Goal Hole But Find a Way Out of It
description: Brad Isbister does not kill penalties for the Islanders, so he found himself marooned on the bench during most of a dismal second period tonight, when the Islanders looked as if they were trying to violate every hockey rule possible.

title: International Fine Art and Antiques Dealers Show
description: Seventh Regiment Armory

title: ASBESTOS-RELATED COSTS INCREASE AT GEORGIA-PACIFIC
description: Georgia-Pacific, the paper and lumber company, said yesterday that costs for asbestos-related lawsuits this year were 63 percent more than it expected. The company disclosed the costs as it reported a third-quarter profit of $66 million, or 27 cents a share, up from a loss a year earlier of $167 million, or 62 cents a share. Sales fell to $6.15 billion from $6.31 billion. Georgia-Pacific had expected to pay about $81 million to settle asbestos lawsuits in the first nine months of the year. Instead, those costs have amounted to $132 million. The higher payments mean that a $350 million reserve, or $221 million after taxes, created last year is being depleted faster than planned.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retailer Rescued
description: Daiei Inc., a Japanese retailer with about $13.5 billion in debt, will be bailed out by the government only two weeks after a new banking regulator said no company was too big to fail. The Development Bank of Japan, financed by public pensions and postal savings, said that it would contribute a sixth of a 60 billion yen ($480 million) fund for Daiei, Japan's third-largest retailer. Daiei's major lenders, UFJ Holdings Inc., Mizuho Holdings Inc. and the Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation, will provide the rest. The Development Bank's participation in Daiei's second bailout this year suggests the state may become the lender of last resort to companies cut off by private banks. Takeshi Komura, governor of the Development Bank, said the bank was in talks with other companies and might invest in similar funds. ''If it's a benefit to the Japanese economy then we will consider other funds,'' he said.

title: Kashmir Chief Quits
description: The chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir said tonight that he was unwilling to continue serving until the parties who defeated his own in elections last week agreed on who would lead the new government.

title: Indonesia Orders Muslim Cleric to Undergo Questioning
description: A fundamentalist Islamic preacher who has been linked to Al Qaeda and a string of terrorist attacks in Southeast Asia, was ordered today to appear for questioning by Indonesian police, a lawyer and Indonesian officials said.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Subverting The Familiar

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teacher's Aide Charged With Abuse
description: A teacher's aide at an intermediate school has been charged with sexual abuse after two teenagers said he had molested them, the police said. In June, a 14-year-old girl told the police she was abused by the man, Juan Benitez, 54, of the Bronx, at Intermediate School 90, on Jumel Place in Washington Heights. The second teenager, a boy, 15, also reported being sexually abused by Mr. Benitez, who was arrested yesterday, the police said. In June, Mr. Benitez was reassigned to the district office, and if he is found guilty of the charges, he will be terminated, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Online Entree To the World Of Fine Wine
description: WEEKEND wine warriors, far from their city cellars, may not be oenologically challenged after all. In truth, given a computer and a phone, they may be well ahead of their urban counterparts no matter how rustic the weekend retreat.

title: Man, 22, Charged With Shooting Deliveryman
description: A 22-year-old man with a history of drug arrests was charged yesterday with firing the fatal shot in the murder of a Chinese food deliveryman in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Irish Stable Does Better Than Just Recover
description: The Breeders' Cup is an American creation, decides American championships and is, by and large, for American horses. But when the pre-entries were announced yesterday for the eight races to be held Oct. 26 at Arlington Park near Chicago, it was clear that an Irish stable would arrive with the most quantity and quality.

title: Sun Reports Loss, Beats Estimates And Cuts Jobs
description: Struggling with an increasingly uncertain and bleak corporate economy, Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it would lay off 11 percent of its employees and reported a loss for its first quarter, but it still exceeded Wall Street's earnings expectations.

title: 73% Bounce Makes EBay an E-Commerce Bright Spot
description: EBay, the Internet auction giant, announced continuing growth yesterday, with nearly $264 million in net revenue from transactions in the third quarter, 73 percent higher than the figures for the period a year ago.

title: DVD's Offering Full Concerts
description: In the 1990's long-form music videos -- performance documentaries and the like -- had their day on videocassette before being buried in an avalanche of heavily promoted movies and further done in by a failure to connect a visual music product with audio CD's. A better fate is predicted for DVD.

title: Sniper Case Fuels a Debate Over Firearm Fingerprinting
description: The sniper shootings in the suburbs of Washington have produced an intense debate over whether the government should create a nationwide database of ballistic fingerprints, electronic images of the unique markings that every gun makes on the bullet it fires and the shell ejected from it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Priest Slashed In Mugging
description: A Roman Catholic priest was robbed and his face slashed early yesterday as he returned to the rectory of his church on West 59th Street, the police said. The priest, the Rev. Robert J. O'Donnell, 54, pastor of St. Paul the Apostle Church at 415 West 59th Street, was returning from dinner with friends shortly before 1 a.m. when he was confronted outside the rectory, the police said. Father O'Donnell, who was not wearing his clerical collar, offered the assailant his wallet, the church said in a statement, but the man cut him across the left side of his face, from his ear to his mouth. Doctors at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center needed 100 stitches to close the wound, the church said. Father O'Donnell was later released. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: SOHO BLOOMINGDALE'S PLAN ADVANCES

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WHEELER, IRA
description: WHEELER - Ira. Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A joins with the late Ira Wheeler's family & his many other friends in celebrating his life and extraordinary contributions to non-profit organizations like ours. The memorial service will be this Sunday, October 20th, at 3 P.M. at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and 5th Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Indonesian Suspect, Due for Questioning, Lands in Hospital
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 18  The Indonesian government's fledgling campaign against terrorism was jolted late this afternoon when a prominent militant Muslim cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, who was to have been questioned by the police on Saturday, was unexpectedly admitted to a hospital.

title: Musical Makeover
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON SOME OF DISNEY'S DEBT
description: The Walt Disney Company's senior unsecured debt was cut one level by Moody's Investors Service, reflecting concern about lagging profit at the media company, particularly at its theme parks and the ABC television network. Moody's cut its rating on Disney's $14 billion in debt to Baa1 from A3, the fourth-lowest investment-grade rating. Disney's outlook is stable, Moody's said. Earlier this month, Standard & Poor's also cut its credit rating on Disney by one level. Fewer guests at the parks, lower advertising sales at ABC and a possible further decline in the economy may make it difficult for Disney to pay back loans, a Moody's analyst, Glenn Eckert, said.

title: Punitive Damages Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBNO, DOROTHY (NEE WATTON)
description: DUBNO-Dorothy (nee Watton) of Queens, NY on Friday. Beloved wife of Irwin. Dear mother to Janis and Bina. Loved grandmother to Kobi and Natalia and loving sister of Abraham Watton. We will miss her unconditional love and support. Funeral Sunday 1:30PM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York. Donations may be made to: Crohn's & Colitis Foundation, or Cancer Care.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Extra Cargo Flights
description: Responding to continued frustration in East Asia over backlogs at West Coast ports in the United States, China Airlines said that it would begin offering four extra weekly cargo flights of Boeing 747-400 freighters from Taipei to Los Angeles, starting on Oct. 21 and lasting at least until mid-November. Although President Bush ordered an end last week to the 11-day lockout of longshoremen at the ports, shippers complain that the unloading of cargoes continues to be delayed and delivery times for cargoes still in Asia have been extended. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Wednesday about the arrival of the wild-card playoff format in baseball and its history in other sports misstated the number of wild-card teams in the National Football League playoffs and the overall number of teams in the playoffs. There are four wild-card teams, not six; the overall number is 12, not 14.

title: Shuttle Returns Home From 11-Day Mission
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Oct. 18  The space shuttle Atlantis and its crew of six returned to Earth today after an 11-day construction mission to the International Space Station.

title: Man Charged In the Murder Of His Mother And a Boy, 11
description: A South Jersey man who was angry because his mother refused to buy him cigarettes went on a rampage Thursday, beating her to death and fatally stabbing an 11-year-old boy who crossed his path, the Burlington County prosecutor said yesterday after the man's arrest.

title: New Rules of Engagement With North Korea
description: Just as the crisis with Iraq is heating up, the United States is on the verge of a serious confrontation with another member of the ''axis of evil,'' North Korea. The recent visit of James A. Kelley, an assistant secretary of state, to Pyongyang ended with North Korea admitting that it is conducting a secret program to produce nuclear bomb-making material. As a result, the stage could be set for a repeat of the 1994 crisis with North Korea over a previous effort to build such weapons, a crisis that brought us close to a second Korean War.

title: Earnings Climb at Lear
description: The Lear Corporation, a maker of auto interiors, said today that third-quarter earnings more than tripled and its yearly profit might rise more than forecast because of improving demand.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: EXTRA CARGO FLIGHTS Responding to continued frustration in East Asia over backlogs at West Coast ports in the United States, China Airlines said that it would begin offering four extra weekly cargo flights of Boeing 747-400 freighters from Taipei to Los Angeles, starting on Oct. 21 and lasting at least until mid-November. Although President Bush ordered an end last week to the 11-day lockout of longshoremen at the ports, shippers complain that the unloading of cargoes continues to be delayed and delivery times for cargoes still in Asia have been extended.   Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Two 10-Hit Innings Is Out of This World
description: If the Angels are to give the San Francisco Giants equal treatment, they will, in one of the games of this World Series, rattle off 10 hits in an inning. It is, however, unlikely that they will produce that inning because they have already done it twice in this postseason.

title: Bonds Sure to See Fewer Strikes Than Williams Did
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 18  One of the more foolish discussions of the day is whether the Anaheim Angels should do the sporting thing and pitch to Barry Bonds in the World Series.

title: Eileen Southern, Chronicler Of Black Music, Is Dead at 82
description: Eileen Jackson Southern, a scholar of Renaissance and African-American music and the first black woman to be appointed a tenured full professor at Harvard University, died on Sunday at her home in Port Charlotte, Fla. She was 82.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENGARD, JEROME HARRY CLASTER
description: LOWENGARD-Jerome Harry Claster, 77. Of West Hartford, CT, on October 17, 2002. He leaves his wife of 51 years, Elaine Title Lowengard, his children, Mary and Sarah of NYC, Henry and wife Nancy Graham of Kingston, NY, Benjamin and wife Susan Cohen of Watertown, MA, Alexander of West Hartford, and Jeremiah and wife Sheila of South Portland, ME, and six grandchildren. Memorial service Monday, October 21, 3 PM, Congregation Beth Israel, 701 Farmington Ave., West Hartford. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Endowment Foundation of the Greater Hartford Jewish Federation, Hartford Stage Co., or Connecticut Forest and Parks Association.

title: Baltimore's Homegrown Terrorism
description: The horrifying murders of a Baltimore woman, Angela Dawson, and five of her six children in an arson fire is a tragedy not only for their loved ones but also for a city where some neighborhoods have been described as under siege by lawbreakers. The fire, in which Mrs. Dawson's husband was critically injured, was apparently the result of her bold decision to do what all of us are asked to do: She reported drug dealing and other crime in her neighborhood to police. And she went a step further recently, testifying in an assault case against a drug dealer.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't listen to any of them. Nobody has anything good to say.''

title: Ways to Combat The Terror Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Wachovia, Prudential Seen in Talks
description: Prudential Financial is in talks with the Wachovia Corporation about a joint venture that would merge their brokerage and research businesses, executives close to the discussions said last night.

title: Challenging the Growth Gurus
description: As the chief economist of the World Bank in the late 1990's, Joseph E. Stiglitz got a firsthand look at how policy was made at its sister institution, the International Monetary Fund, and he was dismayed. Decisions, he said, were made on the basis of ideology rather than sound economic reasoning.

title: VATICAN DEMANDS U.S. BISHOPS REVISE SEX-ABUSE POLICY
description: The Vatican today rejected an aggressive new policy by American bishops to combat child sexual abuse by priests, saying bishops needed to rewrite parts of it to make the policy conform with the laws of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Pataki Gets the Endorsement Of 10 Hudson River Mayors
description: Gov. George E. Pataki listened closely yesterday as he stood on the deck of the pilot boat New York with Brian Monahan, the Democratic mayor of Dobbs Ferry. Mr. Monahan pointed out a privately owned stretch of riverbank that he would love to annex to a waterfront park.

title: Acting as if They've Been There Before
description: One pesky team, more keen-eyed than bright-eyed and more businesslike than bushy-tailed, is in the World Series for the first time in its 42-year history. One powerful player, more wary than wide-eyed and filled with more fervor than wonder, is also here for the first time.

title: Muckraking Governor Slain By Sniper on Moscow Street
description: A sniper hiding behind a billboard and armed with a revolver equipped with a silencer shot and killed one of Moscow's regional governors today just blocks from the Kremlin in one the most brazen in a string of assassinations in Russia over the past decade.

title: Knicks Not Quite Ready To Welcome Back Sprewell
description: Even as the Knicks' play this week brought smiles to the faces of Don Chaney and Scott Layden, the ugliness of the Latrell Sprewell controversy hovered over them, promising to push basketball to the periphery again.

title: In Political Din, South Dakotans Long for 'Mute'
description: Nobody needs to tell the people in this speck of a town, known for its homey steakhouse, that there are more political commercials on television this year than ever before.

title: Markets Finish an Impressive 2-Week Run
description: Stocks finished a volatile week with small gains yesterday but still managed a milestone of sorts: one of the better two-week performances since World War II.

title: Fed Mood Seems to Be Shifting Against a Rate Cut
description: The Federal Reserve, which flooded the economy with money by sharply lowering interest rates last year as growth collapsed, appears much more unwilling to fend off another potential tailspin today.

title: Indonesian Suspect Agrees to Questioning, Then Collapses
description: The Indonesian government's fledgling campaign against terrorism was jolted late this afternoon when a prominent militant Muslim cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, who was to have been questioned by the police on Saturday, was admitted unexpectedly to a hospital.

title: Judge Voids Rules on Pharmaceutical Tests
description: A federal judge has struck down rules that required drug companies to test their products in children. The rules were intended to give doctors and parents more information about the drugs' safety and the proper dosage.

title: Strong Dollar Runs Into Renewed Resistance
description: To hear many American manufacturers complain, the biggest competitive threat is not China or South Korea and certainly not Europe. It is the seemingly unsinkable value of the American dollar.

title: In Today's Business World, Can Doing Good Also Mean Doing Well?
description: Most people want to do ''good work'' -- a combination of high-quality performance and social responsibility, says Howard Gardner, a professor at the Harvard Graduate School of Education. The question is how. So he and two colleagues, Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, a professor at the School of Management at Claremont University, and William Damon, a professor at Stanford University, created the Good Work Project to research how professionals in fields from science to journalism have answered the question. Felicia R. Lee spoke with Professor Gardner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILHELM, GLENN DAVID
description: WILHELM-Glenn David. Beloved husband, father and son. We miss you. Your Famil

title: Off the Field and Into the Fray
description: Sports, and the athletes who play them, have a history of being at the center of controversial issues.

title: Advocates for Abuse Victims Urge Boston Archbishop to Adopt a Tough Policy Quickly
description: Perhaps no city was more riled up today by the Vatican's decision to reject the American bishops' policy on sexual abuse than this one, where the priest scandal erupted nine months ago.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Back to Schumann, With Care and Passion
description: In his final season as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Wolfgang Sawallischhas chosen to revisit the big orchestral works of Robert Schumann. He has made them the focus of his four appearances with the orchestra at Carnegie Hall, the first of which was on Tuesday. Each concert will include one of the symphonies, and the concertos for cello, violin and piano are distributed through the series. He began with the ''Manfred'' Overture, an appropriate curtain raiser.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Paper Profit For Retailer
description: Japan's third-largest retailer, Daiei, which is struggling to deal with debts of 1.7 trillion yen ($13.7 billion), reported that its net income quintupled, to 186.5 billion yen ($1.5 billion) in the six months ended Sept. 30. But the increase was from the accounting effects of debt relief it had already won from some lenders; sales fell 9.7 percent and operating profit fell 20 percent. A government-backed fund said on Thursday that it would organize another debt bailout for Daiei. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Microsoft's pricing practices misspelled the name of the chief information officer of Creative Artists Agency, who predicted that the licensing structure would cut his firm's software costs by 20 percent. He is Michael Keithley, not Keathley.

title: Students Fidget Through Sniper's Lockdown
description: Allie Christman is itchy, itchier by the day.

title: Nuclear Issue In North Korea Colors a Race In the South
description: Conservatives hopeful of ousting the ruling party in the presidential election in December seized today upon North Korea's reported admission of a secret nuclear weapons program to criticize President Kim Dae Jung and his policies.

title: News of Ex-G.I. in North Korea Only Deepens Mystery
description: It was the unlikeliest of marriages.

title: Duty, Honor And Football
description: As the football players at the United States Air Force Academy worked out on their practice field on Wednesday, the thin air was filled with the usual sounds: the coaches' shouts and whistles over the thumping and popping of bodies and pads. Then came another noise: the crack of rifle fire from a nearby practice range.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column yesterday about a woman who contracted the human form of mad cow disease while living in Florida identified the disease incorrectly. It is variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, not Creutzfeldt-Jakob itself.

title: Bring Back Hetch Hetchy?
description: In 1913, in defiance of established law and the wishes of millions of Americans, Congress foolishly approved the construction of a dam and an eight-mile-long reservoir in a lush valley known by its Indian name, Hetch Hetchy, in the northwest corner of Yosemite National Park. The dream of righting this wrong has never really died. Now it's back, in the form of a proposal by Environmental Defense and other conservation groups for a feasibility study to see whether it would be economically and hydrologically plausible to knock down the dam, drain the reservoir, uncover 1,900 acres of valley floor and restore what the naturalist John Muir once described as a ''grand landscape garden, one of nature's rarest and most precious mountain temples.''

title: When All Shows Were Always Live
description: The jury is still out on whether AOL and Time Warner caught the front edge of a media revolution when they merged, but the corporation's television arm has nicely captured an earlier sea change with ''The Big Time,'' a movie about the formative days of television that has its premiere tomorrow on TNT.

title: An Italian Official's Blunt Words Set Off Euro-Mayhem
description: With one word ''stupid'' -- the European Union's top official has blasted a hole into the already damaged budget and lending structure crucial for a unified European economy.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: School Hostage Siege Ends
description: A 16-year-old dropout who held four students and a teacher at gunpoint in a school in Waiblingen, a Stuttgart suburb, surrended to police officials after a six-hour standoff. The hostages were unharmed. The boy, whose name was not released, had demanded a million euros. The episode had echoes of a school shooting in April in Erfurt, where an angry dropout killed himself and 16 others. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Neophytes at the Series

title: Paterno Got His Share Of Calls Over the Years
description: Anyone who saw an agitated Joe Paterno run down Referee Dick Honig after an overtime loss to Iowa earlier this season can attest to the excellent fitness of the Penn State coach at age 75. Anyone who has watched the Nittany Lions' souped-up offense this season knows the coach's mind for football is as sharp and modern as ever.

title: Krone's Return Is Set for November
description: The jockey Julie Krone, the first woman to be inducted into thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame, will return to racing early next month in Southern California.

title: Sniper Cases Prove Hardest For the Authorities to Solve
description: Catching a deadly sniper has long been harder than solving most other forms of homicide, with more sniper killings going unsolved than murders in general, experts say.

title: Looking for Love, and Finally Finding It
description: The first major premiere of American Ballet Theater's season at City Center is the darkly witty ''Sin and Tonic'' by James Kudelka, easily ballet's most original choreographer.

title: College Football | Kickoff; TODAY'S TOP MATCHUPS
description: 1 Notre Dame (6-0) at 11 Air Force (6-0) 10 p.m., ESPN

title: Dr. George Perera, 90, Hypertension Expert
description: Dr. George A. Perera, a former professor of medicine at Columbia University known for his work on high blood pressure and for his antiwar efforts, died on Sept. 14 at a retirement community in Kennett Square, Pa. He was 90.

title: Police in Virginia Seize White Truck With Shell Casing in Their Hunt for Sniper
description: A tip to detectives in the manhunt for the roving suburban sniper led to the seizure of a white box truck that contained a spent shell casing, the Montgomery County police said tonight.

title: Music, Ripped Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, HAROLD
description: SIMON-Harold. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Evelyn and the entire family. Kenneth R. Orr, Pres.

title: Vatican Demands U.S. Bishops Revise Sex-Abuse Policy
description: ROME, Oct. 18  The Vatican today rejected an aggressive new policy by American bishops to combat child sexual abuse by priests, saying bishops needed to rewrite parts of it to make the policy conform with the laws of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Bonuses Challenged
description: A Malaysian cellular company, Technology Resources Industries, filed suit on Thursday against its former directors to force them to return 55.8 million ringgit ($14.8 million) in what it says were improper payments. Before they were compelled to resign in July, the former chairman, Tajudin Ramli, and two other directors awarded themselves severance payments and bonuses for the company's debt restructuring. Mr. Tajudin lost control of the company last year when the government sold his stake to the state-run phone company Telekom Malaysia. Technology Resources has asked police to investigate 259.3 million ringgit in invoices booked when Mr. Tajudin controlled the company. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: White House Backs Off Big S.E.C. Budget Increase

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about efforts by the financially troubled Barnes Foundation to move its art museum from cramped quarters in a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown building misstated the limit on visitors set by local regulations. No more than 1,200 people can visit the museum in a week, not in a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, FRANK
description: CARLIN-Frank. On October 16, 2002, when, after a long struggle, his heart sadly became as weak as it was tremendous. He lived into his 91st year, always with abundant personality and never without as much love for his family as there can be. Beloved father of Gail Benderand Allan Carlin, father-inlaw of Sheldon Bender and Diane Carlin, grandfather of Seth and Michael Bender and Rebecca and Emily Carlin.

title: Belmont Will Host 2005 Breeders' Cup
description: The Breeders' Cup will return to Belmont Park in 2005, the New York Racing Asscoiation announced yesterday. The Breeders' Cup, which rotates among the top tracks in the country, was scheduled for Churchill Downs in 2005, but officials scrapped that plan upon learning that the races would conflict with a Future Farmers of America convention and that there would not be enough hotel space in Louisville, Ky., to accommodate both events. The Breeders' Cup will instead be run at Churchill Downs in 2006.

title: UAL and Unions Set Goal for Cost Cuts
description: United Airlines and its unions said yesterday that they had agreed to try to wring $5.8 billion in savings from labor costs over five and a half years, even as UAL, United's parent company, reported one of its worst quarterly losses.

title: Yaacov Farkas, Zeev the Cartoonist, 79; Student of Israeli Politics
description: Yaacov Farkas, who under the pen name Zeev became the dean of political cartoonists in Israel, died on Tuesday in a hospital near Tel Aviv. He was 79.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Piedmont Journal; Where the Police Log Is a Source of Comfort
description: Like weather, the character of a community reveals itself in many ways.

title: Man, 74, Dies After Fire in Suffolk County
description: A 74-year-old man died after a house fire yesterday in Bay Shore, N.Y., the Suffolk County police said last night.

title: Saddam Hussein, by a Whisker
description: In a developing scandal, there have been widespread claims of voting irregularities in the recent Iraqi election. In a referendum on re-electing President Saddam Hussein, Mr. Hussein won 100 percent of the vote, but Mr. Hussein's aides claim that the real number was probably closer to 110 percent. They contend that a significant number of voters, particularly the elderly, had difficulty reading what they describe as confusing, poorly designed punch-card ballots. Many voters, the aides believe, intended to vote for Mr. Hussein but ''spoiled'' their ballots inadvertently.

title: Poorer Boroughs' Students Get Smaller Slice of Aid
description: Ishmael King is a 9-year-old built like a nose guard who is positively unbeatable at Nintendo, always handy with a quotation from the literary sagas of Captain Underpants and will concede under extreme pressure that the professional wrestling he so adores is staged, at least some of the time.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit For Samsung
description: Samsung Electronics earned $1.39 billion in the third quarter, up from $336 millionin the third quarter of 2001. The company said sales of mobile telephones were up 23.7 percent and memory chips were up 5 percent from the second quarter, but the global downturn cut sales of other products. The profit fell short of the $1.53 billion earned in the second quarter, but shares of Samsung surged 6.2 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Mayor Assails Trial Lawyers For Lawsuits Against City
description: When mayors are invited to speak to professionals at a convention, they usually do their best to make nice. ''Thanks for coming, New York just loves cosmetic dentists/science fiction enthusiasts/middle school principals,'' usually does the trick.

title: In Brazil Runoff, the Straggler Labors On Against Huge Odds
description: These are tough times for Jos Serra. The opinion polls unanimously predict that he is going to take a drubbing on Oct. 27 in Brazil's presidential election runoff, his followers are growing more discouraged by the day and the fence-sitters are flocking to his opponent, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva.

title: Ways to Combat The Terror Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABALME, PATRICIA HOCHSCHILD
description: LABALME-Patricia Hochschild. The Faculty, Trustees and staff of the Institute for Advanced Study are deeply saddened by the loss of Patricia Labalme, friend, colleague and scholar. She was the Associate Director of the Institute from 1982-1988; Secretary of the Corporation from 1982-1992; Assistant to the Director, Phillip A. Griffiths, from 1992-1997; and, most recently, a Visitor in the Institutes' School of Historical Studies, working to complete a book on the Venetian Diarist Marino Sanudo. All who knew Patsy admired her devotion to the humanities and social sciences, respected her personal commitment to the scholarship of the Renaissance, benefited from her wisdom and treasured her friendship. She exemplified the highest standards in all that she did. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband, George, and her entire family. James D. Wolfensohn, Chairman of the Board Phillip A. Griffiths, Director

title: Composers Inspired by an Idyll in Rome
description: The ''Americans in Rome'' series -- concerts of compositions by former fellows of the American Academy in Rome -- reached its second installment in a piano recital by Donald Berman on Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall. As the artistic director of this whole festival, he had already shown both his deep familiarity with what might be called the American-Roman repertory and his flair for programming. What this recital further proved is that he is an excellent musician, and a good companion to composers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 24 about efforts by the financially troubled Barnes Foundation to move its art museum from cramped quarters in a Philadelphia suburb to a downtown building misstated the limit on visitors set by local regulations. No more than 1,200 people can visit the museum in a week, not in a month.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: OVERGRAZING IN FORESTS

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Ericsson's Loss Rises
description: The wireless network equipment maker Ericsson said it lost 5.6 billion kronor ($596 million) in the third quarter, more than the 4.3 billion kronor it lost in the period a year ago. Ericsson's customers, mainly mobile phone operators, have stopped spending money on new networks as they try to reduce debt accrued during the telecommunications boom. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about cooperation by museums in the United States, Britain and France misstated the site of a Matisse-Picasso exhibition now on view. It is at the Grand Palais in Paris. (The Pompidou Center was an organizer of the show.)

title: 6 Students Arrested After High School Fight
description: Two school safety officers sustained minor injuries yesterday morning when they tried to break up a fight between groups of students at Louis D. Brandeis High School in Manhattan, the police said. Six students were arrested after the fight, which erupted in the first-floor hallway of the school at 145 West 84th Street.

title: DYNEGY FIRES 6 ENERGY TRADERS FOR FALSE PRICES
description: Dynegy Inc. said yesterday that it had fired six energy traders and would discipline seven other employees for feeding false natural gas prices to trade journals. Dynegy disclosed last month that its traders had supplied the false prices to trade publications. The American Electric Power Company, the nation's biggest utility owner, fired five energy traders this month for providing false data to Platts, a McGraw-Hill Companies division that reports energy prices. Dynegy is continuing its review, a spokesman, David Byford, said. The inquiry was prompted by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: More Losses in Cigna Reinsurance Unit
description: Cigna reported more losses today for its reinsurance business, creating a total of more than $1 billion in third-quarter costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAGNER, BETTY (NEE REBECCA)
description: WAGNER-Betty (nee Rebecca), 96. On October 17, 2002. Widow of Samuel, beloved mother of Francine Shapiro and Robert, sister of Evelyn Newman and Sheila Kaplan, grandmother of seven, great grandmother of eight.

title: Galaxy's Ruiz Is Named the M.V.P.
description: Carlos Ruiz of the Los Angeles Galaxy, the leading goal scorer in Major League Soccer, was named the league's most valuable player yesterday. A native of Guatemala, Ruiz, with 24 goals and one assist for 49 points, finished second in scoring to Taylor Twellman of the New England Revolution, who finished second in the M.V.P. voting.

title: Hudson Valley Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: E.U. TO MOVE MEETING SO MUGABE CAN ATTEND The European Union has accepted Mozambique's offer to act as host to a Union meeting on aid to a group of southern African countries, which would enable President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to attend. The Union countries, along with the United States, Canada, New Zealand and Australia, have all banned entry to Mr. Mugabe, left, in protest against what they see as his fraudulent electoral victory in March. The meeting, planned for next month, had been scheduled to take place in Copenhagen. (Reuters)

title: The Candidates
description: This report is the second resulting from interviews with leading candidates for governor conducted by reporters and editors of The New York Times. Gov. George E. Pataki has said he will not participate.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA FALLS. Cocoa had its biggest drop in 18 years after rebels in Ivory Coast signed a cease-fire aimed at ending fighting. In New York, cocoa for December delivery fell $201, or 9.5 percent, to $1,910 a metric ton.

title: President Pays Quick Visits To Candidates In Close Races
description: President Bush dropped into the middle of two pivotal Senate races today as he campaigned for a pair of Republican candidates recruited by the White House, former Representative Jim Talent of Missouri and former Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul, whose victories could change the balance of power on Capitol Hill.

title: Fatal Shooting in Harlem
description: Three men were shot, one fatally, during a narcotics operation in Harlem last night, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, JOHN DAVISON
description: ALLEN-John Davison. A loving, caring and generous friend for 27 years. An outstanding architect and designer. Always the consummate host and a superb chef. He was with us at our wedding, our daughter's christening, vacations, holiday celebrations, and the NYC blackout. We will miss him forever. John G.J. Ritter Rita Aiello, Daniela Ritter

title: An Environmentalist Who Loves to Eat Whales
description: IN ''Whale Hunters,'' a new BBC documentary, Masayuki Komatsu can be heard giving a Japanese whaling ship captain advice on how to deal with Greenpeace protest boats: ''When they approach, blow them out of the water.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Earnings Increase
