description: Thailand's consumer spending boom is helping to increase earnings for the country's major banks, as smaller savings accounts translate into lower interest payments. The Thai Farmers Bank, the state-owned Krung Thai Bank, the Bank of Asia and the Bank of Ayudhya posted higher earnings this week. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Johnson & Johnson to Pay $150 Million in Amgen Suit
description: An arbitrator yesterday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay Amgen $150 million for violating terms of a licensing agreement. But the arbitrator denied a request by Amgen to terminate Johnson & Johnson's right to sell the product in question, an anemia treatment that is Johnson & Johnson's top-selling drug.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIRSHNER, NATALIE B.
description: KIRSHNER-Natalie B. May 29, 1920 to October 19, 2001. Love never dies, I am yours forever and miss you. Herbert

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The yen fell against the dollar with pessimism widespread ahead of a report on Japanese banks' huge nonperforming loans. In New York, the yen settled at 125.53 to the dollar, up from 124.87 on Thursday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Kim Dae Jung sees bright side; Koizumi reminds of promises : Asians diverge over revelations
description: SEOUL:  President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan adopted different approaches Friday to persuading North Korea to halt its nuclear program as the United States sought a common response to what all three see as an escalating threat.

title: DiMarco Putts His Way Into Lead
description: On a day when every player in the field seemed to make birdies, Chris DiMarco kept making putts.

title: Making Series With Giants Surprises Dunston
description: Shawon Dunston crinkled his nose and shook his head, as if he were a baby refusing to eat. His team, the San Francisco Giants, in the World Series? Dunston, their oldest player, never expected this.

title: Noelle Bush's Sentence
description: To the Editor:

title: Elias Atones by Helping Devils Find Measure of Success
description: For someone who had just scored the winning goal in overtime, Devils forward Patrik Elias looked nearly crushed. He stood at his locker and fought back his emotions, the ups and downs that he helped create in tonight's wild 3-2 victory over Nashville.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Company Makes Bad Bet On Auto Races
description: It was something of a head scratcher from the start: Interpublic, the giant advertising agency group, becoming involved in the auto racing business. Now it has become a headache.

title: It's 30 Now, And Still Faithful to Its Mission
description: Orpheus has come through some administrative reorganization lately, but it still works as it always has: instead of following a conductor, the principal players (who revolve from work to work) settle on the details of an interpretation and convey them to their sections. The idea is to perform orchestral works as if they were chamber music, and more often than not, the group's performances have been thoughtfully shaped and beautifully polished. This season, Orpheus is celebrating its 30th anniversary, and it got the year off to a busy start: last Saturday evening it opened its own series at Carnegie Hall, and on Wednesday it helped open Lincoln Center's Great Performers series with a concert at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Jerome M. Rosow, 82, Productivity Expert
description: Jerome M. Rosow, the founder and chairman of the Work in America Institute, a nonprofit research organization focusing on productivity and workplace issues, died on Friday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 82 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MAURICE
description: BROWN-Maurice. On October 18th, 2002. Beloved and devoted husband of Eunice (nee Markowitz) for 62 years. Cherished father of Howard and Nancy Brown and Andrea and Harvey Berlent. Adoring grandfather ''Pop'' of Michele and Steven Sweetwood, Michael and Jennifer Brown, Rachel and Robert Barker and Jason and Lauren Gurtman. Loving great grandfather of Amanda, Melissa and Riley. Dear brother of Joseph and his family. Born on February 15, 1915, he was a Syracuse University alumnus '35AB, '38JD, '42MS. A pioneer in the plastic industry, an energetic business entrepreneur choosing to retire and relax at age 54. He was the patriarch of our family, our protector, mentor and counsel. He will be in our hearts forever. Services are Sunday, 11:00 AM, October 20, 2002, at Temple Beth-El, 221 Schraalenburgh Road, Closter, NJ. Contributions, in his memory, may be made to the CCFA Maurice Brown Research Fund Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Greater New York Chapter, 386 Park Avenue South, New York 10016-8804.

title: Fight Terrorism Fairly
description: To the prosecution, they are a terrorist ''sleeper cell.'' To the defense, they are five idealistic but misguided young men who found themselves in a Qaeda training camp but never intended to further terrorism. Where the truth lies is the mystery at the heart of the Justice Department's case in Lackawanna, N.Y.

title: Doubts Aside, Pataki Aides See No Gap in the Budget
description: The Pataki administration defended the state budget today, saying it would hold together through the last six months of the fiscal year despite lagging tax collections.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, COURTNEY
description: STEEL-Courtney. The soul takes flight to the world that is invisible but there arriving she is sure of bliss and forever dwells in Paradise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATES, VICTOR
description: KATES-Victor. Of New York City, Eastchester, and Millbrook, NY on October 16, 2002. Cherished husband of Edith. Incredible father to Michael, Betsy, and Bill. Adored brother of Viola, Ruth, and Daniel. Revered grandfather of Jesse, Malcolm, Cory, Sylvia, Sarah, Emma, and Gabriel. Renaissance man: CW4 retired US Army Corps of Engineers (32 years), actor, harmonicist, naturalist, surveyor, friend to all. Memorial service at Community Unitarian Church of White Plains, Rosedale Avenue and Sycamore Lane, White Plains NY, Saturday, November 9, at 1:30 PM.

title: After Only Seven Games, Zook Feels the Pressure at Florida
description: Jeremy Foley, the University of Florida athletic director, spoke to a group of the state's public relations professionals Thursday. The topic, crisis management, had been set for months, but the timing could not have been better.

title: Pfizer to Face A Wider Inquiry
description: Pfizer faces a wider investigation by states over its marketing of the epilepsy drug Neurontin to doctors, a Washington State official said in a court filing today.

title: Ugandan Paper Back in Print With a Front-Page Apology
description: Uganda's only independent daily newspaper, which was raided by government security agents and blocked from publishing last week, reappeared on the streets today with a carefully worded apology on its front page.

title: Yearning to Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Tampa Bay Is Approved To Talk With Piniella
description: With the unofficial deadline of the World Series bearing down, the Mets' pursuit of Seattle Mariners Manager Lou Piniella took a strange turn yesterday, one that might leave the situation unresolved into next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXYM, STEPHEN
description: MAXYM-Stephen. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of Stephen Maxym. One of the most distinguished bassoonists of the Twentieth Century ry, he was on the Juilliard faculty from 1956 to 1992, where he taught many of today's active, professional bassoonists. His humanity, sincerity and personal integrity were hallmarks of a long and distinguished career. Our condolences go to his wife Lucy, his children, and his many friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, Pres.

title: CONTINENTAL AND THE TEAMSTERS SETTLE
description: Continental Airlines tentatively agreed to a labor contract with about 3,300 mechanics and cleaning workers represented by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The agreement, reached with the help of the National Mediation Board, is subject to a union vote, the board said. Neither the board nor Continental disclosed the terms. A Teamsters spokesman, Rob Black, said the agreement increased wages, improved work rules, increased retirement benefits and strengthened job protection. He declined to provide further details. The union hopes to vote on the tentative agreement some time this month, Mr. Black said.

title: Angels and Bonds Offer a New Look for the Fall Classic
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 18 — One pesky team, more keen-eyed than bright-eyed and more businesslike than bushy-tailed, is in the World Series for the first time in its 42-year history. One powerful player, more wary than wide-eyed and filled with more fervor than wonder, is also here for the first time.

title: UBS Copes With Legacy Of Enron
description: Eight months ago, when UBS Warburg acquired Enron's trading unit, the Swiss investment banking company thought it got a steal.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Lieberman Calls For Tax Rebates
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, called for tax rebates for low-income workers and investment tax credits for businesses as part of a plan to revive the economy. Mr. Lieberman, a possible presidential candidate, used a speech in New York to criticize President Bush and propose rebates for 34 million workers who did not qualify for the $300-a-person rebates last year. He also called for a 20 percent tax credit for companies that invest in information technology. Richard W. Stevenson (NYT)

title: Injured Hughes Drops Out of Events
description: Sarah Hughes, the Olympic figure skating champion, has withdrawn from Skate America and Skate Canada because of an injury, her coach, Robin Wagner, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. to Give New York Schools $80 Million in Sept. 11 Aid
description: New York City schools will receive an $80 million reimbursement from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, to cover lost instruction time after the terrorist attack of Sept. 11, 2001, an official familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUCAS, NANCY
description: LUCAS-Nancy. The Board of Trustees, faculty and families of Grace Church School and the Board and families of Early Steps honor the memory of Nancy Lucas. As a Trustee she was a voice of wisdom. She brought humor, intelligence and wit to every event. She was an ambassador for independent schools and their missions to New York City and beyond. In her work for A Better Chance, she was a tireless advocate for providing access to independent schools for all children of New York City. We will miss her bright smile, energy and friendship.

title: Earnings at Merck Decline For 3rd Consecutive Quarter
description: Merck said yesterday that its third-quarter profit dropped 3.3 percent as a rival's new painkiller and competition from generic products eroded its sales growth.

title: Israel Eases Its Hold on Jenin and Plans Pullback From Hebron
description: The Israeli Army has moved out of Jenin, on the West Bank, surrounding it and digging a trench to prevent militants from sneaking out, the army and the local governor said today.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Charge In Missing Child Case
description: A former state social worker assigned to monitor Rilya Wilson, a 5-year-old who disappeared in the custody of the state welfare system, was charged on Thursday with official misconduct and theft. The former employee, Deborah Muskelly, 45, is accused of working as a substitute and an adult education teacher at the time she worked for the Department Children and Families. Investigators said the state paid Ms. Muskelly more than $7,400 when she was working elsewhere. She resigned from the child welfare agency in March. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Hawaii Democrats Reeling After Scandals and a Death
description: When the voters of Hawaii awake the morning after the Nov. 5 election, they are likely to find they have done two extraordinary things: elect a live Republican to the governor's office and a dead Democrat to Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKIS, MICHAEL J. JR.
description: LAKIS-Michael J. Jr. Of New City, N.Y. On October 17, 2002. Father of Brian Lakis and Christina Dunican. Grandfather of Morgan. Brother of Josephine, Albert and Joseph. Also survived by nieces and nephews, grandnieces and grand-nephews. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10AM, St. Augustine's Church, New City, N.Y. Burial Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. Visiting Higgins Funeral Home, 321 South Main St, New City, Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9PM.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: USFREIGHTWAYS CORP., Chicago, a regional trucking company, said it would sell two freight management units to GPS Logistics Inc., an associate of a former joint venture partner, and Seko Worldwide Acquisition, a group of independent contractors. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Squabbling Over the Homeless
description: New York City is struggling to cope with the largest caseload of homeless families in its history. Faced with a staggering deficit and systemwide budget cuts, Mayor Michael Bloomberg has nonetheless beefed up the Department of Homeless Services and committed more than $100 million to a new plan aimed at finding permanent housing for women and children who might otherwise spend years moving from one homeless shelter to the next. The Bloomberg plan -- the first in history to create a clear route to permanent housing -- is essentially what advocates have been asking for since they first brought the lawsuits that have governed homeless policy in New York for more than 20 years.

title: Leader of New Jersey Troopers Resigns After 7 Rugged Months
description: Joseph J. Santiago, who was brought in seven months ago to restore credibility to a police agency that had made the state the center of the national debate over racial profiling, stepped down today as superintendent of the New Jersey State Police.

title: Old Times Square Surfaces In Brawl on Eighth Avenue
description: On one corner of Eighth Avenue, shortly after 10 a.m. yesterday, ironworkers drilled holes in the plates that give the Westin New York hotel its sleek look. The hotel, a 45-story monument to the transformation of Times Square, opened this week, and the workers were putting on the finishing touches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, EVELYN PECK
description: ROSENFELD-Evelyn Peck, 78. Of Hewlett, New York, and Tamarac, Florida. Devoted mother, grandmother, sister, and aunt, adored by her family. Everyone who came in contact with her will remember Evelyn for her strong spirit, her wonderful sense of humor and enthusiasm for life. With integrity as her hallmark, Evelyn characteristically made a strong impression by always speaking the unvarnished truth. A cheerleader at Brooklyn's Lafayette High School '42, she never lost her pep, enthusiasm, and glamour. The former Miss Peck personified zest for life. After WW II Evelyn fell in love with a much decorated army colonel, Ira Rosenfeld. Evelyn carried on a passionate romance with him, her ''Buddy''; they were married for more than fifty years. He predeceased her, as did her beloved identicaltwin sister, Shirley. Evelyn Rosenfeld will be missed by her family: Mary & Jonathan Sanders; Jacqueline, Andrew, Adam, and Charles Schuyler; Meryl, Bruce, Scott, Stacey and Eric Freedman; Sidney and Rose Peck.

title: Positive earnings reflect management, not fresh growth : Tech firms lift profits, but slump lingers on
description: Microsoft's revenue rises 26 percent, while LG Electronics turns from a loss to a profit. IBM surpasses expectations, and Nokia's net income triples.

title: Bonds Doesn't Want Baker Era to End
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 18  Barry Bonds knows that the San Francisco Giants have never won a World Series. This is only their third trip to the Series since moving from New York after the 1957 season, and their first appearance in Dusty Baker's 10 seasons as manager.

title: New Jersey Kicker Sticks to Lonely but Fruitful Routine
description: During football practice, Rick Krautman usually stands alone on the sideline. As the rest of the Ramapo (N.J.) High School football team engages in full contact drills and conditioning workouts, Krautman keeps his head down and calmly kicks footballs through the uprights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSOVA, ZARA
description: NELSOVA-Zara. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Zara Nelsova, extraordinary artist and dedicated cello faculty member at the School from 1985 to 2001. An artist of exceptional creativity, she embodied the very best attributes of a special teacher and a caring human being. She will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, Pres.

title: 3 Are Charged In Death of Man Who Dressed Like a Woman
description: The authorities today charged three men with murder and committing a hate crime in the death of a 17-year-old man from suburban Newark who frequently wore women's clothing.

title: Record Entries For Head of Charles
description: A record 1,500 crews and more than 7,000 rowers will compete in 22 events in the 38th annual Head of the Charles Regatta today and tomorrow on the Charles River course in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Ways to Combat the Terror Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Teterboro Projects Face a Challenge
description: A coalition of officials from Bergen County and 13 of its communities have asked a judge to halt improvement projects at Teterboro Airport until air quality tests are completed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, KAREN G.
description: WILCOX-Karen G. Bard College mourns the passing of Karen G. Wilcox, who died on October 17 after a courageous struggle with lung cancer. From 1969 to 1977, she worked at Franconia College in New Hampshire. In 1977, she became dean of admissions at Bard College. She was a beloved colleague and a friend. Our condolences go to her husband Joseph, her daughter Beagan, her stepchildren Susan and Michael, and to her mother and siblings. A memorial service will be held in the Chapel of the Holy Innocents, Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, New York, at 3 P.M. on Sunday, October 20, followed by a graveside ceremony at the Bard College cemetery. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman Dimitri B. Papadimitriou, Executive Vice President

title: Fire Fatal to 6 Leads a City To Scrutinize Its Drug War
description: In this city where 60,000 people, about one in 10 residents, are addicted to narcotics, a simple message appears on billboards, police cruisers, city buses, T-shirts, brochures and in television advertisements: ''Believe.''

title: Many Leaders of U.S. Church Say Rome's Stance Is a Relief
description: While victims of sexually abusive priests expressed despair and outrage yesterday at the Vatican's refusal to endorse the American bishops' zero tolerance policy, many bishops, priests and even some laypeople privately breathed a sigh of relief.

title: A Vulnerable Time to Be Moving Oil by Sea
description: After the United States began its war in Afghanistan, many in the oil industry braced for what they saw as inevitable: terrorist attacks on tankers.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Overgrazing In Forests
description: A federal judge has ruled against the Forest Service and in favor of 10 environmental groups that said the government was allowing overgrazing in 11 national forests where the federally protected Mexican spotted owl lives. The judge, Raner C. Collins of Federal District Court in Tucson, ruled that the agency violated the Endangered Species Act and did not follow its environmental standards. The ruling could affect up to 15 million acres of grazing allotments in New Mexico and Arizona. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Sept. 26 about Judge Milton Pollack, an expert on securities law who remains on the federal bench at age 96, referred incorrectly to the 1998 resolution of a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint against Michael R. Milken, who was accused of violating an order barring him for life from the securities industry. Mr. Milken settled the complaint, without admitting guilt or liability, and turned over $42 million he had earned as a consultant. He was not fined that amount by Judge Pollack.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Researchers Say Science Is Hurt by Secrecy Policy Set Up by the White House
description: The presidents of the National Academies said yesterday that the Bush administration was going too far in limiting publication of some scientific research out of concern that it could aid terrorists.

title: The Smoke Nazis
description: The mayor of New York City does not seem to be a particularly puritanical man. Michael Bloomberg is a guy who, when asked if he had ever tried marijuana, replied: ''You bet I did. And I enjoyed it.'' (Alas, he's not willing to advocate decriminalizing the experience for the rest of us, but that's a subject for another day.) He once fondly likened his college fraternity to the one in ''Animal House,'' and he still enjoys a party. He is no libertarian, let alone libertine, but his attitude toward private pleasure is pretty much live and let live.

title: Healthy Stottlemyre To Return
description: Mel Stottlemyre never expected to be back as the Yankees' pitching coach in 2003. Then again, he never expected to feel so healthy or so motivated.

title: Bausch & Lomb Executive Admits to Falsified Rsum
description: Ronald L. Zarrella, the chief executive of Bausch & Lomb, a maker of eye care products, admitted yesterday that his rsum contained false information about his education. But, as Bausch shares began to fall on the news, the company's board issued a statement of confidence in him.

title: 1981 Jets Offer Hope For Current Edition
description: The Jets' franchise and fans are so fragile that a one-month regression evokes the worst of times dating to 1962.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Golisano Proposes Stern Measures to Close Budget Gap and Avoid Tax Rise
description: Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would close the state's looming budget deficit by pushing some people off Medicaid, limiting others from signing up and holding the line on financing for education.

title: U.S. Seeks Support to Press North Korea
description: American officials opened a diplomatic drive across Asia and Europe today to build international pressure on North Korea to abandon its recently revealed nuclear weapons program.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Drug Tests For Welfare Families
description: Families that receive welfare may have to take drug tests, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled. It held that the state's interest in protecting children, in public safety and in not paying for illegal drugs was stronger than the recipients' right to privacy. Earlier decisions had allowed testing students and people with sensitive jobs. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, Graham A. Boyd, said the ruling was the first to endorse testing parents. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: AQUILA, A MIDWESTERN UTILITY, NAMES FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Aquila Inc., the Midwestern utility company based in Kansas City, Mo., named Rick Dobson interim chief financial officer, succeeding Dan Streek, the second senior executive to decide to leave the company recently. Mr. Dobson, 43, will supervise accounting, treasury and financial management activities, the company said. His appointment is effective Nov. 20. Earlier this month, Richard Green replaced his brother Robert as Aquila's chief executive.

title: Hospitals Will Stop Sending Mentally Ill To Nursing Homes
description: Officials at state psychiatric hospitals in New York ordered social workers this week to stop sending discharged patients to locked units in private nursing homes. The move ends a six-year-old practice that was supposed to help scale back the state's costly psychiatric system but has raised civil rights concerns.

title: Golisano's Vision of Government: Leaner, More Efficient and Less Invasive
description: Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: Daschle Takes Parting Shot as Congress Breaks
description: With Congress leaving the capital for a last bout of campaigning, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, today blamed President Bush for a ''very disappointing Congress'' and said the nation was in worse shape than when Mr. Bush took office.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Firefighters Vote To Strike
description: Britain's firefighters voted to stage six strikes over the next several months, their first in 25 years. They are seeking 40 percent pay raises; their employers, the country's local government authorities, have offered an interim increase of 4 percent. Condemning the plans, the government said it would put the armed forces on standby to provide cover during the strikes, which the Fire Brigades Union said would last two to eight days each. The union's general secretary, Andy Gilchrist, said: ''All the government has to do is start genuine pay talks. It's that simple.'' Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: With Age, Set Free by Time
description: ''He defies time, doesn't he?'' Chick Corea asked the audience on the first of Roy Haynes's two nights at Alice Tully Hall this week.

title: Jerome M. Rosow, 82, Productivity Expert, Dies
description: Jerome M. Rosow, the founder and chairman of the Work in America Institute, a nonprofit research organization focusing on productivity and workplace issues, died on Friday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 82 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Ways to Combat The Terror Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and France Closer to Deal on Terms for Iraq
description: With fragments of diplomatic text bouncing back and forth between Washington and Paris and other world capitals, the United States and France moved closer to agreement today on a draft resolution to force Iraq to disarm, Security Council diplomats said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Names Chief
description: Abbey National appointed the former president of UBS as its new chief executive. The executive, Luqman Arnold, 52, succeeds Ian Harley, who resigned in July after a growing number of bad loans took a toll on profits. Those problems helped push shares of Abbey National down 32 percent this year and made the bank vulnerable to takeovers. The National Australia Bank and the Bank of Ireland both approached Abbey National recently, though Abbey has spurned both bids. After Mr. Arnold's appointment was announced, the Bank of Ireland said it was withdrawing its offer. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Lover Of Literary Puzzles
description: Umberto Eco is something of a practical joker. He is also Italy's best-known living novelist and, almost as famously, a philosopher who writes about matters ranging from ''Peanuts'' to Kant, and a semiotician who says he learned his excellent English by reading Marvel Comics and ''Finnegans Wake.''

title: Many Leaders of U.S. Church Say Rome's Stance Is a Relief
description: While victims of sexually abusive priests expressed despair and outrage yesterday at the Vatican's refusal to endorse the American bishops' zero tolerance policy, many bishops, priests and even some laypeople privately breathed a sigh of relief.

title: A Miracle at Assisi
description: The great basilicas of Italy house some of the most important sculpture, painting and craft work in Western art. One of the most prized holdings -- a series of 13th-century ceiling frescoes by the ground-breaking painters Giotto and Cimabue -- was thought to be forever lost when an earthquake ravaged the basilica of St. Francis in the town of Assisi five years ago. Those who have visited this soaring structure since the restoration was unveiled last month are relieved to see that the pessimists were wrong.

title: Japan Hopes to Use Aid to Press North Korea to End A-Bomb Plan
description: Hoping to prevent its neighbor North Korea from becoming an active nuclear power, Japan today brandished what it clearly hoped could be the most powerful weapon: economic leverage.

title: Wisconsin Legislators Face Another Day of Charges
description: For the second day in a row, prosecutors filed criminal charges today accusing legislative leaders in Wisconsin of misconduct in office. This time it was Republicans in the Assembly, charged with illegally running campaign operations from state offices, using government employees.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about Sam Shepard and the inspiration for his plays misstated the nationality of an actor in a British production of ''True West.'' The actor, Michael Rudko, is American, not British.

title: Armstrong Out to Keep His Uniform, and Job
description: Games Brandon Armstrong played in his rookie season: 35.

title: Angels vs. Giants
description: THE RECORDS

title: Dangers of Obesity
description: To the Editor:

title: Artist's Kiln Divides Town In the Catskills; Feud Between Neighbors Embodies Culture Clash
description: Susan Beecher, a nationally recognized potter with a bent for rural life, fell in love with the Catskills for its glorious mountains and deep serenity, qualities that infused her clay creations. Last year, she spent $30,000 to build a wood-burning kiln next to her cedar-shingled home here, and for a moment, she was living a potter's dream.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: Louima Fee Dispute May Be Over
description: The ferocious courtroom battle over $3 million in legal fees from the Abner Louima civil lawsuit stopped abruptly yesterday as the two sides negotiated a possible settlement.

title: Prescriptions for an Ailing Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: SLACK DEMAND HURTS MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS PROFIT
description: Martin Marietta Materials, a supplier of aggregates like sand and gravel, said its profit in the third quarter fell to about 80 cents a share as demand for its products declined. The company had forecast 95 cents a share, the same as its profit a year earlier. But commercial construction has dropped about 20 percent from a year ago, the company said, and road construction is down. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn 92 cents a share. Stock in Martin Marietta, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., fell $2.22, or 7 percent, to $29.87 a share.

title: Irish Referendum Today Looms Large in the Future of Europe
description: With the collapse of the Soviet empire, the end of the cold war conjured heady dreams among Central and Eastern Europe's peoples that they might aspire to the kind of Western freedoms and riches once glimpsed through the chain mail of the Iron Curtain.

title: A free-diver's death : Tragic plunge to the limits
description: Push your limits too far in most sports and you lose. Push your limits too far in free diving, Audrey Mestre's sport, and you die.

title: International Aid Groups Fear New Crisis in Eastern Congo
description: International aid workers are warning of a growing humanitarian crisis in eastern Congo, where the foreign troops who had occupied the area until recently are being replaced by local militias that are just as destabilizing for the local population.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKASH, MORTIMER
description: FARKASH-Mortimer. October 18, 2002. Beloved husband of Doris. Dear sister of Estelle. Devoted uncle of Leslie, Sandra, Robert and Paul. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Sunday, October 20th, 11 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an Arts in America article on Thursday about the Armenian pop singer Nune misidentified the location of Asbarez, an Armenian daily newspaper whose critic discussed the ethnic roots of her music. It is in Glendale, Calif., not Glendale, Ill.

title: Store Clerk Dies After Attack, but Prosecutors Say It's Not a Murder Case
description: Six days a week, Li Qiang Shu worked long hours behind a bullet-proof partition in a liquor store in a crime-ridden section of the Bronx. Conscious of the dangers he faced each day, he passed cash and bottles through a small portal to customers.

title: Religion Journal; A New Library Opens, in More Ways Than One
description: Whatever history makes of Mary Baker Eddy, one thing is undisputed: She liked to write, a lot.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Copter Crash Ascribed To Chechen Rebels
description: A Russian military helicopter that crashed into a river in Chechnya on Thursday went down as it tried to evade fire from Chechen fighters on the ground, officials said. Col. Boris A. Podoprigora, the deputy Russian commander in the Northern Caucasus, told Interfax that the helicopter, an Mi-8 carrying 24 passengers and crew members, clipped a power line while trying to escape fire from the ground and crashed into the Terek River. At least one crew member was killed, while a passenger was missing, evidently washed away in the river. The helicopter was the fourth brought down by hostile fire in two months. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLMAN, PEARL
description: ELLMAN - Pearl. Devoted wife of the late Benjamin. Loving mother of Lois Hofshi & Mark (Nancy). Dear sister of Arnold Rothschild. Cherished grandmother of Jeffrey Fischer, Diana Hofschi and Eric Ellman. Great grandmother of Colin Fischer. Services Sunday 10 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York. For further information call 914-664-6800.

title: An Empty Nest, and Success, For Manhattan Eagle Project
description: In the end, the eagles left as quietly as they came.

title: Black Sunday in Montreal: Lightner Double at 5-Level
description: Many American players remember the diagramed deal, and would prefer not to. It occurred on Aug. 25 at the world championships in Montreal, and the United States teams suffered a series of disasters, some of which are worthy of record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATT, LEON
description: BLATT-Leon. Of Holden, MA, formerly of Nanuet, NY. Died Friday, October 18, in Worcester, after an illness. His wife Rose Roth (Blatt) died in 1969. He leaves a son Howard N. Blatt and a daughter-in-law, Melissa A. Blatt, both of Holden, a brother David Blatt, of Rockville Centre, LI, four grandchildren, and a great-granddaughter. Graveside services 1:30 PM, Sunday, October 20, in Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

title: Bush Tries to Shrink S.E.C. Raise Intended for Corporate Cleanup
description: Less than three months ago, President Bush signed with great fanfare sweeping corporate antifraud legislation that called for a huge increase in the budget of the Securities and Exchange Commission to police corporate America and clean up Wall Street.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: BANK NAMES CHIEF Abbey National appointed the former president of UBS as its new chief executive. The executive, Luqman Arnold, 52, succeeds Ian Harley, who resigned in July after a growing number of bad loans took a toll on profits. Those problems helped push shares of Abbey National down 32 percent this year and made the bank vulnerable to takeovers. The National Australia Bank and the Bank of Ireland both approached Abbey National recently, though Abbey has spurned both bids. After Mr. Arnold's appointment was announced, the Bank of Ireland said it was withdrawing its offer.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSROG, RABBI SEYMOUR L.
description: ESSROG-Rabbi Seymour L. We mourn with profound sorrow the sudden passing of our beloved colleague and past president (1998-2000). After two years in the active U.S. Army chaplaincy, he served his entire rabbinic career in Baltimore, first as rabbi of Beth Israel Synagogue for 30 years and then at Congregation Beth Shalom in Carroll County. At the time of his death, he was the rabbi of Congregation Adat Chaim. He was extremely involved in both the national and local Jewish communities and led 26 trips to Israel. Rabbi Essrog's service to the Rabbinical Assembly was extensive. He held every senior office in the RA. He is remembered for his deep caring for colleagues, his warmth and wonderful sense of humor. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Toby, children, Debra Jo, Michael and Rena, mother, Sadie, brothers and sisters-in-law, our colleagues, Rabbi Sheldon and Shulamith Elster and Rabbi William and Florence Berkowitz. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Sure to See Fewer Strikes Than Williams Did in 1946 Series
description: One of the more foolish discussions of the day is whether the Anaheim Angels should do the sporting thing and pitch to Barry Bonds in the World Series.

title: Catherine Connelly, 109; Escaped Slocum Fire
description: Catherine Connelly, who as an 11-year-old in 1904 escaped the inferno that burned the General Slocum, an excursion boat in the East River, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Wilton, Conn. She was 109 and was one of the last two survivors of the disaster, according to a commemorative group.

title: Senate Candidates Argue Over Ability to Get U.S. Money for New Jersey
description: The two candidates for United States Senate from New Jersey clashed today over who could bring the most federal money back to the state. Former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg stood under the soaring dome of the Frank R. Lautenberg Station here today and took credit for bringing $450 million in federal money to build the Secaucus Transfer center, which will allow passengers to change New Jersey Transit lines without going into Newark or New York.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Hotels Upgrade to Seek Meetings as Well as Guests
description: DRIVEN in part by the need to compete with newer facilities, the Garden City Hotel, which traces its roots to the late 1800's, has nearly completed the first phase of a $25 million interior renovation intended to reflect its elegant history as a grand hotel.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Investing; Shopping for Bond Gains, Overseas
description: FOR investors who believe that the rally in domestic bonds is ending, there may be an overseas alternative.

title: Rapid weight loss, Garbled speech, Body moving in a 'restless dance'
description: 1.Symptoms

title: BackTalk; A Conference Extends the Sun Belt to Logan, Utah
description: Up here in the mountains of northern Utah near the Idaho border, friends of the Aggies characterize Utah State University as a middle-class striver on the brink of national recognition. Down in New Orleans, pals of the Sun Belt Conference describe it as a good-hearted ''league of convenience.'' So when they took their vows here two days ago there was as much relief as celebration.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; New Faces, Old Battle Over Montclair Store Site
description: ON New Year's Eve in 1997 a local artist with a sense of humor dressed up the former Hahne's department store building in the center of downtown here, hanging strips of red Mylar all around the roofline and creating the effect of a huge ribbon on an enormous box. Of course, everyone knew it was a gag gift. The box was empty, and had been since 1989.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFRIN, MAX
description: SCHIFFRIN-Max. 96. On October 16, 2002. In Sunrise, Fla. Devoted husband of the late Elsie. Beloved father of Ellen (Al) Kruger & Victor Schiffrin. Cherished grandfather of Adam (Pam) Kruger and Jennifer (Howard) Freund. Beloved uncle. Loving brother of Mark (Shirley) Schiffrin. Remembered with love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEISER, ELISSA
description: KEISER - Elissa. Beloved mother of David, wife of Richard, and sister of Carmela, Helen, Anne, Ella, and Leonora, passed away Wednesday night, after a two year struggle with cancer. A former teacher and school business administrator, she will be remembered as a kind, compassionate, and generous woman, and as a conscientious and accomplished professional. Her personal commitments to education and social justice never waivered. She will be loved and missed forever by those whose lives she touched.

title: Sports of The Times; Woman's Word and Two Athletes' Honor Are at Odds
description: THE coach better be right. As students walked past the Crayola-colored trees on the University of Maine campus last week, Coach Jack Cosgrove was sitting in his drab office, rubbing holes in his temples, trying to defend his conviction to himself as much as anyone.

title: 'Spinning Into Butter' Raises Questions Without Answers
description: SARAH DANIELS, who is white, thought she could do some enlightened good in a racist society by escaping from the urban grit of Chicago and taking a job as dean of students at Belmont, a proper, mostly white liberal arts college in Vermont.

title: Buying Savings Bonds in a Virtual Environment
description: Investors who have the urge to buy a $25.01 United States Savings Bond can now do so. For that matter, they can now buy bonds in one-cent increments from $25 all the way up to $30,000 whenever they want.

title: Christopher B. Sheldon, 76, Whose Ship Sank in Freak Storm, Dies
description: Christopher B. Sheldon, whose 92-foot twin-masted sailing ship Albatross sank in a freak storm in 1961, a disaster that inspired the 1996 movie "White Squall," died Oct. 5 in Stamford, Conn. He was 76.

title: A Glimpse of Bali Before the Horror
description: With its idyllic beaches, picturesque hillsides and lush tropical jungles, the Indonesian island of Bali has long been a favorite subject for travel publications. National Geographic Traveler, in fact, featured Bali in its October issue -- which hit the newsstands just days before last weekend's terrorist attack. Additional photographs of the island are showcased on the magazine's Web site.

title: Debate on Women at Augusta Catches Woods Off Balance
description: Tiger Woods, who is rarely caught off guard on a fairway or a putting green, was surprised that he had become such a lightning rod in the divisive issue over whether women should be admitted as members of Augusta National Golf Club, home of the Masters tournament.

title: Left Behind
description: I was deeply disappointed to see my reflections on the legal profession lifted out of context and used by George Packer to support the untrue proposition that the ''legal left'' has abandoned Lynne Stewart. While I and many leftist attorneys reject Islamism as a national liberation movement, we are unanimous in condemning Attorney General Ashcroft's claim that Stewart intentionally aided terrorism by providing a conduit for her client to speak to the press. Stewart has faced these charges in the same way she has conducted her law practice: with courage and determination. I am proud to stand with her.

title: For Many High Schools, Homecoming Is a Casualty
description: When the senior class won the hallway decorating contest at homecoming every year, Dana Jones and her friends began to suspect it was rigged. But that was not supposed to matter this year, because Dana Jones and her friends are seniors, and it was their turn.

title: October 13-19: NATIONAL; CONVICTION OVERTURNED
description: A judge in Pensacola, Fla., threw out the second-degree murder convictions of Alex King, 13, and Derek King, 14, in the bludgeoning death of their father. Citing the prosecution's decision to try another man in a separate trial for the same killing, the judge ruled that the strategy violated the boys' rights to due process. Dana Canedy

title: A Happy Homecoming For Paterno
description: As is custom at Beaver Stadium, several fans spent part of their morning hamming it up outside with a statue of Joe Paterno, a likeness of him in midrun with his tie flapping in the manner of a man chasing a taxi.

title: A Nobel Effort Honored Just in Time
description: IN a gold mine nearly a mile beneath the Black Hills of South Dakota, Raymond Davis Jr. of Brookhaven National Laboratory set out four decades ago to catch neutrinos from the core of the sun.

title: 'Lullaby'
description: At first, the new owner pretends he never looked at the living room floor. Never really looked. Not the first time they toured the house. Not when the inspector showed them through it. They'd measured rooms and told the movers where to set the couch and piano, hauled in everything they owned, and never really stopped to look at the living room floor.

title: Making the Most of New York's Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 6 about the filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson, who lives in the San Fernando Valley and has set most of his movies there, misidentified the mountains that separate the valley from Hollywood and the rest of the Los Angeles basin. They are the Santa Monica Mountains. (San Vicente is a peak in the Santa Monica range.)

title: Light and Fast Helps at Regatta
description: Steve Tucker, a lightweight singles sculler on the United States national team, repeated his second-place finish of last year in today's final of the men's championship singles at the 38th Head of the Charles Regatta on the Charles River.

title: Four Centuries of Architectural Icons
description: THE busload of tourists poured onto the formal entrance court of what once was the sculpture studio of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, founder of the Whitney Museum, and despite the heavy rain that was falling, started snapping pictures and traipsing toward the gardens to get a better view.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: There were two American cities attacked on Sept. 11, 2001: one has been busy celebrating itself for its bravery ever since, while the other has gone about its business, doing something about the attacks. Both our cities live in constant fear of further attack and have many other things in common as well. It is not useful to make fun of our capital, which is not, by the way, unique: most states in the union have different political and economic capitals.

title: Left Behind
description: Your article on Lynne Stewart was a timely reminder of how our constitutional rights are being abrogated by John Ashcroft and the Bush administration. But was it necessary to add to the persecution of Stewart by making sexist comments about her weight and haircut? What do they have to do with the fact that she is being singled out and hounded by the Justice Department. I notice that your article on Paul Wolfowitz did not mention that he doesn't seem to know how to get a clean shave.

title: Personal Business; Homeowners Drop the New and Go for Improved
description: EVER since Joe Gardella retired from his engineering job five years ago, he and his wife, Cecile, have been thinking about selling their four-bedroom house in Milford, Mass. They recently checked out the modern condominium units near their home and even considered relocating to Fort Myers Beach, Fla. But they decided to stay put -- and to renovate.

title: Business; HSBC's New Loan: 2,000 Environmentalists
description: LYNNE MARSHALL says she has never fully understood why HSBC Holdings, one of the world's largest banks, would send 2,000 employees on far-flung environmental expeditions. But Ms. Marshall, who was among the first to be chosen, is not second-guessing her employer.

title: Raymond T. McNally, 71, Dies; Researched the Origins of Dracula
description: Raymond T. McNally, a black-caped scholar who combined a childhood fascination with horror films with his study of Eastern Europe to link the fictional Dracula with monstrous historical figures, died on Oct. 2 at his home in Newton, Mass. He was 71.

title: Campaign Season; The Awkward Endorsement Game
description: It's a not-so-secret fact of political life that liberal interest groups sometimes make a point of endorsing Republican incumbents whose influence they need, even when Democratic challengers hold purer positions on the group's pet issues. That has caused bad feelings in some high-profile races this year.

title: Violations By Buildings May Delay Tenant Grants
description: Residents of nearly 200 apartment buildings in Lower Manhattan could find their applications for Sept. 11-related housing grants denied or delayed because of outstanding violations of building or fire codes, according to officials of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

title: A 'Wintertime' Watch: Stormy Romance Ahead
description: IT is the winter of supreme content, solitude and romance. Then the hurricane strikes.

title: Notre Dame's Undefeated Season Continues
description: This game was closer than it should have been, certainly closer than Notre Dame wanted it to be. Despite dominating Air Force for most of the brisk evening, the Fighting Irish led the Falcons by only 7 points late in the fourth quarter and the Falcons had the ball.

title: Helping Hands, Young and Old
description: ''YOU have to lay it back down to dry, honey,'' said Emily Graney, as she gently helped 4-year-old Gillian Rosh place a pine cone studded cardboard picture frame back onto the table. ''That's right, that's good -- oh, that's gorgeous.''

title: Some Museums to Visit But Don't Expect Art
description: A MUSEUM is a museum is a museum, even if it contains no paintings or sculptures. A fair number of specialty museums flourish on the Island, with displays ranging from objects that show where we have been to the keys to the very nature of our being. Here is a sampling.

title: October 13-19
description: STORM CLOUDSIN KOREA East Asia discovered that the world's eighth nuclear power might be in their midst. American diplomats said that they confronted North Korean officials two weeks ago in Pyongyang with evidence that the North has been cheating on a 1994 agreement to forswear nuclear production and development. To their surprise, the North Korean officials first blustered, then admitted it. The confession provoked a conservative backlash in Japan and South Korea, threatening any warming of relations. Just last week, five Japanese citizens kidnapped by North Korean agents in 1978 were allowed to return to Japan for one week.

title: A Taste of Japan With Theatric Touches
description: JAPANESE restaurants are not exactly a novelty in Connecticut. For years there were a steady few scattered here and there across the state. But recently there has been an infusion of new ones, including Ichiro Hibachi & Sushi Bar in Trumbull.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, S. WILLIAM
description: GREEN-S. William. The Board of Trustees of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, Inc. and the Executive Committee of the Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin Bikur Cholim Coordinating Council are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend, former Congressman Bill Green who, along with his sister Cynthia Green Cohen, have been a strong and consistent supporter of the agency's programs and services. We express our deepest sympathy to the immediate and extended family. Jean L. Troubh, President Seymour Kramer, Chairman BCCC Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive VP and CEO Rabbi Isaac N. Trainin

title: Rock's House Photographer
description: IN a business filled with overblown egos, one man modestly turned his hobby into a career. As a musician and member of the Modern Folk Quartet in the 1960's, Henry Diltz loved to take snapshots on the road and then present slide shows back home in Los Angeles. His organic, laid-back approach to photography appealed to his friends, who included the musicians David Crosby and Mama Cass Elliot, and a pastime quickly became a vocation.

title: An Old Friend on Route 7 Is Fading Away
description: THERE is a little log cabin tucked in the trees along Route 7 in Danbury that has been making motorists break and do double takes for 50 years. Many turn around and pull into the lumpy dirt parking lot, curiously sizing up the concrete deer, the wooden teepees and totem poles, the giant Indian statues out front.

The Board of Directors and the staff of the Folksbiene Yiddish Theatre are deeply saddened by the passing of the great artist and Yiddish music and theatre icon, Seymour Rexsite. We extend our condolences to Mel Freedman and his entire family over the loss of their dear uncle. Seymour leaves us a legacy of song and good deeds that will live on in the hearts of Yiddish lovers forever. Zalmen Mlotek, Exec. Dir. Robert Kaplan, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, HANA GININGER ''GINNY''
description: PHILLIPS - Hana Gininger ''Ginny'', 88, died October 11, 2002, at home in Coconut Creek, FL. She was the widow of Dr. Herman Phillips and managed his medical practice for 31 years on Lincoln Road. They moved to Miami Beach from Brooklyn in 1944. A graduate of Girls High, and Brooklyn College, member of Temple Emanuel in Miami Beach, and Hadassah. Hana was a vibrant woman whose thoughtfulness, generosity of spirit and good humor will be missed by her family and friends. She is survived by her three children, Judith Phillips, NYC, Dr. Charles Phillips, Stuart, FL, and Edward Phillips, Attorney, Boca Raton, FL; five grandchildren, Dawn, Jake, Thaddeus, Benjamin and Stephen; sister, Mildred Epstein; and brother, Emanuel Gininger.

title: Back in Anaheim, Snow Torments His Old Team

When he was old enough to drive, he would come to games with his friends, buy cheap tickets and sneak down to the good seats when the other fans left. He would grow up to have an even better view, becoming an everyday major leaguer as the Angels' first baseman in the mid-1990's.

Stewart's personal political history would suggest an exploration of this question.

description: To the Editor:

title: At a Nester's Paradise A Suburban Nightmare Feels Near
description: IN a New York City too often battered by crime and barely a year past Sept. 11, it may be heartening to realize that the Beltway sniper is a quintessentially suburban phenomenon. Every time he strikes, he parks his light-colored van near a highway with an easily accessible escape route. He prefers mall parking lots.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Frank Rich's witty essay (Oct. 6) arguing that a vibrant New York trumps a bland Washington as the nation's true capital gets it about half right. Washington may indeed be America's ultimate generic metropolis. It is also dominated by outsiders. But many of Washington's transplants (at least those who work in its vast white-collar machinery) bring little of their regional quirks to the city. It seems that is exactly what the nation's founders had hoped for -- a capital reflecting the nation, not a particular region. In the process, Washington has been sanitized of much local flavor, a fate that Rich would agree New York has been lucky to avoid.

title: October 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; WASHINGTON ON EDGE
description: The ninth victim was cut down as she went about a simple shopping chore and wandered across the sniper's sights. The rifleman roving the Washington suburbs remained at large, but on Saturday the police in Montgomery County said they had seized a truck in which a shell casing was found, a possible lead in the pursuit of the sniper who has killed nine and wounded two. Francis X. Clines

description: Cathleen Kennedy Maurer, the daughter of Elizabeth A. Maurer and Donald F. Maurer of Lawrenceville, N.J., was married yesterday to Jared Wilson Morgan, the son of Jacqueline C. Morgan and Jasper W. Morgan of Suffield, Conn. The Rev. Michael Lambeth, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Church in Block Island, R.I.

title: October 13-19: NATIONAL; CHURCH ABUSE POLICY TEMPERED
description: After four months of study, the Vatican weighed in on American bishops' zero-tolerance policy on child sexual abuse by priests, and its judgment was that the bishops had gone too far. The withholding of a Vatican endorsement means that all American bishops would not be bound to the policy, a setback for American church leaders who felt that such a requirement was an essential route out of a crisis that has engulfed the Roman Catholic church this year. Frank Bruni

description: Bridget Rosemary Gallagher is to be married today to William John Bartholomew at the Church of St. Peter in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Kevin J. O'Leary, a Roman Catholic priest, will perform the ceremony.

title: Northeasters Make Fishing Impossible
description: Nature may be bountiful, as she has been with this year's run of stripers, blues and false albacore. But she can also be capricious, as she was when she hurled storm after storm against the rocky headlands of Montauk. All that anglers have been able to do is stand on the shore, in unfishable conditions, watching the birds dive and the fish gathering in their murderous feeding frenzy. It's like being a kid without a quarter in F. A. O Schwarz.

title: Iraqi Disputes Charge by Bush That Baghdad Has Qaeda Ties
description: An Iraqi official who is part of President Saddam Hussein's inner circle has said the government has had no links with Al Qaeda or Osama bin Laden, denying a charge made by President Bush.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MICHAEL F. JACOBSON; The 'Organic' Label: Who Wins at the Bank?
description: WHEN they buy ''organic'' foods, consumers can now be a little more confident they are getting something produced and processed without chemical fertilizers, pesticides or preservatives. Starting tomorrow, fruit, vegetables, meat, milk and other products labeled organic can carry a Department of Agriculture seal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, CLAIRE
description: TAYLOR - Claire. Beloved wife of the late James A. Devoted mother of Marjorie Rosenberg. Cherished grandmother of Barry and Robin, Laurie and Joseph. Greatgrandmother of Alyson, Julian, Jack and Jennifer. Loving sister of Jackie Kahn.

title: Caitlin Blue, Eric Waterman
description: Caitlin Blue, a daughter of Kathryn and Anthony Dias Blue of Los Angeles, was married yesterday evening to Eric Michael Waterman, the son of Dr. Evelyn Waterman and Seymour H. Waterman of Encino, Calif. Rabbi Harold M. Schulweis officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Artists at Work

title: October 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; ELECTION OVERHAUL
description: A bill to overhaul the nation's election procedures won final Congressional approval, and President Bush said he would sign it. The measure, intended to prevent ballot disputes like those that bedeviled the 2000 presidential election, authorizes $3.9 billion in federal aid to states. The money can be used to buy new voting machines, train poll workers and establish statewide voter registration lists. Robert Pear

title: Stilettos and Nostalgia
description: IF the new Copacabana that opened Thursday night in a warehouse in west Chelsea is any indication, the era of the big nightclub has returned to New York City. But instead of pierced club kids twirling glow sticks, the legendary Latin dance club that Barry Manilow once called ''the hottest spot north of Havana'' is as squeaky clean as the revitalized 42nd Street.

title: About the Photographs
description: When William Eggleston began the series that he would later name, somewhat misleadingly, ''Los Alamos,'' he was a young photographer known only to insiders and fellow artists, and he had worked only in black and white. In 1965, he decided to experiment with color, photographing scenes in his home city of Memphis. Nine years later, he had traveled throughout the American South and had taken more than 2,000 pictures for the series -- improbably beautiful images of the shards of everyday life, in a striking, unexpected color palette. But despite the strength of the images and support from his fellow artists, most of the series was never displayed or published. The negatives went into storage and, on the whole, stayed there for the next three decades. Eggleston himself can't really say why. ''We kept saying, 'We'll show these,''' he says, but the project, as he puts it, ''remained buried.'' Over that time, however, his work began to attract a great deal of attention, from both collectors and critics. He published several books; he was the subject of close to 100 solo shows; his prints sold for more than $100,000. And yet one large chapter of his career was still all but lost. Recently, accepting an invitation from the Museum Ludwig in Cologne, he returned to the work that had been sitting in storage all that time. He began printing the negatives using the labor-intensive dye-transfer process, which he had been among the first to adapt from advertising to art photography. ''I have seen little proofs through the years,'' he says, ''but not the whole thing. Just recently, now that they've been brought into existence through this process, I've seen them, you could say, for the first time.'' This March, 88 prints from the collection, which will be published in book form by Scalo, will go on display in Germany; later they will travel in Europe and the United States. As for how the images, now so evocative of a lost moment in American culture, have survived the years, Eggleston says: ''I think they look better. It's like seeing some old friends you thought were forever gone.''

title: Drilling For Freedom
description: A funny thing happened in Iran the other day. The official Iranian news agency, IRNA, published a poll on Iranian attitudes toward America, conducted by Iran's National Institute for Research Studies and Opinion Polls. The poll asked 1,500 Iranians whether they favored opening talks with America, and 75 percent said ''yes.'' More interesting, 46 percent said U.S. policies on Iran -- which include an economic boycott and labeling Iran part of an ''axis of evil'' -- were ''to some extent correct.''

title: Keeping Corporate Sponsorships in Tough Times
description: JOHN STRANGFELD, a vice chairman of the Prudential Corporation, kept an eye on the jumping horses a few yards from his luncheon table while keeping up the flow of conversation with guests like the Irish tenor Ronan Tynan and William Clark, the former United States ambassador to Japan and now executive director of the Japan Society.

title: Not Junk, but Treasure
description: WHEN an investor bought the Hillbrook Estate in Harrison two years ago, the cost of fixing the roof alone ran into seven figures, so he decided to demolish the 1916 mansion and build four new buildings on the property. In the short time before the wrecking ball moved in, Recycling the Past, an architectural salvage company in New Jersey, invited buyers to the site and picked the house's carcass clean, carting away an oak staircase with wainscoting and carved panels, a 70-foot limestone balustrade, mantlepieces, marble columns and even door hinges.

title: Mexico City
description: Mexico City can be overwhelming. The largest metropolis in the Western Hemisphere, a mile and a half high, barrages the body and brain. But seen through the right eyes, it is one of the world's great cities: a sublime, occasionally surreal, always sensual place.

title: Island-Shopping at a Tag Sale
description: HAZE RICHARDSON, owner of the classy, low-key Petit St. Vincent resort, on a tiny island in the Grenadines, may be the bravest man in the Caribbean.

But the ruling party revealed a split after it chose the son of the nation's founder as its candidate to replace President Daniel arap Moi, who has ruled Kenya since 1978.

title: Finding Art, And a Cause, In the Forest
description: THE anthropologist Claude Lvi-Strauss once wondered ruefully whether ''pictures could offer something substantial to readers who have never been there.'' The Brazilian photographer Valdir Cruz believes they can. Over the last six years he has traveled the Amazon, photographing people who live in some of the remotest regions of the rain forest, especially the so-called Fierce People, the Yanomami, of northern Brazil and Venezuela. Captured in his current exhibition, at Throckmorton in Manhattan, and a comprehensive book of his photographs, ''Faces of the Rainforest,'' by Mr. Cruz, Kenneth R. Good and Vicki Goldberg (PowerHouse), the ''something substantial'' he has brought back is art. In the process, he has become an aid worker and a political activist, found himself a partner in controversy and discovered someone thought to be dead. And his adventures didn't end when he returned to civilization.

So it is undoubtedly too early to assess how Lorin Maazel and the New York Philharmonic will fare over the four years of his contract. His tenure began only a month ago.

title: A Village In the City Hidden in Plain Sight
description: TUCKED into a sliver of space between two buildings on one of Greenwich Village's many crooked streets, a narrow alleyway is closed to the public by a thin black gate. At the far end of the long claustrophobic passage, the signs of an urban paradise can be glimpsed: a couple of fence posts, the vague edge of a flowering bush and a tease of green leaves hanging from a tall tree.

title: A Proud Product Of the Nick Pipeline

But for the generation that connects the dots of personal growth from Baby Bop to Justin Timberlake via Pokmon, Ms. Bynes is like Lucille Ball, Carol Burnett and Gilda Radner rolled into one 16-year-old package.

description: DIDDEL-Andrew G. 81, on October 12, 2002. Andrew was the husband of Kathryn for 52 years. Survived by four children and their spouses, A. Glenn Diddel III, Roberta, G. Scott Diddel and Susanne, Heather D. Diddel and Sam House, and Katha Diddel Warren and Paul. He was a loving grandfather to Gregory W., Andrew W. and Matthew M. Diddel, and Emily R.D. House, Nathaniel House and Paul D., Thompson A. and Katherine N. Warren. Services Friday, 2 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Family will receive friends at 1 PM on Friday. Contributions in his memory may be made to the West Falmouth Library, P.O. Box 1209, West Falmouth, MA 02574.

title: Teresa Lin, Stephen Lai
description: Teresa Su-Ai Lin, a lawyer, and Dr. Stephen Yenzen Lai, a medical resident, were married yesterday. The Rev. Ronald S. McHatton, a nondenominational Christian minister, officiated at the Abington Art Center in Jenkintown, Pa.

title: Stricter Rules on 'Nonrefundables'
description: SECURITY is not the only thing being tightened up at United States airports these days. Passengers traveling on low-fare tickets will find the airlines are becoming increasingly strict -- most recently, adopting less forgiving rules about making changes to tickets booked with nonrefundable fares.

title: A Language of Light Amid Darkness
description: LATELY, Alfredo Jaar, the Chilean-born installation artist, has been practicing the art of renunciation. For a 1995 exhibition in New York, he famously sealed his photographs of the Rwanda genocide inside black boxes. Since then he has experimented with image deprivation as a kind of visual homeopathy. ''Our society is blind,'' he said in a recent interview in his Manhattan loft. ''We have lost our ability to be affected by imagery.''

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Rapist, Long a Fugitive, Quietly Serves Sentence

title: Turning A Profit With Higher Education
description: HIGHER education pays, but it usually isn't until after graduation that people monetize its value.

title: Millicent Bogert and Scott MacDonald
description: THOUGH she lives on Telegraph Hill in San Francisco, a city where people pride themselves on always being reachable by beeper, cellphone and car phone, Millicent Bogert is deliberately difficult to reach.

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Sarah Deitch, Marc Persily
description: Sarah Jane Deitch, a daughter of Penny and Laurence B. Deitch of Bingham Farms, Mich., was married yesterday to Marc Adam Persily, the son of Linda and Milton P. Persily of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel B. Syme performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.

title: For a Fabled Ship, Lost at Sea, Chances of Local Honor Fade
description: Jubilation swept through Greenpoint on Jan. 30, 1862, the day the ironclad warship Monitor was launched to great fanfare from the Continental Ironworks on the East River waterfront just north of the Bushwick Inlet. The Monitor went on to fight a historic Civil War battle with the Merrimac, and later sank in a storm off Cape Hatteras.

title: The Arches Are Sagging. What Would the Doctors Do?
description: McDONALD'S may serve Happy Meals at its 30,000 sites around the globe, but it's a pretty safe bet that meal times -- and the hours in between -- are less than joyful at the company's headquarters in Oak Brook, Ill. Customers are defecting, franchisees are complaining, and shareholders are fleeing. Mention the Golden Arches on Wall Street, and be prepared for a bunch of ''fallen arches'' jokes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREIBERG, SYLVIA
description: FREIBERG-Sylvia. 7/15/11 10/20/98. Four years of missing her. We can still hear that laugh. The Family

title: Temper Aside, Stewart Closes In on Winston Title
description: CONCORD, N.C. Oct. 19  A few times each week, between testing his cars and traveling to racetracks and driving in Nascar's Winston Cup series, Tony Stewart takes the time to chat with his sports psychologist.

title: The Albany Syndrome: First of Three Articles
description: First of three articles about legislative atrophy in Albany.

title: Pension Accounting Whoppers
description: For all of this year's accounting scandals, one of the most perilous financial minefields may still lie ahead -- corporate America's management of traditional pension plans covering some 45 million Americans. The fate of these funds in the boom-to-bust financial cycle is at once a glaring accounting scandal and a looming threat to the economy.

title: The Hometown Channel
description: REGINA SILVERSMITH likes to say that she battles Katie Couric for ratings every morning and wins, at least in Pleasantville.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Apparently the transfer of the political capital to the banks of the Potomac lo these many years ago still frosts some people. Rich's article is composed of the sort of comments friends from the two cities (or those who move between them) sometimes use to josh one another over the first drink of any reunion. By the second drink, they move on to more substantive and interesting subjects.

title: Punchless Rangers Settle for Tie
description: Offense was supposed to be the Rangers' strong suit this season, but their inability to generate much of it in their 2-2 tie with the Nashville Predators last night led to more boos from the fans at Madison Square Garden.

title: Wendy Morris, Marc Berliner
description: Wendy Alissa Morris, the daughter of Sandra and Kenneth Morris of Melville, N.Y., was married last evening to Marc Andrew Berliner, the son of Randee and Martin Berliner of Mansfield, Conn. Rabbi Steven Sirbu officiated at the Cold Spring Country Club in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARKASH, MORTIMER
description: FARKASH-Mortimer. October 18, 2002. Beloved husband of Doris. Dear brother of Estelle. Devoted uncle of Leslie, Sandra, Robert and Paul. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Sunday, October 20th, 11 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Interment to follow at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Drug Tests Come To Private School
description: ANDREW E. GINDEA, 15, of Lawrence was a little apprehensive when he was called out of class earlier this month and told he had been selected to take a random drug test.

title: Gunman in a Car Kills 2 Men in Bronx
description: Two men were killed in the Soundview section of the Bronx last night in what the police described as random drive-by shootings by someone who hijacked a car earlier in the evening in Fort Lee.

title: Rock and Night Life Revive a Mill Town
description: WHAT you have to remember,'' Tony Wilson declared, ''is just how bad things were here a few years back. It was as if the world was saying, O.K., you were the center of the universe during the Industrial Revolution, you made it all happen, and now thanks very much, you can go down the pan.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANN, JESSE L.
description: VANN-Jesse L. Deceased Thursday at 10 AM. Funeral services Holy Rosary Church on Chauncy St. in Brooklyn.

title: Au Revoir, Africa
description: My parents are missionaries in the Congo Republic. They home-schooled me for a while, but for the last two years, they have sent me to the International Christian Academy near Bouak in Ivory Coast. I'm 16. The school is 1st through 12th, and Nigerians, Liberians, Koreans, Dutch, and kids from other countries go there, but at least 70 percent of the students are Americans like me. It costs more if your parents aren't missionaries, so native families have to be pretty wealthy to send their kids. Over all, the school has a strong American identity. We used to play soccer and basketball with school teams and some clubs from Bouak, but we didn't go off campus often. We had everything we needed. The school is a comfortable place. It's a little America in the middle of West Africa.

title: Q & A
description: No Smoking on Cruises

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, ABRAHAM
description: NEWMAN-Abraham. Died at age 92, after a long, wonderful and happy life, surrounded by his family and friends. ''Poppy'' made his mark on all who knew him because of his warmth, generosity, gentleness and his unique ability to love, care and accept. He had survived his life match Lili, and their life together had been a grand adventure for 59 years. He is survived by his loving family, daughters Vicki and Jessica, sons-in-law Walter and Roger, granddaughters Karen and husband Scott, Amy, Catherine and Rebecca, and great-granddaughters Julie and Lisa. He was a quiet, gentle tower of strength, and all who knew him will miss his sweetness and his smiling face. Funeral services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, at 11 AM, on Sunday, October 20, 2002. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Sturge-Weber Foundation or the Jewish Guild for the Blind.

title: Kerry O'Malley, Adam Heller
description: Kerry O'Malley and Adam Heller, actors, were married on Monday by Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. The Rev. Steven D. Harris, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABANCA, MARGUERITE T.
description: LaBANCA - Marguerite T. Formerly of Whitestone and Manhattan on Saturday, October 19, after a prolonged battle with breast cancer. She is survived by her mother Teresa LaBanca, her two sisters Rose Ann Berardi and Teresa Fuhr and her brother Joseph. She is lovingly remembered by her niece and nephews. Visitation Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue at 70th St. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 10 AM, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 84th St. and Park Avenue, NY, NY. Interment private.

title: Dobbs Ferry Theater Revived For Weekend Nights Out
description: After Bettina Speyer joined Dobbs Ferry's downtown improvement district last year, she observed that the village lacked a magnet to boost area businesses on the weekends.

title: Islanders' Strong Offense Provides Lift for Osgood
description: When Islanders center Jason Wiemer scored a short-handed, unassisted goal with 7 minutes 29 seconds left against the Atlanta Thrashers tonight, his fellow center Dave Scatchard felt sure that the 4-3 lead would hold up.

title: October 13-19: FRONT LINES; STORM CLOUDS IN KOREA
description: East Asia discovered that the world's eighth nuclear power might be in their midst. American diplomats said that they confronted North Korean officials two weeks ago in Pyongyang with evidence that the North has been cheating on a 1994 agreement to forswear nuclear production and development. To their surprise, the North Korean officials first blustered, then admitted it. The confession provoked a conservative backlash in Japan and South Korea, threatening any warming of relations. Just last week, five Japanese citizens kidnapped by North Korean agents in 1978 were allowed to return to Japan for one week. James Brooke

title: Dance Listings
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER  World premieres and a tribute to George Harrison. City Center, 131 W. 55th St. (212-581-1212) Today, next Sun., 2 and 7:30; Tue.-Fri., 8; Sat., 2 and 8. Through next Sun. A related article is on Page 8.

description: Weekend Retreat

title: As Bodies Start Coming Home, Australians Criticize Leaders
description: After an agonizing weeklong wait, the first bodies have finally begun returning home after the terror attack in Bali, and angry Australians are asking hard questions about everything from their intelligence service to the country's foreign policy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 56 of The Times Magazine today about Karl Rove, adviser to President Bush, misstates the vote percentage by which Mr. Bush lost to Al Gore in California. It was 12 percent, not 13.
