description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Oakland's Howe Explains Discussions With Mets
description: There but for Lou Piniella goes Art Howe right into the manager's office of the home clubhouse at Shea Stadium. But with the Mets focused on putting Piniella in that office, Howe withdrew from consideration earlier this week and resigned himself to managing out his contract in Oakland next season.

title: Ad Against Indian Point Plant Is Off, and On
description: A coalition of groups that advocate closing the Indian Point nuclear plant say that Gov. George E. Pataki's office recently held talks with its members concerning the plant and an ongoing review of its safety, prompting one group to withdraw a television ad pressuring the governor.

title: Stacey Rosenfelt, David Lubliner
description: Stacey Ellen Rosenfelt, a daughter of Nancy Rosenfelt and Dr. Fred Rosenfelt of Los Angeles, was married yesterday evening to David Mark Lubliner, a son of Phyllis and Murray Lubliner of New York. Rabbi Dennis J. Eisner officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Huntington Hotel in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENOIT, WOODROW FRANCIS ''WOODY,''
description: BENOIT-Woodrow Francis ''Woody,'' a 44 year resident of Ridgewood, NJ, died at home on October 17, 2002. Woody was born in Edgewater, NJ June 18, 1917. He served as a Captain in the U.S. Army 1941-1945. After leaving a decorated military career, Woody attended Syracuse University graduating Magna Cum Laude. Woody was a Charter Member and President of the reinstated Delta Tau Delta fraternity. Woody was a pioneer in the production of television advertising with J. Walter Thompson. As Vice-President, Woody coordinated the production of ''The Ed Sullivan Show,'' ''The Life of Reilly,'' ''Ozzie and Harriet,'' ''The Real McCoys,'' and ''Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color.'' Woody viewed his greatest success as becoming lifelong friends with his clients. Woody then started a successful travel business focusing on corporate incentive and sales meetings. Upon retirement at 78, Woody became a well-loved volunteer at Valley Hospital & Valley Home Health. Woody is survived by his beloved wife of 53 years Caroline, his sons Peter and Stephen and daughter Caron, grandchildren Marc, Courtney & Leah and Omega. If you had the pleasure of meeting Woody you would never forget him. He will be sorely missed. Memorial Mass will be Monday 10:45AM at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ. Donations to the Valley Hospital EMS Service, Linwood and N. Van Dien Aves, Ridgewood, NJ 07450, would be appreciated by the family. For information, contact the Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ.

title: The Commish
description: To the Editor:

title: Foo Fighters Still, Only Less Ferocious
description: Who could have guessed that Nirvana would spawn a band that was long on consistency and short on excitement?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 56 of The Times Magazine today about Karl Rove, adviser to President Bush, misstates the vote percentage by which Mr. Bush lost to Al Gore in California. It was 12 percent, not 13.

title: From Its Palaces, Iraq's View Is of a World Filled With Allies
description: As Iraq confronts the possibility of a new war with the United States, its leaders appear to have concluded that they have one decisive advantage that they lacked during the countdown to the Persian Gulf war 12 years ago: this time, they seem convinced, the world is on their side and against the United States.

description: 4-bedroom, 2-bath Cape at 15 Albert Street, $310,000.

description: CUOMO-Carmela. On October 18, 2002. Loving sister of Michael. Sister-in-law of Elaine. Fond aunt of Jenifer, Michael and Christopher. Grandaunt of Jenifer and Matthew. She lived for others and will be deeply missed. Reposing at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th St, NYC, Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Agnes Church, 143 East 43th St, NYC. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY.

title: Nicole Elliott, Benjamin Selzer
description: Nicole Kristen Elliott, the daughter of Donna and William H. Elliott of Chicago, was married last evening to Benjamin Adrian Selzer, the son of Linda Warren Simon of San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, and the late Benson A. Selzer. The Rev. John J. Wall performed the ceremony at Old St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago, with Rabbi Allen Secher taking part.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUILLI, EMMANUEL NICHOLAS BERNARDINO
description: CHUILLI-Emmanuel Nicholas Bernardino. September 29, 1911-September 3, 2002. Born in Valhalla, NY. Served in the United States Navy in World War II. Graduate of New York University 1948B.S. in Marketing. Member of the Alpha Delta Sigma fraternity. Worked for many years at the New York School of Printing. 30 + year veteran of the New York Times (1944-1977). Retired to North Palm Beach, Florida in 1977. Husband of the late Dorothy Hyde Chuilli (married 1944-1983). He is survived by three children: Joel Chuilli, Ann Raymer and John Chuilli, four grandchildren: Jessica Raymer Sbordi, James Raymer, Melissa Chuilli and Stephen Chuilli. Siblings: Agilda Antoinette Chuilli Fisher, Thomas Chuilli and Ernest Chuilli. Services were held at St. Paul of the Cross Church in North Palm Beach, Florida on September 6, 2002.

title: 'Memoirs'
description: There is a picture of all the men in the family waiting at the Tarrytown station for the train carrying Grandfather's casket from his winter home in Ormond Beach, Florida. He died quietly in his bed on May 23, 1937, at the age of ninety-seven. While the official cause of death was sclerotic myocarditis, it would be simpler to say he died of old age. I had known him as "Grandfather," not the "robber baron" or great philanthropist of the history books. He had been a constant presence in my childhood: benign, indulgent, revered by my father, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and by the family as a whole.

title: Fresh Eye on a Jaded Slice of New York
description: IT'S a confident director who is willing to take the major theme of his film and whip it past his audience like a Pedro Martinez fastball before the moviegoers have managed to get their Peanut Chews unwrapped. Yet in ''Roger Dodger,'' 33-year-old Dylan Kidd, directing his first feature from his first screenplay, does exactly that.

title: Left Behind
description: Of course every accused person, even Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, deserves representation by a defense lawyer. But there is something Lynne Stewart should grasp: helping the sheik will do nothing to promote self-determination in Egypt. If she believes she is furthering Egypt's welfare by helping him, she is far off in her reckoning. Abdel Rahman may be anti-imperialist, but he is no national liberator. To be governed by his ilk would be disastrous for that country.

title: 9/11 Survival Spurs A First Marathon Run
description: WHEN she was 13, Laura Katen's father, Ronald, said, ''Let's go for a jog.'' They did, for a mile and a half along the Boston Post Road near their Mamaroneck home.

title: Serving Up Laughter As the Main Course
description: DANCE rehearsals can be deadly serious, especially when an opening night is around the corner. Just the other day, David Parsons assembled the members of the Parsons Dance Company in a fifth-floor studio at City Center to put one last coat of polish on ''Too Many Cooks!,'' a new piece that will receive its New York premiere on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater.

title: October 13-19; COMING UP
description: President Bush plans to meet with the NATO secretary general at the White House. He will campaign for Republican candidates, with trips to Pennsylvania, Maine, North and South Carolina and Alabama. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will attend an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Mexico. Mr. Bush will meet with the president of China at Mr. Bush's ranch in Crawford, Tex. Congress will be on its election recess until Nov. 12.

title: Pluses and Minuses
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Guides
description: To the Editor:

title: Fading Into History
description: LINDA Macfarlane, ne Feuer, stood on East Houston Street and looked stunned as she peered south at the sleek bistros and boutiques lining Orchard Street. ''It's all gone,'' she whispered to her husband as she clutched his arm. ''What happened?''

title: The World: Defining Al Qaeda; 'They're Coming After Us.' But Who Are They Now?
description: FROM Lackawanna, N.Y., to Bali, officials use the words Al Qaeda to explain the potential threat or the grisly reality of almost anything resembling a terrorist attack, potential anti-government plot or suspected sleeper cell. The message is heavily coated with fear.

title: Out There Somewhere: Halloween's Bright Side
description: HALLOWEEN may not arrive until Oct. 31, but in recent years its tendrils have seemed to be extending backward: masks, costumes and candy corn appear the minute the weather says fall. Halloween has even insinuated itself into the fabric of harvest festivals: traditional hayrides and haunted houses are now conflated into haunted hayrides, which are available all over the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN FELIX, WILLIAM
description: VAN FELIX-William. Human rights activist, longtime Greenwich Village resident, died peacefully October 8, 2002 at age 86.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Over the last year, people have held the odd notion that not gushing openly about New York City was somehow wrong, even un-American. In fact, Frank Rich holds up Carrie from ''Sex and the City'' as a paragon of patriotism for turning down a sailor after he dissed her town in this season's ''poignant'' first episode. I would now like to declare this sappy and sentimental era over.

title: Now That the Mail's Arriving, Have a Slice of Birthday Cake
description: In the annals of New York celebrations, this one will go down as one of the more esoteric. This weekend, Co-op City is holding a 25th birthday party, complete with cake and a 20-member marching band, for its post office. Although customer appreciation days occur occasionally in ZIP codes around the city, an actual celebration is highly unusual.

title: Round Hill Changes Its Image
description: MY identity crisis came as I sat in a darkened cabana, listening to reggae-infused New Age music and sipping iced ginger tea, trying to decide between the pineapple body scrub and the de-stress aromatherapy massage. It wasn't the choice of body treatment that had set off my introspection. Rather, it was the realization that I, someone who had always traveled either for adventure or culture, was lazing about one of the Caribbean's toniest resorts and not feeling a bit guilty about it. Bring on the pineapple scrub.

title: Rethinking the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Perilous Drive
description: To the Editor: A recent report ''Lisbon-to-Algarve Road Is Now Complete'' (Travel Advisory, Sept. 15) by Benjamin Jones on the opening of the final section of the A2 highway in Portugal brought to mind my drive down from Lisbon to the Algarve some 30 years ago.

title: Paintbrushes in Hand (And Dodging Soccer Balls)
description: It is safe to say that Claude Monet never had to contend with oversize police trucks blocking his view of Rouen Cathedral. He also probably avoided errant soccer balls from nearby playgrounds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIRSHNER, NATALIE B.
description: KIRSHNER-Natalie B. May 29, 1920 to October 19, 2001. Love never dies, I am yours forever and miss you. Herbert

title: Showcase for a Team That's on the Block
description: The ''for sale'' signs are not visible at Edison Field this weekend. Wise decision. How tacky would it be for someone to have a team in the World Series for the first time in its 42-year history and be blatantly trying to sell it at the same time?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, TERRY
description: HOLLAND-Terry. Died on October 12, 2002 at age 36, after a brief illness. A partner with Financial Investment Partners LLC, Terry sat on the Board of Stonewall Community Foundation and was active in Empire State Pride Agenda. Devoted partner to Michael Dunn and to Brian Thompson, loving friend to many. Terry will be remembered by all who knew him, both personally and professionally, for the gift he had for bringing people together and the joy he found in sharing that gift. Larger than life in our memories, he will live on forever in our hearts. Contributions in his memory may be made to Stonewall Community Foundation, 119 West 24 Street, NY, NY 10011.

title: SCHOOL MERGER PLAN
description: Governor McGreevey announced a plan last week that would merge three of the state's public research schools to create one statewide university system. The 114-page proposal, written by a commission appointed by Mr. McGreevey seven months ago, would combine the New Jersey Institute of Technology, the University of Medicine and Dentistry, and Rutgers University to create the University of New Jersey. The proposed 65,000-student university would be split with campuses in Newark, New Brunswick, and Camden. John Holl

description: To the Editor:

title: In Hollywood, Rudeness to Make an Oscar Blink
description: IT started as a typical industry evening: a small but select dinner given by Sony Pictures at the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado this year. Invitations went out to a handful of high-profile guests, including Salman Rushdie and Peter O'Toole. Acceptances came in, and a table was reserved at a local restaurant.

title: Six-Day Layoff Has Not Cooled Off Angels' Glaus
description: The San Francisco Giants put two runs on the board in the second and the sixth innings in Game 1 of the World Series tonight. For a few moments, the red ThunderStix stopped making noise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOONEY, EDWARD
description: NOONEY-Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward Nooney, associated with The Times from 1969 until retiring in 2000.

title: Brazil's Presidential Election Reflects Power of So Paulo
description: The rest of the country may not like it much, but for the first time in Brazilian history a presidential election has come down to this: two candidates from So Paulo, representing parties that were created in So Paulo and that draw their largest support from So Paulo, battling to succeed a president who is from So Paulo.

description: The American Legion says its request to Congress could not have been simpler -- or less controversial.

description: Karen Risa Frome and Nathaniel Ezra Oppenheimer were married last night at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing, Queens, by Bernard H. Jackson, a retired justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan

description: Thus far in Columbia's mostly disappointing season, the Lions have looked capable of beating every team on their schedule during the first 30 minutes. But in the second half, they have been unable to stop anybody.

description: THE area of Suffolk County's town of Brookhaven known as Shoreham consists of two quite different communities that share a ZIP code, a school district and a name usually associated with a failed nuclear power plant.

title: As Its Past Is Exhumed, Russia Turns Away
description: ''They would drive them here and turn down this track,'' Aleksandra A. Reznikova said as she hiked into the woods deep within this military preserve northeast of St. Petersburg.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When people start writing about New York, they tend to go get a thesaurus and find all the synonyms for dysfunctional.''

title: The Vatican Is Rejecting an Erosion of Authority
description: During the months that Vatican officials pored over the American bishops' zero-tolerance policy on child sexual abuse, they found much that troubled them, including ways in which they felt that innocent priests might be sacrificed to runaway public suspicion.

title: October 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; MYSTERIOUS FINNISH BOMBING
description: The police in Finland said they might never know why Petri Gerdt, a 19-year-old college student obsessed with explosions and with the late gangsta rapper Tupac Shakur, decided to set off a bomb on Oct. 11 in a crowded shopping mall north of Helsinki.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: JAKE GANDER

title: Island in an Uproar
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I Stink!' and Other Children's Books
description: I STINK!

title: Stepping Out In Stepford Style
description: LAST month at the spring 2003 collections in New York, designers, with varying degrees of distance, took as their inspiration the sort of woman for whom the word homemaker is not freighted with all kinds of ill meaning. Many dresses were turned out in Easter egg colors, fruit prints and, in the case of Donna Karan's show, exaggerated hourglass shapes.

title: Tracing Bullets
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Your Everyday Everyman
description: ''I'LL be mother,'' Timothy Spall says, pouring the tea in a quiet cafe. The line is common British parlance for the designated server, but it sounds rather arch coming from the 45-year-old Mr. Spall, a Mike Leigh regular known for his riveting, poignant portrayals of everyday slobs in films like ''Secrets and Lies'' (1996) and ''Life Is Sweet'' (1990). In their latest collaboration, ''All or Nothing,'' which was shown in competition at the 2002 Cannes Film Festival and opens on Friday, he plays Phil, a downtrodden cab driver who lives with his wife and two children in a bleak London housing project.

title: Can One Man Make a Difference?
description: HE is an ambassador for Hartford, the one who cuts the ribbons and gives the interviews. He is the man who presides over city government, opening meetings in the high-ceilinged chamber at City Hall from the power seat, flanked on either side by members of the City Council. His are perhaps the most visible shoulders to carry the hopes of this beleaguered city, but under law, the mayor of Hartford is little more than a figurehead, a man who can't even change the time of trash pick up without approval from nine council members.

title: Shannon Kelley, David Loeb
description: Shannon Marie Kelley, a daughter of Florrie Kelley of Atlanta and James Kelley of Annapolis, Md., was married last evening to David Jonathan Loeb, the son of Linda and Michael Loeb of Sharon, Mass. Rabbi Marc S. Jagolinzer officiated at the Castle Hill Inn in Newport, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, ARTHUR J.
description: FRIEDMAN-Arthur J. On October 15, 2002 in his 86th year. Cherished husband of Marjorie. Adored father of Stephanie Friedman Melikian. Beloved grandfather of Noah and Ara Melikian. Caring father-in-law to Harrout Melikian, M.D. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, on Sunday, October 27 at 1 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: The Strong Pull of Romare Bearden
description: ONE of Romare Bearden's attributes is his dependability. He took the art of collage to new heights, so viewers at a Bearden exhibition anticipate they will encounter works that advance this genre. The physical materials he uses make fresh juxtapositions; he amalgamates unusual photographic images and plain bits of paper, for example. But technique is only part of his appeal. It is used in the service of an imagination with a large compass.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: LONDON THANKSGIVING -- Take $25 off when booking online for Virgin Atlantic's three-night Thanksgiving holiday packages to London that include air fare from New York (Kennedy or Newark Liberty) and Boston. The dates are Nov. 27 to Dec. 1, and rates before the online discount start at about $600 a person, based on double occupancy. That price includes airport transfers in London, three nights in the 783-room Strand Palace Hotel near Covent Garden, daily Continental breakfast, hotel taxes and service charges, wine tastings and airport departure and security fees; (888) 937-8474 or www.virgin.com/vacations.

title: Friends, Colleagues, Elevators
description: ELVIS lives.

title: Sandra Eisenberg, Steven Krulwich
description: Sandra Beth Eisenberg, the daughter of Barbara and Michael Eisenberg of Great Neck, N.Y., are to be married today at her parents' house to Steven Levine Krulwich, a son of Maxine and Lewis Krulwich of Summit, N.J. Rabbi William Horn will officiate.

title: Cellphones on Road: Still a Presence?
description: I was taken aback to read the Suffolk County legislator Jon Cooper's comment [''D.W.D. Means Driving While Distracted,'' Oct. 13] that the state prohibition on cellphone use while driving was ''going well,'' immediately followed by his observation that the law continues to be defied ''on the L.I.E. or state parkways,'' as if this were the only failure in compliance. This simply does not reflect reality. One continues to see violators on every corner, on both single and multilane roadways throughout the Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPOSSELA, CAROLEE (CAPPY)
description: CAPOSSELA-Carolee (Cappy). Lyricist, author and advertising creative director, died at her home Thursday, October 17, 2002, following a nine-month battle with brain cancer. She was a copywriter at Y&R, DFS, Geer DuBois and creative director at Ketchum Advertising and Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, where she developed fragrance concepts for Coty, including !ex-cla-mation, Ici, Longing, Dark Vanilla, Celebrate, Avatar and Stetson Country. As lyricist and songwriter, her first hit, ''When The Heat Hits the Street'' was recorded by Laura Branigan and she wrote the theme song ''A Place at the Table.'' Cappy co-authored the book ''Share the Care: How to Organize a Group to Care for Someone Who Is Seriously Ill'' (Simon & Schuster). The book has become an essential tool for families and caregivers around the world, including the American Cancer Society, ALS Foundation and hundreds of other organizations. In the past two years Cappy devoted herself fulltime to working on Broadway musicals. Her first show, ''Grail,'' is scheduled to be produced in London early next year and her final project, ''The Courtesan,'' is currently in development. She is survived by her brother, Jim, of Ossining; mother, Josephine, of Sleepy Hollow and the loving friends of her ''Brain Trust.'' A mass will be held at Holy Cross Church in Tarrytown, NY Monday, October 21, at 10 AM. A Memorial Service will be held at The Players Club on Thursday, October 24, at 3:30 PM. In lieu of gifts, contributions can be made to the Share The Care Foundation by contacting attorney Marc Bailin at Rubin, Bailin, Ortoli, Mayer & Baker, 212-935-0900.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: CosmoCom Leads Growth Among High-Tech Firms

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on Oct. 6, about the phrase ''off the dime,'' misspelled the surname of a writer who used a variation of the phrase in a 1926 novel. He was Carl Van Vechten, not Vechter.

title: Golisano Withdraws Ads To Protest Debate Format
description: Tom Golisano, the wealthy businessman running for governor, has withdrawn his advertisements from a Syracuse television station to protest the format of a candidates' debate the station will hold today.

title: Partying Like It's 1999
description: IT was another exhausting night for David Dobkin. Last Wednesday, on the dance floor at Suite 16 in Chelsea, Mr. Dobkin, 23, twirled and dipped various pretty young things with the panache of a man who had charmed women on many previous evenings on many similar dance floors. He was not quite sweating. Rather, he glowed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, PAUL
description: MILLER-Paul. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Paul Miller, associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1992.

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Oct. 6 for a picture of Jacques Steinberg, author of ''The Gatekeepers,'' about college admissions, misspelled the photographer's name. He is Ozier Muhammad, not Muhammud.

title: The Price of Your Own Money Is Going Up
description: For consumers, the cost of using a bank card can really add up. Surcharges levied by banks for automated teller machine transactions are expected to total $2.3 billion this year, up 44 percent from 1998, according to Bankrate.com.

title: Investment Choices And Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Their Initiation Over, Kings' Time Is Now
description: To many observers, it had to go down the way it did. The Sacramento Kings were too green, too inexperienced, too fresh to win a National Basketball Association title last season. Like the Chicago Bulls of Michael Jordan and the Detroit Pistons Bad Boys, they had to lose a series they should probably have won before being fitted for rings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUSTIN, HELEN
description: AUSTIN-Helen. The HewlettEast Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Helen Austin and extends heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Leonard & the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Ferne Skiba, President

title: Weekend Retreat
description: To the Editor: ''Of Sun, Sand and Money'' (Aug. 11) described the German island of Sylt as a weekend retreat and a place to relax at the beach and enjoy the sun. My great-uncle, Siegfried Wolffberg, and his wife, Rosa, enjoyed vacationing in Westerland, its principal city, in the 1910's. This photograph is of Siegfried in Westerland in 1913. Almost 100 years later the beach's attraction remains unchanged, although luckily beach attire has not.

title: Restlessness Growing At Work, Surveys Say
description: Is America becoming a nation of malcontent workers? Maybe not, although two studies released last week suggest a growing restlessness.

title: The Nation: The Central Park Jogger; An Old Case in a Different New York
description: THIRTEEN years ago, a 28-year-old Manhattan investment banker jogging in Central Park was raped, beaten and left for dead. The brutality, randomness and site of the attack became emblematic not only of a city spun out of control but of intractable racial polarization.

title: My Left Foot (Both of Them)
description: LONG ISLAND loves to dance, but I don't. There are more than 100 dance studios in Nassau and Suffolk, teaching everything from hip-hop to belly dancing. But I had avoided them all, until now.

title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NONFICTION
description: AFTERGLOW:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMORA, ELIZABETH ANNE
description: COMORA-Elizabeth Anne. On October 18, 2002 of Lodi, NJ. Cherished daughter of Rose and the late Dr. Herman Comora. Devoted mother of Roger Lance Comora. Dear sister of Constance Greenfield and the late Susan Rosenfeld. Service on Sunday at 12:30 PM, at ''Gutterman Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to the ASPCA.

title: Victoria Gallarello, Richard Alcock III
description: Victoria Angela Gallarello, a daughter of Josephine and John R. Gallarello of Kings Park, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard J. Alcock III, a son of Therese Alcock of Yonkers and the late Mr. Alcock Jr. The Rev. Francis Vattakudiyil, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Latin Jolt to the Skyline
description: THE redevelopment of Times Square has finally produced a building worth talking about: the new Westin Hotel on Eighth Avenue between 42nd and 43rd Streets. And people are talking about it for a welcome reason. The Westin has raised a flag over the issue of taste. Translation: many people find it ugly. Hideous. The very embodiment of beauty's evil twin.

title: Cellphones on Road: Still a Presence?
description: A study published in August 2002 by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety found widespread compliance with New York's law banning hand-held cellphones while driving. The institute's research data, derived from observations at intersections, shows that the hand-held cellphone use rate for drivers decreased by more than 52 percent.

title: Pamela Schwarz, Michael Pock
description: Pamela Janette Schwarz, a daughter of Andrea and George Schwarz of Wantagh, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Pock, the son of Harriet Klinghoffer Bishins of Delray Beach, Fla., and Ronald Pock of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Mark Greenspan officiated at the Oceanside Jewish Center in Oceanside, N.Y.

title: POLICE CHIEF UNDER FIRE
description: Governor McGreevey last week defended the state police superintendent, Joseph J. Santiago, as new questions arose about his background. Mr. Santiago, who has been in political trouble several times, faced new problems after several New Jersey newspapers reported that unnamed informants told state police detectives that Mr. Santiago was friendly with an organized crime figure. At a news conference last week, Mr. McGreevey angrily dismissed the reports, saying they were based on ''rumor and innuendo.'' The governor said the attorney general had reviewed the detectives' reports during Mr. Santiago's confirmation hearings and had determined they were groundless. Mr. Santiago, the former Newark police director, was the most controversial of the governor's top appointments last winter. During a stormy confirmation process, opponents cited Mr. Santiago's short temper as well as an old assault case and tax problems in his background. Mr. Santiago was already facing problems last week related to internal state police reports. After published reports surfaced that he had requested internal investigative files regarding himself and staff members, the governor announced that the Office of Government Integrity would review whether the request violated state rules. John Sullivan

title: Democrats See a Stealthy Drive by Drug Industry to Help Republicans
description: In important Congressional races around the country, a fierce battle is being waged over what Democrats assert is a stealth campaign by the pharmaceutical industry to help House Republicans.

title: Born to Be Mild
description: MEMOIRS

title: The Right Man for the Record
description: Sometimes her telephone will ring and there will be someone on the line who just wants to reminisce. Other times, people will recognize her on the street and stop her to say how much they loved her husband, as two elderly women did a few weeks ago.

title: CRIME
description: It takes a writer as good as Magdalen Nabb to remind us how subtle the art of the mystery can be. She does make it look easy, though, in SOME BITTER TASTE (Soho, $23), the 12th police procedural in her spare, elegant series set in Florence and featuring Salva Guarnaccia, a self-effacing police marshal who oversees the district carabinieri from his quarters in the Pitti Palace. It's high summer in the city (''there were no words to describe Florence in July''), and streams of bewildered tourists and troubled locals flow through his modest office, including a good-natured Albanian prostitute who wants to keep a young friend out of the business; an elderly Jewish woman with an incoherent story about being robbed (of what, she won't say) by a shadowy intruder in her apartment; and the marshal's superior officer, who asks him to drop everything and investigate a petty burglary at the villa of an English aristocrat.

title: A Desperate, or Hopeful, Act
description: To the Editor:

title: October 13-19: NATIONAL; PLEA BY IMCLONE CHIEF
description: Samuel D. Waksal, the founder and former chief executive of ImClone Systems, pleaded guilty to six of 13 insider trading, fraud and conspiracy charges. Dr. Waksal, who faces at least seven to nine years in prison, did not promise to testify against others who sold ImClone shares in December, just before a critical announcement sent the share price plummeting. But his partial plea is thought to be a bid for leniency when he is sentenced early next year, and any information he provides between now and then would be taken into account. Among the people under investigation are his friend Martha Stewart, who has said her sale of ImClone shares on Dec. 27 was ''entirely lawful.'' Constance L. Hays

title: At a Village Crossroads, Sushi and More
description: SUSHI MIKE'S sits on Main Street, U.S.A. (or at least Dobbs Ferry's version of it); it features jazz and blues recordings to dine by; it offers a specialty roll called American Hero; and it hangs a framed print of Madama Butterfly -- all of which calls into question the spirit of the place: Eastern or Western?

title: In Wading River, Steaks Are Way to Go
description: BLACKWELLS is a smart-looking new dining destination in Wading River. Situated in the clubhouse of the Great Rock Golf Club, its attractive dining room features a wall of floor-to-ceiling windows that provide views of the course. A second wall is filled with wooden wine racks, while another is painted butter yellow. This sunny milieu also includes shining wood floors, green leather banquettes and white wrought-iron chandeliers with a pineapple motif.

title: The World; Ipanema Under Siege: Rio's Gangs Flex Harder
description: AS voters here pick Brazil's president next Sunday, they can expect to have more than the usual election observers watching them. The governor of the state of Rio de Janeiro has asked that the soldiers who patrolled the streets here during the first round of voting on Oct. 6 be deployed again to protect citizens from the threat that criminal gangs will interfere with the election.

title: Private Sector; Edsel Ford, Consultant With a Bankroll
description: Edsel B. Ford II is stretching his wings again.

title: A Lesson in Unintended Consequences
description: In his article, James Traub (Oct. 6) talks of the fraud, mismanagement and educational ignorance of local board members. No one can deny this. What is missing from his piece is the cause. It is twofold. First, the legislation that established community-school boards and the complex voting process was created with considerable input from the United Federation of Teachers. What we in the community wanted was a school board elected by parents with children in the public schools. It was the union and the politicians who insisted that all registered voters, plus parents, be eligible. Traub does concede that the parents in the schools know good education when they see it, as witness the support that Kathy Cashin has received from parents in the face of opposition by politicians.

title: Business; Shareholders Rise Up (In Wild West Fashion)
description: SHAREHOLDERS who think they've been wronged in the corporate fraud scandals are beginning to adopt a form of frontier justice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACHFELD, MARTY
description: BRACHFELD-Marty. Died October 17, 2002. Beloved husband to Brenda, father to Barry and Marcy, beloved father-in-law to Elissa and Michael, and beloved grandfather to Harrison. Services Sunday, 10 AM, Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Urology Department.

title: Look Again: Aztek Visits Beauty Shop
description: GRETA VAN SUSTERAN got one. Jocelyne Wildenstein had several. And last year, the Pontiac Aztek received a face lift at the tender age of 1.

title: A Chef's Dream: To Stir Yonkers
description: PETER KELLY, culinary king of the suburbs with four high-flying restaurants in Rockland and Putnam Counties, is preparing to close the crown jewel of his empire on Jan. 1, 2003, and open a new venture on the waterfront in Yonkers, near industrial lots where commuter buses sigh and people push shopping carts piled with their personal belongings.

title: Channel Islands
description: To the Editor: In ''Channel Islands Tours'' (Q & A, Sept. 29) the author, Ray Cormier, was unable to find any tour operators in the United States who offer tours to the Channel Islands.

title: Miranda Daniloff, Peter Mancusi Jr.
description: Miranda Daniloff and Peter J. Mancusi Jr. are to be married in Boston today at the home of Cathleen and James M. Stone, friends of the bride's family. Mr. Stone has received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Regime Change
description: A friend of mine recently dined with a Japanese couple who had just returned from Disney World and loved it. ''What did you like most?'' she asked. The couple laughed to beat the band, and the husband said, ''All the fat people!''

title: Indonesia Suggests a Cleric Had No Part in the Attack in Bali
description: After arresting a militant Muslim cleric who has been linked to Al Qaeda and a series of terrorist attacks in Southeast Asia, Indonesian officials have indicated that he is not a suspect in the bombing of two nightclubs in Bali a week ago.

title: Beneath White House Optimism, Unease Lurks
description: LIKE most Bush administration aides, R. Glenn Hubbard eagerly lists reasons to be optimistic about the economy. Incomes are rising, and consumer spending should follow, he says. The housing market is expected to avoid sharp price declines, thanks in part to low interest rates. The Federal Reserve, keenly aware of Japan's problems, will act forcefully if deflation threatens.

title: Internal Politics
description: I am a state legislator. This last session I had an excellent student intern. But at the end of his stint, he announced that he was running against me and had intended to for some time. (He had total access to my office, files, etc., but there is no evidence that he misused that.) The director of the internship program was horrified, probably worrying about the willingness of legislators to accept interns in the future. Are we being too sensitive? Should I have been more alert to this possibility? Phyllis Kahn, Minneapolis

title: Stepping Up to the Challenge of Illiteracy
description: ''SHE came when she was 21 years old and it took her a long time because she had to cross the border,'' Christian Hernandez said. ''She had to ride on horses and she had to cross over a river on horses. She was scared that she would fall off.''

title: One Man's Jacket
description: More than 30 of the women photographed for this column over the last three weeks in Paris and New York were wearing a shirred black evening jacket with velvet trim. It is not often that a single creation of one designer appeals so widely. The jacket, from Saint Laurent, is by Tom Ford (in oval with Cate Blanchett), designer of the year at the VH1/Vogue Fashion Awards, taking a fresh look here at femininity with soft dressmaking details. One version has sleeves falling off the shoulders, creating a portrait neckline. While almost all are black silk with velvet trim, Anna Wintour, second from far right, wore a complete suit of midnight velvet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENGARD, JEROME HARRY CLASTER
description: LOWENGARD-Jerome Harry Claster, 77. Of West Hartford, CT, on October 17, 2002. He leaves his wife of 51 years, Elaine Title Lowengard, his children, Mary and Sarah of NYC, Henry and wife Nancy Graham of Kingston, NY, Benjamin and wife Susan Cohen of Watertown, MA, Alexander of West Hartford, and Jeremiah and wife Sheila of South Portland, ME, and six grandchildren. Memorial service Monday, October 21, 3 PM, Congregation Beth Israel, 701 Farmington Ave., West Hartford. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Endowment Foundation of the Greater Hartford Jewish Federation, Hartford Stage Co., or Connecticut Forest and Parks Association.

title: Sooners Fell Another Heisman Hopeful
description: It didn't look fair. Iowa State quarterback Seneca Wallace, once upon a time a Heisman Trophy candidate, could not find a safe spot on the field today against the marauding Oklahoma defense. His running backs and his receivers were hemmed in, too, as the scoreboard in Memorial Stadium kept a running count of the frustration.

title: The Real Paradox: Musical Comedy Made in France
description: A MUSICAL comedy that does well in France is already something of an occasion. A French musical comedy that reaches Broadway -- well, ''Irma la Douce'' was the last to do so, in 1960. So ''Amour,'' which opens tonight at the Music Box Theater after a month of previews, is a happening, if not also a gamble. The French-language version, ''Le Passe-Muraille,'' ran for a year in Paris in 1997. Will this sung-through romantic fairy tale go down as well in English?

title: An Old Idea, Still Rolling: Fewer Cars in the Park
description: Sunday in the park with your car will be a lot less frequent if a group of anti-auto activists succeed in their campaign to ban auto traffic from the two long looping roads in Central Park. The group, Car-Free Central Park, wants the East and West Drives, popular with joggers and bicyclists, entirely off limits to cars. The four east-west transverses, which were designed for traffic, would stay open to vehicles.

title: Remembrance of Baseballs Past
description: To the Editor:

title: October 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; SMUGGLING DEATHS
description: A grain elevator operator made a grisly discovery in a small farming town in southwest Iowa. He opened a rail car and found the remains of 11 people whom authorities believe were Mexican immigrants trying to enter the U.S. through a smuggling operation. The state medical examiner has determined that the four women and seven men died of hypothermia and dehydration related to the extremely hot temperatures inside the airtight car. John W. Fountain

title: He's Got a List
description: WORTH THE FIGHTING FOR

title: A Case of Hard Luck
description: To the Editor:

title: Reverse Engineering
description: AMERICAN GROUND

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Why the tirade? Sore winner? Your point? Washington is not New York City? New York is not Green Bay or Altoona or San Diego or Anaheim either. Thank goodness! How many cities like New York do we need, or want?

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Doda, Kashmir, Oct. 8, 2002

title: Rachel Schifter, Robin Thebault
description: Rachel Larkin Schifter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Schifter of Washington, was married yesterday to Robert Everett Thebault, a son of Lesley Schmidt and a stepson of Robert M. Schmidt of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Elizabeth Orens, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul in Washington, with Rabbi Harold S. White taking part.

title: Shoreham Group's Stand On Open Space
description: ''Shoreham Steps Back From the Brink'' [Oct. 13] states that the Shoreham Civic Organization ''favors industrial development of the town's largest tract of undeveloped land.'' The civic group does not favor industrial development of the wooded, 833-acre KeySpan property. As I said in the article, ''We would prefer if it were left undeveloped. But we need to have a plan in place in case the land is sold.''

title: Back in Anaheim, Snow Torments His Old Team
description: J. T. Snow grew up 20 minutes from the Angels' home stadium. When he was old enough to drive, he would come to games with his friends, buy cheap tickets and sneak down to the good seats when the other fans left. He would grow up to have an even better view, becoming an everyday major leaguer as the Angels' first baseman in the mid-1990's.

title: October 13-19: INTERNATIONAL; AUTISM ON RISE
description: California is experiencing an epidemic in autism -- a brain disorder that affects a person's ability to form basic human relationships -- and no one knows why. A report sent to the state legislature said that 20 years ago autism was diagnosed in fewer than 1,000 children in California. As of July 2002, autism was found in 18,460 children and adults. The report ruled out genetics and vaccines as primary causes of the increase. The extent of childhood autism in other states is unclear but clinicians and educators around the country say that they are being swamped by new cases. Sandra Blakeslee

title: The De Facto Capital
description: It is true that Mayor Giuliani's leadership on Sept. 11 was worthy of an American president. But Frank Rich's observation that President Bush was ''nowhere to be found'' is both factually false and a cheap shot. President Bush spoke publicly about the attacks as early as 9:30 a.m. from Sarasota, Fla. The president's subsequent statements that day are equally well documented, including his pledge, given from Barksdale Air Force Base in Louisiana, to ''hunt down and punish those responsible for these cowardly acts.'' He addressed the nation again from the White House that evening.

title: WORKSHOPS CANCELED
description: The New Jersey Education Association last week canceled three sex education workshops scheduled for its annual convention in Atlantic City after learning that those giving the workshops planned to stress teaching abstinence. In their place, two workshops will be given by a group from Rutgers University, said Karen Joseph, a spokeswoman for the association. The Rutgers group trains teachers in sex education, including how to provide information on both abstinence and contraception. ''They were more in line with the N.J.E.A.'s policies.'' Ms. Joseph said of the Rutgers organization. Debra Nussbaum

title: Reaching For a Pot, Finding Art
description: THE 1950's kitchen was a strange new world, full of brand-new device-o-matics marketed to liberate the droves of new mothers from pre-World War II drudgery. But for many children who grew up in the whirl of pink mixers and green blenders, the kitschy 50's message of perfection -- made easy! -- is viewed not as a credo of liberation but as one of repression: a life sentence of house arrest.

title: I.R.A. Rejects Blair's Disarmament Demand
description: The Irish Republican Army was reported today to have delivered a sharp rebuff to demands for its disarmament by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, in what was taken here as a significant setback to efforts to cement Northern Ireland's frail peace.

title: French Styles, Captured and Unattended
description: FRENCH VIOLIN SONATAS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLENDON, ROBERT G.
description: McLENDON-Robert G. Age 63, beloved husband of Barbara, father of Elizabeth, son of Dorothy, died on October 10. Born in NYC, graduated Trinity School '55, Yale University '59, Rutgers MBA '60. Served in the Army, received the Army Commendation Medal, CPA, Partner and National Director of Accounting and Auditing at Ernst & Young, where he worked from 1959-1996. He served on the Accounting and Auditing Committee of the firm, the AICPA Accounting Standards Executive Committee, and on committees of the Financial Accounting Standards Board. Past Treasurer of the US Committee for UNICEF, past Board member of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Treasurer of the Fund for Peace, and President of 180 Tenants Corp. He sailed life's seas ''for God, for Country, and for Yale.'' Contributions may be made to Yale University, the Fund for Peace of the Ernst & Young Foundation. A Memorial Service will be held at the Yale Club at 11 AM on October 28.

title: With Egg Roll, You Might Get Advertisement
description: It used to be that ordering Chinese takeout meant escaping from the world. A tasty serving of shrimp lo mein, a cheap pair of chopsticks and, perhaps, a John Wayne movie on TV was all it took to keep the noise of daily life at bay.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-10

title: Diocese Programming Ax Was Across the Board
description: Melvin Cooperman's criticism of Bishop William Murphy [''Jewish Programming Falls to Diocese's Ax,'' Oct. 6] is unwarranted and unjust. The cuts of some Jewish programming on Telecare, the diocesan television station, were a part of across-the-board cuts that were undertaken after Telecare learned of the unexpected $1.1 million loss in annual lease payments from WorldCom.

title: Josephine Kuo, Hon-Ming Eng
description: Dr. Josephine Yueh-Fen Kuo and Dr. Hon-Ming Eng were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Protection Of Privacy By States Is Ranked
description: California and Minnesota protect the privacy of their citizens better than any other states, while the federal government does a poor job, a study by Privacy Journal says.

title: A High School And Its Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Hedge-Fund Investigation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether hedge fund managers have inflated the value of their portfolios in an effort to increase their earnings.

title: Dirty Harry
description: DECEMBER 6

title: Who Loves Us, Baby? It's the British
description: THE British were kicked out of the colonies in 1783, but they've been coming back as tourists ever since. And the one place they're going to is Connecticut, so much so that they have become the state's No. 1 foreign tourists.

title: Vicki Grape, David Goodman
description: Vicki Dawn Grape, the daughter of Marcia and Harvey Grape of New City, N.Y., was married last evening to David Bret Goodman, a son of Laura and Melvin Goodman of Jericho, N.Y. Rabbi Michael Katz performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, N.Y.

title: They Fought Side by Side, and Long to Be Buried That Way
description: SEMYON PUNDIK, 76, and Iosef Kruglyak, 75, never knew each other on the Eastern Front. The two men from Ukraine, among more than 1,000 World War II veterans of the Red Army now living in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, met only a few years ago. Yet when they talk about one another, they use the word ''family.''

title: A 115-Year-Old Baby
description: One of the most famous babies in the advertising world is making a comeback, sort of.

title: Iceland Joins Whaling Panel, Shifting Power to the Whalers
description: OSLO, Oct. 19  For two decades, antiwhaling nations led by the United States have safeguarded the International Whaling Commission's moratorium on commercial whale hunting. But a vote this week allowing Iceland to join the commission showed a shift in power toward the defiant whaling nations.

title: And to All, a Good Fright
description: It's that time of year when orange is not a fashion faux pas. And what better place for a Halloween celebration than one with skeletons in its closets -- and its exhibition spaces. On Oct. 31 from 4 to 7 p.m., the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, will open four floors for trick-or-treating, arts and crafts and live music. The Hayden Planetarium's Space Theater will have presentations of a space show with eerie sound effects created by kids. Admission: $6, $12.95 with a Monster Meal; (212) 769-5200.

title: DataBank; Turbulence Pushes the Market Higher
description: Between a tranquil Monday and Friday, the Dow Jones industrials were up 4.8 percent on Tuesday, down 2.7 percent on Thursday and up 3 percent on Thursday. It was a bumpy week -- and it has been a volatile month, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index moving up or down at least 2 percent on 9 of the last 14 trading days.

title: Queens Man Shoots Three, One Fatally
description: An enraged gunman fatally shot his former girlfriend's mother and wounded two men at a house in Queens yesterday morning, then barricaded himself in the house with two others for several hours before killing himself, the police said.

title: The Tarrasch Gallops Again, With Akobian at the Reins
description: The Mechanics Institute in San Francisco is not only one of the oldest chess clubs in the United States, but it is also one of the few still to sponsor elite round-robin competitions. A recent invitational included eight grandmasters and two international masters. The winner was Varuzhan Akobian, formerly of Armenia, now of the United States.

title: Elizabeth Ellis, Jeremy Smale-Adams
description: Elizabeth Tiffany Ellis, the daughter of Anna Kneeland of Enterprise, Ore., and Richard Ellis of New York, was married yesterday to Jeremy Smale-Adams, a son of Marion June and Kenneth Barry Smale-Adams of Richmond, England. Beverly S. Cohen, a retired justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, officiated at Fifth and Sunset Studios, a Manhattan photo studio.

title: QUICK BITE/Wallington; Squaring Off With Pizzas and Pinball
description: Sure, Denver is a mile high. But for width and length, North Jersey is the place to be. Hoboken, of course, has achieved a certain level of fame as the Mile Square City. Keep those tape measures out, though, because nearby Wallington also sits on a square mile of land. I learned this cartographic fact at the One Square Mile Pizzeria and Grill. From the outside, the restaurant is rather inviting, with a stone facade, gravel-and-stucco panels, and most notably, a tall, sloping red roof. Inside, Martin and Alex Papazian, the father and son who have operated One Square Mile for seven years, have created a family-friendly atmosphere. It's surprisingly spacious -- not a square mile, but certainly big enough. Overhead, you'll find exposed beams, ceiling fans and hanging brass lamps. There are also fast-food-style booths, potted plants, a World Class Bowling video game and a Dirty Harry pinball machine. You may recognize the interior as a location from a few episodes of the Comedy Central series ''Strangers With Candy.'' There are no strangers with candy here, just kind folks with great food: soups and salads, pizza, subs, sandwiches, seafood, pasta and more. As an appetizer, my friend Joe devoured a delicious deep-fried hot dog with extra-tasty sauerkraut ($1.45) and washed it down with New Jersey's own Sea Breeze birch beer. I sampled a decent cheeseburger ($1.75). We then split a medium pie with sausage ($8), which was hot, greasy and good, on a thin, crispy crust. In all, we had one square meal at One Square Mile. Jack Silbert

title: Love of His Life
description: Q: Explain to me the nature of your dispute with Courtney Love - was it all about money?

title: A Brazilian Company That Zigs Where Others Zag
description: GRUPO CORPO may be Brazil's most esteemed dance troupe, but its headquarters in this landlocked state capital are far removed from the Rio de Janeiro-So Paulo axis that dominates Brazilian culture. Even by local standards, the company's decision to locate its office and rehearsal space in a nondescript residential neighborhood on the outskirts of town seems a little odd.

title: Clothes Made The Man
description: It sits at the foot of Diamond Head, off a main road, the shoulders of which, if you cruise by on a weekday around 5 p.m., are lined with Hawaiians getting out of their cars -- and office clothes -- into bathing suits and onto surfboards. From the street, it's not terribly imposing, just an entranceway into yet another Western style beach house. A small foyer, bedrooms on either side, a staircase down to the main floor where you are greeted by Nino Rota's ''Dolce Vita'' on the sound system and a killer view of the Pacific. To the left, past the boxes of orchids being readied for shipment back to the mainland, through the living room, with its French Deco fireplace, curvy chairs upholstered in a cow print, past the window screens, whistling as they try to hold up under the relentless assault of warm wind over water, out the door, onto the terrace, Geoffrey Beene is sitting at a cast-iron glass-topped table.

title: The World: Over There; A New Front Opens, but It's Still One War
description: HOW many battles can the United States take on at one time?

title: Sharing Time
description: Oct. 15: The king and queen of Norway were among the 525 guests who attended the American-Scandinavian Foundation's annual gala dinner-dance at the Grand Hyatt New York. The event raised more than $500,000 for the foundation's educational and cultural exchange programs.

title: POSTINGS: At Brooklyn College; Larger Library Is Dedicated
description: The mandate for the architects of a new $72 million library that was dedicated Thursday at Brooklyn College was to join it seamlessly with the original library built in 1937 and an expansion added in 1959.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENEAU, SIDNEY G.
description: DENEAU-Sidney G. Died on October 8th, 2002. Beloved husband of Charlene. Father of Jeffrey. US Army 1942 to 1946; was a motion picture Executive in distribution and sales with Paramount Pictures; Executive positions with Fabian Theatres, Shine Theatres, Selznick Releasing Organizations and Rugoff Theatres. Interment is in Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

title: He Changed the Way Jazz Guitar Is Played
description: CHARLIE CHRISTIAN occupies several artistic planes. On one, he sits aside other guitarists in jazz. On another, he shares room with a huge number of jazz musicians who were never guitarists -- Count Basie, Thelonious Monk, Lester Young, Charlie Parker and so forth -- but who derived a great deal of their aesthetic from the melodic cut and rhythmic swing of Christian's improvisations. And on a third, he belongs with the filmmaker Jean Vigo, the poet John Keats and the rock musician Jimi Hendrix -- artists of inestimable influence who died young.

title: In the Region/Westchester; Major Home Builders Are Turning to Other Counties
description: TURNING away from the county in which they have conducted business for decades, several prominent builders of new subdivisions in Westchester are focusing on Putnam, Dutchess and Orange Counties in New York, and Fairfield and New Haven Counties in Connecticut.

title: Senior Coupons
description: To the Editor: The elimination of senior coupons is a major setback for the travel plans of those over 62, despite the statements by Kurt Ebenhoch of Northwest Airlines in ''Senior Fares, Not Coupons'' (Practical Traveler, Sept. 29). For those with children and grandchildren scattered all over the country, these coupons provided a way of avoiding exorbitant fares near holidays. The fares also allowed flexibility so seniors could go standby on a moment's notice for family emergencies.

title: Revolution and Galaxy Are Pursuing First Title
description: The league championship game is familiar territory for the Los Angeles Galaxy. Sunday's Major League Soccer Cup against the New England Revolution at Gillette Stadium will be the Galaxy's fourth in the league's seven years of existence.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 6 about the artist Ray Johnson misattributed a wordplay that he used as the title of a collage. ''Keir Dullea, gone tomorrow'' is usually credited to Nol Coward, not to the film critic Pauline Kael.

title: BENEFITS
description: Especially for Climbers

title: Sprewell Is Ready to Talk
description: In an attempt to reconcile with the Knicks, Latrell Sprewell has scheduled a news conference for tomorrow morning in Midtown. He has also begun rehabilitating at the team's practice facility and met with Coach Don Chaney yesterday for the first time since Oct. 7.

title: By Crystal Seas, Club Med, 2 Ways
description: LATE last summer, I lived the jet-set life: In a six-week period, I visited two different Club Meds, spending a week in Cancn with my mother and sister and 10 days in Paradise Island, the Bahamas, with my fianc, Andrew.

title: Ray Johnson; Orpheus; 'Tuck Everlasting'
description: RAY JOHNSON

title: Lee McLaughlin, Daniel Klausner
description: Dr. Lee Ann McLaughlin and Daniel Hoffman Klausner were married last evening by the Rev. John S. Bonnici, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Colony Club in Manhattan. Cantor Robert Bloch took part in the ceremony.

title: Killings May Not Affect Gun Control Measures
description: After three weeks of silence as a sniper stalked the Washington suburbs, the head of the gun lobby today dismissed talk of a ballistic fingerprinting system as a ''technical fantasy'' and predicted that Congress would enact no new legislation in response to the killings.

title: Target Gives Up On Plan for Yonkers Store
description: The Target Corporation is withdrawing its plans to open near the Stew Leonard's, Costco and Home Depot stores in Yonkers. According to the company's lawyer, Marc S. Oxman of White Plains, the retailer grew weary of the protracted legal battles between Greenburgh and Yonkers over traffic in the surrounding area. ''Target no longer wants to be strung along waiting for this litigation to be resolved,'' he said.

title: Prada That Can't Be Bought
description: Giorgio Armani designed bell-captain uniforms; Nicole Miller designed hospital gowns. Now, cosmetics-counter saleswomen are getting outfitted by Miuccia Prada -- provided they work for her. This month, skin-care consultants at Prada Beauty counters broke from traditional basic black with a new uniform: rose-colored coatdresses, designed by Ms. Prada herself. Manufactured in the Prada factory in Italy, the stretch-cotton cover-ups have tortoise-shell buttons, satin belts and that all-important Prada label. ''The uniform is an authoritative gesture toward beauty,'' Ms. Prada said. ''The lab coat design speaks to science, while the soft color represents femininity.''

title: E-ZPASS PROBLEMS
description: More than 200,000 E-ZPass users in New Jersey will get free replacements for their windshield transponders because the units are wearing out faster than they should and recording erroneous violations. The company that makes the transponders, which are intended to record highway toll charges, has agreed to replace a total of 900,000 transponders in East Coast states. The state Department of Transportation will try to identify those transponders that are not properly deducting tolls from drivers' accounts and replace them, said John Dourgarian, a spokesman for the department. Karen DeMasters

title: Private Sector; One Sings. The Other Manages.
description: No matter how badly the stock market does, investors in Ronald Baron's mutual funds can count on him to give a good party. Once a year, Mr. Baron is host for a lavish shareholder conference, typically at the Grand Hyatt in Manhattan, featuring speeches by chief executives of companies whose shares are owned by the Baron funds.

title: Kristen DelVecchio, Shawn Landgraf
description: Kristen J. DelVecchio, a daughter of Barbara and Kenneth J. DelVecchio of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Shawn Magnus Landgraf, a son of Jane Landgraf of Huntington, N.Y., and Kurt Landgraf of Greenville, Del. The Rev. Charles W. Froelich, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Brookville Country Club in Glen Head N.Y.

title: Left Behind
description: I found it impossible to sympathize with Lynne Stewart (George Packer, Sept. 22). So she found Omar Abdel Rahman charming? And it never occurred to her that it is possible to be a charming villain?

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Rich misses the point of our city. It is precisely our ''transience,'' as he puts it, that makes Washington America's city. When kids from around the country come to visit D.C. and walk around the Mall, it's plain to see that, if only for a day, they claim the capital city as their own.

title: Helping Medicine Go Down Smoothly
description: TODAY'S apothecary is most often a supermarket or chain-store pharmacy, where pills that can do everything from relieving an upset stomach to reducing allergy symptoms are sold as part a billion-dollar drug industry led by global pharmaceutical companies.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: Rich's critique of Washington showed no mercy. Perhaps the most disturbing thing is that it's all true. It should be noted, however, that most state capitals fall short, too. Trenton, Hartford and Albany in the tristate area are wonderful examples. You can be certain that Tony Bennett would not leave any vital organs in Sacramento. And had Sinatra sung about Springfield (''That toddling town''), he would have been exiled to Carson City to perform instead of to Las Vegas.

title: The Other Rabbi
description: GARY MAZO grabbed a beer from the refrigerator and headed for the den to watch ''NYPD Blue.'' This was his routine.

title: Private Sector; For the Latest Rothschild Label, The Bottle Itself Is the Art
description: Each year a prominent artist creates a painting to illustrate the label of the Chateau Mouton-Rothschild vintage.

title: Possibility of Using Trucks For Terror Remains Concern
description: After the terrorist attacks last year, intelligence agencies and experts warned that America's vast fleet of trucks, particularly rigs hauling loads of explosive fuel or toxic chemicals, would be ideal terrorist weapons.

title: Food With Asian and European Swagger
description: RESTAURANTS make almost instant impressions. At the 69 Wall Street Restaurant and Jazz Lounge in Huntington (631-385-7084) those impressions are cool, hot, sophisticated, singles, bar scene, music. Food is not one of them. Perhaps that's because the previous tenants at this narrow, stand-alone, two-story building (Pourattitudes and the Light House among them) were dedicated to drinking, not eating.

title: A Selectric Made Me Do It
description: MY dad owned a hardware store in Wilmington, N.C. I started working there on Saturdays and during summers when I was 12. I swept floors, stocked shelves and waited on customers. I don't recall whether I wanted to or was told to. It was just expected.

title: A Desperate, or Hopeful, Act
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Worth the Fighting For'
description: We buried my father on a morning in the early spring of 1981. He had died of heart failure five days before, over the Atlantic, with my mother, his wife of forty-eight years, by his side.

title: Gunrunning Suspect Is Killed After Pulling Pistol on Detective, Police Say
description: Undercover detectives investigating a Harlem gunrunning ring opened fire on several suspects late Friday after one put a gun to a detective's head, the authorities said yesterday. The detectives fired as many as 30 shots in a confrontation that left a 19-year-old suspect dead and two others wounded.

title: October 13-19: FRONT LINES; BALI BOMBING
description: The bomb attack in the peaceful resort island of Bali that killed nearly 200 appears to have shaken Indonesia out of its lethargic attitude toward terrorism. After more than a year of warnings from the United States that the archipelago was an ideal place for Al Qaeda members to hide and operate, Indonesia took steps toward cracking down on a radical Islamic network, Jemaah Islamiyah, which Western and Asian governments say is a terrorist organization that has worked with Al Qaeda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUKEK, WILLIAM G.
description: DUKEK-William G., 86. Died October 15 at Winchester Gardens, Maplewood, NJ. He retired from Exxon Research & Engineering Company as Senior Research Associate in charge of aviation fuel research. He was a former chairman of the Coordinating Research Council's Aviation Committee dealing with the military and civil industry problems. He had long been active in ASTM (American Society for Testing and Materials), which gave him their Award of Merit & the Dyrock Honorary Life Membership. He helped create the first civil specifications and tests for jet fuel, served on advisory groups to NATO, NASA, FAA and the Department of Defense, and was an authority on static electricity and consulted on fuel accidents. He was born in Lansdowne, PA, son of Isabel Fairweather and William G. Dukek. He was a Lehigh University graduate, Phi Beta Kappa, editor of the college newspaper and a candidate for a Rhodes Scholarship. Called up in 1939 as an ROTC second lieutenant in ordnance, he spent six years at the Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn and was discharged in 1946 as a major. Almost forty years were spent at Exxon as liaison between the research company and the aviation industry. He married Phoebe Myers, they divorced, & in 1956 he married Nancy Bowman Williams, widow of a colleague, mother of four children, 2 to 12 years old. Three of these survivors have doctorates: Cynthia W. Hinchman of Washington, DC, Todd R. Williams, Ph.D., of Lake Elmo, MN; Janet B.W. Williams, D.S.W., of Irvington, NY, and Patricia D. Williams, M.D., of Woodstock, ME. He is also survived by his wife, Nancy, and 8 grandchildren: David and Alison Hinchman; Roger Williams; Noah, Ezra & Gideon SpitzerWilliams; and Ethan and Camden Elliott-Williams; and he leaves one sister, Jean Dukek Matthews of Cherry Hill, NJ. He willed his body to Robert Wood Johnson Medical School. Service at the Unitarian Church in Summit, NJ Saturday, Nov. 9 at 1 PM, followed by a celebration party from 3-4 PM for residents, family and friends at Winchester Gardens, Maplewood. 973762-5050. Donations to Lehigh University are welcome.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: THE LOST GARDEN, by Helen Humphreys. (Norton, $23.95.) In this author's third novel, an awkward horticultural researcher of 35 leaves a blitzed London for the country to organize young women to grow food; there she expands horizontally in new acquaintances and vertically in some symbolically attractive gardens planted before 1914.

title: Paige Crichton, Ford Draper III
description: Paige Ellis Crichton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Crichton Jr. of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married yesterday to Ford Bowman Draper III, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Draper Jr. of Chadds Ford, Pa. The Rev. Dr. S. Willard Crossan III, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in Chadds Ford at a private chapel belonging to a neighbor of the Drapers.

title: The News Was Bad. I Went To Bendel's.
description: THREE doctors had already told me that the carat-size lump in my left breast was, in all likelihood, nothing to worry about. As a 37-year-old Chinese woman with no history of breast cancer in the family, my chances of a malignancy, they said, were lottery low. The radiologist who performed the routine biopsy last spring seemed less certain. She carried out the needle aspiration with brisk efficiency, extracting tissue samples via four staple-gun-like thrusts to the offending mass. After the fourth ka-chung, she flipped on the lights and turned to face me. ''I'm not going to lie to you,'' she said. ''It doesn't look great. I'd say your odds are about 50-50.''

title: You Are Not the Pine-Scented Air, O.K.?
description: NINE HORSES

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: SOME women can find men anywhere. Jeanette (Ariane Ascaride), a widowed mother of two, meets Marius (Gerard Meylan) while she's trying to steal two cans of paint from a cement works in Marseilles. He's the security guard. Robert Guediguian's MARIUS ET JEANNETTE (1997) is an off-center romantic comedy that celebrates the bumps in the course of true love as much as the happy ending. Poor Jeannette has lost her cashier's job because of her bad posture (sort of), her daughter wants to move to faraway Paris, and her son won't eat. But all the characters in this film know what's really important. In a moment of seriousness, Jeannette's neighbor Caroline (Pascale Roberts) remembers being in a World War II death camp but finding ways and places to make love even there. ''I'd have given up without it,'' she says - Wednesday at 10:30 a.m. and 6:25 p.m. on Sundance.

title: Left Behind
description: So, Stewart says, we are not to take terrorism and murder personally. Though I am now just a fading old soldier of the peace and civil rights movements, I take and took those causes very personally. But I am sure she will understand that when I say I wish her a long and healthy life in prison, it isn't personal.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 6 with an article about President Saddam Hussein's use of lookalikes in Iraq reversed the identities of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery and his lookalike in World War II, Clifton James. Mr. James was shown in the top picture.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about erotic photographs of food misspelled the name of a cosmetics company in a passing reference to the similarities between primping human models for fashion spreads and food for gastronomy magazines. The company is Bobbi Brown, not Bobbie.

title: The Wrong War at the Wrong Time
description: The atrocity in Bali last Saturday is a grim reminder that we are in a long war. It is a war that pits a few thousand unidentified individuals against most of humankind, from the beaches of Bali to lower Manhattan. A year ago President Bush named this conflict the ''war on terror'' and committed the United States to fighting it. Today many people outside America believe that Washington has lost interest in this war, except as rhetorical cover for a retreat to more familiar territory: an old-fashioned battle against an old-fashioned kind of enemy -- Iraq. We are seeking a fight we can win instead of concentrating on the war that we must win.

title: Going Home to Vietnam, a Daughter of Strangers
description: The woeful complexity of America's traumatic misadventure in Vietnam is perfectly captured in ''Daughter From Danang,'' a fascinating documentary, opening in New York on Nov. 1, about a Vietnamese-American woman named Heidi Bub and her reunion with the mother who gave her up for adoption in April 1975, as the war drew to a chaotic close. Ms. Bub was among some 2,700 children flown to the United States in a controversial rescue mission called Operation Babylift.

title: David Rockefeller's 'Memoirs': Born to Be Mild
description: These days we see a lot of memoirs by people with bipolar personalities, but there was an age, before we let Narcissus out for a romp, when the most prominent Americans had antipolar personalities. These were people whose passions started at room temperature and only rarely heated up to lukewarm, people who could be counted on to not fly off the handle, or even raise their voices, no matter how desperate the circumstances. If his autobiography, ''Memoirs,'' is to be believed, David Rockefeller is one such person, a Mozart of modulated tones.

title: Ossining Runner Wins in Chicago
description: Khalid Khannouchi of Ossining missed his own world record by 18 seconds last Sunday while winning the Chicago Marathon in 2 hours 5 minutes 56 seconds despite cold and blustery conditions.

title: A Vulnerable Kuwait Readies Its Defenses For a U.S. Attack on Iraq and the Reaction
description: Air-raid sirens wailed here early one morning this week, signaling to Kuwaitis that it is time to start worrying again about the mercurial leader 360 miles to the north.

title: Jennifer Reich, Matthew Kraft
description: Jennifer Ann Reich, the daughter of Joan and James Reich of Pittsburgh, was married there last evening to Matthew Schuyler Kraft, the son of Barbara and Richard Kraft of Montvale, N.J. Rabbi James Gibson officiated at the Concordia Club.

title: A Fish Tale
description: ONE sushi place, two sushi places, three sushi places.

title: With Torricelli Pushed Aside, Corzine Steps Up to the Plate
description: People who notice these things have been seeing him three or four times a day lately as they scan the nightly news reports on television: Jon Corzine standing behind Frank Lautenberg on the State House steps; Jon Corzine smiling behind Representative Rush Holt in Princeton. Jon Corzine shaking hands in Bergen County with Anne Sumers, the Democratic candidate for Congress there.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the current film ''Safe Conduct'' and about the French film industry during and after the Nazi occupation misstated the American title of the 1947 movie ''Quai des Orfvres,'' which opens on Friday at the Film Forum in New York. It was ''Jenny Lamour.'' (''Port of Shadows'' was the American title of the 1938 film ''Quai des Brumes.'')

title: Apathy by a Landslide
description: THE VANISHING VOTER

title: From Now and From Then, Art That's Both New and Novel
description: ART that was made yesterday or last week or last year is the specialty of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. But this fall the museum has departed from that mission of newness, if only a little, in order to shed some historical light on its mission.

title: Unacceptable
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOFFITT, PETER MIDDLETON
description: MOFFITT-Peter Middleton. Of Southport, CT. died Wednesday, October 16th at 76. Born in New Haven, CT, he was a graduate of Pomfret School and Yale University (Class of 1948). He began his career at Harriman Ripley and Manufacturers Hanover Bank and then founded Moffitt & Company, an independent financial consulting firm. He was a dedicated trustee of Pomfret School and Pequot Library, as well as former Governor of Pequot Yacht Club, Fairfield County Hunt Club and Society of Colonial Wars of Connecticut. His wife, Butzi Moffitt, and three daughters, Maggie Moffitt Rahe, Annie Moffitt Williams and Johanna Middleton Moffitt and five grandchildren, survive him. A memorial service will be held at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church, 4670 Congress Street, Fairfield, CT, on Monday, October 21 at 11:00 A.M.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FIRST THING MY MAMA TOLD ME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGHAM, HENRY J. III
description: BINGHAM-Henry J. III. On October 13, 2002. Most dearly loved husband of Marianne G. Bingham. Graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of 1952, and Amos Tuck Business School, Class of 1953. Executive Managing Director of Van Eck Associates and Executive Vice President of Van Eck Securities. Youngest Junior Partner of Spencer Trask & Company. In 1968, upon incorporation of the firm, elected Vice President and Director. Also survived by four children, Susan, Lynda, Fiona and William, as well as nine grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister-in law, Patricia and his nephew Paul. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 4-9PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street. Funeral service Wednesday at 2 PM, at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street. If so desired, contributions can be made to Dartmouth College.

title: POSTINGS: At 9th Ave. and 13th St., in Meatpacking District; New 13-Story Hotel On Site That Was A Parking Lot
description: The historic cobblestone meatpacking district on the far West Side, in recent times a flashpoint for the hip and trendy, is soon to have a new hotel, which at 13 stories will stand tall in the mostly low-rise district. Ground was broken last month for the hotel, to be called the Gansevoort, which will occupy a triangular slice of land that was once a parking lot at 18 Ninth Avenue, between Little West 12th and 13th Streets.

title: Long Island Calendar
description: Art

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARER, LAURENCE STEPHEN, M.D.
description: FARER-Laurence Stephen, M.D. Of Arden, NC, died on Friday, October 11, 2002 as a result of a brain hemorrhage. For 24 years he served as a US Public Health Service Medical Officer. He was Director, Division of TB Control, and Director, Division of Quarantine at the Centers for Disease Control, receiving numerous awards for exemplary service. Born in The Bronx, NY, Dr. Farer graduated from Cornell University with honors. He received his medical degree from NYU and a Master of Public Health from Harvard. Dr. Farer was an internationally renowned expert on tuberculosis and its control. He was proud to have participated as a CDC medical officer in the 1977 WHO project that successfully eradicated smallpox worldwide. Laurence's colleagues remember his professionalism, integrity, intellect, and sense of humor. A consummate birder, he attained a life list of almost 5000 birds. To observe birds in local habitats, he visited every continent except Antarctica. A philanthropist, he benefited humanitarian charities. His brother, Dr. James W. Farer, a loving extended family, and a worldwide network of friends survive him.
