Contributions in Laurence Farer's honor can be made to the American Thoracic Society, 61 Broadway, New York, New York 10006. Memorial services will be in Asheville, NC, 2 November; and Atlanta, GA, 9 November.

title: Defense Declines With Lewis and Jones
description: It was Mo Lewis's voice, almost alone among the cacophony of Super Bowl optimism coming from Jets training camp, warning that the defense assembled in an off-season shopping spree might not fit together as well as Lego pieces.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: CAMERA MAN'S JOURNEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKMORE, JOHN
description: ROCKMORE-John. 89, died October 12, West Hartford, CT. Former Director of Psychiatric Social Work, Department Mental Health, State of Connecticut. Former Chief Military Psychiatric Social Worker, US Army, 1942-1946. Served on Board of Directors, Columbia University Alumni Association.

title: INSIDE
description: Ireland Saying Yes to Europe

title: Corrections
description: The On Language column on Sept. 22, about meanings of the word ''stiff,'' misspelled the surname of an author who used it in an 1897 novel to mean ''a passenger who fails to tip.'' She was Louise de la Rame, not Rane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGEL, ADELAIDE F.
description: FOGEL-Adelaide F. On October 17, 2002. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and sister. Services Monday, 11 AM, at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th Street, NYC.

title: Elizabeth Hires, Justin Edelson
description: Elizabeth Carol Hires, the daughter of R. Byard Hires of Darien, Conn., and the late Carol S. Hires, was married yesterday to Justin Cowan Edelson, the son of Christine and Edward Edelson of Springfield, Va. The Rev. Kay Greenleaf, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Vassar College Chapel in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Bonds Gets Giants Going, Going...
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 19  The overriding question surrounding the World Series was whether the Anaheim Angels would challenge Barry Bonds by actually throwing him strikes. Should the Angels be cautious in dealing with one of the greatest players in baseball history? The answer came quickly, and Bonds's first World Series home run came a few seconds later.

title: RESTAURANT RESCUED
description: The Surfside Restaurant, a 1960's architectural landmark in Wildwood, got a reprieve from the wrecking ball last week. Local residents and business people pledged $20,000 to pay for dismantling and storing the structure, rather than demolishing it. The 41-year-old Doo-Wop-style restaurant had been bought by the owners of the adjacent Waters Edge Motel, which is slated to expand onto the property occupied by the Surfside. A local preservation group led the effort to save it. The steel superstructure of the building, all bubble-gum, aqua and orange, will be stored until plans for its reconstruction are completed. Robert Strauss

title: Publish and Perish
description: To the Editor:

title: Christa Sheehan, John McNamara
description: Christa Marie Sheehan and John Allen McNamara were married yesterday in the O'Byrne Chapel at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. Jarlath Quinn, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: What to Do, and Not to Do, as Winter Nears
description: TREES, shrubs and vines may need some help getting ready for winter. But to face frigid winter temperatures, what most plants need from you is nothing. Pruning, fertilizing and watering all tend to stimulate growth or cellular activity at a time when plants need to shut down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDWARD
description: GOLDSTEIN - Edward. Of Mission Viejo, CA, formerly of East Meadow, New York, passed away on October 14, 2002 at the age of 89. New York Times employee for thirty-five years, 1963-1998. Survived by his wife Nessa, daughter Karen Berns, son Larry Goldstein, and three grandchildren, Allison, Samantha and Michael.

title: Guards at Nuclear Plants Feel Swamped By Overtime Deluge in the Wake of 9/11
description: To increase security after the Sept. 11 attacks, the Palisades nuclear plant here, like plants around the country, sharply increased the number of guards on duty. To do so, it put the guards on 12-hour shifts instead of 8, often six days a week instead of five.

title: Face Paint Goes Haute
description: From Oct. 29 to 31, MAC cosmetic counters will offer makeovers for Halloween enthusiasts seeking a professional face-paint job. Customers can book appointments with MAC makeup artists, who will apply one of 18 spooky looks, including Batgirl, a rakish pirate and a mournful jester. The cost, $40 in New York City, varies throughout the country (800-387-6707 for reservations and price information). As an alternative, do-it-yourselfers can use the company's new line of costume makeup ($12.50 to $19.50) to effect their own haunting transformations.

title: An Analyst Lowers a Rating, and a Company Clams Up
description: INVESTORS deserve objective and unbiased research from Wall Street analysts, and securities regulators are finally demanding it, too. What a shame that some companies still work to thwart it.

title: A Hard Man Who Saw Art as Power and Vice Versa
description: CARDINAL RICHELIEU's seductive yet guarded expression never varies. He looks out from his portraits with heavy-lidded brown eyes. A goatee exaggerates his pointed chin; a mustache adorns his small, finely formed mouth. His face is almost delicate, but his craggy, beaked nose warns against mistaking refinement for weakness.

title: Island in an Uproar
description: To the Editor:

title: Golf's Diversity Is Underestimated
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Island in an Uproar
description: To the Editor:

title: October 13-19: FRONT LINES; HUSSEIN'S LANDSLIDE
description: Western dictums about absolute power don't have much currency in Iraq, but they came readily to a visitor's mind after Saddam Hussein's hierarchy claimed that he had won 100 percent of the 11.4 million votes cast in a single-candidate presidential referendum. The Baghdad leadership, under threat of war from the U.S., did not have much leeway in its quest for a result that would signify Iraq's resolve, since Mr. Hussein drew 99.96 percent in the last referendum in 1995. John F. Burns

title: Introduction
description: The Beltway vs. the Borough: Let the games begin! Frank Rich leveled the first salvo at D.C., and scores rallied in response. But, hey, some asked, where did all that post-9/11 comity go? Others defended Lynne Stewart's right to represent the radical sheik but called her politics wrong.

title: Monday Morning Quarterback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Left Behind
description: Stewart has been ''left behind'' for good reason. She has twisted and rationalized noble principles to embrace a murderous, would-be oppressor (who would, by the way, take away her license to practice law and slap her into a chador in a minute, given the chance).

title: Excerpts From the Debate
description: Following are excerpts from the debate on Sunday among six of the candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The participants were Thomas K. Leighton, Marijuana Reform Party; Scott Jeffrey, Libertarian Party; George E. Pataki, Republican Party; H. Carl McCall, Democratic Party; Stanley Aronowitz, Green Party; and Tom Golisano, Independence Party.

title: October 13-19: FRONT LINES; NEW TERROR ALERT
description: George J. Tenet, the C.I.A. director, told a Congressional panel that the threat of a new attack inside the U.S. was as serious as it was before the Sept. 11 attacks. ''They've reconstituted, they are coming after us, they want to execute attacks,'' Mr. Tenet said in his testimony. David Johnston

title: The Week of Living Dangerously
description: Americans have been told often enough that post-9/11, they have to learn to live with insecurity. But last week it seemed that everyone was conspiring to terrify them out of their wits. While the president was heading toward a war with one reclusive dictator with a thirst for nuclear weapons, another one popped up in North Korea bragging that he was secretly acquiring all that and much worse. While the area around the nation's capital was being terrorized by a murderous sniper, police were forced to admit that all their best clues -- the description of the van, the shooter, the gun -- were worthless. Then the director of central intelligence told a Congressional committee that in effect, all the national effort to combat Al Qaeda over the last year had left the country in as much danger of internal attack as before the destruction of the World Trade Center.

title: A Bridge That's Ancient, Decaying And Adored by Its Users
description: When people cross the unassuming little bridge that links mainland Bronx with City Island, they enter a historic neighborhood that is constantly debating what historic neighborhoods everywhere debate: creeping development, slipping tradition, invading tourists.

title: An Increase In Test Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, EDWIN
description: THORNE - Edwin. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Weill Cornell Medical College, and Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the passing of Edwin Thorne. Mr. Thorne was elected a Governor of the Society of the New York Hospital in 1968, a Life Governor in 1984, and a Life Trustee of New York-Presbyterian Hospital in 1997. He continued an exemplary record of service begun by his father, Langdon Thorne, who also served on the Board of Governors. He participated fully in the activities of the Board, particularly the Investment Committee, for which he served as Chairman. The Hospital benefited from his unfailing dedication, leadership, and wisdom. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, particularly his four sons: Brinkley, Peter, Gordon, and Edwin, Jr.

title: INVESTING WITH -- Marc Gabelli; Gabelli Global Growth Fund
description: GLOBAL diversification just isn't what it used to be, says Marc J. Gabelli, the lead manager of the $100 million Gabelli Global Growth fund, which holds about half its assets in the United States.

title: Sushi on a Budget
description: Dining on sushi doesn't have to break your budget. These restaurants offer sushi of good quality at reasonable prices.

title: Photographer in Spite of Himself
description: Julian Dimock did not choose to become a photographer, he did not like taking pictures, and his unheralded career was short. It was also spectacular. At the peak of the Gilded Age, Dimock's father, a wealthy Wall Street financier, was also a conservationist and writer; his son accompanied him around North America to take pictures to illustrate his father's prose. When the elder man died in 1917, Dimock promptly packed up his reflex camera and abandoned his entire body of work, roughly 6,000 glass-plate negatives. For the next 80 years they sat untouched in the research library archives of the American Museum of Natural History. CAMERA MAN'S JOURNEY: Julian Dimock's South (University of Georgia, $39.95) does more than record the Dimocks' excursions to South Carolina in 1904-5; the images refract the harsh light of suffering and privation into visual beatitudes. Dimock captured incalculable depths in his offhand studies of farmers and fishermen, young dandies and aged former slaves. The motley rags of a sawyer, the bulging veins of a blacksmith's hand, even horses and oxen possess a striking luster. In one haunting shot, the bent backs, bowed heads and draped bodies of women float like praying angels above the unyielding desiccation of a cotton field. Something that transcends our recognition of common humanity ultimately emerges from these portraits. Despite sharecropping, repression, poverty, illiteracy, exploitation, powerlessness and the grinding humiliations of segregation, these extraordinary images disclose the wellsprings of nobility. Frederick Kaufman

title: Corrections
description: A listing of restaurants on Oct. 6 with the Choice Tables column, about Paris, misstated the credit card policies at two. Both Ze Kitchen Galerie and Passiflore accept all major cards.

title: The Sword, Now Mightier Than the Pen
description: THE ivied walls of Princeton University stand a long way from the killing trenches of France and the battered atolls of the South Pacific -- and even more distant from desert bunkers in Iraq -- but they share a boundary with all modern battlefields.

title: As the Art World Turns, Seeking Balance
description: THERE are boom times and bust times in the arts. Right now, Connecticut seems to be living through both at once.

title: Aeroflot Without Fear In Today's Russia
description: WHEN an airport manager announced a delay of a KrasAir flight from the Siberian airport of Krasnoyarsk to Moscow earlier this month, the explanation was, in its own way, reassuring: mechanics were fixing a malfunction in the plane.

title: Victoria Willard, John Pickett III
description: Victoria Langben Willard, the daughter of Ann Willard of New York and C. Lawson Willard III of Stonington, Conn., was married yesterday to John Olen Pickett III, a son of Marilyn Hollingsworth of Locust Valley, N.Y., and of Mr. Pickett Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Philippa A. Turner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: More Priests Are Now Likely To Challenge Dismissals
description: With the decision from Rome on Friday that the American bishops' zero-tolerance policy on sexually abusive priests must be substantially revised, many more dismissed priests are likely to appeal their cases to the Vatican, according to canon lawyers and other church officials.

title: In Praise of Tea
description: To the Editor: In her essay ''Holding the Bag in Italy'' (Sept. 15), Madeline Drexler quotes Rory Bruce, the manager of Babington's tearoom, who said: ''A lot of English people don't understand tea anymore. They use a tea bag and it's disgusting.''

title: Jury Awards $80 Million In Cerebral Palsy Suit
description: The parents of a child born prematurely with cerebral palsy 12 years ago have been awarded $80 million by a Suffolk County Supreme Court jury. The award was described by The New York Jury Reporter, an East Islip-based court publication, as the largest ever handed down in a court in Suffolk County. It was the second multimillion-dollar award won by the plaintiff's lawyer, James R. Duffy, against the two doctors, Steven Klein and Ira Spector. Sixteen months ago, Mr. Duffy recovered a $10.6 million award from the physicians, who have a joint practice in Melville.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Page 39 of The Times Magazine today with the Diagnosis column includes an extraneous word. The photograph is by Kent Knudson/Getty Images. (''Blood vials'' should have been the start of the next picture credit, on Page 41.)

title: Lenore Nemeth, Alfred Buff
description: Lenore Susan Nemeth and Alfred Milton Buff are to be married today at the bridegroom's farm in Red Hook, N.Y. Judge Dorothy A. Cropper of the New York State Court of Claims will officiate.

title: States Talk Tough. Wall Street Sweats.
description: IN a warren of office cubicles in Salt Lake City, 2,000 miles from Wall Street, temporary workers are scanning e-mail messages that were written in confidence by employees of the Goldman Sachs Group but that could land Goldman on the growing pile of disgraced securities firms.

title: A South Dakota Race Is More Opposites Than Issues
description: Though the candidates do not make a point of disagreeing on most issues, there may be no important House race in the country with two such different opponents.

title: Rove's Way
description: White House tours don't pass through Karl Rove's office, but most everything else around the presidency does. Rove determines which lobbyists and supporters get access to the White House, and he weighs in with Bush on every major domestic-policy decision, from stem cells to farm subsidies. At the same time, he has de facto control of the Republican Party and has made it his crusade to win back the Senate; at least two Senate candidates are running this fall just because Rove decided they should, and several others ran unopposed for their party's nomination -- or might as well have -- because Rove bullied potential competitors out of the race.

title: Light Skin, Dark Skin And the Wounds Below
description: WHEN I write, I don't think about an audience. I think about what I want to say. With my play ''Yellowman,'' which is opening this week, I wanted to look at internal racism among black people.

title: Name That Tune
description: LULLABY

title: An 18th-Century Plea for Tolerance Resounds Today
description: TIMELESSNESS is a good thing in a play, but timeliness is better. The 18th-century drama ''Nathan the Wise'' wins on both counts. The play, dramatizing tensions between Christians, Muslims and Jews, is unlikely to lose its sense of urgency in today's global political climate. A revival is in order, and one is at hand: by the Pearl Theater Company, an Off Broadway resident group dedicated to the classics of world drama. The play, adapted by Richard Sewell and directed by Barbara Bosch, opens tonight and will be performed in repertory with Oliver Goldsmith's comedy ''She Stoops to Conquer.''

title: The Nation; Big Brother Joins the Hunt for the Sniper
description: FOR thousands of people in the Washington region ducking behind their cars as they pump gas, keeping their children indoors or missing the high school football season, there is no limit to what should be done to thwart the sniper who has shot 11 people this month.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH MILLER

title: Using Co-op Shares as Collateral
description: Q. My co-op will not permit anyone to take out a mortgage, a line of credit or a personal loan secured by the value of the shares of the apartment once the original share loan has been paid. The co-op management refuses to sign the paperwork required by a bank or lending institution making such a loan. The co-op was financed by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. I once spoke to a lawyer who said that in his opinion, the co-op's policy was a violation of the 14th Amendment because you cannot create two classes of shareholders -- that is, those who can have mortgages and those who cannot. Can you please advise? . . . Carol Zelenka Cooney, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Streetscapes/141st Street and Convent Avenue; 1892 Church for a Congregation That Moved Uptown
description: THE scaffolding around the 1892 St. Luke's Church, at 141st Street and Convent Avenue, is just the first part of an extensive series of repairs the impressive Romanesque structure needs, both inside and out. The pastor, the Rev. Johan Johnson, has no funds right now for the rest of the work, but he does have an unusual idea of how to accomplish it.

title: Battling the Bottom Line in TV's Earliest Days
description: THERE'S a bit at the beginning of the TNT movie ''The Big Time'' that neatly captures the spirit of television in its infancy. During a live broadcast of ''Hedda Gabler,'' the actress playing Hedda reaches into a velvet-lined box for her pistol. The box is empty. While the camera zooms in and the panic-stricken woman ad-libs for dear life, a quick-thinking and agile floor manager crawls through the tangle of cables on the floor, just below the camera's range, and places the gun in her hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, MARGARET S. (MAGGIE)
description: NEWMAN - Margaret S. (Maggie). Died October 19, 2002. Loving and beloved wife of Harold M. Newman, daughter of the late Albert Strauss and Gertrude Greenwald, mother of Robert P. Newman, mother-in-law of Katheryn, sister of Helen Strauss, sister-in-law of Betty Abrams. Born 1921. Graduate of Barnard College Class of 1942. Former longtime member of the Board of Directors of the YWCA of White Plains and Central Westchester, and Literacy Volunteer. Evergracious, courageous and uncomplaining in the face of Alzheimer's Disease and cancer. Services private. Donations in her name may be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 633 Third Avenue, 12th Floor, NY, NY 10017-6706.

Survived by his sister Mary J.P. Moore and nephews Samuel F. Posey and Nicholas J. Moore, all of Sharon, CT., and David W. Moore of Woodbridge, CT. Memorial service will take place at Christ Church, Sharon, CT. Thursday, October 24, 2002 at 11AM with interment following at the Sharon Cemetery.

title: An Early Start on the 'Brag Sheet'
description: I'M embarrassed to admit this, but it's true: today's typical Westchester teenager has a precollege rsum (yes, rsum) that makes my own professional track record of more than 20 years look positively anorexic by comparison. Thank the current high-stakes college admissions climate; building a suitably impressive application ''brag sheet'' has become, for many county teenagers, virtually a full-time career.

description: To The Editor:

description: GRIPPE - Peter. Sculptor, print maker, teacher, major proponent of abstract expressionist movement, died age 90, Friday.

description: Citing higher-than-projected sales tax revenues, a bipartisan group of Suffolk County legislators said last week they could balance next year's budget without making deep cuts in social services or eliminating a 4.5 percent county sales tax exemption on clothing costing less than $110.

title: The Cook's Blessing
description: There is a story about a convent in which the sisters lived under a vow of silence that could be broken only once a year. So on a certain date as the clock struck noon while the sisters ate lunch, one nun said, ''This soup is terrible.'' The next year, another nun spoke up: ''I don't think it's so bad.'' Another year, noon, and a third sister: ''Bicker, bicker, bicker.''

title: 'No Way to Treat a First Lady'
description: His secretary announced simply, "It's her."

title: Ideas & Trends: Bleak Earnings; Is Bankruptcy Good for the Airlines?
description: THE chief executives of the nation's largest airlines have been engaging in their version of the soup kitchen shuffle. Tin bowls in hand, they have marched up to Capitol Hill in the last few weeks seeking more financial aid for an industry expected to lose at least $7 billion this year. They offer what seems a compelling rationale: Multiple airline bankruptcies could leave a huge dent in the already fragile economy.

title: With Winter's Approach, Help for Plants
description: TREES, shrubs and vines may need some help getting ready for winter. But to face frigid winter temperatures, what most plants need from you is nothing. Pruning, fertilizing and watering all tend to stimulate growth or cellular activity at a time when plants need to shut down.

title: It Adds Up
description: To the Editor:

title: A Former Dodger Readies Sluggers for the Diamond
description: Aspiring young ballplayers can hone their abilities at Pro Swing, a newly opened baseball and softball training center in Mount Kisco.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the government's growing use of private contractors for military activities referred incorrectly to the formation of the International Peace Operations Association, a trade group of private military contractors. Doug Brooks, the president of the group, was its founder; it was not founded by the contractors themselves.

title: Fading Canals
description: To the Editor: Like David Kirby, I too am a ''canal nut'' and found his article (''A Main Artery of the 1800's,'' Aug. 25) about the abandoned D & H canal both fascinating and sad. It is unfortunate that in this country our canals are -- for the most part -- filled in or otherwise no longer navigable. I imagine Mr. Kirby's journey would have been more enriching if he had been on a canal boat, working the locks and picnicking on the banks of the D & H. The Europeans have chosen to maintain their canals and aqueducts, which are now an alternative way of exploring the hinterlands.

title: Intelligence, But Not in Place Of Vocal Beauty
description: The term ''intelligent singer'' is sometimes used as a caveat to describe an artist who lacks something in the way of passion, vocal size or beauty. But in the case of the Belgian baritone Jos van Dam, it is simply an accurate description. Thoughts come through his music.

title: Irish Vote on European Union Expansion
description: In a dramatic reversal, Irish voters appeared tonight to have given overwhelming endorsement to the most ambitious expansion of the European Union, a project they rejected only last year, according to initial results from 7 of 42 voting areas in a closely watched referendum.

title: 'Emma's War'
description: Aid makes itself out to be a practical enterprise, but in Africa at least it's romantics who do most of the work-incongruously, because Africa outside of books and movies is hard and unromantic. In Africa the metaphor is always the belly. "He is eating from that," Africans will say, and what they mean is that is how he gets his living. African politics, says the French scholar Jean-Franasois Bayart, is "the politics of the belly." The power of the proverbial African big man depends on his ability to feed his followers; his girth advertises the wealth he has to share. In Africa the first obligation of kinship is to share food; and yet, as the Nuer say, "eating is warring." They tell this story: Once upon a time Stomach lived by itself in the bush, eating small insects roasted in brush fire, for Man was created apart from Stomach. Then one day Man was walking in the bush and came across Stomach. Man put Stomach in its present place that it might feed there. When it lived by itself, Stomach was satisfied with small morsels of food, but now that Stomach is part of man, it craves more no matter how much it eats. That is why Stomach is the enemy of Man.

title: Tigers in the Wild
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Trying to Spy a Tiger in the Wild'' (Oct. 6) about Nagarahole National Park in southern India: We saved a previous article, ''The Maharajah Wore Stripes'' (May 7, 2000) by Lynn Sherr, about the Royal Tiger Resort in Kanha National Park, India. We were in India in 1996, but only for sightseeing. This last February we finally went to Bandhavgarh and Kanha National Parks and stayed at the Royal Tiger Resort. We saw seven tigers in all during a three-week trip.

title: Global Comfort Food
description: IF you find yourself in the Philadelphia suburbs with hungry children and can't bear the thought of the drive-through, Olive restaurant and bar will serve up deep-fried chicken tenders and plain pasta and understands the need for cups with lids and straws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SIDNEY
description: GOLDMAN-Sidney. Of Delray Beach, FL and Quogue, NY, passed away Thursday, October 17, in Baltimore, MD. A native of NYC, he served his country in the Air Force during WWII and was a passionate volunteer, as well as being an executive and, late in life, a professional singer. Sid was the devoted husband of Gloria and beloved brother of Frances Eberman. He was the loving father/father-inlaw of Neil Harold and Diane Goldman, Charles Mitchell and Susan Goldman, and the ardent supporter of his grandchildren, Jenna, Andrew, Matthew and Rachel. A private funeral service will be held on Sunday, October 20. Donations in lieu of flowers can be made to Hope Lodge, 636 West Lexington Street, Baltimore, MD. 21201.

title: 'The Threatening Storm'
description: For many long years, Iraq and the United States had little to do with each other. The days of Iraq's greatest glory occurred long before there ever was a United States, and in recent centuries, while America was still a young and relatively isolated nation, the Iraqis were ruled by the Ottoman Turks, whose relationship with the United States barely existed. Even after the fall of the Ottoman Empire in World War I and the formation of the modern state of Iraq, it was Britain, not America, that dominated Iraqi politics for decades. Indeed, as for many Arabs, until only the last few decades, the United States was little more than a strange name of a distant land for most Iraqis. Before the Second World War, the United States had only commercial relationships in the Persian Gulf, and it carefully avoided any involvement in the region's politics. In the decades after the war, Washington did take an increasing interest in the Gulf but mostly focused its attentions on Saudi Arabia and Iran. Iraq was a weak radical Arab state with ties to Russia but did not pose enough of a threat to take seriously. It was not until the 1980s that the two countries came into meaningful contact, and then the limits of their prior relations bred ignorance, miscalculation, and suspicion, leading to regular misreadings of each other's intentions.

title: New Shooting Has Similarities To Sniper Spree
description: Detectives tracking the deadly suburban sniper raced to a shooting near Richmond, Va., on Saturday night as the police reported that a man had been wounded by a single shot in a parking lot outside a shopping center restaurant.

title: References in a Time of Mistrust
description: Out-of-work managers and executives are taking longer to find jobs, and they have more to blame than harsh economic times. They can point a finger at their less-honorable colleagues -- the ones who have fueled this bull market in corporate scandals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, EDITH
description: COHEN-Edith. At the age of 97. Loving aunt of Dr. Grace L. Griffenberg and Julian Levine. She was honored, respected and loved by great and great-grand nieces and nephews. She adored her family. She treasured the 40 years she spent as a NYC school teacher touching thousands of lives. We all celebrate her life and will cherish her memory.

description: Best Bet

description: BENJAMIN FRANKLIN

title: How Clinton's Gristmill Grew Into a Museum
description: THE HUNTERDON Museum of Art may not be the largest museum in the state, but it is the most charming and picturesque. It is celebrating its 50th anniversary this month, and its history is told in a simple and effective way through newspaper clippings and memorabilia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHORN, LENORE G.
description: WHITEHORN-Lenore G. Of North Andover, MA. Beloved wife of Richard S. Helstein and Nathaniel Whitehorn. Devoted mother of Richard Helstein II and Catherine Sabath. Loving mother-in-law of Susan Helstein and Jerrold Sabath. Adored grandmother of Anne, Debbie, Liz, Maggie, Mark and Tim. Passed away peacefully on October 16th, 2002. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. Lenore's quick wit and caring heart will be remembered by many.

title: Sundials
description: To the Editor: As a member of the North American Sundial Society, I was pleased that you included a photograph of a sundial in ''Playing Scientist on a Vermont Hillside'' (Travel Advisory, Sept. 22). Sundials are the oldest method of telling time still in use. The particular sundial shown is known as an analemmatic sundial. It is interactive because users must position themselves on a scale of months (the photograph shows June through September). More information is available at www.sundials .org.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the pronunciation of the word ''nuclear'' -- and President Bush's frequent use of ''nucular'' -- quoted a passage incorrectly from a letter used by Merriam-Webster editors when they tell readers that spelling is not always a valid way of determining punctuation. The letter cites the three words ''electrical,'' ''electricity'' and ''electrician'' (not ''electric'').

title: He's Not Inhaling or Exhaling
description: NO WAY TO TREAT

title: Lowering Mortgage Barriers
description: RECENT changes in eligibility requirements for mortgage programs now being offered in several New York counties will make a greater number of prospective homeowners -- with incomes that can go as high as $150,810 -- eligible for low-interest-rate low-down-payment mortgages.

title: Mexico Fears Migrant Deaths Will Increase With Despair
description: Mexico's government, after tentatively identifying 2 of the 11 migrants found dead in a locked boxcar in Iowa this week, says it fears the deaths are a harbinger of many more to come.

title: A Biotech Outcast Awakens
description: LIKE most top executives, Frank Baldino Jr. sometimes does not get enough sleep. But Dr. Baldino, the founder and chief executive of Cephalon Inc., a biotechnology company, may be able to cope with lack of sleep better than most.

title: Our Cars, Ourselves
description: As a committed gear-head, I want to thank you from the bottom of my manual-shifting heart for your feature on cars (Sept. 29). It was superbly photographed and as unexpected as a Harold Bloom treatise in Field & Stream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MAURICE
description: BROWN - Maurice. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Chapter, Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America acknowledges with profound sadness the passing of Maurice Brown, beloved father-in-law of our esteemed president Nancy Brown, father of Howard Brown and grandfather of Board member Michele Sweetwood. We extend our deepest sympathies to the Brown and Sweetwood families and hope that they derive comfort in knowing that they are in our hearts and prayers. Judy Saphir, Chairman Suzanne and Irwin Rosenthal, CCFA Co-Founders Shelby and William Modell, CCFA Co-Founders Joan Telley, Executive Director

title: Danielle Chang, Todd Leong
description: Danielle Chang, a publishing executive, and Todd William Leong, a documentary filmmaker, were married yesterday at the Bryant Park Grill. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: A Mysterious Upsurge in Autism
description: A shocking report from California last week suggested that a large increase in childhood autism in that state over the last 15 years is a true epidemic, not a statistical mirage inflated by artificial factors. If that judgment holds up after further analysis and research, it raises disturbing questions about just why this brain-distorting disease is on the rise and what can be done about it.

title: 'Ham' Survives A Move
description: FOR 17 years, ''Little Ham'' has been the little musical that could. But its ride from New Jersey to New York, where it is now playing at the off-Broadway John Houseman Theater, has been bumpy and long-delayed.

description: TUCKER-Benjamin F. Died October 13, after a brief illness. Ben was a writer, actor and director. He taught acting and mime at The American Academy of Dramatic Arts, The American Mime Theater, Cornell and Ohio Universities. He filled the lives of his wife, Priscilla, and daughters, Plummy Tucker Ontal & Mitie Tucker Graham with love.

description: COOK-Winifred Carlsen. 89. Died peacefully at home on October 13. Wife of the late Donald C. Cook. Beloved mother of Nicholas and grandmother of Stephen. Also survived by sisters Leila Marsh, Carol Silver, Joyce Preston and numerous nieces and nephews.

title: Susanna Dwinell, Reid Boren
description: Susanna Dexter Dwinell, the daughter of Linda Logan of Greenwich, Conn., and the late John A. Dwinell, was married yesterday to Reid Jonathan Boren, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Boren of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The ceremony was held at the Elm Bank Reservation, a 182-acre park in Wellesley, Mass., and was performed by Linda Rocker, a retired judge of the Court of Common Pleas in Cleveland, who received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, OLIVIA PETERS
description: HENRY-Olivia Peters, 84. Died October 16, New York City. Widow of S. Morgan Henry. Children: Olivia and Morgan. Son-in-law: Tim Gurshin. Sister of Priscilla Q. Weld. Three grandchildren. Active in the Colonial Dames of America, the Churchwomen's League and the City Gardens Club. Friends luncheon October 21, 1 PM, The Colony Club, 564 Park Ave., NYC. Private service in MA. Donations to Mt. Vernon Hotel Museum and Garden, 421 East 61 St., NY, NY 10021.

title: With a Bravura Kiss, A Career Lifts Off
description: AS many young dancers learn, technique is the first hurdle in an international ballet career. A grasp of theater is the elusive, arduous second. But as Michele Wiles, a 22-year-old soloist with American Ballet Theater, knows from experience, the endless kiss in ''Manon'' is in another category altogether.

title: A Desperate, or Hopeful, Act
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rules of the Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Required Reading For N.B.A. Fighters
description: READING a book is seldom associated with the leisure activities of a National Basketball Association player, or any professional athlete for that matter. Some surely curl up with a good book occasionally, but for too many others, the only thing they ever seem to read is a stat sheet, a road-trip itinerary or instructions on how to play a new video game.

title: Rejuvenating the Granddaddy of Home Shows
description: THEY'VE finally taken their own advice. ''This Old House,'' PBS's Emmy Award-winning home remodeling show, has recently undergone the most extensive renovation in its 23-year history. This month, it officially became ''The New This Old House Hour,'' a combination of the original series and a half-hour companion series, ''Ask This Old House,'' in which Steve Thomas and a crew of experts answer viewers' home repair questions.

title: When It Comes to Giants' Ferrara, There's Only Full Speed Ahead
description: Full Speed Frankie is the nickname given Frank Ferrara by the Giants' offensive linemen, and it is not always meant as a term of endearment. The truth is that on some days, they can't stand him.

title: Analysts' Choices Had Another Bad Year, but Why?
description: A NEW study of brokerage analysts' ratings offers more ammunition for Wall Street's critics. In 2001, for the second consecutive year, the stocks that analysts rated highest did far worse than those rated lowest.

title: America's Soprano Of Choice
description: THE soprano Rene Fleming, born on Valentine's Day 43 years ago in Rochester, revives a species we thought to be extinct. Without surrendering the persona of the classical musician, she has captured the mainstream audience in the manner of the all-American divas Dorothy Kirsten, Eleanor Steber and Eileen Farrell a half century or so ago.

title: Allison Feiner, Jason Feldman
description: Allison Ricca Feiner, the daughter of Judith Konigsberg of Greenwich, Conn., and Michael C. Feiner of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Jason I. Feldman, a son of Loretta Soroko of Brooklyn and Harvey Feldman of Manhattan. Rabbi Richard Jacobs officiated at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: Angels and Giants Have Seen This Before
description: The Angels have the Giants right where they want them: ahead in the World Series after the first game. That's the Giants who are ahead after the first game, in case there was any confusion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 22 about the musical ''Jolson & Co.'' at the Century Center Theater referred incorrectly to an earlier staging, by the York Theater Company. It was an Off Broadway presentation -- not a showcase, the class of production in which ticket prices are capped and members of Actors' Equity can be paid below the union's minimum wage.

title: The Souffl Doctrine
description: The Boy Emperor picked up the morning paper and, stunned, dropped his Juicy Juice box with the little straw attached.

title: International Datebook: Oct. 25 to Nov. 29
description: OCT. 25 TO 27, CAPE MAY, N.J.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THIS LITTLE CHICK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSOVA, ZARA
description: NELSOVA-Zara. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Zara Nelsova, extraordinary artist and dedicated cello faculty member at the School from 1985 to 2001. An artist of exceptional creativity, she embodied the very best attributes of a special teacher and a caring human being. She will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, Pres.

title: When Animals Attach
description: This fall, women's fashion is full of creature features, with animal appliqus on everything from accessories to outerwear. The next logical step after last year's iron-on patches, the new fad is another nod to the 70's. Catherine Malandrino emblazons the back of a black wool and cashmere jacket with a three-dimensional fake-fur-and-embroidery steer ($977 at Catherine Malandrino in New York and Los Angeles), while Marni makes a white messenger bag decorated with red and black rabbits ($960 at Jeffrey New York, 212-206-1272) and black cowboy boots adorned with white bunnies ($1,140 at Barneys New York). At Louis Vuitton, handbags are bright with rainbow-hued cartoon animals frolicking around the company's designer logo (from $650 to $970 at Saks Fifth Avenue); colorful butterflies flit across Dolce & Gabbana's patchwork suede vest ($1,540). Tait & Style offers a green wool scarf ($168 at Henri Bendel) with a cat that also happens to be wearing a scarf. ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Hardcover Highlights
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: The British Can't Rap, Haven't You Heard?
description: THE British have always had a flair for taking black American music, giving it a twist and then exporting it back, stylishly repackaged. Blues, R & B, soul, funk, disco, house -- each in turn has been the source music for a series of British invasions of the American pop mainstream. Yet, despite years of trying, this native genius for appropriation has spectacularly failed in one area: hip-hop. From late-80's contenders like Ruthless Rap Assassins to 90's groups like the Brotherhood, British rappers have not made much impression in hip-hop's homeland.

title: A Holocaust Story That Has Roots In His Own
description: THERE were 10 nationalities involved in making the ''The Grey Zone,'' Tim Blake Nelson said in the middle of a long conversation about the movie, which he based on his 1996 play of the same name. Listing the countries, Mr. Nelson looked down at the tabletop in the Fairway Cafe on the Upper West Side. ''The United States, England, Israel,'' he said, putting one finger down for each, as if playing scales on a piano. He cruised through seven, but eight and nine came more slowly, and he had real trouble retrieving 10. But instead of letting it go, he stared down at the hovering pinky on his right hand for a full minute. Then it landed at last. ''Oh,'' he said, ''Canada!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERKELTAUB, FRANCES
description: TERKELTAUB - Frances. Age 78, of Boca Raton, FL, died October 16, 2002. Beloved wife of Isak Szternszus and sister of Jerry Gulbas. Devoted mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Predeceased by first husband, Carl Terkeltaub. She will be sorely missed. The Simantov, Sunshine, Terkeltaub and Blas Families

title: Athens
description: To the Editor: I must take issue with some of the statements about Athens in ''Athens Olympic Work Makes Chaos the Norm'' (Correspondent's Report, Sept. 22) by Philip Shenon.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Escher Exhibition

title: Security Check System For Schools Is Faulted
description: DISCLOSURES this fall about the breakdown in how the Harrison school district failed to conduct appropriate criminal background checks on new school district hires have also revealed some fissures in the process itself.

title: Mayors Tout Cities' Health to Tempt Investors
description: HOPING to tempt a panel of venture capitalists and lure new investment, participants in the first annual Westchester Mayors' Business Summit on Wednesday promoted their cities' recent economic achievements. More than 200 business and government leaders attended.

title: Work at Last: Marketing Themselves
description: BEING unemployed is obviously a problem - but did you ever stop to ponder what kind of a problem? A financial problem, of course. An emotional problem, often. A political problem, maybe (or should be, for the politicans).

title: Chinese Power Company Chief Flees the Country and Scrutiny
description: The director of China's giant State Power Corporation has fled the country to avoid prosecution, one in a spate of corruption cases that have embarrassed the Communist Party as it prepares for a major leadership transition.

title: Ynsyde Skynyrd
description: LYNYRD SKYNYRD

title: Crimes Admitted, But Not Committed; Confessing Can Seem Easy After Hours in a Hard Light
description: Yes, the interrogation had taken a long time, but the murderer had freely answered the questions, the lead detective said, each ghastly detail cheerfully supplied upon request. ''There was no reason to persuade him; he was very cooperative,'' the detective, Joseph Di Prima, testified. ''The thing didn't flow from him, because he was slow in responding. All I had to say to him was, 'What happened next, George?' ''

title: Bruce Beckwith, Henri Simonetti
description: Bruce Mitchell Beckwith and Henri Gustave Simonetti affirmed their partnership yesterday at St. Peter's Church in Manhattan. The Rev. David Robb, a Unitarian Universalist minister, led a commitment ceremony.

title: The Nation: Beltway Anxieties; When Risk Ruptures Life
description: AS he prepared last week for a trip to the nation's capital, Arnold I. Barnett, a professor of statistics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, reassured himself that his risk of being shot by the Washington area sniper was ''statistically low.'' Then he worried he might get shot.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Heather Headley; This Lion Is Hungry
description: SHE knows how to close a place, as long as it's an ice cream parlor. Heather Headley, who played Nala in ''The Lion King'' on Broadway and who won a Tony when she had the title role in ''Aida,'' another Disney production, has recorded her first R&B album, ''This Is Who I Am.'' The daughter of two ministers in Trinidad, Ms. Headley, 28, doesn't drink or smoke, but she knows how to party.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the coming film ''Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World,'' adapted from the novels of Patrick O'Brian, referred incorrectly to the father of a central character, Jack Aubrey. Aubrey is the son of an army officer, not a naval officer.

title: Halloween; Eurail Prices; The 'Peanuts' Gang
description: And to All, a Good Fright

title: Connoisseurship Runneth Over
description: The Whiskey Fest at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square was packed last Wednesday night with 1,000 guests, mostly men, who paid $85 to smell, taste, learn and discuss at length bourbon, Irish whiskey and Scotch. It was not for clubby social drinkers and macho booze swillers. If you like Scotch on the rocks, a tourist bar would have been the place for you.

title: 'I'll Take You There'
description: In those days in the early Sixties we were not women yet but girls. This was, without irony, perceived as our advantage.

title: For Richer
description: I.The Disappearing Middle

title: Funny, You Don't Look Jewish
description: Empire bears strange fruit. The French filmmaker Jean Rouch picked some of the strangest in his 1954 movie ''Les Matres Fous'' (''The Crazy Masters''), about a West African cult in which dancers adopt the identities of their British masters (governor general, engineer, major, corporal of the guard) and then, foaming at the mouth, burn themselves with torches and consume a ''tea'' that consists of sacrificed dog. ''Les Matres Fous'' inspired Jean Genet's play ''The Blacks,'' but the subject matter, suggestive as it was, was not the point. Rouch was the point, with his witty, self-mocking voice-over, the most candid heard to date in nonfiction film. Six years later Rouch would return to Paris and help invent cinma vrit, his being the self-referential kind that focused not just on events but on the filmmaker's role in making them happen. But in ''Les Matres Fous'' he was already speculating wryly about what it meant to make movies like that -- what bizarre identities his membership in the cult of anthropologists had allowed him to adopt.

title: Bonds Gets Giants Going, Going ...
description: The overriding question surrounding the World Series was whether the Anaheim Angels would challenge Barry Bonds by actually throwing him strikes. Should the Angels be cautious in dealing with one of the greatest players in baseball history? The answer came quickly, and Bonds's first World Series home run came a few seconds later.

title: McCall Vows To Expand Protections For Tenants
description: On the eve of the second debate in the governor's race, H. Carl McCall yesterday pledged that he would strengthen the state rent-regulation laws that expire next year.

title: Casinos Revive a Town, but Poverty Persists
description: Awnings and young trees line Main Street, where a new town hall, firehouse, police station and town-financed post office have sprung. A new $28,000 carillon-mimicking clock in a new park downtown chimes every 15 minutes and plays hymns on the hour. The city is building and furnishing a supermarket for someone to lease. Residents pay no property taxes or sewer fees. They pay $3 to $5 a month for water.

title: A Lot of Signing and Smiling in the Rain
description: JANICE JOSIAH-BUONINCONTRI'S smile momentarily banished the rain that plagued last weekend's 41st annual Fall Harvest Festival at Mill Neck Manor School for the Deaf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXYM, STEPHEN
description: MAXYM-Stephen. The Juilliard community is deeply saddened by the death of Stephen Maxym. One of the most distinguished bassoonists of the Twentieth Century ry, he was on the Juilliard faculty from 1956 to 1992, where he taught many of today's active, professional bassoonists. His humanity, sincerity and personal integrity were hallmarks of a long and distinguished career. Our condolences go to his wife Lucy, his children, and his many friends. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, Pres.

title: Sports of The Times; He's a Star, And Never A Spectator
description: BARRY BONDS insisted he had no favorite World Series memories. Indeed, he never paid attention when he was growing up, even though his father and his godfather were in the business.

title: 2 Senate Candidates Square Off at Street Fair
description: The candidates for the United State Senate in New Jersey continued their sparring over national security today, with Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican, accusing former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democrat, of voting against several important national defense bills. Mr. Lautenberg countered by saying that Mr. Forrester would waste defense money if he went to Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, JOHN B. JR.
description: GRANT-John B. Jr. Greenberg Traurig mourns the loss of our great partner and friend, John Grant. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family on such an untimely loss. John was a quality lawyer and a truly wonderful person. He was uniquely respected by all of his peers for his integrity, judgement, perspective, and sense of responsibility, all leavened by a wonderful sense of humor. He will be missed by all who had the honor of knowing him.

title: When Insurance Hits the Ceiling
description: WHEN people buy health insurance, few worry that it might run out. As long as they pay their premiums, they expect to be covered, no matter how many medical bills they rack up. After all, what's the point of having insurance if, just when you need it most, your policy shuts down like a bank at closing time?

title: Eurail Prices to Rise And Options to Increase
description: The cost of European rail passes will increase by about 3 percent next year, and one type of pass is being eliminated, allowing travelers greater flexibility in picking the countries they choose to visit.

title: A Spokesman Aims at the Wrong Target
description: To the Editor:

title: Snow Seeks a Title His Father Never Had
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 19  Jack Snow played a dozen seasons in the National Football League for the Los Angeles Rams, catching 340 passes and scoring 45 touchdowns in 150 games. It takes a rugged individual to last that long and remain that productive in the N.F.L.

title: Doctrines
description: 'A Bush Doctrine on Nuclear Arms'' was a headline in The Chicago Tribune two weeks before President-elect George W. Bush took office. But that was just a headline writer's pass at a policy promise; neither a policy nor a program is as grand and sweeping as a doctrine, a word rooted in the Latin for ''teaching.'' Also on the eve of inauguration, Jeffrey Birnbaum of Fortune identified ''a balance between development and environmentalism,'' which he labeled ''the Bush Doctrine.''

title: Jaime Silberman, Barak Bassman
description: Jaime Merritt Silberman, a daughter of Michele and William Silberman of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married today to Barak Aharon Bassman, the son of Sheila and Myron Bassman of New York. Rabbi Richard F. Steinbrink will officiate at the Sheraton Society Hill Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTOK, CHAIM
description: POTOK-Chaim. A memorial service for Chaim Potok will be held on Sunday October 27, 3 PM at The Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Buying Savings Bonds In a Virtual Environment
description: Investors who have the urge to buy a $25.01 United States Savings Bond can now do so. For that matter, they can now buy bonds in one-cent increments from $25 all the way up to $30,000 whenever they want.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Fees Are Forcing College Stations to Scale Back on Webcasts
description: Playing alternative rock and urban folk music, the student-run radio station at the University of Wisconsin was broadcasting to fans from the far corners of the campus to the far corners of the earth.

title: Really Tiny Bubbles
description: In Champagne this season, bottlers are scaling down. As a nod to the younger, Mini Me generation, France's bubbly-wine makers have introduced miniature Champagne bottles, with accessories to match. This month, Mot & Chandon began selling the miniflute, a tiny Champagne glass that slides into the neck of the Mini Mot. The miniflutes come with the wine in a pack of four at liquor stores across the United States for a suggested retail price of $39.99. For aprs-ski bunnies, Pommery (www.pop-champagne.com) has created quarter-bottles, called POP, fitted with diminutive ski parkas designed by Maurizio Galante. The jackets hit the shelves of Le Bon March, an upscale department store in Paris, this November, for about $29. They will also be sold at duty-free stores in the United States and at Sherry-Lehmann on Madison Avenue, for $40. ''Champagne is a very traditional wine, but the packaging, the shape of the bottle, the label, the various boxes -- they change constantly,'' said Daniel Lorson, a spokesman for the Interprofessional Champagne Committee. ''The show is as important as the wine itself.'' Apparently, the show just got a little smaller. KERRY SHAW

title: SEARS IS SUED
description: The state is suing Sears, Roebuck & Company, accusing it of overcharging at least 362 customers in its auto repair centers. Sears mechanics charged customers for four-wheel alignments when only the front wheels could be aligned, and mechanics also made unauthorized repairs to vehicles, the state charged in its suit, filed last week. Sears, which settled fraud charges filed in New Jersey and California 10 years ago, is investigating the new charges and will take ''appropriate action,'' said Peggy Palter, a spokeswoman for the company. Karen DeMasters

title: What to Do, and Not to Do, as Winter Nears
description: TREES, shrubs and vines may need some help getting ready for winter. But to face frigid winter temperatures, what most plants need from you is nothing. Pruning, fertilizing and watering all tend to stimulate growth or cellular activity at a time when plants need to shut down.

title: The View From/Old Saybrook; Falling Down With Time, Held Up by History
description: THE 1750 William Tully House sits, surrounded by ''No trespassing'' signs, on a narrow strip of land facing the Connecticut River in Old Saybrook's Colonial heart.

title: Long Beach Closer On Storm Protection
description: The City of Long Beach has sent a letter of intent to the state Department of Environmental Conservation expressing support for an $85.2 million Army Corps of Engineers storm damage reduction protection project that would rebuild the city's oceanfront beaches.

title: Death and Life
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Under the Lens: Southeast Asia Confronts Its Demons
description: IT was quickly dubbed the second front in the war on terrorism. In the months following the Sept. 11 attacks, a series of arrests in Singapore and Malaysia and the Philippines seemed to imply that Al Qaeda had slipped down-continent and established itself from Bangkok to Manila and across the Indonesian archipelago.

title: For the Web Generation, Travel Is Self-Service
description: WHEN Enda Carey booked his first trip on the Internet in 1998, a journey from New York to Argentina and Brazil, he wasn't immediately convinced that what he'd done was real.

title: The De Facto Capital
description: As a D.C. resident who has lived and spent much time in Manhattan, I've always been puzzled by your borough's obsession with justifying its greatness. I think I speak for a lot of Washingtonians when I say: New York, we love you, baby, but oh, get a life!

title: Our Towns; Waiting for Drug Laws to Change, and Marking Off the Years
description: IF nothing else, Elaine Bartlett has gotten some nice snapshots of herself with big-shot New York politicians in recent months. Pataki. Silver. McCall. Golisano. Not shabby company for a woman just two years out of prison.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE PICKUP, by Nadine Gordimer. (Penguin, $14.) This novel about a rich, white South African woman and a Muslim immigrant whose random encounter turns into a love affair explores how their mutual incomprehension is connected to their mutual attraction. The result is ''a painful account of this unlikely coupling, its persistent misunderstandings, its interaction with a world that increasingly pits wealthy, globally connected Westerners with the often stateless, roaming poor of the world,'' Andrew Sullivan wrote here in 2001.

title: Alluring And Austrian
description: Austria's national grape, the grner veltliner, and its dry wines are increasingly luring young sommeliers. The producer Nigl's brilliant 2001 grner veltliner, from the Kremser Freiheit vineyard in the Kremstal region, is a tapestry of subtle tropical fruit flavors, herbs, minerals and saltiness. It's a $16 giveaway at Winesby.com, 23 Jones Street (near Bleecker Street), Greenwich Village. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Former Mayor Is Acquitted In '69 Race Riot Killing; Two Others Are Convicted
description: Two men were convicted of murder yesterday in the 1969 shooting death of a young black woman during race riots in York, Pa. But a third defendant, York's former mayor, was found not guilty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, JOHN
description: ROSE-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Rose, associated with The Times from 1965 until retiring in 1974.

title: Bush Seeks More Rules To Protect 401(k) Plans
description: President Bush said today that ''more steps are needed'' to protect employee retirement packages from corporate wrongdoing, as he took credit for putting rules in effect under legislation passed by Congress.

title: Giants Pick Staff That Leans to Left
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 19  The San Francisco Giants took the same roster from the National League Championship Series into the World Series, keeping eligible their three left-handed relievers, Scott Eyre, Aaron Fultz and Chad Zerbe.

title: New Rochelle's Late Drive Clinches Class AA South Title
description: New Rochelle quarterback Pete Oswald stood on the sideline in the fourth quarter yesterday knowing that he would have a chance to lead his team downfield and break a 19-19 tie against Mount Vernon. After the Huguenots' loss last week to North Rockland, Oswald knew this was his chance to redeem himself and lead his team to to a division title.

title: The Second Deadly Sin, in a City That Knows It Well
description: THE SETTING -- The New York Public Library, where 100 New Yorkers spent Tuesday night taking a hard look at their souls. The topic -- appropriate in this city of the rich and acquisitive -- was ''Greed,'' the second in a series of lectures on the seven deadly sins. The hosts were the library and Oxford University Press, which is to publish a series of books on sin next year. The speaker was Phyllis Tickle, a majestic 68-year-old from Tennessee who is a contributing editor in religion at Publishers Weekly and has written more than two dozen books on religion and spirituality.

title: Habitats/312 West 11th Street; Getting Into Show Biz On the Ground Floor
description: ROBIN WHITEHOUSE may be sorry she said it, because it's not a sentiment many New York theater producers often express, but she really likes to give newcomers a chance.

title: Private Sector; A Hunter at Home at 30,000 Feet
description: STEPHEN A. LUCKEY has shot at black bears with a .338 Winchester Magnum, Vietnamese soldiers with a Thompson submachine gun and woodchucks with a .22-caliber rifle.

title: The Remote Controllers
description: Sarah D. Bunting and Tara Ariano are obscure names in the high-stakes world of Hollywood TV production. They are anything but L.A. insiders; Bunting works in Manhattan, while Ariano is based in Toronto. Yet their opinions carry real weight among the producers and writers who fashion many of the most popular programs on television. The two women are co-editors of a Web site called Television Without Pity, and that's a name producers know extremely well. True to its name, Televisionwithoutpity.com critiques shows mercilessly and includes message boards where vast communities of passionate viewers register everything from arcane appraisals of a program's story line to their hatred of an actor's leather jacket. When TWoP editors run interviews with writers and producers on the site, it is usually because the Hollywood types have contacted them, a little dazed by the level of the site's vitriol.

title: Jennifer Taylor, Eric Friedland
description: Jennifer Suzanne Taylor, a daughter of Anita Sher Taylor and Dr. Ronald S. Taylor of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married last evening to Eric Adam-Lee Friedland, the son of Pauline C. Friedland of Tenafly, N.J., and Melvin S. Friedland of New York. Rabbi Harold S. Loss officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Dearborn, Mich.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Mercedes-Benz E-Class; Business-Class Cabin; Show-Biz Style
description: AUTUMN brings shorter days, Christmas catalogs and a bumper crop of redesigned cars and trucks. The main wave of new models is arriving in showrooms now; among these, the Mercedes-Benz E-Class sedan is one of the most significant cars in the class of 2003.

title: Volunteers Give Trail A Natural Connection
description: For those who trek from peak to peak along the Appalachian Trail, this is a definite low point. Aptly called the Pochuck Quagmire, a broad valley of empty meadow and soggy marshland here has long forced hikers to detour and dodge traffic along two and a half miles of shoulderless highway.

title: The Perfect Storm
description: A WORLD TURNED OVER

title: Strollers Aplenty, but What About Desks?
description: There must be a lot of love on the East Side. The area has experienced a baby boomlet, fueled not only by ardor but also by prosperity, residential construction and good schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABALME, PATRICIA HOCHSCHILD
description: LABALME-Patricia Hochschild. On October 11, 2002, at the age of 75. She was the wife of George Labalme Jr., mother of Jennifer R. Labalme, Henry G. Labalme, Lisa G. Osterland & Victoria A. Labalme, grandmother of six, and sister of Ann H. Poole, all of whom mourn her passing. A graduate of the Brearley School and Magna Cum Laude graduate of Bryn Mawr, she held an M.A. and Ph.D. from Harvard, where she was awarded the Caroline A. Wilby prize for her doctoral dissertation as ''the best original work in any department.'' Among her many professional activities, Patricia Labalme was Associate Director of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ, (1982-1988) and Secretary of the Corporation (1982-1992). From 1992-1997, she was Assistant to the Director, Dr. Phillip A. Griffiths. Most recently, she was a Visitor in the School of Historical Studies, at the IAS. Known also for her dedication to independent school education, she was, among her many affiliations, president of the Brearley Board of Trustees (1978-1982). She was also a trustee of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation (1979Present), the American Academy in Rome (1979-1999), the first female trustee of the Lawrenceville School (1985-1996), and a trustee of the Renaissance Society of America (1982-Present). She was also a member of the Ateneo Veneto and the Istituto di Scienze, Lettere ed Arti, both in Venice, and Director of the Quantum Chemical Corporation. Her passion for humanism was formed by her lifelong friendships with professors Werner Jaeger, Myron P. Gilmore, Helen Maud Cam, Paul Oskar Kristeller, Vittore Branca and Felix Gilbert. It was Gilbert, her professor at Bryn Mawr and her colleague at the IAS, who, after three decades of encouragement, persuaded her to start her book on Marino Sanudo's diaries. At the time of her death, Dr. Labalme was close to completing this book, which received initial funding from the NEH. The book will be published posthumously under a unique arrangement in which the IAS has created a special position, a Director's Visitor, to be held by Professor Laura S. White, who will oversee the book's completion. A private service was held at the family home in West Cornwall, CT, on October 14. A memorial service will be held at the Marciana Library in Venice. In addition, a New York City memorial service will be held at the Brearley School at a later date to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers can be made to the Brearley School, attention: Alumnae Office, 610 East 83rd Street, New York, New York 10028, for the benefit of faculty salaries.

title: Eat, and Buy, Organic
description: To the Editor:

title: When Figs Fall in Brooklyn, It's Time to Party
description: ONE day during the sweltering heat of August, Laurie Cearley sat in the backyard of her ground-floor Williamsburg apartment, looked up at the sky and was amazed: her fig tree was heavy with ripe green fruit. ''I was so excited,'' she recalled. ''It was like a baby.''

title: Flat Top Wins Steeplechase
description: Flat Top's flag-to-wire victory in the $250,000 Grade I Breeders' Cup Steeplechase at the Far Hills (N.J.) Steeplechase yesterday earned him a shot at his second Eclipse Award in five years.

title: Top 30 Looming for Hoch
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla., Oct. 19  Five players over the age of 40 have won on the PGA Tour this year. Scott Hoch would like to increase that number by one.

title: A Talent Show Straight From the Heart
description: SCHOOLS have been in session long enough that it's talent show time, and perhaps you've received an invitation to see Miss Mandel's kindergarten chorus, Mr. Baxter's sixth-grade magicians, the local high school's Britney imitators. But chances are you've never seen a talent show like the one the other day at the Matheny School in Peapack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORR, WILLIAM PRATT
description: ORR-William Pratt (age 85). On Tuesday, October 8, 2002, in Florida. Predeceased by Mildred Myers Orr, his wife of 57 years; survived by his wife, Pauline Sullivan Orr; a son, Richard Orr of Darien, CT; a daughter, Marie Perlet of Ashton, MD; four grandchildren, and a brother, Robert Orr of Stockton, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDENTHAL, WALTER
description: FRIEDENTHAL-Walter. On October 18, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Renee. Loving son of the late Esther and Max. Adored father of Alan and Eric and father-inlaw of Laura and Felicity. Cherished grandfather of Lanie and Meryl. Dear brother of Doris Schwartz and the late Abraham Friedenthal. Friend to all at Bayside Senior Center. Funeral Sunday, 9:15 AM, at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: When to Err on the Side of Disclosure
description: SEVERAL years ago, the chief executive of a company that repairs aircraft engine parts told me about the time he was called out of a board meeting. He had received a fax from an airline saying that it was grounding eight aircraft on which his company had done engine repairs. ''They were not going to let the jets fly because the turbines went kaput,'' the executive said. ''And they were saying that our parts had caused the problem.'' An hour later, he received another call from the airline, and then another. In all, 11 planes were grounded.

title: Payback Time
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: In France, A New Modesty
description: FRANCE is not known as a prudish country, but its center-right government has found itself swept up in a firestorm of debate about whether and how much to legislate sex.

description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila. 10/16/40-10/20/90. Cherished mother. How can it be that I have lived 1/3 of my life without you? Allison
