Stark (Heidi); Grandma of Jennifer Culver (John) and Julie Gold (Adam Smith), Andrea and Justin Stark. Services 2:30 pm, today, Danzansky Memorial Chapel, Rockville, MD.

title: The 'Peanuts' Gang Gets Its Graceland
description: ''Peanuts'' fans can now learn more about the artist and his legacy at the recently opened Charles M. Schulz Museum and Research Center in Schulz's hometown of Santa Rosa, Calif., 55 miles north of San Francisco. Schulz, who died in February 2000, was intimately involved in the museum's planning.

title: In Europe, Sex Slavery Is Thriving Despite Raids
description: An intensive European operation conducted with American assistance to crack down on the trafficking of women for the sex trade has had mixed success, American officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, MORTON J.
description: LEVY-Morton J. Of the Berkshires and Boca Raton, FL, after a valiant battle with cancer. Born and raised in NYC. Saw distinguished service as Army Air Force pilot with 62 missions over enemy territory in WWII. Married in 1943 to Georgette Rosenthal. He was the third generation of his family in the toy industry. He formed his own business, Gabriel Industries. After retiring he attended Fordham College at Lincoln Center at age 60 and graduated magna cum laude. He formed and chaired the Board of Advisors at Fordham College at Lincoln Center. Former member of the Board at New York Hospital. He chaired the Board at Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, MA for nine years and was a distinguished member of the Board of the Austen Riggs Center in Stockbridge, MA. Former Chairman of the Board of the Boca Raton Venue of the Florida Philharmonic. He was a friend and mentor to many. Beloved husband of Georgette (Rosenthal) Levy for nearly 60 years. Adoring father of Ellen Levy-Lanciano (Tobi) and the late Leon J. Levy. Proud grandfather of David Dahari (Brandi) and Jonathan Lanciano. Loving brotherin-law of Beverly (Rosenthal) Mazursky and caring uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Contributions to the Fordham College at Lincoln Center, Morton J. Levy Scholarship Fund, 113 West 60th Street, NYC 10023 or to the charity of your choice.

title: Investing; Office Furniture Stocks Take a Seat and Wait
description: THE market for new office furniture has fallen sharply over the last two years, as waves of corporate layoffs have left many companies with more furnishings than employees.

title: 2 Friends Put Aside Amity At Disney
description: Chris DiMarco and Skip Kendall have been close friends for years. Close enough that seven years ago, when DiMarco's struggles with his putting became desperate, Kendall showed him a new grip. DiMarco tried the grip, called the claw, and his career took off.

title: Bookshelf
description: COW. By Malachy Doyle. Illustrated by Angelo Rinaldi. Margaret K. McElderry. $17. (Ages 5 to 9) The life of a dairy cow might not seem a large-scale or romantic subject for a children's book, but in this huge format with brief text and lush paintings of the big-eyed bovines, it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, MILDRED H.
description: KATZ - Mildred H. Died peacefully at home on October 17, 2002, at the age of 96. Beloved wife of the late Leonard Katz. Mother of Tony Hill and Polly Hill Landess, stepmother of Laura Katz and John Katz. Loving grandmother to Simon and Elliot Hill, Joshua, Michael and Nicholas Landess and Kimberly Katz. Mrs. Katz was a merchandise manager at Bergdorf Goodman for 30 years and millinery buyer at Lord & Taylor. Active in many charities, she was a founding member of the Manhattan Chapter of the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. Services at home, 1025 Fifth Avenue, Sunday, 1 PM. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. She will be missed for her beauty, generosity, and easy laugh.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: NONFICTION
description: THEATER OF WAR.

title: Chicago's Bradley Interests MetroStars
description: The MetroStars have expressed interest in signing Chicago Fire Coach Bob Bradley, Commissioner Don Garber of Major League Soccer said yesterday.

title: Kathleen Spinelli, Joe Miller II
description: Kathleen Spinelli and Joe Miller II were married last evening at Astra, a party space in Manhattan. Judge John W. Carter of Brooklyn Criminal Court officiated.

title: Campaign Season; Leadership in Statehouses at Stake
description: Control of Congress is not the only thing up for grabs on Election Day. So is leadership of most state legislatures, where partisan advantage is just as narrowly divided. Democrats run both chambers in 18 states, Republicans have 17, and 14 are split between the parties. (Nebraska has a one-house, nonpartisan system).

title: Sour Grapes
description: THE FAR SIDE OF EDEN

title: Smelly Is Good for Us
description: For those who enjoy a good mess (and what child doesn't?), Kate and Jim McMullan's I STINK! (Joanna Cotler/HarperCollins, $15.95; ages 4 to 8) chronicles a day in the life of a garbage truck, in a city that might be New York. It's actually a quirky alphabet, framed by an unusual marriage of instruction and personification.

title: Footlights
description: For Future Generations

title: Letters
description: The Beltway vs. the Borough: Let the games begin! Frank Rich leveled the first salvo at D.C., and scores rallied in response. But, hey, some asked, where did all that post-9/11 comity go? Others defended Lynne Stewart's right to represent the radical sheik but called her politics wrong.

title: Trained to Be Courageous
description: A little girl vanishes in the dead of night, and even the F.B.I. is clueless. But when Brie, a rescue dog, arrives at the scene, she catches a whiff of something the humans can't sense - and that sends her running toward a river where a man, child in arms, stands on a wooden bridge.

title: Devils' Lack of Offense Finally Catches Up With Them
description: The Devils had to consider themselves fortunate through the first three games of their season. They kept finding ways to win even as their stars kept missing the net.

title: A Grim Investigator Goes It Alone
description: LIKE many politicians, William F. Galvin has retained advisers on matters of image, style and political appeal. ''I've had many consultants,'' said Mr. Galvin, the Massachusetts official who is leading the investigation of Credit Suisse First Boston. ''The nice ones put it this way: 'You know you're a stiff.' The less-nice ones say: 'You come across as a monster. You don't smile enough. You're grim.''

title: Coach Isn't Choosy About His Boss
description: Global slump got you glum? Worried about job security?

title: Legislating the New York Way In a Chronic Case of Gridlock
description: A two-year-old federal law withholds money from states that fail to adopt tougher drunken driving laws, lowering the legal blood alcohol limit from .10 to .08. Most states have complied, but not New York, an omission that has cost the state $30 million, and counting.

title: Mapping an Avalanche
description: Last month, a glacier that clung to a mountain face in the Russian republic of North Ossetia collapsed, initially sending eight million tons of ice crashing into the valley below. More than 20 million tons of mud, rock and ice had accumulated in the gorge by the time the avalanche stopped. Summer had brought heavy rains, and when the weather turned colder, there was even more ice on the Maili glacier; possibly because of the amassed weight or an earthquake tremor, it finally gave way on Sept. 20. It was the third time in a century that part of this glacier fell, but this avalanche distinguished itself by claiming an estimated 140 lives. Among those lost under the ice were a film crew and Sergei Bodrov Jr., Russia's James Dean, immortalized by the sudden force of nature. As heroes of the Soviet past had begun slipping from collective memory, the boyish Bodrov, 30, won the love of many Russians. His popular and overtly nationalist film ''Brother'' was criticized by some as racist; nevertheless it struck a chord in a nation that had lost its sense of pride. A government official estimates it will take a decade for the icy grave to thaw. The roaring violence of that day is nearly impossible to imagine now. The only reminder is when the ice creaks as it melts. Sabrina Tavernise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, PHILIP CRANE
description: JONES-Philip Crane. October 16, 2002, while pursuing one of his passions, rock climbing, in Yosemite National Park. Cherished son of Debby and Barton Jones, best friend and brother of Peter and Stuart and funniest of 30 loving grandchildren of Peggy and Curry Jones and John and the late Phyllis Crane. Born in New York City on October 23, 1978. Housatonic River fly fishing guide, sculptor and graduate of Bard College, Northfield Mt. Hermon School and Grace Church School. His memorial service will be held in Grace Church, Tenth Street and Broadway in New York City at 4:30 PM, on Thursday, October 24, 2002. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Philip's memory to The Housatonic Valley Association, P.O. Box 28, Cornwall Bridge, CT 06754-0028 or to his college or either of his schools.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHEVLIN, DR. ALEXANDER
description: SHEVLIN-Dr. Alexander. 3/2/17-10/20/01. We remember your wisdom, wit and warm. You are with us every day. Love Abbe, Sally, David and Ian

title: From Bullpen to Stump
description: IT'S the top of the seventh inning, and the home team is down by three runs. The visitors have the bases loaded and no one out, and the starting pitcher has thrown eight consecutive balls to the last two batters. Clearly he has nothing left.

title: Going Organic
description: JOE RUGGIERI'S crops this year at Hopeview Farm included green beans, sold at his produce stand for a dollar a pound. Next year his offerings will include organic ''haricots verts'' -- French for green beans -- that cost a hefty $6 a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, JOHN
description: MURRAY-John. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John Murray, associated with The Times from 1950 until retiring in 1981.

title: Scared Senseless
description: I have seen the shot in so many films it has become a clich: the cool professional on a high rooftop, wearing a black turtleneck or maybe a coat and tie, assembles his weapon thoughtfully, checks his watch, blinks through the cross hairs until his target comes into sight, and then he squeezes off a subtle pop. When his work is completed, this man does not run. He packs up his belongings as if they were papers going into a briefcase and heads off toward the stairwell. Another day at the office.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the film series ''Scary Movies: 30 Years of Horror,'' at the Walter Reade Theater, misidentified the author of the short story ''The Monkey's Paw,'' which was cited as a model for the 1972 film ''Deathdream.'' It was by W. W. Jacobs, not O. Henry.

title: With One Pass, Entry To New York Sights
description: Visitors to New York City can buy a pass offering admission to 40 attractions, along with such extras as a 20 percent discount on a meal at the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, champagne on a dinner cruise and a $50 upgrade on a helicopter tour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYERS, HARRY
description: MAYERS-Harry. On October 17, 2002 at the age of 93. Devoted husband of Helen Mayers. Beloved father of Melvin Mayers and Phyllis Mayers. Dear father-in-law of Elaine Mayers. Adored grandfather of Candace Shaw, Brian Krinsky and Jennifer Mayers. Proud great grandfather of Harleigh, Zachary and Harrison Shaw. Brother of Florence Goldberg. He will always be loved and remembered. Services took place on Friday, October 18, 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AXLER, MELVIN
description: AXLER - Melvin. Dearest father, another year. Always loved, never forgotten. M and T

title: Don't Call It a String Quartet. It's a Band.
description: EVERY month, dozens of ambitious, hungry young bands play in the cramped confines of the KnitActive Sound Stage, downstairs at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa. So an appearance there tonight by Ethel, a four-piece band hoping that the club's downtown cachet will attract a new audience, may seem nothing unusual. Yet Ethel is basically a classical string quartet, and its concert of works by John King, Phil Kline and Julia Wolfe is part of Sonic Boom, a festival presented by the New York Consortium for New Music, which promotes contemporary classical music.

title: Words Add Flavor To Hillwood Music
description: CAROLINE STOESSINGER is a patient woman. It has taken 13 years, but when ''Music at Hillwood'' opens its 14th season at Tilles Center today, the pianist will stage the kind of concert she always envisioned, by adding drama to the musical mix.

title: A Switch in Mid-Race
description: IT will be dj vu for Democrats on Election Day in the Sound Shore communities. Voters in the 91st Assembly District will be choosing between Noam Bramson and Ronald C. Tocci to represent them in Albany -- precisely the same choice that Democrats faced in the primary. This time Mr. Tocci is running as a Republican.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AKIN, ADOLPH
description: AKIN-Adolph. 10/15/01 ''How do I love thee let me count the ways...'' Your sweet soul, handsome face and the love in your eyes will never leave me. Evy

title: Deterring the Undeterrable
description: THE THREATENING STORM

title: Club Med, Two Ways
description: A first-timer tries out Cancn's menu of beach-centered activities and Paradise Island's more formal pursuits.

title: The New Lower East Side
description: Slowly, inexorably, the Lower East Side is losing its touchstones of Jewish immigrant life. At the same time, the area's mythic qualities are deepening.

title: Irish Vote for a Wider Union, and Europe Celebrates
description: With the final results tallied from a referendum here that endorsed a major expansion of the European Union, diplomats and officials across the continent celebrated the vote today with some relief, saying it heralded a redrawing of the continent's frontiers. The ballot reversed an Irish vote last year to reject the enlargement plan.

title: Interpreter Dropped In Yankees' Firings
description: The Yankees were the team hit hardest by the new collective bargaining agreement, and many of their employees felt the effects of that last week. The Yankees fired 25 front office employees, including Leo Astacio, who served as the interpreter for pitcher Orlando Hernndez.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mel Harder, 93, Indians Pitcher And Longtime Coach in Majors
description: Mel Harder, the Cleveland Indians right-hander who was among the top pitchers of the 1930's and later became a renowned pitching coach in a major league career spanning 42 seasons, died yesterday at his home in Chardon, Ohio. He was 93.

title: Princeton's Fortunes Change in Close Ones
description: Princeton is winning the close ones. The Tigers' best asset in their turnaround season has been playing better when the pressure is greater. Princeton has won its last three games by a total of 9 points, including its 16-14 victory over Brown on Saturday.

title: Compressed Data; Computer Fix Thyself Is Aim of I.B.M. Unit
description: The devilish complexity of computers and -- worse -- networks of computers, has long been the bane of the engineers who try to keep corporate computer systems up and running. And the complexity has exploded in recent years with the rise of the Internet.

title: Jogger Case Confessions
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: East Orange: Expanded Arson Investigation
description: The federal government is investigating at least 10 suspicious fires for signs of a pattern of arson, the Essex County prosecutor's office said. Jeffrey Cartwright, the director of the arson task force in the prosecutor's office, said the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the prosecutor's office would look at 10 fires in 10 days and also planned to look at fires going back at least a year. During the fires in vacant buildings this month, four firefighters were injured. Landlords had abandoned many of these buildings in the 1970's and 1980's after a series of rooftop fires. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIFF, STANLEY
description: SCHIFF - Stanley. Beloved husband and father. We miss you a lot. Helen Posey, Anne, and Ric

title: Sports of The Times; Finally, Angels Win A World Series Game
description: IN a land where people keep reinventing themselves, the Angels could truly be America's team. Like people who come up with new addresses, new spouses, new identities, new faces, new businesses, the Angels kept making changes in the hopes of getting it right.

title: Midtown Traffic: The Mess in the Box
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; For Big Game Maker, Online Play Is a Big Gamble
description: Electronic Arts is a Silicon Valley company markedly out of step with its neighbors.

title: That Other War: Drugs in Our Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Funk, Soul or Progressive Rock, Make It Snappy
description: It's pretty extraordinary for a jazz musician as skilled and smart as Joshua Redman not to make his music even a little forbidding. Not that he must: nobody set a rule that serious mainstream jazz musicians have to make music that comes from deep within and goes over most people's heads. But for at least 40 years the ideas of seriousness and progress have held sway in jazz.

title: BUSH TEAM URGES BOLD INSPECTIONS OF IRAQ'S ARSENAL
description: The Bush administration, anticipating approval of a United Nations Security Council resolution that falls short of what it was seeking, is now pressing harder than ever for inspections of Iraq's weapons program to be carried out quickly and forcefully. Administration officials say the goal is to prevent months of delay that could postpone retaliation for Iraq's noncompliance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RAYMOND, M.D.
description: MILLER-Raymond, M.D. On October 19, 2002. Loving husband of Berenice and proud father of Daniel and David. Retired Vice Chairman of the Anesthesiology Department at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, where he spent his entire medical career in the United States. Raymond, born in London, was a gentleman and scholar, and will be remembered for his honesty, compassion and complete devotion to his family.

title: Comforting Voice in Family
description: Maryliz Gonzalez, 17, recalled that when she was nervous about getting her license, her favorite uncle, Joe Robles, soothed her and gave her driving lessons. He was there for all the milestones in her life, Ms. Gonzalez said yesterday, "my communion, my confirmation, my eighth-grade graduation. He was always there for me."

title: Eagles, With Defense, Continue Mastery of Bucs
description: Warren Sapp, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' meaty and mouthy defensive tackle, was facedown on the Veterans Stadium carpet, right where the merciless Philadelphia Eagles fans wanted him. After struggling to his feet, dazed and blinking after getting hit in the face on a second-quarter play, he walked to the sideline to gather himself, a fortuitous exit for an Eagles offense that had grown tired of his disruptive presence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SELMA
description: RUBEN - Selma. Cherished wife of Lawrence. Beloved mother of Richard, Lenore and Rochelle. Adored grandmother of Tamara, Danielle, William, Andrew, Melissa, Robert, James, Allison and Caroline. Devoted sister and sister-in-law of Robert Belfer, Renee Belfer, Jack Saltz and the late Anita Saltz. Her passion for life and dedication to her family were unsurpassed. Funeral services will be Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering Hospital, New York Hospital or Rockefeller University to further the cause of cancer research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUGAN, HUGH C.
description: DUGAN-Hugh C. 90, of Cornwall, PA, formerly of Nutley, NJ, died peacefully on October 16, 2002. Dear husband of Ora, beloved father of Sloane and Susan, adored grandfather of Bina, Renee, Matt and Christine, brother of Madelyne, treasured friend of Bruce and Tana. Graduated 1935 from Syracuse University with a degree in mechanical engineering; founded Carlee Corp. in 1951; was active in and served as Chairman of the Board at Vincent United Methodist Church in Nutley. We were inspired by his enormous capacity for life, boundless energy, and devotion to family and friends. His embracing spirit was evident in his compassion and generosity for those in need. Memorial service Ssturday, Ocotber 26, 2 PM, at Vincent Church, 100 Vincent Place, Nutley, NJ 07110. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Church in Nutley.

description: `Double Play Dance'

description: THE CRAZED

title: Talk Shows Prove Key to White House
description: For most of last week, it looked as if the White House would not make news this morning. The Sunday talk shows had been trying for more than a month to coax the Bush administration to answer questions about Iraq and, once again, the answer was the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TORO, PULI
description: TORO-Puli. 62, died of ovarian cancer on October 4. Daughter of the late Cesar and Munchita. Leaves a brother, Dr. Cesar Toro, a niece and two nephews, all of San Juan, Puerto Rico. Puli was a brilliant mezzo soprano, inspired teacher and perhaps the greatest interpreter of Puerto Rican music. Her career included performing at the New York City Opera and at opera houses worldwide. A memorial concert will be held on November 15, at St. Stephen's Church, 120 West 69th St, at 8 PM. We will never forget how you uplifted our lives. Your Loving Friends

title: The Week's Economic Events
description: MONDAYLeading IndicatorsSept.

title: Prosecutorial Outrage in Florida
description: Of all the high-profile courtroom dramas in recent years, none have been more surreal than the case of the two young brothers convicted in Florida last month of bludgeoning their father to death. Prosecutors, uncertain who was responsible for the killing, decided, bizarrely, to proceed against the boys in one trial and, at the same time, against a different suspect, under a different theory, in a second trial. The judge in the boys' trial was right last week to toss out their convictions.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Popular Science Properties, New York, which publishes Popular Science magazine, named Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners, New York, as agency of record, to create consumer and trade campaigns and advise on strategic marketing. Billings were not disclosed. Popular Science is part of Time4Media, a division of Time Inc., part of AOL Time Warner.

title: Editorial Observer; Churchgoing Tourists View Harlem on Sunday Mornings
description: Thirty people exit a bus double-parked on a crowded street. There's an air of expectation as they wait to file in and take their seats. They look around at the vast structure, the richly colored paraments, the stylish congregation. And then it begins: the joyous music that fills the church and, even to unaccustomed ears, carries a powerful message of praise, sacrifice and hope.

title: News Analysis; North Korea's Confession: Why?
description: When the United States announced last week that North Korean officials had acknowledged the existence of a secret nuclear weapons program in violation of a 1994 accord, a simple question could be heard echoing around the world: What were the North Koreans thinking?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAGE, ELOISE RANDOLPH
description: PAGE-Eloise Randolph. On Wednesday October 16, 2002 of Washington DC. Sister of the late Randolph Rosewell Page, Jr. Also survived by extended family, the Randolphs of Virginia and Washington DC, the Pages, the Dunnings, the Harrisons and the Mitchells, all of Virginia. Also survived by her care-giver and friend, Michael Eldridge and her companions Randolph and Rosewell. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday October 23 at 10 AM at Christ Church, Georgetown, 31 and O Street NW. Graveside services will be held at 1:30 PM on October 23 at Old Chapel Cemetery, Millwood, Virgina, Clark County. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Christ Church, Georgtown and/or The Old Chapel, Millwood. For more information contact Joseph Gawlers & Sons.

title: Victims With Seven-Day Workweeks; Celebrating a Christening
description: A day off was a rarity for Kleber Valencia, a 29-year-old Ecuadorean immigrant and livery-cab driver who often worked seven days a week to support his wife, Zulieka, and their three children, Kleber Jr., 9; Chelsea, 4; and Nadia, 6 months.

title: Three Female Lawyers Finding Their Footing
description: David E. Kelley's newest series, ''girls club,'' doesn't take long to get around to one of Mr. Kelley's signature humiliating incidents. In the first episode of this one-hour legal drama, tonight on Fox, a young lawyer interviews a client whose male gynecologist fainted during a pelvic exam and fell onto her in a particularly unfortunate position. (The client gets an out-of-court settlement.)

title: Music Industry Is Resisting Tougher Label Standards
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut Democrat, and Representative Billy Tauzin of Louisiana, a leading Congressional Republican, have renewed a push for recording companies to toughen labeling standards on sexually explicit and violent lyrics. But the music industry is in no rush to comply.

title: Pinault Secures Credit Line
description: Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the French retailer that controls the Gucci Group, said today that it had secured a 2.5 billion euro ($2.4 billion) credit line as it sought to shore up its cash and extend the repayment period of its debt.

title: Korean Negotiators Shiver at Chilly Talks
description: The dialogue began even before the delegates sat down to talk. The subject was the weather, but it turned into a verbal duel that captured their tense relationship in images of wind, clouds and rain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURER, IRENE
description: FURER-Irene. Beloved wife, mother and daughter, passed away October 19, in Palm Beach, FL. Services 12 noon, Tuesday, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, NYC.

title: Long Island Oyster Beds to Be Donated to Conservation Group
description: The Bluepoints Company, once a leader in Long Island's shellfish industry, made its name farming plump, juicy oysters that pleased the world's pickiest palates.

title: Saints Make Their Mark on 49ers in the Fourth Quarter
description: Whenever a game features 18 possessions and only one punt, that means the football is being run and tossed in risky, creative and colorful ways. That is exactly what San Francisco and New Orleans did today at the Louisiana Superdome in a splendid show of one-upmanship that the Saints mastered.

title: Vivendi Moves Up Deadline On Bids for Publishing Unit
description: Vivendi Universal is rushing suitors of its publishing business, which includes Houghton Mifflin, to submit final bids by today, executives involved in the discussions said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LABALME, PATRICIA HOCHSCHILD
description: LABALME-Patricia Hochschild. The Trustees and staff of the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation fondly remember our colleague and friend Patsy Labalme. Patsy was our senior trustee who, in many important ways, shaped the work and goals of the foundation. Her intelligence, character, good judgement, and grace set the tone for our deliberations. The way she lived and her achievements are the best arguments imaginable for the salutary effects of placing the humanities at the center of one's life. We join her many friends among the community of scholars in extending our condolences to her husband George and their family. We will do our best to continue her work at the foundation, and to measure up to the high standards she set for us all, but most of all, for herself.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: F.C.C. Chief Says Telecom Isn't Doomed By Cutbacks
description: Don't send out an S.O.S. for the telecom equipment industry just yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGHAM, HENRY J. III
description: BINGHAM-Henry J. III. On October 13, 2002. Most dearly loved husband of Marianne G. Bingham. Graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of 1952, and Amos Tuck Business School, Class of 1953. Executive Managing Director of Van Eck Associates and Executive Vice President of Van Eck Securities. Youngest Junior Partner of Spencer Trask & Company. In 1968, upon incorporation of the firm, elected Vice President and Director. Also survived by four children, Susan, Lynda, Fiona and William, as well as nine grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister-in law, Patricia and his nephew Paul. Family will receive friends Tuesday, 4-9PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street. Funeral service Wednesday at 2 PM, at St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue at 53rd Street. If so desired, contributions can be made to Dartmouth College.

title: In 2nd Debate, Pataki's Rivals Go on Attack
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's opponents battered him today in a televised debate with charges of cronyism, corruption and mismanagement, with Tom Golisano repeatedly accusing the governor's administration of selling paroles for campaign contributions.

title: Church Rallies Behind Its Suspended Pastor
description: During the Prayer of the Faithful this morning at Holy Angels Church, tucked beside the standard petitions on behalf of Cardinal Francis George and President Bush, was a personal plea for a fallen shepherd.

title: Facing Stiff Challenge, Burns Wins First Title
description: Bob Burns had never done this before, but it did not look that way.

title: Hope and Lyric Rock From the Gentle Beatle
description: American Ballet Theater's latest instant hit, ''Within You Without You: A Tribute to George Harrison,'' is the tribute set to music by a rock idol that its title proclaims.

title: Why did free diver die?: Tragic plunge to the limits
description: Push your limits too far in most sports and you lose. Push your limits too far in free diving, Audrey Mestre's sport, and you die.

title: Suspect in Shooting of Two Drivers in Bronx Is Arrested Near Canada
description: A former marine who the police say stole a car at gunpoint in New Jersey on Saturday and drove to the Bronx, where he shot and killed two livery drivers, was arrested yesterday morning after a chase near the Canadian border, the authorities said.

title: College Football | Wrapup; MONDAY MORNING QUARTERBACK
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend:

title: A Revived Downfield Passing Game Piles Up the Yardage
description: Remember when there were complaints about the Jets' lack of a downfield passing attack? That was three weeks ago.

title: White House Letter; Still Advising, From Afar and Near
description: When last we heard from Karen P. Hughes, one of President Bush's closest and most powerful advisers, she and her golden retriever were in her 1995 Mazda on a hot July day headed south to Texas, where she would take up a sane new life away from the pressures of the White House. Her 15-year-old son, Robert, was leaving the stresses of St. Albans, the private incubator of Washington's male elite, for public school in Austin. Her husband, Jerry, a lawyer who had never found full-time work in the capital, would get a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, MURIEL
description: BROWN-Muriel. Born in Old Forge, PA, and resided in Del Ray, FL. Preceded in death by her husband Fred, brothers Morris, Harry, and Irving, sisters Pearl, Sylvie, Ida and Ruthie. Survived by her children Arline and Lester Zuckerman, Jerilynn and John Noto; grandchildren Richard and Brenda Zuckerman, Jarrett Zuckerman, and great-granddaughter Jordan; siblings Gladys, Arnold and Wilma. Remembered lovingly for her devotion to Judaism and to her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVAREZ BRAVO, MANUEL
description: ALVAREZ BRAVO-Manuel. A great photographer and a friend for the last 30 years will be deeply missed by Evelyne Z. Daitz, The Witkin Gallery.

title: 2 Companies Make Offer For Part of TXU Europe
description: Two large power companies have submitted bids for part of TXU Europe, the troubled subsidiary of TXU, the former Texas Utilities, people involved in the discussions said today.

title: Thunder in Paradise: A Resilient Bali Prepares for a Storm
description: The allure of surf and a Hindu culture of temples and incense that tolerated discos and drinking made Bali the elixir of good time, low-cost contemporary tourism.

title: Trying to Figure Out North Korea Motives
description: Close watchers of North Korea have struggled to make sense of the news that the nation operated a secret nuclear weapons program, in violation of a 1994 accord with the United States.

title: How Politics and Rivalries Fed Suspicions of a Meeting
description: A year after reports of a meeting came to light between the lead hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks, Mohamed Atta, and an Iraqi intelligence officer, Ahmad Khalil Ibrahim Samir al-Ani, the story behind the story of their supposed meeting in Prague is perhaps more interesting.

title: Long Treated as a Joke, Brazilian Neofascist May Have the Last Laugh
description: For years, he was written off as an eccentric fringe candidate, a neofascist oddity, a crackpot even. But Enas Ferreira Carneiro got his revenge in the general election this month, when more than 1.5 million people here in Brazil's largest state voted for him, giving him more votes than any other congressional candidate in Brazilian history.

title: Aftershocks of Terror, From Iraq to Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Upstate Voters Wait to Hear A Plan for Jobs
description: THE campaign for governor has not exactly riveted this city in central New York. Many of the people encountered during a visit here last week didn't even know that Syracuse was playing host to a campaign debate yesterday, nor did they evince much interest when told.

title: Are the Greens Pure, or Elitist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mason Hammond -- Scholar, 99
description: Mason Hammond, an authority on Latin and the history of Rome and its empire, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 99.

title: American Men and Women: Eights Wild and Winners
description: The American men and women swept the championship eights events for the second consecutive year at the end of the 38th annual Head of the Charles Regatta today.

title: A Boon for Nonprofits With Software Needs
description: If these are lean times for corporate information technology purchasers, what is the situation for nonprofit groups that need new hardware or software? Surprisingly good, as it turns out.

title: Love and Marriage, in the Language of Show Tunes
description: Is there any way married couples who perform together can break out of what might be called the Steve and Eydie syndrome? That was the unspoken question lurking behind Thursday's cabaret concert at the Kaplan Penthouse at Lincoln Center, where the Broadway stars Marin Mazzie (''Kiss Me, Kate'') and Jason Danieley (''The Full Monty'') sang an evening of mostly theatrical duets. The syndrome typically involves lots of ostentatious billing and cooing spiced with a dash of comic bickering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDES, HENRY M.
description: LANDES-Henry M. Loving husband of Lotte and her family Madelaine, Bill, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Dear uncle of Cerole, Arnie and their children and grandchildren. Services Wednesday, October 23, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Trouble in 'The West Wing'
description: Just a month ago, Aaron Sorkin, the man responsible for creating and writing the hit NBC series ''The West Wing,'' walked out of a theater in Los Angeles gripping his third consecutive Emmy award for best drama. He had every reason to believe he could head right over to NBC, brandish the latest award and, using the leverage that every producer of a hit show up for renegotiation has, tell the network to pay up.

title: Salmon Puts Angels on Track
description: They call him Kingfish. It is an obvious nickname for a player named Tim Salmon, but there is more to it than that. Salmon is the dean of the Anaheim Angels, their quiet leader. He has been here 11 years, playing through pain, living with the heartbreak that defined this franchise for decades.

title: A Chat With Sharon
description: After his visit with President Bush and Congressional leaders, Israel's Ariel Sharon returned to his farm, surveyed his cattle and sheep, and as the Sabbath sun set, took my call.

title: Sports of The Times; Spurrier Enduring A Painful Transition
description: DURING the three-hour drive from Madison to Green Bay, passing exit signs for Sheboygan and Oshkosh, I caught myself thinking about the lengths to which you'll go to see Steve Spurrier get religion.

title: INSIDE
description: Europe Celebrates Irish Vote

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, LIBBIE
description: ROSS-Libbie. Of Merrick, NY, October 19, 2002, at age 89. Beloved wife of Jesse, devoted mother of David (Carol) Ross and Laura (Jeffrey) Blumenfeld, adored grandmother of Peter (Maria Grazia) and Jeremy Ross, Jennifer (Graham) Schwarz and Joshua Blumenfeld. Loving sister to Nettie Schnure, and loving aunt to many neices and nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Her sweetness, wisdom, and warmth were treasured by all who knew and loved her, and she will be deeply missed.

title: Aftershocks of Terror, From Iraq to Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucas Struggles After Fast Start For Dolphins
description: As defensive end Pat Williams headed to the Buffalo Bills' locker room today, he shouted, ''Miami's overrated! Miami's overrated!'' And Williams did not soften that stance later.

title: Democrats Court the Elderly
description: This 30-second commercial, titled ''Starting Over,'' is one of four being broadcast beginning this week by the Democratic Party in states where President Bush is campaigning for local candidates. It will first appear on Tuesday in Bangor, Me., and Chester County, Pa. Party officials said they would spend several hundred thousand dollars on the commercial, but they would not specify the amount.

title: PRAGUE DISCOUNTS AN IRAQI MEETING
description: The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, has quietly told the White House he has concluded that there is no evidence to confirm earlier reports that Mohamed Atta, the leader in the Sept. 11 attacks, met with an Iraqi intelligence officer in Prague just months before the attacks on New York and Washington, according to Czech officials.

title: Helping the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Robotic Dogs and Singing Fish in Cross Hairs
description: When Senator Ernest F. Hollings set out to fight digital piracy, chances were he was not seeking to regulate the inner workings of digital hearing aids, robotic dogs or Shop With Me Barbie cash registers.

title: A French Milquetoast's Talent Lights the Fuse of Mischief
description: Even charming is too weighty a word to describe the wispy appeal of ''Amour,'' the twinkling trinket of a musical from the French pop composer Michel Legrand, which opened last night at the Music Box Theater.

title: Indonesia's Economics Minister Is Confident of Growth
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 21  Indonesia's chief economics minister said today that he was confident his country's economy would meet targets for 5 percent growth next year despite the terrorist bombing in Bali and its expected impact on tourism and foreign investment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALL, MILDRED
description: WALL-Mildred. On October 20, 2002, of Floral Park. Beloved wife of Sol, devoted mother of Barry Wall and Carol Epstein. Dear sister of Seymour Dulberg. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Michael, and Heather. Services today, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Dancing In the Dark
description: ''Never, never, never believe any war will be smooth and easy, or that anyone who embarks on the strange voyage can measure the tides and hurricanes he will encounter. The statesman who yields to war fever must realize that once the signal is given, he is no longer the master of policy but the slave of unforeseeable and uncontrollable events.''

title: Giant Bullpen Starts Strong
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 20  Deep in the top shelf of his locker at Edison Field Saturday night, Livan Hernandez, the San Francisco Giants' pitcher, had a stuffed Anaheim Angels' rally monkey. It was a fitting metaphor for what his teammates had just done. The Angels' late-inning magic, fueled by that frantic scoreboard monkey, had been shelved.

title: Still Replying To Grandma's Persistent, 'And Then?'
description: She was a thin woman without much fantasy. In her dress, I mean. Black from head to toe, in the Sicilian manner. She was a Sicilian, in fact, and she was my grandmother. She spoke little, and to my humiliation -- I wanted to be like the other American kids in the Bronx -- in Sicilian. And then, too, we were at the tail end of the war with Italy. So that in the street and other public places I answered her in English to distance myself.

title: 14 Die as Bomb-Filled S.U.V. Rams Israeli Bus
description: KARKUR JUNCTION, Israel, Oct. 21  A sport utility vehicle primed with a powerful bomb slammed into an Israeli bus at rush hour here this afternoon, igniting fuel tank of the bus and killing at least 14 passengers. Flames rendered the vehicle a blackened, contorted skeleton.

title: A Dark First Novel Suddenly Soars to the Top
description: Something unusual has been happening on the fiction best-seller list lately. A first novel is at No. 1.

title: Turmoil on the Battlefield And on the Home Front
description: Untangled, the events of Armistice Day 1944, in the southern Michigan town of Julie Jensen's play ''Cheat,'' went something like this:

title: Agassi Shows No Signs of Stopping
description: Anyone familiar with Andre Agassi knows the post-victory drill: bows and blown kisses to all four corners of the court, an engaging, empathetic speech and an extended wave on his way out the door with security guards keeping the excitement from turning into something more harrowing.

title: Private Art in Public
description: In America it is individuals, not governments, who have established public collections of art, books and manuscripts of dazzling quality, diversity and depth. The single-donor museum has long contributed to this nation's cultural richness. While tax deductions support the founding of these institutions, it has been the vision of generous donors that has given the public such treasures as Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, New York's Frick Collection, Los Angeles's Getty Museum, and more recently the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts in St. Louis, the Neue Galerie for German and Austrian Art in New York, and the Kreeger Museum in Washington, D.C.

title: Hunt for a Killer Creates A New Kind of Reality TV
description: A Ponderosa steakhouse in Ashland, Va., is where the police investigation of the suburban sniper and television's virtual one intersect.

title: New Bond Issues Will Be Brought To Market in Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill to be auctioned tomorrow.

title: Jets Grab A Victory And Hang On To Hope
description: As he walked off the field today, all Ted Cottrell, the Jets' defensive coordinator, could do was exhale, the sigh of relief and the bags under his eyes speaking volumes about how desperately the Jets' defense needed a game like this.

title: Jerome Rosow, Oil Executive, 82; Led Workplace Research Group
description: Jerome M. Rosow, the founder and chairman of the Work in America Institute, a nonprofit research organization that focuses on productivity and workplace issues, died on Oct. 11 at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 82 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Canadian Journal; The Poison Ivy Is Beautiful This Time of Year
description: Anyone who has lived in Texas can attest that fall is often a matter of interpretation. The dazzling displays of foliage that signal the change of seasons elsewhere in the country are scarce here. Often, the heat across much of Texas breaks only enough in October to adjust the air-conditioning, if not yet turn it off.

title: Sports of The Times; For Pennington, Reality Awaits
description: HIS numbers were dazzling. In the Jets' 20-7 triumph over the Vikings, Chad Pennington completed 24 of 29 passes for 324 yards and a touchdown, with only 2 sacks. Dazzling might even be an understatement for a third-year quarterback in only his second start.

title: A New Organic Era
description: Today marks a milestone in American farming. The Agriculture Department introduces a set of standards that define what the word ''organic'' means and which growers and products are qualified to use it. While most Americans tend to think of organic food as somehow healthier for themselves and their children, there is no hard evidence to support that. The real value of organic farming is its impact on our soil and water and livestock, on the very idea of farming itself. For that alone, it deserves our support.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 5 Plead Guilty In Computer Fraud
description: Five people, including a former Queens school superintendent and her husband, have pleaded guilty to defrauding a southeast Queens school district and have agreed to pay back $4.85 million, the Queens County district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. The five admitted they were part of what prosecutors called ''a corrupt scheme'' to rig bids, pay bribes and receive kickbacks in connection with contracts for school computers. Celestine Miller, 61, the former superintendent of Community School District 29; and her husband, William Harris, 84, both of Hempstead, N.Y., pleaded guilty on Friday.

title: Drawing on the Pain of the Recent Past
description: Stephen Petronio has increasingly turned his attention in recent years to the emotional content of a dance, imbuing his signature fast, glittering movement with nuances and texture of another sort. But emotions and recent history take an unusually central place in the two premieres presented by the Stephen Petronio Company on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater.

title: Victims With Seven-Day Workweeks; Comforting Voice in Family
description: Maryliz Gonzalez, 17, recalled that when she was nervous about getting her license, her favorite uncle, Joe Robles, soothed her and gave her driving lessons. He was there for all the milestones in her life, Ms. Gonzalez said yesterday, ''my communion, my confirmation, my eighth-grade graduation. He was always there for me.''

title: Jolted by North Korea, Japan Grows Angrier
description: American envoys working to forge a united front against North Korea are finding their most receptive ally in Japan, where revelations of kidnappings and spying by North Korea have already hardened opinion against it.

title: Irish No. 1 in Times; Now Comes B.C.S.
description: Leave it to Shane Walton, Notre Dame's animated senior cornerback, to sum up how it feels to be a member of the loved or loathed Fighting Irish. Even after his team had manhandled a previously undefeated and favored Air Force to run its record to 7-0, Walton was still not feeling much love.

title: China Company to Buy and Run A Bankrupt U.S. Battery Maker
description: A Chinese state-owned chemical company has agreed to rescue an American battery manufacturer from bankruptcy and continue its global manufacturing operations, a deal both sides called the first of its kind between the United States and China.

title: Mouth-Watering Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: As Battle Learns New Position, Irish Pass Another Test
description: Some critics might suggest that Notre Dame is often overrated and overpublicized, but few would blame its first-year coach, Tyrone Willingham, for the hyperbole. With Willingham, clichs and measured assessments come one at a time, most of the time.

title: British Bank Sells Stock in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 20  Standard Chartered started the sale of about $355 million of new shares in Hong Kong today, 143 years after it first opened its doors for business in the city of seven million people.

title: New Economy; Chief executives take the education of Congress in hand to help the Postal Service.
description: O.K., true or false?

title: A Thoroughbred of a Track to Stage the Breeders' Cup
description: After 75 years, any racetrack would have to have some stories, tales of the memorable and the forgettable, from terrific to terrible. It's just that Arlington Park has had more than most.

title: The Bloomberg Way
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg seems not to care that he can be a lightning rod for frustration. He matter-of-factly talks about the fiscal pain to come for New York City, offering no sugar coating. That, as New York is learning, is the Bloomberg way.

title: Hussein and Mobs Virtually Empty Iraq's Prisons
description: Tens of thousands of Iraqi prisoners stormed out of their cells to freedom today after President Saddam Hussein declared an amnesty that appeared to have all but emptied a sprawling, nationwide network of prisons that have served as the grim charnel houses of one of the world's harshest police states.

title: Artifact May Be Earliest Relating to Existence of Jesus
description: An inscription in stone, found in or near Jerusalem and written in a language and script of 2,000 years ago, bears the words "James, son of Joseph, brother of Jesus."

title: Bush to Treat China's Departing Leader to a Barbecue Summit
description: For President Jiang Zemin, who leaves on Tuesday for what is likely to be his last visit to the United States as chief of state, the barbecue is the message.

title: Devil Rays Set to Make An Offer To Piniella
description: The Mets' chances of speaking to Lou Piniella about their managerial opening remained uncertain yesterday as the Tampa Bay Devil Rays prepared to make their first formal offer to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, WILLIAM B. JR.
description: STODDARD-William B. Jr. Ridgefield, CT, on October 16, 2002. Loving husband and father to Carol and Emily, most generous friend to all. Born in Carbondale, PA, graduate of New York University and its Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, NYC. Investment economist. For thirty years he was active in civic affairs in Ridgefield as a board member of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Arts and the Ridgefield Library. His wise counsel and loyalty will be missed. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Ridgefield Conservation Commission Open Space Fund, Ridgefield, CT 06877.

title: Sanders Starting to Come Up Big
description: No one will ever name a candy bar after this Reggie but, as he has proved in Games 1 and 2, that isn't stopping him from becoming a World Series hero.

title: Blotting Out the Light: A New Tower by Trump; Neighbors Fight a High-Rise Inches Away
description: Richard Seader and his fellow residents in the Chatsworth, a landmark building on 72nd Street near Riverside Drive, battled their landlady for decades with the dramatic flair of the musicals and plays Mr. Seader once produced on Broadway.

title: Telemarketers Offering a Plan To Cut Sales Calls to Cellphones
description: The Direct Marketing Association, a trade group, plans to announce a plan today to prevent telemarketers from calling people on their cellphones.

title: A Struggle for Vikings and Moss
description: ''Excuse me,'' the Minnesota Vikings' most famous -- and most notorious -- player said today as he slithered through the crowd of reporters around his locker, while some of his teammates growled at the hubbub.

title: Organic Gets an Additive: A U.S.D.A. Seal to Certify It
description: Beginning on Monday, the Department of Agriculture's new seal labeling food organic will appear in grocery stores, making clear to consumers for the first time what produce has been raised without conventional pesticides or fertilizers, antibiotics or growth hormones.

title: Crowd Demands Quick Action To Clear Five in Jogger Case
description: About 50 supporters of the young men convicted in the Central Park jogger case gathered last night to protest the request by Manhattan prosecutors for more time to investigate the claim of a convicted murderer that he alone was responsible for the infamous attack 13 years ago.

title: Protesters Fault Mayor in Fire That Killed Six in Baltimore
description: About 400 people gathered today at the charred row house where Angela Dawson and her family lived to protest what they called the city's neglect of the neighborhood.

title: That Other War: Drugs in Our Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing Victims Remembered Across Australia
description: Pop ballads, surf alarms, Aboriginal music and Balinese flower rituals mingled today as Australia mourned its victims of the bombing on Bali.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Men Stabbed In East Village
description: A 50-year-old man was in custody, and two men in their 40's were being treated for stab wounds at Bellevue Hospital Center last night after a fight broke out at 10 p.m. in a bodega at 11 Avenue D in the East Village, the police said. Investigators declined to identify the victims, but said that one was stabbed in the abdomen and the other was stabbed under one of his arms, and that both were in stable condition early today. The suspect, Ramon Santos, was arrested after he fled and tried to force his way into a taxi at Houston Street and Avenue C, the police said. Charges were pending. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Robert Winthrop White -- Sculptor, 81
description: Robert Winthrop White, a sculptor, died Sept. 21 at a hospital in Smithtown, N.Y. He was 81 and lived in St. James, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about proposals to force high-income people and corporations to disclose the use of tax shelters misstated the party affiliation of Representative Lloyd Doggett of Texas, who favors the plan. He is a Democrat.

title: Republicans Fight Hard to Recapture State Senate Seat in the Old Silk Stocking District
description: For decades, the Upper East Side of Manhattan has been a home of Republican liberalism. That tradition, in the area once known as the Silk Stocking District, was represented most prominently by Nelson A. Rockefeller, John V. Lindsay and a host of others on the City Council and in the Legislature.

title: The Prado Gets Ready To Stretch; Madrid Museums Blossom
description: Expansion of the Prado has been talked about for so long that it is surprising to find machines actually digging holes and moving earth behind that museum's elegant 18th-century headquarters in the heart of this city.

title: Conservatives In Greece Claim Local Victories
description: Greek conservatives claimed victory today in countrywide municipal elections, including one for mayor of Athens, but fell far short of the margin needed to force the long-governing Socialists to call early national elections, according to surveys of voters.

title: Survey Finds PC Sales On Holiday Lists
description: Personal computer sales may have an upturn during the holiday shopping season, according to the Consumer Electronic Association's annual survey of the public's buying plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERK, PHYLLIS
description: BERK-Phyllis. On October 19, 2002. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Shelley, Brian and Edward. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Sarah and Jacob. Services today, at 11:30 AM, from Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: British Concern to Help U.S. Track Terrorists
description: Autonomy, a British developer of sophisticated information retrieval software, plans to announce on Monday that it has been chosen to provide an analysis system to help the United States government track suspected terrorists.

title: Midtown Traffic: The Mess in the Box

title: How Politics and Rivalries Fed Suspicions of a Meeting
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 20  A year after reports of a meeting came to light between the lead hijacker in the Sept. 11 attacks, Mohamed Atta, and an Iraqi intelligence officer, Ahmad Khalil Ibrahim Samir al-Ani, the story behind the story of their supposed meeting in Prague is perhaps more interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, RICHARD L.
description: SALZER-Richard L. 80, died October 19, 2002. Adoring husband of Betty Straus. Beloved father of Richard L. (Linda), and Peggy LoCastro (Thomas). Proud and loving grandfather of Debra, Eric, Caryn and Scott. Trustee of the White Plains Hospital and the Jewish Home and Hospital. Funeral service today, 11 AM, at Congregation EmanuEl of Westchester, Westcheseter Ave, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Anatol & Arthur Charitable Foundation, c/o of Dr. Dan Costin, 2 Longview Avenue, White Plains, NY 10601; or White Plains Hospital Senior Services.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, MARGARET S. (MAGGIE)
description: NEWMAN - Margaret S. (Maggie). Died October 19, 2002. Loving and beloved wife of Harold M. Newman, daughter of the late Albert Strauss and Gertrude Greenwald, mother of Robert P. Newman, mother-in-law of Katheryn, sister of Helen Strauss, sister-in-law of Betty Abrams. Born 1921. Graduate of Barnard College Class of 1942. Former longtime member of the Board of Directors of the YWCA of White Plains and Central Westchester, and Literacy Volunteer. Evergracious, courageous and uncomplaining in the face of Alzheimer's Disease and cancer. Services private. Donations in her name may be made to the Dysautonomia Foundation, 633 Third Avenue, 12th Floor, NY, NY 10017-6706.

title: 'Harry Potter' to Battle 'Lord of the Rings,' Again
description: What a difference a year makes.

title: Even at 71, Mays Can Take Some Good Swings
description: Chided. Chastised. Criticized. I am still trying to determine which word best describes the entertaining exchange, but, someday, I can tell my grandchildren about the details of being chided, chastised and criticized by one of the greatest baseball players during the 2002 World Series. I chided back and I enjoyed it.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HAMILTON: UNION CRITICIZES POST OFFICE The Postal Service should protect New Jersey postal workers in case of another anthrax attack, union leaders said. "There's been nothing put in place to safeguard us or the public," said Bill Lewis, president of the Trenton area branch of the American Postal Workers Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Mr. Lewis spoke on Saturday during a union rally at the mail center in Hamilton, which processed four tainted letters and has been closed since the letters were traced there last October. Diane Todd, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service, has said that the postal service hopes to install equipment at the center that would be able to detect anthrax and other germs. (AP)

title: Pledging to Focus on Lowering Property Taxes and Loosening Drug Laws
description: Following are excerpts from the debate yesterday among six of the candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The participants were Thomas K. Leighton, Marijuana Reform Party; Scott Jeffrey, Libertarian Party; George E. Pataki, Republican Party; H. Carl McCall, Democratic Party; Stanley Aronowitz, Green Party; and Tom Golisano, Independence Party. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

title: North Korea Ready to Discuss Nuclear Arms With U.S.
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 21  North Korea said today that it was ready to negotiate over its continuing development of nuclear weapons and indicated that it had not given up on an agreement that requires it to end the program.

title: That Other War: Drugs in Our Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: A Powerful, Flawed Witness Against Enron
description: The recent plea agreement with a former senior Enron trader presents new opportunities for the law enforcement officials investigating a range of possible crimes at the company. But it also creates challenges for prosecutors that did not exist before.

description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: This Week
description: Nights of Song

title: MediaTalk; Co-Hosts Take Forced March of Friendship
description: CBS News has a problem, one it hopes can be solved with a full schedule of festive meals, intense rehearsals and a Halloween party.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MORE RESTAURANTS OPEN, DESPITE ECONOMY Despite the city's weak economy, almost twice as many restaurants opened in the past year as closed, according to the 2003 Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey published today. The survey said 186 restaurants opened and 104 restaurants closed, but the gap between openings and closings was the narrowest since the recession of the early 1990's. Of the shuttered restaurants, 15 were below Houston Street. "There's definitely been a bigger loss of business downtown, " said Tim Zagat, above, a co-publisher of the survey. The Zagat survey also found that people were returning more often to the same restaurant, which may make it harder for new restaurants to attract customers. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMILTON, GEORGE L.
description: HAMILTON-George L. 78, of Monmouth Beach, NJ, on October 17, 2002, a former Director at Dominick & Dominick, NYC. Beloved husband of Joanne (nee Shook), father of George and Benjamin Hamilton, Jean Marie and her husband Richard Drucker, Mary Kate Hamilton and her husband Gary Pardee. Brother of Joan Elliott and the late Robert Hamilton. Grandfather of R.J., Hamilton, George IV, and Katelyn. Visitation Tuesday, 4-7 PM, at the Thompson Memorial Home, 310 Broad St, Red Bank, NJ. Private cremation to follow. The family extends an invitation to the guests to join them at 7:30 PM, Tuesday, for refreshments at The Channel Club Tower Party Room. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to Clean Ocean Action, PO Box 505, Highlands, NJ 07732, are preferrred.

title: Sprewell Missing, But Not Forgotten
description: The Knicks tried. They held an open practice at St. John's yesterday, handing out tickets for it to community groups. They ran through drills and scrimmaged, players and coaches taking the microphone to explain to the crowd how they worked. Shandon Anderson lifted a child over his head and allowed her to drop a ball through the basket. Allan Houston and Kurt Thomas shot free throws with fans, and the rookie hopeful Jemeil Rich played tag with a handful of youngsters while dribbling around in circles.

title: On Fourth Attempt, Galaxy Wins Its First M.L.S. Cup
description: The Los Angeles Galaxy had come away empty in three appearances in Major League Soccer's championship game.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Vivendi Moves Up Deadline On Bids for Publishing Unit

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, JOHN BARRETT JR.
description: GRANT-John Barrett Jr. Of Stamford, CT. died October 17, 2002, age 53, of cancer. Graduate of Deerfield Academy, Stanford University and Georgetown University Law Center. First Lieutenant in the US Army, 25th Company, 2nd Battalion. Former partner in law firms of Shea & Gould, and Camhy, Karlinsky & Stein. Shareholder in the firm of Greenberg Traurig, et al, at time of death. Beloved husband of Julia F. Grant and father of John B. Grant III and Ann Elizabeth Grant. Memorial service Wednesday, October 23, at 2 PM, Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave, Greenwich, CT.

title: As the Sniping Creeps South, So Do Fear And Precaution
description: For the first time since the sniper shootings began, local officials in Virginia tonight took the drastic step of shutting down the school system, saying there was no other way to guarantee students' safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LENNHOFF, GUNTHER
description: LENNHOFF-Gunther. Loving husband of Thelma. Devoted father of Larry and Malka Esther, and the late Rona. Brother of Marion and Harry Sikovitz. He will be sorely missed by many cousins, nieces, nephews and friends. Services Monday 1:30 PM at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre.

title: Some questions on 'The Sopranos,' an 'American Beauty' star and a Donald. And some answers.
description: IS ''The Sopranos'' being retitled ''Dollars to Doughnuts''? When you ''look closer,'' to quote the slogan for ''American Beauty,'' where can you now find a star of the movie? And what's the deal with a prominent New York deal maker's co-star turn with a character from McDonaldland?

title: Rodriguez Put the Brakes on the Giants
description: Alex Rodriguez is the highest-paid player in baseball, but he is not playing in the World Series. Francisco Rodriguez is. And are the Anaheim Angels relieved and ecstatic that he is.

title: Plan to Seek Faster Release Of Generics
description: President Bush is to announce on Monday that his administration will carry out measures intended to give Americans faster access to low-cost generic versions of brand-name drugs, administration officials said tonight.

title: The Gatekeeper For Literature Is Changing At New Yorker
description: For decades, the fiction editor of The New Yorker has controlled the velvet rope at the gateway to literary stardom, welcoming a fortunate few into the prestigious inner circle of short story writers and a career of lucrative book contracts.

title: Making a Beeline Through the Intricacies
description: Some bridge deals are cut short because an expert declarer can see through complexities that would cause lesser players to struggle. An example is the diagramed deal from the quarter final stage of the world open team championships in Montreal in August. Sitting North and South were Adam Zmudzinski and Cezary Balicki of Poland, who were on the way to capturing bronze medals.

title: The Loss of a Safe Place
description: ''I've been to Bali too!'' goes a rollicking Australian song dedicated to the pleasures of that volcanically contoured triangle of paradise in the Indonesian archipelago. It is, of course, our nearest exotic point of arrival, but also it's cheaper for someone living in Western Australia to go to Bali than it is to come across the continent to Sydney. Every Australian who owns a surfboard has been there.

title: E-Commerce Report; Retail executives are uniting to fight credit-card fraud in the online bazaar.
description: INTERNET merchants, weary of a near constant barrage of credit card fraud that costs them more than $1 billion each year, are joining forces in hopes of helping one another identify users of stolen credit cards, catch criminals and perhaps soothe the fears of millions of potential online shoppers.

title: Israeli Settlers' Zeal Forces Palestinians To Flee Their Town
description: The alleys of this Palestinian hamlet were silent today, the empty stone houses locked, the small local school deserted.

title: Iceland Joins Whale Panel, Giving Whalers Stronger Say
description: For two decades, antiwhaling nations led by the United States have safeguarded the International Whaling Commission's moratorium on commercial whale hunting. But a vote last week allowing Iceland to join the commission showed a shift in power toward the defiant whaling nations.

title: Manuel Alvarez Bravo, Photographer, Dies at 100
description: Manuel Alvarez Bravo, Mexico's greatest photographer and a world master of his art, died on Saturday at his home in Mexico City. He was 100.

title: ... Still Ticking: 4 N.F.L. Games Go Into Overtime
description: People who love baseball say that much of its beauty comes from its lack of time constraints. People who prefer football say that much of its beauty comes from a moving clock that introduces a time limit into an already exciting game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHTA, MEHLI
description: MEHTA-Mehli. The Board of Directors and staff of American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra extend our deepest condolences to our Co-Chairman and IPO Music Director, Zubin Mehta and his wife Nancy on the passing of his father. Mehli Mehta's muscial genius and his dedication to teaching will be remembered with gratitude by generations to come. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Itzhak Perlman, Co-Chairman Lynn Syms, President Suzanne K. Ponsot, Exec. Dir.

title: First Boston Rejects Demand By State for Civil Settlement
description: The investment firm Credit Suisse First Boston, facing a civil charge in Massachusetts over its stock research as soon as today, rejected the state's demand for a settlement in a letter sent yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLOSKY, GERTRUDE
description: PLOSKY-Gertrude. January 28, 1910-October 19, 2002. She is remembered with great affection by the members of her extended family.

title: Prague Discounts an Iraqi Meeting
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 20  The Czech president, Vaclav Havel, has quietly told the White House he has concluded that there is no evidence to confirm earlier reports that Mohamed Atta, the leader in the Sept. 11 attacks, met with an Iraqi intelligence officer in Prague just months before the attacks on New York and Washington, according to Czech officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAROSEN, MARY VIVIAN
description: KAROSEN-Mary Vivian. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Kansas City, passed away on October 19, at her home in Boca Raton, FL. Services will be held Tuesday, 1 PM, at Louis Memorial Chapel in Kansas City. Mary was born in Kansas City and was a graduate of Central High School. She was the ''Swing Girl'' for Swing Magazine in 1948. An accomplished model, actress and devoted wife, mother and grandmother. She was a member of Boca Rio Golf Club and of B'nai B'rith Foundation, Council of Jewish Women, Hadassah Foundation and Brandeis Foundation. She was preceded in death by her loving husband Leon Karosen. She is survived by her daughter and son-in-law Valerie K. and Ludwell Gaines of Shawnee Mission, KS, her son Kent Lawrence Karosen of New York City, her grandson Reed Alan Markowitz of Las Vegas. She is also survived by many loving family members and many loyal friends, all of whom enjoyed the glow of her beauty and the kindness of her heart. She will be missed. The family requests donations be made to the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund at 135 East 57th Street, NY, NY 10022.

title: A Voice Never Allowed To Outsing the Song
description: Near the end of her set at the Cutting Room on Thursday night, Lamya gave the audience a condensed version of her life story. ''I come from the Middle East, where genies are supposed to come from,'' she said. ''I rubbed a whole lot of lamps, hoping someone would come out wearing MC Hammer pants and turn me into Lisa Bonet.''

title: Senate Rivals Shake Hands And Debate More Debating
description: Douglas R. Forrester, indignant about Frank R. Lautenberg's rejection of invitations to debate him in their Senate race, today repeated his challenges to Mr. Lautenberg but said he doubted that a debate would be arranged before the final days of the campaign.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You gave us a telephone number. We do want to talk to you. Call us at the number you provided.''

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: MESSAGE WAS LEFT AT LATEST SCENE OF SNIPER ATTACK
description: The leaders of the hunt for the roving suburban sniper issued an unusual open plea tonight to begin a conversation with someone who left them a message here at the scene of the region's latest random shooting.

title: Mexico City Journal; Uproar Over a Movie Priest Going His Own Way
description: Forbidden love can be the most passionate, and one story of forbidden love recently ignited the passions of this country's powerful Roman Catholic Church, turning a low-budget movie into the biggest box office hit in the history of Mexican film.

title: MediaTalk; No Party, Just a Garage Sale at Time Inc.
description: At a time when Time Inc. is closing magazines, its Christmas will inevitably be a little glum. The company's new chief executive, Ann S. Moore, has decided it is not the best time for grand holiday festivities.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: More Restaurants Open, Despite Economy
description: Despite the city's weak economy, almost twice as many restaurants opened in the past year as closed, according to the 2003 Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey published today. The survey said 186 restaurants opened and 104 restaurants closed, but the gap between openings and closings was the narrowest since the recession of the early 1990's. Of the shuttered restaurants, 15 were below Houston Street. ''There's definitely been a bigger loss of business downtown, '' said Tim Zagat, above, a co-publisher of the survey. The Zagat survey also found that people were returning more often to the same restaurant, which may make it harder for new restaurants to attract customers. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Aileen Riggin Soule, Olympic Diver and Swimmer, Dies at 96
description: Aileen Riggin Soule, a diver and swimmer who at age 14 became the youngest American Olympic gold medalist and later became the oldest living American female gold medalist, died Thursday in a nursing home in Honolulu. She was 96.

title: A Community Formed by Chairs
description: 'Double Play Dance' Symphony Space

title: Before Bills Move in Albany, 3 Leaders Cut Deals in
description: Sometime around last Thanksgiving, Gov. George E. Pataki and Dennis Rivera, a union leader, had a private conversation about money.

title: Community of Interests
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Images of Sudden Freedom and Frenzy
description: In Iraq, prisons were opened and mobs stormed the cellblocks, liberating as many as 10,000 captives. For many, though, it was a day of abysmal grief.

title: It's Now Official, Sort of: Teams Are Playing Hardball
description: Al Levine, a right-hander who apparently thinks like a lefty, found a way to contribute to his Anaheim Angels on Sunday. Levine is not on the World Series roster, but he had heard his teammates complain about the hardness of the baseballs used in the Series. So he went to the clubhouse to prove their hypothesis.
