description: To the Editor:

title: Guide to Children's Hearts
description: ''The Parent's Guide to Children's Congenital Heart Defects,'' by Gerri Freid Kramer and Shari Maurer, Three Rivers Press, $14.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: TMP Will Spin Off Executive Search Unit
description: TMP Worldwide Inc., operator of the Monster.com job-search Web site, said yesterday that it would spin off its executive search and staffing-services business units to eliminate any perceived conflicts of interest. David Rosa, the company's vice president, said the spinoff was expected to be completed by the first quarter of next year. TMP Worldwide named William Pastore, the former president of Cigna Healthcare, as its new chief operating officer.

title: Are the Saudis the Enemy?
description: Osama bin Laden succeeded magnificently, it seems, in at least one of his goals: creating a rift between the United States and Saudi Arabia.

title: Technology Briefing: Internet
description: JUDGE RULES ON WEB SITES FOR THE DISABLED Web sites do not have to be designed to provide easier access for the blind, a federal court ruled on Friday. Southwest.com, the site of Southwest Airlines , is not a "place of public accommodation" covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act, wrote Federal District Judge Patricia A. Seitz of the Southern District of Florida in a decision dismissing a case brought by Access Now Inc., a nonprofit advocacy group in Florida. Advocates for the disabled have argued that Web sites should be covered under the law, and that companies should use technologies like those that that read words on a computer screen aloud. "We disagree with the judge's decision and we intend to appeal," said Phyllis Resnick, vice president of Access Now. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Reports of Bronx Killings Stun A Suspect's Family in Virginia
description: If Roberto Carlos Mayen harbored rage, one of his brothers said yesterday, he kept it well hidden. He had a steady job, two cars, a town house and a newfound faith that had led him to be baptized this month.

title: Police Ask Caller in the Sniper Case to Make Contact
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 21  Police officials today confirmed the wounding of a 12th victim by the sniper preying on the Washington region as they once more reached out directly to the mysterious figure they think has intimate knowledge of the sniper's deadly spree.

title: New Technology in Cancer Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: No Strangers to Pressure, Miami Police Are Enlisted for Election Role
description: The Miami-Dade Police Department has managed hurricanes, Super Bowls, a visit by the pope and the Year 2000 computer problem. But can it handle an election in Miami-Dade County?

title: XEROX TO RECEIVE UP TO $5 BILLION IN FINANCING
description: GE Capital will provide Xerox with as much as $5 billion in financing over the next eight years, the two companies said yesterday. The deal came as something of a surprise on Wall Street, because both companies had led investors to expect that GE Capital would assume Xerox's financing business in the United States. Instead, the arrangement keeps the debt on Xerox's books. The arrangement will have the same impact on Xerox's ability to finance equipment leases as the one originally expected, and investors pushed Xerox's stock up $1.04, to $6.98 a share. Analysts said much of the buying represented relief by investors who had grown nervous when the financing deal took so long to complete. The rest, they said, represented short sellers covering positions. Claudia H. Deutsch (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
description: NORTHWEST AIRLINES REACHES PACT WITH EXPEDIA Northwest Airlines has reached an accord to sell its tickets again through Expedia, the largest online travel agency. At the beginning of the month, Expedia stopped selling Northwest tickets after the two companies could not agree on the commission Northwest would pay Expedia on each ticket sold. Northwest complained that Expedia's fees were far higher than those of Orbitz, the rival online travel site owned by Northwest and four other major airlines. Northwest also complained that Expedia's service was biased to favor airlines that pay it higher commissions. Neither company would comment yesterday on the specific terms of the new arrangement, which was reached over the weekend. Richard Barton, the chief executive of Expedia, said that Northwest's concerns over bias were not valid. "We have always shown the lowest-priced flights first and that has not changed," he said. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Incentives Still Leave G.M. Short of Market Goal
description: Despite a relentless campaign of incentives like interest-free loans with no money down, General Motors officials expressed doubts today about achieving their goal of capturing 29 percent of the United States market for new cars this year. They blamed Korean and Japanese auto companies, saying they have gained an unfair advantage through devalued currencies and marketing actions.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judge Rules On Web Sites For the Disabled
description: Web sites do not have to be designed to provide easier access for the blind, a federal court ruled on Friday. Southwest.com, the site of Southwest Airlines, is not a ''place of public accommodation'' covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act, wrote Federal District Judge Patricia A. Seitz of the Southern District of Florida in a decision dismissing a case brought by Access Now Inc., a nonprofit advocacy group in Florida. Advocates for the disabled have argued that Web sites should be covered under the law, and that companies should use technologies like those that that read words on a computer screen aloud. ''We disagree with the judge's decision and we intend to appeal,'' said Phyllis Resnick, vice president of Access Now. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: HBO Cancels 'Arliss' After Seven Years
description: After a seven-year run, ''Arliss,'' the comedy series about a sports agent, has been canceled by HBO, which is expected to announce the decision today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HAROLD F.
description: LEVIN-Harold F. Age 99, on October 19, 2002, of Florida & New York. A distinguished lawyer and member of the NY bar for 76 years, his professional career was marked by dedication to his clients. One of the oldest living graduates of Columbia's Business School, 1923, and Law School, 1926, he was active in the Stoneagers Alumni Club. Founding partner of the NYC law firms of Delson, Levin & Gordon and later of Levin & Weissman. At the forefront of labor law, particularly in the construction trades, he played an instrumental role in the establishment of benefit plans for unionized workers. He was a consummate advocate, in and out of the courtroom. A sought-after public speaker at conferences, he wrote numerous articles. His colleagues remember his integrity, intellect and sense of humor. He was a friend and mentor to many. Much loved father of Roger M. Levin & Susan E.L. Wiland, grandfather to Jessica, Emily & Chloe, father-in-law to Sally F. King and Keith A. Schepart, husband of the late Blanche M. Levin for 51 years, and loving companion of Norma Benrubi. Admired and loved by many, he will long be remembered by all who knew him. There will be a private interment. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, October 23, 2002 from 3-8 PM at the Levin residence, 15 East 90th St., NYC.

title: Hughes and Bird Win Annual Awards
description: Before Sarah Hughes won an Olympic gold medal in figure skating at the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City, hockey was everything around the Hughes household in Great Neck on Long Island. Hughes's father and brothers played hockey, and Sarah always had to fight to get them to change the television channel from a hockey game to a figure-skating event.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Talking While Running For Judge
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta, struck down limits on what judicial candidates in Georgia may say in election campaigns. Georgia law prohibits false or misleading statements by judicial candidates and establishes a commission to consider complaints. The appeals court held that the law was an unconstitutional prior restraint on speech and that candidates should be able to say what they like so long as they do not knowingly or recklessly utter a falsehood. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: Dispute With U.S.
description: The government said the reason it arrested two Eritrean workers at the United States Embassy in Asmara last year was that they had been meddling in Eritrea's internal affairs. The United States State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, recently marked the anniversary of the arrests by criticizing a ''troubling crackdown on democracy and human rights in Eritrea.'' But the Eritrean Foreign Ministry responded by accusing American officials of interfering in Eritrea's war with Ethiopia, which ended in 2000. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Failed Leads Bring Pattern Of Frustration
description: The investigation of the sniper shootings has followed a familiar and frustrating pattern in recent days: round-the-clock publicity, new batches of seemingly promising tips from the public, frenzied police responses and, ultimately, disappointment.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Grand Canyon, And A Monumental One
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has ruled that the Clinton administration acted within its power when it gave national monument status to seven natural landmarks, including the Grand Canyon-Parashant National Monument in Arizona and the Giant Sequoia National Monument in California. The court rejected arguments from a California county and a conservative legal group, the Mountain States Legal Foundation, that presidents cannot constitutionally designate large land tracts as monuments.

title: United Airlines Plans to Cut $1.4 Billion in Operations and 1,250 Jobs
description: UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, told employees in a phone message yesterday that it had pinpointed a total of $1.4 billion in annual nonlabor cuts that it intends to carry out. In addition, the company said in a separate announcement that it planned to save $100 million a year from a streamlining that includes the loss of about 1,250 jobs.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Reports Net Income
description: Texas Instruments Inc., whose chips powered half of the mobile phones sold last year, showed a profit for the third quarter, as sales increased 22 percent on rising demand for consumer electronics. The company plans to cut 500 jobs. Net income was $188 million, or 11 cents a share, in contrast to a net loss of $117 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $2.25 billion from $1.85 billion, the Dallas-based chip maker said in a statement. Texas Instruments has benefited from higher sales of chips for cellphones and consumer devices like digital cameras and DVD recorders. The chief executive, Thomas Engibous, said this month that order rates had been increasing, even as officials from rivals like Intel forecast lackluster fourth-quarter demand. The company said fourth-quarter net income would be break-even on a per-share basis ''plus or minus a few cents,'' with sales falling 10 percent from the period that ended in September. Profit will be about 2 cents a share before some costs, missing the 11-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Texas Instruments shares rose 2 cents, to $17.12. They have declined 39 percent this year.

title: A.P. Says It Couldn't Find 45 of Fired Writer's Sources
description: The Associated Press said yesterday that it could not verify the existence of more than 45 people and a dozen organizations cited in news articles written by a reporter who was fired by The A.P. last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, WILLIAM B. JR.
description: STODDARD-William B. Jr. Ridgefield, CT, on October 16, 2002. Loving husband and father to Carol and Emily, most generous friend to all. Born in Carbondale, PA, graduate of New York University and its Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, NYC. Investment economist. For thirty years he was active in civic affairs in Ridgefield as a board member of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Arts and the Ridgefield Library. His wise counsel and kindness will be missed. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Ridgefield Conservation Commission Open Space Fund, Ridgefield, CT 06877.

description: Northwest Airlines has reached an accord to sell its tickets again through Expedia, the largest online travel agency. At the beginning of the month, Expedia stopped selling Northwest tickets after the two companies could not agree on the commission Northwest would pay Expedia on each ticket sold. Northwest complained that Expedia's fees were far higher than those of Orbitz, the rival online travel site owned by Northwest and four other major airlines. Northwest also complained that Expedia's service was biased to favor airlines that pay it higher commissions. Neither company would comment yesterday on the specific terms of the new arrangement, which was reached over the weekend. Richard Barton, the chief executive of Expedia, said that Northwest's concerns over bias were not valid. ''We have always shown the lowest-priced flights first and that has not changed,'' he said. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Iraqi City Seen as Powder Keg If Hussein Were to Be Ousted
description: The Iraqi government has displaced or relocated nearly a million Iraqis in the last three decades, creating deep regional and ethnic fractures that could erupt into civil war if President Saddam Hussein is deposed, according to a new report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRITON, PAUL J.
description: HARRITON-Paul J. Of Easthampton, NY, formerly of NYC and Philadelphia died on Sunday, October 20 in Montrose, Colorado. Mr. Harriton is survived by his wife of 33 years, Patricia Daly Harriton, two sisters, Natalie Becker (Stanley) and June Manoff (Norton). Much loved nephews and nieces and cousins. After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania and Harvard Law School, Mr. Harriton practiced law in New York City for over 40 years. He also served in the U.S. Army occupation of Japan. A memorial service will be conducted at 2 P.M., Thursday, October 24 at the Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 91 Hampton Street (Route 114), Sag Harbor, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to Elsa's Ark in Easthampton, which cares for needy pets.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mazda Revises Output
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation will shut a factory near Hiroshima and outsource production of its trucks to the Press Kogyo Company, a Japanese auto parts maker. While cutting back truck production, Mazda will reopen another plant near its Hiroshima headquarters to increase car output 14 percent by March 2005. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Richmond Is Jolted by a Sniper's Attack and Its Aftermath as Well
description: RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 21 — They unleashed the Blackhawk helicopter, the SWAT team, scores of federal agents and even a spy plane.

title: Separating Gold From Junk in Medical Studies
description: You no doubt hear or read about startling new study findings all the time: some food or supplement is found to prevent cancer, relieve arthritis or reverse hair loss; some drug is shown to prevent deaths from heart disease and stroke, or a new outpatient procedure has been developed to replace a major operation.

description: In percent

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Falls
description: For the second consecutive month, the seemingly stumbling Hong Kong economy unexpectedly created jobs considerably faster than the labor force grew. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent in the period from July to September, compared with 7.6 percent in the three-month period through August and 7.8 percent in the three-month period through July. But personal bankruptcies more than tripled in September compared with a year earlier, to 2,580. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VIERTEL, JANET
description: VIERTEL-Janet. October 22, 1992. 10 years is enough. Come home. Old sister Jo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIZNER, GOLDSTEIN, AMI
description: KIZNER - GOLDSTEIN - Ami. Formerly of Bayside, Queens. Passed away October 21 after a hard-fought battle with leukemia. Ami is survived by her loving family and friends. We are all truly privileged to have known and been loved by her. Services today, 11:15AM, at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Exp., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: The Science and Politics of Super Rice
description: Huang Danian, an expert at the National Rice Research Institute here, has created a rice so resilient and tasty, he says, that ''every farmer in China will certainly want it.''

description: Police officials today confirmed the wounding of a 12th victim by the sniper preying on the Washington region as they once more reached out directly to the mysterious figure they think has intimate knowledge of the sniper's deadly spree.

title: Microwaved Microbes
description: Q. Does water boiled in a microwave have the same germ-killing abilities as old-fashioned boiled water? Does chicken cooked all the way through in the microwave get hot enough to kill salmonella?

title: U.S. REFINES PLANS FOR WAR IN CITIES
description: The American military is training furiously and polishing a plan for attacking Baghdad that calls for isolating the city and then taking control of it by seizing or destroying Saddam Hussein's pillars of power -- but avoiding house-to-house combat in its hostile streets.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Supercomputer To Use Advanced Micro Chips
description: A large supercomputer to be built by Sandia National Laboratories and Cray Inc. will use next-generation microprocessors from Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the chip maker said yesterday. The decision by Sandia and Cray to use Advanced Micro's Opteron processors, which will be available next year, is a victory for Advanced Micro. Intel, its perennial rival, has its own next-generation chip designed for servers and supercomputers, named Itanium, which it has developed with Hewlett-Packard. The supercomputer, to be called Red Storm by Sandia, will cost about $90 million. Additionally, the supercomputer will use proprietary technology developed by Cray, which is a move away from how supercomputers have been designed and built in recent years. For the most part, supercomputers in the United States have been built using standard components in commercially available computers. Sandia, which does research for the Department of Energy in Albuquerque, is aiming to hit 100 trillion operations a second with Red Storm. Advanced Micro's success in placing its Opteron chips in Red Storm was first reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal. Shares of Advanced Micro rose $1.15, to $5.55.

title: Unwilling Witnesses, With Violins, to the Death of Love
description: When Stuart Staples sings, his knees go wobbly and he clutches the microphone stand as if to keep from falling, articulating his lyrics in a quavering voice that makes every line sound like a dying confession. On Friday night he was at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn with his band, Tindersticks, for an evening of clever, somber songs. This was parlor music, of a sort. Funeral parlor music.

title: In Defense of a Scientist
description: To the Editor:

title: Index of Leading Indicators Off For Fourth Consecutive Month
description: The index of leading economic indicators fell in September for the fourth consecutive month, a private research firm said today, the first time that has happened since the start of the 1990-91 recession.

title: In Campaign, Subject of Race Is Banished To Background
description: In the campaign of H. Carl McCall, the first black candidate from a major party to run for governor in New York, there is no surer way to kill a conversation than to bring up the subject of race.

title: New Hampshire Bishop Embroiled in Abuse Disputes
description: A priest was dead in circumstances that suggested a tawdry sexual liaison, and an ecclesiastical cleanup crew was dispatched to his rectory here to scour for anything that might further embarrass the church.

title: To Radiation Regimen, Add Spice
description: Turmeric, a principal ingredient of curry, may protect cancer patients from the burns and blisters they often suffer from radiation therapy, researchers report.

title: S.E.C. Said to Tell Stewart of Evidence For Civil Complaint
description: Martha Stewart, the domestic taste maker mired in an insider trading scandal, has been notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has enough evidence to bring a civil complaint against her, a person involved in the investigation said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAX, WALLACE H.
description: FLAX-Wallace H. Our beloved Wally passed away on October 21, 2002. Loving husband of Enid (nee Ochacher). The devoted father of Rabbi Martin and Rabbi and Air Force Major Ira (Vicki) Flax. Adoring grandfather of Debbie and Ben. Dear brother of Marilyn (Bill) Kraemer and Joan (Lenny) Lazarus. Services Wednesday, October 23rd, 11:30AM, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Connecticut Appellate Court's order of a new trial for a former New Milford police officer convicted of having used unreasonable deadly force misspelled the surname of an expert whose testimony was improperly excluded from the first trial. He is David M. Grossi, not Gross.

title: Stony Brook to Study Asia And Asian-Americans
description: No sign is needed to identify the latest addition to the sprawling State University of New York campus here.

title: The Clean Water Act at 30
description: The Clean Water Act of 1972, one of the most successful and popular of all the environmental laws enacted under Richard Nixon, turned 30 last Friday. What should have been a celebratory moment, however, was instead an occasion for grumbling, mostly directed at President Bush. His administration has done little to broaden the reach of the law, and there are those in the environmental community who fear that he is now plotting to weaken it in fundamental ways, chiefly by narrowing its scope.

title: Abrupt Amnesty At Iraqi Prisons: A Joy for Many, Grief for Some
description: No event in years has shaken Iraq like the amnesty with which President Saddam Hussein emptied Iraq's jails on Sunday. Within minutes of the broadcast at noon, a crowd began gathering outside Abu Ghraib prison, 20 miles west of Baghdad, the grimmest in a gulag that has incarcerated tens of thousands of political prisoners. Soon, the gates were forced open and the mob stormed the cellblocks, liberating as many as 10,000 captives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHYET, STANLEY F.
description: CHYET - Stanley F. The Board of Trustees, staff, docents, and volunteers of the Skirball Cultural Center, Los Angeles, express our deepest sorrow upon the death of our beloved friend and Assistant to the President/Secretary to the Board of Trustees, Rabbi Stanley F. Chyet. Dr. Chyet led a life remarkable not only for his own accomplishments but also for his influence on the many people whose lives he touched as a husband, father, poet, professor, mentor, rabbi, colleague, and friend. In the early 1980's, he helped forge the vision for the Skirball Cultural Center one that explores the connections between the age-old Jewish heritage and the vitality of American democratic ideals. Dr. Chyet's wisdom, warmth, and passion for American Jewish history helped shape every aspect of the Skirball. Since opening in 1996, the Skirball has welcomed over 3 million visitors. Its core exhibition, ''Visions and Values: Jewish Life from Antiquity to America,'' is to a major degree the product of his scholarship and teaching brilliance, particularly sections that examine the immigration experience and Jewish life in America. Dr. Chyet loved poetry and was a consummate poet. Through his poetry, he extended the human experience by giving voice to the voiceless. He was a utopian in the truest sense of the word. He taught us that a humane and reflective life is possible and that to be human is somehow not to lose hope in the face of despair, to retain humor in the face of catastrophe, and to realize peace without ignoring conflict. His scholarship, his poetry, his defining humility, and his beautiful humanity will continue to inspire us and all future generations who visit the Skirball Cultural Center. He has left us with an enormous legacy. Howard I. Friedman Chairman, Board of Trustees Skirball Cultural Center Uri D. Herscher Founding President and CEO Skirball Cultural Center

title: Sports of The Times; It's a Game The Knicks Cannot Win
description: FOR years, the Garden Plotters could gloat privately over their skills of mass deception as they created the illusion of Knicks contenders by buying up damaged goods, as they inflated ticket prices after overpaying for those false promises, as they whipped up phony sellouts to prop up their product image.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Coal Miner
description: The joint owners of Luscar Ltd., Canada's biggest coal producer, bid 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($958 million) for a rival, Fording Inc. of Calgary, Alberta. The bidders, the Sherritt International Corporation of Toronto and the Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan, would also take over 128 million Canadian dollars of Fording debt. Sherritt said that combining Luscar's and Fording's metallurgical coal mines in southeast British Columbia would optimize production and reduce costs. The companies produced a total of 29.4 million metric tons of coal in the first six months of 2002, much of it exported to Japanese and other Asian steel mills. Fording had no immediate response to the bid. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: The Order And Chaos Of Clearing Ground Zero
description: AMERICAN GROUND

title: Norbert Schultze Dies at 91; His 'Lili Marleen' Was a Hit
description: Norbert Schultze, the German composer of the melancholy ''Lili Marleen,'' the informal infantryman's anthem that became the best-known song of World War II, died on Oct. 14 in Bad Tlz, Bavaria. He was 91.

title: Was Troy a Metropolis? Homer Isn't Talking
description: A new Trojan War has broken out. In the warrior roles of Achilles and Hector are two respected professors on the same German university faculty who could not differ more fully and vehemently over what to make of the ruins at the presumed site in western Turkey of the legendary siege in the 13th century B.C. immortalized by Homer.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: Onions May Not Always Be Nature's Tear-Jerkers

title: Regulations Are Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE GROUND: In Austin; A High-Technology Star Is Also a Cultural Oasis
description: Austin is not exactly regarded as the business powerhouse of Texas, especially with Houston and its 20 Fortune 500 companies to the east and Dallas (home to Southwest Airlines and 7-Eleven) to the north. But this progressive city, which is the state capital and houses the main campus (48,000 students) of the University of Texas, is a cultural oasis and something of a star in the area of high-technology hardware. The university is by far the city's biggest employer, but Dell Computers, Motorola and I.B.M. have a strong presence. Austin also ranks in the top 10 American cities in growth in women-owned businesses.

title: TV Networks Act to Avoid More Blunders In Vote Tallies
description: Two years after the embarrassment of making erroneous projections in the 2000 presidential election, the major television news organizations are taking extra measures to avoid a recurrence.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 300 Illegal Immigrants Captured
description: Coastal patrols intercepted two ships packed with more than 300 illegal immigrants off the coastline of Sicily, the latest example of Italy's ceaseless struggle against a tide of desperate people trying to enter Europe. The first boat, a small steamer, held about 150 Somalis and Turkish Kurds, law enforcement officials said. The second carried about 160 immigrants from Sierra Leone, Sudan and Somalia. All are in custody. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: System Defies Even a Governor Who Promised to Reform It
description: Albany's entrenched power structure tends to confound reformers who waltz into the Capitol with high hopes of changing how state business is done. That is true even if the reformer happens to be the governor.

title: Using News Media as a Conduit Has Worked, Some Officers Say
description: It is rare for the police to talk to suspects through the news media as law enforcement officials are trying with the sniper in the Washington area, but police commanders in a few cities say they have used the technique successfully.

title: ABB MAY SEEK CHAPTER 11 FOR AMERICAN UNIT
description: The Swiss engineering company ABB said yesterday that it might seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for its Combustion Engineering unit, which faces thousands of lawsuits by former employees who say their health was damaged by asbestos used at their plant. The company said asbestos-related costs would probably exceed the value of the unit's assets, which, as of Sept. 30, was $812 million. The asbestos claims stem from industrial boilers made by Combustion Engineering, based in Stamford, Conn. Combustion Engineering paid $865 million to asbestos claimants from 1990, when it was bought by ABB, to the end of last year, ABB said. ABB, based in Zurich, said it did not expect to reach its earnings estimates for the current year. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHTA, MEHLI
description: MEHTA-Mehli. The New York Philharmonic notes with sorrow the death in Los Angeles, on October 19, of Mehli Mehta, 94, violinist and founder of the Bombay Symphony Orchestra, music director and conductor from 1965 to 1998 of the American Youth Symphony, and father of former New York Philharmonic Music Director Zubin Mehta and current Executive Director Zarin Mehta. Born in Bombay, India, Mehli Mehta was a passionate proponent of Western classical music and the mentor of generations of music students. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Tehmina, his sons, and to the entire family. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Board of Directors Members of the Orchestra Staff of the NY Philharmonic

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Eurotunnel's Sales Up
description: Third-quarter revenue at Eurotunnel P.L.C. rose 2.9 percent as the company, the operator of the Channel Tunnel, carried more trucks on its shuttle trains. Sales rose to 149 million ($231 million) from 144.8 million a year earlier. Eurotunnel said it expected to be at or near break even on a cash basis by the end of the year.

title: Son of Sam Killer Talks of Sniper
description: The Son of Sam killer, David Berkowitz, who terrorized New York City in 1977, speculates that the sniper now spreading terror in the Washington area is under ''what many Christians would call 'a strong demonic bondage,' '' feels rage toward law enforcement and may be motivated by the new Hannibal Lecter movie.

title: Sprewell Chronicles: Gibes and a Lawsuit
description: Latrell Sprewell's contentious relationship with the Knicks soured markedly today when he lashed out at team executives over his recent punishment and the team handed him a new suspension for one game without pay.

title: Citing North Korea, an Iraqi Aide Says 'Oil and Israel,' Not Weapons, Spur the U.S.
description: One of President Saddam Hussein's top advisers said today that the Bush administration's failure to threaten tough action against North Korea since its acknowledgment of a nuclear weapons program showed that the real American objective in threatening Iraq was ''oil and Israel,'' not the administration's professed concern about secret weapons programs.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Aid For Baltimore In Fighting Drug Violence
description: Mayor Martin O'Malley of Baltimore said the state had agreed to provide 150 troopers to patrol city thoroughfares, hire an additional 75 parole officers and provide additional jail space to help the city fight drug-related violence. Mr. O'Malley's announcement came after meetings with clergy members and state officials about the deaths of Angela Dawson, 36, and her five children, who were killed early Wednesday in retaliation, the authorities said, for her efforts to confront drug dealers. Gary Gately (NYT)

title: Bush Seeks Faster Generic Drug Approval
description: President Bush today proposed a way to speed the approval of low-cost generic versions of prescription drugs, and consumer groups lauded the proposal as a worthy first step, although they said it was too late and did not go far enough.

title: Crime: Rising Threat in Many Areas
description: ''THE world is on sale!'' comes the cry from the travel writers, who have been prattling on for weeks about the wonderful air-fare discounts now available for many international trips.

title: Business as Usual
description: The mood among business lobbyists, according to a jubilant official at the Heritage Foundation, is one of ''optimism, bordering on giddiness.'' They expect the elections on Nov. 5 to put Republicans in control of all three branches of government, and have their wish lists ready. ''It's the domestic equivalent of planning for postwar Iraq,'' says the official.

title: 24 Outs, None Coming By Way of 3rd Strike
description: If a player wearing an Anaheim uniform strikes out in Game 3 of the World Series tonight, it will be the first Angels strikeout since Game 1. So what happened in Game 2?

title: A Dream House, in Pure Hawaiian Style
description: The trade winds have begun to blow, softly riffling the palm thatching overhead. In Hana Bay below, the floats of the fishermen's nets bob in the gentle surf, but the akule fish have gone to deeper water for the day. The dugout canoes lie idle on the rocks, for the men will not be pulling their nets tonight.

title: Lautenberg Appeal to Women Gives Him Edge on Forrester
description: It was an appropriate setting for Frank R. Lautenberg: the Elizabeth Y.W.C.A., where, surrounded by women who supported him, he talked today about ending domestic violence and curbing gun sales.

title: Dwellers, Not Homes, at Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: GORDON BROTHERS GROUP TO APPOINT A PRESIDENT
description: The Gordon Brothers Group, a leading retail liquidator, will name Mark J. Schwartz, 45, the chief executive of the Palladin Capital Group, its president. In hiring Mr. Schwartz, Gordon Brothers, which is based in Boston, is ''reaching out to Wall Street,'' said Michael Frieze, Gordon's chief executive. Gordon has already expanded beyond its 99-year-old liquidation business into other retail investments, including last year's investment in Restoration Hardware. Gordon also counsels department stores on ways to eliminate goods that have not sold and close store locations that no longer make money. Tracie Rozhon (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert in the Highlights in Jazz series at the Pace Downtown Theater misstated the day. The concert was yesterday; it is not Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gotbaum Criticizes Nursing Cuts
description: At a time when a $5 billion budget gap may lead to cuts in many programs, Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum, left, has found a cut that outrages her the most -- a reduction in the nursing staff at the city's private and parochial schools. In September, the city's Department of Health cut its school nursing budget across the board. Yesterday, Ms. Gotbaum said in a statement, ''Children attending parochial and private schools have the same needs as public school children.'' Sandra Mullin, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health, responded in a statement, ''Given resource constraints, we cannot continue to provide a higher proportion of nursing services to nonpublic schools without jeopardizing services to public schools.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: CALL CENTER COMPANY FORECASTS 4TH-QUARTER LOSS
description: Sykes Enterprises, an operator of call centers for computer makers and communication companies, said yesterday that it expected a loss of 4 cents to 7 cents a share in the fourth quarter, excluding certain costs. The company's stock price fell 31 percent after the report. Revenue will be $100 million to $110 million in the quarter, the company said, short of the $118.9 million expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sykes had a net loss of $9.35 million, or 23 cents a share, on revenue of $120.3 million a year earlier. The company may close some customer-help centers and cut some jobs because some call-center contracts will end in March. Fourth-quarter revamping costs will reduce pretax results $19 million to $23 million, or 35 cents to 43 cents a share after tax, Sykes said. Shares of Sykes closed down $1.54, at $3.37.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNS, STEVEN
description: BURNS-Steven, 41. Artist and production designer died of natural causes at his home in Los Angeles on Friday, October 18.

title: MEMO PAD
description: Midwest Express Cutting Back on Food

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOLL, MAESTRO CLIFF
description: SCHOLL-Maestro Cliff. A professional musician and well-known Westchester entertainer, died quietly at home on October 20, 2002. Resting at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville, NY on Wednesday from 3:30PM to 7:30PM where his funeral service will be held Thursday 10:30 A.M. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla.

title: TXU Is Selling British Division For $2.1 Billion
description: TXU, the troubled Texas utility, agreed today to sell its British retail business and power generation plants to E.ON of Germany for 1.37 billion, or about $2.1 billion, as it struggles to protect its investment-grade credit rating.

title: Van Horn's Defense Criticized
description: Nets Coach Byron Scott said today that the Nets were a better team since trading Keith Van Horn and Todd MacCulloch to Philadelphia for Dikembe Mutombo, and that the team was especially improved on defense without a slow Van Horn.

title: Kmart Encouraged as Sales Fall at a Slower Rate
description: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that it lost $176 million last month as sales continued to decline, but the rate of that decline slowed considerably as the company introduced new products and tried fresh strategies in some stores.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Deriding Pataki on Health Care
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, began broadcasting on Sunday statewide in New York.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PROGRESS SOFTWARE CORP., Bedford, Mass., said it would buy eXcelon Corp., Burlington, Mass., for $24 million, or about $3.19 a share, to add XML tools, which permit data to travel more freely.

title: Arch Coal Reports a Profit
description: Arch Coal posted a third-quarter profit, as the coal producer increased sales and benefited from higher prices under contracts signed last year.

title: A Pair of Finns Complement Each Other and Tchaikovsky
description: At the National Symphony on Friday, two living Finns engaged one of new music's primary debates: whether to embrace tradition or send it packing. Both composers hold on, though one more tightly than the other. Kaija Saariaho's ''Nymphea Reflection,'' written for string orchestra and new to this country, is a reimagining of an earlier electronically enhanced string quartet. Einojuhani Rautavaara's Clarinet Concerto was being heard for the first time anywhere.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about New York State's financial condition misspelled the given name of Gov. George E. Pataki's budget director in some copies. She is Carole E. Stone, not Carol.

title: 3M Reports 38% Increase In Net Income
description: The 3M Company said today that its third-quarter net income increased 38 percent, the largest quarterly profit in five years.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Teenager Charged In Killing
description: A 17-year-old wanted in a killing in Trenton this month was arrested yesterday in a hotel room in Pennsylvania by a task force of the United States Marshals Service, the authorities said. The youth, Tahaij Wells, 17, is accused of shooting another teenager, Robert McNair, three times in the chest in an argument over a girl on Oct. 11. Mr. Wells was found in a Macintosh Inn in Falls Township, Bucks County, Pa., by members of the New York-New Jersey Regional Fugitive Task Force and surrendered without incident, said Michael Schroeder, a spokesman for the marshals service. A gun believed to have been used in the killing was found in the hotel room, Mr. Schroeder added. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIENSTAG, LEO NATHAN, M.D.
description: DIENSTAG - Leo Nathan, M.D. Brooklyn-born, navy corpsman during WWII, graduate of Drew University and New York Medical College. A boarded internist, he taught and practiced his profession with dedication in Manhattan for more than 40 years. Survived by his wife, Grace, sons, Mark and David, grandchildren, brother, Jerome (Jacqueline), to all of whom he was deeply devoted and who now mourn his passing.

title: A Reporter Scrutinizes War and Its Myths
description: WAR IS A FORCE THAT GIVES US MEANING

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: EUROTUNNEL' S SALES UP Third-quarter revenue at Eurotunnel P.L.C. rose 2.9 percent as the company, the operator of the Channel Tunnel, carried more trucks on its shuttle trains. Sales rose to 149 million ($231 million) from 144.8 million a year earlier. Eurotunnel said it expected to be at or near break even on a cash basis by the end of the year. (Bloomberg News)

title: In Germany, Banks Mirror Wide Malaise In Economy
description: With plummeting share prices, faltering credit ratings and bad loans that keep piling up, Germany's banking system has come to symbolize the country's broader economic distress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAROSEN, MARY
description: KAROSEN-Mary. We were saddened to hear of the passing of Mary Karosen, beloved mother of Kent Karosen, Intrepid Museum Trustee. Our sympathies go out to Kent and his family. Tony Fisher, Bill White, David Winters, and all Intrepid board and staff.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: S.E.C. May File Complaint Against Martha Stewart

title: Three Officers Are Charged In Insurance Fraud Scheme
description: Three New York City police officers were charged yesterday with taking bribes to falsify dozens of motor vehicle accident reports that were then used to defraud insurance companies, according to investigators.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Study To Include Meetings With Parents
description: The city's Department of Education will hold more than 70 meetings with parents in the next three months as part of a $4 million study of the New York City school system. At the second meeting of the Panel for Educational Policy, the former Board of Education, Chancellor Joel I. Klein last night announced plans to collect information from parents, students and community groups. Earlier this month, Mr. Klein announced plans to use private donations for a study of the school system. Department officials will also use youth organizations to set up meetings with students. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Of Baby Boomers, Birds and Books
description: It is a publisher's dream.

title: Carter Is Going To the Dolphins
description: With a persuasive push from Dan Marino, Cris Carter went from sports commentator to Miami Dolphins wide receiver yesterday.

title: Massachusetts Charges Fraud In Complaint On First Boston
description: Taking a page from Eliot Spitzer's playbook, Massachusetts regulators filed a fraud complaint yesterday against Credit Suisse First Boston, contending that the firm's investment advice had been tainted by its hunger for fees from corporate clients.

title: Rating Move Aids Borrowing by Japanese Companies
description: In a bit of good news for Japan's battered economy, Moody's Investors Service raised the country's foreign currency debt ceiling, making it easier and cheaper for big Japanese companies like Toyota to borrow dollars and other foreign currencies.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Effort To Shut British Atom Plant
description: The government began a legal case at an international tribunal in The Hague to shut down Britain's plutonium reprocessing plant at Sellafield, about 60 miles from Dublin across the Irish Sea. Attorney General Rory Brady demanded that British Nuclear Fuels Ltd., a state-owned company, reveal its financial forecasts and sales volumes for the plant, which Ireland says causes nuclear pollution in the sea and is a target for terrorists. A company spokesman said the environmental threat is ''almost nonexistent.'' A shipment of nuclear material was returned to Sellafield from Japan last month after disclosures that some of the plant's safety records had been falsified. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: India and Pakistan: The Dispute Burns On
description: In an undertaking almost as mammoth as preparing for war, India and Pakistan are getting ready to pull hundreds of thousands of troops back from their border after the largest and longest peacetime standoff in their history.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: This year, marketers are trying to take the boo out of Halloween.
description: FOR the second consecutive year, Madison Avenue is exorcising many of the spooky, ghoulish and violent elements from Halloween advertising.

title: Pataki Calls Commuter Tax a Bad Idea
description: With an uncomfortable-looking Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg standing by his side, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he did not support reinstating the commuter tax to help the city out of its fiscal crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WRAGGE, ELIZABETH
description: WRAGGE-Elizabeth. Born in Holland, made her professional debut in silent films at the age of three. As a child actress on Broadway she appeared in more than 10 plays. An accomplished singer and dancer, she played with the Gold Spot Pals and was heard as Betty in Beech-Nut's Red Davis over WJZ and a national hook-up three times a week for two years. She performed on more than 10,000 live radio broadcasts including ''Pepper Young's Family'', which ran 1932-1959. Ms. Wragge was in numerous offbroadway plays, Summer stock, dinner theater and television soap operas. Survived by her daughter Christina Brooke, son Thomas Brooke, daughter - in - law Yolanda Hornedo-Brooke and grandson Justin. Memorial service Sunday, October 27, 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Better-Than-Expected Profit Reports Lift Shares Again
description: Stocks rose yesterday, driving benchmark indexes to their highest levels in more than five weeks. Philip Morris and Coca-Cola helped lead the advance after analysts recommended investors buy their shares.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Another Earthquake? Only Tourists Worry
description: PETER MAGOWAN will not predict there will be no earthquake during the three World Series games here.

title: 'Sopranos' Encroaches on the Series
description: Is it more important to watch Barry Bonds or Bobby Bacala?

title: Healing Unconventionally
description: ''Healing Outside the Margins,'' by Carole O'Toole with Dr. Carolyn B. Hendricks, LifeLine Press, $21.95.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: GEMSTAR-TV GUIDE SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING IT
description: Gemstar-TV Guide International said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. issued an order of investigation last week, Gemstar said. The company had said it was discussing its internal accounting review with the S.E.C. Gemstar, which makes software for running on-screen television program guides, delayed reporting its second-quarter earnings in August and said it would restate 2001 results after its review was complete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SELMA
description: RUBEN-Selma. The Rockefeller University notes with profound sorrow the loss of our beloved friend Selma Belfer Ruben, a dedicated member of The Rockefeller University Council and longtime University benefactor. We join all New Yorkers in saluting the enormous accomplishments of her life. Her generosity, in company with her husband, Lawrence, and often with her siblings, Robert Belfer and the late Anita Saltz, helped shape many of New York City's academic, medical, and cultural institutions, including this one. She gave to charity with a warm hand. At Rockefeller, her philanthropy touched many University initiatives, including research on colon cancer and nutrition, and the creation of the Selma and Lawrence Ruben Laboratory of Synthetic Protein Chemistry, to discover more effective treatments for cancer. We extend our deepest condolences to our Council member Lawrence, to her children Richard, Lenore, and Rochelle, to the Belfer and Saltz families, and to all who loved her. Thomas P. Sakmar, Acting President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Barry S. Coller, Physician-in-Chief Emil C. Gotschlich, Vice President of Medical Sciences Jules Hirsch, Physician-in-Chief Emeritus Tom W. Muir, Professor Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman, RU Council Richard B. Fisher, Chairman of the Board David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: A Sticker That Said 'Search Me'
description: The police in Garland acted unlawfully in searching a pickup truck for guns based in part on having seen a National Rifle Association sticker in the truck's back window, a divided panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, ruled. ''If the presence of an N.R.A. sticker and camouflage gear in a vehicle could be used by an officer to conclude he was in danger,'' the majority wrote, ''half the pickups in the state of Texas would be subject to a vehicle search.'' Chief Judge Carolyn Dineen King dissented, saying that ''throwing an N.R.A. sticker into the calculus'' of whether to search the vehicle was lawful. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Autism Therapy Is Called Effective, but Rare
description: No one has found a cure for autism, the neurological disorder that leads to lifelong impairments in a child's ability to speak, respond to others, share affection and learn. But there is a growing consensus that intensive early intervention is both effective and essential -- the sooner after diagnosis, the better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, HANNA
description: STARK-Hanna. The Yeshiva University family joins in mourning the passing of a highly respected and exemplary Jewish matriarch, the beloved mother of Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary trustee Norman (and Helene) Stark, Shirley (and Mark) Stark Hus, Helen (and Shimon) Spirn and Susan Stark. Helene and Norman Stark are RIETS Fellows and supporters of several projects at Yeshiva University. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Oklahoma Tops Miami In B.C.S. Ranking
description: The computers say Notre Dame is the best team in the nation and the human voters choose Miami. But after blending those two opinions with strength of schedule, the Bowl Championship Series ranking, which was released yesterday for the first time this season, concluded that Oklahoma is college football's No. 1 team.

title: BUSH DECLARES U.S. IS USING DIPLOMACY TO DISARM HUSSEIN
description: President Bush said today that the United States was trying diplomacy ''one more time'' to disarm Saddam Hussein ''peacefully'' and suggested that if the Iraqi leader complied with every United Nations mandate it would ''signal the regime has changed.''

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: BROOKLYN: TALKS OVER LOUIMA LEGAL FEES COLLAPSE Talks to settle the dispute over nearly $3 million in legal fees in the Abner Louima civil case collapsed yesterday. Several of the lawyers involved said testimony in the case would probably resume today. "I don't know whether we're going to be able to resolve the matter," said Bradley D. Simon, a lawyer for the estate of Carl W. Thomas, one of two lawyers who said they were forced out of Mr. Louima's case by a team of lawyers headed by Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. The civil case was settled out of court in July 2001 for $8.75 million, with Mr. Louima receiving about $6 million and the rest reserved for lawyers' fees.

title: Rabbi Retried On Charges Of Hiring Wife's Killer
description: A prosecutor denounced a South Jersey rabbi today as a man of God who betrayed his calling, as the rabbi went on trial for the second time on charges that he hired a friend to murder his wife.

title: Coach Leather Says Sales and Profits Exceed Expectations
description: Coach, the leather goods maker that signaled its rejuvenation four years ago with the introduction of the Jack Russell terrier Eddy as its mascot, will report that sales are up 28 percent and that per-share earnings are up 79 percent, exceeding analysts' expectations.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Talks Over Louima Legal Fees Collapse
description: Talks to settle the dispute over nearly $3 million in legal fees in the Abner Louima civil case collapsed yesterday. Several of the lawyers involved said testimony in the case would probably resume today. ''I don't know whether we're going to be able to resolve the matter,'' said Bradley D. Simon, a lawyer for the estate of Carl W. Thomas, one of two lawyers who said they were forced out of Mr. Louima's case by a team of lawyers headed by Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. The civil case was settled out of court in July 2001 for $8.75 million, with Mr. Louima receiving about $6 million and the rest reserved for lawyers' fees. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Discrimination and Tiger Woods
description: To the Editor:

title: 14 Die as Bomb-Filled S.U.V. Rams Israeli Bus
description: A sport utility vehicle primed with a powerful bomb slammed into an Israeli bus at rush hour here this afternoon, igniting the fuel tank of the bus and killing at least 14 passengers. Flames rendered the vehicle a blackened, contorted skeleton.

title: The Inquiring Minds Behind 200 Years of Inventions
description: They were fathers and mothers of invention, and their children were diverse as ingenuity itself: a kidney dialysis machine, fiber optic cable, a hepatitis vaccine, miniature microphones, a reading machine, the birth control pill, high-resolution radar and a fabric protector.

title: The Vietnam War, as Seen in Art From the Other Side
description: The Vietnam War was the most filmed, photographed and documented conflict in history, but until recently most images have come from the American side. Now, complementing the rarely seen photographs ''from the other side'' exhibited in New York this year, the British Museum is presenting a show of posters, paintings and drawings made by North Vietnamese and Vietcong artists between 1965 and 1975.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHURE, MICHAEL A.
description: SHURE-Michael A. On October 21. Adored husband of Alice. Beloved father of Michael Jr. and Tony. Cherished father-in-law of Sandra. Devoted son of Evelyn and the late Harry Shure. Born in New Haven, CT. on December 23, 1938. Graduate of the University of Virginia. Attended Pratt School of Architecture. He lived his life with inimitable passion. He loved his family and friends unconditionally. He made all who knew him laugh and smile. Private burial. A Memorial service will be held on Wednesday 6pm in the Peter B. Lewis Theatre at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Seek Federal Guidance on Jury in Sentencing That Uses Prior Offenses as Factor
description: The revolution in criminal sentencing that the Supreme Court's decision in Apprendi v. New Jersey started two years ago is still reverberating through the state and federal systems, as was made clear today by a one-line order from the court.

title: Front Row
description: Dior's Uptown Feet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILL, HAROLD F., JR., ''BING''
description: STILL-Harold F., Jr., ''Bing'', 79. Of Rydal, PA., and Barnstable, MA., a commercial banker and civic leader for 40 years in Philadelphia, died October 19. Survived by wife Virginia, sons David, John and James and eight grandchildren. Viewing 6-9PM October 22, Helweg Funeral Home, Jenkintown. Funeral services Oct. 23, 11 AM at Grace Presbyterian Church.

title: Ford Is Seeking $1 Billion More in Cuts
description: Ford Motor's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said today that industrywide auto sales were softer than last month and he asked executives at the automaker to find another $1 billion in cost cuts.

title: For Indonesia Leader, Small Talk Edges Tough Talk
description: When the Australian foreign minister arrived here after the bombings in Bali to talk about terrorism, President Megawati Sukarnoputri greeted him with the kind of inconsequential remark expected from a protocol officer.

title: Scarface? Richard Crookback? The Godfather? Nope, It's a Hitlerian Thug
description: To say that Al Pacino is giving the performance of his career at the moment is not to say that he is giving his best performance ever. What is true is that in the splashy, star-packed new revival of Bertolt Brecht's ''Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui,'' Mr. Pacino sometimes seems to be channeling most of his more celebrated roles. It's as if his entire professional life were passing before your eyes in a series of juicy, iconographic acting bites.

title: Pockets Are Added to Friars' Tunics, and the Sky Falls
description: In this fashion capital, where designers routinely send bare-breasted models onto runways or propose that women wear bikini bottoms to work, it is hard to conceive of making headlines with a pair of pockets. Yet that is what happened to Elisabetta Bianchetti, a designer whom very few here had heard of a year ago.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: HONG KONG: JOBLESS RATE FALLS For the second consecutive month, the seemingly stumbling Hong Kong economy unexpectedly created jobs considerably faster than the labor force grew. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 7.4 percent in the period from July to September, compared with 7.6 percent in the three-month period through August and 7.8 percent in the three-month period through July. But personal bankruptcies more than tripled in September compared with a year earlier, to 2,580.

title: Technology Briefing: Hardware
description: LEXMARK POSTS 29% INCREASE IN INCOME Lexmark International Inc. , the computer printer maker, reported a 29 percent jump in third-quarter net income yesterday on robust sales of ink cartridges for its laser and inkjet printers. Lexmark, the No. 2 maker of inkjet printers after Hewlett-Packard , also raised its fourth-quarter outlook slightly. However, it said it remained cautious because of uncertain spending on technology, a relatively weak consumer market and aggressive competition. Despite an industry slump in personal computer sales, which also weighs on printers, Lexmark has enjoyed the benefits of its ink sales, the high-margin black and color cartridges that users need to keep their printers running. The company reported third-quarter net income of $90 million, or 70 cents a share, compared with $70 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding a write-down for the abandonment of a software project, Lexmark earned 79 cents a share in the latest quarter. After Lexmark announced its outlook for the quarter on Oct. 10, analysts raised their expectations to an average of 78 cents a share from 64 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $1.04 billion from $996 million. Shares rose $1.19, to $56.94. (Reuters)

title: Fighting Frailty to Stay at Home
description: Elderly people who want to stay at home but worry that they may be too frail can benefit from an in-home training program, researcher say.

title: Footlights
description: Into the Light

title: North Korea's Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Oil Still Pours From a Mideast Barrel
description: Even as talk of war with Iraq and the continuing fallout from Sept. 11 stoke concerns about American dependence on Persian Gulf oil, Western oil companies are showing no intentions of veering away from the Middle East, industry executives say.

title: A Square Peg Fills the Hole As the Angels' Catalyst
description: The telephone calls between the father and the son every Saturday night always end the same way. Whitey Eckstein reminds his son David to go to Mass the next morning, and the dutiful son assures his father that he will. Whether the Anaheim Angels are at home or in Seattle, Boston or New York, Eckstein begins Sundays by going to church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNOR, DONALD R.
description: GAYNOR-Donald R. Died on October 20, 2002 in Manhattan. Predeceased by his longtime companion Donald McKechnie. Brother of Richard L. Gaynor and wife Roberta. Uncle of Jennifer Konigsberg and husband Philip. Uncle of Charles David Gaynor, his wife Cynthia & their daughter Elaine. Graveside services are at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in lieu of flowers to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOLAN, ELIZABETH
description: DOLAN-Elizabeth. On October 20, 2002 in Weston, CT., daughter of Marlene Deutsch and Michael Dolan, sister of Andrew Dolan, and granddaughter of Ellen Dolan. Services Tuesday 1:00 PM at Abraham L. Green & Son Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT. Contributions to Elizabeth Dolan Scholarship Fund at Weston High School.

title: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; New Set of Rules Is in the Works For Accounting
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which is the primary body that issues accounting rules in the United States, is moving to simplify its rules and to rein in other rule makers.

title: Dynegy to Lay Off 14% of Work Force
description: Dynegy Inc., which is abandoning its energy trading business, said today that it would lay off about 780 workers, or 14 percent of its work force, including an estimated 600 at its Houston headquarters.

title: Cendant Profit Falls On Adjusted Basis
description: Cendant said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell after it wrote down the value of mortgage servicing rights as homeowners repaid loans faster than expected.

title: INSIDE
description: Dispute on Towers' Collapse

title: Times Co. to Buy Washington Post's Stake in Herald Tribune
description: The New York Times Company said today that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire The Washington Post Company's 50 percent ownership of The International Herald Tribune, which would make it the sole owner of the Paris-based newspaper.

title: Barrett Sees Maturity Taking Root at Seton Hall
description: The bruised ego Andre Barrett sustained after Seton Hall stumbled to a 12-18 record last season bothered him well into August.

title: Treating Related Problems, Not Autism
description: A growing number of autistic children are treated with drugs. But the drugs are prescribed not for autism itself but for behavior problems that often accompany it: self-injury, hyperactivity, aggression, tantrums, anxiety and repetitive behavior.

title: Bonds's Blast Is Still In Orbit
description: The biggest question of the World Series was supposed to be whether the Anaheim Angels would pitch to Barry Bonds. But Bonds has turned that question on its ear and provided a new one: Where exactly did the ball Bonds hit in Anaheim on Sunday night land?

title: Another Accounting Error at Swiss Life
description: Wrong again.

title: Discrimination And Tiger Woods
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Jesus' Inscription on Stone May Be Earliest Ever Found
description: An inscription in stone, found in or near Jerusalem and written in a language and script of 2,000 years ago, bears the words ''James, son of Joseph, brother of Jesus.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union Beach: Death Was No Suicide, Prosecutor Says
description: The gunshot that killed a 20-year-old man on Saturday was unlikely to have been self-inflicted, as first reported, the authorities said yesterday. An autopsy indicated that the bullet's path would not have resulted from a self-inflicted shot, and investigators are treating the death as a crime. Witnesses told the police that the man, Keith Rice, 20, of Keansburg, shot himself playing Russian roulette. But the .357-caliber bullet entered his skull from behind his right ear, unlikely if Mr. Rice had held the gun, John Kaye, the Monmouth County prosecutor, said. A 17-year-old boy said he found the gun on a hiking path; the police said the gun was stolen in Pennsylvania. The boy, identified by The Asbury Park Press as Eric Burke of Keyport, was charged with weapons offenses.

title: North Korea's A-Arms Project Jeopardizes Aid, Japan Says
description: Japan will stop financing two nuclear reactors in North Korea and suspend talks on normalizing relations if there is no progress on ending the North's clandestine nuclear weapons program, Japan's lead negotiator said today.

title: U.N. Agency Urgently Seeks Food for Afghans and Africans
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization appealed today for immediate help for Afghanistan and southern Africa, warning that failure to provide food and agricultural aid could lead to famine.

title: Mexicans Arrest 25 to Stop Ring That Worked for Drug Cartels
description: Mexican officials said today that they had arrested 25 people who infiltrated the army, the federal police and the attorney general's office on behalf of some of the nation's most powerful drug kingpins.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Credit Card Profit Slips
description: Kookmin Credit Card, a subsidiary of Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest commercial bank, reported that net income in the third quarter was $237 million, down 15.5 percent from the third quarter of last year, as it raised its provisions for bad debts to comply with a new government regulation. Kookmin said it ended the quarter with 12.3 million clients, an increase of 25 percent from a year earlier, and its billings rose by 38 percent. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Director at the Top, With an Opera and an Honor
description: On Friday afternoon, Francesca Zambello, the stage director, was made a Chevalier de l'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres. On Friday evening her production of Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov'' opened at the Bastille Opera. Both events demonstrated that she's doing well.

title: Hated Music, but Hear Him Now; From Cultural Revolution Chaos to Metropolitan Fame
description: The operatic story of his life (working title: ''The Long March From Mao to the Met'') begins with a scene of guilty pleasure. Ten-year-old Hao Jiang Tian's piano teacher has just been branded an intellectual and dragged off to a Beijing jail.

title: Golisano Cites an Old Scandal
description: Tom Golisano, the Independence candidate for governor, began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement statewide yesterday, in keeping with his latest line of attack against Gov. George E. Pataki. Both Mr. Golisano and H. Carl McCall sought to make an issue of a fund-raising scandal centered on Mr. Pataki's first run for governor, in 1994.

title: Doubts Raised About Value of Heart Disease Marker
description: Levels of homocysteine in the blood  recently promoted as the new cholesterol as a harbinger of coronary disease  may not be very helpful in predicting heart attacks and strokes in healthy people, a study has found.

title: Going Onstage With Moves Inspired by Street Outside
description: A half block east of the New Victory Theater, youngsters regularly break-dance on a corner for a huge audience. Inside the New Victory, a company called Full Circle is presenting that dance form as an art. Happily, what unfolds in the troupe's hourlong show ''Soular Power'd'' has lost nothing of the gritty vibrancy of New York streets.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERRY, EDWARD
description: PERRY-Edward. June 27, 1908-October 22, 1993. Dear Edward, Your spirit is always with me. Your presence is greatly missed. Much love, Fito

title: MetroStars to Hire Bradley, Giving the League a Lift
description: Major League Soccer took another step toward maturity in its seventh year of existence despite the repeated failures of the MetroStars, arguably the most important team in the league's long-term success.

title: 3 Big Advertisers Shift Their Accounts
description: Three big advertisers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: In Defense of a Scientist
description: To the Editor:

title: Quietly, Professionals Review High-Rise Safety After 9/11
description: Over many months, reams of analysis have piled up  a sometimes competing mix of calculation and deduction that suggests an array of answers to the questions of why and how the steel skeletons of the twin towers suddenly came apart in raging fires on Sept. 11. And with that increased understanding, the storms of emotion surrounding the grim, disturbing questions have quieted some.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, MITCHELL
description: ROBERTS-Mitchell. Happy Birthday. We love you and miss you. Mom, Dad, Jimmy & Jody

title: We've Seen The Outrage, And It Is Us
description: IT seems almost impossible to parade on this mayor's reign without causing an uproar. Everybody is peeved.

title: Acrimony Envelops Piniella Pursuit
description: As Lou Piniella awaited an offer from Tampa Bay to manage the Devil Rays next season, the Mets and the Mariners remained deadlocked over the compensation Seattle would require to allow the Mets to speak to Piniella.

title: 13 Protesting Bush's Stance Enter U.N. and Are Ousted
description: In an episode that raised new questions about security at United Nations headquarters, demonstrators today, protesting the Bush administration's confrontation with Baghdad, got inside the General Assembly, where they shouted, ''No war in Iraq!'' United Nations officials said.

title: Richmond Is Jolted by a Sniper's Attack and Its Aftermath as Well
description: They unleashed the Blackhawk helicopter, the SWAT team, scores of federal agents and even a spy plane.

title: An Edge for Skateboarding
description: A new study offers what may be a surprising verdict on skateboarding: it is a comparatively safe sport. But the growing practice of ''street skating'' and a reluctance to wear safety equipment has nonetheless led to a doubling of skateboard injuries in recent years, the researchers warned.

title: Rejecting the Bishops
description: It is no surprise that Vatican officials have put the United States Catholic bishops' zero-tolerance policy on hold. Many Catholics may be surprised to learn, however, that the Vatican's concern focuses on due process for priests accused of child sexual abuse. Due process has not been a hallmark of Vatican decision making. Why raise it now?

title: Letters
description: In Defense of a Scientist

title: A Teacher Gets Results at Lunch
description: A simple glance at the half-full trays sent back at elementary school cafeterias would confirm suspicions that many children eat little of their lunches.

title: Old Rival Comes Calling As Eagles Ready a Move
description: A stadium elevator was stuck for 20 minutes after an N.F.L. game Sunday, which would be news except that it was an elevator at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia.

title: Grappling With the Dangers Of the New World Order
description: LONGITUDES AND ATTITUDES

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL FALLS. A decline in crude oil prices put pressure on heating oil. In New York, heating oil for November delivery fell 4.06 cents, or 5.1 percent, to 76.29 cents a gallon.

title: Good and Bad Marriage, Boon and Bane to Health
description: In the early 1970's, demographers began to notice a strange pattern in life span data: married people tended to live longer than their single, divorced and widowed counterparts.

title: Bumper-to-Bumper Details of the Crossover Era
description: AMERICANS want more space in their vehicles without adding length. They also want a single vehicle to play the role of many. Those conflicting demands make these the toughest times for car designers since the late 1970's, when fuel crises forced sudden downsizing. Designers now speak of "crossovers"  vehicles that are part truck and part car, part sport utility vehicle and part sports car.

title: READER'S DIGEST TO POST FIRST-QUARTER LOSS
description: The Reader's Digest Association will post a loss for the first quarter of its fiscal year after deciding to delay the recognition of some sales and profit from a publishing unit it acquired in May. The company will book 10 cents a share in profit from Reiman Publications in the second quarter instead of the first, the company said. Reader's Digest had forecast results of breaking even to a profit of 5 cents a share for the three months ended Sept. 30. Reiman recorded revenue from sales of holiday craft and cooking books in the first quarter, then took a reserve to account for customer returns. Reader's Digest will wait until a 30-day deadline for returns passes before booking the revenue. The publisher said it still expected full-year profit of $1.20 to $1.30 a share.

title: Discrimination And Tiger Woods
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Observer; Three Plays, Nine Hours Celebrating Political Imperfection
description: In 1917 Russian Communists declared that the state would wither away, leaving behind a Socialist paradise, but by the end of Stalin's reign of terror tens of millions had been killed. In 1938 the Nazis spoke of a glorious 1,000-year Reich, but within seven years many millions more had been shot, gassed and otherwise murdered. And today the terrorist network Al Qaeda is promising its adherents paradise on earth, ruled by the law of the Koran, and the death toll is mounting rapidly.

title: Abortion Pill May Help Treat Severe Form of Depression
description: Mifepristone, once called RU-486, is best known as the abortion pill.

title: Corrections
description: The White House Letter article yesterday, about Karen Hughes's part-time presence in Washington as an adviser to President Bush, referred incorrectly in some copies to the view from her former White House office. It looked out toward the Truman Balcony, not the South Portico.

title: The Universe Seems So Simple, Until You Have to Explain It
description: The Old Worthen House, a no-frills tavern still sporting what looks like its original 1834 tin ceiling on a street as yet ungentrified in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass., has seen its share of cosmic theorizing.

title: Mayor Weighs Plan To Turn Over Bridges To Transit Authority
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg might just sell the Brooklyn Bridge -- and the Manhattan, Williamsburg and Queensboro Bridges, too.

title: Ending a Drug Patent Scam
description: Goaded into action by election-year politics, President Bush took steps yesterday to close legal loopholes that have allowed manufacturers of brand-name drugs to keep cheaper generic versions off the market through devious delaying tactics. It was a modest step, but one that most people involved in the acrimonious debates over prescription drug prices will be able to support -- except, of course, the pharmaceutical companies that have profited from the loophole.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERNANDEZ, AUGUSTIN
description: FERNANDEZ-Augustin. On October 19. Born in Fontan, Spain. Father of John Paul. Gus was a man who marched to the beat of a different drummer. He loved life, a good meal and good wine. His spirit was drawn to the sea. He lived in Belle Harbor, Queens where the ocean was at his door. A celebration of life will be held on Wednesday, October 23, Casa Galicia, 3709 31 Ave, Astoria, NY, 6-9. Bring a picture, a memory and a story. Dress accordingly, turtleneck sweaters required. Contributions to Calvary Hospital Fund, Tree of Life, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Using Technology to Add New Dimensions to the Nightly Call Home
description: Mara G. Aspinall, a biotechnology executive, and her two sons went over their final report cards last spring -- by fax and phone. She was away on a business trip, and the boys faxed the grades to her hotel and then called her to discuss them.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/David Allen Sibley; 13 Ways (at Least) of Looking at a Sparrow
description: David Allen Sibley is standing at the edge of a pond on this coastal island off northern Massachusetts, peering alternately through binoculars and a telescope at a mixed bag of shorebirds and ducks in the shallow water.

title: City and State Agree to Make Harlem Piers a Waterfront Park
description: City and state officials said yesterday that they had agreed on a plan to transform a desolate strip of waterfront land in Harlem into a recreational area. It would include fishing and boating piers, an esplanade and a small privately financed building with a restaurant, shops and a visitors' or education center.

title: Injuries and Quick Healing Upset Ballet Theater Plans
description: American Ballet Theater has been full of surprises of a nonartistic sort in the first week of the company's fall season at City Center. Injuries and unexpectedly quick recoveries have forced major reorderings of repertory and performers from day to day.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Hungary: Pro-Europe Vote
description: Leftist parties that favor joining the European Union swept local elections over the weekend, also handing a victory to the new government led by the Hungarian Socialist Party. ''Thank you, Hungary,'' the Socialist prime minister, Peter Medgyessy, said after his party and an ally took nearly 49 percent of the vote. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an exhibit at the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis that questions whether James Earl Ray acted alone in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misidentified a recorded voice that speaks of ''a climate of hate'' at the time and says, ''You knew it was going to happen.'' It is the voice of Myrlie Evers, widow of Medgar Evers, not Coretta Scott King.

title: Making a Case for a U.S. Invasion of Iraq
description: THE THREATENING STORM

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Montenegro Government Wins
