description: Montenegro's governing pro-independence coalition appeared to have won a majority in the general election on Sunday, giving it the authority to complete terms of a looser relationship with Serbia, its partner in the Yugoslav federation. The vote was essentially a test of public confidence in President Milo Djukanovic, who agreed under heavy pressure from the European Union to drop demands for outright independence for the next three years. Projections showed Mr. Djukanovic's bloc winning about 39 seats in the 75-member Parliament Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Denison Kitchel, 94, Chief of Goldwater Campaign
description: Denison Kitchel, a close friend and the most influential adviser to Barry M. Goldwater in his presidential campaign in 1964, died on Oct. 10 at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 94.

title: After Loss, A Meeting Is Called By Messier
description: It took just seven games for Mark Messier to call for the Rangers' first closed-door meeting of the season. Messier's message? That it is unacceptable to give away games the way the Rangers did in a 4-2 loss to the Tampa Bay Lightning last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZER, RICHARD
description: SALZER - Richard. The Board of Trustees, management and staff of The Jewish Home and Hospital Lifecare System mourn the passing of our devoted trustee of 20 years. The treasurer of our Board and the mainstay of our Westchester/Sarah Neuman Center, he will be missed for his sage financial counsel and commitment to quality of care. We extend our sincere sympathies to his beloved wife, Betty. He leaves us a great legacy by which he will always be remembered. Fred M. Lowenfels, Chairman of the Board Amy K. Pollinger, Chair, Sarah Neuman Center Sheldon Goldberg, President/CEO

title: Jets' Pennington Is Spreading the Field, and the Joy
description: How drastically has the Jets' offense changed since Chad Pennington took over at quarterback?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, RAYMOND, M.D.
description: MILLER - Raymond, M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni express profound sorrow at the loss of our esteemed colleague and long time friend. He will be missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his entire family. Jeffrey S. Freed, M.D., Pres. William G. Stein, M.D., V.P.. Maria L. Padilla, M.D., Secy. George Raptis, M.D., Treas.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Saturday Night McCain Fever

title: Canadian Bank Is Curbing U.S. Supermarket Venture
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said today that it would ''substantially reduce or close'' its money-losing venture with supermarket chains in the United States.

title: Outbreaks of a Rare Botulism Strain Stymie Scientists
description: When a botulism outbreak hit this provincial park on Lake Erie in early September, it closed the beach. Thousands of dead fish, their white bellies glinting in the sun, washed up on the sandy shore. Hundreds of cormorants, gulls and terns fed on the dead sheephead, burbot and perch and quickly keeled over.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: New Indictments In Bosnia Massacre
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal indicted three former members of the Bosnian Serb Army for the massacre of about 7,000 Muslims at Srebrenica in 1995. Drago Nikolic, Vujadin Popovic and Ljubisa Beara were charged with genocide. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALVAREZ BRAVO, MANUEL
description: ALVAREZ BRAVO-Manuel. A great photographer and a friend for the last 30 years will be deeply missed by Evelyne Z. Daitz, The Witkin Gallery.

title: Lax New York Rules Make Big Money Talk
description: A remarkable series of legislative battles was fought here over the last year, linked by a recurring theme. In each case, powerful business and labor interests, armed with well-connected lobbyists and money for campaign contributions, won a victory that looked unlikely not too long before.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about the multiple roles of Karl Rove, adviser to President Bush, misstated the margin by which Mr. Bush lost to Al Gore in California. And a correction in this space, also on Sunday, expressed the actual margin improperly. The number of percentage points was 12, not 13; the percentage itself was 28 percent, not 12.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Presidential Race Heads To Runoff
description: Political squabbling broke out after a final count after the presidential election on Sunday showed a discharged army colonel and a banana tycoon headed toward a runoff on Nov. 24. The tycoon, lvaro Noboa, 51, set the tone for the five weeks leading to the runoff by charging that Lucio Gutirrez, 45, the former colonel, is a Communist. Mr. Gutirrez, above, won 20.3 percent of the vote; Mr. Noboa had 17.4. Eleven candidates ran in the first election since Indian groups, with the support of Mr. Guitrrez and other military officers, ousted President Jamil Mahuad in 2000. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ad Revenue On Net Drops 4% In 2nd Quarter
description: Internet advertising revenue fell 4 percent in the second quarter of 2002, to $1.46 billion, the Interactive Advertising Bureau said yesterday. It said the results were no surprise given the weakened overall advertising market, but that some online ad sellers were growing and a turnaround in revenue was quite possible by the fourth quarter. For the first half of 2002, marketers spent $2.98 billion, down 20.8 percent over the first half of 2001. The figures were compiled by PricewaterhouseCoopers for the Interactive Advertising Bureau, an industry trade association. Nat Ives (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: PRESSING FIREFIGHTERS NOT TO STRIKE Saying that planned strikes by firefighters were "wrong and dangerous," Prime Minister Tony Blair called on other unions to put pressure on the firefighters not to go ahead. The firefighters, seeking a 40 percent pay increase, have said they will begin a series of walkouts, lasting up to eight days at a time, next Tuesday. Rail union officials have threatened to follow suit, arguing that they would be unable to guarantee their workers' safety if the firefighters went on strike. Seeking a solution, Mr. Blair convened a crisis meeting of the cabinet's Civil Contingencies Committee.    Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: The Price of Stability
description: The Bush administration is now debating a postwar occupation of Iraq modeled on the United States occupation of Japan after World War II. Under this approach, Iraq would initially be ruled by an American military officer while a new Iraqi government is formed. Coalition military forces would perhaps remain in Iraq for years to make good on President Bush's promise of a post-Saddam Iraq where ''the oppression of Kurds, of Assyrians, Turkomans, Shia, Sunnis and others will be lifted'' and in which ''the United States and our allies will help the Iraqi people rebuild their economy and create the institutions of liberty.''

title: Expert Report Disputes U.S. On Collapse
description: Experts commissioned in a $4 billion insurance case involving the World Trade Center have come to conclusions that fundamentally contradict a federal investigation into what caused the twin towers to collapse. The new analysis, according to several experts who have examined the confidential findings, holds that the unusual engineering design of the towers did not contribute to the collapses, and that the damage caused by the planes and the resulting fires made the failures of the buildings inevitable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIENDLY, DOROTHY GREENE
description: FRIENDLY - Dorothy Greene. On Oct. 19, 2002, in her 84th year. Adored mother of Andrew, Lisa and David. Beloved grandmother of Christopher & James Nicholson & Madeleine & Andrew Friendly. Loving sister of Robert Greene. Memorial announcement to follow. Donations to Rhode Island School of Design, 2 College Street, Providence, R.I. 02903, in her memory are appreciated.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Are Guilty Of Pollution Violations
description: A landlord and his son have been convicted of violating federal law by hiring immigrant workers to use knives to cut dangerous asbestos insulation out of a Brooklyn building without following required safety procedures. In a two-week trial that ended with a guilty verdict on Friday, federal prosecutors argued that after environmental inspectors closed the building on Prince Street in downtown Brooklyn because of the hazards, the son, Isaac Rubenstein, tried to hire a contractor to continue with the illegal asbestos removal. Mr. Rubenstein, 27, of Brooklyn, and his father, Marvin Rubenstein, 56, of Muncie, N.Y., were convicted of violating the Clean Air Act. Each could face a prison term of five years and a fine of more than $250,000. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESTEROW, CHARLOTTE
description: ESTEROW - Charlotte. Be loved daughter of the late Harry and Pearl Esterow, devoted sister of David and Phyllis, Ina, and the late Sylvia Barash, cherished aunt of Jeffrey & Joanne, Debbie, Roberta & Gerald, Stuart, Howard & Denise, Marjorie & Michael, Richard & Karen, Kenneth & Laura, loving great aunt and caring friend to many. Services Tuesday 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Strike Staged In Venezuela To Force Vote
description: The opposition movement in Venezuela staged a national strike today, the third in 10 months, to try to force the country's left-leaning leader, Hugo Chvez, to hold early elections before his term expires at the end of 2006.

title: 35-Story Tower Is Planned For Last Open Times Sq. Lot
description: Twenty-two years after the city and the state announced an ambitious project to transform a seedy and forlorn Times Square, a prominent real estate family is planning to build a 35-story tower on the last remaining parcel in the 13-acre redevelopment district.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday about the multiple roles of Karl Rove, adviser to President Bush, misstated the margin by which Mr. Bush lost to Al Gore in California. And a correction in this space, also on Sunday, expressed the actual margin improperly. The number of percentage points was 12, not 13; the percentage itself was 28 percent, not 12.

title: A Duo Paces the Dancers, Adding a Galactic Gateway
description: Introspection for club kids? Dance music for people who think too much? Underworld thrives in a hazy zone where songs metamorphose into dance tracks and textures get reconfigured as tunes. Billowing chords, brooding melodies, thumping beats and vocals that crooned in one song and jabbed in another were all juxtaposed in Underworld's two-and-a-half-hour set at the Hammerstein Ballroom on Friday night. ''This electric stream and my tears, in league with the wires and energy and my machine,'' Karl Hyde sang, ''This is my beautiful dream.''

title: U.S. Revises Iraq Resolution, But an Accord Still Eludes It
description: The United States presented a slightly revised draft resolution on Iraq to the four other permanent members of the Security Council today, but it did not reach agreement with France and Russia, diplomats said.

title: Cairo Journal; For Women, a Male Mannerism: The Water Pipe
description: At the Sidi Mansour outdoor cafe in the upscale Mohandiseen district here, smokers sat around low tables and puffed lazily on water pipes. Fragrant smoke swirled upward, and young men in robes used metal tongs to drop fresh coals on the tobacco.

title: Scant Progress in East Hampton Murder
description: It has been a year of tabloid headlines and ceaseless speculation since R. Theodore Ammon, a multimillionaire Manhattan financier, was found bludgeoned to death inside his ivy-covered country house here on Middle Lane.

title: JEWELRY RETAILER FORECASTS WIDER LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: Zale, a leading North American jewelry retailer, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss would be wider than it forecast as sales at stores open at least a year might decline. The net loss in the three months ending Oct. 31 will be 19 cents to 21 cents a share, Zale said. Sales will change little or drop 1 percent, the company said. The number of customers visiting malls slowed in August and September, hurting sales at its Piercing Pagoda stores, Zale said.

title: Jordan Comes Off the Bench
description: Michael Jordan made his preseason debut last night, hitting his first shot after coming off the bench during the second quarter of the Washington Wizards' 96-73 victory over the Nuggets in Denver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMILOWITZ, BERNARD
description: SMILOWITZ-Bernard. The Yeshiva University family is deeply saddened by the untimely demise of a widely respected member of the Springfield, New Jersey Jewish Community. Condolences are extended to his beloved brother, Herbert (& Marilyn) Smilowitz vice chair and major supporter of the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva University; his cherished wife, Bernice, beloved son Norman (& Cory) Smilowitz & beloved sister Rita Newman. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Bush Sees Korean Nuclear Effort as Different From Iraq's
description: President Bush said today that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, had to disarm his nation ''for the sake of peace,'' but indicated that he saw a significant difference between North Korea's development of nuclear weapons and Iraq's pursuit of them.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: MILFORD: COACH LOSES JOB FOR NOT DISCLOSING CRIMINAL RECORD School officials say a coach at Jonathan Law High School has been fired for failing to disclose his criminal record. Gregory Firn, the superintendent, would not reveal the name of the coach, but he confirmed he recently fired the coach for failing to note the conviction on an employment application. The coach began his duties Sept. 3 and was fired Oct. 1, officials said. Mr. Firn said that the coach was not a teacher and that the conviction had nothing to do with children. He would not reveal the offense. (AP)

title: 6 Indicted on Charges of Providing Material Aid to Terrorist Group
description: A federal grand jury indicted six men today on charges of providing material support to a terrorist organization through their participation in an Al Qaeda training camp in the summer of 2001.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an exhibit at the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis that questions whether James Earl Ray acted alone in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misidentified a recorded voice that speaks of "a climate of hate" at the time and says, "You knew it was going to happen." It is the voice of Myrlie Evers, widow of Medgar Evers, not Coretta Scott King.

title: Investigators in Sniper Case Reveal Threat to Children
description: ASPEN HILL, Md., Oct. 22  A bus driver pausing in the quiet before his morning route was shot to death here today, leaving alarmed residents and police widely fearing the man was the 10th fatality attributable to the roving suburban sniper.

title: U.N. Study Says Armies Leave Corrupt Networks in Congo
description: Even as Rwanda, Zimbabwe and Uganda are withdrawing their troops from Congo, they are leaving behind ''networks'' of corrupt businesspeople and criminals to exploit the nation's natural riches, according to a United Nations report issued today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMESON, EDWIN C. JR.
description: JAMESON-Edwin C. Jr. In Hamble, England. Of West Palm Beach, FL., at the age of 88, on September 28, 2002. Son of the late Mary G. and Edwin C. Jameson of New York and Sharon, CT. Survived by his sister Mary J.P. Moore and nephews Samuel F. Posey and Nicholas J. Moore, all of Sharon, CT., and David W. Moore of Woodbridge, CT. Memorial service will take place at Christ Church, Sharon, CT. Thursday, October 24, 2002 at 11AM with interment following at the Sharon Cemetery.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pressing Firefighters Not To Strike
description: Saying that planned strikes by firefighters were ''wrong and dangerous,'' Prime Minister Tony Blair called on other unions to put pressure on the firefighters not to go ahead. The firefighters, seeking a 40 percent pay increase, have said they will begin a series of walkouts, lasting up to eight days at a time, next Tuesday. Rail union officials have threatened to follow suit, arguing that they would be unable to guarantee their workers' safety if the firefighters went on strike. Seeking a solution, Mr. Blair convened a crisis meeting of the cabinet's Civil Contingencies Committee. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, ABRAHAM
description: ALPERT - Abraham. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the brother of its esteemed member, Mr. Jack Alpert, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: Giants' Big Cat Loves Mixing It Up in the Box
description: The play clock winds down, the quarterback is committed to a play and Giants safety Shaun Williams moves forward toward the line of scrimmage, like a big cat stalking.

title: The Doctor, The Patient, The Funeral
description: When my patient Martha died at the age of 93, she left behind a fascinating medical story of countless recoveries from the brink of death. I knew, of course, that her story was more than medical. I had been her doctor for nine years. But it was not until I attended Martha's funeral that I obtained a complete picture of her life.

title: Choice for the Rock's Team: A Safer Bet or a Bigger Score
description: The horse's name is Rock of Gibraltar, but not too many people in Europe, where he races, call him that anymore. It's just the Rock and that seems a more appropriate fit. It's a pithier description for a 3-year-old colt who has come through so often in so many big races that he may be the most talented thoroughbred in the world, not to mention the best horse among the 100 or so set to compete here Saturday in the Breeders' Cup.

title: Chastain Still Playing For the National Team
description: No one will ever accuse BRANDI CHASTAIN of losing interest.

title: For Hillary Clinton, A Dual Role as Star And as Subordinate
description: By all appearances, the rally and fund-raiser in the overcrowded hotel ballroom here the other night was for Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the Democratic candidate for governor. Yet Mrs. Townsend was not to be the star of her evening.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We've tried diplomacy. We're trying it one more time. I believe the free world, if we make up our mind to, can disarm this man peacefully.''

title: Prosecutors Given 6 Weeks To Sort Facts in Jogger Case
description: The Central Park jogger case is both 13 years old and brand new, prosecutors argued yesterday, and they said its evidence was stored in old boxes and walking around in other states.

title: Challenging Gun Makers to Bear Responsibility
description: ELISA BARNES is flipping through the pages of Gun Digest 2002 in her law office in the financial district. Inside the trade publication, there's this 9-millimeter handgun that a gun manufacturer told her -- with a straight face and in a taped deposition -- is intended to shoot turkeys, mainly. Right. She let him have it for that one.

title: Public College Tuitions Rise 10% Amid Financing Cuts
description: Battered by government budget cuts, public colleges and universities raised tuition almost 10 percent this year, with tuition at private institutions going up almost 6 percent, according to a survey released today by the College Board.

title: Concern to Restate Results
description: Global Crossing Ltd., the bankrupt fiber optic network operator, will restate results for the first nine months of 2001, cutting sales by $19 million after it stops recording revenue from network-use swaps.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Tunnel Vision; The Fare Dance, and Paying the Piper
description: The band is still playing very softly, but make no mistake: the familiar waltz that a transit official once affectionately called the ''dance of death'' is under way again.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY MERIDIAN MEDICAL
description: King Pharmaceuticals said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Meridian Medical Technologies for $247.8 million, adding the EpiPen injector for allergic shock and other devices that ease the administration of drugs. King offered $44.50 a share for Meridian, based in Columbia, Md. The price was 17 percent higher than Meridian's closing share price on Friday. King, which has built its business by buying drug lines from manufacturers and aggressively marketing them, said the purchase would add to profit as soon as the deal closed, excluding one-time transaction expenses. The acquisition is expected to be completed in January. King is based in Bristol, Tenn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HARE, DONALD
description: O'HARE-Donald. The Board of Trustees, Administration and Medical Staff of Flushing Hospital Medical Center express great sorrow on the passing of Donald O'Hare, esteemed member of the Flushing Hospital family and Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees. We extend our profound and heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Michael J. Russo, Chairman Board of Trustees David P. Rosen, Pres. & CEO Dr. Donald Palmadessa, President, Medical Board

title: Court Ruling On Legality Of Execution Is Challenged
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan asked a federal appeals court panel yesterday to reverse a judge's ruling that the death penalty is unconstitutional and ''tantamount to foreseeable, state-sponsored murder of innocent human beings.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTIN, AARON ISAAC
description: MALTIN-Aaron Isaac, 87. Died peacefully at home in Cliffside Park, NJ on Friday. Immigration judge for 30 years, in private practice for another three decades. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Services at Temple Emeth, Teaneck, NJ on Monday, October 21.

title: Continental in Accord With Machinists
description: Continental Airlines will give mechanics with 30 years or more of service $40,000 to retire by 2004 under the terms of a tentative contract reached with the workers' union.

title: In a Class of Their Own
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Designer Vehicles
A Dozen Radical Departures
description: Automakers attempts to offer vehicles in every conceivable niche of the market have taken many of them far from the products and brand images that made them successful.

title: The Indian Chief
Golisano, Battling Red Tape, Bites the Hand That Fed Him
description: As the Independence Party's nominee for governor of New York and the star of his own expensive advertising campaign, Tom Golisano has repeatedly condemned the tax and paperwork burdens that he says Albany imposes on small businesses.

title: Sharing the Organic Harvest
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Microsoft And Orange To Sell Organizer
description: Microsoft and Orange S.A., the mobile unit of France Tlcom, will begin selling a wireless phone Oct. 28 in Britain with the ability to store address books, music and calendars and view e-mail messages. The phone is the first using Microsoft's Smartphone software, which is based on the Windows operating system. Orange will charge 179 ($276) with a one-year wireless service contract for the S.P.V. phone, which stands for sound pictures video, said Ed Suwanjindar, a product manager for Microsoft. Microsoft, competing with the top cellphone maker Nokia, is trying to sell more software for running wireless phones as part of a campaign to increase sales by marketing versions of Windows for devices other than personal computers. Orange, which had 41.4 million customers in 20 countries as of June 30, is trying to increase revenue by selling new wireless data services.

title: Sports of The Times; Tony Bennett, Trolleys And a Series By the Bay
description: LET'S go to the World Series. There's not a better place than right here in downtown San Francisco. Let's get there early. It's the first World Series game here since 1989, plus the first Series game in the old-timey three-year-old ballpark right off the water.

title: The Healthier Side Of Health Care
description: Health costs are spiraling into another year of double-digit increases. Patients, employers and government health programs are feeling the financial pain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSEN, GUSTAV H.
description: PETERSEN-Gustav H. ''Peter'' died at home on October 19, 2002. His family, relatives and friends know that, ''in the variety of God's creations, Peter will be the wonder for us all.''

title: Bonds Has a Big Hit, Hernndez a Big Fall
description: Barry Bonds hit another home run tonight, lining a pitch from Ramon Ortiz over the center-field wall to add another distinction to his Hall of Fame rsum and continue his assault on the Angels in his first World Series.

title: 54% Who Lost Airline Jobs After 9/11 Are Still Jobless
description: Many airlines laid off a fifth of their workers after the Sept. 11 attacks, and a report released yesterday found that 54 percent of New York-area airline workers who lost their jobs remained unemployed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAHEEN, BARBARA TRACY
description: SHAHEEN-Barbara Tracy. Beloved husband of John. Mother of Michael and Bradford, sister to Elizabeth Tracy King and Eleanor Tracy Kuenning. Passed away October 23, 2001. Interment service 2:30 at Arlington National Cemetery, October 23, 2002.

title: New Clubs, Mixed Results For Giants Who Left Town
description: Ron Stone stretched on the south side of Giants Stadium before the season opener Sept. 5, across from players he once called teammates. They were dressed in blue, and he wore the white jersey of the San Francisco 49ers. Jim McNally, the Giants' offensive line coach, walked over and shook Stone's hand, clasping his left elbow warmly, wishing him well.

title: Pataki Rejects East River Tolls, Threatening City Budget and Mayoral Relations
description: Budgetary pressures are threatening to strain the political alliance between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, with the governor stating yesterday that he opposes the mayor's preliminary plan to put tolls on the city's East River bridges.

title: Recipe: Bluefish With Farfalle and Oven-Roasted Tomato Sauce
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Nets Suspend Childs For Being Out of Shape
description: Chris Childs was suspended without pay by the Nets today for being overweight and for failing to get into playing shape.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Vodka Conflict
description: A Russian vodka exporter, in a dispute with the Russian Agriculture Ministry over the rights to the Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya vodka brands, said it would fight a German court decision to ban new imports of its vodka on grounds that it is made in Latvia and not Russia. A spokesman for the Russian company, Soyuzplodimport, said he expected the court to uphold the company's right to sell its Moskovskaya vodka brand in Germany. He acknowledged, however, that the Russian vodka had been produced in Latvia since early this year, when the Russian ministry, which says the company acquired the rights to the brands illegally, blocked the company's shipments of vodka from Russia. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Climate Talks Will Shift Focus From Emissions
description: The latest round of international talks on global warming begins today in New Delhi, with delegates focused more on ways to adapt to changes than on cutting emissions of gases that scientists say are the main cause of rising temperatures.

title: Do Not Let Fear Rule Our Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Senator Loses Bid For New Primary
description: State Senator Pedro Espada Jr.'s bid for a new Democratic primary for re-election to the Senate was denied yesterday in court. The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled against Mr. Espada, who lost the Sept. 10 Democratic primary by 97 votes. But Mr. Espada is still on the ballot for the general election, on the Republican and Independence lines. He said he planned to campaign for the seat in the 32nd Senate District in the heavily Democratic South Bronx. Last week, the State Supreme Court ruled that City Councilman Ruben Diaz Sr. had won the Democratic primary. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: Canadian Bank's Invasion of U.S. Fizzles
description: The plan was nothing if not ambitious: to invade the United States retail banking market, not by buying banks or building traditional branches but by teaming up with supermarket chains and blanketing the country with automated teller machines.

title: Police Investigate Killings of Illegal Immigrants in Arizona Desert
description: The police are investigating whether armed vigilantes, self-appointed guardians of the border with Mexico, fatally shot at least two illegal immigrants in the desert last week.

title: Progress on Food Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: TAIWAN: CHIP COMPANY'S PROFIT MISSES The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company posted a profit that was half what analysts had forecast, sending chip stocks lower on concern that an industry recovery was faltering. Third-quarter net income almost tripled to 3.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($92 million) from 1.2 billion a year earlier, when chip makers were mired in their worst slump. A 2.9 billion tax expense accounted for most of the difference between the profit figure and analysts' average forecast of 6.2 billion. The tax expense arose as some of older factories lost tax exemptions. The charge raised its tax rate in the quarter to 18 percent, and the fourth quarter rate will be similar, it said. A year earlier, it had a tax credit of 1.4 billion Taiwan dollars. (Bloomberg News)

title: At CUNY, a Book of Poetry Meant for the Entire Campus
description: The idea of having all students read the same books is not new at colleges and universities. But a few years ago, cities and states began adopting it. Seattle, for example, invited residents to read Ernest J. Gaines's novel ''A Lesson Before Dying.'' Chicago picked Harper Lee's ''To Kill a Mockingbird.''

title: Corrections
description: The Tunnel Vision column on Oct. 14 about the way subway riders know if a train is approaching misstated the operation of the signal system. It detects a train's location when the wheels and axles cause a short circuit along a section of running rail -- not when a metal shoe on the train bridges a gap in the electrified third rail, completing a circuit.

title: Clean Up Your Act
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Bill On Gay Rights Is Set for Vote
description: The Republican-led New York State Senate will vote for the first time on landmark gay-rights legislation in December after having blocked its passage for decades, the Senate leader said today. The decision makes it likely that the bill will become law and hands Gov. George E. Pataki a vital victory two weeks from Election Day to help him win over gay and lesbian voters.

title: GENERAL MILLS TO SELL $1.35 BILLION IN DEBT
description: General Mills, the maker of Cheerios cereal and Yoplait yogurt, plans to sell about $1.35 billion of zero-coupon debt that matures in 20 years and may be converted into company shares. Money raised through the private sale will be used to repay existing commercial paper, or debt maturing in nine months or less, the company said. The company, based in Minneapolis, also plans to buy an option to purchase General Mills shares owned by Diageo. General Mills gave Diageo 134 million of its shares as part of its $10.4 billion acquisition of Diageo's Pillsbury operations last year. General Mills shares fell $2.60, or 5.9 percent, to $41.25.

title: A City Councilman Proposes A Narrower Ban on Smoking
description: One of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's staunchest allies on the City Council called yesterday for less sweeping antismoking legislation, a sign that the mayor's effort to ban smoking in all indoor public spaces faces stiff political resistance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANLER, WILLIAM A., JR.
description: CHANLER-William A., Jr., 98. Died October 12, 2002. Born in Great Neck, NY on September 24, 1904, he was the son of Congressman William A. Chanler and Beatrice (Ashley) Chanler. Surviving is his beloved wife, Innes J. Chanler of Camden; two sons, William A. Chanler 3rd, of Rowayton, CT; Bayard S. Chanler of Camden; two grandchildren. Memorial Service 12 noon, Saturday, November 9, 2002 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Barrytown, NY.

title: America's Colonial Empire? That Was No Accident
description: FIRST GREAT TRIUMPH

title: I Thought I Bought a Twitty Bird, but Now I'm Not So Sure
description: A PINK Thunderbird, especially the '57, with its sleek, sweeping lines culminating in the subtle fins that make this sweetheart of vintage American cars appear to be flying down the highway even when it's parked, was born to be driven by the gum-snapping bad girl of a 1950's teen flick. At least, that's what I always thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTON LAWRENCE, M.D.
description: ROSENTHAL-Morton Lawrence, M.D. Beloved husband of Bernardine, devoted father of Jeanne (Perry), Karen (Steve), and Benjamin (Susan), grandfather of Michael, Katy, Julie, Anne, and William, brother of J. Robert (Gladys) and the late Gerald (Gloria), brother-in-law of Marie and Richard, Lorraine and Al, and Dorothy and Donald, uncle, great uncle, friend. Physician, surgeon, teacher, musician, sailor, champion of the underdog. He was a man of endless curiosity, boundless intellect, passion, courage, humor and vision. A physician since 1952, he founded The Retina Service at The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary in 1958, the first of its kind in New York City, and was Chief of The Service until 1995. He also served at The Infirmary as Surgeon Director in The Department of Ophthalmology, Chairman of The Medical Board, Member of The Board of Directors, and teacher and mentor of countless residents and fellows. Memorial service Thursday, October 24, 2002, 2-4 P.M. at The Knickerbocker Yacht Club, 433 Main Street, Port Washington, NY, 516-883-7655. ''Two roads diverged in a wood, and I-I took the one less travelled by and that has made all the difference.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Australia's anger over the bombing of two Bali nightclubs that killed nearly 200 Australians misidentified the United States official who warned of a bombing threat to "soft targets" in Indonesia the day before the bombing. He was Ralph C. Boyce, the American ambassador in Jakarta; the same day, the American ambassador to Australia, J. Thomas Schieffer, warned that government of terrorist threats to energy installations.

title: Havel Denies Telephoning U.S. On Iraq Meeting
description: In the long-running controversy over accusations that Mohamed Atta, one of the Sept. 11 hijackers, met in Prague with an Iraqi spy, a spokesman for President Vaclav Havel today denied a report on Monday in The New York Times that Mr. Havel had telephoned senior administration officials to explain that the Czechs had no proof such a meeting had taken place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KETT, EILEEN
description: KETT-Eileen. On October 21. Native of Snugboro, Castlebar, County Mayo, Ireland. Beloved wife of the late Martin. Loving mother of Frances McKenna and Eileen Caulfield. Loving mother-inlaw of Richard V. McKenna and the late William Caulfield. Cherished grandmother of Richard McKenna, Susan McKenna, Kett McKenna, Thomas McKenna, Caroline Caulfield, Frances Caulfield Porraro and Christopher Caulfield. Loving grandmother-inlaw of Siobhan, Sheila, Kathy, Matthew and Dana, and great-grandmother of Richard, Caitlin, Kett, Troy, Meaghan, Caitlin, Sara and Mia. Devoted sister of the late John McGough, the late Miles McGough and the late Annie Kilcoyne. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday, October 23, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday, October 24, at 10 A.M., at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th Street.

title: Triple Crown of Academies
description: When SHELDON WEINBAUM a distinguished professor at the City University of New York, was named one of the 65 new members of the Institute of Medicine last week, he joined a handful of people who have been elected to all three of the national academies, in science, engineering and medicine. It was the first time in a decade that anyone had achieved membership in all three academies. The last people chosen for the triple honor were ROBERT LANGER of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and YUAN-CHENG FUNG of the University of California at San Diego in 1992, and ROBERT MANN of M.I.T. in 1982. Professor Weinbaum works in the departments of biomedical and mechanical engineering at City College. Karen W. Arenson

title: The Prisons of Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: MAN ADMITS ARSON-FOR-HIRE

title: Requiem for a Valley
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New WorldCom Losses Hint at a Disputed Future
description: Despite its troubles, WorldCom is still an immense company, generating about $80 million in revenue daily, according to data WorldCom released yesterday. It is also a deeply unprofitable company.

title: War Emblem Finishing Where His Saga Began
description: In the past six months, they have called the colt a Kentucky Derby thief, the Preakness champion, a potential Triple Crown winner and yet another Belmont Stakes bust. Over that same span, a Chicago steel executive sold him to a Saudi Arabian prince who died over the summer.

title: Your Mentor in Cyberspace Is Standing By Now
description: Rick Goldstein doesn't remember exactly what the sixth grade history project was about, but he remembers logging on to America Online's Ask a Teacher service for help completing it.

title: Confidence Erodes in Big Swiss Engineering Company
description: ABB, the house that Percy Barnevik built, is crumbling and investors, banks, analysts and ratings agencies no longer appear willing to support it.

title: Keep the Sidewalks Ad-Free
description: If you were out enjoying the city last weekend, you might have stumbled, quite literally, across a new low in advertising. Big corporations like Nike and ABC were promoting themselves by pasting large plastic posters, known as street decals, on the sidewalks. This renegade marketing is offensive and illegal, and Nike wisely decided yesterday to remove its decals.

title: Comparing 2 Sets Of Twin Towers; Malaysian Buildings Offered as Model
description: Over many months, reams of analysis have piled up -- a sometimes competing mix of calculation and deduction that suggests an array of answers to the questions of why and how the steel skeletons of the twin towers suddenly came apart in raging fires on Sept. 11. And with that increased understanding, the storms of emotion surrounding the grim, disturbing questions have quieted some.

title: Wider Support Is Sought For Disclosing Fund Votes
description: Three organizations yesterday urged investors to campaign for a new regulation that would require mutual fund companies to disclose how they voted on company issues. In doing so, they contended that the nation's major funds have too often sided in secret with corporate America when making proxy votes for their individual investor customers.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS DRUG IS APPROVED AS DIABETES TREATMENT
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb has received Food and Drug Administration approval for its Metaglip drug for diabetes. The F.D.A. approval is for use of Metaglip, along with diet and exercise, as initial drug therapy for people with Type 2 diabetes that cannot be satisfactorily managed with diet and exercise alone, the company said. Metaglip was also approved as second-line therapy for patients with Type 2 diabetes who are now taking either metformin or a sulfonylurea with a regimen of diet and exercise, but whose blood sugar levels are inadequately controlled. The company said Metaglip combined glipizide and metformin HCl -- two widely prescribed oral antidiabetic agents -- in a single pill.

title: Schools, Transportation, Air Quality Are Issues in Debate
description: In their third debate, Gov. John G. Rowland and his Democratic challenger, William E. Curry Jr., sparred tonight over many of the same issues raised in their first two meetings: education, transportation, the environment and the possibility of a third Indian casino in Connecticut.

title: Knicks Say They'll Get Over Their Dispute With Sprewell
description: There was no sequel to the comedic spectacle that surrounded the Knicks on Monday. Instead, Scott Layden, refusing to contribute to what he called ''a New York moment,'' said that all would soon be well between the team and its star player, Latrell Sprewell.

title: McCall and Golisano Attack Pataki on Use of Rikers Island Chief in Campaign Work
description: Tom Golisano and H. Carl McCall ganged up on Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday over allegations that New York City government employees had been coerced to work on the Pataki campaign. Mr. Golisano called for a federal investigation, and Mr. McCall insisted that Mr. Pataki take responsibility for the actions of those who work for him.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a fraud complaint filed by Massachusetts against Credit Suisse First Boston misspelled the name of the secretary of the commonwealth in some copies. He is William F. Galvin, not Galwin.

title: COSTS FROM LAWSUITS HURT INCOME AT OXFORD HEALTH
description: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York area's biggest health insurers, said third-quarter net income fell on costs from class-action lawsuits that were filed after company shares plunged in 1997. Oxford said it expected net income of about 26 cents a share, compared with 85 cents in the period last year. Oxford will post complete third-quarter results on Oct. 29, which will include a pretax charge of $151.3 million, or 98 cents a share, related to the lawsuits. Excluding the legal costs, Oxford, based in Trumbull, Conn., would have had a profit of $1.24 a share in the most recent quarter, the company said.

title: Chechnya's Wine Industry Clings to Remaining Roots
description: Chechnya is no Tuscany and no Rhone Valley, and it never was. But there was a time not long ago when it produced wines drunk by the Soviet elite and peasants alike.

title: Carolina Makes Islanders' Heads Spin
description: Tonight was Chris Osgood bobblehead doll night at Nassau Coliseum. But the bobbleheads did not arrive, and Osgood did not play because he had been, well, bobbling pucks.

title: How to Hook the Best Deal When Lures Are Everywhere
description: SHUFFLE through a mass of car advertising or drive to your local strip of auto showrooms and the pitches glare at you: ''0% APR Financing,'' ''$0 Down Payment,'' ''Rebates up to $5,700.''

title: Cooking as an Inexact Science
description: WRITE a book that calls traditional recipes, with their exacting quarter-teaspoons of cumin, a waste of time and you tread on dangerous ground. You may be on the money, but how do you persuade home cooks to go from being measurement-obsessed to playing without a score?

title: A Succession At Anti-Drug Group
description: James E. Burke will soon step down after 13 years as chairman of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America in New York, the nonprofit organization that oversees the antidrug campaigns for Madison Avenue. His successor, effective on Dec. 1, will be a longtime agency executive, Roy J. Bostock.

title: Peter G. Bergmann, 87; Worked With Einstein
description: Dr. Peter G. Bergmann, a physicist who worked with Albert Einstein and played a leading role in the advancement of Einstein's theories in the years after World War II, died on Saturday in Seattle. He was 87.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Snits From Eloise

title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Queens; Shops Set Where Industries Were Once at Home
description: The owners of the Atlas Terminals industrial park in the Glendale section of Queens plan to turn half of it into a retail and office complex. The move is partly a reflection of the long-term shift of manufacturing and distribution operations out of New York City and partly a calculation that nearby residents want more convenient shopping.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: KIDNAPPING VICTIMS MAY STAY LONGER Five Japanese who returned home last week for the first time since being abducted by North Korean spies more than two decades ago may stay longer than the two weeks originally planned if they wish, Japanese officials said. North Korea says the five are the only survivors in a group of at least 13 abductees.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Holmdel: Scalping-Law Violation Alleged
description: A company leasing a popular concert hall has been accused of violating New Jersey's antiscalping law by setting aside as many as half of all tickets for a concert for holders of American Express cards. State law allows up to 5 percent of available tickets to be set aside for a particular group before sale to the public. On Monday, the state attorney general and the state's Division of Consumer Affairs sued Clear Channel Entertainment, which leases PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel. They accused the company of at times selling more than 50 percent of the center's 17,500 seats to American Express cardholders. American Express is not a defendant in the suit. Clear Channel released a statement saying that the company was surprised by the lawsuit. ''We remain committed to complying with New Jersey state law,'' it said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Shares In 2 Video Game Companies Fall
description: Share prices of two video game companies dropped markedly yesterday, as industry analysts have begun to wonder whether video game sales will be as robust this holiday season as originally expected. Shares in Eidos P.L.C., based in Britain, fell about 15 percent, to 84 pence, after the company said it would delay the release of ''Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness'' until February. The company said it needed more time to test the game. Shares in THQ Inc. lost 39 percent after the company said Monday that its 2002 profits would be at the low end of earlier projections, and its 2003 earnings would be far below analyst consensus estimates. The company blamed poor global economic conditions, and the lower-than-expected sales of the Nintendo GameCube and Microsoft Xbox. The news came as the industry prepared for the crucial holiday sales season. But not all video game makers were expressing concern. Take-Two Interactive Software Inc., based in New York, said yesterday that it had received more orders for the new version of ''Grand Theft Auto,'' than it did for the first version of the game, one of the most popular games ever. The new version, ''Grand Theft Auto: Vice City,'' is scheduled to reach stores next Tuesday. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: A Stake in Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: An S.E.C. Charge May Force Martha Stewart's Hand

title: No Retaliation From Israel After Bombing
description: Israel did not retaliate today for the bombing of a bus that killed 14 passengers on Monday in what officials said was a nod to American concerns that rising violence here could disrupt plans for possible military action against Iraq.

title: Big Turnaround at Nissan Leads to Record Profits
description: Thanks to strong sales of Altima and Infiniti cars and progress in cutting costs, Nissan Motor will announce record profits today for the six months ended Sept. 30. The automaker will also raise its profit forecast for the year and consider paying shareholders a dividend for the first time in four years, the company said.

title: Friend of Hijacker Admits to Training in Afghanistan
description: On the opening day of the first trial in Europe related to the Sept. 11 attacks, a man accused by German prosecutors of being a member of Mohamed Atta's terrorist cell reversed his earlier claims and admitted that he had attended a training camp sponsored by Osama bin Laden.

title: A Buccaneer and His Love Meeting the Challenge of High C's
description: It's a measure of the soprano Rene Fleming's clout at the Metropolitan Opera that when she asked the company to mount a production of ''Il Pirata,'' a Bellini rarity, especially for her, she got her wish. In these financially pinched times, the Met might have considered this work, which had never been presented there, an audience risk. But the Met is counting on Ms. Fleming's fans to follow her into any repertory venture.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I pulled my daughter out of school. I'm not going to work. This is ridiculous.''

title: Where Danish Means Lunch
description: LEAVE it to the Danes, those past masters of form and color, to turn sandwiches into still lifes.

title: To Have and to Hold, Till Driven Apart
description: I HAVE a thing about turn signals. I think, for example, that when drivers decide to take a parking space, they ought to claim it by using the turn signal.

title: The Second Time Around Turns Out to Be Harder
description: I WAS trying to ride a tight figure 8 when I noticed that the motorcycle wasn't going where I wanted it to. I tried to remember all the instructions. Countersteer, I thought. No, use counterweighting. No, use the friction zone on the clutch. Look where you want to go. Not at the ground! Up! Up! Gas! Clutch!

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Leadership Shuffle Starts
description: The Communist Party leaders of Beijing and Shanghai stepped down. The leadership change was the first of many expected over the next two weeks as China prepares for the start of the Communist Party Congress on Nov. 8. Both men, Jia Qinglin in Beijing and Huang Ju in Shanghai, are expected to move to posts in the central government. Elisabeth Rosenthal (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOODMAN, MILT
description: GOODMAN - Milt. Beloved husband and father. Forever in our hearts and thoughts. Estelle, Bob and Helen

title: Under the Arab Street
description: At a seminar here this week on relations between America and Islam, one of the questions discussed by American and Muslim scholars was that elusive issue: Where is the Arab street and how might it respond to a U.S. invasion of Iraq? For my money, the most helpful answer was provided by the Jordanian columnist Rami Khouri, who said that ''what's really important today is not the Arab street, but the Arab basement.''

title: BUS DRIVER KILLED; CHILDREN NOT SAFE, SNIPER'S NOTE SAYS
description: A bus driver quietly pausing before his morning rounds was shot to death near here today, leaving alarmed residents and the police fearing that the man was the 10th fatality attributable to the roving suburban sniper.

title: A Mideast Buffer
description: To the Editor:

title: The Illusory Prague Connection
description: Most Americans -- two-thirds, according to a Pew Research poll this month -- believe that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq had a hand in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Trouble is, no hard evidence of such a link has been made public. In its campaign for military action against Iraq, the Bush administration frequently asserts that it has proof of extensive ties between Iraq and Al Qaeda. What it has disclosed, however, is unconvincing. This is no way to justify a war -- either the potential one against Iraq or the existing one against Islamic extremists.

title: Bonds Has a Big Hit, Hernndez a Big Fall
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 — Barry Bonds hit another home run tonight, lining a pitch from Ramon Ortiz over the center-field wall to add another distinction to his Hall of Fame résumé and continue his assault on the Angels in his first World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, CHARLES
description: LOEB-Charles. Died peacefully at his home on Monday afternoon, October 21. He was born in NYC but lived from 1943 to 1988 in Bradley Beach, NJ, before returning to his birthplace. He was chairman of the Awards Committee and a civilian procurement officer for the Research and Development Laboratories at the U.S. Signal Corps in Fort Monmouth, NJ for 20 years. Survivors include his loving wife Janet, his brother-in-law Lawrence White and his wife Clarice, sister-in-law Sylvia Eisenberg of San Francisco, a sister-inlaw Miriam Levine of Boynton Beach, FL., and many nieces & nephews. Asbury Park Press please note.

title: U.S. Aide Touring Europe to Cut Qaeda Finances
description: In response to the recent worldwide increase in attacks linked to Al Qaeda, a senior Bush administration official is pressing European financial regulators and bankers to make a more determined effort to shut down the group's financial network.

title: Layoffs at First Boston
description: Credit Suisse First Boston laid off its chief market strategist, Tom Galvin, and dozens of analysts in equity research as part of cutbacks announced two weeks ago, people close to the situation said.

title: A Couple of Detroit Doyens Go From Gas to Electric
description: BOB STEMPEL and Lee Iacocca, former leaders of American carmakers, spent their years in the corner office overseeing the consumption of billions of gallons of gasoline. Now, in active retirements, they have taken different turns, running small companies in the electric car market.

title: Angels' Sore Loser Has No Complaint
description: Darin Erstad was the habitual sore loser, the chronic crybaby, the demanding kid who scooped up his baseball, his hockey puck or his football on frigid days in Fargo, N.D., and went home. When Erstad's team was losing, when there was no hope he could change the outcome of whatever he was playing, he would invariably leave.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column on Friday about a party given by InStyle magazine misidentified the executive who predicted that it would sell more advertising pages than Vogue this year. She was Stephanie George, the president of InStyle, not Charla Lawhon, the managing editor.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: TRENTON: MAN ADMITS ARSON-FOR-HIRE

title: Mercedes's Man in Detroit Wants to Give Chrysler Some Import Magic
description: DURING his first month as Chrysler's chief executive, with the auto company drowning in debt, Dieter Zetsche, newly arrived here from Germany, went to a Costco in search of batteries.

title: Latin Death Squads and the U.S.: A New Disclosure
description: The day before Chilean agents assassinated Orlando Letelier, Chile's former foreign minister, with a car bomb here in 1976, a senior State Department official canceled an order that United States ambassadors approach South American dictators about ending their use of death squads abroad, according to United States government documents.

title: Armed Men Take Moscow Theater Audience Hostage
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23  Proclaiming themselves guerrillas from Russia's separatist province of Chechnya, at least 20 people clad in camouflage and firing automatic rifles seized a crowded theater in central Moscow tonight, taking several hundred hostages in what appeared to be a carefully planned operation.

title: Slain Driver Is Praised As Neighbor And Parent
description: Outside his tidy row house in a development of new homes here, Conrad Everton Johnson was known as the only father who would come outside and play football or basketball with his children and their friends from the neighborhood.

title: Ex-Roommate of 9/11 Defendant Is Sentenced for Lying to Agents
description: A federal judge sentenced a former roommate of Zacarias Moussaoui yesterday to the time he has already served for lying to federal agents last year when he was questioned about Mr. Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with conspiring in the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: With Pedal to the Metal And Stogie in His Pocket, Bob Lutz Is Back at G.M.
description: A FEW rules to keep in mind when interviewing Robert A. Lutz, the vice chairman of General Motors.

title: A Vinegar Substitute, With Half the Pucker
description: Verjuice is traditionally pressed from unripe white grapes, yielding a tart, pale gold juice to use in sauces and as a less acidic substitute for vinegar in salads. Roman Roth, the winemaker at Wlffer Estate in Sagaponack, N.Y., decided to make its ''verjus'' using unripe red grapes. The result, with the faintest blush, offers a sweet-sour balance of alluring delicacy. Try the verjuice for briefly poaching flounder fillets, then garnishing the fish with pink grapefruit segments. Cook down the pan juices, add a little butter and you have a lovely sauce. Wlffer verjus is $9.99 at the winery for a 750-milliliter bottle and $4.99 for half that size. The larger size is $14 at Dean & DeLuca in New York.

title: In Wake of New Threat, Schools Stay Open, While Parents Remain Jittery
description: Four murderous weeks ago, the nine chilling words a sniper left at a shooting scene might have had the same power here as they did in Virginia, consuming the police and closing schools in a collective wave of terror: ''Your children are not safe anywhere, at any time.''

title: Richard M. Helms Dies at 89; Dashing Ex-Chief of the C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON Oct. 23 — Richard Helms, a former director of central intelligence who defiantly guarded some of the darkest secrets of the cold war, died today of multiple myeloma. He was 89.

title: Tiny Poppy Seeds, Ground Tinier for Big Flavor
description: SOMETHING of a dark Gypsy exoticism surrounds blue poppy seeds, whose richness brings savory depth to confections. Their flavor flirts at the edges of animal, vegetable and mineral without making a firm commitment to any of them. Ultimately, it is as a finely granular, dusky backdrop that poppy seeds make their point best, a point well articulated in the presence of lemon or orange peel, the smoke of sweet spices or the fragrant notes of honey or orange flower water.

title: The Jets' Defense Lets Its Play Do the Talking
description: Perhaps the best news from the Jets' victory last Sunday was that Ted Cottrell, their defensive coordinator, saw none of the body language that expressed his players' on-field exasperation in the previous five games, when shoulders sagged and heads shook with each long run by opponents and every missed tackle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSON, REV. PAUL T.
description: MATSON-Rev. Paul T. Bethlehem Lutheran Church announces his passing. Wake, October 25, 4-7 PM, Snooky's Restaurant, 140 7th Ave, Brooklyn. Service October 27, 4 PM at the church, 490 Pacific St, Brooklyn.

title: Movie Stars as Racecar Drivers: What's Their Motivation?
description: IF Jason Priestley did not know it before, he discovered one crucial difference between real-life auto racing and Hollywood's depiction of it when he crashed at the Kentucky Speedway in Sparta on Aug. 11, breaking his feet and back. In the real version, there are no stunt doubles.

title: U.S. SEES THREAT TO TERROR TRIAL
description: The Justice Department is worried that the prosecution of Zacarias Moussaoui and other terrorism defendants could be derailed by the recent capture of key operatives of Al Qaeda whose testimony is potentially valuable to Mr. Moussaoui's defense, federal law enforcement officials say.

title: Giuliani in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Disbelief and Desperation in the Sniper Zone
description: It was at 10:30 this morning that Shirlita Baker's down mood found a new depth.

title: Silk Stocking Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, HAROLD F.
description: LEVIN-Harold F. Age 99, on October 19, 2002, of Florida & New York. A distinguished lawyer and member of the NY bar for 76 years, his professional career was marked by dedication to his clients. One of the oldest living graduates of Columbia's Business School, 1923, and Law School, 1926, he was active in the Stoneagers Alumni Club. Founding partner of the NYC law firms of Delson, Levin & Gordon and later of Levin & Weissman. At the forefront of labor law, particularly in the construction trades, he played an instrumental role in the establishment of benefit plans for unionized workers. He was a consummate advocate, in and out of the courtroom. A sought-after public speaker at conferences, he wrote numerous articles. His colleagues remember his integrity, intellect and sense of humor. He was a friend and mentor to many. Much loved father of Roger M. Levin & Susan E.L. Wiland, grandfather to Jessica, Emily & Chloe, father-in-law to Sally F. King and Keith A. Schepart, husband of the late Blanche M. Levin for 51 years, and loving companion of Norma Benrubi. Admired and loved by many, he will long be remembered by all who knew him. There will be a private interment. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, October 23, 2002 from 3-8 PM at the Levin residence, 15 East 90th St., NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSKIN, SAMUEL, DDS,
description: GRUSKIN-Samuel, DDS, 93. On October 20, 2002, born April 24, 1909 in Brooklyn, NY. He surpasses his wife Dorothy Lieberman of 67 years. He graduated from NYU and 1st in his class at Columbia School of Dentistry. He practiced for fifty years. He is survived by his son Dr. Philip Gruskin and wife Antoinette, his daughter Regina Appelbaum and husband Lewis, and his devoted grandchildren, Steven Appelbaum and Susan, Neal Appelbaum and Garth, Phyllis Sienkiewicz and David. Funeral services will be held 1:30 PM, Tuesday, October 22nd from the Neill Funeral Home, Camp Hill. Interment will follow Wednesday in Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Home, 4000 Linglestown Road, Harrisburg, PA 17112. For information Reese Funeral Home, Harrisburg. www.reesefh.com

title: Travels With Homer: Next Time I'll Bring an Extension Cord
description: IT started with the car, a 1957 Morris Minor four-seat convertible with a downcast ovoid grille and headlights perched on top of the fenders that gave it a sad-funny face like the clown Emmett Kelly Sr. Perhaps it was the Minor's cute demeanor that 15 years or so ago persuaded a restaurateur in Charlotte, N.C., that it would make a good salad bar.

title: San Francisco's Baker Can't Find Any Relief
description: The most pathetic sight of Game 3 of the World Series might have been the scene on the mound at Pacific Bell Park in the fourth inning last night.

title: Study Is Unsure on Tainted Polio Vaccine's Cancer Role
description: The polio vaccine used in the United States from 1955 to 1963 has long been known to have been contaminated with a cancer-causing monkey virus, but even after years of study it is not clear whether the vaccine is linked to any cancers in people, scientists reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, ELLEN WHEELER
description: HOFFMAN-Ellen Wheeler. Ellen was deeply loved by her family and we miss her terribly. She enriched our lives but left us too soon. There is a hole in our hearts.

title: Three Officers Faked Reports, Police Say
description: The accident report was crowded with details: the driver had been looking for an address when he hit the brakes for a stop sign on 12th Street in Brooklyn, skidded on salt and sand left behind by a snowplow and slammed into a parked Acura.

title: Hunt for Sniper Shifts to Search of House in the West
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 23 - The manhunt for the roving suburban sniper suddenly shifted its focus westward across the country tonight as federal investigators searched at a home in Tacoma, Wash., for evidence that might be linked to the shootings here on the East Coast.

title: From Vertical to Horizontal
description: We have the worst governor's race in the country going on here, between the loony and the smarmy.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: 2 Replace Ousted Leader
description: Democrats in the State Senate ousted the majority leader, Charles J. Chvala, less than a week after he was charged with three counts of extortion. Unable to choose between two candidates to replace him, the Democrats elected both, Senators Fred A. Risser of Madison and Russell S. Decker of Schofield, who will lead the caucus until Nov. 7. Mr. Chvala, who has denied the charges against him, voted for his own removal. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Is This the Famous Original Grand Sichuan?
description: NEW YORK abounds in restaurant mysteries. Some, like the original Ray's pizza mess or the Fresco Tortilla tangle, defy unraveling. Others are mere annoyances, like why restaurants insist on using the infantile ''crispy,'' when a simple ''crisp'' will do. But here was an incipient riddle that still might be answered: Where are all the Grand Sichuan restaurants coming from, and are they connected?

title: A Jail Date Awaits Grubman Today in Hamptons Crash
description: She has quit smoking, brushed up on her kick-boxing and traded in her Seven jeans for sweatsuits and sneakers.

title: As Pickup Scenes Go, It Doesn't Get Much Wilder Than This
description: COVER your ears, here come the trucks. The ground throbs and the grandstands shudder at the Richmond International Raceway here, as three-dozen snub-nosed pickups scream around the three-quarter-mile track. Centrifugal force pushes them high against the oval's banked pavement until they explode past --kaPANG-kaPANG-kaPANG-kaPANG! -- blurring into a phantasmagoric, multicolored ribbon of steel, fiberglass and vulcanized rubber. In this ear-splitting instant, it is impossible to think. The crowd reacts as if an electrical current has run through it, fusing the spectators into one helpless mass of humanity.

title: Briefed Further on North Korea, the Russians, Openly Skeptical Before, Are Silent
description: Under Secretary of State John R. Bolton briefed Russian officials for a second day today on American intelligence evidence that North Korea has an active nuclear weapons program. Russian officials, who indicated on Monday that the initial evidence fell short of proof, were silent after today's presentation.

title: TV Program Raises New Assertions of Abuse by Priests in Ireland
description: Fresh assertions about priests sexually abusing children are again infuriating people in this strongly Catholic country.

title: Salmon's 2001 Makes It All That Much Better
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22  When the Anaheim Angels clinched the American League pennant last week, Orlando Palmeiro knew just where to look. Palmeiro, a reserve outfielder for the Angels since 1995, paused during his own celebrating to study right fielder Tim Salmon.

title: Some Guantnamo Prisoners Will Be Freed, Rumsfeld Says
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that a small number of the nearly 600 prisoners being held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, would be released to their home countries because they were no longer of interest to the United States.

title: Regulators to Meet With Wall Street Firms
description: State and federal regulators will meet with 10 of the largest securities firms on Thursday to propose limits on contact between analysts and bankers as one part of a settlement of conflict-of-interest investigations, Wall Street executives and regulators said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMIDT, LLOYD
description: SCHMIDT-Lloyd, 65, of East Brunswick, NJ formerly of Brooklyn on October 21, 2002. Extremely devoted husband of the late Barbara. Extremely devoted father and fatherin-law of Terrie and David George. Predeceased by his parents and sister. Service 12 Noon Thursday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Road at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick. Entombment Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge. Memorial gifts to the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERTHEIMER, LOTHAR, M.D.
description: WERTHEIMER - Lothar, M.D. Physician and friend, he taught and practiced his profession with dedication and respect for each and every human being in New York City's municipal hospitals and private practice for half a century. Survived by his loving wife, Antonia, and by Ellen, Robert, Michelle, Eddie, Lisa, Elliot, Christopher and Serena, to all of whom he was deeply devoted and who now mourn his passing. Admired and loved by many, he will long be remembered by all who knew him. Services Thursday, 11AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. N.Y. Donations may be made to the Simon Weisenthal Center, 1399 South Roxbury, Los Angeles, CA. 90035

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Proudly Claiming Tax Debt
description: The Libertarian candidate for governor, Barry Hess, says he is not ashamed of the $47,000 debt in back taxes to the Internal Revenue Service. Mr. Hess, who has spent only about $2,500 on his campaign, has been fighting the I.R.S. for 10 years and says the income tax is unconstitutional theft. Mr. Hess, 45, who is the co-owner of a water treatment plant and sells granite tablets of the Ten Commandments on the Internet, said he planned to file suit against the I.R.S. after the November election. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Are Red-Light Cameras Aimed at Safety or Fines?
description: CAMERAS meant to catch drivers who run red lights were installed at intersections around the United States in the 1990's, part of an effort to reduce the thousands of accidents they cause.

title: AOL Said to Be Extending Its Inquiry on Revenue Data
description: Three months ago, AOL Time Warner started an internal investigation into $49 million in questionable revenue at its AOL division, saying it hoped to resolve the matter by the end of the quarter.

title: Violetta, the Germonts and Castanets
description: There are pleasures to be had from the principals in the revival of City Opera's ''Traviata'' that opened on Friday night. As Violetta, Pamela Armstrong -- quite a house favorite by now -- has a liquid quality in her voice that she uses expressively and musically. Legato, for her, is not just a matter of moving smoothly through pitch intervals; one vowel sound melts into the next, one color into another, and the result is a line that is supple, rich in sound and full of emotional appeal.

title: Tokyo Journal; To Grandparents, English Word Trend Isn't 'Naisu'
description: When Ayako Komata, 18, talks fashion with her friends, she throws around terms like ''hippu hangu,'' or hip-hugging, jeans and ''shadoh'' (eye shadow), and ponders their effect on ''chou naisu gai'' (very nice-looking guys).

title: For Prospective Tenants, Cash Is King
description: The mixers and steamrollers draw closer every day, rumbling through the tilled and unseeded soil of fallow cotton and onion fields in a rough parallel to the long-abandoned Preston Ridge cattle trail, ladling out the fresh hot asphalt of the Dallas North Tollway, a growth serum for office parks and shopping malls.

title: U.S. Labels Islamic Group as Terrorist Organization
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 23  A Southeast Asian radical Islamic group suspected by the Bush administration of involvement in the Bali bombing was formally declared a foreign terrorist organization by the United States today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Tightening The Border
description: Interior Minister Giuseppe Pisanu said the country planned to reimpose border controls briefly on its European neighbors because of concerns that violent groups and individuals could infiltrate an antiglobalization meeting next month in Florence. Mr. Pisanu told Parliament that the government would suspend the free flow of European Union citizens called for by a 1990 agreement because it provided for such a move when public order is at stake. Italy took the same step before a July 2001 meeting of world leaders in Genoa, which was nonetheless marred by riots. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: My Car Sounds Better Than Yours
description: SOME car owners can spend hours getting their fingers dirty under the hood. Robert Bean is more likely to be in the trunk, tweaking the PC that powers the custom-designed MP3 audio system in his 1996 Mitsubishi Eclipse. Mr. Bean, a junior at Texas A&M University, has a giant control screen built into his dashboard and enough music on the computer's hard drive for nine days of nonstop driving.

title: Student Stabbed Schoolmate in Queens Hallway, Police Say
description: An 18-year-old senior at Springfield Gardens High School in Queens was stabbed in the chest between classes yesterday in what the police said was a dispute with a fellow student over missing money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, DONALD JORDAN
description: DONAHUE-Donald Jordan. October 22nd, 2002. He is survived by his five children, Macy, Judy, Don, Tom and Nick of his late wife, Mary Meyer Donahue, six grandchildren, wife Carol, brother Jack and sister Mary. Passed away peacefully of complications from Parkinson's disease. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 6-8 PM and Thursday 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, October 25th, 11 AM at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Donald J. Donahue to either Parkinson's Disease Foundation Inc., 710 W. 168 Street, New York, NY 10032 or the family's scholarship at Georgetown University, Attn: Mary Prahinski, Office of Alumni and University Relations, P.O. Box 571253, Washington, D.C. 20057.

title: The Perfect Knife Sharpener For Freddy Krueger's Kitchen
description: No, this isn't a torture device from the horror film ''Nightmare on Elm Street.'' It is Diamond Fingers, a highly effective knife sharpener. Swipe a knife a few times through the springy interlaced metal strips coated with diamond dust and its edge will be restored. It takes just a little pressure to draw the knife from shank to point through the six sharpening strips. Never use a back-and-forth motion. The sharpener holds the knife at the correct angle. Made in Australia by Fritechnics, the instrument has a wire guard to partly shield the hand that holds the device steady. It is $79.95 at Broadway Panhandler, 477 Broome Street (Wooster Street).

title: Sniper Plays a Contrary Game of 'Catch Me if You Can'
description: With law enforcement and the news media as his foils, the roving sniper is playing, and so far winning, a contrary and coldblooded game of cat and mouse in the suburbs and exurbs of Washington.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Kidnapping Victims May Stay Longer
description: Five Japanese who returned home last week for the first time since being abducted by North Korean spies more than two decades ago may stay longer than the two weeks originally planned if they wish, Japanese officials said. North Korea says the five are the only survivors in a group of at least 13 abductees. Howard W. French (NYT)

title: S.E.C. Move Could Mean A Resignation By Stewart
description: Martha Stewart could be forced to step down from the company that bears her name, securities lawyers say, if the Securities and Exchange Commission brings a complaint against her in the coming weeks.

title: A Good Excuse to Taste Some Great Wines
description: IF you've got anything to do with the wine business, chances are you're spending a lot of time this week at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. Vinexpo Americas, a domestic version of a big trade show held every other year in Bordeaux, has lured more than 600 exhibitors and 10,000 wine and spirits professionals here to meet and do business.

title: In Opening the Gates of Its Gulag, Iraq Unleashes Pain and Protest
description: President Saddam Hussein's decision on Sunday to open the gates of his prisons and let tens of thousands of political prisoners and common criminals go free has afforded ordinary Iraqis a rare glimpse into the gulag that has maintained his power for 23 years, and prompted small but remarkable protests by some who lost relatives into the grim embrace of the state security police years ago.

title: Christian Values Meet Athletic Scandal
description: Red brick buildings, neatly trimmed lawns and river birch trees dot the campus of Gardner-Webb University in the heart of this small, Bible Belt town. Gardner-Webb was founded as a Baptist college and is known historically for producing teachers and preachers. Alcohol is banned, the student honor code is posted in every classroom and no building eclipses the steeple of Dover Chapel.

title: Columbia Theater in Church
description: ANDREI SERBAN, director of theater studies at Columbia University, joined with students to cut the ribbon last week on a new theater for his program: the 180-seat theater at nearby Riverside Church. Columbia has struck a deal with the church that will allow it to use the theater for five years. Last month Columbia announced that it would use the Apollo Theater in Harlem -- also close to the university -- to present the Royal Shakespeare Company in a stage production of Salman Rushdie's novel ''Midnight's Children'' in March. Columbia's inaugural production at Riverside will be an adaptation of ''Peer Gynt'' by BATHSHEBA DORAN, a Columbia student, next month directed by Mr. Serban and with a musical score by ELIZABETH SWADOS.

title: Land of Giants Invaded by Little Guys
description: THROUGH the 1990's, the market for sport utility vehicles grew and grew, and in more ways than one. Both the number of S.U.V.'s sold and the size of S.U.V.'s available climbed steadily, causing what sometimes seemed like an arms race on the highways and in parking lots.

title: Warren Fenzi, 87, Phelps Dodge President
description: Warren E. Fenzi, a former president of the mining and manufacturing company Phelps Dodge, died on Sunday at his home in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARATOFF, CATHERINE (NEE ILOVAISKY)
description: BARATOFF-Catherine (nee Ilovaisky), 95. Of Sea Cliff, LI, NY, October 20, 2002. Daughter of the late Gen. M. Ilovaisky, and wife of the late Nicholas, son of the late Gen. N.N. Baratoff. She is also survived by her children, Nicholas, Jr., Catherine Hills and Michael, grandchildren Elizabeth W. Todd, Nicholas IV, Phillip K. Hills III, Peter K. Hills, and Michael C. Great grandchildren, Wyatt W. Todd, Graceley J. Todd, and Mary P. Hills. Funeral services Thursday 7 P.M. at Church of Our Lady of Kazan, Sea Cliff, NY. Interment Friday 10:30 A.M. Roslyn Cemetery, Roslyn, NY.

title: Apartments Tested Downtown Are Ruled Free of Asbestos
