description: The vast majority of the apartments in Lower Manhattan that have been cleaned and tested over the last few months had no asbestos contamination from World Trade Center dust, federal Environmental Protection Agency officials said yesterday in releasing the first results from the cleanup program.

title: Rose to Make A Rare Visit
description: Pete Rose, barred from Major League Baseball 13 years ago for misconduct related to gambling, will make a rare ballpark appearance Wednesday night at Game 4 of the World Series. He will be at Pacific Bell Park in connection with a promotion through which his record-breaking 4,192nd career hit was selected by fans as one of the top 10 moments in baseball history.

title: Letters
description: Sharing the Organic Harvest

title: Footlights
description: Wagner Arranges Beethoven

title: Scary Halloween Treats? Just Nibble Their Heads Off
description: Let the children have their Tootsie Rolls and mini-Milky Ways. Grown-ups deserve the Danse Macabre chorus line of ghostly chocolate truffles, below right, made by Larry Burdick in Walpole, N.H. Each of the walnut-size candies is filled with creamy hazelnut-chocolate ganache providing no more than two quick but satisfying bites. They're sold in boxes of 10 for $30 at Mr. Burdick's shops in Walpole and Cambridge, Mass. They can be ordered from (800) 229-2419. Shipping is extra. They can also be ordered from www.burdickchocolate.com.

title: Trump Draws Criticism for Ad He Ran After Jogger Attack
description: On May 1, 1989, Donald J. Trump took out full-page advertisements in four New York newspapers calling for the return of the death penalty. Mr. Trump said he wanted the ''criminals of every age'' who were accused of beating and raping a jogger in Central Park 12 days earlier ''to be afraid.''

title: Peeling Apart Layers of Reality To Deconstruct a Philosopher
description: ''Derrida,'' the adoring and adorable documentary on the philosopher Jacques Derrida by the filmmakers Kirby Dick (''Sick: The Life and Death of Bob Flanagan, Supermasochist'') and Amy Ziering Kofman, presents Mr. Derrida, the so-called father of deconstruction, as quick-witted and impish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, HANNA
description: STARK-Hanna. The Frisch school family is deeply saddened by the passing of Mrs. Hanna Stark, mother of our board member Norman Stark, mother-in-law of Helene & grandmother of Frisch graduates Yehudah, Dov and Avi. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to them & the entire Stark family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mr. Arthur Goldberg, Pres. Dr. Kalman Stein, Principal Elaine R. Weitzman, Exec. Dir.

title: Tip No. 1(a): All Traffic Keep Away!
description: THE first sign was on a road trip to my college reunion. My old roommate refused to let me do any of the driving -- something about her having three young children. The second sign was when my father, newly released from the hospital after a stroke, said he would feel better if he drove. The third sign was when I agreed.

title: It's Not How Many Horses, It's Torque That Counts
description: THE word ''horsepower'' is frequently a big selling point for ordinary car buyers. It's also frequently misunderstood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, EDNA B.
description: STEIN-Edna B. On October 22, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sidney A. Stein. Dear mother of Dorothy & Richard Bernstein, Jon Stein and Fredric and Abbe Stein. Cherished grandmother of Marjorie and Michael, Robert and Carol, Robert, Alexa and Jamie and great-grandmother of Steven, Rachel & Samuel. Services Thursday, October 24th, at 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAX, WALLACE H.
description: FLAX-Wallace H. Our beloved Wally passed away on October 21, 2002. Loving husband of Enid (nee Ochacher). The devoted father of Rabbi Martin and Rabbi and Air Force Major Ira (Vicki) Flax. Adoring grandfather of Debbie and Ben. Dear brother of Marilyn (Bill) Kraemer and Joan (Lenny) Lazarus. Services Wednesday, October 23rd, 11:30AM, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Schrder Sworn In For 2nd Term
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder and his new cabinet were sworn in for a second four-year term after Parliament formally approved the coalition government of Social Democrats and Greens. Reflecting the coalition's narrow victory in the elections last month, Mr. Schrder received 305 votes in the 603-member Parliament with 292 members of the opposision Christian Democratic alliance voting against him. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | International: South Korea And Europe
description: The European Union has lodged a complaint with the World Trade Organization in Geneva, asserting that South Korea has subsidized shipbuilding, permitting South Korean shipbuilders to sell at 10 percent to 15 percent below their cost. South Korea promised to fight the complaint. South Korea also considered filing a complaint of its own if European countries subsidize 6 percent of the cost of building ships, as approved by the union after negotiations failed. A spokesman for South Korea's ministry of foreign affairs and trade said South Korea was ''committed to adhering to its W.T.O. commitments.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: $1 Million for Research
description: MORRIS SILVERMAN, a Manhattan philanthropist and the founder of National Equipment Rental, has donated $1 million to the University at Albany's Life Sciences Research Initiative, an effort to expand the university's research facilities and to attract reseachers. A year ago, Mr. Silverman, 90, a graduate of Albany Law School, helped start another initiative at the university, the Center for Jewish Studies, with a challenge grant of $25,000.

title: 'I Don't Own, I Rent' (Cars, Not Apartments)
description: ROY ZINKIL loved his car. For years, he nurtured the 1977 Lincoln Continental Mark V, keeping it on the road well into the years that the car should have spent rusting in a scrap heap. He had every intention of continuing the restoration project indefinitely, but the car's engine had other ideas, finally giving up in the mid-1990's. Mr. Zinkil, 58, of San Diego, then became a regular at his neighborhood car-rental agency. Seven years later, he still rents every weekend and says he has no plans to buy another car.

title: France Links Tunisian in Jail To Terror Cells in 5 Nations
description: A 33-year-old Tunisian man arrested in Marseille last week is believed to be an important player in a terror network based in Europe, French antiterrorism officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, SR.
description: HALL-Sr. Thelma M. of the Sisters of the Cenacle, suddenly on October 21, 2002 in Southampton, NY. Sr. was a member of the Sisters of the Cenacle for 53 years. She is survived by her niece Jeanne Flight of Annapolis, MD, nephews Keith R. Hall of Virginia and David Hall of New York. Memorial Visitation Thursday 2-9 PM at the Cenacle in Ronkonkoma, NY. Memorial Mass Friday 11 AM at the Cenacle Convent, Ronkonkoma, NY. Burial of ashes to follow in the Cenacle Cemetery.

title: Japanese Plan To Overhaul Banks Hits A Stone Wall
description: Heizo Takenaka, Japan's new economy czar, was forced late today to postpone his plan for sweeping changes in bank regulation to deal with the country's $420 billion mountain of bad bank loans, just before he was scheduled to lay it out in detail to reporters.

title: Court Deals New Setback to Europe's Antitrust Policy
description: A European Union court overturned a ruling today by the union's executive body that had blocked a proposed corporate takeover on antitrust grounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SELMA
description: RUBEN - Selma. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine and the Mount Sinai Hospital are saddened by the passing of Selma Ruben. Her personal generosity, and the generosity of her family included important contributions for medical research and health care. Selma Ruben also shared our deep commitment to improving the lives of those suffering from cancer, and together with her husband, Lawrence, established the Rochelle Belfer Chemotherapy Foundation Laboratory at Mount Sinai. We extend our sincere condolences to her husband, Lawrence, to her children, and to the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Board Mount Sinai Medical Center Kenneth I. Berns, M.D., Ph.D. President and Chief Executive Officer Mount Sinai Medical Center Nathan G. Kase, M.D., Interim Dean Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: Republicans Use Age Issue In Criticism Of Lautenberg
description: Douglas R. Forrester's Senate campaign broached a subject today that the Republicans have been toying with since former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, 78, joined the race three weeks ago: Mr. Lautenberg's age and mental agility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STODDARD, WILLIAM B. JR.
description: STODDARD-William B. Jr. Ridgefield, CT, on October 16, 2002. Loving husband and father to Carol and Emily, most generous friend to all. Born in Carbondale, PA, graduate of New York University and its Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, NYC. Investment economist. For thirty years he was active in civic affairs in Ridgefield as a board member of the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Arts and the Ridgefield Library. His wise counsel and kindness will be missed. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions to Ridgefield Conservation Commission Open Space Fund, Ridgefield, CT 06877.

title: Technology News Briefing
description: SOFTWARE

title: Poet Is Said to Be Leading Contender to Run Federal Arts Agency
description: The poet, critic and anthologist Dana Gioia has emerged as the leading candidate to become the next chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, according to sources close to the process. The previous chairman of that agency, Michael P. Hammond, died in January after just a week in the post.

title: Draft of a U.S.-British Resolution on Iraq and Inspectors
description: Following is the working version of an Iraq resolution drafted by the United States and Britain, not including the preamble, as it stood late Sunday. It has been under negotiation in closed meetings since then.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ANITA
description: SMITH-Anita. Beloved wife of the late Al, loving mother of Michael, Stuart, Cathy and David, Jeffrey, and Richard and Rhonda. Cherished grandmother and greatgrandmother. Dear sister of Harriett. Services are at ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12 noon Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPORN, LAWRENCE B.
description: SPORN-Lawrence B. On October 22, 2002. He died after a long bout with cancer. Larry was born on April 25, 1931 in New York City. He was honorably discharged from the United States Navy in 1955. Shortly thereafter, he went to work for Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. There he enjoyed working in many positions, among which were Publisher of Stereo Review, Circulation Director, and President of Publishing. Upon leaving Ziff-Davis he became President of America's Division for Reed International Publications. Aside from his love for music, books, and gardening, he was a fine woodworker and long distance cyclist. He is survived by his wife, five children, grandchild, a daughter-in-law and son-in-law. Services will be held on October 25th at 10:15 AM at the EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, NY. There will be a private viewing for family and friends at 9:30 AM. Burial will follow at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Angels Take Series Lead

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELAHI, CYRUS
description: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

title: Highway Tip No. 1: Slow Traffic Keep Right
description: WHEN my friends and I gather around the patio table at summer parties or meet for dinner near our homes at the Jersey Shore, the talk often turns to driving and, almost inevitably, to our pet peeves about other motorists. Most of our complaints are not new or surprising: we whine about tailgaters, about those who do not read the E-ZPass signs (the Rosetta stone to our state's cryptic system of highway tolls) as they approach the toll plazas or about fellow commuters who apply mascara, shave, read the stock pages or yap on cellphones smaller than Zippo lighters.

title: Bumper-to-Bumper Details of the Crossover Era
description: AMERICANS want more space in their vehicles without adding length. They also want a single vehicle to play the role of many. Those conflicting demands make these the toughest times for car designers since the late 1970's, when fuel crises forced sudden downsizing. Designers now speak of ''crossovers'' -- vehicles that are part truck and part car, part sport utility vehicle and part sports car.

title: The Prisons of Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTOLA, EDWARD J.
description: MORTOLA-Edward J. The Board of Trustees, Chairman Aniello A. Bianco, President David A. Caputo, the faculty, staff, students and alumni of Pace University express profound sorrow at the loss of Dr. Edward J. Mortola, Chancellor Emeritus and Former President of Pace University. Dr. Mortola's life was notable for his own accomplishments as well as for the influence he had on generations of Pace University students, faculty, staff and alumni. He served as president of Pace from 1960 to 1984 and chancellor from 1984 to 1987, leading Pace during its greatest period of academic and physical expansion and vastly increasing the University's size and scope. During his tenure as president, Dr. Mortola introduced the liberal arts degree programs to Pace and subsequently established a series of professional schools in nursing, education, continuing education and law. We remember him as a great innovator, builder, leader, and dominant force in higher education in New York City. We express our gratitude for his contributions to Pace as dean, vice president, president, chancellor and trustee during the course of his half a century affiliation with the university. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Doris, daughters Doreen Mortola LeMoult and Elaine Mortola-Clark, and his five beloved grandsons.

title: Research Group To Lose President
description: Jim Spaeth, president at the Advertising Research Foundation in New York, said he would leave in April to form a brand consulting company in Cambridge, Mass. The foundation, where Mr. Spaeth, 53, has been president since 1996, is searching for a successor.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Workers Cleared In Sex Abuse Inquiry
description: After a five-month investigation, the United Nations Office of Internal Oversight rejected accusations of widespread sexual abuse by United Nations relief workers in West African refugee camps. A preliminary study, issued in February by Save the Children U.K. and the United Nations high commissioner for refugees, said refugee children in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone were frequently forced by camp officials to have sex in exchange for food and medicine. Of the 43 cases of possible sexual exploitation investigated, only 10 were substantiated and none involved a United Nations staff member, the new report said. But it acknowledged that conditions in the camps made refugees vulnerable to sexual exploitation, especially young women, and included 17 recommendations for improvement. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: War Clouds Will Darken Asia-Pacific Meeting in Mexico
description: The leaders of the United States, Russia, China, Indonesia and other nations are coming here this week to argue over Washington's campaigns against terrorist groups and what it calls rogue nations.

title: Choosing a Teenager's First (Gulp!) Wheels
description: AT 16, Elizabeth Fetsch knows her cars. In fact, she has a good idea of what she would like to be driving. A Honda Civic tops the list, followed by a Ford Focus. Should she win the lottery, she said, a Mercedes S.U.V. would be nice, and for fun there is nothing like an old Mustang convertible.

title: Canned Tuna With a Bite
description: I WAS once amazed to learn that some pasta sauces could be prepared in the time it takes water to boil. That was before I realized that quick sauces are the norm for pasta, and that waiting for the requisite gallon or so of water to boil is usually the most time-consuming part of preparing a pasta dinner.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AIM GROUP, Southampton, England, a maker of aircraft and train interiors, said talks with a potential buyer had ended.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Friday about a California study that sought to account for a sharp increase in diagnoses of childhood autism misstated a finding. The study found that the increase could not be explained by statistical anomalies, like a loosening in the criteria for diagnosis. It did not examine whether rising public awareness of autism might have led more parents to seek treatment for their children, and therefore did not rule out rising awareness as a possible explanation for the increase.

title: ECHOSTAR MAY SEEK TO EXIT DEAL FOR HUGHES ELECTRONICS
description: EchoStar Communications will look for a way out of its $23 billion agreement to buy a satellite TV rival, Hughes Electronics, after regulators said they believed that the companies could not rework the deal to win approval, analysts said. The Federal Communications Commission said last week that no satellite TV service would emerge in two years to replace competition lost by the combination of EchoStar's Dish Network and Hughes's DirecTV. Merger guidelines require a new player to enter the market in that period, the F.C.C. said. The companies say they will propose ways to restructure the deal to meet government objections. ''The companies are in deep denial if they think they can fix this merger,'' said Scott Cleland, chief executive of the Precursor Group, a Washington investment research firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAPP, DAVID PETER
description: KNAPP-David Peter. Of East Setauket, NY, on October 20, 2002. Beloved husband of Sidney (nee Carroll). Devoted father of Allison Womack, Catherine Kern, David, John and Christopher Knapp. Adored grandfather of five grandchildren. Cherished brother of Barbara Schanno and Edward Knapp. Visiting Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9 PM and Thursday 7-9 PM only at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave., Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass Friday, 11:15 AM, at St. Aidan's R.C. Church, Williston Park, NY. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Little Things Again Add Up to Big Innings for Angels
description: Barry Bonds has hit 1,340 feet worth of home runs in this World Series. He is virtually unstoppable, the only player to homer in each of his first three Series games. But the San Francisco Giants are behind, despite Bonds's best efforts. The Anaheim Angels' relentless lineup has been too much.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Farmingdale: Boy Is Fatally Shot At Train Station On Long Island
description: A 15-year-old boy was shot to death last night during an argument with other youths at the Farmingdale station of the Long Island Rail Road, the police said. The victim, whose identity was not disclosed, was shot at 8:45 p.m. and pronounced dead about 10:20 p.m. at New Island Hospital in Bethpage, the authorities said. Lt. Dennis Farrell of the Nassau County Police said that after the boy was shot once in the chest, two young men dressed in dark clothing were seen running from the station. It remained unclear what prompted the shooting, which took place near a stairway leading to the station's platform. Investigators said the victim was accompanied by a friend, who was interviewed by detectives last night. Although no trains were at the station, which is in the central business district of Farmingdale, the shooting was witnessed by several people who had just exited a train that departed only moments before, the police said. The shooting caused officials to suspend rail service in both directions from 9 p.m. to 9:36 p.m., said Brian Dolan, a railroad spokesman. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: The Craving Man takes his lumps in a new campaign for a patch to control smoking.
description: AFTER years of neglect that left Nicotrol a laggard among over-the-counter nicotine-replacement brands, its owner is betting that a $50 million marketing campaign laced with humor will reinvigorate the antismoking patch's domestic sales.

title: IN HOMESTRETCH, BUSH MAKES PUSH FOR G.O.P. GAINS
description: The White House is mounting an all-out push over the final two weeks of the midterm elections, dispatching President Bush to campaign almost nonstop between now and Election Day, as officials seek to turn Mr. Bush's popularity into Republican victories this fall. White House officials today said they were poised for a ''historic'' Republican triumph next month.

title: Escalating Tuition Bills
description: The public universities and colleges that grant three-quarters of this country's degrees are becoming increasingly unaffordable to the poor and working-class students who have traditionally used them to move out of poverty into the middle class. This troubling trend was underscored yet again this week when the College Board released alarming data showing that public-college tuition had risen by nearly 10 percent -- the largest increase in a decade. This sharp tuition rise follows a period when the costs of higher education have outpaced tuition aid.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Term-Limits Law Challenged
description: City Councilman Martin J. Golden, left, and two potential Council candidates filed a lawsuit yesterday against the City Council over its new term-limits law. The law, passed over the veto of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, addressed a provision that limited some members, including Mr. Golden, to six years in office rather than eight, the maximum available to most elected officials in the city. Mr. Golden, a candidate for State Senate, voted against the law, but the suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, is an unusual move for a sitting council member, officials said. Randy M. Mastro, chairman of two past Charter Revision Commissions and the lawyer representing the three, said the law violated the City Charter by changing the term of an elective officer without a voter referendum. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS-Elsa. October 23, 1985. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Nieces Shirley & Lorrain

title: Ruling Clears Way to Ease Beach Access In California
description: California officials said today that they would move quickly to begin opening access to several beaches after the Supreme Court rejected two challenges to their efforts on Monday.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Man Admits Arson-For-Hire
description: A man has admitted setting fires and has agreed to testify against a former detective who prosecutors say was the head of an arson-for-hire ring. The man, Otis Boone, pleaded guilty on Monday to setting six fires in 1998 and 1999, the Division of Criminal Justice said. In exchange for a reduced sentence, Mr. Boone will testify against Marc Rossi, a former narcotics detective at the prosecutor's office, said John R. Hagerty, a division spokesman. Prosecutors said the fires helped Mr. Rossi's insurance adjustment business, which is defunct. Mr. Boone faces up to 10 years in prison at sentencing. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Chip Company's Profit Misses
description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company posted a profit that was half what analysts had forecast, sending chip stocks lower on concern that an industry recovery was faltering. Third-quarter net income almost tripled to 3.2 billion Taiwan dollars ($92 million) from 1.2 billion a year earlier, when chip makers were mired in their worst slump. A 2.9 billion tax expense accounted for most of the difference between the profit figure and analysts' average forecast of 6.2 billion. The tax expense arose as some of older factories lost tax exemptions. The charge raised its tax rate in the quarter to 18 percent, and the fourth quarter rate will be similar, it said. A year earlier, it had a tax credit of 1.4 billion Taiwan dollars.

title: Saints Solve Puzzle by Using New Pieces
description: Any initial thoughts about the Saints before this season focused on what they no longer had -- General Manager Randy Mueller was fired, the defensive coordinator, Ron Zook, left to become the head coach at the University of Florida, offensive tackle Willie Roaf was traded to Kansas City, defensive linemen La'Roi Glover and Joe Johnson were allowed to scoot via free agency and, easily the riskiest move of all, running back Ricky Williams was traded to Miami.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Political Memo; Money and Momentum Elude McCall
description: Short of cash and struggling to find a penetrating message, the campaign of H. Carl McCall has been pushed largely to the sidelines in recent days, while Gov. George E. Pataki and Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, wage a war to win over moderate and conservative voters, political strategists say.

title: UNITED AIRLINES OPENS TALKS WITH ATTENDANTS
description: The Association of Flight Attendants said yesterday that it had begun negotiations with UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, over labor concessions. The company and its five unions are in talks this week to determine how to shave $5.8 billion from labor costs over five and a half years. The company and the unions agreed to that figure last week, but executives must negotiate separately with each union to obtain concessions. The airline said it would file a revised business plan with the federal government this week to bolster an application for a $1.8 billion loan guarantee. That guarantee could help it get private financing to stay out of bankruptcy court. United has a debt payment due on Nov. 17, but hopes to work out a deferral of payment with the bank. Edward Wong (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: VODKA CONFLICT A Russian vodka exporter, in a dispute with the Russian Agriculture Ministry over the rights to the Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya vodka brands, said it would fight a German court decision to ban new imports of its vodka on grounds that it is made in Latvia and not Russia. A spokesman for the Russian company, Soyuzplodimport, said he expected the court to uphold the company's right to sell its Moskovskaya vodka brand in Germany. He acknowledged, however, that the Russian vodka had been produced in Latvia since early this year, when the Russian ministry, which says the company acquired the rights to the brands illegally, blocked the company's shipments of vodka from Russia. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SHEA, JOHN M.
description: O'SHEA-John M. Passed away on October 18. 'Tis better to sit here beside the sea,/Here on the spray kissed beach,/In silence that between such friends is we/Is full of deepest speech. Loving husband, adoring father and friend. Fran, Micki, and Barbara

title: Heston Takes Last Lap In the Cause of Guns
description: Charlton Heston's voice is softer than when he bellowed as Moses, his body frailer than when he commandeered a chariot as Ben-Hur. He shuffles stiffly now across a room, his upper body angled forward. He leans on a lectern because standing tires him. It takes prodding from a colleague for Mr. Heston, 79, to raise a flintlock over his head in his signature pose and challenge his critics to pry the rifle ''from my cold dead hands.''

title: Look What's For Dinner
description: EVERY year around this time, the world's greatest wildlife migration passes by New York City. Whales, dolphins and tuna swim past on their way south, and monarch butterflies as brilliant as stained-glass windows are in the air. Ducks, geese, woodcocks and songbirds fly with them above waters teeming with baitfish in uncountable billions and, best of all for the hungry angler, bluefish and the local champion in pinstripes, the striped bass.

title: Junkyards Discard an Image, and the Scary Dogs, Too
description: IT used to be that only the most dedicated car-parts scrounger would set foot in a junkyard. The popular conception of these automotive graveyards was of a field filled with scrap metal, old tires and burned-out car bodies, oil and other automotive fluids mingling underfoot to form a slippery ooze, with a pack of free-ranging Dobermans policing the perimeter.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Opposition Candidate For President
description: Most of the opposition parties united behind Mwai Kibaki, a 71-year-old former vice president, as their candidate in the December election to replace President Daniel arap Moi, who is retiring. The new National Rainbow Coalition is seeking to end the disunity among the opposition that has helped the governing Kenya Africa National Union party hold on to the presidency throughout Kenya's 39 years of independence. But another opposition leader, Simon Nyachae, said he intended to go it alone. Mr. Moi is backing Uhuru Kenyatta, son of the country's founding president, to succeed him. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Deal Reported For Vivendi Sale Of French Assets
description: Vivendi Universal has agreed to sell its French publishing business and other non-American assets to Lagardre, the French conglomerate that publishes Elle and Car and Driver magazines, for about $1.2 billion in cash, executives involved in the negotiations said last night.

title: Recipe: Oven-Roasted Tomatoes
description: Time: 20 minutes, plus 3 to 4 hours' roasting

title: Amino Acid May Not Predict Heart Attacks
description: Levels of homocysteine in the blood -- promoted as the new cholesterol as a harbinger of coronary disease -- may not be very helpful in predicting heart attacks and strokes in healthy people, a new study finds.

title: The Food Is Old Vietnam; the Setting Is 2002
description: THE restaurant has no sign out front, only potted bamboo plants that wave in the cool Chelsea breeze. Behind them, bathed in soft, amber light, sits a storefront crowded with tautly muscled men in open shirts, voguish women in tight silk, a few older couples in tweed and poplin. The din is incredible and the mood bright, everyone laughing.

title: Designing Drivers, Stylish Wheels
description: TO the fashion set, a car is the ultimate vehicle for self-expression, a luxurious extension of a person's signature style.

title: Finding a Reincarnated American Classic on a Trip to Australia
description: MOST visitors to Australia go home with a stuffed koala, a bottle of wine and maybe a deep winter tan from Bondi Beach.

title: Skin Tone as the Subtle Signal For Hatred in the Racial Family
description: Though its two performers seldom make eye contact, people always seem to be staring at one another in ''Yellowman,'' Dael Orlandersmith's hard and piercing drama about intraracial prejudice, which opened last night at the Manhattan Theater Club. It is difficult, in fact, to think of another play in which the act of seeing figures so aggressively. Characters in this intricate narrative are sometimes described as looking through and past those in front of them, but it's not before they've registered, with categorical precision, the tones of the others' skin.

title: U.S. Role in Inquiry Grows Amid Tales of Turf Battles
description: Even as Attorney General John Ashcroft said the sniper investigation was proceeding effectively, senior officials on the case described the inquiry as an increasingly chaotic effort hobbled by turf battles and a fear of leaks that has kept important information from street-level investigators.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Paper Company Posts Loss
description: Stora Enso, one of the world's biggest paper makers, predicted a recovery in demand after an asset write-down led to a third-quarter loss. The net loss was 998.7 million euros ($973.7 million), or 1.12 euros a share, in contrast to a profit of 213.7 million euros, or 24 cents a share, in the same period last year, the Finnish company said. Sales dropped 2.8 percent, to 3.1 billion euros. An advertising slump over the last year left newspapers and magazines with fewer pages, curbing demand and prices for paper. Stora Enso, which wrote down assets in North America by 1.17 billion euros in the third quarter, is now experiencing a pickup in demand. Pretax profit excluding the charge fell to 195.8 million euros from 305.6 million euros. Stora Enso shares rose 37 cents, or 3.4 percent, to 11.16 euros in Helsinki. Earnings per share excluding one-time items dropped to 15 cents a share from 23 cents.

title: The Prisons of Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Unmanned U.S. Planes Comb Arabian Desert for Suspects
description: The trackless, desolate sands of the vast Arabian desert known as the Empty Quarter are being scoured by pilotless United States surveillance aircraft looking for signs that operatives of Al Qaeda have sought refuge among the nomadic tribes there, according to senior Yemeni officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, LT. COL. ROGER S.
description: RYAN-Lt. Col. Roger S. (Retired USA), died Tuesday, October 22, 2002 at his home in Millbrook, NY from complications related to ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease). During World War II, Ryan served with the 315th Infantry, 79th Division (Cross of Lorraine) and was responsible for 187 enlisted men and 5 officers of an Infantry Rifle company in combat in four campaigns. Ryan received the Purple Heart with three Oak Leaf clusters, European Theatre of Operations ribbon with 4 stars, Combat Infantry Badge, Distinguished Unit Citation, the Bronze Star Medal with three Oak Leaf clusters and the Croix de la Legion d'Honneur from the French government in 1949. After the War, Col. Ryan continued his military career with the New York National Guard and served as the Commanding Officer of the 71st Infantry, 42nd (Rainbow) Division. In 1963, while serving with the 106th Infantry, 42nd Division, Ryan was one of seven recipients of the seldom-awarded New York State Medal of Valor for his heroic actions in rescuing two men unconscious and trapped in a flaming vehicle which crashed through a wall onto the Long Island RR tracks 30 feet below. After his retirement in 1967, Col. Ryan was named Honorary Regimental Commander of the 71st Infantry, a title he deeply cherished as his father served with the 71st during the Spanish-American War. Born in New York City, Ryan started a printing company, Graphic Color of Teaneck, NJ now run by his son. He graduated from Georgia Military Academy and attended NYU. He leaves his wife of 61 years, Eileen, his son Robert of Orangeburg, NY, his daughter Regina of Boston, MA., and 3 granddaughters. Visiting hours will be Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 at Moritz Funeral Home, Tappan, NY. Funeral Mass will be held on Friday at St. Catharine's RC Church at 9:30AM. He will be buried at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-theHudson, in the 71st Infantry Regimental burial grounds. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to Disabled American Veterans.

title: Subsidiary Issue Enters Pledge Case
description: A federal appeals court's decision in June that the words ''under God'' in the Pledge of Allegiance violated the First Amendment generated both immediate controversy and a legal tangle that grows more curious with each passing week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHURE, MICHAEL A.
description: SHURE-Michael A. On October 21. Adored husband of Alice. Beloved father of Michael Jr. and Tony. Cherished father-in-law of Sandra. Devoted son of Evelyn and the late Harry Shure. Born in New Haven, CT. on December 23, 1938. Graduate of the University of Virginia. Attended Pratt School of Architecture. He lived his life with inimitable passion. He loved his family and friends unconditionally. He made all who knew him laugh and smile. Private burial. A Memorial service will be held on Wednesday 6pm in the Peter B. Lewis Theatre at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to The University of Virginia School of Architecture, P.O. Box 400122, Charlottesville, Va. 22904

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIKYAN, KENT R., JR.
description: COSTIKYAN-Kent R., Jr. Of South Norwalk, CT, on October 21, 2002, aboard his sailboat in Norfolk, VA. Beloved father to Kent R. III, Timothy, and Warren, stepfather to Elisabeth Worthington Ruyter, Andrew Burris Jenkins, Andrea Georgia Jenkins, Susan Delatour Cary. Husband to the late Elisabeth Delatour Costikyan, and brother to Thomas Wilson Costikyan. Kent was a graduate of The Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Class of 1948. He was an avid racing and cruising sailor. He passed following a final run south down The Chesapeake Bay. A celebration of his life will be held at 1 P.M. Sunday October 27, 2002 at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Quebec-Labrador Foundation/Atlantic Center For The Environment, 55 South Main Street, Ipswich, MA 01938.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKINS, STELLA (NEE BECKER)
description: ELKINS-Stella (nee Becker). Beloved mother of James and Andrew. Devoted grandmother of five. Cherished great-grandmother of four. Interment is today, 10:30 A.M. at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Theater Founders Are Charged With Fraud
description: After a four-year investigation, the Canadian police today charged the two founders of a Toronto theater group that staged hits like ''Showboat'' and ''Ragtime'' on Broadway with defrauding investors and creditors of $325 million.

title: Wines of the Week
description: It wasn't a trick, but a treat.

title: The Voters' Prerogatives And Bilingual Education
description: IN November, voters in Colorado and Massachusetts will decide on initiatives that would ban bilingual education. Arizona and California have already adopted similar measures. Proponents, who want all instruction in English, rely on a claim that early-20th-century immigrants succeeded by that method, called English immersion.

title: Prune-Loving Pasta
description: THIS is a no-holds-barred spectacle, an elegant and excessive bank-breaker that will take you a couple of hours of solid work and make your guests think you can cook like, well, Barbara Lynch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRELINGER, DOROTHY
description: PRELINGER - Dorothy. Of New Haven, CT on October 19, 2002. Beloved mother of Richard, Elizabeth, Jane and Polly; loving grandmother of Joanna, Benjy, Laura and Fred; sister of Larry Racies.

title: Untypically, a Rockefeller Tells the Story of His Life
description: John D. Rockefeller, the famously secretive oil baron who founded his family's vast fortune, once confided that of all his grandchildren, the one who most resembled him was David A. Rockefeller, the only one of his generation to follow his grandfather into a life of business. They were exceptionally close from the boy's infancy in 1915 until the old man's death in 1937.

title: No Tapes, No Discs, No Top-10 Limit
description: TAKING control over what you listen to -- and for how long -- is a tremendous power bequeathed by today's car audio systems. For example, there's the cross-country trip. Not long ago, drivers traveling coast-to-coast used to risk being trapped in an AM radio world of hog reports and local bank commercials between Dave Dudley's trucker songs. Needless to say, things have improved. Computer hard drives have melded with car stereos and even the humble radio has joined the space age.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the investigation of the sniper attacks around Washington referred incorrectly in some copies to the location of a white van that had been stopped by a SWAT team. It was Henrico County, Va., not Hanover County.

title: Rodgers As Ideal Dance Partner
description: Richard Rodgers wrote only one score for a ballet, and this virtually forgotten work, ''Ghost Town,'' was recalled onstage at City Center on Monday along with the dance-friendly music always found in Rodgers's Broadway shows.

title: A 9/11 Memorial That Offers a Path To Restore the Soul
description: Unlike other monuments in the Battery -- like the hulking slabs listing World War II military casualties and the huge bronze Universal Soldier cutout -- the labyrinth, a new memorial to the victims of the terrorist attacks, is so subtle that a passer-by could walk right over it without noticing.

title: AT&T Posts a Small Profit After Three Quarters of Losses
description: AT&T said yesterday that it had a small profit in the third quarter after three consecutive periods of losses, and attributed it to cost-cutting and improved sales of communications services to large businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, BEATRICE PHILLIPS
description: SACHS-Beatrice Phillips, 93, of New York City, formerly of Boston, MA, died October 19 in NYC. Loving aunt of Maynard and Suzanne Goldman of Boston and great-aunt to Derek and Emily Goldman of Chapel Hill, NC. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Phillips of Boston and the late Henry Sachs of NYC; devoted sister of the late Harriette Feingold Goldman. There will be no funeral service, but a memorial service will be held in November. Contributions in her memory may be made to Street Signs, 85 Amble Wood Run, Chapel Hill, NC 27516.

title: Shining the Laser Lights On Tuned-Up Eye Candy
description: THE young men and women who form the long line leading through the corridors of McCormick Place here could be waiting for a rock concert. The techno rhythms blaring from the convention hall and the colored laser lights shooting through the darkness suggest the same.

title: Software Maker Has Loss
description: Computer Associates International, a software maker, reported a smaller second-quarter loss today as it cut costs and sales rose. The net loss narrowed to $52 million, or 9 cents a share, from $291 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the three months ended Sept. 30 rose 5.3 percent, to $772 million from $733 million a year earlier.

title: Recipe for Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY
description: Cars

title: Reporter's Notebook; Age-Old Culinary Questions Still Stir a Fire
description: This was no everyday summit conference. For a start, there were a lot more bluejeans than pinstripe suits.

title: For Racers of All Stripes, A Club to Call Their Own
description: IT was Saturday at the country club, but nary a golf club or a tennis racket was in sight. Instead, there were plenty of sleek vehicles, as about 85 racecar drivers, real and would-be, gathered at a professional-quality, 1.7-mile track on a former cattle ranch here. It is quite possibly the nation's first car country club.

title: Do Not Let Fear Rule Our Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, MARVIN
description: KRAUSS-Marvin. On October 22, 2002. Cherished husband of Elaine. Father of Anne, Robin and Michael, Nina & David, Seth and Lisa. Brother of Richard. Grandfather of Tatiayna, Ezra, Jacob, Gabriel and Matthew. Funeral service October 24, 11:45AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Harsh Words For Democracy
description: The country's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, said democratic systems were based on lies, propaganda and manipulation of votes. His comments came two days after President Mohammad Khatami spoke in Parliament in defense of people's rights. ''What is called democracy and the rule of people in the world today is the old dictatorship in a new guise that uses money and propaganda in pursuit of the interests of group dictatorship,'' the ayatollah said. He stressed the value of an Islamic state, saying that an Islamic system is based on justice. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: State Court Upholds Authority Of Mayor on Cable Franchises
description: The state's highest court yesterday upheld a decision granting New York's mayor, and not the City Council, oversight authority over cable television franchises, effectively ending a power struggle lingering from the Giuliani era.

title: Times Appoints Two To Newsroom Positions
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that John Darnton would become associate editor for special projects and that Steven Erlanger, chief of the newspaper's Berlin bureau, would succeed him as cultural news editor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLAK, GEORGE
description: BELLAK - George. Award winning screenwriter and novelist, died on October 22, 2002. Cherished husband of Sherry Arden Bellak, devoted father of Nina Bellak and Cathy Arden, adored grandfather of Anya and Micah Kaats and Elijah McClellan, esteemed brother of Claire Katz. Services 1PM Thursday at Temple Beth Torah, Upper Nyack, New York.

title: Canadian Writer Wins A Revamped Booker Prize
description: Yann Martel, a Canadian writer, won the newly renamed Man Booker Prize tonight for his novel ''Life of Pi,'' the magical fable of a young man shipwrecked in the company of a Bengal tiger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHTA, MEHLI
description: MEHTA-Mehli. With great sadness, the Board, Staff and Friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., join the international music community to mourn the passing of Mehli Mehta, founder of the Bombay Symphony Orchestra and Music Director of the American Youth Symphony. We are thankful to the Mehta family for their tremendous impact on the arts in New York City and specifically here at Lincoln Center. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Tehmina, his sons, former New York Philharmonic Music Director, Zubin Mehta, and the Philharmonic's current Executive Director Zarin Mehta, and to the entire family. Bruce Crawford, Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Columbia Theater in Church
description: ANDREI SERBAN, director of theater studies at Columbia University, joined with students to cut the ribbon last week on a new theater for his program: the 180-seat theater at nearby Riverside Church. Columbia has struck a deal with the church that will allow it to use the theater for five years. Last month Columbia announced that it would use the Apollo Theater in Harlem  also close to the university  to present the Royal Shakespeare Company in a stage production of Salman Rushdie's novel "Midnight's Children" in March. Columbia's inaugural production at Riverside will be an adaptation of "Peer Gynt" by BATHSHEBA DORAN, a Columbia student, next month directed by Mr. Serban and with a musical score by ELIZABETH SWADOS.

title: East Germany's Doping Chief, Manfred Ewald, Is Dead at 76
description: Manfred Ewald, the head of sport in East Germany and a chief architect of its state-sponsored system of providing athletes with illicit performance-enhancing drugs, died Monday in Damsdorf, Germany, his hometown. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, JOSEPH
description: BLAU-Joseph. Of Somers, N.Y. Beloved husband of Fran. Loving father of Robert (Ronna) and Marcia. Adored grandfather of Laura, Sarah, Justin and Dylan Funeral services at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y. on Wednesday, October 23 at 10AM. Interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. ''We'll miss you''.

title: Rustic Portuguese, With No Apologies
description: DINNER at Alfama begins, as at so many other restaurants, with an amuse-bouche. At most places, it's a highly refined little presentation: ''The chef would like to welcome you with these special flavors,'' a waiter will say, handing you a bit of smoked salmon on a transparent cucumber slice, or a teaspoon of eggplant cooked down practically to jelly.

title: The Prisons of Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui'' with Al Pacino in the title role misstated the name of a film he starred in and directed. It is ''Looking for Richard,'' not ''Searching for Richard.''

title: Do Not Let Fear Rule Our Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Classic, The Return Journey Gets Smoother
description: MENTION the word ''Indian'' to anyone with a sense of motorcycle history and you will likely get an earful of nostalgia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Australia's anger over the bombing of two Bali nightclubs that killed nearly 200 Australians misidentified the United States official who warned of a bombing threat to ''soft targets'' in Indonesia the day before the bombing. He was Ralph C. Boyce, the American ambassador in Jakarta; the same day, the American ambassador to Australia, J. Thomas Schieffer, warned that government of terrorist threats to energy installations.

title: New Life for New York Rock; The Production Team DFA Offers a Sound You Can Dance To
description: When the English producer Tim Goldsworthy used to think about New York, he imagined break-dancers on every corner, decadent punk rock concerts every night and an atmosphere in which countless artists were breaking boundaries in free-form musical freakouts. At the time, in the 1990's, he was running one of London's best dance-music labels, Mo' Wax.

title: Hyundai: Coming Up Fast, And Ready to Accelerate
description: ANYONE who doubts that the Hyundai Motor Company is serious about becoming an important player in the American car market needs to only consider a couple of construction projects that the South Korean company has started.

title: Cost Moves Aid BellSouth's Profit
description: BellSouth said here today that its third-quarter profit rose on lower investment costs. Net income was $733 million, or 39 cents a share, up from $7 million -- effectively breaking even -- a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMESON, EDWIN C. JR.
description: JAMESON-Edwin C. Jr. In Hamble, England. Of West Palm Beach, FL., at the age of 88, on September 28, 2002. Son of the late Mary G. and Edwin C. Jameson of New York and Sharon, CT. Survived by his sister Mary J.P. Moore and nephews Samuel F. Posey and Nicholas J. Moore, all of Sharon, CT., and David W. Moore of Woodbridge, CT. Memorial service will take place at Christ Church, Sharon, CT. Thursday, October 24, 2002 at 11AM with interment following at the Sharon Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about the interior designer Tony Ingrao, misstated the address of his new store, Tony Ingrao Antiques and Fine Art. It is at 17 East 64th Street, not 74th Street.

title: The Mets Pessimistic On Getting Piniella
description: For the first time, the Mets appear in danger of falling out of the Lou Piniella managerial sweepstakes.

title: Giants Overcome Three-Run Deficit
description: Just in the nick of time, the San Francisco Giants solved the Kid.

title: Author Charged for Islam Remark Is Acquitted
description: The French novelist Michel Houellebecq, who often seems to delight in shocking his readers, was acquitted by a Paris court today of charges of inciting racial hatred when he declared in an interview last year that Islam was ''the most stupid religion.''

title: Envisioning Penn Station as All the World's Stage
description: MICHAEL L. ROYCE is, as they say, up there in the world, way up on the 36th floor in a corner office with a view of Manhattan -- East River, United Nations --that is as big as his job. He is Mr. Penn Station, the new president of the group, the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, promising to expand and make it grand again.

title: The Prisons of Saddam Hussein
description: To the Editor:

title: Comedy and Commentary, With Hyperbolic Jewishness
description: ''People are stupid, and I say that with the greatest respect.'' Such is the sentiment -- mean-spiritedness delivered as a winking joke -- that generally dominates the humor of Jackie Mason. Indeed, that precise line and others like it are reiterated often in ''Prune Danish,'' Mr. Mason's sixth and newest display of chutzpah to appear on Broadway.

title: Man, 22, Held in Sex Assaults On 6 Girls, All Under Age 14
description: A 22-year-old Westchester man was indicted today on charges that he raped a teenage girl and sexually assaulted five others whom he met through a series of part-time jobs, prosecutors said.

title: Ford Gives River Rouge a Green Coat
description: SINCE 1918 around Detroit, the words ''River Rouge'' and ''Ford'' have been associated with simple, traditional things: steel, coal, cars, trucks, smoke, soot and jobs. Now it means sedum, too.

title: Bronx Woman Stabbed to Death and Neighbors Chase Her Attacker
description: Moments before she died, Lynette Luckett stepped off the Bx36 bus on Monday, as she did every night after work. She walked toward the two-story house she shared with her brother on Belmont Avenue in the Bronx.

title: On Your Own Trail: The New Tracking Devices
description: DRIVERS who buy cars with manufacturer-installed navigation systems have the comfort of knowing that if the vehicles crash or break down, someone will know how to find the people in them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALE, ELIZABETH (NEE ESSIG)
description: VALE-Elizabeth (nee Essig). On October 20. Formerly of the Bronx and Floral Park. Wife of the late Joseph. Mother of Joseph. Grandmother of Kerry and Kevin. Funeral Mass Wednesday, October 23, at 11 AM in St. Patrick Church, Highland Mills, NY. For information Thiele Family Funeral Home, Kearny, NJ. (201)-991-1031.

title: Box-Office Patriots
description: To the Editor:

title: A Treat for Shepherds, and Others
description: CLAUDIO CORONAS, an owner of D.O.C. Wine Bar, a little slice of Sardinia in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, wanted to bring the simple foods of his homeland to the United States. Thankfully, that includes pane carasau, a giant cracker bread served just off the grill, moistened with extra virgin olive oil and sprinkled with coarse sea salt and rosemary.

title: Little Things Again Add Up to Big Innings for Angels
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22  Barry Bonds has hit 1,340 feet worth of home runs in this World Series. He is virtually unstoppable, the only player to homer in each of his first three Series games. But the San Francisco Giants are behind, despite Bonds's best efforts. The Anaheim Angels' relentless lineup has been too much.

title: Candidates for Governor in Florida Spar Over Education
description: In their third debate, Gov. Jeb Bush and his Democratic challenger, Bill McBride, traded verbal punches about education tonight as each sought to turn the unexpectedly tight race in his favor.

title: If You Land It, Is It Safe?
description: THE New York State Health Department says it is safe to eat one meal a week of bluefish or striped bass caught in city waters. Women of childbearing age are advised not to consume striped bass.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELLENBOGEN, JOAN L.
description: ELLENBOGEN - Joan L. Your spirit stays with us and your presence is deeply missed. Marcia and your many caring friends

title: Educator on Bank's Board
description: The Federal Reserve Board this month named JOHN SEXTON, president of New York University, as deputy chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for 2003. The board appoints three members to the board of each of its 12 banks and designates one as chairman and one as deputy chairman. The board named PETER G. PETERSON, chairman of the investment banking firm Blackstone Group, as chairman for another year. Karen W. Arenson

title: Deaths Mounting Again In War on Drunk Driving
description: FOR 15 years, the United States was winning the war against drunken driving, steadily reducing the percentage of deaths from accidents involving alcohol.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Freehold: Rabbi's Friend Testifies At Trial
description: The second trial of the rabbi accused of arranging the murder of his wife continued yesterday with testimony from a former radio personality, whom prosecutors described as the rabbi's former mistress. The woman, Elaine Soncini, said the rabbi, Fred J. Neulander, left, pleaded with her before his wife's death to continue their two-year love affair. ''Trust me, we'll be together by your birthday,'' Dec. 17, 1994, the rabbi told Ms. Soncini, she testified. The rabbi also said ''he wished her car would go into the river,'' Ms. Soncini testified he told her, referring to his wife. The rabbi denies hiring a friend to kill his wife, Carol, who died on Nov. 1, 1994.

title: MetroStars Are Able to Find Coach a Little Closer to Home
description: After seven years of mediocrity, the MetroStars introduced Bob Bradley yesterday as the club's seventh coach. Unlike his predecessors, Bradley will not get lost on New Jersey's serpentine highways because he is the only MetroStars coach to call the state home.

title: 'Big 5' at the United Nations Still Jockeying Over Iraq Text
description: In intense negotiations, the United States and Britain pressed the other three permanent members of the Security Council today to accept a draft resolution on Iraq that includes no explicit authorization of military action but leaves the way open for Washington to go to war.

title: Giants Pull Together, if Only for the Moment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22  A couple of hours before Game 3 of the World Series tonight, Dusty Baker, a potential free agent, was asked to imagine a Giants lineup without Jeff Kent next season. The Giants had gone into last off-season with Barry Bonds a free agent, and after receiving few offers, he returned to San Francisco. Kent is not drawing quite as much attention as Bonds did  his potential departure has been overshadowed by Baker's  but his departure could devastate the Giants.

title: Scientists Debating Future Of Hormone Replacement
description: When a large study of hormone replacement therapy was abruptly halted last summer because of risks from the drugs, scientists immediately began a reassessment of all other studies that involved the drugs. Now, one additional study has been halted, and participants in studies that are continuing have had to give their consent again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENZI, WARREN E.
description: FENZI-Warren E. President of Phelps Dodge Corporation from 1975 to 1980, died Sunday, October 20, at his home in Santa Barbara, CA. A graduate of California Institute of Technology in 1937, Mr. Fenzi worked for Phelps Dodge in Arizona and NYC for over 40 years, retiring as president in 1980 and as a director in 1983. He was recognized as an expert in mine planning and administration and as a promoter of mine safety. He served in the Sea Bees in the Pacific in WWII. His wife, the former Eleanor Huse Leeds of Pasadena, CA, died in 1998. He is survived by five children: Charles C. Fenzi, M.D., of Roswell, NM; Louise FenziHaag of Tucson, AZ; Warren S. Fenzi of Prescott, AZ; David L. Fenzi of Las Vegas, NM; and Joan F. Fenzi of Tucson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be conducted at 2 PM Sat. Oct. 26th at All Saints by the Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to United Boys and Girls Clubs of Santa Barbara, POB 1485, Santa Barbara, CA 93102 or the Campaign to Save Franceschi House, POB 41760, Santa Barbara, CA. 93140.

title: Wave of Chocolate Transforms a Village Diner
description: Chocolate treats fill the display case at Lunchbox Food Company, 357 West Street (Clarkson Street) in Greenwich Village. Jennifer Kohns, above center, and Lawrence Rudolph, right, have turned what was a diner into a kitchen, restaurant and shop with chocolate brown furnishings. There are three kinds of chocolate: dark, white and chili-spiced Mexican with a hint of cinnamon.

title: Butter and Cream Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Niche Mania!
description: WHEN Janis Joplin implored the Lord for a Mercedes-Benz, no further elaboration was necessary. At the time, three decades ago, the Mercedes was a symbol in this country of precise engineering, exacting quality and exclusivity. The cars came in four basic sizes, in about a dozen variations, all of them expensive. To most Americans, buying a Benz required divine intervention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDER, MAX (MIKE)
description: ANDER-Max (Mike). On October 22, 2002. Cherished uncle of Richard and Gene Ander. He served his country in the U.S. Army and served the public as an attorney. Graveside service was held at the New Montefiore Cemetery on October 22, 2002.

title: CALENDAR
description: Dumpling Derby

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Zagat Youth Movement

title: Times Co. to Take Control Of Herald Tribune
description: The New York Times Company has signed a letter of intent to buy out the Washington Post Company's share of The International Herald Tribune, dissolving an unusual 35-year partnership of two of the newspaper industry's leading journalistic rivals.

title: A Reasonable Man Finds His Inner Boulevardier
description: BE reasonable and play it safe. I try to keep those two things in mind. When I started driving, I applied that maxim to the road. Always buckle up. Don't speed (too much). Don't draw too much attention to yourself.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bond Sale Limit May Change
description: Finance Minister Masajuro Shiokawa, left, said that the government might reconsider its 30 trillion yen ($240 billion) limit on new bond sales this year if the government continues efforts to restrict spending and stem the growth of state debt. Mr. Shiokawa suggested last month that the government might break the cap, though it wanted to ''avoid a big deviation'' from the 30 trillion yen limit. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has promised to restrict bond sales but members of his party have urged him to increase state spending to help fuel economic growth.

title: Shark's Pearly Teeth Gnash Near 'The West Wing'
description: Maybe it happened when Lily Tomlin turned up as the ditzy secretary to the President of the United States. Maybe it happened when Toby Ziegler, the communications director, lectured the president -- in Toby's increasingly pompous way -- about how he has to stop trying to prove himself to his long-dead father. Maybe it happened over the summer when nobody was looking, but it happened: ''The West Wing'' jumped the shark.

title: 911 Upgrade Is Said to Aid Batterer Cases
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that new technology to create high-quality digital tapes of 911 calls will help the city's district attorneys prosecute domestic violence cases.

title: International Sex Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: For Assembly and New York City Council
description: For the general election Nov. 5, here are our endorsements for three State Assembly races and one special election for New York City Council.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 911 Upgrade Said To Aid Batterer Cases
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that new technology to create high-quality digital tapes of 911 calls will help the city's district attorneys prosecute domestic violence cases. Often, district attorneys have little evidence to prosecute such cases, and the victims themselves often do not show up at trials. High-quality tapes of calls to 911 could give prosecutors the evidence they need, according to the city's district attorneys, who joined the mayor to announce the program at City Hall. The city recently spent $4 million to upgrade the 911 system. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: If the Pitching Is Poor, Just Place Some Blame on the Ball
description: OnBaseball

title: Brazil's Democracy Takes a Chance
description: The potential contradiction between democracy and markets is nowhere more apparent than in Brazil this month. A leftist candidate, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, known as Lula, won 46 percent of the vote in the first round of Brazil's presidential elections on Oct. 6, twice the share of the next contender, centrist Jos Serra. Current polls show Mr. da Silva poised to win the runoff elections on Oct. 27.

title: Romania, Wooed by U.S., Looks to a Big NATO Role
description: Maybe their next mission will be against Iraq. Maybe it will just be routine naval exercises, aboard warships built in the 1980's to combat the West. Either way, the poor and once-forgotten nation of Romania looks set to join NATO, and the very happy sailors at this Black Sea port have no doubt whom to thank.

title: Van Horn Puts On A Show for Ex-Coach
description: Keith Van Horn drove south last summer with only some regret, trying to leave the bitter words and the better memories in his rearview mirror.

title: An Ancient Odyssey
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pint-Size but Not Puny
description: Small appliances leave elbowroom.

title: Making the 100 Best List
description: A new book offers a survey of 100 product designers, plus Frida Kahlo on the big screen, murals in Jackson Heights and more.

title: Costume Drama
description: The fall couture had all the frenzy, surrealism and artistry of the best Fellini flick.

title: Bengals Reach the Bottom, And They Keep Getting Worse
description: The jokes are now as frequent and bruising as the defeats.

title: Richard Helms, Ex-C.I.A. Chief, Dies at 89
description: Richard Helms, a former director of central intelligence who defiantly guarded some of the darkest secrets of the cold war, died of multiple myeloma today. He was 89.

title: Eileen Simpson, 84, Memoirist Of Life With John Berryman
description: Eileen Simpson, a writer who probed the depths of her difficult early life and, in a well-known memoir, the tumultuous years with her husband John Berryman and their circle of poet friends, died on Monday at a hospital in Manhattan. She was 84.

title: Mammogram Clinic's Flaws Highlight Gaps in U.S. Rules
description: On a Bronx sidewalk bustling with Saturday shoppers, the federal government persuaded Alma Amill to have a mammogram.

title: G.E. TO BUILD LAB IN GERMANY FOR $52 MILLION
description: General Electric said yesterday that it would invest $52 million over the next five years to build its first European research laboratory in Garching, on the outskirts of Munich. The laboratory is expected to employ 150 scientists by 2005. G.E. said the lab would focus on technology development in areas like renewable energy, medical imaging and materials science rather than on fundamental research. G.E. opened its first overseas lab in 2000, in Bangalore, India, and is building another, in Shanghai. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Rangers Play Well, but Simply Not Well Enough to Win
description: For the first time during their four-game homestand, the Rangers gave a strong effort, but still lost.

title: Suspension of Childs Has Nets Concerned
description: When the Nets suspended Chris Childs Tuesday for being grossly out of playing condition, his weight gain -- about 25 pounds -- put a strain on his teammates, most noticeably the man he was supposed to back up, Jason Kidd.

title: Officials Seek Changes in Rules For Sept. 11 Business Program
description: Businesses that were in the World Trade Center should get more money than other businesses from a program granting relief from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, a group of officials said yesterday.

title: Bush's Global Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: ORDERING A PARENT TO DO BETTER

title: Helsinki Journal; Jacks? Dolls? Yo-Yos? No, They Want Cellphones
description: A newspaper here recently printed a cartoon of a baby with a cellphone, notifying his parents that his diaper needed changing.

title: The Vatican Objects
description: Shortly after the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops approved a zero-tolerance policy on sexually abusive priests in Dallas last June, someone asked Bishop Wilton Gregory, the conference president, whether he expected Vatican approval. Said the bishop: ''I would never go to the Holy See assuming I have a slam-dunk.''

title: Citigroup Hurt By Worries That Inquiry Could Widen
description: Executives at Citigroup are racing to resolve the multiple investigations into research practices at its Salomon Smith Barney unit. But they must also contend with the possibility that Jack B. Grubman, the former star telecommunications analyst who is the focus of regulatory and prosecutorial scrutiny, may try to implicate some of his superiors to shift blame for any wrongdoing that may be uncovered. And such a possibility appears to be weighing on Citigroup shares.

title: Life Under Siege
description: ''You can ask me all these questions, Bob, but I do not want to be in your story.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIANDAFILLOU, DR. TITOS, B.S., NYU, D.D.S.
description: TRIANDAFILLOU-Dr. Titos, B.S., NYU, D.D.S., U. of Pennsylvania, 1954. Survived by his loving wife of 48 years, Vasiliki, children, Peter and Terri Triandafillou, Gregory and Sheila Triandis, grandchildren Cathy, Laura, Sean and Nora, brother Menelaus and family. Viewing Thursday, October 24, 2-5 and 7-9 PM Riverdale Funeral Home, Broadway and 214 St, NYC. Funeral Friday, October 25, 11AM Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St.

title: Bush to Consider More S.E.C. Financing
description: The Bush administration said today that it would consider increasing financing for the Securities and Exchange Commission beyond a 30 percent increase that White House officials last week said was enough for the agency.

title: 2 Yugoslav Aides Are Fired for Sales of Fighter-Jet Parts to Iraq
description: Yugoslavia has fired a senior military official and the director of the state trading company Yugoimport as a result of NATO's accusations that a Bosnian Serb company exported military hardware to Iraq via Belgrade.

title: AOL and MSN: Two Paths to Milestone 8
description: YOU can always count on certain reassuring harbingers of autumn: the leaves change, the air becomes cool and crisp, and new versions of America Online and MSN appear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHURE, MICHAEL
description: SHURE - Michael. Mike's goodness and great spirit has been a blessing to my life and will remain with me always. Thank you Mike and Alice for taking me under your wing and all those great times with Grandma Shure, Michael and Tony. With heartfelt sympathy, Laraine Mancini-Unik

title: A Chameleon Shakes The Antiques World
description: ONCE past the receiving line, the well-dressed throngs at last Thursday's opening of the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show occupied themselves with a few choice topics of conversation: Was the Belgian dealer Axel Vervoordt's booth as chic as ever, or had he phoned it in this year? Who would triumph in the defamation lawsuit filed against House & Garden by the famed Paris dealer Ariane Dandois?

title: Charlton Heston And the Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: It Will Be Win, Place . . . and No Snow
description: The Chicago area will be host to its first Breeders' Cup on Saturday -- eight races involving many of the world's best racehorses. The weather forecast is for temperatures close to 50 degrees, and some sun. The racing forecasts are by Joe Drape and Bill Finley, with the horses in the Classic listed in order of predicted finish by Drape. The morning-line odds are provided by Mike Battaglia, the oddsmaker for the Breeders' Cup.

title: Chechens Seize Moscow Theater, Taking as Many as 600 Hostages
description: At least 40 Chechen guerrillas wearing masks and camouflage and firing automatic rifles stormed into a crowded theater in Moscow where a popular musical was playing on Wednesday night, took up to 600 hostages, and threatened to blow up the building.

title: France and Germany Clinch Landmark Deal to Enlarge E.U.
description: France and Germany on Thursday night surprised their European partners when they clinched an unexpected agreement to limit agricultural spending in the European Union after 2006 - breaking a deadlock that threatened to jeopardise the enlargement of the union and cause the collapse of this week's Brussels summit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Chief Silent on Rates; Regions Show Sluggishness

title: Japan Seeks Amnesty for Ex-U.S. Soldier Living in North Korea
description: A Japanese government official has asked the United States to grant a special amnesty to a former American serviceman who is married to a Japanese woman living in North Korea.

title: A Softer Spin on the Mean Season
description: For a brief moment this year, as the nation prepared to commemorate the Sept. 11 attacks, television screens were mostly free of mud-slinging political commercials; some consultants wondered whether good cheer and optimism in advertising were here to stay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, MORRIS
description: BLACK-Morris. October 22, 2002. Age 76, of New York City, loving and devoted husband of Marjorie, loving brother of Eli, beloved stepfather of Russell and Nancy Fuhrer, David and Violaine Fuhrer, Beth and Ian Kraemer. Beloved grandfather of Evan, Noah, Gillian. Cherished uncle of Alan, Warren, Harold and Alan Black. Former Director of Community Services at The Jewish Board of Family and Childrens Services. He inspired and will be deeply missed by all who had the good fortune of knowing him. Funeral Thursday October 24th, 1:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to the Morris Black Community Services Fund at JBFCS, 120 W. 57 St., NY, NY 10019.

title: A Republican Woodstock Endorsement
description: An endorsement of the Woodstock experience is not exactly what one expects from Ken Mehlman, the button-down political director of a conservative White House. But Mr. Mehlman, spinning madly about his party's prospects for regaining control of the Senate, did just that this week at a meeting with reporters.

title: Two Bad Pitches Tie It All Up
description: Francisco Rodriguez sat in the first-base dugout for five minutes and watched the relieved San Francisco Giants congratulate each other after edging the Anaheim Angels, 4-3, in Game 4 of the World Series tonight.

title: Derek Bell, 66, Celtic Harpist of the Chieftains
description: Derek Bell, the versatile harpist with the Chieftains, one of the most celebrated Irish traditional bands, died on Oct. 15 in his hotel in Phoenix. He was 66 and lived in Belfast.

title: AOL to Restate Troubled Unit's Revenue Again, Vexing Wall St.
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had turned up several additional improper transactions at its AOL division, broadening the extent of its acknowledged accounting problems and restating its reported revenue down by $190 million over a two-year period that ended this summer.

title: Mostly Sprawling and Warmer; Scientists Factor Land Use Into New Jersey's Climate
description: Scientists who study climate change can sometimes sound as if they have their heads in the clouds, with all the talk of invisible gases and nefarious hydrocarbons. Here, the search for atmospheric explanation is more down to earth.

title: Charlton Heston And the Sniper
description: o the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Debate
description: The Bank of England shifted toward lowering interest rates last month with three of the nine members on the monetary policy committee endorsing a cut of 0.25 percentage points, according to minutes of the panel's meeting. Britain's benchmark interest rate is at a 38-year low of 4 percent, even though the economy has survived the global downturn more successfully than elsewhere in Europe. But with economists calculating growth of only 0.6 percent for each of the last two quarters, the chance of a rate cut has increased amid fears of a slowdown in the global recovery. In previous months policy makers debated lowering rates but voted unanimously to keep them on hold. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ROSE
description: HARRIS-Rose. On October 22nd, 2002. Beloved sister of Miriam. Service Thursday, 11AM, Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, New Jersey.

title: Democratic Party Accuses G.O.P. Of Intimidating Arkansas Voters
description: National Democratic officials said today that Republicans had tried to intimidate black voters during early balloting in Arkansas. The accusation, denied by Republicans, together with other voting incidents, is a sign of the close scrutiny both parties say they are planning for voting procedures in the first national election after the Florida turmoil two years ago.

title: Ex-Mistress Defends Credibility at Rabbi's Trial
description: The former mistress of the South Jersey rabbi charged with arranging his wife's murder tried to fend off defense attacks on her credibility today as she completed two days of testimony in the rabbi's second trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKE, CHARLES L.
description: FRANKE-Charles L. Age 87, of Scarsdale, NY, on October 23, 2002. A native New Yorker, joined ABC Television in its infancy in 1959, retired in 1983. Formerly a journalist and a Paramount publicist.

title: Israel Arrests Officer As a Hezbollah Spy
description: The Israeli authorities said they had arrested a lieutenant colonel in the army on suspicion of spying for the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah. The officer is being held along with nine other suspects, all of the Bedouin minority.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, MORTON LAWRENCE, M.D.
description: ROSENTHAL-Morton Lawrence, M.D. Beloved husband of Bernardine, devoted father of Jeanne (Perry), Karen (Steve), and Benjamin (Susan), grandfather of Michael, Katy, Julie, Anne, and William, brother of J. Robert (Gladys) and the late Gerald (Gloria), brother-in-law of Marie and Richard, Lorraine and Al, and Dorothy and Donald, uncle, great uncle, friend. Physician, surgeon, teacher, musician, sailor, champion of the underdog. He was a man of endless curiosity, boundless intellect, passion, courage, humor and vision. A physician since 1952, he founded The Retina Service at The New York Eye and Ear Infirmary in 1958, the first of its kind in New York City, and was Chief of The Service until 1995. He also served at The Infirmary as Surgeon Director in The Department of Ophthalmology, Chairman of The Medical Board, Member of The Board of Directors, and teacher and mentor of countless residents and fellows. Memorial service Thursday, October 24, 2002, 2-4 P.M. at The Knickerbocker Yacht Club, 433 Main Street, Port Washington, NY, 516-883-7655. ''Two roads diverged in a wood, and I-I took the one less travelled by and that has made all the difference.''

title: Police Questioning Man and Boy at an Undisclosed Location
description: MEYERSVILLE, MD., Oct. 24  The Maryland police arrested a man and a 17-year-old boy found sleeping in a car at a rest stop here early today in connection with the sniper attacks that have killed 10 people since Oct. 2.

title: U.S. Labels Indonesian Faction as Terrorist
