description: The United States today formally declared a Southeast Asian radical Islamic group suspected by the Bush administration of involvement in the Bali bombing to be a foreign terrorist organization.

title: U.S. Asks Enron for Details On Dealings Involving Iran
description: The Treasury Department has directed Enron to provide information about deals the company did in the late 1990's involving products that originated in Iran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIKYAN, KENT R., JR.
description: COSTIKYAN-Kent R., Jr. Of South Norwalk, CT, on October 21, 2002, aboard his sailboat in Norfolk, VA. Beloved father to Kent R. III, Timothy, and Warren, stepfather to Elisabeth Worthington Ruyter, Andrew Burris Jenkins, Andrea Georgia Jenkins, Susan Delatour Cary. Husband to the late Elisabeth Delatour Costikyan, and brother to Thomas Wilson Costikyan. Kent was a graduate of The Hotchkiss School and Yale University, Class of 1948. He was an avid racing and cruising sailor. He passed following a final run south down The Chesapeake Bay. A celebration of his life will be held at 1 P.M. Sunday October 27, 2002 at Saint Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Quebec-Labrador Foundation/Atlantic Center For The Environment, 55 South Main Street, Ipswich, MA 01938.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Aluminum Unit Acquired
description: The British-Dutch company Corus Group has agreed to sell the majority of its aluminum division to the French concern Pechiney, the two companies said. Corus, one of the largest steel manufacturers in Europe, said the sale price was 861 million euros ($842 million), but Pechiney said it expected to pay only 750 million euros after reductions for pension liabilities and debt. The sale involves industrial sites in Germany and Belgium along with majority stakes at sites in Canada and China, representing 1.5 billion euros in sales and more than 4,600 employees. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLMAN, WILLIAM M.
description: HOLMAN-William M. On October 20, 2002. Husband of Jane Holman (nee Steane) of Madison. Father of Christopher A. of Cambridge, MA, Gordon M. of Portland ME, Andrew C. of Somerville, MA, Whitney H. Bauer of Middletown, RI, William M. Holman Jr. of Lake Forest IL, Lindsey H. Swift of St. Louis, MO. Also surviving are his parents John and Susan Holman of Maplewood, NJ, and 9 grandchildren. A brother John W. Holman Jr. of OR. and NYC. Four nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 24, 2002 at 7;30 P.M. at the Chatham Township Presbyterian Church, 240 Southern Blvd., Chatham Township, NJ. Those who wish may donate in his memory to the National Cancer Institute, Financial Management Branch, Bld. 31 Rm. 11A-16, 9000 Rockville Pike, Bethesda, MD 20892. Please make note in memo portion: Pancreatic/Wm. M. Holman.

title: It's Not Just the Action, It's Also the Whoosh
description: In baseball a la Fox, replays must be introduced with a whoosh and then bid adieu with a whoosh. The network's executives decided one day several years ago that a whoosh, not a police siren or bars from the "Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?" theme song, was needed to help viewers distinguish between past action and live action.

title: Wider Use Is Seen For Sleepiness Drug; Tests Said to Go Well
description: Cephalon announced yesterday that its drug Provigil had reduced sleepiness in night-shift workers in a clinical trial. The biotechnology company said that based on the results, it planned by the end of the year to ask the Food and Drug Administration to vastly expand the approved uses of the drug.

title: This Is the House The Book Bought
description: EVEN during the summer, the novelist Michael Cunningham was talking about fall in this Cape Cod town. In October, when the tourists and drag queens thin out, and the slanting sunlight floods the town with reds and yellows, it is folly to try to get anything done. It is enough to make a working writer eager for the premature winter blight of Cape Cod in November.

title: Knicks Extend Olive Branch, And Sprewell Rejoins Team
description: Latrell Sprewell may be weeks away from being healthy enough to get on a basketball court, but he finally sat on the sideline as the Knicks practiced today. After two weeks of fines, suspensions and charged words, this amounted to a truce between the beleaguered team and its best player.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: A Pamphlet Takes Sides
description: A handful of Roman Catholic churches have distributed fliers criticizing the Democratic candidate for governor, Bill Richardson, for his support of abortion rights. But the Archdiocese of Santa Fe said it never meant to inject itself into the campaign. The flier, sponsored by Right To Life of New Mexico, says Mr. Richardson has a record that ''shows a lack of respect for human life.'' It characterized his Republican opponent, John Sanchez, as an anti-abortion candidate. The archdiocese said it never meant for the pamphlet to serve as an endorsement. Right to Life of New Mexico endorsed Mr. Sanchez in August. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOUSE, JANICE M.
description: CLOUSE-Janice M. Of Port Washington, New York. Died on October 17, 2002. Age 61. of a heart attack complicated by Juvenile Diabetes. Janice graduated from the University of Massachusetts and also had an advanced education degree from California State University. Janice was born in Pittsfield, Mass. of Fred and Phyllis Jones. She is survived by her brother, Steven Jones and her adoring husband John. Reposing at Fairchild Sons Inc, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, N.Y. 11030 on Friday, October 25, 2002, 3 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Funeral private.

title: DaimlerChrysler Has Big Profit Gain, but Is Pessimistic
description: DaimlerChrysler said today that net income more than tripled during the third quarter because of aggressive cost-cutting at Chrysler and elsewhere in its operations. But it issued a pessimistic forecast for sales of cars and light trucks in the United States next year, blaming economic and political uncertainty.

title: BANK ONE TO HIRE UP TO 100 PEOPLE IN CAPITAL MARKETS
description: The Bank One Corporation, which has been laying off bankers who make loans to large companies, will hire as many as 100 employees in capital markets trading, sales and research starting next year to increase its market share in areas like bond underwriting. ''As other institutions are cutting, we have an opportunity to pick up some really great people,'' David Schabes, chairman of Banc One Capital Markets, said. Bank One will start hiring in January, he said. Bank One's corporate banking unit, including capital markets, had 2,306 employees at the end of the third quarter, a 17 percent decline from a year earlier. Bank One is based in Chicago.

title: Mostly Sprawling and Warmer
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Scientists who study climate change can sometimes sound as if they have their heads in the clouds, with all the talk of invisible gases and nefarious hydrocarbons. Here, the search for atmospheric explanation is more down to earth.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Troops To Stay In Macedonia
description: Parliament approved an extension of the mandate for German troops serving with NATO's peacekeeping mission in Macedonia. The deployment of 220 German soldiers in the 700-member force, set to expire on Saturday, was extended through Dec. 15 with support from all major parties. The NATO mission was sent to Macedonia in 2001 to oversee a fragile peace agreement that ended six months of fighting between ethnic Albanian guerrillas and Macedonian government forces. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Wary Companies Are Staying in the Muslim World
description: Despite the apparently globe-girdling reach of Islamic terror groups, some of the biggest Western multinational corporations are holding fast to their investments in most Muslim countries.

title: Giants Find Fault With Perfect Reliever
description: As Francisco Rodriguez warmed up for the bottom of the eighth inning at Pacific Bell Park tonight, the scoreboard showed something called a Sound Level Meter. As the crowd roared, the numbers climbed: 96, 98, 106 decibels. Rodriguez calmly went about his practice pitches. Nothing had fazed him yet, and it seemed as if nothing would.

title: Study Favors Aspirin Use For Patients Having Bypass
description: Giving patients aspirin in the first 48 hours after heart bypass surgery can greatly reduce their risk of death and serious complications involving the heart, brain, kidneys and digestive tract, doctors are reporting today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Tuesday about the arrival of a statue of Albert Einstein at the American Museum of Natural History for an exhibition opening Nov. 15 misspelled the sculptor's surname. He is Robert Berks, not Berk.

title: Color Prints, Laser-Tweaked and Sharper Than Ever
description: IN the days before digital cameras and inkjet printers, photographic prints were made by exposing chemically treated paper to light, then bathing it in vats of yet more chemicals. Photo imaging has come a long way, but the route to stunning images still ends with the exposure of special paper to light and chemicals. The difference is this time the light is not from an ordinary bulb, but from color lasers in the most advanced digital commercial film printers.

title: On the Trail of Childhood Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Offers a New Design for Mideast Peace
description: A Bush administration envoy arrived here today in an effort to persuade Israeli and Palestinian leaders to accept an evolving American ''road map'' for achieving peace and establishing a Palestinian state by 2005.

title: Free, Fast Browser in a Box Does More Than Simply Search
description: The chief virtue of GoBox, the free all-in-one search tool developed by a teenage programmer in New Mexico, is not just that it does a wide array of tasks. It also works at rapid speed, without the invasive accouterments of many downloadable tools.

title: A Harder Game of Solitaire
description: To the Editor:

title: Someone Besides Bonds Finally Comes Through
description: Benito Santiago had fallen into the trap. The Giants had fallen behind in the World Series because they had been unable to complement the record-setting performance of Barry Bonds.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Back on the Same Side

title: At the Author's Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: War Emblem a Surprise As Cup Classic Favorite
description: He is the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Haskell champion returning to his home track for the final race of his career, which apparently was enough for the oddsmaker Mike Battaglia to make War Emblem a surprising 3-1 favorite today in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic, the marquee competition among Saturday's eight championship races.

title: Guilty Plea Is Expected From Trader
description: John M. Rusnak, the Baltimore currency trader who is accused of hiding losses of $691 million at Allfirst Financial for five years, will plead guilty today to bank fraud charges.

title: Giants Find Fault With Perfect Reliever
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23  As Francisco Rodriguez warmed up for the bottom of the eighth inning at Pacific Bell Park tonight, the scoreboard showed something called a Sound Level Meter. As the crowd roared, the numbers climbed: 96, 98, 106 decibels. Rodriguez calmly went about his practice pitches. Nothing had fazed him yet, and it seemed as if nothing would.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: 19 Accused Of Drug Offenses
description: Nineteen people, most of them from Long Island, have been arrested on narcotics and money-laundering charges. Roslynn R. Mauskopf, the United States attorney in Brooklyn, said yesterday that the charges dismantled a ring that smuggled five kilograms of cocaine a week into the New York area. Among those charged was Gene Seymour, a co-owner of the Powerhouse Gym in Garden City, which prosecutors said was used as a distribution base, and Shahram Zarnighian, an owner of Royal Palace, a luxury car dealership in Great Neck, which the prosecutors said sold luxury cars to the drug traffickers in exchange for drug profits. According to the prosecutors, a Uniondale man they identified as the leader of the ring, Marcel Sejour, said during wiretapped conversations that he obtained the drugs from Haitian officials who had seized the drugs from Haitian dealers. William Glaberson (NYT)

title: Act to Reduce the Truck-Bomb Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Plane From Russia Is Searched After a Tip
description: Acting on a tip from Russia that a New York-bound jetliner might have radioactive material aboard, the authorities yesterday met the plane from Moscow on the tarmac at Kennedy International airport, but nothing harmful was found, officials said.

title: For Want of a Small Slam, A Shot at a Cup Was Lost
description: The result of the Rosenblum Cup in Montreal in August hung on some very slender threads. Italy, the eventual winners, defeated Sweden by 21 imps in the semifinal, but the result could easily have been different. And Poland lost to Indonesia by 15 after suffering a sad blow on the diagramed deal from the final session.

title: The Disgrace of Juvenile Executions
description: Last June the Supreme Court barred the execution of the mentally retarded as cruel and unusual punishment, noting that such criminals have limited capacity to understand their moral culpability or be deterred by the threat of execution. This week, sadly, the court declined to extend that same reasoning to juveniles. In rejecting the appeal of a death row inmate in Kentucky, the court's majority dashed hopes of overturning its appalling 1989 ruling permitting executions of those who are 16 or 17 when they commit capital crimes.

title: Police Name Man Being Sought For Questioning in Sniper Case
description: The manhunt for the roving suburban sniper focused on two men being sought by the police tonight as key witnesses who were reported on the run and the subjects of an intensive East Coast dragnet.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GREECE: EFFORT TO AVOID CLASH ON CYPRUS Foreign Ministry officials said Greece might call off war games planned for next week on Cyprus, fearing an accidental clash with Turkish forces also planning exercises there. Cyprus, which is expected to join the European Union by 2004, has been divided since 1974, when Turkish troops invaded and occupied its north. Turkey has not yet responded to the Greek plea. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Pass Rush Concerns Edwards And Jets
description: Perhaps Damien Robinson was merely ahead of the curve.

title: Historians Are Doing the Mambo; After Decades, Latin Jazz Develops Its Own Academic Canon
description: By one measure, the invention of Latin jazz could be dated to 1940, when Machito Grillo started his band, the Afro-Cubans, here in New York City. Before long he would be famous for his glorious combinations of jazz harmony and phrasing with Cuban percussion. By another, it could go back farther, to W. C. Handy's composing ''St. Louis Blues'' over a habanera rhythm. Or to Louis Armstrong's recorded version of ''El Manisero'' (''The Peanut Vendor''). Or to the early years of the century in New Orleans, when Cuban and African and Creole cultures mixed so effectively.

title: Cancer Risk Of Hormones May Linger
description: Scientific evidence has not shown that women can avoid the breast cancer risk from hormone replacement therapy by taking the drugs for only a short time, researchers said today. It also has not shown that the risk disappears as soon as the drugs are stopped.

title: Bush Campaigns for Senate Candidates in the Carolinas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Bush traveled to the Carolinas today to campaign for Republican Senate candidates, one of whom is married to a former political rival of his father.

title: What Would Be Best? Area's Parents Are Split
description: In the secrecy bestowed by trees and early-morning darkness, a boys' soccer team practiced for the first time in weeks today, not in its usual place but on the campus of a small Virginia college. The boys' frustration that the sniper had forced them to cancel practices had boiled over, but the team did not want league officials who had ordered the cancellations to find out.

title: Seoul to Urge Talks to Deal With A-Arms In North Korea
description: President Kim Dae Jung today signaled the conciliatory approach that aides said he would advocate when he discusses the North Korean nuclear threat on Saturday in Mexico with President Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SOROS FUND MANAGEMENT, New York, said it would invest $150 million in the telephone book unit of Qwest Communications International, Denver. The unit is being bought by Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, New York, a venture capital firm, and the Carlyle Group, Washington, a private equity firm.

title: Corrections
description: A list of stores last Thursday with an article about the renewed popularity of such ''bohemian'' furnishings as beaded curtains, paisley lanterns and fringed lamp shades misstated the name of the town in New Jersey where one store, Sojourner, is located. It is Lambertville, not Lambertsville.

title: Payoff = Points:A False Equation
description: WAGNER JAMES AU, a 35-year-old journalist from San Francisco, has been playing video games since he was 9, when Space Invaders and Battlezone were about as cutting-edge as games got. These days, though, Mr. Au's tastes are more discerning: instead of playing first-person shooter games, in which winning is only about getting the highest score, he finds himself gravitating toward more complex games like Grand Theft Auto and Planescape: Torment.

title: Hicks Nix Blix Fix
description: North Korea proudly announced in 1994 that it had begun withdrawing plutonium-rich fuel rods from one of its nuclear reactors, which the world knew would enable the Stalinist government to build a half-dozen bombs. Coupled with its threat to turn South Korea's capital, Seoul, into ''a sea of fire,'' this threat to the nonproliferation treaty deeply worried Bill Clinton's Pentagon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Executive Joins Planning Agency
description: The City Council yesterday approved the appointment of Dolly Williams, an executive at A. Williams Construction in Brooklyn, to the City Planning Commission. Ms. Williams, who was appointed by the Brooklyn borough president, Marty Markowitz, is to complete the remainder of a term expiring in June, 2007. She has worked on several public construction and excavation projects, including Kennedy Airport, and the Bronx Criminal Court complex.

title: Two Writers Under One Roof
description: Being married to a writer is hell.

title: At Forum, Victims of Clergy Plead and Vent
description: After being raped by a priest on Easter Sunday at age 13, having his lawsuit against the Roman Catholic Church thrown out and fighting a $4,000 lien on his house over court costs, Joseph Cerniglia admits that his expectations have dwindled over time. All he really wants now is a phone call.

title: A Vitriolic Saudi Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hotels.com 3rd-Quarter Profit Surged
description: Hotels.com's third-quarter earnings surged to $22.6 million as the company, a seller of discounted hotel reservations on other companies' Internet sites, increased sales and benefited from bookings on its new Web page. Net income rose to 39 cents a share, from $1.6 million, or 3 cents, a year earlier, the company said yesterday. Sales jumped 83 percent, to $277.4 million from $151.2 million. The company, which changed its name in April from Hotel Reservations Network Inc., said 20 percent of its revenue came from a Web site introduced in the first quarter. Excluding some expenses, the company said profit would have been 45 cents a share. On that basis, which is not in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected 42 cents. Shares of the Dallas-based company rose $2.05, or 3.6 percent, to $58.81. The stock has climbed 28 percent this year.

title: Longshoremen Accused of Slowdown in West
description: The association of West Coast port operators said yesterday that it had complained to the Justice Department that the dock workers were engaging in a ''concerted, systematic work slowdown.''

title: Iran Conducts A Crackdown On Prostitution
description: The police have arrested 243 members of five ''corruption networks'' and a 74-year-old woman who they said had lured hundreds of young women into her brothel, the Entekhab newspaper reported today.

title: President Pledges Full Resources of Government in Sniper Hunt
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 — Led by President Bush, administration officials pledged the full resources of the federal government today in capturing what Mr. Bush called "a ruthless person on the loose," and mounted an aggressive defense of how the investigation is being run.

title: Carol Channing, Back Where She Belongs
description: Carol Channing was back on Broadway the other night. No, not the bright lights of a stage but, fittingly, at Joe Franklin's Memory Lane Restaurant and Bar on 45th Street and Eighth Avenue. She was there to promote her book "Just Lucky I Guess" (Simon & Schuster)," her own personal walk down memory lane about her career and personal life.

title: Dangerous Foods
description: To the Editor:

title: Classical Pianists Rock, In a Manner of Speaking
description: Just below the faint image of a skull and the legend ''Rock Hotel Presents,'' an advertisement that has appeared around New York and on the Internet lately promises ''the future of classical music, in your face like never before.'' Surrounding the skull, the copy reads ''New Music -- Extraordinary Programs'' and ''The Greatest Pianists in the World -- on Their Own Terms.''

title: Tyco Says It Lost $1.75 Billion and Will Restate Earnings
description: Tyco International reported today that it lost $1.75 billion in its fiscal fourth quarter, and the troubled company said it had restated its financial results for the first nine months of its fiscal year primarily because of accounting practices at its ADT alarm-system business.

title: Lucent Narrows Quarter Loss; Revenue Decreases Further
description: Lucent Technologies, the communications equipment maker, reported its 10th consecutive quarterly loss yesterday after sales plunged 23 percent from the previous quarter and more than 50 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL GETS U.S. PROPOSAL ON DISARMING IRAQ
description: The United States formally presented the full Security Council today with a draft resolution that includes a threat of military action against Iraq, sharply increasing the pressure on France, Russia and China to agree to a tough measure to force Baghdad to disarm.

title: The Giants Are Healing In Time for the Eagles
description: Pain resides in Will Peterson and Jeremy Shockey, and whether the discomfort is dull and manageable or excruciating, each will try to press forward in the name of playoff contention.

title: Proposed Council District Map Reflects Population Shifts
description: After months of public hearings and private wrangling, a government commission took a first stab yesterday at a new map of City Council districts, redrawn to reflect a decade of population shifts in New York City's neighborhoods, and the underlying ethnic politics.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about an exhibition on the Austrian designer Dagobert Peche at the Neue Galerie in Manhattan misspelled the surname of a contemporary whose work was cited as a contrast. He was Gustav Klimt, not Klimpt.

title: Peso's Devaluation Gives Argentina Cost Advantages
description: Over the last six months, Andres Prieto, president of the Argentine subsidiary of Oracle, has been doing something highly unexpected here: hiring, not firing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERYAZOS, MARIELLE (NEE GOHIER)
description: TERYAZOS-Marielle (nee Gohier). At the Montreal Neurological Institute of Montreal. Died on Wednesday, October 23rd, 2002 at the age of 83. Mother of Robert Hackett and of the late John Hackett. Grandmother of Sophie Hackett, Nadia Hackett, Guy Hackett, Alexander Hackett and Amanda Abreu-Hackett. Mother-in-law of Colette Lavoie and Susana Abreu. Sister of Madeliene de Brantes. Visitation at Mount Royal Funeral Complex, 1297 Chemin de la Foret, Outremont (514-279-6540), on Friday, October 25th from 5:00 PM to 9:00 PM. Funeral at St. Leon de Westmount on Saturday at 11:00 AM.

title: G.M. Gets Criticism for Backing Tour of Christian Music Performers
description: Leaders of two religious organizations are questioning Chevrolet's sponsorship of a concert and prayer tour aimed at evangelical Christians, complaining that big consumer marketers should not identify themselves so closely with one faith.

title: Broadway Goes Digital
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Selects Poet For Arts Position
description: President Bush yesterday announced his intention to nominate the poet, critic and anthologist Dana Gioia to be chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. If confirmed by the Senate for the four-year term, Mr. Gioia, 51, the author of three books of poetry and a winner of the American Book Award, would succeed Michael P. Hammond, who died in January after a week in the post.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELMS, THE HONORABLE RICHARD M.
description: HELMS - The Honorable Richard M., 89, on Wednesday, October 23, 2002, at his residence in Washington D.C. Dear husband and friend of Cynthia R. Helms. Father of Dennis and grandfather of Julia and Alexander. Brother of Betty Helms Hawn, Pearsael Helms and Gates Helms. Stepfather of Didi Anderson, Jill McKelvie Neilsen, Roderick McKelvie, Allan McKelvie and Lindsay McKelvie Eakin and step-grandfather of 15 grandchildren. Service and burial at Arlington Cemetery mid-November, date and time to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to CIA Memorial Foundation, created to provide benefits to the families of agents of the CIA killed in the line of duty, c/o Jeffrey H. Smith, Esq., Arnold & Porter, 555 12th St. N.W., Washington DC 20004, or Community Hospices, Hospice of Washington, 4200 Wisconsin Avenue N.W., Washington, DC 20016.

title: Inquiry Expands to Yard in Northwest
description: After a full day's search for shell casings or other ammunition in the backyard of a duplex in the south part of this town today, federal officials refused to say if they had found any evidence that might help to solve the East Coast sniper case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYTTLE, ADA
description: LYTTLE-Ada, beloved sister of Joan Birman, Helen Kimmel and the late Ruth Satter; sister-in-law of Joseph L. Birman, Robert Satter and Martin Kimmel; aunt and greataunt died at age 71 on October 23, 2002. She retired to a life of quiet dignity after a long career as a schoolteacher in New York City. Service Friday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. & Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to the Museum of American Folk Art, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-20

title: Technology Briefing: Biotechnology
description: AMGEN POSTS $2.6 BILLION LOSS Amgen Inc. the world's largest biotechnology company, reported a steep third-quarter loss yesterday as acquisition-related costs offset higher drug sales. The company, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., said its net loss was $2.6 billion, or $2.10 a share, after a $3 billion charge related to the acquisition in July of the Immunex Corporation; that is in contrast to net income of $330 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding one-time charges, Amgen said earnings rose 32 percent, to $437 million, falling within the range of analysts' expectations. Amgen said its quarterly product sales rose 53 percent, to $1.3 billion, benefiting from the Immunex deal and the introduction of new products. The company projected product sales growth in the high 30 percent range for the full year and said earnings per share, excluding one-time items, would grow at a mid-teens rate. Amgen said it still expected combined sales of Epogen and Aranesp to grow this year in the low 20 percent range compared with 2001, but it raised guidance for Neupogen/Neulasta sales to a range of 32 percent to 34 percent compared with previous guidance of about 25 percent growth. (Reuters)

title: On the Trail of Childhood Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: 1 Kitchen, 2 Rehab Recipes
description: WHEN I met my friend Natalie Green four years ago, we quickly discovered how weirdly synchronized our major life events had been. We attended the same high school, married men with copper-colored hair, first gave birth in October 1997 and, a few months after that, moved into loft apartments in the same Brooklyn Heights co-op.

title: Pint-Size but Not Puny
description: YOUR home may be cramped, but that doesn't mean you have to haul clothes to a Laundromat or serve dinner on paper plates. Small appliances, commonplace in Europe, are now catching on here. If you live in a studio, you can run a dishwasher or cook a casserole and still have counter space left over. These mini-amenities also work nicely in a guest suite or boat.

title: A Mouse That Soars Without a Cord, Far From the PC
description: It's a bird! A plane! It's a computer mouse? Yes. The Ultra Cordless Optical Mouse from Gyration can be used in the air, up to 25 feet from a receiver plugged into a computer's U.S.B. port. Using a gyroscope, motion-sensing technology and a proprietary radio-frequency protocol, the dark blue, bullet-shaped device needs no surface -- or red cape. Users must hold down a button to activate the airborne capability.

title: Bugs and Dust Balls: A 'Clean' Installation
description: IF you want to upgrade your computer's memory and operating system and you are doing it yourself, you will need a telephone, a vacuum cleaner and superhuman patience. The rest depends on your computer's configuration. (More on the required items in a moment.)

title: Private Art Collections
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul's leader keeps to soft line on North
description: SEOUL:  President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea pursued a soft-line approach Wednesday to dealing with the North Korean nuclear threat, rejecting an economic or military response as he prepared for a summit meeting in Mexico with President George W. Bush and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan.

title: A Crime-Weary France Plans a Crackdown
description: Squatters who occupy private land will face prison terms. ''Passive soliciting'' by prostitutes will become a crime. Beggars and Gypsies will be banned from using pressure tactics and working in groups.

title: Boris Becker, a Tennis Bad Boy, Faces Prison in German Tax Case
description: Boris Becker, the onetime tennis wunderkind whose star has been dimmed by scandal, could face three and a half years in jail on charges of tax evasion, in a trial that began today in Munich.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Charges Filed Against Putin Critic
description: Prosecutors charged the financier Boris A. Berezovsky, left, and a business aide with defrauding Russia's largest automobile company, Avtovaz, of 2,000 cars worth more than $15 million in 1994 and 1995 through a dealership Mr. Berezovsky founded. Deputy Prosecutor General Vladimir Kolesnikov said that a second Berezovsky associate would also be charged, and that he expected that Mr. Berezovsky would be extradited from London, where he lives in self-imposed exile. Mr. Berezovsky, a fierce political critic of President Vladimir V. Putin, shrugged off the charge. ''They are making it up,'' he told the Moscow radio station Ekho Moskvy in a telephone interview. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Bahrain's Women Take a Step Toward Political Power
description: Barely 36 hours before the polls were set to open, Amal al-Zayani, a political scientist by training and a scion of one of the country's wealthiest families, paced in and out of her campaign headquarters: a canvas tent on an empty sandy lot in a affluent section of the capital. Carpets were spread on the bare ground, chairs lined the walls, cake and coffee were laid out for the would-be voters who trickled in all evening.

title: Israel Accuses Army Officer Of Spying For Hezbollah
description: The Israeli authorities said today that they had arrested a lieutenant colonel in the army on suspicion of spying for the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah.

title: A Palmtop For the Prosecution
description: THE Sony Cli was as good a smoking gun as investigators could get in a white-collar crime.

title: California and Computers In Two Murder Mysteries
description: CHASING THE DIME

title: Grubman Gets Jail Sentence And Scolding From the Judge
description: The judge likened the case to Greek tragedy. But the sentence was somewhat less than Sophoclean: 60 days in the Suffolk County jail for Elizabeth S. Grubman, the Manhattan publicist who provided the material for a tabloid morality play by backing a car into a group of Hamptons clubgoers two summers ago.

title: Say Cheese: A Slideshow Starring You As Narrator
description: Given that Olympus has long been involved with both compact voice recorders and cameras, its latest offering was perhaps inevitable: the W-10 digital voice recorder includes a tiny digital camera.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the economic impact of casinos on Tunica, Miss., misstated the given name of Tunica's mayor. He is Bobby E. Williams, not Billy. The article also misstated the capacity of a planned airport. While it could accommodate Boeing 747's, it is being designed to handle 727's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSEN, GUSTAV H. ''PETER''
description: PETERSEN-Gustav H. ''Peter'' died at home on October 19, 2002. His family, relatives and friends know that, ''in the variety of God's creations, Peter will be the wonder for us all.''

title: Rifle Found Uses Same Type of Bullets Linked to Shootings
description: MYERSVILLE, Md., Oct. 24 - The Maryland police arrested a man and a 17-year-old boy found sleeping in a car at a rest stop here early today in connection with the sniper attacks that have left 10 people dead and 3 injured since Oct. 2. They also recovered a rifle that uses the type of ammunition linked to the sniper attacks.

title: 2 Drug Giants To Restore Big Discounts For Elderly
description: Two major drug companies said yesterday that they would return to the original, deeper discounts that they had been offering to low-income elderly people after they received a letter from the Bush administration stating that the government would not try to demand similar low prices.

title: Lawyers for Detainee Ask Judge Not to Review Classified Papers
description: Lawyers for Jose Padilla, the former Chicago gang member who has been accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States, have asked a federal judge in New York not to review a classified document that is said to lay out the evidence against Mr. Padilla because prosecutors have refused to show it to the defense.

title: Tyco Restating Results $125 Million Lower
description: Tyco International is planning to restate earnings for its last fiscal year after a team of forensic accountants discovered the company overstated its results by about $125 million at its ADT alarm-system business, executives briefed on the accounting irregularities said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Wednesday about the United States' use of unmanned planes over the deserts of Yemen to search for Al Qaeda fugitives omitted part of the last sentence in some copies. It should have read, ''The suicide attack on the Cole, which killed 17 sailors, was made with a small boat believed to have been purchased in Jizan, Saudi Arabia.''

title: With Israeli Army Pledge, a Palestinian Village's People Return
description: Palestinian families who abandoned the West Bank village of Khirbat Yanun last week because of persistent harassment by Jewish settlers have returned home, and the Israeli Army said today that it would protect them.

title: Worldwide servers overwhelmed with data : Attack briefly disrupts Net
description: An unusually powerful, coordinated attack on the 13 computers around the world that act as the backbone of the Internet briefly crippled more than half of them, but because of the built-in workarounds in the system, few Internet users likely even noticed.

title: Jacks? Dolls? Yo-Yos? No, They Want Cellphones
description: HELSINKI, Oct. 17  A newspaper here recently printed a cartoon of a baby with a cellphone, notifying his parents that his diaper needed changing.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba Reports Smaller 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Ariba Inc., whose software lets companies purchase goods on the Internet, yesterday reported a smaller fourth-quarter loss as it pared operating expenses. The shares fell 13 percent. The net loss narrowed to $142.5 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30 from a loss of $224.3 million, or 89 cents, a year earlier, Ariba said. Sales fell 7 percent, to $58.2 million from $62.7 million and will be flat to little higher this quarter, the company said. Ariba expects revenue in the quarter ending in December to be flat to up slightly from the $55.3 million it reported a year earlier, the chief financial officer, James Frankola, said. The company expects profit, excluding some costs, to be 1 cent to 2 cents a share, he said. Ariba is expected to have revenue of $58.8 million, the average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Ariba fell 33 cents, or 13 percent, to $2.13.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: DARIEN: MAN KILLED BY TRAIN

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: On the Trail of Childhood Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Serono Reports Profit Increase
description: Europe's largest biotechnology company, Serono, said its profit rose 17 percent in the third quarter and it was on target to meet its goal of a 10 percent net profit rise for the year. Sales rose 18 percent in the quarter, while sales of the multiple sclerosis drug Rebif, which accounts for more than half of the company's product sales, rose 46 percent to $139.4 million. Shares in Serono rose 11 percent in Swiss trading, to 780 Swiss francs. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, VINCENT T.
description: SMITH-Vincent T., 83. Of Gilgo Beach, L.I., New York, (formerly of New York City), on October 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Madeline ''Dot''. Loving father of Cheryl Lauder and Adrienne Smith. Devoted grandfather of Craig (Kathy), Scott (Tammi), Todd Lauder (Peggy) and great-grandfather of Mackenzie and Stephanie Lauder. Dear brother of Arthur Smith. Friends may visit Friday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 P.M., at the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main Street, Babylon, L.I. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 A.M., at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Wednesday about the United States' use of unmanned planes over the deserts of Yemen to search for Al Qaeda fugitives omitted part of the last sentence in some copies. It should have read, "The suicide attack on the Cole, which killed 17 sailors, was made with a small boat believed to have been purchased in Jizan, Saudi Arabia."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGSTEIN, ALAN
description: BERGSTEIN - Alan. The Board of Directors, staff and members of the Greater Five Towns YM & YWHA mourn the passing of our former Board President, Alan Bergstein, a dedicated supporter of our organization over many years. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire family. Carol Harrison, President Cy Leslie, Founding President Rina Shkolnik, Exec. Director

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Dies After Car Crash
description: A man was killed Tuesday night in Queens when a car that the police said was stolen slammed into his car, propelling him out of the driver's seat and onto the pavement at 173rd Street and Linden Boulevard. The victim, Kevin Fisher, 35, of Rosedale, Queens, was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The other driver and his passenger were in what the police said was a 1991 Lexus sedan that was stolen in New Jersey on Sept. 26. The driver, Robert Pearson, 23, and his passenger, Conrad Lloyd, 28, both of Ozone Park, were taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, where they were in critical but stable condition. Mr. Pearson was charged with manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and criminal possession of stolen property. Mr. Lloyd was also charged with possession of stolen property. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: City Schools Announce Plan To Add 285 Security Guards
description: One day after a student was stabbed in a high school in Queens, school officials announced plans yesterday to place 285 additional security guards in schools in the next two months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOVAN, GENEVIEVE KELLER
description: DONOVAN-Genevieve Keller, 83. A resident of Short Hills, NJ and Delray Beach, FL, died at Lutheran Medical Center, Brooklyn, NY October 20, 2002. Born in Geddes, SD 1919, raised in Yankton, SD, she was a graduate of the University of South Dakota ('40) and was a member of Pi Beta Phi sorority. She is survived by Barbara L. Donovan, West Hartford, CT, Francis J. Donovan III, Chatham, NJ, John E. Donovan, Pittsburgh, PA, T. Keller Donovan, New York City and Mary Helen Donovan, Brooklyn, NY and 5 grandchildren. In lieu of gifts, donations can be made in her name to New Eyes for the Needy, Inc., 549 Millburn Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey 07078.

title: Split on Nuclear Plants: Weak Spot or Fortress?
description: In the what's-next guessing game that began after the terrorist attacks last year, a divide has opened up among experts assessing the risk to the public from attacks on nuclear power plants.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY: CASINO WORKERS REINSTATED

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Forrester and Lautenberg Spar Over Debates and Tax Returns
description: The two main candidates for the United States Senate in New Jersey today each made demands on the other that they knew would not be fulfilled.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTOLA, EDWARD
description: MORTOLA-Edward. Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts Inc. and Lincoln Center Institute express deep sorrow at the loss of Dr. Edward J. Mortola, Chancellor Emeritus of Pace University. As Chairman of the Institute from 1987 to 1992 Dr. Mortola provided dynamic leadership and vision to the education arm of Lincoln Center. During his tenure, the Institute entered a new phase of growth through the expansion of research and program development and through the acquisition of a permanent facility in the Rose Building on the Lincoln Center campus. On behalf of the Board of Directors and Staff, we extend our sincere condolences to his wife Doris and family. Bruce Crawford, Chairman Reynold Levy, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. Sandra Priest Rose, Chairman Scott Noppe-Brandon, Executive Director Lincoln Center Institute

title: INSIDE
description: Aspirin and Heart Bypass

title: Terror Suspect Tells of His Links to 9/11 Hijackers
description: In a second day of testimony, a suspect on trial for involvement in the Sept. 11 attacks today detailed his relationship with five other men accused of being members of Al Qaeda's Hamburg cell.

title: Calling It Confusing, Chancellor Rejects Complex New Report Card
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced yesterday that he would scrap a new report card that measures student progress in more than 100 categories, saying it was impenetrable and would bewilder parents.

title: Heads Up: Rooftop Bars Light the Skies
description: ON a recent Thursday afternoon, Ric Addison, the owner of the new Ava Penthouse Lounge in Midtown, was preparing for its official opening on Halloween. He still had to cloak his bar in fake topiary because the roof terrace for the Ava (pronounced AH-va) is on the 15th floor of the former Woodward Hotel, now called the Majestic, at West 55th Street and Broadway.

title: Xerox Reports a Profit, but Revenue Is Down 6%
description: Xerox, offsetting a 6 percent slump in sales with a 13 percent cut in costs, said yesterday that it had earned $105 million, or 5 cents a share, in the third quarter.

title: HEALTH INSURER'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER TO RETIRE
description: The Cigna Corporation's chief financial officer, James G. Stewart, will retire in December after 36 years at the company, a leading health insurer. Mr. Stewart, 60, will be succeeded by Michael W. Bell, 39, an 18-year employee of the company, Cigna said. Gregory Wolf, 46, will succeed Mr. Bell as president of Cigna Group Insurance, its group disability, life and accident insurance unit.

title: Jesse L. Greenstein, Astronomer, Dies at 93
description: Jesse L. Greenstein, who helped explain astronomical exotica like unimaginably bright beacons at the edge of the universe and hot cinders of burned-out stars, died on Monday in Arcadia, Calif. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, EVELYN J.
description: HALL-Evelyn J. Mrs. Evelyn J. Hall, the former Eve St. John, passed away very quietly on October 22 at her home in New Preston CT. She also lived in NYC and spent the winters on Hutchinson Island, FL. She was an accomplished singer and actress. She was born in Chicago and spent her youth in Evansville, Ind. She was a member of the Meade Johnson family and is survived by her loving husband, Ronald Hall, daughters Pamela Hellstrom, Stephanie Bailey - Britton, and four grandchildren and six great grandchildren. She will be buried on Johnson Island in Evansville.

title: Accounts
description: * Discovery Channel, Bethesda, Md., a division of Discovery Communications, to Bayless Cronin, Atlanta, to handle creative duties on campaigns for its programming, which had been handled internally. Spending was estimated at $20 million. The agency is part of Merkley Newman Harty & Partners, a division of the Omnicom Group.

title: Drug Use and Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTAGON SETS UP INTELLIGENCE UNIT
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his senior advisers have assigned a small intelligence unit to search for information on Iraq's hostile intentions or links to terrorists that the nation's spy agencies may have overlooked, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the effect of New York City's budget crisis on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's alliance with Gov. George E. Pataki misstated the mayor's position on city tax increases. While he has dropped his opposition, he is not advocating them.

title: Friesen Takes the Time to End His Frustration
description: Devils forward Jeff Friesen knew he was wide open in front of Atlanta's goal and he knew that the Devils' best playmaker, center Scott Gomez, was about to slide him a pass. But after a handful of games full of frustration, Friesen also knew scoring would not be easy. Just his luck: the puck was rolling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ANITA
description: SMITH-Anita. ''My big sista'', best friend and protector. Your generosity, sense of humor, bravery and strength will always be in my heart. I will miss you and never forget you. With love, ''Little sista'', Harriett

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Vetoes Loan Bill
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has vetoed a City Council bill banning what are known as predatory lenders from doing business with the city. But the veto is likely to be overridden, council officials said, since the bill passed last month by a vote of 44 to 5, far more than the two-thirds needed to defeat a veto. Predatory lending is the practice of issuing a loan in bad faith that often results in the forfeiture of a borrower's assets. The bill would prohibit companies that issue predatory loans or buy them on the resale market from doing business with the city. Mr. Bloomberg, in a statement, expressed concern about predatory lending but said the measure was defective and ''not the appropriate vehicle for addressing these concerns.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: A Live Ballgame Unfolds On a Cellphone Screen
description: Awaiting applications for the so-called 3G (for third-generation) wireless protocol is a bit like wondering when electric cars will take over the nationrsquos highways. That technology, which will harness enough bandwidth to allow the transmission of streaming video and audio at rates of 2 megabits per second and higher, has yet to reach the mainstream consumer. But a team of companies is delivering graphics-rich content on wireless devices without the 3G bandwidth: Verizon and FoxSports.com have joined with ActiveSky to present live sports events and sports news to Internet-enabled cellphones for a monthly fee.

title: TAP Pharmaceutical Selects New Agency
description: TAP Pharmaceutical Products in Lake Forest, Ill., said yesterday that it had selected Merkley Newman Harty & Partners in New York to create campaigns for Prevacid, a prescription drug for heartburn and ulcers. Trade publications estimated that spending on Prevacid could reach as much as $100 million in 2003, compared with an estimated $37 million spent in 2001.

title: States Get Federal Warning on School Standards
description: The Education Department sent a blistering warning to school commissioners across the country today, calling educators who try to sidestep the intent of President Bush's signature education act, No Child Left Behind, ''enemies of equal justice and equal opportunity,'' and vowing, ''they will not succeed.''

title: World Business Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: TELECOM PROFIT Canada's biggest telephone company, BCE Inc. , reported a third-quarter profit as higher wireless and satellite service sales offset continued declines in revenue from phone and data service. Net income was 384 million Canadian dollars ($245 million) before the payment of preferred dividends, or 43 Canadian cents a share, in contrast to a loss of 128 million Canadian dollars, or 18 Canadian cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was little changed at about 4.82 billion Canadian dollars, the company said. Satellite entertainment services posted a 33 percent jump in sales in the quarter, followed by a 15 percent increase in revenue from BCE's wireless business. BCE is based in Montreal. (Bloomberg News)

title: United Amends Cost-Cut Plan To Try to Get Loan Guarantee
description: United Airlines filed a revised business plan yesterday with the federal government to increase its chances of receiving a $1.8 billion loan guarantee, which would help it avoid a bankruptcy filing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebel Leader Sees Mediators
description: The reclusive leader of the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, Velupillai Prabhakaran, left, met with Norwegian mediators to discuss the second round of peace talks with the Sri Lankan government, which are scheduled for the end of this month. A first round of talks aimed at ending the country's civil war were held in Thailand in September, but the peace effort remains threatened by the strained relationship between Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe and President Chandrika Kumaratunga, who has been critical of the government's peace moves. On Tuesday the Supreme Court ruled that the government cannot amend the Constitution to limit the president's power without first holding a referendum. Government officials have indicated that they would be more likely to call an early election. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Up Close on the Big Screen With Kahlo and Rivera
description: Fans of the Mexican architect Juan O'Gorman can examine his famous red and blue studios in the movie ''Frida,'' which opens tomorrow. The movie, about the marriage of the muralist Diego Rivera and the painter Frida Kahlo, was shot in their adjoining studios in San ngel, part of Mexico City. O'Gorman designed the studios in 1930. Rivera's red studio had sawtooth industrial skylights, seen above in the movie (with Salma Hayek as Kahlo, on the left). Kahlo, above in 1939, is standing atop her blue studio. When the studios were built, ''pretty much everyone in San ngel was shocked,'' said Felipe Fernndez del Paso, 36, the movie's production designer. ''It is in the middle of the most residential neighborhood in San ngel, among these beautiful Mexican haciendas. The neighbors started complaining.'' Today, the twin studios, which were renovated in 1997, are the Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo House Studio Museum.

title: Security At U.S. Lab Is Questioned By Senators
description: New York's Democratic senators have accused the Bush administration of failing to take action on a matter of national security at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the high-security laboratory off Long Island that conducts research on dangerous infectious animal diseases, where workers have been on strike since August.

title: Footlights
description: Remembered Glory

title: Hopes for a Harmonious Senate
description: Control of the Senate, which will be determined by a handful of competitive races like the one in South Dakota, will have vast consequences for judicial nominations, economic policy and domestic affairs. Not to mention the fate of the Singing Senators, the Republican leader, Trent Lott, said.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: A MEGA-AWARD STILL STANDS

title: Wary Bus Drivers Go Back to Work
description: The Citibank banners pasted to the hulls of many buses that thunder through the Friendship Heights station here say, ''May your finances be organized, and your life remain random.'' It is a reminder that in quite a different context, a bus driver, too, has joined the random lives that have been lost to the sniper.

title: Canada's Liberals, in Turmoil, Offer New Guidelines on Ethics
description: The Liberal government unveiled new ethics guidelines for members of Parliament today, only a day after the solicitor general resigned because of charges that he lobbied subordinates to award grants to a college run by his brother.

title: TAP Pharmaceutical Selects New Agency
description: TAP Pharmaceutical Products in Lake Forest, Ill., said yesterday that it had selected Merkley Newman Harty & Partners in New York to create campaigns for Prevacid, a prescription drug for heartburn and ulcers. Trade publications estimated that spending on Prevacid could reach as much as $100 million in 2003, compared with an estimated $37 million spent in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, MINNETTE
description: CIRKER-Minnette. 10/24/86 In loving memory of my dear Minnette enshrined in my memory forever. ''Rest my sweet darling''. Stanley

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, LILLIAN
description: BRODSKY-Lillian. Age 90. Died peacefully of Alzheimer's Disease on October 22, 2002. Beloved wife of the late George. Mother of Mady Salzman, mother-in-law of Richard Salzman. Adored grandmother of Barbara and Charles. Dear sister of the late Moe Lipeles and the late Miriam Polkes. Aunt and great aunt. Services private. Memorial donations may be made to the Lauren Danis Eldernet Committee at Temple Emanu-El, 756 East Broad St, Westfield NJ 07090 or King James Care Center, Activity Dept, 415 Southern Blvd, Chatham Township, NJ 07928.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: For State Senate in New York City
description: Two State Senate races in New York City are particularly competitive this year. Here are our endorsements.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Unchanged
description: Brazil's central bank kept its overnight interest rate unchanged at 21 percent, the highest borrowing rate in more than three years, hoping it will help contain rising consumer prices. The bank's monetary policy committee, in a unanimous decision, also said its president, Arminio Fraga, cannot change rates on his own before its regular meeting next month. The committee increased the rate by 300 basis points from 18 percent at a meeting on Oct. 14.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Names Chief
description: Germany's second-largest bank, the HVB Group, named Dieter Rampl as successor to the chief executive, Albrecht Schmidt, on Jan. 1. Mr. Rampl, a 55-year-old Austrian, had spent most of his career at Bayerische Vereinsbank, which became HVB after the takeover of a German rival, and he is currently head of the corporate customer unit. HVB also reported its results and said it lost 360 million euros ($352 million) in the third quarter, down from a profit of 68 million euros a year earlier, as it raised its provisions for bad loans by 86 percent, to 2.48 billion euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Thinking of Radio as Smart Enough to Live Without Rules
description: RADIO spectrum has always been seen as a limited resource, one that needs to be divided up and managed by the Federal Communications Commission and doled out for use in the form of licenses. But what if it was possible to open up the spectrum to everyone, so that anyone could broadcast anything, on whatever frequency was most convenient, without interfering with anyone else's signal?

title: Los Angeles Police Chief Faces a Huge Challenge
description: The afternoon that William J. Bratton was confirmed as police chief, a man was beaten to death in the South-Central section of this sprawling megalopolis.

title: A Bigger and Better Europe
description: Ireland owes much of its prosperity to its three decades of membership in the European Union. So it was both poignant and fitting for Irish voters last weekend to offer the same opportunity of E.U. membership to Poles, Hungarians, Czechs and the people of seven other nations -- all aspiring, in a sense, to become the next Ireland.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Bombing At State Company
description: Several people in Katmandu, the capital, were wounded when a bomb exploded outside a state-run import-export company, officials said. The government said it suspected Maoist rebels, who have been waging a guerrilla campaign since 1996 to topple the constitutional monarchy. The rebels have planted dozens of bombs in the capital in recent months; most have caused no casualties. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Turkish Government Takes Steps to Shut Popular Islamic Party
description: Just 10 days before national elections, Turkey's chief prosecutor moved today to outlaw the most popular political party, a moderate Islamic group whose leader had already been barred from running for office.

title: Someone Besides Bonds Finally Comes Through
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 — Benito Santiago had fallen into the trap. The Giants had fallen behind in the World Series because they had been unable to complement the record-setting performance of Barry Bonds.

title: Notes From Madison; Clean State, Dirty Politicians
description: People in Wisconsin have tended to think that our geography mirrors our politics: to the right of Minnesota, above Illinois (or so we thought).

title: Charlton Heston And the Sniper
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | West: California: A Mega-Award Still Stands
description: The State Supreme Court, in a 4-to-3 decision, declined to hear a challenge to the largest punitive award in a personal injury case ever affirmed in American history. The decision let stand a $290 million award by a Ceres, Calif., jury to the family of three people killed in the rollover of a Ford Bronco in 1993. Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., a lawyer for Ford, said his client would ask the United States Supreme Court to hear the case. Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Making the 100 Best List; Of Course, It's Debatable
description: Clad in undulating steel, a book titled ''Spoon'' (Phaidon Press, $75) offers a survey of 100 product designers, chosen by 10 specialists from around the world. Four pages are devoted to each designer, with objects both sensible (thermal covers for beer bottles) and exotic (cameras for dogs). Established figures like J Mays of the Ford Motor Company made the cut. So did studios like Blu Dot and Norway Says.

title: McLendon Helps Spark Wolfpack
description: The national television cameras and the critical eyes of college football poll voters will be focused on North Carolina State on Thursday night when the Wolfpack faces Clemson. While they are watching, they will most likely not miss the performance of the freshman running back T. A. McLendon.

title: Report Offers Safeguards For Live Transplant Donors
description: Nine months after a 57-year-old man died donating his liver to his brother at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, a panel of transplant experts will issue a report today recommending several changes intended to protect liver donors from unnecessary risks.

title: Punk Meets Disco, Again
description: Sometimes it seems as though trends just appear, as if by mutual conspiracy, and everywhere one looks they are reinforced by more evidence. In music circles in New York these days, for example, it is hard to go anywhere without seeing more signs of the revival of a certain subchapter of music history that had its center in New York and London in the late 70's and early 80's. At small clubs in those years, post-punk bands began to emerge, working disco, reggae, funk and machine rhythms into their music. Though I am a firm believer in the saying that great minds think alike, it is still somewhat of a surprise to see some of those bands being embraced again. The genre itself has always sounded as exciting and edgy as it has unwieldy.

title: At the Author's Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, DONALD JORDAN
description: DONAHUE-Donald Jordan. October 22nd, 2002. He is survived by his five children, Macy, Judy, Don, Tom and Nick of his late wife, Mary Meyer Donahue, six grandchildren, wife Carol, brother Jack and sister Mary. Passed away peacefully of complications from Parkinson's disease. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 6-8 PM and Thursday 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, October 25th, 11 AM at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Donald J. Donahue to either Parkinson's Disease Foundation Inc., 710 W. 168 Street, New York, NY 10032 or the family's scholarship at Georgetown University, Attn: Mary Prahinski, Office of Alumni and University Relations, P.O. Box 571253, Washington, D.C. 20057.

title: For a Tallahassee Car Collection, A Flamboyant Set of Keys Among the Wheels
description: A copy of the ornate Alma-Tadema piano has ended up at a car museum. The Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., bought the original, built in 1887, with griffin legs and the names of Greek muses inlaid on its lid, for $1.2 million in 1997. Last year, Chapeau Antiques and Restoration in Hoboken, N.J., spent 5,000 man-hours painstakingly duplicating it for Steinway & Sons, using 22 species of wood, said Eric Chapeau, who owns the workshop. Two weeks ago, DeVoe Moore, an entrepreneur in Tallahassee, Fla., bought it for $675,000 to display in his Tallahassee Antique Car Museum, along with the Batmobiles and Corvettes.

title: F.B.I. to Open Liaison Office in Beijing, Ashcroft Says
description: BEIJING, Oct. 24  Concluding a three-day visit, Attorney General John Ashcroft offered praise today for China's efforts to combat international terrorism and announced the opening of an F.B.I. liaison office in Beijing to further that effort.

title: Suspect in Sniper Attacks Called Meticulous and Manipulative
description: Acquaintances gave contrasting images today of John Allen Muhammad, the former Army mechanic who was arrested along with a teenage companion in the investigation of the sniper shootings in the Washington, D.C., region.

title: Stepping Up the Pace for House Races
description: With Congress in recess, the party and Congressional offices on Capitol Hill are beginning to empty as staff members depart to swell the troops in the 40-odd hottest House races in the country. This is the season, in other words, of the ground game, getting people mobilized toward the polls.

title: The Fine Art Of Tuning Teacups
description: Performers who play a lot of contemporary music expect composers to challenge their technical skills. They do not typically expect composers to challenge their shopping skills. But the four members of the So Percussion Group who played Saturday night's premiere of David Lang's ''So-Called Laws of Nature'' had to prove themselves as shoppers before they could even begin to learn the work, one of three by Mr. Lang presented on the first of this season's Composer Portraits concerts at the Miller Theater.

title: Senator Says It's Time To Upgrade Standards
description: The senator who wrote the original law regulating breast-cancer screening says she will seek to rework the legislation with tougher standards for doctors who read mammograms.

title: A Citywide Treasure Hunt For Photographs With Vision
description: For its 50th birthday, Aperture, the photography foundation, gave itself an administrative nightmare. ''It's a fun nightmare!'' said Melissa Harris, the editor of Aperture magazine, who was at Aperture's Burden Gallery in Manhattan last week surrounded by photographs, boxes, schedules and picture hooks, with one exhibition coordinator, Adriana Marques, and two installers, Tony Petracca and Barry W. Schrager, on hand.

title: DEMOCRATS PLACE MCCALL ON NOTICE
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee said today that the party would not channel large sums of money to H. Carl McCall unless he could significantly close the gap in his struggling campaign for governor of New York.

title: On Bridges, Raising Money but Not Blood Pressure
description: Since last winter, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg began looking for ways to mend a $5 billion hole in his city's budget, the idea of collecting tolls on the four city-owned East River bridges has been slowly gaining momentum at City Hall.

title: Finding a Grateful Home For Your Old Computer
description: Q. I would like to donate an old computer to a school or charity, but I don't want to contribute equipment so old and outdated that it is of no use. Are there any guidelines for such donations?

title: Bush Campaigns for Senate Candidates in the Carolinas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Bush traveled to the Carolinas today to campaign for Republican Senate candidates, one of whom is married to a former political rival of his father.

title: House Arrest Doesn't Bar Watching TV, Court Rules
description: He had to go all the way to a federal appeals court, but Edward Bello's right to watch the Discovery Channel has been reaffirmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, ELLEN
description: HOFFMAN-Ellen. Dearest El, a special friendship of over 40 years. Never diminished by a separation of miles. Wonderful memories that will be cherished forever. We will miss you dearly. With much love, Ellen and Bob Jaffe

title: A Bush Insider Heads to Iowa
description: Karen Hughes, the longtime Bush confidante who returned to Austin for the sake of her homesick family, was back on the hustings in Iowa yesterday -- this time, on behalf of Representative Jim Leach, the endangered Republican moderate.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook column in The Arts yesterday about the ''West Wing'' television series misspelled the fictional reference in a characterization of the presidency portrayed on the show. Robert Louis Stevenson's characters are Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, not Jeckyll.

title: CALENDAR
description: Building Dreams

title: Calling a Candidate on 9/11
description: The independent candidate for governor in Oklahoma, United States Attorney Gary Richardson, released a 30-second commercial last week featuring the collapse of the World Trade Center. The advertisement uses part of the Alan Jackson song ''Where Were You (When The World Stopped Turning)'' to focus attention on Steve Largent, the Republican candidate, being in Idaho on a hunting trip on Sept. 11, unaware of the attacks. The advertisement was broadcast in Oklahoma City, Tulsa and Lawton.

title: Suspect Is Arrested in Multiple Rape Cases
description: The police have arrested a man they contend is responsible for at least six rapes in Manhattan and Brooklyn over the last three years, after finding him on a routine check of a public housing project's stairwells, the authorities said.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: RULING FOR ABORTION RIGHTS

title: Inside, Fearful Children; Outside, Frantic Relatives
description: It was an ordinary Wednesday night and Nadezhda Mikhailova had flicked on the evening television news while she made dinner. The news on the evening report seemed incomprehensible. She called a friend to ask if they had seen the same news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, REV. MONSIGNOR JAMES J.
description: MURRAY-Rev. Monsignor James J., 76. Son of the late Joseph and Rose Vallely Murray, brother of the late Rosaleen P. Sage (Donald), Mary M. Houlihan (James G.), John T. Murray (Eileen), Sister Mary Rose Murray, S.U., and Patrick W. Murray (Cathy). ''Uncle Bud'' survived by 10 Sage nieces and nephews and their spouses and children, six Houlihan nephews and nieces and their spouses and children, eight Murray nieces and nephews, and their spouses and children. Graduate of Our Lady of Angels School (Bronx), Regis High School ('42), U.S. Army ('44-'46), Fordham College ('48), Fordham Univ Law School ('51), Saint Joseph's Seminary ('56), Fordham Univ School of Social Service. Knight of Holy Sepulchre and Malta, Executive Director NY Catholic Charities for over 27 years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christ The High Priest at Saint Patrick's Cathedral on Monday at 10 A.M. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, New York. Contributions in his memory may made be made to Saint Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, Yonkers, NY.

title: Market Place; Looking Glass On Earnings Just Got Darker
description: Just how little is American industry making?

title: Little Theater, Big Dreams, for Yiddish Director
description: BLOODY was the battle in which the new generation toppled their elders at the Folksbiene Yiddish Theater a few years ago -- or at least, in the telling of the current executive director, Zalmen Mlotek, very, very guilt ridden.

title: Act to Reduce the Truck-Bomb Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan Hails Output Gains in Sluggish Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, hailed the continued strong growth in business efficiency today but gave no hint as to whether the central bank might consider cutting interest rates when it meets in two weeks.

title: Earnings at DuPont Triple in Quarter
description: DuPont said today its third-quarter profit more than tripled as it cut expenses and paid lower taxes.

title: End to 3 Weeks of Terror for the Capital Region
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 24 - A harrowing three-week ordeal came to an end today as police officers arrested two suspects in the sniper shooting spree that left 10 people dead, three wounded and the capital region terrified.

title: Pittsburgh Has People Talking in Preseason
description: In recent seasons, the Pittsburgh basketball program has improved from one of the worst in the Big East Conference to one of the best. This season, the upgrade is in facilities, from an outmoded field house to a suite-ringed modern arena.

title: Corrections
description: Alist of stores last Thursday with an article about the renewed popularity of such "bohemian" furnishings as beaded curtains, paisley lanterns and fringed lamp shades misstated the name of the town in New Jersey where one store, Sojourner, is located. It is Lambertville, not Lambertsville.

title: Corrections
description: The Commercial Real Estate column in Business Day on Oct. 9, about the building of a research headquarters by Novartis in Cambridge, Mass., included an erroneous reference from the company to its plans for three laboratories in New Jersey. Novartis will continue research at one of them, not three. The one in Summit will close; the lab in East Hanover will remain open. In Florham Park, researchers perform administrative duties; that site, which is not a laboratory, will stay open.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOUSSA, JUDE JOSEPH
description: MOUSSA-Jude Joseph. October 24, 1965 to September 11, 2001. We know you are just around the corner smiling, at peace, and watching over those who love you. You are forever in our hearts, and are well loved always. From your dear friends, Charlie and Cher, Richard and Roxanne, Martin, George and Ruth, Eileen and Vinnie, John and Maureen, Andrea-Lisa, and friends from Foxhounds

title: A Republican Woodstock Endorsement
description: An endorsement of the Woodstock experience is not exactly what one expects from Ken Mehlman, the button-down political director of a conservative White House. But Mr. Mehlman, spinning madly about his party's prospects for regaining control of the Senate, did just that this week at a meeting with reporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHMAN, ALVIN H.
description: CASHMAN-Alvin H. Died on October 20 at the age of 94. He is survived and missed by his wife of 70 years, Sylvia Cashman, by his son Kenneth, by his grandchildren (Bill, Elise Bass, and Keven) by his five great-grandchildren, and by his sister Selma Florman. His funeral service will be held at 11:30 on October 24 at the Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street. Visitation begins at 10:30.

title: Outside Post Big Obstacle
description: With the announcement that his horse Toccet had drawn the 14 post for the $1 million Breeders' Cup Juvenile, the trainer John Scanlan got up and left the room. He said he needed time to recover.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Meeting On Under-Age Drinking
description: Westchester County school superintendents and the district attorney's office said yesterday that they were calling a community meeting on Nov. 7 on under-age drinking. The invitation-only meeting, to be held at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., will include a presentation and discussion with 12 panelists, including the district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, the district attorney; Joseph L. Farmer, the Yonkers schools superintendent; Dr. Debra Jackson, the North Salem schools superintendent, and students and community leaders. In recent weeks, incidents involving drinking have been reported among high school students in Scarsdale and Harrison. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: The Commuter Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Forrester's Estimate of Wealth Seems to Be Hurting, Not Helping
description: In May, when Douglas R. Forrester first asserted that his prescription drug insurance company was worth more than $100 million, New Jersey's Republican primary for the Senate quickly changed from a competitive race into a victory lap for Mr. Forrester.

title: California Panel Bans Fishing Around a Marine Sanctuary
description: After four years of study and debate, the California Fish and Game Commission today approved a network of marine reserves around the Channel Islands, creating what amounts to a network of underwater parks where fishing is off limits.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: MAYOR VETOES LOAN BILL

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Dogwood for the Dooryard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, MARVIN
description: KRAUSS-Marvin. On October 22, 2002. Cherished husband of Elaine. Father of Anne, Robin and Michael, Nina & David, Seth and Lisa. Brother of Richard. Grandfather of Tatiayna, Ezra, Jacob, Gabriel and Matthew. Beloved brother-in-law, uncle and nephew. Funeral service October 24, 11:45AM at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam.

title: Toronto Exchange Is Still Set to Go Public
description: South of the border, the NASD has yet to go ahead with its planned public offering for the battered Nasdaq stock market. And the New York Stock Exchange, which had talked about demutualizing in the late 1990's, currently has no plans to list itself. But in Canada, TSX Inc., the holding company for the Toronto Stock Exchange, is moving forward with plans to become a public company around mid-November.

title: Ruby Slippers on a Budget. That's Scary.
description: WHEN it comes to Halloween rituals, my husband and I have developed different tastes.

title: McAuliffe Describes Jeb Bush As the Democrats' Top Target
description: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic national chairman, said today that his No. 1 goal in the Nov. 5 elections was to defeat Gov. Jeb Bush in Florida and that his No. 1 worry was whether Senator Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri, could hold her seat.

title: Act to Reduce the Truck-Bomb Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Trail of Childhood Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: In Chicago, Killing Keeps Up a Rapid Pace
description: Though it may lose its title as the nation's most murderous city to Los Angeles this year, Chicago is still on a pace that almost matches the number of homicides it logged last year.

title: Chechen Militants Kill One in Moscow Hostage Crisis
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24 — Chechen rebels threatening to blow up a Moscow theater with as many as 700 hostages, including three Americans, turned over the body of a young woman today in sign of their resolve, and they fired grenades at two other women who escaped the theater this afternoon.

title: At the Author's Demand
description: To the Editor:

title: Childhood Practices Pay Off for Spiezios
description: Ed Spiezio left the Chicago White Sox on Sept. 20, 1972, to witness the birth of his son, Scott, a day later and, essentially, he left behind one major league career and started to build another. A career ended, a life began and the sharing of a dual dream for a father and son would soon follow.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Russian Lawmaker Thrown Out
description: A legislator and leader of Russia's largest liberal political party, the Union of Right Forces, was seized at the Minsk airport and then ejected from Belarus in what a party spokesman called ''a pure setup'' by the Belarussian K.G.B. The legislator, Boris Y. Nemtsov, later said that K.G.B. officers had tried to plant a folder stuffed with documents and American dollars on him. Mr. Nemtsov, a supporter of Belarus's democratic opposition, called the detention a provocation by the country's dictator, Aleksandr Lukashenko. Belarus officials said he was trying to destabilize the country; Russia's Foreign Ministry said it would demand an explanation. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Mayor Says Current Deficit May Be as Much as $1 Billion
