description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's current budget could be as much as $1 billion out of balance, echoing concerns that fiscal monitors have been raising since he and the City Council agreed to it in June.

title: Ethics Standards Overhaul Urged for Hospital Buying Groups
description: A noted specialist in corporate ethics urged yesterday that companies involved in helping the nation's hospitals buy billions of dollars in supplies, drugs and medical devices adopt sweeping policy changes to avoid conflicts between their own profit-making interests and the needs of the hospitals they are supposed to represent.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Europeans Honor Dissident
description: The European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought to Oswaldo Pay, a dissident who leads a civic movement for political reform in Cuba. The award, which will be presented in December, recognized him for seeking peaceful change through a petition drive known as the Varela Project. The Cuban government, which has yet to respond to Mr. Paya's request for a referendum on human rights, previously prohibited him from traveling to the United States to receive an honor from the National Democratic Institute. David Gonzalez (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUDASOFF, JOSEPHINE
description: BUDASOFF-Josephine, 78. Of Orlando, Florida. Beloved wife of Israel. Loving mother of Daniel (Barbara) and Pedro (Bonnie). Dear sister of Adolfo and Rosita. Cherished grandmother of Terri, Nicholas, Alana, Larry, Natasha and Gabby. Funeral private. Family will receive friends at her home.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Effort To Avoid Clash On Cyprus
description: Foreign Ministry officials said Greece might call off war games planned for next week on Cyprus, fearing an accidental clash with Turkish forces also planning exercises there. Cyprus, which is expected to join the European Union by 2004, has been divided since 1974, when Turkish troops invaded and occupied its north. Turkey has not yet responded to the Greek plea. Anthee Carassava (NYT)

title: Now, 4 States Look to Start Tracing Shells And Bullets
description: Following the sniper shootings in the Washington area, four states are considering creating a ballistic fingerprinting system that would enable law enforcement to trace bullets or shell casings found at a crime scene to the manufacturer and buyer of the gun.

title: National TV Focuses on Sniper, but Local Stations Pick Up the Slack on Political Coverage
description: Menacing images of cross hairs dominated the screens of the national television newscasts on Tuesday night, as did the chilling words from the Washington sniper's letter: ''Your children are not safe anywhere at any time.''

title: Typewriters For Sale (Gently Used)
description: Time Inc.'s new chief executive, Ann S. Moore, recently announced an officewide cleanup. Many of the pitched items -- including 2,000 books and entire graveyard of Selectric typewriters -- went on sale in a huge ad hoc garage sale, with employees' paying $5 to shop for the salvaged goods. The proceeds will go to a local charity.

title: Calming the Young in a Time of Confusion
description: ''Do you think the sniper could come here?'' a 7-year-old boy in suburban Chicago asked a psychiatrist, Dr. Henry Gault, this week.

title: METROMEDIA SELLS LAWN MOWER UNIT FOR CASH AND DEBT
description: The Metromedia International Group will sell its Snapper unit, maker of Snapper lawn mowers, to Simplicity Manufacturing for $73.3 million in a bid to stave off bankruptcy. Metromedia, which is based in East Rutherford, N.J., owns telecommunications ventures in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union and manufactures Snapper power lawn and garden equipment. The purchase price included an undisclosed amount of debt. Simplicity Manufacturing is a closely held company based in Port Washington, Wis.

title: Challenging Humanity To Try to Do Better
description: ''The witness has the authority that no one else has,'' Elie Wiesel says. He ought to know.

title: Meant to Tickle, a Chabrier Feather
description: Chabrier's ''toile,'' which opened on Tuesday at the New York City Opera in a production that originated at the Glimmerglass Opera, is a bubble, and like any of its kind, it can be caught only with consummate skill and the least possible effort. Grasp it, and pop! And it will not pop just a little bit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUZZATTO, MARJORIE B.
description: LUZZATTO-Marjorie B. On October 22, 2002 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Giovanni. Loving mother of Alan and Stephen and mother-in-law of Sandra and Jane. Cherished Grammy of Jessica, Matthew, Michael and Christopher and three greatgrandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Religious service at funeral home 10 AM Saturday. Interment Cypress Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donation to the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: U.S. Carmakers Losing Ground To Imports Despite Deals
description: The billions of dollars that General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have spent during the last year on the most generous sales incentives in automotive history have not bought them what they wanted: a bigger share of the market.

title: 7th Victim Dies In Baltimore Arson Tied to Drug Fight
description: An East Baltimore man who was badly burned in an arson fire that killed his wife and five of her children died today.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: RATE DEBATE The Bank of England shifted toward lowering interest rates last month with three of the nine members on the monetary policy committee endorsing a cut of 0.25 percentage points, according to minutes of the panel's meeting. Britain's benchmark interest rate is at a 38-year low of 4 percent, even though the economy has survived the global downturn more successfully than elsewhere in Europe. But with economists calculating growth of only 0.6 percent for each of the last two quarters, the chance of a rate cut has increased amid fears of a slowdown in the global recovery. In previous months policy makers debated lowering rates but voted unanimously to keep them on hold.

title: Roadblocks on the Path to Peace
description: This week the Bush administration has been busy unveiling its new ''road map'' for a Mideast peace to Israelis, Palestinians and other nations. It is an exhaustive document that has a little of everything except what is needed most: a detailed blueprint of a comprehensive political settlement and a realistic, internationally monitored way of getting there. As one horrific act of violence follows another, the gap between high-level diplomacy and on-the-ground realities rarely has seemed wider. Diplomats are now wrestling with an elaborate sequence of steps and questions over the minutiae of Palestinian government reform, the timing of Palestinian elections and the establishment of a Palestinian state with provisional borders.

title: On the Trail of Childhood Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: Heckling by Pataki Backers Only Encourages Golisano
description: People in Brooklyn and in White Plains yesterday called Tom Golisano a liar and untrustworthy and sent him the message that he has been nothing but a big pain in the neck. Mr. Golisano was delighted.

title: Citing Age and a Difficult Year, Paterson Bishop Says He'll Retire
description: Bishop Frank J. Rodimer, the leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Paterson, announced today that he was submitting his resignation to the pope, citing the church's mandatory retirement age for bishops and a taxing year for his diocese.

title: As Piniella Talks Stall, Mets Turn Their Attention to Howe
description: With their hopes of landing Lou Piniella to be their next manager all but dead, the Mets have zeroed in on Oakland Athletics Manager Art Howe, and began negotiations with him yesterday.

title: Adolph Green, Broadway Playwright, Dies at 87
description: Adolph Green, the playwright, performer and lyricist who in a six-decade collaboration with Betty Comden was co-author of such hit Broadway musicals as "On the Town," "Wonderful Town" and "Bells Are Ringing" and the screenplays for "Singin' in the Rain" and "The Band Wagon," died today at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: If Only for a Moment, Rose Is Back
description: Cal Ripken was greeted respectfully by the fans at Pacific Bell Park tonight, after his consecutive-games streak was announced as the most memorable moment in baseball history, as voted by fans. But the ovation was loudest for the man whose moment ranked sixth.

title: Over the River, No Longer Fringe
description: WEEKENDS aren't so quiet anymore in Dumbo, the tiny neighborhood of old red-brick buildings on the Brooklyn waterfront. On a Sunday afternoon this month, workers were trundling rugs and furniture into the new ABC Carpet & Home store, which opened last week in a former Jay Street warehouse. Down on Water Street, St. Ann's Warehouse, a former spice packaging plant converted to a 599-seat theater, was crackling with sound checks for that evening's David Bowie concert.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Application On Modified Grass Is Withdrawn
description: Monsanto and the Scotts Company have withdrawn their application to sell the first genetically modified grass because the Agriculture Department had questions. But the companies said they intended to resubmit the application with the questions answered in a few months. The grass, intended primarily for golf courses, has attracted attention because it would be the first major non-agricultural genetically modified crop. The grass has a gene that allows it to withstand Monsanto's Roundup herbicide, allowing groundskeepers to spray herbicide to kill weeds while leaving the grass intact. The Washington-based International Center for Technology Assessment, an environmental group, opposed the application, saying that the type of grass involved, creeping bentgrass, can be a weed and that giving it resistance to Roundup would make it harder to kill and that the herbicide tolerance gene might spread to other grassy weeds. Jim King, a spokesman for Scotts, said that creeping bentgrass was not a type suitable for consumer lawns and would not be sold that way. He would not reveal what questions the Agriculture Department had regarding the application. But he said that withdrawal of an application is not uncommon and that Scotts hoped to have the grass on the market by late 2003 or 2004. Andrew Pollack(NYT)

title: On a Sliver of a Hub, Ports for Every Gadget
description: A laptop computer with a single U.S.B. port generally allows you to hook up only one device to it at a time. Although a U.S.B. hub can quadruple the number of ports and thus the number of gadgets, it typically takes up valuable desk space. But the new four-port MicroHub from Iogear (www.iogear.com) is the size of a cigarette lighter, making it a space-saver on the desktop or in the suitcase.

title: Economic Scene; Observe, theorize, measure, test and don't overlook what goes wrong. Nobel experiments.
description: YOU can learn a lot when an experiment goes wrong.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Broadway Goes Digital

title: 2 Babies Tossed to Safety in Apartment Fire
description: As fire ripped through two apartment buildings here this morning, a couple helped rescue two infants from a second-story unit by telling the mother to drop the children into a blanket.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 8
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Police Name Man Being Sought for Questioning in Sniper Case
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 23  The manhunt for the roving suburban sniper focused on two men being sought by the police tonight as key witnesses who were reported on the run and the subjects of an intensive East Coast dragnet.

title: Sports of The Times; Bonds Takes the Spotlight, But Would Prefer the Ring
description: This is Barry Bonds's World Series. He commands attention as perhaps no other player has ever done.

title: Third-Quarter Sales At GlaxoSmithKline And Lilly Decrease
description: Eli Lilly & Company and GlaxoSmithKline said yesterday that competition from generic versions of top-selling medicines eroded their third-quarter sales. Shares of the companies tumbled.

title: DDB Forms Alliance With Tokyu Agency
description: DDB Japan in Tokyo, part of the DDB Worldwide Communications Group, is forming a strategic alliance with the Tokyu Agency, also in Tokyo. Terms were not disclosed.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Haunted, Schmaunted

title: All That Glitters
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including comments on last week's Magazine cover story on the rich and poor and a discussion of whether tolls on East River bridges are unfair.

title: The Giants' Pitchers Put a Lock on the Angels' Bats
description: Just as the surgeon general of the United States was going to require the Anaheim Angels to place a warning on their uniforms, the San Francisco Giants found at least a temporary antidote for the malady.

title: Tentative Agreement Ends Boston Janitors' Strike
description: A union that represents nearly 11,000 janitors in the Boston region ended a three-week strike yesterday when it reached a tentative five-year contract that provides 30 percent salary increases and health insurance for some part-time janitors.

title: For Evenings That Sing Of the East
description: Feel the trade winds blowing. Flatware from Royal Pacific (right) was designed by Clark Wolf for the Royal Pacific Hotel and Resort at Universal Orlando in Florida. ''Sometimes chopsticks just aren't enough,'' he said. The flatware, in 18/10 stainless steel, is $120 for a 20-piece set and is at Zabar's, 2245 Broadway (80th Street), (212) 787-2000; information also from Fortessa, (800) 296-7508.

title: A Surrogate Shopper Sifts Paris Antiques
description: You may be stateside, but you can still shop in Paris. Gloria Cohen runs a shopping service, Made-in-Paris, and buys furnishings there for people abroad. She takes requests by e-mail or telephone. Sometimes customers send pictures from a magazine, said Ms. Cohen, who combs the flea markets and Left Bank antique shops. The fee for small jobs like finding linens is negotiable. Bigger jobs are $150 an hour.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Don't start the storm, don't shoot at them. There are girls next to me with lots of explosives on them. Men with machine guns. This is why -- don't shoot at them.''

title: The Bengals Hit Bottom, and Keep Getting Worse
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 23 — The jokes are now as frequent and bruising as the defeats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANDEL, ROMA M.
description: ZANDEL-Roma M. On Wednesday, October 23, 2002. Roma M. Zandel of Rockville, MD formerly of Forest Hills, NY; beloved wife of the late Adam A. Zandel; devoted mother of Susan (Lawrence) Chandler; cherished grandmother of Lisa (Michael) Cordell and Jason Chandler. Graveside service to be held at a later date. Expressions of sympathy in her memory may be made to SEEC/VIA Activity Fund, 8905 Fairview Road, #

title: Isles' Kvasha Out For Two Weeks
description: Oleg Kvasha, the left wing on the Islanders' top line, fractured his left ankle Tuesday and will be out of the lineup for at least two weeks, the team said yesterday.

title: A Personal Tech Feedback Forum
description: Usually, you find a "P.S." only at the bottom of a full-fledged letter. This week, however, my e-mail note to you consists of nothing but postscripts. Here are my follow-ups to previous columns:

title: President Pledges Full Resources of Federal Government to Assist in Sniper Hunt
description: Led by President Bush, administration officials pledged the full resources of the federal government today in capturing what Mr. Bush called ''a ruthless person on the loose,'' and mounted an aggressive defense of how the investigation is being run.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Layoffs At Drug Concern
description: The Dutch chemical and drug company Akzo Nobel said it would eliminate 300 jobs at its pharmaceutical division Organon, including some posts in the United States. Akzo declined to go into detail pending discussions with its employees. News of the reductions emerged during Akzo's presentation of its third-quarter results. Its profit fell 3 percent, to 238 million euros ($233 million), from the period a year earlier. The company attributed part of the decline to the strengthening euro as well as an increase in costs related to employee pensions. Operating profit at Organon fell 9 percent largely because of investments in research and development. The company is trying to come up with new medications to supplement income from its best-selling antidepressant Remeron. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Americans and Vatican Officials to Revise Policy on Abuse
description: The Vatican yesterday announced the names of the four American bishops and four Vatican officials responsible for revising the American prelates' zero-tolerance policy on sexual abuse.

title: A Tiny Gulf Kingdom Bets Its Stability on Support for U.S.
description: From the road, the possible nerve center for any American-led offensive against Iraq presents a barely visible profile of buff-colored bunkers, their sloped sides hugging the ground like barnacles and blending into the dunescape of this utterly flat land.

title: Tactile Lessons in the Arts And in the Sciences, Too
description: The ceramist Susan Tunick has grouted sunbursts and educational tiles, above, onto the walls of an elementary school, Public School 222, in Jackson Heights, Queens. For the cafeteria and foyer, she sculptured clay bees and fish, embossed discs with an A. A. Milne poem, inset above, and interspersed the tiles with tiny mirrors.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Hearing On Juvenile Violence
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on security concerns at Department of Juvenile Justice facilities. City Council hearing room, 16th Floor, 250 Broadway, Manhattan, 10 a.m. Information: (718) 857-0959.

title: Planners Urge Decisions on Downtown
description: DELAYED and diverted by the race for governor, interagency rivalries and a bit too much wishful thinking, the planning process in Lower Manhattan must begin showing results soon if it is to counter the very real threat that downtown could lose the financial-service industry, its economic backbone.

title: Campaigning Door to Door, and PC to PC
description: IN his closing statement at the end of the first presidential debate of the 1996 campaign, Senator Bob Dole included a plug for his Web site. Hundreds of thousands of Internet users flocked to the site in the hour after the debate ended, overloading the server to such an extent that the site virtually shut down.

title: Series: Blurred Vision
description: The first article in this series appeared on June 27. It examined the federal government's 10-year effort to ensure accurate screening at the nation's mammography clinics. The second article, on June 28, looked at a medical practice in Colorado that has improved its accuracy in mammography by imposing unusually strict standards on its doctors.

title: Refinancing Wave Buoys Freddie Mac
description: Freddie Mac, the mortgage company, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 34 percent, spurred by a record pace of home-loan refinancing.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Telecom Profit
description: Canada's biggest telephone company, BCE Inc., reported a third-quarter profit as higher wireless and satellite service sales offset continued declines in revenue from phone and data service. Net income was 384 million Canadian dollars ($245 million) before the payment of preferred dividends, or 43 Canadian cents a share, in contrast to a loss of 128 million Canadian dollars, or 18 Canadian cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was little changed at about 4.82 billion Canadian dollars, the company said. Satellite entertainment services posted a 33 percent jump in sales in the quarter, followed by a 15 percent increase in revenue from BCE's wireless business. BCE is based in Montreal.

title: Sex Film Star Is Sentenced in Stock Fraud
description: It was supposed to be a routine court appearance in an insider trading case. But the defendant, formerly an actress in pornographic films, showed up at Federal District Court in Manhattan wearing a cream-colored suit studded with rhinestones and beads, and silver platform shoes.

title: Carol Channing, Back Where She Belongs
description: Carol Channing was back on Broadway the other night. No, not the bright lights of a stage but, fittingly, at Joe Franklin's Memory Lane Restaurant and Bar on 45th Street and Eighth Avenue. She was there to promote her book "Just Lucky I Guess" (Simon & Schuster)," her own personal walk down memory lane about her career and personal life.

title: Fred Troller, 71, Champion of Bold Graphic Style
description: Fred Troller, a design director who helped popularize a minimalist typographic style called Swiss New Typography in the United States in the 1960's, died on Oct. 11 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 71.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In School Stabbing
description: The police arrested a teenager yesterday for stabbing a schoolmate with a steak knife at Springfield Gardens High School in Queens. Malcom Williams, 19, of Gateway Boulevard in Far Rockaway, was arrested yesterday evening in connection with the attack, which occurred Tuesday in a crowded hallway. Mr. Williams is a junior at the school, and his victim, Darnell McCall, 18, is a senior. Mr. McCall is in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said last night. The two students had fought over money, the police said. The school is equipped with a metal detector and X-ray machine just inside the front door, and they were working the day of the attack, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Angling for a Story
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Siege in Moscow
description: Chechen guerrillas seized a theater in Moscow, taking as many as 600 hostages.

title: New York Teamster Leader Is Charged With Misconduct
description: A federal oversight board announced yesterday that it had charged the top Teamster official in New York, Anthony Rumore, with improper behavior for inviting a Teamster leader ousted on corruption charges to speak at a union meeting in Miami Beach.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Most Voters Are Unaffiliated
description: The number of registered voters in New Jersey has risen to 4,655,852, up 1 percent from a year ago. Unaffiliated voters outnumber the total number of Democrats and Republicans. Those without a party total 2,570,402, or 55 percent of the electorate. Since last year's election, 48,099 more unaffiliated residents have registered. Democrats number 1,170,475, up 7,040 since the last election; Republicans total 900,969, up 2,371. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Asks Co-owner of Car to Come Forward
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation appealed last night for the co-owner of the 12-year-old car seized in the sniper investigation to come forward for questioning.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: NEWARK: 'PUFFY CHEEK' SUSPECT ARRESTED

title: Sprewell's Pinkie Still Weak
description: Latrell Sprewell was at practice again today, and this time the cast was off his broken right hand. But Sprewell is hardly ready to help the Knicks, and until he can they are well aware that they could lose the season before it has hardly begun.

title: Symbolic Enclosure Is Allowed, Judges Rule
description: A federal appeals court panel ruled yesterday that the borough of Tenafly, N.J., cannot remove a symbolic line set up by Orthodox Jews in town. Doing so would violate the rights of the Orthodox community, which has 50 to 75 families, and would amount to unconstitutionally selective enforcement of the town's laws.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Legal Dispute Over Cegetel
description: Vivendi Universal is suing the Vodafone Group in an attempt to gain more time to put together a counterbid for Cegetel, the large French phone company. Last week, Vodafone offered to buy the 85 percent of Cegetel it did not already own for 13.1 billion euros ($12.8 billion). The offer includes the stakes held by the BT Group, SBC Communications and Vivendi. Under the terms of a shareholder agreement, Vivendi has the option of counterbidding and can supersede Vodafone's offer for the BT or SBC stakes. Vodafone has given Vivendi a deadline of Nov. 10 to make a counteroffer. Vivendi's plans to either buy those stakes or try to get Vodafone to offer a higher price suffered a setback this week, when Vivendi received unacceptable offers for its publishing division, which includes Houghton Mifflin. It has now decided to auction Houghton Mifflin at a later date if it does not receive higher bids by tomorrow. Vivendi is arguing that the Nov. 10 deadline violates part of the Cegetel shareholder agreement, which stipulates that any offer for Cegetel must be accompanied by a 30-day grace period for due diligence. Vodafone says that rule does not apply to existing shareholders, who are already familiar with the company. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: James VanDerZee Betye Saar
description: Michael Rosenfeld Gallery

title: A Celebrated Artist's Biography, on the Verge of Being a Musical
description: The movie biography, a tricky genre to begin with, is never more so than when the subject is an artist. The lives of creative people are sometimes dramatic, but they rarely make satisfying drama, and even well-made, well-acted biopics tend to be dutiful, decorous and lifeless. The psychology of inspiration and the tedium of artistic labor seem to elude the conventions of filmmaking, so that our desire to glimpse the inner workings of genius is teased and thwarted. Instead, we are usually treated to the superficial pageantry of the artist's career -- sex and politics, drinking and fighting, celebrity and ruin.

title: Off-Season Overhaul May Loom for Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24  Almost all of the Anaheim Angels' significant players are signed for next season. A few important San Francisco Giants are not, and the team has made no secret it will not pay top dollar to bring them back.

title: N.F.L. Matchups | Week 8
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: SWIFT REACHES DEAL WITH UNION WORKERS AT BEEF PLANT
description: Swift & Company, the meat processor, has reached a contract agreement with workers at its beef plant in Omaha, the union representing the workers said yesterday. The contract provides a wage increase of 35 cents this year and 30 cents next year for the plant's 503 production workers, said Jill Cashen, a spokeswoman for the United Food and Commercial Workers Union. The 35 cents amounts to a 3.7 percent pay increase, based on a $9.40-an-hour starting wage at the plant, a Swift spokesman said. The contract took effect yesterday and expires in June 2004, Ms. Cashen said. Workers at the plant organized under the Food and Commercial Workers Union in May.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: General Is Suspended
description: A major general who told Parliament that the defense minister had ignored his warnings of a North Korean plan to attack a South Korean boat has been suspended for a month. After five South Korean sailors were killed in a North Korean attack on a Southern patrol boat in the Yellow Sea on June 29, Maj. Gen. Han Cheol Yong made his assertion about the response of the defense minister at the time, Kim Dong Shim. A defense ministry legal officer said General Han had ''failed to protect classified information and breached military discipline.'' The general said he would appeal. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Hair Evidence In Jogger Case Is Discredited
description: Contrary to arguments made by a prosecutor at two trials in 1990, four strands of hair were never ''matched'' to any of the Harlem teenagers accused of beating and raping a jogger in Central Park, a former police scientist said this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, THOMAS B.
description: ROSS-Thomas B., 73. Died October 24, at Eastern Long Island Hospital, after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife Gunilla (Ekstrand) of Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., daughters Maria, Anne and Kristina, two granddaughters and his sister Grace Shanley. Vice President, Government Relations, Loral Space & Communications, Inc., he was formerly Special Assistant to President Clinton and Senior Director of Public Affairs for the National Security Council, a Senior Vice President of NBC News, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs in the Carter Administration, and foreign correspondent and Washington Bureau Chief of the Chicago Sun-Times. Coauthor with David Wise of three books on government intelligence, including New York Times number one bestseller, ''The Invisible Government,'' and a Nieman Fellow at Harvard, he served three years as an officer in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yale University, Class of 1951 Memorial Scholarship Fund.

title: How Not to Run A State Legislature
description: To the Editor:

title: One Seat Shy of Control, Lott Battles for Senate
description: Trent Lott was at the AQ Chicken House in the Republican heart of Arkansas today, ostensibly to rally support for Tim Hutchinson, one of the Senate colleagues he was most worried about losing.

title: Six American Classics to Conjure With and Celebrate
description: American Ballet Theater moves toward the final weekend of its City Center season, but there is still time for new works. The premiere of ''. . . smile with my heart,'' Lar Lubovitch's tribute to Richard Rodgers, elicited a delirious response on Wednesday night.

title: The Juvenile Jinx
description: In the 18 runnings of the Breeders Cup Juvenile, the winner has gone on to be named the top 2-year-old on 14 occasions. But not once has the winner of the Juvenile gone on to win the Kentucky Derby the following spring.

title: Ex-Wife Finds Her New Life Shadowed by Man She Left
description: Unpleasant things were left behind in Tacoma, Wash., when Mildred Muhammad packed up in the spring of 2001 and came here with her three children to live with her sister in a white town house on Quiet Brook Lane.

title: Remembering Call to Priest And Quiet Pair
description: It seems that John Allen Muhammad, the Muslim convert and, according to the authorities, the East Coast sniper, reached out to a Roman Catholic priest last Friday.

title: Investors Balk a Bit at a Casino Offering
description: Investors, who have lost heavily over the last two years in the stock market, have decided to hedge their bets on Steve Wynn, the casino mogul whose properties revitalized Las Vegas in the 1990's.

title: Where, When and How to BASE Jump . . . or Not
description: BASE jumping experts recommend these prerequisites for would-be participants: jumpers must log 200 sky dives; use BASE gear as opposed to converted sky-diving gear; take a first-jump course; avoid damage to people, property and the environment; use legal sites; and research the jump site.

title: Works for Players to Get Their Teeth Into
description: James Levine appears to have struck a deal with the musicians in the Met's orchestra. In exchange for enduring hours of warbling on Monday when Bellini's ''Pirata'' opened, they could spend the previous afternoon performing works they could get their teeth into, both technically and intellectually.

title: Florida Court Rejects Death Row Appeal
description: The Florida Supreme Court cleared the way today for the execution of two inmates who had challenged the state's death penalty laws on the basis of a United States Supreme Court ruling earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPIETRO, OLGA
description: DePIETRO-Olga. Of Beechhurst, NY on October 23. Died peacefully in her sleep. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Dr. Joseph DePietro. She is survived by her daughter, Phyllis, her sons, Joseph and William, by her grandchildren, Joseph, Deborah, Diana, Douglas, Susan, Michael, Emily and Sarah, and by 9 great-grandchildren; and by her beloved brother Nicholas DeLucia. A devoted mother and grandmother and faithful friend, she will be deeply missed. Visitation at Fairchild Sons Inc. 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, NY on Sunday, October 27, 3-5 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, October 28, 10 AM, at St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset.

title: McCall Faces a Struggle To Emerge From Behind
description: It had been almost a week since the first of two news articles mentioned that Sikhulu Shange would love to hang a ''McCall for Governor'' sign in his shop window in Harlem, if only he had one.

title: END OF A HUNT
description: RIFLE AN UNLIKELY CHOICE -- The gun seized from the two suspects, a civilian version of the standard American military rifle, the M-16, is a slightly unusual choice for a sniper, an expert said. PAGE A29

title: Young Sherlock, Before the Cap and Pipe
description: Professor Moriarty knows he has his hands on a hot, highly profitable new product. ''Five times more powerful than morphine, 10 times more addictive,'' he says. ''People will kill for it. They'll steal the food from their children's mouths for a single injection.''

title: Five Passengers and a Judge With Murder on His Mind
description: THE JUDGES

title: 'The Bank'
description: Directed by Robert Connolly

title: Days of Diplomacy
description: Deep in the heart of Texas, the Bush family is offering some high-powered hospitality to Jiang Zemin. In a trip reminiscent of Deng Xiaoping's visit to Houston in 1979, the Chinese president has toured NASA's Johnson Space Center, been feted by George H. W. Bush, the onetime ambassador to Beijing, and spoken at the presidential library in College Station. Today he will visit the presidential ranch in Crawford and enjoy some Texas barbecue with George W. Bush.

title: Disney to Offer New Internet Access Service
description: The Walt Disney Company will introduce a new dial-up Internet access service aimed at families with children that is a customized version of Microsoft's MSN. Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chief executive, announced the new service in a surprise appearance on a stage set up by Microsoft in Central Park yesterday to start a $300 million marketing blitz for the next version of MSN.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: STATE FUND LOSES LESS THAN EXPECTED

title: They Also Serve Who First Must Primp and Perm
description: The World War II action comedy ''All the Queen's Men'' is even more of a drag than its weary premise suggests. The picture's elements finally fall into place about 40 minutes into it -- a big burden on a film that runs only 99 minutes. It's about a small group of soldiers assigned to infiltrate a factory in Nazi Germany that manufactures the Enigma code machine. Since all of the able-bodied German men were off fighting by 1944, when this movie takes place, the factories employ only women, so the Allied soldiers assigned to retrieve one of these devices have to dress as women.

title: Sports of The Times; These Days, Greatest Moments Seem to Be Everywhere
description: Britney Spears is a better singer than Ella Fitzgerald.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Urge Meeting On Safety
description: The United Federation of Teachers, angry over recent assaults in the schools, has called for a systemwide top-level meeting to explore ways to reduce school violence. The union described nine violent incidents in the last week, including the case of a student who was stabbed in the chest at a Queens high school. ''The last week has demonstrated that we need to do more to solve the problem of violent incidents,'' said Randi Weingarten, the union's president. A spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the Office of School Planning and Safety would address the problem. ''Randi should know by now that we are more interested in taking action than talking,'' the spokesman said. On Wednesday, the chancellor's office said it planned to add nearly 300 security guards to the schools. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: City Officials Tell Microsoft to Get Its Butterfly Decals Out of Town
description: Two days after city inspectors ripped up illegal Nike advertising decals glued to sidewalks along Central Park West, Microsoft unleashed a swarm of large adhesive butterflies in Manhattan.

title: Dying for Lack of Nurses
description: A report in this week's Journal of the American Medical Association says that when hospital nurses are given too many patients to care for, the patients have a much greater risk of dying. That may seem self-evident, but it has been surprisingly difficult to establish that patients suffer harm when a nurse's patient load goes up.

title: 'Ghost Ship'
description: Directed by Steve Beck

title: Bloomberg Is Backing Another Map For Council
description: A day after a government commission released its first draft of a new map of City Council districts, an alternate plan favored by the Bloomberg administration surfaced.

title: Alabama Shooting Is Studied For Clues to a Lethal Debut
description: It was just another Saturday night robbery and killing, or so it seemed, at least to anyone who caught the few paragraphs that it rated in the Alabama newspapers. Someone stalked two women closing a state liquor store on Sept. 21, shot them at close range, killing one, and then eluded a police officer in a foot chase -- helped, intentionally or not, by a mysterious driver in a blue sedan.

title: Terrorism Panel Says U.S. Is Still Unready
description: Despite months of preparations and the spending of millions of dollars, the United States remains extremely vulnerable to a terrorist attack, particularly at seaports, power plants and oil refineries, a panel of security experts has concluded.

title: Starters Are Finishing Early
description: Randy Johnson and Curt Schilling have not pitched and will not pitch in this World Series. They were in the last World Series. Roger Clemens hasn't made an appearance either. And don't expect to see Pedro Martnez. The team he plays for is allergic to the World Series.

title: With 2 Held, Police Tie Rifle in Car to Sniper Killings
description: A harrowing three-week ordeal came to an end today as police officers arrested two suspects in the sniper shootings that left 10 people dead, three wounded and the capital region terrified.

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Voices In a Rarity Of Bizet's
description: For more than 30 years, as the music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, the conductor Eve Queler has been providing New York opera lovers with invaluable chances to hear rare or neglected works in concert performances. But the performance of Bizet's seldom-heard ''Pcheurs de Perles'' (''The Pearl Fishers'') that she presented on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall was far from her best work.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Accused Of Sex Abuse
description: The police are seeking as many as a dozen teenage girls lured by a Queens man who the police believe sexually abused them and made photographs and videotapes of the encounters. The police arrested the man, Alberto Dominquez, 42, of Forest Hills, after a 15-year-old girl said he had sexually abused her in his apartment. The police said Mr. Dominquez, who videotapes weddings and parties professionally, met the girl at her 15th-birthday party and later made an appointment for her to visit his apartment on Wednesday by saying he could make her famous as a model. A search of Mr. Dominquez's home turned up several videotapes and photo albums in which underage girls appear. Mr. Dominquez is charged with sexual abuse and use of a child in a sexual performance and faces a 15-year sentence if convicted. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Millicent H. Boudjakdji -- Philanthropist, 63
description: Millicent Hearst Boudjakdji, president of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation and a director of the Hearst Corporation, died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 63.

title: Drug Agency Weighs Role Of Hormone Replacements
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it was still wrestling with questions about how to regulate hormone replacement therapy for postmenopausal women after a study raised questions about its safety.

title: 'Duck in a Noose' Is Traced to a Folk Tale
description: The caller -- presumably the sniper himself -- was the first to throw out the puzzling phrase, which was then repeated by the Montgomery County police chief on Wednesday at a late-night news conference, apparently by way of confirmation.

title: Lady Longford, 96, a Biographer, Political Activist and Mother of Writers
description: Elizabeth Longford, the best-selling biographer and political activist who was the widow of the social reformer Lord Longford and the matriarch of a family that bred other well-known writers, died on Wednesday at her home in Sussex. She was 96.

title: Japan's Economy Czar Caught in Bitter Revolt
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's hand-picked economic czar came under fresh attack today over his plan for radical action to clean up the country's banking crisis. The developments are rattling the financial community and putting Mr. Koizumi to the most severe political test of his administration.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: 'Puffy Cheek' Suspect Arrested
description: The F.B.I. has arrested a postal employee who officials believe is responsible for a string of bank robberies across New Jersey and several other Eastern states. The authorities said the man, Cazzie Williams, 30, a resident of East Orange, was arrested on Wednesday. He may be responsible for 18 robberies in New Jersey since 1988 and 9 in Maryland, Virginia and Pennsylvania. Investigators had called the robber ''the puffy cheek bandit'' because of what witnesses described as swollen cheeks. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: 'By Hook or by Crook'
description: Directed by Harry Dodge and Silas Howard

title: Suspects Spent Year Traveling, Nearly Destitute
description: John Allen Muhammad was known to friends for his crushing handshake, his deft touch in repairing fast cars -- and his temper.

title: Mets Move On Howe With Baker Nearly Free
description: If scouts were rating Fred Wilpon the way they do players, they would have to downgrade him for having bad hands.

title: Dead Parrot Society
description: A few days ago The Washington Post's Dana Milbank wrote an article explaining that for George W. Bush, ''facts are malleable.'' Documenting ''dubious, if not wrong'' statements on a variety of subjects, from Iraq's military capability to the federal budget, the White House correspondent declared that Mr. Bush's ''rhetoric has taken some flights of fancy.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about President Bush's campaigning on behalf of Republican candidates misstated the White House position once held by John Podesta, who commented on the political risk to President Bush. At the time of the 1994 elections, Mr. Podesta was staff secretary in the Clinton White House; the chief of staff was Leon E. Panetta.

title: Kay WalkingStick
description: June Kelly Gallery

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A Clouzot Star Remembers . . .

title: Gains in Understanding Human Cells
description: Scientists at the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass., have made a significant stride toward understanding how a living cell's operations are controlled by the information in its genome. The insight, which gives a detailed view of the cell's computerlike biological circuitry, should help researchers understand the cellular programming errors that underlie cancer and other diseases.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Chief Seen as Choice for Accounting Post
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has settled on William H. Webster, the former F.B.I. and C.I.A. director, to head a new agency regulating the accounting profession, commission officials and Congressional aides briefed about the decision said today.

title: Officials Say Records Show Gun Was Illegally Owned
description: Federal authorities said last night that a gun seized from two suspects had been officially linked to the shootings in the Washington area and that one of the suspects, John Allen Muhammad, should have been legally disqualified from buying or possessing it.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: THE NETHERLANDS: PROFIT UP AT KLM The Dutch

title: With an Eye on Taking Back the Senate, Bush Hits the Trail With Republican Candidates
description: The Senate will not be the same without Strom Thurmond and Jesse Helms, two Southern conservatives who served the Carolinas for so many decades that, at various moments, they drove Democratic and Republican presidents to distraction. But President Bush made clear today that his strategy of reclaiming control of the Senate depended on keeping in Republican hands the seats they were giving up, and he spent all day pressing for that outcome, and then some.

title: Rangers Prospect Returns to Russia
description: Fedor Tjutin, a 19-year-old defenseman regarded as the top prospect in the Rangers' organization, returned to his team in St. Petersburg, Russia, earlier this week so he could play the remainder of the Russian League season.

title: U.S. outlines shift in criteria for providing development aid
description: PARIS:  The head of the U.S. Agency for International Development this week has been explaining plans to restrict additional U.S. government aid to all but about 15 countries with solid democratic credentials and promising economies.

title: For Sprewell and Knicks, Fragile Partnership Continues
description: An uneasy truce has been forged. The Knicks say they are willing to overlook Latrell Sprewell's harsh criticism of their front office, excusing it as an angry outburst spoken in the heat of the moment. Sprewell says he can get past the embarrassment of being banished from practices and games for almost the entire preseason.

title: Lorna Simpson -- '31' and 'Cameos and Appearances'
description: Whitney Museum of American Art

title: Return Sought Of $10 Million WorldCom Paid Goldman
description: WorldCom's court-appointed bankruptcy monitor is trying to persuade Goldman, Sachs to return $10 million the company paid to Goldman several weeks before it filed for bankruptcy, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: DRS TECHNOLOGIES IS BUYING PARAVANT FOR $92 MILLION
description: DRS Technologies, a maker of computer displays for the military, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Paravant Inc., a maker of military computer products, for about $92 million. DRS said it would pay $4.75 a share for Paravant and assume $13 million in debt. The company, based in Parsippany, N.J., expects the purchase to add to earnings immediately and increase sales about $80 million in the first full year. Paravant, based in Morristown, N.J., said on Wednesday that it would provide computers to a General Dynamics unit for the British Ministry of Defense's Bowman program, a secure communications system. Its five-year contract is valued at $96 million.

title: Instead of Selecting, the Mets Settle for Howe
description: The Mets hired Art Howe as their manager, reaching an agreement Wednesday night with the man the Oakland Athletics were very willing to let depart and in essence ending a three week and one day search by hiring a polar opposite of Bobby Valentine.

title: Ex-Tennis Star Given 2 Years' Probation
description: Boris Becker, the scandal-scarred German tennis star, was sentenced today to two years' probation and fined nearly $300,000 after being found guilty of income tax evasion.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Swedish Diplomat Expelled
description: The government has ordered the expulsion of a Swedish diplomat in retaliation for Sweden's expulsion of an Iranian envoy. Junas Wendes, the deputy chief of mission, has been given a week to leave Iran. An Iranian diplomat in Stockholm, who has not been identified, was told to leave because he was trying to acquire goods that could used for military as well as civilian purposes, press reports said. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Senate Candidates Using Their Own Money, Disclosure Forms Show
description: In the millionaires' race for the United States Senate from New Jersey, the candidates are putting up most of the cash.

title: Budget-Cutting Struggles Sting an Already-Pained Fire Dept.
description: It is a ritual of budget-cutting time. The mayor tells his commissioners to save money by offering up cutbacks. The departments return with too few cuts, or cuts so severe that they can hardly be taken seriously.

title: Prosecutors to Discuss Charges as Rifle Is Tied to Sniper Killings
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 24  A harrowing three-week ordeal came to an end today as police officers arrested two suspects in the sniper shootings that left 10 people dead, three wounded and the capital region terrified.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TINT, ROBERT S.
description: TINT-Robert S. An intelligent, kind and gentle man, a professional engineer, died on October 23rd, 2002. He is survived by his loving wife, Leonora, daughter Barbara, sister Ruth and nephews Rick & Roy. A memorial gathering with collation will be announced at a later date.

title: A Gift to the Whitney, for New Yorkers to Open
description: The trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art recently did something smart. They pooled their pennies, acquired $200 million worth of postwar art and gave the whole shebang -- 87 works -- to the museum at once. That made it a big-bang gift, the kind that generates buzz, institutional optimism and, I'm sure it is hoped, further private largess.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: SLOW GROWTH IN TRADE SURPLUS Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew in September by 1.1 percent over September 2001 as export growth slowed, a worrying sign for the economy. Japan ran a 1.1 trillion yen ($8.4 billion) surplus in September, but exports grew a weaker-than-anticipated 6.9 percent in the month. Analysts worry that declining exports, which had been one of the few bright spots for the economy, will continue to taper off and push the economy back into recession. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Strategy on North Korea

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUSS, MARVIN A.
description: KRAUSS-Marvin A. All the associates from Marvin A. Krauss Associates mourn the loss of our teacher, mentor, and friend. He was a one-ofa-kind giant in the annals of Broadway and in our hearts. Creative, loyal, fair, funny, generous, and a force to be reckoned with. We will miss him. From us all, too many to list

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Some Homeless Reject Housing
description: Homeless families in city shelters rejected nearly one out of every three apartments offered to them in New York City Housing Authority buildings, according to a survey by the Department of Homeless Services released yesterday. The city seeks the right to exclude from city shelters families who repeatedly reject permanent housing. Between July 1 and Oct. 18, the survey said, 43 families rejected at least two apartments in city housing. Thirty-four families from that group have remained in city shelters at a cost of about $165,000, the department said. But critics called the survey politically motivated. Families are entitled to review two apartments before they decide on one, said Steve Banks, legal counsel to the homeless families. Leslie Kaufman (NYT)

title: Residential Real Estate; Co-ops Are Trying to Refinance Without Penalties
description: Like homeowners taking advantage of historically low mortgage rates to reduce their monthly payments, co-op corporations are anxious to refinance underlying mortgages on their buildings. But many co-ops face a hefty penalty if they pay off the current loan before its term expires.

title: China Fills 2nd-Tier Posts Before Coming Shake-Up
description: Two of the Communist Party's most secretive and powerful officials have given up their posts, the government news media announced today, one to retire and the other, apparently, as a prelude to a job at the pinnacle.

title: Adolph Green, Playwright and Lyricist Who Teamed With Comden, Dies at 87
description: Adolph Green, the playwright, performer and lyricist who in a six-decade collaboration with Betty Comden was co-author of such hit Broadway musicals as ''On the Town,'' ''Wonderful Town'' and ''Bells Are Ringing'' and screenplays for ''Singin' in the Rain'' and ''The Band Wagon,'' died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: WPP Revenue Falls About 3% As Profit Outlook Worsens
description: Raising the prospect of a renewed downturn in the advertising industry, the WPP Group said today that its revenue had fallen in the third quarter and that its profit outlook was worsening, not improving.

title: A Charming Cad Tries To Educate His Nephew
description: Who hasn't rubbed shoulders at one time or another with a glib motor-mouthed creep like Roger Swanson (Campbell Scott), the debonair know-it-all who bluffs his way through Dylan Kidd's acutely witty film ''Roger Dodger''? Roger, who is pushing 40, has the mind of a bogus high school lothario grown up and living in Manhattan but still clinging to a Penthouse ideal of bedroom belt-notching.

title: Israeli Troops Enter West Bank Town
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 25  Israeli forces again tightened their grip on the West Bank city of Jenin today.

title: State to Buy Long Island Land, Preserving It for Farms and Park
description: A 533-acre block of land that is among the largest parcels of privately owned undeveloped space on Long Island Sound will be preserved as farmland and a state park, New York State officials announced yesterday.

title: Castles in the Air Adorn Cities on Paper
description: First there was God, then came history, now there is the survival of the fittest. I'm not prepared to argue that this sequence represents the Ascent of Man. I am simply trying to tell you how architecture became the inspired mess it is today. It isn't all Philip Johnson's fault. He had helpers. Major historical influences were at work. And you should know something about these unseen forces if you want to get the most out of ''The Changing of the Avant-Garde,'' an important show of architectural drawings now on view at the Museum of Modern Art's temporary headquarters in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Shares Slump as Doubts About the Recent Rally Increase
description: Stocks fell for a second day in three yesterday amid concern that gains made in the last two weeks have driven prices higher than justified by the outlook for corporate profit growth.

title: 'Paid in Full'
description: Directed by Charles Stone III

title: Lorna Simpson; James VanDerZee; Robert Mangold
description: Lorna Simpson

title: No Excuse Necessary For Avoiding Bonds
description: Believe it or not, with a straight face and with no smile or smirk, Mike Scioscia did not dismiss the possibility of intentionally walking Barry Bonds with the bases loaded. If Scioscia believes it will help the Anaheim Angels inch closer to a victory over the San Francisco Giants, he conceded he would hold up four fingers, ignore any boos and sleep like a winning manager that night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ADOLPH
description: GREEN-Adolph. The Actors' Fund of America mourns the death of Adolph Green, whose brilliance will always illuminate our lives. Our heartfelt condolences to our dear trustee, Phyllis Newman, and their children, Amanda and Adam. Tom Dillon, President Joseph P. Benincasa, Executive Director

title: FAMILY FARE
description: All Hail, Halloween!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, SELMA
description: RUBEN-Selma. The officers and members of Old Oaks Country Club mourn the passing of Selma Ruben, mother of Richard Ruben, sister of Robert Belfer. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to the members of her family. Paul J. Konigsberg, President

title: Many Voice Surprise Arrested Men Are Black
description: The No. 1 topic of conversation at Artistic Expressions Natural Hair Salon this morning was not the Redskins or Iraq or how men just don't do right. The talk was about the person arrested in the Washington sniper case -- or specifically, about his race.

title: Chechens Kill Hostage In Siege at Russian Hall
description: Chechen rebels threatening to blow up a Moscow theater with as many as 700 hostages, including three Americans, turned over the body of a young woman on Thursday in a sign of their resolve and turned a rocket launcher on two other women who escaped the theater Thursday afternoon.

title: Kremlin on Edge After Chechens Threaten to Kill Hostages
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25 - The two-day standoff between Russian leaders and Chechen guerrillas holding at least 600 hostages here took an ominous turn late this evening as the guerrillas issued several threats to execute their captives, then demanded a meeting with a representative of President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: 'Y Tu Mam,' 'E.T.' and Bond
description: ''I enjoy 'Shrek' -- I'd love to do something like that,'' said the Mexican filmmaker Alfonso Cuarn, speaking from London, where he is preparing to direct ''Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban,'' the third installment of the series. If that ever happens, he can add an animated feature to children's classics like the Potter film, his ''Little Princess'' (1993) -- from the Frances Hodgson Burnett novel -- and his adaptation of ''Great Expectations'' (1998) along with social comedies with a sexual bent like his recent, acclaimed ''Y Tu Mam Tambin,'' whose title translates from the Spanish as ''And Your Mama, Too.''

title: World Briefing | World: Pessimism On Greenhouse-Gas Targets
description: At new talks on global warming in New Delhi, the United Nations official overseeing a 1992 climate treaty said the world was unlikely to achieve proposed reductions in heat-trapping gases unless the United States, the biggest source, cuts its emissions. President Bush has endorsed voluntary measures to slow growth in emissions, but not reduce them. The official, Joke Waller-Hunter, told Reuters, ''If you look at the current policies taken in the U.S., it's unlikely'' that targets set under the Kyoto Protocol, a 1997 addendum to the treaty, will be met. The Kyoto pact was signed by the Clinton administration but rejected last year by Mr. Bush. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Amazon's Loss in Quarter Shows a Sharp Decrease
description: With sales buoyed by its offer of free shipping, Amazon.com announced yesterday that it had sharply decreased its loss in the third quarter.

title: Smoking on the Street
description: To the Editor:

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Angry Telephone Call Provided One Crucial Clue
description: The first real break the one that sent investigators scurrying from an Alabama liquor store to a backyard in Tacoma, Wash., and finally to a blue Chevrolet Caprice at a highway rest stop in Maryland -- came on Oct. 17 in an angry telephone call from a man claiming to be the sniper.

title: Losing Its Terror, the Mundane Turns Joyous
description: All around the Washington suburbs today, people pumped their own gas. Children played outside. Their parents went shopping, and walked through the parking lots in steady, straight lines.

title: Cost-Cutting Ax Is Falling Again at ABB
description: Once again, Jrgen Dormann is finding himself having to slash and burn.

title: Citigroup Seen Cutting 1,000 Jobs
description: Citigroup is planning job cuts in its investment banking and corporate banking businesses, with more than 1,000 employees to be dismissed, according to executives who were briefed on the plans.

title: Paul Wellstone, U.S. Senator From Minnesota, Is Dead at 58
description: Senator Paul Wellstone, who was elected to the United States Senate as a maverick from Minnesota and became a leading voice for liberal Democrats, died in a plane crash today in northern Minnesota along with his wife, daughter and five others. He was 58.

title: Bristol-Myers to Restate Results to Reflect Shift in Inventory Policy
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it would restate its financial results to reflect its retreat from controversial inventory practices. The company also said third-quarter sales were hurt by competition from generic drug makers.

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Moment of Happy Fame for a Town
description: It was the helicopters that got Mayor Wayne Creadick's attention early this morning.

title: Its Swing Vote In the Council Gives Mexico More Muscle
description: For six weeks, the Mexican ambassador at the United Nations, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, warmed the bench at the sidelines of the debate over the United States resolution on Iraq, just like all the envoys from the 10 nations with nonpermanent seats on the Security Council.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bristol-Myers to Restate Results to Reflect Inventory

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Electronic Arts Earnings Exceed Expectations
description: The video game maker Electronic Arts, bolstered by strong sales of its flagship game, John Madden Football, reported second-quarter earnings that exceeded estimates of Wall Street analysts. The company reported earnings of 34 cents a share, double the consensus projection of analysts. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., said it sold three million copies of the Madden game in the quarter, a not totally unexpected figure, but still noteworthy given that a video game is considered a hit if it sells in excess of 500,000 copies. The company raised its estimates for how it will perform in the current quarter.

title: Men at Work: Camaraderie and Tension
description: Terry Creach's onrushing new ''Road Work'' is a series of dances that look like physically demanding structured improvisations, though Mr. Creach refers to the process as cooperative construction. The piece, presented by Creach/Company on Saturday night at Joyce SoHo, begins with a fascinating film of men drilling in a city street, projected on the back wall of the stage and shot in close-up and extremely slow motion.

title: An Economy Out of Whack Has a Friend
description: The news media's interest in Ms. Grubman was so high -- you may judge for yourself how much things have changed since 9/11 -- that the Suffolk County sheriff threw open his jail the other day to reporters and photographers. On the Lizzie Cell Tour, they got to see such fascinating items as the shower and toilet she will use and the baggy uniform she will wear for the next two months.

title: Hoping Overnight Success Follows Overnight Wait
description: They began lining up days beforehand, a human river of blond highlights, exposed midriffs, leopardskin-print blouses and bell-bottom jeans.

title: UConn Counting On New Talent
description: What can the Connecticut women's basketball team do for an encore?

title: The Original Australians, on Their Creative Turf
description: When the Australian government changed its currency from the Australian pound to the dollar in the 1960's, it used a design made from a bark painting by an Aboriginal artist, David Daymirringu, on the back of the new dollar note. But it neglected to ask the artist's permission, or even to notify him of its interest in his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, MAX G.
description: SANCHEZ-Max G. Age 83, of Teaneck, NJ, formerly of NYC, died Wednesday, October 23, 2002. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Krol). Devoted father of Max, Jr. Loving grandfather of Christina Randel and her husband Christopher. Loving great-grandfather of Joshua. Family will receive friends on Saturday and Sunday 2:00-4:00 and 7:00-9:00 PM at the Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Teaneck, NJ, (201836-0202). Funeral Monday from the funeral home to St. Joseph's RC Church, Hackensack. Time to be announced. Burial will follow at George Washington Memorial Park.

title: Paul McCarthy -- 'Clean Thoughts'
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRENTE, PATRICIA
description: CORRENTE - Patricia. We mourn the loss of our dear employee Patricia Corrente. All of us that worked alongside of Patty will forever miss her warmth, humor and compassion. Our sympathy and love goes to the friends and family that were close to this very special person. Lazar Corporate Advisors Inc

title: Technology Briefing: Software
description: ELECTRONIC ARTS EARNINGS EXCEED EXPECTATIONS The video game maker Electronic Arts, bolstered by strong sales of its flagship game, John Madden Football, reported second-quarter earnings that exceeded estimates of Wall Street analysts. The company reported earnings of 34 cents a share, double the consensus projection of analysts. The company, based in Redwood City, Calif., said it sold three million copies of the Madden game in the quarter, a not totally unexpected figure, but still noteworthy given that a video game is considered a hit if it sells in excess of 500,000 copies. The company raised its estimates for how it will perform in the current quarter.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about the sponsorship of a concert and prayer tour by the Chevrolet division of General Motors, misstated the name of a performer taking part. He is Michael W. Smith, not W. Michael Smith.

title: Democrats Do an About-Face on McCall, Pledging More
description: The Democratic National Committee agreed to put up another $250,000 for H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, yesterday, people familiar with negotiations between the two camps said.

title: Editors' Note
description: A picture in early editions on Sept. 20 showed a 6-year-old boy aiming a toy pistol alongside a sign reading ''Arabian Foods'' outside a store in Lackawanna, N.Y., near Buffalo. The store was near the scene of two arrests in a raid described by the authorities as a pre-emptive strike against a cell of Al Qaeda, and the picture appeared with an article recounting life stories of the detainees. The picture was not relevant to the article and should not have appeared; news editors deleted it before later editions went to press.

title: Saudis In Bikinis
description: On my first evening in Riyadh, I spotted a surreal scene: three giggly black ghosts, possibly young women enveloped in black cloaks called abayas, clustered around a display in a shopping mall, enthusiastically fingering a blouse so sheer and low-cut that my wife would never be caught dead in it. Afterward, I delicately asked a Saudi woman to explicate the scene.

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds Airport-Related Business in New York Hit Hard by 9/11, With 10,000 Jobs Lost
description: Since the World Trade Center attacks, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports have suffered larger economic losses than most other major hub airports in the country, a new study has found.

title: Rumsfeld Denies Rift Exists Between Pentagon and C.I.A.
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld went to great lengths today to describe a collegial, cooperative relationship between the Pentagon and the Central Intelligence Agency, even as he noted ''differences of opinions'' over how to interpret data on terrorist cells and adversary states like Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, REV. MONSIGNOR JAMES J.
description: MURRAY-Rev. Monsignor James J., 76. Son of the late Joseph and Rose Vallely Murray, brother of the late Rosaleen P. Sage (Donald), Mary M. Houlihan (James G.), John T. Murray (Eileen), Sister Mary Rose Murray, S.U., and Patrick W. Murray (Cathy). ''Uncle Bud'' survived by 10 Sage nieces and nephews and their spouses and children, six Houlihan nephews and nieces and their spouses and children, eight Murray nieces and nephews, and their spouses and children. Graduate of Our Lady of Angels School (Bronx), Regis High School ('42), U.S. Army ('44-'46), Fordham College ('48), Fordham Univ Law School ('51), Saint Joseph's Seminary ('56), Fordham Univ School of Social Service. Knight of Holy Sepulchre and Malta, Executive Director NY Catholic Charities for over 27 years. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Saturday and Sunday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christ The High Priest at Saint Patrick's Cathedral on Monday at 10 A.M. Interment Saint Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, New York. Contributions in his memory may made be made to Saint Joseph's Seminary, Dunwoodie, Yonkers, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CURATIVE HEALTH SERVICES, Hauppauge, N.Y., a manager of wound treatment centers, agreed to buy the drug unit of Home Care of New York, Scotia, N.Y., for $12 million in cash and debt.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: TALKS ON DOCKS CONTRACT A day after West Coast port employers charged longshoremen with staging illegal slowdowns, both sides met with a federal mediator to restart contract talks covering union workers on the docks, which handle more than half of United States trade. The meeting was the first since talks to end a lockout broke down this month. The shutdown prompted the Bush administration to secure a court order requiring the docks to reopen for an 80-day cooling-off period. (Reuters)

title: Japan Extends the Visit of 5 From North Korea
description: Japan said today that it would extend the stay of five people kidnapped by North Korea decades ago as long as possible so the returnees could decide their future ''freely.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Credit Rating Warning For Fujitsu
description: The outlook for Fujitsu's long-term debt was lowered to negative from stable, Moody's Investors Service said, citing the company's exposure to the weakened market for telecommunications equipment. Fujitsu, which has about 980 billion yen ($7.8 billion) in long-term obligations, is also a major producer of semiconductors, another industry in turmoil. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Speculation Swirls About Possible Successors to Wellstone
description: Among the names that are emerging as possible replacements for Senator Paul Wellstone on the Nov. 5 ballot are one that is obvious and one that is especially intriguing.

title: Lower Medicare Payouts Concern Bush Officials
description: Bush administration officials say they have become deeply concerned that a cut in Medicare payments to doctors, to be announced next week, will prompt many doctors to limit their participation in the program, reducing access to health care for the elderly.

title: F.B.I. Issues a Terror Warning, Citing Possible Threat to Trains
description: The F.B.I. issued a warning this evening that Al Qaeda may be planning to attack passenger trains, ''possibly using operatives who have a Western appearance.''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Pumping Up McCall Campaign

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Made in China: All White, Milky, Lily or Lard
description: Blanc de Chine is the neglected stepchild of the Chinese porcelain family. Chinese porcelain experts have, by and large, ignored the fine, white-glazed porcelain known in the West as blanc de Chine. This all-white, largely undecorated porcelain has been made in and around Dehua, a pottery town in the maritime province of Fujian in southern China, since the Ming dynasty (1368-1644).

title: ARAMARK IS BUYING FINE HOST FOR ABOUT $100 MILLION
description: Aramark, the stadium concession and facilities-management company, plans to buy a food service manager, the Fine Host Corporation, for about $100 million. Aramark gains a business with more than $300 million in sales last year and 900 customers across the country, a spokesman, Chris Hardwick, said. Aramark, based in Philadelphia, had sales of $7.8 billion last year. Fine Host is based in Greenwich, Conn. Its clients include schools, stadiums and arenas, convention centers and health-care facilities.

title: Scientists Shrink Computing to Molecular Level
description: Using a novel computing technique that resembles an elaborately staged billiards trick shot, I.B.M. scientists have created what they say is not only the world's smallest logic circuit, but also possibly the smallest that could ever be made.

title: Strong performances at television and radio units keep Viacom's results in line with estimates.
description: BUOYED by strong performances at its advertising-supported divisions like CBS, MTV Networks and radio, Viacom Inc. yesterday posted record third-quarter results in line with expectations.

title: A Synthetic Hormone Outdoes Estrogen in Mice Bone-Building
description: A newly identified synthetic hormone worked better than estrogen to strengthen bone when tested in mice, researchers are reporting today. Unlike estrogen, it did not increase the risk of breast or uterine cancer, they said.

title: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: South Korea And Chile In Pact
description: South Korea announced a free trade agreement with Chile, the first such agreement that it has reached with a foreign country. South Korean officials said the agreement would enable South Korean companies to use Chile as a springboard for business throughout Latin America. Korean farmers have protested, however, fearing that Chilean farmers will export large quantities of their products into Korea duty-free. Officials noted, however, that the agreement had an emergency provision in case of a sudden spike in imports. Korea is considering similar deals with Mexico, Japan and several other Asian countries.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOUSEMAN, JOAN NEE JEANNE COURTNEY
description: HOUSEMAN - Joan nee Jeanne Courtney. Who created so many special times and beautiful places in the course of her life, died on this day one year ago in NYC at the age of 85. She is well remembered by her family and by her beloved friends. We miss her greatly. It is a shock to think that so much time has already passed.

title: Lantau Island Journal; Under the Giant Buddha, a Tussle Over Tourists
description: The high plateau of the Po Lin Monastery was enveloped by a low cloud this morning as monks in ankle-length robes of black, brown and gray moved among gold-roofed, red-walled temples and past the stone pedestal of an 87-foot-tall bronze statue of Buddha. Pilgrims, here for a purification ritual, took turns sitting near a life-size golden Buddha.

title: He Drives, She Drives: A Love Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe To Dismiss 7.4% Of Work Force
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the maker of graphic-design software, is dismissing about 260 employees, or 7.4 percent of its work force, after five quarters of sales declines. The job cuts are taking place this week and are an effort to focus on Adobe's faster-growing businesses, like its Acrobat software for generating electronic forms, a spokeswoman, Holly Campbell, said. The company, which is based in San Jose, Calif., had about 3,500 employees before the reduction.

title: A Brutal Battle for Independence
description: Here are highlights of the Chechen resistance since the last years of the Soviet Union.

title: Crime in France
description: To the Editor:

title: A Son of Privilege, A Man of Torment; For an Upper West Sider, Twists And Turns to a Bewildering Death
description: More than four months after he died face down on a sidewalk in the Manhattan neighborhood where he lived most of his life, a 36-year-old man remains on a refrigerated steel shelf in Room 15A of the New York City morgue.

title: Bahrain Says 52% Vote Turnout Meets Democratic Goals
description: For the first time in nearly 30 years, this tiny Persian Gulf kingdom cast their ballots today to elect a parliament.

title: A Big Helping Of Art
description: The Whitney is showing off a big gift, which includes Claes Oldenburg's ''Giant B.L.T.''

title: Budget Deficit Is Said to Be $159 Billion
description: The Bush administration said today that the federal budget deficit for the year that ended Sept. 30 was $159 billion, a sharp swing from the surplus of $127 billion in the previous year and a harbinger of a partisan battle over how to move the budget back into balance.

title: 10 Hours in Coach? Pack to Make Time Fly
description: LIGHTEN up, pare down and go fly. Or, more likely, go stand and wait. Be ready to be searched, to remove your shoes and to suffer the indignity of seeing your personal belongings strewn about a security checkpoint. All this to get on a fully booked plane with tightly compressed seats, short-tempered fellow travelers, and little baggage room. It's guerrilla travel out there, and fliers need to plan accordingly.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUZZATTO, MARJORIE B.
description: LUZZATTO-Marjorie B. On October 22, 2002 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Giovanni. Loving mother of Alan and Stephen and mother-in-law of Sandra and Jane. Cherished Grammy of Jessica, Matthew, Michael and Christopher and three greatgrandchildren. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City 2-4 and 7-9 PM Friday. Religious service at funeral home 10 AM Saturday. Interment Cypress Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donation to the American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Shockey's Toe Injury Worries The Giants
description: The Giants expended first-round and fourth-round picks in April's draft to grab a 252-pound tight end who could run like a wideout. But now Jeremy Shockey has turf toe, and even if he plays again this season, he may no longer resemble the dynamic receiver who charged through Houston's defensive backs in his first N.F.L. action.

title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Tax Initiative Vote
description: The State Supreme Court would not block from the November ballot an initiative to abolish state and local sales taxes on groceries and over-the-counter medications, worth $435 million a year. Government officials contended that the proposition did not adequately explain the impact ending the taxes would have on government services, and said that other taxes would have to be increased. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Angels Have Giants Where They Want Them
description: Good news for Anaheim: The team trailing 3 games to 2 in the World Series often rallies to win the Series  if it is playing Games 6 and 7 at home. How often does it happen? Six of the last seven times it could have happened, it did.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, SOL.
description: BERNSTEIN-Sol. My dearest Daddy: Gone 3 years this very day. Where will I ever find the likes of you again? B.

title: Illusion and Disillusion: Chechen Crisis Comes Home for Putin
