description: Much of the world wonders tonight whether Russia will be able to free 700 actors and spectators held hostage for more than a day by a band of Chechen guerrillas. The larger question may be how to extract the hostage sitting a mere 10-minute drive from the crisis, behind the Kremlin's towering walls.

title: Jets' Line Is Finally Getting Itself Straight
description: As the Jets' defense went through a protracted getting-to-know-you phase, the offensive line could quietly empathize. It knows what it is like to replace members of a group as tightly knit as a sweater and to watch the results unexpectedly unravel.

title: Extracurricular Task: Testing Condoms
description: Britain's universities are often as not in the news, cast either as pinnacles of elitism or swamps of mediocrity. But today they were offered a new, libertine reputation as testing grounds of hedonism -- all thanks to a German condom maker that is offering to pay British students $150 per semester to rate its wares for ease of use and pleasure.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Slow Growth In Trade Surplus
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew in September by 1.1 percent over September 2001 as export growth slowed, a worrying sign for the economy. Japan ran a 1.1 trillion yen ($8.4 billion) surplus in September, but exports grew a weaker-than-anticipated 6.9 percent in the month. Analysts worry that declining exports, which had been one of the few bright spots for the economy, will continue to taper off and push the economy back into recession. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Tyco's Small Changes Leave Big Questions
description: MINOR frauds don't count.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAUER, ROSALYN BEDERSON
description: MAUER-Rosalyn Bederson, 82. Life-long resident of the Bronx and a committed educator and public schools advocate, died peacefully Wednesday. Loved by Arnold, her husband of 59 years, and her children Peri and Richard, her brother Ben and sister-in-law Betty, her daughter-in-law Barbara, grandchildren Jessica and Michael, and nephews Joshua, Geoffrey, Aron and Benjamin and their families. Services 9:30 AM Sunday, at Hirsch & Sons in the Bronx.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Dispute Affecting Tourists Ends
description: Officials reached an agreement with shrimp fishermen from the upper Gulf of California, resolving a dispute that temporarily affected local tourism. Last weekend, hundreds of fishermen protesting a new law that bans fishing in the upper gulf's federally protected marine reserve blocked the highway to the Arizona border, stranding hundreds of American tourists. The compromise will allow 130 boats to fish in the protected zone if they use special nets to prevent killing the endangered vaquita, the world's smallest porpoise. Eduardo Castillo (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDLER, ALBERT J.
description: SANDLER-Albert J. On October 23, late of Swampscott and Boston, MA. Husband of Frances ''Peppy'' (Geller) Sandler. Father of Leslie Kowal, Dorie Shub & Alan J. Sandler. Also survived by two sisters and 8 grandchildren. Services at Temple Israel, 837 Humphrey St., Swampscott, Massachusetts. on Sunday, October 27 at 11:00 A.M., Stanetsky - Hymanson Cha pels, Salem, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ALFRED
description: LERNER-Alfred. The medical staff, administration and the Board of Trustees of Hospital for Special Surgery expresses their deepest sorrow over the loss of Alfred Lerner. Mr. Lerner, who served as Chairman and CEO of MBNA, made an extraordinary contribution to the civic life of Cleveland. The leadership, character and reputation for integrity of the former Brooklyn native was evident by the growth of MBNA and his many philanthropic donations to medical research and educational causes. We extend our sincere condolences to his family, including his son Randy, who sits on our Board of Trustees. Services will be held Friday at the TempleTifereth Israel in Cleveland. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman, Board of Trustees John R. Reynolds, President and CEO Hospital for Special Surgery

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: HALE HOUSE SENTENCING

title: The Story Is in the Steps
description: LET'S put on a show,'' Twyla said to Billy, or some such thing. And so Twyla Tharp has conceived, directed and choreographed ''Movin' Out,'' a two-act story ballet set to Billy Joel's hit songs, which are performed by a band and a vocalist on a platform above her tornado-driven dancers at the Richard Rodgers Theater.

title: Hong Kong Is Under New Scrutiny
description: Credit-rating agencies, investors and bankers are voicing growing concern about the Hong Kong government's finances, citing a huge budget deficit, a stagnant economy and falling consumer prices.

title: INSIDE ART
description: A Mantegna Is Available

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARE, RICHARD V.
description: HARE-Richard V. Died on October 21st peacefully at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. As a well-known and respected Interior Designer he had the advantage of not only living in surroundings of unusual beauty but also helping to create them. He was educated in Europe but completed his secondary and tertiary education in the U.S. at Tabor Academy and Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, where he graduated with a Fine Arts degree. He continued his studies at Oxford University before returning to New York to begin his career at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and then the Frick Gallery. He then worked as an assistant to Rose Cumming where he learned the commercial aspects of dealing in fine antique furniture, accessories and Interior Design. He opened his own antiques and decorating business in 1949. He had antique showrooms in Manhattan and East Hampton, New York, and was commissioned to decorate notable residences throughout Europe and North America. During his life he was proud to have had the privilege of forging lasting and close friendships with many of his clients. He is survived by his son, Nicholas S. Hare of Darien; daughter-in-law, Christina K. Hare, and two grandchildren, Alexander and Michelle. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: St. George's School, PO Box 910, Newport, R.I. 02840.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYTTLE, ADA
description: LYTTLE-Ada, beloved sister of Joan Birman, Helen Kimmel and the late Ruth Satter; sister-in-law of Joseph L. Birman, Robert Satter and Martin Kimmel; aunt and greataunt died at age 71 on October 23, 2002. She retired to a life of quiet dignity after a long career as a schoolteacher in New York City. Service Friday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. & Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to the Museum of American Folk Art, NY.

title: An Unfamiliar Italian Master in an Unlikely New York Setting
description: Who knows when the last time was that a commercial gallery organized an old master retrospective as ambitious as ''Procaccini in America'' at Hall & Knight? It would do credit to pretty much any museum, including the museums that lent pictures to it, except that almost no American museum today would think of putting it on because Procaccini is an obscure dead artist with no guaranteed box-office appeal.

title: U.S. and Its Asian Partners Strain to Form United Stand on North Korea
description: Bush administration officials struggled today to develop a common strategy on North Korea with Asian partners amid increasing signs of criticism by South Korea, Japan and China that Washington was being too confrontational in its approach.

title: CBS Names Top Sales Executive
description: CBS Names Executive in Charge of Sales

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, VINCENT T.
description: SMITH-Vincent T., 83. Of Gilgo Beach, L.I., New York, (formerly of New York City), on October 22, 2002. Beloved husband of the late Madeline ''Dot''. Loving father of Cheryl Lauder and Adrienne Smith. Devoted grandfather of Craig (Kathy), Scott (Tammi), Todd Lauder (Peggy) and great-grandfather of Mackenzie and Stephanie Lauder. Dear brother of Arthur Smith. Friends may visit Friday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 P.M., at the Claude R. Boyd-Spencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main Street, Babylon, L.I. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 A.M., at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Babylon.

title: U.S. May Ask Court to Dismiss a $1 Trillion Suit Linking Saudis to Al Qaeda and 9/11
description: The Bush administration is closely monitoring a private lawsuit accusing members of the Saudi royal family of ties to Al Qaeda, and may move in a federal court here to dismiss or delay the suit, which was brought by relatives of Sept. 11 victims, according to administration officials.

title: Kent's Breakthrough Game Comes at Opportune Time
description: Jeff Kent gazed at his first home run sail into the left-field stands, watching the Giants' manageable lead balloon to comfortable proportions and broke into a smile, slapped his hands together and punched the sky as he rounded first base.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It takes courage to put together a menu without a steak on it, or any beef at all, for that matter. It especially takes courage to put together such an uncompromising menu at the corner of Broadway and 88th Street.

title: A Fight Over Farms Ends, Opening Way to Wider Europe
description: A rift between France and Germany over aid to farmers was resolved today, allowing the leaders of the European Union to begin talks on integrating 10 new countries into their club by 2004.

title: He Was a Moon Eclipsed by Stars
description: THE first painting you are likely to see in the Metropolitan Museum's show of the 19th-century French artist Thodore Chassriau is one of the few by him that have achieved a measure of fame: his portrait of his sisters Adle and Aline, pale and self-assured, identically dressed in pink-and-gold blouses and red cashmere shawls, staring impassively across the show's first gallery. They look like twins and seem almost joined at the hip, their arms entwined, the flowery patterns on the hems of their shawls meeting as if they were wearing a single garment.

title: Connecticut Group Is Formed to Oppose the Expansion of Casino Gambling
description: With support from state and municipal officials, regional business groups, church leaders and residents, a coalition of casino opponents announced today that they had formed a statewide nonprofit group to fight the expansion of casino gambling.

title: Study Tallies Sites Blocked By Google
description: Google, the popular Internet search engine, has excluded more than 100 Web sites from the French and German versions of its index under pressure from those nations' governments, a new study has found.

title: Democrats Expecting Inroads in the West
description: On the election-night map two years ago, the Interior West was awash in red, a vivid tribute to Republican success even though George W. Bush's triumph over Al Gore would take a few extra weeks to settle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOLLES, HANNAH R.
description: JOLLES-Hannah R. On October 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Harry, mother of Ira and Andrea, grandmother of Adam and Noah and sister of Leonard H. Rapaport. We will miss her. Graveside services Friday 10 A.M. at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: North Carolina State Shows Why It's in the Hunt
description: North Carolina State has stood on the periphery of the national championship hunt. The Wolfpack has been a team to watch, but not necessarily one to follow.

title: Possible Late Rescue for Vanguard Airlines
description: The chief executive of Vanguard Airlines said yesterday that his company, now bankrupt, was preparing to liquidate its assets even as it continued last-minute negotiations with a potential investment group.

title: Tyco Inquiry Mostly Clears Its Accounting
description: Tyco International said yesterday that it did not expect that its internal investigation would uncover a huge accounting fraud, an announcement that pushed its shares higher.

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTOLA, DR. EDWARD
description: MORTOLA - Dr. Edward. President Stephen J. Jerome (an alumnus of Pace University) and The Monroe College community note with sadness the death of Dr. Edward Mortola, Chancellor Emeritus of Pace University. His vision, leadership and innovative approach to higher education had a profound impact on the growth and enhancement of the university. He touched the lives of thousands of people. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Doris, and his family. Stephen J. Jerome, President

title: Ball Profit Up, Stock Down
description: The Ball Corporation, which agreed in August to buy a German can maker for $1.18 billion, said today that its third-quarter profit rose 38 percent because of more sales of aluminum cans and plastic bottles for beverages. Net income increased to $50 million, or 87 cents a share, from $36.3 million, or 61 cents, a year earlier.

title: Israeli Bedouin Colonel Is Formally Charged With Spying
description: An Israeli military court indicted a lieutenant colonel today on charges of spying for the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah, a case that has transfixed Israelis and seems likely to heighten tension between Israel's Jewish and Arab populations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, MAURINE M.
description: WIENER-Maurine M. Died on October 23rd in Savannah after a battle with cancer. She had lived in Litchfield, CT; Rye, NY; and with her beloved husband, Leroy G. Monsky, Sr, in Birmingham, AL. for 35 years. She is now survived by the family who loved her - her husband of 12 years, Jules A. Wiener, her daughters, Julie Metzger and Meredith Bodziner and their spouses, Burton Metzger and Richard Bodziner. Her grandchildren are Thomas A. Garson, Jr, Michael D. Garson, Erica Bodziner, and Lisa Bodziner. There was never a better melding than that with Jules' children - Frank, Joshua, Judith and Leonora, and their spouses, and his seven grandchildren, all of whom adored her. She is also survived by a son - Leroy G. Monsky. Contibutions to a charity of your choice or to Cancer Research, or Hospice of Savannah would be appreciated.

title: Cold Beer, a Warm Grill and 80,000 of Your Closest Friends
description: PATRICK McKELVEY'S silver 1983 Chevy cargo van is insured only from mid-August through late November. The odometer has gone up maybe 5,000 miles since he bought it in 1985, in increments of eight miles -- the distance between his driveway in Mishawaka, Ind., and the University of Notre Dame in South Bend. A beer tap pokes out from the rear flank, underneath a rolled-up awning that he carries in case of rain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMM, SARA BABBITT
description: STAMM-Sara Babbitt. Born May 27, 1916, in Rockingham VT, this indomitable New Yorker died October 19th in Manhattan. She was a passionate cook and the author of the books ''Yankee Magazine's Favorite New England Recipes'' and ''The Park Avenue Cookbook''. After graduating from Vassar in 1936 she moved to NYC where, in 1943, she married John Davies Stamm of Milwaukee, who died in 1974. They had three children: Lisa Stamm Booher of Shelter Island, NY, Davies Stamm of Athens, VT, and Peter Stamm of Westminster West, VT. She is also survived by her sister Betty Babbitt of Keene, NH; her son-in-law Dale Booher and granddaughter Vanessa Babbitt Booher, both of Shelter Island and Steven Connell of NYC. ''It was roses, roses all the way...'' -Robert Browning

title: Kona Gold Continues to Surpass His Age Limits
description: It was a lazy afternoon last year when the venerable Kona Gold was nursing sore feet, wasn't racing and really had nothing better to do. So a bunch of small children climbed aboard, one after another, as he loped back and forth across the pasture outside the home of his trainer and part owner, Bruce Headley. A past Breeders' Cup winner, one with as much speed and will as any among the high-strung fraternity of racing thoroughbreds, was doubling as a kiddie ride.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, PHILIP O., M.D.
description: ETTINGER-Philip O., M.D. Of Leonia, NJ, on October 22, 2002. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Cherished son of the late Sam and Charlotte & stepson of Hana. Devoted father of Alyssa & Jonathan. Dear brother of Stephen J. Ettinger, D.V.M. Services on Monday 1 PM at ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Putney School, Elm Lea Farm, Putney, Vermont 05346.

title: Stability, Not War
description: To the Editor:

title: Nets Waive Three
description: The Nets waived guards John Celestand and Danny Earl yesterday, along with center Lonnie Jones. The team could be interested in reacquiring the free agent Anthony Johnson, who played backup point guard last season. He was released by Cleveland on Wednesday. Liz Robbins

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hale House Sentencing
description: Lorraine E. Hale, the former president of Hale House, and her husband, Jesse L. DeVore, were sentenced yesterday to five years' probation for stealing more than $1 million from the Harlem children's shelter. Dr. Hale, 76, who founded the charity with her mother -- who was known as Mother Hale -- in 1969, and Mr. DeVore, 70, are destitute and cannot pay back most of what they stole, their lawyers said. Judge Herbert I. Altman of Supreme Court in Manhattan imposed the sentence, which was agreed upon when the couple pleaded guilty in July to a single felony count. Vincent J. O'Reilly, an assistant state attorney general, said the couple had filed a required financial statement. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Muddling Through, Souls Shredded but Intact
description: After his foray into period drama and the mysteries of artistic collaboration in ''Topsy-Turvy,'' Mike Leigh returns, with ''All or Nothing,'' to more familiar terrain: the hard luck and domestic distress of the contemporary English working class. Like ''High Hopes'' and ''Life Is Sweet,'' two of Mr. Leigh's earlier explorations of pain and resilience in the housing projects and row houses of modern London, ''All or Nothing,'' which opens today nationwide, has a title that at first glance invites an ironic interpretation. Its characters muddle through lives of lowered expectations and weary disappointment; they hover somewhere between just enough and a little bit less.

title: End Is Seen to Long Battle for Cruise Line
description: The Carnival Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to buy P&O Princess Cruises for about $5.4 billion in stock, bringing a long-running battle for the cruise line to a close.

title: Cable's Focus on Sniper Helped the Authorities, but Also Drew Harsh Critics
description: The omnivorous coverage that the cable news networks gave to the hunt for the sniper terrorizing Maryland and Virginia has thrust them once again into a heated debate over the nature of cable news. Did all the attention prove crucial in the capture of the prime suspects? Or did it just feed audiences a diet of recycled information, misinformation and speculation, keeping them mesmerized and terrified?

title: Sutton to Head Ryder Team
description: If the Americans need more inspiration at the Ryder Cup, Hal Sutton plans to provide it.

title: Ashcroft Says U.S. Will Place Agents in China
description: Concluding a three-day visit to Beijing today, Attorney General John Ashcroft offered praise for China's efforts to combat international terrorism and announced the opening of an F.B.I. liaison office in Beijing to further that effort.

title: Clare Woods
description: Cohan Leslie and Browne

title: Weekender | Falls Village, Conn.
description: IT is not surprising that Main Street in Falls Village often seems deserted. As Connecticut's second-smallest hamlet, Falls Village is also one of the most rural. For New Yorkers who are trying to escape crowds and the creeping conspicuous consumption found in other parts of Litchfield County, Falls Village is a low-key haven.

title: Beauford Smith Linda Hiwot
description: Wilmer Jennings Gallery

title: Giants Might Have Off-Season Overhaul
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 24  Almost all of the Anaheim Angels' significant players are signed for next season. A few important San Francisco Giants are not, and the team has made no secret it will not pay top dollar to bring them back.

title: 'Meet the Women'
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Syracuse Just Not Sure What the Problem Is
description: The taxi driver picked up a fare at the airport and uttered this disjointed greeting: ''Nice day, isn't it? Our football team is lousy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILLEGAS, DONALD L.
description: HILLEGAS-Donald L. Died on October 17th, 2002. He is survived by his sisters Joan and Joy Hillegas, Mary Davis and Barbara Hanggi; his brothers Robert and Andrew and his companion Louis Vuolo. A memorial will be held at a later date.

title: Washington's Mr. Fix-It As Overseer Of Accounting
description: Whenever high-ranking officials have gathered recently to pick someone with an unsullied reputation for a sullied situation, William H. Webster has always been at the top of the list.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's cold out, it's overcast, but I haven't seen a more glorious day in this area for quite a while. It's absolutely gorgeous because we don't have to live in fear.''

title: Gore Calls U.S. Vulnerable To More Bioterror Attacks
description: Former Vice President Al Gore said today that a ''dangerous weakness in our health care system'' made the United States vulnerable to terrorist attacks using anthrax, smallpox and other biological weapons.

title: In a Top 40 State Of Mind
description: WHEN a young man kicks up his heels in the new Broadway show ''Movin' Out,'' which opened last night at the Richard Rodgers Theater, the feeling isn't just fancy-free. True, Eddie, a strapping boy in his salad days, has every reason to be frisky. He is newly split from his fiance, and there are plenty of delicious women just waiting to step out with him.

description: College football's top matchups on Saturday:

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: For Congress in New York
description: Here are our endorsements in two of the more competitive Congressional races in New York:

title: Disease Related To Anemia Drug
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that the number of suspected cases of a rare disease associated with its anemia drug Eprex had risen to 160 as of the end of July from 141 as of the end of May. But the company said that while it was too soon to cite a trend, the number of cases appears to be ''flattening.''

title: Alfred Lerner, 69, Banker; Revived Cleveland Browns
description: Alfred Lerner, who grew up behind his immigrant family's luncheonette in Brooklyn, rose to become a billionaire investor in banking and real estate, then revived one of sport's best-known names as owner of pro football's Cleveland Browns expansion franchise, died Wednesday in Cleveland. Mr. Lerner, who lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio, was 69.

title: 'Food of Love'
description: Directed by Ventura Pons

title: More Talk on Attacks Than Taxes at Trade Forum
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell bumped into his Russian counterpart, Igor S. Ivanov, at a morning kaffeeklatsch today, and all they could talk about were the sniper suspects in Maryland and the hostages in Moscow.

title: Harry Hay, Early Proponent of Gay Rights, Dies at 90
description: Harry Hay, who founded a secret organization six decades ago that proved to be the catalyst for the American gay rights movement, died early Thursday morning at his home in San Francisco. He was 90.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Events

title: MEDIMMUNE EXPECTS DELAY IN INTRODUCTION OF VACCINE
description: MedImmune's FluMist nasal flu vaccine will probably not receive federal approval until the second quarter of 2003, the company said yesterday. MedImmune intended to introduce the vaccine late this year, giving it sales in the winter flu season. After the company said it expected approval next year, its stock fell $3.05, or 11 percent, to $24.50. MedImmune, which acquired the nasal spray in a takeover of Aviron, expects to present its application for the product's approval to a panel of Food and Drug Administration advisers on Dec. 17. The company expects the drug to become its next big product, with the potential to generate almost $1 billion in sales.

title: Minnesota Crash Kills Wellstone Amid Senate Fight
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 25 - Senator Paul Wellstone, a two-term Democrat locked in one of the tightest campaigns in the nation, was killed this morning when his campaign plane crashed in freezing rain near Eveleth, Minn., a small town in the northeastern part of the state. Mr. Wellstone's high school sweetheart and wife of 39 years, Sheila; his 33-year-old daughter, Marcia Markuson; three campaign aides; and two pilots also died in the fiery crash, which obliterated their 11-seat turboprop among the pine trees.

title: Mail-Order Homes: Insert House (A) Into Idyllic Landscape (B)
description: WHAT could be shabbier than a cookie-cutter home designed by Sears, Roebuck & Company, Michelle d'Arcambal wondered. What could the graying uncle to the Home Depot and Target possibly know of architecture and design, let alone modern living?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sales Up At Nestl
description: The food and beverage company Nestl said sales in the first nine months of the year rose 6 percent, to 66.2 billion Swiss francs. Nestl did not release profit figures, but it said the sales increase fell short of its target. The chief executive, Peter Brabeck-Letmathe, said the company, which recently made an unsuccessful bid to buy Hershey Foods, would concentrate on further acquisitions in the nutrition business. Sales in the pet care division, which includes Ralston Purina for the first time, rose to 7.8 billion Swiss francs from 4.5 billion. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: 36 Hours | Ithaca, N.Y.
description: ITHACA is well known for Cornell University, Ithaca College and a landscape of hills, gorges and waterfalls, and less known as the home of the Buddhist monastery where Courtney Love brought two handfuls of the ashes of her husband, Kurt Cobain, for a consecration ritual. At the southern end of Cayuga Lake and surrounded by blue hills and farmland, Ithaca is the center of an area with a rich blend of artistic, intellectual and rural cultures. The young woman serving you coffee might be a cellist and a piano tuner. The farmer who beats you at pool could well be a Socialist. There are enough restaurants so that none can afford to be mediocre, and it's hard to go out without hearing live jazz, bluegrass, rock or ethnic music. (Pick up a copy of The Ithaca Times -- a free weekly entertainment paper lying around in delis and coffeehouses -- to see who's playing where.) The only troubles are the rain, which is frequent, and the winter, which is long and cold. Fall, however, is a great time to visit. REBECCA BARRY

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Profit Up At KLM
description: The Dutch airline KLM said its profit more than tripled in the fiscal second-quarter compared with the period a year earlier when terrorist attacks in New York and Washington caused earnings to plunge. After news that its profit had soared to 86 million euros, compared with 27 million euros a year ago, KLM cautioned investors that it was still expecting a net loss for the year because of market uncertainties. Revenue for the quarter was flat at 1.85 billion euros, but KLM exceeded some analysts' expectations in trimming costs. The carrier, which is based in Amsterdam, cut back on available seating, reduced its flight schedule and lowered fares on many European routes. On average, KLM was able to fill 84 percent of its seats in the quarter, up 1.8 percentage points from a year earlier.

title: Run the Country? No. He Just Wants to Rouse It.
description: SEAN HANNITY, the cable television and radio host who tends to season his compassionate Conservatism with a double dose of buttinski bombast, is on the cusp of losing a debate over the most suitable locale for a heart-to-heart regarding his soaring fortunes. These include a cornucopia of career coups to make a lesser man blush: a best seller, a Fox News primetime show that is knocking Larry King for a loop in the ratings, and a talk fest on WABC-AM that reached second place in the national ranks a year into syndication.

title: If Boys Can Do It, Girls Can Dodge It
description: I CAN admit it only now: I never accepted the theory, advanced in my childhood, that girls can do anything. Around my parents' house in New Hampshire, that ''can'' slipped way too easily into ''should,'' and liberation became an obligation.

title: The Vatican on 'Zero Tolerance'
description: To the Editor:

title: Carmaker's Complaint
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Y Tu Mam,' 'E.T.' and Bond
description: enjoy `Shrek'  I'd love to do something like that," said the Mexican filmmaker Alfonso Cuaron, speaking from London, where he is preparing to direct "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban," the third installment of the series. If that ever happens, he can add an animated feature to children's classics like the Potter film, his "Little Princess" (1993)  from the Frances Hodgson Burnett novel  and his adaptation of "Great Expectations" (1998) along with social comedies with a sexual bent like his recent, acclaimed "Y Tu Mama Tambien," whose title translates from the Spanish as "And Your Mama, Too."

title: Mystery Husband Turns Up Dead
description: Sometimes you fall in love with a movie, even when you should know better. And there's a great possibility that will happen with ''The Truth About Charlie.'' That infatuation is possible in part because the director, Jonathan Demme, uses the nervous energy that he suppressed in more formal works like ''Philadelphia'' and ''The Silence of the Lambs.'' So you may be taken by the director's enormous enthusiasm, but the picture doesn't quite work.

title: Report Finds U.S. Unprepared for Next Terrorist Attack
description: Despite months of preparations and the spending of millions of dollars, the United States remains extremely vulnerable to a major terrorist attack, particularly at its seaports, power plants and oil refineries, a panel of national security experts has concluded.

title: Jurisdictions Will Weigh Options, Including Death
description: When law enforcement officials meet today to discuss what charges to bring against John Allen Muhammad and John Lee Malvo, the two men being held in connection with this month's sniper attacks in the Washington area, the main topic is likely to be the death penalty.

title: Minnesota Senator Is Among 8 Dead in Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 - Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota was killed today when his campaign plane crashed approaching a small airport in a wooded region in the northern part of his state.

title: New Jersey Eases Curbs On Watering Of Lawns
description: The drought is not officially over in New Jersey, but the state said yesterday that it was relaxing its restrictions on water use so that most residents could once again water their lawns and wash their cars at home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, HENRY
description: POPKIN-Henry. Died peacefully at his home in Brooklyn on Thursday, October 24. He was born in Providence, R.I. on April 20, 1924. During his long writing career he contributed to the N.Y. Times, the Times of London, the Financial Times, and many other publications, writing about his passion, the theatre. For nearly 30 years he was a professor of English at SUNY Buffalo. Early in the life of the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis he was its dramaturge. Henry will be sorely missed by his wife, Judy, and his daughter, Sarah. They will remember him as a man of simple tastes, rigorous thought, and a deep love of the theatre and his family. Services will be held on Friday today at 12 noon at the Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Ex-Leftist In the Center As Brazil Votes Again
description: Thirteen years ago, when Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva first ran for president, Mrio Amato, then head of So Paulo's powerful Federation of Industries, predicted that 800,000 businessmen would leave Brazil if Mr. da Silva and his leftist Workers' Party won the ballot.

title: An Angry Telephone Call Provided One Crucial Clue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  The first real break  the one that sent investigators scurrying from an Alabama liquor store to a backyard in Tacoma, Wash., and finally to a blue Chevrolet Caprice at a highway rest stop in Maryland  came on Oct. 17 in an angry telephone call from a man claiming to be the sniper.

title: A Lifetime Spent as an Unapologetic Liberal
description: When Minnesotans voted to send Paul Wellstone to Washington in 1990 in one of the state's biggest political upsets, the counterculture magazine Mother Jones proclaimed him "the first 1960's radicals elected to the U.S. Senate."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSEN, GUSTAV H. ''PETER''
description: PETERSEN-Gustav H. ''Peter'' died at home on October 19, 2002. His family, relatives and friends know that, ''in the variety of God's creations, Peter will be the wonder for us all.''

title: Islanders Give Up Lead But Rebound for Victory
description: Aleksei Yashin waited before he raised both arms in halfhearted triumph. He never seems jubilant when he scores, but this time Yashin looked as if he were waiting for something else to go wrong for the Islanders.

title: DOLE FOOD REJECTS TAKEOVER OFFER BY CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Dole Food, the fruit and vegetable producer, said yesterday that it had rejected the chief executive's $29.50-a-share takeover offer and that its board was negotiating for a higher price. The proposal, which was a 20 percent premium, was extended by a week, to Nov. 13, Dole said. The chief executive, David H. Murdock, offered to buy the company last month and take it private in a transaction valued at about $2.5 billion. Goldman, Sachs, the financial adviser to the special committee that reviewed the offer, will also seek other potential buyers. Mr. Murdock wants to buy the 76 percent of the company not already owned by him or his family.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Top Official For Northern Ireland
description: The secretary for Wales, Paul Murphy, was named Northern Ireland secretary to replace John Reid, who became chairman of the Labor Party in a cabinet shuffle provoked by the resignation on Wednesday of Education Secretary Estelle Morris. Ms. Morris was replaced by the current party chairman. Mr. Murphy, a top official in the Northern Ireland office when the 1998 peace agreement was negotiated and put into effect, takes over when the province has once again been put under direct rule from London. Its assembly was suspended this month when Protestants refused to continue in government with their Catholic rivals in Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, as long as the I.R.A. remained armed, intact and involved in paramilitary activities. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Also at Home on the Range
description: As much as Betty Buckley is a Broadway diva whose voice imparts a slicing operatic edge to an aria like ''Memory,'' she is also a Texan (from Fort Worth) who grew up steeped in country and rock 'n' roll. And in ''Deep in the Heart,'' her wonderful new cabaret show at Feinstein's at the Regency (through Nov. 9), Broadway grandeur gives way to what might be called intellectualized true grit.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing | Washington: White House Fence Jumper
description: A man who jumped the fence surrounding the White House was swiftly apprehended, the Secret Service said. The man, Curtis Best, 41, threw a camera bag into a fountain on the grounds before scaling the fence near the Northwest entrance on Pennsylvania Avenue. Officials later determined the bag was not a danger, the spokesman said. Mr. Best was charged with unlawful entry.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about earnings for Nissan in the six months ended Sept. 30 included an erroneous reference from the company to its record of dividend payments in recent years. Nissan did not pay dividends in the years ended in March 1999 and 2000 but paid them in 2001 and 2002; a payout in March 2003 would not be its first in four years.

title: New Irish Police Squad to Investigate All Clerical Abuse Cases
description: In response to mounting public anger over new revelations of child sexual abuse by Roman Catholic priests in Dublin, the Irish police today set up a special team of detectives that will investigate every case of such abuse ever reported in the country.

description: The Anaheim Angels headed home tonight, back to their rally monkeys, outfield waterfalls and fans wearing red. They would feel better if a dominant starting pitcher were waiting there, too.

description: As Charles A. Moose, the police chief of Montgomery County, strolled into the sniper task force's command center this morning, he wore an expression rarely seen over the last 21 days: an ear-to-ear smile.

title: CBS Names Executive In Charge of Sales
description: CBS in New York said yesterday that it had named JoAnn Ross, executive vice president for sales, to succeed Joseph D. Abruzzese as president for network sales. Ms. Ross has held the No. 2 post under Mr. Abruzzese, and becomes the first woman to hold the senior sales post at CBS, part of Viacom.

title: Has China Become an Ally?
description: American relations with China have improved in a way that few could have imagined when the Bush administration entered office and declared China a ''strategic competitor.'' Now signs of serious cooperation are everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, DONALD JORDAN
description: DONAHUE-Donald Jordan. October 22nd, 2002. He is survived by his five children, Macy, Judy, Don, Tom and Nick of his late wife, Mary Meyer Donahue, six grandchildren, wife Carol, brother Jack and sister Mary. Passed away peacefully of complications from Parkinson's disease. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday 6-8 PM and Thursday 2-4 and 6-8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, October 25th, 11 AM at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Donald J. Donahue to either Parkinson's Disease Foundation Inc., 710 W. 168 Street, New York, NY 10032 or the family's scholarship at Georgetown University, Attn: Mary Prahinski, Office of Alumni and University Relations, P.O. Box 571253, Washington, D.C. 20057.

description: PINE-Arthur (Artie). October 26, 2000. We loved him and we miss him more and more. Leonard Wurzel

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, BEATRICE PHILLIPS
description: SACHS-Beatrice Phillips. The Board of Trustees and executive staff of The Educational Alliance are deeply saddened by the passing of Beatrice Phillips Sachs, wife of the late Henry Sachs who was a beloved Alliance trustee from 1953-1985. Henry and Beatrice Sachs were extraordinary supporters of the diverse community based social, educational, cultural and recreational programs and services that the Alliance has provided to our community for the last 114 years. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Beatrice Phillips Sachs. Richard A. Cantor, President Robin Bernstein, Exec. Dir.

title: Sniper Suspects Face Murder Charges
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Oct. 25  Maryland prosecutors said today that they would bring six counts of first-degree murder against the two suspects accused of subjecting the capital area to a harrowing three-week sniper shooting spree that left 10 people dead and 3 wounded. The officials said they would seek the death penalty against the older suspect, John Allen Muhammad, 41.

title: Into the Wild Blue Yonder (No Airplane Required)
description: FOR most of the year, Fayetteville, population 2,200, blurs into the string of small, somewhat threadbare towns tucked into the hills of southern West Virginia. But nearly every October since 1980, for just one day, people from all over the world put Fayetteville on the map by jumping -- legally and, in most cases, safely -- off its New River Gorge Bridge.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business News yesterday about the elimination of a pharmaceuticals contract between Aetna and Express Scripts misidentified the company that reported quarterly results and had a drop of $1.16 in its stock price. That was Express Scripts, not Aetna.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TERYAZOS, MARIELLE (NEE GOHIER)
description: TERYAZOS-Marielle (nee Gohier). At the Montreal Neurological Institute of Montreal. Died on Wednesday, October 23rd, 2002 at the age of 83. Mother of Robert Hackett and of the late John Hackett. Grandmother of Sophie Hackett, Nadia Hackett, Guy Hackett, Alexander Hackett and Amanda Abreu-Hackett. Mother-in-law of Colette Lavoie and Susana Abreu. Sister of Madeliene de Brantes. Visitation at Mount Royal Funeral Complex, 1297 Chemin de la Foret, Outremont (514-279-6540), on Friday, October 25th from 5:00 PM to 9:00 PM. Funeral at St. Leon de Westmount on Saturday at 11:00 AM.

title: Miscellany
description: * The Samsung Electronics Company renewed its worldwide Olympic sponsorship agreement with the International Olympic Committee, covering two additional Olympics, the 2006 Winter Games in Torino, Italy, and the 2008 Summer Games in Beijing. Terms were not disclosed. Samsung has been a worldwide Olympic sponsor in what is known as the TOP program since the 1998 Winter Games.

title: Cellphones Let Families Hear Ordeal Of Captives
description: In a large school gymnasium rimmed with television sets and steamy windows, relatives of the 700 hostages being held captive inside a central Moscow theater held their vigil throughout the night. One sound punctuated the constant blare of news reports: the electronic warble of cellphones.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Wealthy Few Use Loopholes in Law To Give Pataki Campaign Big Sums
description: The sign at the entrance to the Upper East Side parking garage says no Bentleys, Ferraris or Rolls-Royces. But Gov. George E. Pataki's black S.U.V. would certainly be welcome. The garage, at a luxury apartment building on York Avenue, is one of a dozen commonly owned lots in Manhattan that have donated money to the governor's re-election campaign.

title: The Terror Ends
description: The public wants nothing more, at the moment, than to believe that the police have found the sniper who killed 10 people and wounded 3 others over the past three weeks. But even as details pour in about John Allen Muhammad and John Lee Malvo and about the sudden coalescence of facts binding them to the sniper attacks, the pall over life in the Washington area has begun to lift. Once you learn to think of yourself as a target, the way many people in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia have done, you don't soon get out of the habit of feeling like one. The mere interruption of daily life will have a psychological impact, especially on children, that the resumption of normal schedules won't necessarily cure. If ever there were a time for people to pour out of their houses into the middle of the block, to stand talking in parking lots and to take their time in public places, this is it. A basic confidence in the safety of open spaces needs to be re-established.

title: Angels Have Giants Where They Want Them
description: Good news for Anaheim: The team trailing 3 games to 2 in the World Series often rallies to win the Series  if it is playing Games 6 and 7 at home. How often does it happen? Six of the last seven times it could have happened, it did.

title: Robert Mangold
description: Peter Freeman

title: A Lingerie Maker Returns To Its Racier Past
description: Frederick's of Hollywood, the warhorse that made millions of dollars on risqu lingerie that tickled the fancy of gray-haired men, is coming back from bankruptcy with a new image intended to attract younger shoppers. .

title: New Video Releases
description: Insomnia

title: High Art And Low From Atop The Hood
description: AUTOMOTIVE zealots find hundreds of ways to personalize their vehicles, from vanity plates to Day-Glo paint. But even a free spirit at the far edge might think twice before drilling a hole in his car's hood to affix a chrome-plated basset hound, nude or jester with red light-bulb eyes.

title: Jobless Claims Fall a Bit More Than Expected
description: Claims for jobless benefits fell more than expected last week, a report released today by the Labor Department showed, indicating that the economy might be growing enough to limit a rise in unemployment.

title: Study Finds Storm Cycles Etched in Lake Beds
description: Four times since the last ice age, at intervals roughly 3,000 years apart, the Northeast has been struck by cycles of storms far more powerful than any in recent times, according to a new study. The region appears to have entered a fifth era in which such superstorms are more likely, the researchers say.

title: Berty Skuber -- 'Under Penalty of Law'
description: Emily Harvey Gallery

title: Anger Builds and Seethes as Arabs Await American Invader
description: After last Friday's Prayers at Al Azhar Mosque, anger against the United States spilled out into the courtyard in what was a relatively meager demonstration. Separate groups of men and women chanted in favor of Iraq, a boy on a man's shoulders carried a sign saying ''I love 11 September'' in English and the rally was over within an hour.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Party Accused Of Anti-Semitism
description: Justice Minister Yuri Chaika said that under a law on political parties the government had no choice last month but to register a new group, the National Sovereign Party, which is accused of advocating anti-Semitism. Jewish organizations protested the registration after speakers at a party conference urged a struggle against ''the criminal Jewish occupation'' and called President Vladimir V. Putin the leader of a corrupt Jewish regime. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Marlboro: Superfund Cleanup Sites
description: Seven oil companies will pay nearly $250,000 to contribute to the cleanup of contaminated sites in Monmouth County. The companies had stored oil waste in lagoons on the two Superfund sites. The waste ultimately spread and contaminated 75 acres of land. The companies agreed to the payment as part of a consent decree between federal and state environmental agencies and the owners of the land. Cleanup is expected to be completed by 2005. The companies are Exxon and Mobil, both of Virginia; Atlantic Richfield Company, of California; British Petroleum Products of North America, of Illinois; Shell Oil, of Texas; Chevron Oil, of California; and Sunoco, of Pennsylvania. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: A Day Unfolds
description: Early-morning arrests led to the late-evening announcement that the gun found with the suspects linked them to the killings.

title: The Pre-Dawn Raid
description: Russian special forces seized a theater held by Chechen guerrillas after the rebels began to kill some of the more than 600 hostages they had taken.

title: Do the Right Thing
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: Residents along the west coast of Mexico braced for the onslaught of potentially devastating Hurricane Kenna.

title: Bush and Jiang Vow to Cooperate on North Korea Issue
description: President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China publicly vowed today to work together to persuade North Korea to abandon its newest nuclear weapons project, though they carefully wended their way around the divisive question of whether China would take part in Washington's emerging strategy of economically isolating the North unless it complied.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of Adolph Green yesterday referred incorrectly at one point to the partner with whom he worked as a playwright, performer and lyricist. She is Betty Comden, not Ms. Green.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about potential effects of the Bali nightclub bombing on the economy and people of Bali misstated the surname and nationality of a foreigner who has a jewelry business there. He is John Hardy, not Harding. He is Canadian, not American.

title: U.S. Raises Pressure on Russia and France for Iraq Resolution
description: In a tense three-way contest in the Security Council, the United States pressed today for rapid approval of its tough draft resolution to disarm Iraq while France and Russia presented their own informal texts designed to moderate the threat of military attack.

title: One of His Former Players Calls Howe the Best Choice
description: Mark Guthrie, one of the few Mets who played well last season, spends the off-season at his home in Tampa, Fla. So he could not escape the clamor for Lou Piniella to come home and manage the awful Tampa Bay Devil Rays.
