description: After two days of finger-pointing and sweet-talking, the 15 leaders of the European Union finessed an agreement today on how to pay for the 10 countries invited to join their club.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about hospitals and others that have benefited from increased health-care spending misstated the name of the consulting firm of Dr. Arnold Milstein, who commented on the potential political repercussions for hospitals. It is Mercer Human Resource Consulting, not William M. Mercer Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, PHILIP O., M.D.
description: ETTINGER-Philip O., M.D. Of Leonia, NJ, on October 22, 2002. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Cherished son of the late Sam and Charlotte & stepson of Hana. Devoted father of Alyssa & Jonathan. Dear brother of Stephen J. Ettinger, D.V.M. Services on Monday 1 PM at ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Putney School, Elm Lea Farm, Putney, Vermont 05346.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Has A Profit
description: Air Canada reported a third-quarter net profit of 125 million Canadian dollars ($79.9 million), or 91 cents a share, in spite of a continued slide in traffic to the United States. The airline, which is based in Montreal and dominates air travel in Canada, lost 903 million Canadian dollars, or 7.51 Canadian dollars a share, in the period last year, which included the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Domestic passenger revenue rose 7 percent in the latest period, while international revenue, excluding cross-border flights, was up by 17 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Rutgers Names President As Changes Are Weighed
description: Rutgers University today named a new president: Richard L. McCormick, the president of the University of Washington and a native son with deep professional and family roots on campus here.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Thursday about a planned stock offering by TSX, parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, included an incorrect price projection supplied by the company. In its revised prospectus, TSX projected an offering price of 17 to 19 Canadian dollars a share, not 14 to 17.

title: Knicks Continue to Deal With Sprewell as Nets Thrive
description: The Knicks faced another hint of trouble today from their lightning rod, Latrell Sprewell. A day after filing grievances against the team for two fines totaling $187,500, Sprewell hinted that he might not rush back to the team.

title: A Rocky Road in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Budget Troubles
description: Antony Leung, the financial secretary of the semi-autonomous Chinese territory, told local lawmakers that the budget deficit was serious, but that the government would not propose a specific response until March. Until then, the government will ask the public for ideas on how to respond to spending that exceeds dwindling revenues by 30 percent. Standard & Poor's downgraded its outlook for Hong Kong's local-currency credit rating to negative from stable on Thursday. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Ohio State Stays Unbeaten
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio -- With freshman running back Maurice Clarett out of the game with an injury, Chris Gamble became the catalyst for No. 4 Ohio State.

title: A Lifetime Together, A Death Together
description: Sheila Wellstone had been married to Senator Paul Wellstone, her high school sweetheart, for 39 years. They were all but inseparable, whether in Washington, at home in their town house here, or on the campaign trail.

title: RUSSIA RECAPTURES THEATER AFTER CHECHEN REBEL GROUP BEGINS TO EXECUTE HOSTAGES
description: Russian special forces burst into a theater held by Chechen guerrillas early today after the rebels began to kill some of the more than 600 hostages they had seized, government officials said.

title: Graduate Assistants at Cornell Vote Decisively Against Autoworkers Union
description: In one of the biggest defeats for the fast-growing movement to unionize graduate students, Cornell University announced yesterday that its graduate teaching and research assistants had voted overwhelmingly against joining the United Auto Workers.

title: Company Says Traders Gave Out False Data
description: The Williams Companies, the owner of natural gas pipelines, said today that its traders provided phony information to a journal that compiles gas price indexes used by the industry in sales contracts.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EUROPEAN UNION SHIFT ON RUSSIAN ENCLAVE European Union leaders moved to end a feud with Moscow, endorsing a deal on transit for residents of Russia's Baltic enclave, Kaliningrad. The problem has arisen because Poland and Lithuania are to join the Union in 2004. Kaliningrad will at that point be geographically cut off from the rest of Russia by Union members, which are to introduce tighter border controls. Russia has been pressing for visa-free travel across the future Union territory for Kaliningrad residents.    (Agence France-Presse)

title: Huge Storm Lashes Pacific Coast Of Mexico, Forcing Evacuations
description: One of the strongest Pacific storms to strike Mexico in decades roared ashore this afternoon, threatening thousands of people and hundreds of villages.

title: Indian Point Nuclear Reactor Will Close for Maintenance
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear plant will shut down for about a month, beginning this weekend, as workers replace about one-third of the uranium fuel rods in the reactor core, the plant's owner said today.

title: Woman Who Took Baby in '80 Is Freed
description: A woman sentenced to six months in jail for fleeing with an infant in 1980 and raising him in New Mexico was released after serving less than two months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURSTEIN, MARTHA
description: MURSTEIN - Martha. Died peacefully on October 25, at her home in Miami Beach. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Leon. She was personified love, honor, and dignity throughout her 95 years. She is survived by her children, Bernard and Nelly, Alvin and Aileen, Paul and Marjorie; her grandchildren, Danielle and Ben, Colette and Fletcher, Andrew and Barbara, Amie, Joanna and David; and her great grandchildren, Rebecca, Jacqueline, Melissa, Kimberly and Matthew. She will be greatly missed, may she rest in peace. There will be a private gravesite service Sunday followed by Shiva, which will be observed Sunday in Old Westbury and Monday in Scarsdale.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALICK, SYLVIA
description: BALICK-Sylvia. The Hi-Tech Hebrew School mourns the passing of our dear friend, Mrs. Sylvia Balick. Her friendship, joy and kindness will be greatly missed. Rabbi Naftali Rotenstreich Executive Director

title: Paying the Price of Tolls
description: To the Editor:

title: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF ALLMERICA FINANCIAL RESIGNS
description: John F. O'Brien resigned as president and chief executive of the Allmerica Financial Corporation, an insurer whose profits have been hurt by the stock market slump. The resignation is effective immediately, Allmerica said. The company, which is based in Worcester, Mass., formed a committee to find a replacement for Mr. O'Brien, 59, who has headed the company since 1989. He will continue as a director. Allmerica's profits have been hurt as falling stock markets pared fees from assets under management and cut demand for equity-linked products like variable annuities.

title: A Liberal With a Wrestler's Stance
description: Paul Wellstone was an unlikely politician in a place like Minnesota -- land of walleyes, cornfields and phlegmatic Scandinavians. He was an urban Jew, son of immigrants, a college professor at the fanciest of Minnesota's private colleges. And, probably worst of all for his nontalkative constituents, he was a passionate orator, a skilled rouser of rabble over issues he loved and an unapologetic populist liberal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, MILDRED
description: ABRAMS-Mildred. Passed away peacefully on October 24th. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Franklin and Leslie, Elliott and Rachel. Cherished grandmother of Courtney, Jason, Jacob, Sarah and Joseph. Loving sister of Samuel and the late Joseph and Saul Kauder. Sister-in-law of Rosalind and Beatrice Kauder. We will always treasure her vitality, thoughtfulness and great devotion to everyone in her extended family. Services Sunday 11:30AM at RiversideNassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Bids for Houghton Fall Short of Goal
description: Vivendi Universal received bids today for its Houghton Mifflin publishing unit, but all of them fell short of the 1.75 billion euros ($1.7 billion) that Vivendi had set as a minimum price, one person involved in the discussions said.

title: Sporting Goods Store Pulls Fake Guns From Shelves After Citation From City
description: Sports Authority Inc., a chain of sports-equipment stores, was cited by the city yesterday for selling imitation semiautomatic machine guns that are strikingly similar to the real thing, the Department of Consumer Affairs said.

title: Rare Goal From Daneyko Propels Devils to Victory
description: The sight of his shot sailing through traffic and into the Buffalo Sabres' goal was so foreign to Devils defenseman Ken Daneyko that he almost forgot what to do. It took him a few seconds to do something as simple as throw his arms up.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about criminal charges in Canada against four former executives of the Toronto-based theatrical production company Livent referred incorrectly to earlier American proceedings against some of them. In 1999, federal prosecutors indicted Garth H. Drabinsky and Myron I. Gottlieb and accepted a guilty plea from Gordon C. Eckstein; the fourth, Robert Topol, was not indicted in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VORA, DR. PRAVINCHANDRA
description: VORA-Dr. Pravinchandra. 74, passed away from serious injuries sustained in an automobile accident on October 18, 2002. Dr. Vora graduated with a M.B.B.S. degree in medicine from the University of Bombay in 1951. He was awarded the Dr. R.S. Poredi gold medal for medicine. In 1956, he received his M.D. degree, also from the University of Bombay. In 1958, Dr. Vora received his M.R.C.P. of the Royal College of Physicians of Edinburgh, U.K. After working several years in England, he was appointed Consultant Physician at Queen Elizabeth Hospital, Aden South Yemen. In Aden, he also maintained a very active private practice. After the change in government in Aden, Dr. Vora came to New York. In New York, he completed residences in internal medicine and a Fellowship in Cardio-Pulmonary medicine. Dr. Vora has worked for the past 30 years with the Veterans Administration in both the Montrose and Castle Point Hospital. Over the years he held several positions, including Chief of Nuclear Medicine. Even though, Dr. Vora retired 2 years ago, he continued to serve as a consultant in nuclear medicine. Dr. Vora is survived by his wife of 28 years, Margaret Brady, a son, Suketu Vora, one brother and sister, and several nieces and nephews.

title: Officer in Punching on Video Is Ousted From Department
description: An Inglewood police officer who was videotaped slamming a handcuffed teenager against a car last summer has been dismissed from the department, and a hearing on discipline was held today for a second officer involved in the case.

title: In a New Assembly District in Staten Island, Overlapping Loyalties Complicate Battle
description: On Staten Island, areas are typically dominated by one political party. On the North Shore, Democrats win most of the local offices. The South Shore has one of the most reliably Republican-voting patterns in all of New York City.

title: Nurturing Playwrights Just Cutting Their Teeth
description: The scripts start arriving just about this time every year. Some are typed, some scribbled. Some are just a few pages; others you could use as a doorstop.

title: So Many Books, So Little Space
description: At some point, even ardent bibliophiles begin to view their beloved books as a burden. Maybe it is when the cover finally falls off that college edition of Ezra Pound, or the paperbacks begin to warp as they are forced into shelves that once seemed spacious. But few in this particular fix can bring themselves to take effective remedial action.

title: Sniper Clue Sat for Weeks In Crime Lab In Alabama
description: The evidence that cracked the sniper case was sitting in an Alabama crime lab throughout the three-week shooting spree, law enforcement officials here said today.

title: North Korea Demands U.S. Agree to Nonagression Pact
description: North Korea demanded today that the United States agree to a nonaggression pact before giving up its nuclear weapons program.

title: Succession Rules Leave Few Options
description: Minnesota's election law addresses most but not all of the legal questions arising from the death of Senator Paul Wellstone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, THOMAS B.
description: ROSS-Thomas B., 73. Died October 24, at Eastern Long Island Hospital, after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife Gunilla (Ekstrand) of Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., daughters Maria, Anne and Kristina, two granddaughters and his sister Grace Shanley. Vice President, Government Relations, Loral Space & Communications, Inc., he was formerly Special Assistant to President Clinton and Senior Director of Public Affairs for the National Security Council, a Senior Vice President of NBC News, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs in the Carter Administration, and foreign correspondent and Washington Bureau Chief of the Chicago Sun-Times. Coauthor with David Wise of three books on government intelligence, including New York Times number one bestseller, ''The Invisible Government,'' and a Nieman Fellow at Harvard, he served three years as an officer in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yale University, Class of 1951 Memorial Scholarship Fund.

title: Eloise Returns to the Plaza
description: We all remember a favorite fictional character from our childhood: Huck Finn, perhaps, or Meg of ''Little Women'' or Curious George. There will be no new adventures for Huck or Meg, but those of us who remain Eloise fans are far luckier. After Paris and Moscow -- and more than 40 years -- she's back exactly where she belongs, at the Plaza in New York.

title: For Justice in the Sniper Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Golisano Campaigns in Buffalo, Focusing on Taxes
description: As Tom Golisano took his third-party candidacy for governor into the heart of New York's most terminally depressed region, he could not have picked a much more appropriate place to have dinner today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISLER, MELVIN
description: REISLER-Melvin. Beloved and loving husband of Helen, devoted and loving father of Susan (Mike), Karen (David) and Keith (Cathie). Adored grandfather ''Papa'' of Emily, Jayme, Jake, Gillian, Jenna and Julia. Visitation will be held Sunday 10:30AM 12:30PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Private graveside service.

title: Albany's Big Spenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Series History Is on Side of the Angels
description: If those who forget history are doomed to repeat it, then Dusty Baker was wise to give his players the day off today. That gave the San Francisco Giants plenty of time to study World Series history of the past 20 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ALFRED
description: LERNER-Alfred. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of Alfred Lerner, a member of the Columbia College class of 1955. He was a respected colleague whose leadership as vice chair of the Trustees was marked by exceptional insight, unfailing decency, and dedication to his alma mater. Alfred Lerner Hall, Columbia's innovative student center, was made possible by his generosity to the University. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Mrs. Norma Lerner, his son Randy, his daughter Nancy, and to his seven grandchildren. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Families Humanize 9/11 Aid Forms; Testimonials to Victims Offered Alongside Cold Numbers
description: For many people, applying to the federal Victim Compensation Fund figured to be something of a clinical exercise, a statistical blur in which thousands of families would compute the lost earnings of loved ones, then wait for the government to mail out checks.

title: Breaking Free From Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Stronger With Lautenberg, Poll Shows
description: The legal maneuvering that allowed former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg to replace Senator Robert G. Torricelli as the Democratic nominee on the ballot in New Jersey's United States Senate race has strengthened Democrats' chances of retaining the seat, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Prices Fall Again
description: Consumer prices fell nationwide for the 36th consecutive month as deflation continued to eat into the economy, the world's second largest. Prices fell 0.9 percent in September from a year earlier. Pressure is building for the Bank of Japan to ease monetary policy to combat deflation when its policy board meets on Oct. 30. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: REGIONAL OFFICIAL MEETS REBELS The chief of the 15-member Economic Community of West African States met with Ivory Coast rebel leaders in their central headquarters in Bouaké to work out details of imminent talks with the government. "They are ready to discuss together and we are optimistic because we think it can happen very soon," the official, Mohamed Ibn Chambas, said in the capital, Yamoussoukro, shortly after returning. Leaders of the economic group met in Abidjan to lay the groundwork for a force from its member countries to monitor the fragile cease-fire agreed reached Oct. 17.   (Reuters)

title: Gas Tank's Fall Renews Calls On Safety At U.S. Lab
description: A 600-gallon container of liquid nitrogen fell from the rear of a ferry Thursday afternoon at the Plum Island Animal Disease Center, the high-security laboratory off Long Island that conducts research on dangerous infectious diseases in animals, government officials said yesterday.

title: Two Suspects Aren't Talking To Police Eager for Answers
description: Law enforcement officials said today that they were hoping to persuade John Lee Malvo, the 17-year-old suspected accomplice in this month's sniper attacks, to turn against John Allen Muhammad and help answer many of the lingering questions in the case.

title: Songs, in Many Languages, That Whisper and Linger
description: For her recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, Lorraine Hunt Lieberson chose arias and songs in English, Italian, French, Spanish and German, but she found herself often singing of the same things: evenings, rosy twilights and departures. This is typical mezzo-soprano territory; Ms. Lieberson, though, is not a typical mezzo. The balm she offers is fresh, the delivery immediate. There is no plushness; the warmth comes from somewhere else -- perhaps from a pianissimo that sounds like someone whispering in your ear, or from an absence of subterfuge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about potential effects of the Bali nightclub bombing on the economy and people of Bali misstated the surname and nationality of a foreigner who has a jewelry business there. He is John Hardy, not Harding. He is Canadian, not American.

title: Nader on Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEIL, ELSE
description: WEIL-Else. Gone from us for six years but never from our hearts. Bob and Fre

title: For Rangers, Home Ice Becomes a Disadvantage
description: Rock bottom is a relative term when it comes to the Rangers, who sink to new depths each game.

title: Buffett Quits Gillette Board As He Focuses On His Work
description: The billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett said yesterday that he was resigning as a director of the Gillette Company to focus more on his own business, Berkshire Hathaway.

title: Sets of Hips With Minds Of Their Own
description: Energy is a synonym for Grupo Corpo, the indefatigable and admirable Brazilian company of virtuoso dancers that is performing through tonight in the Next Wave Festival of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, KENNETH R.
description: WOLFF-Kenneth R., 55. Of Mt. Kisco, NY, died October 24, 2002, after a courageous battle with cancer. Loving husband of Adele, son of Joan and Robert; father of Eric and Cheryl; brother of Robert, Sherri and Ellen; stepfather of Jackie and Anthony, Jennifer and Mark, and Stephanie and five adoring grandchildren. Visiting 3:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 Sunday, and services Monday, October 28, 11:00 AM at Cassidy & Flynn, 288 Main St., Mt. Kisco. In lieu of flowers, donations to Make-A-Wish, 828 S. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSON, REV. PAUL T.
description: MATSON-Rev. Paul T. Bethlehem Lutheran Church announces his passing. Wake, October 25, 4-7 PM, Snooky's Restaurant, 140 7th Ave, Brooklyn. Service October 27, 4 PM at the church, 490 Pacific St, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISENBURGER, ANNE LANDSMAN
description: ISENBURGER-Anne Landsman. On October 24, in the hundredth year of her age. Cherished aunt of Landis, David, Joshua, Katherine and Elizabeth Olesker. An interior designer, a collector of modern art, an ardent conservationist, Anne was a true original. She will be greatly missed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 9 about the booming popularity of computer games in South Korea and the industry it has spawned misstated the fee at the RA PC Zone game room in Pusan. It is about $1 an hour, not $10.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit Falls At Bank
description: Korea's largest commercial bank, Kookmin, posted a disappointing third-quarter net income of $283 million, down 11.2 percent from the third quarter of last year and 29 percent from the second quarter of this year. The price of Kookmin shares slid 3.2 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange, to 40,400 won a share. The drop in income was attributed to concerns about the bank's rising credit card risk. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; More Bench For Darren This Time
description: GIVEN the reactions of his mother and his wife, Dusty Baker was not surprised to hear that the commissioner's office also had some concerns about his 3-year-old son, Darren, almost getting in the middle of a tag play at home plate during Thursday night's game.

title: Letters to the editor : Complexities of U.S. citizens' liabilities
description: I write to correct some errors in Barbara Wall's article. The author has done an admirable job of trying to summarize what is a very complex area, so I trust my comments will be taken merely as an attempt to set a couple of hyper-technical points straight.

title: Bitter Divide as Securities Panel Picks an Accounting Watchdog
description: The new board overseeing the accounting profession got off to a troubled start today when the members of the Securities and Exchange Commission split bitterly over the qualifications and competency of the board's new leadership. They voted 3 to 2 to approve formally the selection of William H. Webster, the former director of the C.I.A. and the F.B.I., to head the new board.

title: Jail for Former Tax Assessor Involved in Bribery Scheme
description: A former city tax assessor was sentenced yesterday to more than three years in prison for his role in one of the costliest corruption scandals in city history, as the Bloomberg administration urged the court to impose severe punishment.

title: A $58.5 MILLION VERDICT AGAINST CHRYSLER IS OVERTURNED
description: A Pennsylvania appeals court overturned a $58.5 million verdict against DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler Corporation unit for vehicle owners who said they were injured by defective air bags. The Superior Court of Pennsylvania ruled yesterday that the suit should not have been granted class-action status. The case was brought on behalf of about 75,000 state residents who owned Chrysler vehicles with air bags that were said to have caused hand burns in wrecks, the company said.

title: Game 6 Starters Vow To Be More Effective
description: It had been 45 years since two starting pitchers failed to collect more than six outs apiece in the same World Series game. But that is what the Angels' Kevin Appier and the Giants' Russ Ortiz did last Sunday in Game 2 of this prizefight known as the World Series.

title: Quarterly Loss Widens at Reader's Digest
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter loss widened as it spent more on promotions and marketing.

title: Once Anti-Tax, a Mayor Changes His Thinking
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the candidate, was firmly opposed to raising taxes, arguing they would ''destroy this city.'' Mr. Bloomberg, the mayor, changed his tune only slightly after he was sworn in, saying tax increases were still anathema, largely because they could never get approved in an election year.

title: National Briefing: Religion
description: PICKETS FOR BILLY GRAHAM CEREMONY

title: Fugitive Muslim Cleric, an Outspoken Supporter of Al Qaeda, Is Arrested in London
description: The British authorities were reported today to have arrested a fugitive Islamic cleric known as Abu Qatada, wanted in the United States and Europe as an emissary of Osama bin Laden and labeled by a British legislator ''some sort of Muslim Scarlet Pimpernel.''

title: Energy Companies Weigh Their Possible Future in Iraq
description: Though Iraq's future is hazy, energy companies have begun to weigh the roles they might play in the revival of the country's huge but dilapidated oil industry. According to a report by Deutsche Bank, oil field services companies like Schlumberger Ltd. and the Halliburton Corporation could be the early winners, but the prospects for oil companies themselves are less clear.

title: Anti-Semitic 'Elders of Zion' Gets New Life on Egypt TV
description: The images flash quickly across the television screen. They show a bloody face, Victorian men and women in a drawing room, soldiers wielding rifle butts. And a man in black hat with side curls and long beard.

title: Paul Wellstone, 58, Icon Of Liberalism in Senate
description: Paul Wellstone often seemed out of step. He called himself a liberal when many used that word as a slur. He voted against the Persian Gulf war in his first year in the Senate, and this month opposed using force against Iraq.

title: Bonds Is Feared, Larger Than Life and Stomping on the Angels
description: Godzilla was already showered, dressed and, after another scene of destruction, placid, as he lumbered into the interview room at Pacific Bell Park on Thursday night and answered questions. He looked fatigued after the annihilation he had helped cause on the field in San Francisco. Weary, but not bathing in vindication. Not yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, REV. MONSIGNOR JAMES J.
description: MURRAY-Rev. Monsignor James J. On behalf of the Board of Directors, Administration, and staff of Calvary Hospital, Inc., we mourn the passing of our longtime Board member. Monsignor Murray served on the hospital Board of Directors since 1973. He gave generously of his time as a member of the Finance and Nominating Committees of the hospital Board. His commitment to the special mission of Calvary Hospital, and his dedication and leadership contributed enormously to the growth and success of the hospital program of care. Monsignor Murray's wisdom and vision was instrumental in the strategic planning of Calvary's move to its present location in the Northeast Bronx in 1978. We will miss Monsignor Murray, both as a loyal Board member and a member of the Calvary Family. We extend our condolences to his family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman of the Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President/ Chief Executive Officer Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director James E. Cimino, MD, Director of Calvary Palliative Care Institute Christopher P. Comfort, MD Medical Director Richard J. Kutilek, Chief Operating Officer Frank J. Locaparra, Chief Financial Officer

title: Democrats See Mondale As Best Hope for Victory
description: Even as Democrats in Washington mourned the death of Senator Paul Wellstone today, they scrambled behind the scenes to press former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to enter the race as their best hope for salvaging the Senate seat from Minnesota.

title: Terrifying Nights in a Theater Where Lights Never Dimmed
description: Sometimes they slept with their heads propped on the seats in front of them, or spoke softly to those sitting next to them. But mostly they sat upright in their red upholstered theater seats, watching a terrible drama unfold around an empty stage.

title: At Home Abroad / Third Culture Kids : Nowhere to call home but I like being a global nomad
description: PARIS  'Let me get this straight," said the immigration official at Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina, reviewing the documents that would allow me onto U.S. soil for the first time. "You have a French passport, which was issued in Indonesia, you were born in Australia, and your J-11 visa for entry into the United States of America was delivered in Venezuela. Is that right?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGMANN, GUILFORD J.
description: HAGMANN-Guilford J. 90, on October 22, 2002 in Oklahoma City, OK. Beloved father of R. Keating (Ann), Rev. Ann A., Julia H. Fuqua (Lee). Devoted husband of the late Ann Audrey (nee Campbell). Cherished grandfather of Caroline and Elizabeth. Services October 26 in Oklahoma City. For infomation, call HahnCook Street & Draper Funeral Home, 405-848-3744.

title: Leaders of Gay Rights Group Say It Will Endorse Pataki
description: New York's largest gay rights group will endorse Gov. George E. Pataki today for re-election, its leaders said yesterday, in what they acknowledged was partly repayment for the Republican-led State Senate's agreement to vote on a long-stalled gay rights bill.

title: 8,000 California Birds Killed in Bid to Stop Virus
description: Trying to contain a month-old outbreak of a deadly bird virus known as exotic Newcastle disease, state and federal agriculture officials have killed more than 8,000 birds in Southern California, including thousands of chickens, dozens of household pet birds, several peacocks and four ostriches.

title: La Guardia's Heir?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Grocer Has Warning
description: The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold warned of disappointing third-quarter results, saying that business in the United States was flat or falling. Sales worldwide rose 5.8 percent, to 16.4 billion euros compared with the period a year earlier, but excluding recent acquisitions, revenue rose only 1.5 percent. Analysts registered concern about Ahold's operations in the United States, which include Stop & Shop and Giant-Landover. Ahold gets about 60 percent of its revenue from the United States. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: All That Youthful Tension, All That Youthful Energy
description: The Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie of Bremen, founded in 1980, has a youthful appearance - few players seem to be older than 40 - and plays with a vigor that underscores that impression. Looks, of course, can be deceiving: Daniel Harding, the orchestra's music director since 1999, looks about 18, but he is 27 and already unusually accomplished in a field where careers are usually made slowly. In 1993 (when he actually was 18) he was an assistant conductor to Simon Rattle at the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra, and in 1995 he became Claudio Abbado's assistant at the Berlin Philharmonic. He has made a few highly regarded recordings for the Virgin Classics label in recent years and he is beginning to add American orchestras to an already impressive rAesumAe of European guest conducting appearances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINES, FAY SHIRLEY
description: MINES-Fay Shirley. Of West Orange, N.J. Formerly of West Hartford, CT. Died at the age of 95 on October 24, 2002. The family of Fay Mines mourns her passing. She was the beloved wife of the late Abraham Mines. Mother of Herbert Mines, Patricia Veit and the late Jeffrey Mines; mother-in-law of Barbara Mines, Walter Veit and Barbara Mines; grandmother of Roberta Birmingham, Jacqueline Veit, Catherine Veit, Susan Mines, Deborah Forman, Jonathan Mines and Richard Mines; great-grandmother of Laicy Mines, Larry Mines, Victoria Birmingham and David Birmingham. She had a long and full life, respected and loved by all. She will be greatly missed. The family requests donations be made to Hadassah, 50 W. 58 St, New York, N.Y. 10019, or The American Jewish Committee, 165 East 56 Street, New York, N.Y. 10022. Funeral services will be held at Weinstein Funeral Home in Hartford on Sunday, October 27, 2002 at 1:30 P.M.

title: 'Just a Girl,' Or Wishing To Be More?
description: It was Monday night at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y., and Gwen Stefani was leading the audience in a chant of ''I'm just a girl.'' After a few repetitions, Ms. Stefani smiled and finished the lyric: ''Wanna know something? I'm just a girl because that's all that you'll let me be!''

title: G.E.D. Course Was a Fraud, a Judge Rules
description: Multiple choice: New Yorkers who spent up to $150 to take a test for the high school equivalency diploma offered by a company in Queens got:

description: THE NETHERLANDS: GROCER HAS WARNING The Dutch food retailer Royal Ahold warned of disappointing third-quarter results, saying that business in the United States was flat or falling. Sales worldwide rose 5.8 percent, to 16.4 billion euros compared with the period a year earlier, but excluding recent acquisitions, revenue rose only 1.5 percent. Analysts registered concern about Ahold's operations in the United States, which include Stop & Shop and Giant-Landover. Ahold gets about 60 percent of its revenue from the United States. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: Beliefs; The development of modern Buddhism is traced to a mix of Eastern and Western influences.
description: Although the historic Buddha, Prince Siddhartha Gautama, is said to have lived approximately 2,500 years ago, Buddhism is often viewed as the most modern of world religions.

description: COUTEAU-Margie. 10/26/339/18/00. Beloved sister, best friend, valiant woman. Love, Dot and Ken Kelly

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOWEN, LAWRENCE JAMES
description: GOWEN-Lawrence James, 73. of Vero Beach, died Thursday, October 24, 2002. Mr. Gowen was born in Queens, NY and was a retired member of the footware industry. He was a member of St. Helen's Catholic Church in Vero Beach. Mr. Gowen was the son of the late Lawrence Gowen and Helen Gowen (nee House). Mr. Gowen is survived by his wife of 22 years, Susie Gowen; his mother, Helen Gowen of Ozone Park, NY; his brother, Robert Gowen of Massapequa Park, NY and his eight children: Thomas Gowen of Vero Beach, FL; Kevin Gowen of Celebration, FL; Terrence Gowen of Tampa, FL; Sally Bowdon of San Diego, CA; James Gowen of Tallahassee, FL; Mary Motes of Gainesville, FL; Eileen Bedinghaus of St. Petersburg, FL; and Joseph Gowen of Tampa, FL. Mr. Gowen is preceded in death by his son, Lawrence Gowen Jr. Mr. Gowen is also survived by his 21 grandchildren. Mr. Gowen was a man of eclectic interests. He was a voracious reader who was well-versed in areas from the mundane to the esoteric, a quality that was evidenced whenever he engaged in discussion or debate with one of his family's members. He was an avid sports fan, and loved Saturdays with his Fighting Irish and Sunday with his Miami Dolphins. A cosmopolitan gentleman, he had a love of travel and visited many locations abroad, such as the United Kingdom, France, and his ancestral homeland of Ireland. Whether he was at home or abroad, Mr. Gowen was a lover of food who enjoyed new culinary experiences, although his favorite meals were those shared with a gathering of his children and grandchildren. Of all his joys in life, none was greater to Mr. Gowen than his family. He was dedicated to having special, unique bonds with each one of his children and grandchildren. His memory shall be cherished and he shall be sorely missed by all of them.

title: Flash! White House Split on Housework!
description: When President Bush went campaigning in the Carolinas on Thursday, he apologized for the absence of his wife, Laura, in a way that led some to wince a bit, wondering whether he might hear about it when he got home.

title: 2 Men Could Face Trials In State and U.S. Courts
description: John Allen Muhammad and John Lee Malvo, the two men suspected of this month's sniper attacks in the Washington area, face a series of trials in at least three states. They may be tried in the District of Columbia's local courts and in the federal system as well.

description: Is Chad Pennington about to become the fourth franchise quarterback in Jets history? The statistics say yes, as does history.

description: To the Editor:

title: MARYLAND COUNTY IS FIRST TO MOVE ON SNIPER CHARGES
description: A rivalry among federal and local prosecutors to be the first to try the suburban sniper case became evident today, even after Montgomery County charged each suspect with six counts of first-degree murder.

title: Pirate Haunt Where Bush Will Meet World Leaders
description: This is Margaritaville. It is a strange place for a summit meeting, visited more by pirates than presidents, where American dollars are turning a natural paradise into a money machine.

title: Children and Parents Breathe a Sigh of Relief And Go Back Outdoors
description: The group of young mothers started going out to lunch several times a week two years ago when they met picking up their children from preschool, and stopped when the sniper started shooting three weeks ago.

description: 25 Penn State (5-2) at 6 Ohio State (8-0) 3:30 p.m., ABC

title: Prayers Replace Debate, as the Crash Site Awaits Investigators
description: There was supposed to be a debate here tonight. Instead, the Mitchell Auditorium at the College of St. Scholastica was filled with prayers and tears.

description: As Expected, S.E.C. Splits On Accounting Board Head

title: S.&P. Cuts Its Rating Of Ford Debt To Record Low
description: Executives at the Ford Motor Company tried to persuade investors this week that it was focused on its restructuring and planned to accelerate its comeback plan.

title: Israeli Forces Again Seize Control of Palestinian West Bank City
description: Israeli forces again tightened their grip on the West Bank city of Jenin today. Hundreds of soldiers supported by scores of tanks and other armored vehicles swept into the city in what Israel said was a hunt for a terrorist cell behind the suicide attack that killed 14 people on Monday.

title: Breeders' Cup to Derby Is Racing's Jinxed Path
description: Like the swells in ''Guys and Dolls,'' some of the most accomplished trainers in thoroughbred racing have not been able to help themselves when it comes to talking about Saturday's $1 million Breeders' Cup Juvenile race. ''I got the horse right here,'' has rung out in various forms and in international accents this week as a field of 14 prepared for racing's season-ending world championships.

title: Scolded, Microsoft Takes Blame For Swarms of Butterfly Decals
description: The New York City Transportation Department has done in a day what the United States Justice Department could not do for years: made Microsoft say it's sorry.

title: What Al Qaeda Learned in D.C.
description: Does everyone feel safe now?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ADOLPH
description: GREEN-Adolph. The Officers, Governors and members of the New York Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their beloved and esteemed Member, Adolph Green. We are honored and proud to have been touched by Adolph Green, a great lyricist with enormous talent who shared a legacy of commitment to the very best. Our sincerest condolences to his family. Alan King, Abbot Freddie Roman, Dean Sally Jessy Raphael, Prior Stewie Stone, Scribe Fred C. Klein, Treasurer Jean-Pierre Trebot, Executive Director

title: Ratings Go Through Floor
description: San Francisco's 16-4 trouncing of the Anaheim Angels in Game 5 of the World Series on Thursday night attracted the fewest number of viewers for any Series broadcast since 1969, and was the lowest-rated Series game recorded by Nielsen Market Research.

title: Firefighters' walkout could inspire others,undermining Blair : U.K. to feel heat from unions in November
description: LONDON:  "Remember, remember, the fifth of November," the English intone as they gather around bonfires to burn effigies of Guy Fawkes, a Roman Catholic rabble-rouser who tried to kill the king on Nov. 5, 1605.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush and Jiang on Korea

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday about the Ultra Cordless Optical Mouse, from Gyration, misstated the computer compatibility. In addition to working with PC's that run Windows 2000, ME or XP, and in some cases Windows 98, the mouse is compatible with the Mac operating system, Version 8.0 or higher.

title: Two Prisoners, One in Patrol Car, Another in Hospital, Escape Police Custody
description: Two prisoners escaped their police captors yesterday, one from the back seat of a patrol car, the other from Bellevue Hospital Center's emergency room, and a police officer was suspended in the latter mishap. The escapes were the latest in a year of embarrassing slip-ups for the police, including one in May that involved an escapee who had been arrested in connection with 16 sexual attacks.

title: Native Canadians Bask in New Business Climate
description: Native Canadians remember all too well the booms and busts of the past, when miners came to this barren land of frozen tundra to exploit its copper, uranium and gold and left with hefty wads of cash in their pockets.

title: Police Seek Co-Owner of New Jersey Car Linked to Attacks
description: Nathaniel Osbourne, an aspiring reggae singer who goes by the nickname Thriller, seemed forever to be looking for an audience. Now he is the subject of an intensive search by investigators who want to know why he is a co-owner of the car that the police say was used in the Washington-area sniper attacks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Valuing Hands Marty's Way: Harder, but Worth the Effort
description: Valuing a hand seems easy. A player counts 4-3-2-1 points, and that is all there is to it.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Isuzu To Post Loss
description: The car and truck maker Isuzu Motors expects to lose money for the fourth consecutive year in fiscal year 2002 as it offsets the costs of closing some of its operations in the United States. The automaker, which is 49 percent owned by General Motors, said it would lose 170 billion yen ($1.4 billion) in the full year to March 2003. Isuzu's five main banks also agreed take equity in exchange for writing off 100 billion yen ($800 million) of the automaker's debts. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Germany Urges U.S. to Drop Death Penalty Plan
description: Germany's interior minister urged the Bush administration today to drop its plans to seek the death penalty for Zacarias Moussaoui, the only person charged in an American court with involvement in the Sept. 11 terror attacks.

title: A SECOND DOWNGRADE FOR INTERPUBLIC'S DEBT
description: Moody's Investors Service downgraded the debt of the Interpublic Group, an advertising company, saying Interpublic was not generating enough cash to pay for acquisitions and dividends and to reduce its debt. The company, which is based in New York, has $3 billion in debt that is affected by the downgrade. Its senior unsecured debt was cut to Baa3, the lowest investment-grade rating, from Baa1, Moody's said. Interpublic's senior subordinated debt was cut to Ba1, a junk rating, from Baa2. Interpublic reduced its 2002 profit forecast last week because of losses at its Octagon sports-marketing unit and declining demand for marketing services. Another rating company, Standard & Poor's, has already downgraded Interpublic's debt.

title: Another Asian Nation Battling a Crisis In Its Banking System
description: With one of the world's fastest-growing economies, China seems to have mastered the move to capitalism with surprising speed. But its financial sector is still struggling to cope with the waste from decades of socialism.

title: A Rocky Road In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sniper Suspect Obtained a Rifle Despite a Restraining Order and Gun Laws
description: John Allen Muhammad, the man arrested in the suburban Washington sniper case, owned at least two Bushmaster XM15 rifles in the last two years: the one linked to the shootings and another one that he sold at a gun shop in Tacoma, Wash., according to court documents and an executive of Bushmaster Firearms.

title: Mayor Urges High-Tech Method to Collect Tolls
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday promoted the notion of installing a new toll-collection system that would operate without booths on local bridges, displaying an enthusiasm he generally reserves for all things technological.

title: Turf Condition Could Play Major Role
description: For the second straight day, light rain fell in the Chicago area today, but the forecast for Breeders' Cup Day was promising and track officials were optimistic that the main track would be fast.

title: Antiwar Groups Massing in Washington
description: Tens of thousands of demonstrators from around the country are expected to converge here on Saturday to tell the Bush administration that they oppose its strategy for a pre-emptive military strike against Iraq.

title: Second European Union Ruling To Block a Merger Is Overturned
description: For the second time this week, a European Union court has overturned a decision by the union's antitrust regulators to block a corporate merger. The decision today intensified pressure on the European Commission, the union's executive body, to change the way it assesses proposed mergers.

title: Ina Suspended For Not Taking Test
description: Kyoko Ina, a three-time Olympic pairs skater, was suspended for four years because she refused to take a randomly scheduled drug test in July, the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency announced yesterday. The suspension prohibits Ina from participating in International Skating Union events.

title: Schubert, Too, Told a Winter's Tale
description: At this point in his career as a singer, Jos van Dam has seen a lot and been a lot -- everything from St. Francis to the devil. His performance of Schubert's ''Winterreise'' at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday conveyed, in every breath, that length and breadth of experience, that variety of self-projections, all of which have also been self-examination. Schumann will follow tomorrow.

title: Their Title Hopes Dashed, Seminoles Are Out to End Irish's
description: When Bobby Bowden, the Florida State coach, thinks of Notre Dame, it's always painful. He harks back to the classic meeting in 1993 when the second-ranked Irish ended No. 1-ranked F.S.U.'s national championship hopes, 31-24. A pass by the eventual Heisman Trophy winner, Charlie Ward, was batted away in the end zone as the game ended.

title: At Home Abroad/ Expat adviser : The dos and don'ts of Japanese etiquette
description: Q: I will be going to Tokyo on business this month, and I need some information regarding the cultural differences I may encounter in a professional setting.

title: It Has a Misleading Title, But Not for the First Word
description: ''Jackass the Movie,'' which opened yesterday nationwide, comes with a disclaimer featured prominently in the print advertisements and publicity materials and at the beginning and end of the film itself. It certainly bears repeating: ''Warning: The stunts in this movie were performed by professionals, so neither you nor your dumb buddies should attempt anything from this movie.'' And please, just to extend the warning, don't try any of the activities described in this review. Not that you would be remotely tempted. Right?

title: Animosity, Real or Imagined, Fuels the Giants
description: Michael Strahan lifted his arms into the air the other day, the way a preacher beckons his congregation to stand. ''C'mon everybody,'' Strahan said loudly, ''let's get excited.''

title: HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL SELLS STOCK TO RAISE CASH
description: Household International Inc., the consumer loan company, sold $900 million in stock and in debt convertible into stock as it tries to reassure investors it has enough cash to pay its debts. Household, the nation's biggest lender to homeowners with poor credit histories, also sold $3.2 billion of loans and $4.3 billion of deposits to two buyers whose names it would not disclose, said a spokesman, Craig Streem. The securities, $500 million of debt that must be converted into stock after three years and $400 million of new common shares, was purchased Thursday night by the Goldman Sachs Group, Mr. Streem said. Household had to raise cash to pay existing debt and protect its credit rating at a time when it says more of its loans are uncollectible.

title: Editors' Note; Safety Note
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The change occurs tomorrow morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDERON, JACK
description: CALDERON-Jack. On October 24, 2002. Quintessential New Yorker, Sephardic pasha, devoted son of Sarah, dearest sweetheart of Gwen, best daddy in the world to Solara. Humorous, loyal friend, artist, an elegant, magical man, larger than life. He will be missed. Lovingly remembered by Sarah, Gwen, Solara, Saskia, Elizabeth, Ralph, Taria, Dave and Sophia. Services Sunday, 11:45 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Seeking New Trial In Beatings
description: Five members of an Atlanta church who were convicted of cruelty to children for whipping two boys in church have hired a prominent Atlanta lawyer, Ed Garland, to request a new trial. The Rev. Arthur Allen Jr. and three other church members reported to the Fulton County jail; the fifth will begin her sentence when her husband has finished his. The defendants had represented themselves despite pleas from Judge T. Jackson Bedford of Fulton County Superior Court, and they drew sentences of up to 90 days in jail and 10 years' probation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIGER, EDITH
description: TIGER-Edith. The Center for Constitutional Rights mourns the passing of our beloved Board member, Edith Tiger. Edith was a tireless fighter for justice who figured in many of the most important political battles of the past 60 years. Edith was one of the founders of The National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee, organized to defend against proscecution based on political beliefs. She served as its Director for over 30 years, the first woman in the United States to lead a prominent civil rights organization. Edith's indomitable spirit and devotion to the Constitution will be a source of inspiration to all of us. Our heartfelt condolences to her daughter Martha Potter, son-in-law Mark Potter, grandchildren Jesse Stewart, Judson and Nathan Potter, and her great-grandchildren, Harrison, Gideon, and Ezra Potter. For memorial information call CCR, 212-614-6464 ext 400.

title: The Chechen War Comes Home
description: As horrible as it was to watch the video footage from the Moscow streets around the theater where some 700 hostages were held until government forces stormed the building early this morning, it is as bitter to realize that this tragedy could have been predicted -- and in fact, was bound to happen.

title: North Korea's Response
description: Following are excerpts from a press release yesterday from the United Nations mission of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea):

title: Wellstone Killed in Crash, Clouding Fight Over Senate
description: Senator Paul Wellstone, a two-term Democrat locked in one of the tightest campaigns in the nation, was killed this morning when his campaign plane crashed in freezing rain near Eveleth, Minn., a small town in the northeastern part of the state.

title: A Rocky Road In the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Economic Growth
description: The British economy grew at an annual rate of 1.7 percent in the third quarter, slightly faster than the second quarter's pace of 1.3 percent, the National Statistics Office said. Both the service and manufacturing industries expanded, ending what some economists had called a one-engine economy led by a service sector that expanded while manufacturing contracted. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Politicians, Grow Up!
description: To the Editor:

title: HANCOCK LOWERS QUARTERLY ESTIMATE 9 CENTS A SHARE
description: John Hancock Financial Services reduced its third-quarter earnings estimate by $27.5 million, or 9 cents a share, because of the stock market's decline. Earnings excluding investment losses will be $185.8 million, or 64 cents a share, the company said. That compares with the 71-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net income will be $158.1 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $165.2 million, or 54 cents, a year ago, the company said. Along with other insurers, Hancock, which is to report earnings on Thursday, has been hurt by the decline in the equity markets.

title: Fordham's Big 3 Make Trip North Worthwhile
description: As a chilly wind swept across the field and rain clattered against helmets, the Fordham Rams shivered as they huddled in sodden clumps along the sidelines at a recent practice.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PRICELINE.COM INC., Norwalk, Conn., an Internet seller of discount airline tickets, hotel rooms and cars, expanded its hotel booking service to Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Singapore and Bangkok.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, WILLIAM GERARD
description: ROTH-William Gerard. Of Long Beach, NY, on October 24, 2002. Founder of Centre Mill Work & Supply Company. Beloved husband of Patricia (nee: McAvoy). Devoted and loving father of Gayle (GiGi) Warwick (Edward) ''Ned'', Bonnie Warwick (Anderson) ''Andy''. Adored grandfather of Megan and Eliza. Funeral Mass St. Ignatius Martyr R.C. Church, Monday 10:30 AM. Interment private. For information contact Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, William G. Roth Memorial Fund, will be established at a later date.

title: Paul Wellstone
description: Hardly anyone knew his name when he began his campaign for the Senate in 1990. He had no money to speak of, no experience in politics. He traveled the state in a rickety green school bus, wore a work shirt and jeans, wrote his own speeches and stayed in people's homes rather than hotels. Twelve years later, everyone in Minnesota and everyone of importance in Washington knew who Paul Wellstone was: a principled fighter for liberal causes, a maverick in a Senate known more for collegiality than fierce independence, a sworn enemy of big-money politics -- he championed a ban on gifts to lawmakers by special interests, much to the annoyance of many of his colleagues -- and a reliable friend of the dispossessed and the environment. He voted against giving two presidents named George Bush the authority to wage war against Iraq. His was a consistent voice for the poor and against what he regarded as adventurism, the kind of voice that seemed to have gone out of style more than 30 years ago

title: Those Seeing White Vans Rest Easier. So Do the Drivers.
description: Until the final moments of the three-week reign of sniper terror in the Washington area, there was one image, one all-consuming clue, seared into the minds of a panicked public: the white van.

title: Using Computers to Fight Kidnappers in Karachi
description: ONE minute, Jameel Yusuf, a Pakistani aristocrat turned citizen crime-fighter, curses like a New York beat cop and dismisses the kidnappers who prey on Karachi residents as ''scum.''

title: Cholesterol Drug Wins Approval
description: The drugmakers, Merck & Company and the Schering-Plough Corporation said today that they had received approval of the cholesterol drug Zetia, a potential $1-billion-a-year product, as the companies face more generic competition.

title: Mining Lighthearted Poetry From the Kitchen and Office
description: Disregard what the calendar says. It's still midsummer at the Joyce Theater, where the Parsons Dance Company opened a two-week engagement on Tuesday night. Most of its offerings were the sort of lighthearted and lightweight entertainments traditionally considered suitable for summer, when the brain cannot be taxed but the funny bone can be tickled.

title: Gunfire at Night in a Military Town
description: Some of John Allen Muhammad's former neighbors were surprised at the seemingly random connection between the sniper killings in the Washington, D.C., area and the plain duplex in Tacoma, Wash., where he lived last January. But many others like me were not.

title: Lockheed Profit Increases 36%
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation's third-quarter profit jumped by 36 percent on rising revenue from military programs like the F-35 joint strike fighter and the F/A-22 combat aircraft, the company said today.

title: In Columbus, It's That Perilous Time of Year
description: While John Cooper won more than 70 percent of the football games he coached at Ohio State, he never won the favor of Buckeyes fans, who are as parochial as they are rabid.

title: For Justice in the Sniper Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; A Reminder
description: Standard time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow. Clocks are set back one hour.

title: Man Is Killed in Apartment Near Times Sq.
description: A 50-year-old man was stabbed to death in an apartment near Times Square last night during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: The Devoted 'Stepson'
description: Uma James was desperate to find her son. He had run off with John Muhammad, a former boyfriend of Ms. James, and she had not seen him for months. When she showed up here last December, she set off alarm bells with her sensational accusations.

title: Cigna Shares Tumble After Profit Alert
description: The problems at the Cigna Corporation, which have been deepening for more than a year, grew worse yesterday.

title: Keeping U.S. No. 1: Is It Wise? Is It New?
description: President Bush's release of an audacious new strategy last month for defending America against future foreign threats stunned Washington and even some close allies. The 33-page document, titled the ''National Security Strategy of the United States,'' ostensibly departed from what had been the longstanding conventional wisdom about American strategy.

title: At Home Abroad / Third Culture Kids : Often more accomplished, but sometimes more troubled
description: VIENNA  Dragan Majetic feels gifted to have been raised abroad. His childhood in India, Africa and Japan opened doors to a world of excitement and opportunity out of reach to his peers back home in Belgrade. But sometimes Majetic wonders at the settled lives of those who stayed behind when his diplomat parents took him along for the ride. Would he have been happier if he had stayed home?

title: Mencken and Orwell, Social Critics With Little (and Much) in Common
description: Had H. L. Mencken, an obstreperous polemicist against American Puritanism, ever met George Orwell, a left-wing anti-Communist who fought the fascists in Spain, the result, I imagine, would have been mutual disgust.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It was already teetering on the edge and this throws more uncertainty in to the picture. Nobody knows where this is going.''

title: UNITED'S FLIGHT ATTENDANTS OFFER TO TAKE A PAY CUT
description: United Airlines flight attendants' union offered to take a 3.6 percent pay cut as part of a plan to save the UAL Corporation $5.8 billion over five and a half years. United's Association of Flight Attendants made the offer this week and told members that attendants with six or more years of service, about 85 percent of the 24,000 active attendants, would take the cut. UAL has said it must reduce costs to be viable, win approval for a federal loan guarantee that would help the company raise $2 billion in private loans and avoid a bankruptcy filing.

title: Richard Harris, Versatile And Volatile Star, 72, Dies
description: Richard Harris, the voluble Irishman who starred as King Arthur in the film version of ''Camelot'' and more recently played Albus Dumbledore, the wise, magical and benign headmaster in the first Harry Potter movie and its forthcoming sequel, died yesterday in London. He was 72.

title: Changes in Visa Rules Sink Concert Tour
description: Eleven years ago, a young German cellist walked out of a supermarket in Aspen, Colo., with a pair of 99-cent tweezers that he had not paid for. The musician, Eckart Runge, was charged and brought before a judge, who ordered him to pay court costs. With that, the case was closed.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTH KOREA: PROFIT FALLS AT BANK Korea's largest commercial bank, Kookmin, posted a disappointing third-quarter net income of $283 million, down 11.2 percent from the third quarter of last year and 29 percent from the second quarter of this year. The price of Kookmin shares slid 3.2 percent on the Korea Stock Exchange, to 40,400 won a share. The drop in income was attributed to concerns about the bank's rising credit card risk. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Retailers Like Business Gifts And the Profits They Generate
description: Did you really think corporate perks were out?

title: Rise in Autism
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Webster, Miscast
description: So much for the idea that the fight to restore investor confidence is a bipartisan effort. In a bitter public session yesterday, the five commissioners of the Securities and Exchange Commission split along party lines in voting for a chairman of a new oversight board for the accounting profession. The three Republican commissioners, led by the chairman, Harvey Pitt, voted to appoint William Webster.

title: U.S. Vulnerability to Terror Is Still High, Panel Concludes
description: Former Senators Gary Hart and Warren B. Rudman, the co-chairmen of a panel on domestic security, sharply chastised the White House and Congress today for failing to enact sweeping measures to defend the nation against a catastrophic terrorist attack, which they predicted is virtually certain to occur.

title: Letters to the editor : Indonesia casts its tax net worldwide
description: Regarding "Permanent U.S. expatriates can face hefty liabilities" (Sept. 28-29):
