description: CALIFORNIA: COURT BACKS BAN ON DIESEL VEHICLES

title: As End Nears, New York Race Sets a Record
description: Reports filed yesterday with the State Board of Elections made official what had been expected for more than a month: the race for governor of New York is now the most expensive nonpresidential race in American history.

title: For Justice in the Sniper Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Winton Blount, 81, a Founder Of the New Postal Service
description: Winton M. Blount, the last postmaster general to serve in a president's cabinet and the first chairman of the Postal Service, which he helped create, died on Thursday at his second home in Highlands, N.C. He was 81.

title: Statement by Maryland Prosecutor on Trial Venue
description: Following is a transcript of a statement made yesterday afternoon by the Montgomery County, Md., state's attorney, Doug Gansler, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: CANADA: ACCORD WITH INUIT The Canadian government signed an agreement with Quebec Province's Inuit to grant them rights to royalties from underwater resources off the Nunavik Islands. Ten thousand Natives stand to receive more than $50 million, and they will take part in the development and earnings from any discoveries of oil, gas and precious stones in the area. Officials described the agreement as the first granting of off-shore royalties to Native Canadians.    Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Federal Court Agrees to Hear State's Appeal On Tribal Issue
description: A court of the United States Department of the Interior said today that it would hear an appeal by the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, that contests a June decision by the Bureau of Indian Affairs granting federal recognition to the Eastern Pequot tribe in southeastern Connecticut.

title: In This Series, Hitters Knock The Pitchers Down
description: Tim Salmon considered the absurdity of this World Series while trying to hit Jason Schmidt in Game 5 on Thursday night. Schmidt, the San Francisco Giants' starter, humbled Salmon with a slider in the first inning, then buzzed a 95-mile-an-hour fastball past him in the third. Maybe, Salmon thought, there is a dominant starter here after all.

title: Lightning Isn't Losing Any Steam
description: Chris Dingman and Dave Andreychuk scored 51 seconds apart in the first period, and the Tampa Bay Lightning remained the N.H.L.'s only unbeaten team with a 3-2 victory last night over the visiting Washington Capitals.

title: Languages Aren't Pure
description: To the Editor:

title: Frequent Flights and Small Planes Have Made Politicians Vulnerable
description: Politics and airplanes can be a lethal combination.

title: Anticorruption Lawmaker Slain in Japan; Rightist Detained
description: The police today detained a rightist leader who they say confessed to stabbing an opposition congressman to death outside his suburban home on Friday.

title: Retracking a Trail: Checkpoints; The 2 Suspects Were Stopped By the Police Several Times
description: The police stopped the men who are now charged in the sniper shootings at least three times, including once here for suspicious behavior, during the three-week rampage, law enforcement officials said today.

title: The Sniper Suspects: Two Lives in Disarray
description: The man who stumbled into the tattered neighborhood known as The Avenues late this summer looked like a vagrant. He was dirty, his clothes soiled. He had walked at least four miles from the bus station, relatives say, and when he came to a cousin's doorstep, he wanted food.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Imported Halloween Candy
description: Hershey Kisses are swell. But can they compare to a chili-dipped lollipop?

title: Margaret Mordy, Christian Delesalle
description: Margaret Mitchell Mordy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Mordy of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Christian Olivier Delesalle, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Delesalle of Paris. The Rev. Dr. George S. Cladis performed the ceremony at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien.

title: Isn't It Romantic?
description: Eastern Standard Time begins today. Now there's an extra hour of darkness to dine by candlelight at these places.

title: American Fare in Upscale Surroundings
description: COMFORTABLE, inexpensive, uncomplicated, friendly, contemporary and inconsistent are some of the terms that describe the North Country Grill in Wading River. Three months ago, this charmer, at 2028 North Country Road (631-929-9292) in a delightful setting across the road from a pond filled with waterfowl, replaced the Ponds, a short-lived, upscale restaurant. Since then, the North Country Grill has been serving large portions of straightforward, though at times uneven, American fare to family groups at often remarkably modest prices.

title: Iraq's October Surprise; Fear of Hussein May Be Yielding to Doubt
description: SADDAM HUSSEIN, a keen admirer of Stalin, who has lined his palace libraries with books about the Soviet dictator, is nothing if not a practitioner of the most ruthless school of power politics. But as American and British pressures mount, signs are accumulating that the Iraqi leader, like many a despot before him, may be ready to make further concessions in his domestic and international policies -- concessions that would have seemed unimaginable only a few weeks or months ago -- for the larger purpose of sustaining his power.

title: On the Misuse Of Mammograms
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicole Berkowitz, Matthew Levinson
description: Nicole Berkowitz, a daughter of Marilyn and Alan Berkowitz of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Todd Levinson, a son of Bede and Steven Levinson of Rye, N.Y. Rabbi Bruce Block officiated at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERINGER, BRUCE MARSHALL
description: BERINGER-Bruce Marshall. Beloved husband of Marie Fortin Beringer, passed away peacefully of a heart attack at age 74, on October 23, 2002, near his home at Sugar Plum Farm in Randolph, NH. He was a graduate of Harvard College and was a financial advisor in New York for 38 years, most recently with Advest, Inc. Bruce and Marie have vacationed in Randolph, NH, since 1969, and settled permanately there in 1993. Bruce was involved with the Randolph Church and the Randolph Foundation. He enjoyed climbing, paddle tennis, tennis and chopping wood. Most of all he loved to be surrounded by his family and friends. Bruce was born April 13, 1928, to Albert Frederick Beringer and Elizabeth Morris Beringer of Larchmont, NY. He leaves two sons, Fred and Kathy of Cape Elizabeth, ME, Geoff and Dana of Rowayton, CT, three daughters, Elizabeth and Rafael of San Diego, CA, Ginger and Ray of Berkley, CA, Robin and Hossein of Albany, CA, and seven grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 9, 2002, at 2 PM, at the Larchmont Avenue Church. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Youth Program at the Larchmont Avenue Church, 60 Forest Park Ave, Larchmont, NY 10538, and also to the Randolph Church, Route 2, Randolph, NH 03570.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 27, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Where They Give a Dog A Heap of Socialization
description: HOLIDAYS at All Good Dogs Daycare in Kingston are celebrated with small gifts to the attendees. This week, for example, the dogs will be given orange neckerchiefs printed with tiny white ghosts to wear on Halloween.

title: False Idols
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Greatest Redskin Still Loves New York
description: He shared a locker with Mickey Mantle and sat in the best booth at Toots Shor's restaurant. Sometimes, he became lost on the subway, but that just made the night more adventurous.

title: Word for Word/Inside Iraq; Beheadings, Amputations, Reprisals: Saddam Hussein's Paper Trail
description: HITLER left one. So did Stalin. Modern tyrannies always leave paper trails, as startling for their dry bureaucratic detail as for their testament to rule by oppressive control, fear and cruelty.

title: Habitats/Pound Ridge, N.Y.; Redesigning a House To Suit a Special Need
description: IF she wants to, Helen Younger can race through her new house on her electric scooter, moving from one end to the other without having to face a single obstacle or make her way down a difficult hallway.

title: U.S. and 2 of Its Allies Warn North Korea on Atomic Arms
description: The United States, Japan and South Korea issued a joint statement here today calling on North Korea to dismantle its clandestine nuclear weapons program ''in a prompt and verifiable manner'' and warned Kim Jong Il, North Korea's leader, that his ''relations with the international community'' hinged on his quick compliance with the demand.

title: 'High and Mighty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERINO, NATALIE
description: CERINO-Natalie. For over 59 years the adored wife of Raphael, died October 22, 2002. Mrs. Cerino was the loving and beloved mother of Carol Baer and Paul Cerino, sister of Ira and George Kapp, sister-in-law of June and Doris Kapp, Elaine Karpf and the late Dorothy Waage. Her many interests encompassed music, art and social issues. Her elfin humor and understanding heart will be missed by everyone whoever met her.

title: October 20-26: ECONOMY; TYCO TROUBLES
description: Tyco International became the latest big public company to acknowledge that it had overstated its profits, saying an internal inquiry had found that it had inflated its earnings by $135 million last year. But investors were apparently expecting even worse news from Tyco, whose former chairman, L. Dennis Kozlowski, has been charged with massively looting the company. Tyco shares rose 11 percent when the company announced the news. Alex Berenson

title: HEPATITIS SHOTS REQUIRED
description: Beginning next fall, all students entering high school in New Jersey will have to be vaccinated against hepatitis B. Assemblyman Louis Greenwald, who sponsored the law enacting the requirement, started a campaign last week to inform parents. New Jersey already requires students entering kindergarten, first and sixth grades to have the vaccination. Students entering college will be required to be vaccinated beginning in the 2008-09 school year. The state health department says that about 40 percent of the 327 people who contracted hepatitis B in New Jersey last year were under the age of 19. Karen DeMasters

title: Editing McCarthy
description: To the Editor:

title: California Dreamin'
description: YOU will never confuse Joel's Malibu Kitchen with anybody else's kitchen. Calling Joel Scheinzeit the moving force behind this sweet, eccentric, slightly ramshackle and wholly engaging restaurant is like calling Sylvester Stallone the main character in ''Rocky.'' It's true, but it doesn't even scratch the surface.

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; MOSCOW RESCUE
description: About 40 Chechen gunmen stormed a Moscow theater Wednesday night, taking more than 700 people hostage. They demanded Russia withdraw its troops from the breakaway republic of Chechnya.

title: Campaign Season; A Two-Candidate Couple in Arkansas
description: Arkansas is used to political families. Consider Bill and Hillary Clinton or even Tim and Asa Hutchinson. But the state is breaking new ground with the Republican governor, Mike Huckabee, on the ballot for re-election while his wife, Janet, is the Republican nominee for secretary of state.

title: New Twists in Old Tales Lure Young Audiences
description: THE FORUM THEATER celebrates its 20th anniversary of Mainstage productions this year, with a capital campaign and a mix of classic and original musicals, from ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' to the premiere of ''Eddie and the Cruisers,'' for which the theater's founder, Peter Loewy is writing the book.

title: Man Ray's View of the Female Form
description: 'Man Ray, Voyeur/Voyant'

title: Sports of The Times; Top Skaters Have Power To Reform
description: MICHELLE KWAN had just displayed the pep of a lemon fizz, prompting a crowd smitten by skating's porcelain waif to stand as they beheld the Stradivarius amongst a field of second fiddles at Skate America.

title: Smith Heads for the Record With Soulful Determination
description: Two days before Emmitt Smith hoped to make his most memorable run, the one that would push him past Walter Payton as the National Football League's career rushing leader, Smith lay flat on his back. It is a position Smith assumes on most Friday afternoons, with Dr. Rob Parker kneading the knots out of his body, the buildup of muscle aches and pure torture over 13 pro seasons and 16,634 rushing yards gained, all as a Cowboy.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: One quick way to start clarifying the muddy waters of the sexual-harassment issue is for people to stop using the word ''sex'' when they mean ''gender.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, THOMAS B.
description: ROSS-Thomas B., 73. Died October 24, at Eastern Long Island Hospital, after a battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his wife Gunilla (Ekstrand) of Shelter Island Heights, N.Y., daughters Maria, Anne and Kristina, two granddaughters and his sister Grace Shanley. Vice President, Government Relations, Loral Space & Communications, Inc., he was formerly Special Assistant to President Clinton and Senior Director of Public Affairs for the National Security Council, a Senior Vice President of NBC News, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs in the Carter Administration, and foreign correspondent and Washington Bureau Chief of the Chicago Sun-Times. Coauthor with David Wise of three books on government intelligence, including New York Times number one bestseller, ''The Invisible Government,'' and a Nieman Fellow at Harvard, he served three years as an officer in the U.S. Navy during the Korean War. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in his memory may be made to Yale University, Class of 1951 Memorial Scholarship Fund. Funeral Mass 9 AM Friday, November 8th, at St. Thomas More's Church, 65 E. 89th St., NYC, followed by Memorial Reception, 11:00 AM. For location, phone 212751-1029.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, DR. MIRIAM RUTH GUTMAN
description: BRAVERMAN-Dr. Miriam Ruth Gutman. Of New York City, on October 21st, 2002. Loving sister of Jeanette Bernstein, loving mother of Tommy, cherished grandmother of Matthew Harry and Joel David. Miriam was the former wife of the late Harry Braverman. A professor at Columbia University's School of Library Science, Miriam was for more than 50 years a tireless crusader for social justice. Miriam is mourned by her family and countless friends. Memorial at International House, 500 Riverside Dr., Saturday, November 9, at 2 PM. Donations in Miriam's name may be made to the Progressive Librarians Guild, P.O. Box 2203, New York, New York 10108.

title: Questioning Lautenberg's Age Could Backfire on Forrester
description: In a gerontocracy like the United States Senate where Strom Thurmond, 99, and Robert Byrd, 84 -- still hold seats, Frank R. Lautenberg might be considered something of an adolescent.

title: Securely Lost
description: AS a patriotic American in these difficult times, I try to be understanding at airport security stations when I am patted down, stroked, poked, prodded and frisked by a stern-looking fellow in a cranberry blazer holding a magnetic wand. This is the new reality we must put up with.

title: The Bonds Rules
description: Brian Sabean's job is to evaluate players and decide the best fit for the Giants. As their general manager, Sabean is not supposed to be awed or shocked by what he sees. But when he watches Barry Bonds, Sabean is as amazed as everybody else.

title: Private Sector; Novice Author, Longtime Benefactor
description: It was the author's first book, and he had the usual people to thank -- his agent, Andrew Wylie, and his editor, Robert Loomis at Random House. But little else about the book party on Tuesday was routine.

title: Angels' Comeback Forces Game 7
description: Troy Percival was not supposed to sweat in the top of the ninth inning tonight because it looked as if it would be irrelevant. Waiting anxiously in the Anaheim bullpen and wondering if a magical season was about to end as the San Francisco Giants scampered to a 5-0 lead over the Angels, Percival had to wonder if he would ever throw a pitch.

title: Air Force's Edge
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Where Two Cultures Collided
description: STANDING atop the windy limestone hill, I let my eyes wander from the stone walls of the San Buenaventura mission to the dry plains stretching into the horizon. Multitiered cumulus clouds occupying a distant quadrant of the sky threatened not a drop of rain.

title: In New York, Champagne Days Are Here Again
description: BLAINE TRUMP was not sure what made her wrap herself in a white fox on her way out the door to the Whitney Museum's annual gala last Monday night. ''It might have looked over the top,'' Ms. Trump conceded.

title: Footlights
description: Dancing Back

title: Rightist Confesses to Killing Japanese Lawmaker, Police Say
description: The man accused of stabbing a liberal member of Parliament to death on Friday is a right-wing extremist with a record of arrests for assaulting members of leftist organizations, the police said today.

title: Suozzi Decision On Police Salary Board
description: In December 2001, a few days before he took office as Nassau county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi characterized the appointment of Martin Scheinman as an arbitrator for the detectives' union contract as ''a terrible disappointment'' and criticized his predecessor as county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, for the last-minute appointment.

title: Remains Of the Day, At a Price
description: AS autumn paints the Somerset hills in red, orange and golden tones, the fox's brush makes its own grand appearance in New Jersey's horse country.

title: Campaign Season; Consultants, Know Thy Audience
description: Critics have long viewed ''The West Wing'' as the liberal's dream of a presidency that might have been. Now it has become a prime vehicle for Democratic political consultants who want to place advertisements to reach a sympathetic audience, a Democratic consultant, Rachel Gorlin, says. ''It's become part of the base buy for Democrats,'' Ms. Gorlin said, just as other consultants buy ''Oprah'' to reach women. Jed Bartlet would be pleased.

title: New York Bookshelf/Nonfiction
description: PARADISE ALLEY By Kevin Baker

title: In Brookville, a Bit Of Ancient Egypt
description: GRUESOME is not a word that Bob Brier would use to describe the small, severed brown hand wrapped in linen that was in his office on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University in Brookville the other day.

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List; TOUGH SHOES FOR THE WARRIOR
description: The first thing you notice is the sandals. All the Masai warriors wear them -- 10,000-mile shoes they call them. Because they are made from old car tires. The way the Masai walk, they'll do another 10,000 easy before they wear out. Martin Margiela would love them. Consuelo Castiglioni of Marni has already used a variation of them. In London or New York or Paris, it would be street fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURSTEIN, MARTHA
description: MURSTEIN - Martha. Died peacefully on October 25, at her home in Miami Beach. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Leon. She personified love, honor, and dignity throughout her 95 years. She is survived by her children, Bernard and Nelly, Alvin and Aileen, Paul and Marjorie; her grandchildren, Danielle and Ben, Colette and Fletcher, Andrew and Barbara, Amie, Joanna and David; and her great grandchildren, Rebecca, Jacqueline, Melissa, Kimberly and Matthew. She will be greatly missed, may she rest in peace. There will be a private gravesite service Sunday followed by Shiva, which will be observed Sunday in Old Westbury and Monday in Scarsdale.

title: The Rescue, Seen From Inside: 'We Will All Be Blown Up'
description: ''We were waiting to die,'' said Olga Chernyak, a journalist who was one of more than 800 hostages inside a theater here as the siege by Chechen guerrillas reached its violent, bloody climax.

title: Analogy Strikes Out On Baseball and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Solti and Wagner But Not 'The Ring'
description: Mention Richard Wagner and Georg Solti in the same sentence to a record collector, and a discussion of the ''Ring'' cycle is likely to ensue: specifically, Solti's famous Decca recordings of the four ''Ring'' operas, made in the 1950's and 60's. To cinch the matter, add mention of the legendary Decca producer John Culshaw.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bridge for Sale

title: Giants Aim To Let Dogs Run After McNabb
description: Adrenaline surges in the defensive huddle when a blitz is called, especially for the linebacker or defensive back who is being sent across the line to attack the quarterback. He is relieved of other responsibilities: no pass coverage, no zone assignment. He has received permission to vandalize the offense and engage in football's purest form of aggression.

title: A Fast Start by the Flyers, An Early Night for Osgood
description: Surprisingly, there is at least one person who is not panicking over Chris Osgood's erratic goaltending. Osgood stood in the dressing room after a 6-2 loss to Philadelphia tonight at Nassau Coliseum and said that it was no big deal.

title: Britain Braces for Delays On Its Busiest Rail Line
description: WHEN it comes to causes for complaint, nothing preoccupies Britons more than the state of their transportation systems -- from standing-room-only commuter trains to subway strikes, from congested highways to buses that give new meaning to the word sporadic.

title: Switching Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: You Won't See Me
description: SHELL-SHOCKED, I staggered through the house before finally discovering my sounding board.

title: Through a Credit Lens, Stocks Aren't Alluring
description: THE credit health of the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index is deteriorating. That may be a signal to investors that a rebound in stocks may take longer than they had hoped.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. The haute couture's drop-dead, decadent dresses, larger-than-life hats, high heels and even higher hair would no doubt have pleased Fellini in the post-neorealism period of his career, when he directed ''812'' (a), ''La Dolce Vita'' and ''Juliet of the Spirits.'' The accessories in John Galliano's couture collection for Christian Dior were definitely in keeping with Fellini's most extravagant fashion impulses. Models were tricked out in towering headdresses (b) that might have given even Cher pause and wickedly sexy platform sandals (c).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, JUDITH L.
description: FISCHER-Judith L., 63. Died October 13, 2002 of Lou Gehrig's Disease. Mourned, loved and remembered by her brothers, David and Steve, & family, her ex-husband, Herbert and family, her cousins, Ray and Dorothy, and family, her friend Lenda & family. Lovely, gracious and brave, Judy will be deeply missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOXIE, R. GORDON
description: HOXIE-R. Gordon. Long Island University mourns the death of General R. Gordon Hoxie. Dean, President, and Chancellor, Dr. Hoxie played a major role in developing the C.W. Post Campus and the University as a whole. His legacy is the eighth largest private University in America. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Roger Tilles Chair, Board of Trustees David Steinberg President

title: Going to Disneyland? Not So Fast, Mr. Bonds
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: Co-Owner of Car Linked to Sniper Attacks Is Seized in Michigan as a Material Witness
description: A missing man who helped buy the car believed to have been used in the Washington-area sniper attacks was taken into custody in Michigan yesterday on a federal warrant listing him as a material witness in the case against the two prime suspects.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: A Pastor Makes It Cooler on Campus

title: For a Long-Unnoticed Marsh, A Square-Off Over Its Future
description: If there had been a contest for the city's most overlooked spot, Arlington Marsh might well have won. The 25-acre wetland, on Staten Island's north shore, is wedged between the Howland Hook Marine Terminal and an abandoned Ivory Soap factory. It has shrubs and low trees on the inland side and, as it slopes down to the shore, is covered with low grasses.

title: Corporate Ethics Law Is a Needed Change
description: Although this is a major governmental intrusion, the ultimate result will positively impact stock market investors. The combined effect of increased personal incentives to take far more interest in ensuring the accuracy of the financial reports filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the procedures to require inside investors to report their transactions more expeditiously can only have positive results. The cost of insurance and legal fees will rise, but it is better than the damage created by corporate fraud.

title: Sky Mesa's Handlers Find a Silver Lining
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Oct. 26  The mood was still somber this morning around the John Ward Jr. barn, which was hoping to enjoy a memorable Breeders' Cup Day. Instead, the morning-line favorite, Sky Mesa, had to be scratched from the Juvenile after developing swelling in his right front ankle. The only consolation is that he's still very much on course for next year's Kentucky Derby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, ADOLPH
description: GREEN-Adolph. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the passing of Adolph Green, who typified the joie de vivre of creation and performance of American music in this hall and so many others. In 1943-44, he and others created ''On The Town'' in a Carnegie Hall studio rented to Leonard Bernstein, and he made the first of his 15 appearances on the Carnegie Hall stage, where he last honored us two years ago, at Isaac Stern's 80th birthday celebration. His close friendship with Isaac Stern was a constant support in the rescue and resuscitation of this building, and he mourned Isaac's passing with us a year ago. We will miss his huge smile, his comraderie, and his ''dignity . . . always dignity.'' We extend condolences to Phyllis, Adam and Amanda, and to Betty, his collaborator of a lifetime. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Robert Harth, Executive & Artistic Director

title: At 39, Dunston Savors the Moment
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 26  Shawon Dunston was angry and heartbroken in 1989. He was a certified major leaguer, a starter for several years with the Chicago Cubs. But he was saddened by the death of his grandmother and preoccupied with how much money he was making compared with other players.

title: Top Performers
description: SMART SETS RECORD

title: The Challenge of a Career Ends in Success for Moose
description: On the morning that it became apparent a skilled marksman was on the loose, Charles A. Moose, the police chief of Montgomery County, Md., was putting on his dress uniform to attend an officer's funeral. Instead, he found himself at a Mobil gasoline station, struggling to piece together clues in the third bizarre killing in less than 24 hours.

title: MEMORIAL IN WEST ORANGE
description: ''Remembrance and Rebirth,'' a $1.3 million bronze memorial to people killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was unveiled last week at the Eagle Rock Reservation in West Orange. Patrick Morelli of Cedar Grove designed and built the memorial, which depicts a girl clutching a teddy bear and standing before an open book inscribed with the names of the names, ages and hometowns of Essex County residents who died in the attacks. Behind the book, a bald eagle with an eight-foot wingspan perches atop a tree. A teenage boy holding a lantern and facing New York stands next to the book. The names of all those who died in the attacks are inscribed on granite walls next to the memorial. John Holl

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; PI WINS A PRIZE
description: The Booker prize, Britain's premier literary award, was presented for the first time under new sponsors who want to give it a zippier image and open it to American authors.

title: A New Lyme Vaccine With Roots at B.N.L.
description: IT'S just a coincidence that the research was done in one of the places where it might do the most good. But after 10 years of work, scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory have fashioned a new Lyme disease vaccine that they hope will be on the market by the end of the decade.

title: Still There: Can 40 Years Have Passed?
description: WHEN ''Hollywood Arms,'' the play by Carol Burnett and her daughter Carrie Hamilton, opens on Thursday on Broadway at the Cort Theater, it will mark a special moment in Linda Lavin's theatrical life. She made her Broadway debut in the chorus of the musical ''A Family Affair'' 40 years ago. Then, as now, the director was Harold Prince.

title: Helping Those Without
description: JUST over three decades ago, local community groups here got together to offer children free camp physicals. Not only did they have far more boys and girls take advantage of the free checkups than anticipated, but they also discovered that many of the children examined hadn't had a physical in more than five years. Some had serious conditions that needed further treatment.

title: Nervousville, U.S.A.?; Fear Stalks Suburbs, Even One With a Cheerful Name
description: With fat pumpkins standing guard on turn-of-the-century porches and sidewalks swirling with golden leaves, this postcard-perfect village -- with a name to match -- presents a tableau of peace and plenty.

title: Polls Say Leftist Will Win Brazil's Presidency by Wide Margin
description: In the second and decisive round of Brazil's presidential election on Sunday, all signs indicate that Luiz Incio Lula da Silva, the candidate of the left-wing Workers' Party, will coast to the victory that narrowly eluded him three weeks ago.

title: Wonders Never Cease
description: THE MIRACLE

title: I Stand Alone
description: When I heard about the Gay Games in Sydney, I thought it sounded amazing -- more than 13,000 gay athletes in one place -- so I started looking for other Iraqi rugby players. There was no chance that anyone living in Iraq would be able to go, so I had to draw from the diaspora. I tried word of mouth through the rugby world. I also put postings on the Internet: you know, ''Are you gay, Iraqi and looking to play rugby?'' I didn't get responses -- except from friends. They would see my posting and say, ''Did you see someone is looking for a gay Iraqi rugby player!''

title: INVESTING WITH -- Thomas F. Marsico; Marsico Growth Fund
description: THOMAS F. MARSICO calls managing money a ''three-dimensional chess game.''

title: Supermom Fictions
description: It happens nearly every time a new book comes out about motherhood and work -- the flurry of responses that treat reports of a still-unsolved conflict between the two as a revelation, even a shock. Last spring it was ''Creating a Life,'' Sylvia Ann Hewlett's dour statistical inventory of a career gal's chances for procreating. This fall it's Allison Pearson's cannily amusing novel of working-mom manners, ''I Don't Know How She Does It.'' Each book was greeted, as such books almost always are, with professions of deepest surprise, as if it were news that working mothers seldom feel that their lives are in balance, that the competing goods of work and children are just that, competing, and ceaselessly. The perils of ''having it all'' (a phrase you would think had long since been relegated to 70's nostalgia quizzes) were trotted out again in pursed-lip fashion. Commentators were startled when some maverick finally spoke the truth about a phenomenon -- fertility concerns for older women or the difficulty of operating at full throttle on the job while paying a good deal of attention to your children -- that, in fact, preoccupies many people, who speak about it plenty.

title: Hammerstein's Due
description: To the editor:

title: The Philosopher's Stone
description: TOURMALINE

title: My Hat, It Has A Message
description: FIRST it was a picture book, whose coffee-table size imparted a touch of class; its title, ''Crowns,'' added an air of royalty. Photographs of 54 black women wearing their church hats are accompanied by oral histories, evoking memories and metaphors, signifying that these are not just hats.

title: Baker Sticks Up for Howe
description: Giants Manager Dusty Baker had one word to describe the negative reaction in New York prompted by Art Howe's hiring by the Mets, and the term he used was unprintable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERMAN, ISAAC M. ''IKE.''
description: OBERMAN-Isaac M. ''Ike.'' The employees and staff of The Oberman Companies express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our leader, teacher and friend. As the patriarch of our business family, he was more than just an insurance broker, he was our confidant, our conscience and our true inspiration as a professional. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife Regina, to his son Stuart (Paula), his daughters Susan (Herb) and Arlene (Robert), to his grandchildren, great-grandchild and brothers. Ike's smile, bold laugh and bad jokes will be missed by us all. Our sympathy and love go to his friends and family, and all who have been touched by this truly wonderful man.

title: You Can Bet the House But Save a Token for Dinner
description: It's the ''old-timey'' place where Burt Lancaster brought Susan Sarandon to impress her in the movie ''Atlantic City,'' and it has been an icon for 90 years. Finally -- after being driven to its grave with the arrival of gambling and resurrected by the former owner's son -- the Knife and Fork Restaurant has proven to be casino-worthy.

title: Win a Grand Prize In Another Currency
description: Find a bag of all purple M&M's and you win the grand prize in a worldwide contest by Masterfoods USA, the division of Mars Inc. that makes the candies. But after reading the fine-print rules, you may wonder how grand the cash prize really is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, BERNARD
description: GREEN-Bernard. Died on October 23, 2002, in Williamsville, NY, of prostate cancer at age 88. Originally from Queens, NY, he retired to Poughquag, NY, in 1975, and moved to Williamsville in 2000. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Rita Wolfe and two sons, Dr. Andrew Green and Dr. Leslie Green, and their spouses and five grandchildren. He was a textile technologist.

title: Pouring Paint, Minus a Mess
description: PAINTING has always been a messy project. And the problems can start almost as soon as you pry open the can with a screwdriver. How many times have you spilled paint on the floor before you could even pour it into the tray?

title: Making a Move to the Island a Little Easier
description: FOR three days in May, John and Christi Ruggieri holed up in a motel in Huntington while Nichole, the oldest of their three children, attended cheerleader tryouts at Huntington High School. The family, then living in Freehold, N.J., planned to close on a Huntington house in September, but that would be too late for Nichole's cheerleading plans.

title: Netta Levy, Michael Beebe
description: Netta Levy, a daughter of Ilana and Yair Levy of Allentown, Pa., is to be married this evening to Michael Jason Beebe, a son of Patricia A. Carnevale of Lancaster, Pa., and Terry Beebe of Irvine, Calif. Rabbi Mark L. Shrager is to officiate at the Fiddler's Elbow Country Club in Far Hills, N.J.

title: Commercial Property/New Jersey; New University Plan Could Help Biotech Corridor
description: GOV. JAMES McGREEVEY'S proposal to consolidate Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry and the New Jersey Institute of Technology into one system is apparently discomfiting to many in the academic world -- but many commercial real estate market specialists say they find the idea compelling.

title: France Is Set to Offer the U.N. A Separate Resolution on Iraq
description: In a bold diplomatic challenge to the United States, France announced today that it might formally introduce its own resolution on disarming Iraq at the United Nations Security Council.

title: Dr. Seuss and Friends Return Home in Bronze
description: Dr. Seuss's characters have sold almost a half-billion books around the world and have been stars in movies and television shows and on Broadway. Now they stand in bronze as a tribute to their creator in his hometown.

title: The Role of Politics In a Pension Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUSCH, HELEN
description: RAUSCH-Helen. On October 25, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Loving mother of son Howard and daughter Rita Moelis. Cherished grandmother of four grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Services today, at 12:30 PM, from Boulevard - Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Thursday and Friday about the first parliamentary elections in Bahrain in 30 years referred incorrectly to the regional precedents for women's rights to vote and to run for national office. This was the first election that allowed them in any Arab country in the gulf, not in gulf countries over all. Women hold national office and vote in Iran.

title: Fairs Give Israelis a Boost
description: JUDY PRAGER said she wanted to do a double mitzvah: give Israelis a chance to sell their goods to Connecticut residents who might be afraid to fly to Israel and give people a chance to shop for Judaica items that aren't readily available.

title: Giving Yourself A Holiday Trip
description: BECAUSE parents need to schedule family holidays around school vacations, and because many jobs provide time off around the Christmas-New Year's holiday, much winter travel necessarily takes place between Dec. 20 and Jan. 5. Historically, prices go up, desirable resorts fill well in advance, and crowds and bad weather can frustrate holiday cheer. On the up side are special activities, often geared to families, around this time.

title: Dance Listings
description: ANDREA MARIA DANCE ART TECHNOLOGY  A visual motion construction with choreography and video by Andrea Haenggi. The Construction Company Dance Gallery, 10 E. 18th St. (212-924-7882) Today, Mon., 8.

title: Art Listings
description: Museums/Institutions

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Carnival Rehearsals in Rio

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETTINGER, PHILIP O., M.D.
description: ETTINGER-Philip O., M.D. Of Leonia, NJ, on October 22, 2002. Beloved husband of Roxanne. Cherished son of the late Sam and Charlotte & stepson of Hana. Devoted father of Alyssa & Jonathan. Dear brother of Stephen J. Ettinger, D.V.M. Services on Monday 1 PM at ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Putney School, Elm Lea Farm, Putney, Vermont 05346.

title: On a Vacation, Or Maybe a Quest
description: I WAS my usual anxious self, I admit, when I booked my rental car with a company I'd never heard of. I thought I would probably have to walk miles from the airport to the office, which would no doubt be on a dusty street somewhere on the outskirts of town. But there it was, Advantage Rent-A-Car, right next to the baggage claim at the Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, wedged between Budget and Enterprise and staffed by a harried looking Russian woman wearing misapplied lipstick.

title: Put On Your Toga! Bring Castanets! Rena Sindi Is Giving a Party
description: KRISTINA STEWART, the society editor of Vanity Fair, likes to call the consummate party hostess Rena Kirdar Sindi the new Elsa Maxwell, although Ms. Sindi, the 33-year-old daughter of an Iraqi-born financier, hardly looks anything like plump Elsa did. ''She doesn't take a dilettante's approach to entertaining,'' Ms. Stewart explained. Serena Boardman admits that among her friends, Ms. Sindi does stand out -- and not just because she's attractive, went to Oxford or lives in Sean Combs's town house on Park Avenue. ''Some people are like bumps on a log,'' Ms. Boardman said. ''Rena has a lot to say for herself.''

title: Angels Plan to Be Contenders for Years to Come
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 26  Six billboard-size pictures of Anaheim Angels players line the entrances to Edison Field. Tim Salmon, Garret Anderson, Darin Erstad, Troy Glaus, Jarrod Washburn and David Eckstein, who are in different action poses in all of their 50 feet of glory, stare down anyone who enters the stadium like a posse of superheroes.

title: Dartmouth Survives Challenge From Columbia
description: Mike Giles's 2-yard touchdown run with 2 minutes 24 seconds remaining in the game capped a wild fourth quarter as Dartmouth topped host Columbia, 24-23, yesterday. The loss was the fifth straight for the Lions (0-3 Ivy, 1-5 over all); the Big Green (2-1, 3-3) won its third in a row.

title: Lauren Blum, C. William Merten
description: Lauren Blum and C. William Merten were married last evening at the Cheekwood Botanical Garden in Nashville. Judge Gilbert S. Merritt of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit in Nashville officiated.

title: The Floor Shook, But They Didn't
description: When times are tough, do the tough really get going? The answer is: Sometimes. As the mail indicates, maybe the best strategy for maintaining business in a weak economy is simply to sit tight. But when the outlook is bleak, well-planned action may also pay off in a big way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLACK, MORRIS
description: BLACK-Morris. The Three Arrows community notes with sorrow the passing of Morris Black, a member respected for his deep integrity and humanity. Condolences to his wife Marjorie, and his step-children and grandchildren. Halona W. Balgley, President

title: Hady Hassan Omar's Detention
description: Hady Hassan Omar had made up his mind. He was going to kill himself if he wasn't released by New Year's Eve.

title: Making Something New Out of Dance Music's Past
description: LAST year, disco and new wave underwent a dance-floor revival, as electronic producers mimicked the pop songs they had grown up loving. Smart, beguiling albums by Daft Punk and Felix Da Housecat paid exuberant (if tongue-in-cheek) tribute to the sounds of the late 70's and early 80's. An enterprising promoter gave this new old sound a name -- electroclash -- and organized a three-day music festival in New York last October to celebrate the genre. The 2002 Electroclash tour started in New York earlier this month and ends on Tuesday in Los Angeles.

title: L.I.@WORK
description: Computer Associates Narrows Its Losses

title: Megan Antonelli, Bernard Gerst III
description: Megan Katherine Antonelli, a daughter of Suzanne and Steven C. Antonelli of New York, was married yesterday to Bernard John Gerst III, the son of Mary Anne Rahm of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Gerst Jr. The Rev. Richard J. Simeone performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Gloucester, Mass.

title: October 20-26: FRONT LINES; TERRORIST TRIAL BEGINS
description: In Germany, during the opening of the first trial related to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Mounir el-Motassadeq, accused of providing support for the Hamburg cell of Mohammed Atta and others, admitted that he attended a training camp in Afghanistan sponsored by Osama bin Laden. He denied knowing that his friends, including three of the Sept. 11 suicide pilots, had intended to commit terrorist acts. Desmond Butler

title: A Ribbon of Highway, And Now a Bridge of Plastic
description: New Jersey's lanes are littered with enough foam cups, bottles and throwaway wrappers that no one has been arguing for more plastic chaff in the roadways.

title: The World; Where Novels Get Oscars
description: IF there was ever any doubt that Britain and America have two distinct cultures, it was banished last week. While the London literati toasted the winner of the Booker Prize at a televised banquet in the newly refurbished Great Court of the British Museum, the finalists for America's National Book Awards were announced in a terse press release that didn't even make ''The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer.''

title: Rome
description: In many European capitals, November and early December are decidedly past peak, with the weather dropping a few degrees too many and the sky turning sadly wintry. For Rome, it's a fine season -- not excessively cold or dark, not excessively hot or bright. That matters, because this is a city that beckons visitors outdoors and begs to be walked.

title: Editors' Note; A Reminder
description: Standard time resumed at 2 a.m. today. Clocks were set back one hour.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 22 with an article about Peter Linz, a puppeteer from Katonah, referred incorrectly to the setting of the photograph and carried an erroneous credit. The picture was taken on the set of a television program, not at Mr. Linz's home. The photographer was Richard Termine. The Times was notified of the error on Oct. 9 by the writer of the article; this correction was delayed by difficulty in reaching the photographer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Remembering your birthday Malvin dear, they were such fun! You are always in our hearts and minds, and your presence is felt every day. We miss you so much. Love you always. Audrey, Irik, Jaar-mel

title: Stapling Without a Staple
description: The new Staple Free Stapler by Made by Humans, a design company in Vancouver, British Columbia, means you are not likely ever to run out of staples. The device neatly slices a small stitch and slot in a piece of paper, and in one swift move threads the stitch through the slot for an instant grasp.

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

description: To the Editor:

title: Melissa Ann de la Cruz, Michael Johnston
description: Melissa Ann de la Cruz, a daughter of Concepcion and Alberto de la Cruz of Pasadena, Calif., was married on Friday to Michael Anthony Johnston, a son of Marsha and Dennis Johnston of Kirtland, Ohio. The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: In Search of Good Health? Try a Bad Attitude.
description: NOT to sound too negative about it, but there's yet more evidence that this power-of-positive-thinking idea may not be all it's cracked up to be.

title: Talking With the Giants He Once Walked With
description: UNDER Steven H. Scheuer's name on the screen are the words ''television historian.'' That will have to do. A more telling description, like ''witness to half a century of television history,'' wouldn't fit.

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast; Why Use the Park To Ease Traffic Congestion?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Socratic Method
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling P.S. 8 Tries to Meet Neighborhood's Expectations
description: Ah, Brooklyn Heights! With its beautiful brownstones, lush trees and breathtaking waterfront views, who would ever move away?

title: October 20-26: NATIONAL; SENATOR PAUL WELLSTONE DIES IN PLANE CRASH
description: Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota and one of the foremost liberals in Congress, was killed in a plane crash in northern Minnesota. His wife, daughter and five others were also killed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISLER, MELVIN
description: REISLER-Melvin. Beloved and loving husband of Helen, devoted and loving father of Susan (Mike), Karen (David) and Keith (Cathie). Adored grandfather ''Papa'' of Emily, Jayme, Jake, Gillian, Jenna and Julia. Visitation will be held Sunday 10:30AM 12:30PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Private graveside service.

title: Anh Doan, Thomas Cahill Jr.
description: Anh Ngoc Doan and Thomas Francis Cahill Jr. were married yesterday at St. Mary's Church in Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Halkovic, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: From the East 60's in the 60's To Today on Orchard Street
description: A history of style in New York might be told by charting Bill Cunningham's peregrinations around it. In 36 years of street photography, he has gone from documenting the privileged souls whose social universe pivoted on the restaurants of the East 60's to the blithe young spirits of Orchard Street. The only spot Mr. Cunningham has never abandoned is the corner of Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. ''I've been going since 1948,'' he said. ''Stand there and you see the world.''

title: October 20-26: FRONT LINES; OFFICIAL TERROR
description: In the aftermath of the Bali bombing that killed more than 180 tourists, the Bush administration designated an Islamic militant group, Jemaah Islamiyah, as a terrorist organization. The listing makes it a crime to contribute funds to the Indonesia-based group and bars its members from entering the United States. On the same day, Indonesia joined a U.S. backed Australian initiative to place Jemaah Islamiyah on the United Nations terrorist list. Jane Perlez

title: Georgia's Six Scoring Passes Foil Kentucky
description: First it was Georgia's fans moaning over narrow, seemingly unimpressive victories over Clemson and South Carolina. Then it was Tennessee quarterback Casey Clausen claiming that if he had played, the Vols would have whipped Georgia on Oct. 12. This week, Kentucky quarterback Jared Lorenzen had imagined the thrill of sitting on the goal posts as they came down today after an upset of unbeaten Georgia.

title: When A Bridge Is Not A Bridge
description: In 1557, when Suleiman the Magnificent ruled in Constantinople and the sway of the Ottoman Empire extended as far north as Budapest, an Ottoman engineer named Hajrudin came to the city of Mostar, in southwestern Bosnia, to build a bridge across the Neretva River. Engineers like Hajrudin built bathhouses in Budapest, mosques in Sarajevo and bridges over all the rivers in the empire. The bridge he completed over the Neretva in 1566 had an economic and perhaps a political purpose: to solidify the link between Ottoman possessions and the hinterland of Ragusa, a wealthy city-state on the Adriatic coast, now known as Dubrovnik.

title: Muses of a Street Photographer
description: ANNA WINTOUR, the editor of Vogue, was the assistant to the fashion editor of Queen, the British magazine, when I started photographing her 30 years ago at the couture shows. In those days, she was wearing the mod clothes of swinging London. She wasn't a model for any designer but chose the clothes that were flattering to her and never an exaggerated look. She achieves elegance by wearing beautiful fabrics beautifully fitted. Hers is the art of simplicity. When it comes to accessories she is a minimalist. Any woman with a normal fashion appetite can relate to her.

title: Behind the Camera, After School
description: HAVELOCK HEWES has the name of a silent-movie villain, and he will put on a cape or twirl a mustache if that is what a pint-size auteur needs to flesh out a scene. But Mr. Hewes has -- and has to have -- more range than that of the occasional anti-hero in black and white.

title: Home With Wilma Rudolph
description: In OUT OF THE SOUTH: Poems (Louisiana State University, cloth $22.95; paper, $15.95) the novelist, memoirist and poet Neal Bowers tips his hat to parents whose peculiar comportment gave the writer-to-be something to think about then and write about later. His father ''answered only 'Yes,' 'No,' 'Maybe,' / and never volunteered a private thought''; his mother put up with the silence until the day she walked out and the father followed her in the family car, ''driving beside her, slow as a beginner, / pleading, my baby brother and I / crying out the windows, 'Mama, don't go!' / It was a scene to break your heart / or make you laugh -- those wailing kids, / a woman walking briskly with a suitcase, / the slow car following like a faithful dog.'' Yet Bowers's recollections have an extra dimension because they are set in the segregated South, and his memories of life there can be ugly as well as winsome, often at the same time. In one poem he refuses to forgive himself for his cruelty to the first black student admitted to his school, a classmate whose name he never even bothered to learn. In another, he pretends to be the champion sprinter Wilma Rudolph ''breaking / the finish-line tape, / ashamed to have such thoughts, / not because I was a boy / but because I was white, / proud of her just the same, / of the speed that carried her / down the world's ellipse, / out of our shared hometown.'' Like collard greens that have been cooked all day with ham hocks, ''Out of the South'' is both bitter and delicious. David Kirby

title: Not Quite Right for Our Pages
description: Ian McEwan's novel ''Atonement'' has been praised for its graceful writing, its fully imagined characters, its narrative suspense, its vivid evocation of life in England at the time of World War II. But except for a few editorial churls who make their living by writing turndowns, few readers have remarked that it also contains one of the classic rejection letters.

title: Leadership Struggle Inside Canada's Governing Party Intensifies
description: The parliamentary election is more than a year away, but the campaign to replace Prime Minister Jean Chrtien entered its first critical phase this week with ministers from the governing Liberal Party sharpening their sabers for a rough internal struggle for the party leadership.

title: Private Sector; Praise the Women and Pass the Thin Mints
description: This awards banquet featured cookies and brownies. On Thursday the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York honored seven women at its 10th annual Women of Distinction ceremony.

title: The Enduring Nature Of Art and Headlines
description: BEGINNING in the 1920's, Westport became known as an art town. Besides fine artists, Westport attracted hosts of illustrators, cartoonists and designers.

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; MORE SUICIDE KILLING
description: Two Palestinian suicide bombers in an explosives-laden sport utility vehicle rammed the rear of a bus in northern Israel, killing 14 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANOFF, ABRAHAM
description: DANOFF-Abraham. Artist, free spirit, predeceased by wife Judith, died October 18, (age 86), after enjoying a delicious dinner with son Saul (and Valerie). Also survived by daughter Ann and grandchildren (Kimmer, Joshua, Zachary, Sonya, Isabel) and friends. Back to the earth he loved so much.

title: Knicks Have Learned To Lower Expectations Right From the Start
description: In the closing moments of Friday night's embarrassing preseason finale at the Continental Arena, a fan sitting behind the Knicks bench screamed, ''It must stink to be a Knick!'' Latrell Sprewell, standing on the fringes of the huddle in a gray suit, looked up, allowed his mouth to curve into a bit of a smile and just shrugged his shoulders.

title: An Islamic Treasury By the Pacific
description: AT the end of a steep, shaded driveway where bougainvillea and old philodendrons creep up the trunks of palm trees stands the entrance to Shangri La. Surprising in its modesty, its dark wooden door appears unobtrusively between two Chinese stone camels, close to a large banyan tree. The Arabic script engraved on metalwork on the door, Deborah Pope tells me, is from the Koran, and it means ''Enter therein in peace and security.''

title: Nina Bradley, Thomas Smallhorn
description: Christina Hennings Bradley, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Bradley of Hingham, Mass., was married there yesterday to Thomas Adrian Maximillian Smallhorn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher A. Smallhorn of Beverly Farms, Mass. The Rev. Robert Edson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. John's the Evangelist Church.

title: RETRACING A TRAIL
description: WALKING A DELICATE LINE -- For Chief Charles A. Moose, the intensely public sniper manhunt posed extraordinary challenges. PAGE 37

title: Terror vs. Terrorism; When Just One Gun Is Enough
description: ATOMIZED cells. Leaderless revolutionaries. Soft targets. After Sept. 11, these were the dangers intelligence officials warned us about.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, ALVINA E.
description: MURPHY-Alvina E. October 24, 2002, at age 97. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Willis A. Murphy. She was a nurse, advisor and compassionate person who cared about all living things. Her friends celebrate her long life and mourn their loss. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, October 29, 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, October 30, 11 AM, at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, NYC.

title: From Joy to Despair in Seconds
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 26  After seven straight losses, Army appeared to be on the verge of its first victory today when Josh Holden scored from 2 yards out to give the Black Knights a 4-point lead over Alabama-Birmingham with less than a minute to go.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: ROUGE PULP

title: October 20-26: FRONT LINES; STILL VULNERABLE
description: A panel of national security experts has concluded that the United States remains vulnerable to a major terrorist attack, particularly at sea ports, power plants and oil refineries. The panel, headed by former Senators Gary Hart and Warren B. Rudman, found local emergency response officials ill-equipped to handle biological or chemical attacks, local police to have little access to intelligence data and that only a few ships and containers entering American ports are inspected. James Dao

title: Business; Cigarette Makers Take Anti-Smoking Ads Personally
description: BODY bags. Dying rats. Dog urine.

title: Letters
description: Congress vs. Reagan

title: October 20-26: NATIONAL; SNIPERS CAPTURED
description: Authorities arrested two men in Maryland and charged them in connection with 10 killings and the wounding of three others, over the past three weeks.

title: Jill Hemingway, Michael McCartney
description: Jill Alyson Hemingway and Michael McCartney were married yesterday by the Rev. Peter M. Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Patrick's Old Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: The Enemies on '24': Terrorists and Inconsistency
description: THE real-time format that set the Fox series ''24'' apart in its first season, and helped make it a favorite of critics, looked more like a blueprint for disaster to one of the show's creators two years ago.

title: Miscues in Sniper Pursuit, Then Calls and a Big Break
description: With a loud crack and a blinding light of the SWAT team's disorienting but harmless ''flash bang,'' the agents rushed the blue Chevrolet Caprice parked in a highway rest stop in rural Maryland. They smashed out several windows and unlocked the doors. Within seconds, the agents pulled the two dazed occupants from the car at gunpoint and placed them under arrest.

title: Quiet Neighbor With a Quick Step
description: In the community of Ottos, where wood houses line the narrow streets and the smell of barbecue drifts through the air along with the beat of soca music, John Allen Muhammad was a quiet, hustling man. Though he socialized little, he was a familiar sight walking briskly down the street, often with his children, with a black knapsack on his way to parts unknown.

title: BENEFITS
description: Cabaret for Hospital

title: At Least 67 Captives and 50 Chechens Die in Siege
description: Russian troops crushed a 57-hour hostage siege in Moscow's heart early today, ending a terrorist threat meant to overturn President Vladimir V. Putin's Chechnya war strategy and even his presidency. His iron response won acclaim, but the price -- at least 67 dead hostages, and perhaps far more -- could yet prove dear.

title: Where Big Rigs Roll, Howls of Dismay
description: Leah Dilworth bought a house on Maspeth Avenue in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a year ago, but not until summer did she discover a major drawback.

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Receives Two Editorial Endorsements
description: The editorial page of The New York Times is endorsing George E. Pataki today for a third term as governor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 13 about pronunciation and mispronunciation of the word ''nuclear'' quoted a passage incorrectly from a letter used by Merriam-Webster editors to illustrate the connection between spelling and speech. And a correction in this space last Sunday misstated the message of the letter. The letter cites the three words ''electrical,'' ''electricity'' and ''electrician'' (not electric). It makes the point that spelling is not always a valid way of determining pronunciation (not punctuation).

title: Glen Cove Ferry To Suspend Service
description: The operators of a commuter ferry between Glen Cove and Manhattan, a centerpiece of Glen Cove's waterfront revitalization effort, announced on Oct. 16 that they were suspending service on Nov. 1 until further notice.

title: Job Expenses May Add to Debt for Women
description: Young women are more likely than men the same age to incur debt, and they often have career-related expenses to blame, a study released last week suggests.

title: Player's Computer Strategy Works When He Sticks to It
description: Man and computer fought to a draw in the eight-game showdown in the Meridien Hotel in Manama, Bahrain. The 27-year-old human, world champion Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, and Deep Fritz, the creation of the programmers Franz Morsch of the Netherlands and Mathias Feist of Germany, split the match with two victories each and four draws. The $1 million prize will be divided.

title: This Farm Is Lush but No Sunnybrook
description: Hillary Birmingham doesn't like farm movies -- too sentimental. Ms. Birmingham, who grew up outside Boston, is no great fan of cows, either -- too scary. ''Put a couple of them together, they're huge,'' she says.

title: Cold War Charm and Hot Tub: Silo Site Fetches $2.1 Million
description: A converted missile silo site has been sold for $2.1 million in an online auction to a couple who are getting an Adirondack getaway home with a Jacuzzi, three-foot-thick walls and some cold war charm.

title: Bill on Bill
description: I STARTED photographing people on the street during World War II. I used a little box Brownie. Nothing too expensive. The problem is I'm not a good photographer. To be perfectly honest, I'm too shy. Not aggressive enough. Well, I'm not aggressive at all. I just loved to see wonderfully dressed women, and I still do. That's all there is to it.

title: East Side Girls' School Is Favoring Male Workers, Suit Charges
description: A sex discrimination lawsuit was filed Friday against the Chapin School on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, asserting that two female plaintiffs were paid less than men who did the same cleaning work. The suit also says Chapin, a private girls' school with students from kindergarten through the 12th grade, denied one of the women a promotion that it later gave to a man.

title: In a Key Congressional Race, an Incumbent Suddenly Appears Vulnerable to a Novice
description: As an incumbent with many fellow Republicans in his district, Representative Felix J. Grucci Jr. began his re-election campaign as the odds-on favorite. But a spirited challenge by a novice Democratic opponent, Timothy H. Bishop, has changed all that.

title: POSTINGS: Six-Story $7 Million Building on Bowery; A Gas Station Is Replaced By Loft Project
description: A six-story building with a curved facade and lofts that start at $1.3 million is under construction on a corner lot on the Bowery that was until recently the site of a gas station.

title: Cynthia Miller, Shamil Idriss
description: Cynthia Lynn Miller and Shamil Mustapha Idriss were married yesterday at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society in Chevy Chase, Md. Imam Feisal Abdul Rauf performed the Islamic ceremony.

title: But What Will They Do With All Those Bookshelves?
description: Last month, two artists, Bruce Richards and Kim Katani, bought the old Dobbs Ferry library building from the village for $525,000. Mr. Richards said he wanted to restore the village icon, built in 1855, to its former glory; deed restrictions prohibit altering the building's facade. Mr. Richards, a painter and animator, lives in Los Angeles; Ms. Katani, his wife, has worked for the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan since last year and lives in Brooklyn. They plan to live in the building, situated at the crossroads of downtown, and neighbors expect that they will open a gallery or other art space on the lower floors. Mr. Richards is not discussing his plans until the projected closing on Dec. 15, which is also the date of the new Dobbs Ferry library's official opening ceremony.

title: Protecting Tulips From Beast and Weather
description: TWO years ago, I planted a generous clump of Prinses Irene tulips in the old barnyard, which I am slowly turning into a walled garden at our family farm. They bloomed beautifully the first spring -- fragrant orange flowers flamed with bronzy-purple -- and I eagerly awaited their return the next year. But nary a green shoot appeared. I know tulips don't come back every year, but Prinses Irene is known to return, if not overwatered or overfertilized, so I figured squirrels or chipmunks or some other rodent must have found the bulbs.

title: In Defense of the Boom
description: I. Wall Street Didn't Do It

title: Angels Plan to Be Contenders for Years to Come
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 26  Six billboard-size pictures of Anaheim Angels players line the entrances to Edison Field. Tim Salmon, Garret Anderson, Darin Erstad, Troy Glaus, Jarrod Washburn and David Eckstein, who are in different action poses in all of their 50 feet of glory, stare down anyone who enters the stadium like a posse of superheroes.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: It is sad that supposedly mature men behave so badly that laws have to be passed to keep them in line. But women know that without sexual-harassment laws, the consciousness of the workplace would never have been raised. Now men are willing to stand up to the bullies who define masculinity in such a negative way.

title: Whimsy
His Eyes On the Stars, His Feet On the Earth
description: THE producer's credit says ''Nova,'' but the $1.2 million production of ''Galileo's Battle for the Heavens'' seems to say ''Masterpiece Theater.'' With its dramatic conflict and sumptuous scenes of Renaissance Italy, the two-hour special is so theatrical it wouldn't be surprising to see stalwarts of the Royal Shakespeare Company popping up in bit parts.

title: Defense Sparks Notre Dame Over Seminoles In Latest Victory
description: Notre Dame defensive tackle Derrick Campbell viewed linebacker Courtney Watson's third-quarter interception against Florida State today as the spark that ignited a raging fire. Safety Glenn Earl preferred to see it as the start of a feeding frenzy.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2003 Ford Expedition; Smooth Transition: Still Big, Now Better
description: FORD says its 2003 Expedition has 123 innovations, a number that seems exaggerated if you hew to the dictionary, which defines an innovation as ''something newly introduced; a new method, custom, device.'' Some of the features are not truly new, for they have been incorporated into cars or trucks before. These include second-row seats that recline, second-row captain's chairs, an aluminum engine block and electronic brake-force distribution.

title: Private Sector; A New Pursuit, Perhaps Trivial, For a Veteran of Microsoft
description: The ''aha'' moment came at a barbecue earlier this year, recalled Brad Chase, when the conversation took an etymological turn. Someone asked where terms like ''red-letter day'' came from. A good question, thought Mr. Chase, who likes to play with words. So he decided to create a board game, called Derivation, in which players answer questions about the origins of words, names and phrases.

title: New Asian Center at Stony Brook
description: The new Asian and Asian-American studies department created at the State University of Stony Brook this fall was given a new home last week with the ceremonial opening of a distinctive new Asian culture center on the campus. Nearly a third of the students at Stony Brook are of Asian descent.

title: A Councilman Draws Support in Assembly Run
description: To the Editor:

title: A For-Profit Military Role
description: To the Editor:

title: No Mementos This Time
description: Whitey Eckstein visited his son David, the Angels' shortstop, in Anaheim during the American League Championship Series. He has been thrilled to see fans wearing his son's jersey. Whenever he saw one, he said, he would introduce himself, take down the fan's name and address and promise to mail the fan a baseball card of David.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ALFRED
description: LERNER-Alfred. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of Alfred Lerner, a member of the Columbia College class of 1955. He was a respected colleague whose leadership as vice chair of the Trustees was marked by exceptional insight, unfailing decency, and dedication to his alma mater. Alfred Lerner Hall, Columbia's innovative student center, was made possible by his generosity to the University. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Mrs. Norma Lerner, his son Randy, his daughter Nancy, and to his seven grandchildren. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Costume Drama
description: La Ballerina

title: Mexico Puts Hurricane Deaths at 3 Amid Heavy Damage
description: Mexico began to calculate the costs of a powerful Pacific hurricane today, counting its losses at three dead, thousands of homeless and tens of millions of dollars in damage.

title: Comments Clarified
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, MADELYN
description: ELLIOTT-Madelyn. Of Omaha came to NYC in 1959, moveing easily between Harper & Row and the Metropolitan Opera, working with friends such as Rise Stevens, Christa Ludwig, Evelyn Lear, Birgit Nillsen, Jon Vickers, Joan Sutherland, the late Leonie Rysanek and husband Eleu. She died September 25th, near her 75th birthday in weakened health in Manasquan, NJ. Survived by her sisters Helen, Medora and their children. Her causes were: Broadway Cares: Equity Fights AIDS, Sierra Club and Running Strong for American Indian Youth. Her ashes will be spread with Tosca under the cottonwoods in Great Grannies meadow by the Big Thompson in Loveland, Colorado. Her spirit is probably visiting Vienna right now. Let's shed tears and raise a torte to Maddy.

title: Shake, Shriek, Groan Till the Goblins Go Home
description: THE more screams the better in Nickelodeon's Shriek Week, five days of spine-tingling thrillers for children of all ages - from a ''Rugrats'' special (Monday at 8 p.m.) in which Chuckie finds his inner ''werewulf'' to a prime-time episode of ''The Fairly OddParents'' (Tuesday at 8 p.m.) about a world where everyone turns into his or her costumed character. Five hours of Halloween episodes of ''Little Bill,'' ''Blue's Clues'' and other preschool favorites begin Thursday at 9 a.m. And throughout the week, viewers can vie for a day of trick-or-treating with the cast of ''All That'' in the Nick or Treat sweepstakes.

title: Journey Leads To Distaff Victory
description: Ten years ago, Laura De Seroux was not sure where her career in racing would take her. She had done just about everything around the racetrack, from galloping horses at the long-forgotten Cahokia Downs to working as the coordinator of racing for the former Los Angeles Kings owner Bruce McNall. She could never have imagined it would include a front-and-center position at the Breeders' Cup and a victory by a filly so good that some think she can be Horse of the Year.

title: The Hall of Fame
description: GENIUS

title: Susan Curtis, David Tonking Jr.
description: Susan Jane Curtis, the daughter of Jane and Graydon Curtis of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to David James Tonking Jr., the son of Kathryn D. Tonking and Mr. Tonking of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William Ross Forbes performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Westfield.

title: Unlikely Rally by Filly Is a Family Tradition
description: One moment Storm Flag Flying was hopelessly beaten in the Breeders' Cup Juvenile Fillies today. The next she was a half-length in front at the wire. It must be the genes.

title: Baker's Gesture Proves Premature
description: Starting pitcher Russ Ortiz had given the San Francisco Giants so much tonight, more than they had any right to expect after his performance in Game 2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIGER, EDITH
description: TIGER-Edith. We mourn Edith Tiger. For over a generation, Edith played a major role as Executive Director of the National Emergency Civil Liberties Committee in the never ending struggle to protect and extend civil liberties in the U.S. Working with our partner and ECLC's general counsel, the late Leonard B. Boudin, and with our firm, Edith and ECLC were in the forefront of the fight against McCarthyism and HUAC; provided legal counsel and support for the civil rights and peace movements; established essential legal support for political refugees from Haiti and other countries; and won recognition of important civil liberties, including the rights of Americans to travel internationally, to receive and read foreign journals and literature not approved by the government, and to invite and hear foreign visitors who wish to speak to U.S. audiences on subjects of public concern. We were honored to work with her on these and other critical issues and cases. Victor Rabinowitz Eric Lieberman Michael Krinsky Rabinowitz, Boudin, Standard, Krinsky & Lieberman

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bull Is Back (And He's Confident)
description: SOME investors are starting to believe that the recent run in stock prices is the beginning of a new bull market.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: I was surprised that Margaret Talbot did not cite the oft-repeated statement that sexual harassment is not about sex -- it is about power. That truth lies at the heart of male-on-male (or female-on-female) harassment cases.

title: Shannon Clare, Joseph Prewitt
description: Shannon Ruth Clare, the daughter of Robert L. Clare III and the stepdaughter of Louise Mason Clare of New York, was married yesterday to Joseph William Prewitt, a son of Joan and Wiley C. Prewitt of Winona, Miss. The Rev. Travis Campbell, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the University Club.

title: Business; A Time When Greed Wasn't Good
description: DAVID CALLAHAN, the author of ''Kindred Spirits,'' argues that the values of today's business leaders are very different than those of the Harvard Business School class of 1949 -- many of them World War II veterans. Here are excerpts from an interview. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Power Smoothies, for the Stressed or Stressless
description: In need of a spa weekend? If the answer is yes but cash is short, there is Re-Juice-A-Nation, Hoboken's new smoothie shop. Just walking through the door is guaranteed to work knots out of your shoulders. Instrumental music plays in the background, and a flat-screen television flashes underwater scenes of coral and fish. Then there are the beverages, which promise to pep you up, slim you down and do everything else that mud baths, hot stones and water jets might do. Not that the regular smoothies -- which cost $4.50 to $4.75 and come in 20-plus flavors -- do all that. They're just 24 ounces of refreshment, a not-too-sweet blend of juice, fresh fruit, ice and sherbet or frozen yogurt. The spa factor comes in from eight exotic ''boosters'' that can be added to any drink. With names like flu fighter and fat stripper, they rev the smoothies up with blends of vitamins, minerals, protein powder and other ingredients both familiar (chamomile) and strange (kava kava root). It might take practice before you can order a boosted smoothie with a straight face. Imagine requesting Temptation with a Sex Drive in front of your mother. (That's a smoothie with guava juice, mango, banana and pineapple sherbet boosted with yohimbe bark, Siberian ginseng and saw palmetto.) Considering that I usually go with my daughter, I think I'll stick with the peach plus. Gretchen Kurtz

title: Devils' Offensive Outburst Cools Off the Lightning
description: For a night anyway, the Devils could breathe easy in the third period. They could let the final seconds tick off without sweating every last one. They could afford this because for the first time this season, they scored early and often.

title: Kenneth Johnson, Teacher, 49; Advised Rikers Island Inmates
description: Kenneth Johnson, a cat burglar and holdup man who had a jailhouse conversion after reading Jean-Paul Sartre and transformed himself into a beloved teacher of inmates on Rikers Island, died last Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 49.

title: A Larger Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Chemistry
description: THE LUNAR MEN

title: Candidates for Comptroller Intensify Attacks on Each Other as Race Becomes Tighter
description: In a rally with about 200 Republican Party loyalists, Assemblyman John J. Faso, the party's candidate for state comptroller, lost no time this morning delivering what has become an increasingly familiar attack. He called his Democratic opponent, Alan G. Hevesi, a tax-and-spend Democrat who is out of step with the mainstream of New York voters.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SLOW MONKEYS

title: Deals and Discounts
description: READY TO SHIP OUT -- For those who can book by Thursday, Radisson Seven Seas Cruises offers two-for-one prices and a $100 shipboard credit per person on selected sailings in November and December. A seven-night cruise on the 350-passenger Radisson Diamond leaving Nov. 25 from San Juan for Barbados, Martinique, St. Thomas and other islands, is $1,948 a person and up with the discount; on Dec. 2, it leaves San Juan and goes to Palm Beach, with stops in St. Maarten, St. Kitts and elsewhere, for $2,048 a person and up. The 700-passenger Seven Seas Mariner sails from Fort Lauderdale on Dec. 2 on a 10-night golden oldies cruise, stopping in Antigua, St. Barts and elsewhere, starting at $2,998; a one-week trip from Fort Lauderdale on Dec. 12 to Grand Cayman, among other ports, starts at $1,998. Prices include all tips and wine with dinner but not air fare. Information: (866) 217-1374 or www.rssc.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDERON, JACK
description: CALDERON-Jack. On October 24, 2002. Beloved friend and cousin. We will miss your leadership, wisdom and humor. The Herman's The Misshula's The Mizrahi's The Seidman's The Hazan's and The Calderon's

title: The Role of Politics In a Pension Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Disrupts Bronxville Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress vs. Reagan
