description: To the Editor:

title: Over the Dam
description: WATER WARS

title: October 20-26; COMING UP
description: President Bush plans to campaign on behalf of Republican candidates in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado, South Dakota, Indiana and West Virginia. Congress is on election recess until Nov. 12.

title: Job Expenses May Add To Debt for Women
description: Young women are more likely than men the same age to incur debt, and they often have career-related expenses to blame, a study released last week suggests.

title: Mountain of Trouble
description: THE GYPSY MAN

title: The Most Compassionate Conservative
description: DOMINION

title: Letters
description: To the male victims of goosing and other physical humiliations described in our cover article, readers offered advice: forget litigating for harassment; sue for assault. And to the aging boomers who feel shut out by TV advertising pitched to ''18 to 34,'' others asked, Why would they care?

title: October 20-26
description: SENATOR PAUL WELLSTONE DIES IN PLANE CRASH Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota and one of the foremost liberals in Congress, was killed in a plane crash in northern Minnesota. His wife, daughter and five others were also killed.

title: Winning Isn't Everything
description: MY LOSING SEASON

title: Urban Cowboy
description: THEODORE ROOSEVELT

title: Asian Stars Are Bright in Vancouver's Firmament
description: VANCOUVER is to Asian food what New York is to European: A place where a cuisine is often as good, and sometimes better, than in its country of origin. So splendid is the Chinese cooking in Vancouver that it rivals that of Hong Kong; so original and satisfying are its Japanese, Indian and Thai restaurants that frequent travelers to those countries who are familiar with Vancouver see little difference in the quality of the best establishments.

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List; MANHATTAN CAN TAKE LESSONS FROM HO CHI MINH CITY
description: Some people shop when they travel, loading up their carry-ons with flea-market sconces and duty-free liquor. I collect mental images, mostly of people -- what they wear and how they wear it. Average people. Thin or lumpy, wizened or fresh faced. People who have never hired a stylist, walked down a red carpet, been called an influence on fashion or graced a magazine cover. Call it the Alternative International Best-Dressed List, the one Eleanor Lambert, Mr. Blackwell and the VH1 Vogue Fashion Awards miss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, DR. MORRIS
description: BLUM-Dr. Morris. 103, of Hollywood, FL, died on Tuesday, October 22, 2002. Dr. Blum retired from the practice of medicine in New York City in 1986. He lived a long and remarkable life. He was loved very much and will be remembered by many.

title: Halloween Hordes
description: LAST Halloween night, Richard Mulligan and his family became the rural Connecticut version of F. A. O. Schwarz for more than 1,000 children and their parents.

title: Public or Mormon Plaza? Battle Splits Salt Lake City
description: In this city, where nearly half the residents share the same religion, it is hard to imagine a bare-knuckled legal brawl involving the mayor and the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.

title: Campus Where Lessons Include Fighting Drug and Alcohol Abuse
description: WITH its well-tended lawns, sand volleyball court and neat cluster of low-lying modern buildings, Arms Acres could easily be just another small, private school, tucked into a leafy corner of Putnam County.

title: Fordham Owns First Place in Patriot League
description: For the first time since joining the Patriot League in 1989, Fordham is alone in first place in late October, after a 33-26 victory yesterday over Lafayette, another unlikely contender, at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: Geraldine of Albania, 87, Queen With U.S. Ties, Is Dead
description: Geraldine of Albania, who as the wife of King Zog was for one year her adopted country's first and only queen and the only member of European royalty with American blood, died on Tuesday in Tirana, Albania's capital. She was 87.

title: Russell Crowe; 'Flower Drum Song'; Tom Petty
description: RUSSELL CROWE

title: The Amazing Racer Of Reality TV
description: 'I love Halloween,'' said Florinka Pesenti, a participant in the CBS reality show ''The Amazing Race,'' and a public relations associate for Hogan, the shoe company. ''I love to feel like a kid, I love to eat candy, and I love to wear things that I couldn't really wear on any other day.'' This year, Ms. Pesenti, 23, is considering a black cat, a robot or a ''Flashdance'' girl. ''I'm leaning toward 'Flashdance,' '' she said, ''because I found this batik MOM sweatshirt I made at camp when I was a kid. I remember thinking back then that it was sooo sexy.''

title: The Forlorn Woyzeck, With a New Spin
description: ''DOCTOR, have you ever seen anything of double nature?'' asks the title character in Georg Bchner's seminal modern drama ''Woyzeck.'' In most productions, this line is not taken literally. It is handled as just one among dozens of philosophical abstractions that continually drop from Woyzeck's mouth like half-chewed seeds.

title: Doing Their Nails With a Hammer
description: FOUR decades of feminism have shown that women are capable of crewing on the space shuttle, defeating chess grandmasters and fighting wars. Even that male bastion, the Augusta National Golf Club, is feeling the heat from barricade-storming women.

title: Italian Standout With High-End Prices
description: TUSCAN HOUSE is probably Riverhead's best restaurant. It is an attractive, upscale spot with traditional dining rooms that feature French doors; deep red ceilings; beige walls; vibrant paintings; framed, decorative menus from the turn of the century; wrought-iron sconces; carpeting; and artificial trees trimmed in white lights, which brighten corners. The dining room for smokers, just off the bar, is a cozy retreat dominated by a stone fireplace.

title: A Jazz Trio With a Jam Band's Following
description: SINCE forming in 1991, Medeski, Martin and Wood has been quietly pushing toward the frontiers of jazz. At heart the group is a Hammond B-3 organ-based trio of the sort that has been around in jazz for at least 50 years, featuring the extended keyboard improvisations of John Medeski, the jagged bass grooves of Chris Wood and the rollicking backbeats of the drummer Billy Martin. Its music is shaped by a range of influences from DJ Logic to Sun Ra, John Coltrane to Sly Stone, John Cage to the Meters.

title: The World; Europe Is Jittery, as the Wedding Nears
description: THE European Union is about to grow eastward, whether most Europeans like it or not. But this truly historic moment -- the political reunification of a Europe once divided by the Iron Curtain -- has created enormous anxiety on both sides of the old East-West border.

title: Business; The Enron Shelf Is More Crowded
description: The Enron books keep pouring into bookstores. Following are three of the most recent.

title: Stephanie Avakian, Howard Heiss
description: Stephanie Avakian and Howard Edward Heiss, lawyers, were married yesterday at the Yale Club in Manhattan. Michael B. Mukasey, the chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAINSWIT, SEYMOUR
description: SHAINSWIT - Seymour. Passed away peacefully on October 26, 2002, at the age of 82, of lymphoma. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Justice Beatrice Shainswit of the New York State Supreme Court, and his brother Bernard. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and of New York University Law School, and a distinguished member of the Bar Association of the City of New York, the New York State Bar Association, and the American Bar Association. He was the finest and most brilliant of commercial and libel litigators, a man who loved the law, and an honor to the bar. Services will be on Monday, October 28, 2002, at 11:45 AM, at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. His sweetness, warmth, and love will be with us forever.

title: CELLPHONE SURVEY
description: Support for a ban on the use of hand-held cellphones on the state's highways has come from an unlikely source: people who say that they themselves often use them while driving. A Quinnipiac University poll of 1,002 registered voters in New Jersey disclosed that 85 percent said it was a good idea to make the use of hand-held cellphones illegal for drivers; 12 percent disagreed. Among the 65 percent of voters who said they owned cellphones, the margin was 82 to 16 percent. And of the 24 percent who said they talked on a hand-held phone ''very often'' while driving, 73 percent said that should be illegal. A Senate committee voted last month to make use of hand-held phones illegal but to allow hands-free devices. George James

title: Streetscapes/Edward Durell Stone and the Gallery of Modern Art, at 2 Columbus Circle; An Architect Who Looked Both Forward and Back
description: IN 1956 he unabashedly plunked down a large concrete grille in the middle of a row of East Side brownstones. His 1964 Gallery of Modern Art, at 2 Columbus Circle, was, in the words of a critic for Art News, ''a turkey.'' And critics said that his 1968 marble tower, the General Motors Building at 58th Street and Fifth Avenue, seriously compromised the character of Grand Army Plaza across the street.

title: A Little Bit of Russia In a Dirty Martini
description: NEW YORK is a dirty town. And not much is dirtier, or more New York, than the house drink at Jane, a restaurant in the West Village -- the Dirty Jane. It's a pickled martini. Any questions?

title: Piniella and Howe Find New Security
description: For anyone who has had difficulty keeping up with the high-powered, fast-moving game of musical managers, here is a recapitulation of events of the past week.

title: The Happy Hipster Of Film
description: IN Jonathan Demme's giddy new romantic thriller, ''The Truth About Charlie,'' the camera careers around the streets of Paris as if drunk on the city's color, sound and humanity. Now and then it loiters over a face: a street vendor, a musician, an exuberant young girl, an old woman with an enigmatic smile. There seem to be no extras, only characters from movies yet to be made.

title: A Duo's Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Italian Cuisine That Is Familiar to Locals
description: CAFE ALLEGRE is a fine-looking, well-established restaurant in Madison with a solid reputation.

title: For Teenager, Troubling Bond In Chaotic Life
description: It was the kind of news a boy cannot wait to share with his father.

title: The Nation; Can We Talk? It Depends Who 'We' Is
description: THE words are possibly disrespectful but definitely jarring and decidedly provocative, engendering as much outrage as reasoned discourse. In recent weeks black people have set off noisy public fights by uttering what some have characterized as intemperate remarks. The targets of the barbs could not be more different: two icons of the civil rights era and the secretary of state. But stripped to their essence, the controversies surrounding the hit movie ''Barbershop'' and comments made by Harry Belafonte raise the same questions: What can black people say? And where can they say it?

title: Luchina Fisher, David Parr
description: Luchina Fisher and Dr. David James Parr were married in Manhattan yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Ronald M. Patterson, a minister of the United Church of Christ.

title: Law Extends Time Before Drivers Under 18 Get a License
description: A NEW law in New York state will require motorists under age 18 to spend more time driving under the supervision of an older, experienced driver before advancing from a learner's permit. Under the law, which goes into effect next September, a new driver can only become eligible to take a road test for a limited class or junior license after driving with a learner's permit for six months and completing at least 20 hours of driving under the supervision of an experienced driver or instructor who is at least 21 or older.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTOK, CHAIM
description: POTOK-Chaim. A memorial service for Chaim Potok will be held on Sunday October 27, 3 PM at The Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, 334 Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: PARKWAY LIGHTS
description: The last three traffic lights on the Garden State Parkway are on their way to being eliminated, thanks to a $5 million federal grant to study ways to improve traffic flow at the southern end of the toll road. The grant was announced last week at one of those intersections -- Exit 10, Stone Harbor Boulevard -- by Representative Frank LoBiondo of Cape May. The three lights are all in Cape May County, and local officials say they back up the Parkway, especially in the summer beach season. Mr. LoBiondo estimated that it would cost $60 million to $70 million to create either overpasses or jughandles to eliminate the traffic signals. If all goes well, he said, the work will be finished with federal funds by 2008. Robert Strauss

title: October 20-26: SCIENCE; CYBER-WARFARE
description: A vigorous attack intended to cripple the Internet's 13 crucial ''root'' servers failed. The attack, known as a distributed denial of service, involves taking over vulnerable computers by the dozens or even thousands, and coordinating them to deluge other computers with data that often makes the target machines inaccessible. Although more than half of the servers under attack failed, the network showed barely a blip. John Schwartz

title: Two Political Veterans, but Only One Chair
description: WHEN Connecticut lost a Congressional seat because of a population decline, and voting districts were redrawn last December, the Fifth District race for the United States House was poised to be the toughest contest in the state this fall.

title: Taking a Studio From Lowbrow to Powerful
description: TRAFFIC slowed to a crawl outside Lincoln Center one Saturday night early this month as curious onlookers gawked at Adam Sandler walking down the red carpet at the premiere of his film ''Punch-Drunk Love.'' ''Hey Adam! Over here!'' photographers cried at the comic, whose star turn as an emotionally troubled salesman was already generating Oscar buzz.

title: Elizabeth Ngonzi and John Nandigobe
description: THEIRS was a romance born in boom times. She was a business consultant, he a computer technology specialist. And when John Henry Nandigobe and Elizabeth Natasha Ngonzi began dating in 1999, the promise of their life together seemed as limitless as the prosperity all around them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESCOTT, ELIZABETH COE
description: PRESCOTT-Elizabeth Coe. 94 of Topsham, ME. Formerly of E. Islip, NY. Died Oct. 18, 2002. Loving mother of Ann E. Finlayson and Elizabeth C. Gregory; two grandsons Robert H. Gregory, Jr. and William Prescott Gregory and five great grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to The Coastal Humane Society, Range Road, Brunswick, ME 04011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREUER, DR. HARRY JR. (BUD).
description: BREUER - Dr. Harry Jr. (Bud). 71, of New York City and Sag Harbor, died on October 24, 2002, at NYU Medical Center. He is survived by his beloved wife Fran, his devoted daughter Gina and her husband Eric Hadley, and his cherished granddaughter Francesca. Also survived by his brothers Robert and Tony and their families. Dr. Breuer served as a clinical psychologist at Bellevue Hospital for 27 years and was a faculty member of NYU Medical Center. Friends may call at Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14th St, on Sunday, October 27th, 5-8 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, October 28th, 11 AM, at St. Francis Xavier Church, 30 W. 16th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Survivors' Fund, c/ o Bellevue Program for Survivors of Torture, 462 1st Ave, #

title: Bear Rages Past Wall St. To Tax Coffers
description: That the air has gone out of the stock market balloon is no secret to any American with a 401(k) retirement plan. But what that means for New York, economically and fiscally, is only now becoming clear.

title: THE PICTURE SUBJECTS TALK BACK
description: He calls grown-up women child, and his coterie of young friends muffin. Bill Cunningham has been a habitual presence on the streets of New York for nearly 50 years, and Paris and London know him, too. But as a subject, he has been elusive, a shadow on the run with his camera, who still worries, at 73, about falling into ''the traps of the rich.'' Here, people who have known or observed him since his hat-making days in the 1950's turn their gaze on him.

title: On UConn's Campus, A Brazilian Touch
description: MUSIC lovers will have to show their tickets, but not their passports, to hear orchestras from Brazil and Russia when they visit the University of Connecticut in Storrs.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Wanted: Old Stuff

title: Notes From Sioux Falls; Get That Pollster Off My Lawn
description: South Dakota is the political focal point of the nation. Sound strange? Not half as strange as it does to those of us who live here.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Building Upscale Rental Projects, Welcome or Not
description: DESPITE high prices for houses and condominiums and the sharp declines in the stock market, home sales remain strong, propelled by low interest rates. The movement of buyers who might once have been renters into ownership is being felt by landlords of rental properties.

title: Business; A New Company Tries to Sort the Web's Chaos
description: BY Silicon Valley standards, it was an unassuming debut.

title: Joanna Schaap, Frank Duba
description: Joanna Rose Schaap, the daughter of Madeleine Schaap of Lambertville, N.J., and the late Dick Schaap, is to be married this afternoon to Frank Eugene Duba, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Duba of Huntington, W.Va., and Manhattan. The Rev. Jennifer Pader, an interfaith minister, is to officiate at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADELSON, SAMUEL
description: NADELSON-Samuel. October 22, 2002. Beloved husband to Zelda and late wife Rhea. Devoted father to Leslee, Elliot, Patty and Nancy. Cherished grandfather to Larry, Wendy, Sean, Ashle, Erika, Brett, Clint, Tanya, Adam and Allie. Loving great-grandfather to Samantha, Alana and Rebecca. Best friend and brother to Nettie. Loved Zelda's children, David, Jeffrey, Nitza, Cindy and Larry, and grandchildren Maya, Daniel, Jordan and Hailey, and wonderful uncle, great-uncle and friend. Graveside service Sunday, 1 PM, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: A Delicate Balance at the U.N.
description: Last month President Bush stood before the United Nations General Assembly and offered to work with the Security Council to disarm Iraq. He has lived up to that promise, and last week the Americans submitted a resolution to the Security Council that, perhaps with minor alterations, deserves the support of all 15 members.

title: At 39, Dunston Savors the Moment
description: Shawon Dunston was angry and heartbroken in 1989. He was a certified major leaguer, a starter for several years with the Chicago Cubs. But he was saddened by the death of his grandmother and preoccupied with how much money he was making compared with other players.

title: New York Noir
description: ON the surface, New York has been transformed; Times Square, for example, has been squeakily scrubbed from neon rathole to Mickey Mouse Land. But the city still has a scabby underbelly that bristles with a jittery electricity that evokes the shadow world of noir: certain deserted subway stations after midnight; stygian bars without signs; waterfront piers gnawed by roiled rivers. To find noir in the city simply takes a certain angle of vision.

title: Drums Along the Peconic
description: RESIDENTS of Riverhead, the poorest town in Suffolk County, are forever trying to overcome negative perceptions of the place they live. The Town of Riverhead has spent considerable money and energy trying to reinvigorate the unincorporated hamlet of Riverhead, which straddles the Peconic River, as a commercial center and tourist destination.

title: Lighting Up The Day
description: A new generation is discovering glamour, in the form of gold shoes worn for day -- and why not? Designs like these were once confined to evening wear. Now, they're sparkling in the sunlight. Made in shiny leather, reptile and brocades, the shoes are worn with jeans and with skirts, focusing attention on the foot. The idea is another facet of this age group's discarding of the once-rigid rules of appropriate dress. From strappy sandals to mules, clogs and ankle boots, fancy footwear is again fashion's star.

title: It's Tough to Be a Witch in the Suburbs
description: SUBURBAN life and modern motherhood always involve compromises, and for Susan, a witch and mother of four, Halloween is a case in point. Fussing over the kids' costumes and then spending hours in her witch clothes handing out treats to knee-high ghouls means, Susan said, that she hardly has a moment for her magic.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: ROOFWALKER

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the new Westin Hotel near Times Square, and a growing Latin American influence in New York architecture, rendered the city's name in Spanish incorrectly. It is Nueva York, not Nueve.

title: INSIDE
description: Angels Rally to Win, 6-5, Sending Series to Game 7

title: Decked Out in Classy Castoffs
description: TESTED: 2003 Land Rover Discovery

title: Post-9/11 Modernism
description: Q: Your sculpture commemorating Sept. 11, ''Tumbling Woman,'' was recently removed from Rockefeller Center. Is that the largest controversy you've been through? Certainly the Arthur Ashe statue at Flushing Meadows freaked out some people.

title: Fortune Hunters and Gatherers
description: THE NATURAL HISTORY

title: The Day in College Football; For Hurricanes, This Victory Was a Setback
description: The Miami Hurricanes are defending a national championship, maintaining an undefeated record and holding a No. 1 ranking in some of the polls. But their defense is vulnerable and so is their prestige. All this may be good for the Heisman Trophy hopes of quarterback Ken Dorsey. But it could keep the Hurricanes out of the national title game of the Bowl Championship Series.

title: The Nation: Lost Hurrah; A Senator's Death and the Fight for Congress
description: SENATOR PAUL WELLSTONE, the Minnesota Democrat who died in a plane crash on Friday, was a partisan Democrat and proud of it. In the Senate, he was the guardian of the left, a man ''of conviction, who never swayed from his beliefs, even when he was fighting a lonely battle,'' said Senator Phil Gramm, the conservative Republican of Texas.

title: Engaging North Korea
description: In June 1994, the North Koreans had expelled inspectors of the International Atomic Energy Agency and were threatening to process spent fuel -- from a graphite-moderated nuclear reactor in Yongbyon -- into plutonium. It was clear that war might break out on the Korean peninsula. The United Nations Security Council was being urged by the United States to impose severe sanctions on North Korea. There was a general consensus, shared by American military experts, that the combined forces of South Korea and the United States could defeat North Korea with overwhelming power. But it was almost inevitable that severe damage would be done to Seoul and much of the fighting would take place in its streets. The American military commander in South Korea estimated that total casualties would exceed those of the Korean War.

title: Tying the Two Strands
description: WE arrived in San Francisco from Macau when I was 9. Only my 13-year-old sister, the eldest of five children, spoke English, and she took me to school. I was in the fourth grade. The teacher sat me next to another Chinese girl. I didn't understand her because we spoke different dialects. Mine was Cantonese. She did a lot of finger-pointing, telling me what to do. I learned English in E.S.L. class and by watching TV.

title: Going for the Sweet Spot
description: WHEN Madeline Hauptman talks about tennis racket design, a listener soon feels as if a mathematics degree would come in handy. Words like ''hypotenuse,'' ''ellipses,'' ''sine'' and ''co-sine'' pepper her description of her search to find just the right angle for each string to cross the others and enter a graphite racket frame.

title: Tough Times at Columbia: One Latina's Tale on the Web
description: Cecilia Garza's story sounds familiar: A poor kid from a faraway town is accepted at an Ivy League school; financial woes, academic stress, personal problems and considerable body piercing ensue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, HARVEY R.
description: SHAPIRO-Harvey R. On October 22, in Santa Monica, CA. Writer, publisher, political historian, activist, a founder of the Teachers' Freedom Party, Citizens for Local Democracy, and acclaimed political journal ''The Public Life,'' his major works are ''The Bureaucratic State'' and ''Democracy n America: a Political History of United States.'' H.R. Shapiro is survived by his son, David, and sister, Judy. Memorial service to be held 1 PM, October 28, at Workmen's Circle Cemetery, Saddlebrook, NJ. For information call 800-525-3834. ''The vanguard is the person who I always wanted to be.'' HRS

title: Campaign Season; Fewer 'Oinks' on the Campaign Trail
description: The budget impasse in Congress did more than stall most of the annual spending bills; it deprived incumbent lawmakers of a traditional campaign weapon: the announcement.

title: Abortion Debate Entangles Yet Another Candidate
description: Douglas R. Forrester, whose Senate candidacy has been ailing, according to various polls, briefly trumpeted his endorsement last week by the national Republican Pro-Choice Coalition, a group that actively espouses an abortion rights and whose co-chairwoman is the actress Dina Merrill.

title: Lauren Williams, Todd Baynham
description: Lauren Nicholson Williams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brooke N. Williams of Berwyn, Pa., was married yesterday to Todd Brome Baynham, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Les B. Baynham of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. Eugene C. Bay performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: The law on same-sex harassment certainly has become more complicated since I served as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission between 1994 and 1998. While it may not be intuitive from the legal standpoint to equate raunchy behavior with sexual harassment, it should by now be all but intuitive from the business standpoint that an employer is responsible for taking actions to prevent behavior that can result in lawsuits. When 10 salesmen at Burt Chevrolet find behavior so intolerable that they seek recourse from the E.E.O.C., the problem is as much one of leadership and management as it is one of the behavior of those allowed to turn workplaces into junior-high locker rooms.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: If a guy doesn't want to get goosed or be called a girlie boy, then he shouldn't go to work at an auto dealership or an oil field. Boys will be boys, unfortunately or not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, CRAIG F.
description: KELLY-Craig F. Age 49, died October 25, 2002. Funeral Mass October 29, 11 AM, at St. John and Paul Church, 280 Weaver St, Larchmont, NY.

title: Shows That Really Have 'Em Dancing in the Aisles
description: IN addition to being two of the hottest shows in New York, ''Hairspray'' and ''Harlem Song'' have something else in common. Both shows have gotten audiences out of their seats to dance.

title: Wendi Goldstein, Stephen Trilling
description: Wendi Jan Goldstein, a television executive, and Stephen Matthew Trilling, a computer software executive, are to be married today by Rabbi Jonathan Kupetz at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: Listen Up, Deer Reader
description: YOU are a male deer, born recently in New Jersey. Life should be sweet. You're young, you have big antlers, and you live by simple rules (if only you could remember them). You stand at the edge of Route 78 on a moonlit evening, grazing harmlessly on endangered plants until you thirst for a drink from the nearby Raritan River. You start to cross the black strip to get a drink, minding your own business, when -- Whoosh! -- five metal horses flash past.

title: A Day In The Life Of a Fashion Hound
description: DEAR BOSS: Concerning assignment in which I was to be Bill Cunningham for a day, are you sure you are paying this man enough?

title: Music Listings
description: Opera

title: Not Radio's Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Hundreds in Moscow Search For Loved Ones After Raid
description: The siege was over. As were the gunfights and the desperate dashes to freedom. But for many of the relatives of the approximately 750 hostages released from a Moscow theater this morning, the waiting had entered a new phase.

title: From Iceland Via the Late 60's
description: In skeptical, self-conscious times, Sigur Ros offers reverence without religion and grandeur without guilt. Its songs are processionals and elegies, and a single one can stretch as long as 13 minutes on the band's third album, ''( )'' (MCA/Universal), which is due for release on Tuesday; the band is to perform on Friday at the Beacon Theater.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Thursday and Friday about the first parliamentary elections in Bahrain in 30 years referred incorrectly to the regional precedents for women's rights to vote and to run for national office. This was the first election that allowed them in any Arab country in the gulf, not in gulf countries over all. Women hold national office and vote in Iran.

title: Patients Do Research on Web
description: Where do you go to find information about a medical procedure? If you're like the majority of the 800 patients surveyed recently by the American Academy of Dermatology, you are likely to turn to the Internet first.

title: Private Sector; What Could Have Been at Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways was a victim of ''targeted terrorism'' in the 1980's, not the global terrorism prevalent today, because it was the major United States flag carrier, said Edward S. Trippe, a son of Pan Am's founder, Juan T. Trippe. ''If there had been global terrorism,'' he said, Pan Am ''wouldn't have been allowed to fail.''

title: Lessons From Japan About War's Aftermath
description: In their immediate response to the shock of Sept. 11, journalists and pundits across America evoked, almost as one, Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor 60 years earlier. Headlines proclaimed a new ''day of infamy.'' Feature stories dwelled on similarities (and differences) between the holy-war fanaticism of the Islamic terrorists and that of the Japanese -- and, of course, on the dismal failure of American intelligence to anticipate either attack.

title: POSTINGS: Director of Manhattan Office; City Planning Gets New Aide
description: Vishaan Chakrabarti, an architect and urban planner, has been named director of the Manhattan office of the Department of City Planning. He will assume the post tomorrow. He succeeds Richard Barth, 50, who has been appointed executive director of the department and who has served in the Manhattan post since 1995.

title: Erin Moran, John Priesing Jr.
description: Erin Moran, a daughter of Margaret A. Moran of Livingston, N.J., and Henry A. Moran of Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to John Washburn Priesing Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Priesing of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Lichti performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

title: Frequent-Flier Miles
description: THE ADVENTURES

title: Flies in Amber Caught at 1/250 of a Second
description: BILL CUNNINGHAM records on the fly, finding fashion where it happens, in the streets and at parties. His subject is what's here and now, and often gone tomorrow, as conveyed by real people, not fashion models -- albeit real people who tend to own lime-green overcoats and skirts made of old neckties. One day it's high society, the next street funk. Should historians in a later century wish to see how the fashionable dressed today, they would do best to look at Mr. Cunningham's photographs, not at the Gaultier spreads in Vogue or the Ralph Lauren advertisements on television.

title: Corrections
description: The Bulletin Board chart on Oct. 13, which illustrated changes in six statistical measurements of the economy, mislabeled one of them. The change in the consumer price index was for food costs, not transportation costs.

title: Introduction
description: To the male victims of goosing and other physical humiliations described in our cover article, readers offered advice: forget litigating for harassment; sue for assault. And to the aging boomers who feel shut out by TV advertising pitched to ''18 to 34,'' others asked, Why would they care?

title: When Life's Watermarks Become Visible
description: READERS of this morning's paper fall in one of two separate groups: those who got their extra hour of sleep this morning, and those who quite definitely did not.

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List; IN PARIS, THE LOOK IS BOBO
description: There are two main trends on the streets of Paris this October. Both are the result of globalization, which has brought international chain stores and produced an unnerving homogenization of dress.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: OUT OF THE SOUTH: Poems

title: Nascar Rookie Overcomes Bad Luck to Reach for Top
description: HAMPTON, Ga., Oct. 24  Coming from a veteran, spoken to a rookie, the words were priceless. For Jimmie Johnson, new to the high-speed, high-pressure world of Nascar's Winston Cup Series racing, the veteran Mark Martin's praise made him realize that he had been accepted among stock car racing's elite.

title: The Nation: Democracy in Middle America; Why Iowa Has So Many Hot Seats
description: IOWA has five representatives in the House and three competitive races, more than any other state. California has 53 seats and only one remotely competitive race, the contest to replace Gary A. Condit.

title: At Old Bethpage Village, the Restoration Needs a Renovation
description: THE Coles House at Old Bethpage Village Restoration is little more than a carcass of rotted wood right now. Half of it lies in a field and the other half sits in a nearby barn.

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: More Manhattan Firms Open Backup Offices in Westchester
description: Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft will move some of its employees into 31,520 square feet in Rye Brook, and Cravath, Swaine & Moore has sublet 15,371 square feet of space in White Plains, the companies announced this week.

title: 2 Arrested After Police Find Body In Car Trunk
description: Two young women were found with another woman's nude and battered body in their car early yesterday, two days after being seen in Brooklyn stuffing what appeared to be a body into the trunk, the police said.

title: Campaign Season; Gephardt for President? McAuliffe Says So
description: Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is concentrating on helping his party try to win enough House seats so Representative Richard A. Gephardt, left, will become speaker. But speculation is rampant on Capitol Hill that Mr. Gephardt will step aside if Democrats fail to win a majority on Nov. 5.

title: In Land of the Jobless, The Extreme Approach
description: YOU revamped your rsum months ago, networked until you can't stand to look at a telephone and even hired a job coach. You still can't find a job. You're ready to wear a sandwich board to advertise yourself, or send a gimmick along with your rsum. Maybe even work for no pay.

title: A Rich Dollar Sustains Imbalances In the World
description: THE economy is stumbling. Americans continue to spend far more than they produce, and have already caused the trade deficit to widen to a record annual gap of almost $400 billion. Interest rates are at lows not seen in decades, and the stock market, despite its recent rally, still seems like a risky place to invest.

title: Readers Respond About Joe Pa, Baseball and a Scandal
description: Paterno Slips Off

title: Monday Morning Quarteback
description: Highlights and lowlights from the weekend.

title: Ferry to Begin Cruises From Tampa to Yucatn
description: Travelers will soon have a new way to get to Mexico from Florida. Starting Nov. 22, the Portland-based Scotia Prince Cruises will offer Yucatn Express cruises across the Gulf of Mexico between Tampa and the Yucatn Peninsula.

title: Sports of The Times; Dear Bud: It's Time To Forgive Pete Rose
description: Bud Selig

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about changes in Chinese Communist Party leadership misstated the age of He Guoqiang, new director of the party's organization department. He is 59, not 67.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of advice for visitors on Oct. 6 with an article about Kabini River Lodge in Nagarahole National Park in southern India (also known as Rajiv Gandhi National Park) misstated medical precautions for the region. Vaccination against cholera is not recommended, according to the Centers for Disease Control; indeed, the C.D.C. says the manufacture and sale of the only licensed cholera vaccine in the United States has been discontinued. Vaccination against yellow fever is required only for those traveling from sub-Saharan Africa or other areas where there is active or potential transmission. Vaccinations against hepatitis A and typhoid are recommended by the C.D.C. Vaccination against hepatitis B is recommended only for certain groups of travelers, listed on the C.D.C.'s Web site, www.cdc.gov/travel.

title: Replacing Replacement Therapy
description: IT'S official: no longer will the hormones many women take at menopause be called ''hormone replacement therapy.'' As the National Institutes of Health announced last week, treatment with estrogens and progestins is now to be called ''menopausal hormone therapy.''

title: In Discipline, Following The Rules to the Letter
description: AT Briarcliff High School, the first time a student cheats on a test, the teacher handles it; by the fourth offense, the principal steps in. Students tempted to steal something from a classmate's backpack or from a teacher's desk, know that they can expect a stint at the high school's achievement center, and possible police involvement.

title: Games and Campfires: Cub Scouts Pack Park
description: PACKS of tigers, bears, wolves and Weblos roamed Ward Pound Ridge Reservation last weekend in search of play, food and warm campfires.

title: Karen Bergreen, Daniel R. Alonso
description: Karen Bergreen, the daughter of Barbara and Bernard Bergreen of Manhattan, is to be married today to Daniel R. Alonso, the son of Dr. M. Lita Alonso of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Dr. Daniel R. Alonso of Doha, Qatar. Judge Barrington D. Parker Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in White Plains is to officiate at the Harmonie Club in Manhattan.

title: Understated, In Trump Style
description: AT 7 p.m. on Thursday, Donald J. Trump and his lady friend, Melania Knauss, breezed in to inspect the scene at the World Bar, a new lounge on the ground floor of the Trump World Tower apartments across from the United Nations.

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Giant Weapons Plant Is Renovated Into Offices
description: THE five flags of the permanent members of the Security Council still fly in front of what was an early site of the United Nations, in Lake Success in Nassau County, just east of the Queens border and 16 miles from Manhattan.

title: Spun Gold And Silver Woven Into Jewelry
description: While conventional jewelers fiddle endlessly with ways to make diamond facets look shinier and larger, the arts and crafts world is finding ways to make simple gold and silver look more like fabric. At the Museum of Contemporary Arts and Design on West 53rd Street, an exhibition called ''Elegant Fantasy'' shows the work of Arline Fisch, a Californian who spearheaded the use of textile techniques to make jewelry. A continent away, Gunilla Lundberg, a Swedish textile designer and a graduate of Konstfack, the university of art, craft and design in Stockholm, created a cuff, right, of pure silver strands woven with white cotton threads (gunillalundberg@mail

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, EDWARD
description: GOLDSTEIN-Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard Baer, associated with The Times from 1956 until retiring in 1997.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Rye; A Wealth of Choices Along the Sound
description: WHEN William Blake, now a New York harbor pilot, was growing up in Eastchester, ''I always had a connection to the water and looked forward to a career on it,'' he said. So five years ago, when he and his wife, Joanne, set out to buy a home, they looked first in the Westchester County city of Rye, along Long Island Sound.

title: Scene: The Big Screen Meets a Small Town
description: IS there any town that doesn't melt like butter at the prospect of movie stars showing up? Apparently not. At least not Glen Ridge.

title: Cori Trebing, Frank Gerardi
description: Cori Lynn Trebing, a daughter of Joyce Cuesta of Bay Shore, N.Y., and Frederick Trebing of Lindenhurst, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Frank Gerardi, a son of Kathleen and Paul Gerardi of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. Mario Portella, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: Katherine Zipfel, David Leavy
description: Katherine Barbara Zipfel, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David K. Zipfel of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to David Christopher Leavy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Leavy of Westport, Conn. Msgr. John Delaney, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in in Naples, Fla.

title: Seeing East Africa Up Close From a Bike
description: The 120-day Tour d'Afrique, part bike race, part safari, plans to cover more than 6,500 miles from Cairo to the Cape of Good Hope starting Jan. 18.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: EVERYTHING in THE MAN WHO WASN'T THERE (2001) would have been fine if Ed Crane (Billy Bob Thornton), a quiet small-town barber, hadn't decide to invest in a dry cleaning business. That leads to murder, a suicide and a prisoner on death row for a crime he didn't commit. Film noir is the ultimate morality genre, of course, and nobody living does it better than Joel and Ethan Coen. It starts when a gay venture capitalist passes through town at the same time Ed's wife (Frances McDormand) is having an affair with her boss (James Gandolfini), whose wife (Katherine Borowitz) sees flying saucers. The film is just one big 1950's men's magazine article brought to life - Saturday at 9 p.m. on Sundance.

title: Turning Green
description: I can never understand why, whenever people write about how to prepare brussels sprouts, as Julia Reed does (Food, Oct. 13), they feel they must sound apologetic. When I prepare brussels sprouts, I cook them slowly in water for about 25 minutes and serve them with a little salt and butter, and perhaps a drop of lemon juice to bring out their intense flavor. Nothing better.

title: Taking On Water
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: In 4 Races, an Incumbent Is Guaranteed to Lose
description: Ordinarily, being a member of the House of Representatives is one of the safest jobs in America. With the advantages of free mailings, free travel and political action committee money, 96.7 percent of incumbents were re-elected in 1996, 1998 and 2000 combined.

title: A Roommate Under Rent Regulation
description: Q. I am the sole lessee of a rent-stabilized two-bedroom, two-bath apartment. I rent a bathroom and a bedroom to a roommate, splitting the rent and utilities evenly. The kitchen and living room are common areas. My question concerns the furnishings. The bedroom is unfurnished, but the living room and kitchen are fully furnished. The roommate uses my kitchen appliances (including microwave oven, dishes, pots, pans and utensils), my audio-video equipment and my living room furniture. What compensation, if any, am I entitled to for the roommate's use of my personal items under rent-stabilization guidelines? . . . Kim Barget, Brooklyn.

title: The View From/Coventry; A Proposal That's Not Family Friendly
description: WHILE officials in many towns search for ways to slow growth, maintain rural character and keep taxes low, Coventry is considering an unusual solution: let some of its properties stand vacant to keep families from moving in.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Oct. 6 about bus service from Stansted Airport to London during the upgrading of a rail link referred incompletely to the frequency of service. Stansted Express buses will run on Sundays only.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Friends Say Mondale Is Likely to Join Race
description: As Democrats huddled here to begin the delicate process of replacing Senator Paul Wellstone on the Nov. 5 ballot, associates of Walter F. Mondale, the former vice president, said he was likely to heed the growing pleas from party leaders here and in Washington to join the campaign.

title: Curry's Campaign Is One Big 'If Only'
description: IF William E. Curry's shoestring campaign for governor were an automobile, it would be a 2002 Pontiac LeMans, a power-starved puddle-jumper that is best remembered, in a previous incarnation, as a leaner, meaner muscle car.

title: The Myth of ''18 to 34''
description: Thanks to Jonathan Dee (Oct. 13) for exposing the archaic television ratings demographics that cater to the so-called youth market and ignore the viewing preferences of the upper-range baby boomers, who account for half the nation's discretionary spending but can't buy their way into the ratings samples.

title: The Sweet Spot
description: Candy bars have come a long way since the Clark, the 5th Avenue, the Reggie, the Baby Ruth (named not after the baseball player but President Grover Cleveland's daughter) and Bonomo's Turkish Taffy. They seem richer now, more complex, certainly bigger, frequently more refined -- perhaps because so many of the Mars family are listed near the top of the Forbes 400. But at the wildly popular Dylan's Candy Bar, candy bars, though on vivacious display, are only a few of the confections you might either hand out or plea for -- scary Saddam or W. mask in place -- on Halloween.

title: Turning Green
description: It is difficult to retain a vegetable phobia when instructed to add a stick of butter or a cup of cream to a recipe. Anyone with taste buds will relish the taste. Better to stick with the limited vegetables you like than to subject your arteries to recipes laden with fat!

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Personal Business; Phone Cards Aren't Created Equal
description: FOR Kamlesh Rijhwani, a technology consultant from Somerville, Mass., a simple way to keep in touch with friends and family in Bombay, and to save money in the process, is to use prepaid phone cards. But finding the right card hasn't always been easy.

title: United in Their Love of the Outsider
description: IN 1980, a mutual friend arranged for the composer Elliot Goldenthal to meet the director Julie Taymor, saying, ''I know a person whose work is just as grotesque as yours.'' The matchmaking worked. Their shared appreciation for oddball extravagance and the mythologically fantastic led them into both a romance that has lasted almost 20 years and a creative partnership that spans the worlds of theater (''Juan Darin'') and cinema (''Titus'').

title: Barry and the Babe
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BackTalk; Toughest Play for Veteran of N.F.L. Trench Warfare
description: Esera Tuaolo is up to 310 pounds now, but he says he feels light. Tuaolo, a former N.F.L. nose guard, is in the public phase of his coming-out process, which he describes as ''taking off a costume I've been wearing all my life.''

title: With Earnings, It's Not Just the Quantity but the Quality
description: OVER half the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index have reported their third-quarter earnings, and investors are surely relieved that only 14 percent of them fell short of forecasts. According to First Call, that is a slightly better performance than usual.

title: Delta and American Add Self-Service Aids
description: Delta and American Airlines are increasing the number of self-service machines at airports and putting staff in place to help reduce waiting.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: Is this what America has come to? It's one thing for these sorts of discussions to occur in the ''all victimization, all the time'' ambience of feminist whining. However, is there anybody out there who really believes we need yet another stable of so unlikely a group of martyrs as men who feel ''harassed'' by other men?

title: A Museum Show About Hotels; Africa from a Bike
description: AMuseum Show About Show-Stopping Hotels

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAU, HERBERT H.
description: BLAU-Herbert H. Of Larchmont, died October 24. Wonderful husband for 60 years to Gladys Balog. Devoted sons Leslie and Lawrence and his grandson Fredrick.

title: Dodgers vs. Giants? Baker Is the Bridge
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, LESLIE JR.
description: JORDAN-Leslie Jr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Leslie Jordan Jr., associated with The Times since 1956.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Thursday and Friday about the first parliamentary elections in Bahrain in 30 years referred incorrectly to the regional precedents for women's rights to vote and to run for national office. This was the first election that allowed them in any Arab country in the gulf, not in gulf countries over all. Women hold national office and vote in Iran.

title: For Halloween, Candy as Sweet As the Old Country
description: NEW York's immigrant children may be light years ahead of their parents in adopting American customs, as the preponderance of Bangladeshi Spider-Men and Peruvian SpongeBobs in the streets this Halloween should demonstrate. But children's sweet teeth don't necessarily become American as fast as the rest of them.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 27, 2002
description: Weeks

title: Ariane Nalty, Charles Zewe III
description: Ariane Douglass Nalty and Charles F. Zewe III were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. Louis King of France in New Orleans. The Rev. Christopher H. Nalty, a Roman Catholic priest and a brother of the bride, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Philip M. Hannan and the Rev. Francis B. Schulte, retired archbishops of New Orleans, took part.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Interpreting Bears

title: Art That Gives Meaning To Bits of This and That
description: FAR from the palatial drawing rooms-turned-galleries in the Fridericianum, the epicenter of this summer's Documenta megashow in Kassel, Germany, one of the invited artists could be found building what looked like shacks. Using duct tape, wood scraps, plastic wrapping and whatever else the neighborhood streets yielded, Thomas Hirschhorn was making ''Bataille Monument,'' a temporary ''display'' (he doesn't like the word ''installation'') into which he invited inhabitants of the largely immigrant neighborhood to collaborate with him on an interactive artwork.

title: Receiver's Interception Rescues Ohio State
description: They were two cornerbacks who drew great applause from a record crowd today, one of them a surprise in the starting lineup for Ohio State, the other standing on the Penn State sideline, appreciative to be on his feet, if not in the game.

title: A Maker of Tiny Worlds, a Dealer and an Odd Meeting
description: IN the fall of 1963, the artist Joseph Cornell needed legal advice, and at the suggestion of a friend, he invited Allan Stone, a lawyer turned art dealer, to his home on Utopia Parkway in Flushing, Queens. Mr. Stone went for a half-hour consultation but remained for an afternoon, which he recalls as being filled with wondrous and bizarre happenings. Mr. Cornell's genius lay in creating miniature and magical worlds from ordinary objects arranged in shallow boxes, and by the end of the visit he was helping to pack 15 of them into Mr. Stone's Volkswagen beetle, after Mr. Stone had agreed to exhibit them at his Manhattan gallery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-21

title: Trend Spotting, at the Street Parade
description: WE are a democratic lot when it comes to style -- the pizza delivery girl has it, the corner deli guy has it, most bike messengers definitely have it. It's as if New York empowers you and eggs you on. You can hail a cab like a Roman emperor saluting a citizen or, cloaked in attitude, walk your dog on a cold windy night feeling like Darth Vader. In my neighborhood, at the unstylish Midtown corner of Broadway and 28th Street -- once the music industry's Tin Pan Alley, now home of wholesale merchants -- people who carry off football helmets with pearls or a parka with flip-flops and hot pants are part of the local color and not an uncommon sight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADENS, BETTY CLANCY
description: RADENS-Betty Clancy. July 29, 2002. A visionary educator at the Fieldston Lower School for 33 years. Founder of Fieldston Outdoors. Survived by daughter Leish, son-in-law Bill, and granddaughter Treasa. A concert to celebrate her life will be held on November 3, at the Fieldston School Auditorium at 3 PM. Donations: Betty Clancy Radens Fund, Clearwater, 112 Little Market St, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601.

title: Casting a Critical Eye on Dances, Including His Own
description: DEAN MOSS is a choreographer and curator whose opinion counts for much in the New York dance scene. But his journey to being an influential tastemaker has not always been smooth.

title: The Accidental Senator
description: The six-seat, twin-engine plane climbed 5,000 feet into the bright September sky over Kansas City. I was seated directly across from Jean Carnahan, Missouri's junior senator, who had stopped flipping through her briefing papers and was gazing out the window at the highways and rooftops below.

title: What a Class of '49 Can Teach the Class of '02
description: IN the angry atmosphere left by corporate scandals that have wiped out billions of dollars of shareholder wealth, many Americans are asking: Who failed? Did the government inadequately regulate business leaders? Did Wall Street analysts and investment bankers simply go crazy? Were the auditors corrupt? Did business schools, though handing out pricey degrees, somehow fail to inculcate the recipients with morals?

title: Dread and Dreams Travel by Bus in Israel
description: With the Mediterranean glinting to the passengers' left, the No. 842 bus from Tel Aviv rolled north through Israel's fertile coastal plain, through fields where the first Zionist settlers tended lemon orchards and dreamed of a Jewish state more than a century ago and where, more recently, the country's Internet industry ripened, then rotted.

title: Theater Listings
description: Approximate running times are given at end of Broadway and Off Broadway listings.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''Me With Animal Towering'' on Page 20 of the Book Review today misspells the given name of a comedian who is quoted as providing a parallel to the poetic style of the author, Albert Mobilio. The comedian is Steven Wright, not Stephen.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q.& A. column last week, about suing a tenant for harassment, misstated the policy of Housing Court on such lawsuits. The landlord of a rent-stabilized apartment may bring an eviction action in Housing Court against a tenant on the ground that the renter has used the landlord's property in a way intended to harass the owner or other tenants. There is no blanket prohibition against landlords' suing tenants in Housing Court for harassment.

title: Paterno Slips Off Coaching Pedestal
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WYLE, HELEN P.
description: WYLE-Helen P. I love you, Helen. I always will. T.F

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: I wonder, being the legal novice that I am, why the physical activity (goosing, bagging and the like) cannot be tried pure and simple as assault, rather than as sexual harassment, given the difficulties expressed in the article?

title: 'High and Mighty'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bigger, Bolder, Faster, Weirder
description: WHEN things got out of hand -- I mean out of hand -- was when Phillip Michael Thomas came into the picture and bodies started flying. The man had been invisible since the days of ''Miami Vice'' and Ronald Reagan, and yet here he was, cursing a blue streak and wearing a white suit that hadn't been current in at least as long. And he was jacking cars and menacing pedestrians.

title: Homes Perched on Seawalls Hang in Balance of Dispute
description: Staring up at his home here, Paul Santina sees dreams collapsing.

title: The Other Team in South Bend: Pianists
description: ONE rainy night in May, 20 or so people were eating, drinking and talking nonstop with Finnish, Japanese, Russian, Georgian and some indefinable accents at a long table at T.G.I. Friday's in South Bend, Ind. The Irving S. Gilmore International Keyboard Festival in nearby Kalamazoo, Mich., had just ended, and most of those in the group -- members of the Toradze Piano Studio at Indiana University, South Bend -- had participated. Some had come from far away. The mood was festive, the atmosphere one of warmth, ease, sharing and knowing, like that of a good family.

title: In One City, a Golden Bridge; in the Other, Times Sq.
description: In their quest to lure the 2012 Summer Olympics, New York and San Francisco could not offer more diverse bids.

title: WELLSTONE DEATH BRINGS NEW FOCUS TO SENATE BATTLES
description: The political disarray caused by the death of Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota put a sharp new focus on the battle for control of the Senate, leaving grim strategists in both parties scrambling for their footing today in a national struggle that remains too close to call little more than a week before Election Day.

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List
description: MANHATTAN CAN TAKE LESSONS FROM HO CHI MINH CITY

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List; WALKING THE WALK
description: I was just with Christian Louboutin, the shoe designer, and a group of friends for the opening of Francesco Clemente's show in Naples. Italy is the only country I know where there is no sense of provincialism, because in even the tiniest towns people are interested in fashion. The street culture is based, of course, on the passeggiata -- when people go out in the evening between 5 and 7 for a walk. You see everybody -- children, grandmothers, people eating ice cream. And in every little town, you find trends because people want to look their best. On our way from Rome to Naples, we had lunch in this little village on a hill called Norma. It was a Sunday afternoon, and the local Ferrari Club must have been meeting, because everybody had on Ferrari T-shirts, and they all wore cowboy mules. There's a true street life in Italy. It's where you show yourself. DIANE VON FURSTENBERG

title: Ideas & Trends: Buy Like Bond; Make It a Finlandia and 7Up, Shaken, Not Stirred
description: IF you happen to be looking for a product spokesman, how about a skirt-chasing spy in his 80's who drinks too much, has an unfortunate taste for cashmere turtlenecks and glib one-liners, and who clung to his fear of the Communist menace probably longer than anyone besides Jesse Helms?

title: A Delicate Balance: Community Facilities And Communities
description: NEW YORKERS have always lived shoulder to shoulder with their institutions. But for 40 years, the institutions have had more zoning muscle.

title: Nina Tiger, Robert Dixter
description: Nina Kate Tiger, a daughter of Jane Wartels Tiger and Dr. Arthur Tiger of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Robert Adam Dixter, a son of Ruth Dixter and Dr. Charles Dixter of Montreal. Rabbi David Adelson officiated at InterContinental the Barclay, a hotel in New York.

title: Sonatas on a Sunday in a Concert by Philharmonia Virtuosi
description: A NEW cycle of ''Sunday Serenades'' by Philharmonia Virtuosi will begin today at 2 p.m. with music by Bach, Beethoven and Brahms at Westchester Community College in Valhalla. The group's concertmaster, Mela Tenenbaum, and its conductor, Richard Kapp, have chosen three glorious sonatas: Bach's No. 3 in E, Beethoven's ''Spring'' and the G major Brahms. Information: (914) 693-5595.

title: Lack of Cockpit Voice Recorder Might Hamper Investigation
description: Federal investigators today sorted through the wreckage of a plane crash that killed Senator Paul Wellstone and seven others, but efforts to determine the cause of the crash could be hampered by the absence of a cockpit voice recorder.

title: Madeline Blum, Andrew Rich
description: Madeline Ann Blum, a daughter of Carolyn Zimmerman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Dr. Harris S. Blum of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married last evening to Andrew Scott Rich, a son of Barbara and Howard Rich of Verona, N.J. Rabbi Norman R. Patz officiated at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFF, KENNETH R.
description: WOLFF-Kenneth R., 55. Of Mt. Kisco, NY, died October 24, 2002, after a courageous battle with cancer. Loving husband of Adele, son of Joan and Robert; father of Eric and Cheryl; brother of Robert, Sherri and Ellen; stepfather of Jackie and Anthony, Jennifer and Mark, and Stephanie and five adoring grandchildren. Visiting 3:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00 Sunday, and services Monday, October 28, 11:00 AM at Cassidy & Flynn, 288 Main St., Mt. Kisco. In lieu of flowers, donations to Make-A-Wish, 828 S. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591.

title: Susan Saulny, James Snyder Jr.
description: Susan Marie Saulny, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley M. Saulny of New Orleans, was married there yesterday to Dr. James Burton Snyder Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Snyder of Lindenhurst, N.Y. The Rev. Perry F. Henry performed the ceremony at Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Fare Idea Returns To Haunt Airlines
description: IT was, someone in the room said, ''a Don Corleone moment.'' The room was in the New York office of the Boston Consulting Group, to which top Microsoft executives had been summoned in November 1999.

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast; Washington Irving Was No Historian
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda Plate, Timothy Guy
description: Linda Marlene Plate, a daughter of Elizabeth Plate of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Walter Plate, was married yesterday to Timothy Davidson Guy, a son of Virginia and John Guy of Dover, N.H. The Rev. Jonathan New performed the ceremony at the Waitsfield United Church of Christ in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: For Retailers, a Halloween That's Not Too Scary
description: The weak economy has been scaring off some shoppers, though not many who plan to celebrate Halloween. Sales of Halloween candy, costumes and decorations are expected to total $6.9 billion this year, about the same as last year, according to the National Retail Federation in Washington. The group predicts that households will spend $44, on average, on Halloween purchases, down just $1 from 2001.

title: Editors' Note; Safety Note
description: Fire prevention authorities recommend that smoke alarm batteries be changed twice yearly, at the start and the end of daylight time. The change occurred this morning.

title: In Battle of Underachievers, Rangers Come Out on Top
description: The Rangers ran into a team more inept than they are tonight.

title: Ideas & Trends; Whose Urine Is It?
description: OVER the years, courts have developed a considerable body of jurisprudence on what may be done with a person's urine, but it is not entirely consistent.

title: Going to Disneyland? Not So Fast, Mr. Bonds
description: As the game wound its way toward what the San Francisco Giants thought would be a conclusion that made them World Series champions, it seemed obvious that there was only one way to prevent Barry Bonds from dominating the World Series: keep the Giants out of it.

title: Jennifer Meltzer, Vineet Goswami
description: Jennifer Sharon Meltzer, a daughter of Adrienne Meltzer and Dr. Murray A. Meltzer of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Vineet Goswami, the son of Saroj Goswami and M. K. Goswami of Delhi, India. Rabbi Jack Bemporad performed a Jewish ceremony in the Teaneck Marriott at Glenpointe in New Jersey. On Nov. 9, Pandit Bhagwan Das is to perform a Hindu ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Delhi.

title: For Police, Vital Break In Document
description: On Oct. 19, the Washington-area sniper struck for the 12th time, wounding a man in the parking lot of a Ponderosa Steakhouse. A handwritten letter was left attached to a tree in the woods nearby.

title: The Life Of Brian, Annotated
description: A WHOLE LOT of history surrounds Brian Williams in his compact office at MSNBC Plaza, a faceless building in the Officeparkdom that is Meadlowlands landfill.

title: Women Suffer Most in Afghan Health Crisis, Experts Say
description: The most comprehensive surveys of medical facilities and maternal deaths ever conducted in Afghanistan show that the country's 25 million people have among the world's worst health and greatest needs, according to Afghan officials and foreign health experts.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Sept. 15 about Barcelona, in a roundup about attractions in Europe, referred incorrectly to one architect's role in the renovation of the CaixaForum art museum. A letter received Oct. 15 from another architect involved in the project, Roberto Luna, noted that Arata Isozaki designed the entrance and tree sculptures, not the transformation of the building. Mr. Luna designed new spaces, Francisco Javier Asarta oversaw the restoration and Robert Brufau handled the structural reinforcement.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: 16 Angry Women; Hasta la Vista, Baby
description: THERE really is no such thing as a ''Dear Jane'' letter. A man just goes, leaving no note. But women, well, women have a lot to say, and seem to use the ''Dear John'' letter to say it. Consider these missives letters men never finished reading.

title: Some Bronze Stars Shine Brighter Than Others
description: About a decade ago (no one knows for sure) someone stole the sword from the bronze statue of Adm. David G. Farragut in Madison Square Park in the Flatiron District. The statue, considered by some to be one of the city's most important pieces of public art, is a 1930's replica of the 1881 original by Augustus Saint-Gaudens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, GORDON DAVID
description: PLATT-Gordon David. Retired securities analyst and Vice President of Brown Brothers Harriman, died Saturday at a nursing home in Ridgewood, NJ, following a lengthy and valiant battle with Parkinson's disease. He lived in New York City and Shelter Harbor, Westerly, RI. Born April 29, 1934, in Forest Hills, NY, he graduated from Queens College CUNY and began his career as a journalist for the Rutland (VT) Herald. He was also business editor of the Asbury Park (NJ) Press, and a reporter for Financial World Magazine in New York and the Pink Sheet, a financial publication in Washington, DC. He also served in the US Army from 1957 to 1959. He studied finance at New York University and became a certified financial analyst, working first for Lionel Edie and Co., and later for Chase Investors Management. For many years he was the Secretary of the Shelter Harbor, RI, Conservation Society. Survivors include his wife, Dr. Meredith Platt, a research scientist, his son and daughter-in-law Alexander Barnett and Renee Platt, and a granddaughter, Jordan Nicole Platt. Also surviving are his mother Sophie Platt, his brother and sister-in-law Henry and Maria Platt, and two nieces, Andrea and Alicia Platt. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, New York, NY, Tuesday, October 29, 8-9:30 AM, with service at 9:30 AM. Graveside service to follow at River Bend Cemetery, Westerly, RI, 3 PM. Contributions may be made to the Shelter Harbor Conservation Society, 16 Handel Rd., Westerly, RI 02891.

title: Hecklers Badger McCall as He Campaigns in Manhattan
description: H. Carl McCall spent yesterday shoring up his Democratic base at campaign stops in New York City. But a dozen supporters of Gov. George E. Pataki showed up with megaphones and heckled Mr. McCall during a news conference in Manhattan, provoking a raucous confrontation with McCall supporters that at times overwhelmed the candidate's message.

title: Formula One Is Trying to Eliminate Boredom
description: PARIS, Oct. 24  Formula One, which is billed by its promoters as the third most-watched sport after the World Cup and Olympics, has had a difficult year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, CLAIRE
description: BRODY-Claire. October 25, 2002, died peacefully in her sleep in Providence, Rhode Island. Widow of Steve Brody. True friend of Jean Kalmanoff and Elaine Jupiter. Survived by her daughter Jill, her son-in-law Herb Emers and her loving grandchildren Jenny, Nola and David. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Boulevard, Bronx, NY 10460. Memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: The Greenhouse Stays. Some of the Greenery Goes.
description: Several months ago, Barry Schneider felt a sense of foreboding as he wandered onto a green plot of plants, fountains and patio furniture at the corner of Second Avenue and East 63rd Street. The lot is leased by a business called Patio.com and its glass greenhouse and garden is much loved by the neighborhood. But Mr. Schneider knew that the lot owner, the Metropolitan Transit Authority, could reclaim it at any time.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: MANHATTAN MONOLOGUES

title: The Chechens' Holy War: How Global Is It?
description: WHEN Chechen commandos seized a Russian theater with 700 people inside on Wednesday night, the echoes of Sept. 11 came loud and fast. International terrorism had struck again -- or so it seemed.

title: Free Jewish Programming Without Saying Thanks
description: Having been mentioned in ''Telecare Cuts 75% of Jewish Programming'' [Sept. 29], I must respond to what I feel is an unjust criticism of Telecare. I am extremely surprised that Joel A. Levitch, president and chief executive of National Jewish Television, does not think it proper to express any gratitude to Telecare for carrying his programming pro bono for 20 years.

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Cybercharity
description: The founders of the Web site for the Community Partnership Network call it a sort of bridal registry for community agencies. On the site, cpnworks. org, social agencies in Bergen County post goods and services they need, and site visitors can donate money or, say, a stroller or construction work. Or they can buy through a retailer, GreaterGood.com, which will ship the items to the agencies and donate part of the proceeds to the site. People can also post items they want to donate and agencies can respond. Allison Haas of Tenafly and Elizabeth Corsini of Englewood, who have degrees in health care and are at home rearing children, came up with the idea. The site, which went online this month, was meant to attract younger, technology-savvy givers who don't usually make big charitable contributions.

title: The Kid in the Candy Store Now Runs One of Her Own
description: The newly opened Figgy Sweets shop in Scarsdale manages simultaneously to suggest an old world confectionary and an old-fashioned candy store. Arrayed in the store are expensive European boxed chocolates, Sedutto ice creams, pastries, Neuhaus and Ghislaine brand chocolates, jelly beans, lollipops, teas and coffees, stuffed animals and other gifts.

title: New York vs. San Francisco: A Complex Olympic Question
description: As members of the United States Olympic Committee prepare to choose between New York and San Francisco as their candidate for the site of the 2012 Summer Games, they say they are considering factors that range from how the cities treat their favorite sports to their feelings about a sympathy vote for New York.

title: At Foundry, a 'Great Artisan,' Perhaps a Little Too Great
description: Here is evidence that Long Island City is coming of age as an art scene: it just got its first big-time forgery case. On Oct. 10, a state grand jury in Queens indicted Brian Ramnarine, 48, on charges of defrauding three artists and two wealthy collectors out of $140,000 by making and selling fake sculptures. If convicted, he faces up to 15 years in prison.

title: Stomping Around The World
description: ONLY one word -- ''Shhh!'' -- is spoken in ''Pulse: A Stomp Odyssey,'' the Imax film by the creators of the stage show ''Stomp.'' That ''Shhh!'' is ironic in a movie about sounds: hoots and grunts, whispers and shouts and all the pattering, thudding, plinking, clanking, swishing, booming, rattling and ringing that a world of percussionists can summon. (''Pulse'' is at the American Museum of Natural History through June.)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIFFER, DR. MORTON A.
description: SCHIFFER-Dr. Morton A. A celebratory memorial will be held in his honor on 11/3/02, at 11 AM, at the Stamford Hospital, Whittingham Pavilion, West Broad St, Stamford, CT.

title: Nuclear Negotiations
description: To the Editor:

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: High praise to Margaret Talbot for a layered and insightful discussion on the sexual harassment of men by men (Oct. 13). Sexual-harassment law is indeed problematic. So is the stigmatization of those whom sexual-harassment case law is designed to assist.

title: Drinking Young
description: WHAT? You're messed up?'' said Nicole Belton-Young, who is 17. It was near midnight one recent Friday, and the calls were beginning to come in at the Larchmont-Mamaroneck Safe Rides headquarters at Hommocks Ice Rink in Mamaroneck.

title: For Pope John High Coach, 300th Victory Is Big Relief
description: When Victor Paternostro took over as coach of the football team at Pope John XXIII in Sparta, N.J., in 1968, the team had won only one game in its previous seven seasons. In the 35 seasons since, the Lions have become a Sussex County powerhouse and won 19 state titles. Yesterday, Pope John shut out Vernon Township, 18-0, to give Paternostro his 300th victory at the school.

title: Between the Sexes
description: The courteous and competent real-estate agent I'd just hired to rent my house shocked and offended me when, after we signed our contract, he refused to shake my hand, saying that as an Orthodox Jew he did not touch women. As a feminist, I oppose sex discrimination of all sorts. However, I also support freedom of religious expression. How do I balance these conflicting values? Should I tear up our contract? J.L., New York

title: Mary Pierson, Matthew Farlie
description: Mary Jean Pierson, a daughter of Mary and Richard Pierson of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Bradford Farlie, a son of Barbara and William Farlie Jr. of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Charles J. Beirne, the president of Le Moyne College in Syracuse and a Farlie family friend, performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Montclair.

title: Ichabod Crane's Namesake? Or Not
description: THIS Halloween, Ichabod Crane turns 215 years old. All these years you probably thought poor old Ichabod was a figment of Washington Irving's imagination. As the hapless hero of one of America's most endearing folk tales, ''The Legend of Sleepy Hollow,'' Ichabod Crane is best remembered for his run-in with the Headless Horseman of Sleepy Hollow.

title: There Is Hope
description: There is nothing more beautiful than watching people get to vote in a free election for the first time -- particularly in the Arab world, where elections have been so rare. That's what happened in Bahrain Thursday, as this tiny island nation off the east coast of Saudi Arabia voted for a parliament that will, for the first time, get to share some decision-making with Bahrain's progressive king, Sheik Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa.

title: A Fellini Moment
description: If Federico Fellini were alive and well today, would he go to fashion shows, as so many celebrities now do? Would Fellini, with his fondness for parades and beauty contests, choose to perch with the likes of Britney and P. Diddy in the front row of, say, John Galliano's couture show for Christian Dior to witness the latest circus of elaborate frocks and feathered coats?

title: Fusion Cooking That Doesn't Spare Butter
description: THE drive to Terrapin, a rave-winning restaurant, is stunning. You'll pass over the Ashokan Reservoir, see the Catskill Mountains rising all around, and wonder if this can possibly be the way to destination dining. It is: Terrapin, a former post office, has been transformed into a country roadhouse, all wood paneling, captain's chairs and close quarters. But the food is a fantasy come true.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David. October 27, 1989 remembered always, with love, by his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, SHELDON
description: HARRIS - Sheldon. Passed away peacefully after a battle with kidney cancer on Friday, October 25, 2002. Mr. Harris was an advertising guru, having worked in the field for over 30 years. Mr. Harris began his career as a copywriter at the DDB in 1952 and retired after running his own agency, Harris-Gorbaty. Mr. Harris is survived by his mother Belle Harris of Rego Park, NY, his girlfriend Lenore Adler of Great Neck, NY, and his four children Rhonda Pollina of Oldfield, NY, Jordan Harris of White Plains, NY, Melanie Silverman of Weston, FL, Scott Harris of NY, NY. Mr. Harris is also survived by his eight grandchildren: Bradley, James, Brett, Hunter, Samantha, Bailey, Daryn and Sloane. Mr. Harris was a voracious reader and avid sports fan. Of all Mr. Harris' interests none were greater than his children and grandchildren. Mr. Harris made it a priority to have a very special bond with all of his children and grandchildren. His memory will be cherished and he shall be missed by all of them. Services will be held at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, on Sunday, October 27, at 1 PM; 718896-9000.

title: Corrections
