description: Because of an editing error, a brief report last Sunday about the discovery of the remains of 11 people in a rail car in Iowa misstated their cause of death. It was dehydration and hyperthermia, not hypothermia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCROZATI, JOSEPH F.
description: SCROZATI-Joseph F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph F. Scrozati, associated with The Times from 1960 until retiring in 1982.

title: Thousands March in Washington Against Going to War in Iraq
description: Thousands of protesters marched through Washington's streets, chanting and waving banners against possible military action against Iraq. The rally was one of several held in American and foreign cities today.

title: Beene, Blahniks and a Bike
description: AMY FINE COLLINS, a studiously chic style writer for Vanity Fair magazine, makes no apology for her rarefied tastes -- not the Geoffrey Beene dresses she collects by the trunkful, not her French Art Deco furnishings, not the 1930's fashion illustrations she displays on her walls. But lately those tastes have altered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, HOWARD
description: BAER-Howard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard Baer, associated with The Times from 1972 until retiring in 1982.

title: Caumsett State Park Is an Educational Gem
description: Although there may have been ''universal disappointment when the architectural experts saw the disrepair of Caumsett'' [''Four Centuries of Architectural Icons,'' Oct. 20], the critics' comments did a disservice to the magnificent teaching program run by Queens College at Caumsett State Park, using the Marshall Field mansion as a classroom. The Queens College naturalists share the natural beauty, history and endangered animal habitats existing on the grounds of the park with children and adults, who get to sleep in the servants' quarters of the main building. They teach children for an entire weekend, prepare meals and care for the groups while keeping the cost low for nonprofits. My Girl Scout troop studied pond and seashore ecology while we were there. Kudos to them for the wonderful program offered at Caumsett State Park.

title: BOOKS IN BRIEF: FICTION & POETRY
description: SWAN

title: Executive Life; Creative Thinking by a Working Mom
description: HAVING four children over five years is fairly rare. But when the mother is a senior executive with a high-powered husband, even other working women scratch their heads in disbelief.

title: Two That Please
description: The front label on Martha Clara Vineyards' 2000 cabernet franc faintly depicts a wedding photo, which the back label explains. The bride was Martha Clara Entenmann, who spent the better part of the last century raising her family and then helping them to build a successful bakery business empire on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNBULL, WILLIAM
description: TURNBULL-William. 94, a lifetime resident of Far Hills, NJ, died at home October 23, 2002. Born in New York City December 6, 1907, Mr. Turnbull attended the Buckley School, St. Mark's School, Princeton University (1930), the Ecole des Beaux Arts, and Yale University School of Architecture. He then went on to work with Eero Saarinen at Cranbrook Academy of Art. He subsequently joined the family brokerage firm, Post and Flagg, in New York City. In 1938 he enlisted in the U.S. Navy and served as an O.S.S. officer in World War II. Following the war he founded United Instrument Corporation with his brother, Arthur. After the sale of the company in the late 1950's, he pursued his lifelong love of agriculture with interests in farms and ranches in Georgia, Colorado, California and New Jersey. In the 1960's he became a partner in the Ferris Corporation, a commercial real estate firm. Throughout his life Mr. Turnbull was a leader in and supporter of many community organizations, among which were the Sheltering Arms Children's Service, the Victoria Foundation, the Peapack-Gladstone Bank, the Lamington Presbyterian Church, the Somerset Agriculture Development Board, and the Upper Raritan Watershed Association. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Elizabeth Howe Turnbull; his son, Thomas R. Turnbull; his daughters, Ellen T. Edwards and Margaret T. Simon; his daughters-in-law, Rosamond P. Turnbull and Mary E. Griffin; 12 grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. He was predeceased by his eldest son, architect William Turnbull Jr. in 1997. A service will be held on Monday, October 28, at 11 AM, at the Lamington Presbyterian Church, Lamington, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Upper Raritan Watershed Association, P.O. Box 273, Gladstone, NJ 07934, or the Somerset Hills Hospice, 12 Olcott Ave., Bernardsville, NJ 07924.

title: Murder, She (Usually) Wrote
description: NOTHING THAT

title: An Echo Of the Past, In Four-Part Harmony
description: MENTION the Ink Spots these days, and if there is any sign at all of recognition, it may be wonder that the group is still around.

title: Volponi, at 44-1, Buries Field in the Breeders' Cup Classic
description: In 1942, P. G. Johnson decided to get into the horse business and put up $75 for an undernourished colt named Song Master, who had just survived a fire in a barn near the Chicago stockyards. It was Johnson, a 77-year-old Hall of Fame trainer, who burned his old hometown down today when his colt Volponi, sent off at odds of 44-1, buried 11 others with an emphatic six-and-a-half-length victory in the $4 million Breeders' Cup Classic.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the coming television show ''Queens Supreme'' referred imprecisely to Dan Thomas and Peter Thomas, who had the idea for the series. They do not formally have the title of creator. That title is held by Kevin Fox, who is also an executive producer. The article also misstated the connection of the actress Julia Roberts to the show. She is not an executive producer. Her production company, Shoelace Productions, is helping produce the show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALVIN, RUTH (MEHRTENS)
description: GALVIN-Ruth (Mehrtens). Of Westwood and Edgartown, MA. October 23, 2002. Beloved wife of the late John T. Galvin. Loving sister of Paul H. Mehrtens and his wife Mary Lou of Longmeadow, MA. Beloved aunt of Paul H. Mehrtens, Jr. of Wayland, MA, Stephen R. Mehrtens of Brookline, MA, and Jane Rutherford of PA. Funeral services are private. Memorial donations in Ruth's memory may be made to the Boston Athenaeum, 10-1/2 Beacon St., Boston, MA 02106. Late graduate of Smith College and a Time-Duke Fellow. Former contributing editor and correspondent for Time, Inc. Accomplished writer being published in American Heritage, Atlantic Monthly, London Economist, Fortune, Harvard Magazine, New York Times, Smithsonian Magazine, World Monitor and other magazines and newspapers. Late trustee of the Boston Athenaeum and Smith College. Member of Boston Smith Club, Mass Historical Society, and the Tavern Club. J.S. Waterman & Sons, Eastman-Waring Funeral Service, 617-536-4110.

title: A Death in Minnesota Stirs A Campaign in New Jersey
description: A day after United States Senator Paul Wellstone died in a plane crash, Frank R. Lautenberg, New Jersey's Democratic candidate, said that the best way for Mr. Wellstone's political admirers to honor his memory was to ensure that the Democrats retain control of the Senate.

title: Under the Motorized Clouds
description: ME WITH ANIMAL TOWERING

title: Street Style Sashays And Bops Down the Ages
description: BIKERS and B-boys, punks and Goths, Rastas and ravers -- street style is identified with the dress of subcultures, whether informal cliques or neighborhood gangs. Generally the province of the young, with their self-conscious impulse to provoke, street style disrupts the smooth flow of high fashion. But this collision of high and low didn't start with Madonna or Lil' Kim.

title: A Real-World Education
description: THE CRAZED

title: Woods Are the Same, but Nothing Else
description: THE 102nd Street Transverse is a thick, sensible S-curve among the squiggles on a map of Central Park. Jogging is a good thing to have just finished doing, and the paved belt above the North Meadow is there to help, to cut off the top of the loop and its Great Hill, to get you home quicker.

title: The Age of Street Fashion
description: Has there ever been a designer's catwalk that produced better fashion than a city sidewalk? Is there a style, high or low, that has not felt the influence of Fifth Avenue, or Bushwick Avenue in Brooklyn, or the Rue Bonaparte, where Isabella Blow, above, a sometimes muse to designers, appears as a wind-tossed apparition blown across the old Parisian cobblestones. ''Everything in fashion begins in the street,'' the fashion designer Diane Von Furstenberg said. Take cargo pants, one of the most ubiquitous of garments, whose entry into the fashion mainstream was anything but top down. ''That didn't come from anyone in 'fashion,''' said Julie Gilhart, the fashion director of Barneys. ''It came from the street.'' So, too, did buttocks-baring trousers, and preppy plaids worn ironically, and do-rags and belt buckles with one's name spelled out in block letters. None of these notions originated on any designer's sketch pad and yet each turned up on the fall runways of Dolce & Gabbana, Jean Paul Gaultier and Anna Sui. The photo essays Bill Cunningham contributed to The Times -- since 1989 in a column called ''On the Street'' and for years before under other titles -- have played a compelling part in recording the ephemeral nature of self-invention. Positioning himself in the slipstream of urban imagery, Mr. Cunningham has created an almanac of what city dwellers were wearing at various points in the late 20th century and, probably more important, what they were thinking about themselves at the time.

title: Corporate Ethics Law Is a Needed Change
description: Re ''Coping With New Federal Corporate Ethics Law'' [L.I.@Work, Oct. 13]: the Sarbanes-Oxley Act was passed due to the need for change in the way publicly traded companies handle matters ranging from internal accounting to corporate governance. The irony of former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato addressing the group cannot be lost on anyone. He was a member of the Senate Banking Committee that governed the very issues that generated the corporate climate allowing for the Enron, Worldcom, Tyco and Global Crossing scandals.

title: Day of the Dead, Month of the Charge Card
description: HALLOWEEN

title: Organized Sports And Free-for-Alls
description: JERRY COLLINCINI, director of parks and recreation in this sprawling central New Jersey town, said he saw the trouble coming at least a dozen years ago as clearly as a batter sees a hanging curve.

title: Long After the Windfall, Back to Some Basics
description: NOW that the money is gone, I have at least answered one question: How did it feel to be rich?

title: A Museum Show About Show-Stopping Hotels
description: Anyone who has spent a night at a hip luxury hotel knows that architecture, amenities and attitude, the so-called three A's, are the new benchmarks. Whether these attributes are welcome in a hotel room is up to the guest. But as elements for a museum exhibition, they seem irresistible.

title: Conner Trades Wheel To Wheel and Deal
description: On race-day mornings in Auckland, New Zealand, the crew members of Team Dennis Conner and their families gather at their base camp to watch expectantly as a crane lowers their navy-hulled boat, Stars & Stripes, into the water. The crew boards, and Stars & Stripes is then towed past the waving crowds in Viaduct Harbor toward the race course on the Hauraki Gulf.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Addicts, Relief May Be an Office Visit Away
description: IN years to come, drug addiction will probably be treated like hypertension, diabetes and other chronic, relapsing diseases: with a variety of medications prescribed in the doctor's office.

title: October 20-26: SCIENCE; TAKE TWO
description: In a large study that may change medical practice, researchers found that giving patients aspirin in the first 48 hours after heart bypass surgery saved lives and prevented complications. The death rate was 4 percent in those who got no aspirin, but only 1.3 percent in those who got it.

title: A Skinny Little Girl, a Fishing Rod, a Bluegill
description: She was precisely the kind of little girl I would have fallen madly in love with, had I been 6 or 7 and not her grandfather. She was skinny, with blond curly hair cut short, gangly when she ran, restless with dull adult talk, a chatterbox herself, crazy for her grandfather's stories, her two front teeth gone and paid for, not nearly so shy of seeing worms for the first time that she would not hold one.

title: Private Sector; Chasing the Americas' Pastime
description: LIKE many other baseball fans, Carlos Peralta Quintero was in Southern California last weekend to watch the Anaheim Angels in the World Series, and he liked what he saw. But he was as interested in what went on in the stands as in what happened on the field.

title: 3 Ways to Look at a Landscape
description: THREE new exhibitions at the Jersey City Museum are thematically related, but they also stand alone. The theme that unites them is the American landscape, and the shows reveal that subject to be as broad as the country itself.

title: Loafers Work at Looking Good
description: Cold weather usually brings on loafer lust, and this year shoppers who want something outside the boundaries of classic Gucci or Tod's will have a lot to choose from. Shoe designers are giving loafer looks a kick, mixing in style elements from the 1970's and 80's to modern effect. At Marc Jacobs, above left, patent leather and suede loafers are a style smorgasbord with ballet-flat round toes and military braid trim ($420). Penny and side-buckle loafers by Prada, above, second from right, ($380 to $395 at Saks Fifth Avenue) offer classic styling with a high-gloss finish. Coach follows the side-buckle theme with the lug-sole Tina Loafer, above, second from left, in red suede ($160). A grosgrain schoolboy loafer for women by Hollywould , above, right ($245 at www.ilovehollywould.com), adds star charms to its tie-stripe pattern, while Bergdorf Goodman's private label also goes graphic with a leopard-print pony version ($200).

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: The act of bullying at the workplace is equally as unacceptable as bullying on the playground. We do not let our children get away with it. So why are there so many loopholes through which adults might slip?

title: Drivers Attend a Fallen Colleague's Funeral to Pay Respects and to Move On
description: The buses started lining up here today in the morning darkness.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 29 about the role of conductors in ballet referred incorrectly to choreographers who use live music during their companies' performances, even in lean economic times. The reference was to Mark Morris, not to all modern-dance choreographers.

title: Investing; Coin Trade Becomes More Like A Market
description: THE Professional Coin Grading Service has begun tracking the coin trade electronically in much the same way that Standard & Poor's tracks the stock market.

title: Sprezzatura
description: A couple of high-flying Merrill Lynch brokers catering to New York's beau monde who are enmeshed in the current investigations of insider trading were described by Alex Kuczynski in this way in The New York Times: ''Both are well-groomed social beings known for their sprezzatura.''

title: Marisa Noel, Matthew Brown
description: Marisa Noel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Noel Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Matthew Crawford Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Crawford Brown III of San Marino, Calif. Msgr. Clement J. Connolly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in Manhattan.

title: Written in Stone
description: A CEMETERY visit can make a fascinating, if offbeat, excursion -- and not just at Halloween. While the natural serenity appeals to hikers, walkers and birders, graveyards are also magnets for history buffs and others who are curious about those who went before them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, REV. MONSIGNOR JAMES J.
description: MURRAY-Rev. Monsignor James J. On behalf of the Board of Directors, Administration, and staff of Calvary Hospital, Inc., we mourn the passing of our longtime Board member. Monsignor Murray served on the hospital Board of Directors since 1973. He gave generously of his time as a member of the Finance and Nominating Committees of the hospital Board. His commitment to the special mission of Calvary Hospital, and his dedication and leadership contributed enormously to the growth and success of the hospital program of care. Monsignor Murray's wisdom and vision was instrumental in the strategic planning of Calvary's move to its present location in the Northeast Bronx in 1978. We will miss Monsignor Murray, both as a loyal Board member and a member of the Calvary Family. We extend our condolences to his family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD, Chairman of the Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President/ Chief Executive Officer Michael J. Brescia, MD, Executive Medical Director James E. Cimino, MD, Director of Calvary Palliative Care Institute Christopher P. Comfort, MD Medical Director Richard J. Kutilek, Chief Operating Officer Frank J. Locaparra, Chief Financial Officer

title: Times Change: 'Sixteen Candles' at CBGB
description: FOR us, this is like having it at the Knights of Columbus,'' Emily Armstrong was saying, explaining why her daughter's Sweet 16 party was being held at CBGB, the famous and infamous punk rock club of the 70's.

title: For Syracuse, Relief Comes From Rutgers
description: At the rate Rutgers made mistakes today, winning was almost impossible.

title: Writing Music That Sings, Cries, Screams and Prays
description: EVERY half century, history rolls at us another wave of composers who will change the way music is heard and played. At the beginning of the 20th century came Debussy and Schoenberg, soon joined by Bartok and Stravinsky. In the 1950's, those arriving ranged from John Cage to Milton Babbitt. Now it is time for another great sweep, perhaps going in even more diverse directions and prompted from farther out on the periphery. The 20th century's revolutions were led from Europe and then the United States; now may come the turn of China, Australia and Latin America.

title: Editorial Observer; Ruminating on Smallpox Vaccine and the Notorious Swine Flu Fiasco
description: As public health officials debate whether to offer smallpox vaccine to every American who wants it, they would do well to recall what happened a quarter-century ago when a mass vaccination campaign ended in disaster. That experience -- in the ill-fated swine flu immunizations of 1976 -- does not mean that health officials should shrink from offering smallpox vaccinations today. But it does suggest there are lessons to be learned on how best to do it.

title: Second Generation Joins the Family Business
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Oct. 26 (Bloomberg News)  In his first year as a professional hockey referee, Ryan Fraser reacted quickly when a player yelled, "You're half the man your father is!" His answer? A 10-minute penalty.

title: Hello Mother, Hello Fido
description: In a quirky take on mother-daughter matching outfits, mainstream clothing and pet apparel designers are creating complementary ensembles for humans and dogs. At Kate Spade, a raincoat ($395), rain hat ($110) and dog coat ($125), right, are emblazoned with identical Maira Kalman prints. Coach has the Down Jacket for women ($398) and Puffa vest for dogs, both trimmed in matching leather ($148). Fifi & Romeo offers a red cashmere dog sweater ($225), decorated with a large bone, while a matching human-size hat and scarf ($195 and $175) sport the same design (all at Kirna Zabte, 212-941-9656). From Wag Wear a merino dog sweater ($110), in heather gray with red color block or pink with green color block, has a biped-cut counterpart: a unisex zip-front cardigan with raglan sleeves in the contrasting color ($275, both at www.wagwear.com). And the Nordic Sweater from Land's End is available for men, women, children and dogs ($14 to 49.50, www.landsend.com) so that the whole family can match its Fair Isle. JENNIFER LAING

title: An Ancient Drama Whose Wisdom Is Always Modern
description: IT'S a Saturday night in late August in the Athenian suburb of Aigaleo, and some 1,500 Greeks are seated, waiting for the evening's entertainment, many of them drinking beer, smoking and chatting on cellphones to pass the time. In the United States, a similar scene might be evident at the start of an open-air concert, or perhaps a drive-in movie. But at the al fresco Alexis Minotis Theater, a modern structure designed in the fan-shaped, steeply tiered style of this country's great amphitheaters, the onset of dusk brings with it the reason everyone has come together. On this evening, it is a new production of Sophocles' ''Antigone,'' perhaps the most beloved classical tragedy in modern-day Greece.

title: October 20-26: ECONOMY; HALF-SPEED AHEAD
description: The Federal Reserve reported that the economy remains sluggish. Both the retail and manufacturing sectors were weak . But with the stock market rebounding, the Fed is likely to wait for more economic data, particularly the employment report for October, before deciding whether to cut interest rates again. Richard W. Stevenson

title: Europe Strains To Put Laggards Back in Line
description: LEAVE it to Portugal, the little country known for its fearless explorers, to test the boundaries of Europe's monetary union. In July, the Portuguese government became the first member to breach the ceiling on budget deficits allowed by the European Union.

title: Lindsay Smith, Maurice Blanco
description: Lindsay Kara Smith, the daughter of Iris and Jeffrey F. Smith of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last evening to Maurice Blanco, the son of Elsie B. Blanco and Dr. Jack J. Blanco of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills, N.Y.

title: Personal Business; The Search for Sure Footing in a Shaky Work World
description: GREG DRISCOLL took little for granted before accepting the job of president and chief executive of Enerwise Global Technologies, an energy technology company. He interviewed the company's board members and its entire executive team and even spoke with middle managers. He then prodded people outside the company to get a sense of Enerwise's reputation in the industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BEATRICE MARILYN ''BEASLEY.''
description: LEVY - Beatrice Marilyn ''Beasley.'' Passed away October 25, 2002. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Miami Beach, FL. Loving wife of Richard to whom she was married 51 years. Adored mother of Mark and JoAnn Levy, JoAnn Levy, Daniel and Susan Levy and Allison and Dr. Jack Sacks. Cherished grandmother of Brian, Andrea, Evan, Adam, Alyssa, Sam, Ruth, Hilary and AJ. Beloved sister of Phyllis Pritcher, Herbert Behrens, Arlene Slepoy and Hannah Tolces. Funeral Service Sunday, October 27, 2002. For further information Gutterman Warheit Chapel, Boca Raton, FL; 800-992-9262.

title: New Jersey Well-Water Testing
description: UNDER a law that took effect last month, homeowners in New Jersey who rely on private wells for their drinking water must have the wells tested for contamination before they can sell their property.

title: An 'Art World Secret' Plumbs the Mysterious Id
description: THE world of a Carroll Dunham painting is exuberant, irrational, menacing and comic. It slips fluidly between abstraction and representation. Creatures seemingly coalesce from the sludge of the subconscious, feeling their way blind through the painterly terrain by means of phallic protuberances and bared teeth that almost chew up the scenery. Id incarnate, and sometimes wielding guns or bullwhips, these characters are undeniably appealing, cutting to the quick of rage and humor and frustration the way cartoons do.

title: Corrections
description: Alisting of advice for visitors on Oct. 6 with an article about Kabini River Lodge in Nagarahole National Park in southern India (also known as Rajiv Gandhi National Park) misstated medical precautions for the region. Vaccination against cholera is not recommended, according to the Centers for Disease Control; indeed, the C.D.C. says the manufacture and sale of the only licensed cholera vaccine in the United States has been discontinued. Vaccination against yellow fever is required only for those traveling from sub-Saharan Africa or other areas where there is active or potential transmission. Vaccinations against hepatitis A and typhoid are recommended by the C.D.C. Vaccination against hepatitis B is recommended only for certain groups of travelers, listed on the C.D.C.'s Web site, www.cdc.gov/travel .

title: Thoroughly Bad Guy
description: JESSE JAMES

title: Nader Is Supporting Some Democrats
description: Ralph Nader is still scorned by Democrats who say his third-party campaign tipped the 2000 presidential race to George W. Bush.

title: Oh, She Used To Be Big On Broadway
description: IS there a place on Broadway for Audra McDonald?

title: Campaign Season; Nader Is Supporting Some Democrats
description: Ralph Nader, left, is still scorned by Democrats who say his third-party campaign tipped the 2000 presidential race to George W. Bush.

title: Suspected Robber Falls From Rooftop
description: A man who invaded a house in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, was in critical condition and under arrest last night after falling from a roof as he tried to escape, the police said.

title: Angels Juggle Worn And Weary Pitchers
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 26 (AP)  If Ramon Ortiz's sore right wrist prevents him from starting a seventh game in the World Series on Sunday, the Anaheim Angels might turn to the rookie John Lackey.

title: RUTGERS NAME WILL SURVIVE
description: The Rutgers name will be preserved in a merger of the state's three public research institutions, Governor McGreevey said on Monday after meeting with the president of Rutgers University, Norman Samuels, in New Brunswick. The governor wants to reorganize Rutgers, the New Jersey Institute of Technology and the University of Medicine and Dentistry as regional, autonomous universities under a single umbrella administration. Mr. Samuels praised the vision behind the plan but said he wanted to assess the reaction of the faculty, trustees and potential donors before giving it his full endorsement. A task force is expected to deal with the specifics of the plan, including cost and the final name of the 65,000-student institution. But the governor promised that Col. Henry Rutgers, the Revolutionary War veteran whose name the university bears, would not be turning in his grave. Samantha J. Cooper

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As police chief, I know you need a lot of luck. I'd like to think it's all skill and moxie and brains. But it's mostly luck.''

title: Jets See Long Drive as a Harbinger
description: The Jets point to one drive as the standard by which all others will be judged, an example of how to use multiple offensive threats to maximum advantage -- something that has been a year and a half in the making.

title: The Problem With Bilingual Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Julia Hodgson, Andreas Kottmann
description: Julia Reichenbach Hodgson and Andreas Hugo Kottmann were married on Friday by Judge Peter K. Leisure of the Federal District Court for the Southern District in Manhattan. A religious ceremony is to be performed on Nov. 9 by the Rev. Monika Mhle-Lssig, an Evangelical Church minister, at the Stadtkirche in Wermelskirchen, Germany.

title: A Musical Memoir About Looking for Home in All the Wrong Places
description: WITHOUT its title, you might not know that ''True Home'' was about anything in particular, except a character (coyly identified as Woman in the program) who is wearing pajamas. What is clear in this 90-minute intermissionless musical memoir produced by the Hudson Stage Company is that she had or is still having a bad dream.

title: 'Mr. Aqueduct' Bids Farewell to His Park
description: LIVERPOOL-BORN and formerly a banker, Brian Goodman is the man many credit with stewarding the revival of the Old Croton Aqueduct. Ten years after becoming the aqueduct's first site manager and a constant presence on the trail's 26.2 miles, Mr. Goodman, 70, retired last week. A successor has not yet been named.

title: Glaus, Like His Teammates, Refuses to Stay Down for Long
description: The first pitch Troy Glaus saw in the major leagues was a fastball up near his chin, from Bret Saberhagen, in 1998. Glaus, a strapping power hitter just one year out of U.C.L.A, dug back in and drove a double down the right-field line.

title: The Nazis' Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunny's Wonderful Saloon
description: IT'S 10 p.m. on a Wednesday at Sunny's in Red Hook, and the band is playing in the back room. The place is crowded. No empty seats at the bar, and all four booths are overflowing, two with drinkers playing Scrabble. There are a lot of goatees and black-rimmed glasses, and young women with small tattoos of geometric designs and flowers. A Johnny Cash CD plays in the narrow front room; he is performing an acoustic version of the song ''One'' by U2. ''Have you ever heard this record?'' asks Matt Dilling, who is serving drinks. ''This record is awesome.''

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; FIFTH COLUMN FEARS
description: A lieutenant colonel in the Israeli army was arrested on suspicion of spying for the Lebanese guerrilla group Hezbollah in return for drugs.

title: Paying for College: The Gold Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLSTONE, SENATOR PAUL
description: WELLSTONE-Senator Paul. On behalf of the Board and Staff of NARAL, we express our sadness as we mourn the loss of Sen. Paul Wellstone, a champion of women's rights and a courageous public advocate for Minnesotans, Americans and citizens of the world. Throughout his years of service in the United States Senate, he never wavered from his commitment to ensuring justice and defending the interests of everyday Americans. The Senator embodied a combination of integrity and steadfastness of principle that are all too rare in today's political arena. We hope that others in public service will strive to carry on his dedication to those in need.

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: Bare Ruined Choirs
description: IN RUINS

title: 12 Americans Stage Protest Hussein Is Happy to Allow
description: A group of 12 Americans from a Chicago-based pacifist group, Voices in the Wilderness, gathered today to bring the American style of protest to Saddam Hussein's Iraq.

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; RESISTING REFORM
description: Japan's efforts to overhaul its troubled financial industry were thrown into disarray when conservative lawmakers and bankers blocked the release of a report that included proposals to get tough with lax lenders and dead-beat borrowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRACEY, COLUMBUS
description: BRACEY-Columbus. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Columbus Bracey, associated with The Times since 1980.

title: Hawaiians Find an Unlikely Eden in Las Vegas
description: Some mornings when the beach is empty and the waves are perfect, five-foot left curls crashing gently onto water smooth as glass, Moses Mokuahi goes surfing. He savors every second of the ride, kicking out just before the swell collapses into foam and trickles into drain holes at the edge of a low concrete wall.

title: Men Behaving Badly
description: As far as I understand the law, at least in California, if somebody threatens to harm me, it is assault, and if he actually touches me, it is assault and battery. If somebody in a workplace grabbed my genitals, he would get a warning. Any repetition would result in a criminal complaint.

title: The Myth of ''18 to 34''
description: Why do people -- in this case, those over 34 -- want so badly to be marketed to? Advertising was once characterized as pernicious, advertisers as hidden persuaders enticing us to buy products we didn't need. It is as if we are somehow marginalized if no one wants to sell us anything.

title: George Pataki for Governor
description: Third terms are seldom a good idea for mayors or governors or any elected chief executive. The energy that comes with your administration's early years is long gone, and your enemies have figured out your weak spots. In the case of New York's governor, George Pataki, there have been enough disappointments and broken promises over the last eight years to make the voters prefer an alternative. But having looked at the available options, we believe that Mr. Pataki is the best choice available this Nov. 5.

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast; Subways and Sunsets Can Go Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, MIGNON
description: LEVEY - Mignon. Dearest wife of Dudley. Loving mother of Lisa and Tony Ruggirello. Cherished grandmother of Stacy and Julie. She loved and was loved. Services Monday, 11:15 AM, Parkside Chapels, Queens Blvd at 66th Ave, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Polish Treasures Visit a Kindred Culture
description: JUST days after beginning her job at the Milwaukee Art Museum in 1997, Laurie Winters was given a career-making opportunity.

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not a Levitt House, It's a Levitt's House
description: ANYONE familiar with Levittown might find it hard to believe that a Levitt-built house is on the market for $2.7 million. But Aimee Roderick says the ranch, listed with her Stony Brook real estate agency last month, is worth every penny of the asking price.

title: October 20-26: INTERNATIONAL; WITH FRIENDS LIKE THESE
description: When North Korea admitted recently that it had a secret program to enrich uranium for a nuclear bomb, American officials already knew the source of the technology: Pakistan. Bush administration officials say that in the late 1990's, Pakistan bartered technology used to create bomb-grade uranium for North Korean ballistic missiles. The officials refuse to criticize Pakistan publicly because it is an ally in the war on terrorism. James Dao

title: Summer's Storms Hurt Wine Industry in Italy
description: The floods that plagued Central Europe this summer also wreaked havoc on Italy's wine industry, ruining whole vineyards and hurting an important sector of the economy.

title: Yemen Turns to Tribes to Aid Hunt for Qaeda
description: Given the penchant of tribesmen in this isolated province to tote around weapons like personal bazookas, the Yemeni government is holding hostage about 40 sons of tribal leaders.

title: Business; In Every Building, Turn, Turn, Turn
description: TURNSTILES conjure images of clunky metal contraptions that slow entry to subways or ballparks. But since Sept. 11, 2001, a new generation of those security posts, equipped with sleek metal casings and optical sensors, has been showing up in high-rises like the Sears Tower in Chicago and the Library Tower in Los Angeles.

title: U.A.B. 29, ARMY 26
description: Army appeared to be on the verge of its first victory when Josh Holden scored from 2 yards to give the host Black Knights a 4-point lead over Alabama-Birmingham with less than a minute to go.

title: Candidate Learns Limits of 9/11 Rsum
description: THIRTEEN months ago Joe Finley of Fort Salonga was just another firefighter commuting between a home in the Long Island suburbs and a firehouse in the city.

title: The Mayor Of Greenwich Village
description: WITHIN the reams of city law, there exists a curious rule requiring that parks and playgrounds be named after either the dead or the inanimate. So, two years ago, the city said no when a group of park enthusiasts tried to rename a playground on Thompson Street in SoHo in honor of their hero, a baker named Anthony Dapolito (pronounced da-po-LEE-to).

title: A Place to Sip, or Merely Sit?
description: Last Monday afternoon, the only food in sight at Stuyvesant Square Park was a pink Dunkin' Donut and a supersize coffee. Miriam O'Sullivan, a nanny enjoying the crisp sun of early fall, sat on a park bench licking her fingers.

title: Drink This One Through Fangs
description: If the Addams Family comes for Halloween dinner Thursday, don't put dry Beaunes on the table with the boudin noir, deviled eggs and bitter greens. Pour (nonvintage) Vampire's Blood, made from Marchal Foch and de Chaunac grapes by Rivendell, in the Hudson Valley. It's $6.66 -- $16.66 in a black box lined with red velvet -- at Vintage New York, 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street) in SoHo. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: SCALPING BAN SOUGHT
description: State Attorney General David Samson filed suit last week in Monmouth County Superior Court accusing Clear Channel Entertainment, operator of the PNC Bank Arts Center, of giving American Express cardholders unfair access in buying tickets to events. Earlier this year, Clear Channel began to offer tickets days before releasing them for public sale. Up to half the tickets at some events go to cardholders, in violation of the state's anti-scalping law, Mr. Samson said. The suit seeks an injunction to halt the ticket-selling preference. Jeremy Pearce

title: DataBank; In an Upbeat Market, a Third Week of Gains
description: Stocks rose for the third consecutive week as investors seemed to focus on positive earnings news and to ignore some signs of slowing economic growth and earnings disappointments.

title: Did Santiago Jump, or Was He Pushed?
description: JOSEPH SANTIAGO manicured and muscled and cocky -- came up the hard way. So when Mr. Santiago, the former police chief of Newark, the state's largest city, made it to the polished hallways of the state capital, he thought the job of shaping up the 2,800-member state police force would be, as he put it, ''a light lift.''

title: A Political Radical With a Brahmsian Musical Bent
description: ONE could, perhaps, argue fruitfully about whether the most innovative and progressive classical record company in the world is Nonesuch or Naxos. Nonesuch works within a giant corporation, AOL Time Warner, and turns out consistently superior products. Naxos sets its own rules for the regeneration of a largely moribund recording industry. For all its first-rate performances and innovative repertory, Naxos wins on quantity; Nonesuch on quality.

title: Film Openings and Film Series Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Sad End To a Gift Of Peonies From Japan
description: EXCITEMENT slowly turned to bitter disappointment last week for staff members of the Rockefeller State Park Preserve in Sleepy Hollow, and for the Japanese gardeners who had been waiting to oversee the installation of 500 tree peonies there.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Raymond Davis Jr., the Brookhaven National Laboratory physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize this month at a time when he is suffering from early Alzheimer's, misstated the incidence of the disease. The Long Island Alzheimer's Foundation estimates that it afflicts one in 10 people over the age of 65, not one in 4.

title: Under the Veil, and Proud of It
description: To the Editor:

title: October 20-26: NATIONAL; CELEBRITY SENTENCE
description: Elizabeth S. Grubman, the Manhattan publicist who made headlines by backing a car into a group of Hamptons clubgoers two summers ago, was sentenced to 60 days in the Suffolk County jail.

title: Impact of Suspects's Faith On Action Is Unclear
description: By many accounts, religion had always been a stabilizing factor in the life of John Allen Muhammad, who is charged with murder in the sniper rampage that killed 10 people in the Washington region.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: SAILING ALONE AROUND THE ROOM: New and Selected Poems, by Billy Collins. (Random House, $13.95.) Crisp, suburban and antiseptic, the poems in this greatest hits collection by America's poet laureate are infused with his characteristic self-deprecating humor, even as death, longing and regret hover at the margins of his work. ''There are brainy, observant, spit-shined moments on almost every page,'' Dwight Garner said in the Book Review last year. ''Young writers have plenty to learn from his clarity and apparent ease.''

title: Travelers Elect a Real Best-Dressed List; FASHION FUSION IN TOKYO
description: If you wanted a quick corrective to the notion that Japanese style is a matter of shoji screens and gravel Zen gardens, stand at the corner of Omotesando and Meiji avenues in Tokyo. It is here, near the Harajuku train station, that young Tokyo comes to disprove the proposition that the metropolis is, as some have claimed, the fashion capital of the world, when in fact it is, more important, the crossroads.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BRICKMAN, IRWIN
description: BRICKMAN-Irwin. October 25, 1962. Loving daughters M and M, beloved granddaughter, Laura.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: John Dekker, former convict (left): ''Every time I'm on Alcatraz it's like walking with ghosts, all those feelings. But I go back to reunions to see the guys. Every one of them is a man. Not that I respect them. They're guilty as hell. There weren't rapists and child molesters; there were what I call professional escape artists, high-time burglars, kidnappers. I robbed banks. I got there in November 1953, about a month earlier than Jerie. I saw Jerie at a reunion in the 90's. We've been good friends ever since. I knew him at Alcatraz -- there were only 250-some-odd men out there. But I wasn't a personal friend of his. Actually, we'd had a fight. Jerie was running his mouth in his cell. I said, 'Will you shut your mouth tonight?' He said, 'Tell me to shut up tomorrow.' Next day, coming in from work, I punched him. I had him in a bad position. I'm not saying I won; I'm saying I would have won. The screws broke us up -- that's what we called some officers, screws. After that, I didn't talk to Jerie the rest of the time on Alcatraz.''

title: Unseeded Stevenson Advances to Final
description: Unseeded Alexandra Stevenson, seeking the first title of her career, defeated Daniela Hantuchova, 6-4, 7-6, in the semifinals of the Generali Ladies yesterday in Vienna.

title: Helen Kwon, James Kim
description: Helen Cassandra Kwon, who recruits legal personnel in Los Angeles, and James Jihwook Kim, a lawyer in New York, were married yesterday at Liberty Baptist Church in Newport Beach, Calif. The Rev. Marcus K. Choi, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Sensual, Smart, and Then There Was That Voice
description: MOVIEGOERS who thrilled to the French New Wave can probably still summon up an image of Delphine Seyrig as she appeared in Alain Resnais's 1961 conundrum ''Last Year at Marienbad'': the short, dark, slicked-down hair, the Garboesque cheekbones and jaw, the elegantly erect spine, the surprisingly sinuous sway of her hips and the way she turned her head slightly away from the camera as if sensing its potential for violation.

title: Sports of The Times; One More Chance to Watch a Good Series
description: MAYBE back east, people were not watching. They missed something good. This one was for local consumption. With the eerie little rally monkey prancing around on the message board, the Angels came back from a five-run deficit to stun the Giants, 6-5, to tie this World Series at three games each.

title: Sports of The Times; One More Chapter in a Storybook Season
description: THE college football season is like a good book, and Notre Dame has become a book you can't put down.

title: Center for Youngsters With Multiple Sclerosis
description: Stony Brook University Hospital has opened the nation's first center for the diagnosis and treatment of multiple sclerosis in youngsters.

title: Cedric the Entertainer
description: A. O. Scott appeared happy to report that in his comedy Cedric Kyles isn't angry (Page Turner, Oct. 13). I guess if he were angry, that would be pretty ho-hum. Because isn't America just plain tired of angry black males? I mean, the country has changed, racially speaking, as much as it intends to. So why not just shut up about the problems still existing and, as Cedric's stage name suggests, just entertain?

title: October 20-26: SCIENCE; CONDOR SETBACK
description: A California condor chick was found dead in Los Padres National Forest, north of Los Angeles. It was last of three chicks recently hatched in the wild, the first in nearly two decades. The chicks were the offspring of adults raised in captivity and later released. Their deaths set back efforts to recreate a self-sustaining wild population of the birds.

title: Cutter of Hair, Center of the Universe
description: THIRTY-FOUR years ago last week, Jackie Rogers opened a hair salon on East 67th Street with the novel idea that it would cater exclusively to a male clientele. Complicated licensing laws governing the grooming industry left men relegated to barber shops, and Ms. Rogers wanted to change that. She hired stylists from Vidal Sassoon, she played music, she poured wine.

title: Debbie's Doing New York Now, But Rate Her PG
description: PORNOGRAPHY isn't just for dirty old men anymore. The movies that used to be shown in seedy Times Square theaters are now under bright lights at the Museum of Sex on Fifth Avenue. ''Auto Focus,'' Paul Schrader's biopic about the actor Bob Crane, who filmed his own sex life, is playing in a number of local movie houses. And Elaine May's forthcoming comedy, ''Adult Entertainment,'' which opens on Dec. 2 at the Variety Arts Theater, is about a group of actors who want to make a porn movie with class.

title: Not Exactly College Bowl, But Princeton Won Anyway
description: If Duke Kahanamoku brought surfing to the masses, then it is Andrew O'Riordan's mission to bring it the other way.

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Fading Into History? Not So Fast
description: To the Editor:

title: Investing; Restyling Your Portfolio for Europe's New Face
description: AN investment in emerging markets is often an implicit bet that they will someday join those of the developed world, allowing their businesses to benefit from sounder political, economic and financial systems. For many, that day may never arrive, but in the case of 10 European countries, it has been scheduled for the year after next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALDERON, PATRICIA DIANE
description: CALDERON-Patricia Diane. Patricia Calderon did everything in a special way. She moved from Seattle to New York at age 17. She started her career as a secretary and ended it as a partner in an advertising agency and one of the pioneers and foremost experts in the new field of interactive marketing. Pat embraced her new city and her life in New York with passion and humor distinctly her own. She gave her love, companionship and counsel to so many of us, sharing her specialness, making us each feel special in turn. Pat was an avid sailor. She was amazingly creative, yet also had a wonderful analytical mind. As much as she loved us, Pat had a special passion for two special Bearded Collies, MooShu and Browser. Pat passed away on October 20, at age 42, after a grueling battle with breast cancer. True to herself, she fought the battle in a special waywith dignity, grace, resolve and grit. Pat leaves behind her dad, Dennis, her mom, Esther, her brothers, sisters, nieces, nephews and many friends who counted Pat as family as well. Pat made all of us better; that was her most special gift of all. To honor her life, please send donations in Pat's name to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation. To celebrate her life, there will be a gathering of family and friends on November 9, time and place to be announced. Suffice it to say, it, like our Pat, will be special.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOXIE, R. GORDON, PH.D.
description: HOXIE-R. Gordon, Ph.D. The Board of Trustees, the Board of Editors, and the members of the Center for the Study of the Presidency mourn with deep sadness the passing of their Founder, President and Chairman Emeritus, Dr. R. Gordon Hoxie. A graduate of the Air War College, Dr. Hoxie earned a BA in History in 1940 from the University of Northern Iowa, in Cedar Falls; a Masters of Arts from the University of Wisconsin; and a Ph.D. in History from Columbia University in 1950. In the mid 1950s, with the help of Marjorie Merriweather Post, Hoxie founded the C.W. Post College on Long Island. A retired Brig. General in the United States Air Force and former Chancellor of Long Island University in New York, Hoxie was well known in senior government circles. In 1968 he founded the non-partisan Center for the Study of the Presidency as a forum on the institution of the U.S. Presidency, and established the Presidential Studies Quarterly as a resource and archive for historians and Presidential scholars. Most importantly, Hoxie was deeply committed to the leadership development of young men and women. For this purpose he established the Annual Student Symposium at which college student leaders from around the nation and abroad came to interact with government leaders and other senior level specialists on issues instrumental to the American Presidency. The Center Fellows Program, which grew out of the Symposium, gave selected students additional in-depth opportunities to pursue their own research. Hoxie was a visionary who served his country and his colleagues with distinction.

She was 50. The cause was cancer, friends said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, THOMAS B.
description: ROSS-Thomas B. The employees of Loral Space & Communications express their deepest sorrow over the death of their dear friend and colleague, Tom Ross. Vice President of Government Relations for Loral since 1995, Tom brought intelligence, style, clear-sightedness, integrity and a wealth of experience to the tasks he performed for the company. In his own words, he ''cobbled together'' a rich and interesting life, with significant stints as a newspaper reporter, an official in the Carter and Clinton administrations, a bestselling author and a corporate public relations officer. An elegant writer and terrific storyteller, Tom was admired and loved by all the employees lucky enough to work with him. He spoke with pride of his wife and three daughters and was delightted to be a grandfather. We join Tom's family and friends in mourning the loss of this wonderful man. He had a great run. Funeral Mass to be held Friday, November 8, at 9 AM, Church of St. Thomas More, 89th and Madison. Contributions in Tom's memory may be made to Yale University, Class of 1951 Memorial Scholarship Fund, 265 Church Street, Suite 300, New Haven, CT. 06520. Bernard L. Schwartz, Chairman and the employees of Loral Space & Communications

Theories abound, but many chalk it up to little more than the type of bad luck that has to end sooner or later. It will, they say, have to be the right time for the right horse, a horse like Vindication.

title: Corrections

title: A Voting Bloc Without a Party

One of the poorest communities in the state, they are traditionally one of the most left-leaning in the country. Yet a recent poll by The New York Times shows that among Hispanics the governor is in a statistical dead heat with his rival, H. Carl McCall, and insiders predict that he could win as much as 40 percent to 45 percent of the Latino vote.

title: Corrections

title: Where the Jobs Are
description: Only two fields dominate the top of the Labor Departments list of fastest-growing occupations over the rest of this decade: health care and computers  including the software that drives them and the networks that link them. But a look at the areas that will add the greatest numbers of jobs gives a different view. Here, lower-paying service jobs, like those at fast-food restaurants or in retail sales, top the list alongside the better paying jobs in computers and health care. The job market also varies significantly from state to state, and more surprisingly, perhaps, can vary widely even between nearby cities in the same state. nly two fields dominate the top of the Labor Departments list of fastest-growing occupations over the rest of this decade: health care and computers  including the software that drives them and the networks that link them. title: Political Notebook; Bush Juggles the Roles of Leader and Cheerleader
description: Every modern American president is forced to learn the art of switching rhetorical modes, from the stern tones of leader-of-the-free-world to the folksy approachability of a political cheerleader. But now, as he approaches two critical moments in the next 10 days -- a decision on whether to go it alone in Iraq and a midterm election that seems certain to determine the broad strokes of his presidency for the next two years -- George W. Bush is flipping that switch every few hours.

description: Blitzes came from all directions when the Giants played Seattle last month, relentless and unpredictable. There was so much pressure from the Seahawks, Giants guard Rich Seubert said afterward, that he had no idea what was happening even when standing in the middle of it.

title: Player Collapses After Game
description: Chaos erupted in the Seattle locker room after today's game when receiver Darrell Jackson, who sustained a concussion in the fourth quarter, fell to the training room floor, curled into a ball and had a seizure.

title: Fighting Back, Palm Presents 2 New Devices
description: The hand-held computer-maker Palm, seeking to bolster its shrinking but still dominant market share, plans today to announce two new portable devices aimed at corporate users.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Escaped Prisoner Caught
description: An escaped prisoner, missing since Friday and the 32nd prisoner to slip away from police custody this year, was arrested yesterday in a subway station at 116th Street and Eighth Avenue in Manhattan, the police said. The prisoner, Linda Vega, 39, left, told the police on Friday that she was a heroin addict suffering withdrawal. She was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center for treatment and handcuffed in the hospital room, but freed herself and walked out of Bellevue unnoticed, the police said. The officer guarding Ms. Vega, Gerard Norum, was suspended without pay. Ms. Vega was arrested Wednesday on charges that she entered a Midtown apartment, threatened a resident with a hypodermic needle and demanded money. Another prisoner, April Brown, 35, also escaped Friday but surrendered to the police later that day. Marc Santora (NYT)

title: Mexico Plans Deal With Tokyo
description: Japanese and Mexican trade officials said today that they were prepared to open free trade negotiations.

title: Spiezio Leads Angels With His Eyes Closed
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 27  After Scott Spiezio hit a towering three-run homer off Felix Rodriguez on Saturday night to start the greatest comeback for a team facing elimination in the World Series, he returned to the raucous Anaheim Angels' dugout, somehow found a quiet seat, closed his eyes and looked as if he was meditating. Later, Spiezio admitted he was.

title: Metro Matters; The Governor, Same Time, Other Channel
description: THIS column normally avoids making political endorsements. Not its job.

title: A Nuclear Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: Team-by-Team Preview
description: KEY: (T) Trade, (FA) Free Agent, (D) Draft, (W) Waivers, (I) Injury (R) Retired

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: TRENTON: E-ZPASS OPERATOR TO BE NAMED The state has a tentative agreement with a Washington firm to manage New Jersey's troubled E-ZPass toll system at a cost of $45 million a year for a decade. The deal with the firm, ACS State and Local Government Solutions, is expected to be announced today, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported. ACS will be the third company contracted by the state to run the system. The agreement calls for the E-ZPass systems on the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway to be merged into one violations and customer service center. The state still owes $300 million for construction of the system, which has been plagued with problems since it was installed. (AP)

title: Sorting Out the Leadership Puzzle at Citigroup
description: Sanford I. Weill, the chairman and chief executive of Citigroup, is working quickly to resolve investigations into research practices at its investment banking unit, inquiries that have threatened to tarnish his reputation as the builder of the nation's largest financial services company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOUNT, WINTON M.
description: BLOUNT-Winton M. A hero of the American Theatre, Founder of the Alabama Shakespeare Festival and President of the Board of National Actors Theatre. The great American. Tony Randall and National Actors Theatre

title: Baker Doesn't Regret Giving Ball to Ortiz
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 27  Giants Manager Dusty Baker let starting pitcher Russ Ortiz keep the ball as a souvenir when he removed him in the seventh inning of Game 6. The Giants led, 5-0, but went on to lose the game, and the Angels noticed Baker's gesture.

title: How to Fix the Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Court to Hear Arguments in Groundbreaking Case of U.S. Citizen Seized With Taliban
description: Yasser Esam Hamdi, an American-born Saudi Arabian who was captured on the battlefield in Afghanistan, has been in solitary confinement in Virginia for more than six months. Sitting incommunicado in his windowless cell, he has inadvertently emerged as a central figure in a classic legal clash between national security and civil liberties.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Iraq's Jails, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: TOMORROWLAND NO MORE
description: The Anaheim Angels have long represented a franchise that exemplified futility with so many awful teams, with some memorable teams that had ugly collapses and with an ignominious past that almost rivaled the gloomy histories of the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago Cubs. But, in the Angels' 42nd season, something magical happened to the team owned by Disney. It finally won a World Series title.

title: How to Fix the Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Election Wonders
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons in Hatred
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Story of Caviar, All Is Not Wine and Roses
description: CAVIAR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSHENSON, SYLVIA
description: GERSHENSON - Sylvia. Of Melville, NY, formerly of Merrick, NY, on October 26, 2002. Loving and beloved mother of Stephen and Diane Gershenson of Boca Raton, FL, and Deedee and Dick King of Kansas City, Missouri. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Appel, Alison Appel, Amy Ross, Adam Gershenson, Marjorie Posada, Mary King, Suzanne Raney and Allen King. Great-grandmother of Jancyn Appel and Jacob Ross. Funeral service Monday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's Inc.,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice Care Network or a charity of your choice.

title: Biztech : Safety at your fingertips:EU breaks ground
description: PARIS  Instead of having to punch a code into an automated teller machine, imagine if the machine accepted or rejected the transaction based on a fingerprint. That is one of the ideas behind the FingerCard project, a program funded by the European Community that concluded in Brussels this month.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Government Spin: The Word Is Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Veteran Battles Charge He's Soft on Defense
description: The last thing anyone expected Senator Max Cleland, Democrat of Georgia, to face in his first re-election campaign was a challenge to his patriotism. Mr. Cleland, who led the Veterans Administration under President Jimmy Carter, lost both legs and his right arm to a grenade in Vietnam.

title: Doleac Is A Solid Presence
description: Michael Doleac's signing by the Knicks as a low-priced free agent this summer hardly made a ripple next to the draft-day deal that brought Antonio McDyess to New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: LIEBOWITZ-William. 83, of Purchase, NY, on October 26, 2002. Beloved husband of Estelle, devoted father of Sherry Moran, Howard Liebowitz, M.D., and Lauren Coffman, and five grandchildren. He was devoted and dedicated for 58 years as a CPA in his private practice. Services on Tuesday, 10 AM, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle. Interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Name That Tune, From Your Cellphone
description: European phone companies have bet billions on new wireless networks in the hope that consumers will pay for video and other fancy multimedia services. But a start-up company here, Shazam Entertainment, is attracting attention and customers with a music-searching service that runs on the most basic of cellphones.

title: Magazines; With advertising in deep distress, publishers consider an end to the era of cheap subscriptions.
description: TO entice consumers to part with their hard-earned money at the newsstand, magazine publishers jam their covers with words and images that promise the cover price is worth every penny. But when it comes to subscription offers inside and elsewhere, the message is altogether different.

title: Hernndez Can't Find His Postseason Magic
description: In the upcoming weeks and months, if the half brothers Livn and Orlando Hernndez choose to reflect on the baseball season that ended in heartbreak for both of them, they will know just whom to blame.

title: Coke Sign Goes Dark in Times Square
description: After 11 years of teasing parched New Yorkers, the animated Coca-Cola sign in Times Square is dark. Workers began removing thousands of light bulbs and other small parts of the sign last week, and today they will start to dismantle the large sections. The company is closely guarding designs for a more advanced sign, which will be built there in 2003.

title: Democrats Looking To Familiar Face In Minnesota Race
description: On Tuesday night, 20,000 people will gather here to memorialize Senator Paul Wellstone with speeches, songs and video eulogies. One day later, party officials said today, the state Democratic Party will meet and almost certainly pluck from retirement a man whose name is synonymous with Minnesota political history -- Walter F. Mondale -- to fill an empty spot on the Democratic line.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOM, RICHARD C.
description: BLOOM-Richard C. Beloved father of Jesse and Nicole. Adored son of Beverly and Alfred. Loving brother of Lawrence and Jeane. Cherished uncle of Katie and Jacob. Rest in peace, our gentle giant. Services Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLANTZ, EDITH ''GROM.''
description: GLANTZ-Edith ''Grom.'' October 26, 2002, at age 87, surrounded by her loving children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Her memory and recipes will live forever. The Glantz, Post, Hodas, Federico and Foncello families would appreciate donations to Jansen Memorial Hospice, 69 Main St, Tuckahoe, NY 10707.

title: 'In Material Breach'
description: If the U.N Security Council fails to adopt a resolution holding Iraq ''in material breach'' of its many disarmament agreements, that refusal will have consequences for the U.N. and several of its member nations.

title: Palestinian Subdued and Shot, Yet His Bomb Kills 3
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber killed three Israelis and himself today when his explosive blew up at a gas station at this Israeli settlement. The explosion came after the man was first subdued and then shot by soldiers.

title: Dr. Milton Terris, 87, Editor and Public Health Expert
description: Dr. Milton Terris, who founded the National Association for Public Health Policy and the Society for Epidemiological Research, died on Oct. 3 at his home in South Burlington, Vt. He was 87.

title: Crash Investigators Reconstruct Flight of Wellstone's Plane
description: The investigation of the plane crash that killed Senator Paul Wellstone and seven others reached a ''very difficult stage,'' today, with investigators now searching by hand through ash and debris, said Carol Carmody, the acting chairwoman of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: INSIDE
description: Mexico Disagrees on Iraq

title: Burden Grows On Services For Teenagers
description: Recent changes in state law are expected to double the number of parents requesting government help with their runaway, truant or delinquent teenagers, straining child welfare services at a time of budget cuts.

title: Team-by-Team Preview
description: KEY: (T) Trade, (FA) Free Agent, (D) Draft, (W) Waivers, (I) Injury (R) Retired

title: Smith Races Past Payton's Career Rushing Record
description: Once Emmitt Smith had become the National Football League's career leading rusher, after he had received so many handshakes and hugs and cheers, he finally found a spot alone on the Dallas bench and placed a towel over his face. And he kept it there for a while, a proud man alone with his thoughts, tuning out the world while others still tuned in.

title: Essex County's Top Official Arrested on Corruption Charges
description: NEWARK, Oct. 28 — The Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, who was the front-runner in the Republican Senate primary until he quit the race in April, was arrested today on federal corruption charges.

title: RESERVE CALL-UP FOR AN IRAQ WAR MAY EQUAL 1991'S
description: If President Bush orders an attack against Iraq, the Pentagon has plans to mobilize roughly as many reservists as it did during the Persian Gulf war in 1991, when about 265,000 members of the National Guard and Reserves were summoned to active duty, administration officials and military experts say.

title: Thomas B. Ross, 73, Author And Defense Spokesman
description: Thomas B. Ross, a journalist and best-selling author of books on military intelligence who later became the spokesman for the Pentagon in the Carter administration, died Thursday at Eastern Long Island Hospital. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan and Shelter Island Heights, N.Y.

title: Poet Is Viewed As a Calm Fit For Arts Post
description: Announcing an intention to nominate a new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts is the White House's way of floating a name to see if it engenders controversy or brings skeletons out of the closet.

title: Rookie Lackey Saves Best For Last
description: The last time a rookie started the seventh game of the World Series, in 1997, John Lackey had just graduated from Abilene High School in Texas, where he played first base and did not pitch at all. He looked up to Nolan Ryan, another right-hander from Texas, but when Lackey imagined himself in the World Series, he was in a batter's box, not on a mound.

title: From the Card Table to the Editor's Desk
description: Bridge writers around the world, thirsty for news and interesting deals, rely considerably on the monthly Bulletin issued by the International Bridge Press Association. The Bulletin's editor, Patrick Jourdain of Wales, retired in August after 20 years of distinguished service and was succeeded by John Carruthers of Toronto. Both have represented their countries on many occasions.

title: Fair Trials in Security Cases
description: The Bush administration finds itself in a bind in its case against the accused terrorist Zacarias Moussaoui. Several Al Qaeda operatives captured recently may be able to provide testimony vital to Mr. Moussaoui. But the government is declining to make them available, on national security grounds. A related issue has emerged in the case of another accused terrorist, Jose Padilla, where prosecutors are refusing to make available all the evidence against him. In both cases, the courts should order that with the proper safeguards, defendants' lawyers be given access to the evidence at issue.

title: Schwab takes another kind of swipe at the big Wall Street firms in a new campaign.
description: THE last set of ads from the Charles Schwab Corporation made executives at Wall Street brokerage firms angry. The next campaign might just make them cry.

title: How to Fix the Nursing Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Angels Pitch to Bonds, And It's Kryptonite
description: In the end, Barry Bonds was not the superman, big S or little s, the Anaheim Angels believed him to be. As awesome as they thought he was, and as he was at times, Bonds was merely mortal last night, and the San Francisco Giants were unable to overcome the pestiferous band of Angels hitters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPALEK, IRENE LERNER SOLOVAY
description: OPALEK-Irene Lerner Solovay. Died peacefully on October 25 at her home in Yuma, AZ, at the age of 94. Beloved mother of Norman and Mark Solovay, mother-in-law of Eleanor and Kathryn Solovay. She was the very devoted and adored grandmother of Michael Solovay, Elizabeth Solovay Goldburg, Sondra Solovay and Matthew Solovay, and great-grandmother of Charlie, Samantha, Sarah, Robert, Harry and Jack. Services Monday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Mt. Judah Cemetery, Glendale, NY.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column in The Arts on Thursday, about couples who are both writers, misstated the surname of the author who committed suicide after the breakup of her relationship with the poet Ted Hughes. She was Sylvia Plath, not Path.

title: Angels Defeat Giants and Win World Series
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 27  The Anaheim Angels have long represented a franchise that exemplified futility with so many awful teams, with some memorable teams that had ugly collapses and with an ignominious past that almost rivaled the gloomy histories of the Boston Red Sox and the Chicago Cubs. But, in the Angels' 42nd season, something magical happened to the team owned by Disney. It finally won a World Series title.

title: Finance Chief Is Leaving McCann
description: Salvatore LaGreca, the vice chairman and chief financial officer at the McCann-Erickson World Group in New York, has decided to step down, effective in the first quarter of 2003.

title: Game Delays Tough Decisions for Giants
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.

title: Southeast Asia Remains Fertile For Al Qaeda
description: The terrorist network that Osama bin Laden has stealthily built up in Southeast Asia over the past decade is largely intact, intelligence officials in several countries said in interviews over the last week. It may even have become more deadly and more virulently anti-American than it was a year ago, they say.

title: Hostage Toll in Russia Over 100; Nearly All Deaths Linked to Gas
description: The number of hostages who died as a result of a raid on a Moscow theater jumped to 117 today, as more people succumbed to the effects of a debilitating gas that Russian security forces used as they stormed the building being held by Chechen guerrillas.

title: The Sounds of War
description: To the Editor:

title: The Survivors Dribble Out, All With a Story to Tell
description: It had been quiet for hours when Lyudmila Fedyantseva noticed that a man in the theater of 763 hostages was on the verge of a breakdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OBERMAN, ISAAC M.
description: OBERMAN-Isaac M. 81, of NY and FL, died Friday, October 25, 2002, in Coral Springs FL. Ike was born in the Bronx, a legend in the insurance industry, and led the Oberman Companies for over 55 years. Mr. Oberman was a champion in the fight for the establishment of the State of Israel as National VP of the ZOA. He is preceded in death by his wife Barbara Oberman (Chaskin) and brother Philip. He is survived by his second wife Regina, his brothers Gus and Sol, his children Susan, Arlene and Stuart; his sons-inlaw Herb Gelbart, Robert Brenner and daughter-in-law Paula; grandchildren Sharon, Keith, Marcia, David, Lauren, Rachel, Justin and Derek; great-grandson Jeffrey and stepchildren Barry, Dorie, Neal and Brian. Contributions may be sent to ZOA, or Yad Avraham Institute.

title: Afghans Lead World Again In Poppy Crop
description: Opium production in Afghanistan soared to near-record levels in 2002, making the war-ravaged country again the world's leading producer of the drug, according to a United Nations estimate released on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ALFRED
description: LERNER-Alfred. The President and Trustees of Columbia University in the City of New York express deep sorrow at the passing of Alfred Lerner, a member of the Columbia College class of 1955. He was a respected colleague whose leadership as vice chair of the Trustees was marked by exceptional insight, unfailing decency, and dedication to his alma mater. Alfred Lerner Hall, Columbia's innovative student center, was made possible by his generosity to the University. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his wife, Mrs. Norma Lerner, his son Randy, his daughter Nancy, and to his seven grandchildren. Lee C. Bollinger, President of the University David J. Stern, Chair of the Trustees

title: Little Things Mean a Lot To the Council
description: Imagine this: Public restrooms come equipped with clean, well-lighted diapering stations, and taxis carry child safety seats in their trunks. Young people suddenly eschew metal baseball bats, as well as toy guns that could be made to look real. Trucks stick to their designated routes, never idle and glide quietly over those metal plates in the asphalt.

title: Is Heather O'Reilly the Next Mia Hamm?
description: There is no doubt, the girl can play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEARNE, ALSTAN STEPHEN (CHIP)
description: HEARNE - Alstan Stephen (Chip). Beloved husband of Leslie (nee Shulman). Funeral services at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., NYC, Tuesday, 5:30 PM to 6:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Holding Swing Vote, Mexico Tells Bush It Won't Support Iraq Resolution U.S. Favors
description: President Bush left a summit conference here today without a pledge from Mexico to support the American resolution in the United Nations Security Council to disarm Iraq.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday about the selection of Deborah Treisman as fiction editor of The New Yorker misstated the background of Patrick Chamaoiseau, a writer she has translated. He lives in Martinique and is French-Caribbean, not French.

title: Stewart Keeps His Points Lead in the Rain
description: Atlanta Motor Speedway officials persuaded Nascar this year to change the date of the NAPA 500 from its spot as the final race on the Winston Cup schedule, where it had been since 1996, to today because of recurring rain problems. It did not help.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTA, DINO
description: COSTA-Dino. On October 26, 2002. Native of Varsi, Italy. Beloved husband of Anita (nee Trombetti). Loving father of Clara Carley (Brennan), Dino (Clare), and Sandra Caruso (Michael). Cherished grandfather of nine grandchildren. Also survived by a sister, Carla, and many nieces and nephews. Family will be present 7-9 PM, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday, at F. Ruggiero and Sons, Inc, 726 Morris Park Ave. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's. In lieu of flowers the family prefers donations be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave.

title: What's on Tina Brown's Mind? British Are Finding Out
description: In her first outing as a columnist writing from New York for The Times of London, Tina Brown casually described Gerald M. Levin, the former chief executive of AOL Time Warner, as a ''hamsterish figure,'' and disclosed that Robert Hughes, Time magazine's art critic and a disgruntled post-merger employee, had sent an e-mail message to Mr. Levin saying: ''How can I convey to you the disgust which your name awakens in me?''

title: The Jets Could Kick Themselves (But You Know It'd Be No Good)
description: John Abraham sat at his locker afterward and seethed. John Hall's 44-yard field goal attempt to send the game against Cleveland into overtime had been blocked by Courtney Brown and Alvin McKinley with 24 seconds left. But it was that the Jets needed a field goal to save a game they had led by 21-3 -- and essentially to save the season, too -- that was so galling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPHRAIM, EDWARD H.
description: EPHRAIM-Edward H. 65, of Norwalk, CT, died October 25, 2002, after a courageous battle with cancer. Devoted husband of Hope, son of Frank, loving father of Jennifer. Memorial service Tuesday, October 29, at Congregation Agudath Shalom in Stamford, CT, 301 Strawberry Hill Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan - Kettering, American Cancer Society or Hospice.

title: Chevy Gets the Faith
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAINSWIT, SEYMOUR
description: SHAINSWIT - Seymour. Passed away peacefully on October 26, 2002, at the age of 82, of lymphoma. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Justice Beatrice Shainswit of the New York State Supreme Court, and his brother Bernard. He was a graduate of the City College of New York and of New York University Law School, and a distinguished member of the Bar Association of the City of New York, the New York State Bar Association, and the American Bar Association. He was the finest and most brilliant of commercial and libel litigators, a man who loved the law, and an honor to the bar. Services will be on Monday, October 28, 2002, at 11:45 AM, at The Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. His sweetness, warmth, and love will be with us forever.

title: More Hormone Perplexities
description: The National Institutes of Health held a two-day conference last week to explore what women and doctors should think about hormone replacement therapy in the wake of test results showing that prolonged use can do more harm than good. By the end of the event, it seemed clear that women are faced with even more perplexing choices than anyone had realized.

title: Not the Usual Pattern
description: Working as a team. Killing at a distance. Striking at random. If convicted, the two held in the sniper shootings will add a highly peculiar chapter to the already saturated history of the serial killer.

title: Police Seeking Motive in Killing
description: A Brooklyn resident whose naked and battered body was found in the trunk of a car in Philadelphia on Saturday was described by neighbors as an attractive young woman who kept largely to herself.

title: A Quartet That Defies Expectations
description: Concert Artists Guild has been lucky with new-music ensembles lately. A few years ago the superb Eighth Blackbird won its annual competition, and on Tuesday evening its season at Weill Recital Hall opened with Antares, a high-energy quartet from Connecticut that won a first prize last year.
