title: From Offenbach to Athleticism, Ballet Theater Shows Its Eclectic Nature
description: As the final novelties of its season, American Ballet Theater presented ''Concerto No. 1 for Piano and Orchestra,'' a plotless new work by Robert Hill, and ''Offenbach in the Underworld,'' a revival of the sly belle poque ballet that Antony Tudor created in the mid 1950's.

title: White House Letter; A Politician in the White House (Gasp!) Hits His Stride
description: According to the official rules of the second Bush White House, where there is only good policy and nothing as unseemly as politics, Ken Mehlman shouldn't exist. But here he is, with the audacious title of White House political director, a man who not only lives and breathes but seems to have an awful lot to do.

title: Latinos Are Focus of New Brand of Ads
description: Commercial breaks during ''Despierta America,'' a wacky, popular morning show on Spanish-language television, are usually full of pitches for American products, everything from coffee to detergent. Now, a new brand name has made a frequent appearance: the American politician.

title: James J. Murray, 76, a Director of Catholic Charities in New York
description: Msgr. James J. Murray, the executive director of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York from 1973 to 2000, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Marvin A. Krauss, 74, Manager For Numerous Broadway Shows
description: Marvin A. Krauss, one of Broadway's leading general managers, whose career spanned more than four decades and nearly 100 shows, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: State Comptroller
description: With New York State facing grim financial realities, the state comptroller's job will be crucial in the years to come. Fortunately, the two top candidates, Alan Hevesi, the Democrat, and John Faso, the Republican, are able and decent public servants. This is the best statewide race in what is generally a dismal year for New York politics.

title: Frampton to Phish: New Breed of Live Albums
description: Calling Kiss's 1975 album ''Alive!'' a concert collection is one of rock's favorite inside jokes. After all, says the producer Eddie Kramer, the original concert tapes were so tuneless that the only genuine live tracks on the album are the drums. But the album's dubious origins did not stop ''Alive'' from cracking Billboard's Top 10 and giving the heavy metal band its first Top 20 single.

title: 2 Paces in New Jersey Race: Underdog and Front-Runner
description: The last full week before the election of a new United States senator from New Jersey opened today with Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican underdog, piling on more and more campaigning while Frank R. Lautenberg, the Democrat, followed the leisurely pace of a front-runner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day last Monday about the selection of Deborah Treisman as fiction editor of The New Yorker misstated the background of Patrick Chamaoiseau, a writer she has translated. He lives in Martinique and is French-Caribbean, not French.

title: Bush, on Campaign Trail, Faults U.N. on Iraq
description: DENVER, Oct. 28  President Bush used two campaign appearances today to turn up pressure on the United Nations just days ahead of its vote on Iraq, arguing that Saddam Hussein had made the organization look "foolish" and questioning whether the Security Council had "the will or the courage" to enforce its own resolutions.

title: ABC-CNN Talks Could Leave CBS the Odd Network Out
description: Soon, CBS News could be looking small indeed.

title: Focus on Antigua Passport
description: The prime minister of Antigua, Lester Bird, named a task force today to investigate how John Allen Muhammad, an American citizen being held in the sniper killings, obtained an Antiguan passport.

title: Light-Emitting Silicon Shines Much Brighter in New Invention
description: STMicroelectronics plans to announce a breakthrough on Monday in light-emitting silicon that could lead to a new generation of more powerful computing processors and more efficient automobile components as well as potentially higher-speed optical data-transmission systems.

title: A Writer's Tale Is Victorian; His Past, Gothic
description: Something terrible happened a long time ago to Michel Faber, the author of ''The Crimson Petal and the White.'' He is not sure what it was -- he has few memories before the age of 7, he said -- but he knows that things were so turbulent in his family that his mother severed ties with her two older children, his half-brother and half-sister, and still refuses to discuss them.

title: The Slaughter in Moscow
description: In the eight years that they have wrestled over control of Chechnya, the Russian government and Chechen rebels have descended ever deeper into a hellhole of brutish behavior. The two sides reached a new low over the weekend in their deadly showdown at a crowded Moscow theater that a band of heavily armed rebels had seized earlier in the week. The number of dead hostages and rebels is still being tallied, but it is already abundantly clear that the rebels and government forces once again disgraced themselves. The Kremlin and the guerrillas should come to their senses and settle a conflict that has left thousands of civilians dead and shamed Russian and Chechen leaders alike.

title: Election Officials Are Braced For Big Problems at the Polls
description: Two years after the election fiasco in Florida, when hanging chads in the deadlocked presidential contest alerted the world to major flaws in how Americans vote, the states have made little progress in overhauling their election systems.

title: The Scare Factor
description: Keeping with tradition, Hollywood has introduced a horror film for Halloween in this case Warner Brothers ''Ghost Ship,'' which took in $11.7 million at the box office over the past weekend. A week earlier, DreamWorks released ''The Ring,'' a horror film that has grossed $39.7 million.

title: A TV House Divided; A Debate on Skipping Ads at AOL Time Warner
description: The future of television has finally arrived -- really. Now begins the haggling over who gets control, and negotiations with the highest stakes are taking place inside AOL Time Warner.

title: G.O.P. Candidate Is Treading Warily After Months of Attacking Incumbent
description: Waiting for his turn on a local television program this morning, Norm Coleman, the Republican Senate nominee, clutched his wife's hands in both of his while they stared, eyes filled, at a video tribute to his dead opponent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEL, DR. NINA
description: RUDEL-Dr. Nina. Died in NYC on October 26, 2002, in her 91st year. Dearest friend and family. In the 1960s she headed the Child Health Centers in NYC. Her great interest in literature resulted in forming a book club at the Elmhurst Library which enriched the lives of many. She will be greatly missed and lovingly remembered. Services at Parkside Funeral Chapel, Queens, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Tuesday, 1:30 PM.

title: Stress Just Part of the Test for Selective High Schools
description: Some gobbled down scrambled eggs, others guzzled orange juice and a few went into the two-and-half-hour exam with their stomachs growling. While many studied test strategies for months, others just had their mothers quiz them on the way to school.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, THOMAS B.
description: ROSS-Thomas B. Funeral Mass 9 AM, Friday, November 8th, at St. Thomas More's Church, 65 East 89th St., NYC, followed by reception, 11 AM. For location, phone 212751-1029.

title: A Composer Fascinated by a Lot of Styles
description: The Boston composer Lee Hyla writes works that deftly blend expressionistic, complex contemporary atonal idioms with elements of avant-garde jazz, rock and even punk. But this description, though true as far as it goes, does not begin to convey the ingenious skill and sheer originality of Mr. Hyla's music: for example his brilliant Concerto for Piano and Chamber Orchestra No. 2, a 1991 work that ended the first half of the all-Hyla program presented by Miller Theater on Wednesday night, the second in its Composer Portraits series.

title: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Angels Beat Giants And Win the Series
description: The Anaheim Angels, who were playing in the World Series for the first time in their 42-season history, won their first championship last night by beating the San Francisco Giants, 4-1, in Game 7.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHREIER, LEONARD J.
description: SCHREIER - Leonard J. March 25, 1934, to October 28, 2001. You are with me and I with you always. Be at peace. All my love, Jan

title: The Angry Appeal of Eminem Is Cutting Across Racial Lines
description: The Bronx River Houses are hallowed ground in the hip-hop world, one of the neighborhoods where young African-Americans and Hispanics helped create a new art form in the 1970's. The housing project in the South Bronx takes its heritage seriously. From there emerged a founder of hip-hop, Afrika Bambaataa, and the loose-knit group of D.J.'s, dancers, graffiti artists and rappers called Zulu Nation.

title: Eat, Drink and Bid: Wine Auction Finds a Menu for Success
description: Zachys re-entered New York's wine auction arena over the weekend in an inaugural sale whose form, longtime collectors said, could reshape America's commercial wine auctions.

title: Purchase of Civil War Site Saves It for History
description: The Trust for Public Land, a preservation group, is expected to announce today that it will buy Murphy Farm, site of the decisive engagement in Gen. Stonewall Jackson's capture of Harper's Ferry in 1862, and turn it over to the Harper's Ferry National Historic Park.

title: Lose a Vote, Gain a Vote
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Evidence of Ancient Indian Disease
description: Native American health may have been deteriorating for centuries before 1492.

title: From the Easel, A Surgical View
description: Dr. Joe Wilder was a successful surgeon and painter. These images are from his new book, "Life in the Operating Room."

title: The 2002 World Series
description: Anaheim beat San Francisco 4-1 in the decisive seventh game.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Regional Trade Proposal
description: Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji is hoping to persuade Asian leaders to set up a regional free-trade agreement at an economic meeting next week, Chinese officials said. China presented the free-trade plan to leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations to counter regional concerns that China's booming economy has drawn investment away from its neighbors. The trade plan would encourage greater integration, officials said. Regional leaders will consider a final draft of a so-called framework agreement at a meeting in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, next week. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: In Nassau, Campaign Uses 9/11 In TV Ad
description: The father of a World Trade Center victim who has made tighter immigration controls a personal quest will appear in a televised political advertisement this week, endorsing a Nassau County Republican candidate for Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLIND, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: BLIND-William Charles. Died at home in Lancaster, PA. on October 26, 2002 after a long illness. Also a resident of Kennebunkport, ME. and Beaufort, S.C. Born in Chicago May 18, 1911 to Josephine K. and William A. Blind. Graduated from the University of Notre Dame 1932 and Harvard Law School, 1935. He was a long-term partner of Kelley, Drye and Warren, New York City. He was a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in WWII. He was a member of The New York Yacht Club, The Mid-Ocean Club-Bermuda, Kennebunk River Club, The Cape Arundel Golf Club and The Webhannet Golf Club, Maine. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Peggy A. Blind (nee Kauffman), his brother Robert J. Blind of Colorado, two children, William C. Blind, Jr. of New York City and Anne C. Cook, also of New York City, four grandchildren, Rebecca C. Blind, Burroughs Blind, Cutler Cook and Crosby Cook. Services will be held Saturday, November 2nd, 2PM at Saint Leo the Great Catholic Church, Lancaster, PA. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Hospice of Lancaster County, POB 4125, 685 Good Dr., Lancaster PA 17604-4125.

title: Connecticut Underdog Attacks, But Rowland Sticks to the Script
description: In the last of four debates in the governor's race today, William E. Curry Jr., a Democrat who is far behind in the polls, rained one criticism after another on Gov. John G. Rowland, the two-term Republican, who mostly held his ground.

title: As Season Draws Near, Dolan Is Still Optimistic
description: James L. Dolan made his first trip to the new practice facility for the Knicks and the Rangers today, making his way through the cavernous jumble of basketball courts and offices. In the back rooms he spied Latrell Sprewell working out, and when he stepped onto the brightly lit courts, he got a close-up look at just what $94 million buys these days.

title: The Game's Go-To Guys
description: Chris Webber looked at Mike Bibby during a huddle late last May and told Bibby, a 24-year-old guard, he was going to give him the ball in the final seconds against the Los Angeles Lakers. The pressure immediately shifted from a perennial All-Star to a youngster deep on the right wing, about to take the biggest shot in the history of the Sacramento Kings.

title: An Uneasy Wait in Oklahoma
description: Workers at the General Motors plant here wore red-white-and-blue ribbons today for their colleague Sandy Alan Booker, who was feared dead in the siege that ended the occupation of a Moscow theater by Chechen rebels.

title: C.B. Sheldon, 76, Skipper in a Noted Sinking
description: Christopher B. Sheldon, whose 92-foot twin-masted sailing ship Albatross sank in a freak storm in 1961, a disaster that inspired the 1996 movie ''White Squall,'' died on Oct. 5 in Stamford, Conn. He was 76 and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Hartford School Superintendent Resigns After Rocky 3 Years
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 28  Anthony S. Amato, the superintendent of Hartford's troubled school system, abruptly resigned today, ending a rocky three-and-a-half-year tenure in which he raised abysmally low test scores but alienated some educators and city officials by openly seeking more prestigious job offers elsewhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINES, FAY SHIRLEY
description: MINES-Fay Shirley. The American Jewish Committee extends heartfelt condolences to Herbert Mines, officer and devoted member of our Board of Governors, on the death of his beloved mother. We convey our deepest regrets to the entire family. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Exec Dir

title: Man Shot in Harlem Recalled as One Who Held His Ground
description: More than two years ago, a jury acquitted Wardel Strong on charges of attempted murder.

title: Milton Turner, 39
description: Stock Clerk, Home Depot, Tulsa, Okla.

title: Draft Charter for Europe Points the Way to a Bigger World Role
description: A draft constitution for an enlarged European Union was unveiled today, pointing the way toward creating a greater European presence on the world stage. But as it heads there, Europe has to decide on a name.

title: Not Idols Yet, Just Practicing
description: The competition is over and the merchandising has begun for ''American Idol,'' which was a much better name for a television series than ''The World's Longest Audition.'' Kelly Clarkson, who won the recording contract, and the Fox network show's other nine finalists are now touring. The package came to Nassau Coliseum here tonight for an audience packed with squealing young girls. Only the judges were missing.

title: Once Again, Victory Is Beyond Giants' Grasp
description: The hands of angry Giants reached for Philadelphia quarterback Donovan McNabb tonight, skimming his arms, brushing his back. But tonight, he was the ghost they could not grab.

title: TENET HEALTHCARE SHARES FALL AFTER RATING IS CUT
description: Shares of the Tenet Healthcare Corporation fell 14 percent yesterday after an analyst cut his rating on the stock because of concern about government health care reimbursements to Tenet. The company said its profit outlook had not changed. Shares of Tenet, one of the largest hospital companies in the nation, fell $6.81, to $42.50. Tenet is more dependent than its rivals are on special Medicare payments for patients whose treatments cost much more than the average, a UBS Warburg analyst, Kenneth Weakley, said in a note to investors. Tenet's estimate of at least 25 percent growth in per-share profit in fiscal year 2003 takes into account a cut in the special Medicare payments, the company said after the market closed. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., also left its forecasts for periods after 2003 unchanged.

title: The Post-Dutoit Montreal Symphony Visits Carnegie Hall
description: At the end of last season a battle between the musicians of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra and its music director, Charles Dutoit, ended with Mr. Dutoit's resignation on the eve of what was to have been a season celebrating the 25th anniversary of his association with the orchestra. But life goes on: the orchestra quickly instituted a search for Mr. Dutoit's successor; Canadian newspapers have reported that the job will come with a $1 million salary. When the orchestra visited Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening and Sunday afternoon, it brought two conductors, Michel Plasson and Emmanuel Villaume, and programs devoted to music that had been strongly associated with Mr. Dutoit.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday and a front-page summary for an article about President Bush's visit to Mexico misstated the facts of the article, about Mexico's stance in the United Nations Security Council toward Iraq. Mexico gave President Bush no pledge to support the United States resolution in the Council. But President Vicente Fox did not tell Mr. Bush that Mexico would not support it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBOWITZ, WILLIAM
description: LIEBOWITZ - William. Bill was one of our oldest and dearest friends. He was his own man. He lived in what he believed in. Sincere condolences to his loving wife Estelle, his children Sherry, Howard and Lauren and his grandchildren. Rest in peace. We will miss you. Rita and Paul

title: Europeans Investigate Resale of AIDS Drugs
description: Law enforcement officials in at least four European countries are making steady progress in an investigation into what they say are schemes in which deeply discounted HIV and AIDS drugs meant for poor and dying patients in Africa were resold in Europe at huge profits.

title: Front Row
description: Kahlo's Costume as Signature

title: Giants Have the Ailments But Can't Find the Cure
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28  The Giants keep trying to fine-tune their offense. Kerry Collins is among the league leaders in yards per pass and probably ranked last in points per pass. They have run the ball effectively for a play or two, or even a series, but not when it counted. Tight end Jeremy Shockey would be a target if he were not limping.

title: In Hazard Suits, Preserving History's Dusty Jeans
description: A time capsule from Sept. 11, 2001, the last memorial to stand as testimony to what was left when the smoke lifted at the World Trade Center, was removed yesterday by a team of experts in respirators and hazardous-materials suits.

title: Keys to a Modestly Successful Season
description: 1 Latrell Sprewell must leave his sour feelings for the front office off the court when he returns in two weeks. If his emotions don't hamper his play, he, Allan Houston and Kurt Thomas could give the Knicks at least the hope of making the playoffs.

title: Glaxo Forms An Alliance In Biotech
description: Exelixis Inc., a biotechnology company, has entered into a broad collaboration with GlaxoSmithKline to discover and develop drugs for cancer, inflammatory diseases and disorders involving blood vessels. The deal, announced yesterday, could result in payments to Exelixis of up to several hundred million dollars.

title: U.S. Charges Essex Leader With Extortion
description: The Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, who was the leading Republican candidate for the United States Senate until his office was raided this spring, was arrested today and charged with extortion, fraud and other federal offenses.

title: The Records of Opponents Help Lift Idle Oklahoma
description: Back when college football was propelled by clichs instead of a computer hard drive, Oklahoma Coach Bob Stoops would have stopped caring about Alabama about a millisecond after his Sooners polished off the Crimson Tide on Sept. 7. Coaches were taught to look straight ahead about the same time they first picked up a whistle.

title: We Saved Your Job, But Gave You More Work
description: AS the economy struggles to revive itself and layoffs mount, companies have been trying to get more out of their workers. Businesses like Dell Computer have used the downturn as an opportunity to sharpen their competitive edge. But from the workers' perspective, a productivity drive can mean new sources of stress -- longer hours put in off the books and the fear of following laid-off colleagues out the door.

title: Officials Also Suspect Pair In Earlier West Coast Case
description: The authorities named John Muhammad and Lee Malvo tonight as suspects in the killing of a young woman here in February, placing the start of their killing spree seven months earlier than previously believed.

title: Well-Received 'Harlem Song' May Close by Week's End
description: Despite strong reviews, ''Harlem Song,'' the variety show at the Apollo Theater that chronicles Harlem's history through song, dance, photographs and film, announced yesterday that it would close at the end of the week unless $300,000 could be raised.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Lisbon; An Accessible City With an Empire in Its Past
description: In the 15th century, Portugal's empire straddled the globe, and Lisbon was one of the most important trading posts in Europe, revered for its explorers. The city center was destroyed by an earthquake in 1755 and later rebuilt by the Marqus de Pombal. He lent his name to Baixa Pombalina, the city's commercial hub, which retains much of its original character: narrow streets, wrought-iron balconies and tiled facades.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda's Profit Rises
description: Profit at the Honda Motor Company rose just 3.3 percent in the July-September quarter as a stronger yen chewed into potential gains. Honda, Japan's second-largest automaker, also said operating profit, a better gauge of the company's core business, fell 6.6 percent. Honda's sales, however, grew 9.5 percent, helped by strong demand in North America for its sport utility vehicles and minivans. Honda lowered its earning targets for the full year ending in March 2003, but still expects to post a record profit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Shares Plunge After Results Miss Forecast
description: Brocade Communications Systems shares fell more than 17 percent yesterday after the maker of switches for computer networks said fiscal fourth-quarter sales and profit rose less than it expected. Shares dropped $1.42, to $6.83. They have fallen 79 percent this year. The company said before regular trading that it earned 7 cents a share on sales of $152 million to $153 million in the quarter that ended Saturday. A year earlier, Brocade reported a net loss of $53.7 million, or 24 cents a share, on sales of $116.5 million. The company will report final results on Nov. 21. Sales of computer-data storage systems have slowed as Brocade customers like EMC have cut spending on gear. Brocade's switches speed and direct the flow of data among computer servers and storage devices in computer networks and competes with switches made by its rival, the McData Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROMBERG, RABBI KEN NETH
description: BROMBERG - Rabbi Ken neth. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. After serving as chaplain in the US Air Force, he served several rabbinic and educational positions before becoming rabbi of Congregation Beth Shalom in Clearwater, FL where he retired as rabbi emeritus in 1995. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Johanna, children, Naomi Bar-Yam, Efrem, and Hillel, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Reuven Hammer, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Executive Vice President The Rabbinical Assembly

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TAUBMAN CENTERS, Bloomfield Hills, Mich., bought the 50 percent of the Dolphin Mall in Miami it did not own from the Swerdlow Real Estate Group, Hollywood, Fla., for $94.5 million in debt and $2.3 million in land.

title: McCall's Attack and Reminder
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic nominee for governor, began broadcasting this 30-second advertisement yesterday. It is on the air across the state.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: NEWBURGH: 18 ACCUSED OF GUNRUNNING Eighteen people have been arrested on charges of gunrunning and drug-trafficking as part of a seven-month investigation, James B. Comey, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday. Mr. Comey said that the suspects illegally obtained guns by paying others to buy them legally in Southeastern states. They then transported the guns north to Newburgh, in Orange County, for resale. So far, investigators have seized 26 guns, including shotguns and pistols, and three-quarters of a kilo of crack cocaine, among other drugs. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Sharon Says He Is Ready for Early Elections Over Budget
description: Facing a stiff challenge from his main coalition partner over financing for Jewish settlements, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said today that he was ready for early elections if his government unraveled.

title: The Humor in Haydn Revealed With an Extra Dollop Added
description: Andras Schiff, pianist

title: Don't Blame Columbus for All the Indians' Ills
description: Europeans first came to the Western Hemisphere armed with guns, the cross and, unknowingly, pathogens. Against the alien agents of disease, the indigenous people never had a chance. Their immune systems were unprepared to fight smallpox and measles, malaria and yellow fever.

title: Piniella All Smiles On Being Back Home
description: Lou Piniella came home to the warmest of receptions with the Devil Rays today, back to the area where he grew up, attended the University of Tampa and now lives with his family.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Gujurat Plans Elections
description: Balloting for members of the state Assembly is to be held on Dec. 12 in riot-torn Gujarat, the chief election commissioner, L. M. Lyngdoh, announced. More than 1,000 people, mostly Muslims, were killed in Hindu-Muslim rioting that began in February in Gujarat. Nominations for the 182-member Legislature open on Nov. 18. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Sales Fall
description: The Belgian brewing group Interbrew said sales declined 2.5 percent during the first nine months of 2002, but reiterated its earnings target of 1.5 euros a share for the full year. Sales dropped to 1.76 billion gallons from 1.80 billion gallons during the first nine months of last year, the company said. Packaging problems in Russia weighed on the figures and resulted in a loss of market share, Interbrew said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Army Takes On Critics of an Armored Vehicle
description: The Army's most senior general has complained that ''misinformation'' is damaging prospects for the Stryker, a light armored vehicle that the service argues is central to its transformation into a more mobile fighting force.

title: New Skills, and Paying for Them
description: SINCE the day she graduated from high school in 1965, Elaine Mitchell had never been out of work. But 14 months ago, the 55-year-old Stamford, Conn., resident was laid off from her job as a tape librarian at a multinational corporation, where she retrieved and cataloged data from the company's computer. She has been unemployed ever since. After a year into a job search, conducted from her personal computer at home, Ms. Mitchell realized that without a college degree or advanced computer skills, she ''wasn't going to be hired,'' she said.

title: Judge Overturns Fee Farmers Pay for Pork Ads
description: Midwestern hog farmers have won a lawsuit against the secretary of agriculture in their battle to abolish a fee assessed on hogs for pork advertisements, most famously as ''the other white meat.''

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Lesotho: Bribery Penalty
description: A court in Maseru, Lesotho, fined Acres International, the Canadian engineering group, $2.2 million after finding it guilty of passing bribes to a former head of the Lesotho Highlands Development Authority, which oversaw construction of one of Africa's biggest water projects. Acres said that it would appeal the verdict and the sentence. Acres said it had been exonerated of the same charges by the World Bank. The company said it was unaware that its representative in Lesotho was secretly paying part of his fee to the director of the water project in exchange for lucrative contracts. The director was earlier sentenced to 18 years in prison. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Strahan Can't Catch McNabb
description: Even when the football left Donovan McNabb's hands, Michael Strahan took an extra step forward to bump him on the shoulder, to breathe on him, anything to let him know he was in the neighborhood.

title: Smile, Electron! Fast 'Camera' Captures Action Around Atom
description: Using a form of ultrafast flash photography, scientists have for the first time tracked the motion of electrons deep within atoms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, MYRA L.
description: BERGER-Myra L., 69. Of Scarsdale, NY, on October 27, 2002. Devoted wife of Ronald. Loving sister of Judy Bernstein. Beloved mother of Karen and her husband Ivan and Steven and his wife Nicole. Loving and devoted grandmother to Stephanie, Alyssa, Jordyn, Tyler and Alexa. Cherished sister-in-law to Leroy and sister-in-law to Leila Berger. She dedicated her life to her family and will always live on in their hearts. Services will be 12 noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment is at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Counties in Virginia File Sniper Charges; U.S. to Act as Well
description: Prosecutors in Virginia filed capital murder charges today against the two suspects in the Washington-area sniper shootings, as law enforcement officials in suburban Maryland, the area with the most victims, conceded that they would most likely lose control of the case.

title: A Motley Office Crew Works to Meet a Deadline
description: Something happens after intermission to the office workers played by a charming, talented cast in ''The Water Coolers,'' a new musical revue at Dillons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, DENNIS PATRICK
description: HARRISON-Dennis Patrick. March 14, 1918-October 13, 2002. Actor, director, husband, father, grandfather and friend. As a child he tapdanced with his Irish-born father and in WWII made Naval training movies. His first professional job was in Harvey. Unsure of show business, he worked as a traffic manager for Pan Am. Actress, Amelia Baines, convinced him to return to theatre. Smitten, he never did anything else. He married Amelia and they had two daughters. Dennis Harrison was one of 1950's television most recognizable faces. He was television's first vampire in a 1951 episode of Stage 13. He won awards for theatrical portrayals in The Life of Father Flannigan and The Life of Thomas Moore. His big break was The Liar, directed by Alfred Drake. Dennis' chiseled good looks, phenomenal charm, and gifted singing voice brought him to Hollywood using his middle name as his last. As Dennis Patrick, he guest-starred in more than 1,000 television shows. In the 1960s, divorced, he returned to New York appearing in several plays including an award-winning Marat Sade. There, in 1970, he met and wed actress Barbara Cason. They were a quintessential show-biz couple working extensively from coast to coast and sharing everything in their lives with family and friends. Lucky were the guests at homey, funny dinner parties of food, music, laughter, and story telling. Dennis was in three series: Bert D'Angelo Superstar with Paul Sorvino, Dallas, as a chief suspect in the shooting of JR, and Dark Shadows, reprising a vampire role. Motion picture credits include, Joe with Peter Boyle, The Air Up There with Kevin Bacon, The House of Dark Shadows, and The Secret of Nikola Tesla with Orson Welles. Dennis continued working following the untimely 1990 death of his wife, Barbara Cason, though he was forever changed. On October 13, in the house Dennis and Barbara had shared, a fire claimed Dennis and his dog, Josh. A word-loving, voracious reader, who enjoyed life, remembered countless stories and jokes, he was proud, funny, sweet, and eternally in love with Barbara Cason. His ashes were scattered at sea, where Barbara's ashes waited. Josh's ashes went with him. Survived by sisters Mary and Joan, beloved daughter Chris and granddaughter, Autumn. Donations honoring the memory of Dennis Patrick may be made to the Actor's Fund.

title: Coping With the Spiral of Stress That Layoffs Create
description: ROBERT TODARO lost his job a year ago as a technical writer at General Dynamics. It was nothing personal, companywide layoffs, but the experience was ''utterly devastating,'' said Mr. Todaro, 45, of Middleboro, Mass. ''You feel as though you've done something wrong.''

title: Soon-to-Be Graduates See the Need for Plan B
description: HIEU LE, a business economics major at the University of California at Los Angeles, wants to land a job with a Big Four accounting firm when she graduates in May 2003.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Announces Latest Financing Deals
description: No money down, and no payments or interest charges until next year. It sounds like a pitch from Detroit to get consumers into a new car, but it is actually part of I.B.M.'s latest round of financing deals for hardware, software and services. In addition to deferring payments, a marketing tactic I.B.M. has used in the past, I.B.M. said it cut interest rates on hardware to as low as 4.2 percent, and for some software packages like its DB2 database to as low as 3.1 percent. I.B.M. also courted small businesses by cutting the minimum software purchase eligible for I.B.M financing to $25,000, Big Blue's lowest level ever, according to a company spokesman. Analysts said the financing offers were similar to those being offered by many rivals as everyone fights for attention from buyers who have been cutting spending on information technology. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOETTIGHEIMER, MA RIANNE
description: BOETTIGHEIMER - Ma rianne. On October 27th. Beloved and devoted wife for sixty years of Ludwig, who died on March 23, 2002. She will be greatly missed by all her relatives and friends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCK, MAREE (SWEENEY)
description: BOCK-Maree (Sweeney). On October 26, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth E., Sr. Loving mother of Kenneth, Marguerite, Michael and Maree (son-in-law John) and grandmother of Peter Hartley. Dear sister of J. Clement Sweeney. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY on Wednesday. Funeral Mass at Sacred Heart Church at 11AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Viewing 2-5, 7-9 PM, Tuesday.

title: OBSERVATORY
description: When One Nostril Teaches the Other

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPHRAIM, EDWARD
description: EPHRAIM - Edward. We mourn the passing of our best and most wonderful friend, loved by all who knew him. Our heartfelt condolences to Bunny, Hope and Jenny. Heide, Kristina and Warren

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the debate between the Democratic and Independence Party challengers for governor misstated Gov. George E. Pataki's campaign schedule with Rudolph W. Giuliani. They campaigned together yesterday in the New York City area, not on a train trip upstate on Sunday.

title: The Second Ballot
description: To the Editor:

title: North Korea Rejects Demands to Abandon Nuclear Program
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 29  North Korea flatly rejected international demands that it abandon its nuclear weapons program in the opening session of normalization talks with Japanese that began here today.

title: Federal Report On Confession From Egyptian Is in Dispute
description: Release to the public of a report due this week on how the F.B.I. obtained a confession from an innocent Egyptian student who was detained in connection with the attack on the World Trade Center could be delayed as a result of an escalating dispute between prosecutors and the judge who ordered the inquiry, court documents show.

title: In Performance
description: DANCE

title: Fighting Terrorism, and Lassitude
description: An American diplomat gunned down yesterday in Amman, Jordan, appears to be the latest victim of a renewed global terrorism campaign. Al Qaeda or allied groups are believed responsible for recent attacks against American Marines in Kuwait, a nightclub in Bali and a French tanker off the shore of Yemen. Too often in the past, Americans have been tempted to regard such attacks on Western interests around the world, tragic as they may be, as signs that terrorists lack the reach to strike targets within the United States. We cannot afford to succumb to that temptation ever again.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: MORE FIGHTING IN CAPITAL Mortar and automatic-weapons fire rocked Bangui for a fourth day as rebels backing an ousted army chief battled government supporters. The Central African Republic has a poorly equipped army of about 3,500, few of whom could be seen in Bangui. President Ange-Félix Patassé was said to have taken refuge in the Japanese Embassy, but that could not be confirmed.    (AP)

title: Pilots of Doomed Airliner Struggled to Regain Control
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 — As their doomed jetliner rose into clear skies from Kennedy Airport last Nov. 12, the pilot and co-pilot chatted calmly as their American Airlines Airbus A300 ran into choppy air — the wake of an even bigger jet several miles away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUD, NELSON M.
description: LOUD-Nelson M. On October 26, 2002 at age 88. Loving father of Douglass N. Loud & the late Kathryn L. Wilson and stepfather of Jeanette Wotkyns, Marion Frankson and Elizabeth Ruble. Dear brother of Francis T. Loud. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, October 29th, at 4 P.M.

title: Stop the Clock? Critics Call the Billable Hour a Legal Fiction
description: IN 1996, in a taped conversation, the former associate attorney general Webster Hubbell gave his wife an education in legal ethics. He was in prison at the time, serving a sentence for tax evasion.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Tomorrow: 'Living Wage' Bill
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on so-called living wage legislation that would require minimum health benefits and wages for workers employed by companies doing business with the city. Council Chambers, City Hall, Manhattan, 1 p.m. Information: (212) 788-7397.

title: Many Hotels Are Turning to Fancy Spa Services to Stand Out in Soft Market
description: It is called the ''morning jump start'' and is designed for jet-lagged guests who have to clear their minds for negotiating deals. Here is what you get at the Hotel Inter-Continental in Hong Kong: a dry-skin brushing to stimulate circulation, the application of a spearmint-scented exfoliating body polish to remove the dead skin cells, an aromatherapy body massage, a luxury aromatherapy facial and, finally, a ''stimulating'' foot massage.

title: When Doctors Say Don't and the Patient Says Do
description: The woman was 93 and still tap-dancing. In her 20's, she performed for a professional touring dance company. In her 30's and 40's, she taught dance at Juilliard. For the 50 years since then, she had tapped eagerly at amateur shows and recitals.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: JAPAN: HONDA'S PROFIT RISES Profit at the Honda Motor Company rose just 3.3 percent in the July-September quarter as a stronger yen chewed into potential gains. Honda, Japan's second-largest automaker, also said operating profit, a better gauge of the company's core business, fell 6.6 percent. Honda's sales, however, grew 9.5 percent, helped by strong demand in North America for its sport utility vehicles and minivans. Honda lowered its earning targets for the full year ending in March 2003, but still expects to post a record profit. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Trapped in Japan's Bank Crisis
description: It is an old routine that goes back half a century: a sudden show of resolve in Tokyo to do whatever it takes to fix whatever problem worries the United States -- complete with ''reformist'' ministers and bold policy pronouncements. In time, both the policy and the minister are forgotten, and Japan returns to business and politics as usual.

title: Iraq Makes U.N. Seem 'Foolish,' Bush Asserts
description: President Bush used two campaign appearances today to turn up pressure on the United Nations just days ahead of its vote on Iraq, arguing that Saddam Hussein had made the organization look ''foolish'' and questioning whether the Security Council has ''the will or the courage'' to enforce its own resolutions.

title: Qwest Plans $34.8 Billion Write-Down Of Its Assets
description: Qwest Communications International said late yesterday that it would write down the reported value of its assets by $34.8 billion, an accounting change that wipes out the book value of shareholders' equity in the company but does not directly affect Qwest's cash reserves or current operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUBITZ, JUDITH
description: LUBITZ-Judith. Age 63. October 27, 2002, in Stamford Hospital. Beloved wife of Allen. Devoted mother of Karen and Steven. Loving sister of Goldie. Funeral will be held Tuesday, October 29, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's Parkside Building,'' 98-60 Queens Blvd, Rego Park, NY. Burial will follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Shiva will take place at the home of Allen Lubitz, 202-17 Soundview Ave., Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hadassah, Fund Raising Services, 50 West 58th St., NY, NY 10019-2500.

title: Getting the Work of 30 Fingers To Come From Only 10
description: Boris Berezovsky, pianist

title: A New Life For Revolutionary Art
description: When the Mexican artist David Alfaro Siqueiros visited California in 1962, he was not surprised to discover that two of the three murals he painted in Los Angeles 30 years earlier had disappeared. What surprised him was that one remained. That surviving mural, a powerfully emotional panorama called ''Portrait of Mexico Today,'' is now on public view for the first time. In an extraordinary conservation effort, the mural and the entire building on whose walls it was painted have been moved 90 miles to the Santa Barbara Museum of Art. After its unveiling on Oct. 20, visitors lined up for several hours to see it.

title: Stand Clear of Closing Doors, and That Love Seat
description: City life, especially in New York, requires countless daily calculations involving the fundamentals of physics: space, time, mass and energy.

title: With Allies Likely and Unlikely, U.S. Navy Stems Flow of Iraqi Oil
description: The United States and its allies, with quiet help from Iran, have all but shut off the flow of illegal Iraqi oil in the Persian Gulf, playing a game of cat and mouse with small boats that had proven effective tools for smugglers and terrorists alike.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Dies In Shooting
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, after they got into an argument while walking together on Sheridan Avenue in Mount Eden, the police said. Just after 9 p.m. yesterday, Dwayne Irving, 26, of East 161st Street in Manhattan, was shot twice in the face and once in the chest. He was taken to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, where he was pronounced dead on arrival, the police said. The second victim, a 24-year-old, was shot twice in the back and was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in stable condition. The police have not released his name. ''They were walking together when they became involved in a dispute,'' said Det. Carolyn Chew, but the subject of the dispute was not known. No weapons were recovered, and no arrests were made, the police said. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: A Passionate Voice, Stilled in Minnesota
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghans Freed from Guantnamo Speak of Heat and Isolation
description: Three members of the first group of prisoners to be freed from indefinite, secret detention at the Guantnamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba complained tonight that prisoners are locked for days at a time in sweltering 8-by-8-foot cells and are denied contact with their families.

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Art illustration on Sunday about daylight saving time omitted the artist's name. The artist is Lauren Redniss.

title: Bets May Be Too Good To Be True
description: Was it a betting scam or just extraordinary horse picking? This is what Breeders' Cup officials have asked the New York State Racing and Wagering Board to determine in the case of a Maryland man who holds all six winning tickets worth more than $2.5 million from the lucrative Ultra Pick Six wager that was offered on Saturday's World Thoroughbred Championships day.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray's Chief Financial Officer Resigns
description: Cray Inc., maker of supercomputers used by Ford Motor to analyze vehicle safety, said yesterday that its chief financial officer quit and was replaced by Scott Poteracki, an executive at the Broadcom Corporation. Douglas Ralphs, who joined Cray in January 2001 from Interpoint Inc., resigned to ''pursue other interests,'' Cray said in a statement. It did not elaborate. Mr. Poteracki, 49, had been Racal Instruments' finance chief since March, after serving as controller at Broadcom. Cray's computers help the United States government simulate nuclear explosions and the University of Toronto measure the Earth's core. The shares of Cray, which is based in Seattle, rose 36 cents, to $4.84.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: GERMANY: BUSINESS CONFIDENCE FALLS Business confidence in Germany sagged to a nine-month low this month amid fears that tax increases and spending cuts proposed by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's new government would revive the torpid economy. The monthly index published by the Ifo Institute, a Munich-based economic research group, dropped to 87.7, from 88.2 in September. Private-sector economic forecasts for Germany predict near-zero growth in 2002. Ifo's researchers noted, however, that confidence improved among retailers, wholesalers and construction concerns in October, suggesting that Germany might escape a double-dip recession. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO CLIMBS. The dollar declined sharply against the euro on concerns that a weakening economic expansion may slow investment in the United States. In New York, the euro rose to 98.44 cents from 97.68 cents on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, VIRGINIA ANNE
description: BERMAN - Virginia Anne. Passed away peacefully on October 26 in her 78th year. She was a graduate of Sarah Lawrence College. Beloved wife of the late Emile Zola Berman, defense attorney in the Sirhan Sirhan trial. She is survived by her daughter, Ellen Tackling, of New Canaan, CT, grandchildren Melissa and Seth, and niece, Jan Abraham. Virginia shall always be remembered for her outstanding human values and the importance of many lasting friendships, including Eileen, Pearl, Maria, Mildred, Sarah, Ursula, and Cheryl. A memorial gathering will be held at a later date.

title: Documents Show Effort To Promote Unproven Drug
description: Marketing executives at Warner-Lambert urged their superiors to let them promote the epilepsy drug Neurontin for an unapproved use rather than perform the clinical studies needed to prove the medicine was safe for such patients, according to a corporate memorandum unsealed on Friday in federal court.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHREIBMAN, MYRNA
description: SCHREIBMAN-Myrna. Our lives were brightened by knowing you. For two years we've had only memories to hang onto, and love you still, for giving us such good ones. Thank you for being our friend, our inspiration, my sister. Your fan club misses you. Always, Susi

title: Peace and Political Status at 39,000 Feet
description: Before President Bush boards Air Force One, his staff makes sure that the jumbo jet's televisions are tuned to ESPN or anything other than the relentless bleat of cable news. Otherwise, Mr. Bush might spot an offending CNN or Fox news crawl and demand, as he has in the past, ''Who turned that on?''

title: The Greatest Threat
description: The scariest place in the world right now is not Iraq, but rather the Korean peninsula.

title: Arafat Wins Approval for New Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 29  Yasir Arafat won overwhelming approval for a new cabinet from the Palestinian parliament today, turning back a legislative challenge to his authority that had forced his ministers to resign last month.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Power Plant Shut
description: Regulators ordered the Tokyo Electric Power Company to halt operations at one of its nuclear reactors for one year, a penalty for falsifying safety records. The shutdown will cost the company, Japan's largest utility, an estimated 20 billion yen ($161 million) and is likely to force the company to buy energy from competitors to meet demand in the winter months. In late August, the company admitted falsifying data over a 15-year period. The president and chairman of the company have since resigned. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Grappling With Mighty Issues On a Journey to a Sculpture
description: 'Time of Communion'

title: Per Bak, 54, Physicist of Sudden Change, Dies
description: Dr. Per Bak, an intellectually pugnacious physicist who sought to understand how complexity arises in the world, died on Oct. 16 in Copenhagen. He was 54.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: SCHOOLS SUPERINTENDENT RESIGNS Anthony S. Amato, the superintendent of Hartford's troubled school system, abruptly resigned yesterday, ending a rocky three-and-a-half-year tenure in which he raised abysmally low test scores but alienated some educators and city officials by openly seeking more prestigious job offers elsewhere. Though Mr. Amato said his departure was voluntary, some officials in Hartford said that they believed he was forced out by Mayor Eddie A. Perez. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Flawed Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | The Environment: Warmer Oceans Kill Reefs
description: Coral reefs, vital ocean habitats, suffered the worst damage from warming waters this year since a record episode in 1998, scientists said. More than 400 suffer extensive bleaching, in which heat kills algae that help reef-building organisms grow. The most extensive damage is along the Great Barrier Reef, off Australia. The scientists maintain a Web site, reefbase.org. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Aegis Reports Gains From Broadcast Ads
description: The Aegis Group in London said it was reaping the benefits of "further clear improvements" in broadcast advertising in the United States since the first half of the year and that it expected results for the year before one-time costs to be "significantly better" than in 2001.

title: Sports of The Times; Angels Were Throwbacks To Older Era
description: THIS was in early October. The Angels still carried around the reputation of a Goofy franchise that had never won anything.

title: Court Gives Vivendi More Time for Bid
description: Vivendi Universal received an extension from a French court today in its battle with the Vodafone Group for control of Cegetel, the French phone company.

title: Hiromi Okumura Lorenz, 26
description: Forensic Social Worker, Legal Aid Society, Juvenile Rights Division, Bronx

title: MEMO PAD
description: Finding More Room For Carry-On Bags

title: In East, Only Thing New Is Season
description: In the beginning, there were bitter, ornery rivalries between storied franchises -- the Celtics and the Knickerbockers or the Celtics and the 76ers, played in some dingy cracker box of an arena -- and this was good. For plot lines and ratings.

title: Observing The Stars, Channeling Laughton
description: In her gracefully detailed and tellingly named book ''Galileo's Daughter,'' Dava Sobel captures the personal drama and enduring paradox of Galileo Galilei, the scientific genius and faithful Roman Catholic who was accused of heresy and faced the Inquisition for declaring that the Earth revolved around the Sun. Ms. Sobel's elegant, humanizing approach shines through ''Galileo's Battle for the Heavens,'' the two-hour documentary based on that book (part of the PBS science series ''Nova'').

title: Europe Reels From Lives Lost And Damage Caused by Storm
description: Northern Europe picked itself up today from a violent weekend storm that killed at least 33 people, destroyed buildings, uprooted trees, wreaked havoc with roads, airlines, ferries and railways, cut off power and caused tens of millions of dollars worth of damage.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with a review of the play ''The Romance of Magno Rubio'' named the actors out of order. Jojo Gonzalez was at the left; at the right Ramon de Ocampo stood behind Orlando Pabotoy.

title: OIL FIELD TOOL COMPANY TO BUY DRILL-BIT DIVISION
description: Grant Prideco said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a drill-bit maker, Reed-Hycalog, from Schlumberger for about $345 million in cash and stock to add to its line of oil field tools. Grant Prideco will pay $255 million in cash and about 10 million of its own shares, the chief financial officer, Louis A. Raspino, said. The company will also assume about $5 million in debt from Schlumberger, an oil-services company.

title: U.S. Suspects Opiate in Gas In Russia Raid
description: American officials said yesterday that they suspected the Russian security police who raided a Moscow theater early Saturday might have used an aerosol version of a powerful, fast-acting opiate called Fentanyl to knock out Chechen extremists and prevent them from killing the 750 hostages they were holding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOROME, JOSEPH ALFRED
description: BOROME - Joseph Alfred. October 27, 2002. Funeral mass Thursday 10 A.M. St. Mark the Evangelist Church, 65 W. 138 St, Manhattan. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to Scholarship Fund, Dominica Benevolant Society, c/o Mrs. Gwendolyn Cable, 145-53 Lakewood Avenue, Jamaica, New York 11435.

title: The Fateful Gamble in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Naming That Bird
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fateful Gamble in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Brooklyn Judge to Serve at Least 3 Years for Bribe
description: Victor I. Barron, the Brooklyn judge who pleaded guilty to receiving a bribe, returned to his former court yesterday and was led away in handcuffs after being sentenced to serve at least three years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/452/9/94. Wish you could be celebrating today-with friends, food and much wry humor. Miss you always. Love, Vicki

title: Footlights
description: Glassmaker's Dozen

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Former Crime Boss Testifies
description: A former organized crime boss who became a government witness said yesterday that he turned against the mob out of fear for his own family. Joseph DeFede, the acting boss of the Luchese organized crime family in the late 1990's, testified for the first time as a witness for the prosecution in the murder trial of a mob associate. While in prison for extortion, Mr. DeFede learned that other Luchese family members suspected him of stealing mob money, so he agreed to plead guilty to racketeering charges and cooperate with the government. Mr. DeFede, 68, said that he made clear to other mob members that ''if they wanted me, they could kill me'' but to leave his family alone. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Edwin Bayley, 84; Led Berkeley Journalism School
description: Edwin R. Bayley, the founding dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at the University of California, died on Sunday in Green Bay, Wis. He was 84 and lived in Carmel, Calif., and Door County, Wis., in recent years.

title: Coping With Minibars And Overpriced Peanuts
description: I CHECK into the hotel room and, as always, march around on inspection like a Parris Island drill sergeant. Sure enough, I spot things. On a tray by the television, for example, is a bottle of water with a cardboard sign hanging around its neck like a clown-school regimental tie.

title: CBS Tries to Out-Anchor The Morning Competition
description: On network equivalency charts, do three brunettes make a blonde? That seems to be the calculation that CBS made with the debut of its new four-anchor format yesterday on ''The Early Show.''

title: PGA Tour Is Pressed on Admitting Women at Augusta
description: The head of the women's group pressing Augusta National Golf Club to admit women as members demanded yesterday that the PGA Tour dissociate itself from the Masters tournament until the membership issue was resolved.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ALFRED
description: LERNER - Alfred. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, and Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the passing of Alfred Lerner, a member since 1998 of the Hospital's Board of Trustees. Mr. Lerner, a uniquely brilliant and generous man with broad perspective and insight, was a prominent businessman and valued friend. We extend our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Determined Anaheim Produces Disney Ending
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 28  Tim Salmon, the endless Angel, started the celebratory lap around a delirious Edison Field with the World Series trophy on Sunday night. Salmon carried it as gently as he would hold a 6-month old baby. He carefully passed it to Troy Glaus, who gingerly handed it to Garret Anderson. As the fans howled, the players lifted the symbol of their success to the dark sky. A dark sky had never felt so bright.

title: REIT Cuts 2003 Forecast
description: Equity Office Properties Trust cut its earnings forecast for 2003 today after announcing that its third-quarter profit fell 14 percent because rising vacancies made it harder to raise rents.

title: They're Alive! They're Alive! Not!; Japan Hesitates to Put an End to Its 'Zombie' Businesses
description: For a corporate deadbeat, the retailer Daiei was positively hopping downstairs on a recent evening with customers lured in by peppy tunes blaring from loudspeakers and clerks offering free sushi morsels. But upstairs at the three-floor store in the Nishi Kasai district, a forest of commuter high rises in eastern Tokyo, ghostly empty aisles in home appliances and women's clothing made it clear why Daiei had become perhaps the leading Japanese ''zombie,'' a prime example of the thousands of dead businesses acting as if they are still alive.

title: At Request of Wellstones, Cheney Will Not Attend Memorial
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 29 — Complying with a request from the sons of Senator Paul Wellstone, Vice President Dick Cheney will not attend tonight's memorial service for the senator, his wife and his daughter, who were killed in a plane crash on Friday, the White House said.

title: Senator's Death Also Reverberates in Tight 3-Way Race for Minnesota Governor
description: The fatal plane crash that upended one of the nation's tightest and most aggressive contests for the United States Senate has also frozen the remarkable race to replace Gov. Jesse Ventura, the professional wrestler who was elected four years ago after an iconoclastic run against the political system.

title: A Week to Define Himself; No Longer Merely the Anti-Torricelli, Forrester Tries to Get His Message Across
description: His has been a charmed life, a study in sizing up obstacles and blithely knocking them down, of skipping over one Everest and scanning the horizon for the next. Few things for which Douglas R. Forrester ever reached have exceeded his grasp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, IRENE
description: LEONARD-Irene. Of Sea Cliff, Long Island, NY, on October 28, 2002. Daughter of the late Nicholas and Helen Guilbick. Beloved wife of the late Alexis Leonard. Loving mother of Ellen McPartland (Tom) and Alex Leonard (Elizabeth). Dear grandmother of Peter and James McPartland, Christopher Leonard, Nicholas Sargent, Alex Leonard Sargent, and great-grandmother of Sophie and Jackson. Funeral Liturgy Tuesday, 7 PM, Church of Our Lady of Kazan, Sea Cliff, NY. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Church of Our Lady of Kazan, Willow Shore Avenue, Sea Cliff, NY 11579.

title: INSIDE
description: Warnings on Priest Ignored

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. & 90 St., on Friday, November 1 at 11 AM.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Arrested In Killing Of His Mother
description: A 25-year-old man killed his mother, then stabbed himself twice in the chest yesterday morning, the police said. The man, Robert Jeanlord, who is charged with second-degree murder, called the police to his home, on 216th Street in Middle Village, and said he had suffocated his mother, Marie Jeanlord, 52, because he believed she was poisoning him, a law enforcement official said. Mr. Jeanlord was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital in stable condition and was to undergo a psychiatric evaluation there, the law enforcement official said, adding that the suspect's mental health had suffered after the recent death of his father. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Letters
description: Short-Lived Glory

title: In Georgia, Clues to A Puzzling Job Market
description: THEY live not much more than 100 miles apart as the crow flies. Last year, both were laid off by employers in the throes of downsizing. But for Bob Fowler and Cathy Bragg, things are very different nowadays.

title: Moms Go to Class but Kids Gain
description: Giving recently divorced mothers training in child-rearing skills cut in half the mental disorders found six years later among their adolescent children in comparison with children in a similar group, a new study is reporting.

title: Sam Moore, Breaking and Mending Hearts
description: In 1970 and 1971 Sam Moore -- half of Sam and Dave -- recorded an album's worth of songs with Aretha Franklin's band. Most of the tunes were other people's hits at the time, and perhaps because the material seemed overly familiar, the album was not released until this year, as ''Plenty Good Lovin' '' (2-K Sounds). On Wednesday night at the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, Mr. Moore reconvened the surviving core of the band -- Bernard Purdie on drums, Cornell Dupree on guitar and Chuck Rainey on bass -- and let loose a voice that's as vital now as it was three decades ago.

title: Stocks Bounce Back From an Early Sell-off
description: Stocks came under pressure today and bond prices rose as investors were surprised by an unexpectedly steep drop in consumer confidence, which fell its lowest level in nine years.

title: Student Kills 3 Instructors and Himself at U. of Arizona
description: An aggrieved student killed three instructors at the University of Arizona nursing school this morning and then fatally shot himself, the Tucson police said. The medical complex at the university was locked down as Tucson police and bomb squad officers searched for explosives.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Millicent Hearst Boudjakdji, president of the William Randolph Hearst Foundation, misstated the date of her death. It was Oct. 16, not Oct. 23.

title: F.D.A. Vows Crackdown On Lenses
description: Dr. Thomas E. Steinemann, a Cleveland ophthalmologist, has seen his fair share of patients with tragic eye disorders. But few have been sadder, he said, than the teenager whose vision was permanently damaged last year by a pair of contact lenses she wore solely to change the color of her eyes.

title: In the West, Forgive. Forget?
description: Grudges rarely take hold anymore in the N.B.A. or any other professional sport. Too many athletes, too much money. They either share the same agents or the same Jet Ski in Orlando, Fla., during the off-season to stay mad over a playoff defeat for too long.

title: AMERICAN ENVOY KILLED IN JORDAN
description: A senior American diplomat in Jordan, Laurence Foley, was gunned down outside his house today, shot eight times at close range in what appeared to be the latest of a string of terror attacks against Western targets in the region and beyond.

title: In Some Bird Species, Little Chance for an Empty Nest
description: In the dense conifer forests of northern Sweden, just below the Arctic Circle, the Siberian jay, its feathers the color of pine bark, hides its nests high in the tall pines and spruces.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAGAN, SHEL
description: KAGAN-Shel. 1/30/3510/29/92. Ten years and you are still ''the wind beneath my wings''. Big Sister Bea

title: From the Easel, A Surgical View
description: Dr. Joe Wilder was a successful surgeon in New York when he took up painting in 1959. Art soon became a second career, and he began dividing his life between operating room and studio. He retired from surgery in 1985, but today, at 82, he is still painting. His subjects include athletes, race cars, landscapes, seascapes, still lifes and his fellow surgeons, whom, he said, he hopes to ''honor and celebrate.'' The images are from ''Life in the Operating Room: The True World of Surgery,'' which is to be his third art book.

title: Cure for Low Turnout
description: To the Editor:

title: Readable Report Cards
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Obstacle
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Jobs Are
description: Only two fields dominate the top of the Labor Department's list of fastest-growing occupations over the rest of this decade: health care and computers -- including the software that drives them and the networks that link them. But a look at the areas that will add the greatest numbers of jobs gives a different view. Here, lower-paying service jobs, like those at fast-food restaurants or in retail sales, top the list alongside the better paying jobs in computers and health care. The job market also varies significantly from state to state, and more surprisingly, perhaps, can vary widely even between nearby cities in the same state. SETH FEASTER

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: ACTOR'S LAWYER RESIGNS The lawyer who has represented the actor Robert Blake since Mr. Blake's wife was shot to death last year announced his resignation, saying he objected to his client's decision to grant a jailhouse television interview with Diane Sawyer of ABC. "He insists on doing an interview on camera with Diane Sawyer," the lawyer, Harland Braun, left, said. "I think it's insane for a person charged with a crime to go on camera to answer questions about the case." The judge presiding over the case will decide whether to let Mr. Braun resign. Mr. Blake is charged with murdering his wife, Bonny Lee Bakley.    (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELBAN, ARTHUR
description: KELBAN-Arthur. Devoted husband to Lorraine for 58 years, loving father to Daryl and Jay Marx, and Steven Kelban and Ellen Schall, grandfather to Eva and Jonathan and GP to Abigail and Angelina. We celebrated his 80th birthday together this weekend. We will miss him terribly. He loved life and was young for 80 years. Services Tuesday, 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Clock Reset, Agent Bauer Returns to Work
description: David Palmer is the first black president of the United States, but nobody seems to notice. The matter-of-fact way ''24'' has placed him in the White House just hints at how this clever suspense series -- one of the most compelling to arrive last season -- toys with and enhances reality. As the second season begins (tonight on Fox), it is a year after Jack Bauer, a C.I.A. agent in the counterterrorism unit, has saved Palmer, then a senator, from assassination. Jack (played by Kiefer Sutherland with low-key intensity and a notable lack of vanity) is on leave from his job, unkempt and despondent because the events that tangled his family in the assassination attempt also caused the death of his wife.

title: Pilots Find Themselves Left Up in the Air
description: AT the beginning of 2001, Dave Jewell was in demand as a pilot. Having flown jets for 20 years in the Air Force, he had offers from three airlines when he left the service. He happily accepted one from Delta Air Lines, moved his family to Atlanta from St. Louis and began flying MD-88's that June.

title: Coach Cannot Control His Son
description: As if Wisconsin's first-year coach, MIKE EAVES, did not have a tough enough task replacing Jeff Sauer, the coach with the most victories in Western Collegiate Hockey Association history, Eaves had to face a rare challenge last weekend when the Badgers visited Boston College. The Eagles' roster included Eaves's sons, PATRICK, a freshman, and BEN, a junior and the team captain.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: WOMEN ACCOUNT FOR THIRD OF NEW AIDS CASES Women account for roughly one-third of new AIDS cases in the District of Columbia, with a majority of those new cases involving black and Latino women, health officials say. Last year, 616 new adult AIDS cases were reported, 204 of them among women. The number of city residents ages 13 or older with AIDS is 13,899. Twenty-four percent are girls or women. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIERNOFF, MILDRED
description: BIERNOFF-Mildred, age 91. Passed away peacefully Sunday, October 27. Loving wife of the late Meyer Biernoff. Loving mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Sister of Joseph Brown and Lillian Lublang and loving aunt. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her and loved her.

title: Bill and Lanie Isgrig, 65 and 51
description: Owners, Rim Solutions, document management and storage company, Henderson, Nev.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Prices rose as colder temperatures in the Midwest raised expectations of higher demand. In New York, gas for November delivery rose 14.8 cents, or 3.7 percent, to $4.176 for a million B.T.U.'s.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENFELD, LILY
description: SEIDENFELD-Lily. On October 27, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Edith and Andrew. Cherished grandmother of Renee, Franklin, Laura and Justin. Loving mother-in-law of Sandy and Melissa.

title: Approval Is Seen for Abbott Arthritis Drug
description: Abbott Laboratories' experimental drug for rheumatoid arthritis proved effective and safe in late-stage clinical trials, making it a potentially strong competitor to Amgen's Enbrel and Johnson & Johnson's Remicade, doctors and analysts said yesterday and over the weekend.

title: Corrections
description: Aheadline yesterday and a front-page summary for an article about President Bush's visit to Mexico misstated the facts of the article, about Mexico's stance in the United Nations Security Council toward Iraq. Mexico gave President Bush no pledge to support the United States resolution in the Council. But President Vicente Fox did not tell Mr. Bush that Mexico would not support it.

title: Another Problem With Poverty
description: Children who live in the poorest neighborhoods of cities tend to face the biggest risk of being hit by cars, according to two new studies that independently looked at the problem in Britain and the United States.

title: WAL-MART SAYS SALES ROSE LAST WEEK BUT SAM'S LAGGED
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that last week's sales at its discount stores rose within the company's monthly forecast as shoppers bought more men's clothing. Sales at the Sam's Club warehouse chain lagged. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., forecast a 2 percent to 4 percent gain in October sales at stores open at least a year. Total same-store sales rose within that forecast for the week ended on Friday, Wal-Mart said. Halloween candy and costumes sales rose less than forecast, Wal-Mart said. The retailer missed its original sales estimate for the last three months as consumer spending slowed.

title: Protesters Seek Local Hearing On Flight 587 Crash in Queens
description: As federal investigators prepared to open hearings on Tuesday on the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 near Kennedy International Airport last November, a busload of protesters from New York called for a boycott of the proceedings because they will not be held near the crash site.

title: World Briefing: The Environment
description: WARMER OCEANS KILL REEFS Coral reefs, vital ocean habitats, suffered the worst damage from warming waters this year since a record episode in 1998, scientists said. More than 400 suffer extensive bleaching, in which heat kills algae that help reef-building organisms grow. The most extensive damage is along the Great Barrier Reef, off Australia. The scientists maintain a Web site, reefbase.org. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Big Job Sites Try to Think Small
description: LIKE many products of the technology boom, online job boards have not exactly gone bust, but they are reinventing themselves. Many are evolving from sites where jobs and rsums were posted into ''career management'' sites that offer expanded services and a more hands-on approach to matching job seekers and employers.

title: $2 Bud, and a Bundy for Every Bar Stool
description: Serial killers drank here, they say at this bar on Holly Street.

title: A New View Of Our Universe: Only One of Many
description: Astronomers have gazed out at the universe for centuries, asking why it is the way it is. But lately a growing number of them are dreaming of universes that never were and asking, why not?

title: Short-Lived Glory
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Entrust Future to Howe (Not Piniella And Not Baker)
description: When Fred Wilpon sat down with Art Howe in a New York hotel room Wednesday with an eye to making him the next manager of the Mets, he had already received an endorsement of Howe from Mets General Manager Steve Phillips. Wilpon also knew that Howe was hardly known as a demonstrative manager during his seven years with the Oakland Athletics, that he was not Lou Piniella.

title: Bush Signs Bill Overhauling National Elections System
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29  President Bush signed a bill today to clean up the nation's election procedures and to set minimum federal standards intended to prevent a repetition of the problems that cast a cloud over voting in Florida two years ago.

title: Bishop Knew Boston Priest Had Praised Man-Boy Sex
description: When he was a top official in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston, Bishop Thomas V. Daily, who now heads the Diocese of Brooklyn, promoted a priest to lead a suburban parish in 1983 even though he had received numerous complaints that the priest was advocating sex between men and boys, according to a deposition released today.

title: Accounts

description: There is no doubt, the girl can play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, LEONARD
description: COHEN-Leonard. Of Riverdale, NY and Boca Raton, FL died on October 26, 2002 from cancer. Born December 25, 1915 in New York City, the second born son of Mary and Irving Cohen. Loving father of Mark Cohen & Lori Klein and grandfather of Erica & Jenna. Dearly beloved by Joyce Horn, the DeGuires & David Bailey and all others who truly knew him. Retired former dentist, practicing in Manhattan and a strong supporter of the state of Israel. Funeral service will be held on Tuesday, October 29 at Forest Lawn, 200 W. Copans Road, Pompano Beach, FL. at 10AM. Interment will be on Wednesday October 30 at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-onthe-Hudson, NY 914-478-1855.
