title: Keys to Returning to the N.B.A. Finals
description: Free from expectations last season, Jason Kidd and the Nets turned the basketball world upside down with their 56-victory Eastern Conference championship season. But now, there are plenty of expectations. "If we don't get there," Nets Coach Byron Scott said of the N.B.A. finals, "then the season wasn't a success. I don't care if you win 62 games."

title: Fire in Vietnam Office-Building Kills at Least 54
description: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam, Oct. 29  A huge fire in the heart of the city trapped hundreds of people inside a six-story office building this afternoon, killing at least 54 of them and injuring more than 100, officials said.

title: Israel's Coalition Government on Brink of Breaking Apart
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29  Israel's coalition government was on the brink of breaking apart tonight after 19 months of broad-based unity, as ministers from the left-leaning Labor party said they would bolt rather than support Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's proposed budget.

title: Editors' Note; SPECIAL TODAY/Working
description: Neighboring cities in Georgia -- one losing jobs, the other gaining them -- reflect today's puzzling employment picture. With a look at the effects of the staggering economy and corporate scandals on the attitude of American workers. SECTION G

title: Chads and Butterflies Give Way to Social Security and Prescription Drugs in Florida
description: Like so many other local Florida officials, Tom Feeney and Carol Roberts took the short and bumpy ride from obscurity to renown in the protracted 2000 presidential election.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Bank Posts Loss
description: Italy's biggest investment bank, Mediobanca, slumped to a first-quarter loss after writing down the value of holdings in companies including Commerzbank and IntesaBci by 375.1 million euros ($365 million). The pretax loss was 346.3 million euros in the three months to Sept. 30 in contrast to a profit of 347.9 million euros a year earlier. The write-downs for holdings in the two banks together accounted for 39 percent of the reduction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, CATHERINE
description: ROSENBERG-Catherine. Beloved mother of Stuart. Cherished grandmother to Jennifer, Pamela, Peter and Jeff. Loving mother-in-law to her Barbara. Devoted sister to Gertrude Dubin and dear aunt to Sherry Patterson. We will miss her dearly.

title: Poor Study Methods
description: To the Editor:

title: The Connecticut Elections; Bill Curry for Governor
description: Gov. John Rowland of Connecticut is seeking a third term as chief executive in a contest against Bill Curry, a Democrat who formerly served as state comptroller. In general, third terms are not a good idea, and Mr. Rowland's administration has begun to suffer from the kind of cronyism and questionable practices that typify a governor who has been in power too long. Connecticut's race, with a two-term governor versus a former state comptroller, is strangely similar to New York's. The big difference is that Connecticut voters are not being forced to choose between an unsatisfactory incumbent and an even less promising opponent. Bill Curry is a good candidate with fresh ideas and strong credentials as a political reformer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTA, DINO
description: COSTA-Dino. On October 26, 2002. Native of Varsi, Italy. Beloved husband of Anita (nee Trombetti). Loving father of Clara Carley (Brennan), Dino (Clare), and Sandra Caruso (Michael). Cherished grandfather of nine grandchildren. Also survived by a sister, Carla, and many nieces and nephews. Family will be present 7-9 PM, Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday, at F. Ruggiero and Sons, Inc, 726 Morris Park Ave. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's. In lieu of flowers the family prefers donations be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave.

title: The Boy on a Date and Other Sad Stories
description: It was a grown-up thing to do. Pavel Platonov, a first-year college student, bought two tickets for the Wednesday night performance of ''Nord-Ost,'' a musical. He wanted to impress a new girlfriend he had been dating for about three weeks, his father said.

title: Welch Wants New Lawyer Brought In In Divorce Suit
description: John F. Welch Jr., the former chairman and chief executive of General Electric, is trying to bring in Daniel K. Webb, a prominent trial lawyer and a former United States attorney in Chicago, to work on his pending divorce from Jane Beasley Welch.

Loving mother of William and Dana Herrman II and Alexandra and David Kamin. Adoring grandmother of Henry and Charles Herrman and Grace Kamin. Sister of George Macpherson. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The Society for PSP, Woodholme Medical Building, Suite 515, 1838 Greene Tree Road, Baltimore, MD 21208. Services will be held on Tuesday at 1 PM at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Avenue at 90th Street.

title: Cigna to Feel Major Loss In Customers
description: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it would lose at least 530,000 members this year and surrender its longstanding position as the nation's third-largest health insurer.

description: A longtime WorldCom director has resigned and agreed to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars for benefits he received in the years before the company collapsed into bankruptcy.

description: DURING the Giants' 17-3 loss in their last visit to the cauldron of chaos known as Veterans Stadium, it was as if the rookie tight end Jeremy Shockey's face were on a ''wanted'' poster as the Eagles' public enemy No. 1.

He spent a lifetime in the service of the Jewish people and Bnai Zion, setting an example of devotion to generations. We extend our condolences to his family. He shall indeed be missed. Funeral services on Tuesday, Oct. 29 at 12 noon at Plaza Memorial, 92/Amsterdam, NYC. Contributions in his memory to Bnai Zion Foundation, 136 E. 39th St., NY, NY 10016. 212-725-1211. Michael J. Lazar, President Jack Grunspan, Nat'l Sec'y

title: U.S. Envoy Offers Criticism of Kremlin as Burials Begin
description: MOSCOW, October 29  The United States ambassador to Russia offered the first muted criticism today of Russia's handling of last weekend's hostage crisis in a central Moscow theatre, saying the storming of Chechen terrorists inside had been an operational success, but that confusion in its aftermath may have needlessly raised the death toll.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Miner Acquired
description: The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian miner with holdings in western Africa, agreed to buy the Repadre Capital Corporation, which has stakes in two mines in Ghana, for about 348.1 million Canadian dollars ($223 million) to increase production. Iamgold will pay 1.6 shares for each Repadre share, equivalent to 8.48 Canadian dollars a share, a 16 percent over Repadre's closing price on Friday. With the acquisition, Iamgold, which is based in Toronto, will raise annual production to 450,000 ounces from last year's 256,000 ounces.

title: NETS SET ROSTER
description: The Nets set their regular-season roster yesterday in anticipation of tomorrow's home opener against the Atlanta Hawks, trimming it, as expected, to 14 players. They waived the veteran forward Donny Marshall and placed guard Brandon Armstrong, who has a lower back strain, on the injured list, where he joins forward Jamie Feick.

title: Appeals Court Again Hears Case of American Held Without Charges or Counsel
description: In nearly two hours of oral arguments here, the government said today that the Bush administration had the authority to hold a United States citizen caught in the Afghan battle for an unlimited period without charging him with anything or giving him access to a lawyer.

title: The Rights of 'Enemy Combatants'
description: Yasser Esam Hamdi, an American citizen captured in Afghanistan, has been held since April in a naval brig, without formal charges or access to a lawyer. The Bush administration told a federal appeals court in Virginia yesterday that as an ''enemy combatant,'' he is entitled to neither. The administration's position would give the president sweeping powers to strip citizens of their rights and hold them indefinitely. It is unconstitutional, and the appeals court should reject it.

title: 2 Colombians Extradited In Kidnappings
description: Colombia has extradited two men suspected of taking part in a violent kidnapping ring that focused on American and other foreign workers in Ecuador and demanded huge ransoms from their multinational employers, officials said today.

Cherished daughter of the late Reuben and Minnie Iceland. Beloved sister of Oscar and the late Ben Iceland. Beloved grandmother of Robert and Jennifer Stevens. Rebecca was a teacher, a social activist, and a beautiful and vibrant woman who was passionately involved with the world around her. She loved her family and she will live in our hearts.

We extend our deepest sympathy to the Senator's family and friends.

It is $20 million a year; $50 million is an estimate of the program's total cost after the change.

title: Sales of Video Games and Movies Increase Profit at Sony
description: The Sony Corporation is showing a growing knack for wringing profits from its most important market, the United States, even when it cannot find much sales growth there. The company announced today a much larger profit for the quarter ended Sept. 30 than analysts had expected. But it said that sales in the period were flat and were not likely to grow as much as hoped for the full year.

title: Technology Briefing
description: CRAY'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER RESIGNS Cray Inc. , maker of supercomputers used by Ford Motor to analyze vehicle safety, said yesterday that its chief financial officer quit and was replaced by Scott Poteracki, an executive at the Broadcom Corporation . Douglas Ralphs, who joined Cray in January 2001 from Interpoint Inc., resigned to "pursue other interests," Cray said in a statement. It did not elaborate. Mr. Poteracki, 49, had been Racal Instruments' finance chief since March, after serving as controller at Broadcom. Cray's computers help the United States government simulate nuclear explosions and the University of Toronto measure the Earth's core. The shares of Cray, which is based in Seattle, rose 36 cents, to $4.84. (Bloomberg News)

title: ENDO WILL NOT SEEK APPROVAL FOR DRUG THAT FAILED TESTS
description: Endo Pharmaceuticals Holdings said it would probably not seek federal approval for an experimental pain treatment after the drug failed to show a significant benefit in studies. The treatment, MorphiDex, proved no better than morphine in relieving pain, the company said. Endo said in June that the medication had failed in a similar late-stage study, and the results suggested there was not enough evidence to file an application for Food and Drug Administration approval. Shares of Endo, which is based in Chadds Ford, Pa., fell $2.68, or 28 percent, to $6.82 a share.

title: Only Path to Security

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Bank Sells Shares
description: The British bank Standard Chartered, which makes two-thirds of its profit in Asia, said it set the price of new shares it is selling in Hong Kong at 84 Hong Kong dollars ($10.77) each. Standard Chartered sold 30.4 million shares, or about 2.8 percent of its stock, meaning it will raise 2.6 billion Hong Kong dollars ($333 million).

title: A Pataki Overseer of Safety Is Removed at Indian Point
description: One of the people who has been heading Gov. George E. Pataki's safety review of the Indian Point nuclear plant was removed from the project today after The New York Times inquired about his links to the Entergy Corp., the plant's owner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, SYLVIA
description: COOPER - Sylvia. Devoted and loving daughter, sister, wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Our heartfelt thanks to Josephine, Lisette and Mary for their devotion and care. May she rest in peace. Amy and Dr. Sheldon Cooper and family. Ellen and Arthur Singer and family.

title: City Announces Hiring Freeze And Imposes More Cutbacks
description: With the city's fiscal outlook going from bad to worse, the Bloomberg administration ordered a citywide hiring freeze yesterday and told most agencies to cut spending by an additional 2 percent.

title: World Briefing | The Environment: Twin Threats To Kyoto Treaty
description: European Union officials and environmentalists criticized two developments at talks in New Delhi aimed at curbing global warming. One was a retreat by Russia from its announced plans to speedily ratify the Kyoto protocol, the first to require cuts in heat-trapping gases. Russia's delegate said the details needed more study. The other issue was a draft declaration from negotiators halfway through the 10-day conference that appeared to reflect the views of the Bush administration, which rejected the pact last year. Without American participation, ratification by Russia is essential for the treaty to have legal force.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK -- Alfred McLaren; Explorer of Arctic Depths Plans Another Trip North
description: Dr. Alfred S. McLaren has probably spent more time than anyone else in the twilight zone beneath the earth's northern ice, measuring its thickness, probing dark waters below, investigating its life and mapping the plains, crags and fissures of its seabed.

title: A Passionate Voice, Stilled in Minnesota
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, LESLIE NEI LAND
description: GALLAGHER - Leslie Nei land. 1923 to October, 2002. The Board of Directors and The Members of The University Glee Club of New York City mourn with deep sadness the passing of their Brother in Song and Past President, L. Neiland Gallagher. Neil joined The Glee Club as a second tenor in 1954, shortly after having earned a degree in English from Amherst College in 1951. From the beginning, he participated in many of The Club's activities. One of his greatest successes was playing the hilarious role of ''Adelaide'' in the stag ''Hairy Leg'' rendition of ''Guys and Dolls.'' One critic of his performance said: ''Gallagher was a born Broadway actress with a Bronx accent who sang as sweetly as Vivian Blaine.'' He served on The Board of Directors for many years, eventually becoming Vice President in 1977 and President in 1979. With the establishment of The International Concert Tours, as a Club tradition in 1987, Neil went overseas and sang with The Club in each and every one of those adventurous journeys, including the most recent concert tour to Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic this past summer. He is renowned for his conducting of his beloved ''Lord Jeffrey Amherst'' around the world and successfully accomplished this one last time while in Hungary. He was famous for remembering every bit of minutia, detail and trivia that came across his mind. As a result he was appointed Club Historian. Because of his depth of knowledge of The UGC's history, its constitution and traditions, he was regularly asked by The Board to be the speaker at The Induction Ceremony of each new incoming freshman class. Neil was a unique individual, intelligent, a man of action, a loving father and a good friend. In his life he had four great loves: his family, The University Glee Club of New York City, Amherst College, and The United States Marine Corps (he saw action in Okinawa and was part of the Occupation Forces in Tsingtao, China). It was not an option to love one more than the other, he loved them all equally. We shall miss him and he is remembered fondly by all of his Brothers in Song at The University Glee Club of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, EDITH
description: LYONS-Edith. The Board, Council and staff of Planned Parenthood of New York City are deeply saddened by the death of Honorary Board member Mrs. Edith Lyons. Edith joined the PPNYC Board in the early 1960's, volunteered in our medical centers and served as the first president of the merged New York City affiliate from 1966 to 1971. Edith was an outstanding fundraiser and was herself a very generous supporter of our programs. We will long remember Edith forher half century commitment to this agency, and to the health and rights of women in New York City. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her entire family. Cathy A. Cramer, Chair, PPNYC Board of Directors Joan Malin, President & CEO

description: Truls Mork, cellist; Yefim Bronfman, pianist; and Gil Shaham, violinist

description: SHAHEEN-Barbara Tracy. Beloved wife of John. Mother of Michael and Bradford, sister to Elizabeth Tracy King and Eleanor Tracy Kuenning. Passed away October 23, 2001. Interment service at Arlington National Cemetery was held on October 23, 2002.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA: NATIONALISTS SWORN IN Croatian, Muslim and Serbian nationalists were sworn in as the members of Bosnia's tripartite presidency and sought to dispel fears that a hard-liners' comeback in elections this month would deepen the ethnic divide. Sulejman Tihic (Muslim Party of Democratic Action), Mirko Sarovic (Serbian Democratic Party) and Dragan Covic (Croatian Democratic Union) are to share power in the largely symbolic presidency for four years. "Do believe us," Mr. Covic said in comments directed at international envoys at the ceremony. "More than you, we want a democratic and European Bosnia-Herzegovina."    (Agence France-Presse)

title: New Hampshire Rivals Look to Independents
description: The most potent campaign commercial so far in New Hampshire's neck-and-neck Senate race is one that in other states might be considered milquetoast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, BARBARA (NEE STEGLEIN)
description: ANDERSON-Barbara (nee Steglein). Age 52, inspirational teacher, F.I.T., died October 26, 2002 after a long illness. Her husband Lennart, daughter Jeanette, family, friends and colleagues celebrate her life. Friends may visit at M.J. Smith Sons Funeral Home, 248 Prospect Park West, Bklyn, 718-788-2255, Tuesday, October 29, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service Wednesday, October 30, 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Lymphoma Foundation would be appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Mobile Phone Merger
description: Telekom Malaysia will offer $1 billion to buy the shares it does not own in a rival mobile phone company, bidding to become the country's No. 1 cellular operator after a government call for consolidation. The merger of state-owned Telekom's mobile unit with the rival, Celcom Malaysia, will give the company a 40 percent market share, toppling Maxis Communications. Telekom Malaysia, the country's biggest fixed-line operator, will sell its unprofitable mobile phone unit Telekom Cellular to Celcom for 1.68 billion ringgit ($442 million) in new stock, increasing its stake in Celcom to 47.9 percent and requiring it to make an offer for the rest of Celcom. Telekom Malaysia will also assume 316 million ringgit of debt.

title: Metro Briefing: New Jersey
description: HARTFORD: SCHOOLS SUPERINTENDENT RESIGNS Anthony S. Amato, the superintendent of Hartford's troubled school system, abruptly resigned yesterday, ending a rocky three-and-a-half-year tenure in which he raised abysmally low test scores but alienated some educators and city officials by openly seeking more prestigious job offers elsewhere. Though Mr. Amato said his departure was voluntary, some officials in Hartford said that they believed he was forced out by Mayor Eddie A. Perez. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
description: Business confidence in Germany sagged to a nine-month low this month amid fears that tax increases and spending cuts proposed by Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's new government would revive the torpid economy. The monthly index published by the Ifo Institute, a Munich-based economic research group, dropped to 87.7, from 88.2 in September. Private-sector economic forecasts for Germany predict near-zero growth in 2002. Ifo's researchers noted, however, that confidence improved among retailers, wholesalers and construction concerns in October, suggesting that Germany might escape a double-dip recession. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: ARMS  INSPECTORS BACK TOUGH TERMS TO PRESSURE IRAQ
description: The leaders of the United Nations weapons inspections teams asked the Security Council today for an aggressive new mandate backed up with a threat of enforcement action, giving the United States a boost in negotiations over its draft resolution to disarm Iraq.

title: Seven-Footer Chooses Rutgers
description: Shagari Alleyne, a 7-foot-3 senior center from Rice High School, verbally committed to play basketball for Rutgers next season at a news conference at the Manhattan school yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Schools Superintendent Resigns
description: Anthony S. Amato, the superintendent of Hartford's troubled school system, abruptly resigned yesterday, ending a rocky three-and-a-half-year tenure in which he raised abysmally low test scores but alienated some educators and city officials by openly seeking more prestigious job offers elsewhere. Though Mr. Amato said his departure was voluntary, some officials in Hartford said that they believed he was forced out by Mayor Eddie A. Perez. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Inquiry Finds American Was Killed by Fire From U.S. Gunship, Not Enemy
description: The first American soldier killed in the last major battle in Afghanistan died from fire from an Air Force AC-130 gunship, not hostile mortar blasts as the Pentagon initially thought, a military investigation has concluded.

title: Handbag Maker Takes Aim at Knockoffs
description: When housewives in the suburbs began selling Kate Spade knockoffs at ''purse parties'' -- and telling the police they couldn't be doing anything illegal because they were careful to tell their customers they were fake -- Andy Spade knew the company had to take some serious action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, NATHAN
description: WEINTRAUB - Nathan. Be loved husband of Roslyn, devoted father of Kenneth and the late Clifford. Cherished brother of Morton. Services Wednesday, 1 P.M. at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Fox's Program Beats Out 'Larry King Live'
description: For the first time since ''Larry King Live'' made its debut 16 years ago, something else has become the most-watched cable news program at 9 p.m.

title: Global Trade in Elmwood Park: Familiar Saga With a Twist
description: WHEN legislation making it easier for the United States to enter new free-trade agreements was passed last summer, reactions were black and white.

title: Leftist Brazilian Victor Moves to Calm Nervous Markets
description: Brazil's president-elect, Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of the leftist Workers' Party, moved quickly today to calm financial markets here and abroad that have displayed nervousness about his assumption of power, promising that Brazil will not default on its growing public debt or embark on a spending binge once he takes office.

title: A Lesson in Cleaner Hands
description: Antibacterial soap is no better than regular soap at keeping hands free of bacteria, according to a study presented last week. But what does seem to have a striking effect on cleanliness, the study's author said, is the feeling that somebody is keeping track of how well people scrub.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hundreds Of Weapons Turned In
description: A program offering cash for guns has persuaded the public to turn in nearly 1,600 weapons, including sawed-off shotguns and assault weapons, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. In the five months since May, when the program began, 898 revolvers, 542 semiautomatic pistols, 96 sawed-off shotguns and 49 assault weapons have been turned in. The city pays $100 in cash, with no questions asked, for each gun and has so far paid more than $158,000. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Edward Mortola, 85; Oversaw Expansion at Pace
description: Dr. Edward Joseph Mortola, who presided as Pace grew from a small downtown Manhattan business school into one of the country's largest independent universities, died on Oct. 21 at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Stoic British Folk Tradition Offers Tales of Faded Hopes
description: Linda Thompson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, EWALD
description: MAYER-Ewald, 83. Passed away peacefully in his home. Until late in life, he was active in the financial field with Herzog, Heine & Geduld. He is mourned by his wife Eva, daughter Catheryne Johnston and granddaughter Tonya. Funeral services will be private.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Chief Says Hardware Demand Is Improving
description: Michael Dell, the chief executive of Dell Computer, said yesterday that worldwide demand for computer hardware had improved and that the Far East would be a good market for the world's biggest personal computer maker. ''Globally, we've seen some rebound in overall demand,'' Mr. Dell said at a news conference in Tokyo, where he introduced the company's smallest desktop computer. ''There's great opportunity for Dell, especially in Japan and the Asia Pacific.'' Dell surpassed the Hewlett-Packard Company in the third quarter to again become the world's biggest personal-computer maker, the market researcher IDC said earlier this month. Mr. Dell, above, reiterated that a rebound in PC's will be driven by improvement in corporate customers' profits. ''We continue to face a challenging market in an economic sense around the world, but Dell is succeeding by maintaining a relentless focus on customers,'' he said. Shares of Dell, based in Austin, Tex. fell 10 cents yesterday, to $28.94.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Sunday about the resignation of an Emory University professor, Michael Bellesiles, who was accused of unprofessional and misleading work on a book about guns in America, misstated recent accusations against three other authors. The three -- Doris Kearns Goodwin, Prof. Louis W. Roberts and the late Stephen Ambrose -- were not accused of academic fraud.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Abraham Gives Edwards and the Struggling Jets Some Feud for Thought
description: Quarterback Chad Pennington threw his arms around John Abraham this afternoon, a playful gesture by the team's new golden boy to indicate that despite Abraham's harsh postgame assessment of the Jets and their coaches, he had not alienated his teammates.

title: Online in Cairo, With News, Views and 'Fatwa Corner'
description: Inside a run-down building in a middle-class Cairo neighborhood, a hybrid group of eager young dot-commers and idealistic religious messengers produces one of the Islamic world's leading Web sites, Islam-Online.net.

title: Executive Quits As Bayer Wins Patent Case
description: Heightening the sense of disarray surrounding the German drug and chemical maker Bayer, the company said yesterday that it was replacing a senior executive of its health care operations for the second time in less than a year.

title: Sure, Life May Be a Drag, But You Can Laugh at It
description: Maybe I've just seen too many drag queens, but I no longer find the sight of a man wearing makeup, a wig, high heels and a dress (usually from some other decade) inherently funny. Or politically important. The audience at ''Blessing in Disguise,'' however, appeared to find every minute of it hysterical.

title: Social Whirl May Help Keep the Mind Dancing
description: People hoping to stay sharp as they age often turn to crossword puzzles, math problems and other demanding intellectual pursuits.

title: Something Amiss in the Garlic
description: People who chew garlic tablets to help their hearts while avoiding the smell may be helping nothing at all. A study being published online today showed that 7 of 14 garlic supplements contained less of garlic's active ingredient than researchers called necessary for a therapeutic effect.

title: U.S. Crime Rate Rose 2% in 2001 After 10 Years of Decreases
description: For the first time since 1991, serious and violent crime in the United States increased last year, the F.B.I. reported yesterday.

title: How Foods Earn the New Organic Seal
description: Less than 1 percent of U.S. agricultural land is organic, but that is changing fast. More than 2.3 million acres were farmed in 2001 -- two-and-a-half times as much as in 1995. For the first time, ''organic'' foods have to meet consistent standards, the government announced last week. Here are some of the rules farmers and processors must follow.

title: Consumer Confidence Plunged to 9-Year Low
description: In a report that is not only a warning signal for the economy but could also have an impact on next week's Congressional elections, the Conference Board reported today that consumer confidence plunged to a nine-year low in October.

title: Nassau Raises Property Tax By 20% in Its New Budget
description: Nassau County legislators late tonight adopted a $2.3 billion budget for 2003 that raises county property taxes by nearly 20 percent and cuts the work force by 1,400 jobs as the first chapter of a four-year plan to rescue the county from near-bankruptcy.

title: The King's New Clothes, for All to See
description: Can there be anything about the Duke and Duchess of Windsor that has not been written or that isn't already known? Biographers, hagiographers, muckrakers and Hollywood have all had a field day with this curious couple, whose story legendarily turns on a mystifying passion and inevitably devolves into one about more humdrum pathos. Now, with ''Blithe Spirit: The Windsor Set,'' which opens on Thursday, the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art brings them back into view.

title: The Connecticut Elections; For Congress
description: For the two most competitive Congressional races in Connecticut this year, here are our endorsements:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Arrivederci, Self-Esteem

title: World Business Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: MINER ACQUIRED The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian miner with holdings in western Africa, agreed to buy the Repadre Capital Corporation , which has stakes in two mines in Ghana, for about 348.1 million Canadian dollars ($223 million) to increase production. Iamgold will pay 1.6 shares for each Repadre share, equivalent to 8.48 Canadian dollars a share, a 16 percent over Repadre's closing price on Friday. With the acquisition, Iamgold, which is based in Toronto, will raise annual production to 450,000 ounces from last year's 256,000 ounces. (Bloomberg News)

title: Teenagers Told to Turn In Fake ID's
description: Westchester County teenagers have 30 days to turn in fake driver's licenses used to buy alcohol, or risk losing their real licenses under a new campaign against under-age drinking announced today by the Westchester district attorney's office.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: INDIA: GUJURAT PLANS ELECTIONS Balloting for members of the state Assembly is to be held on Dec. 12 in riot-torn Gujarat, the chief election commissioner, L. M. Lyngdoh, announced. More than 1,000 people, mostly Muslims, were killed in Hindu-Muslim rioting that began in February in Gujarat. Nominations for the 182-member Legislature open on Nov. 18. P. J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Shop Slows U.S. Inquiry Into Rifle
description: Upstairs above his gun shop and behind a door marked ''Employees Only,'' Brian Borgelt huddled today at a laptop computer on a desk piled high with paperwork. Mr. Borgelt, the owner of Bull's Eye Shooter Supply, flipped through a wad of business cards from journalists. Outside in the parking lot, television cameras were fixed on the store's entrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, DONALD J.
description: DONAHUE-Donald J. We mourn the passing of Donald J. Donahue, a distinguished and valued former member of the Board of Trustees of ICD-International Center for the Disabled.

title: Endorsement Paradox
description: To the Editor:

title: PUTIN VOWS HUNT FOR TERROR CELLS AROUND THE WORLD
description: President Vladimir V. Putin, echoing statements by President Bush after the Sept. 11 attacks, said today that Russia was prepared to strike at international terrorist groups in whatever country harbored them.

title: 'But Will You Be Warm Enough, Dear?'
description: To the Editor:

title: Aegis Reports Gains From Broadcast Ads
description: The Aegis Group in London said it was reaping the benefits of ''further clear improvements'' in broadcast advertising in the United States since the first half of the year and that it expected results for the year before one-time costs to be ''significantly better'' than in 2001.

title: New Hopes for Quieting the Roaring in the Ear
description: External sounds that disrupt your concentration and your sleep are bad enough. But in most cases they are either short-lived or there is some way to escape them or shut them out. But when the noise is inside your head and continuous or nearly so, it could literally drive you crazy.

title: Guided Sightseeing Tours
description: Boat, bus and other vehicular tours tend to have reasonably regular schedules, but some seasonal change can occur. Schedules, prices and meeting places for most of the walking tours listed here can vary wildly throughout the year, so call or check each companys Web site well in advance to avoid surprises.

title: Carbon Monoxide Fumes Kill Four in a Family
description: Four members of a family were found dead in their home this morning in what the authorities said was an accidental case of carbon monoxide poisoning, possibly a result of a malfunctioning heating system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Another Lawmaker Attacked
description: An opposition legislator was punched in the stomach while making a speech, three days after a lawmaker of the same party was stabbed to death. The police in Nagoya arrested an 18-year-old man for attacking Yukichi Maeda at a commuter station; the man appeared not to have political connections. On Saturday, a right-wing extremist was arrested and charged with the murder of Koki Ishii, also a deputy from the Democratic Party, the largest opposition. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROOT, JACK
description: ROOT-Jack. I loved you dearly. Love Anna

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDEL, DR. NINA
description: RUDEL-Dr. Nina. Died in NYC on October 26, 2002, in her 91st year. Dearest friend and family. In the 1960s she headed the Child Health Centers in NYC. Her great interest in literature resulted in forming a book club at the Elmhurst Library which enriched the lives of many. She will be greatly missed and lovingly remembered. Services at Parkside Funeral Chapel, Queens, 98-60 Queens Blvd, Tuesday, 1:30 PM.

title: Mushroom Rings
description: Q. There is a perfectly circular ring of about 50 mushrooms in my yard in Chappaqua, N.Y., five or six feet in diameter. Are they growing over a circular septic system?

title: A Sick Banking System Resists Therapy
description: In the heady, asset-inflated bubble of the 1980's, Hamao Yokota used to receive marching orders from his boss, a branch manager at the Bank of Yokohama: Lend money or else.

title: The Moods of Urban Society Are a New Troupe's Focus
description: Urban Ballet Theater

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Express Earnings Rise Sharply in Quarter

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Usually people ask us to clean up toxic dust. But this is the first time we've ever been asked to preserve toxic dust.''

title: The Fateful Gamble in Moscow
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNDY, EVELYN B.
description: GUNDY-Evelyn B., 98. Died October 25, 2002 in Natick, MA. She leaves her children Elizabeth of Seal Cove, ME., and Walter of Lincoln, MA, and her grandchildren Nathaniel, Alexander and Aaron.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Newburgh: 18 Accused Of Gunrunning
description: Eighteen people have been arrested on charges of gunrunning and drug-trafficking as part of a seven-month investigation, James B. Comey, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said yesterday. Mr. Comey said that the suspects illegally obtained guns by paying others to buy them legally in Southeastern states. They then transported the guns north to Newburgh, in Orange County, for resale. So far, investigators have seized 26 guns, including shotguns and pistols, and three-quarters of a kilo of crack cocaine, among other drugs. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: FANNIE MAE PLANS A RECORD SALE OF LONG-TERM DEBT
description: Fannie Mae, the largest buyer of home mortgages, said yesterday that it expects to sell a record $290 billion of long-term debt next year to finance growth in its loan portfolio. The sales will include as much as $30 billion of callable benchmark notes, a spokesman, Jason Lobo, said. Fannie Mae has sold $172.5 billion in debt due in two or more years through Sept. 30 this year, including $15.8 billion in callable benchmark debt. Fannie Mae expects ''rapid portfolio growth'' in 2003, according to its third-quarter earnings announcement, even as the Mortgage Bankers Association of America forecasts a decline in mortgage originations. The company's commitments to buy mortgages rose to a record $57 billion in September as mortgage rates fell to the lowest levels in more than three decades.

title: In Data Trove, a Graphic Look at Towers' Fall
description: There is a computer image that captures the jetliner's nose as it splays open like a log being split, its wings shearing apart, the entire aircraft dissolving into a hail of steel and aluminum buckshot during its deadly plunge through one of the twin towers.

title: A cable network offers the ultimate plan to end ad zapping: commercials within programs.
description: TELEVISION networks, dreading a future in which digital devices hand viewers the power to skip commercials automatically, have responded by increasingly integrating ads into the programs themselves. Now, a new cable network has elevated the practice beyond the occasional, building such anti-ad-zapping efforts directly into its business model.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GORMAN, ETHEL
description: GORMAN-Ethel. October 29, 1914. Lovingly remembered on her birthday and every day by her family. Linda, Doug, Abby & Richard

title: Feeling Postwar Changes In One American Backyard
description: ''The Sweepers'' has reopened at Urban Stages, 259 West 30th Street, Manhattan, where it had a limited run last spring. Following are excerpts from Lawrence Van Gelder's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 9. The full text is online at nytimes.com/theater.

title: The Mood at Work: Anger and Anxiety
description: THE ebullient mood of American workers during the 1990's boom has evaporated over the last two years, a victim of recession, rising unemployment, a hobbled stock market and scandals at WorldCom, Enron and other corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAHER, BRIAN JOHN
description: MAHER-Brian John. In his 38th year, suddenly. Of Charlotte, NC, also Chatham, NJ, and Oakville, Ontario. Beloved by his wife Barbara (Davren) Maher and their children, Clare and Liam Maher. Loving son of Edward Gerry Maher and Eileen Maher of Cape Coral, FL., and Oakville, Ontario, Canada. Cherished brother of Kevin Maher, Phyllis Florian, Diane Sarikas, Clare Emery, Carol Murray, and Patrick Maher. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews, and beloved by his many aunts and uncles. The family will receive visitors at St. Matthew's Catholic Church at 8015 Ballintyne Commons Boulevard, Charlotte, N.C. 28277. On Wednesday, October 30th, 2002 at 10 AM followed by Mass at 11AM, a reception will follow at the church hall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Brian's memory to St., Matthew's Catholic Church Building Fund, 8015 Ballintyne Commons Blvd, Charlotte, NC 28277.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUM, BILLIE
description: STRUM-Billie. We mourn the death of our beloved friend and Board Member who was instrumental in creating AICF's Young Leadership Group. After immigrating to Israel, he continued his involvement with the arts. Our hearts go out to his wonderful family. Vera Stern, President Harvey Rothenberg, Treas. America-Israel Cultural Foundation

title: American Express Third-Quarter Earnings More Than Double
description: The American Express Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled from the period a year earlier, when it was suffering from a slump in travel and spending after the terrorist attacks, bad junk-bond investments and costs from layoffs.

title: On the Prowl in the Land of Lost Cats
description: IT is a chilly evening in Chinatown and Holly Staver, the president of City Critters, an animal rescue group, is tapping on the smudged window of a silver van near Grand Street. Inside the van, there are cats, 14 of them; some pressed against the windshield, others sprawled across a grizzled man lying on the front seat.

title: Citigroup Deal Approved
description: Citigroup's planned $4.9 billion purchase of the California-based Golden State Bancorp, was approved yesterday by the Federal Reserve in a 7-to-0 vote.

title: Available Spaces Behind The Prescription Counter
description: SOMETIMES a job pays well but perhaps not well enough. While other health care positions go begging because nurses and others feel that they are being paid too little to care for too many patients, pharmacy has generally been viewed as a lucrative and attractive profession. But many hospitals and clinics, in addition to drugstores and retailers, are struggling to find pharmacists. Although pharmacists, even right out of school, can earn about $80,000 a year, industry executives say it remains a challenge to find licensed people.

title: MERCK AND SCHERING-PLOUGH RISE AFTER DRUG APPROVAL
description: Shares of the Schering-Plough Corporation and Merck & Company rose yesterday after the drug makers won federal approval of Zetia, a cholesterol treatment that analysts expect to have annual sales of $1 billion or more. Shares of Schering-Plough, based in Kenilworth, N.J., climbed 78 cents, to $21.13, and Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., rose $1.32, to $54.23. Zetia sales may top $2 billion, said Jami Rubin, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, in a note to investors. The Food and Drug Administration approved Zetia after a 10-month review, the companies said late Friday. Studies have shown that Zetia further reduced cholesterol levels when combined with Merck's Zocor or Pfizer's Lipitor, the top cholesterol medicines.

title: Minnesota Senator's Last Day Had a Typical Start
description: Settling into his small campaign plane bound for northern Minnesota on a cold and drizzly Friday morning, Senator Paul Wellstone yanked his seat belt tighter, heaved a sigh, and confided: ''I hate this.'' The pilot, who flew with him frequently and, like everyone else, called the senator by his first name, teased her jittery passenger about the uncertain weather and probable turbulence. ''Take it easy on me,'' Mr. Wellstone pleaded.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ads Protest Possible Fire Dept. Cuts
description: A volunteer group has produced a series of broadcast commercials and print advertisements opposing possible budget cuts at the New York Fire Department. The commercials will star such performers as James Gandolfini, from the television show ''The Sopranos,'' and Doug E. Fresh, the rap performer. The volunteer group, F.D.N.Y. Is Worth It, is headed by a law school student, Susan Berkowitz. The television and radio advertisements will be offered to stations as public service announcements, she said. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Chechen Missile Downs Russian Helicopter Over Its Base
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29  A Russian military helicopter was shot down today as it prepared to land at the main Russian military base in Chechnya, killing the three crew members and one passenger.

title: Priests Have Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: For the People
description: Ghoulish but true: as Minnesota mourns the death of Senator Paul Wellstone, many of the state's residents have been receiving fliers bearing a picture of a tombstone. The fliers, sent out by a conservative business group, denounce the late senator's support for maintaining the estate tax. Under the tombstone, the text reads in part: ''Paul Wellstone not only wants to tax you and your business to death . . . he wants to tax you in the hereafter.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday and a front-page summary for an article about President Bush's visit to Mexico misstated the facts of the article, about Mexico's stance in the United Nations Security Council toward Iraq. Mexico gave President Bush no pledge to support the United States resolution in the Council. But President Vicente Fox did not tell Mr. Bush that Mexico would not support it.

title: Many Universes, Several Theories
description: Is the universe all that is the case? Or are there worlds beyond our own? Many cosmologists these days contemplate a so-called multiverse of an endless series of big bangs blooming from one another, creating universes without limit, but they are not alone. A variety of modern theories predict a plethora of universes. Here are a few.

title: Fakery and Moths
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eyes Have It
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Aboard the Cruiser Shiloh
description: The U.S. Navy, with allies likely and unlikely, stems the flow of Iraqi oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, NATHAN
description: WEINTRAUB - Nathan. Be loved husband of Roslyn, devoted father of Kenneth and the late Clifford. Cherished brother of Morton. Services Wednesday, 1 P.M. at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Listeria Thrives in a Political Hotbed
description: SINCE summer, foods contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes bacteria have killed 7 people, sickened 46 and caused 3 miscarriages. This month Wampler Foods, a division of Pilgrim's Pride, recalled over 27 million pounds of poultry products it had manufactured, in the largest such recall in the history of the Agriculture Department.

title: Accounts
description: * Helzberg Diamonds, Kansas City, Mo., part of Berkshire Hathaway, to Doner, Southfield, Mich., to handle the retailer's account, with spending estimated at $10 million. The account had been handled by Earle Palmer Brown, New York, part of Panoramic Communications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKEY, SHANNON E.
description: HICKEY-Shannon E. 19, of Jupiter Island, FL, passed away Sunday, October 27, 2002 as the result of an automobile accident. He was born and raised in East Rockaway, NY, had been a resident of Jupiter Island for five years, coming from New York. Shannon was a 2001 graduate of Jupiter High School, attended Palm Beach Community College and planned on attending Florida State University. He was an avid outdoorsman enjoying boating, golfing and fishing. He was a friend to many and loved by all. Survivors include his parents, Thomas and Valerie Hickey of Jupiter Island; his two Brothers, Ryan Thomas and Colin Jesse Hickey, both of Jupiter Island; his maternal grandmother, Elizabeth Guarnieri of East Rockaway, NY; his paternal grandparents, Thomas and Maureen Hickey of Franklin Square, NY and many aunts, uncles and cousins. He was predeceased by his maternal grandfather Louis Guarnieri. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10am Friday, November 1, 2002 at St. Jude Catholic Church, Tequesta, FL. Those who wish, may make contributions to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, 332 North Lauderdale, Box 318, Memphis, TN 38101-2729. Friends may call Thursday, October 31 from 1-3 & 6-9pm at the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL

title: Big Eaters, Sure, But This Is Absurd
description: ED (COOKIE) JARVIS was sipping a glass of water. A large man with a body shaped like a water balloon pinched at the top, Mr. Jarvis looked calm.

title: Old-Fashioned Graft
description: As graft goes, New Jersey's latest cases are small and old-fashioned: a mayor keeps $50,000 in bribes around the house, most in the pocket of an old suit in his attic. Another mayor has a contractor install a waterfall in his backyard. A county executive takes an envelope full of bills in a hotel room. Big or small, old style or new, North Jersey or South, the game goes on. Most recently, two powerful county executives, one Democrat and one Republican, have been brought down.

title: Memorial for Wellstone Assumes Spirit of Rally
description: The mourners wore green Wellstone buttons on their black suits. The closing hymn was a campaign song, ''Stand Up, Keep Fighting'' -- only its refrain was edited, from ''Vote for Paul Wellstone'' to ''Remember Paul Wellstone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, BEATRICE (NEE BEHRENS)
description: LEVY-Beatrice (nee Behrens) in Boca Raton, FL. Woodmere HS '47, Cornell Univ '51. Loving wife of Richard. Devoted mom and grandma. Brother Herb. Sisters Phyllis, Arline, Hannah. You are in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'HEARN, JAMES
description: O'HEARN-James, on October 26th. He is survived by his beloved sisters, Barbara and Ellen. Devoted uncle to his many nieces and nephews. Dearest friend of Ronald Bogus and Augusto Labat.

title: Tensions Rise Over Who Will Prosecute, and How
description: The Justice Department brought federal extortion and firearms charges today against John Muhammad that could result in his execution, ratcheting up tensions over where and how the former soldier should be prosecuted.

title: Investigators In Jordan Seek Clues in Death Of U.S. Envoy
description: A day after a senior American diplomat was assassinated here, Jordan today began rounding up dozens of men with links to training camps in Afghanistan or other militant Islamic causes, still seeking clues to who might have been behind the attack, security officials and Western diplomats said.

title: Vandals, With Fire and Rockets, Attack 4 Afghan Girls' Schools
description: Vandals attacked four elementary schools for girls outside Kabul last week, firing rockets at two and burning blackboards and floor mats at two others, United Nations officials said today.

title: McCall Audit Says State Agency Wasted Millions
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall released an audit yesterday that he said showed that the Pataki administration had allowed the State Institute for Entrepreneurship to squander millions of dollars.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Executive Takes On Additional Role
description: Samuel J. Palmisano, the chief executive of I.B.M., will assume the added role of chairman from Louis V. Gerstner, who will retire from the computer maker at the end of the year. Mr. Palmisano, 51, replaced Mr. Gerstner as chief executive in March. Mr. Gerstner, 60, was hired in 1993 and restored I.B.M.'s profit a year later, after $15.9 billion in net losses from 1991 to 1993. He will be an adviser to I.B.M. after leaving the company and its board, a spokeswoman, Carol Makovich, said yesterday. Since Mr. Palmisano's promotion from chief operating officer, the 29-year I.B.M. veteran has cut jobs and costs and shed underperforming businesses to maintain profitability amid slumping demand. Such efforts will continue with the greater authority he will have after the departure of Mr. Gerstner, the company's leader for almost a decade, investors and analysts said.

title: Hurricanes Make a Little Go a Long Way in Victory
description: Sometime between the shocking first-round playoff collapse last spring and tonight, the Devils elevated Carolina from a new rival into a baffling nemesis.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Another View of Leadership

title: With Maryland Arrest, Tacoma Family Finds an Answer
description: To the Nichols family, John Muhammad was just a guy who came by with his three kids for barbecues in the backyard, an adept auto mechanic with an eye for detail and an air of conviction.

title: Gay History Is Still in the Closet
description: Harry Hay was a remarkable figure by any measure, though most Americans have not heard his name. As a Marxist who proudly called himself a sissy, he was the first American to imagine a gay community.

title: McDonald's France Says Slow Down on the Fast Food
description: It isn't often that a food company tells its customers that it should eat less of its food. But that is what McDonald's appears to have done in France.

title: Oil Pipeline Forges Ahead in Ecuador
description: Environmentalists in this cloud forest of northern Ecuador still dream of halting construction of a new oil pipeline that the builders said could bring spectacular wealth to this poor Andean country. But with the 300-mile-long, privately financed pipeline now 70 percent complete, and long green tubes replacing the palm and canelo trees, even the most die-hard opponents acknowledge that stopping the construction is next to impossible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. & 90 St., on Friday, November 1 at 11 AM.

title: Barber's 'Vanessa' at the Washington Opera
description: WASHINGTON - Samuel Barber's "Vanessa" fades from view but always seems to reappear, now at the Washington Opera. Real worth keeps it alive, but "Vanessa" also benefits from its competition: a parade of new American operas that light up and die like fireflies.

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disney Resort Remodels for Business Travelers
description: The advertisements for restaurants in the Walt Disney Swan Resort and the Walt Disney Dolphin Resort hotels here include a place with ''Disney Character Dining Opportunities,'' as illustrated by a young girl grinning at a person dressed as a dog who holds a thumbed paw the size of a steering wheel atop her blond head. For more sophisticated travelers, a steakhouse, the promotional literature states, features ''a pleasant, intimate atmosphere, surrounded by Miami Dolphins memorabilia.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Taxi Survey On Celebrity Voices
description: You might like Joe Torre, Jackie Mason, Yo-Yo Ma and even Joan Rivers, left. But do you like being required to hear them in the back of a speeding taxicab? The city's Taxi and Limousine Commission wants to know. Yesterday, the agency posted a brief questionnaire on its Web site, www.ci.nyc.ny.us/html/tlc, and asked the public to fill it out. Five years ago, the commission equipped all of the city's 12,187 cabs with speaker systems that play safety messages from New York celebrities, mostly to cajole passengers into buckling up. Officials want to make sure the messages work and see whether passengers find the voices annoying. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Howe and Mets Talk to Baylor
description: The Mets' new manager, Art Howe, has talked to Don Baylor about becoming his bench coach. But Baylor, the former manager of the Colorado Rockies and the Chicago Cubs, is waiting to see if managing opportunities become available.

title: Courting American Dreamers
description: Gov. George E. Pataki released this 30-second advertisement yesterday in which he speaks more Spanish than in any of his previous commercials. The governor, who has been aggressively courting traditionally Democratic voters, also released two 60-second radio ads intended for African-American and Haitian-American listeners (the latter is in Haitian Creole but an announcer speaks, not Mr. Pataki.) The television ad is running on Spanish-language stations in New York City.

title: A Surprise From Bologna Warms a Village Table
description: HERE'S a tip from the boys at the WXOU bar on Hudson Street, whispered over pints. Just walk into Da Andrea, that little joint across the street, and order a plate of tigelle ($8.50). Do it even before you've looked at the menu, before you've asked for a short glass of wine, before anything. Biscuits are involved. It takes a while to make.

title: Mugging, Hamming It Up and 4 Debuts at City Opera
description: With colorful costumes and stucco sets like frosting, City Opera's staging of Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' on Saturday afternoon seemed a bright Halloween, a world of amusing artifice and an antic foil for four American singers making company debuts.

title: Rummy Runs Rampant
description: Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld fired off a memo last week revoking the longstanding title ''CINC,'' or ''commander in chief,'' bestowed on Tommy Franks and the cadre of other four-star military chieftains who plan and fight American wars around the world.

title: Herring, the Fish That Roared
description: CAPT. BO CHRISTIANSON, the skipper of the Ron, a sturdy 115-foot trawler out of Fiskeback, a small port on Sweden's west coast, warned me to be careful. The deck was covered with slippery silver scales. Then he lifted a hatch so I could see the night's catch in the hold below: tens of thousands of beautiful fish, 8 to 10 inches long, with bluish backs, iridescent sides and gold eyes, kept fresh in a bath of refrigerated sea water.

title: Pyongyang Rejects Demands to End Atom Bomb Program
description: North Korea today flatly rejected international demands that it abandon its nuclear weapons program. The statement came at the opening session of talks with Japan aimed at establishing normal relations between the two countries.

title: The Democracy Thing
description: Think about the contrasting headlines made last week by the biggest Arab state and the smallest Arab state. From the biggest state, Egypt, came the news that its state TV planned to run a 41-part series during the month of Ramadan -- when TV viewing is at its highest -- about a Zionist conspiracy to control Arab lands. From the smallest state, Bahrain, came the news that it had successfully conducted the first democratic parliamentary election in the Arab gulf, to begin empowering Bahrainis to control their own land.

title: In the Spirit of Lorca, Distilling Hate and Love
description: Mention new dance of the 1960's and the image of a formalist avant-garde springs to mind. Yet Eleo Pomare represented a different rebellious strain at the time. His powerful dances were filled with social protest and drama, and still are.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Misuse Of Permit
description: A college student was charged yesterday with using a parking permit from a fire commissioner who died in the World Trade Center attack, fire officials said yesterday. The student, Vadim Reznikov, 20, of Brooklyn, was charged with possession of stolen property and other crimes. The dead commissioner, William Feehan, 71, was the Fire Department's second in command and had left his car on Broadway when he rushed inside the trade center on Sept. 11. Yesterday, fire marshals investigating the improper use of placards spotted Mr. Feehan's permit in the windshield of an Oldsmobile parked near Pace University. Nine other people have been arrested by marshals since September on charges of using fake parking permits. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: U.S. Report Makes No Call on For-Profit Schools
description: Claims that three private companies hired to run public schools here do significantly better -- or worse -- at improving student performance than traditional public schools cannot be substantiated, the General Accounting Office concluded in a report released today.

title: Skidmore College President Is Stepping Down
description: JAMIENNE S. STUDLEY, the president of Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., announced last week that she would step down at the end of the academic year after four years in the position. She said it was a ''natural time for transition'' since she had completed a new strategic plan. She said she hoped to strengthen financial aid and Skidmore's financial position in the coming year, but did not know what she would do after she left the college. A graduate of Barnard College and Harvard Law School, she previously was general counsel at the federal Department of Education and associate dean at Yale Law School. Karen W. Arenson

title: Bush Signs Legislation Intended to End Voting Disputes
description: President Bush signed a bill today to clean up the nation's election procedures. The measure sets minimum federal standards intended to prevent a repetition of the ballot disputes that cast a cloud over his election two years ago.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Head Of Orthodox Church Ailing
description: The Patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, Aleksy II, was hospitalized on Monday in the southern republic of Astrakhan and flown back to Moscow yesterday for further treatment and testing. The Interfax news agency reported that the patriarch, who is 73, was in serious condition on Monday after falling ill during a visit to the region, apparently suffering from the effects of hypertension. His condition improved enough by yesterday morning for him to return to Moscow. Aleksy II was elected patriarch in 1990. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Consumer Confidence at 9-Year Low, a Warning on Economy
description: In a report that was seen as a warning signal for the economy, the Conference Board said yesterday that consumer confidence in October plunged to a nine-year low.

title: Cheerleaders Put the Fun in Fund-Raising
description: Parodying a pornographic movie is redundant, but that's about my only complaint about ''Debbie Does Dallas,'' the cheerfully raunchy stage version -- adaptation is probably too strong a word -- of the 1979 film about cheerleaders in heat. Only complaint, that is, unless you consider this 85-minute sketch with music to be theater.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and three articles yesterday about the raid by Russian security forces on a Moscow theater held by Chechen guerrillas misstated the current figure for hostage deaths in the raid. It was 116, not 117 or 118. Gas used by the security forces killed the 116, according to Russian officials. Another was shot and killed by the guerrillas about three hours before the raid began. A woman who entered the theater after the guerrillas took it over on Wednesday night was also shot and killed by them.

title: World Business Briefing: Asia
description: SOUTHEAST ASIA: SHIFTING CREDIT OUTLOOK The Standard & Poor's credit rating agency warned that it might lower the Philippines' long-term credit rating because the country's budget deficit was widening, tax collection was poor and national debt was unusually large in proportion to the economy. The warning pushed up interest rates in the Philippines, which is struggling to pay for a war on terrorism after a series of bombings in the last six months. The agency now rates the Philippines BB+ for foreign-currency debts, just below investment grade. Standard & Poor's said it expected no change in its comparable rating of Indonesia, already well below investment grade at CCC+, despite the economic harm expected after the bombing in Bali.

title: U.S. AND FRANCE NEAR COMPROMISE ON ACTION ON IRAQ
description: The United States and France are moving toward a compromise on Iraq that would oblige the Bush administration to consult the United Nations Security Council before embarking on military action against Saddam Hussein but still leave it the freedom to act alone.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ulster: Republican Says 'War Is Over'
description: Martin McGuinness, a former leader of the Irish Republican Army and now a senior official of Sinn Fein, the guerrilla force's political party, said he had abandoned his fight with Britain, left the paramilitary group and was committed to preventing the deaths of any more British soldiers or I.R.A. members. ''My war is over,'' he said in a television documentary broadcast in Northern Ireland. Since the suspension this month of the Catholic-Protestant power-sharing government, in which Mr. McGuinness served, republicans have been under pressure to move to disarm and disband the I.R.A. Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, last week discouraged predictions of that happening but added that he could ''envisage a future without the I.R.A.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLE, CHARLES J.
description: COLE-Charles J. It's been 10 long years of missing and loving you. We will all be together this weekend to celebrate Alex's Bar Mitzvah and know that you will be there with us in our hearts and minds. Love, Abbie

title: Isles Fall Again After Early Lead
description: What started out as perhaps a minor slide to open the N.H.L. season has turned into a troubling slump for the Islanders. They dropped their third game in a row and fourth in five games, falling to the Carolina Hurricanes, 4-2, last night at the RBC Center in Raleigh, N.C. For the second night in a row, the Islanders took an early 2-0 lead and watched it disappear. On Tuesday, it was Phoenix that rallied from a 2-0 first-period deficit to post a 3-2 victory at Nassau Coliseum. Last night, the Hurricanes did the same, coming back from two goals down with three second-period goals. The Islanders are 1-3 in games in which they led after the first period. More significant, a season after finishing second in the Atlantic Division, the Islanders are last in the division at 3-6-1-0. Power-play goals by Shawn Bates and the rookie Justin Mapletoft gave the Islanders the 2-0 advantage against Carolina. Mapletoft's goal was his first in the N.H.L. But Carolina responded with a three-goal second period, two of the goals coming on power plays. Sami Kapanen closed the score to 2-1 when he took a pass from Bates Battaglia in front of the net and beat Islanders goalie Garth Snow from close range 4 minutes 28 seconds into the period. Then Jeff O'Neill scored on a rebound of a Kapanen shot to tie it at 8:35. When defenseman Niclas Wallin beat Snow between the pads with a low wrist shot from above the left circle pads at 15:46, the Hurricanes had the lead for good. Rod Brind'Amour added an empty-net goal with 26 seconds left. It was the second start in a row for Snow, who replaced the slumping Chris Osgood. It was the first time Snow had started consecutive games with Osgood healthy since last December.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Revenue Rises
description: Aventis, the French-German pharmaceutical company, said that third-quarter sales rose 21 percent, helped by sales of Allegra, an allergy treatment. Net income in the drug, vaccine and animal health units climbed to 560 million euros ($551 million) from 461 million euros one year earlier. Aventis, which also manufactures a cancer treatment, Taxotere, and a blood thinner, Lovenox, is one of the world's fastest-growing drug companies and is the largest drug manufacturer in France. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Arafat's New Cabinet, With Few New Faces, Is Approved
description: Yasir Arafat won overwhelming approval for his new cabinet from the Palestinian parliament today, turning back a legislative challenge to his authority that had forced his ministers to resign last month.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a briefing for the Security Council by United Nations weapons inspectors referred incorrectly to a comment by Hans Blix, the head of the chemical and biological weapons team, on Iraq's ability to comply with a proposed resolution. Mr. Blix did not say he thought it would be hard for Iraq to declare its chemical and biological weapons programs in 30 days, as the draft resolution demands; he said it would be hard for Iraq to complete a declaration of all of its chemical and biological industries in that time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Priest Gets Probation In Embezzlement
description: A Roman Catholic priest who pleaded guilty to stealing nearly $100,000 from the parish where he was once pastor was sentenced yesterday to five years' probation at a turbulent court hearing attended by members of his parish. The priest, the Rev. John Thompson, also made the first restitution payment of $10,000 to the working-class parish, St. Elizabeth's, in Ozone Park, Queens. Barbara Samide, the former principal of the parish school, attended the hearing. Ms. Samide was let go after she reported Father Thompson. One man had to be removed from the courtroom after he threatened Father Thompson. The priest's relatives provided the restitution money and would help him repay the remaining $84,000, the priest's lawyer said. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Even in Moscow's Grimness, A Spirit of the Arts Endures
description: It was a proud, young theater troupe, the first in Russia to perform musical plays Broadway style. It had just celebrated the first anniversary of its creation, ''Nord-Ost,'' a Russian musical that broke from Soviet traditions.

title: Police Checks on Vehicle Show Suspects' Movement
description: Police officers in Maryland, Virginia and Mississippi ran four checks on the license plate of the suspected snipers' Chevrolet Caprice in the 18 days before the first in the series of killings that shocked the Washington area, police records show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOCK, MAREE (SWEENEY)
description: BOCK-Maree (Sweeney). On October 26, 2002. Beloved wife of the late Kenneth E., Sr. Loving mother of Kenneth, Marguerite, Michael, Christopher and Maree (sonin-law John) and grandmother of Peter Hartley. Dear sister of J. Clement Sweeney. Funeral from Francis X. Hatton Funeral Home, 36-46 Bell Blvd., Bayside, NY on Wednesday. Funeral Mass at Sacred Heart Church, 11am. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Frank Lautenberg for U.S. Senate
description: The Senate race in New Jersey is a very different kind of contest than voters were anticipating a few weeks ago. With Senator Robert Torricelli out of the race, the contest no longer revolves around the question of how much of Mr. Torricelli's unappetizing ethics the state can stomach. Since Frank Lautenberg stepped in as the Democratic nominee, the voters have had the luxury of focusing on the actual issues.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Another Loss At Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu lost less money in the period from April to September than last year, but the company said it expected to remain in the red for the full year that ends in March because of continued weakness in the market for telecommunications equipment. In addition to losing 147 billion yen ($1.2 billion) in the first half of the year, the company expects to lose 110 billion yen for the full year; in an earlier forecast, it had predicted that it would break even. The company also sliced its sales target by 4 percent. The company plans to cut 7,100 more jobs, or 4.3 percent of its global payroll. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: A $10 million campaign for Swanson focuses on the new, fashionable TV dinner.
description: AS the camera lovingly alights on a beautiful woman, dressed to the nines in a plum-colored, strapless, taffeta gown, her brown hair upswept in a chignon, one can be forgiven for thinking yet another perfume ad is unfolding.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and three articles yesterday about the raid by Russian security forces on a Moscow theater held by Chechen guerrillas misstated the current figure for hostage deaths in the raid. It was 116, not 117 or 118. Gas used by the security forces killed the 116, according to Russian officials. Another was shot and killed by the guerrillas about three hours before the raid began. A woman who entered the theater after the guerrillas took it over on Wednesday night was also shot and killed by them.

title: Fassel Likely To Take Over Play Calling
description: The Giants have scored 50 points in their last 53 possessions, an anchor of ineptitude dragging them out of contention, and Coach Jim Fassel considered a range of possible changes today, his long-term fate lashed to a listing offense.

title: After Study, Zambia Rejects Altered Food
description: The Zambian agriculture minister said today that after several weeks of study, the government was rejecting American genetically modified food offered as United Nations aid.

title: Tom Dowd, 77, an Innovator In the Art of Recording Music
description: Tom Dowd, an innovative recording engineer and producer who made noted albums with John Coltrane, Ornette Coleman, Otis Redding, Eric Clapton, the Allman Brothers and many other musicians, died on Sunday in Aventura, Fla., near Miami. He was 77 and had lived until recently in Miami.

title: Small University In Battle for Control Of Billions in Art; On Campus the Storm Seems Far Away
description: For some at this university in the rolling farmlands of southeastern Pennsylvania, it can easily seem a faraway battle. Students streaming to class at Lincoln, the nation's first higher education academy established for blacks, give little thought to the institution's link to a Main Line legacy of art worth billions -- or to the current effort to wrest it from the university's control.

title: Viacom Leader Hopes to Keep Its President
description: The chairman of Viacom, Sumner M. Redstone, said yesterday that he was optimistic that Mel Karmazin, the company's president and chief operating officer, would remain at the company.

title: Arguing That Historians Can Be Scientists, Too
description: THE LANDSCAPE OF HISTORY

title: Corrections
description: A report from Mexico by Agence France-Presse in the World Briefing column yesterday about the release of a kidnapped writer, Ernestina Sodi, a sister of an entertainer known as Thalia, misstated the timing of the release of Laura Zapata, another sister who was kidnapped. She was released on Oct. 10, not last week.

title: Personality And Posture Transform A Work
description: Do ballets look different with new dancers in leading roles? This was a question to ponder as American Ballet Theater closed its season on Sunday night at City Center. The dancers joined hands at the end and rushed forward, faces beaming, during a standing ovation. They have rarely looked happier than as part of the international youth culture they had just depicted in ''Within You Without You: A Tribute to George Harrison.''

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Increase In AIDS Spending
description: The government announced that it would allocate an additional $300 million over the next three years to combat the country's H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic. With almost five million people infected, South Africa has the largest H.I.V.-positive population in the world, and the government has been criticized by treatment advocates as moving too slowly to deal with the problem. In announcing the new financing, an increase of more than 60 percent, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel said the money would be directed toward various treatment programs. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Tokyo Journal; At a Military Museum, the Losers Write History
description: Judging by the texts on the walls at this new museum of military history, Japan sacrificed its blood and treasure throughout the 20th century not to conquer other Asian countries but to fight for their independence.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Vivendi Rebuffs Vodafone's Bid For Phone Stake
description: Vivendi Universal's board struck back today at its onetime partner, the Vodafone Group, intensifying a battle for control of a French phone company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and three articles yesterday about the raid by Russian security forces on a Moscow theater held by Chechen guerrillas misstated the current figure for hostage deaths in the raid. It was 116, not 117 or 118. Gas used by the security forces killed the 116, according to Russian officials. Another was shot and killed by the guerrillas about three hours before the raid began. A woman who entered the theater after the guerrillas took it over on Wednesday night was also shot and killed by them.

title: Hospitals Battle For-Profit Groups For Patients
description: As doctors in some of the most lucrative fields of medicine rush to invest in upstart specialty hospitals, community hospitals around the country are striking back by stripping the defectors of medical privileges or setting up physician groups to compete against them.

title: Group Formed Over Scandal Wins Meeting With Cardinal
description: After months of distancing himself and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston from Voice of the Faithful, an increasingly popular lay group formed in response to the clergy sexual abuse crisis, Cardinal Bernard F. Law agreed today to meet with the group.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Acquired
description: Novartis, the Swiss pharmaceuticals company, said it had agreed to buy the Lek Pharmaceutical and Chemical Company, the maker of a generic form of Augmentin, a top-selling antibiotic, for 1.5 billion Swiss francs ($1 billion). The acquisition could make Novartis the world's largest maker of generic drugs. Novartis said it was buying Lek, which is based in Slovenia, to gain market share in Central and Eastern Europe, where the patent on Augmentin, made by GlaxoSmithKline, has expired. The current leader in generic drugs is Teva Pharmaceutical Industries of Israel. Alison Langley (NYT)

title: Israel Coalition Nears Collapse In Budget Fight
description: Israel's 19-month-old coalition government was on the brink of breaking apart tonight as ministers from the left-leaning Labor Party said they would depart to protest Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's proposal to spend money on settlements rather than on other social needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEMATTEO, NICHOLAS (NICK)
description: DeMATTEO - Nicholas (Nick), died suddenly on October 27, 2002, at age 45. Beloved husband of Lori (nee Veltri). Devoted father of Armand ''Duke'', Lora, and Steven. Cherished son of Armand and Marion. Dear brother of Michael, Mary De Moor and the late Albert. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10am, at St. John the Baptist Church, 670 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, with burial following at St. Mary's Cemetery. Donations may be made to the American Lung Association. The family will be present Wednesday 2-4 and 79pm at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers. For information, call 914-375-1400

title: Budget Passed, Nassau Leader Goes on Attack Against G.O.P.
description: The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, was savoring a major victory this morning as he signed his first budget, in a ceremony just hours after the County Legislature's Democratic majority adopted the plan. But the celebratory mood lasted only a few moments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILLER, DOROTHY, REBBETZIN
description: FILLER-Dorothy, Rebbetzin. S/A/R Academy mourns the loss of the beloved mother of Dr. Naomi Leib, wife of our esteemed Trustee, Dr. Martin Leib. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Old Lies, New Media
description: To the Editor:
