title: World Series Ratings Are the Lowest Ever
description: For the second time in three seasons, Fox has the distinction of having televised the worst-rated World Series ever. First came the Yankees-Mets Subway Series in 2000. Now, the Anaheim-San Francisco series has overtaken the all-New York series as the lowest-rated baseball championship.

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: TELECOM SALES LAG The mobile unit of France Telecom said it would probably miss its 15 percent target for revenue growth because of slowed sales of handsets. Third-quarter revenue rose 11 percent, to 4.48 billion euros ($4.41 billion) as the company added subscribers and existing ones spent more money on mobile services. That unit, Orange, is France's biggest mobile phone company and is counting on new features to increase sales. In a partnership with Microsoft this month in Britain, it began selling wireless phones that will let users store address books, music and calendars and view e-mail messages. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Rally in Washington Is Said to Invigorate the Antiwar Movement
description: Emboldened by a weekend antiwar protest in Washington that organizers called the biggest since the days of the Vietnam War, groups opposed to military action in Iraq said they were preparing a wave of new demonstrations across the country in the next few weeks.

title: Pleas for Cash As Campaigns Hit Final Days
description: A week before Election Day, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Terry McAuliffe, is the banker of last resort for struggling candidates around the country, and his phone never stops ringing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAYTON, WALLACE C.
description: DAYTON-Wallace C. Conservationist and leader of local and national organizations devoted to improving and saving the environment. He died peacefully at his home in Wayzata, MN, on October 27, survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary Lee Lowe Dayton. With his four brothers, he inherited Dayton's Department Store in downtown Minneapolis in 1950. They added branch stores, acquired Hudson's in Detroit to become the publicly owned Dayton Hudson Corporation, which as Target is now the nation's fourth largest retailer. In 1968, Wallace Dayton retired as president of the Dayton Development Company to devote his life to conservation. He was chairman of the board of The Nature Conservancy, and also headed the Minnesota chapter. He also chaired the Yellowstone Library Museum Association, and served on the boards of the National Audubon Society, the Wilderness Society, World Wildlife Fund, and the Sierra Club Foundation. For his work as a conservationist he received three honorary doctorates: from Amherst College, from which he graduated in 1943, from Macalester College in St. Paul, MN, and from Northland College in Ashland, WS. He is also survived by his four daughters, Sally D. Clement of New York City, Ellen D. Sturgis and Katherine D. Nielsen, both of Minneapolis, and Elizabeth Dovydenas, of Lenox, MA, and nine grandchildren. Contributions may be made to the Minnesota Chapter of the Nature Conservancy, 1313 South East 5th St., Minneapolis, MN 55414, or to the charity of the donor's choice.

title: The Funerals Begin, and Russians Are Swept by Grief and Questions
description: The American ambassador to Russia said today that Russian secrecy about the use of a powerful anesthetic gas may have needlessly raised the toll in Saturday's raid on Chechen terrorists in a Moscow theater. At least 116 hostages died during the raid; another was shot dead in the hours before it.

title: Arts Groups And Artists Find Angels: Universities
description: As artists and arts organizations find themselves facing yet another brutal decline in financial support, they are increasingly turning to a small but growing corps of universities that are quietly helping fill that gap.

title: Profit at Oxford Health Declines 72%
description: Oxford Health Plans reported today that third-quarter profit dropped 72 percent, hurt by costs from lawsuits over a 1997 decline in its share price.

title: U.S. to Add to Forces in Horn of Africa
description: The United States is increasing its forces stationed around the Horn of Africa to about 1,200 troops, allowing them to conduct training missions and remain positioned to stage attacks against fighters for Al Qaeda who are believed to be hiding throughout the region, military officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ROBERT
description: PHILLIPS-Robert. October 19, 2002. Our dear friend. Our sympathy to his family. Dorothy and Jean Cropper

title: I.O.C. Visits to Candidate Cities May Be Allowed Again
description: When the International Olympic Committee passed a series of reforms after the Salt Lake City bidding scandal, one of the changes was to end members' visits to prospective Olympic host cities.

title: Muslim-as-Apple-Pie Videos Are Greeted With Skepticism
description: Rawia Ismail, a vivacious young teacher in Toledo, Ohio, her head covered with an Islamic head scarf, appears in a United States government video that will have its first public showing this week on national television here in the world's most populous Muslim country.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about Michel Faber, whose recent novel ''The Crimson Petal and the White'' is a best seller, misattributed ''Now Sleeps the Crimson Petal,'' the poem from which he took his title. It is by Tennyson, not Wordsworth.

title: Brazil Sets an Example in Computerizing Its National Elections
description: Brazil's two elections this month had all the ingredients to be slow and messy. This country is larger than the continental United States, with millions living in remote jungle and rural areas.

title: Pomegranates For One And All
description: IN this age of fast fruit, the pomegranate seems a paradoxical candidate for mass appeal. Of ancient origin, celebrated in myth and art, it is regally beautiful in its leathery scarlet skin and turreted crown. Inside, it is like a treasure chest, with papery white membranes encasing hundreds of glistening garnet gems -- seeds embedded in juice sacs. The flavor is sweet-tart and winy, intense but refreshing. Pomegranates are laborious and messy to eat, however, which is probably why only 5 percent of Americans have ever tasted one.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Earthlink Posts Narrower Quarterly Loss
description: EarthLink Inc. reported a narrower third-quarter loss as the Internet-service provider added more customers and cut expenses. The net loss shrank to $25.7 million, or 20 cents a share, from $77 million, or 62 cents, a year earlier, EarthLink said in a statement. Sales rose 6.8 percent, to $340.7 million from $319 million. The company added 77,000 Internet customers in the quarter, increasing its customer base by 1.2 percent, to 4.83 million. Shares of EarthLink, which is based in Atlanta, rose 2 cents, to $5.37.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARNESS, JOSEPH
description: PARNESS-Joseph. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations mourns the passing of the beloved father of our colleague and friend, Mel Parness, Executive Director of Bnai Zion. We pray that the Parness family will be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mortimer B. Zuckerman, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Advice for Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Nikon and Fallon End Relationship
description: For the second time in less than a month, a longtime client is unexpectedly parting ways with Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis.

title: A Colombian Clay Pot, Ready to Take the Heat
description: Need a caldron for tomorrow night's witches' stew with ''gall of goat and slips of yew''? This black pottery casserole will also do a fine job with something more appetizing -- a creamy risotto, say, or chicken braised in wine. The thick, handsomely low-tech pot is made in Colombia from baked clay, which is rubbed with river pebbles and blackened in a bed of very hot leaves to give it a finish that is practically nonstick. It provides extremely even cooking and can go from the top of the stove to the oven to the table. (Use an insulating pad on an electric burner.) It is $48 plus shipping from Pure Seasons, (800) 721-3909, or www.pureseasons.com. The catalog says it holds a quart and a half, but nearly three quarts is more like it.

title: Brazil's Next President
description: Luiz Incio Lula da Silva became the first leftist ever elected president of Brazil when he won last Sunday's runoff by a wide margin. Since Brazil was governed by a military dictatorship only two decades ago and Mr. da Silva was once an imprisoned dissident, his election is a tribute to the triumphant consolidation of democracy in South America's largest nation.

title: Procter & Gamble Has 33% Profit Rise
description: Procter & Gamble, the maker of consumer products, said yesterday that its earnings in the most recent quarter rose 33 percent on the strength of products like Crest SpinBrush, Cascade Complete dish detergent and Actonel, a bone-building drug.

title: Minnesota Senate Campaign Resumes; Mondale Says He's In
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 30  The campaign here for Paul Wellstone's United States Senate seat resumed in earnest this morning with the Republican candidate, Norm Coleman, vowing an upbeat campaign about the state's future and the presumptive Democratic candidate, Walter F. Mondale, saying he would accept a nomination.

title: 'Girls Club' Makes Swift Exit, Dimming Creator's Golden Aura
description: After a second week of disastrously low ratings for ''Girls Club,'' a new drama from one of television's most celebrated writer-producers, David E. Kelley, the Fox television network canceled the series last night.

title: Commissioner Rallies the N.F.L. for New York City
description: FOR 13 years, Paul Tagliabue has been, in his own words, the National Football League's ''invisible guiding hand,'' a commissioner content in the role of behind-the-scenes playmaker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, RHODA
description: ROBERTS-Rhoda. On October 27, 2002 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Maxwell B. Roberts (deceased September 11, 1988). Loving mother of John J. Roberts and Jean Colonomos. Devoted grandmother of Benjamin Roberts, Sarah Nayer, and Sarah Colonomos and great-grandmother of Danielle Roberts, Emily Roberts and Rachel Nayer. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Metropolitan Opera, Lincoln Center, NY, NY 10023, Attention: Margery Laughery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and three articles yesterday about the raid by Russian security forces on a Moscow theater held by Chechen guerrillas misstated the current figure for hostage deaths in the raid. It was 116, not 117. Gas used by the security forces killed the 116, according to Russian officials. Another was shot and killed by the guerrillas about three hours before the raid began. A woman who entered the theater after the guerrillas took it over on Wednesday night was also shot and killed by them.

title: A War for Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly and After Much Discussion, Forrester and Lautenberg Are to Debate Tonight
description: After weeks of public feuding about the length, number and format of their debates, New Jersey's two major candidates for the United States Senate are finally about to engage in a brief televised encounter Wednesday night.

title: I Want My Cellphone, and I Want It Now!
description: To the Editor:

title: BP Results Fall Short And Targets Are Lowered
description: The cold reality of a slowing economy is grinding the optimism out of BP.

title: National Briefing: West
description: CALIFORNIA: BLAKE INTERVIEW DENIED

title: N.Y.U. and University of Cape Town Collaborate
description: New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science and the University of Cape Town in South Africa announced last week that they would work together on the issue of diversity, with special attention to the AIDS problem. They will run exchange programs for graduate students and professors, cooperate on research and sponsor joint conferences, including one in New York in April called ''Who Owns Diversity?'' and another in Cape Town in June on corporations and diversity. CATHARINE R. STIMPSON, the dean of N.Y.U.'s Graduate School of Arts and Science, said the universities hoped to build ''a model which will show two great universities working together on problems that we must solve if we are to survive.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, GILBERT
description: SIMON-Gilbert. On October 26, 2002, 84 years old. A loving family man and long time resident of the Bronx. Survived by two sons Martin and Joel and his sister Muriel and his five grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at the Kittay House, 2550 Web Ave, Bronx, N.Y. (across the street from Bronx Veteran Hospital) on Thursday 11am. For information, George T. Davis Funeral Home, 914632-0324

title: Chirac Delays Meeting Blair In a Dispute
description: A dispute between Britain and France has prompted President Jacques Chirac to back out of a traditional year-end meeting with Prime Minister Tony Blair amid mutual pledges to assert national goals even at the risk of deepening division.

title: Omnicom Has 37% Increase In Earnings
description: The Omnicom Group, the big advertising agency company, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased 37 percent as it picked up accounts from companies including Staples and Hershey Foods.

title: A War for Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nikon and Fallon End Relationship
description: For the second time in less than a month, a longtime client is unexpectedly parting ways with Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ROSE
description: BERNSTEIN-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Terry and Maxine Bernstein. Cherished grandmother of Deena, Lawrence and Bradley. Adoring great grandmother of Michael, Matthew and Jeremy. Devoted sister of Mary Weiss and the late Irving Jonas. Graveside service 11:30AM Thursday, October 31st, New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. For information, contact Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapels, 718-377-7300.

title: McCall and Pataki Preach to the Choirs
description: Campaigning for the second consecutive day with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, H. Carl McCall labored yesterday to inspire Democratic voters in his home base of New York City to go to the polls in record numbers.

title: Nelly Likes to Toe the Line Between Ballad and Tirade
description: For some listeners, a hip-hop concert must seem like a bait and switch. You turn on the television, and Nelly is crooning ''Dilemma,'' a mellow duet with Kelly Rowland, from Destiny's Child. Then you show up at Nassau Coliseum here on a Friday night, and Nelly is onstage with a bunch of rappers, doing a song called ''Pimp Juice.''

title: Fed may force ECB's hand on rates
description: LONDON:  European central bankers may soon be forced to yield in their standoff with political leaders and cut interest rates as growth conditions erode and the U.S. Federal Reserve moves to bolster the world's largest economy, analysts say.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Partners Expects Narrower Loss
description: Nextel Partners Inc., the seller of a combined mobile-telephone and walkie-talkie service in medium-sized cities, said yesterday that it expected a narrower fourth-quarter loss as it adds 90,000 subscribers. The loss will be 26 cents a share, the chief financial officer, John Thompson, said in a conference call. Nextel Partners, which is based in Kirkland, Wash., had a loss of 33 cents a share in the fourth quarter of 2001. Nextel Partners, like the part-owner Nextel Communications Inc., is adding customers as some its rivals, like Cingular Wireless and Sprint's PCS unit, lose subscribers. The company is paring losses as it generates higher revenue per user than some competitors by selling under the Nextel brand mainly to businesses. Shares of Nextel Partners fell 10 cents, to $7.05. Shares reached a high of $40.13 in March 2000, less than a month after its initial share sale. The stock has declined 42 percent this year.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If I had one brain cell in my head, I'd leave. But I don't. These young guys are our future.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLSTONE, SENATOR PAUL
description: WELLSTONE-Senator Paul. The American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc. greatly mourns the death of Senator Paul Wellstone, who was a staunch advocate in the fight against Parkinson's disease. His dedication to aid in the struggle of those who suffered with this disease will never be forgotten. We and the Parkinson's community will miss him enormously. Vincent N. Gattullo, President Joel Gerstel, Exec. Director American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc.

title: Synagogue Shooting Is Attributed to Borrowed Gun
description: The bullet went through a fence, an outside wall, a storeroom, an interior wall, a small chapel and a wooden door before becoming lodged in some Sheetrock. Had it struck the Torah, Rabbi Mark S. Glickman would have noticed the damage immediately. But it missed by inches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHENHORN, FRANCES
description: HIRSHENHORN - Frances. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherisned member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Patricia Lampl, President Michael Z. Cahana, Rabbi

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Medical Marijuana Wins a Court Victory
description: A federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled yesterday that the federal government may not revoke the licenses of doctors who recommend marijuana to their patients.

title: Edith Tiger, 83, a Proponent Of Liberties for the Dissident
description: Edith Tiger, the director of a civil liberties organization who fought for the rights of people ranging from the victims of McCarthyism to Haitian refugees to rebellious high school students, died on Oct. 22 in Brooklyn. She was 83.

title: Pataki's Record: 2 Terms, Unexpected Turns
description: George E. Pataki ran for governor in 1994 promising tax cuts, tougher criminal penalties, welfare reform and not much else. It was a conservative platform well suited to the year of the Gingrich revolution and it worked, as Mr. Pataki unseated Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: 'Tweed Academy' Is Latest Courthouse Role
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg revealed plans yesterday for a ''learning center'' in the Tweed Courthouse, where students from around the city will come for classes with New York themes in government, literature, architecture, economics, art and history.

title: Judge Declares Mistrial in Lead-Paint Suit
description: A judge declared a mistrial today in a groundbreaking suit in which Rhode Island tried to hold paint manufacturers responsible for the health hazards of lead-based paint.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRMAN, SANDRA
description: BIRMAN-Sandra. Of Delray Beach, Fl. Formerly of Bronx, N.Y. Devoted mother of Lisa, Michele (Keith) and Barry (Debra), grandmother of Rachel and Noah, brother of Joseph (Joan). Loving friend. Graveside service Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, 3PM today. Contributions in her memory to Temple Emanu-El Religious School, Rumsey Road, Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYTTLE, HANNA LOWEN STEIN
description: LYTTLE - Hanna Lowen stein. Beloved mother, grandmother and sister, passed away on Friday, October 11, 2002 of Alzheimer's disease. She was a Speech Therapist with the Board of Education and a dynamic member of the Park Avenue Synagogue. She was President of its Sisterhood for four years and was responsible for many prominent speakers. She was also an active member of the B'Nai B'rith's Anti-Defamation League and served on its Board for several years, believing very deeply in its cause. She was elected to Who's Who in American Jewish Women. She is survived by her dearest son Lawrence A. Lyttle, a television executive in Los Angeles, her devoted grandchildren Charles and Zoey, and her loving sister Vivian Lowe.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Taxi! School, Please
description: The Chicago public schools are considering contracting with taxi and limousine companies to pick up students who live in remote areas or attend magnet schools or special education programs requiring them to travel long distances. School officials say it would be cheaper than bus service, which costs roughly $200 a day, and could save the district $2 million a year. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: More Homeless People, Mayor Now Says
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, reversing an assessment of homelessness that he made two weeks ago, said yesterday that he believed the number of New Yorkers sleeping in the streets was increasing.

title: Globo of Brazil Credit Rating Is Downgraded
description: Despite its dominant position in Brazil's mass media markets, Globo, the largest media group in Latin America, said its finances had been hit so hard by the weak Brazilian currency and sluggish economy that it would make no debt payments for 90 days.

title: Revisiting the Rule of Four and the Role of Solicitor General
description: Q. Why doesn't the Cleveland decision apply to all the states?

title: Knicks Banking On Chaney This Season
description: The Knicks' front office concluded a bizarre and unsettling preseason yesterday with a move so startling that even its chief beneficiary was surprised.

title: CIT Group's Earnings Fall 26%
description: The CIT Group, the finance company that was spun off from Tyco International in July, said yesterday that earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter fell 26 percent as leasing revenue declined, and it lost money on venture investments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZECK, WILLIAM A.
description: ZECK-William A. Beloved husband to Belle, devoted father to Deborah Zeck Thorne and husband Eric, John Zeck and wife Belva Ann. Loving grandfather to Jessica, Andrew Thorne, Daniel, and Benjamin Zeck. Funeral service Wednesday 1:00 PM. Montebello Jewish Center, 34 Montebello Road, NY. To sign William's guestbook please visit www.scarrfuneralhome.com

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Carmaker In Debt Deal
description: An Indonesian carmaker, Astra International, reached an agreement with a committee of its leading creditors, including Mizuho Holdings, UFJ Holdings, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, ABN Amro and BNP Paribas, on restructuring more than $800 million in debt. Under the terms of the deal, Astra will get three more years in which to pay off the debts. The agreement must still be approved by at least two-thirds of the company's creditors in a meeting scheduled for next month. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page summary on Oct. 22 for an article about a private engineering study that contradicted a federal investigation of the World Trade Center collapse referred incorrectly to the federal findings. They identified an element in the towers -- the design of floor trusses -- as ''likely critical to the building collapse,'' but emphasized that this conclusion was preliminary. They did not say the buildings had design flaws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, ESTHER
description: DUBIN-Esther. On October 20th, 2002 at the age of 89. Wife of the late Murray Dubin. Remembered by her nephew Ronald Dubin, nieces, Jane Cates, Shirley Cohodas and Sandy Bock. Rest in peace, Esther. Services on Wednesday, October 30, 11:30AM at the Riverside, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, a maker of axles for light trucks, said it would sell three nonautomotive businesses to the Riverside Co., New York, a leveraged buyout firm, to focus on selling car and truck parts. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Carbon Monoxide Cited in 2 Queens Deaths
description: A husband and wife were found dead in their home in Queens yesterday, apparently from carbon monoxide poisoning, the police said.

title: That Pole? You Slide Down It; With Fewer Veterans, Fire Dept. Strains to Train Recruits
description: Late one night recently at the East Harlem firehouse of Engine Company 53 and Ladder Company 43, a veteran firefighter stumbled upon two confused probationary firefighters surrounded by a pile of rope. The younger men, known as probies, were practicing tying rescue ropes for lowering themselves from upper floors of burning buildings, and they were struggling to master the technique of doubling the line, which they had been taught in the academy.

title: Russia's Poison Gases
description: More than 100 hostages are dead after Russian authorities used an unidentified gas to incapacitate terrorists holding 750 people in a Moscow theater. Nearly all of the deaths were due to the gas, which Russian authorities have so far refused to identify.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NERENBERG, MURIEL
description: NERENBERG - Muriel. Passed away on October 29, 2002 in West Hartford, CT. Beloved wife of the late Harry, and beloved companion of the late James Lustig. Devoted mother of Ira and Eliot, and mother-in-law of Bev and Amy Jaffe. Dear sister of Marilyn Senz, Judy Salit and Rhoda Barris. Cherished grandmother of Craig, Rebecca and Katie. Services Wednesday, 1pm, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A New Gadget To Give You Hindsight? Just Kidding
description: Bagotronics? It is the ungainly name of a company that, according to a full-page advertisement in The New York Times yesterday, sells a ''business time machine'' that gives its user ''the power to go back in time and erase all your costly business blunders.''

title: Writers Hone Words of Praise for a Treasured Mentor
description: When contemporary American authors debate the age-old question of whether writing can be taught, the name of Nicholas Delbanco is apt to be mentioned.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with the Tunnel Vision column, about people who carry bulky objects on the subway, misidentified the subject. The picture showed Tetsu Shiina with a case of videotapes, not Tessa Grundon with a stack of bags.

title: A Kansas Cardiologist With His Eye on the World
description: After a slow month or two, the $20 million Galichia Heart Hospital, which opened in February on the east side of this bustling agribusiness city, took off like a cornfield in July.

title: Gorgeous Pumpkin Treats
description: I AM not a chef and never will be. I don't say this despondently. As far as I'm concerned, home cooking is the cooking that really matters, and for the home cook nothing is better than just having to deal with the ingredients you have on hand. I like the spontaneity of it -- that's the exciting part. And because in the kitchen as in life balance is crucial, there's nothing to beat the smug feeling of being both homespun and industrious. I am often extravagant but never wasteful. The glow you get from not throwing anything away is the true cook's perk.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Procter & Gamble Profit Increases 33% in Quarter

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SOUTH AFRICA: INCREASE IN AIDS SPENDING The government announced that it would allocate an additional $300 million over the next three years to combat the country's H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic. With almost five million people infected, South Africa has the largest H.I.V.-positive population in the world, and the government has been criticized by treatment advocates as moving too slowly to deal with the problem. In announcing the new financing, an increase of more than 60 percent, Finance Minister Trevor Manuel said the money would be directed toward various treatment programs.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: More Flaws Found In Plane That Crashed
description: A China Airlines Boeing 747 that broke apart over the Taiwan Strait on May 25, killing all 225 people aboard, appears to have had more tiny cracks before the crash than previously believed. The Aviation Safety Council, a Taiwan government agency, said metal-fatigue cracks had been found in a five-foot segment of the fuselage near a rear door where the back of the aircraft struck a runway on takeoff in 1980. Investigators also found cracks in the center fuel tank. After finding 175 bodies, investigators said they would search no further at the site as currents and waves have become worse with the onset of winter. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: From an Indian Chef, Tandoori Fare And Wild Cards
description: FOR a seemingly shy, modest man, Hemant Mathur spends a lot of time on display. If you visit Diwan, an Indian restaurant on East 48th Street, you are likely to see Mr. Mathur behind a big glass window in his bread kitchen, tending his tandoors. You may see him standing next to your table, waiting quietly to ask how you are enjoying your meal. Who knows how long he was standing there before you noticed? You might grasp his surprisingly soft hand as he wishes you goodbye, asking again how everything went. And you may even notice Mr. Mathur's name in an unexpected place: on the menu.

title: The Unearthing of an Ancient Wine Region
description: LEAVING the Autostrada at Naples, I realized I'd run out of lire. So I gave the toll collector a $5 bill and held my breath. What came back was not the emotional fireworks I expected, but a grin and a fistful of Italian change; the proper amount, as it turned out. At that moment, I knew the south of Italy had changed.

title: Federal Panel Suggests Incentives for Improving Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30  The National Academy of Sciences said today that Medicare, Medicaid and other government programs should reward high-quality health care by paying higher fees or bonuses to the best doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations.

title: NICOR WILL RESTATE ITS EARNINGS A SECOND TIME
description: Nicor Inc., a holding company for a northern Illinois utility, said yesterday that it would restate earnings for the second time since August, reducing net income by as much as $35 million, and pay refunds to customers who were overcharged for natural gas. Nicor will correct financial statements since 1999 and pay as much as $15 million in refunds after an internal probe, it said. Nicor will also quit a joint venture with Dynegy that is under investigation for booking more revenue than it collected. A review of Nicor Energy, the energy-marketing joint venture, led the company on Aug. 14 to restate first-half net income. Federal and state officials are examining the venture's accounting and a separate customer-billing program at Nicor Gas, based in Naperville, Ill.

title: Council Offers Compromise On 'Living Wage' Measure
description: In the hope of winning quick passage and mayoral backing, City Council members said yesterday that they had negotiated a scaled-back compromise bill that would require some city contractors to grant higher pay to more than 50,000 employees.

title: Risks of Small Aircraft
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Workers Ignored Anthrax Pill Regimen
description: Most postal, government and news people who were advised to take an antibiotic to prevent inhalation anthrax a year ago failed to complete the full course of therapy, a federal study has found.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the annual Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village, the following street closings and detours will be in effect tomorrow night starting at 6:

title: New Witnesses in Rabbi's Trial
description: The prosecutor in the second murder trial of a South Jersey rabbi called three new witnesses today, in an attempt to bolster his depiction of the rabbi as an adulterer who was not grief stricken when his wife was killed eight years ago.

title: 'Amour' to Close Sunday
description: ''Amour,'' the new musical with an original score by Michel Legrand and directed by James Lapine, starring Malcolm Gets and Melissa Errico, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The show will have run for 17 performances and 31 previews.

title: President Offers Plan to Expedite Judicial Confirmations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 — President Bush, who has been frustrated by Democrats in his efforts to shape the federal judiciary, suggested a new method today for handling judicial appointments and ending a situation that he said "endangers the quality of justice in America."

title: As TV Cameras Roll, Haitians Dash From Stranded Boat to the Florida Shore
description: About 200 Haitian refugees jumped off a stranded wooden freighter this afternoon into the shallows off Key Biscayne, lunging through chest-deep water in a scramble to evade the Coast Guard and the police and to complete their desperate journey to Miami.

title: Our Towns; A Quaint State Where Rivals Really Debate
description: THERE is a big election in Connecticut next week just as in New York and New Jersey -- and you will never guess what the two major candidates for governor did on Monday afternoon. They had a debate. In fact, they have had four of them. Questions. Answers. Rebuttals. Amazing.

title: Who Put the Marigold in the Spice Jar? The Answer's in a Real Page-Turner
description: ''Herbs & Spices: The Cook's Reference,'' by Jill Norman (DK Publishing, $30), is so packed with information and beautiful photographs that it's hard to put down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERBERG, MICHAEL COUSINS
description: SILBERBERG-Michael Cousins. We deeply mourn the sudden loss of our treasured friend. Michael's rigorous intellect, quiet warmth, subtle humor and unique seaweedgrilled lobster, which he prepared with such pride and gusto, will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to Randi, Dana and Bob. Andy Feuerstein and family

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: William F. Treiber, 94, Retired Fed Official
description: William F. Treiber, a longtime senior official of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Bloomfield, Conn., according to a spokeswoman for the bank. He was 94.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: ALBANY: GOLISANO LOAN MAY VIOLATE LAW

title: Werner Eberlein, Interpreter for Khrushchev And Survivor of the Gulag, Dies in Berlin at 82
description: Werner Eberlein, a German who spent nearly eight years in the Siberian gulag under Stalin, and later, after an amnesty, rose to become Nikita S. Khrushchev's interpreter at the height of the cold war, died Oct. 11 in Berlin, German newspapers reported this week. He was 82.

title: Destination South Asia
description: THE flavor and texture of sugar undergoes a dramatic change when it is caramelized, or cooked until liquid. You see this cooking technique a lot in Vietnam, where caramelized sugar is the basis for a savory sauce used in dishes made with pork, beef, shrimp, finfish, chicken and even frog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASE, SARA LEE
description: KASE-Sara Lee, age 92 on October 29th. Beloved wife of Harold. Mother of John and the late Martin. Grandmother of Marjorie, Elizabeth Kase Johnson and Craig Johnson. Great grandmother of Benjamin MacLean Johnson. Alumna of Simmons College and Columbia University School of Social Work. Services Thursday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Martin R. Kase Scholarship Fund, UJA Federation, 130 E,. 59th St., NYC

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Date Set For Presidential Election
description: Election officials chose Dec. 27 as the day voters will elect the country's first new president in 24 years. Uhuru Kenyatta, the son of the country's founding president, is competing against two veteran opposition politicians, Mwai Kibaki and Simeon Nyachae. President Daniel arap Moi has governed the country since 1978, when he took over upon the death of Jomo Kenyatta, Uhuru's father. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Apples as Crisp as the Autumn Air at Rockefeller Center
description: A fresh Macoun apple in Midtown? Might as well try to buy Ferragamos on a farm. But a Greenmarket that's brightening Rockefeller Plaza on Fridays and Saturdays has apples, including crisp, tart Macouns ($1 to $1.25 a pound) that are great for snacking.

title: 4 Are Killed When Copter Is Shot Down In Chechnya
description: A Russian military helicopter was shot down today as it prepared to land at the main Russian military base in Chechnya, killing all three crew members and one passenger.

title: Mets Might Rehire Pitching Coach
description: The Mets have spoken to Dave Wallace, now an executive with the Dodgers, about returning to become the team's pitching coach under Manager Art Howe.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: ULSTER: REPUBLICAN SAYS `WAR IS OVER' Martin McGuinness, a former leader of the Irish Republican Army and now a senior official of Sinn Fein, the guerrilla force's political party, said he had abandoned his fight with Britain, left the paramilitary group and was committed to preventing the deaths of any more British soldiers or I.R.A. members. "My war is over," he said in a television documentary broadcast in Northern Ireland. Since the suspension this month of the Catholic-Protestant power-sharing government, in which Mr. McGuinness served, republicans have been under pressure to move to disarm and disband the I.R.A. Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, last week discouraged predictions of that happening but added that he could "envisage a future without the I.R.A."    Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Critics Voice Opposition To City Plan On Toilets
description: An ambitious Bloomberg administration plan to coordinate the city's so-called street furniture and, at long last, install public toilets is proving no easier than renovating a luxury penthouse for finicky clients.

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: REGIONAL MARKET -- Newark; Prime Office Space Heading to Market
description: The vacancy rate for the most desirable class of office space in downtown Newark has remained low in recent months, but a number of large spaces are to be vacated over the next year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tlcom Sales Lag
description: The mobile unit of France Tlcom said it would probably miss its 15 percent target for revenue growth because of slowed sales of handsets. Third-quarter revenue rose 11 percent, to 4.48 billion euros ($4.41 billion) as the company added subscribers and existing ones spent more money on mobile services. That unit, Orange, is France's biggest mobile phone company and is counting on new features to increase sales. In a partnership with Microsoft this month in Britain, it began selling wireless phones that will let users store address books, music and calendars and view e-mail messages. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Next on the Syllabus, Romeo v. Juliet
description: Kafka was a lawyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLANAGAN, SR. DOROTHY
description: FLANAGAN - Sr. Dorothy, CND, died October 27, 2002. Principal Notre Dame Academy, SI, Villa Maria Academy, Bronx, and NY Archdiocesan Office religious education. Funeral, 4:15 Thursday, October 31, St. Mary Church, Ridgefield, CT.

title: Pick-Six Winner Waits as Investigation Expands
description: An investigation into the suspicious nature of wagers placed on Saturday's Breeders' Cup Ultra Pick Six bet continued yesterday, with racing officials examining if there was an improper explanation for why one bettor held all six winning tickets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEID, SARA
description: SCHNEID-Sara. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary express heartfelt condolences to our colleague and distinguished alumnus Rabbi Dr. Emanuel Rackman HS'27, RIETS '34, and chancellor of Bar Ilan University, on the passing of his beloved sister in Israel, and to her children, Rabbi Chaim Paul Schneid, Barbara Schneid Wiseberg, & Tzippy Schneid. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Jets Trying to Salvage Something to Play For
description: Leave it to a former player like Jets Coach Herman Edwards to cut through the disbelief that enveloped his team Monday.

title: A Boy, 15, Shoots and Wounds Another in a Jersey City School
description: A student sneaked a handgun into Lincoln High School today, past security guards and police officers, and shot another student in the abdomen during a dispute, the authorities said.

title: For Hilliard, Serenity Vanishes in a Second
description: Ike Hilliard found peace of mind this season, moving beyond worries about past injuries, an agent who robbed him and a rancorous relationship with the Giants. He was playing perhaps the best football of his career, a few months before he was eligible for free agency.

title: Wedge Issue? In Hard Times, Mayor Golfs
description: When the going gets tough, the mayor goes golfing.

title: Prudential and Wachovia Drop Venture
description: Prudential Financial and Wachovia have abandoned talks to create a joint venture that would merge their brokerage and research businesses, executives close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon's Profit Rises
description: Canon said profits grew 53 percent in the quarter from July to September, helped by strong sales of its digital and video cameras. Canon, Japan's largest maker of office automation equipment, also raised its full year forecast by 4.2 percent, to 175 billion yen ($1.4 billion), but left its sales target unchanged. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Rangers Are Facing Age-Old Question
description: Ninety minutes before the Rangers played the Phoenix Coyotes at Madison Square Garden on Monday night, James L. Dolan, the chairman of the Garden, hurried down the hallway near the team dressing room. ''Let's see,'' he said. ''Where am I going here?''

title: N.Y.U. and University of Cape Town Collaborate
description: New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science and the University of Cape Town in South Africa announced last week that they would work together on the issue of diversity, with special attention to the AIDS problem. They will run exchange programs for graduate students and professors, cooperate on research and sponsor joint conferences, including one in New York in April called "Who Owns Diversity?" and another in Cape Town in June on corporations and diversity. CATHARINE R. STIMPSON, the dean of N.Y.U.'s Graduate School of Arts and Science, said the universities hoped to build "a model which will show two great universities working together on problems that we must solve if we are to survive."

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Denial Of Shoot-To-Kill Order
description: Britain's most senior front-line officer at the 1972 army attack in Londonderry that left 14 civil rights marchers dead told the ''Bloody Sunday'' inquiry in London that his instructions to ''shoot selected ringleaders'' did not constitute a shoot-to-kill policy as family members of the dead have charged. General Sir Robert Ford, 78, who was responsible for the British Army's day-to-day operations at the time, denied that his recommendations, which were outside the army's rules of engagements, condoned killing. ''The suggestion to shoot a few leaders was not an instruction to kill -- 'shoot' and 'kill' are obviously different words,'' he said. The inquiry, which is two years old and has at least a year to run, was moved from Londonderry to London this fall because soldiers said they feared testifying in Northern Ireland. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Grim Figures Cast a Shadow On Japan's Bank-Debt Plan
description: As policy makers here wrangle over the murky question of what to do about the country's huge overhang of bad bank loans, the signals from the economy have become clear: Japan's fragile 10-month-old economic recovery is rapidly running out of steam.

title: Iranian Leader Says U.S. Helps bin Laden's Image
description: In a sharp criticism of the United States, President Mohammad Khatami of Iran said today that his country opposed a war against neighboring Iraq and charged that Washington's misguided campaign against terrorism had strengthened support for Osama bin Laden in the Muslim world.

title: Footlights
description: Test of Wills

title: As U.S. Seeks a Trade Accord, Brazilians Recall Discord
description: For a hint of the trouble lying ahead this week for the United States proposals for a free-trade pact with Latin America, consider Luiz Fernando Furlan's chicken problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DR. ELIEZER
description: GOLDMAN-Dr. Eliezer. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing in Israel of one of its most illustrious Yeshiva College alumni '37. He made Aliyah in 1938, earned a Ph.D from Bar Ilan University where he taught and later was chairman of the Department of Philosophy. He was the recipient of the prestigious Bialik Prize in 1998. A man of wide erudition, he was considered one of the leading philosophers in Israel. Our heartfelt condolences to his children; Pnina Agam, Menachem and Yoel, his brother Dr. Jacob E. Goldman, honorary member of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, and sister Judith Crystal and grandchildren. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman YU Board of Trustees

title: Political Memo; How Deep and How Often to Use the City Budget Knife
description: The city was going broke. The rookie mayor ordered across-the-board cuts to city agencies. The agencies balked, saying they could do so only with draconian service reductions. So the mayor relented, and postponed many of the cutbacks he had sought.

title: North Korea Puzzle
description: To the Editor:

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders Lose Their Way While Killing Penalties
description: Phoenix had a two-man advantage that lasted 98 seconds tonight, and the crowd at Nassau Coliseum roared as it did last season when the Islanders shoved the puck out of their zone or goaltender Garth Snow made a save.

title: Arizona Gunman Chose Victims in Advance
description: A man who the police and witnesses say killed three nursing instructors and then himself at the University of Arizona on Monday was a Persian Gulf war veteran who qualified as an expert marksman, his military records show.

title: Lawmaker Cited In Bribery Case
description: A five-term Hudson County lawmaker was indicted today on charges that she acted as the go-between for cash bribes from a county contractor that were paid to Robert C. Janiszewski, the former county executive.

title: The Search for a Knockout Weapon
description: Russia's use of a dangerous incapacitating gas to knock out Chechen terrorists who had seized more than 750 hostages at a Moscow theater has underscored the urgent need to develop safer methods to immobilize hostage takers without harming their hostages. The powerful gas, which was pumped in through the theater's ventilation system, killed at least 116 of the hostages and sent hundreds more to the hospital. Whether the high death toll was deemed acceptable collateral damage or was the result of a terrible miscalculation is not known. Russia needs to provide fuller details on the assault and its harm to the hostages. Such information could help this country and others prepare to deal with future terrorist takeovers.

title: 'Enemy Combatant' Fights to Obtain Counsel
description: Lawyers for Jose Padilla, the man accused of plotting to explode a radioactive bomb in the United States, argued to a federal judge in New York yesterday that the government should not be allowed to deny his right to counsel ''merely by transferring his custody to another branch of the government.''

title: Sports of The Times; It's Already Exciting In the N.B.A.
description: THE N.B.A. season officially began last night. Actually, it started on Friday when Los Angeles and Sacramento squared off. Four months removed from the heated seven-game Western Conference finals, Kings-Lakers is the league's latest blood feud, and the latest problem for the image-driven N.B.A.

title: Rudder Risks Cited Years Before Crash
description: Several years before the tail fell off an Airbus jet over Queens last November, killing 265 people, an American Airlines manager and Airbus warned separately that excessive rudder use could make an airplane break up in flight, documents released today by the National Transportation Safety Board show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, HARLENE
description: EPSTEIN-Harlene. On October 29, 2002. Loving wife of Seymour. Beloved mother of Steven Brian and Ivy Dawn (Patrick). Cherished grandmother of Shane Nathaniel. Services Wednesday, 12:00 noon from I.J. Morris, Inc., 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Strudel for Four, but Why Would Anyone Share?
description: Serge Decrauzat, a Swiss-trained pastry chef who worked at Le Cirque 2000 and Caf Sabarsky, has gone out on his own. His company, Dessert by Serge, bakes for caterers and restaurants.

title: U.S. SNIPER CASE SEEN AS A BARRIER TO A CONFESSION
description: State and federal investigators said today that John Muhammad had been talking to them for more than an hour on the day of his arrest in the sniper shootings, explaining the roots of his anger, when the United States attorney for Maryland told them to deliver him to Baltimore to face federal weapons charges and forcing them to end their interrogation.

title: VAIL RESORTS IS ELIMINATING 100 JOBS TO TRIM COSTS
description: Vail Resorts, owner of the Vail, Breckenridge and Keystone ski resorts, is cutting 100 jobs, including that of its president, to save $10 million a year. The company, based in Vail, Colo., said its president, Andy Daly, would leave his job tomorrow and that the position would be eliminated. The company is laying off 50 workers and is not filling 50 vacant positions, the chief executive, Adam Aron, said in a conference call. The cuts represent less than 1 percent of the resort owner's work force. After the cuts, four executives will oversee its mountain resorts instead of six. Vail also reported results and said its fourth-quarter loss widened to $35.1 million, or $1 a share, from $19.1 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier. Expenses rose 30 percent in the quarter, which ended July 31.

title: Gene-Mappers Take New Aim at Diseases
description: A $100 million project to develop a new kind of map of the human genome was announced today by an international consortium. Its goal is to hasten discovery of the variant genes thought to underlie common human diseases like diabetes, asthma and cancer.

title: Since Attacks, U.S. Admits Fewer Refugees
description: The number of refugees admitted to the United States declined sharply in the 2002 fiscal year because security concerns stemming from the Sept. 11 attacks bogged down the screening process, State Department officials say.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Japan and North Korea End Talks After Modest Progress
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Oct. 30  Japan and North Korea ended two days of negotiations here, angrily talking past each other on issues that each side depicts as the major obstacles to normalized relations.

title: Three Managers Are Hired, but Randolph Is Left Out
description: Willie Randolph specifically and members of minorities generally are facing a shutout this off-season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASIN, MILTON
description: CHASIN-Milton. The Seventh Masonic District Purple Association of the Seventh Manhattan District records with profound sorrow the passing of our distinguished Brother, Milton, who passed away on October 26, 2002. George Abraham, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EFROS, JUDY
description: EFROS-Judy. Dearest Judy, I will love and remember you always. On this anniversary, I sense your spirit everywhere. Edwin

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a draft constitution for the European Union misspelled the given name of the union's foreign policy chief, whose position would become more powerful. He is Javier Solana, not Xavier.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Chides Russia

title: Georgia About to Plunge Into Touch-Screen Vote
description: Few people have as much riding on next week's elections as Cathy Cox, the secretary of state of Georgia, and not just because her name is on the ballot.

title: McCall Televises Trump Card
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, began broadcasting statewide yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday and three articles yesterday about the raid by Russian security forces on a Moscow theater held by Chechen guerrillas misstated the current figure for hostage deaths in the raid. It was 116, not 117 or 118. Gas used by the security forces killed the 116, according to Russian officials. Another was shot and killed by the guerrillas about three hours before the raid began. A woman who entered the theater after the guerrillas took it over on Wednesday night was also shot and killed by them.

title: Indefinable Style, Bursting at the Seams
description: ''Die Drei Pintos,'' Carl Maria von Weber's ghost of an opera, comes to us through several filters. The first is Gustav Mahler, who made much of his own early reputation taking posthumous sketches, a scattering of less-known music and his own imagination to compose someone else's opera. The second filter is the comic theater of 1820, whose archaic love triangles and crumbling humor need the most accommodating suspensions of disbelief to function two centuries later.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Families Flee Quakes And Lava
description: Hundreds of families in Sicily fled their homes yesterday as a series of earthquakes and the continued eruption of Mount Etna devastated areas near the eastern Sicilian city of Catania. While no deaths had been reported by last night, rescue workers built barricades to protect mountainside restaurants, and Italian planes and helicopters again dropped water to cool rivers of lava. The 10,860-foot volcano is the biggest and most active in Europe. The fiery geysers that started shooting lava into the air three days ago marked Etna's first major eruption since 1992. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: A Colombian Clay Pot, Ready to Take the Heat
description: Need a caldron for tomorrow night's witches' stew with "gall of goat and slips of yew"? This black pottery casserole will also do a fine job with something more appetizing  a creamy risotto, say, or chicken braised in wine. The thick, handsomely low-tech pot is made in Colombia from baked clay, which is rubbed with river pebbles and blackened in a bed of very hot leaves to give it a finish that is practically nonstick. It provides extremely even cooking and can go from the top of the stove to the oven to the table. (Use an insulating pad on an electric burner.) It is $48 plus shipping from Pure Seasons, (800) 721-3909, or www.pureseasons.com. The catalog says it holds a quart and a half, but nearly three quarts is more like it.

title: Effective Political Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Rates Lowered
description: The Indian central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter point, to 6.25 percent, to stimulate economic growth, which has been hurt by a major drought. The failure of the monsoon rains this year will cut food production by 5 percent, the bank forecast in its half-yearly review of monetary policy. It said economic output would rise by 5 to 5.5 percent this year, not 6 to 6.5 percent, as previously thought. Growth of 8 percent or more is thought to be needed to reduce poverty. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: OFF THE MENU
description: An Atlas Makeover

title: Preservationists Mobilize To Save a Niemeyer House
description: Oscar Niemeyer is best known as the chief architect of Brasilia and for his work with Le Corbusier in designing the United Nations building in New York. His only other known project in the United States is a modernist house that Mr. Niemeyer, who is now 94 and still working in Rio de Janeiro, designed in Santa Monica, Calif., 38 years ago.

title: Improve the Health Of Afghan Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridges and Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: A War for Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidd Casts a Giant Shadow
description: Two small houses have sprung up on a quiet street in Bergen County, N.J., where 70-foot oak trees sway in a canary-colored chorus.

title: Competing for the Sniper Trial
description: The Justice Department and prosecutors from Virginia and Maryland are engaged in unseemly jockeying over who will be first to try the accused Beltway snipers, John Muhammad and Lee Malvo. It demeans the justice system for the decision to turn on politics, prosecutorial ego or, worst of all, a capital-punishment bidding war, in which the case goes to the jurisdiction deemed most likely to execute the defendants. On the merits alone, Maryland, where most of the murders occurred, including the first one, has the strongest claim to try Mr. Muhammad and Mr. Malvo first.

title: Pairing: From Duck Soup to Octopus, This Red Has No Enemies
description: WHEN you have a good wine to drink, there is no shame in pairing it with whatever food you like.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: South Orange: Fire Guts Seton Hall Fraternity House
description: A fire last night at a house being used by a Seton Hall University fraternity left several students homeless and led to the evacuation of several homes in the neighborhood. No one was injured in the fire, which started around 6 p.m. and was brought under control about 90 minutes later. Some fraternities do not have an official house, but the burned building had been rented and occupied by members of the Tau Kappa Epsilon fraternity. It was across the street from campus and was destroyed. In January 2000, three Seton Hall students were killed and 58 others were injured in an early-morning fire at a freshman dormitory.

title: Wendy's Murder Suspect Guilty, But Not as Charged, Defense Says
description: Lawyers for the man accused of masterminding the massacre of Wendy's employees admitted yesterday that he took part in the murders, but pleaded with a Queens jury to consider his ''flawed humanity'' when deciding whether he should be executed.

title: Honor Thy Father? Not if Game Is on Line
description: As if Wisconsin's new coach, MIKE EAVES, did not have a tough enough task replacing Jeff Sauer, the coach with the most victories in Western Collegiate Hockey Association history, Eaves had to face a rare challenge last weekend when his Badgers visited Boston College. The Eagles' roster included Eaves's sons, PATRICK EAVES, a freshman, and BEN EAVES, a junior, who is the team captain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONG, AMY M.
description: STRONG-Amy M. Cherished daughter of Nancy and the late Robert, beloved sister of Wendy, special niece and cousin to the Riegels and Goldins. Loving friend. Rememberances to Cancer Care or Melanoma Research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: R. Gordon Hoxie, 83, Chancellor of Long Island University in 60's
description: R. Gordon Hoxie, an educator and scholar of the presidency who had a brief, stormy tenure as chancellor of Long Island University in the late 1960's, died last Wednesday at his home in Oyster Bay Cove, on Long Island. He was 83.

title: Juggling 3 Goals, Texas Trips
description: MOST Americans want low taxes, good schools and equal access to public education for the rich and the poor. Texas has pushed this combination farther than any other state, but the three elements are contradictory. The Texas system is about to implode, with lessons for other states (like New York) that will later face similar crises.

title: To See Recorded Music as an Art Form
description: Clive Davis, the legendary record producer, has donated $5 million to New York University to establish an undergraduate program in recorded music, which will include classes on identifying musical talent and picking out a hit single.

title: Scores Die in Fire in Heart of Ho Chi Minh City
description: A huge fire in the heart of the city this afternoon in a six-story building that included offices for foreign companies and a popular disco, Blue, trapped hundreds of people, killing at least 54 and injuring more than 100, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZERLIP, JACK
description: SZERLIP-Jack. The Board of Governors, and we of North Shore Country Club, record with deep sorrow the passing of our former esteemed member, Jack Szerlip. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Judy, and family. Peter J. Baum, President Stuart Bednoff, Secretary

title: A Lack of Money Forces Computer Initiative to Close
description: When Stephen M. Case, then the chairman of America Online, and many other high-technology executives announced an initiative called PowerUP less than three years ago, they said that their donated millions would help bridge the ''digital divide'' between rich and poor.

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Shocks, Fits And Jolts, All Inevitable
description: Because more than a dozen music ensembles and presenting institutions in New York were interested in acknowledging the 100th anniversary of the composer Stefan Wolpe's birth in Berlin in 1902, there is, in effect, a citywide Wolpe festival going on this season. It began earlier this month at Merkin Concert Hall. On Saturday night the 92nd Street Y offered the first of its Wolpe events: a riveting program performed by the pianist Peter Serkin, the violinist Daniel Phillips and the Brentano String quartet.

title: Bicyclists to Help Runyan Navigate Unfamiliar Course
description: Dressed in tights and a skullcap against yesterday's chill, Marla Runyan stepped out of a van in Queens and pressed a course map of the New York City Marathon close to her face. She is the most versatile female runner in the country, and perhaps the best all-around athlete, all the more remarkable given that she is also legally blind.

title: Shares End Mixed, Despite Souring of Confidence
description: The stock market managed to bounce back from big losses yesterday despite an unexpectedly steep drop in consumer confidence, which fell to its lowest level in nine years.

title: Wall Street Is Near Accord On Research
description: The biggest firms on Wall Street are nearing an agreement with regulators for fixing the problems with stock research. But some champions of independent investment advice are criticizing the plan and the process that produced it.

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Nebraska: Pastor Fined For Restraining Boy
description: An Assembly of God pastor and his wife were fined $100 each for restraining a 16-year-old boy during a youth group meeting in February and praying over him against his will. The pastor, Dwight Sandoz, and his wife, Nadine, were also charged with false imprisonment of a minor. Judge Glenn Camerer of Scotts Bluff County Court said the two had good intentions but broke the law. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: To Ease E-ZPass Use, Trenton Will Reconfigure Toll Plazas
description: Drivers using the E-ZPass electronic toll collection system may soon see an end to their last-second hunting and lane shifting at New Jersey toll plazas.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Southeast Asia: Shifting Credit Outlook
description: The Standard & Poor's credit rating agency warned that it might lower the Philippines' long-term credit rating because the country's budget deficit was widening, tax collection was poor and national debt was unusually large in proportion to the economy. The warning pushed up interest rates in the Philippines, which is struggling to pay for a war on terrorism after a series of bombings in the last six months. The agency now rates the Philippines BB+ for foreign-currency debts, just below investment grade. Standard & Poor's said it expected no change in its comparable rating of Indonesia, already well below investment grade at CCC+, despite the economic harm expected after the bombing in Bali. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Toasts and Tastes In an Empire State of Mind
description: In a further expansion of the food scene on the Upper West Side, Vintage New York has opened a branch of its SoHo store at 2492 Broadway (93rd Street).

title: Cornell President Leads Universities Association
description: HUNTER R. RAWLINGS III, the president of Cornell University, became chairman of the Association of American Universities this month, succeeding ROBERT M. BERDAHL, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley. The organization, which comprises 63 leading public and private research-oriented colleges and universities, was founded in 1900 to strengthen and standardize doctoral programs. An invitation to join is viewed as a signal that an institution has achieved a certain prominence in research. Dr. Rawlings, who has said that he will step down as Cornell's president next June, will be the association's chairman until then. He is also chairman of the Council of Ivy Group Presidents, the presidents of the eight Ivy League universities. Karen W. Arenson

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. You will live on forever in our hearts. Love Sylvia, Susan, Gwe

title: To Loosen the Bonds of Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Online Shopper column in Circuits on Thursday, about the search for ruby slippers for Halloween, misspelled the surname of a representative of Buycostumes.com, an online retailer. She is Diana Krohn, not Kron.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Broadwing To Cut 500 Jobs As Sales Fall
description: Broadwing Inc., a telephone company that is facing $1.2 billion in debt payments amid falling sales, will cut 500 jobs and defer a dividend payment to conserve cash. Net income in the third quarter was $4 million, or 1 cent a share, in contrast to a loss of $27.9 million, or 14 cents a share, in the period a year ago, Broadwing, the parent of the local-phone provider Cincinnati Bell, said in a statement yesterday. Sales fell 2.6 percent, to $562.9 million. The chief executive, Kevin W. Mooney, who replaced Richard Ellenberger last month, is cutting expenses so the company can meet $1.2 billion in debt payments due in the next two years. Mr. Mooney said on a conference call he would try to persuade Broadwing's banks to extend the maturity on $1 billion in debt due in 2004. Broadwing will cut about 500 jobs, or about 25 percent of the staff, at its Broadwing Communications unit, the company's high-speed Internet network. It will also discontinue service to less profitable customers, the company said. Shares of Broadwing rose 32 cents, or 15.3 percent, to $2.40.

title: Balance of (Nuclear) Power
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Contemporary Entertainment Centers
description: Fresh designs accommodate the new electronics.

title: Echoes of Manhattan at a Queens Lounge
description: A Manhattan architecture firm designs a Queens billiards lounge.

title: Metro Briefing: Connecticut
description: HARTFORD: STATE SUES ENRON

title: Sports of The Times; Mutombo Is Key To Nets' Prospects
description: AS the Nets raised their 2002 Eastern Conference and Atlantic Division championship banners to the roof last night, they never had it so good.

title: Economic Scene; If taxes were lower, the economy would grow faster, right? Economists say not necessarily.
description: AS Election Day approaches, serious discussion about economic policies is hamstrung by the devotion of both parties to reducing taxes. The big reason, of course, is that President Bush emphasizes tax cuts, including elimination of the estate tax, to the exclusion of almost everything else. The Democrats, in turn, hesitate to propose an economic plan that does not include long-term reductions for middle-income workers, and most refuse to talk about rescinding the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Corning Posts Loss And Cuts Jobs
description: Corning, the maker of fiber optic cable, posted its sixth consecutive quarterly loss yesterday and said it would cut another 2,200 jobs, or 8.5 percent of its global payroll. Corning has already said it would cut 4,600 jobs this year because of weakness in telecommunications spending. Last year it eliminated 12,000 jobs. The latest round of cuts will bring Corning's work force to about 23,500. Sales in the latest quarter fell 45 percent to $837 million from $1.51 billion a year earlier, and the company reported a loss of $260 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with a loss of $220 million, or 24 cents a share, a year ago. Corning plans to take a fourth-quarter charge of $550 million to $650 million to account for the layoffs and the closing of optical fiber plants in Australia and Germany, and the shutdown of a facility in Concord, N.C. Although the company said it would consider future cost-cutting moves, it expected annual savings of at least $165 million from this latest round of cuts. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Governors Island Transfer to New York Is Delayed
description: A few weeks ago it seemed a foregone conclusion that Gov. George E. Pataki would be standing on the more picturesque part of Governors Island sometime before Election Day as he signed papers that transferred control over the former military base from the federal government to New York State.

title: Pataki Basks in Support While the Others Play Catch-Up
description: Striving to energize voters in New York City, H. Carl McCall received a warm welcome from supporters yesterday in the Bronx, even as his campaign for governor received dispiriting poll results and faced negative ads from the campaigns of his two opponents.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Moscow's Population Passes 10 Million
description: Preliminary results from Russia's census showed that Moscow's population has swelled to 10.4 million, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov announced. In 1989, when Russia was still a part of the Soviet Union and residence in the capital was more strictly controlled, the population was 8.9 million, meaning the number of residents has grown by nearly 17 percent in the tumultuous years since then. The census, conducted this month, is expected to confirm what many demographers have predicted: a mass migration of Russians from small villages in Siberia and the Far East to metropolitan centers. Russia's total population is estimated to be 143 million, down from 147 million in 1989. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Another Loss At Alcatel
description: Europe's biggest maker of phone equipment, Alcatel, reported its sixth consecutive quarterly loss, which it said was a result of write-downs and restructuring charges. The net loss was 1.35 billion euros ($1.33 billion), compared with 558 million euros a year earlier. Alcatel said it expects to be profitable next year and expects sales to rise more than 10 percent in the fourth quarter. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 22 about inventors gave an outdated affiliation for Dr. James E. West, who advanced microphone technology. He is an engineering professor at Johns Hopkins University and a consultant with the Avaya company; he retired from Bell Labs last year.

title: Party With Islamic Roots Likely to Win Turkish Vote
description: Turkey looks set to give a victory in this Sunday's parliamentary elections to an untested party with Islamic roots, a prospect that scares many in this moderate Muslim nation but that others see as a crucial test of how well democracy here and a greater emphasis on Islam can co-exist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENAVIDEZ, MILLER, LOR NA
description: BENAVIDEZ - MILLER - Lor na. Beloved mother of Jarrell, wife of Gabe, daughter of Carlos and Justicia and sister of Jerry, Elizabeth, Amy, Robert, Feby and Florence. An early soldier in the war on AIDS. The Filipino native was head nurse on Goldwater Hospital's AIDS unit, then the largest unit of its type at any City hospital. Family requests that donations be sent to The Hassenfeld Center for Cancer and Blood Disorders, 317 E 34 St, NY, NY 10016. Visiting Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, Friday, November 1, from 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Borland Acquires Togethersoft
description: Borland Software said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held TogetherSoft Corporation for $185 million in cash and stock. The deal, which has been approved by the boards of both companies and is expected to close within the next two quarters, involves a transaction of $82.5 million in cash and 9.05 million shares of common stock. TogetherSoft, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., and has 390 employees, makes systems that assist software development. The company generated $51 million in sales over the last four quarters. According to IDC, a technology research firm, the software-development market is currently worth about $9 billion and is expected to grow to more than $15 billion by 2006. Borland said that it expected the acquisition to increase revenue by approximately $60 million to $70 million in 2003, excluding $6 million to $7 million in costs associated with the deal. Shares in Borland rose $1.16, to $12.50. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Jamaica: New L.I.R.R. Cars In Service
description: Long Island Rail Road passengers got their first ride on the line's train of the future as the first M-7 cars went into regular service yesterday. Railroad officials said that the trains, which will eventually make up most of the fleet, are designed to offer more comfort and reliability. The cost starts at $2.3 million each for the early cars and will drops to $1.7 million for later purchases. The cars are the first of 858 ordered for the L.I.R.R. and Metro-North; schedules call for delivery of 20 a month. The L.I.R.R. president, Kenneth J. Bauer, has said that the M-7's are the fleet's biggest change since the Rockefeller administration started adding cars in the late 1960's. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Giants Stadium Counter Tray: Grass Gets Greener in an Instant
description: In the last two days, the scruffy grass field at Giants Stadium -- the tattered remains of a three-year, $7 million attempt to install a revolutionary grass tray system -- was ground into pieces and deposited into a dump truck.

title: A Death Sentence in the Sniper Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock-Trading Inquiry Weighs on Martha Stewart's Profit
description: Dragged down by costs stemming from the investigations into Martha Stewart's stock trading, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia said today that its earnings fell 42 percent in the third quarter, and it painted an even gloomier picture for the rest of the year.

title: The Cordless Phone Gets an Upgrade
description: Way back in February 2001, I reviewed the next wave in home telephones: multiple-handset cordless phones. These systems let you park the base station anywhere in your home or small office. Then you can strategically position as many cordless handsets as you need, all over the premises. The tiny recharging stand that comes with each handset requires a power outlet but no phone line.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: It's the Prestige That Counts

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: High Honors For a Lifetime Of Drollery
description: The capital's high and mighty came together Tuesday night to honor a failed accountant and advertising copywriter who punctured the gray conventions of Eisenhower America and rose to fame and fortune by talking. To himself. On a telephone.

title: Japan-North Korea Talks Conclude With Deep Splits
description: Japan and North Korea ended two days of negotiations here, angrily talking past each other on issues that each side depicts as the major obstacles to normalized relations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Unilever Raises Profit Forecast
description: The British-Dutch food and soap company Unilever raised its earnings forecast for 2002 and reported a jump in third-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations. Third-quarter profit rose to 780 million euros ($767 million) from 493 million euros. Unilever is cutting jobs and nearly three-quarters of its products to focus on 400 strong sellers, including Dove soap and Lipton tea. Sales of top products rose 5.4 percent in the quarter compared with a year ago; total sales fell slightly. The company expects yearly earnings per share to increase a few percentage points beyond the 15 estimated previously, excluding nonoperating items. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: SHARON COALITION SHATTERS AS LABOR QUITS OVER BUDGET
description: Splitting apart the coalition government of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon after 19 months, ministers of the Labor Party resigned today over their accusation that Mr. Sharon was favoring Israel's settlers at the expense of its poor in his proposed budget.

title: Judge Permits a Litigator to Join the Welch Divorce Team
description: A Connecticut judge agreed yesterday to allow Dan K. Webb, a well-known litigator, to join the legal team working on the divorce of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric.

title: Much Faster E-ZPass Lanes Are Planned at 7 Toll Plazas
description: New Jersey's troubled E-ZPass system, in an effort to win over disgruntled drivers, will install high-speed lanes at seven toll plazas, where payments are clocked as cars cruise through barrier-free lanes at 50 miles per hour, state officials announced today.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Just the Ticket

title: Bloomberg, Needing Albany's Fiscal Help, Is Asking Nicely
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has had a fairly consistent Albany strategy all year: do not ask for too much state money, do not whine or bully, and praise state officials, especially Gov. George E. Pataki, at every possible juncture in this election year.

title: Editors' Note; Traffic Alert
description: Because of the annual Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village, the following street closings and detours will be in effect tonight starting at 6:

title: Indictment Is Seen for Ex-Enron Official
description: Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, is expected to be indicted this week on charges that he manipulated a series of off-the-books partnerships to disguise the company's financial performance while enriching himself with millions of dollars, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Memories Are Made of This: From a Faucet to an Ensemble
description: Everything old is new again.
