''People have fond memories of old plumbing, but the reality is that customers want the performance and easy care of a modern faucet,'' said Gary Uhl, director of design for American Standard. His company patented the Alton faucet in 1918, and is now offering a new version, the Standard faucet, left, with modern ceramic disk valves to control flow instead of the original Quicko valves, which required washers. The historic Standard typeface was added photographically. The faucet, which is made in Mexico ($149.10 at Home Depot), is available as part of the 1922 collection, a bathroom suite of products including coordinated basins, toilets, towel bars and tub and shower fittings; www.americanstandard-us.com.

title: Japan Settles For Baby Steps To Help Banks Buried in Debt
description: Japan's government today unveiled proposals to revive the nation's ailing financial system by calling on banks to purge half of their bad loans over the next two years. But several economists said the package was little more than a vague and watered-down version of a tougher plan blocked last week by bankers, bureaucrats and parliamentarians.

title: Range War in Nevada Pits U.S. Against 2 Shoshone Sisters
description: The Dann sisters are rough, elderly, hidebound ranchers who live without electricity, hot water or furnace. Though Carrie Dann is nearly 70 and her sister Mary is nearly 80, they still break their own horses and mend their own fences. This is how their Shoshone Indian ancestors lived, and the bones of those ancestors are among the Danns' closest neighbors.

title: In Season of Change, Nets Are Hard to Find
description: In a season of widespread change on the National Basketball Association's television landscape, NBC is gone, ESPN and ABC are in, and TNT is the exclusive home of the league on Thursday nights.

title: Offspring Of the Dream Recount The Struggle
description: The children of the leaders and of the foot soldiers of the civil rights movement, and those who are but the offspring of the dream, are telling their stories in a cluster of books recently published or about to be. The hope of the writers is that these narratives will engrave the movement as a defining event in the 20th century, particularly for this generation of Americans, in much the same way that Tom Brokaw and Stephen E. Ambrose did for World War II remembrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIT, EDWARD
description: FEIT-Edward. Proud of his loving family, always an advocate for the West Side Jewish Center, and a credit to the accounting profession; he will be missed by many. Condolences to his wife Adele, daughters Marilyn & Rachel, sons-in-law Alon and Michael, and grandchildren. Alan Fell

title: Chechen Leader Arrested In Denmark Is a Quarry Of Putin's Terrorist Hunt
description: A senior Chechen leader was arrested and jailed here Wednesday on Russian charges that he was involved in the Moscow theater siege, signaling that the vow of Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, to apprehend Chechen separatists in an American-style, worldwide war on terror is winning friends beyond his borders.

title: Bearden Plays in Pain. Should He Be Playing?
description: The punter staggered off the field, limping badly and grimacing, like a wounded animal trying to get out of the road after being clipped by a pickup. By the time Lane Bearden got to the sideline, about five seconds after the play was over, he was in excruciating pain -- as would anybody kicking a football with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: How to Get a Job, Maybe

title: Paris Museums Make Plans In Case Seine Turns Nasty
description: After devastating floods damaged museums, opera houses and other cultural institutions in Central Europe this summer, the specter of a repetition of the floods that swamped Paris in 1910 has prompted the French government to order measures to safeguard the art collections at the Louvre, the Muse d'Orsay and other Paris museums close to the Seine.

title: 2 Agencies Merge Back-Office Units
description: Two independent agencies in New York are combining back-office operations to cut costs. The agencies -- Mad Dogs and Englishmen, and Spier New York -- will continue to operate independently in other areas.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Airport Lounges To Add T-Mobile Net Service
description: The airport club lounges of American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and United Airlines will add the HotSpot high-speed wireless Internet service from T-Mobile USA in the next 12 months. T-Mobile, a division of Deutsche Telekom, will expand from 40 American Airlines lounges, in which it already provides industry-standard wireless-fidelity access, to more than 100 lounges among the three airlines. T-Mobile said that 20 million travelers pass through these three airlines domestic lounges in the course of a year. The company has plans to eventually expand into airport terminal gate areas as well, according to Frank Ramirez, director of business product marketing. Glenn Fleishman (NYT)

title: I.R.A. Breaks Off All Contact With Disarmament Overseers
description: The Irish Republican Army said tonight that it had broken off all contact with the independent panel set up to oversee disarmament of Northern Ireland's paramilitary organizations, a move it said was in response to the suspension of the province's fledgling home-rule government by the British authorities two weeks ago.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of facilities and events in Escapes on Friday with an article about the form of parachuting known as BASE jumping -- diving from buildings, antennas, spans and earth -- included three competitive events erroneously for the coming year. The jumps, at Moab, Utah; Twin Falls, Idaho; and Fayetteville, W. Va., which were previously sponsored by the International Pro BASE Circuit, will no longer be held; other organizations will still hold jumping events at those locations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Storm Halts Channel Tunnel Trains
description: In the aftermath of last weekend's severe gales, train service between France and Britain has been suspended because salt whipped up by the storm-tossed sea sprayed onto overhead power lines, crystallized and cut off the electricity at the French entrance to the Channel Tunnel. About 7,000 passengers were stranded on Tuesday night, and many complained of having to sleep on the trains, with only rolls and croissants to eat. A spokesman for the Eurostar train service said engineers were working continuously to fix the problem. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Israeli Ex-Army Chief Accepts Defense Post
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 31  Shaul Mofaz, who as army chief of staff advocated aggressive measures against Palestinians, including exiling Yasir Arafat, has agreed to become Israel's next defense minister, Israeli officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the prospect that Walter F. Mondale will replace Senator Paul Wellstone on Minnesota ballots misstated the year Mr. Mondale was last elected to the Senate. It was 1972, not 1970. (He left in 1976, when he was elected vice president.)

title: World Business Briefing: Europe
description: UNILEVER RAISES PROFIT FORECAST The British-Dutch food and soap company Unilever raised its earnings forecast for 2002 and reported a jump in third-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations. Third-quarter profit rose to 780 million euros ($767 million) from 493 million euros. Unilever is cutting jobs and nearly three-quarters of its products to focus on 400 strong sellers, including Dove soap and Lipton tea. Sales of top products rose 5.4 percent in the quarter compared with a year ago; total sales fell slightly. The company expects yearly earnings per share to increase a few percentage points beyond the 15 estimated previously, excluding nonoperating items.

title: No Veto Threat From Security Council Negotiations on Iraq, but No Resolution Either
description: The first round of Iraq negotiations including both permanent and rotating Security Council members ended today without threats from France, Russia or China to use their veto or moves to confront Washington with competing resolutions.

title: B's, Not Need, Are Enough For Some State Scholarships
description: Kelly Ryan has made good use of her college trust fund. It has bought a trusty Honda, trips to Italy, Switzerland, Argentina, some painful lessons about picking her own stocks and, if all goes well, maybe even her first piece of real estate after graduation. About the only thing it is has not paid for is, well, college.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Retailer May Sell Credit Unit
description: The French retailer that controls the Gucci Group, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, confirmed it was holding exclusive discussions to sell four-fifths of its consumer credit unit to the French bank Crdit Agricole. The sale, valued at 2.5 billion euros, would be completed in two stages, 61 percent in January and 29 percent in January 2004, with the remaining 10 percent interest maintained by Pinault. Shares of Pinault have lost about half their value this year because of concern about its 6.4 billion euros of debt and its obligation to pay $4.8 billion in 2004 to buy the remainder of Gucci. Kerry Shaw (NYT)

title: Painting a Still Life That Moves at 17,000 M.P.H.
description: THE Celestron telescope that hulks, out of place and outnumbered by mahogany antiques, in the dining room corner was a whimsical Christmas gift from her to her family three years back. Until now, along with an unpublished astronomy book that her grandfather wrote, it represented the artist Barbara Ernst Prey's karmic relationship to outer space. But no more.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTS, TRACY KEITH
description: ROBERTS-Tracy Keith. 25 years have passed and the pain of not being able to see your face or hear your voice still remains. You're in my heart and mind always. I will always love you with the very special love we had. Hugs and Kisses, Mom

title: Revisiting the Rule of Four and the Role of Solicitor General
description: Q. Why doesn't the Cleveland decision apply to all the states?

title: Belgrade Accused of Involvement in Arms Sales to Baghdad
description: Two years after Slobodan Milosevic was ousted, many features of his rule are still hampering Yugoslavia's integration into the world community -- especially the sale of arms to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.

title: CALENDAR
description: Rockwell Designs

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: MANHATTAN: EX-INVESTIGATOR SENTENCED

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: GOVERNMENT AND REBELS MEET Government officials and rebels held their first face-to-face talks in a bid to end more than five weeks of violent unrest in the West African country. Participants in the talks, in Lome, the capital of Togo, said they had focused on rebel demands for changes in the armed forces and on the government's demand that the rebels disarm. The rebels  mainly soldiers and former soldiers  also want new elections, saying that the election in 2000 that brought President Laurent Gbagbo to power was marred by violence and that the disqualification of the opposition leader, Alassane Ouattara, was unjust.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday with an article about Florida Congressional election campaigns located three districts incorrectly, and the article misstated the location of the Fifth District. The district is northwest of Orlando, not in the northeast corner of the state. A corrected map appears today, on Page A24.

title: Co-Pilot's Swings of Rudder Examined in Queens Crash
description: American Airlines Flight 587 was destroyed in flight by a series of rare side-to-side swings initiated by the co-pilot, experts testified today in the second day of hearings on the crash, but they disagreed on whether the cause was his training, the nature of the plane's control system or the manufacturer's failure to warn that inducing such movement was dangerous.

title: A Strong Start For '24' on Fox
description: The television drama ''24'' got off to such a roaring start on Tuesday night on Fox that the network will repeat the opening episode on Monday at 9, in the spot vacated by ''Girls Club,'' the series that was canceled earlier this week.

title: As Terror Sweep Begins, Chechens in Russia Say Police Single Them Out
description: As Russian officials began executing a pledge to scour Russia for new clues about terror plots, Chechens in Moscow and elsewhere in Russia accused the police of harassment and false arrest in what some called a campaign of intimidation based on ethnic background.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poor Vs. Rich At Climate Conference
description: Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee said that developing countries like India could not afford to substitute cleaner but more expensive energy sources for the fossil fuels that emit heat-trapping gases. Speaking in New Delhi at a conference on reducing global warming, he said that ''our per capita greenhouse gas emissions are only a fraction of the world average'' but that the developing countries would bear the financial burden of coping with the effects of climate changes caused by the gases. The speech highlighted the divide at the conference between richer and poorer nations over who should take responsibility for addressing the causes of global warming. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Self-Published and Proud
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes of Manhattan At a Punchy Queens Lounge
description: The new billiards lounge Slate, right, is in a strip mall in Bayside, Queens. ''I had never been to Bayside before -- it's like Santa Monica,'' said Claire Weisz of Weisz & Yoes, the Manhattan architecture firm that did the renovation. (Southern California has an endless landscape of strip malls.)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., the pipeline owner, agreed to sell its 60 truck stops and services stations in 15 states to a joint venture of Marathon Oil Corp., Houston, and Pilot Corp., Tokyo, a maker of office supplies, for $190 million in cash.

title: Shameless Plugs of Yore
description: To the Editor:

title: Fassel Decides It's Time To Call the Plays Again
description: Giants players said that Coach Jim Fassel informed them today in a morning meeting that he would be calling the team's offensive plays, a switch that would take the responsibility out of the hands of Sean Payton, the offensive coordinator.

title: A Japanese tour with a twist
description: TOKYO  If you spotted a group of Japanese following a flag-toting tour guide in, say, Geneva or Monaco, you might well think that they were just another group of tourists enjoying their holidays abroad. But you could be wrong. They might be sounding out the Continent's private bankers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNE, EDWIN
description: THORNE - Edwin. The Trustees and staff of the American Museum of Natural History mourn the passing of Honorary Trustee Edwin Thorne. A dedicated friend and generous supporter for nearly 40 years, Ed will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marion and all of his family. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President

title: Foreign Banks Are Reported To Be Bidders In Korea
description: Is the government willing to give foreign bidders a chance to acquire the bank stakes it is selling?

title: President's Shadow on Brother's Race
description: Barbara Bush was speaking at a rally for Gov. Jeb Bush the other day, rummaging through her cabinet of Bush family stories to the delight of a crowd of elderly Floridians. She spoke about Jeb, and the grandchildren, and her husband, before beaming and turning to the subject of ''your brother the president.''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Frost on the Kale

title: With Pomp and Pageantry, 'Aida' Returns
description: ''Aida'' at the Met remains, as the latest revival showed on Monday, a rare and endearing example of the kind of blatant spectacle you can otherwise see only in old photographs. As a consequence, the production needs principal singers who live up to the image of old recordings, and they are not easy to find.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: MOSCOW'S POPULATION PASSES 10 MILLION Preliminary results from Russia's census showed that Moscow's population has swelled to 10.4 million, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov announced. In 1989, when Russia was still a part of the Soviet Union and residence in the capital was more strictly controlled, the population was 8.9 million, meaning the number of residents has grown by nearly 17 percent in the tumultuous years since then. The census, conducted this month, is expected to confirm what many demographers have predicted: a mass migration of Russians from small villages in Siberia and the Far East to metropolitan centers. Russia's total population is estimated to be 143 million, down from 147 million in 1989. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Munsters Deep In the Heart Of Texas
description: THE cobwebs were in place, the framed portraits were hung askew and the ladyfingers -- with slivered almonds for fingernails -- were baking at a friend's house. But on Saturday morning, on a farm road just outside this town 27 miles south of Dallas, Sandra McKee was having a fashion emergency: it was almost noon and her shroud hadn't yet left Austin.

title: Theodore Roosevelt Speaks Across a Century
description: 'Teddy Tonight!'

title: Woyzeck as a Normal Guy Who Gets Jealous
description: It took crusty romantics like Tom Waits and his wife and longtime songwriting partner, Kathleen Brennan, to bring out the sympathetic side of the director and designer Robert Wilson.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH TO BUY BACK MARKETING RIGHTS TO DRUG
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, which is struggling to overcome declining orders for its Claritin allergy treatment, said yesterday that it plans to buy back marketing rights to the cancer medicine Leucomax from Novartis. The two drug makers have jointly marketed Leucomax in several countries since 1991. The drug is not sold in the United States, a Schering-Plough spokeswoman, Dana Bicsko, said. The medication, which was developed by both companies, reduces the loss of white blood cells in patients undergoing chemotherapy for cancer treatment. Schering-Plough will get the full rights as of Nov. 1, Ms. Bicsko said. Schering-Plough, which is based in Kenilworth, N.J., is looking for new products to help replace sales of Claritin, which may face generic rivals as early as December.

title: GOLDMAN ANALYST CUTS HIS RATING ON WAL-MART STOCK
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. was dropped from Goldman, Sachs & Company's list of recommended stocks because the shares are considered expensive relative to those of its rivals. A Goldman analyst, George Strachan, cut the rating to market perform in a report. Fourth-quarter sales gains at stores open at least a year may not match last year's as consumers cut spending, Mr. Strachan wrote. Wal-Mart's sales increases, which last year outpaced the industry average, have missed initial forecasts the last three months. Shares of Wal-Mart, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., fell $2.67, or 5 percent, to $53.80.

title: Panel of Bishops Completes Changes to Zero-Tolerance Policy
description: A committee of Vatican officials and American bishops announced today that they had revised a zero-tolerance policy for dealing with sexually abusive priests, bringing American bishops closer to Vatican approval for some of the new rules they sought.

title: Singh and Lowery Share First-Round Lead
description: Only the top 30 players on the PGA Tour money list are invited to the Tour Championship. Vijay Singh never worries about making the list.

title: On Playing Hunches
description: The financier Bernard Baruch went before a Congressional committee investigating stock market gyrations and startled it by asserting, ''I am a speculator.''

title: An Early Mies House Commandeered in '45 Is Restored in Berlin
description: Two years of reconstruction have culminated in the reopening of Lemke House, a 1932 lakefront villa in Berlin by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. A modest red brick structure with a flat concrete roof, it was built six years before Mies fled Germany. In 1945, the house was commandeered, along with the rest of the neighborhood, by the Red Army. Later, the Stasi, the East German secret police, converted the house into a laundry and a lounge for workers from the surrounding villas, which were occupied by Stasi officials. When Berlin was reunited in 1989, the house became a community center.

title: 2 Agencies Merge Back-Office Units
description: Two independent agencies in New York are combining back-office operations to cut costs. The agencies  Mad Dogs and Englishmen, and Spier New York  will continue to operate independently in other areas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Accounting Oversight Chief Told Pitt About Red Flag

title: Edwards's Take on Jets: Quitting Is Never an Option
description: There is no situation so dire it would make Jets Coach Herman Edwards curse. But to Edwards, ''quit'' is a four-letter word, and when he was asked today if there were any risk of the Jets giving up as the season spirals toward disaster, he reacted with more anger than he had previously displayed publicly in his season and a half as head coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERN, IRVING
description: HALPERN-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Belle. Loving father of Susan. Dear brother of Jeanette Robinson. Cherished grandfather of Janine Lounsbury and Todd Uva. Great-grandfather of Lewis Kampf. Service Friday 1 PM at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey.

title: A Win for Medical Marijuana
description: A federal appeals court in California this week struck an important blow for medical marijuana, and for the First Amendment. It held that the government cannot revoke the licenses of doctors who recommend marijuana to their patients. The federal government should now abandon its misguided policy of targeting doctors and sick people to fight marijuana use.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 22 Charged In Insurance Fraud
description: The police have arrested 22 people in connection with an insurance fraud in the Bronx that involved 47 cars worth more than $820,000. People would deliver cars to the leaders of the ring and report the cars stolen to collect insurance money, the police said. Undercover detectives from the Bronx Auto Crime Division set up a fake warehouse in Hunts Point, and over the past 30 months bought the cars from the leaders of the ring, saying they would ship them to Asia for resale. The ring's four leaders were charged with grand larceny auto and insurance fraud. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Teenagers and Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 Voices Celebrate 25 Years Of Harmony
description: The 12 singing men of Chanticleer smartly introduced themselves on Friday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they are scheduled to return frequently. They will be welcome. Performing without a conductor, they gave performances of fine rhythmic precision and squeaky-clean tuning. They also showed off the bell-like clarity of their ensemble sound and the extraordinary range and purity of their top voices, justly billed as sopranos. These men are phenomenal: as fresh as a blade of grass, tightly focused and keenly expressive.

title: Senate Candidates Exchange Fire In New Jersey Cable TV Debate
description: Douglas R. Forrester, New Jersey's Republican nominee for the United States Senate, tonight finally got the debate he had so desperately sought. He used the televised forum to paint his Democratic opponent, Frank R. Lautenberg, as a relic of the past whose three terms in office had contributed to higher taxes, a depleted military and weakened intelligence-gathering capabilities.

title: Don't Say Ghostbuster, Say Spirit Plumber
description: IT was a dark and stormy night well, it was drizzly anyway -- and for the Atlantic Paranormal Society, things were taking a sudden dark turn. The group had come to this harbor town near Boston at the request of a young couple named Jeff and Bekka Caruso, who reported strange goings-on in their small, waterfront house. There had been barking noises, the couple said, and a dresser had inexplicably emptied its contents on Ms. Caruso.

title: Chang-Lin Tien, 67, Affirmative-Action Steward at Berkeley
description: Chang-Lin Tien, the chancellor of the University of California from 1990 to 1997 and an outspoken advocate of affirmative action, died on Tuesday at the Kaiser Permanente hospital in Redwood City, Calif. He was 67 and lived in Hillsborough, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPIDUS, RHODA
description: LAPIDUS-Rhoda. On October 29, 2002. Beloved wife of Irving. Loving mother of Jane Shaul and mother-inlaw of Avi. Cherished grandmother of Reuben, Noah and Elizabeth. Sister of Dr. Bernard J. Brener. Services today at 12:30 at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY.

title: American Women Lead In International Rankings
description: The world bridge rankings for women show that the Americans are somewhat ahead of the rest of the world, with 7 in the top 12. These are the Americans:

title: To Lower Payroll, Yanks Consider Trading Posada
description: The Yankees had highly paid veterans in every corner of the clubhouse last season, and they understand that must change. The team is determined to lower its payroll to soften the blow of the new collective bargaining agreement, and the best way to do so may be to trade a mainstay, catcher Jorge Posada.

title: Microsoft Antitrust Decision Expected Tomorrow
description: Update WASHINGTON--A federal judge will disclose Friday whether she has accepted a proposed settlement in Microsoft's long-running antitrust case.

title: Saturday's Top Matchups
description: Wisconsin (6-3)

title: New Ways to Get Out the Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKEY, SHANNON E.
description: HICKEY-Shannon E. 19, of Jupiter Island, FL, passed away Sunday, October 27, 2002 as the result of an automobile accident. He was born and raised in East Rockaway, NY, had been a resident of Jupiter Island for five years, coming from New York. Shannon was a 2001 graduate of Jupiter High School, attended Palm Beach Community College and planned on attending Florida State University. He was an avid outdoorsman enjoying boating, golfing and fishing. He was a friend to many and loved by all. Survivors include his parents, Thomas and Valerie Hickey of Jupiter Island; his two Brothers, Ryan Thomas and Colin Jesse Hickey, both of Jupiter Island; his maternal grandmother, Elizabeth Guarnieri of East Rockaway, NY; his paternal grandparents, Thomas and Maureen Hickey of Franklin Square, NY and many aunts, uncles and cousins. He was predeceased by his maternal grandfather Louis Guarnieri. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10am Friday, November 1, 2002 at St. Jude Catholic Church, Tequesta, FL. Those who wish, may make contributions to St. Jude's Children's Hospital, 332 North Lauderdale, Box 318, Memphis, TN 38101-2729. Friends may call Thursday, October 31 from 1-3 & 6-9pm at the Aycock Funeral Home, 1112 Military Trail, Jupiter, FL

title: Upgrading to Windows XP
description: To the Editor:

title: Custom Digital Prints Without a Computer
description: The increasing popularity of digital cameras is creating something of a problem, says Fabia Ochoa, the product manager for photo printers at Epson. Camera owners may become more keen about taking pictures than they are about using computers.

title: The Virtual Stomach (No, It's Not a Diet Aid)
description: ENGINEERS usually study the effects of turbulence on objects like airplane wings. But one professor of mechanical and bioengineering has turned his expertise in fluid mechanics, turbulence and shear stress to an unlikely subject : the roiling contents of the human stomach.

title: Number of Women Governors Is Expected to Rise
description: This will probably not be the ''Year of the Woman'' in the House or the Senate, but those who track women's political progress still have high hopes for the governorships, one of the last glass ceilings for women.

title: New Ways to Get Out the Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: From Inside, Palm Makes A New Start
description: THERE may come a time in every corporation's life when it must stand tall, swallow hard and abandon the very technology that made it successful. Hewlett-Packard sold off its scientific-instruments division. Apple jettisoned an aging Mac operating system and conceived a new one. DOS is no longer the heart of Microsoft Windows. In Silicon Valley, you could get rich selling ''If you love something, let it go'' T-shirts.

title: Pain and the Low Pay Don't Stop This Runner
description: Scott Larson, who won last year's national championship, is the most experienced American-born elite male marathon runner. But no matter how fast he runs in the New York City Marathon on Sunday, he almost surely will finish more than a mile behind the winner.

title: MONDALE ACCEPTS PARTY CALL TO RUN IN MINNESOTA RACE
description: Walter F. Mondale, the former vice president who last held elective office 22 years ago, agreed tonight to replace Senator Paul Wellstone on the Nov. 5 ballot, but the nomination was marred by a partisan squabble over the previous evening's televised memorial service for Mr. Wellstone.

title: They Called It Witchcraft
description: In 17th-century New England, almost everyone believed in witches.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the performer, lyricist and playwright Adolph Green on Friday misstated the Broadway opening year of ''On the 20th Century,'' for which he and Betty Comden wrote the book and lyrics. It was 1978, not 1981. The article also referred imprecisely to the order of production of two films -- ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' and ''On the Town'' -- for which he and Ms. Comden wrote the screenplays. Both were released in 1949, but ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game'' was filmed a year earlier.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Thomas B. Ross, a former government official who wrote best-selling books on military intelligence, misstated his position at The Chicago Sun-Times in 1960, when an American U-2 spy plane was shot down over the Soviet Union. He was a Washington reporter; he became the bureau chief in 1971.

title: Proposal Would Put Super Bowl In the Cold
description: Representatives of the Giants, the Jets and the Washington Redskins officially proposed the New York City and Washington areas as sites for the Super Bowl at a four-and-a-half-hour meeting of National Football League owners yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Old Dog, New Tricks: A Brighter C.R.T. Screen
description: In the battle of fat versus flat, bulky cathode-ray tube monitors have steadily been losing desktop ground to thinner, lighter flat-panel displays. But the C.R.T. screens are not down for the count yet. Samsung continues to make improvements to the older monitor technology and has developed the SyncMaster 957MB, which might have special appeal for those with both brightness and budget in mind.

title: Off to the Country, Packing a Vote
description: SOME people have discovered how to squeeze a second four-day weekend out of November this year, and it involves an institution even more crucial to democracy than turkey and stuffing.

title: An Israeli Entertainer Serves a Personal Potluck
description: 'Something Old, Something New'

title: Campaigning in South Dakota, Bush Warns U.N. on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 — President Bush flew to South Dakota today to campaign again for a man he had personally lobbied to run for the Senate, Representative John Thune, whom he praised as a man of common sense and deep patriotism.

title: Economy Grew at 3.1% in 3rd Quarter, Slower Than Expected
description: The economy grew at a moderate 3.1 percent rate in the third quarter, the Commerce Department estimated today, but there were indications that growth may be slowing as the year comes to an end.

title: Report Card Gets an F
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, JOSEPH H.
description: MEYER-Joseph H., 82. Of Stuart, FL., and Port Ewen, NY. Died on October 30, 2002. Beloved husband of 58 years to Anne, father of Joseph, William, Joanne, Margaret and Laura. Grandfather of four, and brother of three sisters Maxine Greene, his twin, Jeanne Shinefield and Carol Meyer (deceased). Veteran of the U.S. Army Air Corps, President of Richelieu Pearls Corp., Board Member and Alumnus of Alfred University, Board President of South Nassau Communities Hospital, Member of Young Presidents Organization (YPO).

title: Howe and Mets Talk to Baylor
description: The Mets' new manager, Art Howe, has talked to Don Baylor about becoming his bench coach. But Baylor, the former manager of the Colorado Rockies and the Chicago Cubs, is waiting to see if managing opportunities become available.

title: DRUG MAKER TO SEEK APPROVAL FOR EYE TREATMENT
description: Shares of Inspire Pharmaceuticals Inc. jumped 54 percent yesterday after the company said it would seek approval of an ophthalmic treatment for dry eye syndrome. Inspire, which is based in Durham, N.C., will seek Food and Drug Administration approval of the treatment based on data from studies of 1,200 patients, the company said. If approved, the eye therapy would be the company's first marketed product. Dry eye is currently treated with over-the-counter saline solutions. Inspire's product, called INS365, is administered as drops and is designed to prompt the eye to release water, salt, mucin and lipid, the key components of natural tears. The company estimates that dry eye affects about 10 million Americans. Shares of Inspire rose $2.02, to $5.79.

title: A Versatile Organizer Is All Windows at Heart
description: The appearance of ViewSonic's new V35 Pocket PC tomorrow will be news not just for hand-held fanatics but for the software business too. With the V35, ViewSonic becomes the 29th company to produce an organizer with an operating system from Microsoft rather than Palm.

title: Prosecutors Say Former Nets Star Was Drunk the Night of a Fatal Shooting
description: Jayson Williams, the former New Jersey Nets star who is accused of fatally shooting a limousine driver, was drunk on the night of the incident, prosecutors said in court papers filed today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Protest At Indian Point
description: Antinuclear advocates, seeking to point out potential security flaws at the Indian Point nuclear power plant, attempted to paddle there by kayak but were intercepted by a National Guard boat, detained by the state police and then released. The attempt on Tuesday was the latest move to embarrass Entergy, the operator of the nuclear plant, which is on the Hudson River. ''We're through tolerating these stunts,'' said Jim Steets, an Entergy spokesman. ''Somebody's going to get hurt clowning around like this.'' Corey Kilgannon (NYT)

title: The new leader of I.B.M. explains his strategic course.
description: WITH a speech in New York yesterday at the start of a costly and quirky marketing campaign, Samuel J. Palmisano, I.B.M.'s chief executive, declared his company was making a $10-billion bet on a strategic shift toward what it calls ''on-demand computing.''

title: U.S. to Challenge Deal by EchoStar To Acquire DirecTV
description: The Justice Department and several states plan to go to court today to challenge EchoStar Communications's proposed $26 billion acquisition of Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV satellite business, people briefed on the situation said.

title: Crash in Iran Kills 2 M.P.'s
description: Two members of Parliament were killed and one was severely injured this afternoon when their car ran off a cliff on the Chalous road in northern Iran, a state news agency reported.

title: Siegfried Unseld, German Literary Publisher Noted for Taste and Erudition, Dies at 78
description: Siegfried Unseld, the head of the major German publishing house Suhrkamp Verlag and the man considered to be Germany's leading literary publisher, died at home in Frankfurt-am-Main on Saturday. He was 78, and had been suffering from the effects of a stroke.

title: Corrections
description: Congressional campaigns in three Florida districts involve politicians who made names for themselves in the 2000 presidential recount. A map on Tuesday with an article about the races located the districts incorrectly.

title: Market Place; Vivendi Is Said To Be Near Sale Of Houghton
description: Vivendi Universal is planning to sell Houghton Mifflin, the publisher of ''Curious George,'' ''The Lord of the Rings'' and a wide range of textbooks, to a consortium of financiers led by the Blackstone Group, for about $1.7 billion, executives involved in the discussions said yesterday.

title: Canada Warns Travelers
description: The Canadian government issued an unusual travel advisory today, warning Canadian citizens born in Syria, Sudan, Libya, Iraq or Iran to reconsider travel plans to the United States because of a new American law requiring that they be fingerprinted and photographed.

title: Wedding Ring Is a Millstone in 2 Arkansas Races
description: Gov. Mike Huckabee was supposed to glide to re-election over Jimmie Lou Fisher, a Democratic Party functionary whose job in her 22 years as state treasurer has involved little besides signing government checks.

title: Renewed Calls for Revising Policy on Haitians
description: The sudden appearance of more than 200 Haitians in the waters off Miami on Tuesday has reignited a debate about the treatment of Haitian refugees and posed yet another political headache for Gov. Jeb Bush in the final days of his re-election bid.

title: Series of Bombings Shake Soweto, Killing One
description: A series of bombs shook this sprawling black community early today, killing one person and wounding another in what the police suspect was a coordinated strike by white extremists.

title: Integrity of the Sport Is on Trial in Breeders' Cup Pick-Six Investigation
description: Bruce Fischbein was back at his usual perch today at Monmouth Park, doing what he does most every day, trying to win a few bucks at the track. He says he loves racing and the challenge of trying to select a winner, but he is not sure the game he is playing is a fair one. To him, an investigation into the winning tickets in last Saturday's Breeders' Cup Ultra Pick Six was one more bit of evidence that horse racing has an integrity problem.

title: Metro Matters; Flight, Fine. Ride Home, Delayed.
description: SOMETIMES, you cannot get there from here. Not when here is La Guardia or Kennedy Airport and there is everywhere else.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINSTON, ERWIN
description: WINSTON-Erwin. In memory of our father, Erwin Winston, January 22, 1930-October 31, 1977. Dad, you've been gone for 25 years, but your presence is as vibrant as ever. We will always love you. Bonnie Winston Sugarman Stacey Winston Levita

title: Prosecutor Says U.S. Involvement Did Not Block Sniper Confession
description: The federal prosecutor who has been accused of interrupting an interrogation to take John Muhammad to court on federal gun charges in the Washington-area sniper case said today that he was only following the law.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the prospect that Walter F. Mondale will replace Senator Paul Wellstone on Minnesota ballots misstated the year Mr. Mondale was last elected to the Senate. It was 1972, not 1970. (He left in 1976, when he was elected vice president.)

title: An Old-Time Newspaper War for Young Loyalties
description: Phil Ardelean, 18, a slightly distracted teenager just entering the dream demographic of 18- to 34-year-olds so coveted by American advertisers, headed to class at DePaul University this morning carrying something he seldom touches. A newspaper.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a legal clash over national security and civil liberties in the case of Yasser Esam Hamdi, an American-born Saudi captured on the battlefield in Afghanistan, misidentified the law cited by William J. Haynes II, general counsel for the Defense Department, in support of the government's right to detain him without due process. It was the joint resolution of Sept. 18, 2001 (also known as Public Law 107-40), not the United States Patriot Act.

title: Bush Wants Fast Vetting On Judges
description: President Bush proposed a plan today to speed Senate confirmation of his judicial nominees and to counteract what he called the ''poisoned and polarized atmosphere'' surrounding the process.

title: Bring On Bridge Tolls!
description: To the Editor:

title: Less Socialist, But Still Social; Circle Is Link to a Yiddish Past
description: It was started in a tenement on the Lower East Side.

title: PGA Tour Won't Act Against the Masters
description: Anyone waiting for the PGA Tour to alter its relationship with Augusta National Golf Club or the Masters should probably stop waiting.

title: Q&A / Christian de Juniac : The lessons of the bubble years
description: Christian de Juniac, senior vice president and director of the Boston Consulting Group, is in charge of BCG's global asset management and private banking practice. He specializes in strategy development for private banks worldwide. He spoke recently with Rick Smith on the effects of the economic downturn on private banks.

title: A Disk on an Armband That Never Skips a Beat
description: The small size of many MP3 players makes them a natural choice for those who want to listen to music while working out. While a few early models looked like heart monitors on belt clips, some new music players from Nike and Philips Electronics are designed specifically for physically active people.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KORN, JACK
description: KORN-Jack 6/18/10-10/31/94. Forever remembered and loved by his family.

title: Kabul to Send Team to Check on Afghans Held at Guantnamo
description: President Hamid Karzai announced today that he would send a delegation to the American naval base in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to check the conditions under which Afghans are being held there in indefinite detention. Mr. Karzai made the announcement after meeting today with three Afghan men freed from Guantnamo this week, who said they were innocent and had been wrongly detained for months.

title: Talisman to Sell Its Stake in Company in Sudan
description: Talisman Energy said today that it was ending a controversial four-year investment in Sudan by selling its 25 percent stake in the Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company for $758 million. The buyer is a unit of the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation of India.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Shades of Last Season as a New One Begins; In New Jersey, Raising a Banner (And the Roof)
description: The banners were fluttering 120 feet above his head when Jason Kidd exhorted his teammates in a huddle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SZERLIP, JACK L.
description: SZERLIP-Jack L. Suddenly, October 29, 2002. Beloved husband and best friend of Judy; loving father of Ann, Bill (Marcia) and Lynn Cleaver; adoring grandfather of Emily and Michael Cleaver and Joshua Szerlip; brotherin-law of Arnold and Joan Wolfe. He proudly served as a pilot in W.W. II, completing 25 missions in Italy. His war experience was followed by a long career at Lehman Brothers. Memorial Service at Levitt Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 5411 Okeechobee Blvd, West Palm Beach, FL. Thursday, October 31, 2 PM.

title: Plans to Curb Teenage Use Of Alcohol In Westchester
description: It was not yet noon, but there was a keg of beer in Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky's office in Elmsford. As a half-dozen journalists gathered around, he leaned atop the keg and smiled for the cameras.

title: Last-Minute Efforts Shift From Talking to Walking
description: Democrats and Republicans are mounting what their party leaders say are their most aggressive drives ever to get voters to the polls, last-ditch efforts that could prove decisive in elections across the country on Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: What Mature Gamers Need

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNBULL, WILLIAM
description: TURNBULL - William. The Board of Directors and staff of Sheltering Arms Childrens Service note with sorrow the death on October 23, 2002 of William Turnbull, past President & longtime Board member. Bill Turnbull was dedicated to improving the lives of disadvantaged children, and to the work of Sheltering Arms. The agency benefited greatly from his wisdom and thoughtfulness. Henry A. Lambert, Chairman Wayne R. Mucci, Executive Director

title: At Sea, an Aircraft Carrier Is Ready for a 911 Call
description: Steel slingshots were catapulting F-14A Tomcat jets off the flight deck here at the rate of one a minute today. The flights were for training, but the men and women aboard this aircraft carrier know that one telephone call can turn training into fighting.

title: Columbia in Talks to Build at St. John
description: The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine and Columbia University are in discussions about developing the north end and southeast corner of the cathedral's 13-acre grounds in Morningside Heights.

title: Careful, Not Nervous
description: To the Editor:

title: Re-elect Eliot Spitzer
description: During his four years as New York State's attorney general, Eliot Spitzer has used the powers of his office, and his own considerable legal skills, to pursue some worthy targets, from abusive practices on Wall Street to irresponsible marketing by gun manufacturers and major threats to the environment. Often, he has worked in cooperation with other state attorneys general to help fill large enforcement voids left by the federal government. In the process, Mr. Spitzer has emerged as a savvy and responsible champion of the public interest, easily earning our endorsement for a second term over his token Republican opponent, Dora Irizarry, a former state court judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUSACK, MAURICE
description: CUSACK - Maurice. The Board and staff of The Spanish Institute mourns our colleague and friend, Maurice Cusack, who died on Friday, October 25th. A distinguished banker, he worked with the Royal Bank of Canada for twenty-one years and with Irving Trust Company for twenty-three. Maurice, a dedicated member of our Board for many years, and his beloved wife, Yvonne, will always be remembered with great warmth.

title: TOMMY HILFIGER'S SHARES FALL ON DIMMER PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation's shares fell 20 percent after the clothing maker said profit this year will fall because of slowing sales and expenses to close stores. The company, which also said second-quarter profit rose 27 percent on cost-cutting, will close 37 of its 44 stores in the United States after the holiday season and lay off about 500 workers. Tommy Hilfiger, which is based in Hong Kong and has offices in New York, expects that this year's profit, excluding some costs, will be $1.15 to $1.35 a share, less than its earlier forecast. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn $1.58 a share. Net income was $1.49 a share a year earlier. Second-quarter net income increased to $61 million, or 67 cents, from $47.9 million, or 53 cents. The company's shares fell $1.85, to $7.50.

title: Excuse Me, but Your Teeth Are in My Neck
description: 'Son of Drakula'

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

title: From Low-Key Boutique to Pressure-Cooker Firm
description: No one ever questioned the integrity of Sallie Krawcheck's research reports.

title: Karachi Journal; For a Sickening Encounter, Just Turn on the Tap
description: Dr. Shahana Urooj Kazmi earned a Ph.D. in microbiology in the United States with research on camphylobacter, which causes diarrhea in infants. Now the chairwoman of the University of Karachi's department of microbiology, she can walk a novice through the gut-wrenching symptoms of e. coli, shigella, giardia and sundry other intestinal bugs with the detachment of a bored tour guide on a London double-decker.

title: House of 8 Gables, Back in Black
description: IT could have been a mistake that haunted them forever.

title: That Old Black Vinyl: A Magical Makeover for the CD
description: What goes around at 45 revolutions a minute has come around again.

title: A Death Sentence In the Sniper Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: A Pad That Recharges With Nubs, Not Wires
description: FOR users of laptops, palmtops, cellphones and other wireless devices, the least attractive attribute of such widgets is the tangled web that ensues when it's time to plug them in for a recharge. Now a Silicon Valley company, MobileWise, has designed a product that it claims will solve the problem.

title: A New Aria for the Architect of Sydney's Opera House
description: Making an opera about the making of an opera house may seem like artistic or architectural navel-gazing. But there was enough drama in the creation of the Sydney Opera House to justify setting it to words and music and performing the backstage story onstage at the opera house itself as ''The Eighth Wonder,'' a 1995 production revived two years ago. Now an emerging epilogue to that drama is worthy of a new finale.

title: Drought Rules End, but They May Come Again Another Day
description: New York City lifted its emergency drought declaration yesterday, suspending restrictions on water use that were imposed in April, when falling reservoir levels presented the likelihood of yet another crisis in a city already facing more than enough of them.

title: Asylum for Haitians
description: To the Editor:

title: Relations With U.S. a Challenge for Leftist Elected in Brazil
description: A leftist Workers' Party government here and a conservative Republican administration in Washington could make for a combustible combination.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LAMBERT, MILDRED
description: LAMBERT-Mildred. Beloved mother and grandmother on your 90th birthday. You are missed and loved each and every day. Steven, Barbara, Corey, and Joseph

title: A Ripsnorting Life Gets A Ripsnorting Memoir
description: A THIRD FACE

title: Chance for Change in Israel
description: After 19 months of trying in vain to act as a moderating force on Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, Israel's Labor Party walked out of his government on the right issue -- the indefensibly high priority he gives to the Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. If, as is widely expected, early elections are called, Labor should keep to its current course and offer the electorate a real alternative to existing policy.

title: When Headphones Measure Up To the Music
description: THE arrival of the Sony Walkman more than two decades ago transformed consumer headphones from something once mainly owned by audiophiles into a mass-market portable product. But as portable audio has progressed from cassette tape players to miniature hard drives capable of holding hours of music, the headphones packed with them have not undergone a similar transformation.

title: Jacques Massu, 94, General Who Led Battle of Algiers
description: Gen. Jacques Massu, a soldier who late in life came to deplore and regret France's use of torture during his triumphant direction of the Battle of Algiers in 1957, died on Saturday at his home in Conflans-sur-Loing in the Loiret region of France. He was 94.

title: Clients demand a better deal for investments
description: PARIS  In August, HSBC Republic bought the U.S. wealth tax advisory service of Arthur Andersen, after the once high-flying accounting and auditing firm was tarred in the Enron scandal.

title: Attention, Cows: Please Speak Into the Microphone
description: IT is marketed as a toy: a dog collar equipped with a wireless microphone that records a pet's barks, interprets them as emotions and transmits them as text messages like ''I'm bored, let's play.''

title: Bellwether Races in Tight Contest for House Control
description: Calling the winner in the battle for the House could be complicated, given the narrow Republican margin of control. But strategists in both parties say there are bellwether races to watch. Jenny Backus, spokeswoman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, picked these: Maryland's Eighth (Representative Constance A. Morella, left, moderate Republican, vs. Chris Van Hollen, state senator); Iowa's Second (Mr. Leach vs. Dr. Thomas); and Indiana's Second, an open seat based in South Bend.

title: Brooklyn Husband Is Killed Trying to Protect His Wife From Two Masked Robbers
description: A former Soviet Army officer who had walked his wife home from a subway station in Brooklyn every night since she was confronted by a mugger last spring was shot to death early yesterday as he defended her from robbers, the police said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Police Shape-Up
description: The Chicago Police Department is offering officers $250 to get in shape, and so far it has 2,600 takers, up from 230 last year when the department offered only a ribbon as a reward. The new program is age and sex specific. A 42-year-old sergeant said he had to run 1.5 miles in 15 minutes, bench press 87 percent of his body weight and do 28 sit-ups in a minute. Police officials said they were pleased with the participation rate. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Europe Fines Nintendo $147 Million for Price Fixing
description: The European Commission fined Nintendo, the Japanese video game maker, $147 million today for colluding with seven European distributors to fix prices on its products.

title: Recent Plays
description: Lusciously Lurid Is the Name of the Game

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISH, DR. HARRY G.
description: ENGLISH-Dr. Harry G. on October 29, 2002. Beloved husband of 51 years to Eileen (nee Maxwell). Loving brother of the late Annetta Brand and J. Walter English. Proud uncle of Dawn Joy, Erica Brand, Jeffrey English, Randy English, Janet Somerville, Jennifer Leonardi and Deborah Cummings. Survived by many grand nieces and nephews and one great grand-niece and many, many dear friends. Graduate of St. John's University, 1946, BBA, received his Master's at NYU. Graduate of New York Law School, 1952, with the degree of Juris Doctor, attended Adelphi University, receiving his Certified Financial Planning certificate. Honorary degree from Cumberland College. Former professor at Long Island University (Brooklyn). Practicing law, specializing in estate and taxes in Bay Ridge for over 50 years. Past-president, member, activist and volunteer for numerous organizations. Visiting Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday (at his request), 2-4 and 7-9PM, Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Funeral services 10AM, Monday, at St. Philip Episcopal Church (80th St. and 11th Avenue). Harry requests, in lieu of flowers, donations to Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 381 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10016.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about an effort by Lincoln University, in southeastern Pennsylvania, to keep control of the Barnes Foundation and its multibillion-dollar art collection misspelled the name of an organization offering financial support if Lincoln gives up control. It is the Lenfest Foundation, not Linfest.

title: Islanders Take Lead, Then Fall
description: What started out as perhaps a minor slide to open the N.H.L. season has turned into a troubling slump for the Islanders.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Rights Watchdog Banned
description: President Aleksandr Lukashenko banned the last remaining member of a European rights watchdog group from remaining in the country, Reuters reported. Alina Josan, of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, said she had to leave the country because her visa had not been renewed. Government officials were not immediately available for comment. Mr. Lukashenko's authoritarian government has accused the organization of openly supporting the opposition. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Political Memo; A Storm of Political Ads Hits Race to Little Effect
description: With the election six days away, the airwaves have become cluttered with political advertisements as the three candidates for governor jockey for position in the home stretch. So far, however, the blizzard of ads seems not to have changed the dynamic of the race, strategists say.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Campaign Season column on Sunday about Ralph Nader's support for Democratic candidates around the country referred incompletely to his connection with Public Citizen, the consumer advocacy group he founded. While Mr. Nader, the Green Party candidate for president in 2000, repeatedly cites Public Citizen's analysis of voting records when praising or criticizing candidates, he is not officially connected with the organization.

title: War Inflates Cocoa Prices But Leaves Africans Poor
description: As civil war raged in Ivory Coast, the world's biggest cocoa producer, speculative traders here and in New York sent prices this month to 17-year highs. Investors cashed in, as did middlemen along the global food chain. Candy makers like Hershey and Nestl are thought to have secured their Halloween profits by carefully hedging their exposure.

title: For the Internet, The Ultimate Test
description: I IMAGINED the body cold and prone, lying on a stainless steel table under a harsh light as the tall man pried it open and reached inside with shiny tongs.

title: Clorox Announces 84% Profit Increase, Beating Forecasts
description: The Clorox Company said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 84 percent because of lower expenses and increased sales of new products. The company also said it planned to sell its money-losing Brazilian business.

title: In Sleek Packages, That's Entertainment
description: AS televisions and other electronic items slim down, the home entertainment center, a fixture in many homes, is due to change. Unwieldy armoires, cabinets and trolleys are giving way to narrow updated versions designed for smaller stereos, flat-screen televisions and units with built-in DVD players. Here are six contemporary ways to present audio and video:

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Shades of Last Season as a New One Begins; After Fast Start, Knicks Experience Familiar Collapse
description: All the components were there the missed jump shots, the backbreaking 3-pointers, the helpless and confused looks. The dreaded fourth quarter that caused the Knicks so much heartbreak last season proved disastrous again tonight in their season opener at the Palace of Auburn Hills.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Convenience Stores Acquired
description: The large British supermarket chain Tesco has agreed to buy T&S Stores for 377.3 million ($587 million) in stock to expand in convenience stores. The price represents a premium of 26.7 percent over the closing price of T&S shares on Tuesday. Tesco said it plans to convert 450 of T&S's 862 convenience stores to the Tesco Express format. Tesco plans to sell noncore businesses, including Dillons, a seller of newspapers and magazines, and Supercigs, a chain of discount tobacco shops. As part of the deal, Tesco will assume 153 million ($238 million) in T&S debt. Tesco said that after the acquisition, it would control about 5 percent of the convenience store market in Britain. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Floor That Won't Warp or Stain And Doesn't Need Polishing
description: Paying to wax and refinish wood floors can quickly double the cost of having them. A composite strip flooring from Mannington Commercial, iCore, offers the look of wood planks but will not warp or stain. There's no polishing, and the melamine veneer surface will not scuff.

title: A Death Sentence In the Sniper Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: To Retake House, Democrats Campaign on Buddy System
description: The Baltimore County executive, C. A. Dutch Ruppersberger, knew the national Democratic Party was eager -- or to put it bluntly, desperate -- for him to win the open House seat here in Maryland's Second District. Even so, he was a bit surprised by what the party bestowed on him.

title: The Rural Life; Second Frost
description: The other day I noticed that I was walking down to the barn again. It sounds like a strange thing to notice, because some days I walk down to the barn a dozen times without noticing it. My mind is on the tape measure I left on the workbench or the way the horses watch me as I pass. Sometimes I get down to the barn and can't remember why I came. I never worry about those moments, because there are so many things I could have walked down to the barn for that I'm sure to find something I need, or need to do.

title: Upgrading to Windows XP
description: To the Editor:

title: Upgrading to Windows XP
description: To the Editor:

title: Audit Overseer Cited Problems In Previous Post
description: Shortly before William H. Webster was appointed to head a new board overseeing the accounting profession by the Securities and Exchange Commission last Friday, he told the commission's chairman, Harvey L. Pitt, that he had until recently headed the auditing committee of a company that was facing fraud accusations, Mr. Webster recounted today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen's Profit Slides
description: Third-quarter profit at Volkswagen fell 51 percent, to 439 million euros ($432 million), while sales increased 2 percent, to 21 billion euros. The company said the profit decline resulted from losses on investments, the high cost of creating new models and currency exchange rates. Volkswagen expects sales to fall short of the five million vehicles sold last year but it still expects to have a profit of 4 billion euros this year. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Attacks on Schools for Girls Hint At Lingering Split in Afghanistan
description: A handwritten letter discovered in this village just south of Kabul on Saturday appears to confirm the opening of a sad new front in the struggle between Afghanistan's American-backed central government and remnants of the Taliban.

title: Ghoul Cool on a Budget
description: WANT the maximum scare for your dollar? This is not the time to shop for it. Off-season is always better, said Rob Pruitt, who recommends holding off until next week at least.

title: At This Capitol Hill Door, It's News Release or Treat
description: In the midst of all the electoral furor, it is also, of course, Halloween, a special time for children, a time for setting aside partisan maneuvering and political spin. Or maybe not. Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, who is moving into a new town house on Capitol Hill, told a reporter, ''Send the kids over. We'll have a basket of press releases for handing out at the door.''

title: Accounts
description: * The Iomega Corporation, San Diego, a maker of digital storage devices, to Suissa Miller, Los Angeles, as agency of record, with spending estimated at $5 million. The account had been handled by Power Creative, Louisville, Ky. Suissa Miller is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 9
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Ex-Councilman And Developer Are Charged
description: A former Asbury Park city council member and a developer have been charged with bribery and extortion in an indictment announced today by the United States attorney's office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUM, WILLIAM
description: STRUM - William. S/A/R Academy mourns the loss of the loving brother of Anita Gluck, wife of A. Stanley Gluck, Vice Chairman of the Executive Committee. May the entire family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President

title: Op-Art
Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, RHODA
description: ROBERTS-Rhoda. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member Rhoda Roberts. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. Herbert C. Bernard, Secy.

title: Out Goes Majolica, In Goes Nothing
description: WHEN he burst onto the London fashion scene in the 1970's, the Japanese designer Gnyuki Torimaru -- Yuki, as he is known professionally -- acquired a reputation for elegant simplicity: evening gowns that hugged the body like poured silk, and jackets and cat suits that wrapped around their subjects seamlessly.

title: Fighting Zombies: All in a Night's Work
description: BLOODRAYNE

title: Russia Names Drug in Raid, Defending Use
description: Russia acknowledged today that it pumped an aerosol version of a powerful painkiller, Fentanyl, into a Moscow theater to end a hostage crisis last Saturday, breaking a four-day silence on the drug's identity that had drawn mounting criticism in the United States and Europe.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: IVORY COAST: SOME PROGRESS IN TALKS On a second day of talks in Togo's capital, Lome, Ivory Coast rebels and government negotiators signed a statement saying they would avoid "warlike acts" that could threaten their cease-fire, including extrajudicial executions, recruiting child soldiers and bringing in mercenaries. The conflict has left hundreds dead, driven thousands from their homes, including the children above, and intensified tension between the Muslim north and Christian south. (Reuters)

title: Citigroup Picks A Former Star Of Research For a New Unit
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it had hired Sallie L. Krawcheck, the chief executive of Sanford C. Bernstein, to lead a separate division for its stock research and brokerage businesses, even before it has reached a agreement with regulators on how its analysts will operate.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest Reports $214 Million Loss
description: Qwest Communications International, which is struggling to overcome an accounting scandal and hugh debts in addition to the general slump in the telecommunications sector, said yesterday that it lost $214 million, or 13 cents a share, in the third quarter. Revenue fell 13.2 percent from a year ago, to $3.80 billion, excluding revenue from the QwestDex directories business that Qwest is selling. The decline will be reported later in a final filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission as just under 10 percent once Qwest completes a restatement of 2001 revenue. Qwest has said that the 2001 quarter's revenue were inflated by improper accounting of sales of capacity on its optical network. No matter which figures are used, they add up to continued weakness and Qwest said that revenue for the year would end up at the low end of the range it previously projected. But Qwest's operating units did manage to generate $53 million more cash than they used by cutting costs and capital spending. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: A Design That Claims a Link To the Kennedy White House
description: Constantin von Haeften of Coconut Company in SoHo attributes the design of the new silver-plated floor lamp at right to Jansen, the French firm that decorated the White House for Jacqueline Kennedy. But the lamps in his store are copies made by a Romanian metalworker in Paris. ''The work is very nice,'' said Mr. von Haeften, who has sold 16 lamps since January.

title: Sports of The Times; What Counts Lies Under The Facade
description: THE freedom of the road: it's a top down, untethered state of mind for many people, and an escape route from the conscience for some basketball players.

title: Stock Sale Inquiry Exonerates Chairman of HealthSouth
description: HealthSouth said yesterday that an investigation by an outside law firm into the recent stock sales of its chairman, Richard M. Scrushy, had found no evidence of wrongdoing and had cleared Mr. Scrushy of having insider information before he sold nearly $100 million in stock.

title: In Sniper Case, Two Defenders With Two Styles
description: It is a tale of two lawyers.

title: BAYER SEEKS EXPANDED MEDICAL USE FOR CIPRO IN U.S.
description: Bayer, Germany's biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it would ask regulators in the United States to approve its best-selling antibiotic, Cipro, to treat complicated urinary tract infections. Bayer would not estimate the potential increase in Cipro sales if the new use for the extended-release formula of the antibiotic is approved, a spokesman, Hermann-Josef Baaken, said. Cipro had sales of 2 billion euros ($1.97 billion) in 2001. The world market for complicated urinary tract infection treatments is 350 million euros, he said. Bayer asked the Food and Drug Administration in March to approve Cipro for uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: MEDICINE CLEARED IN KILLINGS

title: A Death Sentence In the Sniper Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: Art and Anxiety; Economic Fears Cast Shadows Over Fall Auctions
description: When times get tough, art pours onto the market. Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg will offer more than $400 million of art in the November fine art sales in New York over the next two weeks, including works by masters like Picasso and Monet, Roy Lichtenstein and Jasper Johns. While the monetary total is not unusually high, the sheer number of works for sale this fall has increased. Some is being sold by people in financial distress, but many other sellers think this is the moment to cash in.

title: Setting Its Sights High, Levi's Aims Low With New Jeans
description: Hoping to reverse years of declining market share, Levi Strauss & Company yesterday brought forth a cheaper brand of jeans to take the company into Wal-Mart and other discount stores for the first time.

title: Penalties and Khabibulin Stop Rangers
description: There was disappointment on Coach Bryan Trottier's face tonight as he lashed out at some of the Rangers for continuing to incur penalties.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Electronic Data Systems Plans Job Cuts
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss as much as 4 percent of its worldwide staff and sell business units to raise cash after third-quarter profit dropped 59 percent. The shares rose as much as 15 percent. Net income dropped to $86 million, or 18 cents a share, from $212 million, or 44 cents, a year earlier. Sales fell 2.8 percent, to $5.41 billion from $5.56 billion, the company said in a statement. Customers cut the size of contracts with Electronic Data or did not purchase additional services, and some European contracts produced less revenue than Electronic Data had expected. Profit was reduced by the bankruptcy of the US Airways Group and a loss on the sale of its subscription fulfillment business. Shares in E.D.S. rose as high as $15.85 in after-hours trading.

title: What Mature Gamers Need
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany and U.S. Tentatively Ease Chill in Relationship
description: Germany and the United States struggled today to get past an unusual period of estrangement prompted by Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's recent re-election campaign, in which he assailed President Bush's policies on Iraq.

title: Campus Confidential
description: Highlights from this week's forum discussions, including reports from colleges about the state of student activism and a rumination on whether the best team won the World Series.

title: Many Found the Senate a Nice Place to Come Home To
description: If Walter F. Mondale and Frank R. Lautenberg return to the Senate, they will join a surprisingly large class of senators interruptus.

title: Vital Statistics
description: John Muhammad and Lee Malvo are accused of killing 10 people during their terrifying three-week sniping spree in and around Washington.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Drug Maker Posts Loss
description: The Irish drug maker Elan reported a third-quarter loss of $60.7 million before charges of $943.1 million, which left it with a net loss of $1 billion. That is in contrast to net income of $128.6 million in the third quarter of last year. Revenue fell 30 percent, to $340 million, while product revenue fell 42 percent, to $220 million, in large part because of competition from new generic versions of Elan's Zanaflex, a muscle spasm treatment. The chairman, Garo Armen, said that the figures were better than expected and that Elan had made aggressive steps toward completing its recovery plan. ''We're inundated with calls'' from potential buyers for noncore assets, which the company is selling to raise $1.5 billion by December 2003, Mr. Armen said. Elan has made 700 of 1,000 planned job cuts, and will have more than $1 billion in cash when recent product sales are completed. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Passage of Antismoking Law May Be Linked to Wage Bill
description: The City Council and the Bloomberg administration remained at an impasse yesterday over the mayor's antismoking legislation, as Council officials hastily scheduled a second hearing on the measure for tomorrow.

title: In Iowa, Rare Support From an Unusual Quarter
description: In the final days of a campaign, candidates like to bring in the big guns of surrogate politics. Representative Jim Leach, the moderate Iowa Republican in a competitive race against Dr. Julie Thomas, had one of the more unusual big guns in Des Moines last week, Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: D.J. for Rap's Run-DMC Is Shot to Death in Queens
description: Jam Master Jay, the D.J. who provided beats and scratches to the rap group Run-DMC's groundbreaking records, was shot and killed last night at a recording studio in Jamaica, Queens, the authorities said.

title: Swiss Investor Buys Some Time for BZ Group
description: Martin Ebner, the outspoken Swiss investor, bought his troubled BZ Group some time today by selling its 19.1 percent stake in a specialty chemical manufacturer, Lonza, for 800 million Swiss francs ($537.2 million). But analysts said BZ was not out of trouble yet.

title: Revamping Lags for Polling Service Tied to Flawed Data in 2000
description: The service that provides the news media with information about how and why major blocs vote the way they do may not operate fully on Tuesday, resulting in an incomplete picture of the electorate's mood and motivation, officials of the service have said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: 8 Plead Guilty In Hazing
description: Eight teenagers have pleaded guilty to beating three boys with a wooden paddle so severely during a fraternity hazing rite that they had to be taken to a hospital. The teenagers, members of the Sigma Kappa Delta fraternity, are 15 to 17 and pleaded guilty to hazing charges stemming from the July initiation rite for a fraternity at Hawthorne High School. The authorities did not release the names of the teenagers because of their age. Prosecutors said that the boys who were hazed were struck 30 times with a paddle, resulting in bruises to the lower back and buttocks so severe that each sought medical treatment. As part of a plea agreement, charges of aggravated assault were dismissed. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Satellites Help Point the Way to a Speedier Commute
description: TRAFFIC is notoriously bad in and around the nation's capital; ask anyone who spends time on the roadways. The average driver in the Washington area wastes some 84 hours a year stuck in traffic, by one measure. Only drivers in San Francisco and Los Angeles have it worse.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I am afraid. But I will continue.''

title: Tape Shows the Grisly Aftermath at Wendy's
description: It looked like the routine end to another fast-food day. Upstairs, the night shift had stacked chairs onto the tables so the floors could be mopped. Downstairs, the walk-in refrigerator was well stocked, chopped salad greens on the right-hand shelves, uncut romaine on the left.

title: Bogart and Martha Stewart? It Happened in High Point
description: At the High Point furniture market, which ended last week, the pieces were scaled down, but the names were big: Oscar de la Renta for Century Furniture, Humphrey Bogart for Thomasville and Martha Stewart for Bernhardt. The de la Renta collection included the Trellis Party chair, above left, $1,500 retail, and an intricately carved pine cabinet inspired by furniture from Mr. de la Renta's three homes. The 65-piece Art Deco Bogart Collection included the Hollywood vanity (above right, $4,125 retail; stool, $885). Martha Stewart's collection showed an Austin slipcovered sofa (in linen, $1,850) and a Lily Pond coffee table in fen green with glass top ($1,250).

title: An Olympic Mistake
description: This weekend the United States Olympic Committee will choose either New York City or San Francisco as this country's candidate to host the 2012 Summer Olympic Games. NYC 2012, the committee representing New York's bid to bring the games here, says that 84 percent of city residents support the idea.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Secaucus: 3,500 Graves Block Freeway
description: A potter's field of more than 3,500 paupers' graves dating back to the 1860's will be relocated under a plan about to be reviewed by a state judge. The bodies would be moved by the New Jersey Turnpike Authority from the five-acre grave site in Hudson County to other locations. The 19th-century cemetery, which received the dead from a poorhouse, a mental hospital and a penitentiary, blocks construction of an interchange between exits 15E and 16E. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Many Found the Senate a Nice Place to Come Home To
description: If Walter F. Mondale and Frank R. Lautenberg return to the Senate, they will join a surprisingly large class of senators interruptus.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Union Plan Worries Farmers
description: Some 3,000 farmers protested in Prague, fearful that their country's plan to join the European Union by 2004 could leave them ruined. The union, which spends about half its annual budget on farm support, says it will give Czech and other Central and East European farmers about one-fourth the subsidies it now gives to agriculture in the 15 current member states. But Central European farmers say they will be unable to compete against Western Europe's industrialized agriculture, which they fear will dump subsidized produce into their markets after the union takes in 10 new members. Peter S. Green (NYT)

title: Slowdown? Don't Tell Toyota Motor
description: Few companies can make the extraordinary look more ordinary than Toyota.

title: New Ways to Get Out the Vote
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop-Up 'Alerts': Spam In Sheep's Clothing
description: Q. An alert box popped up on my screen the other day, and I assumed that it indicated a serious Windows XP error. Then I read closely and realized that it was an advertisement. How can advertisers take over my computer's dialogue boxes like this, and how can I prevent it?

title: Antitrust Enforcement
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Health-Care Rewards Urged

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Investigator Sentenced
