description: A former city investigator who disclosed information about an inquiry into tax assessments to her husband, a tax assessor, was sentenced yesterday to three years' probation. In 1996, the investigator, Nancy Sidaross, while working for the city's Department of Investigation, told her husband, Fady Sidaross, about the corruption inquiry. Mr. Sidaross is one of 18 current and former tax assessors indicted on charges that they took bribes to reduce tax bills for owners of skyscrapers, hotels and other major buildings in Manhattan. A federal judge sentenced Mrs. Sidaross to probation and a $5,000 fine. He also ordered her to perform 600 hours of community service. Mr. Sidaross and two others will go on trial in January. Fifteen assessors have already pleaded guilty. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Mortgage Index Declines
description: An index of applications for mortgages fell last week to a three-month low as home purchases and refinancing declined.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, EDWARD HALLAM
description: TUCK-Edward Hallam. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 5th Ave. & 90 St., on Friday, November 1 at 11 AM.

title: Roy Hertz, 93, Discoverer of a Cancer Treatment
description: Dr. Roy Hertz, who won an Albert Lasker Medical Research Award in 1972 for an early and remarkably effective drug treatment for a cancerous tumor, died on Monday at his home in Hollywood, Md. He was 93.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit In Electronics
description: The maker of the Panasonic brand of electronics, Matsushita Electric Industrial, posted a profit of 13.5 billion yen ($108 million) in the July-September quarter, helped by sales of its audio-visual products and cost-cutting measures. It had a loss of 50 billion yen in the period a year ago. Sales rose 4 percent, but the company said a quick recovery in the Japanese economy is unlikely and a slowing economy in the United States has begun to cast a shadow on the outlook for other areas. Ken Belson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Gang Suspects Charged
description: Thirty-nine men and two women suspected of belonging to a violent street gang have been charged in 16 state indictments ranging from the sale of illegal drugs to kidnapping. The authorities said they confiscated three assault weapons, more than $360,000 worth of cocaine, and 19 stolen vehicles. The gang, part of the Latin Kings, is headed by a state ''chairman'' and eight ''council members,'' according to the State Division of Criminal Justice. Yesterday, the state police identified Isabelino Gonzalez as the chairman. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Swedes Drop Hijacking Charge Against Armed Man at Airport
description: A Swedish prosecutor has dropped hijacking charges against Kerim Chatty, 29, who was arrested at a Swedish airport in August when he tried to board a flight to Britain with a gun in his toiletry kit.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Break For Smokers
description: British cross-Channel shoppers will be allowed to bring more cheap cigarettes from the Continent into the country, the government announced. Economic Secretary John Healey said the permitted number was being raised from 800 to 3,200 per person. Because of high taxes, cigarettes in Britain can cost up to $7 a pack, more than twice what some cost in Europe. The move, announced in the House of Commons, follows criticism of customs officers' treatment of travelers suspected of bringing in cigarettes to sell on the black market. Smuggled cigarettes accounted for 20 percent of the British tobacco market in 2001, an estimated loss in revenue of $5.5 billion. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: For Americans in Mideast, Daily Balance of Risk
description: Jack E. Davis, a professor on leave from the University of Alabama at Birmingham to teach American Studies here, spent all day holed up in his apartment after a friend called to tell him an American diplomat had been assassinated.

title: The Wellstone Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Assassinations Thwarted, Police Say
description: The Serbian police said that four men arrested on charges of murdering a former Belgrade police chief had been planning to assassinate leading politicians to safeguard criminal businesses. The director of Serbia's secret service, Andreja Savic, said investigators had uncovered a hit list of senior Serbian politicians including Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic and Interior Minister Dusan Mihajlovic. Daniel Simpson (NYT)

title: Optical vs. Digital Prints
description: To the Editor:

title: To the Liberal Arts, He Adds Computer Science
description: TALL and slender with a flowing beard, dressed in a gray sweater and jeans, Brian Kernighan works his audience with a fast patter and a ready smile. The challenge he has set for himself is to demystify computing for a classroom full of liberal arts undergraduates at Princeton.

title: Searching for a Safety Zone
description: SEO needs help with her geometry homework. Zara wonders aloud whether a pair of khakis are appropriate garb for a visit to Western Michigan University. Dig asks if anyone has ever heard of ''Fydor something Russian.'' Globe asks if anyone saw ''Trigger Happy'' on Comedy Central. Zimmy laments her glitchy copy of a Sims game.

title: Study Tells U.S. to Pay More For the Best Medical Care
description: The National Academy of Sciences said today that Medicare, Medicaid and other government programs should reward high-quality health care by paying higher fees or bonuses to the best doctors, hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESKOW, DENNIS
description: ESKOW-Dennis. Noted expert in technology journalism, passed away at his home on October 29. Eskow began his career as a reporter for the NY Daily News, and later wrote for the Associated Press and served as science editor for Popular Mechanics. He went on to spearhead many technology publications such as InformationWeek, Datamation, and, most recently, Consumer Goods Technology and RIS News. Eskow won numerous journalism awards as Front Page, Neal Award, Computer Press Association, and the Magazine Publishers Award. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, his children, Jessica, Simon, Moriah and Rachel, two grandchildren, Evan and Ian, two brothers, Martin and Steve, and numerous friends and relatives.

title: Lusciously Lurid Is the Name of the Game
description: 'The Shanghai Gesture'

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Frighteningly Fabulous Festivals
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
